title: Mondale, Ending China Trip, Says Ties Have Assumed New Maturity
description: CANTON, China, Aug. 31 Vice President Mondale concluded a weeklong visit to China today expressing confidence that ChineseAmerican ties had taken on a maturity and directness comparable to those between the United States and its European allies.

title: Picking Up the Pieces
description: If President Carter had chosen a white to succeed Andrew Young as the American Ambassador to the United Nations, he would have risked disappointed criticism from blacks. If he had chosen a black, he would have risked criticism for political pandering from whites. Wisely, the President chose a professional diplomat.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Hurricane David is visible just west of Hispaniola and Hurricane Elena is to the west of the Texas Gulf. The Northern Rockies are overcast as are parts of the Plains States, the South Atlantic States,the lake region and the Pacific Northwest.

title: Markets Closed Monday
description: Exchanges, commodity and bond markets and banks in the United States will be closed on Monday in observance of Labor Day.

title: Treasury Bills Rise in Yield
description: Average yields on threemonth and sixmonth bills at the Treasury's weekly auction yesterday rose to new fiveyear highs. The auction was held yesterday instead of next Monday because of the Labor Day holiday.

title: Events Today
description: FILMMOBILE, 156th Street between Melrose and Courtland Avenues, Bronx, after dark.

title: Iran's Prime Minister Again Asks to Resign, Citing Lack of Power
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 31 (AP) Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan asked to be relieved of his duties today and called on the people of Iran to ask Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini to take the reins of government. TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 31 (Reuters) Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini accused Kurdish insurgents today of trying to set up a Communist state in northwest Iran with foreign backing. He said their latest uprising, now more than two weeks old, must be crushed as soon as possible, and he called for the execution of their leaders.

title: W. A. H. Birnie, 69; Editor HadHeldPost With Reader's Digest
description: A memorial service for William A. H. Birnie, a retired senior editor of Reader's Digest, will be held at 4 P.M. Sept. 14 at the Bimie home in Greens Farms, Conn.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP)  Congress violated constitutional protections of an independent judiciary by denying costofliving raises to 600 Federal judges in 1976 and 1977, Federal District Judge Stanley J. Roszkowski has ruled. ALEXANDRIA, Va., Aug. 31 (UPI) A Virginia man has filed a $219,000 suit against the Central Intelligence Agency on the ground that he was hired as a spy but was never paid.NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31 (UPI)  The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled yesterday that an Atlanta ordinance that bars a religious group from impeding the conduct of any authorized business at the city airport was unconstitutionally vague. GOOD HOPE, La., Aug. 31 (AP)  The last fire was extinguished today and 300 persons who had been evacuated from their homes on the nearby river bank returned home, but the Coast Guard found no trace of three men missing in a ship. barge collision that killed four crewmen and injured nine others on the cargo ship.

title: Amusement Parks Rebounding From Summer Travel Slump
description: The amusement park industry is slowly recovering from a deep midsummer slump set off by public uncertainty over vacation travel during the gasoline crisis, a spot check has shown.

title: Electronic Bullies Intimidate Dieters Into Staying Trim
description: In the electronic age, it is getting harder and harder to overeat. There are now dinner forks with traffic lights built into their handles. You eat on the green, stop on the red. It takes forever for the light to change.

title: Bridge:
description: Sooner or later, but more likely later, nearly all players have the delightful experience of bringing home a hopeless contract by a mixture of skillful play and defensive error. Sooner or later, all players have the less delightful experience of defending in such a scenario.

title: The Chrysler Tower Is Sold
description: The Chrysler Building, a 77story monument to Art Deco, has changed owners for the second time in 18 months, the seller announced yesterday.

title: $10,000 Notes Still Growing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Bank regulators released figures today showing explosive growth in moneymarket certificate accounts at the nation's banks and thrift institutions.

title: Dispute Over Cambodians Grows At Nonaligned Meeting in Havana
description: HAVANA, Aug. 31  Vietnam and Cuba pressed their fight today to keep representatives of the ousted Cambodian Government of Pol Pot out of the conference of socalled nonaligned nations here.

title: Astros Top Mets, 20, On 2 Unearned Runs
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 31  The Houston Astros, seeking to overtake the Cincinnati Reds in the National League West, received help from the New York Mets tonight at the Astrodome and moved to within a halfgame of the Reds, who lost to Montreal.

title: News Summary
description: About 2,000 Soviet combat troops are in Cuba, and the United States has expressed its concern to the Soviet Union, the State Department said. Hodding Carter 3d, the department spokesman, estimating the number of troops at 2,000 to 3,000, said, This is the first time we have been able to confirm the presence of a Soviet ground forces unit on the island. He said that it poses no threat to the United States and violates no previous SovietAmerican understanding on Cuba. But the development might make Senate approval of the SovietAmerican arms treaty more difficult. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Suspect Held and Ransom Found After Three Are Freed in Florida
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 31 (AP)  The wife and two children of a Gainesville bank president were released unharmed today and a man accused as their kidnapper was arrested with the $100,000 ransom, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Wilson, Citing High Risks, Drops Football Helmets
description: Citing the continuing high risk of product liability suits, the Wilson Sporting Goods Company has decided to withdraw from the manufacture of football helmets at the end of the 1979 season, which is already over in terms of production.

title: Police Think More Than 2 in I.R.A Plotted Mountbatten Assassination
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 31  The Irish police have concluded that more than two members of the outlawed Irish Republican Army were involved in the bombing plot that killed Earl Mountbatten of Burma on Monday.

title: Banks Assigned More Protection On a Busy Day
description: More than a hundred special plainclothes police units of two or three officers were assigned in a steppedup effort to protect city banks yesterday on what is usually one of the busiest bank days of the year.

title: Tracy Austin Ousts Miss Jaeger
description: Still quivering from the Ilie NastaseJohn McEnroe fireworks of the night before, the United States Open tennis championships settled down yesterday with a more ordinary run of upsets, marathon struggles, nervous tension and children playing pattyball under the stadium lights of the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadow.

title: JERSEY'S CRIME CODE TAKES EFFECT TODAY
description: TRENTON, Aug. 31  An almost total revision of New Jersey's criminal laws, which took more than 10 years of study and legislative debate, goes into effect tomorrow amid a continuing debate over many of its provisions.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 20.

title: U.S. Official Denies He Told Jury Of Apparent Perjury in Vesco Case
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  Philip B. Heymann, an Assistant Attorney General, denied today that he told Federal grand jurors last month that a top White House official had apparently committed perjury in the grand jury's investigation involving Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier.

title: CELSO EMILIO FERREIRO
description: SANTIAGO DE COMPOSTELA, Spain, Aug. 31 (REUTERS)  Celso Emilio Ferreiro, a Galician poet and opponent of the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, died here today, according to friends. He was 67 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: If you go browsing in the music section of any large bookstore, you will find whole shelves of opera guides in every imaginable shade of sophistication. Whether you are interested in Mozart's Don Giovanni or Verdi's II Finto Stanislao, you will have no trouble finding a synopsis, a detailed historical discussion and perhaps even a musical analysis. But until recently, if you wanted to know who did what to whom in, say, Janacek's Katya Kabanova or Tippett's The Knot Garden, you generally were in for a long search.

title: Music: Troupe From Santa Fe Closes Festival
description: The Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival rather melted to the close of its first New York season Thursday night at the 92d Street Y. The air conditioning in the Kaufmann Concert Hall was not up to the job, and the result was sweltering indeed.

title: Carter Now Seeks Raise Of 7% for U.S. Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)  President Carter, acknowledging the impact of inflation, today raised his proposed pay increase for 3.5 million military and civilian Government employees to 7 percent from 5.5 percent.

title: Your Money
description: APPRAISALS, the means of determining the value of property or other possessions, are becoming increasingly essential for businesses and individuals as a high rate of inflation continues unabated.

title: C.A.B. LETS AIRLINES RAISE FARES BY 9.5% TO MEET FUEL COSTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  The Civil Aeronautics Board agreed today to allow the nation's airlines to raise their fares by as much as 9.5 percent because of the fastrising cost of fuel.

title: Actors Theater of Louisville Is Flourishing Under Jon jory
description: Soon Louisville may become as famous for nurturing new drama as it is for breeding horses  all because of Jon Jory. Mr. Jory is a man in a hurry. When he was 6, he was already a member of Actors Equity. By the time he was 24 he had cofounded the Long Wharf Theater. Now, at 41, he is beginning his 11th season as producerdirecwhich, under his leadership, has become one of America's major regional companies. Every director has his own metabolism, he says. Mine is quick.'

title: Sally Rand, Whose Fan Dancing Shocked Country, Is Dead at 75
description: Sally Rand, whose fan dance to the strains of Debussy's Clair de Lune and Chopin's Waltz in C Sharp Minor, created a sensation at the 1933 Chicago World's Fair and helped launch a career that lasted for more than 30 years, died yesterday in Glendora, Calif. She was 75 years old.

title: $19 Billion Loss To U.S. Is Found In Tax Cheating
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  The Internal Revenue Service estimated today that in 1976 it failed to collect $19 billion to $26 billion of income taxes owed the Government by individuals. The Federal deficit for that calendar year was $66.4 billion.

title: City School Aide Asks for Closing Of 16 Buildings
description: The Deputy School Chancellor, Richard F. Halverson, recommended yesterday that 14 publicschool buildings in New York City be closed. A total of 3,100 gradeschool children, most of them in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Manhattan, would have to be transferred.

title: M'HENRY APPOINTED  TO YYOUNG'S U.N. JOB
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 31  Donald F. McHenry, who was designated by President Carter today to be the next chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said that he would welcome help and advice from Andrew Young, but that he wanted to get on with his diplomatic assignment in my own way.

title: Boston Symphony Wins The Swiss and Austrians
description: MONTREUX, Switzerland, Aug. 31 (AP)  The globetrotting Boston Symphony Orchestra headed for France yesterday after highly successful appearances in Switzerland and Austria on its first tour of the European festival circuit. Earlier this year, the Bostonians made a historic visit to China.

title: Solar Storms Disrupt Transmission Of Data as Pioneer 11 Nears Saturn
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Aug. 31 Solar storms propagating a heavy tide of charged particles out through interplanetary space disrupted Pioneer 11's radio transmissions today and threatened to reduce the amount of data and the quality of the pictures expected from the spacecraft's rendezvous with Saturn tomorrow.

title: Jazz: Quartet Revives Spirit Of Tristano
description: Two disciples of the late Lennie Tristano, the pianist who led a group at the Village Vanguard 30 years ago, are themselves leading a quartet in that same room through tomorrow. Thus, Warne Marsh, tenor saxophonist, and Sal Mosca, pianist, are bringing the Tristano style and some of the Tristano repertory home.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON

title: Deaths
description: SILVERDr. Harry Burton, Dear father of Alvin B. Silver, and Kenneth D. Silver of Pleasantville, N.Y., stepson Howard Vitow of L.I. Loving grandfather and greatgrandfather. Graveside services Sunday, September 2, 2 P.M. at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, L.I.

title: Series Will Feature Chamber Ensembles
description: Carnegie Hall will sponsor a new series this season called a Celebration of Chamber Ensembles. It will open Oct. 6, with the debut of a new orchestra called the Jupiter Symphony of New York. The group's founder and conductor is Jens Nygaard, and its first program will end, appropriately, with Mozart's Jupiter Symphony.

title: Alex Minewski, 61, a Painter With a Broad Subject Range
description: Alex Minewski, an artist, died Aug. 24 at the Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, N.Y. He was 61 years old and lived in New Paltz. N.Y.

title: Top Fire Officers Win Delay on City's Demand for Financial Disclosure
description: Highranking members of the Fire Department won a delay in Federal Court yesterday of an order to file statements of their personal finances with New York City by Tuesday.

title: Deliberate Falsehood, Cuban Says
description: HAVANA, Aug. 31 The only comment on the United States report of Soviet combat troops in Cuba came from a high Cuban official who said it was a deliberate falsehood and a dishonest campaign. He refused to be identified on the grounds the report was not worthy of denial.

title: Republic Steel Upgrading
description: The Republic Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had started $73 million worth of capital improvement and expansion projects in its district steel operations in Cleveland. The improvements, which do not include a $200 mil lion slab caster facility currently in the engineering stage, are part of Republic's previously reported $275 million capital spending plans for 1979.

title: Scott, Jackson Key Yanks Rout of Royals
description: George Scott could have been in Baltimore last night helping the Orioles take another step toward the American League's Eastern Division title, but instead he was in New York helping the Yankees knock the Kansas City Royals back out of first place in the Western Division.

title: Citibank Raises Prime to 12%
description: Citibank, the nation's secondlargest bank, yesterday joined other major banks in raising the prime rate to a record 12 percent.

title: Crowd Assailed in Open Uproar
description: Bill Talbert called it an ugly scene, the worst episode he had ever experienced in the sport. Mike Blanchard, who has been officiating tennis matches since 1932, could not recall a more bizarre series of circumstances on the court.

title: McGuire Says He Won't Let Police Be Fall Guy for All the City's Ills
description: New York City's Police Commissioner, denouncing what he described as the recent vilification of the Police Department, charged yesterday that certain people who purport to be community leaders were attempting to blame the department for all the ills of the city and society.

title: Drive, But Save
description: This country can save 500,000 barrels of oil a day if employers and workers make a serious commitment to sharing rides. Such a move would involve no legislation or drastic Government action  simply the willingness of people across the country to slightly alter their commutine habits.

title: Billionaire Adds Hotel Partner
description: LONDON, Aug. 31  A partnership of two of the world's most successful entrepreneurs has been forged by Daniel K. Ludwig, the reclusive shipping and real estate billionaire, and Roland Rowland, the head of Lonrho Ltd., it was announced today.

title: On Ulster's Uneasy Border, Little Hope of End to Terror
description: ARMAGH, Northern Ireland, Aug. 30  To the Protestants here, the border with Ireland a few miles away sometimes seems a threat.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown. ( N ) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Sears Acts on TV Fires
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (UPI)  Sears, Roebuck & Company says it will voluntarily repair about 21,000 of its color television sets to correct an overheating resistor that caused fires in five models. The faulty sets are 19inch portables retailed under the Sears brand name for about $490 from 1973 to 1975. They carry the following model numbers on the back section of the cabinet: 564.41990300, 564.4199301, 564.41991302 and 564.4199303.

title: Deaths
description: BERKOWITZDotty. 76, died of heart failure on August 30, 1979. Well known as the successor of her deceased husband Harry as Captain Jack in the management of the fishing vessel Starstream", Freeport, L.I. Affectionately referred to by her brotherinlaw George as Tugboat Annie". Her family, many friends and patrons mourn their loss. She is survived by her sister and her brothers, Herny, Jack and Al Hochman. Funeral services Jeffers Funeral Home, Hillside Ave. and 188 St., Hollis, Sunday noon September 2.

title: Asbestos Study Is Begun On 150 Types of Products
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)  The Government is starting an investigation of nearly 150 types of consumer products to see whether they pose any danger caused by asbestos, a substance that when breathed can cause cancer.

title: California's High Court Upholds The State's Death Penalty, 5 to
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 (AP) California's Supreme Court upheld the state's death penalty law today by a vote of 5 to 2. The decision affects 21 persons on death row in San Quentin prison.

title: Letting Pupils In on School Tax Reform
description: Courts in state after state, including New York, have declared it unconstitutional to use local property taxes to pay for public schools. Grudgingly, many states have appropriated funds to help narrow the gulf between rich and poor communities. But who is supposed to benefit from such equalization decrees pupils or their taxpaying parents? The rulings sidestep this question and state lawmakers are left exposed to local pressures to use education aid for tax relief instead of instruction. The controversy is again before the courts, on appeal or for compliance reviews, and we hope they will make clear that the reform of school finance does, after all, concern schools.

title: Space Shuttle Program Assailed by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI)  The United States space shuttle program has pinched pennies from the start and that could be expensive in the future, a House space subcommittee declared today.

title: 2 Representatives With Style: The Old and the New
description: Representative Martin Frost's district office in Dallas is on the 13th floor of a 15story bank building, hard by Interstate 35, with parking on the ground floor. The structure has no distinguishing marks, just a concrete tower perched on the bank of a fastflowing freeway.

title: Black Watch to Perform In New York and on L.I.
description: Scotland's famous Black Watch regiment, which will arrive in the United States on Oct. 1 for a threemonth tour, is scheduled to give two performances in the metroplolitan area in early December.

title: She Is a Lawyer in a Sporting World
description: Tracy Austin, the 16yearold tennis star, was announcing her endorsement of a tennis shoe at a recent news conference in New York City. From out of the crowd of reporters came a question: How much was the manufacturer paying her?

title: City Opera Management Seeks New Contract With Musicians
description: The threeyear musicians union contract at the New York City Opera expired yesterday, and the New York Philharmonic's threeyear contract ends on Sept. 29. But management and musician spokesmen at both institutions expressed hope that negotiations could be concluded amicably, and the City Opera's season began Thursday night with no threat of a work stoppage.

title: A Weekend Fit for Plans Of All Kinds
description: For thousands of New Yorkers, the Labor Day weekend began yesterday in a bumpertobumper exodus from the city.

title: Rumanian Special Envoy Confers With Begin on Mideast Situation
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 31 (Reuters)  A close adviser to President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania conferred with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel today on the Middle East situation.

title: Figure in Hamilton Jordan Inquiry Is Said to Deny Supplying Cocaine
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  The man who allegedly gave cocaine to Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, last year at Studio 54 has denied the entire allegation in testimony to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to sources close to the case.

title: Glory
description: The British aren't as weary as they're sometimes said to be. The Transglobe Expedition, seven years the planning, is scheduled to leave Greenwich, England, tomorrow on a journey of such daring that makes one wonder ho* the sun ever set on empire.

title: State Accuses Hooker Corp. Of Illegal Dumping on L.I.
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 31  New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation said today that the Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Corporation had dumped toxic wastes at landfills on Long Island more than 400 times in violation of state law.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Down 4.1%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)  Prices that farmers get for their products tumbled 4.1 percent from midJuly to midAugust, the sharpest decline in more than two years, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: $25 Million Stock Sale
description: The American General Insurance Company announced yesterday that it had sold 250,000 shares of a new junior preferred stock to an undisclosed institutional investor for $25 million. The company said the shares had a stated value of $100 a share and were designated as the 9.125 percent series of 1979. The shares are entitled to dividends of $9.125 a share annualy.

title: Ohio Cities Gird for CourtOrdered Busing
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 30  It is a tale of two Ohio cities. Both have been ordered after years of bitter court battles to begin busing for school desegregation within the next two weeks.

title: 50's Uranium Miners Tell of Disease and Fight for Aid
description: GRANTS, N. M., Aug. 31 A large proportion of the early uranium miners, those who worked in the late 1940's and 1950's before there were any safety regulations, are dead or dying, Government studies have shown.

title: U.S. Crew Gains Semifinals
description: BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 31 (AP)  The United States women's four with coxswain won its repechage heat today and qualified for the semifinals at the world rowing championships on Lake Bled. The Americans, Coz Crawford, Anita DeFrantz, Cathy Thaxton, Nancy Storrs and Lynn Silliman, finished in 3 minutes 31.07 seconds, more than four seconds ahead of Britain. The final is scheduled for Sunday.

title: 1,700 Executives Facing 10% Pay Cut at Chrysler
description: DETROIT, Aug. 31  The Chrysler Corporation said today that it was reducing by up to 10 percent the salaries of 1,700 company executives for a period of up to two years, starting tomorrow.

title: 1 or 2 Things About ...
description: During the summer just ending, I volunteered, for the first time, to share a summer house in East Hampton with two men and five women  only one whom (one of the women, a former almostgirlfriend) I had ever met before.

title: New Giants Tackle Lines Up for Opener
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 31  The Giants newest starting player, who has been with the team three days now, cheered when the Philadelphia Eagles recovered The Fumble last year to beat the Giants. But Gus Coppens also thinks the Giants are a great football team.

title: About New York
description: There are clubs for all seasons in New York. There are clubs for all social and ethnic categories. There are pages of clubs listed in the telephone yellow pages, and clubs covers everything from Hispanic storefront affairs where the men sit in front and play cards to the rarefied ambiance of the clubs so restricted that only fine bloodlines or fat Swiss bank accounts can open their doors.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)  The State Department lodged a strong objection with Canada today over its recent seizures of tuna fishing boats and threatened to embargo Canadian tuna in retaliation.

title: Cyclists Honor a Leader At Portsmouth Funeral
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 31 (AP) The roar of hundreds of motorcycles echoed off Portsmouth's centuriesold red brick buildings as leatherclad motorcyclists from around the country honored a dead leader in their own way.

title: U.S. Extends $5 HeatingOil Bonus to Raise Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  Secretary of Energy Charles W. Duncan Jr. today extended for two months a 0abarrel incentive intended to encourage the importation of heating and other distillate oils.

title: MacPhail Suspends Carew
description: At a time when his team has slipped from first place, Rod Carew of the California Angels has been suspended by the American League president, Lee MacPhail, for two games because he made physical contact with Umpire Nick Bremigan during Wednesday night's game in Detroit.

title: Phillies Drop Ozark as Pilot
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 31 (UPI)  The Philadelphia Phillies, foundering fifth place in National League East, dismissed Manager Danny Ozark to night and replaced him with Dallas Green, director of the team's minor league system. A team spokesman said Green would manage the Phillies over the final 30 games on an interim basis.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: In New Hampshire. The bank lends to the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, a Seabrook owner. A statement by protesters said, We recognize the First is truly the godfather of the nuclear industry In New England.

title: Dutch Seek to End Dock Walkout By 7,000 Workers in Rotterdam
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 31 (Reuters)  Management and transport unions opened negotiations today to end a strike by dock workers in Rotterdam, the world's busiest port.

title: Shell Is Not Lifting Monthly Gas Level
description: The Shell Oil Company, the leading United States gasoline marketer, said yesterday that it would not be able to increase its gasoline deliveries in September because of difficulty in purchasing crude oil.

title: Now It's Camisoles to Collect, Lingerie to Flaunt
description: Women who sleep in their old Tshirts will never understand the mystique, but there are those of us who find the feel of silk or satin next to the skin as luxurious as a bubble bath. To these sybaritic souls, Ora Feder is a heroine. They collect her handembroidered camisoles and lacelavished slips the way they collect silk shirts to wear over them.

title: U.F.W. Reaches Accord With Big Lettuce Grower
description: SALINAS, Calif., Aug. 31 (AP)  The United Farm Workers union, announcing a major victory in its sevenmonthold strike, said today that a tentative contract agreement had been reached with Sun Harvest, the largest of California's lettuce growers.

title: Shipping/Mails;
description: Incoming

title: Letter: On City Officials Raises
description: To the Editor:

title: Deaths
description: LEVINEDaniel Beloved husband of Shirley, devoted father of Sue Ellen, dear brother of Helene Packer. Services Sunday, 9:30AM at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, Glengary Rd, CrotononHudson, NY.

title: Soweto Black Ghetto Gets First Visit by a Premier
description: SOWETO, South Africa, Aug. 31 This sprawling black ghetto, the scene three years ago of deadly riots against the country's race laws, was a peaceful host today to the first visit by a leader of the country's white minority Government.

title: Homeless Given Help On Streets
description: He was sitting, disheveled and apparently disoriented, on a bench on the traffic island at 91st Street and Broadway.

title: PortugalNigeria Oil Pact
description: LISBON, Aug. 31 (Reuters)  Petrogal, Portugal's state oil company, said today that it had signed a contract with the Nigerian National Petroleum Company to buy 500,000 tons of Nigerian crude a year, worth about $90 million.

title: Beatty Sues to Have City Clerk Validate RecallDrive Petitions
description: State Senator Vander L. Beatty, a Democrat from Brooklyn, filed suit yesterday in an effort to have the City Clerk validate petitions Mr. Beatty submitted last July in a drive to empower voters to recall the Mayor and other elected officials.

title: Revised Code Is Like Neighbors
description: TRENTON, Aug. 31  New Jersey's new criminal code that takes effect tomorrow will treat crimes in much the same fashion as New York and Connecticut do, grading them according to circumstances.

title: Going out Guide
description: FADING SUMMER Labor Day is a sort of contradiction  a 97yearold holiday on which most Americans pay tribute to labor by not working. And now, wrapped in its usual ambivalence, the Labor Day weekend has arrived. Everybody likes a threeday weekend, but Labor Day tells us the livin is no longer easy, get back to the grind. Cunningly structured, the holiday cuts off summer if not in its prime, then in its golden days. Labor Day tells us to take leave of the summer at the peak of the party and readies us for the actual late September autumnal equinox. In the city, the weekend's virtues include a lack of the usual crowds and lines.

title: U.S. Makes Payments On Money Owed U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 31 A buoyant Andrew Young presented $102,931,354 to Secretary General Kurt Waldheim today in delayed payment of Washington's contributions to the United Nations budget. The payment had been held up for months because of restrictions by Comess.

title: State Improves Bid For Hambletonian
description: DU QUOIN, In., Aug. 31 New York State made a surprisingly strong bid today for the Hambletonian Trot, promising a milliondollar purse for the most prestigious event in harness racing.

title: Music: The Beverly Sills Era Starts Officially at City Opera
description: The Beverly Sills era started on Thursday night at the New York City Opera. Or, at least, it officially did. The real Beverly Sills era will start when she has worked out her own repertory and castings, and that is probably two years away. But when the City Opera started its fall season on Thursday, it was with Miss Sills officially in charge of the company.

title: Radio
description: 58:30, A.M., WBAI. Folk Music. Ira Leibin, host.

title: Japan Reports 4.2% Inflation
description: TOKYO, Aug. 31 (Reuters) Japan's inflation, fueled by higher oil prices, increased ninetenths of a percentage point in July and officials predicted today that there would be further increases in the next few months.

title: Notes on People
description: Another former member of President Carter's Cabinet has completed new job plans. James R. Schlesinger, who was Secretary of Energy until the recent Cabinet shakeup, will join the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a conservatively oriented research facility associated with Georgetown University in Washington. He will probably begin work within a month.

title: The City
description: A State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan dismissed a lawsuit that had sought to block a $20,000ayear pay increase for Mayor Koch and an increase of $10,000 for other top elected officials.

title: GENEVIEVE FOSTER; CHILDREN'S AUTHOR
description: Genevieve Foster, a writer and illustrator of children's books on historical subjects, died Thursday at her daughter's home in Westport, Conn. She was 86 years old and for many years had been a resident of Manhattan.

title: Sturges Film Retrospective Is Set
description: Preston Sturges, whose iconoclastic wit as a director and writer startled and delighted moviegoers in the 1940's  starting with The Great McGinty, his 1940 satire on machine politics will be honored with a retrospective at the Thalia Theater, Broadway at 95th Street, starting next Tuesday.

title: U.S. REPORTS SOVIET HAS COMBAT TROOPS STATIONED IN CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  The United States said today that it had expressed concern to the Soviet Union over what the Carter Administration said was the newly discovered presence of 2,000 to 3,000 Soviet combat troops in Cuba.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Youth, 13, Arrested on Long Island in Sex Assault and Beating of Boy,
description: A I3yearold Nassau County boy was arrested last night and charged with assaulting a 6yearold boy who was beaten, burned and sexually molested in a wooded area of Hempstead Lake State Park on Long Island last Wednesday.

title: Me, Sue And Blue
description: I don't know which was worse: losing my girl or my whiteoverblue Monte Carlo.

title: Carter Says No Top Arab He's Met Privately Backs a Palestinian State
description: PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 31 President Carter says he has never met an Arab leader who told him in private what Arabs say in public  that there should be an independent Palestinian state.

title: The AntiTennis Cult
description: In the aftermath of Ilie Nastase's antics in the United States Open, at least it's consoling to know that he's out of the tournament. It's too bad those spectators who sympathize with him aren't out too.

title: Hammond Concedes He Lost Control
description: After his tearful resignation in the small hours of the morning yesterday, Frank Hammond went home to his rented room at the YMCA on West 63d Street. By the time the portly umpire who was removed from the chair during a raucous match between John McEnroe and Ilie Nastase  arrived at the Y, the telephone switchboard was alive.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Phone Pact Reached
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 31 (Reuters)  Managers and negotiators for 15,000 telephone technicians in Ontario and Quebec reached agreement in principle today on a new contract and the end of an 18day strike, Bell Canada announced.

title: Pregnant Woman and 3 Children Die in Fire Fed by Stored Gasoline
description: BRADFORD, Ill., Aug. 31 (AP)  Containers of gasoline stored in a basement by a pregnant woman so that she would have enough fuel to get to the hospital caught fire today, starting a blaze that killed three of her five children, the authorities said.

title: European Summer: St.Tropez Still Lures People on Yachts and People on the Curbs
description: ST.TROPEZ, France  In A.D. 68 the decapitated body of a Christian named Tropez, martyred in Rome and thrown into the sea, washed up in these Darts. Miracles. exorcism  the stuff of saints  followed, and the town, with a kind of logic that future generations of local Tshirt salesmen could only approve, eventually changed its name from Heraclea Caccabaria to St.Tropez.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Sun Company, a major domestic intergrated oil company based in Radnor, Pa. announced yesterday that had agreed in principle to acquire for $300 million in Sun stock the Elk River Resources Company of Wilmington, Del.

title: 2D DEFAULT IN YEAR IS UPON CLEVELAND
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 (AP)  Cleveland headed into fiscal default today for the second time in less than a year, and one official called the situation a planned catastrophe.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Aug. 31,1979

title: The Region
description: Saying they had kidnapped his two sons, two men demanded a $100,000 ransom from a Plainfield, N.J., banker yesterday in an extortion attempt that was foiled when the boys, tied up in their own home, wriggled free and called the police.

title: U.S.Mexico Session Set Despite Dispute on Gas
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 31  The United States and Mexico announced today that, despite their failure to reach agreement on Mexican natural gas exports to the United States, President Jose Lopez Portin would visit Washington as scheduled next month for talks with President Carter.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Airlines were allowed to raise fares 9.5 percent by the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday because of fastrising fuel costs. The rise, the third this year, brought the total increase in 1979 to 20.1 percent. United Airlines, Braniff and Trans World Airlines said after the C.A.B. ruling that they expected to announce acrosstheboard increases up to the limits allowed. [1.]

title: New Airline for an Old Airport
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 31  Midway Airport, once the world's busiest but virtually abandoned in recent years, is home base for a new airline that is pinning its hope for success on a nofrills, discount formula and the airport's convenient location.

title: Dow at Best Level In Last 10 Months
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed at its highest level in 10 months yesterday as the general market scored a moderate advance in slower trading. The best performers were the takeover and oil issues.

title: Pipeline Gets Whiff of Success
description: When Canada announced in 1975 that it would gradually cut off oil exports to the United States, the news sent a shock wave through refineries in the border states west of the Great Lakes. Canada was their only source of crude oil.

title: Snapshots From Cuba
description: HAVANA  Posters proclaim the upcoming conference of nonaligned nations, and the Sandinistas are national heroes. The Cuban Revolution is 20 years old, but most of the people viewed during summerafternoon strolls are younger than the Revolution.

title: G.M. Raises Prices 3.1% On 80 Cars
description: DETROIT, Aug. 31  The General Motors Corporation today announced an average price increase of $244 on 1980 model cars that is 3.1 percent above the final 1979 model prices listed in July.

title: Guards 7, Inmates 6 at Rikers Island Game
description: The inmates of the Women's House of Detention on Rikers Island and their guards played softball yesterday in the main yard of the facility. After a quick fourrun uprising by the inmates, the guards rallied with five runs in the last inning to gain the upper hand and fought off a last ditch efffort to run for home with the tying run. When the dust cleared the victorious guards congratulated one another, and the inmates vowed revenge next time. It was the first time that guards and inmates played softball together there, and more games may be scheduled.

title: Alberto of Cosmos Suspended for Rest of 79
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 31  The North American Soccer League fined and suspended Carlos Alberto of the Cosmos tonight for the remainder of the season for his violent and abusive conduct Wednesday night after the Cosmos playoff loss to the Vancouver Whitecaps.

title: A High Interest In Interest Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (Reuters) The Carter Administration will heed a Congressman's concerns that West Ger many and Japan are forcing the United States to set record high interest rates, Treasury Secretary G. William Miller said today.

title: Arlen Realty Reduces Losses
description: The Arlen Realty and Development Corporation reduced its losses to $984,000 in its first quarter ended May 1, from $9.9 million in the yearearlier period, the company said yesterday.

title: OBSERVER Stranger Than Orwell
description: A nononsense letter from the National Academy of National Academies puts the question crisply: The 1980's will be here before you know it. What should America do about it?

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY houses in this area have crawl spaces under part or all of the house or have part of the first floor of the house built out over an unheated garage, porch or crawl space. In any of these instances, the floor over this unheated area should be insulated to cut down on heat loss and to increase the comfort of any occupants of that room.

title: E.A. du Bray Weds Elizabeth Vernon
description: Elizabeth Ann Vernon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Vernon of Mountain Lakes, N.J., and Edward Arthur du Bray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest du Bray of San Mateo, Calif., were married yesterday at the Vernon home. The Rev. Samuel Edwin Purdy of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Mountain Lakes performed the ceremony.

title: 2D YOUTH ARRESTED IN TORTURE OF BOY
description: A second suspect in the beating and torture of a 6yearold Long Island boy surrendered yesterday to the Long Island State Parkway Police. The police said the youth, who is 12 years old and from Hempstead. L.I., and a 13yearold Hempstead youth arrested Friday night, will be tried as juveniles, although initially the 13yearold had been charged as an adult with firstdegree assault.

title: Sallie Wilson Makes A Drama of Dance
description: To have seen Sallie Wilson perform the role of Hagar in Antony Tudor's Pillar of Fire, or Lizzie Borden in Agnes de Mille's Fall River Legend, or the Mother of the Groom in Jerome Robbins's Les Noces is to have been in the presence of an artist who transforms dance into pure drama. Called one of the great dramatic ballerinas of her time, Miss Wilson, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater since 1961, has long made clear the virtues of understatement, psychological penetration and utmost expressiveness.

title: FILM VIEW
description: VINCENT CANBY

title: She  uh, He Writes Romantic Novels
description: VANESSA ROYALL of Manhasset, author of the popular historical novel Flames of Desire, is 5 feet 10 inches tall and has blue eyes, blond hair and a blond beard. That's right, a blond beard.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Bcause more and more coin buyers will take nothing less than the best and keep insisting on superlative quality the prices of firstrate coins have

title: Lame Work in Little Magazines
description: HE purpose of Bill Henderson's annual volume is to collect outstanding stories, poems and essays from the smaller literary magazines and presses. The first effect

title: Population Religion Technology
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic  Long after the damage caused by Hurricane David in the Dominican Republic and Haiti last week, the two nations that share the island of Hispaniola. has been cleared away. poverty and the pressure of overpopulation will remain. In both countries, millions of people have too little food and too many children, and, until the last decade, in neither country was the ruling elite much interested in population control.

title: 3 More Suspects Are Arrested in Killing of Aide at the Metropolitan
description: Three more suspects have been arrested in the shooting death of Charlotte Louise Rivenburgh, an official of the Metropolitan Museum of Art who was killed near Hancock, N.Y., on Aug. 16.

title: Chinese Strive To Halt Decline Of Their Frogs
description: PEKING, Aug. 31  In a move that might moisten Kermit's PingPong ball eyes, the Chinese Government has ordered a ban on catching, buying and selling frogs in most areas in an effort to protect them as insectcontrol agents.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: BONN  It is the flip side to American worries about the inroads being made by foreign banks. West German authorities are becoming concerned that their banks may be moving too far afield, especially into countries without extensive supervision

title: BRIDGE
description: In the late 19th century, when bridge was bridge and auction and contract were still in the future only one partnership was permitted to name the trump suit. But if somebody doubled, there was no limit to the number of redoubles, introducing a poker element into an otherwise sedate game. That concept was quickly abandoned, and today a redoubled contract is very rare indeed in serious play.

title: ANTIQUES Salisbury's Venerable Flea Market
description: THE 22d annual oneday flea market is to be held here next Saturday in the Cow Pasture, where the prototype for such outdoor antiques shows  now numbering more than a thousand  was first produced.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: MUSIC IN THE PARKJens Nygaard conducts the Naumburg Symphony Orchestra this afternoon in an allMozart program at the bandshell on the Mall in Central Park.

title: Old Jersey City Piers Are Fuel for Big Fire Along the Waterfront
description: Multialarm fires swept the Jersey City waterfront last night and this morning when flames from an old abandoned pier caused barges and other piers to ignite.

title: Photo essay by BARTON SILVERMAN
description: IN waning summer, when longer nights and shorter days presage the advent of autumn and the distant savagery of deepest winter, the mind's eye lays up a store of fond memories of warm days at the seashore. If the shore is the narrow, 32mile stretch of beach called Fire Island, it is an album of memories filled with seascapes, action, pensive repose and crowds:

title: The Idea Of a University
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  Daddy in his infinite knowledge always saw the roots and not the flowers. He took all the watches of the world apart, and never knew what time it was. So wrote Bette Davis of her father. It is an epitaph that might also be applied to much of what now passes for liberal education.

title: Signing of Pact Marks Milestone In 8Month Coast Lettuce Strike
description: SALINAS, Calif., Sept. 1 (UPI) Cesar Chavez, the leader of the United Farm Workers, marked a milestone in his union's eightmonth lettuce strike today by signing of a contract with the nation's biggest lettuce grower.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: THE envelope was there in my pile of mail, fairly throbbing with its manila message: There's a check in here. Open me quick.

title: Food
description: Leftovers pose an undeniable challenge. What can a cook do when guests and family are fed to the teeth with sandwiches made from yesterday's roast beef, ham, chicken, fish, seafood, lamb or veal? The answeris simple: Chop or slice those leftover victuals and turn them into a cold salad with mayonnaise. Or grind them for croquettes. On this page are printed two foundation recipes for leftovers that could be called the endlessly variable mayonnaise salad or the anything croquettes.

title: Questions/Answers
description: I want to extend my planting of Vinca minor groundcover. Is September too late or would spring be better? Mrs. V.B., Middletown, Conn.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Rangers and Islanders Begin Seasons on the Road

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: The Bee Gees, who tour infrequently, are on the road now and arrive in New York this week for an engagement at Madison Square Garden Friday through next Sunday and Sept. 1112. They have taken to the road in the wake of the success of their latest album release, appropriately titled Spirits Having Flown, which, according to The Times's Janet Maslin, is astonishingly precise, tailormade to match the format of earlier successes. (See Music)

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: OFFICIALS in the Bergen County town of WoodRidge, from Mayor Peter Incardone on down, are pleased that

title: A Saxophone Foursome Comes Into Its Own
description: The World Saxophone Quartet belongs on videodisks. In their most recent New York appearances, the four reedmen, who between them command flute and bass clarinet in addition to soprano, alto, tenor and baritone saxophones, strutted on stage in white ties and tails. Complex arrangements were interrupted for procedural discussions that turned into barbed, devastating parodies of musician's jive talk. When they played music that vividly recalled the big band saxophone sections of the 1930's and 40's, they even executed some wryly jerky choreography.

title: Spinach Planted Soon Will Be Ready in Spring
description: Gardeners assume that vegetable planting duties are finished for the season. Perhaps. Yet, three vegetables can be planted later this month for harvest next year.

title: The Day Rocky Took the Count
description: Sports of The Times

title: Seven Stages of Jeans
description: Fashion from time to time reveals a small truth. Nothing, apparently, can resist the power of chic, not even the one article of clothing that was supposed to be especially immune from the stigma of status.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: I'm increasingly dismayed about the flippant twaddle concerning the East End of Long Island published in your Long Island section.

title: Strike Two
description: Not long ago, a couple we know drove to New England to see their son at camp. They apologized for being unable to come to the next visiting day. Oh, I understand, the boy interjected. This is the weekend of the odd parents. Next time is for the even parents.

title: Other World Events
description: Thailand last week blamed Vietnamese troops for threatening the very existence of the Khmer race and civilization. Continued killing and fighting, Thai Prime Minister Kriangsak Chamanand charged, together with the resultant famine is endangering the Cambodian nation. Although a relief plane carrying 22 tons of medecine and powdered milk arrived in Bangkok and a Vietnamese relief ship docked at the newly reopened Kompong Som harbor, he questioned whether Cambodia can survive without an end to fighting between the Vietnamese and Cambodian guerrillas

title: North Haven Neighbors Band Against Chemicals
description: FUNGICIDES, dyes, acrylics and other chemicals have been manufactured in this New Haven suburb since 1947, and gases from the settling ponds and smokestacks in the small industrial park along the Quinnipiac River have drifted over the $200,000 homes along Ridge Road and the smaller houses across the river, generating occasional complaints.

title: Nancy L. Atwood Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hubert C. Atwood Jr. of Northport, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Leigh Atwood, to Bruce Philip Fogwell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fogwell of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Dalai Lama Begins New York Visit Tomorrow
description: For the next seven weeks, hundreds of separate American Buddhist groups will enjoy a rare period of unity and public attention, because of the visit, beginning tomorrow in New York, of the Dalai Lama. This 44yearold monk is regarded as the spiritual and national leader of as many as six million Tibetans scattered in Tibet or in China or India, even though he has lived in exile in India since fleeing a Chinese Communist crackdown in 1959. He is, moreover, an important figure to many Americans because he has encouraged the exportation of Eastern spiritualism to the West.

title: Topics
description: One of our commuting colleagues takes the energy crisis seriously enough that he no longer drives his car into Manhattan but parks it at a bus station and boards a bus. The bus ride, he says, gives him time to think.

title: Bloody Monday  A New Chapter In an Old Tragedy
description: A missing element in Britain's attempts to break the back of Northern Ireland terrorism has been a coordinated campaign with the Republic of Ireland to the south. The murder in Ireland last week of Earl Mountbatten of Burma, a war hero and cousin of Queen Elizabeth, may supply that missing ingredient. The Irish Prime Minister, John Lynch, agreed to discuss counterterrorism with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in London this week, after Lord Mountbatten's funeral in Westminster Abbey.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: When Paul and Silas sang and prayed loudly in a jail in Philippi more than 1,900 years ago, an earthquake followed and the jailer was converted to Christianity, the Bible recounts. When the Rev. Walter L. King and 200 members of the Voice of the Nazarene Association of Independent Churches sang and prayed loudly in their tabernacle in Nottingham Township, Pa., last July 3, a constable walked in bearing three citations signed by a justice of the peace. The papers said the group was being fined $978 for excessive noise, with $326 added for every day the camp meetings continued.

title: Susan Barbara Sperber Fiance
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Sperber of East Hills, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Barbara Sperber, a senior at the University of Pennsylvania, to Curt I. Parnes, who is in his second year at Vanderbilt University's Medical School. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Parries of Emerson, N.J .

title: Faust and the Loan Shark
description: NTIL now, Peter Maas has concentrated on writing nonfiction, with admirable results Serpico, The Valachi Papers, King of the

title: Ethnic Divisions Characterize Democratic Primary on Sept. 11
description: President Carter made the Bronx a national symbol of urban decay 19 months ago when he stood in the ruins of Charlotte Street and pledged his Administration's help to rebuild at least that small portion of the South Bronx. Since then there has been some talk and some planning but no bricks and mortar. Instead, the blight has spread over more than half the borough that was once the middleclass bedroom community of Manhattan.

title: Wine
description: Nothing, said Philip Dallas in his book The Great Wines of Italy, has ever gone quite right for Sicily.  Romans, barbarians, Byzantines. Normans, Swabian, Angevins, Spaniards, Piedmontese, the French under Napoleon and finally the Bourbons  took turns at ruling the island. None of them had the interests of the Sicilians at heart; it is not surprising that finally the Sicilians decided it was best to handle their own justice with the aid of a sawedoff shotgun.

title: Five Novels
description: TE CITY, COLO., a town that has more than a touch of Vail and Aspen, is undergoing a wave of sabotage. (1) Someone

title: SENATE TO RESUME ARMS PACT HEARINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1  When the Senate resumes consideration of the strategic arms treaty next week, the White House seems prepared to gamble that it can win approval of the pact without a major increase in military spending.

title: ATHOME
description: CARRYING a large plastic garbage can, I was cleaning up that part of my property that is on the other side of the stone wall.

title: U.S. Forecasts Decline In School Enrollment, With a Spending Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)  School enrollment is continuing to decline in the United States, but inflation will cause school expenditures to increase by $11 billion in the coming year, the Government has forecast.

title: Barbato Cleared In Suffolk Scandal
description: A week from Tuesday, the Suffolk County Republican Party, which has been run by the same people for a decade, will hold one of the more provocative primaries in its history. The primary was significant because Nicholas Barbato, the former Republican leader of Smithtown and the political mentor of County Executive John V. N. Klein, who is running for reelection, was indicted on charges of extorting more than $100,000 from an insurance agent in return for a large county insurance contract. Mr. Klein's opponent, Islip Town Supervisor Peter Cohalan, had used the BarbatoKlein connection as the main entrenching tool in his campaign. The primary took on added significance when Ronald Reagan endorsed Mr. Klein.

title: Hillary L. Scoutt Wed to a Minister
description: In St. Margaret's Episcopal Church in Washington yesterday afternoon, Hillary Loughridge Scoutt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Jerrold Scoutt Jr. of Bethesda. Md., became the bride of the Rev. Philip Lyon Rountree Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rountree of Gates Mills, Ohio. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Stephen Arpee, who was assisted by the Revs. Gary L'Hommedieu and Molly Macsherry.

title: Glenn Miller's Executor Ordered To Return $800,000 to 2 Children
description: HACKENSACK  A lawyer who allegedly wrote himself a sweetheart contract while serving as the executor of Glenn Miller's estate has been ordered to return to the bandleader's two children more than half a million dollars he earned on the agreement, plus interest.

title: Best Sellers
description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1,400 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: Grace Cook Is Wed To Peter Wagoner
description: Grace Tracy Cook, daughter of Charles T. Cook of New York and Dublin, N.H., and the late Mrs. George A. Phelps of New York. was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Stewart Wagoner, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stewart Clyde Wagoner of Scotia, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel Abrams performed the Protestant ceremony in South Park, Jackson Hole, Wyo., at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Byron Kellam, friends of the couple.

title: ART VIEW
description: At the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, Long Island, there can be seen (through Sept. 30) a revisionist exhibition of paintings by the Belgian Surrealist Ren Magritte (18961967). He comes out of it as what he is, but is not always taken to be: one of the strongest and most disquieting of all the European Surrealists.

title: GARDENINGLandscaping With a Design in Mind
description: PERHAPS the greatest luxury to be afforded a gardener is that of acquiring land that has natural character and beauty. Hills and valleys, cliffs and ravines, streams and lakes inherently add interest that is otherwise difficult to capture. Least interesting is flat land, unless its immediate surroundings are such that they provide the interest. Thus a flat meadow in the Poconos or the Rockies may provide a striking garden setting because of its spectacular view of the surrounding hills and forests. Vistas then become an important element in the landscape.

title: Jamie Hoffman Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard P. Hoffman of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jamie Hoffman, to Michael Arnow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron H. Arnow of Newton, Mass. Miss Hoffman's father is president of Howard P. Hoffman Associates, a subsidiary of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., of which he is a partner. Mr. Arnow is a realestate investor in the Boston area.

title: Coal Gasification: A Wary Welcome
description: BEULAH, N.D.  A few miles down an unpaved county road here in Mercer County are the red barns and expansive fields of the livestock operation run by Werner Benfit and his mother. Mrs. Anna Fuchs. The North American Coal Corporation's Indian Head strip mine is an unwelcome neighbor, once reaching within 500 yards of Mr. Benfit's vegetable garden. During warm summer evenings, the groans and clanks of its Gypsy Rose dragline blend strangely with the sound of crickets.

title: Proxmire Fails to Cut Guarantees on Loans for City
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee asked the Treasury Department to cut back on Federal loan guarantees to New York City this year because the city unexpectedly had $200 million in cash left over from the last fiscal year. But the request was rejected by the Treasury, which last week approved the latest guarantee, for $100 million in city bonds.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Savage Will Be Wed
description: In Christ Episcopal Church in Christiana Hundred, Greenville, Del., yesterday afternoon, Marion Lind Savage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest C. Savage Jr. of Wilmington. Del., became the bride of. David Alfred Recht of Jamaica Plain, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Recht of Lincolnshire, Ill. The Rev. John O'Hear performed the ceremony.

title: ANTIQUESOn Creating Your Own Heirlooms
description: MONTVALE WHAT if Aunt Helen didn't leave you her 100yearold string of opals and Cousin Jenny got Grandma's gold huntingcase watch? One way to console yourself is to create your own heirlooms by buying your own antique jewelry.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BEACH HAVEN (Surflight Summer Theater, Engleside Avenue)  You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown. Today, 8:30 P.M. California Suite. Opens Wednesday, 8:30 P.M. (through Sept. 9). $5$5.50. (609) 4929477.

title: ART
description: IN 1962, the mill here was still grinding grist  reason enough, according to the Darwinian law of the marketplace, to replace it with a nervegas factory or some such enterprise. That the preRevolutionary

title: The Real Christopher
description: THE memoirs of a provincial bookseller do not in themselves suggest exciting reading. Nor does the name of the author, Christopher Milne, bring instant recognition. Christopher Robin of Winnie the Pooh, however, is known to millions. Mr. Milne has spent his life trying to live down his fictional namesake. In The Path Through the Trees, a

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: IT might never have happened if Skip and Susan Clark had not been giving a clambake that Saturday night in June. They had just bought a solar heater for their swimming pool and the neighbors were curious to see what it was all about.

title: Spacecraft Takes First Close Look At Saturn, Slipping Through Rings
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Sept. 1 Pioneer 11 survived a bombardment of fine particles from the rings of Saturn today and then swept within 13,000 miles of its pale yellow clouds for the first rendezvous by a spacecraft with the solar system's secondlargest planet.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: METROPOLITAN LIFE, by Fran Lebowitz. (Fawcett/Crest, $2.25.) Short, sharp essays about the absurdities of urban manners  particularly those peculiar to New York City  by a writer whom our reviewer, Jill Robinson, described as an important humorist in the classic tradition. There is character here as well as personality.

title: Sunshine and Gas Are Plentiful for Holiday's Start
description: A combination of bright sunshine and ready gasoline pumps sent residents of the New York metropolitan area to parks and beaches by the hundreds of thousands yesterday to celebrate while they could the start of summer's final holiday. Looming for the rest of the Labor Day weekend was a predicted relapse into the muggy days of early August, with possible showers today and tomorrow.

title: A Mansion Is Divided In Darien
description: DARIEN, Conn.  First it was an industrialist's home with a 60foot living room, a fourthfloor squash court and countless bedrooms  so many that the son of the man who built them asked if he could invite his Yale class over for the weekend.

title: College Students March to a Changing Beat
description: BLOODY Monday it's called the day most highschool seniors receive notification of their success or failure to achieve college admission. One glance at the return address, one heft of the envelope tells all: Forms and further instructions accompany acceptance, while rejection requires only a single sheet.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Emlyn Williams, the gifted British actor, will make his only appearance in the New Jersey area before continuing on a nationwide tour in Dylan Thomas Growing Up.

title: Back to Social Studies
description: LABOR Day signals the end of summer to most people, but for the 5to17yearold segment of the population it has an added meaning: going back to school. Blue looseleaf notebooks, No. 2 pencils, plastic protractors and dimestore compasses: For the schoolaged group, these are as much a part of September as changing leaves and early darkness.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: The theory of quantum chromodynamics, developed since the 1960's to account in a more parsimonious fashion for what seemed a bewildering variety of apparently elementary subatomic particles, received considerable substantiation last week. In a symposium at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory at Batavia, Ill., scientists reported on new experiments that have gone far toward establishing the actual existence of an entity, fancifully called the gluon, that the chromodynamic theory calls for.

title: Wendy C. Warren Is Married To William R.Osborne on L.I.
description: Wendy Christine Warren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel R. Warren of Syosset, L.I., was married there yesterday to William Reyburn Osborne, son of Charlotte Osborne of East Poultney, Vt., and the late William McKinley Osborne 3d. The Rev. Dr. Malcolm C. Bertram of the United Church of Christ performed the ceremony at the Warren home.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1  After 40 years on a newspaper a man is entitled to go away for a while, but I've discovered this summer that for the people who make or report the news in Washington, there's no away today.

title: Planar Compositions That Are Fantasy, but Not Science Fiction
description: HUNTINGTON ARTISTS often have to find what their families would call something steady to keep the wolf from the door, and frequently they become better known for their work as writers, teachers or museum professionals than for their achievements as artists. This is true of Marshall Didier, who has devoted great deal of his time and energy during the last six years to Marshall Art Transport, the company of art movers that he founded and has built into a successful and respected concern.

title: Katherine Lyons Wed to B.R. Henry
description: Katherine Wilberding Lyons and Bruce Riblet Henry, both of Pittsfield, Mass., were married yesterday in Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. William Rhodes performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: Eagles' Line Is Tough to Crack
description: The Giants go into today's seasonopening game at Philadelphia today with their offensive line in a shambles and their old offensive line coach happily employed on the other sideline.

title: Dylan and Morrison In a Religious Vein
description: Bob Dylan's Slow Train Coming and Van Morrison's Into the Music represent two new disks by male rock veterans with growly, idiosyncratic voices who work in a bluesrock idiom with walling female backup singers and who write songs, at least on this occasion, that concern themselves with religion.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: WILL County Executive Alfred B. DelBello run for another term? I don't know, he said, after an aide needed to remind him that his current term expires in 1981.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: TV VIEW
description: People conditioned by American television often have difficulty getting involved with foreignmade programs, even those of the lightentertainment phylum, for reasons that have nothing to do with linguistic differences. As was apparent as recently

title: Tax Lures For Builders Facing Cuts This Month
description: The city's revised commercial and industrial incentive program, which is expected to be signed into law this week and to take effect by the end of this month, will sharply cut the amount of tax exemptions now available and give the city more discretion in granting exemptions.

title: The Smell of School
description: WHEN the air is full of the sounds of transitory leaves brushing against each other for the last time before they fall, when the nights have turned perceptibly cooler and when the late August air loses its thickness and humidity, and the morning throws itself out like the scent of a broken mint leaf, the smell of school pervades me and makes me become a child again. It makes me recall snippets of my past that have ceased to be memories and have become feelings.

title: The Squandering of Educational Expertise
description: AS SOCIETY moved through the trauma of the 1960's into the hedonism of the 1970's, education and teachers became whipping boys for America's various ills. A major manifestation of that concern and ill feeling became evident every time that school bond issues and budgets came up for approval by the electorate.

title: D.E. Chapman Fian of Carol Huntington
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan Trumbull Huntington of Salem, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Carol Lee Huntington, to Duncan Earle Chapman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Earle MacArthur Chapman of Brookline, Mass. The couple will be married Oct. 20 in Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston. Church in Boston.

title: Synthetic Fuel Plan Is Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI)  Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that it would be a terrible idea to set up a Federal corporation to develop synthetic fuels, given the

title: ART
description: THE Joseloff Gallery at Hartford Art School is resplendent with a show of baskets made by Eastern American Indians, together with examples of their tools and raw materials. The curator was Carol Grant Hart, who, with her exhusband, Dan, wrote the manual Natural Basketry. A former teacher of basketry in Hartford, Mrs. Hart has been conducting workshops there this summer.

title: Hartford Man Sought in Shootings After Auto Accident Surrenders
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 1 (AP)  The man sought in the shooting of seven persons after a motorvehicle accident here on Tuesday turned himself in tonight, the police said.

title: Recluta Sails on Incentive
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 1  When dawn broke today, Walter Hanson made a final check of his position in the Vineyard  perhaps the most important yacht race of the year on Long Island Sound  and turned in for some sleep.

title: GARDENING
description: PERHAPS the greatest luxury to be afforded a gardener is that of acquiring land that has natural character and beauty. Hills and valleys, cliffs and ravines, streams and lakes inherently add interest that is otherwise difficult to capture. Least interesting is flat land, unless its immediate surroundings are such that they provide the interest. Thus a flat meadow in the Poconos or the Rockies may provide a striking garden setting because of its spectacular view of the surrounding hills and forests. Vistas then become an important element in the landscape.

title: Design
description: The paynowseelater aspect of custom decorating can baffle shoppers reared on readytowear. For them, a retailstore decorator may be just the thing.

title: Learning the Book Fair Lesson
description: The onagain, offagain story of Robert Bernstein reveals a lot about the vexations of doing cultural business with the Soviet Union. Mr. Bernstein, a prominent publisher, planned to be in Moscow next Tuesday for the opening of the second International Book Fair. But he was abruptly bumped from his journey, probably because a Bolshoi dancer defected and some American had to be taught a lesson. A lesson can indeed be found, though not the one the Russians may have intended.

title: Jay Kalish Fianc Of Judith S. Miller
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Israel Miller of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Sharon Miller, to Jay Alan Kalish, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Kalish of Far Rockaway, Queens. January wedding is planned.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: THE envelope was there in my pile of mail, fairly throbbing with its manila message: There's a check in here. Open me quick.

title: Noah, 19, Triumphs, Delights Open Fans
description: New York tennis fans, always eager for a charismatic new performer, found one at the United States Open last night when Yannick Noah, a 19yearold from France who grew up in West Africa, made his stadium court debut and beat Butch Walts, a Californian, 76, 63, 62.

title: Oil Costs Swelling Poor Nations' Aid Needs
description: A United States Government analysis to determine the economic impact of this year's oilprice increases on developing countries has concluded that several billion dollars in special aid to the world's poorest countries will be necessary in the next 18 months.

title: More Prisoners Get U.S. Benefits
description: TRENTON, Sept. 1  The arrival of Gary Maik's Social Security disability payment is one of .the big events of his month. He gets fidgety if the check is late. With careful management, he has saved over $6.000 in the last four years.

title: Vincent Giffuni, Builder, Marries Barbara Smith
description: Barbara Lee Jacqueline Smith, a textile and fashion designer and stylist, was married yesterday in New Hope, Pa., to Vincent Joseph Giffuni, a New York builder and developer. The ceremony was performed in St. Martin of Tours Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Paul J. Carey.

title: G.C. Adkins Weds S. Dianne Balfour
description: S. Dianne Balfour, assistant treasurer of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in New York, and G. Carlton Adkins, counsel to Philip Morris Inc., were married yesterday at the Ridge Avenue Baptist Church in West Monroe, La. The Rev. Raymond M. Howe performed the ceremony.

title: Nancy Armstrong Bride of James Bolt
description: St. John's Lutheran Church in Stamford, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Nancy Lee Armstrong, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wakefield Armstrong of Stamford, to James Francis Bolt, son of Mr. and Mrs. James N. Bolt of Herndon, Va. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Bernard Johnson.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Labor Day is a New Yorker's holiday. Its origins date to a parade held in New York City by the Knights of Labor in 1882. Since its official recognition in April 1887, it has come to be a traditional weekend in which to celebrate the last of summer. In Westchester, music highlights the celebration.

title: Fuel Equation Is Still Unsolved
description: SCHOOL officials say there will be plenty of gasoline for school buses when students begin returning to school this week, but they say the sharp increase in price, not only for gasoline but also for heating oil, is taking a bigger bite out of school budgets than had been anticipated.

title: Maria C. Anzovino Engaged
description: The engagement of Maria Christine Anzovino to Paul Joseph Rogers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Rogers of Mamaroneck, N.Y., has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Michael Anzovino of Ossining, N.Y. Miss Anzovino, daughter also of the late Mr. Anzovino, and her fianc are students at Westchester Community College. Mr. Rogers's father is a makeup manager with The New York Times.

title: ARTHUR W. MOORE
description: Arthur W. Moore, a retired insurance broker, died Wednesday at his home in Rumson, N.J., after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: World News Briefs
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 1 (Reuters) Vice President Mondale arrived here today after a weeklong trip to China and discussed the problems of Indochinese refugees with officials of 12 relief organizations operating in Hong Kong, a reluctant host to about 67,000 boat people from Vietnam.

title: Prosecutor Accused Of Bias
description: ANTISEMITISM in the office of the Union County Prosecutor is alleged by two investigators who were dismissed in a staff cutback. Armed with a finding by a Federal agency that there is reasonable cause to believe their complaints, they have filed a suit in United States District Court in Newark.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: FRANK O. BRAYNARD, the indefatigable ship buff who staged Op Sail in 1976, was off again the other day on his latest crush: the new American Merchant Marine Museum on the grounds of the United States Merchant Marine Academy.

title: Matisse Museum: An Ironic Comment
description: NICE Were one to measure the historical importance of Henri Matisse and Marc Chagall by the number and size of the signposts pointing to their respective museums in Nice, one would conclude the Russian Chagall to be

title: Editors' Choice
description: BURGER'S DAUGHTER, by Nadine Gordlmer. (Viking Press, $10.95.) The daughter of a South African political martyr struggles to keep her father's cause alive and to find an Identity of her own: a dazzling novel.

title: Sandra Bartolini Wed To Peter G. Lawrence
description: Sandra Bartolini, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. John Bartolini of New Vernon, N.J., was married there yesterday to Peter Gordon Lawrence, son of Thomas E. Lawrence of Boston and the late Alida Gulick Lawrence. The Rev. John Corr performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (2) Face the Nation: Ray Marshall, Secretary of Labor.

title: THE MARKETS
description: The stock market last week scored a moderate advance in continued heavy trading despite some bearish economic developments. The Dow Jones industrial average finished up 7.43 to 887.63, it highest level in 10 months.

title: Hofstra Faculty Union Plans a Strike Tuesday In Dispute on Salaries
description: The union representing faculty members at Hofstra University yesterday called for a strike on Tuesday by the school's 450member teaching staff.

title: Ellen Mary Baxter Wed To Jonathan G. Hatch
description: Ellen Mary Baxter and Jonathan George Hatch, graduates of Franklin and Marshall College, were married yesterday morning. The Rev. Laurence D. Fish, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Ayer Memorial Chapel of the Peddie School in Hightstown, N.J.

title: Bruce L. Rosen Is Fianc Of Pamela Jane Sherman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael S. Sherman of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Jane Sherman, to Bruce Lawrence Rosen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay M. Rosen, also of Stamford.

title: Influx of Transvestite Prostitutes Plaguing Manhattan Plaza Area
description: Five prostitutes stand at the corner of 42d Street and Ninth Avenue at 12:50 A.M. The air is hot and humid. When the M11 bus stops, two more join them. All are strapping, powerfully built. Soon the largest, about 6 feet 6 inches tall in spike heels, strolls through two traffic lanes. As cars swing aside, the prostitute flags them with his skirt

title: DOMING OUT
description: OHANA, recently opened in Wainscott, bills itself as a Japanese haute cuisine restaurant and purveys interesting, complex food that often uses the Japanese culinary vocabulary to dramatic effect. The effort is to be enthusiastically commended, the results a little less wholeheartedly so.

title: Detection of the Elusive Gluon Exciting Scientists
description: A thrill of excitement has reverberated among scientists around the world since the disclosure last week that a hypothetically vital component of all matter has apparently been found to exist in reality.

title: The Sinologue and the Witchhunters
description: BY now the old sad story and the lessons to be drawn from it hardly seem to need repeating: how the State Department's China specialists recognized Chiang Kaishek as one of the century's great losers at a time when American wartime propoganda and Henry R. Luce were exalting him and his Madame as symbols of a Free China; how recommendations of the specialists were ignored, overrid

title: Jets: Uncertain, but Exuberant
description: Some of them will talk about it, but quietly. The words are Super Bowl, and a few Jets believe it is within reach. Who knows?

title: Deaths
