description: ABRAHAMSENAlfred E. Insurance Square Club of NY Inc., Officers and Members are requested to meet at ObergBedell Funeral Home, 3787 Hylan Blvd, S.I. on Sunday, September 2, at 8:30 p.m. to participate with Kllwinning Lodge No. 825, in services for our departed brother.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: The Fall Boating Season Docks With Large, New Fleet of Ships
description: The fall boat show season begins Thursday at 10 A.M. when the North Atlantic sailboat show opens its doors.

title: Births 5016
description: Carol and David Buda joyfully announce the birth of their son, Jordan Saxe Buda, August 29, 1979. Proud grandparents are Dr. and Mrs. Theodore Saxe, Ft. Lee NJ and Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Feiner, Merrick L.I.

title: CHRYSLER PAY PLAN IS STUDIED BY U.A.W.
description: DETROIT, Sept. 1  The United Automobile Workers may seek to be included in the Chrysler Corporation's plans to pay its executives work credits in lieu of cash for as long as two years, Douglas A. Fraser, the union's president, said today.

title: Moscow Book Fair May Set Off Literary Fireworks
description: There could be literary fireworks with political overtones between American publishers and their Soviet hosts at the Moscow International Book Fair, which begins Tuesday. The centerpiece of the Association of American Publishers display at the fair is a catalogue, in English and Russian, called America Through American Eyes. The catalogue, prepared by a group led by Kurt Vonnegut Jr., lists the titles, authors and contents of 321 books, which will themselves be on display. The fair's officials could regard some of the books as provocative.

title: Kelly Ann Stone Fiance Of Michael G. Monsarrat
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence H. Stone of Watertown, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kelly Ann Stone, to Michael G. Monsarrat, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Monsarrat of South Windsor, Conn.

title: Bonn Gives Unprecedented Attention to Nazi Era
description: BONN, Sept. 1  West Germany is commemorating the 40th anniversary of the outbreak of World War II with a flood of analysis and documentation.

title: Giving Birth Outside the Hospital
description: CAROLE GREEN and her husband, Monty, had their first child six months ago  at home in their apartment in Irvington. They believe that home birth should be an option for those women who want it, as long as it poses no special dangers. They are among a growing group of people who maintain that what has become the normal American way of giving birth  in a hospital, with a doctor present  isn't necessarily the only way.

title: CARTER'S RACE AGAINST TIME
description: In a city where no gathering or time of day is wholly immune to the intrusion of politics, one group of political reporters likes to breakfast with notables to get a jump on the news. One morning last June, they were badgering Representative Morris K. Udall, the Arizona liberal who for a time was Jimmy Carter's leading rival for the 1976 Presidential nomination, about whether the Democrats might really dump Mr. Carter in 1980.

title: Letters
description: Your Aug. 20 editorial regarding the proposed Energy Mobilization Board failed to consider some important points.

title: CHESS
description: The last refuge of a desperate man is a gambit. When adversity stares you in the face, when nothing but a victory will do you any good, it's time to shake up your opponent with a sacrifice.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Tomorrow  Coker Farms, Stone Hill Road., Bedford, N.Y. Local, junior and children's working hunter; pleasure horses, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Freud Wouldn't Recognize Today's Analyst's Office
description: Sigmuna Freud's office at Berggasse 19 in Vienna set the tone for psychoanalysts' offices for many years. Although part of his apartment, it had its own separate entrance, with a waiting room area and two exits, so that patients would not meet.

title: On Language
description: During the past two decades, interest in language seems to have grown enormously: more dictionaries and other word books have been published since 1960 than ever before.

title: Carol Strickland Wed to T.C. McGinnis Jr.
description: Carol Anne Strickland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Strickland Jr. of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Charles McGinnis

title: Discount Dentistry Growing
description: EVERY year, New Jerseyans spend $600 million having their teeth drilled, filled, capped, cleaned, straightened, removed, remodeled or otherwise taken care of.

title: The Unspoken Hope Is That the U.N. Will Move From New York
description: VIENNA  A choir sang Beethoven's Ode to Joy at the inauguration 10 days ago of what Austrian Chancellor Bruno Kreisky proudly called the United Nations' new house on the Danube, but the lavish affair was singularly cheerless. Local newspapers noted afterward that despite the official rhetoric, television coverage, blue United Nations flags on all streetcars and special postage stamps, Austrians seemed generally unimpressed about providing the world organization with a third home. Was not the glass house in Manhattan and the Palais des Nations in Geneva sufficient? they asked.

title: Happiness Is a Red Sox Victory
description: IF you lived within range of the Bridgeport, New Haven or Hartford radio stations in the 1930's, you probably heard the immortal Fred Hoey broadcasting Boston Red Sox baseball games. Fred also announced the Boston Braves games, but it would be the Red Sox games you would be more apt to remember.

title: Health Professionals Feel Power Shifting
description: MEMBERS of the healthcare professions in Connecticut have been watching, in many instances uneasily. a shift in Dower.

title: Surgical Memoirs
description: SURGEONS rarely make good writers, perhaps because writing requires patience bordering on passivity, while surgery is, above all, an act of intervention and aggression. One exception has been Richard Selzer, a professor of surgery at Yale, whose earlier collection of essays, Mortal Lessons, main

title: Letter TO THE EDITOR
description: Much as I agree with Clifford Mason's comments on the present state of black American theater (A New Black Theater, July 22), I am afraid his historical remarks were inflated to bolster his arguments.

title: Jewish Coalition Asks F.C.C. to Prevent Sale Of WEVDAM Radio
description: A coalition of Jewish organizations has filed a petition with the Federal Communications Commission to stop the sale of radio station WEVDAM to a group specializing in Christian religious broadcasting.

title: Retaliatory Raids by Ulster Protestants Feared as I.R.A. Presses Attacks
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 1  In its redbrick headquarters in a tough part of Belfast's Protestant East End, the leaders of the Ulster Defense Association are spending a good bit of their time these days talking of war.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: DEER are walking into the back yard and eating the tomatoes, raccoons are munching on corn, skunks are digging up lawns and geese are plopping into swimming pools.

title: Michelle O'Brien Sets Fall Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Aloysius O'Brien Jr. of New London, NH., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michelle Marian O'Brien, to Charles Harold Free 3d of Cambridge, Mass. The wedding is planned for October.

title: Alexandra Corbin, An Artist, Is Bride Of L.S. Mondschein
description: Alexandra Kraeler Corbin, an artist, and Lawrence S. Mondschein, a Foreign Service officer, were married at noon yesterday in Ridgefield, Conn. Rabbi Charles Davidson performed the ceremony m the garden at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Corbin. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Milton Mondschein of Bayside, Queens.

title: 1929: Market Hits New High! When Will It Ever Stop:
description: Fifty years ago tomorrow much of the eastern United States sweltered in a heat wave. The temperature in New York City hit 94 degrees, making it the hottest day of the year. Connie Mack's Philadelphia Athletics were also hot that day. They won their third straight game over a Yankee lineup that included sluggers Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, and went on to win the American League pennant and then the World Series.

title: HURRICANE KILLS 84; EVACUATION OF KEYS ORDERED IN FLORIDA
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 1  Hurricane David swept back out to sea today after battering this island nation and leaving the capital of Santo Domingo a disaster area. Extensive damage to crops was also reported by officials here.

title: 3 New Radiation Cases Reported
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., Sept. 1 (UPI) Three more workmen at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant here have received minor radiation doses, bringing to nine the number of people contaminated at the plant in the last week. Six workers received higher than permissible levels of exposure on Tuesday while repairing a leaky valve. In the latest incident, disclosed yesterday, three employees of a contracting company doing masonry work at the plant received minor radiation doses. None were hospitalized.

title: POLICERADIO ISSUE UPSETS DEPARTMENT
description: The message on the police radio advised all officers to be on the lookout for two men in a 1979 maroon Buick who were wanted in connection with a kidnaphostage situation.

title: Classics: Friends That Don't Grow Old
description: Once upon a time, the words classic and timeless were anathema to anyone interested in a fashion image. They were, to the chic, one big blah, as scintillating as mashed potato sandwiches.

title: Loft Tenants Risk Loss of Fixture Fee
description: Lisa Benson rented a loft in SoHo. She is happy with the space, which is completely renovated and unusually spacious  2,500 square feet. She is also happy with the rent, $350 a month.

title: Rte: Infusions of Money
description: AS the 1890's opened, John Davison Rockefeller was a man beset by problems. His Standard Oil empire faced growing waves of criticism. Judges, lawmakers and journalists, even those of moderate leanings, had cited long lists of abuses and demanded more than token remedies. Not the least cause of complaint was Rockefeller's huge personal fortune.

title: New Animal Shelter Stirs Controversy
description: BERGEN County's new animal shelter, which was opened only two months ago, has already become the focus of a controversy, with animalwelfare activists saying that it is poorly managed and overcrowded and its animals mistreated.

title: London's Stage Is Set For Lean Times
description: The lights may be going out in theaters all over Britain this winter, and some will not come on again. That is the gloomy forecast being heard

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: THE MERRY WIDOWDiana Soviero and Alan Titus sing the romantic leads in the New York City Opera production in English of Franz Lehar's operetta, Wednesday through next Sunday at the State Theater.

title: U.S. Pledge to NATO To Use Nuclear Arms Criticized by Kissinger
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 1  Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that America's pledge to defend European NATO allies against a Russian attack with its own strategic nuclear weapons was losing credibility because of the risk of exposing American cities to nuclear devastation by the Soviet Union.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Having bid farewell to school houses several years ago with the sorrow of a man emerging from 30 years of lost wanderings in the Dismal Swamp, I have only lately begun studying the nuances of human passion created by the busing issue and the strange behavior they produce.

title: Iran, Irked by FuelDeal Reaction, Talks of Reviewing U.S. Oil Sales
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 1 (AP)  The chairman of Iran's oil industry says his country may be forced to revise its agreement to sell oil to the United States because of all the hullabaloo over an American agreement to sell diesel fuel and kerosene to the Iranians, according to the newspaper Kayhan International.

title: Bonn Minister Meets With Sadat
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Sept.1 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister HansDietrich Genscher of West Germany held talks today with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt on Middle East peace efforts. Mr. Genscher arrived here yesterday after visits to Syria, Lebanon and Jordan.

title: Legislature Ponders Fall Session on Oil
description: GROWING concern over the possibility of a serious shortage of homeheating oil this winter has led the leadership of the Legislature to reconsider the possibility of holding a special session this fall to deal with the problem.

title: INSURANCE GOING UP FOR SMALLER AUTOS
description: ALBANY, Aug. 30 (AP)  Owners of smaller foreign or sports cars may soon routinely pay more for their automobile insurance in New York State than do people with standard Americanmade cars.

title: How American Culture Has Been Shaped by the Artist in Exile
description: We are a nation of runaways. The history of the United States is largely an account of how fast and how successfully our ancestors ran from other lands, and to a remarkable extent American culture today is still shaped, defined  perhaps even justified  by refugees, migrs, fugitives, political pariahs and defectors. When Aleksandr Godunov left the Bolshoi Ballet the other day and was granted asylum by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, the young dancer was, in every sense, voting with his feet. He took his place in a long and distinguished line of artists and scholars who have run to this country in search of the 20th century's most rapidly disappearing commodity, personal freedom. At very least, Mr. Godunov found a way to get his name mentioned in the same paragraph with those of Albert Einstein, Thomas Mann and Igor Stravinsky.

title: Capital Report: Public Initiative
description: THERE is a growing demand in New Jersey for initiative and referendum, a government device that lets voters propose and pass laws, as well as repeal them.

title: Thais Expelling Refugee Boat
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 1 (UPI) The police said today that they would allow refugees who landed their battered fishing boat on a Thai beach to repair it but that then they would be pushed back out to sea. The police in Pakpanang district, 420 miles south of Bangkok, said the 18foot open boat, crowded with 21 Vietnamese refugees, was badly damaged when it carne onto the beach.

title: RobesonConcert Protests Recalled 30 Years Later
description: THIRTY years ago, Peekskill residents were forced to wear sweaters as the temperature dropped into the 50's. The new Ford Tudor was selling for $1,625 at Belmont Motors on Main Street, Bill's Grocery had sirloin steak at 69 cents a pound and Good News had just opened at the Peekskill Theater. All in all, this hillhugging community of 17,700 people 32 miles north of New York City was at ease.

title: Gardening
description: PERHAPS the greatest luxury to be afforded a gardener is that of acquiring land that has natural character and beauty. Hills and valleys, cliffs and ravines, streams and lakes inherently add interest that is otherwise difficult to capture. Least interesting is flat land, unless its immediate surroundings are such that they provide the interest. Thus a flat meadow in the Poconos or the Rockies may provide a striking garden setting because of its spectacular view of the surrounding hills and forests. Vistas then become an important element in the landscape.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Which alternative energy sources are most likely to find their way into popular use? The answer to this  and a thousand other questions you never before needed to ask  will be explored at a daylong energy symposium to be held at the Campus Center of Fairfield University next Saturday beginning at 9 A.M. Sponsored by the department of politics in conjunction with the Bridgeport Clamshell Alliance, an antinuclear, proalternatives group, the day will be divided into three parts.

title: Bolshoi Case and Troops in Cuba Are Irritants
description: WASHINGTONThe United States and the Soviet Union demonstrated again last week the uncanny ability of superpowers to elevate irritating episodes into public dramas. First, there was the excitement over whether or not a Bolshoi ballerina really wanted to return to Moscow. No sooner was that threeday affair seemingly settled than a new and possibly more serious issue arose. The presence of a 2,000 to 3,000man Soviet combat force in Cuba was disclosed. Why was it there? Nobody in Washington had a clear reason.

title: Giants' No. 1 Problem Is Offense
description: The Fumble led to turmoil which led to chaos, which is where the Giants still are as they open their 1979 National Football League season today against the Eagles. If the Giants were a Broadway show, they could very well close in Philadelphia.

title: Getting Help If the Car Breaks Down
description: The scenario is familiar to almost everyone who drives a car: a breakdown far from a telephone or town. If it happens on a Sunday and a gasoline station should be nearby, it is probably closed. Suddenly a happy journey disintegrates into despair. A delay is inevitable and it can be prolonged, costly and inconvenient. But help is rarely as far away as it may seem at first.

title: Recruiter of Black Executives
description: In 1963, Charles L. Fields was a New York City official charged with getting jobs for blacks. He was dismissed, he says, for pushing too hard. Mr. Fields found jobs for 3,000 blacks and other minorities, but along the way he was reported by the press to have said that certain companies were discriminating against minorities.

title: Images of Hastings
description: FOR the last two months, Larry D'Amico has chased the image of HastingsonHudson's past on seven panels that will form a mural in the village library. He painted everyday scenes from the year 1929, a time when every workingman wore a cap, women wore hats and even gloves, and buses were called surface transportation.

title: Realty News
description: WASHINGTON  Fearing that the conversion of rental apartments to condominiums and cooperatives is displacing tenants and creating a shortage of rental housing, a New York Representative will introduce a bill this week that calls for a 3year moratorium on such conversions.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Outwardly, at least, it had all the earmarks of a promotion when J. Richard Munro was named vice president of Time Inc.'s video group in 1975, but sometimes he must have wondered if he hadn't landed instead on somebody's black list. We really threw him a bunch of dogs and said, make something with it,  said Time's chairman, Andrew Heiskell.

title: Cars Increase, Creating Greater Gasoline Need
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI)  The nation is experiencing such a population explosion of motor vehicles that there is little hope of reducing gasoline consumption in the next few years, a researcher says.

title: Let Your Fingers Do the Burning
description: We're very happy to see the two new directories being introduced,  says Bill Nikolis of Bill's Florist in an ad promoting the New York Telephone Company's plan to split the Manhattan Yellow Pages into two volumes  one for consumers, one for business. But Mr. Nikolis is not so sure anymore. I don't want to see the telephone company use this as an excuse just to raise rates, he said. And Morris Glasser, of Morris Glasser & Son Inc., who says in the same ad I think it will make more money for me, has also had second thoughts  to the point where the glazier has joined the Coalition of Businesses against Yellow Pages Advertising Abuse, an ad hoc group that says it represents 3,000 to 4,000 businesses.

title: Fashion
description: Part of the appeal of a dress is that it only takes a moment, one decision and you are ready to go. No colors to juggle, no perplexing layers to conjugate. It may be less creative than playing with pieces, but it's infinitely easier and faster.

title: Headliners
description: In 1970, even the United States Army was somewhat sceptical of the story told by Dr. Jeffrey R. MacDonald to explain the deaths of his wife and daughters at Fort Bragg, N.C. Dr. MacDonald, then a Green Beret captain, maintained that his apartment had been invaded early in the morning by at least four young people who beat and stabbed him and his family while chanting, Acid is groovy, kill the pigs. Doubting that young people chanted such things, even in 1970, the Army investigated Dr. MacDonald as a murder suspect, but eventually dropped the case. But Mrs. MacDonald's family, who originally supported the doctor, came to believe in his guilt and pursued a crusade to bring him to justice. Last week, a Federal jury in Raleigh, N.C., found Dr. MacDonald guilty on three charges of murder.

title: Stephanie Crafton Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Stephanie Kim Crafton. to Thomas Edmund Evangelista has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Henry Crafton of Brookfield, Conn, The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Evangelista of Georgetown, Conn. Miss Crafton's father is general manager of the radio station WSUB in Groton, Conn. Mr. Evangelista's father is with the advertising department of The New York Times.

title: What Guinness Plans for America
description: LONDON  From the time it launched its advertising campaign in Britain 50 years ago, Arthur Guinness Son & Company has promoted the axiom that Guinness is good for you. But in the United States, with its more restrictive advertising code, such slogans do not go down easily, and the brewer is making no such claims for its murky, dark stout there.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: The Forgotten Man In Elephant Man
description: On the door of Kevin Conway's dressing room in the Booth Theater hangs a copy of a poem published by the Fund for Animals that reads, We need another and a wiser and perhaps more mystical concept of animals. We patronize them for their incompleteness, for their tragic fate of having taken forms far below ourselves and therein we err and greatly err. The verse is oddly appropriate, for Mr. Conway is currently appearing in The Elephant Man, Bernard Pomerance's affecting parable about a tragically deformed circus freak, rejected, rescued and ultimately destroyed by society.

title: On Life With His Wife, the Weight Lifter
description: I arrived home early the other day. The afternoon was muggy, and I stripped off my tie and steamy shirt in the hallway. Inside the apartment, I heard odd noises from the direction of the bedroom.

title: Teachers From Lower 48 States Teach Eskimo Children to Swim
description: HOOPER BAY, Alaska, Sept. 1 (AP) Eskimo children in this Bering Sea community do not travel to summer camp. Summer camp travels thousands of miles to them.

title: Inner Cities' Hospitals Vanishing In Wake of Sharply Rising Costs
description: ST. LOUIS  The elderly man, walking to the Homer G. Phillips Hospital to visit his sick wife, found 120 helmeted police officers standing around the institution.

title: A New Look at a Swedish Romantic
description: Is there any future for the music of Franz Berwald? About 20 years ago, the early stirrings of the Romantic revival led to a flurry of interest in the scores of this unusual mid19thcentury Swedish composer. Orchestras began playing his symphonies, the chamber music was investigated and a number of recordings appeared. But all the activity died down almost as soon as it started, and it looked as if Berwald was once again relegated to the obscurity from which he came.

title: DogShow Season Reaches Peak With 62d Westchester Event
description: The Eastern outdoor dogshow season reaches its peak next Sunday, when the 62d Westchester Kennel Club fixture takes place at Lyndhurst, the national landmark in Tarrytown. N.Y.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M. (Television  Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio  WINS, 2 P.M.)

title: GREAT BLUE HERON
description: Size: Stands about four feet tall, with a sixfoot wingspread.

title: Is the Anthony Dollar A ThreeDollar Bill?
description: WASHINGTON  I don't deal with women, the businessman snapped at Maria Hallam, who with her husband Keith was trying to buy a refrigeration unit for their new delicatessen in Burke. Va.

title: The Nation
description: On every postWatergate White House's lastthingweneed list are reports of illegality, or of attempts to cover them up  particularly if they involve people such as Robert L. Vesco, on the lam in the Caribbean since 1973, after being indicted for looting a multimilliondollar mutual fund and trying to quash a Federal investigation by secretly donating $200,000 to Richard M. Nixon's 1972 campaign.

title: U.S. POSTAL SERVICE EXPECTING A SURPLUS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1  The United States Postal Service, long mired in red ink and mounting operating deficits, expects to announce in a month the first revenue surplus since 1945, the Postmaster General says.

title: Claudia Yvonne Istel Wed to Grant Taylor
description: Claudia Yvonne Istel and Grant Lamson Taylor were married yesterday at the Norfield Mount Hermon School in Norfield, Mass. The bride's uncle, the Rev. Alvord Miner Beardslee, chairman of the department of philosophy and religion at Hollins College, performed the ceremony.

title: Berkeley G. Burrell Is Dead at 60; Head of a Black Business Group
description: Berkeley Graham Burrell, president of the National Business League, the major trade association of black businessmen throughout the United States, died Friday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington, D.C. He was 60 years old.

title: THE AMERICAN WAY OF TESTING
description: What today inhibits the writing of citizens, scholars and students? Americans, long vigorous and inventive in speech, object to the act of writing. Two out of three abilities ex

title: NEW TRIAL TO BEGIN OVER DRUG CHARGES
description: To Federal authorities, 42yearold John Grammatikos is a man who deserves to spend the rest of his life in jail.

title: The Squeeze: Prime Rate Up, Construction, Factory Orders Down
description: Like an athlete who finds that his playing field injuries have multiplied  first the knees, then the elbows and the back  the nation's economy was sounding a host of complaints from several sectors last week, from the credit markets to housing. Yet, much like an aging pass receiver who boasts that he still has a great pair of hands, the economy showed at least one source of vigor: the money supply.

title: Canada Is Seizing Fishing Boats In Dispute With U.S. Over Tuna
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 1 (AP)  Albacore tuna, the white, most expensive grade of tuna in supermarkets, are swimming in the midst of a fishing rights squabble between the United States and Canada.

title: A Young Man's Life In an Ancient Craft
description: UP in an old industrial building in the south end of Hartford is 31yearold Terry Harlow, one of a handful of Connecticut craftsmen who bind books by hand.

title: Schools: Hope Despite Problems
description: AS classes at most Long Island public schools begin this week, those directly responsible for education here  district administrators, principals, teachers and school board members  find themselves faced with what seem to be enormous difficulties.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY houses in this area have crawl spaces under part or all of the house or have part of the first floor of the house built out over an unheated garage, porch or crawl space. In any of these instances. the floor over this unheated area should be insulated to cut down on heat loss and to increase the comfort of any occupants of that room.

title: Drop by Drop
description: THE summer of 1989 came quietly to Orwell Beach on the Island's East End. If anything, it was noted for the end of all those tired environmentalists. The oil interests had won. Oil was now a way of life. It had seeped into our work and leisure lives. There was no turning back.

title: Rights and Prices Fight Stressed for Labor Day
description: Human rights and the need to fight inflation were themes in statements issued by the leaders of organized labor and President Carter for the Labor Day weekend.

title: Teaching: It Needs An Overhauling
description: IN THE movie Annie Hall, Woody Allen declares at one point: Those who can't do anything teach, and those who cannot teach teach physical education.

title: Lobbyists Lobbied
description: SEVERAL years ago, New Jersey enacted a law requiring lobbyists to register with the Attorney General's office, wear red identification tags when walking the State House corridors and file regular reports on those pieces of legislation that they were trying to influence.

title: Miss Partridge And a Student Plan Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Partridge of Princeton, N.J., and Wellfleet, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Tuan Partridge, to F. Douglas Raymond 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Jr. of Bryn Mawr and Pocono Pines, Pa.

title: Progress' Hurts in Westbury
description: LOUIS FIORILLO has plenty of time to chat with customers in his stationery store here on Post Avenue. Since last April.

title: Feldman Enjoying It as G.O.P. Rivals Debate
description: WHILE John V. N. Klein and Peter F. Cohalan are occupying center stage  or center ring  in Suffolk County, the Democratic candidate for County Executive, Martin J. Feldman, is quietly gearing up his generalelection campaign against the winner of the KleinCohalan Republican primary on Sent. 11.

title: Quigley's Summer Game
description: THE baseball fans at Quigley Stadium, where signs advertise sausage and pepper heroes for a dollar and frozen Charleston Chews for 35 cents, seemed oblivious to whether their team was crammed with future candybar celebrities.

title: Schools Opening Amid Many Challenges
description: WHEN schools open on Wednesday in Westchester, teachers and administrators in the county's 40 districts will find that they, too, face homework along with their more than 140,000 students

title: SecondOpinion Procedures for Surgery Criticized
description: A program designed to prevent unnecessary surgery in New York City's municipal hospitals is not working, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has charged, because doctors asked to give second opinions on whether elective surgery should be performed almost always say yes.

title: Montreal Mausoleum
description: MONTREAL  First Diane Giddings left. Then Jennifer Giddings. Now Philip Giddings is gone too. You can't blame them, says their mother, Judy, a French Canadian and lifelong Montrealer. Diane left when her hus band's employer, a huge real estate and investment company, moved its computer operations to Calgary. Jennifer went to Vancouver to avoid the frictions she felt when she chose to speak English in places like department stores. And Philip went to Toronto when a Montreal electronics company chose to hire an equally qualified applicant whose French was slightly better. The way I see it, says Mrs. Giddings, for everyone who leaves, that's one less vote against separation in the referendum.

title: Pearl Necklace Belmont Victor
description: Thirty years after bringing home his first winner, Willie Shoemaker showed up at Belmont Park yesterday in a familiar role: riding the favorite to victory in a rich stakes race.

title: Michael Krumholz to Marry Norene A. Ginsburg in May
description: Norene A. Ginsburg, a placement counselor with the National Center for Paralegal Training, educational consultants in New York, and Michael P. Krumholz, who is in his fourth year at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, plan to be married in May.

title: Appeals Court for Second Circuit Clears Its Calendar for Sixth Year
description: For the sixth year in a row, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has succeeded in clearing its calendar, according to a report released yesterday by Chief Judge Irving R. Kaufman.

title: Deborah Lester Is Betrothed To Stephen Gordon, Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Lester of Clifton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Jane Lester, to Stephen Louis Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Gordon of DeWitt, N.Y. The wedding is planned for next June.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Thomas Wheeler says that American students can't write. His observation comes as no surprise, but his conclusions about why this is so and what can be done about it may raise some hackles and start a few arguments. Mr. Wheeler teaches writing to SEEK (Search

title: Gasoline: A Full Tank Again
description: That knot in the nation's gasoline hose is finally loosening, and with the peak driving season ending, the crunch is clearly over  at least for now. Some states using the oddeven rationing system are finding it difficult to enforce, and are talking of abandoning it altogether.

title: Jane Butcher's Task
description: WHITE PLAINS WHICH agency has the final responsibility for commuter railroad service in Westchester  Conrail or its employer, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority?

title: Susan Colleen Dempsey, Newscaster, Bride
description: Susan Colleen Dempsey, a newscaster for WHN radio in New York, was married yesterday afternoon in Norfolk, Va., to Carlos Ernesto Loumiet, a lawyer with the New York law firm of Coudert Brothers. The ceremony was performed in the Fleet Catholic Chapel by Capt. John Laboon of the Navy Chaplains Corps.

title: Ellen Marie Chambault Wed To Charles John Schaefer
description: Ellen Marie Chambault, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Chambault of West Caldwell, N.J., was married there yesterday in St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church to Charles John Schaefer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles James Schaefer of Scranton, Pa. The Rev. Michael E. Kelly of Seton Hall University performed the ceremony.

title: Mexico Reports Increase In Oil and Gas Reserves
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1  President Jos Lpez Portillo today announced that Mexico's proven reserves of oil and natural gas now stand at the equivalent of 45.8 billion barrels, an increase of 12.5 percent during the past eight months.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: CANTON  Graphics, sculpture, oils and watercolors by member artists. Gallery on the Green, Wednesday through Sept. 23. Wednesday through Sunday, 1:30 to 4:30. Phone 6834102.

title: Salesman Portman
description: It was yet another blow aimed at Seventh Avenue, as if the growing competition from regional apparel marts in Chicago and Los Angeles, New Orleans and San Francisco hasn't been ignominy enough. And it was delivered by none other than John C. Portman. the flamboyant and futuristic architect/ developer, who marched on Manhattan last week to herald his latest venturethe $41.7 million Atlanta Apparel Mart. The 54yearold Atlanta native told guests a lavish midtown luncheon that the South has the potential to create the best apparel market in America.

title: The Lesson Of the Master
description: IT was the last daylight hour of a December afternoon more than twenty years ago  I was twentythree, writing and publishing my first short stories, and like many a Bildungsroman hero before me, already contemplating my own massive Bildungsroman when I arrived at his hideaway to meet the great man.

title: The Kurds Dig In; So Does Khomeini
description: Responding to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's demands for surrender and threats of execution as traitors, leaders of Iran's Kurdish rebels held fast last week, behind heavy weapons captured from the Iranian Army, in their fortress capital of Mehabad.

title: Torre Is Regrouping For Big Things in '80
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 1  Players and fans had trouble reaching the Astrodome tonight because of torrential rains shortly before the game between the Mets and the Astros. After the game, the Mets may have wished they had never arrived.

title: Peter Cleary, Lawyer, Weds Miss D'Arcy
description: Katherine Dawn D'Arcy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Martin D'Arcy of Palos Verdes, Calif., was married yesterday to Peter Dennis Cleary, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Leo Cleary of Calgary, Alberta. The Rev. F. Roderick Dail performed the ceremony in Christ Church United Methodist.

title: The Joy (and Sadness) of Receiving a Gift
description: HER gifts to me are usually practical things that she knows I need or has decided I should have: Jars of vita- mins, cans of pure maple syrup, books, magazines. All arrive smothered in shredded newspaper and cushioned on little foam pellets.

title: Woodlands at Stake in Nassau
description: LIKE players in a giant game of Monopoly, state, county and town officials here are devising strategy to buy up the waterworks. Their object is to purchase the property before its owner, the City of New York, can sell it at auction.

description: Sept. 8Tulsa

description: IT IS not surprising that education brings out the armchair quarterback. After all, almost everyone has spent 12 years being educated and can parlay this experience into an educational game plan at the drop of a school budget.

description: A United States citizen, Vitas Gerulaitis, recently lost a tennis match to a Polish citizen, Wojtek Fibak, and then marched off the court in a rage without congratulating or acknowledging Fibak's victory. After the match, Fibak was quoted as having said:

title: MUSIC
description: AS an an incurable optimist, I like to think that summers will never end, and the busy local music schedule is giving me renewed hope that this year I might be right for once, at least for a little while longer. Unlike the concert scene across the border in Westchester, which has dried up to virtual nonexistence, the September song  not to mention march, dance and symphony  happily vlays on in Connecticut.

title: Physician Assistants Seeking Recognition
description: MARYANN RAMOS is trained physician's assistant but, unlike most such professionals who live in New Jersey, she is working at her job in her home state  the only one that refuses to recognize such assistants as a bona fide occupation.

description: 8 P.M. (7) 240ROBERT. The premiere of a weekly, hourlong series dramatizing the exploits of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Emergency Service Detail.

Sladen's The HumbleBee, which appeared in 1912 in Great Britain, and O. E. Plath's Bumblebees and Their Ways, which was issued in the United States in 1934. It is a merit of this

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Sussex Hills Kennel Club allbreed and obedience, Automatic Switch Company grounds, Hanover Road, Florham Park, N.J.; 1,203 dogs; 9A.M.

title: Mondale Visit Last Week Underlined U.S. Interest
description: WASHINGTON  There is oil beneath the 900,000 square miles of the South China Sea, possibly a lot of oil. But nobody has the murkiest idea how large the reserves are or how much might eventually be recoverable, and the coastal countries lack resources and knowhow to get at offshore oil.

title: New Challengers Rise in N.F.L.
description: The most intriguing game on the National Football League's schedule of 14 weekend contests will be played today in the Kingdome at Seattle where the Seahawks take on the San Diego Chargers in one of a dozen seasonopening matches.

title: Carter Happy at Denial On Jordan Accusation
description: PLAINS, Ga., Sept. 1  President Carter said today that he was pleased by reports that a man known as Johnny C. had denied giving cocaine to Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, at Studio 54 in June last year, as has been alleged.

title: Peking Plans to Publish A New Edition of Bible
description: PEKING, Sep. 1 (UPI)  A Chineselanguage edition of the Bible will be published in China for the first time since the 1999 revolution, the pastor of China's only Protestant church has announced.

title: U.S. Agency Seeks Rise In Child CarSeat Safety
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1  In an effort to reduce the number of deaths among young children from injuries suffered in automobile crashes, the United States Department of Transportation will conduct a nationwide safety campaign throughout September to promote the use of safely constructed infant and child car seats.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: Police Issue Divides Rights Unit In Suffolk
description: ACCUSATIONS by blacks and Hispanic people that they have been beaten, harassed and subjected to ethnic slurs by some members of the Suffolk County Police Department have led to far more than a widening of whatever gulf may have existed between members of minority groups and the police.

title: In-the-Water Boat Shows Find Smooth Sailing
description: ICAN remember how it all started: Peter Carroll bouncing up one autumn morning in Annapolis and decreeing: Let there be inthewater boat shows! That was 1970, and such an outlandish muttering was laughed off as the gibberish of a madman or, worse, plain heresy to the ears of any normalthinking, moneyhungry nautical salesman.

title: Congress Faces Key Spending Decisions as Vacation Ends
description: Congress returns to Washington Wednesday after a monthlong vacation and faces a series of decisions on how to spend the taxpayers' money for the production of energy, the development of new weapons, the rescue of the Chrysler Corporation and dozens of other pressing issues.

title: Notes/
description: Among tour offerings being promoted as gassavers these days are overland treks from England to Asia by doubledecker London bus, thousandmile safaris by motorcycle through the canyon country of America's Southwest and sharearide car pools that operate nationwide out of Portland, Ore.

title: We're Not Making A Gimmick Movie
description: MONDAY: Greenwich Village. It is Nancy Walker's first day as a movie director, and on top of orchestrating the actors and the traffic, she's being heckled by a youth on the sidelines who yells, Stop this movie! It's demeaning to gays!

title: Collect Your Own Vegetable Seed
description: Along with everything else, seed has gone up in price. Since a big vegetable garden requires lots of seed, why not beat the high cost and collect your own?

title: Two From China Begin College Life
description: WHEN classes open Tuesday at Westchester Community College, the student body will include two young men from China who are believed to be among the first citizens of that country to come to the United States for study under private sponsorship.

title: MUSIC
description: AS an inveterate optimist, I like to think that summer will never end, but it looks like I may be wrong again this year. Subscription campaigns for the fall and winter concert seasons are already in high gear, and it's not at all too early for some judicious calendarmarking and bargainticket buying.

title: Tennis's Problems Increasing As It Encompasses the Masses
description: It was always thought of as a game for the classes, and the cozy summer meccas were Merton, Southampton, South Orange, Piping Rock, Longwood and, finally, Forest Hills. There were grass courts, icedtea specials on the veranda, blue blazers and Lacostes and pleasant evening socials.

title: Affirmative Case For Women's Bar
description: LAWYERS, like other professional and business people, tend to organize themselves according to their interests. Birds of a feather, as the proverb says. People who do not have much to do with lawyers  except perhaps when they buy or sell a house  may mostly think of lawyers' organizations as consisting of the American Bar Association and its state, county and local counterparts.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: THE envelope was there in my pile of mail, fairly throbbing with its manila message: There's a check in here. Open me quick.

description: IN retirement, Katharine S. White, the fiction editor of The New Yorker, wrote a series of critical essays for the magazine under the heading Onward and Upward in the Garden. Their reissue in

title: Jet Robinson Doubtful With Injured Thumb
description: The most destructive element thus far in the New York Jets' regular season, which begins today at Shea Stadium against the Cleveland Browns, is a door on Room 346 of the Holiday Inn in Westbury, L.I.

title: Student Is Fianc Of Eileen Burke
description: The engagement of Eileen P. Burke to Walter J. Black 2d has been announced by her mother, Jacqueline M. Burke of Port Washington and Shelter Island, L.I. Mr. Black is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore M. Black of Sands Point, L.I. Miss Burke is a daughter also of the late Charles W. Burke.

title: FOOD
description: THE aroma of freshly ground cinnamon bark and roasted filberts spices the air as glazed and chocolatecovered doughnuts glide by on a conveyer belt. Apple pies, chocolate chip cookies, butter pound cake and walnut Danish rings slide from lowslung ovens and head toward spiral cooling racks.

title: Sabotage Called Oil Pipeline Peril
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)  The General Accounting Office says that major United States oil pipelines are exposed to sabotage and that neither the Government nor the pipeline companies are doing much about it.

title: Heating Aid for Poor Likely to Fall Short
description: TRENTON PROJECTED Federal and state aid to help the poor and elderly pay heating bills this winter is expected to fall far short of the need, not only in New Jersey but also in other states in the Northeast.

title: Debra Dawn Sara Married To Michael Robert Coburn
description: Debra Dawn Sara, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Doyle Sara of Greenwich, Conn., and Michael Robert Coburn, son of Mrs. Donald Davis of Watertown, Mass., and Robert Coburn of Cambridge, were married yesterday. The Rev. Thomas P. Guinan performed the ceremony in St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Lady Mary Stewart, contemplating the magnolia tree and the fishpond in her garden, was feeling peckish for high tea when reached by telephone at her home outside Edinburgh. Both cats are asleep, and I've got a line of washing hanging out, she said. She is recuperating from the publication of her 16th novel, The Last Enchantment, the third and final volume in a richly imaginative life of Merlin and King Arthur's court set in fifthcentury Britain.

title: Susan Bitner Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lynn N. Bitner of Hilton Head Island, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Franklin Bitner, to Michael Ritner Weaver, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Ritner Weaver of Orange, Conn. The couple will be married Oct. 20 in Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in New York.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Sidney Sisk's characterization of the University of Connecticut campus at Storrs as a large, banal monster [Storrs Campus: Banal Isolation, Opinion Page, July 22], deserves an answer.

title: Catholic is Shot to Death in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 1 (UPI)  A Roman Catholic shopkeeper was shot to death today in what the police feared may be a renewed Protestant attack against Irish Republican terrorists.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Romancing the ladies. Run your eye down the massmarket paperback bestseller list any week, and you'll be struck by the prevailing theme in the descriptions of books: A woman's search for  An immigrant woman's rise  A woman takes on Elizabeth I  Spoiled rich girl A woman's rough road to  Little wonder that market surveys indicate that 60 percent of all paperbacks are bought by women.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Reading Roy Bongartz's article on Mount Katandin, The Best Climbing Hike in New England (Travel Section, Aug. 12), I cringed to think of the increasing popularity it would bring to the first point in the continental United States that the sun shines upon each day.

title: Five Poets
description: HAT might a radical feminist think now that Erica Jong has declared a truce in the battle of the sexes? Because I believed in them,/ I found gentle men./ Because I loved myself,/ I was loved. What might a contemporary theologian say about the notion that God is dog spelled backward? But God is all too human./ Somehow we have spelled his

title: Long Island/This Week
description: CEDARHURST  Group exhibition; 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. daily, except Mondays; through Sept. 27; Gallery Carron, 586 Central Ave.

title: A Visit With Philip Roth
description: FAR from the Newark of Nathan Zuckerman, Alexander Portnoy and Neil Klugman, their creator dwells in the rural splendor of a secluded Connecticut estate, the sort one reads about in a Cheever story. Its resident, however, would be more likely to show up in one of his own novels. Tall, energetic, alert, he wears the standard uniform of summer camps on the New Jersey shore  shorts, a Tshirt and sandals  and rejects any suggestion of a resemblance between Saul Bellow and the novelist Felix Abravanel, a minor character in The Ghost Writer, by noting that the physical description applies to himself: The rug dealer's thinning dark hair, the guarded appraising black eyes, and a tropical bird's curving bill.

title: Owl and Pussycat Staged in a Diner
description: ISLIP TERRACE DINNER theater has proven successful attempt to despecialtze theater as a form and deformalize the ritual of attending it. The producerdirector David Babcock is serving plays in a diner  yet another step in bringing theater to the table.

description: Tomorrow  New England Region Sports Car Club of America racing; at Lime Rock (Conn.) Park, Route 7 near Junction with Route 112. Gates open 7:30 A.M.; threehour endurance race for stock showroom sedans at 9; seven S.C.C.A. national races starting 12:30 P.M. Information: (203) 4352572,

title: Mac Rand, Flight Instructor, Will Marry Amy E. Haidinger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Haidinger of Riverside, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Amy Eileen Haidinger, to Walter McNeill Rand, son of Mrs. Stanley Rand Jr., also of Riverside, and the late Mr. Rand.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Open's Closed Places
description: The Great Hall reads the sign over the main entrance to the Louis Armstrong Stadium at the United States Open tennis championships in Flushing Meadows, Queens. However, few of the thousands of fans who daily pass through these portals realize just how great a hall it is. Hidden in almost every niche and cranny here is the Open's biggest secret: the human machinery that makes the world's richest tournament run.

title: POLITICS
description: AS a clerk in the Sharon Town Hall describes it, James L. Buckley just walked in on Aug. 20 and registered as voter like an ordinary, everyday citizen.

title: Cosmos' Bowl Bid Ends in Shootout Against Vancouver
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. Sept. 1  It took 3 hours 34 minutes of soccer at Giants Stadium today before the Cosmos finally expired, ending their twoyear reign as champions of the North American Soccer League.

title: Lessons of Fastnet Race: Preparation, Respect
description: THERE are many ways to kill yourself in the name of sport. Motor racing, mountain climbing and sky diving have traditionally been the highrisk sports, with hang gliding a dangerous newcomer.

title: TV MAILBAG
description: The article Yes, Sesame Street Has Its Detractors, by Edith Spiegel [Aug. 5], reports that I was recently visited by experts from Israel and India who informed me of negative effects on children in their countries as a result of watching Sesame Street. I don't know how this would be possible because the program is not broadcast in either country.

title: Summer, Adieu, Adieu
description: The Clambake at Brenton's Beach is a yearly event, a tradition that has been going on since long before my parents even met each other. It is always held on the Saturday of Labor Day weekend  the end of summer in a New England resort town. Many years ago it was organized on a smaller scale, for maybe a hundred people, but now it's a huge party of more like five hundred, probably because all of those oldtimers grew up and had children and grandchildren, who now enlarge the crowd so that bigger and bigger tents have to be put up. The Clambake is for all ages, of course; my grandparents used to go with us before they died, and my sister's two little boys go now. I started to attend as soon as I was old enough to eat the corn on the cob.

title: Black Museum Seeks a Home
description: NEW EGYPT LATE in July, New Jersey's only black museum  the Museum for the Education and Research on the American Black in the Arts, Sciences and History  was forced to close its headquarters here because it could not pay its rent.

title: Wendy Beth Heilberg Engaged
description: Wendy Beth Heilberg and Steven Joseph Denholtz plan to be married in the fall of next year. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Heilberg of North Woodmere, L.I. Mr. Denholtz is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack W. Denholtz of Livingston, N.J. The couple are graduates of Northwestern University.

title: Shelley Anderson Sagar Is Wed
description: Shelley Anderson Sagar, daughter of Mrs. Lindsay Anderson Sagar of New Vernon, N.J., and Naples, Fla., and Charles Parker Sagar of St. Thomas, V.I., was married yesterday to Jeffrey

title: For Steam Train Fans
description: It may seem a bit early to announce a Thanksgiving train ride but when one is dealing with steam train fans, considerable advance planning is necessary. That is why the Steamtown Foundation in Bellows Falls, Vt.. has released plans for a 100mile excursion well ahead of time. The trip, aboard a 12car train pulled by two Pacific steam locomotives from the Steamtown collection, will take place on Nov. 24 and wind through the Green Mountains from Bellows Falls to Rutland, Vt., and back. Departure is scheduled for 9:30 A.M. and the fare is expected to be approximately $30 a person. A turnout of about 800 passengers is anticipated, according to Bob Barbera, Steamtown's director.

title: Panel Narrows Focus Of Study on Payments To Radiation Victims
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1  A highlevel study group established by President Carter to find ways to deal with radiation compensation claims will not make any recommendations, as requested by the President, but will simply list the options open to him, according to the minutes of one of its early meetings

title: Stakes Are High in the Sagebrush Rebellion
description: Uncle Sam owns and manages onethird of the nation's terrain  more than 750 million acres. The attendant headaches are of commensurate size and persistence. Dissatisfaction on the part of one segment of the public or another with this stewardship is chronic, and lately there has been an upsurge.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: HAROLD C. SCHONBERG

title: Thomas Wethered Weds Miss Ruane
description: Colleen Ruane, daughter of Thomas Ruane of Halifax, Yorkshire, England, and the late Dr. Emily Ruane, was married yesterday in England to Thomas Wethered, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Wethered of Bedford, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at the Old Palace (Convent of the Holy Child), Mayfield, Sussex, by the Rev. A.J. Baxter, headmaster of Ratcliffe College, Leicester, England.

title: Pickles by the Barrel
description: MOST people who like pickles consider themselves to be mavens, but Arlene Weisburd is something of a maven's maven. She is constantly in search of the best pickles for her store, Pickle Packin Mama in Wantagh.

title: U.S. Swimmers Win Five Golds at Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Sept. 1 (AP)  United States swimmers captured five of the 10 gold medals at stake on the opening day of the first International Swimming Federation (FINA) World Cup meet today.

title: William J. Narvell, Betty Jeanne Katen Wed at Princeton
description: Betty Jeanne Katen and William John Narvell, graduates of Princeton University, were married there yesterday. The Rev. Wallace M. Alston Jr., a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the university's chapel. The Rev. Timothy Cogan, the Episcopal chaplain at Princeton, assisted.

title: Torture Case Raises Alien Rights Issue
description: DOUGLAS, Ariz., Aug. 26  On an August morning three years ago, Manuel Garca, Bemab Herrera and Eleazar Ruelas walked into a grocery store in the Mexican border town of Agua Prieta and filled their pockets and knapsacks with bread, bologna, cheese, bananas and water. The three men, all in their 20's, wore heavy trousers and stout walking shoes, and to anyone who saw them it must have been clear that they were preparing for the trek across the border in serch of work.

title: 2 Utilities Suing Standard Oil Co. Over Deliveries of LowSulfur Oil
description: Consolidated Edison and the Long Island Lighting Company have filed suits totaling $137 million against the Standard Oil Company Of California, charging that it had reneged on a promise to furnish lowsulfur oil to a supplier.

title: State to Winnow Highway Program
description: DESPITE the opening last month of a ninemile section of Interstate 195 in Ocean and Monmouth Counties, more than 100 miles of Interstate roadway in New Jersey remain unbuilt because of the objections of people who live in areas through which the roads must pass.

title: LETTER TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: In Yiddish Lebt Takeh (Lives Indeed) in Westchester [Aug. 5], the writer, Gloria Dones Sosin, mentioned some of the Westchester agencies that have been active with and involved in programs relating to the Yiddish language, folklore, culture, etc.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Ann Ida Lemelson Planning Wedding to H. Mark Denson
description: Ann Ida Lemelson and H. Mark Denson, who graduated this year from the University of Rochester, plan to be married.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Fishing Rewards Man and Boy
description: WEST TISBURY, Mass.,  When you take a boy fishing, you also bring along the lad you once were, and if you are in familiar haunts you often catch as many memories as fish.

title: DINING OUT
description: IN a state stacked with Italian restaurants, it is a pleasure to find one a cut above most of the rest, and Casella's, in the southwest corner of Hoboken, is certainly one of them. It is not in the area of restored brownstones, nor is it in what might be considered the best section of that city, but it is still a restaurant that should be visited.

title: Hot Hops: Foreign Beers
description: Tooths KB, Brahma Chopp, 33, Modelo, Cinci, Hacker Pschorr, Hurlimann, Niksicko, Sagres, MacEwan's, Zywiec*: They're all beers, imported beers, and if some of them haven't shown up yet in the corner deli alongside the Heineken, Beck's and other betterknown imports, chances are they may soon.

title: British Polaris Missile Explodes
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 1 (UPI)  A British Polaris missile fired from a land pad at 12:16 A.M. today failed in flight and exploded into chunks of debris minutes after launching. It was not immediately known whether the missile exploded itself or whether it was destroyed by a signal sent by the Air Force Eastern Test Range safety officer at Cape Canaveral.

title: Swinging Convention Enlivens Princeton
description: PRINCETON THE Association for Humanistic Psychology held its 17th annual meeting here last week, a weeklong session that ranged from workshops on eliminating sex roles to lectures on the prospects for the 1980's.

title: MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: 171 Shot Wins at Du Quoin
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 1  Legend Hanover upset the oddson Chiola Hanover in two straight heats today and won the 54th Hambletonian Trot.

title: Suspended Executive Seeks Casino Job
description: AMONG the thousands of men and women who have applied to the state for a license to work for a hotelgambling casino here is Seymour Alter. He should have an answer to his request before the end of the year.

title: How Blacks Can Build Political Influence
description: This article was prepared by Dr. Canute Parris, president of the Central Long Island branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and by members of the Frederick Douglass Collective, a socialchange group in Wyandanch.

title: Libya Marks Coup Anniversary With Attacks on Egypt and U.S
description: BENGHAZI, Libya, Sept. 1  President Muammar elQaddafi of Libya said today on the 10th anniversary of the coup that brought him to power that only unity among Arabs could help them overcome the treachery of Egypt's peace treaty with Israel.

title: Battle Over Toll Bridge Widens
description: A NEW campaign has been started to strip the drawbridge that links the Village of Lawrence and the beachfront community of Atlantic Beach of its exclusive status: It is the only bridge in

title: Miss Maxwell To Be Bride Of D.L. Morris
description: Jennifer Anne Maxwell and Dwight Leslie Morris plan to be married on Oct. 7 in Los Angeles. The future bride's parents, Doris Schine Maxwell of Wellesley Hills. Mass., and Dr. Morton Harrison Maxwell of Los Angeles have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Prof. and Mrs. Herbert A. Morris of Peoria, Ill., where his father is chairman of the computerscience department of Bradley University.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: TOKYO  The dire moment is unlikely to arrive, at least in the forseeable future. Nor would any Japanese welcome seeing the assumption verified soon. But the question is asked anyway: Is dignified surrender recommendable for Japan  if the Soviet Union invades this country?

title: Schools Aide Told to Return His Children to School
description: PORT BYRON, N.Y., Sept. 1 Thomas Hempel, a dairy farmer who until recently was president of the Board of Education in this central New York State village, was ordered yesterday to send his three children back to accredited schools. For the last year, Mr. Hempel had taught them at home.

title: Yankees Beaten, 98; Ken Clay Is Berated
description: Ken Clay, a young pitcher who has lurked on the fringe of the Yankee pitching staff the last three seasons, determined his future with the Yankees yesterday: he has none.

title: The World
description: The recognition that Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization resolutely deny each other at negotiating forums, they accord each other almost daily on the battleground they have made of southern Lebanon. The fighting has intensified in the past month, and the United States, unable to find a way around the negotiating stalemate, last week addressed the bloodier side of the coin. In the United Nations Security Council, outgoing Ambassador Andrew Young urged an end to the deadlock of terror and counterterror which has killed hundreds of civilian Lebanese and turned thousands more into refugees.

title: ANTIQUES
description: James Abbe Jr. began acquiring American folkart portraits, weathervanes, decoys and such more than 40 years ago. At that time no one had vet found an appropriate name for this 19thcentury material, and only artists, photographers and a few art collectors gave it a second glance.

title: Cosmos End Season On CliffHanger Note
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 1  To the New York Cosmos, a season ended today in Giants Stadium, not an era in the history of a team that signed a dazzling array of international stars en route to two consecutive championships.

title: SALT and Energy Head the Agenda as Congress Returns
description: PLAINS, Ga.  Dear President Carter, The Tampa Tribune said in an open letter splashed across its front page last week. Many Tampa Bay area residents respect you as a man, but doubt your abilities as President.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: In the current debate over President Carter's plan to phase out price controls on crude oil and impose a windfall profits tax, a key political and economic consideration is the impact decontrol will have on retail prices of refined products such as gasoline and heating oil. Conventional calculations estimate decontrol will mean price increases for gasoline of 5 cents a gallon or more. This policy change is viewed as necessary in order to increase conservation of energy by allowing United States energy prices to rise to the world level. But the consequent increase in oil company revenues, estimated to be about $10 billion per year, is considered a windfall, the President proposing to tax 50 percent of these revenues not profits  away.

title: Once Famed Hotel Closes in Unsentimental Dallas
description: DALLAS, Sept. 1  When President Theodore Roosevelt visited Dallas in 1905, he stayed at the 12yearold Oriental Hotel, a dusty Moorish fantasy capped by a squat arabesque dome that was billed as the finest hotel in the South.

title: Bank Robbed 2d Time as Holdups in City Continue
description: One bank was broken into yesterday and another robbed for the second time in three days as the police continued trying to break a recordsetting streak of bank holdups.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: TEN Suffolk County women have devised a new plan to . fight inflation. They have formed a couponexchange group, the Price Fighters, and once a month they gather in a member's home to trade coupons and ideas.

title: The Region
description: In the first two weeks of August, 461 psychologically disturbed people, many of them systematically released from mental institutions, required police attention. Some wielded knives, scissors, axes, bayonets, icepicks and guns. Most, according to Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire, were subdued without injury to themselves or others. Two cases, however, resulted in death.

title: The Sky(light)'s the Limit
description: Astainedglass skylight in Woodrow Wilson Hall at Monmouth College, believed to be the only one of its kind in the world, has been the object of a delicate

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: SLAYING IN TORONTO INCREASES TENSIONS
description: TORONTO, Sept. 1 Toronto's police force found itself under attack and its relations with the city's growing ethnic groups strained this week following the slaying of a black by a notice officer.

title: Engagement 5022
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bloom of Oceanside N.Y. happily announce the engagement of their daughter, Cindy Fran, to Gary Keith Baumann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Baumann, also of Oceanside.

title: THAT FATEFUL WEEK
description: Forty years ago, as the storm clouds of war were rolling across Europe, a young American reporter in London found the days sunny, the people outwardly unruffled, the city serene and complacent. Text begins on Page 20.That last week before the war had a dreamlike quality. The barrage balloons rode in the skies above London and antiaircraft gun emplacements appeared in the parks. But the grass was never greener, the music never sweeter. The confident, even tenor of life went on, so outwardly undisturbed at first that in those warm, sunny days it was hard to envisage the fury of the storm about to break and sweep away the comfortable, complacent world of England between the wars.

title: A Season Begins Without Woody Hayes
description: EARLE BRUCE was in front of a television set, as any good Ohio State alumnus would have been, on that Friday night late last December when Woody Hayes went too far. Bruce was in Miami that week and he would

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: Celebrity Softball  TagSale Gas Saving

title: DINING OUT
description: JAPAN has often been called the land of the chrysanthemum and the sword, a dichotomy that suggests devotion to natural beauty and an equally determined commitment to the noble values of the samurai. Although Americans are familiar with the knifewielding intensity of the Japanese chef at the stainlesssteel grill, the tempan, we rarely notice the chrysanthemum side. The esthetic aspect of authentic, traditional cuisine differs significantly from the slicedsteakandshrimp style that has become so popular in this country.

title: On the Wooing of an Island That Won't Be Won
description: I first saw Crete from the deck of a freighter. The coastline was enshrouded by a late summer haze that gave the lie to the fabled clarity of Greek air. Occasional glimpses of what lay beyond the shore suggested that Crete was mountainous, wooded and, except for a fishing village or two, unpopulated.

title: Oldest League Of Nations, the Iroquois, Torn By Modernism
description: SYRACUSE  The first spokesman for armed Mohawk Indians who confronted the State Police at the St. Regis Reservation in northern New York last week was not a Mohawk. He was Lee Lyons, an Onondaga.

title: THEATHER
description: HALF of my first column for this newspaper was devoted to an interview with Gay Goldman of the Westchester Regional Theater, then in the middle of its second season. The Feb. 13, 1977, interview ended with a quote from the theater's statement of income and expense: If all goes according to predictions the company will end its second season of struggle with a profit of $13.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: The Young America is the largest Americanbuilt squarerigger afloat, and to help the Long Island Nautical Heritage Foundation celebrate  you guessed it  Long Island's nautical heritage, the ship will cruise local waters this fall. Starting today at Montauk (through Sept. 12), the Young America will pull into ports where visitors can go on board and also enjoy the dockside entertainment being planned.

title: Flights in Eye Give Best Data On Hurricanes
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 1  Despite the wizardry of satellite photographs, radar monitoring and computer analysis, it is still human beings in aging airplanes who provide the most accurate and sensitive data on the path, force and speed of advancing storms.

title: A Chilean Omnibus: Santiago to the South
description: It was October and spring had come to Santiago, bringing brilliant blooms of red and purple. The warming of the air made me more restless every day.

title: Patricia McDonnell Is Married
description: Patricia McDonnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Murray McDonnell of Peapack, N.J., was married there yesterday to Simon Pearce of Bennettsbridge, County Kilkenny, Ireland. The ceremony was performed in St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Vincent Dwyer, director of the Center for Human Development at the University of Notre Dame.

title: Notes: A Pianist Finds His True Career
description: There will be the usual horde of pianists parading across New York's concert stages this season, and the earliest is Russell Sherman, who will give a recital in Alice Tully Hall on Friday night. He has been called late bloomer, because recent recordings and appearances here after a long absence have earned him a reputation as a remarkable virtuoso and fascinating interpreter. But it has perhaps been forgotten that he was an early bloomer, too. The New Yorkborn artist made his debut in Town Hall in 1995 when he was only 15. He gave a second recital two years later, and he was only 19 when he was graduated from Columbia University. In the years that immediately followed, he developed a reputation as performer of contemporary music.

title: INVESTING
description: Bank stocks, which had lagged behind the market early this year, have rebounded over the oast several weeks.

title: How to Be Threadbare and Happy
description: MY mother and father are coming; an annual visit. I'm getting the house ready. So far, I've replaced the shelf paper on the three shelves I missed last year, picked the crumbs out of the silverware drawer, cleaned the oven three times, wiped under Mr. Coffee and the toaster, alphabetized the spices, arranged the canned goods frontally, with titles showing, grocerystore style. Each cupboard looks like a collage now. I've put the lemon oil with the silver polish, the bug killer with the ant bane, the tonic with the booze. All the hampers in the house are empty; so are the wastebaskets. The magazines on the coffee table date only from this year, and most no further back than April. And now, I'm looking at the couch... .

title: Iran Reports Broad New Offensive To Put Down Kurdish Insurrection
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 1  The Iranian Deputy Prime Minister directing military operations in Kurdistan said today that air and ground forces had gone into action to crush the rebellion by Kurdish tribesmen.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Time off for the threeday weekend if the drought ravagedlawn has been fed, patch seeded or sodded.

title: For Children, a Few Nuggets Amid the Cartoons
description: Amid all the ballyhoo over the new primetime schedules, little attention has been paid to the television fare being offered in one of the more controversial, not to mention lucrative, time periods for the commercial networks: Saturday morning. This is the time period that accounts for the highest concentration of programming aimed at children under 12. Indeed, of the 32 million American children from 2 to 11 who live with television sets, at some point during any Saturday morning at least 25 million of them are tuned to the three commercial networks. And, despite claims about the low advertising revenues derived from Saturday morning programming (the networks refuse to disclose precise figures), last year toy, cereal and candy manufacturers  the biggest buyers of advertising minutes surrounding programs aimed at children  spent $94 million at the networks for weekend daytime commercials. Yet, the content and style of the programming offered on Saturday mornings by the commercial networks continues to be the object of often stinging criticism from parents, educators, child psychologists and government officials.

title: CRIME
description: A deathbed communication starts things off in THE 65TH TAPE, by Frank Ross (Atheneum, $10.95), and from that point, tension and suspense build up. Mr. Ross has everything at his command: espionage, doubledealing, politics, our old friend the rich and reclusive supercriminal, a threat to American democracy, the radical right. And, to cap things off, there is even Richard Nixon and not necessarily in a badguy role, though it is clear what the author thinks about him.

title: Miller Faces New Challenges in Mine Union
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1  Fifty years ago, in a West Virginia hollow called Cabin Creek, Arnold R. Miller recalls, he had to cross the creek 29 times to reach the bottom land at the Kanawha River.

title: Cosmos Are Eliminated
description: The Cosmos, North American Soccer League champions for the last two years, were eliminated in the playoffs by the Vancouver Whitecaps. Section 5.

title: Atlantic City's Clerics Say Casinos Hurt Churches
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 31  Casino gambling has done wonders in the service of mammon in the center of Atlantic City, but it has brought a sharp decline in membership and attendance at churches of all denominations here.

title: The Airlines Come Down From the Clouds Again
description: Deregulation, or at least the beginning of it, won out and with it arrived the predicted period of euphoria. Fares were cut. Passenger traffic increased. Merger activity heated up  and profits at many lines took off. Now, however, with the Labor Day finale to the year's peak travel season, the airlines stand at the edge of the turbulence the naysayers foresaw. But the gathering clouds can't totally be laid to the strains of deregulation. Along the way an economic slowdown emerged. The price of fuel jumped, and passenger skittishness over the DC10 after its crash in Chicago still plagues the airlines that fly it.

title: CAMERA
description: For many years photographers who wanted to do available light photography with color negative films had to depend on very fast lenses or long expo

title: A Correction
description: An article in last Sunday's Week in Review, discussing technical assistance for underdeveloped nations, stated that a Carter Administration proposal that would have created a Federal Institute for Scientific and Technological Cooperation had stalled in Congress. In fact a bill authorizing the institute has, after a series of setbacks, been passed while an appropriations measure calling for funding of about $23 million has been drafted.

title: STAMPS
description: The 100th anniversary of the death of Sir Rowland Hill, the Briton who introduced the world's first adhesive postage stamp, the Penny Black, combined with the International Year of the Child, has served to make 1979 the year

title: Marriage Announcement 2 -- No Title
description: Lucy Boswell Is Affianced

title: At NBC, Another Finger in the Dike
description: Fred Silverman's mandate when he took over the presidency of the National Broadcasting Company last year was to shore up the entertainment side of the network. As he struggled with that monumental task the troubled network sprang another leak: its nightly newscast began to lose precious ground to archrival ABC News. Last week, NBC moved to put yet another finger in the dike. It hired William J. Small away from CBS Inc. and in effect gave him the same kind of challenge that Mr. Silverman took on.

title: SIOUX CHIEFS URGED TO REJECT U.S. OFFER
description: PIERRE, S.D., Sept. 1 (AP)  Sioux tribal leaders, meeting to discuss a proposed $105 million Federal settlement for the Black Hills, heard the Indian activist Russell Means and others contend that the settlement should be rejected in voting this fall.

title: Yanks Take Aim at Next Year
description: Joseph Durso

title: White Plains: The Decision
description: MINUTES after the Board of Legislators voted to approve a countywide solidwaste disposal facility last week, County Executive Alfred B. DelBello was asked whether the reason White Plains had missed being included in the resolution was because of something personal between himself and Mayor Alfred Del Vecchio of White Plains.

title: Cook Triumphs in U.S. Amateur Semifinal
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 1  John Cook, the defending champion, will have a chance tomorrow to repeat his 1978 victory when he meets Mark O'Meara in the final of the 79th United States Amateur at the Canterbury Golf Club.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Jesus Christ Superstar, by Tim Rice and Andrew Lloyd Weber, starring Main Van Achte. Tonight at 8 P.M. $5.50. Discount available for students, the elderly and groups. Reservations. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, junction of Routes 6 and 118. 6281169.

title: State Mental Official Opposes a Police Plan To Handle Disturbed
description: The State Commissioner of Mental Health said yesterday that he was seeking a meeting with New York City's Police Commissioner, Robert J. McGuire, to discuss two recent fatal shootings of apparently mentally disturbed people by police officers and orders for the handling of such people that Mr. McGuire issued after the first shooting.

title: GARDENING
