description: PERHAPS the greatest luxury to be afforded a gardener is that of acquiring land that has natural character and beauty.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: THE envelope was there in my pile of mail, fairly throbbing with its manila message: There's a check in here. Open me quick

title: BOOK ENDS
description: At last count, James Baldwin had 18 books to his name novels, short stories, essays, plays. Later this month, the Harlemborn writer, grandson of a slave, will have his new novel.

title: Bronx Man Shot Dead in Dispute At Entrance to a Subway Station
description: A 22yearold man was shot to death early yesterday in a dispute with two assailants on the steps leading to a subway station in the Bronx, the transit police said.

title: World's First Surgery to Replace Vertebrae Is Termed Successful
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 1 (AP)  After more than 19 hours of surgery, 33yearold Jessie Thomas today became the first person known to have her spine replaced by a metal prosthesis, and doctors said they were optimistic about her chances for recovery.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: According to the latest reports, next spring, when the Paris Opera Ballet pays its first visit to New York since 1948, the venerable French company will probably feature Rudolf Nureyev as guest star in an adaptation of The Phantom of the Opera by Roland Petit and in a new work of his own based upon Byron's Manfred.

title: Board Criticized
description: THE agency charged with supervising dentistry in New Jersey, the state's Board of Dentistry, could stand some supervision itself, say critics in and out of state government.

title: Maryann Carley Married to John Campbell Arensmeyer
description: Maryann Carley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Carley of Kensington, Md., was married yesterday to John Campbell Arensmeyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Arensmeyer of Princeton, N.J.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING Apartment Owners Wary of Winter
description: WEST ORANGE TUCKED away on a quiet street in this Essex County community is a 10yearold, 36unit, gardenapartment complex called the Carriage House. Rents total about $130,000 a year, the project has never been refinanced and, according to Rosemarie BuckleyKohn, who manages the complex for its four owners (including her husband, George), its profit picture is borderline.

title: The Biggest Little Dog Show in the East
description: THE Westchester Kennel Club, one of the smallest clubs in the United States, annually stages one of America's biggest dog shows, and next Sunday it will hold its 62d fixture at Lyndhurst, the national landmark on Route 9, just south of the Tappan Zee Bridge in Tarrytown.

title: College Football Preview: U.S.C. and Alabama Favored
description: One or two of the 139 majorcollege football teams will be elected as a national champion by the wireservice polls this season and, apparently, for years to come because the majority of Division IA institutions do not approve of a championship playoff.

title: Columbus and Dayton School Rulings Have Not Had Expected Results
description: LOS ANGELES  When the United States Supreme Court upheld crosstown busing to integrate the public schools of Columbus and Dayton, Ohio, civil rights leaders in Los Angeles called the decision a milestone and said it would help quell mounting opposition to busing. They were wrong. Last week, the Los Angeles Board of Education, which for more than 15 years has been fighting a lawsuit charging that it has unlawfully sanctioned racial segregation, voted to seek authority to all but abolish courtordered mandatory busing that began only a year ago.

title: Touring the Old Cherry Valley Pike
description: There is a stillness now. The summer people have gone. Labor Day is about here, and in its wake comes the harvest  vegetables and fruits in orange, red, green, purple, yellow and gold stacked in the shadows of weathertextured barns. Soon, on the wooded hills and down among the valleys, the maples, elms and oaks will spread a carpet of color. The cornfields that were green and gold in high summer will become a melancholy brown stubble.

title: Study of Congress Votes Sees Conservative Gain
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)  The American Conservative Union today offered an analysis of voting records in the House and Senate that showed, it said, that Congress was growing more conservative.

title: Susan R. Friedman Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Susan Renee Friedman to Gerald Allen Feuer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Feuer of Brooklyn, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Friedman of Great Neck, L.I. The wedding is planned for December.

title: New Peril to Clams
description: BLUE crabs, prized as seafood all along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, have returned to the Great South Bay this summer in such numbers that scientists and baymen fear they may do serious damage to the Island's $100 million clamming industry.

title: What's Doing in MUNICH
description: THE CITY  Munich is special. Unlike other big cities of West Germany and it is the third largest, after West Berlin and Hamburg  it does not beat you over the head with its efficiency or ignore you with its wealth and success. It is a relatively soft place, a happy city where the sun shines more than almost anywhere else in the country; its broad avenues, baroque architecture and rolling Bavarian accents provide a pleasant backdrop for whatever you are doing. Its citizens, about 1.3 million, think of themselves as Southerners as, by German reckoning, they are. This means a certain amount of extra care in the art of human contact, and more time for it.

title: Rangers Near Choice on Rink
description: THE iceskating arena at Playland Amusement Park in Rye is expected to echo before long with the sound of New York Rangers hockey sticks as the team practices for another go at the Stanley Cup finals. The park will become the new training camp and regularseason practice site for the Rangers, if an agreement can be reached between the Playland Commission and the National Hockey League club,

title: Texan in the Rhodesian Army Says He Fights for Love, Not Money
description: MAGUNGE, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Aug. 30  When Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa stepped off a helicopter here this morning to be briefed on guerrilla activity in this remote northern tribal area, the first person to greet him was Joseph Columbus Smith. of San Antonio, Tex.

title: Miss Paine Is Married
description: Katharine Delahaye Paine, daughter of Mrs. George Keys Thompson of New York and Ralph Delahaye Paine Jr. of Barton, Vt., was married yesterday in Durham, N.H., to Douglas Robertson Chapin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace A. Chapin of Durham.

title: W. Germany Still Leads
description: BONN  A new version of the postwar German phoenix seems about ready to rise, this time on the wings of the oil crisis.

title: Sandra O'Donnell Wed To George Roosevelt 3d
description: Sandra Lee O'Donnell, daughter of Mrs. Gerald Smith of Brodheadsville, Pa., was married yesterday to George E. Roosevelt 3d, son of Mrs. Eric Ridder of Locust Valley, L.I., and Julian K. Roosevelt of Centre Island, Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: Election Could Be Affected
description: NEW DELHI  That the intricacies of caste relationships will play a significant, perhaps determining, role in the forthcoming Indian elections is hardly surprising. After all, caste still shapes most human behavior in India, setting the rules of courtship, diet, housing and employment.

title: Tito and Castro Are at the Center of the Latest Dispute
description: HAVANA  When Yugoslavia's Tito, India's Nehru, Egypt's Nasser and Indonesia's Sukarno launched their nonaligned movement in Belgrade in 1961, the winds of change that were liquidating empires were gathering momentum. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, who preached that neutrality in the Cold War was immoral, had been lining up defense pacts around the world.

title: Virginia Emery, Nurse, Fiance of R.S. S. Downey
description: Virginia Emery, a nurse at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, and Richard Stuart Downey, a Columbia College alumnus in his fourth year at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, plan to be married in May in Grace Episcopal Church.

title: East End Tourism Survives Gas Slump
description: THE East End's $600millionayear tourist industry fared well this summer despite predictions at the beginning of the season of a severe gasoline shortage that would have a serious impact on tourism.

title: THE LITERARY CONSPIRACIES OF RICHARD CONDON
description: Considering who lives there, Rossenarra House in Kilmoganny, Ireland, ought to be a Gothic pile, bidden behind lichenencrusted granite walls, shaded by dripping, funereal cypresses  a sinister place to be avoided, especially on nights when the mist sweeps in from the sea and hides the moon and the stars. The master of Rossenarra is Richard Condon, novelist, literary vaudevillian, weaver of spells, conjurer of darkly garish visions of the United States  and the rest of the world, for that matterin the grip of unfathomable conspiracies, drived by insensate greed for money and power, its leaders haunted by perversion, madness and violent death.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: In Larry Fink's photographs, on view at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, through Oct. 30, freaks and decadence flourish everywhere, from New York discotheques and society parties to smalltown farming communities. Indeed, decadence seems as commonplace in small towns as in the cities.

title: Rebecca Lynn Westover Fiance of Bank Officer
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Charles Barry Westover of Erie, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca Lynn Westover, to James Joseph McAndrews Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McAndrews of Madison, Conn.

title: Anthony $1 Coin Flops In a Test in Hometown
description: ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 1 (AP)  Even though this is her home town, Susan B. Anthony Dollar Days, a Chamber of Commerce promotion, did little to increase interest in the new dollar coin that bears the likeness of the 19thcentury feminist.

title: LONG ISLAND HOUSING
description: APARTMENTS in Nassau County are in as short supply as apartments in Manhattan. Some owners and brokers, in fact, say that the situation in Nassau is even worse than in the city.

title: Sally Anne Bruyette Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leo T. Bruyette Jr. of Windsor, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally Anne Bruyette, a Chicagobased flight attendant for American Airlines, to Peter S.P. Gimber, an account executive for Group W Productions in Evanston, Ill., a division of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company. Mr. Gimber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Gimber of Montclair, N.J., and his fiance, whose father is a dentist, plan to be married Oct. 6 in St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church in Windsor.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Terri Lowen Finn's article, Arts Council: From F to C  (Aug. 5), raised, but I think did not stress enough, the issues and problems in the changing nature of the arts.

title: THIS WEEK IN SPORTS
description: The Yankees conclude their homestand against the Boston Red Sox with games tomorrow at 2 P.M. and Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 P.M.

title: Seafood in Pleasant Surroundings
description: LOAVES & FISHES, a smartly named, perky little restaurant located in a rather unprepossessing, small shopping center near Exit 3940 on the Merritt Parkway, is a welcome addition to the rather sparse dining choices along Route 7.

title: Trouble, Trouble
description: LONDON  The murder last Monday of 23 people, including Earl Mountbatten of Burma, appears to have opened a new chapter in the long and bloody history of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Events
description: NEW YORK DANCE FESTIVAL, Delacorte Theater, Central Park, Musawwir Gymnastic Dance Ensemble, Ann Marie de Angelo and Peter Fonseca, Atlanta Ballet, Matthew Diamond and Douglas Varone, Loremil Machado, AfroBrazilian Dance Company, 8.

title: Jill Hershbain Married To Philip Harlan Sider
description: In Temple Beth Shalom in Livingston N.J., yesterday evening, Jill Hershbain, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Hershbain of West Orange, N.J., became the bride of Philip Harlan Sider.son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome P. Sider of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Theodore Jungreis of North Woodmere performed the ceremony.

title: Accord Filed on Linen Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP)  A proposed settlement of a Federal civil antitrust suit against five Florida linenservice companies was announced by the Justice Department.

title: Rose N. Franzblau Is Dead at 77
description: Dr. Rose N. Franzblau, a psychologist and former syndicated newspaper columnist, died yesterday of cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 77 years old and lived on Gracie Terrace.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Himalayan, a 71 chance, took command in the stretch and scored an easy victory in the $54,050 Gazelle Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Gorman, Connors and Mrs. Lloyd Advance in Open
description: It is two separate tournaments, Tom Gorman was sayingon court 3 it the National Tennis Center yesterday. There is the medium,speed tournament being played by the stars in the stadium and the grandstand courts and the fastspeed event for everyone else, back on the field courts.

title: KURDS SAID TO REPEL 400 IRANIAN TROOPS FROM REBEL CENTER
description: MIYANDUAB, Iran, Sept. 2  Kurdish rebels reportedly repelled 400 soldiers advancing on the mountain stronghold of Mehabad today in the second day of a new Iranian Government offensive to put down a Kurdish rebellion.

title: Press Can't Keep Up With Carter On a Baseball Diamond in Plains
description: PLAINS, Ga., Sept. 2  With a standup triple and a fistfull of junk balls, President Carter pitched and batted a team of convicts and White House aides to a 17to4 victory over a team of reporters and local women softball players.

title: 42d Street Library Offers Henry George Exhibition
description: One hundred years ago, the American economist Henry George (183997) wrote Progress and Poverty, the influential book that expounded his singletax theory. To celebrate the centennial of George's book, a special exhibition of his work has been installed in the economics department on the second floor of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

title: 12 Britons Set Off to Circle Globe Via the North and South Poles
description: LONDON, Sept. 2  A poor but proud 35yearold baronet, one of whose ancestors commanded the Normans who invaded England in 1066, set off with 11 companions today for a threeyear journey around the world the hard way: via the North and South Poles.

title: The Region
description: BETHPAGE, L.I. (AP)  Two explosions caused damage but no injuries early yesterday in an office building here and in a van in Mineola, L.I. Detective Sgt. Richard Block of the Nassau County Bomb Squad noted that in both bombings timeactivated devices were placed adjacent to electrical contracting companies.

title: Voting on Environment By Northeast Is Praised
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI)  Members of Congress from the Northeast had a much better voting record on environmental issues last year than those in the Southwest, the League of Conservation Voters concluded today.

title: Hurricane Ranks Among Century's 6 Deadliest AtlanticArea Storms
description: With more than 400 people reported dead in the Dominican Republican, David has become one of the six deadliest Atlanticarea hurricanes of this century and the worst since Hurricane Fifi struck Honduras in 1974, kiting 2,000 people.

title: Dominican Republic AT A GLANCE
description: The Dominican Republic occupies the eastern portion of the island of Hispaniola, which lies between Cuba and Puerto Rico in the Caribbean Sea. Haiti occupies the western portion. The country is 18,700 square miles, about the size of New Hampshire and Vermont, with 870 miles of coastline. It is generally mountainous, with extensive deserts in the western region.

title: Hungary Decides to Proceed With New Economic Program Based on the Profit Motive
description: BUDAPEST  The Hungarian leadership has decided to proceed with an economic program designed to produce an economy in which profit is the key criterion of success.

title: Oilers Top Redskins, 2927
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2  The Houston Oilers fired their cannon, Earl Campbell, at the Washington team today and mowed down the Redskins, who had led by 11 points at halftime. Campbell scored two touchdowns, the last of which won the game in the 58th minute. Final score: Houston 29, Washington 27.

title: SST Forced to Land in Scotland
description: GLASGOW, Sept. 2 (Reuters)  A British Airways Concorde making a special flight from Toronto to London was forced to land at Prestwick Airport here today after the oil pressure in one of its four engines failed.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Krishna Palace Amazes West Virginia
description: LIMESTONE, W.Va., Sept 2  Millie Morningstar, dressed in a yellowandwhite pantsuit, led the way up the terrace steps for her husband, William, who was wearing striped Bermuda shorts, rolleddown socks and a plaid hat.

title: The N.F.L.'s First 60 Years: Wonders and Piffle
description: AL HORWITS of The Philadelphia Evening Ledger was depressed when he caught the train home from Washington. I blew a tough bet today, he said. had the Redskins and 72 points. It was Dec. 1940, a date that lives in infamy as far as professional football in Washington is concerned. That day Horwits had covered the National Football League championship game between the Washington Redskins and the Chicago Bears, who had won the Western Championship in spite of a 73 defeat by the Skins three Sundays before the playoff.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: After Bill Lee, the Montreal pitcher, grew a beard, Tom LaSorda, the Los Angeles manager, said, He should play for the House of David. What was the House of David? When did its baseball team play, and did all the players wear beards?

title: Bonnie Kasander Is Bride of Lawyer
description: The marriage of Bonnie Kasander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kasander of Manhattan, to Stephen P. O'Rourke, son of Mr. and Mrs. James O'Rourke of Elmont, L.I., took placeyesterday evening in the Roslyn Country Club in Roslyn Heights, L.I. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg and the Rev. Nicholas Tortorella, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Gov. Graham Calls Florida Guard
description: MIAMI, Sept. 2  Hurricane David, drawing renewed destructive force from open water, moved toward south Florida tonight, forcing tens of thousands in coastal areas from their homes as far north as Cape Canaveral.

title: Sweden Faces Problem Of Currency Outflows
description: PARIS, Sept. 2  A currency problem, largely unnoticed by the rest of the world, is developing in Sweden as the campaign gets under way for elections Sept. 16 that will decide the fate of the country's present minority Liberal Government.

title: Sports World Specials
description: A vase tilled with a dozen longstem red roses rested just to the right of George Scott's locker in the Yankee clubhouse last week. The newest Yankee said they were sent by a secret admirer.

title: Rights Inquiry Sought on Arrest Of Youth in Fatal RockThrowing
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 2  The attorney for a 13yearold youth who had been charged with seconddegree murder in the case of a woman who was fatally injured by a rock thrown through her windshield said today that he would seek aFederal investigation into whether the youth's civil rights had been violated.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1979

title: Georgians Uneasy Over Charges Of Sabotage in Hospital Deaths
description: MACON, Ga., Sept. 1  Accusations that lifesupport equipment was sabotaged at the Medical Center of Central Georgia have sent ripples of alarm through a city with a history of political turmoil and intense racial conflict.

title: The Dance: Fall Season Has Opened
description: IT must be autumn. There was dancing Saturday night in Central Park. The New York Dance Festival, which is traditionally regarded as the fall season's first dance event, opened at the Delacorte Theater under the sponsorship of the TAG Foundation Ltd. in cooperation with the New York Shakespeare Festival. Like those of the past, this year' sfestival, which runs through Sept. 11, features varied programs of ballet and modern and ethnic dance.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Bobby Unser Wins in California
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Sept. 2 (AP) Bobby Unser won a duel of pit stops with his Penske teammates, Rick Mears and Mario Andretti, to capture the $294,000 California 500 auto race for championship cars at the Ontario Motor Speedway today.

title: Cambodian Calls for AntiHanoi Front
description: HAVANA, Sept. 2  Khieu Samphan, President of the Cambodian regime that was ousted after the Vietnamese invasion early this year, called today for a new front of national union to fight the Vietnamese.

title: Second Cast Sings Marietta
description: TWO casts alternated the principal roles during the sixperformance run of Naughty Marietta at the City Opera last week. Despite some fine vocal talent, hard work and earnest intentions, the secondstring singers, as seen on Saturday night, brought the piece to life only in fits and starts.

title: Membership in Unions Reaches Record 21.7 Million, Up 605,000
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI)  The Labor Department said today that unions gained 605,000 members between 1976 and 1978, bringing the total to a record 21.7 million.

title: Canadian Ousted by Soviet Hints Gulag Justice Is Not Monolithic
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 2 A few hours after the end of a meeting of the International Political Science Association in Moscow last month, Irwin Cotler, a prominent Montreal lawyer and law professor, was evicted from the Soviet Union and put on a Japan Air Lines flight to London.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Beirut Aide Meets Saudi

title: Workers, Arise! Throw Off Your Brains!
description: On St. Patrick's Day, every New Yorker has a little Irish in him. Many years ago, on Labor Day, every New Yorker, even those working for the city, had a little worker in him. It was a time for celebration, for tradition, for open hostility to the ruling class, and somehow people were always a little more thoughtful during the holiday season.

title: In BusinessOriented Japan, An Original Artist Is in Trouble
description: TOKYO IT'S odd, Seiji Tsutsumi said, but in Japan, we ignore independent and original artists. Contemporary Japan overlooks gifted people.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Enemy and Other Worries Felt by Catskills Visitors
description: LIBERTY, N.Y.  Thunderstorms chased the sunbathers from the side of the enormous pool at Grossinger's, the 1,500room dowager of the Borscht Circuit resorts, and sent them grumbling into the lounges, card rooms and boutiques of the hotel.

title: Home Found Looted Of $300,000 in Gems When Family Returns
description: The theft of $300,000 worth of jewelry from an East Side apartment was discovered yesterday when the residents returned from a vacation in Europe, the police said.

title: Yiddish Musical to Open At Town Hall on Oct. 16
description: Yiddish musical theater comes to Town Hall on Oct. 16, when Rebecca  the Rabbi's Daughter opens for a 12week run, to be followed by another vettobeannounced Yiddish musical.

title: Around the Nation
description: MIAMI, Sept. 2 (UPI)  Nine defendants in a union corruption trial were convicted yesterday of trying to control Southern waterfronts through bribery, kickbacks, threats and intimidation.

title: Radio
description: 57 A.M., WBAI: Reggae Music. Beaumont Small, host.

title: Scholar With a Winning Record
description: WASHINGTON  Karen Stevenson is 5 feet 9 inches tall and very fit; she looks, in fact, every inch the athlete. In the direct gaze of her large dark eyes, the mark of a quick intelligence is unmistakable. And in the way she carries herself there is the easy confidence of someone who's not embarrassed by winning.

title: Notes on People
description: Back home in Moscow, Lyudmila Vlasova says her attention is focused once again on ballet, and she is getting ready for a new Bolshoi production, a choreographic version of Shakespeare's Much Ado About Nothing.

title: Ship Lays Pipe in Gulf For Supertanker Port
description: NEW ORLEANS Sept. 2 (AP)  Well out to sea, the Louisiana coast, the crew of a specialized ship is laying pipelines in the Gulf of Mexico that by the end of 1980 will carry up to 1.4 million barrels of oil daily from seagoing tankers to the United States petroleum distribution system.

title: Democrats See Difficulty With Presidency Caucus
description: Now that New York State's Democrats have decided on a caucus system, instead of a primary, for selecting delegates to next year's national convention, party lawyers are turning their attention to problems such as where tohold the caucuses to insure maximum turnout and how to screen out nonDemocrats.

title: Hofstra Resumes Contract Talks With Faculty Union
description: Contract negotiations between Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., and the union representing its faculty resumed yesterday evening.

title: Explosions Are Reported In Syrian Coastal Town
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 2 (Reuters)  A series of explosions wrecked parked cars in the Syrian coastal gown of Latakia and a popular theater there was set on fire, Lebanon's rightwing Phalangist radio said today.

title: No Slump For Metals Producers
description: Even though such large consumers of metals as the automobile and construction industries are in the midst of a recession, producers of aluminum, copper and lead have yet to feel the slump. Zinc, however, has been hit by weakness.

title: Suit Opposes Affirmative Action in U.S. Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2  The name Fullilove is not as familiar as the names Bakke or Weber but it may soon be. The Supreme Court, in its new term beginning next month, will hear a case called Fullilove v. Kreps, the third case in three years to present a significant challenge to a program of special help for blacks.

title: De Gustibus In Search of the SoftShell Lobster
description: It's interesting, what captures the public fancy. There was an uncommon response recently to an inquiry from a reader who asked if there was such a thing as a softshell lobster, the equivalent of a softshell crab. It was a logicalquery, in that lobsters, like crabs, molt or shed their hard shells at certain times of the year.

title: Illicit Liquor Kills 16 in India
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 2 (Reuters)  Sixteen people have died after drinking illicitly distilled liquor in Lucknow, northern India, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: Ireland Rebuffs Britain on Right Of Hot Pursuit
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 2  John Lynch, the Prime Minister of Ireland, today ruled out giving British authorities the lawenforcement tools they have said are needed to end terrorism in Northern Ireland.

title: Inverness First Yacht to Finish
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 2  Inverness, skippered by Bob McCullough, former commodore of the New York Yacht Club, was the first yacht to cross the finish line today in the 45th annual Vineyard race.

title: UNIONS BARGAINING OVER 3 MILE ISLAND
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2  Executives of the stricken Three Mile Island nuclear reactor have opened negotiations here with a union leader on working conditions for the thousands of skilled craftsmen who will be needed to reopen the severely damaged Pennsylvania plant.

title: Carmichael a Big Factor
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 Harold Carmichael is 6 feet 8 inches tall. Ray Rhodes is listed at 511, and Terry Jackson at 510. Each small Giant cornerback was beaten by Carmichael for a touchdown on oneonone coverage today.

title: The City
description: A suspect was arrested yesterday in the stabbing death of a 71yearold Manhattan man whose body was found in his apartment on the upper East Side last month.

title: WNYC to Sponsor Storytelling Festival
description: WNYCAM and FM, the radio stations owned and run by New York City, will sponsor a sixday Storytelling Festival beginning Sunday.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE time of this remarkable novel is the near future. The place is Australia. The society is divided into Servants and FreeCitizens. The Servants are actually the privileged class. They havepasses unscathed through the machine of childhood and the grading. Having proved their superiority, they are allowed to work, to run things, whereas the Free are useless, without merit. We are told:

title: Race in Bronx Grows Rough
description: Street crime became more than a campaign issue yesterday in the race for the Bronx Borough Presidency, when supporters of G. Oliver Koppell charged that a backer of the incumbent, Stanley Simon, had pulled agun on them. They had been tearing down Mr. Simon's campaign signs along Mosholu Parkway in the northeast Bronx when the alleged incident occurred.

title: ABROAD AT HOME The Brown Strategy
description: LOS ANGELES  In a recent Harris Poll Democrats and Independents, given three choices, went 52 percent for Edward Kennedy, 25 for Jimmy Carter, 18 for Jerry Brown. With figures like that, with a skeptical national press, with much political disaffection in his own state, how can Brown expect to win the nomination?

title: Janie Sell in Vonnegut Show
description: Janie Sell, Tony Award winner for her performance in the musical Over Here, will join the original cast members of the W.P.A production of Kurt Vonnegut Jr.'s God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater when it opens at the Entermedia Theater on Oct. 11. Previewsbegin Sept. 27. Miss Sell was also seen on and off Broadway in I Love My Wife, George M. and Dames at Sea. The musical comedy version of Mr. Vonnegut's novel was adapted and directed by Howard Ashman, with music by Alan Menken and lyrics by Mr. Ashman and Dennis Green.

title: New Books
description: Alone Around the World, by Namoi James (Coward McCann & Geohegan, $9.95). Young woman attempts an aroundtheworld sea voyage.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TODAY

title: Warm, Wet Air On Sea Is Fuel For Hurricanes
description: The vast engine of destruction called Hurricane David is fueled by the warm, extremely moist air that sometimes hangs over subtropical oceans. Such an awesome storm should remain highly destructive until starved for such fuel.

title: O'Meara Routs Cook, 8 and 7, in U.S. Amateur
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 2  Mark O'Meara, whose golf game pivots on smooth and easy swing, muted John Cook, the defending champion, 8 and 7, to win the 79th United States Amateur championship today. The match, on the par71 Canterbury Golf Club course, had been scheduled for 36 holes.

title: Bethlehem Consent Decree
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Sept. 2 (AP) The Bethlehem Steel Corporation signed a consent decree last Friday with national and state environmental agencies under which the company will spend $100 million to modernize and clean up its steelmaking facilities here. Bethlehem is to replace an existing coke oven battery, blast furnace,  openhearth furnaces and sinter plant with two new electric furnaces, a project the company announced in June.

title: Small Touches Give a Big Edge to Little Corner Grocery
description: It is 7 A.M. and quiet on Eighth Avenue near 20th Street when Nunzio (Frank) Reyes unlocks the steel door protecting the entrance to his grocery. As he switches on the lights and air conditioning, the first customer stumbles in.

title: Britain's Trident Television Starts U.S. Subsidiary
description: Trident Television, one of Britain's major commercial broadcasting companies, has created a subsidiary in the United States to produce programs for the American networks that would also play in Britain and be marketed worldwide.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: Linda Radin Wed Upstate

title: 5 ModernDance Troupes Trying Subscription Plan
description: Five moderndance companies have joined in an experiment in marketing dance that is expected both to increase their audiences and to provide them with statistically predictable boxoffice advances that will facilitate the budgeting of their New York seasons. It is also expected that the resultant increased receipts will offset the losses traditionally suffered by such companies from New York seasons, losses that must be made up from the greater profits accruing from outoftown touring.

title: In the Running for the E.R.A.
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 2  More than 150 people got up early in the Hamptons today to do something other than play tennis for a change. What lured them from the courts was the chance to see Betty Friedan, Representative Elizabeth Holtzman, Lucie Amaz, Carl Reiner and other celebrities work up a sweat and to see a 1.3mile race billed as a. breakfast run for the equal rights amendment.

title: Officials Rebuff A Builder's Plan For L.I. Housing
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 1  A developer has been temporarily blocked in his application to build a development of $100,000 houses on what is now a nature preserve owned by the American Museum of Natural History, but he is expected to meet conditions laid down by the town and to get permission later.

title: Bank Merger Planned
description: The Security Pacific National Bank of Los Angeles announced that it had sent a letter of intent to the InyoMono National Bank on a merger agreement under which Security Pacific would pay $70.40 a share in cash to InyoMono shareholders, less certain adjustments. InyoMano National Bank has six branches in Inyo and Mano Counties in California.

title: Andreoli's Investigations Stir a Debate in Syracuse
description: SYRACUSE  Since 1976, when Governor Carey made Peter D. Andreoli the special prosecutor for Onondaga County, three special grand juries have indicted the County Executive, a former district attorney, the Republican county chairman, a former assistant district attorney, a current assistant district attorney, a former Republican election commissioner, a Republican state senator, the former county attorney, three insurance agents, deputy county comptroller, a former town supervisor, a truck manufacturer and the nation's largest insurance brokerage.

title: Expos Rout Reds With 21 Hits, 131
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 2 (UPI)  Mike LaCoss allowed seven consecutive singles today to open the game and Steve Rogers pitched a fourhitter as Montreal routed Cincinnati, 134. The Expos scored six runs, in their firstinning rally and completed a threegame sweep of the Reds.

title: Bridge:
description: When a player picks up the hand of lifetime, which is usually a mass of high cards with a probable slam in view at the start, he can expect the bidding and play to be relatively straightforward. The chances are that his partner's hand will have little relevance in the bidding and the play.

title: DOMINICANS REPORT 400 KILLED BY HURRICANE AND FLOODING; RESIDENTS FLEE FLORIDA KEYS
description: Hurricane David killed more than 400 people and left 150,000 others homeless in the Dominican Republic, officials reported yesterday as the storm battered the Bahamas and headed for the batteneddown south Florida coast.

title: Coast Boulevard Closed to Thwart Crimes by Youths in Cruising Cars
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2  Whittier Boulevard, a milelong strip in East Los Angeles where Hispanic youths known as lowriders cruise in their exotically decorated cars, has been closed on weekend nights by the Los Angeles Sheriff in an effort to curb gang violence. Since January, there have been 15 murders and eieht rams on the street.

title: Reattached Arm Is Removed
description: BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 2 (AP)  Surgeons say that the clotting of blood has forced them to remove the arm of a man who lost it in an industrial accident Aug. 20, then had it reattached in an operation.Dr. John R. Border, of the Erie County Medical Center, said yesterday that Arthur Parry, 24 years old, was doing well following the removal of the limb, his right arm, on Thursday.

title: Sporting Gear
description: A useful way of recycling old automobile tires has been instituted by a West Coast company, which is turning them into buoys. The new Topper Bouy is actually an old tire filled with solidified polystyrene, a process which makes it unsinkable and virtually indestructable. It can be used to moor a boat or, because it is radar reflective, be used as markers to designate channels, speed limits, diving areas and shallowwater hazards. All that needs to be added to the tire and the buoy superstructure are an anchor and chain. The Topper Bouy, which comes in orange or white, is sold for $97.50, plus freight charges, by Topper Industries, Box 1611, Vancouver, Wash. 98668, (206) 6949261.

title: Durables Sales Still Vigorous
description: Although sales are still running at surprisingly vigorous pace, the makers and sellers of what economists call consumer durables are cutting inventories and bracing for recession.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Intelligence Operations an Accepted Practice at U.N.
description: Soon after Andrew Young submitted his resignation as the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, he suggested that his supposedly secret meeting with a Palestine Liberation Organization representative in New York had been discovered through intelligence operations.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 2 (AP)  A United States District Court jury has ruled in favor of a dozen Spokanearea Texaco dealers who had accused the oil company of price discrimination.

title: Textbooks That Don't Embalm
description: SANTA FE I'm waiting for a plane in the Las Vegas airport, listening to the tinny clunkclash of silver dollars falling into pans below slot machines.The rain of money sounds torrential. Passersby stop to look. They know money is being made, as we say, just as in school they knewthat when textbooks were opened and read for a test, knowledge was being acquired. In truth, more money is being lost than won from slot machines and more facts forgotten than remembered from textbooks.

title: Washington Watch
description: WHEN Congress reconvenes Wednesday after a monthlong recess, it will be faced with number of nettlesome measures involving energy and the economy. The best guess is that when the session ends sometime in December, many those issues will still be unresolved.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Survivors of Holocaust Retell the Unspeakable
description: NEW HAVEN  On Sept. 3 the Germans came in; the first lie I heard was that all the people were going to go back to work, to normal life, said Leon Glick, remembering the events in Czestochowa, Poland, when World War II officially began in Europe 40 yearsago toaay. Nazis on motorcycles rode through the streets reassuring the Jewish population, which had only vague ideas of what was to come.

title: Wetbacks Who Go To Mexico
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  The President of Mexico, Jos Lpez Portillo, is to visit Jimmy Carter in Washington next month, and energy is on their agenda. Few know it, but while President Carter has only recently begun paying attention to Mexico to solve our energy problem by buying oil and gas, other Americans have looked southward for years  to solve their employment problem.

title: 5 Die in Indian Train Crash
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 2 (Reuters)  Five people were killed and 200 injured, 10 seriously, when a freight train and a passenger train collided yesterday at Dholi, northeast India, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: Cross Burned at Another L.I. Home
description: A twofoottall cross was burned Saturday night on a sidewalk outside a home in East Meadow, L.I., where a black person rents an apartment, the Nassau County police said.

title: Dr. Allen Kern Marries Salena Rapp in Tenafly
description: Salena Ehrich Rapp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Rapp of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Allen J. Kern, son of Mr. andMrs. Harold Kern of Westfield, N.J. Rabbi Irwin M. Blank performed the ceremony at the Rapp home.

title: Jets Bow in Overtime, 2522
description: Suddenly, with only 15 seconds remaining in overtime, the Jets dropped their opening game in yesterday's dusk. They proved that, as always, a young team will find more than one way to lose.

title: Blacks in Prison Given New Aid By N.A.A.C.P.
description: OSSINING, N.Y.  Inmates at the Ossining Correctional Facility did not scoff when Leroy Mobley told them that he understood their problems. The tall, softspoken Mr. Mobley had spent a long stretch in prison himself  he was paroled last March from the Federal prison system after serving 14 years of a 100year sentence for kidnapping, robbery and murder.

title: Letter: On Aged Veterans
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess:
description: It is difficult to develop clearcut, positive plans against the Hippopotamus Formation, a defense to the Maroczy Bind that restrains intrusion in the center by putting black pawns at Q3 and IC3. White always has a slight advantage in control of more space in the center, but how can he build upon it?

title: Crowds Defy Downpour In Hunt for Holiday Fun
description: Kept off balance in the middle of long weekend by fickle weather, the city and its neighbors and its many Labor Day visitors faced up gamely yesterday to turning a steamy, often showery Sunday into something to remember.

title: Drop Forecast In Sugar Stocks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (Reuters) World sugar stocks may decline in 1980 for the first time in five years, an Agriculture Department report has predicted.

title: Ceausescu Proposes to Mediate Between Israel, Syria and P.L.O.
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 2 (UPI)  President Nicolae Ceaucescu of Rumania has offered to mediate talks between Israel, Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization, Israeli Government sources said today.

title: Rowdies Gain the Soccer Bowl
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 2 (AP)  Ivan Grnja, a late substitute, scored early in the minigame to give the Tampa Bay Rowdies a 10 victory over the San Diego Sockers today for the North American Soccer League's American Conference title

title: Dominicans Put Storm Toll at 400 Dead and 600 Missing
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 2  Officials here said late today that they feared the death toll from Hurricane David and the flooding that follbwed could exceed 1,000.

title: Grand Jury Dispute in Vesco Case Is Complicated by Report of Perjury
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2  From the first allegations that Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, had sought to buy help for his legal problems from the Carter Administration, the White House and the Justice Department have been embroiled in controversy.

title: To Our Readers
description: Starting today, the suggested newsstand price of The New York Times on weekdays has been increased to 25 cents within 50 miles of New York City, and to 30 cents elsewhere. The price change reflects increased costs to The Times, including the costs of fuel and newsprint.

title: Searchers Find Body on Tanker; 2 Men Are Still Missing in Blast
description: DEER PARK, Tex., Sept. 2 (AP)  A search team today found the body of one man aboard a tanker that exploded in the Houston Ship Channel yesterday, possibly because of lightning. Two other men were missine.

title: Time to Return to the I.L.O.
description: Almost two years ago the Carter Administration decided to try to change the International Labor Organization by heeding George Meany's advice that the United States should just pull out. So far, this blunt approach has paid off.

title: In Ulster, Sense of Futility Amid Bitter Determination
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Sept. 2  Among Roman Catholics here, one of the most popular songs these days is, The Town I Loved So Well, a haunting ballad about a man who comes back to Londonderry, his childhood home, after a long absence:

title: PunkRock: 3 English Groups Team for a Concert at Club 57
description: IT didn't take very long for the hard rock of the late 60's, a music whose innovators included Cream and Jimi Hendrix, to transform itself from a brash, exciting style into an exercise in overkill and clichs. Similarly, the hard core of English punk rock seems to have been unable to sustain itself musically beyond its original nosethumbing gestures. Those eestures were valuable assignals that the mainstream of rock, which had been going soft since the beginning of the 70's, was about to harden again.

title: Woodstock Reunion Show Set for Saturday on L.I.
description: A 10hour Reunion Concert, designed to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Woodstock Festival, will take place on Saturday at Parr Meadows in Brookhaven. L.I. The concertserves as a substitute for a larger event that some of the same promoters had hoped to stage last month at or near the site of the original festival, but were forced to abandon for lack of an available site.

title: Mets Top Astros, 54, Losing Streak Ends
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 2  The New York Mets ended their ninegame losing streak this afternoon but victory did not come easily.

title: Outdoors Nature Has Way Of Forecasting Weather, Too
description: WATCHING a television meteorologist wave his little wand across a map of the nation and satellite pictures of cloud formations, many of us forget the time when we relied on natural signs to predict what weather was coming.

title: Haig Says NATO Needs To Correct Deficiencies
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 2 (Reuters)  Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. said at a NATO conference today that the problem for the Western alliance was not to set a new strategy but to correct the deficiencies in its forces.

title: Israel's Lebanon Attacks: Risks Both Ways
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 2  Israel is now caught between two extreme dangers in pursuing its policy of hitting Palestinian guerrilla bases among the civilian settlements of southern Lebanon.

title: Recession in the City
description: New York's economy has achieved a fragile stability in the last few years, a stability that is about to be severely tested by the gathering recession. However deep the recession becomes nationally, the effects will be harsher here. National firms with factories to close will want to close their oldest, most expensive plantsfirst, and those are likely to be in the snowbelt. Consumers with large home heating bills will have to cut back on something else. And unemployment, which is already even higher here than in other snowbelt cities, could be aggravated by even a moderate recession to a level normally associated with depression.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP)  Administration sources said today that it was highly probable that the North Koreans are digging another tunnel under the demilitarized zone along the border between their territory and South Korea.

title: Raiders Down Rams, 2417
description: Ken Stabler, the quarterback, spent the offseason trying to escape the Oakland Raiders and failed. Pat Haden, the quarterback, used the offseason to finish his first year at Loyola Law School in Los Angeles and passed. Haden, whoaveraged 83 in contracts, civil procedure, criminal law, accounting and legal writing, was thinking about life after football.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Blacks Trying to Reopen Historic 1954 School Case
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 31 Eight black parents have asked the Federal District Court here to reopen the historic Brown v. the Board of Education case, alleging that after 25 years, school officials have failed to end segregation in the city's public schools.

title: Photography Exhibition To Center on 10 Women
description: Recollections: 10 Women of Photography, an exhibition highlighting the careers of 10 women regarded by the show's organizers as distinguished elders of their profession, will open Sept. 21 and run through Nov. 4 at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue. at 94th Street.

title: Books: Sayles's  Winning Way in Short Stories
description: IT doesn't really require the 15 stories in John Sayles's collection to prove that Mr. Sayles has a winning way with the short story. In fact, any number of passages could be extracted from his two novels, Pride of the Bimbos and Union Dues, to prove the point. The youngsters chooseup baseball game in a scruffy field, the black rural church service and the Reverend Orison's (wonderful name) sermon in Pride of the Bimbos, and the ideological discussions in Union Dues are passages so rounded, shaped and satisfying that they could easily stand alone, though they are organically related to the works in which they appear.

title: Former Regulator Builds New Mortgage Vehicle
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2  While Preston Martin was chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in the early 1970's, he presided over the creation of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The quasigovernmental company, nicknamed Freddie Mac, was designed to create a secondary market in conventional home mort ages.,

title: Yankees Beat Royals, 65
description: Whitey Herzog is not a superstitious man, which is lucky for him. If he were, his demons would all wear pinstripes. They would follow him through the lastmonths of every baseball season. when his Royals most needed a victory they would offer him one, but at the last moment, they would snatch it away.

title: Union Chief to Seek a 30% Pay Rise in Transit Pact
description: The president of Local 100 of the Transit Workers Union, which represents the city's 34,000 subway and bus workers, said yesterday that he would seek a 30 percent wage increase for his membership in contract negotiations with the New York City Transit Authority next year.

title: Shark Nets Protect South African Beaches
description: DURBAN, South Africa  Shaga! A few hundred yards off the Umhlanga Rocks beach, one of the most popular tourist areas on the Natal coast, Zulu boatmen erupted in a joyous shout as they hauled a net into the speedboat. Enmeshed in the polyethylene twine, was dead, 9foot, 400pound female copper shark, its razoredge teeth sharp enough to sever a human limb at a bite.

title: Taiwan's Soaring Credit Rating
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 3 . By removing a pervasive uncertainty, the American withdrawal of diplomatic recognition of Nationalist China last Dec. 31 has had the unexpected effect of elevating Taiwan's credit rating to top grade in international financial circles.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Deaths

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1979

title: Hungary's U.S. Trade Campaign
description: BUDAPEST, Aug. 31  One year after winning mostfavorednation status from the United States, Hungary has embarked on an intensive campaign to wring the maximum possible advantage from the lower tariffs that the new status entails

title: Ray Perkins Went for It
description: PHILADELPHIA IN his first game as the Giants coach, Ray Perkins was confronted with his first moment of truth yesterdayGiants trailing, 2317, fourth quarter, 6 minutes 2 seconds remaining, fourth down and 6 yards to go at the Philadelphia Eagles 26yard line. Most coaches would havegone for the field goal. In retrospect, perhaps Ray Perkins should have gone for the field goal. He has a dependable kicker in Joe Danelo, perhaps the Giants most consistent offensive weapon. If the field goal had been successful, the Giants would have moved within one field goal of tying the score. But on the sideline, in his white shirt and bluish gray slacks with the telephone headset perched above the unemo. tional stare on his intense face, the rookie coach never hesitated. He pointed at Joe Pisarcik, which let the quarterback know that the Giants were going for the first down. But they didn't make it. Joe Pisarcik's pass over the middle to Earnest Gray, the rookie wide receiver, was incomplete and the Giants lost, 2317.

title: Spacecraft Takes CloseUp Photos Of Titan, Saturn's Largest Satellite
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Sept. 2Pioneer 11, outbound from Saturn, cruised within photographic range of Titan today for the first closeup examination of what is believed to be the largest moon in the solar system.

title: Noah: Leader in the Rise Of Black Tennis Players
description: Arthur Ashe, recovering from a heart attack, made a special trip to the National Tennis Center on Saturday to watch his 19yearold protg, Yannick Noah, play his first centercourt match at the United States Open.

title: PEKING SEEKS HELP OF U.N. FOR REFUGEES
description: BEIHAI, China, Sept. 2  Feeling an economic strain, China has turned to the United Nations for financial help in resettling some of the 251,000 refugees from Vietnam who have entered southern China during the last 15 months.

title: Fire Worshipper
description: We know a man who bought his first orange at a county fair for a nickel, having walked barefoot from home, carrying his shoes. The closest thing to a machine on the midway was the horse that tugged the merrygoround around. Honesttogoodness gypsies told your fortune and a few Indian families selling baskets came over from Maine.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LAST CALL This is the final day of an exhibition entitled 101 Photographs From the Brooklyn Museum. The museum is open from 1 to 5 P.M. this holiday. The New York Times photography critic called the pictures a wonderful hodgepodge of the old and the new, the distinguished and the commonplace, the uptodate and the dowdy. Apparently the museum once had a photographic department but it died with its curator, Henry De Wetter, almost 30 years ago. There are 100yearold pictures by amateurs of the 1880's and professionals such as Berenice Abbott, whose exhibited photographs were made in the 1930's.

title: Rolland Adams, OwnerPublisher Of Newspaper in Bethlehem, Pa.
description: Rolland Adams, owner and publisher of the The GlobeTimes of Bethlehem, Pa., died Saturday at St. Luke's Hospital in Bethlehem. He was 74 years old and a resident of Palm Beach_ Fla.

title: Libyans Living Abroad Take Over Six Embassies at Urging of Qaddafi
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept. 2  The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, today urged all Libyans studying and living abroad to take over the Libyan embassies in their host countries and turn them into nongovernmental people's bureaus.

title: U.S. Embassy Protests Soviet Denial of Visa By Barring Reception
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2  The United States Embassy, acting at the request of the Association of American Publishers, has canceled a reception for Soviet publishing officials because Robert L. Bernstein, chairman of Random House, has been denied a visa to the second Moscow International Book Fair.

title: Twitty Is Victor By a Shot
description: ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 2 (AP) Having watched Doug Tewell and Tom Punier fail, Howard Twitty sank a 4foot putt to make par on the final hole today and won the $275,000 B.C. open golf tournament.

title: Rock: Tim Curry Is Building On Rocky Horror Show Cult
description: TIM CURRY, who has parlayed his cult following as a star of The Rocky Horror Show into the beginnings of a career as a rock singer, may be talented. His lyricsshow signs of cleverness, and at times he temporarily abandons the campy recitative that is his stock in trade and actually sings. But if Mr. Curry is a talent, he certainly isn't a rock talent, as his Friday evening show at the Palladium amply demonstrated.

title: Giants Rally but Fall, 2317
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2  The way it turned out, there were several opportunities for the Giants to begin their new era with a victory today  individual plays that could have made the final score different from Philadelphia 23, Giants 17.

title: Union Official Endorses Carter
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 2 (AP)  Martin J. Hughes, international vice president of the 550,000member Communications Workers of America, has called for the reelection of President Carter in 1980.

title: Oil Aide Says Iranians May Cancel Purchase Of Products From U.S.
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 2 (AP)  The chairman of the National Iranian Oil , Company said today his Government might cancel a purchase of Americanrefined kerosene and heating oil and send two Iranianbound tankers carrying the products back to the United States.

title: U.S. Ability To Chart Oil Questioned
description: A change in work rules by the United States Customs Commissioner, which was intended to reduce overtime paid to Customs inspectors, has brought loud complaints from Congressment and the department's employees about its possible effect on the agency's ability to regulate the oil industry, the cargoes of which it is supposed to measure and tax.

title: Guidry Posts 15th
description: Last year about this time, Ron Guidry was pitching a pair of twohit shutouts against the Boston Red Sox, then beating them in a playoff for the American League's Eastern Division championship. Guidry encountered the Red Sox yesterday, and the result was the same: Guidry won; the Red Sox lost.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Banks, exchanges and commodity and bond markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Labor Day.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 4,.1979

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY TELEPHONED TO 354.3900 UNTIL 5: P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3467767.

title: Bringing Back Traditional Styles Of Country Wear
description: The Country Clothes Shop is back at Lord & Taylor. The place where for 20 years women shopped for timeless tweeds and leathers is reopening today after an absence of nearly four years.

title: Sir Felix Aylmer, 90, British Character Actor
description: LONDON, Sept. 3  Sir Felix Aylmer, one of Britain's most admired character actors, died yesterday in a hospital in Sussex. He was 90 years old.

title: A Relieved Miami Greets Sun as Storm Veers North
description: MIAMI, Sept. 3  The sun broke through lingering crowds over a relieved Miami today as Hurricane David, some of its fury spent, rumbled northward, threatening other cities along the Florida coastline.

title: Pie in the Sky Triumphs In $1.3 Million Futurity
description: RUIDOSO DOWNS, N.M., Sept. 3 (UPI)  Pie in the Sky used a strong finishing kick today to capture the 21st running of the $1.3 million AllAmerican Futurity, the world's richest horse race.

title: 4 Killed in 2 Air Crashes in Hour Within Southeastern Wisconsin
description: LAKE GENEVA, Wis., Sept. 3 (AP) Two air crashes that occurred within an hour in southeastern Wisconsin killed four persons, officials said.

title: Donleavy to Tour U.S. To Promote New Novel
description: J.P. Donleavy, the expatriate American author of The Ginger Man, will return to this country from Ireland next month for an 11city tour to promote his latest novel.Schultz.

title: Labor Finds Food and Fun at White House Picnic
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3  For more than 1,000 labor leaders and their guests gathered on the White House lawn today, labor did not stop for the holiday. It merely switched gears from mundane exertions to eggonspoon races and negotiating the intricacies of an obstacle course.

title: Iran Invites Newspapers To Send New Journalists
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 3 (Reuters)Iran's Minister of Information and National Guidance, Nasser Minachi, said today that foreign publications whose correspondents had been expelled from Iran were free to send replacements.

title: Iran to Resume OilGroup Talk
description: TEHERAN, Sept 3 (Reuters)  The stateowned National Iranian Oil Company is to resume negotiations in London with a consortium of Western oil companies that distributed most of Iran's oil until the overthrow of the Shah earlier this year, the official Pars press agency reported today.

title: Practice to Decide
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 3  Matt Robinson stood on the side today while Richard Todd, the man he had beaten for the Jets quarterback job, directed the team.

title: Cynthia Woodhead Sets Record Of 1:58.23 in 200Meter Freestyle
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3 (UPI)  Cynthia Woodhead of Riverside, Calif., shattered her world record in winning the women's 200meter freestyle today, leading the United States to five gold medals on the final day of the World Cup swimming championships.

title: Events
description: GRATEFUL DEAD, rock, Madison Square Garden, ?? LIZA MINNELLI, pop singer, Carnegle Hall, ??.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Britain's Trade Unionists Begin Convention in a Mood of Confrontation
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 3  The British Trades Union Congress, facing a Conservative Government for the first time since 1974, began its annual convention here today in a mood of confrontation that could lead to a second straight winter of industrial strife.

title: Jet Flying Over Labor Day Parade Hits a Grain Elevator in Montana
description: DILLON, Mont., Sept. 3 (AP)  One of two jet fighters making a low flight over a Labor Day parade on Dillon's main street crashed into a grain elevator and exploded, killing the pilot and setting a bulk oilstorage plant afire. Much of the city's electrical power was knocked out, the police reported.

title: Policeman Shot During Robbery Of Brooklyn Bar
description: A prison guard was arrested in his Queens home late last night and accused of shooting a New York City police officer during the robbery of a tavern in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn earlier in the day.

title: Blondie and The Beach Boys
description: There was a momentary silence in the phone conversation and then a crackling sound of papers shuffled rapidly.

title: Class, Heritage and Cash Count in Buying a Coop
description: In today's tight realestate market, those trying to buy into one of the better cooperative apartments on the Upper East Side will find that money often talks. But they will also find that in the city's most restricted buildings, they need more than a fat bank account.

title: The Editorial Notebook Is It Racist to Close Hospitals?
description: Mayor Koch has been called a racist for proposing to close four municipal hospitals and reduce the size of others. Washington is investigating, and the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense Fund has filed suit. These attacksraise perplexing questions as to what constitutes racial discrimination. Twothirds of the patients in municipal hospitals are from minority groups. Will it ever be possible to reduce services without adversely affecting minorities?

title: Syria Said to Send Army Troops To Latakia to Put Down Rioting
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 3 (AP)President Hafez alAssad sent troops into the northern city of Latakia to put down demonstrations by members of his own Alawite Moslem sect, Western diplomatic sources said today. The sourcessaid that five people were reported killed.

title: Cross Burned at a 3d L.I. Home
description: A threefoot cross was set afire on the lawn of a black family's house in North Valley Stream, L.I., yesterday morning, the Nassau County police said, and a neighbor apparently threw it away before anyone else noticed it.

title: ExSaigon Banker Sues to Free Assets Frozen by U.S.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3  Tran Qui Than, a 54yearold former Saigon banker now living in Berkeley, Calif., has be. come the central figure in an effort to gain access to millions of dollars in Vietnamese assets fiozen by the United States Government.

title: Army Is Told to Take a More Respectful Attitude Toward the Recruit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP)  Army recruits will no longer have to endure skinhead haircuts and will be treated with the same respect and dignity accorded to all soldiers. That is an order from the Army's Training and Doctrine Command to all recruit reception stations and basic training centers.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION Disarray in Washington
description: THE Federal education bureaucracy is in disarray. Its top position of United .States Commissioner of Education has been vacant since July 1, and there has been no Acting Commissioner since Aug. 1.

title: The ExPresident's Men Reunite at San Clethente
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 3 Richard M. Nixon and his wife, Pat, began their withdrawal from the home that the world once called the Western White House yesterday with a nostalgic reunion of many of Mr. Nixon's closest a Meg from his White House years

title: Sadat Leaves for Israel and New Talks on Palestinians
description: CAIRO, Sept. 3 (AP)  Anwar elSadat sailed for Israel today aboard his presidential yacht to take up with Prime Minister Menachem Begin the issues of Palestinian selfrule in the Israelioccupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and the future of Jerusalem.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, Sept. 3 (UPI)  An American warship rescued 154 Vietnamese refugees from the South China Sea today in the largest single rescue by the United States Seventh Fleet since it began searching for boat people 45 days ago.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: BRIGGSJames E., of Wilson Point, Norwalk, Conn. on Sept 1, father of James and Thomas Briggs, brother of Margaret Roberts, grandfather of three. Services private. For Information call Collins Funeral Home, 2038660747.

title: HURRICANE BATTERS THE FLORIDA COAST; DAMAGE WIDESPREAD
description: TITUSVILLE, Fla., Tuesday, Sept. 4 Hurricane David left a path of felled trees, downed power lines and heavily damaged buildings, bridges and cars along Florida's Atlantic coast as it continued rumbling northward early today.

title: Chicago Burglars Skirt Alarms And Remove $1 Million in Gold
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (UPI)  Burglars who circumvented a sophisticated electronic alarm and broke through a wall into a sixthfloor jewelry shop in thecity's downtown Loop over the weekend escaped with an estimated $1 million in gold jewelry and gems, the police said.

title: Train Crash Injures 34 in Spain
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Sept. 3 (UPI)  A Madridbound express train sped through a red signal light and smashed into a local passenger train halted at a station here today, injuring at least 38 people.

title: Science Library
description: In 1817 an English physician, James Parkinson, wrote an essay describing an illness called shaking palsy. The patients, of whom he had seen just six, had a characteristic trembling of the limbs while the muscles were at rest; slow body movements; muscular stiffness bordering on rigidity; the tendency to bend forward while walking and to break into a run without intending to do so.

title: Castro Assails U.S. as He Opens Parley
description: HAVANA, Sept. 3  President Fidel Castro of Cuba opened the conference of the socalled nonaligned movement today with a fiery speech attributing the major evils of the world to the United States and its old and new allies, by which I mean the Chinese.

title: Black Theater Fills Big Role in Queens
description: A woman strode off the street into the Black Spectrum Theater in Queens and looked with surprise at the bleacher seats and tiny stage.

title: Expos Win, 72, 65
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 3  The Expos, who had been unable to sweep a doubleheader in eight attempts this season, finally did it today, helped by an error in the 10th inning of the second game on a rundown that had the Montreal manager, Dick Williams, expressing his gratitude.

title: Corning Glass to Recall 18.5 Million Coffee Makers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI)  Representatives of the Corning Glass Works have agreed in negotiations with the Consumer Product Safety Commission to recall voluntarily 18.5 million Corning coffee makers with handle defects, ProductSafety Letter, a Washingtonbased weekly publication for consumers, reported today.

title: Child Prostitution: Causes Are Sought
description: Stephen Torkelson works in the heart of the Times Square pornography belt and part of his job, he says, is to take the pulse of the street. He was doing this the other night, standing on Eighth Avenue with a coworker, when a stranger in a wellcut threepiece suit appeared with a familiar proposition.

title: Sara Jane Moore Refuses Meals
description: ALDERSON, W.Va., Sept. 3 (UPI)Sara Jane Moore, serving a life sentence for trying to assassinate President Ford, began a hunger strike Aug. 10 to protestbeing kept in isolation at the Federal Correctional Institution for Women, officials said. Mrs. Moore, 48 years old, was convicted in April of escaping from the facility and a threeyear sentence was added to the life term she is serving for the assassination attempt in 1975.

title: Panda That Was a Gift Of China Dies in Japan
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 3 (UPI)Lan Lan, a 10yearold panda that was a gift from China to the people of Japan, died early today at the Ueno Zoo here.

title: The Rev. Dr. Paul C. Empie, 70, Lutheran World Church Leader
description: The Rev. Dr. Paul C. Empie, an international leader of the Lutheran Church, relief official and ecumenist, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Zionsville, Pa. He was 70 years old.

title: Ristorante Emigrates To Houston From Rome
description: HOUSTON  It all began because Sergio Ballatori of Italy trusted Maxine Van Dusen of Texas. She was absolutely convinced that Texas needed him more than Rome did. And so, after considerable cajoling on her part, he packed his belongings, ended a 40year family business in Rome, moved to Houston, bought a bankand transformed it into a restaurant.

title: POLITICAL SCIENTISTS HOLD A TRADE FAIR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3  The loss of confidence in government caused by Watergate may have ended two years ago, the voting public is not getting any more ideological and the Congressmen who spent Labor Day at picnics to meet the voters may have been wasting time.

title: Appeal Could Clarify Justices Stand on Closed Courts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 An appeal on the Supreme Court calendar would permit the Justices to clarify a recent decision that gave judges broad discretion to conduct closed criminal proceedings.Public comments by some of the Justices have fueled confusion over what that decision really held and have given lawyers and scholars the impression that the Court would welcome the opportunity.

title: Q&A
description: Q. How does aspirin work?

title: Cattails Studied As Energy Source
description: MIDDLE RIVER, MINN. THE latest possible alternative to coal, oil, gas and nuclear power is a prolific water plant that may be one of the most efficient natural converters of solar energy yet discovered  the common cattail.

title: Some Leaves From the Groves of Academe
description: Questions

title: Social Security Versus Reality
description: According to the Congressional Budget Office, Social Security is paying out benefits faster than it is collecting taxes. Unless it wishes to risk a fiscal emergency in 1983, Congress must promptly take one of two courses: authorize new revenues or trim benefits.

title: The Doctor's World
description: HEART attacks strike a million Americans a year, killing 650,000. In the face of that death toll, the treatment of heart attacks has shown steady improvement: there are four million Americans living who have had at least one attack. Nevertheless, the heart attack remains one of the world's most puzzling disorders, with much that doctors understand partly at best.

title: Dayan Meets Supporter Of P.L.O. on West Bank
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 3 (AP)  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan, already under fire from conservative Israelis for meeting a supporter of the Palestine Liberation Organization, met another supporter of the P.L.O. today. it was announced.

title: Elaine Reich Wed To R.M. Weinberg
description: Elaine M. Reich and Richard M. Weinberg, New York lawyers, were married yesterday in the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue. Rabbi Ephraim M. Wolf performed the ceremony.

title: Street Peddlers Proliferating in U.S. Cities
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 3  By day it is a bustling boulevard where men and women of conspicuous wealth, the chic and the strivers go to work, to shop and to be seen.

title: Show Traces Jews In Early New York
description: The Jewish Community in Early New York: 16541800 will open at the Fraunces Tavern Museum, 54 Pearl Street, on Oct. 18, the first exhibition in the museum's Adeline Moses Loeb. Gallery. The show traces the founding of New York's Jewish community, rrom the first immigrants, men of Dutch and Portuguese descent who came from Brazil in 1654, through the secondgeneration colonists and Revolutionary War patriots.

title: Reporter's Notebook: In a European Summer, Curiosity About America, and Contrasts
description: ZERMATT, Switzerland  Way up at the edge of the Thodule glacier, 1,500 feet above the last tuft of vegetation and a good half mile higher than Zermatt, Europe stops shoving.

title: Power Plant's Waste Heat Helps Start a Fish Farm
description: TRENTON, Sept. 3  Electric power companies could become major producers of fish and vegetables, according to a team of biologists and marine scientists who have worked five years on the nation's largest wasteheat aquaculture project.

title: Study Says Moscow Uses More Military Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3  The growth of Soviet military power has made the Kremlin more willing to use its armed forces as a diplomatic instrument, according to a study prepared for the Defense Department.

title: Frederic Strikes Leeward Islands
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 3 (AP)  Hurricane Frederic lashed Guadeloupe and other Leeward Islands with strong winds and driving rain today.

title: Around the Nation
description: SOUTH PADRE ISLAND, Tex., Sept. 3 (AP)  Rain and cloudy skies left the beaches of South Texas nearly deserted today, dashing hopes for recouping tourist dollars lost to the world's largest oil spill.

title: Taxes
description: THE first anniversary of the residential energy tax credit is fast approaching, and it appears that the writeoff has proved immensely popular. The Internal Revenue Service has released statistics showing that the credit was claimed by about 7 percent of the taxpayers, or some six million of the 88 million who filed 1978 returns. A total of $600 million, or an average of $100 per return, was claimed.

title: Coast Court Rules Insane Person May Not Be Held to Be a Suicide
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 3 (AP)  In a ruling that could affect numerous insurance policies, a state appeals court has ruled that an insane person cannot be said to have committed suicide. The court said such a person cannot form the intent to take his own life.

title: Consumer View Worsens in Study
description: Fewer than 10 percent of American families expect business conditions to improve over the next six months, according to the latest monthly survey of consumer confidence by the Conference Board, a business research organization.

title: Westinghouse Strike Ending as Union Ratifies Pact
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 (AP)  Some 18,000 employees of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, off the job for seven weeks, overwhelmingly ratified a new threeyear contract yesterday, and most are expected to return to work tomorrow.

title: Kissinger Tones Down Warning to NATO on U.S Nuclear Pledges
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 3  Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger sought today to clarify a warning that he delivered here Saturday that Western Europe could no longer believe America's pledge to defend it with nuclear weapons against a Soviet attack.

title: Japan's Premier Calls for Tax Rise And Big Cut in Use of Imported Oil
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3  Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira called today for higher taxes to offset a huge budget deficit and for drastic cuts in the use of imported oil.

title: Michael A. Peppe, 81, Swimming Coach at Ohio State 32 Years
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 3 (AP)  Michael A. Peppe, who led Ohio State University's swimming team to 11 National Collegiate championships in his 32 years as coach, died yesterday after a long battle against cancer. He was 81 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: Two of Europe's smaller countries, usually overshadowed in bridge terms by their powerful neighbors, achieved their best performances in the recent European championships in Lausanne, Switzerland. Denmark, which usually plays second fiddle?? in Scandinavia to the strong Swedish squad, placed second behind Italy and had an excellent chance to win the title in the final hour of a 12day tournament.

title: Jamie Marie Ball Is Bride of Andrew Laurence Hope Robertson
description: Jamie Marie Ball, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Ball 2d of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Andrew Laurence Hope Robertson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hope Robertson of Skelmorlie, Scotland. The ceremony was performed at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn., by the Rev. Edward Howley of St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien.

title: Critic's Notebook Of the Proscenium Arch and How It Affects Dance
description: WATCHING dance performances night after night, one not only thinks about dancing, one also starts thinking about the theaters in which the dancing takes place. Over the years. I've observed certain things about theaters for dance  about proscenium theaters for dance, to be specific.

title: About New York
description: New York is one of the most exciting cities in the world, and the tourists who throng it are privy to its everintriguing, everchanging personality. They must often have the impression that New Yorkers are caught up in a spectacle of sight and sound and smell that constantly titillates.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1979

title: Bronxville: The PublicSchool ShangriLa
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y. Sept. 3  Mary Alice Guinee, about to begin her 16th year of teaching what the highschool seniors here call difficult math, is contemplating making it more difficult  by adding instruction in computer science.

title: Market Place
description: While the shares of many leading banks have risen sharply in recent months, some believe that they are still cheap  and this may include Europeans interested in acquiring banks here.

title: Borg and Gerulaitis Reach Quarterfinals
description: The war of survival continued in the United States Open tennis championshins yesterday. even for Biorn Bore.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: ALMOST as if to celebrate the 20th birthday of his first book, Goodbye, Columbus, Philip Roth has given us a beautifully intricate novel that fulfills the promise of those early stories.
