Indeed, the 23yearold hero of The Ghost Writer,' Nathan LUCkerMan, might as well be the author of those stories, so much does he resemble the young Roth trying to break out of the spiritual ghetto of his middleclass NewarkJewish upbringing and seeking in the person of an older writer who resembles a cross between Bernard Malamud and Isaac Bashevis Singer, the love and approval to sustain him in his Dedalean flight. But an older, mature Roth is in command of the narrative here  a Roth who knows when to curb his deadly tongue for parody, who restrains his bent for outlandish comedy and Kafkaesque hallucination, who senses when to be ironic and when to let pathos speak for itself  and that makes all the difference.

title: Maryland Jockey Dies
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 3 (UPI)  Kenneth Plchette, a 35yearold Jockey, died at the University of Maryland Hospital yesterday of injuries incurred in a spill at Timonium Race Course last Tuesday.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Ruth Niese, Radiologist Once Aided Marie Curie
description: Ruth Halstead Niese, one of the first women to practice as a radiologist in the United States, died Friday at Orange Memorial Hospital, Orange, N.J., of a heart attack. She was 82 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J.

title: Strike Voted, FilmIndustry Talks Set
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 (AP)  With the first industrywide strike in more than 30 years a definite possibility, leaders of the film industry's major technical and craft unions plan to meet with film producers representatives on Wednesday.

title: Orioles Flanagan Wins 20th Game
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 3 (AP) Mike Flanagan became the first 20game winner in the major leagues as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Toronto Blue Jays, 51, today and completed a doubleheader sweep.

title: Accusations Threaten BritishIrish Talks
description: LONDON, Sept. 3  On the surface, the British and the Irish are treating each other with elaborate politeness as both attempt to recover from the shock of the killing of Earl Mountbatten of Burma.

title: In Detroit, the Workers and Academe Unite
description: DETROIT FOR years, business administration departments of major colleges and universities have been training a steady supply of leaders for the nation's industries. Perhaps less obvious has been higher education's expanding contribution to the labor movement.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: Deaths

title: The NonVolunteer Army
description: Signing up for the draft, said Daniel Ellsberg at a recent California rally, is like signing up for the KoolAid at Guyana. Such grim wisecracks may or may not make it harder for the United States to get involved in another Vietnam. What is clear is thatsuch attitudes might make it hard for the country to defend itself even in a war that the whole country recognized as necessary. The problem is that the volunteer army, prescribed as an alternative to the draft, is not working. There aren't enough volunteers.

title: Body of Mountbatten Rests in English Abbey
description: ROMSEY, England, Sept. 3 (UPI)A Royal Navy honor guard carried the body of Earl Mountbatten of Burma past hundreds of mourners today into the medieval church where he will be buried later this week.

title: Carnivorous Beetle Works at Museum
description: THE tiny room is dark, humid and maintained at 85 degrees. The odor is overwhelming, and visitors are advised to wear a mask to keep from inhaling the dust of decaying matter. The thousands of employees who work in the room, however, are content, plying their trade round the clock, only the occasional illumination of a lightbulb distracting them from their task.

title: Commodities
description: AS the nation's biggest industry, agriculture, prepares to shatter production records for the fifth consecutive season, commodity market analysts have become fascinated by a new farm development this year:

title: Increasing Costs May Dilute Suburban School Programs
description: GREENWICH, Conn. Sept. 3  Public schools in the suburban areas of New York City will open this week amid growing anxiety that budget constraints rooted in inflation and taxpayer uneasiness, and intensified recently by the energy crisis and new state aid formulas  are slowly eroding the quality of their programs.

title: Street Fairs Mix Unionism and Hoopla
description: Expressions of union solidarity meshed with all the customary attractions of New York City street fairs yesterday, providing some city dwellers who stayed close to home this weekend with a taste of organized labor on Labor Day.

title: Notes on People
description: Only once a year, on Labor Day, are pedestrians allowed to walk across the fivemilelong Mackinac Bridge over the Straits of Mackinac that connects the Upper Peninsula and the Lower Peninsula in Michigan. Making the trip across the bridge on foot has become quite a tradition in those parts. The first walker across yesterday was Gov. William G. Milliken, who in his 11th annual straits stroll made the trip in 63 minutes, far off his record.

title: 8th Ship Fire Victim Dies
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 3 (UPI)  A 20yearold tug boat worker who was critically burned last week in an explosion and fire aboard the Peruvian cargo ship Inca Tupac Yupanqui has died. Kenneth Lotz, who died in the intensive care unit of East Jefferson Hospital, became the eighth fatality of the Aug. 30 accident on the Mississippi River at Good Hope, La. The Coast Guard also said that a body found floating in the river this weekend had been identified as Carlos Rios, 23. Mr. Rios, the ship's third mate, had been counted as missing and presumed dead in the fire.

title: A Financing Plan for the Alaskan Segment
description: A tentative financing plan for the Alaskan portion of the Alaskan naturalgas pipeline has been submitted by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. to the Alaskan Northwest Natural Gas Transportation Company, the consortium of gastransmission companies responsible for that segment.

title: Pretoria Rugby Stadium Is Permanently Integrated
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 3 (AP)  Local authorities have decided to open a rugby stadium, site of a coming World Boxing Association heavyweight title fight, to all races permanently.

title: Obituary 7  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Saturn: Discovery and Disappointment
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Sept. 3 As Pioneer 11 sped away from Saturn today, away from the giant moon Titan and out of the Saturnian magnetic sphere, scientists reported that pictures taxen by me spacecraft revealed a heretofore undetected gap between two of the brightest rings circling the planet.

title: Steelers Defeat Patriots
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. 3  Matt Bahr's 41yard field goal in the sixth minute of overtime enabled the Pittsburgh Steelers to defeat the New England Patriots tonight. 1613. Bahr's kick concluded a final Steeler drive of eight. plays covering 45 yards that came after New England had failed on its first offensive sequence of the overtime period.

title: Yanks Will Let Dent Go Free
description: Bucky Dent, who had not made up his mind about whether he would become a free agent at the end of the season, has apparently had it made up for him.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PHOTOGRAPHIC ROOTS In its guide booklet, the Commission for Cultural Affairs lists 115 New York museums. Some, of course, are traditionally sedate; and none is much more sedate tnan the 55yearold institution at 29 East 36th Street, in Manhattan's Murray Hill section, the Pierpont Morgan Library, formerly the home of the financier and his son.

title: TV: NBC Revives White Paper Series
description: WITH the backing of a single sponsor, the Weyerhaeuser Company, NBC News is reviving its White Paper series. The first twohour production is No More Vietnams, but . . . , an examination of the connections between oil and American power. It can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock.

title: Canada's New Premier Proffers Friendly Hand to Hostile Quebec
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 3  Prime Minister Joe Clark, who came to power in May at the head of his Progressive Conservative Party against the wishes of the great majority of Quebec's voters, has since been trying to woo them and establish a power base in the Frenchspeaking province.

title: Disaster Help Arriving At the Stricken Islands
description: Despite an almost total absence of information by telephone from the Dominican Republic and Dominica, disasterrelief assistance teams and supplies from the United States Government were arriving at the hurricanestricken islands yesterday. Meanwhile, American voluntary agencies that operate projects in the Dominican Republic were seeking news of their personnel there and of what part private agencies could play in relief plans.

title: Big Computer Sector Prospers
description: For more months than most in the business would like to remember, most of the announcements concerning the dataprocessing industry have been singularly depressing.

title: Thevis Trial Entering 3d Week
description: ROME, Ga., Sept. 3 (AP)  The trial of Michael Thevis, the Atlanta pornographer now accused of racketeering, enters its third week tomorrow. Defense attorneys are expected to try to damage the testimony of a key Government witness who has testified that he saw Mr. Thevis last fall in a wooded lot in Atlanta where key witness against Mr. Thevis was slain.

title: StormBattered Dominican Cities Digging Out the Hundreds of Dead
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 3  Rocks filled main streets and roofs jutted from the flooded Ozama River as the Dominican people began digging out hundreds of bodies and cleaning up some of the devastation left by Hurricane David.

title: French Are Accelerating Nuclear Power Program
description: PARIS, Sept. 3 (Reuters)  France has begun assembling the world's first commercial fast breeder reactor and is stepping up its overall nuclear energy nroeram to beat the oil crisis.

title: Ontario Debenture Issue To Test a Weak Market
description: The highlight of the current week in the bond market will be $300 million of 30year debentures to be issued by the Province of Ontario and underwritten by a grout) led by Salomon Brothers.

title: New Books
description: Quest for the Best, by Stanley Marcus (Viking, $12.95). Insider's view of the retail business by former chairman of Neiman Marcus department store.

title: New Hampshire Tanker's Oil Spill Now Estimated at 25,000 Gallons
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 3 (UPI) What was first thought to be a tiny mess in the Piscataqua River turned out to be a 25,000gallon oil spill that has blackened 10 miles of shore in New Hampshire and Maine, the Coast Guard said today.

title: China Negotiating On Credit Cards
description: PEKING, Sept 3, (Reuters) The credit card is coming to China. Western banking sources today said that China was negotiating with some United States banking organizations on the use of credit cards in the People's Republic.

title: Gold Breaks $320 Level
description: LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP)  The price of gold jumped $8 today, breaking through the $320anounce level for the first time. The closing price in London was $323.15 a troy ounce. In Zurich, it was $322.875.

title: Advertising
description: THEY are often at the very bottom of national ads. They are on direct mail. They crop up on warranty cards. Some of them are scribbled on such remote places as batteries tucked under the hoods of trucks or cars. You see them only when the battery dies.

title: Hurricane Can't Budge 27 Diehard Drinkers
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla., Sept. 3 (AP)  Most of the 13,000 residents of this island community south of the nation's space center fled inland today before the arrival of Hurricane David, but thestorm did not deter 27 diehard drinkers at an openair bar on the beach.

title: Affirmed Assigned 133 for Marlboro
description: ELMONT, L.I., Sept 3  Affirmed received the top weight of 133 pounds today, nine more than Spectacular Bid, for Saturday's Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park. Lenny Hale, the racing secretary who assigned the impost, said, I don't see how Laz Barrera can complain about it, but he will.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: VWEast German Barter
description: LEIPZIG, East Germany, Sept. 3 (Reuters)  East Germany is interested in further shipments of Volkswagen cars in exchange for goods, following deliveries of 10,000 Golf models in 1978, a VW spokesman said today. The Golf is similar to the car known as the Rabbit in the United States.

title: Profit Increase In Japan Seen
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3 (Reuters)  Profits before tax and special items for Japanese manufacturing concerns in the first half, April to September, of fiscal 1979 are expected to rise 27.5 percent from the comparable 1978 period following an increase in production and sales, the Bank of Japan said today in its survey report.

title: GEORGE MOONEY, 67, BANK OFFICIAL, DIES
description: George A. Mooney, a former New York State Superintendent of Banks and retired chairman of the Washington Federal Savings and Loan Association, died yesterday following heart surgery at New York University Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 187 Puritan Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, and in Northville, L.I.

title: Festival of Independents' Films Slated
description: Six independently made American feature films that have not been released, as well as nine independent films that have enjoyed distribution, will be shown at the American Independents festival at the Paramount Theater, 2 Gulf and Western Plaza, from Sept. 22 to Sept. 27.

title: Engine Runs Wild Upstate
description: If ever there was a little engine that could, this one was it.

title: When a Civil Rights Group Backs the P.L.O.
description: Letters

title: LIST OF U. S. BOOKS AT ISSUE IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3  The following books apparently were confiscated by Soviet authorities today:

title: Bullets in Manila
description: MANILA, Sept. 3 (AP) The Washington Bullets of the National Basketball Association arrived today for an exhibition game against a Filipino professional team.

title: Shows Leadership
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept.3 The Philadelphia Eagles kept knocking him down; Joe Pisarcik kept getting up. In the end, Pisarcik did not win yesterday's opener for the Giants, but his display of courage in rallying his teammates may have helped save their season.

title: Inverness Is Winner In Vineyard Yacht Race
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 3  Bob McCullough's Inverness, one of the nautical graybeards of the fleet, today was declared the winner of the Vineyard Yacht Race on corrected time.

title: 1,216Page History Of Human Events
description: The People's Chronology: A YearbyYear Record of Human Events From Prehistory to the Present, a history that stresses human rather than political achievement, will be published Sept. 14 by Holt, Rinehart and Winston at $27.95. In 1,216 pages, the book covers more than 30,000 happenings, on a yearly basis, and includes a 49page index.

title: Business to Fill TV Void Inflation to Be First Topic
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI)  The United States Chamber of Commerce will begin producing its own television talk show next weekend, in competition with the interview programs on the three networks each Sunday.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Concerto a Cinque in G, Tartini; Das Echo, Suite for Two String Orchestras, Haydn; Artist's Life, J. Strauss; Two Sinfonias a tre, Stradella.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Ashland Petroleum Company, Ashland, Ky., has named Charles J. Luellen executive vice president, Charles M. Russell group vice presidentadministration, James E. Fout group vice presidentwholesale and retail marketing of light petroleum products, Billy W. Davis group vice presidentsales of heavy oil products and Sam S. Watson group vice presidentproduct supply, distribution and transportation operations.

title: Brazil Sets Historic Plan To Redistribute Income
description: In a historic move last week, the Brazilian Government acted to redistribute income toward the country's lowestpaid workers, whose share of the national wealth has steadily worsened in 15 years of military rule.

title: Soviet Union Seizes More Books From American Exhibits at Fair
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3  Soviet officials continued to weed out books from the American exhibits at the Moscow International Book Fair today and defended the action as the highest affirmation of freedom of speech.

title: Pipeline a Challenge to Wall St.
description: The proposed Alaskan natural gas pipeline, a giant project that would help alleviate the shortage of energy by carrying the fuel from Alaska across Canada to the lower states, is proving to be both a nightmare and a dream to Wall Street financiers.

title: Typhoon Strikes Southern Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3 (Reuters)  A typhoon with winds up to 55 miles an hour struck southwestern Japan today, disrupting sea and air services, the Meteorological Agency said. Weathermen said that the typhoon, codenamed Ken, was a weak one and had hit the southern tip of Kyushu, the southernmost of the main islands.

title: Vote Set Today in Race For Hunter College Chief
description: A new president is to be chosen today for Hunter College, and the contest between the two leading candidates is said to be close.

title: Boy, 11, Killed in Jersey City Park
description: An autopsy conducted yesterday established stab wounds of the abdomen as the cause of death, according to the police, who said they had a couple of good leads as to who had committed the crime.

title: Boise Looking to Its Hot Springs As a Heat Source for Downtown
description: BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 3 (AP)  The Gleans of Boise pay only $10 a month to heat their twostory, Tudorstyle home with natural steam and hot water.

title: Psychologists Advance Theories Of Sex Development
description: WHEN women are given sex hormones to treat mild pregnancy complications, the hormones can affect the sexrelated behavior of the children born to them, a study has concluded. From age 8 to 14, according to the research, boys may behave in a less masculine way and girls may be more feminine.

title: Flight From Laos
description: The author of the following article, who often writes on Southeast Asian matters and covered the Vietnam War as a reporter and photographer for several newspapers and magazines, recently returned to Connecticut from Thailand.

title: Can a Museum Have Too Much Money? The Getty May; Interest Is Paid
description: MALIBU, Calif. I' M one of the few museum directors in the country whose board is not looking over his shoulder to check attendance figures, said Stephen Garrett, the Englishborn architect who directs the J. Paul Getty Museum here. And indeed, although visitors are by no means unwelcome at the sumptuous Pompeiian villa built in the early 1970's by the late J. Paul Getty, officials feel no pressure to pack them in by such measures as, say, blockbuster shows. Endowed by Mr. Getty with $750 million worth of stock in his Getty Oil Company, the museum will, after some lawsuits delaying settlement of the estate are resolved, be the nation's  if not the world's  most monied art institution.

title: 10% Growth Rate Expected for Money
description: The outlook is for further tightening of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy this month because the nation's money supply is expected to continue to rise at an unacceptably swift pace, according to Lacy H. Hunt, senior vice president and chief economist of the Fidelity Bank.

title: Juan Prez Alfonso, Venezuelan, Regarded as Founder of OPEC
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP)  Juan Pablo Perez Alfonzo, the man widely regarded as the founder of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, died today. He was 75 years old.

title: Science Watch
description: A team of Canadian geologists who dove into caverns more than 147 feet below sea level in the Bahamas found stalagmites that were deposited 160,000 to 139,000 years ago when the caves were above sea level.

title: Open Fun: Nastase in Mixed Doubles
description: Jeff Green and his 15yearold daughter, Beth, staked out their seats in the court 5 bleachers early. They kept up to date on the scores from the stadium as other fans came and went. Meanwhile, they avidly watched a series of doubles matches.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) Roman Catholic, Jewish and Protestant spokesmen have joined in condemning as blasphemous a movie produced by the British satirical group known as Monty Python.

title: Miss Washam Rebounds And Wins Rail Golf Classic
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 3 (UPI) Jo Ann Washam turned in a fiveunderpar 67 today to forge past Silvia Bertolaccini and win the $15,000 first prize at the $100,000 Rail Charity Golf Classic.

title: CARTER HAILS LABOR AND RENEWS HIS BID FOR ENERGY MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3  President Carter told more than 1,000 labor leaders at the White House for a Labor Day picnic tonight that they had been in the forefront in all the enlightened social progress for which we have struggled.

title: Dalai Lama Arrives for Tour of U.S.
description: The Dalai Lama of Tibet flew to New York yesterday from Zurich and was greeted by hundreds of admirers at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Little Progress Reported At G.M.Union Meeting
description: DETROIT, Sept. 3 (UPI)  Bargainers for the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers labored today to resolve various technical contract issues, but no significant progress was reported. Work on those issues is being carried out by subcommittes from the two bargaining teams.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Anthony J. Amendola has been elected president of the Pabst Brewing Company, the nation's fourthlargest brewer. He succeeds Frank C. DeGuire, who was named to the vacant position of chairman and who remains chief executive officer.

title: Kurdish Rebels Flee Stronghold As Iranians Drive Through Lines
description: MEHABAD, Iran, Sept. 3  Iranian troops aided by jet fighters, helicopter gunships and tanks pushed through defense lines outside this Kurdish insurgent stronghold today, and the main guerrilla force and most of the city's inhabitants withdrew into the surrounding hills.

title: Dominicans Seeking Water Amid AfterStorm Repairs
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 3  Ybelca Hidalgo, 14 years old, painfully scooped at the small pool of clear water seeping upthrough the sand at the edge of the muddy, swollen Yaque del Norte river as it flowed through Santiago today.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Taping of Happy Fella Stirs Shubert Opposition
description: In a departure for the Broadway theater, Sherwin M. Goldman, whose revival of The Most Happy Fella is scheduled to open Oct. 11 at the Majestic Theater, plans to videotape a live performance of the show Sept. 16. when it will be playing in Detroit, for a national telecast. The tape will be shown on the Public Broadcasting Service, probably next spring, as part of WNET's Great Performances series.

title: Auto Insurers Reacting to Adversity
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 3  After three profitable years, the highly cyclical automobile insurance business is going into a downturn. According to management textbooks, car insurers should protect themselves in such situations by seeking rate increases, avoiding new business, tightening up on policyholder renewals and slashing administrative expenses.

title: OBSERVER ByeBye, Silver Bullets
description: The Lone Ranger is through. Washed up. He stands in a Los Angeles law office. Oriental rugs under foot. A Kandinsky on the wall. The desk rich and sleek, covered with writs, injunctions, habeas corpus, mandamus, certiorari, nolo contendere, duces tecum, bills of attainder.

title: The Region
description: EASTCHESTER N.Y. (AP)  The Westchester County police said they had charged a 35yearold man with bribery for allegedly offering a police officer $100 to forget about giving him tickets for driving while intoxicated and speeding.

title: The City
description: Gold jewelry valued at $100,000 was taken in a burglary at a midManhattan jewelry store over the Labor Day weekend, the police said.

title: Japan Mourns Lan Lan, Who Conquered Public
description: TOKYO, Sept. 4  For days, all Japan waited anxiously as a team of veterinary surgeons from Tokyo University labored around the clock to save the life of Lan Lan, the ailing female giant panda at the city's Ueno Zoo.

title: The Crescent of Confusion
description: In dealing with Iran, the United States is like a gambler with a fistful of chips who can'ft decide whether to bet black or red. Even a small bet  like the shipment of kerosene and heating fuel to oilblessed Iran  can misfire. That shipment of 2 million barrels, intended as a goodwill gesture, will apparently be resold at a profit. Thus the Carter Administration ismade to look foolish in its attempt to win friends and warm hearths in the Ayatollah's domain.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: JACK A. FINKE

title: Bronx Man Is Indicted In Mailman's Shooting
description: A suspect in the July 21 shooting of a Manhattan mailman has been indicted with five other defendants on charges of robbing mailmen to obtain master keys for letter boxes.

title: Police Learn Identity Of a Suspect in Killing At Parade in Brooklyn
description: The police said yesterday they had identified a suspect in the slaying of a man, believed to be an innocent bystander, who was felled by gunfire exchanged by two men during a sidewalk dispute Monday night at Brooklyn's West Indian American Day Parade.

title: Holiday Inns to Buy Harrah's
description: Holiday Inns Inc. has agreed to acquire Harrah's, a Nevadabased casino and hotels operation, in a transaction valued at about $300 million in stock and cash.

title: Consumers, Unions and Elderly Plan Drive to Cut Energy Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI)  Consumer, labor and seniorcitizen groups said today they would hold nationwide rallies next month to protest against President Carter's energy program and what they termed his puny effort to help the poor deal with high fuel costs.

title: Carter Appeals for Help On Hospital Costs Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI)  President Carter appealed to 300 community leaders today to help win Congressional passage of his bill to hold down medical costs, saying the measure would cut the price of an average hospital stay $500 by 1984.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadiurn, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (Television  Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio WINS, 8 P.M.)

title: N.Y.U. Law Professor to Teach on Coast via TV
description: Morton I. Hamburg, a member of the New York law firm of Netter, Dowd & Alfieri, will be teaching again at the New York University School of Law this fall, as he has for the last seven years. But he will also be teaching, for the first time, at the McGeorge School of Law at the University of the Pacific, some 3,000 miles away in Sacramento, Calif.

title: Expansion Blocked, Aspen Institute Is Leaving Its Namesake City
description: DENVER, Sept. 4  The Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies announced today that it was carrying out its longthreatened move to pull most of its programs and activities out of the mountain resort town that gave the institute its name. The move, to the Baca Grande Ranch, 40 miles north of Alamosa, Colo., was prompted by an unsuccessful sixyear zoning fight with the strongly environmentalist Aspen City Council.

title: Live Shows Pack Amusement Parks
description: LOS ANGELES HOW do amusement parks from Disneyland in California to Disney World in Florida  make customers come back after they've ridden Space Mountain, Pirates of the Caribbean, the Great American Revolution or Rolling Thunder three times?

title: South Africa Oil Plan May Be Hard to Sell
description: SECUNDA, South Africa, Sept. 4 (Reuters)  Oil from coal: that idea, simple in concept but complex and costly to realize, is one that South Africa has pursued since 1955. .

title: Seoul's G.N.P. Growth Slows
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 4 (AP) South Korea's gross national product rose at an inflationadjusted 11.4 percent annual rate in this year's first half, down from 16.9 percent a year earlier, according to an estimate by the Bank of Korea released today.

title: Careers
description: THE desire of many young people to start and operate their own businesses never dies. In fact, it may be thriving these days as never before, despite talk of recession, a paucity of new ideas and other depressants.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Teacher Strikes May Affect Nearly 50,000 Jersey Pupils
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Sept. 4  Most of the 1.3 million public school youngsters in New Jersey will find their teachers in the classroom when they report for the first Clay of school tomorrow, but almost 50,000 pupils here, in nearby Perth Amboy and in Paterson are likely to find their teachers on picket lines outside.

title: Texaco Signs Pact In Angola
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a contract with the state oil company of Angola for exploration and production of oil in the former Portuguese colony in southwestern Africa.

title: TITO, IN CUBA, BIDS THIRD WORLD AVOID TIES TO BIG POWERS
description: HAVANA, Sept. 4  President Tito of Yugoslavia urged third world nations today to maintain their independence from the superpowers and warned that foreign influences were trying to divide them.

title: Chrysler Canada Pay Cut
description: WINDSOR, Ontario, Sept. 4 (Reuters)  Chrysler Canada Ltd. said today that about 85 of its executives had their salaries cut, effective Sept. 1. The company said that the reductions were as much as 10 percent and that they would be in effect for up to two years.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THERE I was, writes Linda Neukrug, having a hot dog in Nedick's on 34th and Sixth when a sweet little Spanish lady came up and asked, Habla espanol?

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP)  A Federal district judge ruled today that shipments of used nuclear fuel from Europe could continue to arrive in Portsmouth. Va., over the objections of antinuclear groups and some local residents.

title: U.S. and East Germany Conclude Consular Agreement on Access
description: EAST BERLIN, Sept. 4 (Reuters)The United States and East Germany signed a consular agreement today after nearly two years of negotiations, the East German cress agency reported.

title: Iran Shuts Associated Press Operation Over Coverage of Kurdish Unrest
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 4 (UPI)  The Iranian Government today ordered The Associated Press to close its Teheran bureau and to withdraw its four correspondents, accusing the agency of presenting a distorted picture of unrest in the Kurdish region of the northwest.

title: New Storm Hampers Efforts to Aid Stranded Dominicans
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 4  A new storm threat hampered rescue efforts here today as officials struggled to get relief to thousands of Dominican residents who have been stranded on hilltops without food or medical supplies since Hurricane David struck this Caribbean nation four days ago.

title: The Patriots Had Game for the Asking, but the Steelers Won
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. 4  The Pittsburgh Steelers have lost only 18 of 84 football games over the last five seasons, and the time to catch them is when they are hurt, distracted or unlucky.

title: Whitney To Display 190030 Art
description: Tradition and Modernism in American Art, 190030 will open at the Whitney Museum next Tuesday, to run through Nov. 11. The exhibition covers the years when Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney was the most active patron of American art, before she founded the Whitney Museum of American Art in 1930, and it examines the popular attitudes of traditionalism and modernism at the time.

title: Soviet Pentecostals Meet Illegally and Form Council
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 4  The Soviet Union's Pentecostals have stepped up their struggle with the Government by holding an illegal meeting and founding an underground council, according to a spokesman for the fundamentalist sect.

title: U.S. Auto Output Off 27.9% in Month
description: DETROIT, Sept. 4 (UPI) United States auto makers produced 27.9 percent fewer passenger cars in August than in the same month last year, with the Ford Motor Company reporting the largest decline.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS More Means Less
description: In affluent societies, contemporary inflation is an ailment of extravagant group expectations and inadequate political responses to them. Although Americans take rueful pride in the outstanding ineptitude of their Presidentand Congress, both more and less competently led nations are faring little or no better.

title: A Dictionary of How Just Plain Folks Talk
description: MADISON, WIS. WHEN a man marries, depending on where he lives, he is headed for a variety of peculiar fates. He's about to hop the broomstick in Indiana, hook up double in New York, jump the puddle in Alaska, throw the switch in Massachusetts, get buckled up in Connecticut, get hung in Michigan, take on a boarder in Oklahoma, go up the middle aisle in Pennsylvania, head for the last roundup in Wyoming  or simply get hitched, as Americans say from coast to coast.

title: All Airlines Can Seek 9.5% Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4  The Civil Aeronautics Board, in a clarification of a policy announced Friday, said today that all airlines could apply for a fare increase of a full 9.5 percent to cover higher fuel costs.

title: Qaddafi, an Arab Leader Seeking Followers
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept. 4  The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, moving to fill a leadership void in the Arab world after Egypt's settlement with Israel, has started a fresh effort to get the other Arab nations to rally around Libya and adopt a more aggressive stance against Israel.

title: Still Recalling Conn
description: The filly was so fast, Conn McCreary couldn't understand why Steve Judge worked her openly in the mornings when everybody on the race track could clock her and spread the word. The result was thatwhen she made her first start she was 4 to 5, not the sort of price to attract a bettor like Steve Judge. Holdher, the trainer said when he hoisted McCreary into the saddle.

title: Poor Image of India Called a Bar to Trade
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 4  A negative image of India in the developed nations is inhibiting trade between India and the United States, participants in a conference of scholars here have suggested.

title: Where Les Halles Stood: Culture Center and Shops
description: PARIS, Sept. 4, (Reuters)  Mayor Jacques Chirac today opened a giant underground shopping and cultural center on the site of Les Halles, the former fruit and vegetable market that was one of the French capital's most famous landmarks.

title: Q&A; Scungilli (Conch) Salad
description: Q. I was reading an English novel dealing with manners and mores of the 19th century. Mention was made of a lavish dinner in a grand banquet hall and the principal dish was a baron of lamb. What is it?

title: College on L.I. Opens Campus
description: PATCHOGUE, L.I., Sept. 4 (AP)  St. Joseph's College opened its new Patchogue campus today, welcoming more than 200 freshmen and transfer students. A picnic supper for all 400 students registered in the college's school of arts andsciences was the final event of the orientation day. Classes begin tomorrow. The new St. Joseph's campus was formerly Seton Hall High School. The college had been using rented quarters in Brentwood.

title: Acting President Named at Hunter After a Deadlock
description: The Board of Trustees of the City University of New York was unable to agree yesterday on a new president for Hunter College and named Dr. Joseph Shenker, the president of Fiorello H. La Guardia Community College in Long Island City, as acting president.

title: Some Refugees Safe at Home In China Again
description: BEIHAI, China, Sept. 2  When Liu Sou Fong was 7 years old and growing up in this coastal harbor village, fear and freedom were linked to what was happening to the north and south of here.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Cash Prices

title: Koosman Wins On TwoHitter
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 4 (UPI)  Jerry Koosman allowed two hits  a oneout homer by John Wathan in the sixth and a twoout single by Willie Wilson in the ninth  and gainedhis 18th victory tonight as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Kansas City Royals, 51.

title: Police in Ulster Arrest 10 Reporters Interviewing AntiBritish Activists
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 4The police moved in on reporters interviewing antiBritish political activists this morning and arrested 10 persons, including Pierre Salinger, a television correspondent who once served as President John F. Kennedy's press secretary.

title: Stocks Post Sharpest Drop of 79
description: The stock market plunged 15.02 points yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average registered its biggest oneday drop since Dec. 18, 1978, when the index fell 17.84 points.

title: U.S. Moves to Keep Arguments on HBomb Article Closed to Public
description: The Government moved yesterday to have oral arguments before a Federal appeals court in The Progressive magazine case closed to the public to avoid the risk of inadvertent disclosure of sensitive data by counsel or the court. The magazine is under a Federal District Court order not to publish an article about the hydrogen bomb:

title: A State Senator Asserts Bankers Cheat on Loans
description: State Senator Thomas J. Bartosiewicz of Brooklyn has charged banks in New York State with swindling borrowers of $40 million a year in overcharges for credit insurance.

title: Business Stake Abroad to Rise
description: United States companies plan to increase the dollar value of their capital investment outside the country 23 percent this year to $32.9 billion, McGrawHill Inc.'s McGrawHill Publications Company said.

title: Oil Diversions to Europe Tied to U.S. Price Curbs
description: Texaco Inc., one of the largest United States oil companies, earlier this year diverted 65,000 barrels a day of petroleum products from its Caribbean refinery to the highly profitable European spot market and raised American prices, Energy User News reported yesterday.

title: Rookie Race Driver Dies
description: CARSON, Calif., Sept. 4 (AP) Mark Munroe, a 24yearold racing driver from Sun Valley, Calif., died early today at Harbor General Hospital from head injuries suffered in a crash yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allied Farm Equipment Inc., Chicagobased distributor and manufacturer of specialty farm implements, has elected Carl E. McNair president and chief operating officer.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: During the time she worked as a wardrobe consultant, Rita de Rosa found that an instant way to change the mood of an outfit was with a hat. When hats returned to the fashion picture, Mrs. de Rosa decided to turn milliner and make hats with an extra fillip. Her friend Rebecca Goodrich makes vermeil jewelry in California. The two young women have joined forces, and the results are jeweled hats whose ornaments may be transferred to another hat or redesigned as pins. The shapes are basic: fedoras, toques, pillboxes, berets. What individualizes them are the ornaments  a band of vermeil leaves on a brimmed hat, for instance; or silk and vermeil flowers on a veiled toque, or a whoosh of feathers on a pillbox swathed in veiling. The hats are $50 to $200 in Bloomingdale's balcony hat department, or they can be custommade by Mrs. de Rosa. Her number is 6799007.

title: Americans Protest Curbs as Soviet Book Fair Opens
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 4  The second Moscow International Book Fair opened here today, but the chairman of an organization of American publishers said his group might consider boycotting future fairs unless the Soviet authorities stopped keeping out publishers they did not like and stopped censoring exhibits of foreign books

title: Florence King, ExHead Librarian At Wellesley College, Dead at 80
description: Florence Louise King, former head librarian at Denison University and Wellesley College, died Sunday at a nursing home in Elmira, N. Y. She was 80 years old.

title: Church Delays Arms Pact Hearings To Study Soviet Troop Use in Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4  Senator Frank Church, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, announced today that hearings on the nuclear arms treaty would be postponed so his committee could deal immediately with reports of Soviet combat forces in Cuba.

title: UpperIncome Users Spur Cocaine Dealing
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4  Increasing demand for cocaine among middle and upperincome Americans is fueling an illicit, newly whitecollar trade that may exceed $15 billion a year, law enforcement officials say.

title: Floridians Return Home
description: MELBOURNE BEACH, Fla., Sept. 4 Thousands of evacuees streamed back into this and other Atlantic beach communities today to find that their towns had escaped the death and heavy property damage that marked Hurricane David's passage through the Caribbean islands.

title: Wheeling Steel Lifts Prices
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4 (UPI)  The WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation announced price increases today on tin mill products, effective Oct. 1. A company spokesman said the price increases would be equal to those previously announced by other major steel producers but declined to provide details of the new price schedule. Last week, other producers announced increases averaging about 6 percent.

title: Market Place
description: AFILIATED PUBLICATIONS INC., best known as the publisher of The Boston Globe, flourished in the stock market last week and, in a rousing market for newspaper shares, the activity suggested to some that Affiliated might be for sale. It is not.

title: Avnet Net Up 66% in Quarter
description: Avnet Inc., engaged in electronic components, home entertainment and highfidelity products, reported yesterday that it had profit increases of 66 percent for the quarter ended June 30 and 38 percent for the full fiscal year.Simon Sheib, chairman and president, said annual sales exceeded $1 billion for the first time.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The price of gold soared to records yesterday, and traders foresaw no quick end to the gold rush that has pushed the price of an ounce of the precious metal up by nearly $100 since the beginning of the year.

title: Events
description: THE FIFTH MUSKETEER, directed by Ken Annakin; starring Sylvia Kristel and Beau Bridges, at the Victoria and other theaters.

title: Aquaculturists Envision Lobster Ranches and Salmon Ranges
description: MONTROSS. VA. Here, in 10 algaecovered ponds laid out like a giant crossword puzzle, 100,000 tiny eels are lazing away the summer under the hot Virginia sun, eating menhaden fed them like pig slops in barnyardstyle troughs and growing fat for the flight from New York to Amsterdam that will land them, as delicacies, on European tables.

title: Strikes by 20,000 Teachers Delay Beginning of School in 11 States
description: More than 12,000 public school teachers from Oregon to New Jersey went on strike yesterday, joining 8,000 of their colleagues who had already walked out, disrupting the start of fall classes for pupils in 11 states. In most of the disputes, the issue was money.

title: Nathaniel Sorkin, Judge Since '55
description: Judge Nathaniel Sorkin of the New York City Civil Court died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Giant German Concern Weighs Bid for Belridge
description: BONN, Sept. 4  Veba A.G., West Germany's largest company, which is 43.75 percent Governmentowned, said today that it was considering joining the bidding for the Belridge Oil Company.

title: 12% Broker Rate Is Set by Chemical
description: The Chemical Bank yesterday raised the rate it charges brokers to finance their customers margin accounts to 12 percent from 12 percent. Most other major banks continued to post a 12 percent rate for these secured credits.

title: NASA's Failure to Alert Russians Caused Loss of Saturn Moon Data
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Sept. 4 Because the National Aeronautics and Space Administration failed to alert the Soviet Union to its plans, radio interference from a Soviet satellite orbiting the Earth unintentionally drowned out the transmission yesterday of crucial data from Pioneer 11, the space agency announced today.

title: Military Signs Up For FastFood Era By Updating Chow
description: LOOKS like rain. Yeah, but the mess sergeant swears it's coffee. This ancient wheeze, which was probably a kneeslapper in the Mexican War, reflects the traditional skepticism with which the serviceman approaches his chow. Nevertheless, the Defense Department is once again making an effort to improve the food.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Mean Aluminum Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing the price of aluminum ingot by 2.5 cents a pound, to 60.5 cents a pound, effective today. The increase is the maximum allowed under the Carter Administration's wageprice guidelines.

title: Suffolk Poverty Unit to Lose Aid
description: The Federal Community Services Administration said yesterday it would cut off funds sent to the principal antipoverty agency in Suffolk County, the Economic Opportunity Council, because of the continuing abuses and lack of accountability that characterize its fiscal and administrative systems.

title: PleaBargaining Ban Is Clogging Courts in New Haven, State Says
description: STAMFORD, Conn. Sept. 4  An eightmonth moratorium on plea bargaining in criminal cases in the State Judicial District headquartered in New Haven has produced the largest backlog of cases a year or more old in any judicial district in the state, according to the state's chief court administrator.

title: 2 Youths Held In the Burning Of Cross on L.I.
description: The Nassau County police arrested two 17yearold youths yesterday afternoon in connection with a crossburning incident last Saturday on the lawn of a home in East Meadow, L.I., where a retired black postal worker rented a room.

title: Best Buys
description: AT last, a flour manufacturer has realized that some Americans love to bake bread. Although professional bakers have always had access to the special highgluten bread flours that improve the texture and rising of bread doughs, until now home bakers have been limited to allpurpose versions used for pastries as well as breads.

title: For Brooklyn's Civil Court
description: Next Tuesday, Democrats in Brooklyn will pick eight candidates for Civil Court judge to run in the general election in November. At least two Democrats are running for each vacancy. The ballot may be confusing because six vacancies are listed as countywide, meaning that all Brooklyn voters will decide their nomination, while two vacancies are districtwide,meaning that only voters in the Third or Sixth Districts will vote for them. The Third District consists mostly of Williamsburg and Bushwick. The Sixth is usually identified with Park Slope.

title: Queens Woman Is Accused On Care of Former Patients
description: Queens detectives yesterday arrested former employee of Creedmoor Psychiatric Center who has allegedly run a network of private homes where community groups said former mental patients lived illfed, poorly clothed and neglected.

title: STUDENT LOSS SLOWS IN CATHOLIC SCHOOLS
description: Roman Catholic parochial schools in New York City will start reopening today for about 211,000 students. While the figure is slightly below last year's, it still reflects the belief of many educators that the great decline in parochialschool enrollments has tapered off.

title: Real Estate
description: BUFFALO THE nice thing about a city like this of a few hundred thousand persons, Larry Quinn, the city's director of development, ob served recently, is that projects are doable. There's no trouble getting access to the mayor. Projects are visible and make a tangible difference.

title: U.S. Use of Oil Held 1.1% Less
description: PARIS, Sept. 4 (Reuters)  Oil consumption has fallen in the United States since the beginning of last year but has risen in Japan and leading European industrialized countries, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

title: John Cromwell, Actor In Broadway Theater
description: John Cromwell, an actor and playwright, died Saturday in London after a brief illness. He was 65 years old and lived in New York and Amagansett, L.I.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1979

title: Homer E. Capehart Is Dead at 82; Was 3Term Senator From Indiana
description: Homer E. Capehart, a forceful and consistent opponent of the Roosevelt and Truman Administrations who served three terms in the United States Senate, died Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Indianapolis. He was 82 years old.

title: Misunderstood McEnroe?; Ice Cream to Celebrate
description: John McEnroe Sr. passed an apprehensive afternoon in his Manhattan law office anticipating his son's next match at the United States Open. Mr. McEnroe was not afraid that John would lose to Tom Gorman. He was not afraid that John would make a scene on the court. Mr. McEnroe's only fear was that there would be a repeat performance of last Thursday's match against Ilie Nastase when a stadium full of fans thundered their disapproval of his eldest son.

title: News of the Theater Shakespeareans Visit At MakeorBreak Stage
description: THIS is the week when it will be decided whether Britain's Royal Shakespeare Company will come to Broadway this winter. The whole thing is totally dependent on theater commitments. says Alexander H. Cohen, the producer who wants to bring the company here in late January. If we can't make the proper arrangements for theaters in the next peek, it won't happen.

title: A Lunar Eclipse To Begin at Dawn.
description: The earth's shadow will fully eclipse the moon tomorrow at dawn, but residents of the New York metropolitan area will see only part of a celestial spectacle that awed their ancestors.

title: Books: Martin Bormann, Hitler's Obedient Servant
description: THE names of the functionaries and fellow criminals around Hitler begin to fade in the mists of memory, obscured by current crimes in countries with dictators. Who was convicted at the Nuremberg trials after the war? Who disappeared and was tried in absentia? Who is still known to live under the protection of some sympathetic South American regime  saved from extradition because the statute of limitations has run out in Germany?

title: Schools Are Reopening For Most in City Area
description: Between today and Monday nearly all of the schoolchildren in public, private and parochial schools in the New York area are expected to report to classes

title: SARDINIA ENDURING RASH OF KIDNAPPING
description: ROME, Sept. 4  Just as Italy's embattled police finally seem to be making headway in their fight against the political terrorism that has troubled the country for several years, a new and frustrating challenge confronts them.

title: Building Up 2.4% in July
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP)  New construction in July rose 2.4 percent to an annual rate of $230 billion, the Commerce Department reported today. The increase in June was sixtenths of 1 percent.

title: Napoli Bribery Charge Dropped
description: Bribery charges against James Napoli, a reputed organized crime figure, and Joseph Tuseo were dismissed yesterday by Justice Richard Denzer in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Mr. Napoli and Mr. Tuseo had been charged with paying ajail official to get special treatment for Mr. Napoli during a contempt sentence. In his ruling, the judge said the evidence did not show that any future conduct had been agreed upon. Both are still charged with rewarding official conduct.

title: Private Lives
description: THE children demanded to know what I had done with their tape recorder, the very same tape recorder they had taken with them into the garden the other night. The other night was a victim of a sleepover party. The sleepersover decided to oversleep in the garden, on the sun deck, under the hovering mug. They refuse, of course, to go anywhere, even to the bathroom, with3ut their music, and so they stuffed their music into the tape recorder, and at 2 o'clock in the morning, as lay on my rack reviewing my many crimes against intelligence and decency, the garden was full of the sound of Mick Jagger, who is not my fault, although the neighbors who telephoned to animadvert seemed to think he was.

title: Bridge:
description: In almost all bridge situations the right strategy is to play steadily and wait for the opponents to make mistakes. But there are some rare circumstances in which it is right to swing wildly from the rafters, seeking action at any cost. suppose you are playing in a sevendeal Swiss team match, and the only consideration is winning or losing. In the first two deals you have bid to good slam contracts that have been beaten by bad breaks, and you feel sure you are far behind in the match.

title: Dalai Lama, in U.S., Doubtful Exile Will End Soon
description: The Dalai Lama, who numbers his Tibetan Buddhist followers at about six million, said yesterday in a midtown news conference that some contact had been made with Chinese leaders in recent months. But he said he doubted that he would return soon from exile in India to his mountain homeland.

title: Film Institute Plans National Conference
description: The American Film Institute will conduct a threeday event next month that will feature public symposiums and convocations with film and television professionals. Billed as the institute's first annual National Conference on Film and Television, it will be held Oct. 1114 at the SheratonUniversal Hotel in Los Angeles.

title: Boy Dies as Bus Is Struck
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (UPI)  A school bus was struck on the side by a car at a South Side intersection today, killing a 4yearold boy and injuring 10 other persons. Ronald Colwell apparently fell out a window of the bus as it tipped over and was crushed underneath, the police said.

title: China Jet Fuel to Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 4 (AP)  The Nichimen Company, one of Japan's major commercial houses, said today that it had signed a contract to import jet fuel from China. The contract signed with the Chinese National Chemicals Import and Export Corporation called for China to ship 6,000 tons, or 50,300 barrels, of jet fuel a year, a Nichimen official said. It was the first jetfuel deal concluded between Japan and China, the spokesman said.

title: Books of The Times
description: SALLY HEMINGS was the quadroon slave with whom Thomas Jefferson lived for 38 years. He seduced her when they were in Paris and she was the very young servant of his daughter Polly. He had many children by her. Quite possibly she was the person in the world who knew him best. She ran his house in the country. Thanks in part to his teaching and in part to her own quite exceptional capacities, she grew up to be wellinformed, well spoken in both French and English, and a good judge of people. She was never intimidated. When she chose, she was the bestlooking and the bestdressed woman in the room. But she never sat down at Jefferson's table when guests were present. She went to Washington only once, and by stealth, during his Presidency. And he never freed her.

title: Soviet Buys U.S. Grain
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI)  The Agriculture Department reported today that private exporters had sold another 555,000 metric tons of corn and 525,000 tons of American wheat to the Soviet Union. The sale brings to 15.46million tons the total amount of grain sold to the Russians for the third year of a fiveyear United StatesSoviet grain agreement. A metric ton equals 2,204 pounds. All of the corn and most of the wheat were reported previously as having an unknown destination. A portion of the wheat was previously reported bound for China.

title: 29 Films By Emigres Scheduled
description: Twentynine American films, made between 1924 and 1956 by Germans who had emigrated from their homeland, will be the subject of a threemonth retrospective, German Film Directors in Hollywood, at Goethe House, 1014 Fifth Avenue. The retrospective willbegin on Sept. 20, with a screening of Ernst Lubitsch's 1939 Ninotchka.

title: The NotSoNew Nouvelle Cuisine
description: NO culinary movement has ever earned so much fame so quickly as France's nouvelle cuisine. Although the new cooking was christened by the French food critics Henri Gault and Christian Millau 10 years ago, it had already been developing for at least 10 years before that. Now, as this gastronomic revolution begins to take hold on our shores through the rapidly increasing number of restaurants and cookbooks that follow its dogma, an evaluation seems in order.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: IF prophets are without honor in their own country, there's probably good reason for it. A decade ago, the prophets were convinced that weddings were on the rocks, that with the stigma of living together removed, marriage would soon be as extinct as courtships in hammocks. So what happened? Weddings jumped right back into the big time.

title: 2 Lawyers Face a Bar Inquiry on Mock Subpoena of Koch
description: Two lawyers who issued a mock subpoena demanding that Mayor Koch appear at a Bronx Hospital face possible disciplinary action as a result of a complaint filed by the Mayor with the grievance committee of the New York City Bar Association.

title: Chairman of Mays Fined in Bribe Case
description: Max L. Shulman, board chairman of the Mays Department Stores in New York, was fined $20,000 for trying to bribe an Internal Revenue Service agent.

title: Mistrial Ruled in Tennessee's CashforClemency Case
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 4 (AP)  Over defense objections, a judge declared a mistrial today in Tennessee's clemencyforcash trial, which has been delayed for a month by another judge's illness. Today's ruling ordered a new trial Oct. 22 before a new jury.

title: Dance Festival: Potpourri in the Park
description: THE New York Dance Festival's Monday night program mixed ballet, modern and ethnic dance together. Yet, although the dance forms may have been disparate, the items presented on the stage of the Delacorte Theater in CentralPark had one thing in common: they were all virtuoso showpieces.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Death

title: Expos Defeat Mets, 51
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 4  Two former Mets, recently returned to Montreal, came back to haunt New York today in a 51 victory by the Expos.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Silver futures surged to more than $11 an ounce today, while interest rate futures toppled on evidence that the nation's central bank has once again tightened credit.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Notes on People
description: Edward Kosner, who was suddenly replaced last June as editor of Newsweek magazine, has signed on as a fulltime consultant with the ABC network. His duties, according to a network spokesman, will be to formulate story and content suggestions for ABC's weekly magazine, 20 / 20;  its nightly news program, and its coverage of the 1980 political campaigns. National politics was one of Mr. Kosner's areas of specialty at Newsweek for much of his 16 years there.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: REED MAN There was a time when children, perhaps most often boys, received harmonicas as gifts on one occasion or another. Some boys got more harmonicas than trains during a childhood. In proportion to the number of kids with harmonicas there were very few role model harmonica players and many children never produced any logical arrangement of sounds with their mouth organs. But to adults it always seemed right somehow to give a child a harmonica as a toy. In fact, when Larry Adler, who is usually pointed out as the world's best player of this 150yearold reed instrument, was making between $45,000 and $85,000 a year in the 1940's, he was not a member of the American Federation of Musicians. The union regarded the harmonica as a toy.

title: New Round On Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4  Congress returns to work here tomorrow, facing a heavy load of energy legislation that is likely to keep its members busy for most of the rest of the year.

title: Perry Leaves Padres
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 4 (UPI)  Gaylord Perry, who has won more games than any other active pitcher in the majors, said today that he was quitting the San Diego Padres immediately and hoped that a deal could be worked out so that he could return to the Texas Rangers.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Sept. 4,1979

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: LIKE most professional chefs, I tend to pride myself on my ability to detect the ingredients of almost any dish set before me as well as being able to recreate it in fairly accurate detail within the confines of my own kitchen. Perhaps I should qualify that: I am speaking generally of foods of the Western world. In some preparations, much of the cooking of the Far and Middle East is infinitely more complex, and many of the ingredients are  for better or for worse  foreign to my Western palate.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE 1970's are coming to an end, and 1984  the year of George Orwell's totalitarian nightmare for the industrial countries  is only half a decade away. The true function of the prophet is not to predict the future but to warn against and ward off its horrors. In that sense, Orwell was a successful prophet, as was Julien Benda who, in The Treason of the Intellectuals, published half a century ago, prophesied that humanity would be unified in one immense army, one immense factory, would be aware only of heroisms, disciplines, inventions, would denounce all free and disinterested activity, would long cease to situate the good outside the real world, would have no God but itself and its desires.

title: Tremor Shakes Portugese Area
description: LISBON, Sept. 4 (Reuters)  An earth tremor shook a farming area south of Lisbon last night, but no damage was reported, the National Geophysical Institute said today.

title: This Unlikely Cook Earns His Wings In the Kitchen
description: STAMFORD, CONN. THERE has been a notion of long standing in my mind that I can tell from a person's occupation whether or not he is likely to be a good cook. In the likely category, I would include doctors, lawyers, actors, painters, musicians and, stretching the Point a bit, baseball players.

title: Israelis Cheer Sadat as He Arrives In Haifa on Yacht for 3Day Visit
description: HAIFA, Israel, Sept. 4  Under the protection of American, Egyptian and Israeli naval vessels, President Anwar elSadat of Egypt cruised into this Israeli port today aboard the Presidential yacht for a threeday visit.

title: U.S Puts an Embargo On All Canada Tuna After Vessel Seizures
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP)  The United States announced today that it has prohibited imports of tuna and tuna products from Canada in a conflict over fishing rights in the Pacific Northwest. A spokesman said the Government was considering expanding the embargo to other fish.

title: Young Backs Caliber's Nomination As Borough President of the Bronx
description: Calling for a return to the balanced ethnic ticket that he said was a Democratic party tradition, Andrew Young urged yesterday the nomination of Joseph L. Galiber for Bronx Borough President.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Byrne Calls for Aides to Justify Continued Use of Confidential Car Plates
description: TRENTON, Sept. 4  Hundreds of New Jersey officials and employees are driving cars with license plates that cannot be traced through normal channels, and Governor Byrne has asked department heads to justify the continued use of the cars by them and their subordinates.

title: $45 Million Offer Due By Bemis for Shares
description: The Bemis Company announced an offer yesterday to buy back as much as 1.5 million of its shares, or about onethird of the total outstanding, for $30 a share.

title: The Art Of Trussing A Chicken
description: 1. Begin by placing the chicken's legs at an angle perpendicular to the counter, forcing downward to expose breast fully to heat. Push the needle into the chicken at the base of the thigh bone diagonally so that it emerges through the opposing leg at a point where the meat of the leg and thigh join.

title: TV: As Men See Breaking Up Merry Wives of Windsor To Be Put on Videotape
description: BREAKING Up Is Hard to Do is a fourhour televison movie contending that it's different. Exploring the muddied terrains of marriage and divorce, the producers, Jim Green and Allen Epstein, are concentrating not on the woman's but on the man's point of view, hoping that the film will allow men to understand that they needn't be afraid to express their feelings.

title: Affirmed Is Out of Marlboro
description: Affirmed was withdrawn yesterday from the Marlboro Cup race at Belmont Park on Saturday.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Rates on United States Treasury bills, the most liquid shortterm securities, exceeded 10 percent yesterday for the first time as the Federal Reserve appeared to signal another move to make money still more expensive to borrow.

title: Turmoil for LongHaul Movers
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 4  The country's longdistance movers, not yet recovered from an earnings pinch in 1978, are now having to cope with what promises to be the most troublesome year in their history.

title: 2 South African Women Detained After a Flight Into Mozambique
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 4 (Reuters)  Mozambique authorities arrested two South African women whose light aircraft made a forced landing there over the weekend, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: BoatBuilding Yards Are Struck
description: BOSTON, Sept. 4 (AP)  The 320strong production force at Boston Whaler's two boatbuilding plants in Norwell and Rockland, Mass., struck today, shutting down the assembly line at the motorboat plant. Members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 653 walked out after contract negotiations broke down, according to Gerald Gross, local president. The current contract expired Friday.

title: 41,155 See Cauthen Ride in New Jersey
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. Sept. 4  To the strains of Yankee Doodle Dandy, the Meadowlands pulled 19yearold Steve Cauthen out of its promotional hat tonight and came up with a recordbreaking winner.

title: Solomon Ousted, Miss Austin Wins
description: The road to the quarterfinals was fraught with danger at the United States Open tennis championships yesterday, especially for the seeded players.

title: Traveler's Check Ad: Dj Vu?
description: The people who issue First National City traveler's checks have been extremely miffed at the people who issue American Express traveler's checks for recent TV commercials. The ads, the First National people groused, were unfair because they implied that it was difficult for stranded travelers to get refunds for lost checks if they were not those of American Express.

title: Rohatyn Weighs Offer To Stay in M.A.C. Post
description: Governor Carey is reported to have asked Felix G. Rohatyn to stay on as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation and not resign as planned at the end of this month.

title: U.N. Checks Report of Employee Bugging Rights Office in Geneva
description: GENEVA, Sept. 4 (AP)  The United Nations is investigating reports that a senior United Nations employee tapped a phone at the United Nations Division of Human Rights, a spokesman said today.

title: Jews, Blacks and Affirmative Action
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J.  The ouster of Andrew Young as United States delegate to the United Nations has precipitated a confrontation between blacks and Jews, but it is not its cause.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Objects from 10 Smithsonian Institution museums will be brought together for the first time Outside Washington in a major exhibition to be held at the CooperHewitt Museum, Fifth Avenue and 91st Street. The exhibition, Smithsonian, will begin Oct. 16, with sections to open as they are installed. The entire show will remain on view through Jan. 6.

title: ExProsecutor Is Hired In Jordan Drug Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, has hired Henry Ruth Jr., a former Watergate special prosecutor, to represent him in the Federal investigation of an alleged cocaineusing incident, according.to sources close to the investigation.

title: Suffolk's First G.O.P.Primary Is Dividing the Party
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.  The Islip Town Supervisor marched into the Suffolk County Executive's office here the other day looking for an argument.

title: Havana Parley: Long on Oratory and Maneuvering
description: HAVANA, Sept. 4  The tenor of the summit meeting in progress here was summed up today by Singapore's Foreign Minister, Sinnathamby Rajaratnam. The veteran diplomat said the parade of orators reminded him of thestory about the lawyer who got up in court and said, Now, gentlemen, let me tell you the opinions on which my facts are based.

title: Mondale Informs Carter Ties to China Are Strong
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (Reuters)Vice President Mondale told President Carter today that on his 10day visit to China he had found ChineseAmerican relations to be in excellent condition.

title: Transit Dispute Cripples Traffic in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4  Heavy commuter traffic into the city from East Bay communities clogged the San FranciscoOakland Bay Bridge today while the rapid transit tubes were shut down in a labor dispute. The shutdown was the latest of a series of blows to this city's commuter traffic.

title: France Asks Swiss to Extradite Suspect in P.L.O. Aide's Murder
description: BERN, Sept. 4 (Reuters)  France has asked Switzerland to extradite a young Lebanese held in Bern on suspicion of having taken part in the murder of Zuheir Mohsen, a leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, at Cannes in July, the Justice and Police Department said today.

title: WASHINGTON An Unhappy Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4  This is not a happy or even a purposeful city at the end of the summer and the beginning of the 1980 Presidential election. It faces fundamental questions of principle and public policy both at home and abroad, but it is thinking primarily about the coming struggle for control of the White House and the congress.

title: Texas Cleric Is Promoted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP)  Msgr. Joseph A. Fiorenza, chancellor of the Roman Catholic diocese of GalvestonHouston, has been appointed by Pope John Paul II to be Bishop of San Angelo, Tex., the National Conference of Catholic Bishops announced today. The 48yearold monsignor succeeds Stephen A. Leven, who resigned in April.

title: American Pixy a Hit on Japanese TV
description: TOKYO, Sept. 4  Wherever 6yearold Barony Clark goes in Japan, heads turn her way and voices murmur, Ah, Banychan! It is the same when she is home in Hawaii, where she is often surrounded by surprised Japanese tourists.

title: Trussing: Key to Properly Cooked Fowl
description: WHEN I was a 14yearold apprentice some decades ago at the Drouant in Paris, I was allowed to have only three tools: a paring knife, a vegetable peeler and a trussing needle.

title: U. N. Food Conference Opens With a Gloomy Report
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 4  With more hungry people than ever in the world, the World Food Council, an arm of the United Nations General Assembly, began a conference here today aimed at increasing food production and improving distribution to those most in need.

title: Percival Borde, Dancer, Teacher, Choreographer
description: Percival Borde, the dancer, choreographer and teacher, died of a heart attack Friday during a performance at the Perry Street Theater, where he was appearing with his wife, Pearl Primus. He was 56 years old.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: In Moscow, Da Replaces Nyet
description: WASHINGTON  Running through Red Square one morning, passing St. Basil's cathedral, I was surprised when a militiaman near the Kremlin smiled and tipped his baton in my direction. He knew I was an American.Moscovites do not jog through Red Square at 6 A.M. in faded Tshirts and old running shorts. Russians prefer the parks and almost always wear blue warmup suits. But this friendly salute from the haughty, normally stiff militiaman was only one of several changes I noticed in a city I've known well for the last six years.

title: Economic Problems Beset North Korea
description: TOKYO, Sept. 4 (AP) After a threeyear depression that hit bottom in 1977, North Korea's economy is showing some improvement. But Japanese officials say there is little hope for economic development in the Communist nation without a sharp change in policy and a great deal of outside help  both of which are considered highly unlikely.

title: Manufacturers Supported on Risk in Transbus Bids
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4  An independent panel of researchers selected by the Carter Administration to study Federal policies on standards for new buses said today that bus manufacturers had been correct in not bidding on contracts to build the proposed Transbus.

title: HURRICANE STRIKES THE GEORGIA COAST AND SOUTH CAROLINA
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 4  Hurricane David smashed into the GeorgiaSouth Carolina coast this afternoon, then headed inland toward the capital city of Columbia, S.C., after lashing Savannah,1 Ga., and the barrier islands near the two states border with winds of 70 to 90 miles, an hour.

title: Mayor Supports Delay Of Bronx Power Plant To Permit More Study
description: New York City favors another delay in a proposal for a garbage and coalburning electric plant in the Bronx, Mayor Koch said in a letter to Governor Carey released yesterday.

title: Vouching for Justice
description: Once again the Carter Administration is showing itself determined to misinterpret one of the main lessons of Watergate: incumbents cannot credibly investigate themselves. The latest example involves the investigation of alleged intercession on behalf of Robert Vesco, a fugitive sought to face charges of criminal financial fraud. It is true that a special prosecutor is not legally required here. But would it not be good politics, as well as good government, to appoint one?

title: Ghana's Military Council Reports Civilian Rule Will Return Sept. 24
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 4 (Reuters)Ghana's ruling Revolutionary Council has announced that civilian rule will be reinstated in the country on Sept. 24, a week earlier than planned, the Ghana News Agency reported.

title: Nuclear Agency's Shift on Safety Issue Stirs Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4  One week after the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear reactor, the Government issued a safety bulletin identifying a decision to turn off one set of pumps as one of the maior causes of the accident. The Government ordered utilities to keep at least some of these pumps operating should a similar accident develop in one of their reactors.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Edgar Fosburgh Kaiser Jr., the thirdgeneration scion of the international industrial empire founded by Henry J. Kaiser, faces his most difficult task as a result of his appointment last week as president and chief executive officer of the troubled Kaiser Steel Company. The 37yearold executive has no illusions about what lies ahead.

title: British TaxLaw Change A Boon to U.S. Concerns
description: LONDON, Sept. 4  The British Government, not known for generosity to stockholders, has enacted a law with substantial potential benefit for American investors.

title: S.E.C. Pact By Buckley Associates
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4Norman C. Francis and Mack H. Hannah Jr., two former directors of the Starr Broadcasting Group Inc., today settled charges brought against them and a fellow director, William F. Buckley Jr., by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: ELSA MINER

title: Corning Ads Warn Of Faulty Coffeepots
description: In a series of newspaper advertisements scheduled to run next Monday throughout the country, Corning Glass Works Inc. will ask consumers to stop using the company's 18.5 million coffeemakers because they may have defective handles, a Corning spokesman confirmed yesterday.

title: FRANK H. BEREND, 81, LEADING FUND RAISER
description: Frank H. Berend, founder and chairman of Frank H. Berend & Associates Inc., of New York City and Beverly Hills, Calif., died Saturday, in his office at the Beverly Hilton Hotel, apparently of heart attack. He was 81 years old and lived in New York and Beverly Hills.

title: Bonn Aide Rejects Idea Of Joint Atomic Forces
description: BONN, Sept. 4  West Germany's Defense Minister, Hans Apel, today ruled out any consideration of a joint FrenchWest German nuclear force that could undercut Europe's reliance on the American nuclear deterrent.

title: The Region
description: Samuel G. Fredman announced yesterday that he would not seek another term as Westchester Democratic leader, citing reasons that sounded more like those of an insurgent than a party leader. It's because of my frustration at my inability to penetrate the political process and the governmental pro cess, he said.

title: Belridge Rides OilPrice Boom
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4  As John Elliot Cook, a lawyer, tells the story, the founders of the Belridge Oil Company were land speculators.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson Faculty Declines Final Pay Offer
description: Faculty members at Fairleigh Dickinson University as well as at two New Jersey colleges voted yesterday to reject final offer contract terms and gave their negotiating teams authority to call strike unless settlements were reached before the beginning of classes today.

title: Judge Voids U.S. Sale Of Guns at Discount To Rifle Association
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI)  A Federal district judge struck down as discriminatory today a program under which the Defense Department has sold hundreds of thousands of surplus guns to members of the National Rifle Association at a big discount since 1905.

title: Wine Talk
description: A LOT of space is allotted here to California wines and judgings of them. There is good reason to do so. Of every 10 bottles of wine we consume in this country, at least seven come from that state. What's more, it is arguable that, bottle for bottle, California consistently produces the best wines made in this country.

title: Geoffrion To Coach Montreal
