description: Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion, a member of hockey's Hall of Fame and one of the most colorful players of his time, was appointed yesterday to the job he had coveted for a dozen years: coach of the Montreal Canadiens, theclub that gave him his start in the National Hockey League. The contract, whose financial details were not disclosed, runs for three years.

title: Pacers Set to Sign Ann Meyers
description: The Indiana Pacers are expected to announce today the first signing of woman by a National Basketball Association team.

title: Survey Charges Schools Remain Male Strongholds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) America's educational system, seven years after a landmark law to end sex discrimination in the schools, remains a male stronghold when it comes to advancement opportunity, the National Organization for Women charged today.

title: Personal Health
description: IN the 1950's, women  inspired by widely publicized reports of a new lifesaving technique  succeeded in changing the practice of medicine by demanding that their doctors do Pap smears to detect cervical cancer. In the 1970's. women started agitating for another change in their care: the treatment of breast cancer, an increasingly common disease that will be detected in some 106,000 women in the United States this year.

title: Japan Is Not Invited to Lord Mountbatten's Funeral
description: LONDON, Sept. 4 (AP)  Japan will not be represented tomorrow at the funeral of a World War II foe, Earl Mountbatten of Burma, apparently at his express wish, a Japanese diplomat said today.

title: Koch Seeks Private Employment For CETA Workers Losing Jobs
description: Mayor Koch will urge officials of a number of large companies today to provide jobs for 2,000 city employees who are paid with Federal funds but are to be dismissed at the end of the month.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Metropolitan Report yesterday incorrectly reported the number of teachers and other employees in the public schools of four suburban counties. The correct totals are Nassau, 17,502; Suffolk, 19,199; Westchester, 10,534, and Rockland, 3,417.

title: Summer's Farewell: The Sun and Solace
description: One of the best ways to face up to the end of the vacation season and the beginning of the work season . . . and of school . . . and of evenings when it starts to get dark by suppertime .. and of the realization that, inevitably, it will be February one of these months. . . one of the best way is to lie flat on your back and look up at the whoosh of the fountain at the tip of City Hall Park and think of the good things that were.

title: The City
description: A total of 237 felonies were committed in the city's subways last week, according to the latest statistics reported by the Transit Police chief, Sanford D. Garelik, to the Mayor's office. It marked a decrease from the 251 felonies the previous week, the highest total since patrols were augmented on March 19.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1979

title: 5Nation Talks On Economy
description: LONDON, Sept. 4 (AP)  Finance ministers and central bankers of five major industrialized nations will discuss the world economy and international monetary system in a Paris meeting scheduled for Sept. 16, informed sources said today.

title: Citicorp Sells Notes
description: Citicorp sold $150 million of 91day notes yesterday at an average rate of 11.680 percent, up from 11.363 percent a week ago and the highest rate since the bankholding company began itsweekly auctions last September. There were $647.24 million of bids, and Citicorp accepted those with interest rates ranging from 11.30 percent to 11.75 percent, including 25.5 percent of those at the high rate.

title: Memoirs of a TeenAge Beauty Queen
description: EACH year when the Miss America Pageant rolls around, I tune in with bemused curiosity. The women's movement hasn't made a dent in the pageant. I'm told that there was a decline in the number of participants on the local level in the early 1970's, but 80,000 girls now compete nationwide. I have mixed feelings about the pageant and its smiling, manicured contestants. I know something about these things.

title: Chess:
description: Tigran Petrosian, the former world champion, won the 1979 Paul Keres Memorial Tournament in Tallinn, in the Soviet Republic of Estonia, with a score of 124. Mikhail Tal, another former world champion and the winner of the first Keres Memorial in 1977, shared second place with Grandmaster Rafael Vaganian, one of the leading Soviet representatives of the younger generation. Each tallied 114.

title: Advertising
description: GIMBELS, which acknowledges that it has had some difficulty defining precisely who its merchandise is aimed at, believes it has finally worked things out and has stocked the store with goods directed at the middlelevel New Yorker. So it is ready to start telling people as much, and it will initiate next Sunday what maintains is the largest advertising and promotion effort in its history.

title: Rabbit Photo Is Kept Secret
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI)  Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, said today that the photograph of a rabbit attacking President Carter's canoe in Georgia in April would not be made public. We're afraid if we release the photo, the rabbit controversy over the next two weeks will receive more ink than the SALT treaty, Mr. Powell told reporters.

title: Husband Pleads in Trespassing
description: SALEM, Ore., Sept. 4 (AP)  John Rideout, acquitted last December on a charge of raping his wife, pleaded guilty today to trespassing in her apartment. The misdemeanor offense, punishable by up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine, was separate from the rape charge.

title: Address Unknown
description: Of course we've all been poring hopefully over the advertisements that the city's banks have been placing in newspapers listing the names and addresses of accounts that have languished. These ads appear every year about this time. But one of the odd things about them is how often address unknown appears.

title: Steel Output Rises by 1.4%
description: Steel production rose to 2.6 million tons in the week ended Sept. 1, up 1.4 percent from the previous week's 2.5 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: World Gold
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1979

title: Iran's Troops Take Control of Kurdish Rebel Center
description: MEHABAD, Iran, Sept. 4 (UPI)Scores of Iranian Army tanks entered this former Kurdish rebel center today and took up positions abandoned by Kurds yesterday after Government forces broke through the city's defenses on both the north and the south.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: CHARLTON WALLACE

title: Canadian Banks Merge
description: The merger of the Bank Canadian National and Provincial Bank of Canada was approved yesterday by shareholders of the two banks, but is subject to approval by the Canadian Cabinet under the Canadian Bank Act. Managements of the bank, however,expect the merger to become effective about Nov. 1 under the new name of the National Bank of Canada. Their combined assets on July 31 totaled $15 billion. The chairman of the new bank will be Germain Perreault, now chairman and chief executive of Bank Canadian National. Michel Belanger, president and chief executive of the Provincial Bank, will hold those posts with the new bank.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Sept. 4 (UPI)  The Government extended martial law to cover all but one of the country's black rural areas today and turned down a British request for the release of political prisoners so they could attend peace talks starting Monday in London.

title: 2 Groups Plan Postdoctoral Awards for Minorities
description: The Ford Foundation and the National Academy of Sciences yesterday announced formation of a $1.6 million Minority Postdoctoral Fellowship Program aimed at increasing the number of blacks, Hispanic persons and American Indians in prestigious advancedstudy and research programs.

title: New Drug Law Brings Pleas To Reduce Prison Sentences
description: Sterling Johnson Jr., New York City's special narcotics prosecutor, said yesterday that his office had been deluged with applications for reduced prison sentences under a new drug law that cuts prison terms for narcotics offenders.

title: What County Executives Do
description: New York's county executives are much like mayors, directing increasingly centralized governments for counties that, before the suburban boom, worried mostly about the roads, the sheriff and the poorhouse.

title: Yankees Win
description: Luis Tiant, who defected from Boston to New York as a free agent, defeated the Red Sox last night for the first time in 10 seasons. Mike Torrez, who defected from New York to Boston as a free agent, lost to the Yankees for the sixth time in seven decisions since making his move nearly two years ago.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: N.B.A.'s Raggedy Ann
description: Now that the Indiana Pacers have signed Ann Meyers a contract that will guarantee her $50,000, if not 50,000 bruises, male chauvinists are howling that going up for a rebound in the National Basketball Association is not woman's work. But the essence of the challenge confronting this former Olympic and allAmerica player is not that she is a woman; rather, it is that the top of her hairdo is only 5 feet 9 inches above the soles of her sneakers and that she weighs only 135 pounds. In the physical matchups of the N.B.A., sheis a Raggedy Ann doll among dinosaurs, a tulip among redwoods. Nobody who is 59 and 135 is capable of competing in the N.B.A.  be it man, woman or robot. In the decades to come, a wonder woman will emerge as a useful player in the N.B.A., butshe is likely to be 66 and 195 with the strength and stamina to survive in an exhausting game with an exhausting schedule. At only 59 and 135, the Pacers rookie guard is not much bigger than the pile of headlines she has produced as the Susan B. Anthony of the N.B.A., but perhaps the publicity is worth $50,000 to Sam Nassi, the Pacers new owner.

title: Hers
description: WHEN Popi lets herself in the front door, I can tell something good has happened just by the sound of her footsteps. If the door closes quietly, I'm in for a barrage of mutinous mutterings because the bus was crowded or her husband didn't come home all night. But today her new shoes click smartly down the hall and she calls the children, who tear into her pockets in search of the gum they know is there.

title: Disks: Baryton Trios Haydn Wrote for Patron
description: THE baryton was a curious hybrid, with the body of a bass viol but with a set of wire strings running underneath the principal gut strings. The wire strings resonate when the gut strings are bowed, but they can also be plucked from below (the wide neck has a hole in it for that purpose). The result is that, with doublestopping, threepart harmony can be played.

title: Dalgety: Bon Apptit on Coast
description: SAN MATEO, Calif.  Peter Gardiner, chairman and president of the American arm of Dalgety & Company, the British agribusiness concern, sums up his business strategy in a little slogan. Dalgety, he said, wants to be positioned between the farm gate, the restaurant door and the supermarket floor.

title: Bonn Picks Foreign Ministry Aide To Be Its New Washington Envoy
description: BONN, Sept. 5 (UPI)  The Foreign Ministry announced the appointment of Dr. Peter Hermes as West Germany's new Ambassador to the United States today. The 57yearold Dr. Hermes has been State Secretary at the Foreign Ministry since 1975. He has represented West Germany in many trade talks since 1965, including those with the Soviet Union and China.

title: An Army Discharge Is Upgraded After 2Decade Fight by Veteran
description: When James A. Long, a 41yearold Brooklyn letter carrier, opened his own mailbox on a recent day, he found a large brown envelope, which, as he later recalled, sent him into a state of total excitment.

title: DATA LONG IMPLIED SOVIET UNITS IN CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  The United States intelligence community has been receiving reports indicating the presence of Soviet combat units in Cuba for at least eight years, highranking Administration officials said today. But only in recent weeks did intelligence officials tentatively conclude that the troops were an organized combat force.

title: Advertising
description: IT'S a completely different breed of cat than consumer advertising, Van Evans was saying at the Manhattan offices of Deutsch, Shea and Evans. The type of job a person takes is much more important to people than the brand of toothpaste they brush with or the model car they tool around in. You need a serious creative approach. Forget gimmicks.

title: Dance: London Critics Divided on City Ballet
description: LONDON, Sept. 5  The New York City Ballet returned to London for the first time in 14 years last night, receiving a warm reception from its audience at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden.

title: Designer's Assistant: Not Quite His
description: WHEN you spend all day taking care of other people's design problems, you don't have the time or you just don't feel like working on your own place, said Peter Maase, who has been an assistant to Joseph Paul D'Urso, the minimalist designer, for about a year.

title: Environment Is Erudite As Psychologists Gather
description: More than 13,000 people were in New York City this week to attend the symposiums, addresses, discussions and sessions at the 87th annual convention of the American Psychological Association. It was not what most conventioneers would call a good time.

title: McEnroe, Gerulaitis Get Davis Cup Singles Berths
description: John McEnroe and Vitas Gerulaitis will represent the United States in singles against Argentina in the American Zone final of the Davis Cup next week in Memphis, Tony Trabert, team captain, said yesterday.

title: David Spins Off Tornadoes And Aims for the Northeast
description: By The Associated Press

title: Dismantling of Petrocan Draws Protest in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 5  The new ProgressiveConservative Government began the process of dismantling Canada's national oil company today by announcing that a significant proportion of its assets would be returned to the private sector.

title: U.S. Swimmers Advance
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 5 (AP) Americans won three of four swimming events, claimed eight medals in all from the pool, and tied  at least briefly  the Russians today in the 10th World University Games with seven gold medals and 18 over all.

title: Q &
description: Q.In my recently purchased condo minium, the bathtub shows the remains of worn and faded decal applications that have apparently long since been removed. Can you suggest a way to remove these traces?  Mrs. J . H. M., Washington.

title: Bank Is Robbed Despite Presence Of Police Squad
description: Despite the presence of two police detectives from a newly formed bankrobbery squad, a man passed a note to a teller, showed her a gun and fled by taxi with $784 from the European American Bank at Park Avenue and 40th Street yesterday. The detectives learned of the robbery too late to signal other members of the stakeout team waiting outside.

title: Bronx Groups Accused of Using Violence to Get Minorities Jobs
description: Local Bronx groups demanding jobs for minority workers have conducted a campaign of intimidation  including acts of violence  at construction sites, according to a special police unit.

title: 2 Firemen Injured in Park Slope
description: Two firemen were injured yesterday as they fought a twoalarm fire of unknown origin at a threestory apartment building in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Residents of the dwelling, at 560 Fourth Avenue, escaped without injury. The injured men were identified as Frederick Meyers, who suffered from heat exhaustion, and Robert McNellis, who sustained neck burns. Officials said both were treated and released from Methodist Hospital.

title: About East Rutherford
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 4  Down below, on the Meadowlands race track, everyone knows that Steve Cauthen, America's once prodigious jockey, has been coaxed back from the Continent for this opening night's racing card. Less well known but more important in the long run for the track's churn of betting appetites in this new season is the fact that Helmut ichwaden, a German master chef vized for his cool touch in feeding affluent people by the crowdful, has been :oaxed over from Cologne to take over :he kitchen of Pegasus.

title: Baseball Drops ABC In Monday Ratings
description: Televised baseball games, unless they are All Star or World Series games, are nowhere as popular in prime time as the professional football games played on Monday nights, as the Nielsen ratings confirmed last week.

title: Budget Director Gets New Office On Civil Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  The Carter Administration announced today the creation of a new civil rights office in the Office of Management and Budget to coordinate and assist enforcement action in Government agencies.

title: New York Retail Sales Up 17.6%
description: Retail sales in New York City last month showed the largest monthly gain in the last three and a half years, averaging 17.6 percent above the August 1978 level, a monthly spot check of six major city retail companies found yesterday

title: As Nicaragua Seeks Normality
description: LOS ANGELES  This is the international year of the child, and the children have taken over Nicaragua. The average age in Latin America is 14. Nicaragua is no exception. Veteran Sandinists with three years of combat under their belt informed me when I was in Nicaragua that they are now 16 years of age. But these heroic youngsters lack the technical skills to administer an economy. Who is going to do it?

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: VANCE TELLS SOVIET ITS TROOPS IN CUBA COULD IMPERIL TIES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the newly discovered Soviet combat brigade in Cuba was a matter of serious concern to the United States that affected this country's overall relations with the Soviet Union.

title: Alberto Di Jorio, Oldest Cardinal, Dies at 95 at His Home in Rome
description: ROME, Sept. 5 (AP)  Alberto Cardinal Di Jorio, 95 years old and the oldest member of the College of Cardinals, died early today at his residence in Rome, the Vatican announced.

title: Options Plan Is Defeated
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP)  A pilot plan to permit trading in commodity options on the nation's futures exchanges died today as a Federal agency failed to agree on who should be allowed to trade them.

title: Second Storm Heads for Battered Dominican Republic
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 5  Tropical Storm Frederic began dumping rain on this already soaked and beleaguered country this afternoon, threatening heavy flooding and hindering efforts to recover from Hurricane David's onslaught last week.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, August 27, to Sunday, September 2), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: Senate Suggests Nixon Pay for Improvements At Estate in California
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP)  The Senate voted today to urge former President Richard M. Nixon to repay the Government for improvements made at taxpayer expense that increased the value of his esstate in San Clemente. Calif.

title: Something New in Spiral Staircases
description: SPIRAL staircases are an attractive way to gain access to another level without using a great deal of space, and many people find the sculptural forms are intriguing in their homes. Now there is new twist in spirals: readytoinstall styles are available on the market.

title: A Citicorp Ad Under Attack
description: Still more advertising controversy is brewing at Citicorp, but this time it does not have to do with the Citicorp complaint that American Express commercials for traveler's checks are false and misleading.

title: 5,000 at St. Patrick's Hear the Dalai Lama Extol Peace and Compassion
description: Without inner peace, it is impossible to have world peace, the Dalai Lama told nearly 5,000 people in St. Patrick's Cathedral last night during an interfaith service that attracted many nationalities.

title: Oil Figures Delayed
description: Because of the Labor Day holiday, the statistics prepared by the American Petroleum Institute to describe the previous week's oil imports, output at the nation's refineries and inventories of crude oil and refined products will be delayed this week, a spokesman said yesterday. Preliminary statistics for any given week are normally available the following Wednesday afternoon. Last week's preliminary figures will instead he available this afternoon, he said.

title: Grandson of R.J. Reynolds Killed With Three Others in Plane Crash
description: PINNACLE, N.C., Sept. 5 (UPI)Four men, including a grandson of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company founder, were killed in the crash of their singleengine plane in a wooded area off U.S. 52 late yesterday.

title: France Lifts Taxes on Luxuries
description: PARIS, Sept. 5 (AP)  France raised taxes on income, pleasure boats, private planes, cars, cigarettes and liquor today, and said it also planned to tax oilcompany profits. The measures were included in a budget package providing for a deficit of $7.3 billion, almost double the figure originally set for 1979. Treasury officials said they were trying to avert a recession that could result from oilprice increases.

title: GARDENING
description: PURPLE butterflies fluttered on the broad green leaves of squash plants. Crickets chirped in the steamy afternoon sun. Blackbirds roosted nearby. Stooped down to the ground, Katherine Brealond harvested several thick, stubby carrots and a long yellow squash from her small farm in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: Equity Library to Open With The Sound of Music
description: A monthlong revival of The Sound of Music will begin the 37th season of the Equity Library Theater, 103d Street and Riverside Drive. The production will open on Sept. 20 and run through Oct. 14.

title: Ann Meyers Signs Amid Doubts
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5  Ann Meyers, the first fourtime allAmerican in women's college basketball, today became the first woman to be signed by a National Basketball Association team.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: SOFU TESHIGAHARA
description: TOKYO, Sept. 5 (Reuters)  Sofu Teshigahara, the 78yearold sculptor and founder of the Sogetsu flowerarranging school, died at a Tokyo hospital today, the hospital said. Mr. Teshigahara received many international awards, including France's Legion of Honor in 1961. He published books on flower arranging in several languages.

title: A Houseful of PreCoordinated Furnishings
description: THERE are those who, without much ado, pick furnishings for their homes as easily as they put on a new shirt; and then there are those who find any decision in this area fraught with anxiety.

title: Texaco Denies Diverting Oil
description: Texaco Inc. denied yesterday a report that it had diverted 65,000 barrels a day of petroleum products from its Caribbean refinery to the European spot market earlier this year, forcing up United States petroleum prices.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: ROLLING MEADOWS, Ill., Sept. 5 (Reuters)  Gould Inc., in another apparent bid to enter the semiconductor industry, announced today the first step of what could become a takeover of the Mostek Corporation.

title: Fiat Prices Rise by 4%
description: TURIN, Sept. 5 (Reuters)  Fiat S.p.A. said today that the price of its cars would rise by an average of 4 percent tomorrow to cover higher production costs.

title: Stocks Slump
description: The stock market incurred its second consecutive broad decline yesterday, with losers on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering advances by almost a 7to1 ratio.

title: Red Sox Defeat Yankees
description: To the good and faithful fans of Boston, the Red Sox are a paradox. They consistently have one of the best teams in baseball, but they generally wind up, at best, second best in their division. Last night the paradoxical Red Sox gained a 50 victory over the Yankees and Tommy John, who posted a paradoxical Ditching performance.

title: The Intangible Equity Of Owning a Home
description: SUDDENLY, almost everyone we knew was frantically looking for a house. Spiraling rents, the follies of the stock market, the deplorably small closets of apartments, the canceled rent checks that had no significance at tax time  all made buying a house seem eminently practical.

title: Calendar of Events: A Stroll in Trenton
description: State Street Stroll, Trenton, N.J. Trenton will celebrate its 300th anniversary Sunday with festivities beginning at 10 A.M. and concluding at a P.M. with a massive reunion party at the Contemporary Club, an old Victorian museum.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Jay Janis has appeared before the Senate Banking Committee so many times that, by his own reckoning, I'm used to their procedure, and they are used to me.

title: Design Notebook
description: IN New York City, where life  or at least urban design  so often borders on the uncivilized, there is one amenity that is consistently gracious, almost always useful and frequently attractive. It is the canopy, the protective extension of metal or glass or canvas or vinyl that keeps away rain and snow along the path from front door to taxi, and acts as a symbolic welcoming device as well.

title: Teachers Strike at Fairleigh Dickinson
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J. Sept. 5  Fall classes were to open at Fairleigh Dickinson University today for Jerry Deveney and friends. But the faculty struck in midmorning after fruitless, allnight contract talks, and Mr. Deveney and a dozen or so classmates wound up sitting on a bench outside Becton Hall, sharing some beforenoon beers and a bottle of wine.

title: PROFILE
description: Working from his base of selfapproval, the Mayor is a combative manwith businessmen, labor leaders, politicians, the city bureaucracy, Jews, blacks, Puerto Ricans, and constituents in general. He quotes Manhattan Representative Charles Rangel as saying of him, You think he's mean to you? He's mean to everybody.

title: 50,000 Iranian Kurds Said to Flee To Asylum Near the Iraq Border
description: MEHABAD, Iran, Sept. 5 (Reuters) In this former Kurdish rebel center, now in Iranian Government hands, army officers estimate that 50,000 armed insurgents have taken refuge in a mountain town near the Iraqi border.

title: Iranian Oil Output Down Almost 20%
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 5 (Reuters)  Iranian oil production has dropped almost 20 percent from average levels of around 3.75 million barrels a day last month, according to figures issued by the National Iranian Oil Company

title: Federal Inquiry On Police Action At Protest Urged
description: Four lawyers organizations representing liberal and minority groups asked the Justice Department yesterday to investigate allegations of deliberate and organized police brutality at a demonstration last week to protest the police killing of Luis Baez.

title: Detroit Seeks Semiconductors
description: The automobile industry's longawaited changeover to solidstate electronics has kicked into high gear. The computer is finally becoming commonplace in cars.

title: Shakespeare Hearing
description: The Shakespeare Company, which makes electric outboard motors, golf clubs and other sporting goods, announced yesterday from its Columbia, S.C., headquarters that the hearing on its request for a temporary injunction in its lawsuit against two other companies had been changed from Sept. 10 to 2 P.M., Eastern daylight time, today. Shakespeare has obtained court orders blocking the sale of 35 percent of its 2.4 million shares to Anthony Industries by subsidiaries of the Hillman Company, pending the hearing.

title: India's Janata Party Is Accused Of Abusing Freedom of the Press
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 5 (UPI)  Two news organizations and a former Information Minister today accused the caretaker Government of Prime Minister Charan Singh and his Janata Party of interfering with freedom of the press.

title: Books of The Times
description: BEFORE I devoured Scott Spencer's touching new novel, Endless Love (his previous two were Last Night at the Brain Thieves Ball and Preservation Hall'), I thought it would be quite impossible for a contemporary writer to get me interested in a lovesick teenager who keeps wrecking his life to be with a girl he has been forbidden to see. But then I read the opening paragraph of David Axelrod's confession:

title: Rock: The Grateful Dead Open Series at Garden
description: THE Grateful Dead, for some reason or other, has become the New York area's biggest cult rock band, as attested to in this time of supposed musicindustry recession  by its arrival Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden for the first of three soidout concerts.

title: Siamese Twin Survives Dominican Hurricane>
description: SAN JOSE DE OCOA, Dominican Republic, Sept. 5 (UPI)  Clara Altagracia Rodriguez, the 6yearold surviving Siamese twin who was separated from her sister five years ago in a rare operation in Philadelphia, Pa., survived the devastation of Hurricane David although her home was in the path of the storm.

title: 10 Arrested in Pentagon Protest
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP)  Ten protesters against nuclear arms were arrested today at the Pentagon after they threw red paint on the building and blocked an entrance, the police said. Seven were charged with destruction of Government property, the others with failing to obey a police officer's directions. They were taking part in a sixhour demonstration by 35 members of the Atlantic Life Community, based in Baltimore.

title: StormTorn Dominicans Fight to Survive
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 5  She is a thin reed of a woman with a small pile of coconuts and avocados at her feet, picked from the ground and brought to the capital for sale in a desperate search for money to keep her family going.

title: Fifth Ave. Space Leased for Bonwit
description: A longterm lease was signed yesterday for Bonwit Teller, which closed its Fifth Avenue store last May after 49 years, to return to the same site late next year in a new building.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 (UPI) Federal district judge ruled today that 25 percent of all officers hired by the Philadelphia Police Department must be women.

title: DATA LONG IMPLIED SOVIET UNITS IN CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  The United States intelligence community has been receiving reports indicating the presence of Soviet combat units in Cuba for at least eight years, highranking Administration officials said today. But only in recent weeks did intelligence officials tentatively conclude that the troops were an organized combat force.

title: Fluor Profits Increase 13%
description: The Fluor Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings increased 13 percent for the third fiscal quarter ending July 31 and 33 percent for the nine months. The results, bolstered by overseas energy operations, domestic general construction and offshore drilling and supply services for the petroleum industry, continued to set record highs.

title: Market Place
description: THE speed with which the price of gold has risen this year has surprised all but its most confirmed advocates.

title: Harmonica Fans Get Tip From the Master's Mouth
description: A small harmonica to his lips, 14yearold Adrian Danzig played a tentative version of Mary Had a Little Lamb and won encouragement from a master. Try getting your mouth very small, said Larry Adler, the worldfamous virtuoso of the instrument. That's it; that's better already.

title: Bomb Injures Man in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 5 (AP)  A bomb exploded near a Jerusalem swimming pool today, slightly injuring a man, the police reported. Earlier in the day, several Israelis were injured when a bottle of chlorine exploded at the Tel Aviv bus station, but the police said that the explosion had been an accident.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, Sept. 5 (AP)  The Vatican said today that Pope John Paul II had summoned seven Dutch bishops to an extraordinary synod in Rome in January to try to resolve differences in their ranks.

title: SeaLand Service Resumes
description: SeaLand Service, a subsidiary of R.J. Reynolds Industries, said yesterday that it had resumed containerized freight operations in the port of Rio Haina, Dominican Republic, following Hurricane David.

title: U.S. BOOKS IN SOVIET DRAW LARGE CROWD
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 5  Thousands of Russians swarmed over a display of 13,000 American books as the second Moscow International Book Fair opened to the public this afternoon.

title: Gold Brings $333 At I.M.F. Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP)The average price of gold sold today at the International Monetary Fund's monthly auction was a $333.24 an ounce.

title: Alitalia Reported Set to Buy 5 747's
description: ROME, Sept. 5 (AP)  A top union official said today that Italy's flag airline, Alitalia, has decided to buy five Boeing Jumbo 747 aircraft in place of the six McDonnell Douglas DC10's for which it canceled tentative order last month.

title: A Chinese Elm in Central Park Is Aiding Its American Cousins
description: MILLBROOK, N.Y., Sept. 5  A 120yearold Chinese elm tree in New York City's Central Park is the key in an experiment at the Cary Arboretum here to save the American elm, which is gradually being killed off by Dutch elm disease.

title: Volcker Will Keep Restraints
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP)  The Federal Reserve Board will continue restraining the growth of the nation's money supply, even if that means pushing interest rates still higher, the head of the board, Paul A. Volcker, said today.

title: Carson Returns... For Now
description: The new television season began last night for Johnny Carson, who returned to his familiar desk on NBCTV's Tonight show after a summer vacation. But it is still uncertain whether the popular comedian will be at that post when the season ends, or even after Sept. 30, the date that will mark his 17th anniversary as host of the nightly talkandvariety program.

title: Mayor Appointed in Portland
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 5 (AP)  A City Commissioner, Connie McCready, was appointed by the Council today to succeed Mr. Goldschmidt as Mayor of Portland. Mrs. McCready, 58 years old, had been acting mayor since Mr. Goldschmidt resigned in midAugust to serve as interim Transportation Secretary.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Gold Continues to Rise
description: The price of gold reached new peaks on bullion markets again yesterday as the dollar turned in a mixed performance on currency exchanges.

title: 2,000 Attend TeachIn On Breast Cancer
description: ONE of every 13 women now alive in the United States will develop breast cancer at some time in the future. That grim statistic was repeated over and over to the 2,000 women attending a national breast cancer teachin yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. A panel of physicians and other authorities on the disease gave speeches and answered questions during the program, which was sponsored by the American Cancer Society and seven of its divisions in the metropolitan area.

title: Hospital Tells Barnard To Take Less Time Off
description: CAPE TOWN, Sept. 5 (Reuters)  Dr. Christiaan Barnard, the hearttransplant pioneer, has been told he can no longer take leave from his hospital whenever he wants to travel as an unofficial ambassador for South Africa.

title: Rogers Auditorium Marking a Jubilee
description: The Metropolitan Museum is marking the 25th anniversary of concerts in Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium with the presentation of 65 musical events during the 197980 season. Since the first program played in 1954 by Isaac Stern, 1,312 concerts have been given in the auditorium, most of them devoted to chamber music.

title: HomeLoan Yields Jump To 10.917%
description: Mortgage rates are headed still higher, the latest auction by the Federal National Mortgage Association of fourmonth commitments to purchase home loans indicated yesterday.

title: Antinuclear Rally to Have Rock Stars
description: Antinuclear activists will stage rally on Sept. 23 at the Battery Park City landfill, south of the World Trade Center. The rally has been planned in conjunction with the series of antinuclear/prosolar benefit rock concerts earlier that week at Madison Square Garden.

title: Coast Fare of $108 Is Set by Pan Am
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it was introducing an $108 oneway fare between New York and Los Angeles. The move comes shortly after Trans World, United and American said they were dropping similar fares and asking for higher rates.

title: PAPERWORK BATTLE PRESSED BY CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP)  An Administration report said today that President Carter's drive against Federal paperwork had slowed markedly as Government agencies ran out of easy targets and that he would soon order elimination of Federal reports that cannot be proved useful.

title: Iran Expels Reporter, 15th in Two Months
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 5 (UPI) The Iranian Government today ordered the expulsion of another foreign correspondent, bringing to 15 the number expelled since July.

title: Artist to Recreate Times Tower in 42d Street Mural
description: The best and least expensive way to finish an uncompleted, rather ordinary building may be to paint it to look as though it were finished. And in the process why not paint it to look like an important building, a famous building?

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Reagan Campaign Said to Be in Debt as Donations Lag
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5  The Presidential campaign of Ronald Reagan, the acknowledged frontrunner for the 1980 Republican nomination, is at least $500,000 in debt and is raising money at a substantially lower pace than the staff anticipated, according to sources in the Reagan organization.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Piano Sonata No. 5, Schubert; Su le Sponde del Tebro, Scarlatti; Mitternachtswalzer, Lanner.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Deaths

title: JOINT PEACE PATROLS FOR SINAI APPROVED BY SADAT AND BEGIN
description: HAIFA, Israel, Sept. 5  Prime Minister Menachem Begin and President Anwar elSadat agreed today to joint IsraeilEgyptian patrols as a temporary policing mechanism in Sinai in the wake of withdrawal of the armed United Nations Emergency Force.

title: Topics Banned Books, Racquet Racket
description: At first, the Soviet officials in charge of the Moscow International Book Fair weeded out publishers. South Korean publishers who applied for visas never got an answer. Fourteen Israelis were told there was no hotel space, then that they had applied for the wrong kind of visa; in any case, they were excluded. The visa of Robert Bernstein, a leading American publisher, was first granted  and then abruptly revoked.

title: TV: Medical Shows From NBC and CBS
description: ON Tuesday evening, ABCTV offered a preview of a new weekly series called The Lazarus Syndrome. Its hero is a doctor and the principal setting is a hospital. Not to be outdone by a competitor, CBS and NBC are presenting their own medicalsweepstakes entries tonight. Each is scheduled against the other at 8 o'clock.

title: At Your Service: Where to Buy Stairs
description: LOOKING for a spiral staircase usually begins with reading a lot of brochures; then you have to step out and try your foot on the ones that look good. Sometime early in the process, have an architect, contractor or engineer from a stair company examine the site to estimate construction work and costs, and to specify what stair equipment is necessary.

title: Chrysler Rebates Help 10Day Sales Rise 23%
description: DETROIT, Sept. 5 (UPI)  The Chrysler Corporation's $400 customer rebate program helped push its lateAugust car sales 23 percent above the level of the corresponding period last year  a far better performance than that of the other Big Three auto makers.

title: The City
description: A member of the Savage Nomads youth gang told detectives yesterday that he and a companion had killed two 14yearold girls because the companion had raped one of the girls and the Bronx youths feared she would go to the police.

title: U.S. Reassigns Meat Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI) Australia, New Zealand and four Central American nations may increase exports of meat to the United States to make up a 56millionpound shortfall in Mexican shipments, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Dance: Ballet Theater Opens Encore Season With Giselle
description: AMERICAN Ballet Theater opened what it calls an Encore Season with a performance of Giselle Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. If all performances in the twoweek engagement are like that Giselle, then ballet lovers will have much to shout Encore! about.

title: Interest on Checking: Action Set
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  Legislation to legalize interestbearing checking accounts throughout the nation is expected to win overwhelming approval tomorrow when the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee takes up the controversial measure.

title: Simpson to Start for 49ers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5 (UPI) O.J. Simpson, who missed the entire preseason because of an injury and a personal tragedy, is scheduled to start at halfback Sunday when the San Francisco 49ers play host to the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Strike Cancels St. Louis Symphony's Centennial Celebration
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5  The St. Louis Symphony Society canceled today its centennial celebration concerts scheduled for this week and the first two weeks of its 197980 concert season because of a strike by orchestra members over wages and other contract issues.

title: BoatBuilding Yards Are Struck
description: BOSTON, Sept. 5 (AP)  The 320strong production force at Boston Whaler's two boatbuilding plants in Norwell and Rockland, Mass., struck yesterday shutting down the assembly line at the motorboat plant.

title: Hirshhorn Adding Ramps To Aid the Handicapped
description: Renovations have been started to make the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden at Washington's Smithsonian Institution more accessible to handicapped visitors.

title: COMMODMES Silver and Gold Futures Soar to Highs Again
description: Silver futures rose as much as 73 cents an ounce yesterday, soaring to a new alltime high for the ninth successive trading session. At the close, prices were onethird higher than a month ago.

title: Sound
description: NUMBERS have a particular persuasiveness, and that is something to watch out for. It may well be that figures don't lie; but it is certain that liars can figure, and when it comes to interpreting the numerical specifications of sound equipment, a measure of skepticism is definitely apropos.

title: Texts of Letter and Statements by Vance and Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  Following are the texts of a July 27 letter from Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance to Senator Richard Stone, Democrat of Florida, denying an increase of Soviet strength in Cuba; of the Aug. 31 announcement by Hodding Carter 3d, the State Department spokesman, confirming the presence of Soviet troops in Cuba, and of Mr. Vance's opening statement at a news conference today:

title: Yanks Bow
description: Butch Hobson's tworun homer helped the Red Sox beat the Yankees last night, 50. The MetsPhils game was rained out. Details, page D17.

title: ESSAY Brezhnev's Big Ear
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  The primary purpose of the 3,000man Soviet armored brigade in Cuba is to protect a massive new communications intercept facility, which will give the Russians the ability to listen in on most United States telephone conversations as well as to monitor transmission of data between computers and from our satellites and missiles.

title: Philip C. Lewis, Writer For Film, Radio and TV
description: Philip C. Lewis, an author and dramatist, died Monday of leukemia in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: L. C. Barrow Dies at 66
description: DALLAS, Sept. 5 (AP)  L.C. Barrow, the last surviving brother of Clyde and Buck Barrow, who became notorious in the 1930's when they and Bonnie Parker were accused of robbing several banks in which at least 15 persons were killed, died Monday at a hospital in Athens, Tex. He was 66 years old.

title: Funds Use of Assets For Marketing Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today that mutual funds be permitted to use their assets for marketing purposes.

title: Affirmed's Prestige Endangered If He Stays Out, Horsemen Say
description: Will he or won't he? Will Affirmed run in Saturday's Marlboro Cup Handicap, despite his trainer's indignation over the high weight of 133 pounds? Or does the trainer, Laz Barrera, really mean it when he says the 4yearold Harbor View Farm colt will stay in the barn?

title: Siemens Merger Delayed
description: The planned acquisition of the Microwave Semiconductor Corporation by Siemens A.G. has been postponed. The merger, which was to take place on Sept. 30, has been delayed until about Nov. 15, according to an announcement by the companies.

title: Soviet Role in Afghan Clash Shows Signs of Toughening
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 2  The Soviet Union has been unable to find a political solution to the fighting here and, according to diplomatic sources, there are signs that Moscow is moving toward direct, broad military intervention to quell the dozens of fierce local uprisings.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1979

title: U.S. and Turkish Negotiators Near an Accord on Bases
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 5  Turkish and'American negotiators are putting the finishing touches to a defense cooperation agreement that would guarantee the future of United States military installations on Turkish soil. officials doubt that a comprehensive agreement will be ready by Oct. 9, when the temporary status of the bases expires. However, the bases are expected to continue functioning while negotiations continue,

title: Zoning Change Opposed For Tower at Bonwit Site
description: Opponents of a plan to build a 58story skyscraper to replace the abandoned Bonwit Teller building on Fifth Avenue at 56th Street urged the City Planning Commission yesterday to deny zoning changes requested by the developer.

title: Indictment Alleges Plot to Defraud Teamsters' Funds
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 5 (AP)  The Aladdin Hotel Corporation, the Del E. Webb Corporation and six persons were indicted yesterday in connection with an alleged plot to defraud teamsters union pension funds of $1 million through a series of kickbacks on a construction project at the hotel.

title: Francis Drake's Prayer Given for Mountbatten
description: LONDON, Sept. 5  A prayer for peace and the prayer of Sir Francis Drake were offered today in Westminster Abbey at the funeral service for Earl Mountbatten of Burma.

title: Guy Bolton, One of the Originators Of the Broadway Musical, 96, Dies
description: Guy Bolton, the author or coauthor of dozens of light, romantic Broadway musicals that won wide audiences in the 1920's and 30's, died Tuesday in GoringonThames, which is near London. He was 96 years old.

title: British Unions  Bar Mass Protests
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 5  British trade unions, divided over strategy in opposing the new Government, rejected by a small margin today a call for members to take their campaign into the streets.

title: ULSTER FALLS SILENT IN TRIBUTE TO DEAD
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 5 Much of Northern Ireland fell silent today in tribute to Earl Mountbatten of Burma and the 1,957 other men, women and children who have died in the past decade of Irish violence.

title: Digest BUSINESS Digest
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1979

title: Home Improvement
description: LADDERS are probably among the most commonly used tools around most homes, especially at this time of year when there is more than an average amount of fixing and sprucing up going on.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Unveiling the Courts
description: SAN FRANCISCO  There is a line of thought these days that the courts, like other American institutions, need exposing. The mystique of the robe should be stripped away, it is said. The inner workings of appellate courts, the judges motives, their exchanges in the privacy of the conference room: All should be known to the public in a democracy.

title: I.R.A. Suspect Sought by Britain Applies for U.S. Political Asylum
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5 (Reuters) A man sought by Britain as a suspected member of the Irish Republican Army, Peter McMullen, has applied for asylum in the United States, his attorney said today.

title: Mild Quake Felt in Los Angeles
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif., Sept. 5 (AP)  A mild earthquake shook the Thousand OaksWestlake area of suburban Los Angeles this morning. Seismologists at the California Institute of Technology said that it measured 3.6 on the Richter scale. There were no reports of damage.

title: Harriman Remembers His Old Friend Dickie
description: LONDON, Sept. 5  Not many of the major figures of World War II are left now that Earl Mountbatten of Burma is gone. Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia. Gen. Omar N. Bradley. And Averell Harriman, who led the official American delegation to the ceremonial funeral of his friend of 50 years.

title: Aftermath of Andrew Young Affair: Blacks, Jews and Carter All Could Suffer Greatly
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  Three groups  blacks, Jews and the Carter Administration  potentially could suffer major damage in the controversy prompted by the resignation of Andrew Young as chief delegate to the United Nations, according to a range of persons close to the matter.

title: Error Helps Pirates Win in 11 th
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 (UPI)  Omar Moreno and Dave Parker both scored on a wild pickoff attempt by Darold Knowles in the 11th inning tonight leading the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 75 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. The victory kept the firstplace Pirates two games ahead of Montreal in the National League East race.

title: Carter May Seek Extra $4 Billion For the Military; Promise of 3 Percent Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  President Carter may ask Congress next week for nearly $4 billion in supplemental military appropriations, informed sources said today, in a step Administration officials hope will help win Senate approval of the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: Libya Said to Give Syria MIG23's To Replace 4 IsraeliDowned Jets
description: KUWAIT, Sept. 5 (UPI)  Libya has replaced Syrian jets that the Israelis shot down with more advanced models, the newspaper Al Rai al Am reported today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Hunter Chief Won't Take Job Permanently
description: Dr. Joseph Shenker, the newly appointed acting president of Hunter College, ruled himself out yesterday as a candidate for president of the school.

title: 403 Museums, 56 in New York, Granted $7.4 Million by H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  The awarding of $7.4 million in grants to 403 museums across the country, including $1 million in grants to 56 New York State museums, was announced today by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare's Institute of Museum Services.

title: Picking at the Cuban Sore
description: Cuba, and Soviet military activity in Cuba, have a special resonance in American politics. That is why the Administration's discovery there of a Soviet combat force of 2,000 or 3,000 men is a disturbance in SovietAmerican relations far exceeding the military threat of one brigade. If the flashpoints of the cold war are not now out of bounds to new efforts to upset the military balance, no policy of general reconciliation with Moscow can long survive in the American political arena. That is why the Administration is right to ask that the combat force be dismantled. The SovietAmerican competition has either been channeled into less vital regions or it hasn't. This is a good time to find out.

title: MONDALE SUGGESTED AS POSSIBLE NOMINEE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  Although publicly committed to support President Carter's reelection, Vice President Mondale is beginning to come under some pressure to run for the Presidency himself and has privately voiced some dissatisfaction with the White House's handling of important political moves in recent weeks.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MUSIC IN THE AIR An afternoon concert of traditional and contemporary Jewish music will be presented today in the lower plaza of the McGrawHill building in Rockefeller Center, 1221 Avenue of the Americas, at 48th Street. The 18piece King David Chamber orchestra will play traditional frailachs, shers and doinas as well as music by American Jewish composers from 4:30 to 5:15 P.M. Admission: free. Rain will cancel this event.

title: David Moving In With Drenching Rainfall
description: Tropical Storm David  downgraded from a hurricane, but still laden with water and spinning off tornados as it moved  lumbered toward the New York City area this morning, threatening to dump an estimated three to five inches of rain and cause some beach damage before blowing away by tonight.

title: Senate Forbids I.R.S. To Penalize Schools Found to Discriminate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) The Senate voted today to block a move by the Internal Revenue Service to deny tax breaks to private schools that discriminate against blacks and other racial minorities.

title: Connors Advances; Scheduling Disputed; Talbert Takes the Blame; Double Standard?; The Morning News; Wimbledon Schedule Different; Mrs. King vs. Mrs. Lloyd
description: While Jimmy Connors and Chris Evert Lloyd, the defending champions, and Billie Jean King, the old lady gathering a youthful second wind, reached the semifinals of the United States Open yesterday, the real commotion at the National Tennis Center was the combination of events  some planned, others spontaneous  that produced a scheduling mixup in the second week of the tournament.

title: I.B.M. and MCA Form VideoDisk Joint Venture
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and MCA Inc. announced yesterday that they had formed a joint venture to develop, manufacture and market videodisk systems.

title: The Region
description: HARTFORD  An committee appointed by Gov. Ella T. Grasso to measure the economic impact of the energy shortage on Connecticut recommended yesterday that the Governor take all actions necessary for the completion of Millstone III, a nuclearpower plant in Waterford, to reduce the state's dependence on foreign oil.

title: TopSeeded Borg Is Upset By Tanner, 62, 46, 62, 76
description: Firing his serve like a cannon, Roscoe Tanner squelched Bjorn Borg's bid for a Grand Slam and a first United States Open singles title with a dramatic fourset victory last night at the National Tennis Center.

title: A Display of Toys Captures the Wind
description: AN obsessed Captain Ahab braves the fierce wind. His arms flail about. His harpoon has pierced the flesh of his prey, the Great White Whale. Alas, the harpoon line has become entangled around his left leg and he is struggling with his right peg leg to stand squarely atop this behemoth, lest he be gobbled up by its razorsharp teeth. Suddenly, the raging gusts wane and turn into a gentle breeze. The frenetic Ahab's arms slow down and stop. Almost as quickly as it began, this windgenerated fantasy is at. rest, transformed back into a 17inch high wooden whirligig.

title: Liza Minnelli Displays Her Versatility
description: LIZA MINNELLI came into Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening trailing an impressive collection of awards behind her three Tonys, an Oscar and an Emmy. But when she leaves Carnegie Hall a week from tomorrow after a run of 11 nights, she will be taking with her something far more important than awards.

title: Investment in Taiwan Up
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 5 (Reuters) Overseas Chinese and foreign investment in Taiwan reached $237.6 million in the first eight months of this year, nearly double the $125.3 million recorded in the yearearlier period, the Ministry of Economic Affairs reported. Electronics attracted the most investment, taking 38.9 percent of the total.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Congress Returns With a Mandate to Move on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  Congress reopened for business after the August recess today with Senators and Representatives saying that they have a new mandate from their constituents to deal effectively with the energy crisis.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Sept. 5, 1979

title: Clippers Triumph in 15th, Lead Tides in Series, 21
description: The Columbus Clippers, top farm club of the New York Yankees, ran away with the regularseason title in the International League, but are having trouble with the Tidewater Tides, the New York Mets top farm.

title: House Increases Aid for Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI)  The House of Representatives voted today to increase American aid for Indochinese refugees by $207 million. It criticized other nations for not doing more to provide the refugees with relief and permanent homes.

title: Aztecs Cruyff Most Valuable
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 5  Johan Cruyff, who did not join the Los Angeles Aztecs until their eighth game of the season, was named the North American Soccer League's most valuable player today.

title: Transportation Nominee Favors New Roads Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  Neil E. Golcischmidt, President Carter's nominee to be Secretary of Transportation, said today at the opening of Senate confirmation hearings that he favored a new Federal policy to help states maintain and repair deteriorating sections of the Interstate Highway System.

title: KLM Reassigns Manager Of Troubled U.S. Office
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines announced yesterday the reassignment of its longtime general manager in New York, Frederick O. Kielman, whose office is the focus of an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into allegations of secret loans and other financial misdealings by the airline.

title: Duran, Leonard On Holmes Card
description: The card featuring the Larry HolmesEarnie Shavers fight for the World Boxing Council's heavyweight title was rounded out yesterday with bouts including Roberto Duran and Sugar Ray Leonard. The card is scheduled for Sept. 28 in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Mrs. Thatcher and Lynch Meet, But Report No Accord on Terror
description: LONDON, Sept. 5  The Prime Minsters of Britain and Ireland, after spending five hours urgently discussing the problem of terrorism and border security today, indicated tonight that they had come to no significant new agreement on what to do about it.

title: Notes on People
description: Details of precisely what took place were sparse, but the former Bolshoi Ballet star Aleksandr Godunov met with Soviet officials in New York yesterday and explained, face to face, why he had defected to the United States.

title: More Teachers Join Picket Lines As Strikes Spread Across Nation
description: By The Associated Press

title: Wallace Repayment to Treasury Noted in Election Panel's Audit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI)  The Federal Election Commission closed the books on 1976 yesterday with completion of an audit of George C. Wallace's Presidential campaign that showed the former Alabama Governor had repaid $45,000 to the United States Treasury.

title: Ford Would Seek Equal Rule Relief
description: DETROIT, Sept. 5 (UPI)  A top executive of the Ford Motor Company said today that Ford would seek equal treatment if the Government granted relief from automotive safety, fueleconomy and exhaustemission standards to the ailing Chrysler Corporation.

title: Home Beat
description: FOR the last 10 years, Ken Brozen explained, he has been somewhat involved in the relationship between design and merchandising.

title: Castro Meets Growing Opposition To Attempt to Sway Third World
description: HAVANA, Sept. 5  President Fidel Castro of Cuba met growing resistance from third world governments today to his efforts to bring their movement closer to the Soviet position on world issues and to control their conference here.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Louisiana Home Buyers Camp Out to Vie for LowCost Mortgages
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 5 (AP)  Applications for 1,700 lowinterest mortgages were snapped up today by wouldbe home buyers, about 3,000 of whom had waited up to six days outside 61 loan offices with sleeping bags, beach chairs and umbrellas.

title: EARNINGS Bache Profits Fall 15.2%, But Revenues Set Record
description: The Bache Group Inc., parent of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., a leading securities brokerage firm, showed a 15.2 pecent decline in profits for the fourth fiscal quarter ended July 31, the first quarterly drop in a year and half, the company reported yesterday.

title: Entertainment Events
description: PETER PAN, by Sir James Barrie. Directed and choreographed by Rob Iscove; music by Mark Charlap; lyrics by Carolyn Leigh. Starring Sandy Duncan and George Rose. At the LuntFontanne Theater, 205 West 46th Street, 6:15.

title: Talking Business
description: Despite its reputation as one of the strongest lobbyist groups in Washington, the American banking industry is not as monolithic as some may think.

title: Memorial Rite Is Held For Lord Mountbatten In a Fifth Ave. Church
description: A faint, distant echo of the solemn pageantry that marked the Westminster Abbey funeral of Earl Mountbatten of Burma sounded in New York yesterday at St. Thomas Church, where about 500 people, including the consul general of Ireland, gathered for a memorial service.

title: Young Begins Trade Mission to 7 African Nations
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 5 Andrew Young left today on his final diplomatic assignment as a Government official, heading a White House trade mission to Africa.

title: What's a Borough President?
description: Before choosing a candidate for Bronx Borough President next Tuesday, voters might ask themselves why there are four names on the Democratic ballot. Who wants to assume a role bristling with so many difficulties and blessed with so few powers? The hypothetical answers to that question may help the voter choose.

title: Rangers Move Practice Site To Rye Rink for Five Years
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 5  The New York Rangers of the National Hockey League will use the Ice Casino at Playland Amusement Park in Rye, N.Y., for practice beginning this season.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Bakers Protest Creates Bread Shortage
description: TELAVIV, Sept. 5  The Voice of Israel broadcast recipes for bread today and advised housewives to bake their own to cope with a shortage caused by a protest action of bakery workers demanding a 30 percent wage increase.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1979

title: Grogan Warned by Jets Coach
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 5  Steve Grogan, the New England Patriots scampering quarterback, was warned today that he would be fair game once he gets past the line of scrimmage next Sunday in the game against the Jets.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bank of New York has named Ross M. Weale to the new position of executive vice president and assigned him to the County Trust Region, while Herbert C. Hooley becomes president of the Central Region.

title: Synthetic Fuel Plan Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 Experts on synthetic fuel told senators today that President Carter's plan to reduce reliance on foreign oil imports probably involved spending more money than is practical more rapidly than would be efficient.

title: The Vienna Syndrome
description: An odd assortment of people, estimated at 5,000, descended on Vienna the last two weeks of August: diplomats, politicians, international bureaucrats, antinuclear and other social activists, scientists, officials of multinational corporations, and various other professional and amateur problemsolvers.

title: Giants Patching Offense
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 5  The Giants stood pat today. All was quiet on their offensive front. They did not claim anyone on waivers, did not sign any free agents, did not lure anyone out of retirement.

title: Hushed London Bids Mountbatten Farewell
description: LONDON, Sept. 5  Britain bade farewell today to Earl Mountbatten of Burma, perhaps the last of its storybook heroes, with the most magnificent military funeral since that of the Duke of Wellineton in 1852.

title: Hurricane Leaves Carolina Areas With Much to Do
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 5  At the plush Mills House hotel on Meeting Street in the heart of Charleston, the whitejacketed staff plucked up spent candles and toweled the marble floors with clean white cloths.

title: Vance Backs Dayan's Arab Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP)  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today defended conversations that Israel's Foreign Minister, Moshe Dayan, has had with Palestinian Arabs who support the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Record $3 Million Paid For English Soccer Star
description: MANCHESTER, England, Sept. 5 (AP)  Manchester City set a British soccer transfer record today, paying nearly $3 million for Steve Daley, 26yearold Wolverhampton midfielder.

title: Archibald Alexander, 72
description: Archibald Stevens Alexander, Under Secretary of the Army in the Truman Administration, died Tuesday at his home in Bernardsville, N.J., after a short illness. He was 72 years old.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: THERE are two new portable alarms on the market  a smoke alarm and an intrusion alarm  that offer protection to people who are traveling or who live in rented homes and do not want install a permanent alarm. The portable smoke alarm, made by Westclox, is a rectangle about eight inches high and has a small bracket for hooking the alarm over an open or closed door. The alarm is battery powered and when set off emits an 85decibel warning. A test switch enables one to test both battery and operating functions. The Westclox alarm comes with a travel bag and is $19.99 at all E. J. Korvette stores.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Rates Climb Sharply On TaxFree Notes
description: Interest rates on shortterm taxexempt notes yesterday rose to their highest levels since September 1974, and the Federal Government failed to sell $160 million of the notes to finance housing projects because of a 6 percent ceiling on the securities.

title: Resorts Reports Gains at Casino
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 5 (AP) Resorts International Inc. announced today that it had a monthly gross win of $23.8 million for August at its Boardwalk casino.

title: Bush Calls for Balanced Budget And Curbs on Federal Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  George Bush, about to start a television campaign to make himself better known in New England, charged today that the economy was in the worst mess since the Great Depression and called for traditional Republican remedies to cure it.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the bestknown clubs in New York City, the Barclay Bridge Club, is suffering from declining attendance and has recently undergone a reorganization.

title: 2 in Harlem Rob David Kennedy, 24YearOld Son of Late Senator
description: David A. Kennedy, the 24yearold son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was robbed of $30 in cash last night in the lobby of a hotel in Harlem, the police reported.

title: Albano Opposed in Primary For Republican District Post
description: A Manhattan Republican is spending $5,000 and has appealed all the way to the state's highest court to run next Tuesday for a Republican district leadership in overwhelmingly Democratic Manhattan.

title: Jailbird
description: In his last novel, "Slapstick" (1976), Kurt Vonnegut told us that he believed in the Bill of Rights, Robert's Rules of Order and the principles of Alcoholics Anonymous. In his new novel, "Jailbird"--his best, in my opinion, since "Mother Night" (1961) and "Cat's Cradle" (1963)--he adds another sacred document. It is the Sermon on the Mount.

title: Carter Aide Bars Senate Fuel Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  The White House today rejected the kind of syntheticfuel legislation taking shape in Congress that would involve testing several new technologies before making a major investment in any of them.

title: Inmates Panel Airs Complaints On Court System
description: A delegation of inmates from the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men met with a top court official yesterday to complain about what its members said was excessive bail, adjournment procedures and the caliber of representation provided by courtappointed lawyers in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: Syrians Said to Seal Off 2 Cities in Moslem Strife
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 6 (Reuters)  About 2,000 Syrian soldiers, backed by tanks and armored cars, have sealed off two cities in that country after interMoslem strife, travelers from the area said today.

title: Canadians Find Oil Offshore in Arctic
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Sept. 6  The Beaufort Sea appears to have yielded its first crude oil with commercial potential at a well drilled by Dome Petroleum Ltd.

title: Dispute Over Absence of Governor Heard by High Court in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6  The California Supreme Court heard arguments today in a dispute over the authority of the Lieutenant Governor when the Governor is absent from the state, which is one of the leading political issues of the day in California.

title: Frank C. Schreiber Is Dead at 57
description: Frank C. Schreiber of Silver Spring, Md., executive director for the National Association of the Deaf, died yesterday at New York University Hospital in Manhattan. He was 57 years old.

title: Tighter Currency Rules Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) The Treasury Department today proposed to tighten regulations governing currency transactions after reporting that billions in cash had recently flowed in unusual patterns into some Florida banks.

title: Armenian Cathedral Plays Host to World
description: The One World Festival  now in its seventh year and well on its way to becoming one of New York City's most popular ethnic celebrations  returns this weekend to the park and plaza area around St. Vartan Cathedral at Second Avenue and 35th Street in Manhattan, with more than 1,000 musicians, dancers, artists and artisans.

title: Screen: 'Vipers, 'Venice and Facism:Romance of Decadence
description: "NEST of Vipers," which opens today at the Translux East Theater, is the English title of Tonino Cervi's "Ritratto di Borghesia in Nero," an Italian romantic melodrama that attempts (but fails) to take a dim view of the kind of upper-class decadence that helped (it says here) make possible the rise of Mussolini and Italian Fascism in the 1930's.Like Bernardo Bertolucci and Luchino Visconti at their very worst. Mr. Cervi is too fascinated by the picturesque details of decadence to be very convincing as a moralist. He's more like a gossipmonger and "Nest of Vipers" is a solemn-faced joke, played by a lot of people who are better than their material. The setting is Venice, a city that should be protected from overwrought movie directors as well as from the sea.The film, which is based on a story by Roger Peyrefitte, is about the worldly, beautiful Carla and the equally worldly, beautiful Renato, who behave less like the mother and teen-age son they are than like sister and brother. Renato calls her Carla and, though he's madly in love with her, he doesn't hesitate to act as Pandarus when someone strikes his mother's fancy. Carla and Renato are poor but well-born. They make do with the casual arrogance of true aristocrats.At the beginning of "Nest of Vipers" we meet their newest victim, a handsome young music student from the provinces, a highly moral, strait-laced fellow named Mattio. For a while it's touch and go whether Mattio will be seduced by Carla or Renato, or maybe by both at the same time. Carla wins the race by a beautiful nose and then goes on to fall deeply in love with Mattio, much to Renato's fury. But then Mattio, in his turn, falls deeply in love with the beautiful, worldly but far younger and much richer Elena.It's the sort of situation that bodes danger for all, and one that is finally resolved when one character picks up a bronze statuette and bashes another character over the head. I don't know about you but I've long since learned not to take seriously any movie in which someone hits someone else over the head with a bronze statuette, if only because of their rarity in the households I frequent.Everyone in "Nest of Vipers" lives in a palazzo or a part of a palazzo and because it's Venice, it's impossible for anyone to go anywhere, even, I suppose, to buy toothpaste, without walking in front of a vista that screams, "Having wonderful time. Wish you were here."In movies like this, of course, no one ever buys toothpaste. They're too busy falling in and out of love, being seduced and abandoned and eating well, to pay much attention to such ordinary functions as daily dental prophylaxis.Mr. Cervi obviously means this story of ravaged innocence to have some relation to the political and social life of Italy in the early 30's. We see uniformed Fascists speaking from balconies in the distance and sometimes close up as bit players dropping names (Mussolini, Mussolini's mistress), but his system is too simple to be of much interest. When Mattio succumbs to the evil in this world, it doesn't seem inevitable but more like an accident of nature, something on the order of swamp fever.The performers, though, are attractive and forthright, especially Senta Berger, who looks like Rita Hayworth in her prime, as the wicked but eventually victimized Carla, and Ornella Muti ("The Last Woman") as the sweet-faced rich girl who lures Mattio away from Carla. Christian Borromeo is very good as the once-innocent Mattio and Capucine, still rail-thin and elegant, is nice to see as Miss Muti's far-from-foolish mother.Nobody at Paramount Pictures, which is distributing this film, seems to know the names of the actors who play Renato and Miss Muti's father. Both actors are fine enough to be acknowledged, and the roles too important to be dismissed in this fashion.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: BUSINESS. Digest
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1979

title: Senate Votes to Block I.R.S. on School Bias Penalties
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)  The Senate voted today to kill for a year Internal Revenue Service guidelines under which private schools that discriminate against blacks and other minorities would be denied taxexempt status.

title: Ballet Theater Has New Queen In Swan Lake
description: NINE years ago, a coltish 15yearold American toiled away on the second act of Swan Lake in a small London ballet studio with Natalia Dudinskaya, then the codirector Leningrad's Kirov Ballet. On Sunday afternoon thatyoung American dancer, now 24, will dance OdetteOdile in Swan Lake on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House. She is Jolinda Menendez, a soloist with the American Ballet Theater and the company's first new swan queen in six years of New York performances.

title: Gold Soars, Tops $340 Abroad
description: The price of gold soared more than $11 an ounce early yesterday and traded above $340 for the first time as heavy speculative demand surged into the world bullion markets.

title: Helen Ward Brings Swing Songs to Marty's
description: Helen Ward, the brighteyed, darkhaired singer who soared to fame with Benny Goodman's orchestra almost 45 years ago singing Goodie Goodie, It's Been So Long and You Turned the Tables on Me, is playing her first extended engagement in New York since those Swing Era days, at Marty's, Third Avenue at 73d Street,through Sept. 15. This weekend she will be singing songs from her Goodman years as well as Come Rain or Come Shine, My Old Flame and Someone to Watch Over Me.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Chairman of Westchester Says He Won't Seek Reelection
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 6  Dr. James F. X. O'Rourke, the chairman of the Westchester County Republican Party, said today that he would not seek another term. The announcement came two days after his Democratic counterpart said he would resign his post.

title: President to Free 4 Puerto Ricans In Washington Shootings of 1950's
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  President Carter, citing humane considerations, today commuted the sentences of a Puerto Rican nationalist who attempted to assassinate President Truman in 1950 and of three others who sprayed gunfire from a gallery overlooking the House of Representatives in 1954, wounding five Congressmen.

title: House Passes Foreign Aid Bill, Slashing Funds for World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (Reuters) The House of Representatives approved a foreign aid bill today containing deep cuts in funds to international lending institutions and banning indirect United States aid to Vietnam, Cuba and four other nations.

title: Silver Fever Infecting Investors
description: As speculative fever has gripped gold markets and pushed prices to record levels in recent weeks, silver prices have advanced almost in lockstep, climbing from about $6 an ounce at the beginning of the year to $11.80 an ounce at yesterday's trading close.

title: Teheran Says Its Forces Capture Kurdish Rebels Last Stronghold
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 6 (Reuters)Iran's official press agency said today that Government forces had captured what it described as the last stronghold of the Kurdish insurgents, completing a threeweek campaign to drive the rebels from the northwestern towns they had controlled.

title: Mets Top Phils, 53, And Then Lose, 21
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6  What's left for the New York Mets in 1979? Manager Joe Torre pondered the question tonight as the sixthplace Mets split a doubleheader with the fifthplace Philadelphia Phillies. Both teams have their eyes fixed firmly on 1980.

title: Quebec. Economic Plan Stresses Local Ownership
