description: QUEBEC, Sept. 6  Quebec's nationalist government, which is seeking separation of the province from Canada, unveiled an economic plan today aimed at encouraging local ownership and control of the Frenchspeaking province's natural resources.

title: Iran Battles Cholera Outbreak
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 6 (UPI)  The Government announced a countrywide campaign today to combat a cholera outbreak that has taken five lives. The Ministry of Social Welfare said 12,000 suspected cases of cholera had been reported but only 240 had been confirmed. The ministry said earlier that cholera had killed five people and threatened the entire country.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK; MANHATTAN; BRONX; BRONX (Cont'd); BROOKLYN; STATEN ISLAND; QUEENS; LONG ISLAND; LONG ISLAND (Cont'd); ROCKLAND; WESTCHESTER; FAIRFIELD
description: Below 42d Street

title: SOME LIBERALS BALK AT PACT TILL SOVIET PULLS OUT CUBA UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  Some liberal Senators joined conservatives today in saying that the treaty limiting strategic nuclear arms would be either defeated or substanially altered if it reached the Senate floor before President Carter had achieved a satisfactory solution of the problem posed by the newly discovered presence of Soviet troops in Cuba.

title: Columbus, Ohio, Calm as Busing Is Begun on Staggered Schedule
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 6 (UPI) Courtordered busing of 37,000 students to 140 schools to achieve racial integration began without incident today in Ohio's capital city.

title: Business and the Law
description: THERE is probably nothing more confusing or misunderstood about lawyers than their ethical obligations to clients, corporate or otherwise. How can a lawyer argue one side of an issue in the morning for one client and the other side of the identical issue for another client in the afternoon? How cana dignified lawyer represent an unsavory type of client? How can a lawyer represent someone who sues a corporation and then later represent that corporation? And when a lawyer represents a company, who is the client? Is the client the corporate entity or the corporate management that hired the lawyer?

title: About Real Estate Housing Inn ovation Tested In a Strong Jersey Market
description: Despite a national decline in housing starts this year as compared with last, certain regions remain strong and major builders such as Kaufman & Broad and the Inganamort LaSala Organization continue to experiment with new products in New Jersey.

title: Tremor Kills 2 in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 6 (AP)  An earth tremor set off a rock fall in a gold mine early today, killing two miners, a spokesman at the mine said. The tremor, which lasted about 40 seconds, rattled windows and awoke residents of greater Johannesburg.

title: Luther Holbrook Dies
description: EAST BLUE HILL, Me., Sept. 6  Luther Gardner Holbrook, a financial adviser to the Richard King Mellon family, died here yesterday. He was 67 years old.

title: McGuire To Lose His Post
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 6 (AP)The board of trustees at the University of South Carolina has voted to replace Frank McGuire as head basketball coach at the end of the 197980 season, Markley Dennis Sr., the board's chairman, confirmed today.

title: Wright Backed In the Primary For Civil Court
description: Judge Bruce McM. Wright of Manhattan Criminal Court, who has been derided as turn'emloose Bruce by those who think his bail policies are too liberal, was praised yesterday as a courageous judge who deserves election to the Civil Court.

title: Goodrich Approves Offer for Tremco
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company announced that it had approved a definitive agreement under which shareholders of Tremco Inc. would be offered $40 cash for each of their shares. Thetransaction is valued at about $105 million. Goodrich said that it intended to begin its tender offer no later than Monday for Tremco's 2.6 million common share. The company, which is traded over the counter, is a Cleveland producer of specialty chemical products and also is in the roofing replacement market. Last year its net income was $6.1 million on sales of $91.3 million.

title: EARNINGS
description: The British Petroleum Company almost tripled its earnings in the second quarter and also in the first half this year compared with a year earlier. It also almost tripled its semiannual dividend and intends to split its stock on a 4for1 basis, according to an announcement yesterday by the company at its headquarters in London.

title: COMMODMES
description: Live cattle futures closed from 0.25 to 1.5 cents a pound higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday, recovering from two days of mostly lower prices.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Puppet figures with people inside them will cavort on East Ninth Street between First and Second Avenues this evening  and in Brooklyn tomorrow  as the Bread and Puppet Theater winds up a series of free performances in New York. At 5 P.M. tonight, washerwomen with large puppet heads, wearing peasant dresses and aprons, will appear at a street fair in vignettes from the troupe's play Washerwoman Nativity. Then at 7, same location, Bread and Puppet dancing bears, jugglers, fairy tale figures and who knows what else will present a circus. The next afternoon, a larger version of the circus will be offered at a site that has more elbow room, in the Nelly Bly Amusement Park, Shore and Bay Parkways in Bensonhurst. For infor9969002.

title: G.M. Pays a Penalty of $250,000 For '77 Chevette Gasoline Leaks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)  Government safety officials said today that the General Motors Corporation paid a $250,000 penalty last month because the gasoline tanks in 1977 Chevettes failed to comply with a Federal safety standard.

title: 3 Japanese Tourists Die In Eruption of Volcano
description: TOKYO, Sept. 6 (AP)  A volcano in southern Japan erupted suddenly today and sent huge rocks crashing onto a crowd of sightseers near its crater. Three people were killed and 12 injured, the police said.

title: NATO Autumn Drills Starting
description: CASTEAU, Belgium, Sept. 6 (Reuters)  Hundreds of thousands of troops will take part, starting tomorrow, in NATO's annual military exercises, code named Autumn Forge. The maneuvers will extend from Norway to the Mediterranean.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: 13% Rise Is Expected In Capital Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)  Despite the recession, American businesses plan to spend $179.1 billion for plant and equipment in 1979, 13.2 percent more than last year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Russian Fair On
description: The mood will be vesyoloyeRussian for joyous  this weekend at the third annual festival at St. Nicholas Russian Orthodox Church of Whitestone, 1465 Clintonville Street, in Whitestone, Oueens.

title: Allegheny Ludlum Debt
description: Allegheny Ludlum Industries said that it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $93 million of 20year subordinated sinkingfund debentures. It said the debentures would be offered under a planned exchange for a like amount of outstanding 9 percent subordinated sinkingfund debentures, due Dec. 1, 1989.

title: New York City's New Greeter
description: Whenever Mayor Koch's inner circle is discussed, the names David and Bobbie Margolis always pop up near the top. He is the president of Colt Industries Inc., and on Tuesday, she became the city's $1ayear official greeter  the first woman to hold that post.

title: Dalai Lama Thrills Some AmericanBorn Disciples
description: They show up wherever the Dalai Lama goes, nodding quietly at his remarks. They are the Americanborn westerners who have discovered Buddhism and who are thrilled by his messages.

title: Gaylord, Gilliam and Joe Black
description: Before the San Diego Padres 139th game, Gaylord Perry called a news conference to announce that his season was over and he and his family were leaving for their farm in Williamston, N.C. With 23 games remaining on their schedule, the Padres had a chance to overtake the Giants for fourth place in the National League West or be caught by the Braves and finish last. Perry, who is paid $220,000 a year, could have started four or five of those games but he wasn't interested. He has won 12 and lost 11 this year.

title: Art: 86 Mobiles By George Rickey
description: AS of now and through Oct. 14 there is a retrospective exhibition of mobile sculptures by George Rickey at the Guggenheim Museum. It comes none too soon (Mr. Rickey was born in 1907), and by the standards of today it is none too large. There are 86 items in the catalogue, admittedly, but many of them are small. Besides, it is fundamental to Mr. Rickey's art that it does not so much commandeer space as borrow it. And where earlier sculptures press down heavily upoon the earth, Mr. Rickey's hover above it like dragonflies in search of a pit stop.

title: Curb Panel On Energy, Aides Ask
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  Three toplevel environmental officials have written to President Carter to express concern over White House failure to prevent Congress from broadening the authority of the proposed Energy Mobilization Board, Government officials said today.

title: Business Loans Up $1.14 Billion
description: Business loans at the major New York City banks soared by a record $1.19 billion in the week ended Sept. 5, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The previous high of $1.06 billion was set in May 1978.

title: New York City Plans a Note Sale To Meet Current Financial Needs
description: New York City plans to return to the public lending market for the third time this year with an issue of $150 million to $200 million of shortterm notes.

title: Carey, in Switch, Backs Power Plant on S.I.
description: John S. Dyson, the chairman of the State Power Authority, said yesterday that his agency would seek permission to build a billiondollar electric power plant on Staten Island. The plant, on Arthur Kill, would burn coal and garbage.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)  Black lawyers today denounced a proposed promotion for Federal District Judge Cornelia M. Kennedy of Detroit, while Judge Kennedy said she was offended by suggestions she was racially prejudiced.

title: Yanks Rally in 10th And Beat Tigers, 31
description: DETROIT, Sept. 6  Rich Gossage demonstrated again tonight that when he is ready and able in the bull pen, the Yankees are difficult to beat. He pitched onehit ball for 3 innings against the Tigers and helped New York beat Detroit, 31, in 10 innings.

title: Stage: Soaring in Peter Pan
description: SANDY DUNCAN has convinced me of one thing, at least. Flying is the only way to go. From the time of her moonburst entrance through the suddenly parted rooftop windows of the Darling nursery right through to her second curtain call  in which she soars rather farther than most performers would care to chance  Miss Duncan is a Peter Pan who is at her most exhilarating when dizzyingly airborne.

title: Market Place
description: IT is a curiosity of finance that the dividends some utilities are either partly or wholly nontaxable. These nontaxable dividends arise when a utility has insufficient earnings to cover the dividend as reported on its income tax return.

title: Two Children and Policeman Drown in Jersey Culvert
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Sept. 6  A boy and a girl as well as a 51yearold police officer attempting to rescue them drowned here this afternoon when the rubber raft on which the youngsters were riding down a rainswollen creek was sucked into a huge drainage culvert.

title: Henry Ford Bids Press Adieu
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 6Henry Ford 2d, for 34 years the undisputed boss of the Ford Motor Company, bid a formal public farewell today to the daytoday hustle and bustle of his worldwide headquarters here.

title: Jailed Terrorists Spurred Interest In Independence
description: Independence for Puerto Rico has been an issue since United States troops occupied the former Spanish colony in 1898, but in recent years the movement has received impetus from demands for freeing the terrorists whose sentences were commuted by President Carter yesterday.

title: Dance: Cynthia Harvey Debuts As Myrta in Giselle
description: IT was a very young Giselle that American Ballet Theater presented on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House. Marianna Tcherkassky, small and delicate, is an almost adolescent Giselle. In his New York debut in the role, Kirk Peterson, stepping in to replace the indisposed John Meehan as Giselle's aristocratic suitor, has such a boyish face he might instead be Romeo. And Cynthia Harvey, a young soloist relatively new to major classical roles, made her New York debut as Myrta, the queen of the vengeful spirit Wills.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Dennis J. Carney, chairman and president of the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation and the man who signed his company's controversial agreement last week with two Federal agencies to guarantee $150 million in loans, feels as comfortable in his company's plants as in its executive suite.

title: Advertising
description: MUSEUMS, it seems, are in. Americans are thronging to museums with boundless enthusiasm. Membership is way up. Attendance is way up. So it would seem that museumgoers could use a magazine about museums. That is exactly what they are about to get.

title: Pistons Get McAdoo in Carr Compensation
description: Bob McAdoo, one of the National Basketball Association's most prolific scorers and frequent travelers, was sent to the Detroit Pistons yesterday by the Boston Celtics. In return, the Celtics will receive the Pistons two 1980 firstround draft choices. The deal also settled the Celtics compensation to the Pistons for signing M.L. Carr, a free agent, in July.

title: Cuban Inmate's Brother Hopeful but Wary
description: The younger brother of Lawrence Lunt, one of the four United States citizens whose release soon from prison in Cuba is now seen as likely, said yesterday that he was hopeful but refused to get excited until his brother was actually free.

title: TV Weekend Miss America, Emmies And Tennis Featured
description: THE schedule contains a liberal sprinkling of specials. Tomorrow at 10 P.M., NBC will carry live the Miss America Pageant, with Bert Parks marking his 25th year as host. On ABC Sunday at 8:30, theEmmy Awards will have Henry Winkler and Cheryl Ladd as principal hosts. And on both Saturday and Sunday, CBS will be offering parts of the United States Open Tennis tournament from Flushing Meadow Park. Coverage concludes Sunday with a fivehour session that begins at 4 P.M.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: By The Associated Press

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Publishing: Norman Cousins and the Doctors
description: IN his latest work, Anatomy of an Illness: As Perceived by the Patient, Norman Cousins uses his own chilling experience to advance the controversial idea that a patient's attitude can affect the course of a serious disease. This may seem as unusual to some laymen and physicians as some of the notions that the longtime polemicist, now chairman of the editorial board of Saturday Review, has put forth across a long career. Among those notions are world federalism and safeguarding the environment against the onslaughts of industrial polluters.

title: Fury Coach Resigns
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (UPI) Marko Valok resigned today as head coach of the Philadelphia Fury of the North American Soccer League. Valok, who joined the Fury on Feb. 16, said he would return to Belgrade, possibly to coach the Partizan team, which he had left to coach Philadelphia.

title: Leader of South Africa Warns Neighbor on Presence of Cubans
description: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa, Sept. 6 (Reuters) South African Prime Minister P.W. Botha tonight warned Lesotho, a country surrounded by South Africa, against allowing Cubans into its territory.

title: Kingston Celebrates a Festival on the Hudson
description: In 1609, Henry Hudson sailed up the river that now bears his name and anchored at the Roundout Creek to take on fresh water for the crew of the Half Moon. In 1777, the British fleet sailedup the river to the same area and burned the flourishing city of Kingston, then the first capital of New York State. This weekend, a Hudson River Festival in Kingston will commemorate those great moments in Kingston's maritime history.

title: The Pop Life
description: IN August 1977, Karla Bonoff released her debut album, entitled Karla Bonoff. It was a lovely disk, and was received as such by many critics and enough of the public to insure a respectable if not overwhelming commercial success. In concert, too, Miss Bonoff had a grave, sad beauty, reinforcing the same qualities in her songs and her singing.

title: 3 Top Rookies In Knick Fold
description: The Knicks invested heavily in their future yesterday, spending a total of more than $500,000 a year to sign Bill Cartwright, Larry Demic and Sly Williams, their three firstround draft choices.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Airlift International Inc., a Miamibased airfreight and charter service, has elected James Lawrence Smith executive vice president.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, Sept. 6, 1979

title: Funds for Restitution In Franchise Swindle Are Ordered by Court
description: The New York State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, obtained orders in state and Federal courts yesterday that are expected to provide nearly $3 million in restitution to victims of a New York City franchiseselling operation that reportedly bilked participants of $12.5 million.

title: Fire Officers Reelect Jennings
description: Edward Jennings has been elected president of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association for a fifth consecutive term, the union announced yesterday. Theunion represents 2,300 fire officers in the city, including lieutenants, captains, battalion and deputy chiefs. Others elected were Lieut. Thomas C. Henderson, vice president; Capt. James P. Leddy, treasurer; Vincent J. Bollon, recording secretary; James J. McGowan, financial secretary, and Frank J. D'Amico, sergeantatarms.

title: RollsRoyce Plans Layoffs of 30,000
description: LONDON, Sept. 6 (Reuters)  RollsRoyce Ltd., the aircraftengine maker, said that it would lay off all its 30,000 engineering workers if the current series of engineering strikes and the ban on overtime are not ended by Sept. 14.

title: Alaska Pipeline Incentive Set
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (Reuters) The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission took the final step to allow for the financing of the Alaska naturalgas pipeline system by issuing an order today approving an incentive rate of return for the Alaska and northernborder segments of the pipeline system.

title: Jets Name Todd as Starter
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 6  The continuing drama involving the Jets quarterbacks was charged anew today when Richard Todd got back the No. 1 job, replacing Matt Robinson, who has a sprained thumb.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown. ( N ) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Police Say Suspect Rode to Rob in Limousine
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 6  A 20yearold robbery suspect with a touch of class rode a chauffeurdriven limousine to three holdup sites last night in Staten Island, New Jersey and Long Island, the Nassau County police said today.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Broadway
description: BROADWAY this season is beginning to look like a musical memory lane, what with Peter Pan flying around the LuntFontanne and West Side Story, Oklahoma! and The Most Happy Fella waiting in the wings. But little by little, names of fresh dramas are creeping into the list of coming attractions: Frank D. Gilroy's Last Licks, Abe Polsky's Devour the Snow, Martin Sherman's Bent, Tennessee Williams's Clothes for a Summer Hotel.

title: Landrieu, in Hearing on Confirmation, Says Real Estate Deals Were Ethical
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  Moon Landrieu, President Carter's nominee to head the Department of Housing and Urban Development, acknowledged today that while Mayor of New Orleans he was a business partner and shared a substantial profit with a man who did business with the city.

title: Sadat Says He and Begin Agreed on Need for Palestinian Progress Soon
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 6  Ending a threeday visit to Israel, President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said today that he and Prime Minister Menachem Begin had agreed on the vital necessity to make progress on the Palestinian question soon.

title: T.W.A. to Reduce Service, Personnel
description: Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that it was planning cutbacks in airline service and layoffs of at least 1,000 employees on all levels next month. It cited the projected recession, rising fuel and operating costs and decreases in air travel.

title: Human Rights Group Opens Inquiry in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 6  The InterAmerican Human Rights Commission opened a twoweek investigation of human rights in Argentina today.

title: Opera Notebook When Is a Light Touch The Right Touch?
description: EVERY time an American opera company sneaks a work of a popular musical nature into its repertory, there is always someone to voice a complaint. Johann Strauss, Lehar, Herbert, Gershwin or Weill? Surely such composers should not be rubbing shoulders with Mozart, Verdi or Wagner.

title: Sefton Delmer, Reporter Witnessed Hitler 's Rise
description: LONDON, Sept. 6 (AP)  Sefton Delmer, one of Britain 's bestknown foreign correspondents in the period between the World Wars, has died at the age of 75, the Press Association reported today. The British domestic news agency nave no details of his death.

title: Metropilitan Baedeker Atlantic City: What's Happening Along the Boardwalk
description: TRADITIONALLY, this is the climactic weekend for the Atlantic City summer season, the last chance to mingle with beachgoers and Boardwalk strollers. Once upon a time the Labor Day weekend was the final fling. The changebegan more than half a century ago, when local promoters in 1921 started a beauty contest to extend the season a week past Labor Day. The contest has blossomed into the annual multimilliondollar Miss America Pageant, drawing throngs to the resort each year during the second weekend of September. Now, for the second year, these throngs merge with crowds attracted to Atlantic City's new casinos, multiplying the numbers and gladdening the hearts of owners of enterprises from gambling houses to pinball arcades, from restaurants to shops.

title: Miss Rapp Wins Butterfly
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 6 (AP) Betsy Rapp won her third gold medal in swimming but three more American tennis entries were eliminated today at the lath World University Games, leaving alive only the topseeded men's doubles team of Dick Metz and Blaine Willenborg.

title: Bridge:
description: Notwithstanding the growing popularity of Swiss team events, enthusiasts competing in clubs and tournaments spend the vast majority of their playing time in pair events scored by match points. Curiously enough, the specialized techniques required in this form of the game, so vastly different from those needed at rubber bridge, and in the various forms of team play, have received relatively little attention in the literature of the game.

title: Doctor's Wife Stabbed to Death; He's Booked as Material Witness
description: GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Sept.6 (AP) The wife of a surgeon in Essex County was found stabbed to death yesterday, and the surgeon was arraigned as a material witness. the police said.

title: Pioneer Craft Detects 11 th Moon And Second New Ring of Saturn
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Sept. 6 Pioneer 11 scientists reported today that the spacecraft had discovered an 11th moon orbiting Saturn and yet another tenuous ring of debris circling the planet, the seventh such feature.

title: In Israel, Sadat Offers Nile's Water for Negev
description: TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 6 (AP)  P resident Anwar elSadat of Egypt suggested at a meeting with Israeli newspaper editors today that the Nile River could be a source of irrigation water for Israel's Negev Desert once a tunnel is completed next year under the Suez Canal.

title: Random House Blends The Elite and the Popular
description: In American and international publishing, and among authors, Random House and its divisions are considered both prestigious and commercial. The combined publishing lists of its components include some of the world's leading writers as well as children's and paperback titles that compete in the mass marketplace.

title: Redskins Seek to Avoid Conflict With Pope's Visit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI)  The Washington Redskins of the National Football League are seeking permission to move their Oct. 7 home game with the Philadelphia Eagles from Robert F. Kennedy Stadium to Philadelphia so it will not conflict with the Washington visit of Pope John Paul II.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Auctions
description: HOW could the City of New York be host to a folkart festival that did not include A folkart auction? That, as one might suspect, was the question asked by certain executives of Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, following Mayor Koch's announcement last month scheduling the city's first such festival for next Monday through Sunday, Sept. 16. The celebration includes an exhibition of Shaker art, architecture and antiques at the Museum of American Folk Art, 49 West 53d Street; the fall antiques show at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street, and a twoday seminar on Shaker history and achievements.

title: Strong Army Buildup By Vietnam Reported On LaosChina Border
description: KUNMING, China, Sept. 6  Vietnamese regular army troops have taken up fortified positions along the Laotian border with China in the last few months, a senior Yunnan Province official said today.

title: World Gold
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1979

title: Vice President Dismisses Report On Potential for Heading Ticket
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)  Vice President Mondale, dismissing reports on his potential as a Presidential candidate, says he would be honored to serve as President Carter's running mate in a reelection bid.

title: Heating Fuel Supply Up Sharply in Week
description: The oil industry's stockpile of homeheating fuel and related products jumped sharply last week, surpassing the yearearlier level for the first time in 1979, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: McEnroe Is Victor As Dibbs Defaults; Gerulaitis Prevails
description: It took John McEnroe 12 minutes and Vitas Gerulaitis 2 hours 30 minutes to complete an allAmerican lineup for the men's singles semifinals at the United States Open tennis championships.

title: New Look at Parks Department: Some Progress, Some Problems
description: I caught myself thinking on Labor Day that we'd made it through another summer without mishap, Parks Comissioner Gordon J. Davis said the other day, and then I realized that we weren't through it at all.

title: RCA Aims to Sell Book, Food Units
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to sell two of its wholly owned subsidiaries, Random House Inc., the publishing company, and the Banquet Foods Corporation, a leading supplier of frozen prepared foods.

title: Nixon Demands U.S. Restore San Clemente To Original Condition
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 6 (UPI)  Former President Richard M. Nixon gave the Government 60 days today to remove Secret Servicerequired improvements to his property and restore it to its original condition.

title: Israeli Troops Repel Guerrillas Trying to Cross the Jordan River
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 6 (UPI)  Israeli troops drove off Palestinian guerrillas last night when they tried to slip across the Jordan River on a mission apparently timed with President Anwar elSadat's visit to Israel, the military command said today.

title: Changes Costing Birmingham Its Feeling of Security
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  This used to be called the South's biggest country town, but the problems worrying Birmingham's citizens this summer are neither smalltown nor particularly Southern.

title: Meriden Calls In Help After Riot By a Young Mob
description: MERIDEN, Conn., Sept. 6  City officials today imposed an 8 P.M. curfew in a 10block area around a public housing project after an estimated 75 to 100 youths converged on a police station last night and threw rocks and bottles.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: Movie: 'Patrick' From Australia:A Seventh Sense
description: "PATRICK," the Australian shock-melodrama that opens today at the Rivoli and other theaters, is about a short-tempered fellow whose mother insists on making noisy love to a man not her husband in the room next to Patrick's. Later, while the pair is having a soothing soak in the tub, Patrick shocks them fatally by dropping an electric heater into the water. In what we are told is the explosion that follows, Patrick suffers brain damage and is considered dead except for the fact that his heart continues to beat.All of this happens behind the opening credits of "Patrick," which is the story of Patrick's revenge on the living as he lies in a comatose state in a private clinic, a none-too-reassuring establishment run by a certain Dr. Roget (Robert Helpmann), who looks 2,000 years old and hasn't a line in his face. Patrick, in his isolation from his other senses, has developed what is called "a seventh sense." He can read other people's minds and move objects, often at a great distance and sometimes with lethal effect.The film, which was directed by Richard Franklin and is called "a Richard Franklin film," much as "Prophecy" was called "a John Frank-enheimer film," is absurd but not without its comic moments, which "Prophecy" lacked. There's a cold, emotionally unreliable chief nurse, nicely played by Julia Blake, who says such things as "Disease, like God, moves in mysterious ways," and, of a new nurse, "She comes to us in the wake of an unstable marriage situation."You can't be mad at a movie with lines like that, or with one that casts Susan Penhaligon as its worried heroine, a nurse for whom Patrick develops an unhealthy passion. Miss Penhaligon has the round-faced prettiness of a silent-film star and the sexy, self-assured humor of French actresses like Bulle Ogier and Miou-Miou. It's a terrific combination.The special effects aren't at all bad, but the only shock in the movie comes when the mad doctor sticks a long needle into the brain of a real-life frog. Somehow that doesn't seem entirely cricket.With the exception of Miss Penhaligon and Miss Blake, the other actors in the movie, including Robert Thompson, who plays Patrick, seem ill-atease, badly directed or just rotten."Patrick," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), includes some details of bogus medical procedures that might prove usetting to the weak of stomach.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: Deaths

title: 13 Food Establishments Called Health Violators
description: The New York City Department of Health yesterday released the names of 13 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code.

title: RHODESIANS ATTACK MOZAMBIQUE'S ARMY
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Sept. 6  The military headquarters of Zimbabwe Rhodesia announced today that its forces were staging a major land and air attack into Mozambique against troops and installations of the Mozambican Army as well as against black guerrilla bases there.

title: Nicaragua Asks for Aid at Third World Talks in Cuba
description: HAVANA, Sept. 6  Nicaragua's new Government appealed to the conference of third world nations here today for disinterested help to enable it to rebuild the country's devastated economy.

title: OddEven Sales of Gas Ending In New York and 4 Other States
description: Oddeven gasoline purchase restrictions, in effect since June 21, were lifted late yesterday by New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Rhode Island after an assessment indicated that fuel supplies would be sufficient to prevent the panic buying that the rules had been imposed to curb. Pennsylvania will end the restrictions tomorrow.

title: Beauty Queen vs. Jaycees
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 6 (AP) Debbie Shook, stripped of her Miss North Carolina title in a dispute with the Jaycees, has filed a lawsuit seeking $87,204.88 in damages and restoration of the title.

title: Masters of the Photo Reviewed in 3 Shows
description: THIS promises to be quite a season on the photography exhibition scene in New York, and it has begun with something of a bang with three very remarkable exhibitions. For photographs of historical

title: Storm Plays Odd Tricks, Both on Land and at Sea
description: Early yesterday morning, the waters of Upper New York Bay were heaving from the combination of a flood tide and an ebbing hurricane. Capt. Kenneth Finnerty of the ferryboat Cornelius G. Kolff, a man with 27 years of experience on the BatterytoStaten Island run, observed a fading blip on his radar. He looked out to see if there were any hands on deck, but he couldn't see a deck.

title: At the Movies
description: ONE of the more unusual things about Rich Kids, the second feature film Robert M. Young has directed, is its title. Franny Phillips and Jeremy Harris, the two young New York teenagers who are the movie's principal characters, do indeed come from affluent families. But their households, while comfortable, aren't all that much more extravagant than the homes American movies generally take for granted.

title: U.S. Steps Up Aid to Dominicans; New Storm Brings Heavy Rains
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 6  Tropical Storm Frederic drifted over the northwest part of this country today and continued to dump heavy rains on areas ravaged earlier by Hurricane David.

title: 2 Banks Are Robbed And Attempts Made At Others in the City
description: There were two successful bank robberies and three attempted ones in New York City yesterday, and at least two in the suburbs.

title: The City
description: Arnold Stokes, the 15yearold Brooklyn youth convicted of killing Irene Maxwell, the 31yearold Scottish fashion designer, was sentenced to nine years to life in prison, the maximum sentence for murder under the state's Youthful Offender Act.

title: Music: Merry Widow
description: THE New York City Opera's operetta prelude to the company's regular fall season of repertory is continuing at the New York State Theater this week with a sevenperformance run of Franz Lehar's The Merry Widow that began on Wednesday night.

title: The Cuban Line for the Nonaligned
description: Probably by accident, reports of the Soviet military buildup in Cuba surfaced just as 90odd nonaligned nations were about to meet in Havana. But it was surely no accident that Fidel Castro chose to open the Havana summit with a call to arms against American imperialism. Mr. Castro apparently aspires to be doctrinal pontiff as well as titular chairman of the nonaligned bloc. And he might succeed.

title: C.A.B. Will Study T.W.A. Fare Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board voted today to investigate whether Trans World Airlines started charging higher fares last Saturday, before the airline had filed for permission to raise fares.

title: Affirmed Officially Out of the Marlboro
description: Thoroughbred racing's best field of the year will be going to the post tomorrow at Belmont Park, but Affirmed will not be in it.

title: Drive to Bar Pay Raises Is Halted
description: An attempt to block pay increases for the Mayor and other elected city officials by putting the issue on the ballot this year was halted yesterday when organizers decided not to file the more than 160,000 signatures they said they had gathered.

title: Gold, the Streets Are Paved With
description: Strolling home a few weeks ago near Sheridan Square, I was stopped by one of those wayfaring travelers who are often seen snoozing, merry as iguanas, on Greenwich Village sidewalks in the summer sun. Unwashed, ragged, slurping a wine that had known no vineyard, he stumbled over and thrust a small manila envelope in my face. What's this, he mumbled, some kinda foreign money?

title: World News Briefs
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 6 (Reuters)  Tribal insurgents fighting the Sovietbacked Government in Afghanistan said today that they had laid siege to Mukur, a garrison town south of Kabul, the capital.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Deaths

title: NOWAccount Bill Advances
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)  The House Banking Committee overwhelmingly approved today a bill to legalize interestpaying checking accounts nationwide. By a 35to4 vote, the panel sent the bill to the full House where a vote is possible as early as next week.

title: Election Panel Rules Party Rivals of Carter Are a Political Group
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)  A group of Democrats seeking to dump President Carter from the party's 1980 national ticket must register and file reports as a political committee, the Federal Election Commission ruled today.

title: Churning Path of Destruction Begins in the DeadCalm Doldrums
description: They begin in the doldrums at sea and, as often as not, follow a path of destruction and end in disaster on land.

title: On Ireland
description: LONDON  Just three days before the murder of Lord Mountbatten shattered London's holiday calm last week, a top official of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government looked out at the peaceful scene in St. James's Park, and told his American visitor: We're absolutely committed to taking a political initiative in Northern Ireland. I can't yet say exactly what it will be, but I can tell you what it won't be: It will give the people of Ulster more control over their own affairs, without going back to any of the disastrous failures of the past.

title: House Votes to Cut Social Security Disability Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  The House voted today to revamp the Social Security disability programs by reducing certain benefits and increasing incentives for the disabled to return to work.

title: Young Assures Africans on U.S.
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Sept. 6  Andrew Young, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, sought tonight to assure black African nations that the Carter Administration's policies toward them would not change and that its relations with them would be sound.

title: Jazz: World's Greatest as Quintet
description: WHEN the World's Greatest Jazz Band was started in 1968, it was a ninepiece group that quickly established itself as the Cadillac of the traditional jazz world. Not only was it bigger than other traditional jazz bands but it included such established stars as Yank Lawson, Bob Haggart, Bud Freeman, Bob Wilber, Billy Butterfield and Ralph Sutton. Since 1973, however, some of the fancy trimmings have been removed. Aside from Mr. Lawson and Mr. Haggart, who are the coleaders of the band, the personnel has been in a state of flux, drawing on a pool of musicians rather than maintaining a steady group, and it has dwindled in numbers.

title: Claude Montana's SpaceAge Styles Touch Down on West 54th Street
description: The audience at Studio 54 almost upstaged Claude Montana's fashions on the stage Wednesday night. Almost but not quite. Not that the fashion groupies didn't try. Anybody with a sewing machine had done his best to copy Montana's yardwide shoulders and intergalactic space suits, but the designer, who along with Thierry Mugler is one of the Katzenjammer Kids of French readytowear, was a million miles ahead of his satellites in showmanship.

title: Senate Panel Calls a Hearing on Intelligence on Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence will hold hearings next week to determine whether there was an intelligence failure by the United States in detecting Soviet combat brigade in Cuba, a committee spokesman said today.

title: Nuclear Issue Raised at Hearings On State's Energy Master Plan
description: Arguments for and against a proposed moratorium on the growth of nuculear power dominated the start of hearings yesterday by New YorkState's Energy Planning Board on a master plan for energy usage.

title: For Judges in Manhattan and Queens
description: On Tuesday, Manhattan Democrats will decide whether or not the controversial Judge Bruce McM. Wright will move up from Criminal Court to Civil Court. Judge Wright's challenger is Jack Dubinsky, law assistant and secretary to Justice Harold Birns the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN his last novel, Slapstick (1976), Kurt Vonnegut told us that he believed in the Bill of Rights, Robert's Rules of Order and the principles of Alcoholics Anonymous. In his new novel, Jailbird  his best, inmy opinion, since Mother Night (1961) and Cat's Cradle (1963)  he adds another sacred document. It is the Sermon on the Mount.

title: Borg Returns Home After Storm of Aces
description: In the players lounge, the weather forecast was chalked on a blackboard. After the temperature and the winds and the humidity, it read: Next hurricane coming our way  Hurricane Roscoe.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Jet, Giant Games Clash on TV
description: The Giants home opener against the St. Louis Cardinals and the Jets match with the New England Patriots at Foxboro, Mass., on Sunday will be played at the same time, beginning at 1 P.M. There will be no lateafternoon telecast in New York of an outoftown game, such as Oakland at San Diego or Seattle at Miami. Channel 2 will televise the Giants game, and Channel 4 the Jets game. Both local teams are underdogs.

title: Split Among Irish Americans Said to Cut Funds to I.R.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  A major split between two IrishAmerican groups aligned with the Irish Republican Army has led to a sharp reduction of American financial support for the organization, Irish officials said today.

title: Economic Scene
description: WALL STREET, after weeks of cheering the arrival of Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board to administer a stronger dose of monetary restraint than that of his predecessor, G. William Miller, has suddenly decided that it does not have much stomach for soaring interest rates and recessiondamaged profits after all.

title: Missile Plan Is Reportedly Chosen
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI)  President Carter has approved a socalled race track system for the MX landbased strategic intercontinental missiles to hide them from a Soviet sneak attack, an Administration official said today.

title: Berlin Driver Reportedly Defects
description: WEST BERLIN, Sept. 6 (UPI)  The driver of the United States Ambassador in East Berlin has defected with his family to West Berlin in the embassy car, a press report said today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, Sept. 8

title: New Face: Ken Jennings Sweeney Todd's Innocent Apprentice
description: HE has not played a leprechaun yet, but it seems almost inevitable. And sure enough, Ken Jennings confides, I've always wanted to play Og in Finian's Rainbow.

title: Most Foods in Freezer Can Survive Blackout
description: Most foods will keep for some time in refrigerator freezers even though electrical power is off. Wellfrozen juices, vegetables or meats, cooked and uncooked, will not spoil for 24 to 48 hours as long as the refrigerator remains closed, according to the New York City Health Department.

title: Market Ends Slump As Oil Stocks Star
description: The stock market advanced moderately yesterday in slower trading following two consecutive sessions of sharp declines. The best performers were some oil and specialsituation issues.

title: The Editorial Notebook What's the Right Tax for Foreign Oil?
description: According to some Congressional liberals, big oil companies are paying billions less than their fair share of taxes. That is why they are pressing for legislation to prevent the industry from crediting foreign tax payments against domestic tax liabilities. The reformers are a bit late: the I.R.S. already taxes overseas oil income the same as foreign profits on computers or hairspray. But given the peculiar politics of energy, there may be a case for making foreign oil pay more than its fair share. The American economy  and perhaps the industry, too might benefit in the long run.

title: Prosecution Says Member of Gang Admitted Role in Murder of 2 Girls
description: The Bronx District Attorney's office reports that an 18yearold member of the Savage Nomads, a Bronx street gang, has said on videotape that he took a part in the murders of two 14yearold girls and has implicated others in the gang in the rave of one of the victims.

title: The Sovereign Again Assailed By Its Tenants
description: A longsimmering feud between some tenants and the management of the Sovereign apartment building has erupted into angry accusations again, this time over windows that blew out and a lack of gas for the stoves.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page 1 on Wednesday incorrectly identified Senator John C. Stennis as a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. He is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Art People
description: ONE of the pleasanter new sights around Manhattan the last year or two has been the series of 23 heads of women by Alex Katz that was put up in 1977 on the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 42d Street. They were wrapped around two sides of the building at fourthfloor level, and they also went streaking up the sides of a 60foot tower on the corner. They had the look of tranquil expectancy that is one of Mr Katz's specialities, and in 1977 they also looked clean, fresh and trim, the way his people usually do.

title: Chinese Paupers Renew Protest Near Peking Government Offices
description: PEKING, Sept. 6 (AP)  A group of Chinese with grievances rekindled their protests today outside Government offices and tacked up a poster pledging that they would not leave until we are victorious.

title: Rock: Rory Gallagher
description: CREAM, the band that became rock's most influential power trio, inspired countless lesser bands to play loud, bluesbased music with improvisational extensions during the late 1960's and early 70's. In the typical trio of the period, the guitar was thunderously amplified and created the illusion, at least, of simultaneous rhythm and lead playing while bass and drums thundered darkly beneath. This brand of musicmaking soon proved limiting, especially for guitarists, and only a few musicians have carried it into the middle and late 70's, most notably Robin Trower and Rory Gallagher.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1979

title: Rams Conquer Broncos by 139
description: DENVER, Sept. 6 (AP)  Jack Reynolds, a Los Angeles linebacker, scooped up a Craig Morton fumble and staggered 4 yards into the end zone midway through the final quarter, lifting the Rams to a 139 victory over the Denver Broncos in a defensedominated National Football League game tonight.

title: Restaurants
description: SLOWLY but surely, Brazilian restaurants have been proliferating on the local scene, and we were surprised to discover recently that they now number 13. Except for the 16year old Casa Brasil on East 85th Street, Brazilian restaurants until about two years ago were relegated to the theater district, particularly to 46th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.

title: KENNEDY CAMP SEES A STEP TO 1980 RACE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  Senator Edward M. Kennedy has moved a step closer to becoming a candidate for the 1980 Democratic Presidential nomination by letting it be known that, for the first time, his family has given its blessing to his running for President if he chooses to do so.

title: Grandparents Day Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)  President Carter signed a proclamation today designating Sunday as the first annual National Grandparents Day. He did so after signing a Congressional resolution asking that the first Sunday after Labor Day be officially set aside as a day to honor grandparents.

title: Silver Screens For Star Gazing
description: This weekend, if you choose, you can spend a long, glamorous evening with Marlene Dietrich and an afternoon with Charlie Chan. You can trace the history of postwar Italian cinema, from Stromboli to Padre Padrone, or contemplate the 1960's as seen by JeanLuc Godard. You can hear Eleanor Powell singing Cole Porter, or Nelson Eddy and Jeanette MacDonald singing duets, or just watch Eleanor Parker lipsynching as she plays a dying opera star in Interrupted Melody. Should you be more interested in what you see than what you hear, there's Werner Herzog's The Mystery of Kaspar Hauser, a movie with a star  Bruno H.  who says almost nothing at all.

title: For Children
description: WILDLIFE THEATER BIRD SHOW, with seven parrots, including Cookie, a white sulphurcrested cockatoo and two macaws, who will perform at 11 A.M., 12:30, 2, 3:30 and 4:30 P.M., at the Zoological Park, the Bronx Zoo, 185th Street and Southern Boulevard. Show free. Zoo admission: children, 75 cents; adults, S1.50, Friday through Monday. Parking, $2. Call 2205100.

title: Notes on People
description: A littleknown cloakanddagger episode of World War II will be recalled today in Hyde Park, N.Y., when a batch of cables, memos and reports will be formally presented to the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library.

title: U.S. Disclaims AntiIsrael Votes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  The State Department dissociated itself today from two antiIsrael votes cast by an American representative at a United Nations human rights subcommission meeting in Geneva, saying he had been acting in a personal capacity.

title: Inquiry Pursued in David Kennedy Incident in Harlem
description: The police continued their investigation yesterday of an incident at a dilapidated hotel in Harlem where David A. Kennedy, the 24yearold son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, said he was robbed of $30 early Wednesday evening.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1979

title: China Asks Japan for $5.5 Billion Loan For 8 Rail, Port and Power Projects
description: TOKYO, Sept. 6  A top Chinese economic official has asked Japan for Government loans totaling about $5.54 billion for eight railway, port and power projects that Peking considers fundmental to its industrialization.

title: Delay in Reactor Permits Is Seen Until Panel Reports on Accident
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today it was unlikely that any new construction or operating permits would be granted for reactors until after the publication in October of a report by the Presidential commission investigating the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island.

title: Revised British Payments Gap
description: LONDON, Sept. 6 (Reuters)  Britain had a balanceofpayments deficit of $5.05 billion for the first half of this year, in contrast to a surplus of $2.04 billion for the second half of last year, the Government said today.

title: F.C.C. Moves to Loosen Controls On Radio Ads and Programming
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  The Federal Communications Commission today proposed a number of steps to allow the radio industry to broadcast programs and commercials free of Government control.

title: Four Who Got Clemency
description: Born in Puerto Rico and shuttled between homeland and the Bronx as a young man . . . reputation before assassination attempt was as kind, peaceable man . . . was member of Nationalist Party of Puerto Rico . . . 37 years old, married with a child at time of shooting . . . had been employed as metal polisher in New Rochelle ... pleaded not guilty on ground that he was just trying to create demonstration and had not intended to kill ... 8thgrade education but voracious reader with passion for history . . . long outraged by what he felt was oppression of Puerto Ricans in United States . . . spent Sundays meeting planes filled with immigrant Puerto Ricans . . . said after President Truman granted clemency on death sentence that he preferred death and martyrdom to life imprisonment . . . waived consideration for parole when it first came up in 1966 . . . sued officials at Leavenworth in 1976 for mistreatment.

title: WASHINGTON Carter's Abiding Optimism
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  Almost everybody is writing Jimmy Carter's political obituary these days except the President and the little band of Georgians who helped get him here in the first place.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets weakened for the third consecutive day yesterday, driving interest rates higher for a wide variety of fixedincome securities.

title: Among Allies: Doubt on U.S.
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 5  For the second time in 20 years, the credibility of the American commitment to use nuclear weapons in the defense of Western Europe has become a volatile issue in relations between the United States and its principal allies.

title: 8 Dead in Northeast as Storm Hits; Utilities Working to Restore Power
description: Spawning tornados as it moved up from the South, Tropical Storm David tore into the Northeast yesterday, killing at least eight people and leaving more than 2.5 million residents of the New York metropolitan area without electricity.

title: Chrysler Raises 79 Loss Forecast
description: The Chrysler Corporation, again raising its estimate of how much money it expects to lose this year, warned yesterday that the amount would be even greater than the $600 million to $700 million pretax loss it had projected a week ago.

title: Unmasked Lone Ranger Pledges Life to His Role
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6  I've been the Lone Ranger for 30 years, Clayton Moore said in a drawl that seemed to have originated somewhere West of the Pecos and South of Yesteryear, and I intend to be the Lone Ranger for the rest of my life; I've decided I'll stay the Lone Ranger until I'm called.

title: Retired Gravelle Rejoins Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 6  Gordon Gravelle today rejoined the Giants, who were beginning to resemble a home for retired and castoff offensive tackles.

title: Rhode Island University Cancels All Classes During Faculty Strike
description: The University of Rhode Island suspended all further classes yesterday until settlement of a faculty strike, the first in the school's 87 years.

title: The Inevitability Of U.S. Dealings With the P.L.O.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Two questions are currently raised by the central issue in the ArabIsraeli conflict: the conciliation of Palestinian aspirations and of Israeli security.

title: BigTime Show Business Back Las Vegas Style
description: Old Blue Eyes is in Atlantic City this weekend and that revivified resort town which sees an alteration in its skyline virtually every day, can now be officially considered to be back in big time show business.

title: Koch Trying to Improve Image Among Minorities
description: Mayor Koch, saying that his administration was embarking on a major effort to improve his image among minorities, conceded that there was a negative feeling that I have to correct among many black residents of the city.

title: Federal Reserve In millions
description: Wednesday, Sept. 5, 1979

title: New Jersey's Prescription for Hospitals
description: New Jersey's Health Commissioner, Joanne Finley, said recently that if hospitals couldn't get the money to pay for indigent patients from local governments, they would simply have to eat the costs. Some hospitals  particularly those in big cities have just about choked. Now New Jersey has a much better solution for its $2billion hospital industry. It plans to spread the cost of indigent care among all insurers, thus relieving the hospitals that have been serving a disproportionate share of nonpaying patients.

title: Latest Gordimer Novel Barred in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 6 (AP) Censors have banned the latest novel by Nadine Gordimer, the South African author, on the ground that it depicts, among other things, whites as baddies, blacks as goodies and endangers the safety of the state, according to a censorship letter published today.

title: A County Fair On Third Avenue
description: The sponsors are calling it a county fair, but there will be no tractors to ride, hogs to call or marching bands to listen to. Fairgoers won't be able to kick the tires on the latest pickup or gaze at the largest squash ever harvested.

title: Wildlife Group Honors Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI)  The Florida Wildlife Federation presented its conservation award today to President Carter for his help in blocking construction of the Cross Florida Barge canal and other efforts to preserve the state's natural beauty. At a ceremony in the Oval Office, the federation president, Walter Brandon, told Mr. Carter that his firm stance against the canal had resulted in one of the first reversals of an Army Corps of Engineers project.

title: Fed Finds Banks Wary on Chrysler Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  The Federal Reserve has concluded that commercial banks have lent the financially ailing Chrysler Corporation only 50 percent of the credit they can legally extend.

title: W.J. vanden Heuvel Weds Melinda Pierce
description: The marriage of William J. vanden Heuvel, United States representative at the office of the United Nations in Geneva, and Melinda Fuller Pierce took place in New York yesterday.

title: The Region
description: ALBANY  A Federal judge yesterday ordered substantial increases in the numbers of black, Hispanic and female state troopers.

title: John Mulhearn Dies; Was Chief Executive For Phone Company
description: John R. Mulhearn, president and chief executive officer of the New York Telephone Company, died last evening during a meeting in Yonkers. He was 55 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Pollution Curbs Being Proposed For U.S. Lands
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP)  The Government proposed today to shield 47 primitive areas and national monuments from the spoilage that can result from unchecked air pollution.

title: Senator Nunn Bids Carter Push For a Big Rise in Arms Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, today urged President Carter to lead a campaign to persuade Congress and the public that the United States should significantly increase defense spending.

title: Lionel Goldfrank Jr., 73, Is Dead; Retired Chief of a Paint Concern
description: Lionel Goldfrank Jr., retired chairman of the board of the Clover Leaf Paint and Varnish Corporation, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital of complications following a stroke. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Stroh Brewery Company, the eighth largest in the industry, announced a proposal yesterday to acquire a 51 percent interest in the F.& M. Schaefer Corporation, the 10thranking brewer, subject to successful renegotiation of the debt structure of Schaefer with its longterm institutional creditors.

title: Burukksu Burazazu Brings Ivy League Styles to Japan
description: TOKYO  An American gazing at the gleaming new granite facade among the wood and stucco fronts along AoyamaDori, a popular Tokyo shopping street, might easily have imagined himself in the heart of Manhattan. There are the same wide windows, with suits displayed on headless dummies, and the discreet metal plaque with Brooks Brothers in flowing script, exactly like the one at the entrance to 346 Madison Avenue.

title: Big Board Profits Down for Quarter
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that its member firms doing business with the public had a total net profit of $146 million after taxes in the second quarter this year, down from $169.1 million in the comparable three months of 1978, when trading reached the highest volume in the exchange's history.

title: India May Push Panning For Gold as Price Rises
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 7 (Reuters) With the price of gold soaring to record heights and India's only gold mine nearing exhaustion, the country may revive panning for the precious metal.

title: 1.2% Increase Is Largest Since January  Prime Rate at Record 12%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  Paced by new increases in food costs, producer prices rose by 1.2 percent in August, the largest monthly increase since January, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: Muzorewa Heads for London Talks As Forces Press Mozambique Raids
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Sept. 7  While forces under his command continued to attack targets in Mozambique, Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa left for a constitutional conference in London today saying he believed we are going to succeed in solving the! problems of this country once and for all

title: Peak 12% Prime Rate Is Set
description: Dozens of banks across the nation raised their prime rate, or basic lending charge, by onehalf of a percentage point yesterday to a record 12 percent in an unusual move that underscored the upward thrust of interest rates in general throughout the economy. The prime is usually raised in quarterpoint steps.

title: P.L.O.'s New York Office Glows in PostYoung Spotlight
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 7 Representatives of the Palestine Liberation Organization are basking in attention they are receiving from Americans these days, and admit they can thank Andrew Young, the outgoing United States chief delegate.

title: Your Money
description: THE television commercial goes something like this: Have you old diamond jewelry or fine silverware around the house? Turn them into cash for the new things you want. Then, along with the details about where to get the highest prices for the old treasure, the commercial ends with a picture of a smiling matron  minus jewelry  with a new refrigerator.

title: ConservativeLiberal Clergyman
description: LONDON, Sept. 7  Dashing war hero, pig breeder, brilliant debater, dinnertable wit  these were among the descriptions of the next Archbishop of Canterbury given by newspapers, television and radio when the choice was announced today.

title: Papal Visit Switches Game
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP)  The National Football League game between the Philadelphia Eagles and the Redskins scheduled for Washington Oct. 7 will be played in Philadelphia because of the enormous crowds expected for Pope John Paul II's visit to the capitol on that date. The game between the clubs set for Philadelphia Oct. 21 will be switched to Washington.

title: U.S. URGED TO RELAX CURB ON DNA STUDIES
description: BETHESDA Md., Sept. 7  A national advisory committee has recommended exemption from strict Federal guidelines of 80 to 85 percent of current studies with recombinant DNA, or genesplicing research.

title: Miller Bars Chrysler Tax Credits
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  The Chrysler Corporation's top officials, John A. Riccardo, its chairman, and Lee A. Iacocca, its president, met with Treasury Secretary G. William Miller today to present a preliminary report on the company's efforts to develop a financial recovery plan.

title: Sally Little Ahead by 3 In Denver L.P.G.A. Event
description: DENVER, Sept. 7 (AP)  Sally Little carded eight birdies and posted six-under-par 66 today to take a threestroke lead after the first round of the $100,000 Columbia Savings golf tournament.

title: Pope's Journey to U.S. Is a Political Test for Planners
description: ROME, Sept. 7  The planners of the visit to the United States by Pope John Paul II next month have been faced with interrelated and often conflicting factors of religion, politics, diplomacy and logistics in drawing up his itinerary. And there may be lastminute changes.

title: Koch, Displeased by a Crime Rise In Subways, Plans a New Strategy
description: Mayor Koch is dissatisfied with the recent results of a sixmonth campaign to combat crime in the city's subway system  an effort that has already cost $8.6 million  and is expected to announce changes in the program next week.

title: Tunnels Are Searched for Missing Student
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 7 The authorities at Michigan State University and private investigators are combing an eightmile maze of steam tunnels underneath the campus here in an effort to find a 16yearold computer science student who disappeared Aug. 15.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Friday, Sept. 7, 1979

title: The Region
description: SOMERVILLE, N.J. (AP)  Investigators tracing money taken in what was described as the nation's largest embezzlement at a credit union said yesterday that almost all of the missing $4.8 million had been lost in a string of bad investments.

title: Injured Mrs. King Is Routed By Mrs. Lloyd in Semifinals
description: Chris Evert Lloyd could sense a difference in the locker room before the match.

title: Deaths
description: SCHWARTZArnold. The Officers, Trustees and staff, of The Brooklyn Hospital, express profound sorrow at the loss of their friend and collegue, Arnold Schwartz. His leadership, inspiration, & vision madw possible the Arnold & Marie Schwartz Clinical Research & Instruction Unit at The Brooklyn Hospital. His wisdom, generosity and concern, in advancing medical research & clinical care has earned him the gratitude not only of those whom the Hospital served but all New Yorkers. The Brooklyn Hospital family expresses their deepest sympathy and condolences to his beloved wife, Marie.

title: Deaths
description: NADLERRaoul P, M.D.FAPA, of Harrison, N.Y. Beloved husband of Jane (nee Damon). Devoted father of Lisetta, Alexander and Jonathan. Funeral services Saturday, 2 p.m., at Ferncliff Chapel. Dr. Nadler was clinical director of Edenwald CenterJCCA, Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: Bruce Is on the Spot In Ohio State Debut
description: Last year, Ohio State opened its season by losing to Penn State, a perennial Eastern power, 190. More surprising than the outcome was that Ohio State began the game with a freshman, Art Schlichter, throwing a pass on the Buckeyes' first play.

title: Bridge
description: Entry to bridge events can be restricted by past performance, masterpoint status, sex and geography geography because one would not wish to have a European team, for example, qualify as the United States squad.

title: A Soviet Reply to 5 U.S. Writers
description: Following is a condensation of a letter that Feliks Kuznetsov, chairman of the Moscow branch of the Soviet Writers Union, mailed recently to five American authors  the playwrights Edward Albee and Arthur Miller and the novelists William Styron, John Updike and Kurt Vonnegut Jr. In this version, provided to The New York Times by Mr. Kuzentsov, he replies to the writers, who sent a sharply worded protest to the union denouncing both the suppression of a literary anthology known as Metropol that had been planned by 23 Soviet writers and the union's suspension of two of the contributors, Yevgeny Popov and Viktor Yerofeyev. The 500page manuscript consisted of work that the 23 considered their best writings and that they had never been able to get past the censors. The Americans termed the efforts last winter to publish the anthology a courageous undertaking that would have marked a historic moment in the struggle for literary freedom in the Soviet Union. The Americans noted that the contributors had been subject to official sanctions since seeking approval to publish the anthology without censorship.

title: Clay Seeks Confidence, but Loses to Tigers
description: DETROIT, Sept. 7  Ken Clay, already stung by the harsh comments of George Steinbrenner a week ago, did nothing to improve his standing with the Yankees' principal owner here last night.

title: Marine Band to Play Two Concerts on L.I.
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 7  The United States Marine Band, which is on a tour of the Northeast, will give afternoon and evening performances at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum here next Wednesday for the benefit of the Nassau Chapter of the American Red Cross.

title: Dance: A 1910 Revival And a Debut for Today
description: American Ballet Theater's first mixed bill of the season, Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, featured a revival from 1910 and a young dancer's debut in a contemporary work.

title: Notes on People
description: Miss Sills Gets a Nice Key and Hears Her Praises Sung

title: Deaths
description: Abraham, Max

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 26.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: SCHWARTZArnold. The Medical Board of New York University Me dical Center express their sorrow at the death of Arnold Schwartz whose foresighted beneficence provided our Cooperative Care facility at University Hospital, a pioneering effort in the advancement of patient care. His many contributions to this institution will benefit generations to come.

title: Dance: Festival in Park
description: The New York Dance Festival, presented by the TAG Foundation at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, moved into its third program of the season on Thursday. If there has been bet- ter modern dance, Indian classical dance and ballet on New York stages this year, there have also been worse. This was a night of generally lowkeyed but pleasant dance.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: ABRAHAMMax, beloved husband of Ann. dear brother of Henrietta Stern and David, and devoted uncle. Services Sunday, September 9, 1:45 PM, The Riverside, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Visiting at the chapel Saturday evening 7:309 PM.

title: Commercials at the Movies
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 7 To moviegoers, a brief film of a top rock group performing one of its new hits may seem like a little extra bit of entertainment. And, if so, that's just what the producers of the new minifilms being shown at firstrun movie theaters intend. But these short films are actually commercials, however subtle.

title: The City
description: Mayor Koch signed into law yesterday two bills providing for tighter controls on street peddlers of nonfood items.

title: Giants Fine Gravelle $15,300
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 7  Gordon Gravelle, who came out of retirement to bolster the Giants' battered offensive line, has been fined $15,300 for his trouble.

title: Business Records
description: ANTONA TRUCKING COMPANY, 62 South St., Washingtonville, N.Y. Joseph M. Antona is president. Liabilities, $797,212; assets, $499,819.

title: JURY STUDYING TIES OF A U.S. PUBLISHER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  A Federal grand jury here has begun investigating activities in the United States in behalf of South Africa and is focusing its attention on John P. McGoff, the conservative Michigan publisher who tried unsuccessfully to buy The Washington Star several years ago.

title: Amy Clark Is Wed To John Davidson
description: Amy McLaurey Clark, daughter of Judith Abbott Clark of New York and Richard Clark, was married Tuesday to John Matthew Davidson, son of Joan K. Davidson of New York and C. Girard Davidson of Portland, Ore. Civil Court Judge Felice K. Shea performed the ceremony at the Manhattan home of the bride's aunt, Mrs. John Wharton.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Producer prices jumped 1.2 percent in August, the largest monthly gain since January, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. Food costs paced the increase, the department said. Energy prices also rose rapidly, although some of the gains have not yet reached the wholesale level, which the index measures. [Page 1.]

title: News Summary
description: President Carter warned Moscow that its relations with Washington would be adversely affected if it does not take seriously the United States concern over the presence of Soviet combat troops in Cuba. He urged the nation to remain calm and said that the Administration would seek to negotiate a diplomatic resolution of the troops issue. He noted that the combat unit was not an assault force, though its purpose was not yet clear. [Page 1, Col. 6.]

title: Kennedy's Remarks on 1980 Seem To Increase Chances of Candidacy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  Senator Edward M. Kennedy indicated today that he was reevaluating whether to run for the 1980 Democratic Presidential nomination and seemed to leave open a greater possibility than ever before that he would make the race.

title: Coroner: Paralysis Hit Munson
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 7 (AP)  Thurman Munson, the New York Yankees' catcher, was paralyzed from the neck down as a result of the crash of the plane he piloted Aug. 2, but was fully aware of the circumstances from the onset of the accident, the Summit County coroner reported today.

title: Boy Stabbed to Death In IRT Station Attack
description: A Harlem teenager was stabbed to death and his brother was also stabbed yesterday during an attempted robbery in a Lexington Avenue IRT subway station.

title: Tanner's Motion Serves Him Well
description: Given a choice between facing a firing squad or Roscoe Tanner's serve on a hard, fast court under the lights, most tennis players probably would choose the firing squad.

title: Text of the President's Statement
description: I want to take a few minutes to speak to you about the presence of the Soviet combat brigade in Cuba. The facts relating to this issue have been carefully laid out by Secretary Vance both in his public statement and in his testimony before the Congress. The facts in brief are as follows:

title: City's Jobless Rate Down a Point, From 10.2% to 9.2%, Last Month
description: New York City's unemployment rate dropped a full point last month, from 10.2 percent to 9.2 percent, but remained far above the national rate of 6 percent.

title: Lawyer Given Term in Trial Delay
description: Herald Price Fahringer, a wellknown criminal defense lawyer who specializes in constitutional and obscenity cases, was sentenced yesterday to 10 days in jail after being held in contempt for refusing to begin a trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: I. A. Richards, Author, Teacher And Literary Critic, Is Dead at 86
description: I. A. Richards, the teacher and writer whose influential early books on literary criticism urged Occidental man to feel and reason in a coherent way, died yesterday at Addenbrooke Hospital in Cambridge, England. He was 86 years old and had been seriously ill since returning last month from a stay in China.

title: Deaths
description: SCHWARTZArnold on September 7th. Beloved husband of Marie. Father of Constance. Son of the late Samuel and Lena Schwartz of Brooklyn, New York. Brother of Henry and the late I. W., Robert B.. B. D. and Bessie Levy. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Saturday with services on Sunday, Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue at 55th Street, at 1 P.M. Interment Washington Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Thumbs Down on Robinson as Holder
description: Matt Robinson, the Jets' quarterback whose sprained thumb will keep him sidelined tomorrow against New England, will also be unable to hold the ball for Pat Leahy's placekicking. Tim Moresco will replace him.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Agriculture U.S.A.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: City's Children Shortchanged on Services, Study Finds
description: New York City schools are currently graduating fewer than half of their students.

title: ARNOLD SCHWARTZ, PHILANTHROPIST, 74
description: Arnold Schwartz, a founder and former vice president of the Paragon Oil Company and a philanthropist in health care and education, died yesterday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital following a heart attack. Mr. Schwartz, who had homes in New York City and Greenwich, was 74 years old.

title: Film: Dumas Is Revived In 'The Fifth Musketeer':The Cast
description: Ken Annakin's "The Fifth Musketeer" revives without quite giving life to Alexander Dumas's story about the man in the iron mask, the intelligent, stout-hearted, look-alike twin brother of France's Louis XIV who, according to Dumas, was so stupid he couldn't have successfully checked into a motel, much less conceive of the construction of Versailles."The Fifth Musketeer," which is now playing at the Victoria Theater, has a cast that reads like the passenger list for next year's "Airport" movie: Beau Bridges, Sylvia Kristel, Ursula Andress, Cornel Wilde, Helmut Dantine, Alan Hale Jr., Olivia DeHavilland, Jose Ferrer, Rex Harrison, Lloyd Bridges (Beau's father) and Britain's Ian McShane who, being both a good actor and still in the top of his form, may be the only one who wouldn't fit aboard one of Universal's jetliners.With Beau Bridges playing both Louis and his brother, Philippe, the movie was photographed by Jack Cardiff on some very grand Austrian locations that double for the Louvre, Fontainbleau, the Bastille, among other places. Mr. Wilde, Mr. Hale, Mr. Ferrer and Lloyd Bridges play the aged Musketeers who set history straight. Rex Harrison plays Jean Baptiste Colbert, Louis's remarkably able chief minister, as a wily but immensely benign old fellow, and Mr. McShane is the evil Nicolas Fouquet, whose enduring monument is the magnificent chateau, Vaux-le-Vicomte. In life he died in prison. In the movie he disappears into a sewer.Miss Andress, as Louis's mistress, pops prettily out of dresses that make her look like a self-propelled vanity table, while Miss Kristel ("Emmanuelle," "The Concorde  Airport '79") is sweet without being stupid as the Spanish Infanta, Louis's fiance.Though "The Fifth Musketeer" is loaded with intrigue, duels, large-scale swordplay, heavy costumes and heavier dcor, it is singularly without style or even excitement. In the center of it, Mr. Bridges the younger seems bewildered in the manner of someone unsure of his real identity."The Fifth Musketeer," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains duels in which one person or another inevitably gets stuck, but the blood is kept to a minimum.

title: Seatrain Cites Quarterly Loss
description: Seatrain Lines Inc. reported yesterday that it had a $26.2 million deficit for the fourth fiscal quarter ended June 30 as a result of a $26.7 million loss owing to the discontinuation of its shipbuilding operations.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP) The Irish Republican Army said today that many more deaths of both British and Irish people would follow the assassination of Earl Mountbatten of Burma if Britain continued its rule in Northern Ireland.

title: Ettore Bertona, Founder Of Several Eating Places
description: Ettore Bertona, the founder of several New York City restaurants, including the Curb Exchange in the Wall Street district, died Aug. 21 while vacationing in Montecatini, Italy.
