He was 93 years old. Mr. Bertona founded the Hotel Marguery Restaurant at 270 Park Avenue, which he operated from 1918 to 1953, when it closed. He later established the Curb Exchange Restaurant, which became the American Stock Exchange Restaurant. He ran it until he retired in 1967. He also founded several other restaurants in New York during his career.

title: Plenum Wins a 10Year Extension Of Pact to Publish Soviet Material
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 7  The second Moscow International Book Fair has produced the extension of a major agreement between Soviet publishing authorities and a New Yorkbased publisher of scientific and technical works, it was announced today.

title: James Edward Fuller Weds Susan Friedman, Executive
description: Susan Friedman, president of Friedman Huss Viseltear Inc., an advertising creative recruitment concern, was married yesterday to James Edward Fuller, a vice president of Benton & Bowles, a New York advertising agency. The ceremony was performed by State Supreme Court Justice Harold Birns in his chambers.

title: Strauss Off to the Mideast Again To Get Views of Sadat and Begin
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special Middle East negotiator, said today that he planned to have detailed discussions with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel in the next few days on the results of the justconcluded meeting in Haifa and on ways of proceeding in the Palestinian autonomy talks.

title: Chicago Opera Will Tape Gounod's Faust for TV
description: The Lyric Opera of Chicago, as part of its 25th anniversary celebration this year, is videotaping for public television this season's production of Charles Franois Gounod's 19thcentury opera Faust, starring Mirella Freni as Marguerite and Alfredo Kraus as Faust.

title: Health Hazards Beset Hempstead TrashFired Plant
description: WESTBURY. N.Y.  The power plant built to produce onefifth of the Town of Hempstead's electricity out of 2,000 tons of its garbage daily has been spreading nauseating gases over nearby neighborhoods and exposing workers to unsafe levels of dust and germs in its first year's shakedown, according to residents and Federal officials.

title: PRESIDENT CHOOSES MOBILE MISSILE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  President Carter, expressing worry about the Soviet threat to current United States fixedbase missiles, announced plans today for a $33 billion system for deploying 200 new mobile missiles in Western desert valleys.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON APRACTICING physician who is on the faculty of the New York Medical College has invented what he calls an Alertometron, an electronic instrument to measure a person's responses to visual, auditory and tactile stimuli  sight, sound and touch.

title: Going Out Guide
description: EARLY RISERS If you are at least 16 years old and can tread water or float for 10 minutes, The American Small Craft Association will teach you the basics of handling a sailboat. Lessons start next year, but today the association is holding sailing graduation ceremonies at the boathouse in Flushing Meadow Park, in Queens. And, to whet your sailing appetite, there will be demonstrations of canoeing and formation sailing on Flushing Meadow Lake.

title: Federal Judge Rejects Resignation of a Juror In Vesco Investigation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  A Federal judge has decided not to accept the resignation of the foreman of a Federal grand jury who has accused the Justice Department of covering up information in an investigation involving Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier.

title: Stocks Up; Bad News Ignored
description: Oil stocks and takeover issues made large gains yesterday, while the stock market in general registered a strong advance despite some unfavorable economic developments.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WQXR. Sinfonia Concertante in E flat, Mozart; Suite from L'Europe Galante, Campra; Overture to the Italian Girl in Algiers. Rossini; Salome. Hadley: Montagues and Capulets from Romeo and Juliet, Prokofiev.

title: HAVANA CONFEREES REACH COMPROMISES
description: HAVANA, Sept. 7After a night of bitter clashes at the conference of thirdworld nations, compromise resolutions were found early today on disputes involving Cambodia and Egypt that should avert an open split.

title: Texaco FuelOil Supply at 87%
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it expected to supply its homeheating oil customers this winter with at least 87 percent of the amount of fuel they received a year ago.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA, Lehar's The Merry Widow, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, 2 and 8.

title: Jack Tell Dies at 70 in Las Vegas; Founder of Weekly Jewish Paper
description: Jack Tell, the founder and editor of The Las Vegas (Nev.) Israelite, an Englishlanguage weekly newspaper reporting events of the Jewish community, died Aug. 26 in Las Vegas after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: 2 More Inmates Caught
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 7 (AP)  Two more of the 30 inmates who escaped from a jail in Jessup, Md., last month have been captured in Savannah, Ga., according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Six remain at large. John Lee Childress, 23 years old, and Donald E. Craddock, 42, were taken into custody yesterday morning at a motel.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reportsin The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 36.

title: ExPresident Arrested by Manila for Rumormongering and Sedition
description: MANILA, Sept. 7  The martiallaw Philippine Government accused former President Diosdado Macapagal of sedition and rumormongering today and placed three of his associates in the opposition Liberal Party under house arrest on similar charges.

title: Panel Suggests 9 For 3 Vacancies On Bench Here
description: A report yesterday by a screening panel on candidates for State Supreme Court in Manhattan and the Bronx touched off a complicated jostle among ethnic, political and geographical groups.

title: P.S.A.L. Football Officials Strike
description: The Public Schools Athletic League's opening football games, scheduled for next Saturday, were jeopardized yesterday as game officials voted not to work.

title: Three Steal $100,000 in Jewelry
description: Three armed men robbed a Manhattan jewel company of more than $100,000 in assorted jewelry, the police said. The robbery occurred at the Jewel Manufacturing Company at 915 Broadway, near 20th Street, the police said. There were no arrests.

title: Letter: On Transracial Adoption
description: We are replying to the recent editorial concerning the ruling by Connecticut Superior Court Judge Harry Hammer which ordered a white couple in Vernon, Conn., to relinquish custody of the 4monthold black (male) child they were caring for on a fostercare basis.

title: Around the Nation
description: RENO, Nev., Sept. 7 (AP)  Representatives from a dozen Western states voted today to enlist in Nevada's Sagebrush Rebellion, joining the fight to wrest control of Federal lands in their territory from the Government.

title: War Hero, 57, to Succeed Coggan As the Archbishop of Canterbury
description: LONDON, Sept. 7  A 57yearold Bishop, Robert Runcie, was designated today as the 102d Archbishop of Canterbury, Primate of the Church of England and spiritual leader of the 65millionmember worldwide Anglican communion.

title: Plenum Hails Agreement
description: According to Mark Shaw, executive vice president of the Plenum Publishing Corporation, interviewed by phone at the company's headquarters in New York, the 10year deal signed in Moscow is the most lucrative one Plenum has received to date from the Russians, but he gave no figures. The agreement renews a fiveyear publishing deal between the Russians and Plenum.

title: Letters
description: As one long associated with the civil rights movement and the N.A.A.C.P., I deplore my good friend Bayard Rustin's sophomoric lecture to blacks about the P.L.O. [OpEd Aug. 30].

title: U.S. Swimmers Capture Only One Final at Games
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 7 (AP)  The United States, which had dominated the swimming events, won only one of four finals in the pool today, but salvaged some pride with a basketball rout of Cuba in the 10th World University Games.

title: Afraid to Show Our Linen in Public
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.  The slightest news media mention of security risks, spies and secret documents transforms me instantly into a young Alaskan housewife with a complete set of Elmendorf Air Force Base blueprints jammed into a linen closet.

title: New York city Level Off to 9.2%  a Recession Since spring Indicated
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  The national unemploymert rate climbed to 6 percent in August. the highest level in more than a year. as a result of layoffs, especially in manufacturing and construction, the Labor Department reported today.

title: CBS Records Taking Steps To Spur Sales
description: Even with some signs that record sales are rebounding after a period of decline, CBS Records has announced new policies relating to pricing and dealer returns that may further stimulate sales. The new policies include a tightening of the return rate to 20 percent and the slashing of list prices of most extant popmusic records from $7.98 to $5.98.

title: The Sewers of Suffolk County
description: All the political dirt dug up in Suffolk County's longdelayed Southwest Sewer Project has been hurled by Peter Cohalan and John Klein in the course of a dismal campaign for the Republican nomination for County Executive. Republicans would be wise to vote Tuesday for Mr. Cohalan, now the Supervisor of Islip Township. Mr. Klein's genuine talents have been irremediably muddied by the sewer scandal.

title: Pirates Rally in 14th To Defeat Mets, 64
description: Neil Allen had done what he could. For the final four of last night's 14 innings. the Mets' best relief pitcher held the firstplace Pittsburgh Pirates scoreless. He watched his team load the bases and fail to score in the eleventh, and just before midnight he watched the Mets collapse behind him, giving the Pirates a 64 victory.

title: Cuba to Weigh Release Of 4 Jailed Americans
description: HAVANA, Sept. 7 (AP)  Foreign Minister Isidoro Malmierca said today that the Cuban Government would study the possibility of relasing four Americans imprisoned since the 1960's once the United States carried out its promise to set free four Puerto Rican nationalists.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1979

title: OBSERVER
description: They call him a spoiled brat, a blowhard, an insufferable lout. In England they call him a bounder. When he kicks an autograph seeker in the shins, they call him a boor. If he thumbs his nose at the stands, they call him hideous names, names that may not be printed in family journals.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 2 P.M. (Radio WMCA, 2 P.M.)

title: Crisis in Cuba: Political Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  President Carter's political prestige, as well as SovietAmerican relations, have now been caught up in the furor over the belated discovery of a Soviet combat brigade in Cuba.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times Thursday about relations between blacks and Jews incorrectly identified Carolyn R. Payton as the current director of the Peace Corps. She was succeeded in that post several months ago by Richard Celeste.

title: Little Gain At Talks on Gas Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  Senate and House conferees talked for four hours today about giving President Carter standby authority to order gasoline rationing, but they made little progress toward agreeing on legislation to achieve that end.

title: Money
description: FRIDAY. SEPTEMBER 7 1979

title: A Venerable Limb Falls, And It's the 1940's Again
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 7  James Sheridan paused while sawing a silver maple tree that had toppled onto his backyard tomato patch yesterday during Tropical Storm David and he recalled how, during World War II, the 23 children then living on Reynen Court used to climb in the 100yearold English oak tree that stands in his front yard.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVINGTODAY, Sept. 8

title: Breakthrough Reported In Treating Gonorrheal
description: BOSTON, Sept. 7 (UPI)  Strains of gonorrhea resistant to penicillin can he treated effectively in 24 hours with one dose of a synthetic antibiotic that was recently approved by the Food and Drug Administration, researchers said today.

title: Tennessee Williams Work At Bouwerie Lane Theater
description: Kirche, Ktchen and Kinder (Church, Kitchen and Children), a new workinprogress by Tennessee Williams, will open next Saturday at the Bouwerie Lane Theater, 330 Bowery. The play will mark the Jean Cocteau Repertory Company's ninth season.

title: Advice Given About Claims For Damages
description: For the homeowner whose house and property were damaged by Tropical Storm David, there are several things to consider when putting things back into shape.

title: Wall St. Journal May Add Section
description: A top executive of The Wall Street Journal said yesterday that the newspaper might add a new section next year  the first such change since it was founded in 1889  to provide more space for advertising and to bolster its coverage of foreign news.

title: Pop Concert: Ella Fitzgerald Is Full of Surprises
description: It is easy to take Ella Fitzgerald for granted. She has been out there in front of us as a single, on her own, for almost 40 years, and for six years before that she was one of the most popular singers of the Swing Era, with Chick Webb's band.

title: Beef Prices Begin to Rise After Steep August Drop
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  After a welcome and unusually sharp drop in retail beef prices last month, the price of beef in the supermarket appears to have firmed and resumed its more familiar upward pattern.

title: A Contrast of Styles in Soccer Title Game
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 7  In what looms as a clash of contrasting styles, the Tampa Bay Rowdies and the Vancouver Whitecaps will meet at Giants Stadium tomorrow to decide the championship of the North American Soccer League.

title: Israel Holds 70 as Gaza Terrorists
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 7  Israeli military authorities in the occupied Gaza Strip announced the arrest today of 70 alleged terrorists, including the 19yearold son of a Palestinian leftist who recently met with Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan. Further arrests are planned.

title: Discoveries in Cuba, and Washington
description: One belated discovery has now produced another: those two or three thousand Soviet combat troops in Cuba pose a greater political problem for President Carter than he originally reckoned. Relations with the Soviet Union have been clouded. Confidence in American intelligence has been eroded. And the coherence of Administration foreign policies has been widely questioned. Cuba has long been a sore point in American politics and an election year approaches.

title: Jazz: Turner and Glenn Team at Lone Star Cafe
description: Jazz critics have often marvelled at how much Joe Turner is able to accomplish within what they perceive as the limitations of the blues form  the narrow melodic range, the simple and unvarying structures and so on. But one might more profitably marvel at Mr. Turner's gifts, which render the apparent limitations of his chosen idiom irrelevant. He executes the subtlest gradations in pitch with an exactitude that should make any sort of singer envious. His voice is huge and heavy, but he handles it with supple grace, phrasing flexibly, sometimes playfully, but always with absolute rhythmic authority. And from the almost limitless storehouse of traditional blues verses, he has selected a relative handful of vivid, numinous images and made them his own.

title: Congress Accused in Suit On Capital's Air Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  Down a shady neighborhood street, only four blocks from the shadow of the Capitol, lies a lesson for those Congressmen who think that the laws they pass should be meant for them, too.

title: Vote on Kennedy Center Keeps President's Boxes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  The Senate refused this week to trim the number of free tickets to the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts that are made available to the White House and the center's director.

title: Antoinette Slovik, Widow of a G.I. Shot by Army for Desertion in 1945
description: Antoinette Wisniewski Slovik, widow of Pvt. Edward Donald Slovik, a soldier in World War II who was the only American to be executed for desertion since the Civil War, died yesterday in Sinai Hospital in Detroit after a long illness. She was 64 years old.

title: Invitation to a South African Team Raises Problems for Mrs. Thatcher
description: LONDON, Sept. 7  A proposed tour of Britain by a South African rugby team threatens to embarrass the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and possibly to disrupt the constitutional conference on Zimbabwe Rhodesia that opens here Monday.

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY. SEPTEMBER 7, 1979

title: Examiners Say Lance Felt Kin's Overdrafts In '75 Were Improper
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 7 (AP)  Bert Lance told investigators as early as 1975 that he believed that his relatives' overdrafts of of checking accounts were improper, according to documents filed in Federal District Court.

title: Dalai Lama Says Buddhists Could Learn From Christians' Activism
description: Western religion has many points which we must learn, the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhists, said yesterday. He added that he and his form of Buddhism had changed in some ways.

title: Books of The Times
description: In only a limited sense, Carey McWilliams writes in the preface to his latest book, is this an autobiographical narrative. And the man who has

title: Electric Power Remains Out For Thousands After Storm
description: Utilities' crews continued to restore electricity late last night to metropolitanarea homes and businesses left without power by Tropical Storm David, but the tedious process was not expected to be completed until today or tomorrow.

title: Mexicans Use Chemical Sprays In Bid to Dissolve Oil Spill Patct
description: SOUTH PADRE ISLAND, Tex., Sept. 7 (AP)  The Mexican authorities are using aerial chemical sprays in an attempt to dissolve a patch of oil 135 miles south of Brownsville in the Gulf of Mexico, United States officials have said.

title: For Some at School, Summer Ends Early
description: It's almost the beginning of school again  the days of spelling quizzes and biology labs, bus passes and report cards, early bedtimes and boxed lunches, science fairs and gvm.

title: CARTER TELLS SOVIET DISPUTE ON TROOPS MAY HURT RELATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  President Carter warned the Soviet Union today that its relations with the United States would be adversely affected unless it respected United States concern about Soviet troops in Cuba, but he urged the nation to remain calm as the Administration dealt with the issue.

title: Polish Leader Visiting France
description: PARIS, Sept. 7 (Reuters)  The Polish Communist Party leader, Edward Gierek, arrived at Evreux Air Force Base, west of Paris, today for two days of talks with President Valery Giscard d'Estaing. Their talks are expected to focus on EastWest detente and disarmament.

title: Art Dealer, $16.2 Million in Debt, Sued by Investors
description: BOSTON, Sept. 7 (AP)  A financial scandal has erupted over the multimilliondollar bankruptcy proceedings of an art dealer who allegedly sold paintings that did not exist.

title: Mistrial Declared on Coast
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Sept. 7 (AP)  A mistrial has been declared in the murder trial of Tom Yu, alleged ringleader in the 1977 Golden Dragon restaurant shootings in San Francisco's Chinatown. After deliberating for two days, jurors toId Juage John Westwick of Superior Court yesterday that they were unable to reach a verdict. Five bystanders were killed and 11 wounded as they ate dinner as a gangland battle broke out.

title: Police Officials Explain Actions In Kennedy Case
description: Two highranking police officers said yesterday that a police inspector was assigned to supervise the investigation of the reported robbery of David Kennedy, the 29yearold son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, because young Kennedy was a person of note, the nephew of the late President John F. Kennedy.

title: Integrity Wins at Belmont
description: In the press box at Belmont Park, copies of thoroughbred racing's most exciting 1979 news release still dangled limply yesterday from a hook on the bulletin board.

title: Birds Not Easily Ruffled
description: MILLBORO, Va.  This is naturewatching season and, as all watchers are aware, perspectives become more acute than at any other time of the year.

title: Italian Jet's Hijackers Quit Rome and Head for Iran
description: ROME, Saturday, Sept. 8  Three gunmen, identified as Lebanese Shiite Moslems, seized control of an Italian airliner yesterday shortly after takeoff from Beirut, Lebanon, in what they said was an attempt to win freedom for a missing Moslem spiritual leader.

title: WORLD FOOD PARLEY URGES MORE ACTION
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 7  A determination by the poor nations of the world to coordinate action to feed their hungry populations and a greater commitment by the wealthy nations to help the poor ones have emerged from the fifth session of the World Food Council that ended here today.

title: About New York
description: Miss Vicky is snipping away in layers at the next chair but listening closely as George congratulates himself for not behaving like a lot of other old barbers by fighting the unisex. He talks of it that way, the unisex, sounding like an old blacksmith talking of an early automobile as the machine.

title: Another Round for Welfare Reform
description: Whenever welfare is mentioned these days, the reaction in Congress ranges from yawns to opposition. A few diehard reformers talk optimistically of passing President Carter's proposal to create jobs and improve benefits for welfare recipients; in fact, the House Ways and Means welfare subcommittee has already endorsed it. But now that Congress is back in session, the legislative going will get rougher. That's a shame because the Administration's approach is sensible. More than a shame, it's tragic, given the alarmingly high rates of pregnancy among poor teenagers. Welfare dependency will be with us until these young parents gain access, with Washington's help, to the world of work.

title: Kosygin to Visit Ethiopia
description: MOSCOW, Sept 7 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin will visit Ethiopia later this month for celebrations marking the fifth anniversary of the overthrow of Emperor Haile Selassie, an official announcement said today. It will the first visit by a senior Soviet leader to Ethiopia since Cuban troops and Soviet advisers helped the leftwing military Government crush Somalibacked insurgents in the Ogaden region last year.

title: At a Fragrance Workshop, 200 Executives Are Led by the Nose
description: The participants, some 200 of them, spent the morning sniffing, roundrobin style, shifting tables every 30 minutes, from Oriental to Floral, from Green to Fruity and Spicy, from Men's to Mossy. By early afternoon, they had smelled themselves out. But all in a good cause.

title: Wider Aid Sought on Fuel Bills
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP)  Up to onethird of the nation's families could be eligible to share $1.6 billion in Federal aid to pay heating bills this winter, under legislation introduced today by a group of Northeastern senators led by Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey..

title: New Clashes in Lebanon Break Fragile CeaseFire
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 7 (Reuters)  Israelibacked militia units and Lebanese leftist forces broke the ceasefire in southern Lebanon as they clashed during the night with tank, artillery and machinegun fire.

title: Using a New Strategy, Police Spray Chemical To Stop KnifeWielder
description: Acting under a twoweekold order by Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire, officers used Mace, a temporarily disabling chemical spray, to subdue a Booklyn man who had apparently gone berserk and was menacing his mother with a 10inch knife, the police reported yesterday.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Broken clouds extend from the upper lake region through the Appalachians to New England. A band of bright thunderstorms are visible along the Atlantic Coast and the Gulf Coast. Clear skies are apparent elsewhere.

title: Notes
description: Chesapeake Appreciation Days, launched in 1965 by a sailing association called the Windjammers, will be held on Oct. 27 and 28 at Sandy Point State Park in Maryland.

title: 2 Rapists Who Escaped Are Seized in Wildwood
description: Two rapists who escaped from a New Jersey prison last month were captured by the police Thursday after they allegedly robbed a luncheonette in Wildwood, N.J.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error in today's Arts and Leisure section, the sponsor of the Sculpture From Notre Dame show at the Metropolitan Museum was incorrectly listed in a revie': The sponsor is the Interpace Corporation.

title: The Right to Read Banned Books
description: DEAR Young People: As you may have heard or read, a Federal District Court judge has ruled that the school board where you live has not violated the law in removing from your school library shelves nine books. Although I do not reside in your school district, and hence have no vote there, I am nevertheless deeply concerned. I have spoken on this issue in my pulpit and feel much regret over the judge's decision.

title: Staging for Public Whims Instead of Tastes
description: ANEW theater season is astir, bringing with it the inevitable rush of anticipation that is all too often more exhilarating than the real thing. Before all the new repertories are announced and newly converted theater spaces open for inspection, it seems time to collect and share random thoughts and impressions garnered over the last half year of roving about the Island and reviewing its manyfaceted theaters.

title: Kenya President to Visit Saudis; Growing Links With Arabs Seen
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 8 (Reuters) President Daniel arap Moi leaves tomorrow for a threeday visit to Saudi Arabia, his first trip to an Arab country since taking office last year after the death of President Jomo Kenyatta.

title: Highway Travel Down in Year
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI)  The Transportation Department said yesterday that traffic on the nation's highways in the week ended Aug. 31 was less than in the same period last year and that motorists were setting into a continuing routine of reduced travel.

title: Norwalk to Feast On Fish and History
description: NORWALK FOR many decades oystering was one of Norwalk's major industries, and to celebrate that fact, and mark the city's maritime past, the second Norwalk Seaport Oyster Festival will be held Friday to Sunday at Veterans Memorial Park, across the Norwalk River from the wharves where oyster boats unload.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Same Time, Next Year, comedy by Bernard Slade. Today 2 P.M., Thursday to Saturday 8 P.M., next Sunday 2 P.M. Through September. $5.50 to $7.50. Discount available for students, the elderly and groups. Reservations. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, junction of Routes 6 and 118.6281169.

title: Jillian Rowe Bride Of William Kent
description: Jillian Ackley Rowe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Ackley Rowe of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to William Kent, son of Dr. Edwin Head Kent and June Dassau Kent, also of Greenwich. The Rev. Mark Anthony DeWolf performed the ceremony in St Barnabas Episcopal Church.

title: THE EDUCATION CONSUMER
description: EVANSTON, ILL. AT the age of 80, Vilner Randolph doesn't get around the way he used to, so he gives music lessons in his home on Chicago's South Side. He passes on the music that he learned in the South as well as his experiences as a member of Louis Armstronn's band in the 1930's.

title: Judge Inspects Goats on Island To Decide if Navy May Kill Them
description: SAN CLEMENTE ISLAND, Calif., Sept. 8 (AP)  Federal District Judge Robert M. Takasugi and his aides flew yesterday from Los Angeles to San Clemente Island, 75 miles off the coast from San Diego, to inspect the island's 4,000 wild goats.

title: It's Bluefish Season Again, Hook, Line and Sinker
description: ABOARD THE SEA SPRITE V THE boat bobs wildly on Long Island Sound in the boil of conflicting currents, but that is ignored. All attention is turned to the rods that jut over the side.

title: ART VIEW
description: Asevered head is one of the most evocative things there is. In mythology, in literature, in history, in art and in life it never fails of its impact. Severed heads are fundamental to our notions of ancient Egypt, ancient Greece and many another bygone society. When real and shrunken, they serve as terrifying reminders. When made of stone, or bronze, or wood, they have a poignancy that we do not always find in complete figures of the same period. It is as if the image in question were caught off its guard: we do not quite like to meet its gaze, and we dread to hear it speak.

title: GARDENING
description: WHAT'S to be done with the fading flower border at the end of summer? Several things will extend the flowering season well into fall.

title: The Quest of Sister Mary Pelagia
description: ICTION in English has not done very well at describing the spiritual life. For this, our language has better served its poets: Donne and Herbert and Crashaw, Hopkins and Eliot; even after World War II, there were some sidelong victories in the work of Auden and of Stevie Smith. But we have no Unamuno, no Bernanos. The two writers who have done best with this material, Flannery O'Connor and Graham Greene, always steer their characters through waters gummy with sordidness and violence, and their style is deliberately antipoetic, almost rigorously spare of images. Anyone writing in English about religion has two dangerous specters to contend with: the Romantic tradition and the sentimental one.

title: CONFRONTING THE P.L.O.
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the executive committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization, likes to show visitors in Beirut a statuette of an Aztec, emphasizing that the Palestinians will not be swept into extinction as were those ancient Mexicans. And, he makes clear, the P.L.O. is the chief preventive force.

title: Health; FACING A NEW FACE When I was told I had cancer and that surgery would take off my nose, I was sure the only way I could deal with it was to kill myself.
description: A year and a half ago, I went into the hospital at the Medical Center of the University of California at Los Angeles and had my nose and part of my face removed by Dr. Harvey Zarem, head of plastic surgery at U.C.L.A. The operation is called a resection of squamous cell carcinoma of the nose, the upper lip and the jaw bone. I waited until I was quite alone to look into a mirror and see the great hole in my face. For a moment everything inside me seemed to lurch sideways and up as though all of me wanted to get outside of me. And then my stomach steadied and I swallowed bile. I stood forlorn in a bleak landscape. had stayed too long at the fair.

title: A Road by Any Other Name
description: LIFE on the Island is fun. Separated from the troubled mainland of the United States, we live the happy life typical of island people the world over. Yet, despite our carefree life style, we do have our share of hangups, and I would like to note one particularly irksome quality we have. As a visiting friend from Minnesota recently pointed out to me, we Long Islanders have a curious lack of imagination in naming our roads, parks and buildings.

title: Tennis Crowds Reflect the Differences Among Nations
description: WORLD Championship Tennis, the Texas promotional organization that revolutionized the pro game, recently made a comorehensive assessment of big tournaments. It ranked the French open, Wimbledon and the United States Open close together, in that order.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Iknew I could trust them. I mean the four young and sunnily impertinent performers who have spent the summer at the Village Gate bouncing through a satirical revue called Scrambled Feet and who are likely to spend winter or two in residence keeping it uptodate. The show is topical and strictly showbiz, merrily aiming its merciless puns at Broadway producers, Joseph Papp's penchant for producing plays about blinded Vietnam War veterans, choreographers who don't choreograph, agents, outofans, choreographers who don't choreograph, agents, outofwork actors, critics and the rest of the sorry  and ever vulnerable  block. I'd missed the frolic just before going on vacation and I was now catching up on a herecomesSeptember, rainspattered night. By 9:30 or so, we'd already been through a wrestling match between The Elephant Man and the paralyzed hero of Whose Life Is It Anyway? (very funny), the difficulties Christ would have getting a job even with his good connections (of particular interest to collectors of horrendous puns, tossed into the air lightly as flapjacks), and were beginning to plunge into the Improvisa tional bit when I realized how much confidence I'd acquired in the zany quartet.

title: Letters TO THE EDITOR
description: Eugene Kennedy has written a remarkably clear and nonpolitical essay (Carter Agonistes, Aug. 5) which perhaps speaks more directly to our crisis of confidence than all of the editorials that have been written since that phrase became a national buzzword. That President Carter is the king in the altogether is sadly quite true. And that we, his loyal subjects, dare not break the truth to him or to ourselves is the apparent reason that we continue to accept the blame for his personal crisis [of] the soul.

title: Bronx and Suffolk Contests to Highlight Primary Tuesday
description: Two very different New York State counties  one trying to stem a tide of urban decay and another growing into one of the key areas of the state  will be the scene of the most significant contests in an otherwise peaceful primary election on Tuesday.

title: Sandra Kiely, Banker, Wed to Martin R. Kolb
description: Sandra Ivins Kiely, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Procter Kiely of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Martin Robert Kolb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Kolb of Rochester. The Rev. E.O. Megill performed the ceremony at the Elberon (N.Y.) Memorial Presbyterian Church.

title: What's Doing in ITHACA
description: WEALTH OF WONDERSIthaca was described by Solomon Southwick, a 19th.century traveler, as a wealth of wonders; it is still true today. The glaciers invaded twice, changing the area's topography and creating an area of natural splendor. The city lies at the southern end of Cayuga Lake, once a northflowing stream, but after the glaciers a 40milelong lake. Gorges with waterfalls, created when small streams cut through the slopes to the deepened lake, run through the community. Three more waterfalls within a short drive of Ithaca include Taughannock, with a 215footdrop. (Niagara is only 167 feet.) Surrounded on the east, south and west by rolling hills, which are a patchwork of farms and woods, Ithaca is home to two colleges, Cornell University on East Hill, Ithaca College on South Hill.

title: Afghanistan Regime Keeps Control With Core of Loyalists
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A recent demonstration here was billed as a mass rally, but attendance seemed to be by invitation only.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW; It Began With; Fox Talbot
description: O ne of the most interesting objects in the history of photography is a sketchbook containing a draw- ing of Lake Como as it was in 1833. This rather amateurish little drawing was done by William Henry Fox Talbot, the subject of an exhibition at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, through Oct. 28, and the sketchbook opened to the drawing is a part of the exhibition.

title: McEnroe and Gerulaitis Reach U.S. Open Final
description: After all the madness of jet noise, injury defaults, rain and griping, John McEnroe and Vitas Gerulaitis will meet in the men's singles final of the United States Open tennis championships today.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: For most Americans, the nation's Bicentennial ended on July 4, 1976  the 200th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence.

title: Drama: Wilde Play Is Festival's Best
description: MADISON THE director of The Importance of Being Earnest, John Ulmer, strives for an elegant precision, and he achieves occasionally in the best production that the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival has presented so far this season.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: GARDENING
description: WHAT'S to be done with the fading flower border at the end of summer? Several things will extend the flowering season well into fall.

title: Beauty
description: Sultry sirens they aren't, but these women share a quiet, compelling quality that can melt the hearts of heroes. Here are guidelines for achieving this demure look.

title: Exploring the Wilderness That Survives in the Smokies
description: We were strolling along a stream in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, looking for a mill once owned by a man named Mingus, and we stumbled on a set of millstones lying in the grass. We stopped for a moment, and thought they looked like rough old faces, death masks, maybe, scarred and seared from years of work, resting along the quiet creek.

title: Deaths
description: REI SMANAron, beloved husband of the late Lillian, devoted father of Irwin, Murray, and Marilyn, grandlather of Helene Fox, Frances Holtzman and Donald, greatgrandfather of Edward Holtzman. Service today, 2 PM, at The Riverside, Bronx, 179 St. and Grand Concourse.

description: EVERY year at this time many letters come in from homeowners who plan to close up their homes for the winter. Some of the owners go south for the season and want to shut down their primary houses; others have vacation homes that they seldom visit in winter, and want to save the cost of heating them.

description: Whether they are Robin Hoods or just plain hoods isn't really in doubt, according to the police and the District Attorney; several Bronx groups are engaged in a pattern of extortion.

title: Storm Misery Still Unfolds for Dominicans
description: SAN CRISTOBAL, Dominican Republic, Sept. 8  Rows of toddlers weak from hunger and suffering from gastroenteritis lay on wooden benches, glucose dripping into their arms as their mothers sat in the dark fanning them with newspapers.

title: Beatha
description: SCHWARTZ  Arnold.The Medical Staff of The Brookdale Hospital Medical Center expresses its sorrow on the death of our Hospital's eminent former President and a great benefactor of those who practice the healing art.Our ability to prevent, treat and cure disease and suffering for countless thousands of people was immeasurably advanced through his dedicated efforts. JERRY BLOOM,M.D. President,Medical Board BERNARD ZALEZNAK,M.D. President,Medical Staff

description: Justine Hayward Schmidt and Robert Russell Bloomingdale were married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Good, Shepherd in Beverly Hills, Calif. Msgr. Daniel Sullivan performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. William Kenney.

title: Headliners
description: The world will not soon forget, perhaps, Sir Ranulph TwisletonWykehamFiennes. Last week, Sir Ranulph set sail from England as leader of the first polar circumnavigation, following, as closely as possible, the meridian of Greenwich and its opposite number, the 180th meridian  using ships, Land Rovers, rubber rafts, whatever works. The trip is expected to take three years.

description: June Sherie Almenoff and L. Allen Kindman, students at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, were married yesterday at the Plaza. Rabbi Karen Fox performed the ceremony and Cantor Charles Bloch assisted_

title: The SmallBusiness Man Also Gets a Helping Hand
description: PEOPLE who seek to start their own businesses are getting more lowcost help these days from colleges and government agencies like the Small Business Administration. The S.B.A. courses. which range from one intensive day of lectures to several weeks of classes, rarely cost the student more than $5 course hour and may ultimately save the student thousands of dollars.

description: There are at least a dozen philosophies of dressing, from ultraconservative to artsycraftsy to downright flamboyant, but the only correct approach is for a man to suit himseft ana whomever it is he wants to impress.

description: Joe Paterno, Penn State's coach, said, I don't know that we are the No. 1 team in the East right now.

description: Lynn Marsh Matteson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Matteson of New York, was married yesterday to Hal Fales, son of Mr. and Mrs. Haliburton Fales of Gladstone, N.J.

description: THE following facts are uncontroverted: 1. The defendant has for some years been active in the Republican Party of Suffolk county.

title: China Enrolls Law Students
description: PEKING, Sept. 8 (Reuters)  China has enrolled 1,855 law students in universities and other institutes to meet the expected need for attorneys after its new legal code comes into effect Jan. 1, the official New China News Agency said. Law studies were stopped at the start of the Cultural Revolution in the 1960's.

title: Envoys Defend Themselves Against Uganda Gangs
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Sept. 8 (UPI) Diplomats from the United States and other countries have begun arming themselves, and some embassies have brought in special squads as protection against general lawlessness and daily murders, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Mary Angela Fifield Married To Samuel G. Allis, Newsman
description: Mary Angela Fifield, director of public and press relations for ABC News, was married yesterday to Samuel Gummere Allis, who writes regularly about New York City for The Washington Post. The Rev. Malcolm Warford performed the Protestant ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Piano: Russell Sherman Again Visiting New York
description: Russell Sherman is apparently becoming an annual visitor to New York's recital stages again after several years devoted to study and teaching in the Boston area, where he heads the piano department, at nie New England Conservatory. On Friday night he played a catholic program in Alice Tully Hall consisting of music by Schumann. Schoenberg. Mozart and Liszt.

title: 2 Dead in Linden Blaze; 4 Families Are Homeless
description: LINDEN, N.J., Sept. 8 (UPI)  An early morning that swept through a twostory brick building today took the lives of two people and left 11 others homeless today, the police said.

title: Barbara Chadwick Bride Of Martin C. Hoffman Jr.
description: Barbara Caverly Chadwick and Martin Colden Hoffman Jr. of Denver were married yesterday in Old Lyme, Conn. The Rev. David Good, assisted by the Rev. Sidney Lovett, performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church.

title: Undermining Camp David
description: It's been a foolish summer for United States diplomacy in the Middle East, making it all the more remarkable that President Sadat and Prime Minister Begin come in such harmony to the first anniversary of their Camp David embrace. While the United States was offering the Palestine Liberation Organization virtual veto over the further execution of their peace treaty, Mr. Sadat and Mr. Begin joined hands to defeat the move. And when Washington invited an illsuited team of United Nations observers to monitor adherence to the treaty in the Sinai, the two leaders quickly formed a joint military patrol instead. Having brokered the marriage between Egypt and Israel, Jimmy Carter seemed unwilling to let the newlyweds furnish their own house.

title: Arrest in Cameraman's Death
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8 (AP)  An Atlantic Richfield Company employee was charged today in the death of a television camerman who was run over by a tank truck while covering a strike at a gasoline depot. Richard Field, 38 years old, of Dallas, Pa., was accused in the death of Ed Romano, 61, a camerman for KDKATV, who was run over by an Arco tank truck while covering teamster strike activity at a depot Thursday.

title: A 2d Life for New York's Retired
description: For starters, this college program has an unusual application form. High on the list of things to fill in, higher even than Past Education/Schooling is a place for the applicant to write about his significant life exoerience.

title: Alabama Overruns Georgia Tech by 306
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 8 (UPI)  Steadman Shealy ran for 82 yards, including an 11yard touchdown jaunt, and completed nine of 11 passes today to lead Alabama to a 306 victory over Georgia Tech in the first meeting between the two schools in 15 years.

title: Pop: Bee Gees Open a Series of 5 Concerts at Garden
description: Last year the Bee Gees dominated American popular music with their lushly soft disco beat and floating ballads, the high falsetto harmonies supported by an ingeniously textured instrumental backing. It was a formula that sold millions of records.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON PERMAKING is an ancient craft, believed to have originated in secondcentury China. Since the Industrial Revolution, however, mechanized production methods and lowgrade materials have come to dominate the field, leaving little room for the sensitive and dedicated craftsman.

title: Westchester Show On Despite Storm
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 7 Every year since 1905, the Westchester Kennel Club, one of the nation's most prestigious, has been holding dog shows at Lyndhurst, the national landmark on Route 9. The 62d edition, however, was almost canceled after the remnants of Tropical Storm David passed through the area Thursday.

title: FIGHT ON ILLITERACY FOUND TO LAG BADLY
description: Efforts to eradicate illiteracy in the United States are grossly inadequate, and new and varied approaches are needed to help tens of millions of adults who lack the skills to perform basic tasks, according to a report issued yesterday by the Ford Foundation.

title: Bridgehampton Hoping for a Turnaround
description: Mention of the Bridgehampton racing circuit cm Long Island brings back all kinds of memories for roadracing fans. The track was built in 1956, and during its glory years it was the site for all kinds of sportscar races, including CanAm, TransAm and International Motor Snorts Association events.

title: The Nation
description: The Carter Administration had practically developed eyestrain looking for the unemployment increase that its economists deemed a necessary, if politically risky, weapon in the fight against inflation. The numbers finally came up last week, and in large type: The Labor Department reported that the jobless rate jumped to 6 percent in August.

title: INVESTING
description: Manfred Tordella & Brooks purchased a 1927D $20 gold piece recently for $250,000. Within a week the coin was resold for more than $300,000.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 (2) Face the Nation': Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho.

title: Groundwork for Springtime
description: I see daffodils every time I think spring. Although my garden seems to have enough of them, I can't resist planting a few more each fall.

title: Elizabeth Simons Wed To Michael A. Ficalora
description: Elizabeth Baldwin Simons, daughter of Mrs. Williani A Hebert Jr. of South Yarmouth, Mass., and Richard L.F. Simons of Agawam, Mass., was married yesterday morning to Michael Anthony Ficalora, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Fielders Of Irvington, N.Y. The Rev. Ward R. Smith krformed the ceremony, in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Longmeadow, Mass.

title: Gold and Silver Prices Spiral;Prime Rate Boosted to 12 Percent
description: Worries about American inflation in particular, the economy in general and the overall strength of the dollar were reflected last week, once again, in the demand for gold. The metal is regarded as a safe haven for investment funds in times of economic or political uncertainty. And the speculative fever that heated up the interest in gold spilled over into the silver market as well.

title: Maureen Sullivan Becomes the Bride Of John Landers Jr.
description: Maureen Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Sullivan of Huntington, L.I., was married there yesterday in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church to John Quincy Landers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Landers of Honolulu. The Rev. Donald Beckmann performed the ceremony.

title: >Paris Starts to Heal the Gaping Wound Left by Les Halles
description: PARIS, Sept. 7  The Forum des Halles, dedicated last, Tuesday by Mayor Jacques Chirac, marks the first concrete step to close the gaping wound opened in the heart of Paris in 1971, when the ironandglass buildings of Les Halles, the central market built by Victor Ballard more than 120 years ago, were de stroyed.

title: Pelham Manor AT A GLANCE
description: In 1654, Thomas Pell of Fairfield, Conn., purchased 9,160 acres of land from the Siwanoy Indians on behalf of the English Crown and established an estate on the property which he then called Pelham. The land, which at that time included parts of Eastchester, New Rochelle, the Pelhams, Mount Vernon and the Bronx, was divided among various heirs in the decades following his death, and remained sparsely populated for the better part of two centuries.

title: PartTimers Seek a Part of Government Aid
description: AMOVE is growing to provide help to the 3.4 million American students who attend colleges parttime without benefit from the financialaid programs regularly available to fulltimers.

title: This College Museum Rates a Cum Laude
description: This fall the Smith College Museum of Art, an adjunct of the women's college which is the chief ornament of the small northwestern Massachusetts city of Northampton, is celebrating its 100th anniversary. While this relatively small institution cannot hope to mark the event with the brouhaha attending the Museum of Modern Art's 50th birthday this year, let alone the Metropolitan's centenary a few seasons back, its pride in the occasion is pardonable. For in its first hundred years, the Smith Museum, underfinanced and understaffed  women's loyalty to their Alma Mater tends to measure higher on the sentimental than on the dollarsandcents scale  has managed to accumulate possessions that make it the envy of many larger, betterknown art repositories. Its current anniversary exhibition, which will run through Dec. 21, is made up of as many of its most notable paintings, sculptures, drawings, photographs and other miscellany as can be crammed into the handsome building it has occupied since 1972. In the words which the Michelin restaurant guides have made immortal, it is well worth a detour.

title: 12 Spectacular Bid Captures Marlboro Cup
description: Maybe Laz Barrera had the right idea when he kept Affirmed out of yesterday's $300,000 Marlboro Cup Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: PREVIEW of FALL BOOKS
description: FOR Americans, the word fall has many connotations, but in the publishing world, fall is the season between now and Christmas, four months during which more than 7,000 new hard cover titles will be sent into the stores to await the verdicts of reviewers, buyers and readers. This year the publishers are particularly anxious because, thanks to a wobbly economy, the past spring season, which at the outset seemed to be an accountant's delight, turned out to be a grave disappointment, particularly in sales of fiction.

title: Whitecaps Set Back Rowdies for Title, 21
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 8  While the Vancouver Whitecaps were beating the Tampa Bay Rowdies, 21, in capturing their first championship of the North American Soccer League, the fans were reserving their loudest cheers at Giants Stadium for team not in the game.

title: ART Jack B. Yeats: A View of Ireland
description: STAMFORD

title: A Killer Terrorizes Yorkshire and Taunts the Police
description: BRADFORD, England, Sept. 7 brutal and cunning killer who calls himself Jack the Ripper is terrorizing the people of Yorkshire.

title: V.A. Director Awaits Study by the Air Force Of Users of Defoliant
description: Last May 28, Max Cleland, the Veterans Administrator, announced that the Air Force would conduct a major study on the health of the 1,200 veterans who were involved in Operation Ranch Hand, the unit that sprayed Agent Orange to defoliate Jungles in Vietnam.

title: Stevens Says Closed Trials May Justify New Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8  Justice John Paul Stevens of the Supreme Court said today that the possibility that judges might too casually grant requests to close entire trials to the public may justify the adoption of new court rules, or even new legislation.

title: Boy, 2, Dies in 3Story Fall
description: A 2yearold Brooklyn boy died yesterday after he fell from a thirdfloor window in Harlem, the police reported. They said Deborah D'Adamo of 1352 65th Street in Brooklyn had taken her son, Franko DiCara, with her on a visit to a friend at 204 West 111th Street late Friday. She told officers that the boy was peering out the window when he fell out around 11:30 P.M., the police said. The boy died at 2 a.m. today at St. Luke's Hospital.

title: Jazz: Helen Ward Back
description: Helen Ward was 18 when she joined Benny Goodman's unknown band in December 1934. When she left the band to get married two years later, she was 20, Mr. Goodman was the King of Swing and if anybody was the Queen of Swing, it was Helen Ward. For all practical purposes that was her career.

title: Rhodesian Forces End Their Mozambique Invasion'
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Sept. 8  The threeday invasion of Mozambique by Zimbabwe Rhodesia has ended, according to a Government communiqu issued here today, and all Salisbury's forces have returned to their bases.

title: WHATEVER HAPPENED TO VASSAR?; An alumna of the 60's returns to the college as a teacher and finds some remarkable changes  architectural, sexual and intellectual. The biggest surprise: workaholism is rampant on the campus.
description: The red oak and chestnut that grace Vassar's luxuriant campus have always delighted me, but by the autumn of my senior year, I found myself looking at them with something bordering on disgust; their serenity offended my growing discontentment.

title: Mets Defeat Pirates  In 15 Innings by 32
description: Not many hours after they had played 14 innings in Shea Stadium, the New York Mets and the Pittsburgh Pirates outdid themselves yesterday and played 15. This time, the lastplace Mets survived the firstplace Pirates by scoring a run off the seventh Pittsburgh pitcher for a 32 victory.

title: Begin and Sadat Happy in Haifa
description: President Anwar elSadat stepped off King Farouk's yacht at Haifa last week to trade concessions with my friend Prime Minister Menachem Begin. The Egyptian leader agreed to let Israeli soldiers stay in the Sinai to patrol jointly with Egyptian troops supervising Israeli withdrawal, and to sell Israel the full 2 million tons of annual oil production in the Sinai.

title: CAMERA
description: Although almost anyone can enjoy taking pictures without necessarily acquiring an enormous amount of technical knowledge, even the fundamentals can sometimes be confusing and distracting  especially to the beginner.

title: Best Sellers
description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1,400 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: The Region
description: The Regional Plan Association, in a study published last month, made a telling statistical observation: Blacks make up 12.4 percent of the region's population, but twothirds of the black families occupy only 1.35 percent of the region's residential land. Most of that disparity, the association said, is the result of racial discrimination, which remains very strong in the New York metropolitan area housing market

title: MACCMAROLA SEEKS TEST FOR PRINCIPALS
description: School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola is pressing the city's Board of Examiners to expedite examinations for elementary, junior high and high school principals to provide new leaders for the city's public schools.

title: Planners Bus Tour To Go to Queens
description: The Planners New York Tours conducted by Hunter College's Graduate Program in Urban Planning this weekend will begin the final twoandahalf months of this season's bus trips around four of the city's boroughs. These tours are educational, emphasizing the urban planning, housing and social aspects of the neighborhoods.

title: Colleges Find That Adult Market Brings
description: SEVERAL years ago the University of Bridgeport, realizing that it faced a shrinking market in the 1980's because of a declining number of 18 to 22yearolds, moved to bolster its offerings in the area of continuing education. The logic was compelling. The faculty, staff and classroom space were place. Bringing in more students would increase revenues and reduce the per student cost of nonacademic services. The programs could be organized without making a commitment to students for full academic programs for four years.

title: INTERVIEW Rights Leader Sees Pattern of Racism
description: WESTCHESTER County was made a priority concern last month for the state conference of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People because the county was termed a bastion of racism,  Winston Ross, regional director of the county's eight N.A.A.C.P. chanters said last week

title: Melissa Gregory Vail Is a Bride
description: Melissa Gregory Vail, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Vail of Bedford, N.Y., and Stonington, Conn., was married last night to Norman Canaan Selby, son of Dr. Cecily C. Selby of New York and Dr. Henry M. Selby, also of New York and Quogue, L.I. The Rev. Donald F. Miner performed the ceremony in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: LOS ANGELES  In 1973, two California utility companies announced a plan to ease the developing energy shortage by importing liquefied natural gas (L.N.G.) from Indonesia. Six years later, the billiondollar California gas importation project is still unhatched  its story an offagain, onagain energycrisis cliffhanger whose dnouement is still in doubt.

title: IslandLiving: The Focus Is Toward the Outdoors
description: WITH an east wind blowing hard, Sandy Falconer, who lives yearround on threeacre Tavern Island, one of the 16 Norwalk Islands about a halfmile off the coast, was considering canceling her teenage daughter's horseriding lesson on the shore that afternoon.

title: Renaults Pace Qualifying For Italian Grand Prix
description: MONZA, Italy, Sept. 8 (UPI) French Renaults took both frontrow spots on the starting grid for tomorrow's Italian Grand Prix, with JeanPierre Jabouille winning the pole position before spinning out and damaging the suspension on his turbocharger.

title: LETTER TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Your recent twopart article on New Jersey's environmental movement deserves applause. Especially meritorious was your list of environmental organizations.

description: Joari Ganz Cooney, President of the Children's Television Workshop. calls it

title: News Summary
description: President Carter said the arms treaty with the Soviet Union should be approved by the Senate on its own merits without being tied to Soviet activity in Cuba or in other countries. In an interview with outoftown editors at the White House, Mr. Carter took issue with the senators who would link the treaty's approval to the removal of the 2,000 to 3,000 Soviet troops in Cuba. Meanwhile, Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, said the treaty would be defeated if it came up for a vote now, but it should not, he said, be held hostage to the troop issue. He said the treaty could be considered on its own when it voted on late in November when the dust should have settled. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: St. Lucia Seeks Seat at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 7 (Reuters)  The Caribbean island of St. Lucia, which became independent from Britain in February, has applied to become the 152d member of the United Nations. The island nation south of Martinique has a population of just over 100,000.

title: Russians in Cuba Pose New Threat To SALT Agreement
description: Linkage. Democratic Senator Richard Stone is from Florida, which is why he maintains a special vigil over Cuba, which is why he first brought up the question of 2,000 to 3,000 Soviet combat troops in Cuba, which is why the Pentagon finally confirmed the presence of a command structure for the Soviet brigade, which is why some senators who recall the missile crisis of 1962 demanded that Moscow get its troops out of Cuba, which is why the Senate may refuse to take up the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty with the Russians until the troops are withdrawn, possibly hanging up the SALT agreement for months, which is why President Carter was abruptly faced last week with a major, delicate test of domestic and foreign policy.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IN a slick legal political maneuver, the Passaic County Board of Chosen Freeholders has blocked a move by the Paterson Regional Development Corporation to call for a vote in November on changing the form of county government to a County Executive plan. The Freeholders voted, 50, for a resolution placing a charterstudy question on the ballot, thus preventing any other proposal from being listed.

title: Elizabeth Menk Bride Of William R. Griffin lr,
description: Elizabeth Regina Menk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl W. Menk of Glen Ridge and Sea Girt, N.J., was married yesterday to William Richard Griffin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Griffin of Silver Spring, Md. The Rev. Charles Dolan performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: Meeting This Week, They Fight Harder Over Traditions, Than Finer Points of Doctrine
description: Two years ago, Bishop Paul Moore Jr., the Episcopal Bishop of New York, provoked furious controversy among Episcopalians by ordaining an avowed lesbian, the Rev. Ellen Barrett, to the priesthood. As the General Convention of the Episcopal Church opens its triennial sessions tonight in Denver, several resolutions on homosexual ordination are pending, and a counterconvention of Integrity, an organization of Episcopalian homosexuals, is drawing to an end in the same city.

title: Katherine Seavey Married
description: In the Episcopal Church of the Ascension yesterday afternoon, Katherine Mackay Seavey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hollis M. Seavey of East Sandwich, Mass., became the bride of Charles Ashley Bryant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Randolph Bryant Jr. of Katy, Tex. The Rev. Donald Goodness performed the ceremony. The bride's previous marriage ended diverce

title: THEATER Ivoryton's Playhouse
description: IVORYTON IVORYTON is a sleepy village that is part of historic, touristpacked Essex. The village is famous for two things: the pianokey factory that gave the town its name, and the Ivoryton Playhouse, the first summer stock theater in the state. Times change, though. Today, piano keys are no longer made of ivory, and the playhouse, noted, among other things, as the theater in which Katharine Hepburn made her stage debut 49 years ago, is closed.

description: SAN DIEGO
