description: TILE IIWISMLE FIRE The Story of Mankind's Triumph Over the Ancient Scourge of Smallpox. By Joel N. Shurkin. Illustrated. 447pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $12.95.

title: POPE IS SCHEDULED TO VISIT 4 BOROUGHS
description: The twoday visit to New York by Pope John Paul II on Oct. 2 and 3 will include visits to four of the city's five boroughs, with motorcades through the West Side, Harlem, the South Bronx and Queens, church officials say.

title: The Shadowy Figure in Israel's Knesset
description: TEL AVIV  A few miles east of Tel Aviv in the exclusive suburb of Savyon, Samuel FlattoSharon, an international financier and real estate magnate, lives in a villa complete with gardens, patios, tennis court, swimming pool and an art collection that would be the envy of museum curators.

title: Composers on Disks Bach to Schumann
description: Every musician who makes records, it sometimes seems, is in the process of recording the complete works of one composer or another. Collec- tors keeping up with these series have had a few months respite over the summer, but the new fall releases show a renewed vigor in the unrelenting march to put all of Western music on disk. Here is a sampling of the latest installments.

title: Deborah Eifler Bride of Kim Fennebresque
description: Deborah Johnson Eifler, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Milton E. Johnson of Spokane, Wash., was married yesterday to Kim Samuel Fennebresque, son of Mrs. John B. Fennebresque of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and the late Mr. Fennebresque. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor by the Rev. Carlton Lee.

title: Diver Finds Ancient Greek Ship
description: MESSINA, Sicily, Sept. 7 (Reuters)An amateur diver has discovered the wreck of a 2,000yearold Greek ship off the island of Panarea, north of Sicily, officials said today.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: A DISTANT MIRROR, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Ballantine, $6.95.) Europe in the 14th century time of famine, pestilence, religious hysteria, Chaucer and Petrarch, tournaments and pageants, greed and chivalryobserved mostly through the career Enguerrand de Coucy VII, a feudal lord in Picardy. Some historians have complained that this ambitious work by the twotime Pulitzer Prizewinner adds nothing to what was already known about the age, but certainly is a brilliantly written introduction for the layman.

title: FILM MAILBAG
description: To the Editor: While his tone is more or less friendly, the text of Vincent Canby's review of Apocalypse Now [Aug. 19] is a straightforward and somewhat strident dismissal of the film. After having viewed Apocalypse myself, I couldn't disagree more.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: In his new novel Jailbird, reviewed on page 1, Kurt Vonnegut once again uses everyday phrases that somehow sum up the current state of the human race and the world. Students of his work will recall that in SlaughterhouseFive, the phrase that recurred was: So it goes. In his last novel, Slapstick, the word was: Hiho.

title: Ballet: Other Dances, Artistry and an Afterthought
description: Balletgoing is getting to be an adventurous pastime at the Metropolitan Opera House these days, where the American Ballet Theatre is in the midst of an injuryplagued fall season. On Friday, injuries accounted for some reshuffling of casts and even a substitute ballet, which in turn provided the audience with an alwayswelcome additional performance by Natalia Makarova and Anthony Dowell.

title: Another American Institution Goes By the Boards
description: Like Kodak for snapshots and Polaroid for instant pictures, Bell & Howell came to stand for home movies. With close to a third of the domestic market in 8millimeter movie cameras and almost half the market in projectors, Bell & Howell seemed permanently wedded to motion photography. But in recent years, with the intense competition from instant cameras, and slim profit margins, earnings from homemovie products have been at best static.

title: 11,000 Homes Await Restoration Of Electric Power Cut by Storm
description: More than 11,000 homes were still without electricity in the New York City area last night as utility crews struggled to restore power to eversmaller blackedout areas.

title: Man Dies at Party in Railroad Car
description: One person attending a party aboard a private railroad car in Pennsylvania Station was killed and another injured yes; terday morning when the two climbed atop the car and touched an overhead power line.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: JOAN LEE FAUST

title: The World
description: BRUSSELS  Western Europe's three economic disciplinarians face a winter of discontent. French Prime Minister Raymond Barre, German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and Britain's Margaret Thatcher have all chosen the same, painful strategy for rescuing their economies from the worldwide slowdown.

title: Fourfifths Survived
description: MUSSOLWE AND THE JEWS GermanItalian Relations and the Jewish Question in Italy 19221945. By Meir Michaelis. 472 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $39.

title: Told to Avoid Any Link to Post, Investigator Says
description: A former investigator for the New York State special prosecutor's office has charged that a superior ordered him not to actively seek evidence that might have directly linked The New York Post to an alleged bribery scheme to obtain prison photographs of David R. Berkowitz, the socalled Son of Sam killer.

title: Napoli Convicted of Paying $500 for Favors in Jail
description: James Napoli Sr., a reputed figure in organized crime, and his nephew were convicted yesterday of paying $500 to a prison official to get special treatment for Mr. Napoli while he was imprisoned on a contempt conviction.

title: Eliza E. Rathbone, Curator, Is Married
description: The marriage of Eliza Euretta Rath bone, assistant curator for 20thcentury art at the National Gallery in Washington, to Andrew Hamilton, a principal analyst with the Congressional Budget Office in Washington, took place yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Pettigrew V. Hamilton, brother of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Stephanie Taylor French Wed
description: Stephanie Taylor. French, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. French of Darien, Comr., was married yesterday in New York to Amory Houghton 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Houghton Jr. of Corning, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at theEpsicopal Church of the Heavenly Rest by the Rev. Alanson B. Houghton, an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: ForSale Signs
description: It caught the financial community unawares: the RCA Corporation announced plans to sell two of its wholly owned subsidiaries, Random House Inc., the publishing company and the Banquet Foods Corporation, a leading supplier of frozen prepared foods.

title: A Skating Club That's This Year's Hit of Hollywood
description: RESEDA, Calif.  Each Monday this sleepy town in the San Fernando Valley is invaded by RollsRoyces, groupies and paparazzi. It is the current weekly ritual of Le Tout Hollywood to take to the wheels at Skataway, an exclusive private club that is, for the moment, the hottest thing going in the film capital.

title: DINING OUT
description: LA CAPANNINA, situated in a house in Northport, is one of the better restaurants in this part of the Island. It is small, subdued and quiet  almost drab. The dining rooms are done in an allover silver and bluegray pattern that seems to have a vaguely Egyptian motif.

title: Fully Detached And by the Bay In Perth Amboy
description: PERTH AMBOY, N.J.  The discovery that a New Jersey home builder named Barry Rosengarten made in Bayonne 13 years ago is that plenty of Hudson County people wanted to remain in the city and not fly off to the suburbs.

title: Vineland: Will It Be a Video Wasteland?
description: CHANNEL 65 in Vineland was to have been something special: locally owned television outlet dedicated to presenting quality programming for South Jersey instead of depressing network reruns and aging movies.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Presidential Hopefuls Wooing Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 8 (AP)  John B. Connally, a Republican Presidential hopeful, flew here to campaign even though the island's residents are not allowed to vote in next year's Presidential election. He did so because Puerto Rico will have what may possibly be the first Republican primary of 1980.

title: Housing Woes Emerging at New Submarine Base
description: KINGS BAY, Ga., Sept. 8 (UPI)  I feel like the grocer with no bread on his shelves, Dave Cowles of Kings Bay Realty Inc. said as he sat in his prefabricated office in a clearing in southeast Georgia.

title: WHO'S IN CHARGE OF
description: The stately brawling in the Senate over SALT II raises issues larger even than the strategicweapons balance between the Soviet Union and the United States. Congress is also writing another chapter in the history of its aggregation of power over the foreign relations of the United States.

title: CountryWestern Music Ignites a Spark
description: MONTAUK FOR those who bemoan having lost the kind of countrywestern music that filled Southern honkytonks in the 1940's and 50's and has since been overshadowed by tamer, poporiented variations, the emergence of a Long Island band called Shotgun may be cause for celebration.

title: Soviet Writer Accuses Iran's Islamic Regime Of Hostile Fanaticism
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 8 (AP)  A Soviet commentary said today that Iran's Islamic revolutionary Government headed by Ayatollah RuhoIlah Khomeini had promoted religious fanaticism and failed to establish stable rule.

title: Reuters Reporter Is Held By Iran in Kurdish City
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 8 (Reuters) Nassir Shirkhani, a correspondent for Reuters, was detained by Islamic revolutionary guards in the Kurdish city of Mehabad today and questioned for five hours about his contacts in the former rebel capital.

title: The Classroom Appetite
description: MY students are hungry. Last year they sat in class at 9 in the morning, their stomachs holding whatever breakfast a 19yearold is likely to eat, waiting for me to begin.

title: Laura Jackson Bride of James Whittemore
description: Laura Jackson and James Melville Whittemore were married yesterday at the Dover, Mass., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Jackson Jr. The Rev. Richard Muir of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Cohasset, Mass., performed the ceremony.

title: Deaths
description: HARTNETTCatherine M., of Hempstead, LI on Sept 8, 1979, beloved mother of Elizabeth Hixon, Mary Strickland and Rosemary Scott, dear sister of Rose Keough, also survived by 9 grandchildren. Friends may call at the Hartnett Funeral Home, 148 Greenwich St, Hempstead between the hours of 25 and 710PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Loretto R.C. Church, Hempstead on Tuesday at 9:45AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, LI.

title: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 12
description: Morning

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: The Lyricist as Performer
description: The initial intention of the Lyrics and Lyricists series of concerts which have been presented each year at the 92d Street Y since 1970, was to draw long overdue attention to those who wrote the words to our popular songs, to offset the tendency to refer to Richard Rodgers's Oh, What a Beautiful Morning',  even though it is called Oh, What a Beautiful Morning because Oscar Hammerstein II wrote the lyrics from which the title is taken.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Ten years ago, some dancers spaced themselves out on a lawn in the twilight of a summer evening and began to move very slowly so slowly, in fact, that they scarcely seemed to move at all. Yet they were moving, moving as if a sculpture garden had come to life. And as they moved, they faded away into the gathering dusk.

title: County to Show Off Itself and Business
description: WHITE PLANS COUNTY officials, who have long attempted to build a bigger tax base and spur the local economy by attracting more businesses to Westchester, will carry their efforts one step further later this month with the county's second annual exposition at the Rye Town Hilton.

title: Catherine J. Clark, Married in Darien
description: The chapel of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Catherine Judkins Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Clark of Rowayton, Conn., to Robert Michael Shopneck, son of Samuel M. Shopneck of Toledo, Ohio, and Hillaine J. Shopneck of Denver. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frederick Tuttle Bender.

title: Questions/Answers
description: I grew popcorn this year and dried for about two weeks. It seemed dry but when I tried to pop it, it did not pop. What did 1 do wrong?

title: Deep Financial Problems Threaten Groups Aiding Vietnam Veterans
description: In the 18 months since Frank McCarthy created Agent Orange Victims International, he has helped it gain attention, heard legislators and other veterans rally to support its cause  and watched it begin to disintegrate for lack of money and answers.

title: Grambling Turns Back Morgan St.
description: Robert Parham scored two touchdowns last night to lead Grambling University to a 2818 triumph over Morgan State at Yankee Stadium. It was the 11th straight victory for Grambling over the Golden Bears.

title: Gunmen Take $75,000 In Rare Coins and Cash
description: Two gunmen escaped with rare coins and cash valued at more than $75,000 yesterday morning in the robbery of a midtown liquor store that belongs to a coin collector.

title: PRESIDENT OPPOSES TYING CUBA DISPUTE TO ARMS PACT VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8  President Carter says the strategic arms limitation treaty should be approved by the Senate on its own merits without being tied to Soviet activity in Cuba or other parts of the world.

title: Weekend Bargains Out of London by Air
description: Americans in London can take advantage of the city's position as jumpingoff place for weekend trips to the Continent  and by shopping around they can save money by joining excursions originally designed for bargainhunting Britons. Although air fares in Europe are still far higher than those for comparable distances within the United States, weekend travel packages and discount rates can reduce costs considerably.

title: Laurie A. Haskell, Alfred de Grazia 3d Married in West
description: Laurie Amory Haskell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Garner Haskell Jr. of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Alfred Joseph de Grazia 3d, son of Mrs. Miriam de Grazia of Washington and Sebastian de Grazia of Princeton. N.J.

title: P.L. Larkin Fianc Of Cynthia A. Close
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Close of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Anne Close, to Paul Leo Larkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Larkin of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Suffolk D.A. Seeks New Corruption Law
description: HAUPPAUGE

title: Nuclear Blast Set Off in West
description: YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Sept. 8 (UPI) A, weaponsrelated nuclear device of less than the explosive force of 20,000 pounds of TNT was set off under the Nevada desert this morning with no radiation leakage, the Department of Energy announced.

title: T and E Problems Persist As New School Year Begins
description: THE state's 1.3 million schoolchildren are back in class again with their new startofschool clothing, their new books and their new teachers.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Museums and galleries are welcoming the fall this month with new exhibits and programs.

title: Long Island /This Week
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR  Works by Christian White; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Oct. 1 to 6 P.M. Sundays; through Oct. 6; Harbor Gallery, 43 Main St. Reception 1 to 6 P.M. today.

title: DINING OUT
description: WHEN it comes to eating, sometimes anticipation helps make for a better menu than what is on a printed page. For the 10,000 or more who will visit Peekskill next Sunday for the Second Culinary Festival, the main course will be a sandwich cut from a 1.000foot loaf of bread to be baked on the scene starting at 5:30 A.M. by Franz Eichenauer, a master chef who is research specialist for the General Foods Corporation. The anticipation comes from Mr. Eichenauer's success at last year's festival in preparing a 10,000egg omelet that rivaled the best offered in sophisticated restaurants.

title: Classes Open Under a Watchful State
description: WITH the opening of a new school year in many towns across the state last week, Connecticut took another major step toward more state oversight of its public schools.

title: Kansas Officials Hope a Slogan Lures Tourists to Land of Ah's;
description: WICHITA, Kan., Sept. 8 (AP)  Ever since L. Frank Baum told how a tornado lifted Dorothy Gale from her Kansas farm home and carried her to the Land of Oz, some Kansans have cringed at the image his classic story gave the state.

title: Waterloo Is Ready for Its Festival
description: WATERLOO VILLAGE NEXT Saturday and Sunday, this restored community, with its huge old trees and lawns sloping down to the Musconetcong River, will be providing a day's outing that should prove tempting not only to antiquers, but to other family members as well.

title: Kurds of Turkey Grow Restless As Their Kin Fight Iran's Army
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 7  Signs of unrest among Turkey's eight million Kurds are growing, apparently ignited by rebellion in the Kurdish areas of neighboring Iran.

title: DINING OUT
description: WHERE this rather pleasantlooking restaurant now sits in West Orange, a cable car once ran up the sloping foothills to a resort known as Cable Lake. In fact, South Valley Street, on which the restaurant is situated, was once known locally as Cable Car Row.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Abreathtaking simplicity and elegance characterizes all of the finest Shaker designs. And some are even awesome, as will be seen in The Shakers in New York State, an ambitious exhibition that opened Friday at the Museum of American Folk Art, 49 West 53d Street, and remains on view through Nov. 21.

title: Muzorewa Arrives in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 8 (UPI) Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa arrived in London from Salisbury today for the constitutional conference on Zimbabwe Rhodesia and said his country's invasion of Mozambique would not jeopardize the conference.

title: L.I. Banks Giving Way to Foreign Ownership
description: STONY BROOK THE expected approval of the purchase of the Bank of Suffolk County by the Madridbased Banco Exterior de Espana this month points up the increasing foreign ownership of Long Island banks.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: People In Stress
description: HE prevailing subjects in Ward Just's fiction (The Congressman Who Loved Flaubert, A Family Trust and other books) are politics, war and, more recently, the Middle West. His view of all three is bleak and ironic, yet it is tempered by affection: Mr. Just genuinely likes politicians, understands the appeal of warfare and loves his native Middle West (he was born in Indiana) even as he despairs of what has happened to it. Thus his fiction has an ambiguous quality that is most effective, providing as it does an underlying tension and an appreciation of complexity.

title: More Risk or Less Risk in Pension Plans?
description: Congress passed the Employment Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to enable participants in pension plans to understand and protect their pension investments. But ERISA fails to do this for the fastgrowing number of people in definedcontribution pension plans.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on tabling amendment to reserve $500,000 of the Federal Election Commission budget to facilitate investigation of allegations of possible violations of Federal law connected with the Carter peanut warehouse in Plains, Ga., passed, 61 to 29, Sept. 5.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE How High Must Rates Go?
description: The country's economic problems are getting worse.

title: Deaths
description: SCHWARTZArnold. The passing of Arnold Schwartz, thenoted humanitarian, philanthropist, and devoted friend of the New York University Dental Center, is a sad occasion for all of us who were privileged to share the fruits of his wisdom, generosity and benevolence. For the past 10 years, Arnold Schwartz's unprecedented commitment to the future of dental health education in this country has served as an inspiration to us all. An extremely generous naming gift from Arnold and Marie Schwartz, presented in 1976, made possible the creation of the Arnold and Marie Schwartz Hall of Dental Sciences. which is the largest and most modern dental health facility of its type in the nation. We mourn the loss of a dear friend and revered benefactor, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Marie, and his bereaved family.

title: Adult Courses in China: A Leap Forward for Millions
description: MA SHUE is 25yearold worker at a printing factory in Guangzhou, China. Four nights a week, two hours a night, he and 24 other workers study English. They have no teacher or textbook, only a set of mirneographed pages stapled together. On the pages are lessons, really groups of sentences and phrases that the Government thinks Mr. Ma will need to know.

title: ART
description: STAMFORD THE painting of Jack Butler Yeats (18711957) has appeared here on several occasions, notably in the Armory Show of 1913 and in an exhibition marking the centenary of his birth, at the New York Cultural Center. Yet to most Americans, the artist remains comparatively obscure. Even in Ireland and England, where his memory has been widely honored, Jack B. has been overshadowed by his more renowned brother, William B., the poet and chief architect of the Celtic renaissance.

title: SPORTS Greenwich Sailor Recalls Perils of Fastnet Race
description: GREENWICH

title: Ohio State, Minus Hayes, Routs Syracuse
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 8  Woody Hayes came close to attending Ohio State's 318 football victory over Syracuse today, but moments before the kickoff he made a final decision. It was not to walk across the street to Ohio Stadium for the first Buckeye football game since 1950 in which he was not coaching Ohio State.

title: Kristine Montamat, Jeffrey A. Jannuzzo, Lawyer, Are Wed
description: Kristine Lea Montamat, daughter of Harold Montamat of Gay Head on Martha's Vineyard, Mass., and the late Mrs. Montamat was married yesterday in New York to Jeffrey A. Jannuzzo, an associate with the New York law firm of Debevoise, Plimpton, Lyons & Gates.

title: Special Programs for the Elderly in Metropolitan Area Colleges
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: HOOKS ATTEMPTING TO RENEW N.A.A.C.P.;
description: Two years after he became executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the Rev. Benjamin L. Hooks is leading major effort to solve the organization's financial, administrative, membership and image problems.

title: Japanes Chip Gain Hold in U.S.
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  The Japanese, who have successfully invaded the automobile market in the United States and have fared none too badly with cameras and television sets, now are taking a slice of still another American industry  computer components known as semiconductor chips. And, as in their prior incursions, the move has raised the ire of some United States manufacturers.

title: Michigan Trounces Northwestern, 497
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 8 (AP) B. J. Dickey, Michigan's quarterback, ran for two touchdowns and passed for a third as the Wolverines overwhelmed Northwestern, 497, today in the season's opening football game for the Big Ten foes.

title: American Architects in Iran Saw Gigantic Projects Fade Away
description: I.M. Pei keeps his in a locked filing cabinet high above Madison Avenue. Jordan L. Gruzen has his on a bookshelf in his private office 21 floors above Broadway. It takes a few minutes for Jaquelin T. Robertson to fish his from a pile of papers on the floor beside his desk in Carnegie Hall.

title: Manning the Hot Line: It's a Boring but Critical Job
description: FREDERICK, Md., Sept. 8 (UPI) Jim Phillips sits in front of a computer console eight hours a day performing a routine, somewhat boring job on what could be the world's most crucial communications device  the hot line between Washington and Moscow.

title: Heidi Hammond, Kevin O'Brien Wed
description: Heidi Anne Hammond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Harrison Hammond of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday in the Congregational Church to Kevin Kilpatrick O'Brien, son of Mrs. M. Moulaison O'Brien of Melrose, Mass., and Edward James O'Brien of Lynnfield, Mass. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith performed the ceremony.

title: Church Gives $6 Million For Antipoverty Projects
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI)  The Campaign for Human Development, the Roman Catholic church's antipoverty program, has allocated $6 million in grants and loans for selfhelp groups seeking to alleviate poverty and oppose iniustice.

title: Man Is Arrested in Rape in Miami And Charged With Five Murders
description: MIAMI, Sept. 8 (AP)  Detectives questioned a 27yearold suspect today about some unsolved rapemurders and then charged him with five slayings.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: It isn't officially autumn yet, but the Bernie Leighton Quartet will open the fall jazz concert season at the Eastern Branch of the Monmouth County Library, Route 35, Shrewsbury. The program will begin at 3 P.M.

title: Conflicts and Fastnet Badger Race Groups
description: In yachting, no one waits to serve on a race committee. Instead, one usually is drafted, spending hours doing tedious management work while friends on the water complain the starting line is askew.

title: One Teacher's Experience With Open Education
description: PEN elementary education is alive and well in two suburban towns in south central Connecticut.

title: AMTRAK'S RIDERSHIP POSTS GAIN OF 25%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8  Amtrak has reported that more than two million passengers used its nationwide rail service in June, a 25 percent gain over June 1978 and the highest monthly total in the eight years of the federally subsidized system.

title: A Business Sentry For Risky Places
description: IN an unpredictable world, where seemingly stable governments topple overnight, what could be more predictable than politicalrisk management and insurance?

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE invitation came on creamy stationery under the seal of Puerto Rico: Mrs. Kate Donnelly de Romero Barcel cordially invites you to visit her at La Fortaleza in San Juan ...

title: Sirens Mark Path of Yonkers Arsonist
description: THREE of the men were sitting around a table in the kitchen. A fourth man, sprawled out on nearby couch, was sleepily listening to the talk of fishing, family and politics when the alarm sounded.

title: Grass Turns Brown
description: BOSTON, Sept. 8  It's worse here than in most places. There are 22 teams in the major leagues that won't make the divisional playoffs, 24 that won't win a pennant, 25 that will miss out on the baseball championship of North America. In other towns these disappointments come with the franchise. You can't win em all, as the St. Louis Browns used to remind themselves unnecessarily. In Boston, it is disaster.

title: Ford Denies Russians Were in Cuba at Time Of His Administration
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 8 (UPI)  Former President Gerald R. Ford today called for the immediate withdrawal of Soviet combat troops from Cuba and criticized the Carter Administration for its handling of the issue.

title: The Diploma for the OutofSchool
description: IT took several decades, but after raising four children and making sure they all went to college, Barbara Jean Nardozzi went out and got herself a diploma from high school this year.

title: ANTIQUES
description: WETHERSFIELD

title: A Village Built Just to Amuse
description: We were so captivated by the setting for the TV series The Prisoner that once we discovered the place actually existed we both wanted to go there. That setting, an isolated, maximum security village, inhabited by former spies and others whose memories are weighted by state secrets, is, in fact, Portmeirion, an architectural fantasia on the coast of North Wales, which was planned and built by the architect Sir Clough WilliamsEllis in the 1920's and 1930's.

title: The Region; Continued; Police Wonder Does Shoot to Stop Mean Shoot to Kill?
description: The advantage is all with the criminal, said Robert Brandes, a New York City police officer who works out of the 112th Precinct in Forest Hills, Queens. You have to stand there and be shot at before you can shoot back. He doesn't have to think twice before he can fire his gun, but you have to.

title: Hollis Russell Weds Graham Maxwell
description: Graham Elizabeth Hyslop Maxwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hamish Walter Hyslop Maxwell of Brooklyn and Quogue, L.I., was married yesterday in Quogue to Hollis Forbes Russell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Russell of Hampton Bays, L.I. The ceremony was performed in the Episcopal Church of the Atonement by the Rev. F. Goldthwaite Sherrill of Brooklyn Heights.

title: ART
description: BARNEGAT LIGHT WHEN people go on vacation, art goes with them in a manner of speaking. Summer galleries bloom in the smallest resorts, sometimes with local talent and other times with names imported for the occasion.

title: Scholastic Aptitude Test Scores Drop as 10Year Trend Goes On
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP)  The Scholastic Aptitude Test scores of America's high school seniors fell slightly this year, continuing a downward trend that began a decade ago, the College Board said today.

title: Jets Goal: To Blend Ingredients of a Sack
description: The coaches talk about stances and angles and squaring off, but to the men in the trench, the sacking of a quarterback is simply a question of desire.

title: Doctor Sentenced in Drug Case
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 (UPI)  A doctor has been sentenced to two years in prison and fined $250,000 in Federal court on charges that he conspired to receive and distribute four million amphetamines to patients at his weight control clinic over a fouryear period. Dr. Irvin Lepoff, 55 years old, of Narberth, an osteopath and plastic surgeon, was sentenced yesterday under a plea bargaining agreement, according to Assistant United States Attorney Thomas Mellon.

title: HUNGARIANS DIFFER ON PIECEWORK PLAN
description: BUDAPEST  After 24 years Vilmos Vasvari, who works in the iron foundry of the Red Star tractor factory, is no longer being judged on how many hours he works each week but on how many castings he produces each day.

title: HEARING SCHEDULED ON TOXIC PESTICIDE
description: ALBANY, Sept. 8  For the third year a row, a controversy about the use of endrin, a toxic pesticide, has aligned the agricultural community of the Hudson Valley, one of the country's major appleproducing areas, against the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, which has banned it as dangerous.

title: Miss Green Is Married
description: Deborah Dukes Green, daughter of Elizabeth Magruder Green of Annapolis, Md., and the late Col. Robert B. Green Jr., U.S.A.F., retired, was married yesterday to Stephen David Heyman. He is a son of Geraldine L. Heyman of Aspen, Colo., and D. John Heyman of Stony Brook, L.I.

title: POLL SHOWS CARTER TRAILS ON ABILITIES
description: BOSTON, Sept. 8  The American people overwhelmingly regard Senator Edward M. Kennedy as a strong leader and just as resoundingly believe that President Carter is not, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: GiltEdge Executive Training
description: NORMALLY, Charles M. Sweeney spends his time running a $100 million chain of restaurants and hotels, but this summer he left his wife and two children at home in San Mateo, Calif., moved into a dormitory at Harvard University for seven weeks and devoted most of his waking hours to the study of general management.

title: Miss McClure Wed To R.S. Hatfield Jr.
description: Susan English McClure, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Nettleton McClure of Guilford, Conn., was married there yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church to Robert Sherman Hatfield Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hatfield of Greenwicn ana Sherman, Conn. Tne Rev. Stephen Hines of Houston performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Bradford B. Locke, rector of Christ Church.

title: Auto Talks: Struggling to Avoid a Strike
description: DETROIT  In the best of times, a strike in the auto industry can spell disaster for the nation's economy. Now, with an economic slowdown under way, an auto strike, with its ripple effect on other industries, would surely push the economy into serious disarray.

title: Dr. M.N. Danielson Weds Miss Fingerhood
description: Patricia Frank Fingerhood of Princeton, N.J., an urban policy aide to Governor Byrne of New Jersey, was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Nils Danielson of Princeton, professor of politics and public affairs at Princeton University. The ceremony was performed in the Princeton University Chapel by its dean, the Rev. Dr. Ernest Gordon, a Presbyterian minister.

title: A List of Contributors To Simon Is Overdue, Elections Board Says
description: A required list of contributors to the Democratic primary campaign of Stanley Simon, the interim Bronx Borough President, had not been received by the Board of Elections yesterday, eight days after it was due

title: Prostitution Law Invalidated
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Sept. 8 (AP)  The State Supreme Court has ruled that Alaska's prostitution law is discriminatory because it defines prostitution in terms of women. The court said in an Aug. 24 ruling that the law discriminated against women by defining prostitution as the giving or receiving of the body by a female for sexual intercourse for hire. The law, it said, could be enforced by deleting the words by a female, thereby, making the language neutral as to gender so that the rest of the statute couldiemaln legally intact.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: For those who like to have something to show for their exercise  like trophies and Tshirts  there are four chances to compete in running and biking events today, and two on Saturday.

title: Suffolk, in Primary Throes, Is a No Man's Land
description: The graffiti in southwest Suffolk County is political. Flush Klein in 79 urges the bright redpainted message on the sides of huge concrete sewer pipes stacked along Montauk Highway.

title: Argentine Prices Rise 171%
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 8 (AP)  The cost of living increased 11.5 percent here last month, making inflation for the 12 months ending in August 171.1 percent, the Government announced yesterday. The increase was the largest since January's 12.8 percent rise.

title: The World
description: Fidel Castro had his hands full in Havana last week presiding over a conference of countries held together loosely by a talent of some for talking back to Washington and Moscow. Some talked back to Mr. Castro as well in terms rarely, if ever, heard in Cuba.

title: CHESS
description: Rooks generally do not belong in the middle of the board in the early middle game because they are usually subject to attacks from the opponent's minor pieces and pawns. Even if they cannot actually be trapped, the tactical care they require outweighs whatever benefits they might be supposed to produce.

title: Canadians Arrive in Peking
description: PEKING, Sept. 8 (Reuters)  A delegation of Canadian legislators led by the speakers of the Senate and the House of Commons arrived in Peking today at the invitation of the National People's Congress, China's Parliament.

title: Giants' Task: Stop Cardinals' Rookie Star
description: The boos were still reverberating among the chandeliers of the WaldorfAstoria's Grand Ballroom and hardly anyone heard when the St. Louis Cardinals announced their selection in the first round of last May's college draft: Ottis Jerome Anderson, running back from Miami of Florida.

title: Kay Crawford Crosland Is Wed
description: Kay Crawford Crosland and Reginald Franklin Pierce 3d of Norwalk, Conn., were married yesterday in Westport, Conn. The Rev. Theodore Hoskins performed the ceremony in the Saugatuck Congregational Church. The bride, fashion buyer of sportswear for men and women for the catalogue division of ChrisCraft Industries Inc. in New York, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Crawford Crosland of Bradenton, Fla. Mr. Pierce, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierce Jr. of Etna, N.H., is an account executive with DancerFitzgeraldSample Inc., a New York advertising agency.

title: The New Power at Fisher Hall
description: The New York Philharmonic looms large in the city's cultural life, but it will be in the news even more than usual in the next couple of weeks. The orchestra's seasonal opening on Thursday, with Rafael Kubelik leading a program of Martinu's Double Concerto and Beethoven's Eroica Symphony, is as good a way as any to mark the formal beginning of the autumn classicalmusic season. And on Sept. 20 the Philharmonic's threeyear contract with the American Federation of Musicians expires. Although preliminary signs indicate a more amicable negotiation than sometimes in the past, contract expirations always pose the threat of a strike.

title: Local Politics: A Focal Point
description: PRESIDENT CARTER, to rally the country to action on energy problems, speaks of wartime motivation. Middleincome Americans, however, more than any other citizens group. must in- volve themselves on the real battleground of this war: local politics. Our energy problem is only one of many such home rule issues, and the issue of privateproperty rights is pivotal as we move into the 1980's.

title: Cheap Help Needed: Many Poll Watchers
description: FOR pay  Democratic election inspectors, the ad in a Westchester pennysaver beckoned.

title: Why Turkish Rug Dealers Wear Dark Glasses
description: DAVID BARASH'S new book is a goodnatured, anecdotal exposition of the sober and, to many people, distasteful discipline called sociobiology, which seeks a biological basis in all social behavior and asserts that we exist only as a device by which our genes survive and reproduce themselves. Since was monumentally described several years ago in Edward O. Wilson's Sociobiology: The New Synthesis, it has been both highly praised as a genuine scientific advance and ferociously attacked as racist, sexist, determinist, reactionary, a misuse of science and assault on human dignity.

title: Middleman Role Suits Colorado Company
description: GREELEY, Colo.  Between the rancher and the Red Apple, a lot of cows go skinny to a Monfort feedlot, go fat to Monfort packing plant, go neatly packed in boxes onto Monfort trucks and go fast to Monfort distribution centers, whence they are sold. The buyers are restaurants, schoolsor the Red Apple.

title: Doctors Who Prescribe For Ailing Radio Stations
description: The phone jangled in Kent Burkhart's Atlanta office on Friday evening in July, a little more than a year ago. The caller was Edward Cossman, head of WKTU, a modestly successful FM radio station in New York City. Kent, he said, I've decided to take the station solid disco. How fast can you do it?

title: Chinese Wildlife Hurt During Period of Strife
description: PEKING, Sept. 8 (Reuters)  Some species of wildlife in China have disappeared over the past dozen years during the disturbances of the Cultural Revolution, the Guangming Daily of Peking said today.

title: Aita M. Zito Becomes the Bride of G. Thomas Hansson
description: In St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church yesterday afternoon, Aita M. Zito, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Zito of Melville, L.I., was married to G. Thomas Hanson, son of Mrs. Gunnar T. Hanson of London and Darien, Conn., and the late Mr. Hansson. The Rev. Anthony J. Barretta performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BEACH HAVEN (Surflight Summer Theater, Engleside Avenue)  California Suite (today, 8:30 P.M.) Same Time Next Year, opens Wednesday (through Sept. 16). 8:30 P.M. $54$5.50. (609) 4929477.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Until the invention of the telescope in the early 17th century, it never occurred to astronomers that planets other than Earth might have moons. Galileo, using his crude optick stick in 1610, opened their eyes with the discovery of Jupiter's four largest moons.

title: A Data Conglomerate
description: The time is the early 1980's. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 leading stocks has been falling for more than week. The F.W. Dodge index reports sharp decline in the value of the previous month's new construction contracts. Platt's Oilgram Price Report, confirming what Platt's Oilgram News reported days earlier, contains the bad news about the latest round of OPEC price increases. In Data Resources Inc.'s monthly report to bluechip clients, its chairman, economist Otto Eckstein, acknowledges that the nation does indeed appear to be slipping into a recession.

title: Townsfolk Mix With Inmates in a Prison School
description: CARBONDALE, ILL EVERY morning Alice Ribley leaves her two children with her mother, drives to a state prison and learns how to weld steel with 35 male convicts. Mrs. Ribley, who is not a criminal and who never saw the inside of a prison until she began attending class at the Vienna Correctional Center in southern Illinois, now spends seven hours a day, five days a week, cutting, grinding and blowtorching metal with men convicted of armed robbery, burglary and murder.

title: Professional Retraining In Flux
description: TWO podiatristsDr. Richard M. Breault of Schnectady, N.Y., and Dr. Morris Morin of Hackensack, N.J. will be traveling to Hershey, Pa., in November to attend lectures and seminars meant to sharpen their professional skills. While both say that they would attend anyway, New York State, by law, requires Dr. Breault to accumulate continuingeducation credits in order to get his license renewed, and in New Jersey, where there is no applicable law, insurance companies require Dr. Morin to do the same if he wants to continue his malpractice coverage.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: New York City Spent Most in 78 Albany Lobbying
description: ALBANY, Sept. 8  New York City spent more on lobbying activity  a total of $193.894  at the 1978 session of the State Legislature than any other public or private group, according to a report by the state's Temporary Commission on Regulation of Lobbying.

title: Farm and City People Sharing Experiences In Exchange Program
description: FORREST, Ill., Sept. 8 (UPI)  When Connie and Bob Ratzel tell of visiting David and Linda Miller on their farm, they speak enthusiastically of the freedom, the open air, meeting new people and exchanging experiences.

title: Traveling Exhibits To Make Library Rounds
description: TRENTON BLACK stockings reaching almost to her knees, and her baggy bathing suit extending from her shoulders to her knees, she sits on a rock next to a New Jersey lake, dimpling seductively at the camera.

title: MUSIC
description: IN very short order, the county will be flowering with chamber music of high excellence, and considering that some of these series have been sold out in the past, while others discourage (or actually prohibit) singleticket sales, it might be wise to consider early bookings.

title: On Language
description: Reporting of economics in the press has greatly increased in volume and sophistication, but the economic literacy of readers, even of The New York Times, has not kept pace. Therefore the public may not be getting the full benefit of the economic wisdom being spread before it. As a contribution to remedying this situation, I present here definitions of some words and terms most commonly encountered in current discussions.

title: Shelley Bradner Is Married
description: Shelley Bradner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Bradner Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Scott Cantrell Harrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Harrison Jr. of Pelham Manor, N.Y. The Rev. Robert J. Goodley performed the ceremony in St. James the Less Episcopal Church.

title: Miss Newburg Becomes Bride
description: Anne Colby Newburg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andre W.G. Newburg of New York and Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday to Bruce Gregory Baldwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald W. Baldwin of Ottawa. The Rev. David W. Good performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme. Conn.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Ever seeking ways to rule weather, the Weather Modification Office of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in Boulder, Colo., said in May 1978 that it would try seeding Atlantic hurricanes with silver iodide in the hope of dissipating their furious winds. Five aircraft fitted with special instruments were standing by last summer to carry out the experiments.

title: Carolyn Schreiner Is Married To Scott B. Calder in Darien
description: Carolyn Cort Schreiner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Agnew Schreiner Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Scott B. Calder of New York, president of Scott Calder International Inc., hotel representatives. The Rev. Edward R. Denim performed the ceremony in the Noroton Presbyterian Church.

title: DRESSING TO LOOK YOUR BEST 29
description: No matter how much or little one may think about clothes, what a man wears makes a statement to the world about who he is.

title: Indonesia Reports Illiteracy
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 8 (AP) Minister of Education Daud Jusuf said in a television interview last night that about 21 million Indonesians were illiterate. That is 15 percent of the nation's 140 million inhabitants. He said the problem of illiteracy was growing. His statement contradicted previous Government reports that illiteracy had been conquered.

title: A Playwright's Fluke Runs On and On
description: Today, Jack Heifner's Vanities becomes the longestrunning play in Off Broadway history and no one more surprised than the playwright himself. He still can't figure out how it all happened.

title: Alaska's Employees May Drop U.S. Social Security
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Sept. 8 (AP)  Alaska's state employees, who have grumbled for years that Social Security's bite exceeded its benefits in this highcost state, will soon find out whether they are withdrawing from the Federal pension program.

title: Margaret H. Child Of WNYC Is Wed
description: Margaret Harrison Child, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Josiah Humphrey Child Jr. of Boston, was married yesterday to Abbott Cotton Widdicombe, son of Abbott Widdicombe of Memphis, and the late Jacqueline Laporte Widdicombe. The Rev. Carl Scovel performed the Episcopal ceremony at King's Chapel in Boston.

title: Mexico Frees a Dakotan Jailed on a Drug Charge
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Sept. 8 (AP) The Mexican authorities have released a Sioux Falls woman who has been imprisoned in Mexico for more than a year and a half on drug charges.

title: Behind U.S. Open, One Man's Big Service
description: WHILE honors are being handed out to the winners of the United States Open tennis championships today at the National Tennis Center in Queens, Hy Zausner will be standing quietly on the sidelines. His eyes will roam over the center that he helped to build, the gleaming $12 million home of America's most prestigious tennis tournament.

title: 39 Are Injured in Battle For Mexico City Campus
description: MEXICO CITY Sept. 8 (AP)  A battle for control of the Mexico City campus of the Polytechnical Institute left 39 persons injured, the police said.

title: Shirting the Issues, and Everything Else, Too
description: A rose is a wise is a rose. But a Tshirt is something else again.

title: Of Soil and Toil and the Small, Good Earth
description: DIGGING in my backyard, doubledigging, expanding my vegetable garden for next year by a third, I toil and sweat but neither cry nor bleed as I attempt to cultivate and improve the barren soil. I, who spent a career at a typewriter, enjoy physical labor in the garden, where the miracles of life and death  animal and vegetable  occur daily.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 8  The Government's chief political opponent was stripped of his authority to run the country's largest opposition group today.

title: PRIMING FOR PRIME TIME
description: By the early spring of 1978, television producers in the hundreds, ranging from those who lived in Beverly Hills and owned hisandher RollsRoyces to those who were behind in the rent for their desk space, were already thinking furiously about the the 197980 season. What they were trying to figure out was how to get their hands on a piece of the $75 million to $100 million that the three television networks spend each year on develop ing new shows, it being understood that in the world of commercial television new can generally be defined as resembling some previous success.

title: You Can't Always Depend on the BuiltIn Meter
description: Most of us depend on cameras with builtin meters. Fortunately, the lightsensitive cells and electronic circuits used by these meters to measure light intensity are usually reliable and give good exposures. In 35mm singlelens reflex cameras the meter reads the light through the lens, but in some pockettype and compact 35mm models with autoexposure capability the meter eye is alongside the lens. Both designs are quite capable of accurate exposures.

title: 50 Stolen Guns Found In a Raid in Brooklyn; 2 Suspects Are Seized
description: A police raid in Brooklyn early yesterday uncovered part of a small arsenal of firearms taken by burglars at an upstate arms concern last month, counterfeit plates for $20 bills and small quantities of drugs, authorities reported last night.

title: Realty News
description: A partnership headed by Bernard H. Mendik has purchased the 41story office building at 330 Madison Avenue from the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company for $35 million.

title: James Buckley Weighs Pleas to Seek Ribicoff's Seat
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 7James L. Buckley, the former ConservativeRepublican Senator from New York, says he is beginning to consider the appeals of some Connecticut Republicans to run in their state for the Senate next year.

title: A Smoky Fire at Grand Central Disrupts Train Service
description: Fire broke out in a string of empty passenger cars on the lowerlevel tracks of Grand Central Terminal yesterday afternoon, filling the cavernous station with thick, gray smoke and forcing several hundred people to flee.

title: Wells Beats McTear in 100
description: GATESHEAD, England, Sept. (AP)  Allan Wells of Scotland produced a strong finish to defeat Houston McTear of the United States in the 100meter dash at an international track and field meet today.

title: DINING OUT
description: BROOK FIELD ONE expects to find decent seafood at the water's edge, but seafood restaurants inland are normally approached with caution. Such temerity, however, is uncalled for at Ship's Wheel in Brookfield. where seafood dominates and is treated with respect. There are 27 seafood entrees, plus five entrees for fish frowners and five for children, wisely allowing for youngsters who do not yet care for fish.

title: S. H. Harper Weds Josephine Angevin
description: Josephine Garrett Angevin, a Boston lawyer, was married yesterday in Ed.. gartown, Mass., to Stephen Henry Harper, a consultant in the computer industry. The ceremony was performed in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. John Greely.

title: CONNECTICUT VOTING FOCUSES ON 2 RACES
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 8  Two of Connecticut's most influential politicians, men with national reputations as urban experts, face uphill battles in Tuesday's mayoral primaries.

title: Bruno Schulz, Hidden Genius
description: Bruno Schulz was born in 1892 in Drogobych, a small city in Galicia, then a province of the AustroHungarian Empire, after 1926 part of independent Poland. Offspring of a line of Jewish merchants. Schulz taught himself to draw, and supported himself as a highschool drawing master. He was reclusive and, though once engaged to a Catholic woman, never married. He wrote privately, in Polish, and was at last induced to publish in 1934 a collection of sketches entitled The Street of Crocodiles. The book achieved considerable success and was followed three years later by Sanitorium Under the Sign of the Hourglass. In 1941 Drogobych was occupied by the Germans, and in November of 1942 Schulz, at the age of 50, was shot and killed in the street by a Gestapo officer.

title: STAMPS
description: Anew issue and a new show: A 50cent stamp out this Tuesday is the finale of the Americana Series; and Stamp Festival 79, a new show opening a fourday stand on Thursday in Madison Square Garden, is the curtainraiser for the fall season of big philatelic shows along the Atlantic Seaboard.

title: FRANK M. BASIL, 69, RACING ARCHITECT
description: HUNTINGTON STATION, L. 1., Sept. 8  Frank Martin Basil, a former president of the New York Racing Association whose financial accumen helped make possible the rebuilding of Aqueduct Race Track and Belmont Park, died today at his home after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

title: Thompson Banking Future on Decathlon
description: LONDON DALEY THOMPSON is British, black and brash. He is also, at age 21, the world's best decathlon athlete, with lofty goals to challenge even his supple skills. His plans include capturing the Olympic gold medal in 1980, 1984 and, if he feels like it, in 1988, before trading in his Olympic rewards for some of the endorsement variety.

title: Deaths
description: TUNNELLEthel L., on September 6, 1979, of Southampton, N.Y. Wife of the late Arthur W. Survived by her son, Arthur W.Tunnell, Jr. of Fort Myers, Fla, 2 daughters, Julia L. of Southampton, N.Y. and Adelaide E. of Trenton, N.J. Also survived by grandchildren. Reposing at the Brockett Funeral Home, 203 Hampton Road, Southampton. Services Monday, September 10 at 2pm. Interment Good Grounds Cemetery, Hampton Bays, N.Y. Mrs.Tunnell was an officer of the Southampton Colonial Society, a member of the First Presbyterian Church of Southampton, past regent of the Southampton Colonial chapter Daughters of the American Revolution and officer of New York State chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Rogers Memorial Library in Southampton, NY

title: Just What This Country Needs At This Moment
description: After its highly successful crosscountry romp via San Francisco, Los Angeles, Chicago, Detroit and Philadelphia, the longawaited new musicalSugar Babies, with its stars Mickey Rooney and Ann Miller, will open October 8 in Broadway's Mark Hellinger Theatre.

title: Job Plan in Works
description: WASHINGTON THE Northeast is wasting much of the Federal money it receives for job training by failing to train workers in skills needed by local industries, according to a report by a Congressional coalition.

title: A New Wall Street Furor; Underwriting; Fee System; Now at Issue
description: Wall Street, which has been buffeted by change, from the elimination of fixed commission rates nearly five years ago to a wave of mergers and mandated national market system, is now bracing for another blow. What has set the financial community's adrenalin flowing are possible changes in its lucrative investment banking business.

title: Enforcement of Ban on Smoking In Minnesota Is No Easy Matter
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 8 (UPI)  The woman in the doorway of Charles Schneider's office at the Minnesota Health Department was clearly angry.

title: Food
description: It's classic to malign British food. Admire the dappled English countryside, the thatchedroof villages, the promptness of the trains  anything British  but don't discuss the

title: Rock: Records Do 1960's
description: The overnight success of the Knack, who topped both the albums and singles charts recently, is ample indication that concise, melodic rockandroll with a mid60's flavor has become a potent commercial force. The Records, an English quartet at the Bottom Line over the weekend, offered the same sort of music, which. is sometimes called power pop but strikes this listener as nothing more or less than a welcome return to rockandroll basics.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: AFTER THERISEAN ILLUSTRATED INTERVIEWA dramatized social criticism incorporating film and theater, written and directed by Gerhard Barris. Astor Place, 434 Lafayette St. (2544370) Opens Mon.

title: A Capital Gala as Produced by the Right Contacts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8  With Hope, as in Bob, it needed only a mention of the idea and the judicious use of the right connections to whip together a Kennedy Center benefit for the Vietnamese boat people in under two weeks.

title: Tractors Called Less Economical For Asian Subcontinent Farming
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 7 (Reuters)Tractors are less economical than bullocks for farming purposes in India, Pakistan and Bangladesh, according to a survey published here

title: It's Bluefish Season Again, Hook, Line and Sinker
description: THE boat bobs wildly on Long Island Sound in a boil of conflicting currents, but those aboard ignore the motion; all attention is turned to the rods that jut over the side.

title: Barbara Bannard Wed To Christopher Haller
description: Barbara Markle Bannard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William N. Barnard 3d of Cold. Spring Harbor, L.I., was married there yesterday in St. John's Episcopal Church to Christopher George Haller, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Haller Jr. of Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony.

title: South Africa White Liberals Pin Hopes on New Leader
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 7  White liberals here are hoping to stiffen their challehge to the ruling National Party and its policies of separate racial development following the election of a new leader of the official opposition group in Parliament.

title: After Grim Warnings to the Contrary, Homeowners Won't Face Shortages
description: After a summer of much ado, the nation's oil refiners have managed to build their stocks of heating oil to a level that practically insures there will be no serious shortages for homes this winter. Assuming no new disruption in world oil supplies, the experts are now saying that the nation cluding New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and the rest of the Northeast, the region by far the most dependent on oil for heating  has been spared. There's only one catch: The oil will cost a whale of a lot more this year.

title: To Be Female Is to Die
description: THE BASEMENT Meditations on a Human Sacrifice. By Kate Millett. Illustrated. 341 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $10.95.

title: Pelham Manor: Troubled Enclave of Affluence
description: FOR decades, Pelham Manor has been known as a quietly wealthy residential community bordering Long Island Sound and New York City, just 29 minutes from Grand Central Terminal and yet remarkably untouched by urban blight and the social ills that have plagued many other Southern Westchester communities.

title: Nancy Ilene Sabol Is Married
description: Nancy Ilene Sabol, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey C. Sabol of Stamford, Conn., was married last evening to Lawrence Kenneth Echikson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Echikson, of Jenkintown, Pa. Rabbi Joseph Ehrenkranz performed the ceremony in Temple Congregation Agudath Sholom in Stamford.

title: CONNECTICUTH HOUSING The Return of OnCampus Living
description: THE 1973 Datsun 1200 parked in the driveway of the Pagano home in Ridgefield needed to have been made of rubber to accommodate the bare necessities deemed essential to college survival these days  the clothes, stereo set, re- frigerator, cooking utensils, tabletop range, toaster oven, basketball, football, baseball mitt, bed linens, sleeping bag. And, of course, the books.

title: Klein Slight Favorite; Turnout May Be Key
description: SUFFOLK County Executive John V. N. Klein is considered the favorite to weather the toughest fight of his political career so far, the Republican and Conservative primaries for the County Executive nomination on Tuesday.

title: THE MARKETS Credit Anxiety Hits Stocks
description: Stock prices, under the pressure of further increases in interest rates, suffered a sharp break last week before making a modest recovery at week's end.

title: Fairbanks's Return Is Spoiled by Oregon
description: BOULDER, Colo., Sept. 8 (AP) Reggie Ogburn, a junior college transfer, ran for 108 yards and passed for 168, leading a versatile Oregon offense to a 3319 upset of Colorado today. It spoiled the Colorado debut of Coach Chuck Fairbanks, who returned to the college ranks after six years with the New England Patriots.

title: Elderhostel: A Growing Chain
description: DURHAM. N.H. WHEN Irving Ott retired as a machinist 10 years ago, he took a job as an orderly in a nursing home to occupy his idle hours. But the daily routine of watching people his age dying and suffering from neglect left him depressed about himself and his peers. Within two years, he quit.

title: Navy Inquiry Focuses on Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP)  A recent Navy investigation into its nationwide recruiting practices has turned up more suspected violations of recruiting rules in Chicago than anywhere else in the country, a Navy spokesman said yesterday.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Roger Brown of Harvard University rejoices in the title of John Lindsley Professor of Psychology Memory of William James. Dr. Brown is a musiclover: not a trained musician in any sense of the word. but an avid listener and enjoyer. Certain eternal musical questions about the psychology and the very nature of music have interested him for a long time, and earlier this year he did some experiments that resulted in a paper for the Ann Arbor Symposium. Dr. Brown did come to some conclusions, but in many respects the questions he raised were more interesting than his answers.

title: Fund Expert Foresees $200 Million Outlays In 80 Presidency Bids
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI)  Presidential candidates spent $160 million in 1976, and in the 1980 campaign may spend $200 million, according to a leading researcher on United States political financing.33 percent of the total of $425 million spent in 1972, but only 30 percent of the $540 million spent in 1976.

title: The Cars of the 80's
description: DETROIT  The auto strike threatens as the industry prepares to introduce its 1980 models. Some of the changes:

title: JOE CLARK ATTACKS DIVISIONS IN CANADA
description: TORONTO, Sept. 8  In a flurry of moves indicative of his emerging style of leadership, Canada's new Prime Minister, Joe Clark, started a series of talks this week with his country's powerful provincial premiers.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: DUBLIN  Interest in Ireland by IrishAmerican politicians is at present helping Irish Republican Army terrorists more than anything has helped them during the past seven years.

title: Museum Woes
description: The shadow of inflation and the energy situation have cast a pall on virtually all sectors of the economy, and the cultural arena is no exception. Even the nation's museums are snared in the trap, according to a report by the University of Chicago. While museum attendance last year soared above the 500 million mark  more than eight times the annual turnout at all American professional sports events  the institutions faced still higher fuel, labor, maintenance and development costs. At the same time, most of their endowment funds are producing low returns on their traditionally conservative portfolios.

title: Miss Cartwright Becomes the Bride Of Burgess Nichols
description: In St. Thomas Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon, Georgette Constance Cartwright, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Lester Cartwright of New York, became the bride of Burgess Evans Nichols, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fernald Hobart Nichols of Lowell, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Andrew.

title: MARYLAND AGENCIES DIVIDED ON TUITION
description: SchoolsLINTHICUM, Md., Sept. 8  The governments of Maryland and Montgomery County are at odds over whether the county can charge tuition to foreign diplomats and employees of international agencies if they send their children to public schools.

title: The Art of Feeding the Political Kitty
description: RAISING money is never out of season for political candidates, although most people only become aware of it a few weeks before an election.

title: Metal Detector Yields Australians Big Nugget
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 8 (UPI) Two prospectors for gold in Australia have struck it rich with the help of a metal detector, finding a 13pound nugget worth more than $100,000, it was reported here today.

title: The Absolute Truth About Mankind
description: THIS is a book in which the author's vanity has dulled his wits. Freud is mistaken, LeviStrauss does not deserve to be read seriously, Marx was headed in the right direction but was inadequate. In the end there is only Harris, Marvin Harris.

title: Courtney Pastorfield Wed to Dr. T.C.M. Li
description: Courtney Pastorfield, a publichealth nurse, and Dr. Theodore C.M. Li, a senior medical resident at the New York Hospital, were married yesterday in Old Westbury, L.I. The ceremony was performed at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Fletcher McDowell by the Rev. Charles P. Calcagni of the Congregational Church of Manhasset, L.I.

title: A Correction
description: Because of typographical errors, an article in last Sunday's Week in Review incorrectly reported German production of synthetic oil in 1943. The correct figure is 32 million barrels a year. The same article incorrectly reported the production of a South African synthetic crude oil plant in 1978. The correct figure is 8.5 million barrels.

title: A Climate of Fear Among Doctors
description: SOUTH ORANGE ACLIMATE of fear pervades the practice of medicine in New Jersey, and it is threatening to spread to other states.

title: Oil Official Says Mexico Ignored Advice on Well
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Sept. 8 (AP)  Mexican officials ignored advice from American experts concerning the Campeche Bay offshore oil rig, whose blowout caused the world's largest oil spill, an official of an oil drilling company said today.

title: CRIME
description: Philis, the tough, wisecracking British operative, has been with us ever since The Fall Guy came out in 1972. One wonders it Ritchie Perry, who dreamed up this character, did aot from the beginning deliberately set out io compose an antimasque to the James Bond masque. Philis does pretty much what Bond did, and has much the same masters. And as many girls. But he is definitely middle class. He always gives the impression of talking out of the corner of his mouth, he often has the speech patterns of an American private eye, and there is nothing elegant about him. But he gets the job done.

title: CITY U. IS PERVADED BY OPTIMISTIC MOOD
description: Recent legislation providing the City University of New York with a new governance and financial structure has put university officials in an upbeat mood for the first time since the onset of the city's fiscal crisis four years ago.

title: AlmostFederal School in the Capital
description: WASHINGTON THE name suggests Government scientists at work inventing, say, the square tomato, but the Graduate School of the United States Department of Agriculture is neither a graduate school nor a branch of the Department of Agriculture. It is a special school for working adults that constitutes one of the most important  and little known  educational institutions in the nation's capital. It operates without any federally appropriated funds, in rented quarters, conducting day and night sessions.

title: Bruce Douglas Beinfield Marries Kathleen Miller
description: Kathleen Edith Miller, daughter of Mrs. Paul Augustus Stuhlreyer Jr. of Cincinnati, and Eric Thomas Miller of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Bruce Douglas Beinfield. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Malcolm Sydney Beinfield of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Charles L. Copenhaver of the Bronxville Reformed Church performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father.

title: EXILED POLITICIANS RETURNING TO BRAZIL
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 8  Brazilians who have been living abroad during the 15 years of military rule here have been flocking home this week to delirious airport reunions in the wake of a Government amnesty.

title: Karen Michelle Pilch Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Milton Pilch of Bay Shore, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Michelle Pilch, to Richard Blair Prince, son of Mrs. Si Milton of Tucson, Ariz., and Gerald Prince of Pittsburgh.

title: Events Today
description: Flea Market: A benefit for Sisters of Mercy Infirmary at Mercy College; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; North Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.entertainment; 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fifth Avenue from 16th Street to Garfield Place Brooklyn.

title: Senate Votes to Bolster Challenges of Agency Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8  The Senate yesterday approved by a wide margin an amendment that would significantly strengthen the hand of those who challenge Federal agency rules and regulations in the courts.

title: Calendars
description: Today  Westchester Kennel Club allbreed, Lyndhurst, Route 9, Tarrytown, N.Y.; 2,955 dogs; 8 A.M.

title: Burger King to Horn and Hardart: Have It Our Way
description: Who's got the best darn fast food in the whole wide world?

title: China Expanding Its Rail System
description: TOKYO, Sept. 8 (AP)  China is working to expand its railroad apacity by 50 to 100 percent, the New China News Agency said today. About 75 percent of the new railways are distributed in the western part of China which used to have practically no railways, the agency said. China now has 31,000 miles of track open to traffic, it said.

title: Miss Globus and Lee Day 3d, Students at New School, Wed
description: Laura Globus, daughter of Dr. David L. Globus, a New York internist, and the late Vivian Globus, was married yesterday to Lee Garnett Day 3d, son of Mrs. Arnaldo Lacagnina of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Day Jr. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony in New Canaan's First Presbyterian Church.

title: LIFE WITH MAILER
description: Nervous and alert as a ship's captain scanning the horizon, Norman Mailer trotted over to the podium of Harvard's Sanders Theater one evening this spring and surveyed his audience: bland, expectant undergraduates, neighborhood intellectuals and newly sedate veterans of the 1960's  a generation complacent in its maturity.

title: Obituary 9 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFF/COS 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. title: Gordana Markoc Is Married
description: The marriage of Gordana Markoc to Brian J. O'Brien Jr. took place yesterday in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Cathedral in Rockville Centre, L.I. The Rev. Robert Brown of Manhasset, L.I., performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Capt. Boris Markoc of the Yugoslav Merchant Marine and Mrs. Markoc of Dubrovnik, Yugoslavia. Mr. O'Brien is a son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Brien of Rockville Centre.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WHEN animal lovers  and art collectors  met last weekend in East Hampton at the benefit auction called Art for ARF's Sake, no one seemed interested in the obvious. An original drawing by Betsy the Chimpanzee, a resident of the Baltimore Zoo, was not sold.

title: Movie Don Giovanni; Will Have Premiere Nov.
description: Joseph Losey's film Don Giovanni, based on the Mozart opera, will have its world premiere at Kennedy Center in Washington, Nov. 4. The following day, it will be screened at Lincoln Center in New York as part of an invitational benefit.

title: A Female Umpire Gets Beaned, Berated and Better at the Job
description: I am a 24yearold woman who likes history and baseball. I teach history, which takes care of that. I played right field on my college women's softball team, but that wasn't enough.

title: Deaths
description: MULHEARNJohn R.48E. The members of the Board of Trustees of Manhattan College express with profound sense of foss their condolences for their colleague, friend and Chairman of the Board. Devoted husband, loving father, professional businessman, John has also been an inspiration and leader for the Manhattan College family. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mrs. Mulhearn and her children as well as to AT&T and the New York Telephone Co. Brother J. Stephen Sullivan, F.S.C. President, Manhattan College John J. Cooke,30. Vice Chairman, Board of Trustees.

title: POLITICS
description: FREDERICK K. BIEBEL, the Republican state chairman, usually gets a laugh from his partisan audiences as he tells them that when Republicans organize firing squad, they form a circle.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 2 P.M. (Television Channel 9, 2 P.M. Radio WMCA, P.M.)

title: Miss Caudle, Social Worker, Is Married to John T. Hughes
description: The Interfaith Chapel on the campus of the C.W. Post College in Greenvale, L.I., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Andrea Marta Caudle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Caudle of Great Neck, L.I., to John T. Hughes, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Hughes 2d of Flushing, Queens. Town Court Judge Charles C. Mehrmann of Freeport, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title: A Hard Bargainer
description: As early as this spring, Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Auto Workers, was acknowledging that these were indeed unsettled times for auto workers. I haven't seen any like them in my time, he said.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Among treasures recently uncovered by Italian workmen excavating for a new discotheque in Rome is an essay entitled How I Spent My Summer Vacation written by Julius Caesar at the start of his junior year in Cato the Elder High School. At the request of the Italian Government and the classics faculty of Oxford University, I have translated it from the Latin into English. The text reads as follows:

title: Guidry's 16th Tops Tigers
description: DETROIT, Sept. 8  Ron Guidry posted his 10th straight victory here tonight, and Rich Gossage gained a save against the Detroit Tigers for the second time in three games as the Yankees captured a 54 decision.

title: Small Fire at Lord & Taylor Store Is Extinguished by Sprinkler Unit
description: A small fire broke out at the Lord & Taylor department store yesterday afternoon and was extinguished by the store's sprinkler system before firemen got there, according to fire officials.

title: Japanese Logic and Illogic
description: SECRET RENDEZVOUS By Kobo Abe. Translated by Juliet W. Carpenter. 179 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. .$8.95.

title: Florida Gas Hot Lines End
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 8 (AP) With tourism in Florida on the rebound, Gov. Bob Graham yesterday ended ewergency gasoline hot lines and his travel. ers network of statesupplied service stations.

title: THIS WEEK IN SPORTS
description: The Philadelphia Phillies play the Mets at Shea Stadium Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday nights at 8. The Mets then go to Pittsburgh to play the Pirates Saturday and next Sunday.

title: Under the Pacific
description: RETURN FROM THE RIVER KWAI By Joan and Clay Blair Jr. Illustrated. 338 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $12.95.

title: Doreen Lee Landers Wed To Dr. Dwight D. Weller
description: Doreen Lee Landers, daughter of.Dr. and Mrs. Leo Augustine Landers of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday in St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church to Dr. Dwight Donan Weller, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Weller of Neptune, N.J. The Rev. Richard Grady pertformed the ceremony.

title: Mumps Cases Decline by 16.6%
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 8 (AP)  Slightly more than 11,000 cases of mumps have been reported in the United States so far this year, a decrease of 16.6 percent from the same period last year, the national Center for Disease Control said yesterday. In its weekly morbidity and mortality report, the center said that mumps activity declined fairly steadily since 1971, four years after the licensing of mumps vaccine.

title: BRIDGE
description: For a variety of reasons the inventors of conventions seldom have their names permanently attached to them and the credit goes to someone else  sometimes indeed to someone who not only did not invent it, but would not dream of employing it.

title: Woodworkers to Share Secrets of the Art
description: FINE furniture making is not lost art, despite the prevalence of massproduced products in today's showrooms. Museums display the work of living woodworkers alongside that of history's master craftsmen. Art galleries often display fine modern furniture, designed with beauty in mind as much as utility. Some of the country's most prominent woodworkers, many of whom produce furniture, will gather for an Oct. 57 conference called Wood 79, the State of the Art, at the State University of New York in Purchase.

title: Cosmos to Tour Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 8 (AP)  The Cosmos of the North American Soccer League

title: School Closings: An Issue of Control
description: AS he sets off each morning for his secondgrade class at the Cos Cob Elementary School in Greenwich, 7-year-old John Wells is not in the habit of dwelling upon such weighty concerns as tradition and family roots.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: In a footnote to a muchtold tale, John Dean, former White House counsel, will give a talk Tuesday at the University of New Haven, entitled Unfinished Testimony, on his Watergate experiences.

title: Mormon Leader Resting
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 8 (AP)  The Mormon Church president, Spencer W. Kimball, spent a restful night following emergency surgery at LDS Hospital, a church spokesman said today. Mr. Kimball, 84 years old, underwent surgery to drain blood and other fluid from his skull.

title: Estelle Rothschild Roddy Wed
description: Estelle Rothschild Roddy of Elkins Park, Pa., widow of Dr. Rudolph L. Roddy, was married yesterday to Joseph Thanhauser Jr. of Philadelphia.

title: Chills, Thrills and Many Sightings On a St. Lawrence Whaling Trip
description: It was gray, overcast and cold with a winddriven drizzle that coats coats with moisture in seconds. Faces winced. Hands and feet chilled. A perfect day for sitting by the fireplace sipping something hot and reading a newspaper.

title: Susan Durst Halpern Is Wed
description: The marriage of Susan Durst Halpern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Halpern of West End, N.J., to Joseph Michael Shyne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Shyne of East Brunswick, N.J., took place yesterday in New York. The ceremony was performed at Hampshire House by Rabbi Joseph Goldman of Elberon, N.J.

title: Deaths Laid to Jammed Drill Bit
