description: BELL RIVER, La., Sept. 8 (AP)  An accident that killed two men when a der rick on a oil barge collapsed was apparently caused by a drill bit that jammed, according to an official of the company that owned the rig. R.V. Pierce. vice president for Whelles Drilling said Thursday that a crew was pulling a pipe out of a hole when a drill bit jammed. The rotation of the drill pulled down the 140derrick tower of the rig Wednesday, he said. The rig was situated on the south leg of West Bayou Pigeon, a remote Iberia Parish area near here.

title: Parachutists Jumping Off a Rock Worry Officials at Yosemite Park
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Sept. 8 (AP)  Park officials are worried about parachutists jumping off a 3,600foot high rock here, despite what advocates say is a very beautiful experience.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE county's Department of Transportation has expressed more than a little interest in a proposal by the head of Westchester's largest bus network for a consolidation of bus operations and maintenance in Yonkers.

title: NEW FALL CLASSICS
description: Men's fashion, like any other creative or business endeavor, is constantly evolving and being influenced by changing life styles and economic climates. Every few years a revolutionary trend erupts, then a reactionary trend sets in, and finally, good sense takes over. The best of the revolution and its reactionary counterpart are combined to produce clothes that are both realistic and comfortably stylish.

title: Coast Lawyer Will Lead 1980 Libertarian Ticket
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8 (UPI)  Ed Clark, a Los Angeles lawyer, was selected today to be the Libertarian Party's Presidential candidate in the 1980 election.

title: Elizabeth A. Chew Is Bride in Capital
description: Elizabeth Aldridge Chew, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter T. Chew of Washington, and Allen Burr Rider 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rider of Boston, were married yesterday afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square, in Washington.

title: Patricia Murphy Is Married to Paul Stuebe.
description: Patricia Kay Murphy and Paul Henry Stuebe, graduates of Boston College, were married yesterday in the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scotch Plains, N.J.

title: Song: Chin Hwa Chiang
description: Chin Hwa Chiang, whose New York recital debut took place Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a lyric soprano who was born in Indonesia, and has studied in Taiwan and Rome. Miss Chiang's voice is a bright, pert instrument, and her manner is engaging. Unfortunately, her work is hampered by a persistent tendency to sing slightly under pitch.

title: Few Bank Robbers on L.I.
description: MINEOLA

title: Husband of the Tennis Queen
description: Shortly after Chris Evert Lloyd qualified for today's women's final at the United States Open championships, she was walking toward the locker room at the National Tennis Center with a tall, blond man. Near a gate, a security guard quickly recognized the famous face of the woman with the opportunity to win a record fifth consecutive Open title, but he glared at her companion. Badge, the security guard gyowled. Where 's your badge? Looking up, John Lloyd could have Identified himself as the husband of America's tennis queen. But he chose to identify himself another way.

title: Notes: Culture at the Olympics
description: Not many people realize that the charter of the Olympic Games calls for cultural activity to complement all the sports competitions. Coverage of past Games in print and on television has focused exclusively on athletic events, accounting for the ignorance of their esthetic counterparts.

title: Susan A. Stone Becomes the Bride Of S.G. Moorhead
description: Susan Appleton Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Stone Jr. of Middletown and Madison, Conn., was married in Middletown yesterday to Stephen Galpin Moorhead, son of Representative and Mrs. William S. Moorhead of Pittsburgh, Washington and The Plains, Va. The Rev. William A. Spurrier performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Wesleyan Memorial Chapel.

title: Today He'll Start Testing the Waters in New Hampshire
description: WASHINGTON  The candidate arrives in politically crucial New Hampshire, arguing for a balanced budget and against the traditional liberal programs of his party. He has no experience in Washington, D.C., and comes from a state that has never produced a Democratic presidential nominee. Moreover, in personality he seems a bit odd to most of the political professionals, and is known, among other things, for a deep interest in religion. He and his homestate staff are confident, but much of the political community scoffs.

title: Deaths
description: BURNSIsaac M., on Sept. 8, age 99 years, (retired supervisor N.Y.City Transit Authority), beloved husband of the late Mary C. Hodel, devoted father of Clarence, William, Mary L., Irene Ehrlich, Barbara Kutny, Daniel and the late Robert and Felix, survived by loving sisters, Irene Bushey and Elsie Burns, also survived by 24 grandchildren and 26 great grandchildren. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 6900 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial at Our Lady of Angels, Tuesday, 9:30 AM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: Connecticut /This Week
description: BRIDGEPORT  Paintings and watercolors by Judith Dolnick, mixed media by Maureen McCabe, sculpture by Stephen Zaima, Carlson Gallery, Bernhard Center, University and Iranistan Ayes., through Oct. 9; weekdays 11 to 5, Saturday and Sunday 1 to 5. 5764016.

title: FOOD AID COALS SET IN DOMINICAN STORM
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 8  Three independent relief agencies say they believe 19 million pounds of food will be needed to care for 500,000 people whose lives have been disrupted by Hurricane David and Tropical Storm Frederic.

title: Rutgers, Led by McMichael's Passing, Downs Holy Cross, 28 to 0
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 8 Ed McMichael, a junior from Jersey City, made his first varsity start today and despite a case of butterflies led Rutgers to a 280 victory over Holy Cross.

title: Aeromexico Orders Two DC10's
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 8 (AP)The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has received the first new order for DC10's since the Federal Aviation Administration grounded the widebodied jet after the nation's worst air crash. Aeromexico, the national airline of Mexico, announced yesterday that it was buying two DC10's and six smaller DC9's for a total purchase price of more than $190 million. Last May, an American Airlines DC10 crashed at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago, killing 273 people.

title: RADIO COMMERICIALS STIR RACE IN BRONX
description: Birds tweet. Leaves rustle in the breeze.

title: Around the Nation
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 8 (AP)  The search for a missing youth shifted today from a maze of sweltering tunnels under the Michigan State University campus to the scene of a fantasy game convention in Kenosha, Wis.

title: Queens Man Stabbed at Funeral
description: A man was stabbed while attending the funeral rites of his grandmother in Queens yesterday. Dennis Rizzato of 5342 67th Street, Maspeth, Queens, was renorted in serious condition at St. John's Hospital after being stabbed as he sat in Our Lady of Good Hope Roman Catholic Church at 71st Street and Eliot Avenue in Queens. Ralph Scotti, 35 years old, of 6988 Eliot Avenue in Maspeth, Queens, was charged with attempted homicide. The police said no motive was known.

title: Licensing Boards vs. Degnan
description: TRENTON ASTORM of protest against Attorney General John J. Degnan by the state's 19 professional boards is gathering momentum. The boards. which govern doctors, dentists, psychologists, morticians and other professions, are part of the Attorney General's Division of Consumer Affairs, and its members are angered over Mr. Degnan's efforts to take away some of their longstanding authority.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING Optimism Reigns in Vernon Twp.
description: VERNON TOWNSHIP DONALD WITMEYER is not worried about the energy crisis. In fact, he thinks it will work to his advantage. Mr. Witmeyer is a principal in Black Creek Associates, which is now developing a recreation/vacationhome complex in this Sussex County community.

title: Amateurs Who Act Like Professionals
description: THEY laughed in my face back in 1964, when I applied to study psychohistory at Columbia, recalls Lloyd deMause. At that time the field was unknown in academe  like most fields when they first start up. So I really had no choice but to do it myself, as an independent scholar.

title: The Uphill Fight To Get a Refund
description: Repeatedly travelers ask: Why it is often so difficult to obtain a refund when plans change or a trip turns sour?

title: Battle Foreshadowed For Next Year's Race To Head Police Union
description: TANNERSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 8Posted on a tree near the entrance to the Police Recreation Center, where delegates from the New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association held their 85th annual convention this week, was a sign that read: Caruso and McFeeley welcome you to the new P.B.A.

title: GARDENING
description: WHAT'S to be done with the fading flower border at the end of summer? Several things will extend the flowering season well into fall.

title: Uranium Mining Projects Backed By U.S. Judge for Nuclear Plants
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP)  A Federal district judge has ruled that current and future uranium mining projects may continue in an area that now supplies much of the fuel for the nation's nuclear power plants.

title: King Hussein in Paris for Talks
description: PARIS, Sept. 8 (Reuters)  King Hussein of Jordan arrived here today from Havana, where he took part in the thirdworld summit conference. He is to have talks with President Valery Giscard d'Estaing Monday on the Middle East situation.

title: Consumers Blame Referral Agencies
description: Complaints about apartmentreferral agencies in New York City are rising, according to Patrick J. Cea, principal attorney in the counsel's office of the New York Department of State.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THE seashore of the July and August vacationers  the Bennies  has once again become the ocean for us natives.

title: Giants and Jets Limit Local TV Selections
description: On Sunday afternoons during the National Football League season, about 1.2 million people watch pro football on television, according to Nielsen ratings in the New York market, the largest in the nation. The choices for those fans today are limited and overlapping.

title: Letters of the Artist as a Young Man
description: IF D. H. Lawrence had ended up as one of that mildly ludicrous type, the Ancient British Intellectual, he would have been 94 this Tuesday. Cambridge University Press has chosen to mark the day by publishing this first volume of a definitive edition of his writings. Like many major literary events, this one is well seasoned with irony. In adult life, Lawrence himself never celebrated his birthday, and kept the date a secret; he cared nothing for first or last editions'; and after his disastrous visit of March 1915 he loathed Cambridge and everything it stood for. The list could go on; nevertheless, one should not lose sight of the basic truth that Lawrence's letters are among the finest in the English language and have much to gain from the scholarly presentation given them in this new edition.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Should one, because of their contamination by polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB's), eat fish from the Hudson River?

title: Koch Schedules Talks With Blacks
description: In an effort to improve his relations with the black community, Mayor Koch had breakfast yesterday with Representative Charles Rangel and then promised to meet regularly with Mr. Rangel and the five black members of the City Council. He said the first gathering would take place later this week.

title: Sharon M. Collins, Law Clerk, Is Wed to Frederic Townsend
description: Sharon M. Collins, a law clerk to Judge Thomas C. Platt of the United States Eastern District Court in Brooklyn, and Frederic Townsend, a lawyer, were married yesterday afternoon in Elmira, N.Y. The Rev. Paul McCabe performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church.

title: Iranian Aide Meets Saudi Prince
description: TAIF, Saudi Arabia, Sept. 8 (Reuters)  Iran's Minister of National Guidance, Nasser Minachi, met here today with Crown Prince Fand, it was reported by the Saudi news agency. The agency gave no details of the meeting, the first between a member of the Islamic revolutionary Government of Iran and the Saudi ruling family.

title: WASHINGTON The Cuban Dilemma
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8  Ever since the beginning of this nation, there has been anxiety about foreign intervention in Cuba. It is startling now to read the correspondence between Thomas Jefferson, John Adams and President Monroe on this subject. It dramatizes their concern that control over the point of Florida  then in Spanish hands  and Cuba were essential to the security of the young Republic.

title: POINTS OF VIEW Open Skies Close Doors to U.S. Airlines
description: A recent headline announced that company that had construction facilities in the old Brooklyn Navy Yard was discontinuing its shipbuilding operations there. The reason: It lost $25 million at the facility last year trying to compete with statesubsidized foreign companies.

title: I Like Jimmy
description: I recently read a letter in a magazine from a British subject who said he couldn't understand the fuss about President Carter since he thought that Mr. Carter was the best President since World War II. His statement was so completely out of phase with everything we read in the newspapers each day that it took me a minute to realize that this person was absolutely right.

title: Jazz: Esther Satterfield
description: Esther Satterfield will probably be singing Chuck Mangione's Land of Make Believe for the rest of her life. For awhile it seemed probable that her entire musical personality would remain mired in the treacly nevernever world of that number, which featured her vocal when it was originally released on a Mangione album that has become something of a pop standard. When she first went out on her own, she fronted groups that performed in the pale fusion style popularized by Mr. Mangione, and her material tended to be unfailingly upbeat and simplistic.

title: Sports News Briefs; Warner Heads Inductees To Cornell Hall of Fame
description: Glenn S.(Pop) Warner, late football player and coach at Cornell and also coach at Georgia, Carlisle (where he coached Jim Thorpe), Pittsburgh, Stanford and Temple, headed a list of 17 named to the Cornell University Athletic Hall of Fame. Also named was Allison Danzig, a Cornell football player who achieved greater fame as a sportswriter with The New York Times. Formal induction will be on Sept.28.

title: Man, the King Of the Beasts
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J.  An Indian maharajah often used children as bait during his tiger hunts, assuring the terrified parents that he would shoot the creature before their little ones were torn limb from limb.

title: Topics Deathless Dam, Brotherly Storm
description: The proposed Tellico Dam in Tennessee is the project we all thought was killed off long ago by the tiny snail darter, an endangered fish whose spawning grounds would be destroyed if the dam were completed. It's not dead after all. The Tennessee delegation in the House managed to sneak through an amendment that would exempt Tellico from virtually any law that could prevent its completion. Now the issue must again be dealt with by the Senate in a vote expected soon.

title: Soviet Climbers Report Sighting Track of Abominable Snowman
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 8 (Reuters)  Soviet mountain climbers have found what appear to be footprints of an abominable snowman in Central Asia, the daily Komsomolskaya Pravda said today.

title: Decorating
description: Though the late John Fowler did not invent the English countryhouse style, he is responsible for the way we perceive that sort of decorating today. When he began his career in the 1930's, the modernist message had just begun to reach Europe's upper classes. In France, Art Deco was much the rage, and in London, Syrie Maugham, the decorator and wife of Somerset Maugham, was offering the smart set her own lush version of modernist austerity. Fowler, an astute student of design, heard the word, no doubt, but somehow he failed to see the point.

title: Roberson Sets Games Record in 100 Meters
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 8 (AP)  Mike Roberson of the United States broke the World University Game's record in the 100meter dash, Udo Beyer of East Germany won the shot put and I lie Floroiu of Rumania took the 10,000meter run today.

title: Police Accuse Suspect Of Robbing 2 Banks And a Savings Office
description: A suspect was arrested in Queens Friday afternoon and charged with four robberies at two bank branches and savings and loan office in Manhattan in an eightday period that began Aug. 30.

title: Jakob Michael Dead; Industrialist, 85, Gave Aid to Jewish Causes
description: Jakob Michael, an industrialist and philanthropist, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: SPOTLIGHT Alaska's Economic Cheerleader
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska  One of my problems is that I'm a born optimist, concedes Robert R. Richards, president of the Alaska Pacific Bank and the man widely regarded as the state's economic pundit. On the other hand, I think when one looks at the long run, there is a lot to be optimistic about in Alaska.

title: Deaths
description: FOSTEREsty, on September 6, 1979 of Maplewood NJ, Husband of the late Grace Reed Foster and the late Elizabeth Hippie Foster. Father of Esty Foster Jr of New York City, W. Reed Foster of Oakland Calif, Charles W. Foster of Chatham N.J. and Mrs. Mary F. Orben of Columbus, Indiana. Also survived by thirteen grandchildren. Memorial service in First Presbyterian & Trinity Church, So. Orange N.J. Monday September 10, at 2 PM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to William's College, Williamstown, Mass, Hospital Center at Orange, Orange N.J. or American Cancer Society

title: CAPITAL REPORT
description: IS THERE a recession in New Jersey? Not yet, but one may be building. The indicators are mixed.

title: Coast Pharmacy Dean Named by Mrs. Harris To Head Drug Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI)  Jere Edwin Goyan, dean of the school of pharmacy at the University of California at San Francisco, has been appointed Commissioner of Food and Drugs, it was announced today.

title: The Yale Rep Goes to Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. Robert Brustein, who for the past 13 years has been astonishing, provoking, irritating and, in the view of his admirers, inspiring and enlightening the theater world'in his capacity as dean of the Yale School of Drama and director of the Yale Repertory Theater, has just moved to Harvard. It did not take more than a small van to pack up his correspondence files and some old pictures and posters, but the move from New Haven to Cambridge was weighty all the same. At Harvard, Mr. Brustein will start teaching drama next year as a regular member of the English Department, and, in January 1980, he will become director of the Loeb Drama Center's new American Repertory Theater Company, a producing unit to be partially funded by Harvard and to include many on its staff who worked side by side with Mr. Brustein at the Yale Rep. The American Rep will open a pilot season in March and, of course, it, too, will be guided by Mr: Brustein's demanding idealism.

title: How to Make Out as a Writer in Russia
description: DOES challenge to art and literature lead to response? Do writers who have to create under regime of persecution achieve a greatness and a quality denied to their more fortunate colleagues living in a wholly indulgent and permissive society? The answer must be that one can't compare achievements of such different kinds. Good writers may be the product of any sort of society, but they will be as different as the environments that have made them what they are.

title: Holograms That Fascinate Eye and Mind
description: PORT WASHINGTON HOLOGRAMS have made marked imprint on the art world, but they still give rise to questions about their status as an art form. Are they more a product of science than of art, or a happy combination of both? Are conventional scientific and artistic definitions even necessary in experiencing and classifying these works, which produce threedimensional imagery through the use of laser beams?

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The cross burning on Inga Grant's lawn is the overt symbol of the internal prejudice that keeps most Long Islanders separated and fearful. The ignorance that fosters this prejudice perpetuates unnecessary reactions such as panic selling. The separation that results causes communities to be burdened with what appears to be the only method of integration: busing.

title: TestCoaching: Is It Worth It?
description: FRANK CARMONA sat intently in a makeshift classroom at Manhattan's Barbizon Plaza Hotel as a Columbia Test Preparation Institute teacher, Steven Stumpf, outlined strategy for taking the business section of the Graduate Management Admission Test. Don't think any more than you have to, advised Mr. Stumpf, The best approach is to eliminate the bad answers first, then concentrate on the remaining choices.

title: Secrecy About Secrecy
description: If the Emperor has no clothes, it's better not to hold the imperial parade in public. In that sense only does the Justice Department have good reason to try to argue its case against The Progressive magazine behind closed doors in a Federal appeals court in Chicago next week.

title: Mixing the Young and Old
description: BELLINGHAM, WASH. AGRAYHAIRED student sharpened the focus of a Fairhaven College class discussion on aging as she explained what happened to her when she was widowed. It didn't crush me, she said. It was a challenge to pursue other options. I realized I would have to make a new life for myself, otherwise, I'd have none.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMMax, beloved husband of Ann, dear brother of Henrietta Stern and David, and devoted uncle. Services Sunday, September 9, 1:45 PM, The Riverside, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A Grim View Of a Farmless Connecticut
description: THERE was no corn at the roadside stands that year. There were no peaches. The roadside stands that had sold Connecticutgrown fruits and vegetables were closed now. Only a few remained open, manned by 10yearolds selling lemonade that was faintly warm and tasted of Florida.

title: Still New Under the Sun
description: A great burden was lifted from my shoulders as I entered the summer of 1979. For the first time in 32 summers, I didn't care if I got tanned.

title: Transport Bond Issue At Stake
description: TRENTON VOTERS will be asked on Nov.6 to increase the state debt by $475 million, the request coming in a referendum on a new transportation bond issue that earmarks $245 million for state highways. $150 million for public transportation and $80 million in state aid for county and municipal road work.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: EVERY year at this time many letters come in from homeowners who plan to close up their homes for the winter. Some of the owners go south for the season and want to shut down their primary houses; others have vacation homes that they seldom visit in winter, and want to save the cost of heating them.

title: How City Tenant Groups Take Steps Toward Ownership
description: Felix Polanco is thinking ahead to the day he can hire a doorman for the tenantmanaged building he heads at 238 West 106th Street, where stained glass windows, sparkling marble, and decorative metal doors in the lobby give the building the look of a luxury apartment house.

title: Lou Graham, on 67, Takes 2Stroke Lead
description: SUTTON, Mass., Sept. 8 (AP)  Lou Graham, a golfing millionaire although he has won only four events since joining the pro tour in 1964, took a twostroke lead today at the halfway mark of the $250.000 Pleasant Valley Classic.

title: The C.E.U.: What's Its Credit Rating?
description: ONE of the painless chores in the life of an Olympia, Wash., pharmacist, Richard Rhodes, is going back to school for a weekend. Because of a state law reouirine him to oarticioate in 10 hours of professional continuing education annually, Mr. Rhodes recently attended a twoday series of seminars called Pharmacy and the Law in the public conference rooms of an Olympia bank. There were lecturers from state government and the medical profession, refreshments, lively debates  and no exams. The program was sponsored by a national drug manufacturer.

title: Teachers Learn To Switch Careers
description: TRADITIONALLY, teachers have signed up for courses and workshops to help them become more effective educators. Now, in a growing number of careeralternative centers and federally financed teacher centers across the country, teachers are taking courses and workshops to help them find more satisfying fobs outside education.

title: Jet Run, in Jumpoff, Takes $32,000 American Cup
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8Jet Run, owned by F. Eugene Dixon and ridden by Mike Matz, won the $32,000added American Gold Cup for show jumpers today at John F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: Briton Says China Is Expecting Little From Talks with Moscow
description: PEKING, Sept 8 (Reuters)  Former British Prime Minister Edward Heath said today that the Chinese did not expect much from the talks with the Soviet Union opening in Moscow later this month.

title: State and City Agree to Share Costs of Treating Mentally Ill in Brooklyn
description: New York City and State have reached agreement on a joint arrangement to provide full psychiatric services to the mentally ill in Brooklyn, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Barbara Taylor Bradford, whose first novel, A Woman of Substance, has made the bestseller list, wants to dispel the notion that her success is as sudden as it appears. I've been a working journalist most of my life, she says, but I always wanted to be a novelist. started writing fiction when I was 12. have at least five unfinished novels in my drawer.

title: FOOD
description: THE fresh vegetables and herbs abundant in the garden and at farm stands and markets can be used to advantage in combination with pasta. Not only the juicy scarlet tomatoes but also zucchini. fragrant basil and verdant broccoli or snowy cauliflower add zesty crunch and color to strands of pasta.

title: Flying for the Last Time
description: BALDWIN ONE thing the Island has in plentitude is burial ground  from Brooklyn out into Suffolk, big ones, little ones, public ones and private ones.

title: CONGRESS TO START BATTLE OVER BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8A battle over the Federal budget starts in Congress next week as the projected deficit for 1980 threatens to increase by $10 billion, and perhaps more.

title: Edison Pacers Are Beim Edited
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ONE of the habits that Thomas A. Edison had was always putting things in writing. His staff did the same.

title: Miss Austin: Money in the Bank
description: A stranger in a courtside box at the National Tennis Center turned in his seat and addressed a question to Donald Dell and Sarah Kieppinger, Tracy Austin's lawyers.

title: Canadian Hospital Hires Medicine Man for Indians
description: WINNIPEG, Ontario, Sept. 2A rural hospital near here has hired a 42yearold Indian healer as part of a program to improve'services to its considerable number of Indian patients.

title: If You Go . . .
description: ... looking for unusual festivals and fairs, here are some sources for additional information:

title: TV VIEW
description: The home screen is currently offering several quite diverse and controversial views of one of the most horrific periods in the history of mankind. On public television, WNET/Channel 13 is in the midst of a month of special programming to mark the 40th anniversary of the start of World War II. This package of programs, under the umbrella title of Reflections of the Third Reich, consists of feature films and documentaries  a few being shown for the first time on television  all of which were originally produced abroad. And on NBC, a fourpart rebroadcast of the dramatic miniseries Holocaust will get under way tomorrow at 8 P.M.

title: Fashion
description: Variety has always been the spice of good fashion. The woman who varies her wardrobe with these proper new clothes may be sending a message that is as sexy as it is subdued.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, Sept.9 VOLENDAM (Holland America). Lett Bermuda Sept. 7; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Elizabeth Lowe, Consultant, Is Married to Warren Welsh
description: Elizabeth Cochran Lowe, a consultant in written business communications, and Warren Reed Welsh, director of corporate security for the American Can Company, were married yesterday in St. James Episcopal Church. The Rev. Dr. Hays H. Rockwell performed the ceremony.

title: Energy: Just One Carter Trouble
description: By his own admission, Jimmy Carter needs to win a few big ones on Capitol Hill, and soon. Accordingly, he greeted returning Congressmen last week with his oftrepeated assertion that energy legislation should be their top priority. People want action, House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. loyally agreed. But some Congressmen, back from a month of soundings in malaiseland, contended that whatever Congress delivers and at whatever pace, it will be too litle too late for the President. There's a clear feeling that he's in over his head, said Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat.

title: NEW FALL CLASSICS THE LOOK IS CONFIDENT, VERSATILE AND STYLISH
CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: MANY homeowners who think of themselves as respectable, well-established citizens have been wondering if they, too, will be asked to pay for their fuel oil within 10 days of delivery, or whether a good credit history will suffice to maintain the 30day terms that were standard in earlier winters.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: TREES and shrubs can be trespassers, even standing still, and more than that, they can be a nuisance to a neighbor without going over the property line.

title: KidnappingRape Suspect Held
description: JACKSON, Mich., Sept. 8 (AP) The police said today they had arrested a fugitive from the Schenectady County Jail and charged him with kidnapping and raping a 12yearold girl. Douglas Hyson, 23 years old, of Schenectady, who escaped from the jail in February, is being held in lieu of $50,000 bail in the attack last Sunday, the police said. The victim, a Jackson girl, is recovering.

title: Sylvia W. Horner Wed to G. D. Baker
description: Sylvia Wigglesworth Horner, daughter of Mrs. G. Philip Lynch of Cedarhurst, L.I., and Martin McG. Horner of San Juan Capistrano, Calif., was married yesterday to George Dickson Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. J.H. Baker of Scottsdale, Ariz. The ceremony was performed in TrinitySt. John Episcopal Church in Hewlett, L.I. by the Rev. Earle D. Pratt.

title: Aides Ousted Over Leipzig Show
description: EAST BERLIN, Sept. 8 (Reuters) Two Leipzig officials have been dismissed for having allowed the staging of a revue poking fun at Erich Honecker, the East German Communist leader, and the secret police, it was reported here today. The city's cultural affairs officer, Ruth Gehrke, and the local Communist Party cultural affairs secretary, Eva Bart, were dismissed. the sources said.

title: HardCore Jobless Count Politically, Economically
description: WASHINGTON  How can a country battered by inflation combat rising unemployment without speeding up the wageprice spiral?

title: Papers and TV Offering Courses for College Credit
description: Thousands of people around the country will have the opportunity this fall to receive college credit for reading newspapers and watching television.

title: Miss Skidmore Is Wed in Ohio
description: Suzanne vosmer Skidmore of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Skidmore of Cincinnati, was married yesterday evening to William Joseph Mills 2d, also of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Steward Mills of Trenton. The Rev. Gerald Dickey performed the ceremony in the Armstrong Methodist Chapel in Indian Hill. Cincinnati.

title: Another Effort to End the Rhodesia Impasse Begins Tomorrow
description: LONDON Four times in the 19 years since Ian D. Smith's unilateral declaration of independence, Britain has seemed within sight of a solution to the intractable problem of Rhodesia. But each time aboard H. M. S. Fearless in 1966, aboard H. M. S. Tiger in 1968, in Salisbury in 1971 and in Geneva in 1976general agreement could not be achieved.

title: Western Airlift of Aid To Cambodia Continues
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 8 (Reuters)  A plane carrying 41 tons of food and medicine for Cambodia left here for Phnom Penh today after a brief refueling stop on its way from Geneva.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: THIRDWORLD TALKS CLOSE TO APPROVAL OF A NEUTRAL STAND
description: HAVANA, Sept. 8 Third world leaders moved toward formal reaffirmation of the principle of nonalignment with the great powers today but remained deeply divided on many political issues.

title: Engagements
description: FRATKINHINDERSTEIN

title: Liberian Is Cautious On Young's Proposal To Renew Israeli Ties
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Sept. 8  President William R. Tolbert Jr. said after meeting here with Andrew Young that, while he agreed with the American's position that formal talks between black African countries and Israel could be a helpful step toward peace in the Middle East, he was less certain when such talks might start.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: EVERY year at this time many letters come in from homeowners who plan to close up their homes for the winter. Some of the owners go south for the season and want to shut down their primary houses; others have vacation homes that they seldom visit in winter, and want to save the cost of heating them.

title: David Turns Out To Be a Goliath
description: We are totally destroyed, a villager in the Dominican Republic told a reporter. There is no water. There is no food. There is nothing. Hurricane David and its 150mileanhour winds had passed, leaving behind it, according to Government estimates, 150,000 people homeless and at least 1,000 dead; more bodies were discovered daily and the toll was expected to reach as many as 1,200. With electricity cut off, water supplies were totally disrupted and medical authorities dreaded epidemics as the population turned to polluted water sources. And in David's wake came Tropical Storm Frederic, bringing new floods and landslides the island.

title: GARDENING
description: WHAT'S to be done with the fading flower border at the end of summer? Several things will extend the flowering season well into fall.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The second Moscow International Book Fair opened last week, governed, as Russian cultural commissars were careful to point out well in advance, by the regulations of the Soviet Union. The most significant regulation was this one: The exhibitor is forbidden to exhibit, as well as to present as souvenirs, books and other printed matter incompatible in content and design with Soviet legislation (books advocating war, race or national exclusiveness, offending the national dignity of other exhibitors, publications incompatible with public morals, etc.).

title: Magnetic Train Engine Reaches 235 M.P.H. in Japanese Test Run
description: TOKYO, Sept. 8 (Reuters)  Japan broke the world speed record for magnetically operated vehicles today when a prototype train engine reached 235 miles per hour at the Miyazaki test track, the Japanese National Railways said.

title: Going For Broke
description: WASHINGTON  When the Democratic leaders of Congress assembled in the White House for breakfast on Wednesday, House Speaker Thomas P. Tip O'Neill had some advice for President Carter.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: EVERY year at this time many letters come in from homeowners who plan to close up their homes for the winter. Some of the owners go south for the season and want to shut down their primary houses; others have vacation homes that they seldom visit in winter, and want to save the cost of heating them.

title: BASIC SKIN CARE
description: It is not accidental that the current emphasis on physical fitness and the boom in men's skincare products are happening at the same time. Skin that looks and feels healthy has become matter of importance to the American man, no matter what his profession.

title: Sex Education: On With Show
description: IS sex education an idea whose time has arrived? The State Board of Education thinks so. It recently mandated that all local school boards provide familylife education in grades kindergarten through 12 by 1981.

title: Brookhaven Zoning Issue Afloat
description: FARFUL that the taxfree way of life aboard a houseboat is becoming too attractive, members of the Brookhaven Town Board are expected to adopt next month the most comprehensive ordinance on the Island restricting floating homes.

title: Jenny Semans Married in South
description: Jenny Lillian Semans and Michael V. Koortbojian were married yesterday afternoon at the bride's family home, Pinecrest, in Durham, N.C. The Rev. George Brinkman Ehlhardt, a retired Methodist minister and the bride's godfather, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: SHOP TALK
description: GREENPORT GREENPORT, long overlooked as a shopping center because of its location near the tip of the North Fork, is finally beginning to attract the attention it deserves. Several new shops have opened up, and many older establishments have expanded. The bustling fishing village has enough diversity of merchandise to attract the eye of even the most discriminating shopper.

title: For the Fairgoer in Search
description: Just because summer is over there is no reason to suppose the fun is gone for another year. There are plenty of highjinks left for fall and winter in cities and towns across the land, festivals and celebrations of traditions and life styles that thrive mightily smack in the face of all the standardization of our national scene.

title: Vonnegut's Softer Focus
description: JAILBIRD By Kurt Vonnegut. 246 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/ Seymour Lawrence. $9.95.

title: Jean Seberg Found Dead in Paris; Actress Was Missing for 10 Days
description: According to the police, Ahmed Hasni, a 29yearold Algerian who recently became Miss Seberg's fourth husband, reported that the 40yearold actress disappeared 10 days ago, wearing only the blanket and carrying a supply of barbiturates prescribed by a physician.

title: Winter Vegetables From Mexico Stir Frustration on Florida Farms
description: NOGALES, Ariz.  Sometime in December the big trucks will begin rolling into town from the south, piled high with vineripened tomatoes, gleaming bell peppers, squash, cucumbers and eggplant to satisfy the prodigious American appetite for fresh winter vegetables.

title: SWANSON SAGA: END OF A DREAM
description: Every city has its prominent families whose male progeny are called scions and whose good name ranks among its civic landmarks. In Omaha, Neb., the first among those families has always been the Swansons. The name Swanson commanded as much influence and respect in Omaha as Chandler in Los Angeles or Dupont in Wilmington. Most notably, the family gave America the TV Dinner; the Swansons were as much a factor of Nebraska lite as Cornhusker football or horizons that run westward in a seemingly infinite flat line.

title: An InterAmerican Panel Last Week Began a Painful Inquiry Into 6,000 Disappearances
description: BUENOS AIRES Argentina's military leaders opened the country's record of leftwing terrorism and ruthless official repression for international inspection last week, in a show of confidence that the bloodbath was over.

title: Imposing Pirates Make Their Run
description: MAYBE it is the black uniforms, which remind people of Boris Karloff as the evil executioner of the Tower of London.

title: Coastal Zone Plan Being Drawn
description: WASHINGTON NEW JERSEY environmental officials are applying the finishing touches to a program designed to regulate development along the coast, and they plan to make it public soon.

title: Brown Planning to Visit New Hampshire Today
description: CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 8 (AP)  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California brings his unofficial Presidential campaign to New Hampshire tomorrow for 12hour visit.

title: Editors Choice
description: BURGER'S DAUGHTER, by Nadine Gordimer. (Viking Press, $10.95.) The daughter of a South African political martyr struggles to keep her father's cause alive and to find an identity of her own: a dazzling novel.

title: Why Americans Fall for French Film Romance
description: The typical response of the French film community last spring to the news that Get Out Your Handkerchiefs won the Academy Award for Best Foreign Film was the same bemused shrug as when Cousin, Cousin first passed the $1milliongross figure in America. Indeed, these fluffy but delicately seasoned romantic comedies are part of the same phenomenon: French films that do moderately well in their own country  critically and commercially  and move on to extraordinary success in the U.S.

title: Mississippi River Crash Hurts
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 8 (AP)  A minor collision of the Mississippi Queen and an oil tanker on the Mississippi River north of New Orleans sent five crewmen from the excursion sternwheeler to the hospital for treatment. The Coast Guard said the Panamanian tanker Spes received a small gash in its bow and leaked oil briefly in the collision yesterday with the Mississippi Queen, which was carrying 500 passengers on a cruise from St. Louis to New Orleans.

title: Indictments Cloud Essex Sheriff Race
description: NEWARK THE arraignment last Thursday of Essex County Sheriff John F. Cryan on Federal charges of conspiracy, extortion and bribery has cast a pall over his chances of reelection to a fourth term in November. It also is causing concern among Democratic Party officials, who are worried that the charges may affect some closely contested State Assembly races.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Little Boys Are Also in Favor of Detente
description: HAVANA  Under attack for his radical handling of last week's meeting of nations that call themselves nonaligned, President Fidel Castro could at least feel satisfied that 22 Latin American regimes sent delegations to the forbidden city of Havana to attend the triennial conterence. Only 14 regional governments have diplomatic relations with Havana, just are full members of the nonaligned movement (another 11 sent observer missions) and perhaps none shares Cuba's proSoviet view of nonalignment.

title: Births
description: BORDEN

title: FILM VIEW
description: There's always at least one junk movie that some us will find irresistible. The first film I saw when returned from vacation was not Breaking Away or Rich Kids or Orchestra Rehearsal Apocalypse Now but The Concorde  Airport 79. I could no more have stayed away from it than I can stop eating red pistachio nuts once I start. I haven't looked at and written about Airport (1969), Airport 1975 (1974) and Airport 77 (1977) to be denied the potential pleasures of the fourth film in the series. I was not one of those pessimists who believed that each one of these pictures was bad that the succeeding picture couldnt be worse  that if everyone buckled down and tried. I was right.

title: Drug Agency Is Investigating Pill Called Lawful, Organic Stimulant
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 9 (AP)  The Food and Drug Administration is investigating the legally available stimulant called Zoom that is causing a sensation among users of drugs.

title: Scotto, Dockworker Leader, Facing Rackets Trial Today
description: Anthony M. Scotto, a top dockunion leader with extensive political power, is scheduled to go on trial in Manhattan today on a Federal racketeering indictment that accuses him of accepting $300,000 in payoffs from waterfront companies.

title: DC10 Lands Safely After Fire
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 9 (UPI) The right engine of a Northwest Airlines DC10 caught fire yesterday on takeoff from Spokane International Airport, but the airplane returned to the field and landed safely. There were no reports of injuries on the flight, which had originated in Seattle and was bound for Minneapolis.

title: Jets Worst Loss: 563 to Patriots
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. 9  Leon Hess, chairman of the board, and Marvin Powell, right offensive tackle, concurred. Both said the Jets played like a high school team today in losing to the New England Patriots, 563.

title: Lou Grant and Taxi Get BestShow Emmys
description: Lou Grant, a television series about life on a bigcity newspaper, and Taxi, a series about a bigcity cab company, were named best television drama and best comedy series last night at the 31st Emmy Awards presentation in Pasadena. Calif.

title: Lois Ann Goodman Bride of Marc Richards
description: Lois Ann Goodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Goodman of White Plains, was married there yesterday to Marc Evan Richards, son of Mrs. Howard Spitz of Eastchester, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in Temple Israel by Rabbi Arnold S. Turetsky, assisted by Cantor Abraham Mizrahi.

title: DANIEL KORNBLUM, LABOR ARBITRATOR
description: Daniel Kornblum, a leading arbitrator who served in the late 1940's and early 50's as New York City's chief labor negotiator and troubleshooter, died Saturday of cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 16625 Powells Cove Boulevard in Beechhurst, Queens.

title: Bomb Found at Exile's Church
description: HIALEAH, Fla., Sept. 9 (UPI)  An unexploded bomb was found early yesterday outside the church where the Rev. Manuel Espinosa, a Cuban exile, is pastor. Mr. Espinosa, a member of the Committee of 75, which has been active in securing the release of Cuban political prisoners, advocates peaceful relations between the United States and Cuba. A caller had told United Press International that an antiCommunist group had planted the explosive outside the Reformed Evangelical Church.

title: Outdoors: As Summer Ends, Good Surf Fishing Begins
description: RESORT owners may deplore the passing of August, but not so the surf fishermen.

title: Tigers Humble Yanks, 31
description: DETROIT, Sept. 9  Sparky Anderson, who has been rebuilding the Detroit Tigers around youngsters since becoming the manager last June, got an encouraging return on his efforts today.

title: McEnroe and Miss Austin Win U.S. Open Titles
description: In the International Year of the Child, youth had the final say at the United States Open tennis championships yesterday with straightset victories by Tracy Austin and John McEnroe.

title: Greek Freighter With Crew of 25 Is Reported in Distress Off Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 (UPI)  A Greek freighter carrying a crew of 25 and laden with phosphate radioed a distress call to the Coast Guard three times today before disappearing in the Pacific 400 miles westsouthwest of San Francisco.

title: PLAN WOULD SHIFT TRANSIT POLICEMEN INTO CITY COMMAND
description: A New York City study on subway crime recommends that the Transit Authority police be placed under the cornmand of the city's Police Department, high criminaljustice officials in the city said yesterday.

title: Rochelle S. Katsh Bride of Physician
description: Rochelle Seena Katsh, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Abraham I. Katsh of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Dr. Mark David Gabry, son of Mrs. Sol Gabry of Brooklyn and the late Mr.

title: Satellite Seeks Uranium In Western River Valley
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI)  Satellite pictures of sagebrush patterns in northeastern Wyoming and southeastern Montana may point to hidden deposits of uranium, the United States Geological Survey reported today.

title: City's Troubled Public Schools Open Today
description: New York City's 947,000 publicschool pupils begin classes today at a time when the school system faces problems some of the city's educators consider staggering.

title: Supplementary OTC Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Los Angeles Issues Health Alerts In Smoggiest Weekend in 5 Years
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 (AP)  This weekend was the smoggiest in five years, and forecasters said today that the smog might continue into tomorrow.

title: C.J. Homer Weds Judith Fabricant
description: Judith Fabricant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Fabricant of Woodburn, Ore., was married yesterday to Charles Jay Homer, son of Dr. and Mrs. LeRoy Homer of Coloria, N.J. Rabbi Arnold Jacob Wolf, Hillel chaplain of Yale University, performed the ceremony at the Homer residence.

title: For Information On School Buses
description: The Board of Education has set up five special telephone numbers for parents needing information about school bus routes and schedules. They are:

title: Bridge:
description: For many years, British publishers, and most notably Faber and Faber, have led the world in the production of bridge books of the highest quality. An addition to their winning string is The Tough Game by Hugh Kelsey, priced at $13.50 and available from Barclay Bridge Supplies, 8 Bush Avenue, Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Allison Captures Capital City Race
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 9 (AP)  Bobby Allison took the lead early and held nearly all the rest of the way today, gaining an easy victory in the Capital City 400 Grand National stock car race.

title: Pastorini Injured in Oilers Loss
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9 (AP)  Dan Pastorini, Houston's quarterback, was sacked five times, intercepted three times and finally knocked out of action with a jammed arm as the Pittsburgh Steelers routed the Oilers today, 387.

title: Sadat Reports Progress In Talks on Palestinians
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI)  President Anwar elSadat said in an interview broadcast today that Egypt and Israel had made progress in talks on Palestinian selfrule and that Jordan and maybe even the Palestine Liberation Organization might join the negotiations by the end of the year.

title: Who's on Third? Everyone
description: Leslie's and Deedee's Lemonade Stand  cup 40 cents, read the handlettered sign at a curb at Third Avenue and 24th Street, midway in the 20block stretch of yesterday's County Fair on the avenue. Also, with your great lemonade, get five comic books for $1.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: First ChineseAmerican Takes Bid Board Seat

title: Strauss Is Optimistic After Briefing by Sadat on His Meeting With Begin
description: CAIRO, Sept. 9  The Carter Administration's special Middle East envoy, Robert S. Strauss, arrived in Cairo today and emerged optimisitic after a briefing by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt on his meeting last week with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel.

title: Ruling Allowing Illegal Searches In Deportation Cases Is Attacked
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9  The American Civil Liberties Union said today that it had asked the Attorney General to overturn a ruling by the Immigration and Naturalization Service approving the use of illegally obtained evidence in deportation cases.

title: Market Place
description: THE action in the shares of Dome Petroleum Ltd. and other companies with interests Canada's Beaufort Sea could be premature, the opinion of some analysts.

title: Chavez 's Farm Workers Union, Once Fighting to Survive, Senses Victory
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9  The United Farm Workers of America, which seemed to be struggling merely to survive a few weeks ago, now appears to be close to winning one of its most important victories since Cesar Chavez began trying to organize the farm workers 19 years ago.

title: No Title
description: Deaths

title: TV: As a Boy Saw Nazis
description: TONIGHT at 8, NBCTV begins a rerun of Holocaust. Ten years of the rise and fall of Nazi Germany are compressed into several melodramatic episodes. The focus is the systematic murder of 6 million Jews.

title: Violinist: Claire Deene
description: CLAIRE DEENE made a gallant gesture on behalf of several senior American composers by devoting her program at Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday afternoon to infrequently performed native works for violin and piano. On the face of it, this would not seem to be a very rich lode of music, but perhaps that is because so few violinists choose to mine it.

title: Indian Jewel Auction Bidding Starts at $25 Million
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 9  There are only eight days left in which to put up the $25.4 milliop deposit that will enable you to bid on 37 pieces of jewelry that belonged to the last Nizam of Hyderabad.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TODAY

title: Washington Watch
description: THE Judiciary Committees in the House and Senate are busy rewriting the nation's criminal law code, and one of the provisions of the measure being discussed in both committees would make it a Federal crime to extend credit at an annual rate exceeding 45 percent.

title: On the Docks, Scotto Is Seen As Victimized
description: At Lento's Restaurant in South Brooklyn, the doors swing open at noon, and the dockworkers who have spent the morning a block away at the 39th Street pier, hoisting containers at the Royal Dutch Steamship Company terminal, come in to wrap their fists around something cool and discuss the major issues of the day.

title: Postscript On the Millenium
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  The outpouring of newsmedia attention to The Woodstock Generation 10 Years After marks the worst outbreak so far of a plague that has been afflicting journalists and pundits for some years Sixtomania.

title: Nina A. Shafiroff Bride Of Dr. Richard H. Cohan
description: Nina Alexandra Shafiroff, a lawyer, was married yesterday in Temple BethEl in Great Neck, L.I., to Dr. Richard Harris Cohan, a resident in internal medicine at the University of Cincinnati Medical Center. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson officiated.

title: East Berlin Honors Nazi Victims
description: EAST BERLIN, Sept. 9 (Reuters) Thousands of people gathered in the center of East Berlin today to honor victims of the Nazis. Speaking on behalf of the East German leadership, Paul Verrier, a member of the Politburo, praised the heroism of resistance fighters and thanked the Soviet army for its sacrifices during World War II.

title: Restraining Suburban Sprawl
description: Earlier this summer, New Haven's Mayor Frank Logue complained to the White House that the Army Corps of Engineers was about to issue a wetlands construction permit for a suburban mall that would lure shoppers away from downtown stores. He and other mayors argued that if President Carter's urban policy means anything, it should deter Federal agencies from actions that undermine urban economies and neighborhoods. The mayors protests have been heard. The Administration is considering a useful requirement that Federal agencies weigh the urban impact of aid to outlying shopping centers.

title: James Robbins Marries Ilene Maslow in Jersey
description: Ilene Lois Maslow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Maslow of South Orange, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to James Robbins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Robbins of Jamaica Estates, Queens. Rabbi Herbert Weiner performed the ceremony at the Greenbrook Country Club in North Caldwell, N.J.

title: The Region
description: Although most residents of the metropolitan area could enjoy yesterday's nearperfect weather, a few thousand residents and dozens of repair crews were still trying to overcome the power losses caused by Tropical Storm David on Thursday.

title: Around the Nation 721 Board Two Lifeboats After Cruise Ship Fire
description: MIAMI, Sept. 9 (AP)  Nearing port after a sevenday Caribbean cruise, 721 vacationers suddenly found themselves aboard lifeboats after flames broke out on a luxury liner. But officials said today that the engineroom fire had produced lots of smoke but no panic.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1979

title: The City
description: Train service in and out of Grand Central Terminal was expected to be normal today following a fire Saturday that forced out several hundred people and damaged 13 railroad cars.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Sports World Specials
description: Jim Russo, Super Scout

title: Camisoles in Silk and Chiffon
description: Camisoles, which started many years ago as frothy little linen or cotton underclothes, have come out of hiding in recent seasons. They go to discothques over skintight pants or to dinner under a suit.

title: The New Spain Will Soon See A Divorce Law
description: MADRID, Sept. 9  Legislators, feminists, churchmen and others have opened a debate here over legislation that soon will remove democratic Spain from the dwindling list of European states  Ireland, Andorra, the Vatican  where divorce is virtually impossible.

title: No Title
description: Deaths

title: Chess:
description: The argument over the respective merits of the knight and bishop is still going on after more than a century.

title: 5,000 in a Casino Take a Gamble, Betting That Fire Alarm Is False
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 9 (UPI)  A fire alarm went off in the Boardwalk HotelCasino, and 5,000 gamblers hardly moved a muscle.

title: Wisconson Democrats Resisting National Party on Closed Primary
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 9 (AP)  Wisconsin Democrats are resisting the national party's demand that it close its April Presidential primary to voters who are not declared Democrats.

title: Heavy Bond Schedule Set for Week
description: The credit markets, which fell sharply last week without much new financing activity to help push prices down, face a large volume of bond offerings this week. And the general presumption is that yields will have to move still higher in order to get investors to buy.

title: Barbiturates and a Suicide Note Found With Jean Seberg's Body
description: PARIS, Sept. 9 (Reuters)  Jean Seberg, the American actress whose body was found last night in a car on a Paris street, left a suicide note complaining of depression, the police said today.

title: Program Is Sharply Reducing Childhood Diseases
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 9 (UPI)  At least 90 percent of the nation's children have been protected against childhood diseases by a sweeping, twoyear immunization program, Federal health figures show.

title: Ford Official May Be Aide to Transportation Chief
description: DETROIT, Sept. 9  Neil E. Goldschmidt, the Transportation Secretarydesignate, has selected William U. Beckham Jr., a Ford Motor Company official, as his deputy, sources close to Mr. Goldschmidt said today.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Commodities
description: AT A.M. every night in Hong Kong, some 200 people gather around a telex machine in the office of Shearson Hayden Stone, the American brokerage firm. Their focus is the movement in gold and silver prices in the United States commodity futures markets. As the prices swing up and down, the early morning traders  local gold bullion dealers, wealthy individuals and small investors  send their orders to be transacted halfway around the world.

title: Iran Says a Key Religious Leader, Ayatollah Taleghani, Dies in Sleep
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Monday, Sept. 10 (UPI)  Ayatollah Mahmoud Taleghani, an Iranian religious leader who was a key figure in the revolution that overthrew the regime of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi this year, died in his sleep early today, according to Pars, the official press agency.

title: More and More, Winning Is Spelled R-E-L-I-E-F
description: RELIEF pitching, says Gabe Paul, the veteran baseball executive, takes a fellow who is absolutely unafraid of the consequences, a fellow who has no fear. Being a little nuts goes along with that.

title: How to Find Energy in the Woodwork
description: The most promising source of energy saving around these days is home insulation. Yet for the typical homeowner bracing for winter, the task of calculating what ought to be done  and then finding someone to do it  is proving immensely frustrating. Therein lies the appeal of a program suggested by New Jersey's Senator Bill Bradley. He thinks he knows a way to promote home energy conservation at no cost to taxpayers or homeowners, and with minimal government interference in the marketplace. It is not certain that his plan is practical. But there is no doubt that the Bradley approach, or something equally clever, is needed to get the job done.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: ABC Is Off and Running In Fall Race for Ratings
description: With the momentum of three years of leadership in audiencepopularity ratings, ABCTV tonight begins its new fall schedule, one that many advertisers and financial analysts believe could be the most successful ever mounted by a network.

title: Dayan's Sessions With P.L.O. Sympathizers May Contain the Seeds of Change for Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 9  It is not merely what people say to each other that is important in Middle East politics, but who talks to whom.

title: Castro Closes Third World Talks With Vow of Restraint as Leader
description: HAVANA, Sept. 9  President Fidel Castro closed a stormy weeklong meeting of third world leaders today with a pledge not to use his new position as coordinator of the 95nation Nonaligned Movement to promote his own political views.

title: Growth of In ven tories Worrying Economists
description: Many economists, recalling how a rapid and surprising accumulation of inventories in 1974 helped push the nation into its worst recession since World War II, are worried again that goods are piling up too quickly in manufacturers warehouses.

title: Letter: On Andrew Young's Resignation
description: In your Aug. 26 editorial charging President Carter with failure to speak out on the donnybrook over Andrew Young's resignation as our Ambassador to the United Nations, you yourself omitted comment upon a central fact in the case. The omission did an injustice to Israel and American Jews, and the failure was typical of the editorial comment in the nation's press.

title: A Fatal Prank on Train to Nowhere
description: Amtrak officials pressed an investigation yesterday into the electrocution of a man and the severe burning of a woman on the roof of a private railroad car in Pennsylvania Station at a party early Saturday.

title: A Family Love Match at U.S. Open
description: John McEnroe Sr. sat hunched over in his frontrow seat, his elbows on his knees and his wife by his side. Vitas Gerulaitis Sr. sat two seats away, his face expressionless and his arms folded across his chest. The tennis match between their firstborn sons was nearly over, with 20yearold John McEnroe Jr. about to win the United States Open championship. Still the two fathers turned toward each other, chatting and laughing.

title: Pleasant Valley Golf
description: SUTTON, Mass., Sept. 9 (AP)  Lou Graham surrendered the lead in the third round this morning, then rebounded with a strong effort during the afternoon for a onestroke victory over Ben Crenshaw in the $250,000 Pleasant Valley golf classic.

title: No Title
description: Deaths

title: No Title
description: Deaths

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Non Carborundum Est
description: FOXBORO,MASS. STEVE GROGAN, a wealthy Kansas wheat farmer, stands 6 feet 4, weighs 208 pounds and has the tender sensibilities of a schoolgirl. Every boo he hears from customers of the New England Patriots wounds him, opprobrium makes him bleed,invective hurled his way leaves bruises. Starting his fifth season as quarterback for the Patriots last Monday night, he threw some poor passes late in the game, and the crowd rode him with roweled spurs when his team lost to the Pittsburgh Steelers in overtime, 1613.

title: 6 Held With 15 Gallons of PCP
description: TUSCON, Ariz., Sept. 9 (AP)  Six men have been arrested in what authorities say could be one of the largest confiscations of the drug PCP ever seized. The authorities said 15 gallons of the liquified drug, or angel dust, was seized in a raid Saturday on a house a few blocks from the Drug Enforcement Administration offices.

title: Sporting Gear
description: For campers who often misplace their flashlights, especially at night, there is one kind that is easy to locate in the dark. RediRay virtually eliminates the problem because of a solid state lightemitting diode implanted in the case, causing a small red light to glow. The light also functions as an indicator for the bulb and battery, shutting off automatically when the power drops too low. The chromeplated flashlight sells for $13 from RediRay, Box 8, Abington, Pa. 19001, (215) 9470304.

title: Arafat Says Mideast Resolution Adopted at Parley Was Enough
description: Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, says it was enough for third world countries to condemn the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty while declining to expel Egypt from the movement.

title: 2,000 CLEVELANDERS MARCH OVER BUSING
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 (AP)  Advocates and opponents of busing alike held rallies simultaneously and peacefully today on a bridge connecting white and black neighborhoods, as Ohio's largest city prepared to begin courtordered busing to integrate public schools.

title: Air Merger Spawns a Shakeout
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 9  The merger of North Central Airlines and Southern Airways into Republic Airlines, which created the nation's 13thlargest airline, has resulted in a shakeout in the combined corporate suite.

title: Mystery of Purple Blobs Solved
description: FRISCO, Tex., Sept. 9 (AP)  Mysterious purple blobs found in this farming community after a meteorite shower turned out to be chemical leftovers from a battery reprocessing plant, Ron Dilulio, an official of the Fort Worth Museum of Science and History, said. The blobs had been turned over to United States space officials to determine whether they had come from outer space.

title: U.S. Plan to Store Oil Is Stalled and Faces Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP)  Unable to buy oil without encouraging new price increases, the Federal program to put a billion barrels of petroleum into emergency storage is stalled and may soon be curtailed, according to analysts close to the program.

title: Parley on Rhodesia Opens Today; Participants in London Unyielding
description: LONDON, Sept. 9  Delegates to a constitutional conference on Zimbabwe Rhodesia, widely regarded as the last chance to achieve a peaceful solution to the 14yearold crisis in southern Africa, issued uncompromising statements as they arrived in London this weekend.

title: Astros Triumph And Regain Lead
description: For the second time in less than 24 hours, the leaders in the National League West exchanged positions. The Houston Astros regained the top spot yesterday by turning back the San Francisco Giants, 41, in Houston, before the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Reds in Cincinnati. 31.

title: One to Go for Yastrzemski
description: BOSTON, Sept. 9 (UPI)  Carl Yastrzemski today moved within one hit of becoming the first American League player to get 3,000 hits, including 400 home runs. But his eighthinning single was the only consolation for the Boston Red Sox, who absorbed a 164 trouncing from the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Home Purchases By State Sought Near Love Canal
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 9  One year after the state moved 239 families from the Love Canal neighborhood and bought their homes, some of the 550 families that were left behind have begun trying to force the state to do the same for them.

title: Lyle Is Golf Victor
description: TURNBERRY, Scotland, Sept. 9 (UPI)  Sandy Lyle of Britain birdied six of the first seven holes and shot a final round of 65 in brilliant sunshine today to win the European golf championship by seven strokes. Dale Hayes of South Africa and Peter Townsend of Britain tied for second.

title: Carter Deplores Violence In the Name of Religions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI)  President Carter told his Bible class today that Christians and Moslems were still taking up the sword in the name of God but obviously not with God's annroval.

title: Federal Grants Aiding Affluent Stirring Debate
description: Key West is a place that some people remember as a Presidential sanctuary before Presidents went to fish near Plains, ski in Vail or ride golf carts in San Clemente. Harry S. Truman went there to wear loud shirts and to play poker with Urban Affairs his friends. The other image, of.course, is Hemingway's  Key West, the place to drink and have good talk between bouts with the big fish.

title: Chargers Fouts Stops Raiders
description: Dan Fouts is on a winning streak nine games worth.

title: Chile 6 Years After Coup: More Goods but Fewer Jobs
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 9  The Chile shaped by six years of military rule under President Augusto Pinochet presents glaring contrasts between lively middleclass consumerism and the privations of workers driven by high unemployment to accept subsistence wages.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TERPSICHORE'S TURF It seems as if more people dance onstage in New York City than live in, say, Council Grove, Kan.  population: about 2,300. This week, for example, in Rockefeller Center at the lower plaza of the McGrawHill building, a different dance group will be presented outdoors every day.

title: Lincoln Barnett, ExEditor of Life
description: Lincoln K. Barnett, a former editor of Life magazine and the author of a number of books, including The Universe and Dr. Einstein, died Saturday in Champlain Valley Physicians Hospital in Plattsburgh, N.Y. Mr. Barnett, who lived in Westport, N.Y., was 70 years old.

title: Libertarians, Foes of Big Government, Nominate coast Lawyer for President
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9  Aiming at the disenchanted, the Libertarian Party chose Ed Clark, an oil company lawyer, last night to run for President in what spokesmen depicted as the 8yearold party's most auspicious campaign.

title: Notes on People
description: When the fall semester begins Wednesday at Williams College, the student body will include 19yearold Rhca Pahlevi, who may be better known as the Crown Prince of Iran and the eldest son of the exiled Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and Empress Farah.

title: Miss Little Triumphs
description: DENVER, Sept. 9 (AP)  Sally Little, enjoying her best season on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, carded a par 72 today and posted a twostroke victory in the $100,000 Columbia Savings Classic.

title: Land Speed Mark at 638.637
description: BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 9 (UPI)  Stan Barrett, a Hollywood stunt man, drove a 48,000horsepower rocket car to a world landspeed record of 638.637 miles per hour today and then decided that Utah's salt flats were too rough for an attempt to exceed the speed of sound.

title: On a Highway in Arizona, the Mile Makes Way for Metric Standard
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Sept. 9  More than one unwitting motorist has doubtless remarked that the trip from Tucson to the Mexican border was going much more quickly than expected, not to mention that his car's gasoline consumption seemed to have improved dramatically. As the mystery deepens, a sign flashes past: This highway signed in metric.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Pacific Bell Delays Sale
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 (Reuters)  The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company said that directors had delayed the sale of $10 million of its common shares, originally scheduled for later this year, on the advice of the lead underwriter, Morgan Stanley & Company. The company's shares were trading last week at the year's low of $14, compared with the high for the year of $16.125

title: 6 West Germans Slain Near Afghan Capital
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 9 (AP) Six West Germans were shot and killed by unknown assailants, probably bandits or Moslem rebels, a West German Embassy spokesman said today.

title: Schlitz Clings to Its Heritage
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 9  For years, the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company has proudly proclaimed its product as the beer :hat made Milwaukee famous. Today, that strong identification with the city, and the local attachments of Schlitz's owning family, represent a major management headache.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  Philip Heymann, Chief of the Criminal Division of the Department of Justice  who boasts of his experience as a special prosecutor investigating Republicans  has been leading the Carter Administration fight to prevent the appointment of special prosecutors to investigate Democrats.

title: No Title
description: Deaths

title: World's Trade Rose in 1978
description: GENEVA, Sept. 9 (Reuters)  World trade grew faster last year than in 1977, outpacing world production and amounting to about $1,300 billion, the leading agency monitoring international commerce said in a report scheduled to be released tomorrow.

title: Carter Denies Kennedy Asked Him to Quit Race
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI)  President Carter today denied a published report that Senator Edward M. Kennedy had asked him to pull out of the 1980 Presidential race.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 9 (Reuters)  Tugboat operators interrupted their 17dayold strike today to assist a British gas tanker that ran aground in the port of Rotterdam.

title: Herrmann, Steele Set Records in Openers
description: One quick way to make a name in sports is to break a record set by a famous athlete, and the older the record the better. Thus Joe Steele of Washington and Mark Herrmann of Purdue enhanced their reputations Saturday as Steele snapped a 28-year-old rushing mark set by Hugh McElhenny and Herrmann broke a 13-year-old record set by Bob Griese.

title: Exxon's Takeover Bid For Reliance Electric
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 On May 18, Californians fumed in gas lines and New Yorkers were introduced to dollaragallon gasoline. The preceding month President Carter had demanded that oil companies not use their money to buy such things as department stores and hotels, and on that day in May a handful of senators were busy preparing a bill to insure that the oil companies didn't.

title: Ballet: John da Menendez Makes Her Swan Debut
description: THE swans gathered at Swan Lake over the weekend at the Metropolitan Opera House and ballet fans flocked to see them. At American Ballet Theater's first two performances of the Tchaikovsky classic this season, the swans had twoqueens. Saturday night's performance starred Cynthia Gregory, one of the company's most acclaimed Swan Queens. Yesterday afternoon, Jolinda Menendez made her New York debut in the dual role of OdetteOdile.

title: NO WORD ON SINDONA ON EVE OF HIS TRIAL
description: In the five weeks since he disappeared on Fifth Avenue, the Italian financier Michele Sindona has written more than a score of letters to his family, the last arriving Aug. 27 in a packet of 14 notes, according to law enforcement officials on the case.

title: Cecotto, on Yamaha, Thrills Dutch Fans
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, Sept. 9 (AP)  Boet van Dulmen of the Netherlands won the 750c.c. motorcycle race in this northeastern Dutch town today, but Johnny Cecotto of Venezuela, who finished fourth in the overall standing, stole the show with feats of spectacular riding.

title: BROYN OPENS DRIVE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: NASHUA, N.H., Sept. 9  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California began his New Hampshire primary campaign today by calling for a Government that puts the people ahead of profits, the domestic economy ahead of multinationals and puts peace ahead of the Cold War.

title: Ungentle Rain That Droppeth
description: OTTAWA  Man's inability to pre serve nature is dramatized by the recent disclosures about acid rains. The result of sulphur oxides and nitrogen oxides spewed from great furnaces, these rains have destroyed aquatic lite in almost 200 Ontario lakes and probably have damaged as many elsewhere, from the United States Midwest to Maine and Nova Scotia. The findings frighteningly suggest a chemicalindustrial complex not yet, but potentially, out of control.

title: Across the South, Hunting for Doves Is a Social and Political Ritual for Fall
description: CARTERSVILLE, Ga.  Joe Bishop had everything a dove hunter needs on opening day: a canebottom rocker, a front porch overlooking Glenn Taylor's dove fields, a small boy to fetch the birds he hit and a sense of humor about the ones he missed.

title: Bid Heads Home, Position Enhanced
description: With commandolike clockwork, Spectacular Bid slipped out of town before dawn yesterday after ambushing thoroughbred racing's strongest field of the year Saturday in the $300,000 Marlboro Cup Handicap. He left for Delaware Park at 5 A.M.

title: Iraqi Oil Threat Reported
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 9 (UPI) The Middle East Economic Survey reported today that Iraq might cut off supplies of crude oil to multinational oil companies that do not comply with its boycott of Israel, Egypt, Rhodesia and South Africa.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Stopping Secret Trials
description: BOSTON, Sept. 9  When members of the Supreme Court disagree publicly about the meaning of a decision they have just handed down, something is not right. That is what has happened since the Court's July decision in the Gannett case, which upheld a New York judge's order excluding the public and the press from a criminal pretrial hearing.

title: Open Winners
description: Men's Singles  John McEnroe, U.S.; runnerup, Vitas Gerulaitis, U.S.

title: Marcia Ostrow Wed to Analyst
description: Marcia Ostrow, widow of Theodore Ostrow, who was a State Supreme Court Justice, was married yesterday at her Manhattan apartment to Dr. Abraham Pinsky, a Brooklyn psychoanalyst. State Supreme Court Justice Murray T. Feiden performed the ceremony. The bride, daughter of Mrs. Irving Kerr and the late Mr. Kerr, is a former merchandise consultant for Cluett Peabody & Jacobson stores. Dr. Pinsky's first wife died. He is a son of Mrs. Benjamin Pinsky of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Pinsky.

title: Gary Floam Weds Dr. Kathy Lesser
