description: Dr. Kathy Lesser, daughter of Dr. Ruth and Dr. Gerson Lesser of New York and Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Gary Charles Floam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Floam of Baltimore. The ceremony was performed at the Westport home of the bride's parents by Rabbi M. I. Hecht of New Haven.

title: Tight Oil Market Easing, Study Says
description: The worldwide shortage of oil has begun to recede, according to a report by the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, a group of oil economists.

title: Patricia Jean MacDonald Is Married to Leslie A. Fieger
description: Patricia Jean MacDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James G. MacDonald of Westport, Conn., was married in the Saugatuck Congregational Church there yesterday to Leslie Alexander Fieger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aloise Fieger of Calgary, Alberta. The Rev. Theodore Hoskins performed the ceremony.

title: McGill University in Montreal Confronts a Dual Challenge
description: MONTREAL  The old college chant began: What's the matter with Old McGill? And the answer bounced back: She's all right, oh yes, you bet.

title: Pirate Rally Tops Mets, 65
description: For a change, they played only nine innings of baseball yesterday at Shea Stadium instead of the 29 of the two previous days. But even in regulation time, the New York Mets squandered a threerun lead in the late innings as the Pittsburgh Pirates rallied for a 65 victory that kept them in first place by one game over Montreal in the National League East.

title: 8 Held in AntiAbortion Protest
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (UPI)  Eighty members of an antiabortion group were arrested yesterday at a protest outside an abortion clinic. Six men and two women were charged with disorderly conduct. They were among 50 demonstrators who blocked the entrance of the Concord Medical Center, the authorities said.

title: Rate Rise Prompts Credit Fear
description: Shortterm interest rates, which hit their highest levels in financial history last week, are headed still higher. And for the first time in the current upswing in rates, borrowers are beginning to worry that money may not be available  no matter how high rates go.

title: Joan B. Morse Is the Bride of Prof. Donald E. Gordon
description: Joan B. Morse, widow of Arthur D. Morse, was married yesterday to Donald E. Gordon, professor of art history at the University of Pittsburgh. The ceremony was performed in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., at the home of the bridegroom's sister, Mrs. Maurice J. Cohn, by Rabbi Jack Stern of Scarsdale, N.Y. The bride and bridegroom's children, Ann B. Morse and Jonathan Fuzzbee Morse, and Richard E. Gordon and Thomas H. Gordon took part in the service.

title: Excerpts From Final Declaration of Third World Parley in Havana
description: HAVANA, Sept. 9 (Reuters)  Following are excerpts from the official English text of a declaration approved by delegates at the conference of nations professing nonalignment:

title: Sports Briefs
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Sept. 9 (AP) Pole Position, carrying the top weight, led from start to finish in a powerful performance over a sloppy track today and won the 34th British Columbia Derby, for 3yearolds, at Exhibition Park.

title: No Title
description: World News Briefs

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: With shortterm Interest rates headed even higher, according to monetary specialists interviewed in the wake of the record prime rate of 12 3/4 percent set last week, borrowers are beginning to worry whether enough money will be available. [Page D1.]

title: Moscow Hails Results Of Cuban Conference
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 9 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union greeted the results of the conference of third world nations in Havana today as a successful reaffirmation of what it called the countries antiimperialist character.

title: Reporter's Notebook: To Many, Dalai Lama's Visit Is Dream Come True
description: WASHINGTON, N.J., Sept. 9 This is a onceinalifetime day, Giga Andreyev, a MongolianAmerican Buddhist, said today as 2,000 people attended a service led by the Dalai Lama himself.

title: Russians Maintain World Games Lead
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 9 (AP) Vadim Borissov of the Soviet Union won two tennis gold medals, Britain picked up four medals and the United States scored in track and field today on the busiest day of the 10th World University Games.

title: World Driving Title to Scheckter
description: MONZA, Italy, Sept. 9  Jody Scheckter of South Africa clinched the world drivers championship today when he drove his Ferrari to victory in the Italian Grand Prix, gaining a points total in the Formula One standing that none of his rivals can match in the two races remaining in the 1979 season.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 6, 29, 17, 30, 8 and 39. The supplementary number was 31.

title: F. C. C. and LaissezFaire Broadcasting Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9  The Federal Communications Commission formally proposed last week to free the radio industry of significant control by the Government, but a number of issues divide the commissioners and must be resolved

title: Smoky Warehouse Fire Burns Out of Control
description: A four alarm fire in an abandoned warehouse next to the West Side Highway burned out of control for several hours last night and early this morning, closing the highway and sending out clouds of thick black smoke that was reported many blocks to the north and on the East Side.

title: Books of The Times
description: SAY this for what Alan Saperstein achieves in his unusual first novel, Mom Kllls Kids and Self: He never stoops to the sensationalism of his tabloid title. No,

title: Chicago Police Corruption Cost Put at $10 Million Over 5 Years
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP)  Theft and mismanagement in the Chicago Police Department has cost at least $10 million over the last five years, according to acting Police Superintendent Jospeh DiLeonardi.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Why did you give the onbase total leaders and not the onbase average leaders in a recent baseball answer? Also, is the total figure of 5,179 for Ty Cobb correct, since The Baseball Encylopedia shows he had 4,191 hits and 1,249 walks for a total of 5,440?

title: N.A.A.C.P. IS SEEKING FOREIGN POLICY ROLE
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is planning a series of steps intended to increase the influence of American blacks on world affairs, officials of the organization said yesterday.

title: Roy E. Larsen, 80, Key Executive At Time Inc. for 56 Years, Is Dead
description: Roy E. Larsen, vice president of Time Inc. for 21 years and one of the most influential figures in the golden age of the company's empire, died at his home in Fairfield, Conn., yesterday. He was 80 years old and had retired in April.

title: Advertising
description: COMPANIES in the transmission business, by and large, have not enjoyed the most glimmering image. Motorists think of autoparts people and daggers form in their eyes. More often than not, when they pull in to have their cars repaired, they figure they're about to eet taken for a ride.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED T0 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS, UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION, IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY, NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3484767.

title: New York Area Primary Races
description: Following are the candidates in the major contests for Democratic, Republican and Conservative Party nominations for public office in the primary elections tomorrow in the New York metropolitan area. Unopposed candidates are not listed. Asterisks denote incumbents.

title: Judgeship Races In the City Liven Primary Election
description: Renee R. Roth, a resident of Manhattan's West Side, is running for Civil Court in Brooklyn, and like other judicial candidates and the candidates for Bronx Borough President in tomorrow's primary, she spent yesterday shaking hands and handing out shopping bags, copies of endorsements and other campaign literature.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 9 (Reuters) Tugboat operators interrupted their 17-day-old strike today to assist a British gas tanker that ran aground in the port of Rotterdam.

title: City Police Officer Is Shot to Death After Chase Near Harlem River Dr.
description: A New York City police officer was killed and his partner wounded yesterday in an exchange of gunfire with a man who had crashed his car into a concrete retaining wall after a chase on an approach to the Harlem River Drive in upper Manhattan.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Autonumberic Inc. has elected to its board Stephen B. Weissman, vice president of Weissman & Weissman Inc., insurance brokers and adjusters, and Lawrence Miller, president of National Dye Works Inc.

title: Oil Parley Meets
description: VIENNA, Sept. 9 (Reuters)  The 10th World Petroleum Congress, bringing together 5,000 technical experts from 70 countries for an exchange of ideas on oil extraction and processing, opened in Bucharest, Rumania, today.

title: Native Courier Wins
description: Native Courier, a 4yearold chestnut gelding owned by Stephen C. Clark Jr., scored a frontrunning victory in the $57,400 Brighton Beach Handicap yesterday at Belmont. The $5.20-for-$2 winner nmsnea the mile-ana-a-quarter race four lengths ahead of secondplace Fluorescent Light. Tiller took third in the field of eight.

title: Linda Gilbert Wed To Peter B. Cooper
description: Linda J. Gilbert, a public relations supervisor for the I.T.T. Continental Baking Company in Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Bradford Cooper, an accountant in Stamford, Conn. The ceremony was performed in Ossining, N.Y., at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Phil E. Gilbert Jr., by Village Justice Arthur Sullivan of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Shostakovich Memoir, Smuggled Out, Is Due
description: While Soviet officials are confiscating dozens of works from American publishing houses that were brought into the Moscow Book Fair, a manuscript that originated in Russia but was never published there is about to come out in the United States

title: CHURCH SAYS SOVIET TESTS U.S. RESOLVE ON TROOPS IN CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9  Senator Frank Church, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said today that an insufficient Administration response to the presence of Soviet combat troops in Cuba would invite further adventurism by the Soviet Union in Latin America and other areas.

title: St. Louis Fed Money Figures
description: The monetary base of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis averaged $150.6 billion in the week ended last Wednesday, up from $150.3 billion a week earlier, the bank reported Friday. The figure was unavailable late Thursday afternoon, the time it is usually released.

title: CORRECTION
description: A United Press International dispatch carried in The Times on Aug. 19 incorrectly stated the results of a test involving the Federal Government's Calspan safety research vehicle. The test showed that frontseat riders in the research vehicle would survive if the car were in a headon crash at 40 miles an hour.

title: Sorrow, Anger, Pride Vented as Policemen Mourn for Colleague
description: Officially, the 400 officers in New York City's three highway units, traveling by motorcycle or by patrol car, are responsible for enforcing traffic regulations on the major roads in their area. But an officer's routine duties sometimes lead him to unexpected danger, and yesterday, for the first time in 30 years, they led an officer to death in a gunfight.

title: HolidayHarrah Merger Advances
description: The directors of Holiday Inns Inc., the motel chain, and Harrah's, operator of Nevada casino hotels, yesterday approved a merger plan formalizing an agreement reached last week. The transaction, involving cash and stock valued at $300 million, is still subject to shareholder approval, Federal tax rulings and clearance by Nevada gaming authorities.

title: Concert to Save Mansion Brings Sharps and Flats
description: LONDON, Sept. 9  Delegates to a constitutional conference on Zimbabwe Rhodesia, widely regarded as the last chance to achieve a peaceful solution to the 14yearold crisis in southern Africa, issued uncompromising statements as they arrived in London this weekend.

title: Virginia Bateson Is Wed To Adams H. Nickerson
description: Virginia Moffat Bateson of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., widow of E. Farrar Bateson, was married there yesterday to Adams H. Nickerson of New York, president of the Adams H. Nickerson Corporation and the Estate of Eugene A. Hoffman Inc., both realestate concerns. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Phenomenon of the Superstar Who Draws SupraAdulation
description: THE hero of Frederick Exley's novgl is talking about Frank Gifford, the former New York Giants football player. But the phenomenon of certain public figures evoking extraordinary adulation from their fans crosses over into entertainment, politics and indeed all forms of

title: White Clubs and Black Robes
description: Is membership in a whiteonly social club compatible with service on the Federal bench? The Senate Judiciary Committee must come to grips with that question Tuesday when it is scheduled to decide whether to approve the nomination of Bailey Brown, a wellregarded Federal District judge in Memphis, for promotion to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

title: Knickerbocker Greys Are Marching Into a Far Less Exclusive Present
description: They still wear the plumes  red, white or blue, depending on rank  but the question is, do they have the same panache? To this day, a member must be at least four feet tall, 7 years old and the son of parents who don't flinch at seeing their son bear arms  but blue blood is no longer a requirement.

title: Giants Falter in 2d Half, Lose, 2714
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 9 This time the Giants forgot to play in the second half. This time they did not even reach 17 points. This time, having taken a 190 lead in the first five minutes of the game, they wound up losing, 2714, to the St. Louis Cardinals in their home opening before 71,370 restless, booing fans. This time, like last time, they were chewed out by Coach Ray Perkins.

title: Dance: Stornant's Work
description: THERE'S something atmospheric about a man standing at ease, arms outstretched, quietly chanting vowels to droning string music while four women crouch behind him in halflight. A grounded. stretching solo for a woman typing on an imaginary machine and a quick crawl to syrupy music are eyecatching. But in between those images, Vic Stornant had little to show in a concert of his work, performed Saturday by the fivemember Vic Stornant Dance Theater at the American Theater Laboratory.

title: Estonia Reports a Tornado
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 10 (UPI)  A tornado swept through the town of Jarlepa, near Tallinn in Estonia, ripping the roof off warehouse and carrying it 150 yards, the press agency Tess reported today. Such a whirlwind is an unusual phenomenon in the region. No casualties were reported.

title: Why Kids Can Reach the Top in Tennis
description: They have turned tennis into child's play. At 20 years old, curlyhaired John McEnroe is the youngest national men's champion since Richard (Pancho) Gonzales in 1948; at 16 years old, blonde Tracy Austin is the youngest national women's champion ever. And neither one because of a fluke in the draw. John McEnroe dethroned Jimmy Connors, a threetime champion in the tournament that Bjorn Borg has never won, in straight sets in the semifinals. Tracy Austin dethroned Chris Evert Lloyd, the champion the previous four years, in straight sets in the final, after having eliminated Martina Navratilova, the ruling Wimbledon queen, in straight sets in the semifinals. John McEnroe and Tracy Austin are here to stay as champions. What they accomplished in the last major tournament of 1979 is only a foreshadowing of how they will dominate the 1980's. But perhaps sooner than they realize, their reigns will be threatened not so much by their contemporaries as by youngsters somewhere out there coming up behind them. More than most sports, tennis is a game that can be played on a championship level by precocious moppets.

title: Chrysler Plan Seems Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  The Chrysler Corporation has apparently been delayed in its plan to submit to the Carter Administration a comprehensive plan for the troubled company's fiscal rehabilitation.

title: Advertising
description: DURING an interview a couple of years ago, Seth H. Baker, the former broker who had been named president of the newly formed ABC Publishing, talked about the commitment to growth through acquisition of publications or by starting new ones.

title: School Teaches Sherpas Mountaineering Skills
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  The Sherpas of Nepal, who have long risked their lives accompanying more skilled foreign mountaineers on Himalayan peaks, now have a mountaineering school to teach them the latest climbing skills.

title: Jazz: Young Saxophonist
description: THE late Lennie Tristano used to insist that his jazz students listen carefully to recorded works of certain masters. Lester Young, the tenor saxophonist, was one of his favorite musicians, so it's hardly surprising that the saxophonists who have come out of the Tristano school, Lee Konitz and Warne Marsh being the most celebrated, retain a decided Young orientation.

title: Carter Sends Puerto Rico's National Guard to Help in Dominican Relief
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 10  President Carter today authorized up to 100 National Guard troops from Puerto Rico to join almost 200 American soldiers already providing disaster relief here after Hurriance David.

title: KOCH UNIFIES POLICE OF 3 FORCES TO STOP SUBWAY CRIME WAVE
description: Mayor Koch yesterday put the Transit and Housing Authority police forces under the command of the Police Department and said he hoped it would strengthen law enforcement against the lawless element that preys upon our citizens.

title: New CETA Aid for Business
description: PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 7  When the Henry L. Hanson Company opens its new tool and die plant in this coastal city in November, Ernest Murray, husky 21yearold, will be operating one of the machines. He is one of 18 men and women now being trained in a cinderblock shed to run the machinery before the plant's opening.

title: Charges Revised For Scotto Trial, Postponing Start
description: Federal prosecutors filed a revised indictment yesterday in the racketeering case of Anthony M. Scotto, a major dockunion leader, causing a oneday postponement of the scheduled opening of the trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Anna Hamlet, 81, Dies; Active in Civic Groups
description: Anna S. Hamlet, active for many years in civic and welfare organizations in Westchester and Dutchess Counties, died Friday at her home in Quaker Hill in Pawling. N.Y. She was 81 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Known as a pioneer in the Pop Art movement, Roy Lichtenstein is famous for his canvases that appear to be huge blowups of cartoon comic strips.

title: Pravda Cites Threat to Cuba
description: MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 11  The Pravda editorial denying the presence of Soviet combat troops in Cuba said those who started up the loud campaign in Washington did so to undermine Cuba's prestige among thirdworld nations. It said that those who exploited the outcry sought to prevent Senate ratification of the strategic arms treaty.

title: Hong Kong Gold Market Strictly a Man's Domain
description: HONG KONG, Sept.10 (AP) At the Hong Kong gold exchange, where an average of one million ounces of pure glitter is bought and sold daily, women are banned from the trading floor and men without ties generally pad about in rubbersoled shoes.

title: First Phase of CourtOrdered Busing in Cleveland Begins Peacefully
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 10  Fears of violence and promises of a widespread white boycott evaporated here this morning as the buses began to roll in Cleveland's longdelayed courtordered desegregation program with a little confusion but no untoward incidents.

title: Jail Sentence for Knight Imposed, Warrant Issued
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 10 (AP) Bobby Knight, the basketball coach at Indiana University, was sentenced today to six months in jail in Puerto Rico for a fight with a police officer during the Pan American Games. Knight was not present, and Judge Rurico Rivera of the San Juan District Court issued an arrest warrant.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Lazard Prospers on Plan Bequeathed by Meyer
description: Lazard Freres, the investment banking firm that Andr Meyer presided over for three decades and built to preeminence on Wall Street, is expected to stay on the path he established, a path that is leading to handsome dividends.

title: Senate Panel Is Told of Dangers of Valium Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP)  A psychiatrist who has treated celebrities for alcohol and drug abuse told a Senate health subcommittee today that Valium, the most widely used drug in the United States, was addictive and that doctors should not prescribe it for everyday stress.

title: Graphnet Accord Set With I.T.T.
description: The Graphic Scanning Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed a contract with I.T.T. World Communications joining I.T.T's international Telex system with Graphic Scanning's domestic communications network.

title: It's a Bird! A Plane? Superman?
description: GLENDALE, N.Y.  As the search for energyefficient forms of transportation continues, it's time to reassess a type of longdistance transport that held great promise until a world war, cheap oil and other factors caused its death over 40 years ago. It's time to bring back the zeppelin. The zeppelin, or rigid airship as it's technically known, is the perfect cargo carrier for these oilscarce times. Unlike airplanes, which must fight against gravity and wind resistance to remain aloft, an airship is designed to work with the environment. Instead of burning precious jet fuel in a vain attempt to battle nature, a zeppelin, using lighterthanair helium, floats gently in the needing only a few modest propellers to power its journey. However, since trucks, not airplanes, carry most of the nation's goods, zeppelins would have to be competitive with interstate trucking to be a real transportation alternative. To this end, even by using 30yearold technology, we could construct a line of 1,300footlong zeppelins capable of carrying over 500 tons of cargo between New York and Los Angeles in 36 hours. That's at least two to three days faster than by truck. While they were shaving days from shipping time, such zeppelins would also save fuel. For instance, the four 1,800horsepower engines that would be needed to propel a large airship would consume at least 35 percent less diesel fuel than the equivalent number of trucks that would be necessary to transport the same goods. But airships don't have to compete against trucks; they can work with them. Just as container ships have replaced traditional ocean freighters, zeppelins could be built to carry containerized cargo across the land. Trucks could then be used, as they are bestsuited, for the short trips between airports, distribution markets and local merchants. In the past, the major drawback to building a zeppelin fleet was the initial design and construction costs. Until the recent oilprice increases, the amount of fuel that airplanes and trucks wasted was inconsequential when compared to the cost of building zeppelins. It was for this reason that in the late 1940's Goodyear scrapped its plans for a freight and passenger airship line. Now, however, with oil many times its 1940's price, an airship's fuel savings would more than set its construction costs. Besides cost, the only other hindrance to a renewed zeppelin program is zepplins allegedly poor safety record. But when one considers how safe airplanes were in the 1930's (when zeppelins last flew), one can see that this is really a nonargument. At rate, the public's perception of the zeppelin as a flammable deathtrap is based on the fact that the old zeppelins carried hydrogen to provide lift. Today, nonflammable helium will give almost the same lift potential, without hydrogen's inherent danger. Another advantage modern zeppelins would have over their ancestors is advanced navigational and safety equip

title: Entertainment Events
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA.. Puccini's Tonca, New York State Theater, 8

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A dense band of clouds is apparent from the lake region through the Northern Plains States to the northern Rockies. Thunderstorms extend from Florida Into the Gulf of Mexico. Tropical Storm Frederic is northeast of the South Atlantic States.

title: Drought in Western Indian State Said to Affect 10 Million People
description: NEW DELHI, Sept, 10 (Reuters) About 10 million people have been affected by a drought in the state of Rajasthan in western India, a Government spokesman said yesterday in the state capital of Jaipur.

title: Iranians Take to Streets to Mourn Ayatollah Taleghani, a Key Leader
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 10 (Reuters) Huge crowds poured into the streets of Teheran today for the burial of Ayatollah Mahmoud Taleghani, the Moslem spiritual leader of Teheran who died early this morning at the age of 68.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Anders Kallur, a 27yearold right wing who was the most valuable player in Sweden last season, was among 26 prospects yesterday at Cantiague Park in Hicksville, L.I., as the New York Islanders opened their rookie camp under Coach Al Arbour.

title: A Vietnamese Refugee's Story: War Hero to Unwanted Alien
description: YUANJIANG, China, Sept. 5 Hoang Quoc Bao's family had lived in Vietnam for four generations, long enough for him to consider himself to be Vietnamese even though his ancestors came from China.

title: TV: Life Of Prinze On CBS
description: FREDDIE PRINZE bopped his way into show business as a standup comic, drawing heavily on his experiences as a part Puerto Rican growing up in New York City. In 1979, he became a national personality portraying a sassily spirited Chicano in the sitcorn Chico and the Man.

title: College Entrance Truth in Testing Effort Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  A spokesman for the American College Testing Program told a Congressional subcommittee today that publishers of college and graduate school admissions tests were becoming the scapegoat for the failure of American society to assure equal educational opportunity for all of our peoples.

title: Steel Making Off in Week
description: Production of steel fell to 2.46 million tons last week, a decrease of 4.5 percent from the preceding week's 2.58 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Morgan Raises Rate To Brokers
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company yesterday raised the interest rate it charges brokers to finance their customers' margin accounts by a half percentage point to 12 percent.

title: Begin Derides Arafat Comment
description: Minister Menachem Begin today scoffed at comments by Yasir Arafat, the head of the P.L.O., who told an American television interviewer Sunday he did not remember if the P.L.O. charter called for the elimination of Israel. Mr. Begin

title: Chief Is Ousted From Academy At Kings Point
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., Sept. 10  The superintendent of the United States Merchant Marine Academy was suddenly dismissed today. Although no official reasons were given for his ouster, the unofficial ones included a quarrel over the future direction of the academy, partisan politics and his handling of the dismissal of the football coach.

title: Books: Incest, a Topic Finally Open to Discussion
description: IN this era of sexual permissiveness, rampant pornography and freewheeling discussions and displays of every conceivable form of sexual interaction, incest is finally coming out of the closet. It still has a very long way to go, and it may never reach the point of the present openness surrounding, say, homosexuality, in which many practitioners readily and proudly admit to their inclinations. But as this book and a number of others like it indicate, incest is at least now a subject for upfront discussion and legitimate research.

title: Cleanup Begins After Derailing
description: JOAQUIN, Tex., Sept. 10 (AP) Flames from a burning train wreck near this eastern Texas community subsided enough today to enable workers to begin cleanup operations, the Shelby County sheriff's department said. A dispatcher said about 200 people who were evacuated when the 53car Southern Pacific train derailed last Saturday had been allowed to return to their homes, but U.S. 84 leading into Louisiana remained closed. Five persons were hurt, none seriously, in the derailment, six miles from Joaquin.

title: Unity in City Police Forces an Elusive Goal
description: They are police officers in the same city, they wear almost identical blue uniforms and they get virtually the same pay. But despite their supposedly similar objectives of fighting crime, the New York City Police Department and the city's two smaller police agencies, the Transit Authority and Housing Authority forces, have rarely worked together in a coordinated manner.

title: San Francisco Leaves Its Heart at the Opera
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10  The annual opera season began here last weekend as this city, along with scores of visitors from New York and Europe, focused with unabashed affection on the San Francisco Opera.

title: The City
description: Maria Petra Ramsay, who was convicted last January of conspiring to kidnap her wealthy former husband, has been sentenced to five years probation on the condition that she stay away from him and also submit to psychiatric therapy.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSAnabel on September 9. Devoted mother of Ariyne Myer and Arnold Abrams, beloved sister of Irving and Norman Satin, adored grandmother of Jarrett, Tracy, Sacha and Sierra. Service at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Calvary Hospital, , 174070 Eastchester Road, Bronx, N.Y.

title: Prosecutor and Investigator Clash in Court On Case Involving Berkowitz Photographs
description: A former investigator for the New York State special prosecutor's office and a current assistant prosecutor clashed in court yesterday over whether the office had sufficiently pursued evidence that might have linked The New York Post to an alleged bribery scheme.

title: A Man Ready For Inspection
description: There was something about James B. Meehan as he stood in the Blue Room at City Hall yesterday that seemed more emblematic of the New York City Police Department than the official seal he wore on his tie clip. It

title: Talks to Study Grain Hauling
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) The White House said today that a Cabinetlevel meeting would be held this week to consider ways to transport grain in the face of a shortage of railroad capacity in the Middle West.

title: Hartford, Facing Many Problems, Awaits Carter
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 10  When President Carter arrives here on Wednesday to talk about health insurance, hospital costs and energy at the annual convention of the American Association of Retired Persons, he will find a city where most residents would be willing to give him a cordial reception, if not for all the other things on their minds.

title: BUSINESS
description: Britain's MG sports car has lost the race for survival. Stateowned BL Ltd., which also plans to close all or parts of 13 plants and lay off 25,000 workers, said that 70 percent of the MG's market was among American sports car aficionados. But with the slumping value of the dollar against the pound, the financially distressed company will discontinue both its B and Midget models. [Page A1.]

title: Court of Appeals Refuses to Bar Public From HBomb Hearings
description: A Federal appeals court in Chicago yesterday denied a Government motion that the public be barred from hearings on the efforts of The Progressive magazine to publish an article on the hydrogen bomb.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, Sept. 10, 1979

title: 400 Young Chinese Demonstrate Over the Right to Go to College
description: PEKING, Sept. 10 (AP)  Raising their fists and shouting, We want to go to school, 400 young people marched down Peking's main street today demanding the right to a university education.

title: I.R.S. and Couple Waging Tax Divorce Test Case
description: ELLICOTT CITY, Md., Sept. 10 (AP)  David and Angela Boyter have been divorced from each other three times and have remarried twice to take advantage of tax rates for single persons.

title: Yale Management School Dean Leaving
description: William H. Donaldson, a onetime Wall Street whiz kid who became the first dean and chief architect of Yale University's unorthodox graduate management school, plans to leave the job next July, the university announced yesterday.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Richard A. Voell, 45 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Penn Central Corporation, the successor company to the defunct Penn Central Railroad. He succeeds Frank E. Loy, 50, whose resignation was announced last month. Richard Dicker, 65, remains chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Soviet Explorers Report Finding Arctic Grave of Willem Barents
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  Soviet explorers believe they have found the grave of Willem Barents, the 16thcentury Dutch navigator, on the Arctic island where he died trying to find a northern route from Europe to China, the press agency Tass said yesterday.

title: Blowing Smoke in Havana
description: Composing communiqus is the opiate of the working diplomat. But even by charitable standards of international meetings, the Havana Declaration sets a record for woolly silliness. If the words of the document are to be taken seriously, leaders of some 90 ostensibly nonaligned nations, meeting in solemn conclave, have decided that:

title: Etna Shows Signs of Unrest
description: CATANIA, Sicily, Sept. 10 (AP) Smoke billowed from the main crater of Mount Etna today but experts said it was too early to determine whether the volcano was about to erupt. A weeklong eruption last month, the strongest in 20 years, forced the evacuation of villages on the upper slopes of the twomilehigh volcano.

title: 12th Avenue Fire Leaves Only Rubble
description: A fivealarm fire that burned a vacant West Side warehouse to the ground late Sunday night was brought under control early yesterday, fire officials said, but some rubble in the collapsed building continued to burn last evening, sending thick smoke over the area.

title: 50 Injured on Two Bronx Buses As One Rams Rear of the Other
description: About 50 passengers and a bus driver were injured yesterday when one city bus rammed into the rear of another as it was discharging riders on a Pelham Park service road in the Bronx, authorities said.

title: $29 Million Suit Filed Against Parker Pen
description: MADISON, Wis., Sept 10 (AP)  A $29 million suit has been filed against the Parker Pen Company by a South American concern that alleges Parker conspired to monopolize the manufacture and sale of pens in Venezuela.

title: About Education
description: AS millions of youngsters return to their classrooms, most of them want to learn as much as possible in as little time as feasible. In industry, this is called productivity, and much effort goes into timeandmotion studies to improve the workers skills. In education, according to some experts, similar skills are largely neglected, to the students immediate disadvantage and possibly lasting detriment.

title: Primary Election Is Today; Contest in Bronx Heats Up
description: Democrats in the Bronx, the troubled borough that has come to be regarded as a symbol of urban blight, will nominate a candidate for Borough President today after a quiet campaign that turned testy at the end.

title: Studies Report Refugees Plagued by Persistent Stress
description: THE psychological distress shown by many of the 150,000 Vietnamese refugees who have settled in America in the last few years has spurred an increasing number of researchers to investigate the effects of problems experienced by immigrants as they begin a new life in a strange land.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, Sept. 10 (AP)  Protestants, a civil rights group and an advocate of birth control and abortion raised questions today about the constitutional separation of church and state as Boston prepared for the Oct. 1 visit of Pope John Paul II.

title: O'Neill Feels Kennedy Would Get 1980 Nomination if He Wanted It
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP)  House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that the 1980 Democratic Presidential nomination belongs to Senator Edward M. Kennedy if he wants it.

title: Detroit Schools Struck As 3Week Walkout Is Ended in Oklahoma
description: A strike by about 12,000 teachers virtually shut down Detroit's 300 public schools yesterday, but 650 Oklahoma City teachers ended their threeweek walkout.

title: Japan Pressed On Iran Plant
description: TOKYO, Sept 10 (Reuters)  The Iranian Government has urged Japan to make sincere efforts to complete a joint $3.5 billion petrochemical project at the Persian Gulf port of Bandar Shapur, a senior Japanese Government official said today.

title: News Summary
description: Moscow denied its combat troops were in Cuba, terming reports about them totally groundless. Washington stood by its contention that 2,000 to 3,000 Soviet combat troops had recently been detected in Cuba. The Soviet denial was made a few hours after Secretary of State Vance opened talks about the issue with Soviet Ambassador Dobrynin. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: N.A.A. C.P. Urges Review of Ban on Talks with P.L.O.
description: Leaders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday urged President Carter to reexamine a fouryearold agreement with Israel barring direct negotiations by the U.S. with Palestinian officials until the Palestine Liberation Organization recognized Israel's rieht to exist.

title: Lebanon's Struggling Christians Are Determined to Stay
description: JUNIYE, Lebanon  This fishing port, spread out at the base of Mount Lebanon, has become the de facto capital of Lebanon's Christian heartland and is the region's fastest growing city.

title: Rev. Dr. Arthur Adams; Led Princeton Seminary
description: The Rev. Dr. Arthur M. Adams, dean emeritus of the Princeton (N.J.) Theological Seminary, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Princeton. He was 70 years old. He had retired on Sept. 1.

title: In a CheeverLike Setting, John Cheever Gets MacDowell Medal
description: PETERBOROUGH, N.H., Sept 9 It might have been a scene from one of John Cheever's short stories. The early autumn light shimmered off the poplar trees, and the lawn was green and lovely. To one side of the fine white clanboard house, a greenandwhite tent stood in the shade, and at the white clothcovered tables, guests dined upon stuffed tomatoes and white wine. The men, for the most part, wore blue blazers and gray flannels; the women, brightly colored shirtwaist dresses. They talked of children and dogs, of summer trips to Long Island and the Vineyard, of books and authors. Most of all, they talked of John Cheever.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Roy E. Larsen in The Times yesterday misstated his title at Time Inc. and circulation figures for Time magazine. Mr. Larsen was president of Time Inc., and he helped to increase Time's circulation to 200,000 in 1928, not 1948.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: SPECIALISTS In a nation brimming with professional photographers and aspiring professional photographers, only a few photographic Renaissance people do the everything from photojournalism to pictorial art. Most picture takers who earn money specialize. Martha Swope, Bert Andrews and Frederic Ohringer, for example, have found their niche as performingarts photographers. Miss Swope has focused on dance and Mr. Andrews on black theater. What Mr. Ohringer is about may be seen at Nikon House in an exhibition, Portrait of the Theater.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AMF Inc., producer of leisuretime and industrial products, has formed AMF International to increase exports, and named Bernard E. Conor, currently corporate vice presidentinternational marketing, as its president.

title: Oil Output Rise Cited in Kuwait
description: KUWAIT, Sept. 10 (UPI)  Kuwait's Dil production during the first half of 1979 was up 37 percent from the same period last year, the Kuwaiti daily Al Anba said today.

title: Fuel Board Powers at Issue Again
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  The move to give the proposed Energy Mobilization Board power to override substantive Federal and state laws and speed the construction of synthetic fuel plants is being revived in the Senate, where it had appeared to be dead.

title: 70% in ABC NewsHarris Survey Say Carter Can't Win Reelection
description: Seventy percent of respondents in an ABC NewsHarris poll believe that President Carter cannot win reelection. It was Mr. Carter's lowest rating in the poll's history.

title: Michaels: Jets Lack Aggressive Attitude
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.1., Sept. 10  I haven't seen anybody fail to pick up his paycheck for two games, Coach Walt Michaels told his Jet players at a team meeting today. But I haven't seen anybody earn their pay for two games, and that includes everybody.

title: Plentiful Hydrogen Viewed as Potent Energy Source
description: WHILE recent strides in automobile battery technology have made it likely that the electric car will be part of the answer to the nation's energy problems, many researchers feel that the longrange successor to petroleum as a heating and motor fuel will be that commonest of all elements. hydrogen.

title: Party Leaders Ponder Decline in Influence
description: The unusual resignation of both the Republican and Democratic leaders of Westchester County last week pointed up the decline of party leaders influence in government, but whether that makes for better government is a matter of debate between party leaders and government officials.

title: Books of The Times
description: IT seems that the people at Random House grew weary of waiting around for the American public to discover the many virtues of Edward Hoagland, as if by accident, in a library or a secondhand bookstore. By publishing, simultaneously, his new book on the Sudan and a reader consisting of excerpts from his four previous nonfiction titles, they make us pay attention. It's about time. Mr. Hoagland, who began his writing life as a novelist, has quietly too quietly  become our preeminent personal essayist. He can make me read about subjects in which I have no interest whatsoever, like tugboats and the Golden Rule.

title: Science Watch
description: It has long been known that the sun takes about 24.65 earth days to rotate once on its axis, but astronomers have always worried about the precision of this estimate. A team of astronomers at Britain's Royal Greenwich Observatory has found that solar rotation appears in some strange way to be affected by sunspot activity, and has called for development of a new astronomical theory to account for the finding.

title: Fahringer Wins a Stay Of Jail Pending Appeal
description: The jailing of Herald Price Fahringer, a wellknown defense lawyer from Buffalo who was held in contempt of court last week for refusing to start the trial of a client, was stayed until tomorrow, when Mr. Fahringer's appeal will be heard by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.

title: U.S. Is Studying Overall Buildup Of Cuban Forces
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  A senior Administration official said today that an evaluation of Soviet military aid to Cuba over the last several years has shown a general increase in Havana's military capacity that is a more important strategic problem for the United States than the presence of a few thousand Soviet troops.

title: EDUCATION
description: ALTHOUGH Congress revised the laws governing copyright more than two and a half years ago, the changes have had little practical effect on college campuses.

title: Mortgage Rates at 11.485% High
description: Yields on home mortgages rose to a record high yesterday in the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation's weekly purchase of housing loans. The average yield climbed to 11.485 percent from 11.274 percent last week.

title: Listen, Washington: The Heartland's Angry
description: WASHINGTON  Last month, I left Washington to visit St. Louis. It had been five years since I last visited my birthplace, and, in addition to pressing family business and general nostalgia, I wanted to feel the pulse of the heartland. After all, I had lived in Washington for 13 years and chances were that I had become insulated, impervious to what happens out there in the real world.

title: Chinese in Maryland on Trade Mission
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 10  A muzzleloading cannon smoked, a band played, flags flew and dignitaries dwelt on history recalled as Harry R. Hughes of Maryland today opened the first governor-to-governor exchange of visits with a chief executive of a Chinese province.

title: Howard B. Nichols Is Dead at 78; A Former Caltex Vice President
description: Howard B. Nichols, a civil engineer and former senior vice president of the Caltex Petroleum Corporation, died yesterday at the New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: E.E.C. Prices Climb Sharply
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 10 (AP)  Consumer prices rose sharply in the European Economic Community in July, jumping 1.7 percent from June, it was announced today. The rise brought the increase for the last 12 months to 10.9 percent.

title: Perkins: No Giant Shakeup
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 10  Like a Mondaymorning quarterback with a chance to secondguess himself, Coach Ray Perkins softened his accusations against his players today and said that no wholesale changes would be made to the team that has taken only two games to reach its customary lastplace position.

title: Sri Lanka Pinpoints Subsidies
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  The Sri Lanka Government has devised a plan to insure that food and fuel subsidies go where they are intended  to the poor.

title: Wherein Conventional Wisdom Is Asked, What HealthCare Crisis?
description: Whatever happened to the national healthcare crisis?

title: Rock: Model Citizens
description: THE Model Citizens, a new rock sextet that appeared at Hurrah Friday night, has achieved something increasingly difficult to attain in this noveltyprone age  a uniqueness. Whether the band is important or pleasurable is something else. But at least it's innovative

title: Capital Area to End OddEven
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)  Gov. Harry R. Hughes of Maryland, Gov. John Dalton of Virginia and Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of the District of Columbia agreed today to end the oddeven gasoline purchase restriction in the region on Sept. 30. The officials said that the plan, which went into effect in June, would be lifted if gasoline lines did not form between now and the end of the month. The three jurisdictions postponed a decision on minimum purchase requirements.

title: A Vow by Fluor Is Made On Academic Donations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  J. Robert Fluor, chairman of the Fluor Corporation, promised Jewish leaders in Los Angeles that he would take whatever steps may be necessary to insure that his corporation would nbt exercise improper influence over academic institutions that receive gifts from his company.

title: A G.O.P. Committee Files for Haig 80 Run
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP)  A committee to draft Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., former chief of NATO forces in Europe, for the Republican Presidential nomination filed organization papers today with the Federal Election Commission.

title: Books: After Holocaust, A Survivor Finds Love
description: THIS first novel by Barbara Fischman Traub, who as a girl survived Hitler's Holocaust, an unusual and moving story that goes on a slightly different tangent from the course many other accounts follow. The Matrushka Doll starts with the liberation of a young woman, Lisa Engler, from a concentration camp in 1944 and her return to her hometown, Sighet, in Transylvania, that beautiful region so bitterly contested by Rumanians and Hungarians.

title: Japan to Continue BankLoan Curbs
description: TOKYO, Sept. 10 (AP)  The Bank of Japan is planning to continue tightening commercial bank lending in an effort to fight inflation, an official of the central bank said today.

title: Yale Repertory to Open 14th Season Oct. 5
description: A new version of John Guare's Bosoms and Neglect will open the 14th season of the Yale Repertory Theater, its first season under the artistic direction of Lloyd Richards. It will open Oct. 5 in New Haven, to be followed by new plays by Peter Handke and Athol Fugard and a production of Shakespeare's Timon of Athens.

title: Archbishop Athenagoras Is Dead; British Orthodox Prelate Was 67
description: LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 11 (AP) Archbishop Athenagoras, a leading British Greek Orthodox prelate who formerly served in the United States and Canada, has died in London, it was announced today. He was 67.

title: OBSERVER
description: In the public domain, everything has been overdone in the summer now fading. President Carter's decline in the polls, which took him down near record depths of disapproval, is a case in point. Is President Carter really that bad? Surely not.

title: Police Thank 7 People for Aid to Slain Officer and Trailing of Suspect
description: The New York City Police Department, still jolted by the fatal shooting Sunday of an officer and the wounding of his partner, expressed its gratitude yesterday to seven persons who went to the aid of the stricken officers or gave information that helped in the capture of the alleged gunman.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Chinese Women Offer Some Views of Feminism
description: There is a saying in China: Seeing flowers on a galloping horse. Substitute buses and airplanes for horses, substitute the American landscape for flowers, and you have Zi Zhongyun's reaction to her fastpaced, threeweek tour as part of the first delegation to this country of the Chinese People's Association for Friendship With Foreign Countries.

title: Play: After the Rise In RedBaiting 50's
description: IF I'd realized, before setting foot in the Astor Place Theater, that the title of Gerhard Borris's After the Rise was really and truly a bit of wordplay drawn directly from the title of Arthur Miller's After the Fall, I think I might have gone elsewhere. Back to Oh! Calcutta! perhaps, which I haven't seen in quite few years now.

title: Fire Drives Thousands From West Side Subway Tunnel
description: Thousands of rushhour subway passengers were led through dense smoke to safety last night after a fire broke out in the Central Park crossover tunnel between the Broadway and Lenox Avenue IRT lines. The fire stranded four trains and forced the shutdown of both lines above West 72d Street between 6:40 and 9:16 P.M., when full service was restored.

title: From Madison Avenue,. A Communal Show
description: They came in their silk shirts and stovepipe pants, 700 of them, their hair sunstreaked and their skin tanned, from the Hamptons and other watering holes. They showed up early yesterday morning at Sotheby Parke Bernet to see what they would put on their backs when they exchanged their summer gear for cool weather clothes.

title: Rhodesian Issue: How It Arose
description: LONDON, Sept. 10  The constitutional conference that opened at Lancaster House here today was the ninth major effort to resolve the dispute over black majority rule in Britain's rebel colony of Rhodesia since the white minority there declared its independence in 1965.

title: Senate Votes to Finish Dam Halted by Snail Darter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP)  The Senate voted today to authorize completion of the multimilliondollar Tellico Dam, despite the threat it poses to the tiny snail darter.

title: Atlantic City Track Drops Last Week of Its Meeting
description: HAMILTON TOWNSHIP, N.J., Sept. 10 (AP)  The Atlantic City race track today canceled the last week of its meeting because of poor business. The meet had been scheduled to run through Sept. 22, but will end next Saturday instead.

title: 2 Housing Issues Priced; TaxFree Yields Surge
description: Interest rates on taxexempt bonds climbed sharply yesterday as investment bankers set preliminary terms on almost $300 million of highgrade home mortgage revenue bonds. Taxfree yields as high as 7 percent were set.

title: Some Vietnamese Ethnic Chinese Find Life Hard in China
description: YUANJIANG, China, Sept. 5  The Red River Valley, 300 miles upstream from Hanoi, is a dozen shades of green this time of year. Terraces of rice, sugar cane, and pineapple march up the foothills of the mountains to meet a thick fog creeping down from the peaks.

title: Anderson, Cards Rookie, Is Running in Elite Company
description: By running for 111 yards against the Giants on Sunday, Ottis Anderson of the St. Louis Cardinals joined some distinguished company. Anderson, described as a great back by Harry Carson. the Giants linebacker. became only the fourth runner in the 60year history of the National Football League to gain 100 yards or more in his first two games in the league. The others were Earl Campbell a year ago, Alan Ameche of the Baltimore Colts in 1955 and Zollie Toth of the New York Yanks in 1950.

title: 7 Teams Left in Baseball Races
description: Listening to Dick Williams, one might get the impression that he was talking about the Baltimore Orioles, who have a 12game lead with 19 games to play, instead of his Montreal Expos, who are one game behind Pittsburgh and have 26 games to play in the next 20 days.

title: Market Moves Higher as Oil Stocks Lead the Way
description: Oil stocks ranging from integrated giants to small exploration companies continued to star yesterday as the general market moved slightly higher.

title: TaxCut Talk Rises In Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  Several weeks ago, President Carter sent a memorandum to his senior economic policy officials asking that they not talk about a 1980 tax cut, not even in their private deliberations.

title: Mother Barry, 86, Former Vicar Of Religious of the Sacred Heart
description: Mother Agnes M. Barry, former vicar of the Religious of the Sacred Heart, died last Saturday at the Convent of the Sacred Heart, Kenwood, in Albany. She was 86 years old.

title: Knicks' Cartwright Gets Started
description: He was as inconspicuous as a 7foot1inch man wearing a threepiece brown pinstriped suit could be. Nobody asked him for his autograph as he walked across East 31st Street last week toward Madison Square Garden. Even the people who stared did so only briefly. Everybody knew he was Someone  well dressed 7footers usually are Someone  but nobody was quite sure who. The New York Knicks are not sure yet either, but they are hoping that Bill Cartwright is the future. briefly. Everybody knew he was Someone  well dressed 7footers usually are Someone  but nobody was quite sure who. The New York Knicks are not sure yet either, but they are hoping that Bill Cartwright is the future.

title: The Region
description: WATERBURY, Conn. (AP)  A murder suspect was captured last night at gunpoint inside a bar, less than 24 hours after he escaped from the hospital unit of the State Correction Center in New Haven. The 36-year-old suspect, Lawrence J. Pelletier Jr., had been awaiting trial in the slayings of three private security guards in the $1.8 million Purolator robbery in Waterbury last April, the police said.

title: Taxes
description: NEW YORK is losing the dubious distinction of being the state that imposes the highest income taxes on wage earners.

title: About New York
description: If there is truly a world of spirits abutting us, then there was a double loss in the death two months ago of Alberto Rendon, one of East Harlem's most respected botanica purveyors of the implements of spiritism and folk pharmaceuticals.

title: Search for a Vessel Is Called Off As Distress Signals Prove False
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 (UPI) The Coast Guard undertook a search for a Greek freighter today but called it off when the ship radioed that it had not sent the S O S messages that reported it sinking with a dangerous chemical careo.

title: Andr Meyer Is Dead; Financier Led Lazard
description: Andr Meyer, the New Yorkbased investment banker whose virtuoso skill at dealmaking brought him vast wealth and power, died Sunday, a spokesman for Lazard Frres & Company, the firm Mr. Meyer dominated for decades, said yesterday.

title: Tito, Back From Cuba, Gets Rousing Welcome
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept. 10 President Tito returned home today from the third world conference in Havana to an enthusiastic welcome in Belgrade.

title: Jersey Legislature Passes a 50% Rise in Casino Tax
description: TRENTON, Sept. 10  Under strong pressure from Governor Byrne, the New Jersey Legislature gave final passage today to legislation raising the state's casino gambling tax from 8 to 12 percent. The extra millions of dollars in revenue was earmarked to pay part of the utility bills of about 400,000 elderly and disabled residents of the state.

title: Right Missile Track, Wrong Horse
description: President Carter's choice of a new basing system to make American missiles mobile and invulnerable to surprise attack removes the only real obstacle to ratification of the SALT treaty. Some fhlse obstacles remain, like the argument about 3,000 Soviet combat troops in Cuba, or whether spending on conventional forces will be increased next year by 3 or 4 percent. The crucial issue is whether SALT enhances American security and permits action to keep our landbased missiles invulnerable. That action is now under way.

title: Clabir Plans Bid For General Host
description: The Clabir Corporation, a precision instrument and food services company, announced that it planned to acquire the General Host Corporation, a food producer and retailer. Clabir, a much smaller company, already owns 24 percent of General Host, which has registered net losses in the last three years.

title: RetailSales Rise Outrun By Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) Total sales of the nation's retail stores increased by seventenths of 1 percent in dollar terms in August, although the sales volume probably declined for the fifth consecutive month, a Commerce Department report showed today.

title: After Pioneer, High Hopes for Voyager
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 10  A preliminary review of Pioneer ll's trailblazing flight by Saturn has convinced scientists that the two Saturnbound Voyager spacecraft should have no trouble weaving their way by the many moons and rings and solving some of the remaining mysteries.

title: City's Schools Open Again; Smooth and Hectic as Usual
description: On a sparkling day that must have seemed more conducive to stickball and hopscotch than a morning in school, 947,000 children returned to their classrooms yesterday for the official start of the 197980 school year.

title: Bridge:
description: Those whose childhood included the works of A. A. Milne will recall James James Morrison Morrison Weatherby George Dupree, a 3yearold who gave positive instructions to his mother You must never go down to the end of the town without consultinu me.

title: Rhodesia Conference Condemned by Pravda
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union today condemned the Lon3 don conference on Zimbabwe Rhodesia as an attempt to block a just settlement to the problems of the breakaway British colony.

title: 4 Cholera Cases in Bahrain
description: BAHRAIN, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  The Health Ministry of this Persian Gulf sheikdom today reported four cases of cholera, but said none were fatal. The first three cases were found Wednesday and the fourth was detected yesterday, a spokesman said. He said the World Health Organization had been advised of the outbreak. Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait have also announced preventive measures following reports of cholera in Jordan and Iran. spokesman said. He said the World Health Organization had been advised of the outbreak. Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait have also announced preventive measures following reports of cholera in Jordan and Iran.

title: Dayan Is Pleased by Bonn Talks
description: BONN, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel emerged smiling from a meeting with Foreign Minister HansDietrich Genscher today and indicated that Israel's trust in West Germany had been restored.

title: Specially Designed Florida Beach Weathered the Hurricane's Blast
description: MIAMI, Sept. 8 (AP)  Scientifically designed stretches of beach have come through a reallife stress test with flying colors, weathering the fierce winds and tides of Hurricane David with only minor damage, officials say.

title: Month's Strike Paralyzes British Commercial TV
description: LONDON, Sept. 10  A halfpage advertisement appeared in The London Daily Telegraph on Saturday setting out the fall programs of London Weekend Television.

title: Worms Can Feel Pain, Research Indicates
description: Since man began making tools, he has been baiting fishhooks with worms, generally assuming that a worm impaled by a hook feels no pain. But a team of Swedish researchers has uncovered evidence that worms do indeed feel pain, and that worms have developed a chemical system similar to that of human beings to protect themselves from it.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: A Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Shipping / Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Itel Votes to Skip 2 Dividend Issues
description: Shareholders of the financially troubled Itel Corporation received some more bad news yesterday when directors of the company voted to omit payment of thirdquarter dividends on its two outstanding preferred stock issues.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: TOSSED OUT: Whitey Herzog, Royals manager, right, being thrown out after arguing with umpire, Derryl Cousins, in Kansas City last night.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: United Press International; STRIKE HALTS AIRLINE ON WEST COAST: Passengers at San Francisco Airport waiting for alternative transportation after Hughes Airwest Airlines canceled all flights. Ground employees of the airline had walked off their Jobs after a dispute over wages. The airline serves 45 cities in western United States, Mexico and Canada.

title: Consumer Debt Rise Was Slower in July
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP)  The Federal Reserve Board said today that the rate of growth of consumer borrowing slowed in July for the third consecutive month, a sign that consumers were being more careful about going into debt while the economy is in a recession.

title: Market Place
description: SPECULATORS who are sure that New York State will meet its moral obligations may be tempted by the high yields offered by the least secure state bonds available. They are the Battery Park City Authority 63/8 percent Series A bonds of Nov. 1, 2014, and the eight issues of Urban Development Corporation general purpose bonds. One of the corporation's issues is comparable to the Battery Park issue, namely the 63/8 percent general purpose bonds due Oct 1, 2012.

title: Oak Revives The Blackout
description: WALDWICK, N.J., Sept. 10 Until Tropical Storm David came, Alan McAllister says he had cut down 100 or so trees in his 10 years in carpentry and landclearing. Yesterday, the 80foot oak tree in Neddie Sabile's front yard on Highwood Avenue became No. 101. Mr. McAllister wishes now he had never put his chain saw to the tree.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, Sept. 10 (AP)  Italy's three largest labor unions announced a series of strikes today that are expected to snarl the country's transportation system for a week.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Now is it determined where un derground pools of oil are?

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bill Rates Climb to Peak Level
description: Yields on United States Treasury bills yesterday climbed to 11 percent or slightly more  the highest levels on record for these shortterm securities.

title: ChinaJapan Steel Talks Due
description: TOKYO, Sept. 10 (AP)  Japan's six major steel companies will send a highlevel mission to Peking in midNovember to negotiate the amount of steel exports to China in the first half of next year, officials said today.

title: Dance: Appalachian By Vanaver Caravan
description: DO you suppose they do that for a living? a man murmured incredulously as the Vanaver Caravan stamped and clapped its way through Appalachianinspired dance Sunday at the New York Dance Festival in Central Park. It did look like too much fun to be real work, and that went for most of the rest of the program of the festival, which ends tonight.

title: Joint International Effort Urged To Speed Up the Search for Oil
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 10 (AP)  An American geologist called today for international efforts to develop new oil and gas wells, saying that the world probably has as much undiscovered fuel in the ground as has been discovered so far.

title: Yastrzemski Still One Short
description: BOSTON, Sept. 10  Carl Yastrzemski, on the threshold of American League history, got four chances to record his 3,000th hit tonight, but he was retired all four times by Dennis Martinez of the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Sadat Assures Strauss EgyptianIsraeli Ties Are Strong
description: CAIRO, Sept. 10  President Anwar elSadat has told Robert S. Strauss, the special American envoy to the Middle East, that the budding relationship between Egypt and Israel has passed the danger point and become so strong that it will hold against any future strains.

title: Afghan Driver Says He Saw Soldiers Blind and Strangle Children
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The man was middleaged and anguished. He said he was a simple man, a former coal miner and a good mechanic with no political interests. But because of what he had seen, he sought out a foreigner to tell his story, aware of the risks he was taking. He asked not to be identified. This is the story he told.

title: Rudolf Hess, 85, Has a Checkup
description: WEST BERLIN, Sept. 4 (Reuters) Hitler's former deputy Rudolf Hess returned today to his cell in Spandau jail after a weeklong routine medical checkup, a British spokesman said. The spokesman refused to comment on the state of health of Mr. Hess, 85 years old, the sole inmate at Spandau since 1966. He was sentenced in 1946 to life imprisonment at the Nuremberg war crimes trial.

title: The Silver Lining Fades For the Retired in Florida
description: COCOA, Fla.  When the space age swept America, this coastal city in central Florida, in the shadow of the rocket gantries at Cape Canaveral, was transformed.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Because Gilda Radner is ill with the flu, her show, Gilda Radner Live From New York has canceled performances at the Winter Garden until Friday night, when it is hoped the actress will be well enough to resume. The comedienne has been out since last Saturday. Tickets for canceled performances may be exchanged at the box office.

title: SOVIET SAYS TROOPS ARE TO AD VISE CUBA; DENIES COMBAT ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  United States statements that there is a Soviet combat brigade in Cuba were rejected as totally groundless by Pravda today, hours after a meeting during which Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and the Soviet Ambassador began a search for a diplomatic solution to the situation.

title: Student at Tilden High Is Shot in Robbery Try
description: A 17year old student at Tilden High School was shot yesterday morning outside Prospect Heights High School by a man who had tried to rip away a gold chain the youth was wearing around his neck, the police said.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  In 1972, the Nixon Administration and Congress undertook a new initiative that has had a major impact on the way taxes are collected and public services financed in states and communities across the country.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS 2D ARMS FUNDS RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  The House Budget Committee voted today to increase arms spending by an additional $1.6 billion to $138.2 billion next year, but legislators said they were under tremendous pressure from the Pentagon and its allies in Congress to raise the military budget even higher.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 9 (Reuters)  Tugboat operators interrupted their 17dayold strike today to assist a British gas tanker that ran aground in the port of Rotterdam.

title: Falcons Top Eagles By 1410
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (AP) Steve Bartkowski, who scored the first Atlanta touchdown, threw a 13yard scoring pass to Wallace Francis for the decisive touchdown tonight as the Atlanta Falcons scored a 1410 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles in a National Football League game.

title: DNA: Industrial Interest Grows
description: THE horizons of recombinant DNA technology are rapidly expanding from pure research to industrial application with potentially important consequences for science, government and other areas of society.

title: Primary Choices
description: New York voters go to the polls today for a primary election. We review here our preferences in contests for Democratic nominations in several New York City races and for the Republican nomination for County Executive in Suffolk County.

title: Saudis Said to Plan No Cutback on Oil
description: COPENHAGEN, Sept. 10 (AP) Sheik Zaki Yamani, the Saudi Arabian oil minister, told the visiting Danish Foreign Minister, Henning Christophersen, that Saudi Arabia hopes to keep its oil production at the current level for perhaps the rest of the year, Danish newspapers reported today.

title: 4 Freed Puerto Rican Nationalists Vow to Continue Fight
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 10  Four Puerto Rican nationalists released from prison today on President Carter's order came to Chicago for a rally of their supporters and vowed to carry on their fight for Puerto Rican independence.

title: British to End Production of MG; 25,000 Auto Workers to Be Idled
description: LONDON, Sept. 10  BL Ltd., the last major Britishowned automobile company, announced plans today to end production of the MG sports car, lay off 25,000 workers and close all or parts of 13 plants.

title: BRITONS ARE BUYING HOWARD JOHNSON'S
description: the Howard Johnson Company, whose motels and orangeroofed restaurants have been patronized by two generations of American motorists, is being sold to a British concern.

title: Canadian Tourist Shot Dead on Bus in Afghanistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  A Canadian tourist was shot and killed as he rode on a bus through Afghanistan yesterday. He was the seventh foreigner killed there since Friday.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: ROME, Sept. 10 (UPI)  Italy's staterun Alitalia Airlines said today that it had signed a $580 million contract with the Boeing Company of Seattle for nine 747, Series 200 jumbo jets.

title: Parley on Rhodesia Begins in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 10  Lord Carrington, the British Foreign Secretary, opened the constitutional conference on Zimbabwe Rhodesia today with a warning to delegates that the people of Rhodesia would not readily forgive any party which deprives them of this opportunity to settle their future by peaceful means.

title: Social Worker Ordered to Prison For 25 Years in Murder of Client
description: A social worker who had been convicted of murdering a 68yearold client after stealing her life's savings was sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to a minimum of 25 years in prison.

title: American Women Win, 6862
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 10 (AP)  The United States advanced to the women's basketball final at the World University Games by scoring a 6862 semifinal triumph over Canada tonight.

title: Sindona Still Missing, Trial Is Off Indefinitely
description: The missing Italian financier Michele Sindona did not show up yesterday for the scheduled start of his trial on charges that he took part in the fraud that led to the 1879 collapse of the Franklin National Bank. It was the country's bieeest bank failure.

title: The Slovik Examples
description: It seemed important, in the closing months of World War II, to make an example of Private Slovik. Desertions were increasing so fast that commanders were alarmed. Edward Donald Slovak had twice deserted during battle in France and Supreme Headquarters decided that he would be executed as a deterrent. That he was the only deserter, of 49 sentenced to death in World War II, actually to go before a firing squad may have made it an extreme example but not an unjust one.

title: Cross Is Burned in Elmont; Police Charge 8 TeenAgers
description: ELMONT, L.I., Sept. 10  Hours after a threefoot wooden cross was set ablaze on the lawn of a black family's home here, the Nassau County police arrested eight youths, including a 16yearold high school dropout, and charged them with criminal mischief in connection with the incident. Last night's cross burning was the fourth in Nassau County in four weeks.

title: Hussein Rules Out Role in Parley
description: PARIS, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  King Hussein of Jordan said today that he did not plan to join Egypt and Israel in negotiations for Palestinian autonomy.

title: Guard, 59, Slays 2 and Captures 1 In Robbery of Irvington, N.J., Bank
description: IRVINGTON, N.J., Sept. 10  Two armed men were shot and killed shortly after noon today by a bank guard as they tried to rob the First National State Bank branch in this Newark suburb, the police said.

title: Notes on People
description: Presley's Doctor Accused in Prescribing of Drugs

title: Agostinho Neto, 56, Angola's Leader, Diesin Moscow After Surgery
description: Dr. Agostinho Neto, the 56yearold Marxist poet, physician and revolutionary who became the first President of Angola, died Monday night in Moscow after surgery for cancer and other ailments.

title: Reds Use Homers to Turn Back Astros, 98
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 11  For all the misplayed dramas and tortuous twists of plot that the Houston Astros and the Cincinnati Reds coaxed out of each other last night, only one mattered to Dave Concepcion.

title: BUSINESS
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1979

title: Pinochet, Marking 6 Years in Power, Rejects Calls for Civil Rule in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 11  President Augusto Pinochet completed six years as Chile's military ruler today with a violent attack on political leaders who have suggested that he set a timetable for restoration of elected government.

title: Property
description: PLANNERS have had high hopes in recent years that public investments in new transit lines and stations would stimulate significant new private real estate investments in adjoining properties. Such expectations have been based in part on the successes of new transit systems and the major private projects that have been tied into them in Toronto and Montreal.

title: With Young's Focus on Mideast, Aides on Africa Trip Push Trade
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Sept. 11 Although Andrew Young's trip to the Ivory Coast and to Liberia so far has been dominated by his comments on peace in the Middle East, officials and businessmen accompanying him have stressed that the primary purpose of his journey is to promote trade with black African countries.

title: In a Small Syrian Town, MoslemChristian Peace
description: MALULA, Syria  Christians and Moslems here go to each other's festivals and funerals, and at one time they even fought together against Moslem invaders from a neighboring town.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Inventories Grew 1.9% luring July
description: The value of inventories of goods held by American businesses grew by 1.9 percent in July over the preceding month, the largest monthly rise since September 1974, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Economists said the figure added evidence that the nation was sliding into recession.

title: Classes in the Other Boroughs
description: An astonishing range of cooking courses is offered in the city's boroughs, from the finest professional curriculum in the city at New York City Community College to a few amateurish attempts not worth the time or money.

title: Corporate Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Borough Chiefs in Key Roles
description: While the Borough President has lost number of specific powers in recent years to deliver city services, he still plays key role in molding city policy.

title: Miller Makes Bid For Energy Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) The surge in world gold prices and the softness of the United States dollar abroad dramatize the need for a strong energy program in this country, Ireasury Secretary G. William Miller said today in testimony before the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Vicitms of Rhodesia War Fear Both Sides
description: SEKE, Zimbabwe Rhodesia  In better world, Gladys Jani would be too young and pretty to have dreams about fire and death. Both her legs, from ankle to thigh, and her left arm would not bear the ugly scars of war. She would walk without nain.

title: H. L. Hooker, 103, Oldest Doctor In the New York Medical Society
description: Dr. H. Lyman Hooker, a physician, died Monday at his home in Manhattan at the age of 103. He was the oldest living member of the New York County Medical Society.

title: Agnes Weil Dead at 86; Volunteer for Red Cross
description: Agnes S. Weil, a Red Cross volunteer who established the adult recreation department at the Bellevue Hospital Medical Center 30 years ago, died Monday at New York Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Congress Skeptical On Chrysler
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Despite an intensive lobbying effort by the Chrysler Corporation, key members of Congress whose views often represent a cross section of political sentiment are expressing skepticism and appear disinclined to support Federal financial assistance of any kind for the beleaguered company.

title: Careers
