description: AROSE is a rose is a rose, according to the late Gertrude Stein, who reveled in the complex but sometimes liked to simplify. In the world of secretaries, however, all is not so simple. A secretary is not always a secretary.

title: MORE U.S AID SOUGHT BY EGYPT AND ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Egypt and Israel have informed the United States, separately, that each is seeking multibillion dollar infusions of economic and military aid far beyond help given the two countries in the past.

title: Death
description: COHENEva Spiwak. Beloved wife of the late David, devoted mother of Allan Sarafconn and Gertrude Friedberg. Loving grandmother of Georgina Glazer, Eric Friedberg, Robert and Steven Sarafconn. Adored greatgrandmother of Douglas Glazer. Services today 2PM Garlick's, 1439 Unionport Road at Olmstead Avenue Bronx.

title: ALASKA'S EMPIAOYEES QUIT SOCIAL SECURITY
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Sept. 11 (AP)  State workers here have voted to withdraw from the Social Security System next Jan. 1, making Alaska the first state whose employees will have withdrawn from the nrosram.

title: A Guide To New York Cooking Schools
description: THE cooking school business is booming. In California's Napa Valley, students now pay $1,700 for the pleasures of cooking with Michel Gurard for just one week. In the Middle West, students drive as much as 200 miles one way for a single class with Madame Liane Kuony. Itinerant cooks can even share a Tuscan kitchen with Giuliano Bugialli or vacation in Paris at Thanksgiving, while studying pastry making at La Varenne. And here in New York, where some classes are booked two to three years in advance, students compete for spots in the best schools the same way youngsters do for entry into prep schools. In some cases, it's who you know that gets you in.

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, Sept. 11  Sylvestre Bangui, Central Africa's former Ambassador to France, today announced the formation of a provisional government of the Republic of Ubangi to attempt to overthrow the regime of Emperor Bokassa.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: France Taking Picassos as Taxes
description: PARIS, Sept. 11 (AP)  The French Government announced today that it would select more than 700 art works valued at about $71.5 million from the estate of Pablo Picasso in payment of inheritance taxes.

title: The Reforming of Sly Williams
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 11  Sylvester (Sly) Williams, a 21yearold lefthander with an unorthodox shooting style, led the University of Rhode Island in eight categories last season, including a 23.9 scoring average. But with the impressive statistics came the reputation of a gunner and a hot dog, playground terms for players who showboat and fail to perform within a team concept.

title: The Hospitals Deepest Affliction
description: Hospitals in America's inner cities are heading for financial collapse. Public and private institutions serving poor neighborhoods are being closed, dismantled, consolidated or moved to the suburbs, according to a recent survey by The Times's Sheila Rule. Philadelphia has closed its public general hospital. Chicago may do the same. Detroit is moving its sole public hospital to the city's outskirts. The City of New York, faced with an enormous budget deficit, is trying to close four of 17 hospitals and reduce the size of others. How did urban hospitals get into this mess and how can they get out?

title: Expos Sweep Pair; Trail by Half a Game
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 11 (UPI)  Led by the homerun hitting of Larry Parrish, the Montreal Expos swept a doubleheader from the Chicago Cubs, 86 and 32, tonight to move within half game of firstplace Pittsburgh in the National League East.

title: Miss Austin Returns To School Unseeded
description: ROLLING HILLS ESTATES, Calif., Sept. 11  A huge banner greeted Tracy Austin when she arrived for classes today at Rolling Hills High School.

title: State Inspectors Forced to Leave Hospital Project
description: New York State healthcare monitors were forced out of two Brooklyn hospitals yesterday by Federal Judge George C. Pratt.

title: Inflation's Vise on Retired Automobile Workers Fuels Union's Drive for Pension Relief
description: DETROIT Sept. 11  For years, Del Manier worked as a spray painter at the General Motors Corporation's Cadillac assembly plant on the Detroit West Side. Now, Mr. Manier, 66 years old, is retired. and he and his wife, Esther, must live on his pension and Social Security benefits, which provide about $650 a month. The problem is this: his and his wife's expenses more than match their income.

title: Economic Scene A New View On Stagflation
description: MONETARY policy has become the only wheel in town for dealing with inflation, but the wheel is fixed. There is nothing crooked or concealed about that. When Paul A. Volcker was confirmed as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board two months ago, he made clear his intention to fix the growth of the monetary aggregates at a low rate, even if that meant rising interest rates and unemployment.

title: Hess's Reports It May Be Sold
description: Hess's Inc., the Allentown, Pa., departmentstore chain, said yesterday that it was negotiating with another company for the possible sale of Hess's for cash.

title: Business Records
description: Chapter XI Petition for an Arrangement Filed by:

title: Spain Rushes to Aid New Regime in Equatorial Guinea
description: MADRID, Sept. 11  The Spanish Government is swiftly sending supplies and technical assistance to its former West African colony of Equatorial Guinea, which was the scene of a successful military coup last month.

title: Kitchen Equipment A Better Copper Pot
description: AS anyone who has ever cooked with a copper pot knows, there is no better cooking tool available because the copper distributes heat so evenly and quickly. It is just as well known that the tin lining in most copper pots, which keeps the potentially toxic copper away from the food being cooked, is a nuisance.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: TOKYO  Few people are aware of the state of JapanUnited States trade in the noncommercial field. Although America's trade deficit with Japan has been reduced of late, the balance remains heavily in Japan's favor. But while this is widely known, there is lit tle recognition of the overwhelmingly oneway trade, with Japan deep in red ink, in vocabulary.

title: Police Practice Driving Habits To Cut Gas Use
description: PIKESVILLE, Md., Sept. 10  The first time around the 9.9mile test course, Cpl. David Franklin of the Maryland State Police drove like many ordinary motorists and got 11.6 miles to the gallon.

title: Klein Upset by Cohalan in Suffolk; Simon Wins 4Way Bronx Primary
description: The Islip Supervisor, Peter F. Cohalan, scored a stunning upset yesterday by defeating the Suffolk County Executive, John V. N. Klein, by more than 2 to 1 for the Republican nomination for County Executive.

title: Prepared Foods Dominate Fair in Cologne
description: More than 129,000 visitors from 87 nations have gathered at the fairgrounds here this week for this city's biennial world food fair, a massive and stunning assembly of international foodstuffs, restaurant equipment and supermarket paraphernalia. Formally, it is known as the A.N.U.G.A. fair, the initials standing for Allgemeine Nahrungs and Genussmittel Ausstellung, the German words that mean General Food and Delicacies Fair.

title: Rock: The Who Returns
description: PASSAIC, N.J., Sept. 10  When Keith Moon died just over a year ago, it seemed impossile that the Who could survive. The band, formed in 1964, counted then as the oldest major rock group that had survived intact with the same personnel from the beginning. Mr. Moon, the group's madcap, seemingly irrepressible drummer, appeared to be so integral a part of the proceedings that to carry on without him would be a sacrilege.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AMF Inc., producer of leisuretime and industrial products, has elected Ray A. Tritten president and chief operating officer, and William P. Sovey executive vice president, operationsleisure products.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Wouldn't it be nice, Jimmy Carter suggested in the last Presidential campaign, to have a President and a Congress of the same party? Well, that's what we have, and watching the Democrats since they came back from vacation, one wonders.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 11 (AP)  Wilt Chamberlain Is getting back into the pro basketball game and may even suit up with the Hawaii Volcanos of the Continental Basketball Association, it was reported here today.

title: Canadian Nuclear Plant Closed
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 11 (Reuters)  The Rolfton nuclear power plant about 130 miles northwest of here has been shut down for repairs to the casing of the cooling system, which could take months, spokesman for the Ontario Hydro Company said today. The reactor itself was unaffected and there was no radiation danger, he said.

title: Salt Lake City Changing as Ties to Mormon Church Fade
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Utah  This city in a valley between the mountains, which has long served as the capital and as the fortress of the Mormon religion, is taking on a more secular character.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE novelists who take the greatest risks may not be those who use experimental techniques, for experimentalism can cover a multitude of sins. It is rather, the writers who use conventional techniques who need a world of courage, for they work with the ordinary materials of life and run the risk of succumbing to that ordinariness.

title: Incoming Chief Of Drug Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  When manpower was in short supply in World War II, an eighth grader named Jere Goyan was hired to deliver prescriptions by bicycle from Buxton's Drugstore in Eureka, Calif.

title: Striking Musicians in St. Louis Agree to Play Charity Concert
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11  St. Louis Symphony musicians have agreed to perform in the annual fall charity concert Friday, even though they are on strike. A meeting with Federal mediators is scheduled for next Monday to seek settlement of the weeklong strike. .

title: Guideline Revision Reportedly Due
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) The Carter Administration plans to tighten its price guideline and relax its wage guideline this fall and to set up watchdog committees to obtain compliance in the hope of winning badly needed labor support for the antiinflation program, Government sources report.

title: Lowenstein Cuts Dividend
description: Directors of the M. Lowenstein Corporation, a textile producer, halved the quarterly common stock dividend yesterday to 71% cents a share, payable Oct. 1 to holders of record Sept. 21. Robert Bendheim, chairman, said the action was taken since we expect to show a loss in the third quarter because of the poor performance of our apparel fabrics area. He cited reduced demand for lightweight apparel fabrics.

title: Chess:
description: Bobby Fischer remarked some years ago that Mikhail Tal played as though he expected to win every game by one smashing move. Even if that were so, no one could fulfill such an ambition. But how does Tal win when he is not taking brilliancy prizes?

title: Trade Group Visiting Nigeria
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 11  Nigeria's Commissioner for Industries told Andrew Young and a visiting American trade delegation accompanying him that he expected a great deal of continuity in economic policy after the country's newly elected civilian Government took over from the current military administration on Oct. 1.

title: Beyond the Havana Talks: Castro Sows Trouble for U.S.
description: PARIS, Sept. 11  Cuba's considerable success in dominating the meeting of the Nonaligned Movement last week has been taken by European observers as another disturbing sign of growing weakness in the West.

title: Rights Leader in Suffolk Cites Rise in Racist Acts
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Sept. 11  The executive director of the Suffolk County Human Rights Commission said today that incidents of racism had increased sharply on Long Island recently and that the church, civic groups and the police had been unable to prevent their spread.

title: Senate Unit Approves 30 Nominees for Judgeships
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)  The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved 30 of President Carter's nominees for Federal judgeships, including three of his most controversial choices for appeals court seats.

title: Wachovia to Weigh Selling Some Assests
description: Wachovia Realty Investments, a mortgage lender based in WinstonSalem, N.C., that has incurred substantial losses in recent years, said that its merger negotiations with Security Mortgage Investors had been halted, but that it would hold discussions with

title: Yastrzemski Blanked as Yanks Win.
description: BOSTON, Sept. 11 Carl Yastrzemski, the only point of interest remaining in an unusually meaningless New YorkBoston confrontation, failed to register his 3,000th hit tonight, but he did make a tworun throwing error that was the pivotal play in an 83 Yankee victory.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The headline on an article in The Times last Wednesday incorrectly said that the Aspen Insititute for Humanistic Studies was leaving Aspen, Colo. As the article reported, some programs of the institute will continue in Aspen and others will move to a new installation near Alamosa, Colo.

title: Sunshine Agrees To Sell Three Units
description: The Sunshine Mining Company said that it had entered into an agreement in principle with individual investors and members of the management of businesses being sold to sell all of its manufacturing operations for $23 million in cash and a note of not less than $8 million.

title: Change of Scene, Change of Heart
description: FROM the terrace of the farmhouse I rented In southern France this summer, there was a 50mile view of rolling hills, of golden, rust and pale green fields, divided by dark clumps of trees that might have been composed by Corot  yet, when I sat on that terrace, I sometimes found myself looking not at the landscape, but at the geography of my feelings, at what a French poet called interior distances. I was thinking about changes of scene.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Clap hands, brightcolored kid gloves are back. Not just red, but hyacinth and periwinkle blue, violet, yellow, grass green and bottle green. One would like to own the entire rainbow of them. Lord & Taylor has the tempting array, over-the-wrist length, at $25 for unlined ones, or $36 with silk linings.

title: Muzorewa Demands Britain's Terms for Recognition
description: LONDON, Sept. 11  Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa of Zimbabwe Rhodesia demanded today that the British Government state clearly what changes were required in Salisbury before Britain would lift economic sanctions and grant immediate recognition.

title: Fiendish Plot, G.O.P. Senator Opines
description: WASHINGTON  Notice of the fall of yet another venerable American institution to blatant foreign economic adventurism is always demoralizing, but the latest news really gets me.Texan Denounces Britons Deal for Howard Johnsorfi as Threat to CherryVanilla  Hands Off the Lone Star's Pecans, He Warns

title: Queen Elizabeth to Visit France
description: PARIS, Sept. 11 (Reuters)  Queen Elizabeth will make a private twoday visit to France next month at the invitation of President Valry Giscard d'Estaing, his office announced today.

title: Emmy Awards Top TV Ratings
description: The Emmy Awards telecast on ABCTV Sunday night took the No. 1 honors in last week's ratings, reaching an estimated 60 million viewers, the largest audience for the television program awards since 1973. It helped propel ABC to a rousing victory over the competing networks on the final week (MondaySunday) of the summer season. ABC had a ratings average of 20.3, compared with 15.0 for CBS and 13.1 for NBC.

title: A Library of CreoleCajun Cooking
description: The CreoleCajun cooking of Louisiana is beyond doubt the richest, most romantic and most enticing regional cuisine in the United States.

title: Advertising
description: JAMES KEMPER AGNEW, who was president of the class of 61 at the University of Michigan, became president (and chief executive officer) on Sept. 1 of McCannErickson, U.S.A., the country's ninthlargest agency. He is 40 years old and has only been at McCann since 1973, most recently as head of the Los Angeles office.

title: News Summary
description: Opposition to the arms treaty rose. Senator Henry M. Jackson, a leading critic of the pact, said the Senate would reject it unless Moscow withdrew not only its combat brigade from Cuba, but also planes it had supplied Havana and unless it agreed to provide no more submarines. [Page Al, Column 5.]

title: KENNEDY HAS TOLD CARTER HE MAY SEEK PARTY'S NOMINATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 Senator Edward M. Kennedy has told President Carter that he is now considering challenging him for the 1980 Democratic Presidential nomination, an aide to the Massachusetts Senator confirmed tonight.

title: U.S. Women Defeat Cuba, Capture Medal
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 11 (AP)  Lynette Woodard poured in 19 points and grabbed 11 rebounds as the United States endured a hostile crowd and secondhalf threat to beat Cuba, 7360, tonight and capture the women's basketball gold medal at the World University Games.

title: Stock Market Moves Broadly Lower
description: The stock market turned lower across a broad front yesterday amid weakness in such recently popular groups as oil, glamour and gambling issues.

title: Philip Morris Drops Liggett Contract
description: DURHAM, N.C., Sept. 11(AP)  The Philip Morris Tobacco Company has canceled a contract with the Liggett & Meyers Tobacco Company under which Liggett had made cigarettes for Philip Morris to sell overseas.

title: Catholics Aid Cambodians
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 11 (AP) Roman Catholic relief organizations have distributed 10 truckloads of food, medicine and clothing to Cambodians in wardevastated areas along the border of Thailand, officials here said today.

title: Maggie Smith Finds the She on Stage Is Easier to Know Than One at Home
description: IT is perfectly clear that Maggie Smith is not Ruth Carson, the wisecracking, lusting, fantasizing, bored lady she has been playing here in Tom Stoppard's Night and Day, and will do in an American production opening Oct. 17 in Washington and Nov. 26 on Broadway.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The nation's largest volunteer fishtagging program will, it is hoped, gain new recruits Sept. 22 and 23, when the American Littoral Society meets at Sandy Hook. N.J.

title: States Lagging in Drive to Ratify Amendment on Voting in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  One year ago today, New Jersey became the first state to ratify a constitutional amendment that would give the District of Columbia voting representation in Congress. The scorecard is now six ratifications and nine rejections; prospects are poor that the the additional 32 states needed will ratify the measure by 1985.

title: News of the Theater Irene Worth to Star In Albee's New Play
description: AFTER a long, frustrating search, Edward Albee's new play, The Lady From Dubuque, has finally found its lady. She is Irene Worth. No contract has been signed yet; but according to Richard Barr, who will produce the play with Lester Osterman, plans for a fall opening on Broadway are going ahead on the basis of Miss Worth's verbal agreement to star in it.

title: Woman, 80, Surrenders $1 Million in a Con Game
description: An 80year old Park Avenue resident handed more than $1 million in securities, jewelry and cash to a stranger the other day in the expectation of adding to her wealth. Consequently, she became the victim of what the police say is the biggest pocketbook job ever attempted in New York City.

title: Westinghouse Adds Post
description: Allen J. Hendry, executive vice president of the control equipment group of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, has been appointed a senior executive vice president.

title: Around the Nation
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (UPI)  Christmas should be banned from public school assemblies because of the United States Supreme Court decision barring official prayer in public schools, the American Civil Liberties Union argued today.

title: Odd Illness Idling Staff At L.I. Plant
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I.  A mysterious illness has been plaguing employees of a medicalservices company here for the last six months and baffled Federal, state and Nassau County public health officials can say only that they believe it is something in the air.

title: CARTER REJECTS RISE OF 5% FOR MILITARY; ASKS INCREASE OF 3%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  President Carter rejected the requests of promilitary senators for increases in Pentagon spending of up to 5 percent and instead asked Congress today for an increased military budget for next year that would maintain a real rate of spending growth of 3 percent after inflation.

title: Amram Scheinfeld, Cartoonist And Writer on Human Genetics
description: Amram Scheinfeld, a comicstrip artist who became a widely read science writer on genetics, died yesterday at University Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: U.S. to Send Mondale to Panama For Canal Pact Ceremony Oct. 1
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (Reuters) President Carter announced today that he will send Vice President Mondale to ceremonies in Panama on Oct. 1 marking the effective beginning of the new Panama Canal Treaties.

title: 10% Yield on Bell Issue Sets Off Modest Rally
description: A $250 million Bell System bond issue yesterday was priced to yield 10 percent, the highest such rate of return in five years, and the securities sold quickly and rose to a small premium, touching off a modest rally throughout the credit markets.

title: Jury Selection Begins At Racketeering Trial Of Scotto, Dock Chief
description: Jury selection began yesterday for the racketeering trial of Anthony M. Scotto, politically influential leader of the International Longshoremen's Association who is charged with obtaining $300,000 in illegal labor payoffs.

title: Citicorp Note Sale
description: Citicorp sold $150 million of 91day notes yesterday at an average rate of 12.13 percent, up from 11.68 percent last week and the highest rate the bankholding company has incurred since it began weekly auctions a year ago. Accepted rates yesterday ranged from 11.75 percent to 12.14 percent as bids totaling $750.45 million were submitted.

title: Arson Suspected as Queens Fire Levels 16 New Homes
description: A fastmoving fire destroyed 16 new houses, 28 vehicles and a construction trailer in Douglaston, Queens, early yesterday morning, and an arsonist was blamed.

title: Boston Commuter Trains Halted As Pickets Defy a Court's Order
description: BOSTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)  Rail commuters were forced to find other means of reaching the city today because of continued picketing, in defiance of a court order, by striking Boston & Maine Railroad maintenance workers

title: First Pennsylvania Gets Lower Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it was downgrading its rating on commercial paper, or corporate i.o.u.'s, issued by the First Pennsylvania Corporation to Prime 3 from Prime 2.

title: New Life, New Spice For Classic Cookbook
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I. WHERE my basic persuasions in the world of food are concerned, I am probably more indebted to a 1912 edition of Fannie Merritt Farmer's Boston Cooking School Cook Book than to any other work.

title: Study Suggests Conrail Should Cut Trackage
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The Consolidated Rail Corporation, the huge and troubled Governmentsponsored railroad, probably cannot become profitable without the elimination more than 4,000 miles of track and without the freedom to set its rates, according to a Federal agency study released today.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Jackson Insists Soviet Withdraw Planes in Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Senator Henry M. Jackson, a leading critic of the strategic arms limitation treaty, said today that the accord would go down the tubes unless the Soviet Union withdrew not only its combat brigade from Cuba but also the planes it had supplied Havana and unless it agreed to provide no more submarines.

title: Jersey PlanOn DiplomaIs Protested
description: TRENTON With Governor Byrne expected to sign legislation setting minimum standards for graduation from high school, the State Education Department is preparing regulations establishing the number and kinds of courses necessary tomeet the new competency requirements  and is already running into strong protests from teachers, school administrators and its own policy board.

title: Blacks And Democrats
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  In a recent address before the Prince Hall Shriners Convention, Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, stated that he felt that some Republicans had goodenough records on racial issues to receive black endorsements in next year's Presidential race.

title: TV: Charlie's Angels
description: COMING off the assembly line of purely escapist entertainment, Charlie's Angels is close to being what most network executives would doubtlessly consider television's perfect vehicle. While the basic structure never changes, the parts are completely interchangeable.

title: Cabaret: Tracy Nelson
description: TRACY NELSON'S voice is one of the glories of popular music. More than 10 years have passed since she made her first recordings as lead vocalist for Mother Earth, and during that time she has refined her style somewhat. In the beginning, she was one of the queens of overkill, milking almost every syllable for everything it was worth. Now she is more sparing with her power. In fact, she can be positively restrained. And when she is singing to an audience that relishes power for its own sake, as her audiences often do, restraint is positively heroic.

title: Money
description: Rates as of 3:45 P.M

title: JAMES M'INNIS KILLED WITH WIFE IN CRASH
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11  James Martin MacInnis, one of the city's leading defense lawyers for 40 years, and his wife, Edith, were killed Sunday night in an automobile accident.

title: Private Lives
description: IPUBLISHED my first newspaper in the eighth grade. It was called The Telescope, and it was the official journal of the astronomy club at my grade school. The astronomy club had one member: me. The Telescope achieved publication by means of a tray of gelatin in which ink was trapped. You covered the gelatin with a sheet of paper; you rubbed the sheet of paper with the bowl of a warm spoon; the sheet of paper sucked up some of the ink from the gelatin. It was popsible in this manner to print four or five copies of the same page, which were three or fourcopies more than I really needed.

title: Letters
description: On July 26, the President sent each member of Congress a letter strongly urging oppositikn to a House amendment to the Department of Energy Authorization Act designed to repeal the program of phased decontrol, which he commenced on June 1.

title: Carter Meets President of Zaire
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)  President Carter and President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire met at the White House today. President Mobutu, here on private business, was greeted by an honor guard and ruffles and flourishes.

title: Are Teachers Professionals?; Concerned About the Qualifications of Educators, New York's Regents Consider a Licensing System
description: Many educators agree that the New York City publicschool system's process for hiring teachers and principals is needlessly confused and often does not put the right person in the right job.

title: Senate Approves a Bill Severely Cutting Back On Strip Mining Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 11 (AP)  The Senate approved a bill today that would virtually repeal tough stripmining regulations scheduled to be put into effect next month.

title: House Votes to Continue Bank Checking Interest
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)  The House voted overwhelmingly today to continue allowing commercial banks and credit unions to offer interest on checkingtype accounts.

title: Foremost Suit Seeks Sharon Plans
description: ForemostMcKesson Inc. has filed a suit in Federal court in San Francisco demanding that the Sharon Steel Corporation disclose its future intentions on buying more Foremost stock. A court order prohibiting Sharon Steel from buying more Foremost stock expires Oct. 2.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  The Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court yesterday reversed a lowercourt ruling that 11 suburban towns in Middlesex County had an obligation to provide for increased low- and moderateincome housing to ease the burden now borne by New Brunswick and Perth Amboy, the county's two urban centers.

title: SaveQuarterback Rule a Factor in N.F.L.
description: An example of the way the National Football League's new preservethequarterback rule can change the outcome of a game came up last Sunday.

title: Synanon Founder Enters Plea
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 (AP) Charles E. Dederich, founder of Synanon, today pleaded not guilty to plotting the murder of a lawyer who was bitten by a rattlesnake that had been placed in his mailbox. Mr. Dederich. 66 years old, is accused of soliciting the murder of Paul Morantz, who had won a $300,000 judgment against the rehabilitation agency for drug addicts. Two of Mr. Dederich's. associates, Lance Kenton and Joseph Musico, are to stand trial next month on charges of conspiring to kill Mr. Morantz.

title: M.T.A. Aides Raise New Questions on Unifying Police
description: Officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that Mayor Koch had exceeded his authority in placing the transit police under the command of the city's Police Commissioner. They said he would need legislation to make such a chanee.

title: Some New Recipes
description: 1. If the spinach is in bulk, pick over it to remove and discard any tough stems or blemished leaves. In any event, rinse the spinach well in cold water and drain.

title: Koch Expresses Anger After Cross Burnings At 2 Homes of Blacks
description: Crosses were set on fire yesterday morning outside two homes in which blacks live on Staten Island and in Brooklyn. A string of such incidents has been reported in the New York metropolitan area in recent weeks.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Congress Is Warned Not to Deny Aid to Nicaragua
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Failure of the United States to supply aid to Nicaragua, whose economy was devastated by Civil war, could push its new leadership Foward Communism, the Carter Adminis tration warned Congress today.

title: DuckRaising Restaurateur Makes a Splash
description: MICHAEL'S is mad. The waiters dress in Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren. Exotic scented lilies grow in the outdoor garden. A twicedaily computer printout shows profits and food consumption. On the tables there is antique Christofle silver from Paris and on the walls there are works by Jasper Johns, Richard Diebenkorn and David Hockney. Ducks are bred by the owner himself to produce real Frenchstyle magrets, fillets of duck breast, and are fed in his garage to yield foie gras. The restaurant has no sign out front nor a listing in the telephone directory, but it is booked weeks in advance. computer printout shows profits and food consumption. On the tables there is antique Christofle silver from Paris and on the walls there are works by Jasper Johns, Richard Diebenkorn and David Hockney. Ducks are bred by the owner himself to produce real Frenchstyle magrets, fillets of duck breast, and are fed in his garage to yield foie gras. The restaurant has no sign out front nor a listing in the telephone directory, but it is booked weeks in advance.

title: Brazil Oil Contract
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 11 (Reuters)  Petrolbrasileiro S.A., known as Petrobras, said it will sign an onshore oil exploration contract with a unit of the French company Elf Aquitaine on Friday. The block covered by the contract is situated in the middle Amazon, south of Manaus in the Madeira River region, the company said.

title: Simon Gets Nomination In Bronx
description: Stanley Simon, the Democratic organization candidate for Bronx Borough, President, won the party nomination yesterday in an unexpectedly heavy vote for an offyear primary.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: O N the hairpinshaped line at the bank, writes Ruth Tepper, stood a little fellow about 3 years old, clutching his mother's hand and taking in the scene with great interest. An elderly man on the line opposite gave the child a broad, totally toothless grin. The child stared back solemnly at the man.

title: Wine Talk
description: WHEN it comes to.Spanish wines  and it is coming to them more and more often these days  we automatically think of Rioja. Nothing wrong with that; Rioja wines are good and getting better. Now here's another name to conjure up: Torres.

title: The U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Teheran Crowds Mourn Key Aide to Khomeini
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 11 (UPI) Tens of thousands of mourners surged through the streets of Teheran today to mourn the death of Ayatollah Mahmoud Taleghani, a key aide to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: 12 Buildings Are Named Landmarks
description: Twelve Manhattan buildings, including the former McGrawHill skyscraper on West 42d Street and four midtown men's clubs dating to the turn of the century were designated New York City landmarks yesterday.

title: Letters
description: About Fitting Big Foot

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Will Success Spoil CBS News?
description: AS the longtime leader in broadcast journalism and at present the most stable of the three network news organizations with all its prestige intact, CBS News would seem to be entering the 80's with few serious concerns. But in the view of many broadcast journalists, including some at CBS News itself, the organization is headed for a critical period of change in which it could become the victim of its own success.

title: 2 Freed Puerto Rican Nationalists Say They Can't Rule Out Violence
description: Two of the four Puerto Rican nationalists freed by President Carter said yesterday that they hoped to help Puerto Rico achieve independence in the next year and a half and that they could not rule out violence as Dart of the struggle.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: U.S. and Martin Marietta Settle
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)  The Justice Department agreed today to settle its suit against the Martin MarIetta Corporation's planned acquisition of the Wedron Silica Company of Park Ridge, Ill.

title: The Yaz Countdown
description: BOSTON, Sept. 11  The lady barber phoned to say that she was under heavy pressure from the press to get Carl Yastrzemski into her chair so he would be tonsorially presentable when he made his 3,000th hit. She

title: Soviet to Loft a Laboratory for RatBreeding Test
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)  The Soviet Union plans to launch an international orbiting laboratory in late September to breed rats in space for the first time to see if their offspring are affected by the lack of gravity, the United States space agency announced today.

title: Abercrombie's Reborn on Coast
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 11 Abercrombie & Fitch, the store that once outfitted New York's outdoor elite, but which lost its clientele and closed in 1977, is being revived this week on the West Coast.

title: Equity Library Theater Is Moving
description: Equity Library Theater, the 36yearold showcase for acting talent that has been at Riverside Drive and 103d Street since 1960, will move next year to what is described as its first permanent home, in a complex to be rebuilt on Broadway at 76th Street.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IHAVE tried  quite diligently  to keep in mind that those who may read this column with the thought of producing worthwhile meals in the course of an hour will not all be equipped with the same dexterity in wielding a knife or stirring vigorously with a wire whisk. At the request of some readers I have, in the last few months, made an effort to get down to the most elementary techniques in cooking while keeping the end product at a gourmet level. There have been cipes for basic broiled fish dishes, broiled meats and the simplest method for preparing a chicken saut plus variations on that method. Recently was asked if I would print a basic recipe for a broiled chicken. That I am happy to do, if for no other reason than that I consider a simply broiled chicken one of the natural good things on earth.

title: Logue Beaten, Athanson Wins In Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 11  Nicholas R. Carbone, Deputy Mayor of Hartford and the city's acknowledged political chief, and Frank Logue, twoterm liberal Mayor of New Haven, were soundly defeated tonight in Democratic mayoral primaries. The voter turnout in both cities was very heavy.

title: Inland Steel Plans Some Price Rises
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (UPI)  The Inland Steel Company announced today that it would raise the prices of its carbon steel plate and structural products, effective Oct. 1.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: The City
description: The operator of a cartowing service was arrested in Queens, and the police said they had found evidence of 27 stolen automobiles in his shop.

title: The Dalai Lama Talks About Religion, Not Politics, on a 2DayVisit to Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  On his twoday visit to the capital, the Dalai Lama offered a few simple words to the city's politicians and citizenry: love, peace and compassion.

title: Carter Modifies 2 Energy Proposals And Wins More Backing in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  President Carter agreed to make two concessions in his energy program today, and grateful senators renewed their promises to approve two major segments of the plan in the relatively near future.

title: Judge Won't Step Down. In I.B.M. Antitrust Case
description: Judge David N. Edelstein issued a 97page decision yesterday refusing to disqualify himself from presiding over the Government's huge antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Closed End Bond Funds
description: TUESDAY, SEPT. 11, 1979

title: Dominican Chief Asserts Control Of Relief Aid in Dispute on Cuba
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 11  President Antonio Gutmn, apparently upset about disaster relief provided by Cuba, announced last night that all aid coming into the country has to have the authorization of the exectitive.

title: EARNINGS
description: Columbia Pictures Industries reported yesterday that its earnings fell 43 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter andin the fiscal year ended June 30.

title: Hamdy alGamal Dies, Was Editor of Al Ahram
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)  The chairman of the board and editor of Al Ahram, Egypt's semiofficial Government newspaper, died here of an apparent heart attack, the police said today.

title: Leftists in El Salvador End Their Occupation Of National Cathedral
description: SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 11 (AP) Leftist activists ended their twoandahalfweek occupation of the National Cathedral today as about 2,500 protesters marched by in an antiGovernment demonstration.

title: President to Leave Norton Simon Office
description: Norton Simon Inc. said yesterday that its president, Timm F. Crull, was preparing to leave the company. The disclosure came in an announcement by the $2.4 billion international consumerproducts company that it was creating an office of the chairman in which Mr. Crull would have a transitional role.

title: Best Buys
description: FOR years, Manhattan cooks who love Middle Eastern food have journeyed to Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn to stock their pantries with everything from pistachio nuts to burghul, basmati rice to rose water. Now, those too hurried or busy to make the trek to Brooklyn need go no farther than 325 East 48th Street, where they'll find Le Baklava Inc., a new Middle Eastern food shop run by Victoria Habib, a native of Beirut, Lebanon.

title: $1 Million Lawyer's Fee: Case Behind the Ruling
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9  A Federal appeals court has upheld a prominent San Francisco lawyer's $1 million claim against the Telex Corporation as his fee for asking the United States Supreme Court to hear a case.

title: Coast Robbers Get $1.5 Million In Gold, Diamonds and Jewelry
description: ROLLING HILLS ESTATES, Calif., Sept. 11 (UPI)  Two robbers, apparently unarmed, got away with $1.5 million worth of gold, diamonds and other jewelry in a few seconds yesterday.

title: The Shame of Cambodia
description: Even as the world struggles to cope with thousands of Vietnamese refugees, Thailand reports a new wave of starving people approaching overland from Cambodia. Endless though the flow may seem, these people cannot be ignored. Forceful American and international efforts are needed to get the Cambodian authorities, such as they are, to permit the world to help fight their spreading famine.

title: Decision in Walton Case Expected Within 10 Days
description: Two days of hearings to determine the compensation due the Portland Trail Blazers for the San Diego Clippers' signing of Bill Walton ended yesterday at the National Basketball Association's offices here.

title: New Layoffs At British Steel
description: LONDON, Sept. 11 (AP)  The staterun British Steel Corporation, losing $1.8 million a day, announced today that because of falling orders it would cut nearly 500 jobs at three plants in Lanarkshire County, Scotland.

title: SayOnDrugs Halts Acquisition Talks
description: SayOnDrugs Inc. said that it had ended talks with an unidentified company concerning the possible acquisition of SayOn, a Marina Del Ray, Calif.,based operator of drugstores that sell proprietary drugs and general merchandise at discount prices.

title: Deaths
description: HAMLETMrs. R. William. The Natime! Society of Colonial Dames In the State of New York, records with deep regret the death of Its valued member.

title: Cleveland's Politics Astir While 3d Default Looms
description: CLEVELAND, Sept.11 The political conflicts that have paralyzed this city's effort's to correct its financial problems seem almost certain to make a third municipal default unavoidable early next month.

title: The Bruises And Breaks Of Roller Skating
description: WHENEVER a new sports fad sweeps the country, a characteristic syndrome of injuries follows close behind. The net set has its tennis elbow, runners their sore feet, skiers their broken legs, snowmobilers their spinal injuries, skateboarders their abraded limbs.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, September 3, to Sunday, September 9). listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: House Panel Votes Pay Increase Of 7% for Congress, Not 12.9%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) House subcommittee voted today to give Congress a 7 percent pay increase, rejecting an automatic 12.9 percent raise that would otherwise take effect Oct.1.

title: Dance: Fun in the Park
description: TALK about a dance explosion! These days, it seems, even the cockroaches are dancing. At least, that's what was implied at the New York Dance Festival's Monday night program in Central Park.

title: Ullman, Long Back A ValueAdded Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  The chairmen of the taxwriting committees of Congress urged business today to support a socalled Federal valueadded tax on the ground that the revenue it would raise would make possible reductions in individual and corporate income taxes and in the Social Security navroll tax.

title: Pop: Shirley Bassey
description: SHIRLEY BASSEY, who seems to have sung everywhere in the last 20 years except on Broadway, whooped for joy at finally being there on Monday night when she opened a 10evening engagement at the Minskoff Theater. At the Minskoff, she is more literally on Broadway than she would be in most socalled Broadway theaters, since the Minskoff's secondfloor lobby looks directly out on what was once the Great White Way.

title: Frank Church: Hero or Villain, Or a Politician?
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Frank Church is a man in the middle. The Idaho Democrat is a firm advocate of a nuclear arms treaty, which pleases the White House, but he is also demanding the immediate withdrawal of Soviet combat troops. from Cuba, and insisting that until they are withdrawn the Senate will not approve the arms treaty.

title: ExCongressman Wins Minneapolis Mayoral Vote
description: Former Representative Donald M. Fraser, upset in a race for Hubert H. Humphrey's Senate seat last year, won an an easy victory last night in the DemocraticFarmerLabor Party primary for mayor.

title: The Cohalans Family Tree Bears Many Political Limbs
description: Peter Fox Cohalan comes from a long family tradition of politicians, lawyers and judges, and when he thrusts both arms above his head and moves swiftly into a cheering crowd of supporters, the 41yearold lawyer does as his father and grandfather did before him.

title: Strauss Said to Calm Israeli Fears Of Stress on a Role for Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 11  Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special envoy to the Middle East, reportedly assured Israel today that the United States was not wooing the Palestine Liberation Organization, was in no hurry to bring Palestinfans into the talks on selfgovernment for Arabs in Israelioccupied territories and would refrain from pressing for quick progress in the negotiations.

title: Market. Place
description: WHILE some purchasers of oil shares have grown giddy weighing the prospects of recovering oil from a well in the icy Beaufort Sea, others have focused on a drilling site in less hostile waters off Newfoundland.

title: Threat on Sindona's Life Alleged by Friends in Italy
description: ROME, Sept. 11 Friends of Michele Sindona, the missing Italian financier, said today that the group they say is holding him got in touch with his family and lawyers twice in the last 10 days. They said Mr. Sindona's alleged captors had demanded information about his financial dealings and had warned that his life depended on its being provided.

title: Canadian Bank's U.S. Role Grows
description: The Royal Bank of Canada announced yesterday that it would invest an additional $100 million in its New York trust company, a move that rival bankers described as an important new element in the already keen competition for the banking business of mediumsized companies in the United States.

title: Study Favors Coal Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Most of the nation's power plants that now burn oil can lower the costs of producing electricity  without increasing air pollution  by switching to coal, according to an analysis made public today by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Mets Beaten by Phillies, 52
description: With only 9,713 customers in the seats in Shea Stadium last night, the New York Mets continued their relentless march toward twin disasters less than three weeks off; a third straight season in last place and the lowest at tendance in the club's 18year history.

title: Imperial Oil Pipeline
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Sept. 11 (Reuters)  Imperial Oil Ltd., a division of Esso Resources Canada Ltd., said that it wanted to build a $270 million oil pipeline through the Mackenzie Valley in the Canadian Northwest territories. It said it will apply later this year for permission to build a pipeline to transport 25,000 barrels of crude oil a day by 1983.

title: Deaths
description: FINEHelen Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member. She was a Sisterhood Board Member and her presence was everywhere a blessing in our community and congregational life.

title: Piano: Goldsand's Series
description: IN the last century, Anton Rubinstein and other pianists of a pedagogical bent liked to give what were known as historical programs in which the listener was taken on a sort of aerial reconnaissance over music's past. Robert Goldsand, a VienneseAmerican pianist whose New York recital career spans 52 years, began just such a series of three programs on Monday night at the 92d Street Y, where he played works of C.P.E. Bach, Paradies, Haydn, Mozart, Clementi and Beethoven.

title: Death
description: ABBADESSAAnna, on Sept 10, 1979 of Old Brookville, N.Y. Beloved wife of the late Girolamo. Dear mother of Mary Barone, Tullio Abbadessa and the late Dr. Joseph Abbadessa. Also survived by 11 grandchildren and 11 greatgrandchildren. Reposing at the Roslyn Heights Funeral Home, Inc., 75 Mineola Ave, Roslyn Heights. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10AM at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Bryant Ave, Roslyn Harbor. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Lung Ass'n of Nassau & Suffolk Counties would be appreciated.

title: Seoul's Trade Gap Grows
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 11 (Reuters) South Korea's trade deficit widened to $518 million in August, from $330 million in July and $235 million in August 1978, the Economic Planning Board said. Exports totaled $1.32 billion in August, against July's $1.29 billion, and showed a 26 percent rise over August 1978.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What are soft bread crumbs, which you mention often? Are they simply the crumbs of white bread torn out of the crust and pulled into small bits? Should the bread be fresh, day or two old or stale? And toasted or not?

title: Koch to Answer Callers In Channel 13 PhoneIn
description: Mayor Koch will answer questions from viewers in a live televised callprogram next Monday from 8 to 9 P.M. on WNETTV, Channel 13.

title: Mayor Inviting 6 Black Leaders To First Parley
description: The first of a series of meetings designed to improve Mayor Koch's relations with the black community has been scheduled for Saturday morning at Gracie Mansion.

title: GOIN GOUT Guide
description: OLD, HONORABLE The immortal gods alone, said Sophocles, have neither age nor death! All other things almighty Time disquiets. Import laws define things disquieted by time as antiques in the United States the New World  if they are 100 years old. In Europe  the Old World  antiques are generally about 60 year old.

title: Outrage Is Voiced at Extending The Search for Hunter President
description: A group of faculty, student and alumni leaders at Hunter College has expressed outrage that a sixmonth search for a new president of Hunter has been extended and that the board has not picked the candidate of the group's choice.

title: Canada To Reduce Oil Exports
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 11  The Canadian Government announced today that it would reduce exports of light crude oil to the United States for the last three months of this year because Canada's surpluses were not sufficient to provide for both exchanges and exports at their present levels.

title: Alberta Energy Sells Part of Oil Sand Unit
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Sept. 11 (UPI)  The Alberta Energy Corporation announced today that it was selling half of its 20 percent interest in Syncrude Canada Ltd., the world's largest oil sands plant, to Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Ltd. and Petrofina Canada Inc.

title: Big Impact Seen If Chrysler Closes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) A shutdown of the financially troubled Chrysler Corporation would have a severe effect on the United States economy and result in longlasting damage to several metropolitan areas, according to a study by the Department of Transportation.

title: Hurricane Frederic Grows Stronger; Warnings Posted Along Gulf Coast
description: MIAMI, Sept. 11 (AP)  Hurricane Frederic will swirl ashore tomorrow near Mobile, Ala., if the storm behaves as expected, a forecaster at the National Hurricane Center said late today.

title: Bridge:
description: When two 19thcentury whist players could not find a third and a fourth, they sometimes played double dummy, a form of the game in which each player had a dummy hand exposed. This took all the guesswork out of the game, for the opponent's hand could be identified by subtraction.

title: Topics
description: President Carter bent the rules a little in commuting the sentences of four Puerto Rican nationalists imprisoned since the 1950's for their part in two bloodlettings in Washington. But on balance, he did the right thing. The commutation removes a persistent thorn in the touchy relations between mainland America and the island.

title: Pemex Negotiates $2.5 Billion Credit
description: A 66bank syndicate, led by the Bank of America, has agreed to provide Pemex, Mexico's national oil company, with $2.5 billion in export credit at rates described as well below prime. The prime is the rate banks charge highquality domestic corporate borrowers for shortterm credit.

title: Cuba Issue May Delay a Vote on Soviet Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  What had been a tight and finely adjusted timetable for guiding the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union through the Senate wilt now be stretched by at least four weeks and possibly longer, Congressional sources said today.

title: Winners and Losers in the Bronx
description: A third of the 1.3 million counted residents of the Bronx are registered to vote, 320,000 of them as Democrats, 50,000 as Republicans. Fewer than a third of the registered Democrats voted Tuesday to nominate their party's candidate for Borough President and fewer than a third of these  only 29,337 people  chose Stanley Simon, the organization's candidate, who is thus assured of victory in November.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Rates on oneyear Treasury bills climbed to a record 9.893 percent yesterday as the recovery in the credit markets that began Tuesday failed to continue beyond midday yesterday.

title: EARNINGS
description: Heinz Net Climbs 51.4% On 18.3% Rise in Sales

title: Chrysler 3dQuarter Loss Seen as Twice That of 2d
description: DETROIT, Sept. 12  The Chrysler Corporation's loss in the third quarter ending Sept. 30 will be at least double the $207 million deficit reported for the second period, Lee A. Iacocca, president, said.

title: About Glen Cove
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept.10  Watching Yaz on the cable TV, pressing like rookie to get career hit No. 3,000, casual fan sees again the simple beauty of baseball. The sight encourages sympathy for the new policy of Frank Earning, the editor of The Baseball Hobby News, that henceforth he will refuse to cover silly, inflated auctions of the more coveted bubblegum baseball cards.

title: CBS Fields Entertainment Against Baseball Games
description: My dream, Robert A. Daly, president of CBS Entertainment, said, is for a World Series between Kansas City and AinntrPal derided in four games This was not the fantasy of a sports enthusiast, but of the program chief of a network that does not have the telecast rights to any of the postseason baseball competition. NBCTV will carry the leagues playoffs and ABC the World Series.

title: Heating Oil Dealers Support Price Freeze
description: Fuel oil dealers said yesterday that they would be happy with the freeze on heating fuel prices proposed by President Carter because it would ease their costs of doing business and curb resistance and complaints from customers.

title: The British Offer Some Cold Comfort
description: LONDON IN England, the energy crisis has brought to the fore that generation of aging residents who never acknowledged the reliance on modern fuels. They have no central heating, no cars and they long ago real ized that the only sin worse than using the telephone was turning on an electric light. Why, after all, did God give us legs, the sun (on occasions) and Harris Tweed?

title: C.I.A. Director, Praised Briefly, Again Attacked
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Less than year after he was criticized for having failed to anticipate the revolution in Iran, Adm. Stanfield Turner, the strongwilled Director of Central Intelligence, again coming under attack.

title: Ailing Bid Out Of Woodward
description: Spectacular Bid developed fever on Tuesday night, and his trainer said yesterday that the star 3yearold thoroughbred colt would miss a confrontation with Affirmed in the Woodward Stakes on Sept. 22.

title: Italian Dies Imitating Movie
description: LATINA, Italy, Sept. 12 (UPI)  Giampaolo Paoletta, 25 year old, was discussing The Deerhunter with friends at his bookstore today when he imitated a scene from the movie by spinning the chamber on a .22caliber revolver, pointing the gun at his head and pulling the trigger. He was rushed to a hospital, where doctors prOnounced him dead, the police reported.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, Sept. 12 (UPI)  President Ferdinand E. Marcos stopped the pretrial investigation today of former President Diosdado Macapagal on charges of rumormongering and inciting to sedition.

title: Official Tallies Listed For Mayoral Contests In Connecticut Cities
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 12 Official tallies in mayoral primaries across the state showed the followinE results:

title: I.R.S. Will Give You a Tax Credit to Save Fuel
description: WASHINGTON THE Federal Government is eager to provide both information and money for home improvements that save energy. Its most tangible offer is a subsidy of up to $300 per taxpayer, taken as a tax credit on your annual income tax return, for a variety of conservation projects  from insulating your house to something as simple and inexpensive as insulating your water heater.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Committee on Economic Issues 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: $170 Million Queens SubwayStation Complex Is Planned
description: The City Planning Commission announced plans yesterday for a $170 million subwaystation complex at the Queens Plaza junction of six subway and seven bus lines. The station will include an aboveground mall and an underground shopping arcade.

title: Falcons Lose Thielemann And Faumuina to Injuries
description: SUWANEE, Ga., Sept. 12 (AP), The Atlanta Falcons are unbeaten after two games, but their latest victory, a 1410 decision over the Philadelphia Eagles on Monday night, was a costly one. he Falcons said today that a starting guard, R.C. Thielemann, had separated his left shoulder and would be out four to six weeks and that a starting defensive tackle, Wilson Faumuina, had strained a knee and would miss Sunday's game against Denver and might be lost for three weeks.

title: Judge Orders Trial Of I.B.M. to Resume
description: Federal District Judge David N. Edelstein has ordered the Justice Department's suit against the International Business Machines Corporation on antitrust charges to resume tomorrow.

title: Dividends
description: x  company Intends to pay on semiannual rate, amount in Canadian funds.

title: AGENDA ISSUE SOLVED AT RHODESIA TALKS
description: LONDON, Sept. 12  The conference on Zimbabwe Rhodesia cleared a preliminary obstacle today when the Patriotic Front guerrilla alliance accepted Britain's proposal that the conference seek agreement on a constitution for black majority rule before it turns to the problems involved in establishing a new political order.

title: And in Canada, Federal Grants
description: OTTAWA IN Canada, where the winters are long and cold, heating homes accounts for fully 15 percent of the country's energy consumption. Although Canada is better off than other nations in being able to provide for its energy needs out of domestic resources, the need for conservation is acutely felt as prices rise and supplies from abroad become less dependable.

title: Episcopalians Give Final Passage To New Book of Common Prayer
description: DENVER, Sept. 12  The 66th triennial convention of the Episcopal Church overwhelmingly gave final approval today to a hotly debated revision of the church's Standard Book of Common Prayer.

title: Soviet Dissident Gets Exit Visa
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 12 (Reuters)  Lev Ulyanovsky, a dissident who has worked as a spokesman for the Jewish emigration movement, said today that he had received permission to leave the Soviet Union. Mr. Ulyanovsky, a 29yearold physicist, said officials told him yesterday that he had been issued an exit visa valid until Oct. 5.

title: Cornerback Problem Is Still Plaguing Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 12  The Jets right cornerback slot, where players have trouble finding a home, was declared open again today by Coach Walt Michaels.

title: L.J. Judge Opens Pretrial Hearings In Murder Case to Public and Press
description: RIVERHEAD, Li., Sept. 12  A Suffolk County Court judge refused today to bar the public and news reporters from pretrial hearings in a murder case, rejecting the:arguments of the defendant's lawyer, who contended that open hearings would keep his client from getting fair trial.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, Sept. 13 BEEN ELIZABETH 2 (Cunard).. ett Cherbourg Sept. 8; due 8 A.M. ati .55th Street.

title: How to Keep Your House From Leaking Costly Heat
description: Half the heat produced by the furnace in a typically inefficient twostory house quickly escapes from the home. The same principle applies to any dwelling. Here are the escape routes and their percentages of this heat loss, if no energyconserving steps are taken:

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: There is much media discussion on outer space, and Congress will soon be considering the United Nations moon treaty now before the General Assembly.

title: Theater: Morse's Mimes
description: THE Richard Morse Mime Theater celebrated its fifth anniversary as a New York company with a performance Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall. It was quite a happy birthday. Even before the program began, the Other Clockwise Chamber Ensemble provided musical entertainment in the lobby, and during the curtain calls it was announced that Mayor Koch had proclaimed Tuesday Richard Morse Mime Theater Day.

title: Truck Crash Leaks Radioactivity
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Sept. 12 (UPI)  A truck carrying radioactive materials crashed today on U.S. 30 about 20 miles southeast of Johnstown, the state police said. A 20mile stretch of highway between Reels Corner and Shellsburg was reported closed to all traffic. The office of Lieut. Gov. William Scranton 3d said there was a minor leakage of radioactivity from the cylinders of hexafluoride uranium.

title: U.S. Airlift to Oman Reported
description: KUWAIT, Sept. 12 (UPI)  The newspaper Al Qabas said today that the United States had started an airlift of troops to Oman to counter the Soviet military presence in Cuba and South Yemen. In a dispatch from Washington, Al Qabas said the troops were sent on confidential orders from President Carter and were being stationed on the Omani island of Masirah. [In Washington, the State Department said there was no substance to the story.]

title: Mennea of Italy Sets World Record in 200
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 12 (AP)  Pietro Mennea of Italy, confident that he could break the world record in the 200meter dash, did exactly that today with a clocking of 19.72 seconds at the World University Games.

title: DoItYourself Interior Shutters
description: THERE is a mediumpriced, highly efficient way to reduce heatloss from windows: interior thermal shutters you make yourself or assemble from a kit. These shutters, using a stiff foilfaced foam board called Thermoply, reduce heat loss by up to 84 percent and cost about $2 per square foot. Fuel savings derived from the shutters should return the investment in about two years. The shutters can be covered with decorative fabric and take the place of curtains. Here are the steps for making them yourself:

title: Soviet Brigade: How the U.S. Traced It
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  The United States Government received indications of the presence of a Soviet combat brigade in Cuba through overhearing the Russian word brigada in radio monitoring in 1975 and 1976, intelligence officials said this week.

title: Ann Meyers Cut By the Pacers
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 12 (AP) Ann Meyers convinced the Indiana Pacers coach, Bobby Leonard, she knew the fundamentals of basketball well enough to play in the National Basketball Association. But, Leonard said her size just wasn't right.

title: GasRationing Steps Voted by Conferees
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  The Congressional conference working to give President Carter standby gasoline rationing authority cleared a major hurdle today, agreeing on machinery to permit the White House to put a plan into effect.

title: Nixon Off for 3d Visit to China
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 12 (Reuters)  Former President Richard M. Nixon left his home here today on the first leg 0 a trip to China that an aide called a working visit. Mr. Nixon will arrive in Peking on Tuesday for his third visit.

title: Nationalist's Niece Dies
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 12 (UPI)  The niece of Mr. Collazo collapsed just after hugging him at the airport and was pronounced dead on arrival at a hospital. Irma Collazo, 45 years old, apparently died of a heart attack, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Deaths
description: JACKSONBertha. Beloved wife of the late Benny Jackson. Loving I mother of Norman M. and Betty Trompeter. Dear sister of Abe Suhl. I Loving grandmother of Carol and Barry Trompeter. Services today at I 2 PM Garlick's 1700 Coney Island I Ave. near Ave N.

title: POLICE IN HOUSTON ARE FOND IMPROVED
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 12  Critics of the Houston Police Department testified at Federal hearings today and yesterday that the department had made some praiseworthy efforts to correct past abuses. But they expressed concern over how carefully policemen were following those policies and said there was still fear of the police in minority neighborhoods.

title: Move Grows at Capitol to Urge Carter to Shun Race
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  As Senator Edward M. Kennedy's challenge to President Carter intensifies, dozens of Congressional Democrats who back the Senator are moving toward concerted action to urge Mr. Carter to step aside in 1980.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Canadian Bank's Man in New York

title: The City
description: A 40yearold fireman rescued three women and two children from a burning tenement in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn shortly after noon yesterday and hissuperiors said he would be recom for a heroism citation.

title: 8 Are Killed and 6 Hurt in Crash Of a Bus Carrying Elderly in Utah
description: DELTA, Utah, Sept. 12 (UPI) minibus carrying a group of elderly people to the Utah State Fair struck a bridge abutement early today, killing eight persons and seriously injuring six others.

title: Design Notebook
description: IN September 1896, Henry D. Thoreau returned from an extended trip to the Maine woods with some sharp observations about the loggers who lived there and the design of their log cabins: The chimney was an oblong square hole in the middle [of the roof]  The fireplace, the most important place of all, was in shape and size like the chimney, and directly under it, defined by a log fence  These houses are made comfortable by the huge fires that can be afforded night and day.

title: Dance: Etudes by Ballet Theater
description: THE American Ballet Theater opened the second and final week of its fall Encore Season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday with a mixed bill that lived up to that description in every way.

title: 21 Jersey Teachers Seized As School Strikes Go On
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Sept. 12 Twentyone striking teachers were arrested here today for violating a court injunction against picketing at the 30 schools in the district where a strike, now in its sixth day, has curtailed classes for 16,000 pupils. Strikes continued, however, at two other school districts.

title: Inherited Genetic Flaw Is Linked to a Family's Cancer
description: An inherited genetic abnormality has been linked to a specific type of kidney cancer in a family in which 10 members were affected over three generations.

title: A House Within a Greenhouse
description: ROBERT MASTIN'S 2,600squarefoot home just outside of Newport, RI., has no conventional heating system just the sun and the ambient heat given off by people, appliances, light bulbs and two ordinary fireplaces. The secret of this rather ordinary looking Cape Codstyle house is its passive solar design. Lee Porter Butler, a San Francisco designer, has built five such solarheated houses and has 100 more in the planning and construction stages across the country.

title: Seoul Bars Visitors at Home of a Leading Dissident
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 12  The police today stopped all visitors to the home of a dissident leader, Kim Dae Jung, for the first time since the Government released him from detention last December.

title: Eastern Urges Link To National
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) Frank Borman, the chairman of Eastern Air Lines, urged the Civil Aeronautics Board today to approve Eastern's proposed merger with. National Airlines, saying it would aid domestic air competition and produce lower fares between the United States and Europe.

title: Aides Using School Cars In Off Hours
description: On most weekday mornings, Amelia H. Ashe is picked up in a chauffeurdriven car at her Park Avenue apartment. Often she has the driver drop her husband off at work and then take her to the hairdresser and on other errands, where he waits outside.

title: Stocks Take Prime Rise In Stride and Edge Up
description: Stock prices edged higher yesterday despite an increase in the prime rate by the Chase Manhattan Bank to a record 13 percent.

title: Suit Challenges Verdict on OPEC
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (AP) An appeal notice was filed today in a unusual antitrust suit against the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that previously was thrown out of Federal court.

title: Dead Woman Elected By Democrats on L.I.
description: Voters in a Long Beach, L.I., election district in Nassau County elected two members to the Democratic County Committee Tuesday night, including woman who died a month aeo.

title: Going Underground: Radical Savings
description: ROBERT HOMAN and his wife Nancy spend between nothing and $60 a year on oil to heat their sunny threebedroom home in the New Jersey pine barrens, in Vincentown. Their 2,400squarefoot home, designed by architect Malcolm Wells, is a solarheated building that's deeply set into the ground on three sides and has an earthen roof three feet deep.

title: Giants Give Pisarcik A Vote of Sympathy
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 11 Dave Jennings took an imaginary snap, dropped back to pass, looked up in mock anguish at makebelieve rushers and fell backward in a perfect imitation of a Giant quarterback. Joe Pisarcik laughed. It doesn't hurt when You laugh.

title: Television
description: 5:50(5)New Zoo Revue 5:55(4)Teenage Alcoholics 6:00(7)News

title: CARTER CONFRONTED BY KENNEDY ISSUES IN TRIP TO HARTFORD
description: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio. Sept. 12 President Carter flew to New England today, into the heart of Kennedy country, and was confronted with repeated reminders of the programs and political appeal of the Senator from Massachusetts. Later, he flew on to a more enthusiastic reception here in coal mining country.

title: Joseph Frantz, First French Pilot To Down a German Plane in 1914
description: PARIS, Sept. 12 (AP) Joseph Frantz, the first French pilot to shoot down a German plane in World War I, died today at the age of 89, his family reported.

title: Draths
description: FINEHelen (Mrs. Marvin). In lovino memory of Helen Fine, a founding member and past president, aclive member of the Keret League since its inception, Heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family.

title: Catholics to Pay for Pope's Mass
description: BOSTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)  Roman Catholic officials said today that the Boston Archdiocese would be. willing and happy to pay the costs of the upcoming visit of Pope John Paul II.

title: City Opera: Tosca With 2 Newcomers
description: HAVING warmed up with twoweek operetta season, the New York City Opera put aside frivolity Tuesday night and got down to the more serious business of the regular fall season. No doubt things will look up as the weeks go by, but it must be said that the opening night's Tosca was a dud.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY 01:: TELEPHONED TO 354.3900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2'30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 3.3900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 9.5303. NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. 15161 6691800: CONNECTICUT 12031 3da.77A7

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Hurricane Frederic is apparent off Florida and broken to overcast cloudiness covers most of the Southeast. Broken thunderstorms extend from the Texas Gulf coast to the Missouri Valley. A band of cloudiness extends from the Middle West to the Rockies.

title: Mrs: Carter Goes to New Hampshire, Where Eyes Are on Kennedy
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 12 Rosalynd Carter, opening the Carter campaign headquarters in New Hampshire's largest city this morning, called for Democratic Party unity behind President Carter, but her appearance failed to  diminish the growing expectation here that Senator Edward M. Kennedy will formally enter the Presidential race later this fall.

title: Wood Stove's Allure
description: IN American iconography, the woodburning stove stands about even with a white picket fence and slightly west of mom and apple pie. A woodburning stove possesses endless allure. It nurtured winteriong cneciter matcnes between village elders. Children pulled their bedclothes in front of it. True baseball fans spent long nights huddled around it. While discussing the game's finer points, they evolved the hot stove league.

title: Joachim 0. Ronall, 67; Economist and an Envoy
description: Joachim 0. Ronal!, a professor of economics who served as an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York 1 and had been an Israeli vice consul in New York, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 67 years old.

title: Sawhill Selected For Energy Post
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) President Carter today announced the selection of John C. Sawhill, top energy official in the Nixon Administration, to return to Government as deputy secretary at the Department of Energy.

title: Strauss Urges Israelis to Abide by Lebanon CeaseFire
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 12  Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special envoy to the Middle East, said today that he had raised the subject of Israeli attacks into southern Lebanon with Prime Minister Menachem Begin, and had urged a continuation of a ceasefire prevailing for the last two weeks.

title: Mets Bow To Lerch Of Phillies
description: Randy Lerch, a 24yearold leftbander for the Philadelphia Phillies who has been pitching with his right wrist in a cast after an injury during mugging incident in early July, posted his first career shutout last night.

title: A Swiss Also Said to Die In Afghan Bus Ambush
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 12 (Reuters)  A Swiss was killed and an Australian was critically injured when guerrillas ambushed a tourist bus in Afghanistan Sunday, Western diplomats here said today. First reports of the attack mentioned only the death of a Canadian, naetan Dion. of Disraeli. Ouebec.

title: Cohalan Asserts Victory Marks Start of New Era for Republicans on L.I.
description: BAYPORT, L.I., Sept. 12  Peter F. Cohalan, the Islip Town Supervisor, said today that his landslide victory over Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein for the Republican nomination for County Executive marked the beginning of a new era for the Republican Party on Long island.

title: U.S. Corrects Inventory Ratio
description: The inventorysales ratio for manufacturing and trade, unadjusted for inflation, was 1.45 when the last recession began in the first quarter of 1974, according to the Department of Commerce.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Mien Group Inc., maker of auto accessories and testing equipment, has elected J. Chisholm Lyons vice chairman.

title: Heimann Warns on Credit Use
description: The Comptroller of the Currency, John G. Heimann, has warned national banks against overextension of consumer credit. He said he was particularly concerned over the extension of credit through the indiscriminate use of credit cards.

title: Administration Prepares Youth Employment Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  The Carter Administration is putting the finishing touches on a fouryear legislatiye program to combat youth unemployment that would change traditional ways of thinking about the problem, recommend substantially higher expenditures and give greater autonomy to local jurisdictions in spending the money.

title: Burning Crosses
description: Some friends of ours recently expressed what seems to be a common belief: that black Americans no longer face the kind of intimidation and violence that were common years ago, particularly in the South. The rash of firebombings and crossburnings against black families around New York shows how sadly wrong that belief still is. Some blacks moving into new homes nearly lost their lives. Others now dwell in fear. As Suffolk's Police Commissioner, Donald Dilworth, says, This stuff is contagious.

title: Exclusion in Trenton Appealed
description: TRENTON, Sept. 12  A state appellate court judge will hear an appeal this afternoon by attorneys for Trenton's two daily newspapers on a Superior Court judge's exclusion yesterday of the press and public from a portion of a major drug trial.

title: Gulf Hurricane Crashes Ashore In Mobile, Ala.
description: MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 12  Hurricane Frederic plowed ashore tonight at Dauphin Island, 25 miles south of here, wrecking small towns along the western shore of Mobile Bay with winds recorded at 100 miles an hour and causing heavy damage in this populous port city.

title: 2 Airlines Cancel Flights
description: Eastern Airlines canceled all flights into and out of New Orleans, Mobile and Pensacola because of the hurricane's approach, and National Airlines canceled flights to Mobile and Pensacola. Fourteen flights were affected.

title: Lack of Food For Cambodia
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 11  Although foreign experts who attempt to monitor conditions in Cambodia agree that famine conditions exist there, efforts to mount an international relief effort are encountering a series of political obstacles.

title: Two Rented Elephants To Trace Alpine Trek
