description: BRAMANS, France, Sept. 12 (AP) Two Americans and a Frenchwoman left this picturesque Alpine village today with a couple of tons of hay, two rented circus elephants and the ambition to follow the 2,197yearold trail of Hannibal into Italy.

title: 29 Killed and 55 Hurt In Clashes in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Wednesday, Sept. 13 (AP)  At least 26 persons were killed and 55 wounded yesterday in fighting between Armenian and rightwing Lebanese militias in Beirut's Christian sector, and 3 were killed in a clash between two leftist groups in the city's Moslem sector.

title: U S. Raises Forecasts For Corn and Soybeans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  The Agriculture Department predicted today that American corn and soybean crops this fall would be even larger than the record crops forecast by the department last month.

title: 4 Nationalists Are Welcomed as Heroes in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 12  Four Puerto Rican nationalists released by President Carter after spending a quarter of a century in United States prisons for terrorist acts returned home today to a welcome as heroes.

title: JOSEPH NEWMAN
description: Joseph Newman, a portrait painter and I water colorist, died yesterday at Beth Is, rael Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: Plants That Love Lower Thermostats
description: Plants should have no difficulty cooperating with efforts to keep this winter's fuel bills down. For most of them, the cooler the room the better. If the thermometer hovers around 65 degrees during the day, and drops five to maybe 10 degrees during the night, nothine could be finer.

title: U.S. WEIGHING VIEW THAT SOVIET FORCE IS TRAINING CUBANS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  The Carter Administration is studying the possibility that the Soviet combat brigade that is reported to be in Cuba may have as its primary mission the training of Cuban forces for action in Africa, State Department officials said today.

title: Sound
description: MY neighbor's daughter Margaret voiced a complaint about this column. All the stuff you write about is too expensive, she told me reproachfully, and explained how she had arrived at that opinion. She had saved most of her earnings from her summer job as a babysitter to buy a stereo system to take back to school, only to find that most of the items I had mentioned in print were out of her reach.

title: EnergySaving Methods That Don't Cost Money
description: NOT every energysaving tactic costs you money. Here here are several conservation methods that can be accomplished at no expense: 1. After taking a bath, open the bathroom door and let the bathwater stand in the tub until it cools to room temperature. The heat from the water is sufficient to heat a small house for an hour since a full tub of water will give up about 10,000 B.T.U.'s as it cools from 100 degrees Fahrenheit to 70 degrees. If showering, leave the stopper in the tub to catch the water. A little detergent or bubble bath will eliminate the ring around the tub and scent the air.

title: Union Official Is Charged
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 12 (UPI)  The president of the United Steelworkers of America's Local 3205 was charged today with stealing more than $16,000 from the union. Gordon L. Brubaker, 55 years old, of Oak Creek, was charged on four counts of embezzling and converting union money to his own use.

title: SOVIET REASSESSING ITS POSITION ON IRAN
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 12 Over the weekend, an authoritative commentator writing in Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, assailed the course taken by the Iranian Islamic revolution, and he cited the words of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini as an example of religious fanaticism that, the commentator said, was darkening Iran's future.

title: Energy Strategies Tested on N.J. Town
description: PRINCETON, N.J. SOMETIMES a house is more than a home. To the researchers at Princeton University's Center for Energy and Environmental Studies, for example, it's repository for a great deal of oil and gas waiting to be recovered not some time in the future but rieht now.

title: U.S.Canada Talks Fail To End Fishing Dispute
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 12The United States and Canada failed to settle their dispute over tuna fishing off the Canadian west coast today, but they agreed to meet again after consulting their fishing industries.

title: What Tenants And Landlords Are Attempting
description: NEW YORK CITY'S tenants and landlords, despite differences over rents and services, agree that when it comes to energy conservation, landlords can do better. Hit by higher retail fueloil prices, which have jumped from about 10 cents a gallon in 1969 to an expected 85 cents to $1 this winter, both tenant leaders and landlords are asking building owners to make their buildings more energy efficient. Solutions range from installing better boilers to fixing broken windows.

title: Board Nominee Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)  The Senate voted 95 to 0 today to confirm the nomination of Jay Janis as a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. Mr. Janis, who has been serving as Under Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, was confirmed for a term expiring June 30, 1981, replacing Robert H. McKinney, who has resigned as chairman of the board.

title: Corporate Reports
description: For periods as shown (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter, For periods as shown. ( N) incliBRENNANDPAIGE INDUS (O)

title: The F.C.C. Tunes In to the Public
description: Who will bark at the media when the F.C.C. watchdog is gone? David Dunaway, a California radio producer, asked that question last June in a discussion of the pitfalls of deregulating radio on the opposite page. The marketplace, the Federal Communications Commission answered, in effect, as it moved last week to rescind rules dictating how much air time must be devoted to commercials and public affairs. Not surprisingly, some organizations fear that the industry, once freed of regulation, will become less publicspirited. But the radio marketplace caters well enough to listeners tastes in entertainment and information, with no need for Washington to prescribe the program mix.

title: Carter Aide for New York Named
description: The White Kouse has named a New York coordinator for President Carter's reelection campaign, and his first task will be defensive  to try to stem a stampede by New York Democrats to Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: 4 Hindus Hanged in Cult Case
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 12 (AP)  Four Hindu men were hanged today for murdering 12 girls and a young woman for village elder who believed a witch doetor's advice that offering the victims blood to a local god would bring fertility to his mistress and make him wealthy. The United News of India, reporting on the case, said the village elder and his mistress were acquitted of the murders, committed between 1972 and 1974 in Manwat, about 220 miles east of Bombay.

title: Chiefs Tie Clipper Series
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 12 (AP)  The Syracuse Chiefs trounced the Columbus Clippers last night, 61, tying the fourofsevengame International League baseball final at two games apiece.

title: Knight Helps Reds Sink Astros
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 12 Ray Knight is the luckiest person in the world, at least he thinks so. John McNamara, the Cincinnati Reds manager, is pretty lucky, too, because Knight gets a lot of hits.

title: Brush Wellman Stock Split
description: Brush Wellman Inc. announced yes terday that its shareholders had votec to approve a proposal to increase the company's authorized common stocl to 15 million shares from 5 million, al lowing the company to enact a 2for1 stock split. The split shares will be dis. tributed Sept. 28 to holders of record Sept. 19. The company manufacture: beryllium, beryllium alloys and cul. tured quartz.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Sept. 12,1979

title: CARTER ASKS FREEZE ON HEATING OIL COST
description: President Carter said yesterday that he had asked 27 of the largest oil companies in the nation not to raise the prices of heating oil for the balance of this year.

title: Five Girls and a Big Mortgage
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 12 Behind the ring at the far end of the Concord Hotel's indoor tennis courts, a big blackandwhite banner proclaimed, Shavers KO's Holmes, Eamie is New Chaimd. Another banner reminded, We've Got To Feed The Babies. And now, after his workout, Earnie Shavers, his friendly smile minimizing the menace of his shaved head, was relaxing in a skyblue sweatsuit with red and blue sneakers. If he dethrones Larry Holmes in Las Vegas, Nev., on Sept. 28 for the World Boxing Council title, he would be the second oldest gladiator to win the heavyweight championship, having turned 35 last week. Jersey Joe Walcott was 37 in 1951 when he won the title. But win or lose, Earnie Shavers will go to Mecca after the fight  Mecca, Ohio, where he recently purchased a new home for his wife, LeVerne, and their five young daughters.

title: In New York, Expert Audits
description: UNTIL recently, little technical assistance was available to the homeowner to help plan energysaving improvements. But now there is a new species of technician, called an energy auditor, who inspects houses and makes moneysaving suggestions. A growing number of private companies are involved in this business, but the state's public utilities offer one of the least expensive such services.

title: William Dillon, 58, Senior Partner With Simpson Thacher &
description: William G. Dillon, a senior partner and member of the administrative committee of the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, died Tuesday at Memorial SloanKettering Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  How shall we approach the campaign of 1980?

title: Pirates 2, Cardinals 0
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 (AP)  The Pittsburgh Pirates beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 20, on the sixhit pitching of John Candelaria and Kent Tekulve tonight. Ed Ott and Phil Garner each drove in runs with singles for the Pirates, who have won 19 of their last 18 games but are in a virtual firstplace tie with Montreal In National League West.

title: GOING OUTGuide
description: TRINITY WEST Standing tall on Broadway like a stern, forbidding cleric, Trinity Church glares eastward down on Wall Street and sniffs to the west over Trinity Place.

title: On the Coast, Utility Loans
description: SAN FRANCISCO WE'VE all seen the colorful flyers, the billboards and the television commercials, all paid for by our utility companies, asking us to use less energy. But now some gas and electric companies are backing up the plea with financial and practical programs. One such company is Pacific Gas and Electric, the San Franciscobased public utility known as P.G.& E. to its customers in northern and central California. In the last year, P.G.& E. has lent 6,000 of its customers more than $3 million to improve the insulation on their homes. The loans, up to $500, are offered at a relatively low annual rate of 8 percent and are repayable over up to 60 months.

title: HERBERT M. CLEAVES
description: Herbert M. Cleaves, former senior vice president and director of the General Foods Corporation, died Monday at the Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 68 years old and lived in Round Pond, Me., and North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Scotto a Contributor to Simon Election
description: Stanley Simon's tardy list of campaign contributors turned up at the Board of Elections yesterday, and people close to his campaign said that the late filing had been a calculated risk  to accept unfavorable headlines about the lateness rather than risk potentially worse headlines about names on it.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Gold prices retreated yesterday from record closings in Europe, while the dollar rose sharply against the British pound sterling but slipped against most other currencies.

title: Deaths
description: GLICKMANMorris, Founder of the United States Paper Bag Co.. Inc. formerly L. Glickman & Co. Past Chairman of the Board and Past President. He will be sorely missed by all.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the inventorysales ratio of manufacturing and trade, unadjusted for inflation, for the first quarter of 1979. The correct ratio was 1.95. A corrective article appears on Page D14

title: Keeping Snug in Saskatchewan for 16 Cents in Fuel
description: SASKATOON, SASKATCHEWAN IN this Canadian prairie town, the thermometer can fall to 90 below zero in January or February. But Earl Brooks, an engineering professor at the University of Saskatchewan, is snugly secure, with his wife and daughter, in a small house that does not look much different from all the others on his treelined block.

title: From the Ocean Floor, Attic Insulation
description: ILL try anything new that pops up, even things that have been around for thousands of years, said a New Jersey architect, Matthew Rue, who is insulating his attic with seaweed and partially ne aesignea ana DUllt flIMSell. tins winter he expects his improvements will reduce his fuel bill by 90 percent.

title: Stage: Jewel Walker's Silent Cityscape
description: TUESDAY, a silent play at the Black Theater Alliance's stage through Sept. 23, takes a city's entire population through a city day without word of dialogue. Conceived and directed by Jewel Walker, a drama professor at the University of Wisconsin, the 70minute tour de farce is a charming and inventive blend of Jacques Tati and Richard Scarry, full of shrewdlybut not too shrewdly  observed detail. As acted by a highspirited, young cast, it falls somewhere between drama and traditional pantomime, greatly resembling the silent film, which is its inspiration.

title: Crum &
description: CBS Inc. and Crum & Forster, an insurance holding company, said yesterday that they had terminated preliminary merger talks.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia PhiIlies, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television  Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio  WMCA, P.M.)

title: Chile Court Hands Over Bodies of Police Victims
description: SANTIAGO; Chile, Sept. 12  A nineday hunger strike by relatives of missing political prisoners and Roman Catholic clergymen ended today after a military court handed over the bodies of 15 persons killed by the police.

title: Edginess In the U.A.W.
description: DETROIT  The threeyear contracts between the United Auto Workers and General Motors, Ford and Chrysler expire tomorrow. This is an event of national importance if only because 750,000 people work under these contracts.

title: A Council Panel Passes Measure To Limit Noises
description: A City Council committee unanimously approved yesterday a measure that would provide for decibel limitations on the city's ambient noise levels. It applies to stationary sources of noise only and not to noisy moving objects or vehicles.

title: U.S Won't Fly U2 Over Turkey to Check on Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  The United States has given up the idea of using flights by U2 reconnaissance planes over Turkey to verify Soviet compliance with the new strategic arms treaty, but Government officials said today that the Carter Administration hoped to use another type of aircraft for the task.

title: Kenon Rejoins Spurs And Signs for a Year
description: SAN ANTONIO, Sept. 12 (AP)Larry Kenon, the allstar free agent whose signing with the Los Angeles Lakers was reportedly blocked only when the Lakers and the San Antonio Spurs could not agree on compensation, returned today to the Spurs for the National Basketball Association's 197980 season.

title: Labor in Negotiations On Bigger Guideline Role
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Led by Vice President Mondale, Administration economic policy officials negotiated with senior labor representatives today over labor's proposals for playing a larger role in rewriting President Carter's pay guidelines.

title: Bridge:
description: Battling on when all seems lost is, on the face of it, an admirable attitude. But there comes a point, in warfare or in bridge, when determination fades into stubbornness and stupidity.

title: Jazz: Mickey Bass Sextet
description: WHEN Mickey Bass and Cooperation get in the right groove, it is doubtful there is a jazz group in town that swings as hard as this sextet, which appeared early this week at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South.

title: Talking Business
description: With Henry Kaufman of Salomon Brothers

title: China. Entering a New Legal Era, Scans the Police Blotter
description: PEKING, Aug. 29  Although China's new legal system does not go into effect until Jan. 1, Chinese newspapers and radio and television stations have been carrying more reports about crime and punishment in an apparent effort to prepare people for the new era.

title: House Bars Registration for Draft; Manpower Study Is Sought Instead
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  The House voted today, 259 to 155, against reviving Selective Service registration of all 18yearold males for possible military service.

title: MidContinent Offering
description: The MidContinent Telephone Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the issuance of one million shares of common stock. The proceeds will be utilized to reduce shortterm debt incurred in connection with acquisitions, to extend service to new customers and to modernize existing service facilities.

title: Deaths
description: MEYERAndre. The Faculty. Students and staff of the Dept. of Physics of New York University mourn the passing of their benefactor Andre Meyer. His vision and generosity made possible our Andre and Bella Meyer Hall of Physics. We extend our sympathy to his family. Lawrence A. Bernstein, Assoc.

title: Senate Military Bloc Warms to New Carter Arms Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Promilitary senators reacted favorably today to President Carter's proposal to increase real spending for arms by 3 percent next year, after accounting for inflation. But they stopped short of endorsing the strategic arms treaty now before the Senate.

title: West Side Highway Blocked in Protest
description: Two hundred demonstrators, waving placards and singing protest songs, sat down across the West Side Highway at 96th Street yesterday morning and blocked traffic to protest school budget cuts in District 3 on the Upper West Side.

title: Blyth Missing $1.3 Million
description: One of Wall Street's leading brokerage houses is short $1.3 million, the apparent result of a scheme involving the use of phony accounts to buy and sell Government bonds.

title: Deaths
description: SCHWARTZArnold. The President, Staff, Parent Body and Officers of the Hebrew Academy of Nassau Co. extend their heartfelt condolences to the family of Arnold Schwarz on the passing of the Academy's oreat benefactor.

title: New York Area Primary Results
description: Following are the final or nearfinal results in the major contests for Democratic, Republican and Conservative Party nominations for public office in the primary elections Tuesday in the New York metropolitan area.. Unopposed candidates are not listed. Asterisks (*) denote incumbents. Daggers () denote incomplete returns.

title: Dominican Legislators Ask Inquiry Into Charge U.S. Sent 2,000 Troops
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 12  The Chamber of Deputies asked President Antonio Guzman last night to investigate allegations that 2,000 United States soldiers had been sent here as a response to the Russian brigade they say is in Cuba.

title: Blitey Defeats Favorites
description: There was a fashion show for women at Belmont Park yesterday but most of the style was on the track in a 3yearold filly named Blitey.

title: Amnesty International Accuses Guatemalans of a Wave of Terror
description: LONDON, Sept. 12 (UPI)  Amnesty International began a major campaign today to draw worldwide attention to wave of political murder and repression in Guatemala that it said had claimed 2,000 lives in 16 months.

title: A Glossary Of Energy Terms
description: WITH the heightened concern about energy use comes a vocabulary that may be unfamiliar to many. The following basic terms are often used in discussing the problems of saving energy and the possible solutions:

title: David Kennedy Listed As lieu Seriously Ill With Heart Infection
description: David A. Kennedy, the 24yearold son of the late Robert F. Kennedy, has been hospitalized in Boston in very serious condition with a rare infection of the lining of the heart, a family spokesman said yesterday.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Flute Concerto No. 1, 1st movement, Pergolesi; Harpsichord Concerto No. 5, J.C. Bach ; Suite in A minor, Book IV, No. 9, Marais.

title: 2 Parties Team Up for Japan Vote
description: TOKYO, Sept. 12  With internal discord threatening the unity of the conservative forces backing Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira, two middleoftheroad parties have teamed up to fight his governing Liberal Democrats in the parliamentary elections Oct. 7.

title: Campaign Debate Limit Is Opposed by the F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)  The Federal Communications Commission urged Congress yesterday to reject a proposed regulation that would prohibit networks, newspapers and news agencies from sponsoring campaign debates.

title: Outrage at 111 TA. Cited Over Removal of Garelik
description: Sources close to Harold L. Fisher, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that Mr. Fisher had said it was an outrage for Mayor Koch to have removed Sanford D. Garelik as chief of the Transit Authority police.

title: P.E.N. Joins the Foes Of Publishing Mergers
description: Bernard Malamud, novelist and president of the American Center of P.E.N. (Poets, Playwrights, Editors, Essayists and Novelists), has issued statement against the growing influence of conglomerates upon publishing houses and of big bookstore chains upon authors, editors and the creative process in the United States.

title: Vacor Brand of Rodent Poisons To Be Banned by Federal Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)  The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would ban the widely sold Vacor brand of mice and rat poisons because of human deaths and illnesses linked to them.

title: Investment Units Ethics Codes Set
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission approved a rule today requiring investment companies and their advisers to adopt ethics codes. The codes, aimed at preventing stock manipulation, would prescribe standards of conduct for the first time for investment company advisers.

title: Advertising
description: IN July and once again this week The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal have both carried small ads that announced, London Ad Agency Now in New York.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 It is 1981. The Mobil Corporation announces plans for the country's biggest oil refinery, to be built on the New River in North Carolina.

title: $115 Million Is Raised In N.Y.U.'s Fund Drive
description: Dr. John C. Sawhill, the president of New York University, announced yesterday the completion of a threeyear, $115 million fundraising drive, the largest in the school's 148year history.

title: Candidate Kennedy
description: A few days after Richard Nixon's election in 1968, many people in politics opened their mail to find a pale green button reading EMK 1972. It turned out that the Senator had had nothing to do with the mailing. Still, it showed that some people were certainly eager for him to make the race even if he was not. The Presidential candidacy of Edward Kennedy has been Phantom ship on the political seas ever since.

title: Royals 4, Twins 0
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 12 (AP) Dennis Leonard pitched a threehitter, and Amos Otis drove in two runs to spark the Kansas City Royals to a 40 decision over the Minnesota Twins tonight.

title: Getty Plans to Plug Dry Offshore Well
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 12 (Reuters)  The Getty Oil Company said that its first exploratory well off the coast of Georgia was dry and would be plugged.

title: Third World Nations Advised by Waldheim To Stay Out of Blocs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 12 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim advised third world countries today to stay independent of the Soviet and Western blocs, saying they should be truly neutral in international affairs.

title: Emery Air Freight Corp. Struck At Kennedy and Newark Airports
description: Truck drivers and clerks last. night struck the Emery Air Freight Corporation at Kennedy and Newark International Airoorts.

title: Britain Plans to End State's MailPhone Monopoly
description: LONDON, Sept. 12  Britain's Conservative Party Government today announced plans to end the mailcarrying and telephone monopolies of the British Post Office, by far the state's biggest business, and to split the enterprise into two companies.

title: Home Improvement
description: SINCE fuel prices are almost certain to continue climbing, it is not surprising that increasing numbers of homeowners are investigating ways to update or improve their existing heating equipment from making minor repairs and adjustments to replacing the furnace or boiler with a more efficient modern unit that will get more heat out of each dollar's worth of fuel consumed. aware of the steps to keep heat from being lost to the outside  adding more insulation where practical, installing weatherstripping on all windows and doors, putting up storm sashes and doors, applying calking to all open joints around the outside of the house, Most homeowners are by now well and closing all gaps where cold air can infiltrate.

title: I.T.T. to Report Loss for 3d Quarter
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the nation's 11thlargest industrial concern, announced late yesterday that it would report a loss in earnings for the third quarter. This would be the company's first quarterly loss in at least the last two decades.

title: Q &
description: The following are some typical questions asked about heat conservation in the home:

title: Balanchine: Obeying Doctor's Orders?
description: LONDON, Sept. 12  George Balanchine took a'sip of tea  real English tea, with milk in it  and said he was feeling a lot better, thank you. taut It was not yet tnree montns since his openheart surgery on June 19, the balletmaster added, and he still had to watch himself. No shouting. No heavy lifting. No openingnight parties. And certainly no strenuous demonstrations for his dancers.

title: Peterson of Sweden Wins World Cup SixMeter Title
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 12 (AP)  Despite the loss of a mainsail in the fifth race, Pelle Petterson of Sweden yesterday won his second straight World Cup SixMeter sailing crown.

title: Chase Lifts Prime Rate To 13%
description: Other Banks Hold Back on Matching Rise

title: Deaths
description: BE RLINRUTSelma. Beloved wife of the late John (Jan). Graveside services will take place at King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, N.J. on September 14, at 10:30am.

title: Market Place
description: Robert Metz

title: Efficiency Labels Planned for Major Appliances
description: WHAT does it cost to operate a clothes dryer for a year? A water heater? A freezer? Is a General Electric dishwasher cheaper to run than a Whirlpool or a Maytag? A Fedders airconditioner more energy efficient than an Airtemp? Consumers should soon have such answers at hand.

title: Wilbur Ware, Bassist, 56, Dies; Toured With Many Stars of Jazz
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP)  Wilbur B. Ware, a bassist, died Sunday in Germantown Hospital a day after his 56th birthday. He had suffered from emphysema for many years.

title: TV: Move To Mansion By Benson
description: THIS evening at 9:30, ABC'010;TV's Soap begins its third season. This anniversary might seem singularly ordinary, but students of television trivia will remember that, even before it went on the air, Soap was being nationally condemned as the biggest threat to family and flag since Jane Russell shouldered her way lasciviously through The Outlaw.

title: 4Alarm Fire in Jersey City Destroys Part of City Hall
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 12  A spectacular fouralarm fire that raged out of control for more than an hour and a half with flames sometimes shooting 50 feet in the air destroyed portions of the centuryold City Hall here today.

title: Orr Enters Hall of Fame A Year After Retirement
description: TORONTO, Sept. 12 (UPI)  Bobby Orr, whose grace and speed revolutionized the game for defensemen, capped his career today by becoming a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame just one year after his retirement.

title: General Singlaub Says Soviet's Cuba Brigade Protects Atomic Arms
description: TABERNASH, Colo., Sept. 12 (AP) Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub said today that he believes Soviet troops are in Cuba to protect nuclear warheads on Soviet planes. He said an interview in a Connecticut newspaper quoting him as having said that there were Soviet missiles in Cuba was inaccurate.

title: A Potpourri of Shows: Textiles, Toys and Glass
description: Textile Exhibition, Consulate General of Finland, 540 Madison Avenue.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA, New York State Theater, Gounod's Faust, 8.

title: 5 in Arts to Be Honored
description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington will honor Aaron Copland, Ella Fitzgerald, Henry Fonda, Martha Graham and Tennessee Williams at the center's Opera House on Sunday nieht. Dec. 2. The composer, singer, actor, dancerchoreographer and playwright will be cited for lifetime achievement in the performing arts.

title: OPTIMISM EXPRESSED ON AUTO BARGAINING
description: DETROIT, Sept. 12The United Automobile Workers said today that a positive atmosphere prevailed at the automobile negotiations and that, while there had been no essential changes on key issues since yesterday, the union and the General Motors Corporation were making progress on noneconomic matters.

title: Polaroid Writes Off $68 Million
description: I.T.T. to Report Loss in Quarter

title: Home Beat
description: THE battle to keep warm this winter need not be limited to grappling with B.T.U.'s, Rfactors and weatherstripping. There are more amusing strategies to beat the cold, a parsimonious landlord or the household budget.

title: The U.N.'s Ongoing Decline
description: When Skylab recently crashed in Australia, The Daily Express of London commented that the United Nations building in New York, the world capital of humbug and hypocrisy, would have been a more suitable target. For all its facetiousness, this statement aptly illustrates the growing disenchantment with the United Nations and the steady decline in its standing and prestige, as reflected also in its constantly diminishing resonance in the news media.

title: Utilities Switch to Coal Power
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12  In his televised energy address on June 15, President Carter announced that, as one major step toward cutting oil imports, he was asking Congress to require that electric utilities cut their use of oil by half over the next 10 years by shifting to coal and other fuels.

title: CHINESE SHED LIGHT ON THE PEKING MAN
description: PEKING, Sept. 12  Chinese scientists, engaged in an intensive new archeological effort, yesterday described details of the life of Peking Man, a major character in evolutionary history, the study of whom was stifled by the mysterious disappearance of fossil remains in World War II.

title: An AllFemale Class Is Planned For Jersey State Police Academy
description: TRENTON, Sept. 12  After being able to graduate only two women from the State Police Academy in five years, New Jersey officials announced today that they would experiment with having an allfemale class of 80 or more.

title: Big Bronx Vote Restores Control By Organization
description: The regular Democratic organization reestablished control of Bronx Borough Hall on Tuesday for the first time in 12 years by piling up votes in the white middleclass districts that sweep across the borough's northern border, an inspection of the final primaryelection figures showed yesterday.

title: Hers
description: OFTEN when I can't cope with the three children I have, I pass the portrait of my maternal grandmother, Anna Truan Dobson, which hangs at the top of the stairs, and wish I could ask her how she managed her nine. In the photograph, taken about 1890, she is 18 years old, with high cheekbones, a sensuous mouth, a mass of light brown hair falling over her lace collar. Her brown eyes are fixed confidently on the future, which at,that point included college. She earned two degrees, in piano and classical languages, from Washington College (now Tusculum) in Greeneville, Tenn., a rare achievement for a Southern woman those days.

title: 8 Are Killed and 6 Hurt in Crash Of a Bus Carrying Elderly in Utah
description: DELTA, Utah, Sept. 12 (UPI) minibus carrying a group of elderly people to the Utah State Fair struck a bridge abutement early today, killing eight persons and seriously injuring six others.

title: Fraser Comes Back in Minnesota Mayoral Primary
description: Former Representative Donald Fraser of Minnesota, the first casualty in the 1978 election collapse of the late Hubert H. Humphrey's DemocraticFarmerLabor coalition, ran away with the party's nomination for Mayor of Minneapolis on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Is Castigated on Oil Policy
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 12 (AP)  A top United States oil executive, in Bucharest for the world oil conference, charged today that a bunch of amateurs in the Carter Administration were threatening petroleum supplies with policies aimed at winning votes in the 1980 Presidential election.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: PASSION PLAY. by Jerzy Kosinshi. 271 pages. St. Martin's. $10.95.

title: U.S. Unperturbed by Comments
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Justice Department officials said today that they were neither surprised nor disturbed when two of the recently freed Puerto Rican nationalists said they could not rule out violence as part of their struggle to help Puerto Rico achieve independence.

title: Yastrzemski Gets 3,000th on Single
description: BOSTON, Sept. 12  Carl Yastrzemski, with an assist from Dwight Evans and his infield single, ended three nights of growing frustration tonight by grounding a single to right field off Jim Beattie with two out in the eighth inning for the 3,000th hit of his 19year ma for league career.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter appealed to 27 oil companies to hold prices heating oil at present levels, he told an assembly of retired people Hartford. He also said that he was planning a $2.9 billion program help lowincome families pay fuel bills and reassured them that oil supplies would be adequate this winter. [Page Al.]

title: Weizman Says Israel Seeks Doubling of Arms Aid
description: Defense Minister Ezer Weizman said today that Israel needed a virtual doubling of military aid from the United States to ward off threats from powerfully armed Arab nations to its north.

title: Bank Holdup Suspect Shot; 79 Robbery Total a Record
description: Two gunmen forced their way into a bank in Manhattan's financial district shortly before it was supposed to open yesterday morning. One of them, after duping his partner into staying behind to cover the bank manager and five employees, escaped with $183.230.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne announced yesterday that undercover agents would search out bartenders and packagestore clerks who sell alcoholic beverages to intoxicated persons. The Governor said the aim of the new program was to cut down on the number of drunken drivers in New Jersey.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Paramount and EMI Halt Music Venture

title: Expos 6, Cubs 3
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 12v (AP)  Tony Perez drove in two runs with an eighth, inning double in a rally that carried the Montreal Expos to a 63 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight. The Expos maintained their .0001 lead over the Pittsburgh Piratesin the National League East.

title: Bowker Is Distributing Guide to Australian Books
description: Australian Books in Print 1979, comprehensive guide to the Australian book publishing industry issued by D. W. Thorpe Pty. Ltd., is now available in the Western Hemisphere from the R. R. Bowker Company. The volume includes bibliographic information on all Australian titles in print, as well as information on Australian book and publishing organizations, awards and prizes.

title: Yastrzemski Joins An Elite Circle
description: Following is a list of players who have either 3,000 hits 400 home runs, or both. By getting his 3,000th hit last night, Carl Yastrzemski joined Henry Aaron, Stan Musial and Willie Mays as players who reached both mile. stones.

title: H.E.W. Inspector General Quits
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) Thomas D. Morris, the first inspector general of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, will resign at the end of the month, the department announced today.

title: Grammatikos Is Guilty of Running International DrugSmuggling Ring
description: John Grammatikos, accused by the Government of having headed the largest drugsmuggling ring between the Middle East and the United States, was found guilty in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday of charges that could lead to a sentence of life in prison.

title: Lie Test Raised Doubts in Vesco Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  The Justice Department began to doubt the grand jury testimony of a White House aide, Richard M. Harden, in a case involving Robert L. Vesco after Federal investigators concluded that a close friend of Mr. Harden had repeatedly lied to them, according to sources familiar with the case.

title: Notes on eople
description: In a new introduction to his 1962 book, Six Crises, Richard M. Nixon comes right out and says that history will justifiably record that his handling of the Watergate scandal was an unmitigated disaster.

title: New York Puerto Ricans Wary Over Independence
description: They spoke of the corruption of old customs, of women sitting by their fires cooking pasteles in aluminum foil instead of plantain leaf. They spoke of the paving over or the farm land, of the motels and race tracks where once there was sugar and coffee crops. They spoke of the demoralizing effects of the food stamp program, of men sitting in front of their houses with their big cigars, big glasses of beer.

title: The New York Times/Larry C. Morris
description: DESPAIR OF A LOSING SEASON: Joe Torre, the Mets manager, covering his face as his team went down to defeat against the Phi!lies, 40, at Shea Stadium last night. The loss was Mets 21st in last 25 games and the 19th in last 23 at home.

title: Nurse's Aide Accused Of Beating Patient, 91
description: A nurse's aide was charged yesterday with beating a 91yearold woman at a Queens nursing home Sunday night  an alleged assault, the police said, that nursing home officials had improperly failed to report.

title: White Sox 11, Angels 5
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP)  Jim Morrison drove in three runs with a single and sacrifice fly and Mike Colbern ripped a tworun triple to lead the.Chicago White Sox to an 115 victory over the California Angels tonight.

title: COMMODITIES
description: A steep and prolonged rally in silver futures was interrupted yesterday as silver fell along with other, precious. metals.

title: Piano: Ivan Davis at Y
description: IT was 20 years ago that Ivan Davis gave his first New York piano recital. To celebrate the anniversary, the Texasborn musician gave a concert last night at the 92nd Street Y. His program mixed the conventional and unconventional. Conventional were Beethoven's Waldstein Sonata and the two Schubert Klavierstiicke. Less conventional was Schumann's Faschingsschwank aus Wien, a wonderful work but one of his lessplayed. Closing the program was work that must have been a novelty to most listeners  Liszt's paraphrase on themes from Bellini's Norma.

title: Supplies of Heating Oil Show Big Rise in Week
description: Stocks of heating oil surged once again last week, rising 5.7 million barrels to 202.7 million, according to the weekly statistical report released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)  Ray Marshall, the Secretary of Labor, said today that the Carter Administration would act before the end of the week if no movement was made before then toward settling the twoweekold strike against the Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad.

title: News Summary
description: The mission of a Soviet brigade in Cuba was under intensive study by the Carter Administration. State Department officials said that one of various possibilities was that the troops might be training Cuban units for action in Africa. The theory suggested a possible modification in the Administration's previous emphasis that the Soviet brigade was strictly a combat force. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: Technology
description: Phillip H. Wiggins

title: San Francisco's Schools Are Shut for This Week
description: San Francisco's 59,000 students yesterday joined a million other pupils across the nation enjoying prolonged summer vacations because their teachers were on Wicket lines.

title: Vietnamese Says Baby Died as Soviet Ships Rejected Plea
description: SUBIC BAY NAVAL BASE, Sept. 13 Nguyen Van Tuoi held his dying baby up for the departing Soviet sailors to see and pleaded for help. But the sailors looked stonyfaced, he recalled today, and the dinghy on which they had ferried water, bread and fuel to the boatload of 29 Vietnamese refugees about 225 miles northeast of Camranh Bay cast off and returned to the three Soviet naval vessels that had come across the drifting fishing boat.

title: G.M. TALKS ADVANCE TO ECONOMIC ISSUES
description: DETROIT, Friday, Sept. 14  Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers, expressed guarded optimism late yesterday afternoon that the union and the General Motors Corporation could reach agreement on a new contract without a strike against the giant auto maker. The current pact, covering some 450,000 General Motors workers around the country, expires at midnight tonight.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Fashionconscious folks who want to see what they missed by being born century or two late will get the chance this weekend at the second annual fashion promenade at Philipsburg Manor, on Route 9 in North Tarrytown, N.Y. The clothing of men and women who lived in Westchester County in the 18th and 19th centuries will be modeled today at 2 and 8 P.M. by staff members of Sleepy Hollow Restorations. Garments and accessories of both the wealthy and the working class will be displayed, from a riding outfit to a wedding dress. Admission is $8 for the afternoon show and $10 for the evening. Information: (914) 6318200.

title: Dougherty, Sanudo Lead Buick Open by a Shot at 67
description: GRAND BLANC, Mich., Sept. 13 (AP)  Ed Dougherty waited out a 1hour8minute rain delay, then sank a 12foot birdie putt to earn a share of the firstround lead with Cesar Sanudo today in the $150.000 Buick open.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Committee on Economic Issues 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Golden Gate Leaper Survives
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 (AP) Ann McGuire, 25 years old, survived a leap from the Golden Gate Bridge yesterday and was listed in serious condition today after extensive surgery. She was was believed to be the 11th person to survive the 211foot plunge. She was found in the moat that encloses the base of the bridge's south tower, the authorities said.

title: Restaurants
description: Continental fare and a healthfood cafe.

title: Sales of Illegal Drugs in the City Are Found to Be Commonplace
description: As soon as the blue sedan doubleparked at 118th Street and Lenox Avenue, the driver honked his horn twice and waved a handful of bills out the window. A man who had been on the sidewalk took the cash in exchange for two small glassine envelopes that were apparently filled with heroin.

title: Airco Graphite Plant
description: TALLULAH, La., Sept. 13 (Reuters)  Airco Inc. said today that it planned to build a new graphite manufacturing plant here. The initial phase of the project will cost $150 million, it said. The plant, expected to be operating in 1982, will make premium graphite electrodes for the electric furnace steelmaking industry.

title: Spurs Send Green to Kings
description: SAN ANTONIO, Sept. 13 (AP)  The San Antonio Spurs sent Mike Green, a reserve center, to the Kansas City Kings today for a secondround draft choice and an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Survey Rates U.S. Most Creditworthy
description: The United States, for all of its political and economic problems, has drawn the highest credit rating of 93 countries measured on a scale of zero to 10 by 50 international banks. It received an overall score of 9.89. West Germany was rated second at 9.83. The next three countries were Switzerland, 9.82; Japan, 9.69, and Canada, 9.35.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (Television  Cablevision, 8 P.M. Radio WINS, 8 P.M.)

description: Federal funds rate:

title: Blaze Evokes Memories in Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 13  After the workers had been removed and the fire in City Hall was under control yesterday, Paul J. Byrne, the city's economic development director, and Deputy Police Chief Edward Russ were placing tax records and cash from the tax collector's office in the trunk of a police car. An elderly woman was watching carefully.

title: West 84th St. Honors Poe Again Tomorrow
description: For the eighth time in eight years, in a tradition that could go on forever more, there will be an Edgar Allan Poe Festival tomorrow from 11 A.M. to P.M. on West 84th Street, between Broadway and Riverside Drive. It is sponsored by the West 84th Street Block Association to honor a former resident of the block.

title: Strauss Sees Gain for Peace
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 13 (AP)  Robert S. Strauss, the special American envoy to the Middle East, said today on ending a fourday mission to Egypt and Israel that he had progressed from a feeling of hope and optimism to one of certainty and inevitability that our search for peace will be successful.

title: Guilty Plea in Newark Killing
description: NEWARK, Sept. 13 (AP)  Felix Rodriguez, 32 years old, the man accused of shooting to death Essex County Patrolman Joseph Pocchio on Aug. 4, pleaded guilty to the murder charge in Superior Court here yesterday.

title: Atlantic Richfield In Pact to Sell Gas
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company announced that five companies had agreed to purchase all of its natural gas production from Prudhoe Bay, Alaska, the site of the company's major oil discovery in 1968.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, Sept. 13 SAGAFJORD (Norwegian America Line). Lett Southampton Sept. 6; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: A Dialogue Between The Music of Two Indias
description: Ali Akbar Khan gave a concert at the Museum of Modern Art in 1955 that must be counted as one of the crucial events in introducing Indian music to North America. His brotherinlaw Ravi Shankar made his own American debut a year later, and by that time Ali Akbar Khan had made the first album of Indian classical music for an American label (Angel) and brought the music to national television as a guest on Alistair Cooke's Omnibus. The impact these two musicians have had on a broad spectrum of American music in the last 25 years has never been fully documented, but between them, they have managed to touch musicians working in almost every idiom, from classical composers to music for the Broadway stage to jazz and rock.

title: High Tides Spread Oil Pollution
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Sept. 13 (UPI)  High tides generated by the hurricane washed tar balls from a runaway Mexican offshore oil well all the way to the sand dunes on some parts of Padre Island, 40 to 60 feet farther ashore than before. Roger Meacham, a spokesman for the Environmental Protection Agency, said that since the storm, currents and winds had kept oil away from the beaches, and added: Mother nature seems to be doing a good job of natural cleaning.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Yugoslavia Completes 50 Sweep
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 13 (AP)  Yugoslavia won both singles matches today, concluding a 50 victory over Portugal and advancing to the third round of the European Zone B Davis Cup tournament. Zoltan Ili defeated Jose Cardeira, 61, 60, 62, and Marko Ostoja beat Jose Vilela, 26, 75, 64, 46, 75.

title: Carter and Senators Firm in Dispute on Military Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  President Carter and militaryminded Senators discussed future arms spending today but failed to resolve a disagreement over budget increases that could eventually determine the fate of the proposed treaty to limit strategic arms that is now before the Senate.

title: Kuwait Oil Output
description: KUWAIT, Sept. 13 (Reuters)  Kuwait's Oil Minister, All Khalifa alSabah, has said that Kuwait will maintain 1979 crude oil production at an average rate of two million barrels day, the weekly magazine alHadaf reported. Kuwait oil production in 1978 averaged 2.1 million barrels a day.

title: Early SpaceAge Christmas in a Toy Universe
description: It doesn't look like Christmas, not on earth anyway, but Gimbels says it is. What's more, it's going to stay Christmas in the sixthfloor toy department, renamed Toy Universe, throughout September, October, November, December and January.

title: The City
description: Negotiators for Bronx apartmenthouse owners and their employees are scheduled to meet with the state mediator, John J. Kreidler, tomorrow in an effort to avert a weekend strike that could affect service for 750,000 residents.

title: This Article Contains a Mixture of Choice Turkish and Domestic Blends
description: SYRACUSE  Look at you  a doctor  smoking! is a remark directed at me with such monotonous regularity that it has required me to formulate a satisfactory response to all those seemingly healthconscious but uninformed individuals who appear to be multiplying in numbers more rapidly than rabbits in a confined area.

description: AMF Inc., producer of leisure and industrial products, has named John M. Gentner president of its AMF Wyott Inc. subsidiary, which manufactures foodservice equipment.

description: How many times have the backers of development projects complained that environmentalists use every legal and political trick possible to kill a project? Well, now it turns out that the environmentalists could learn a trick or two from backers of the Tellico Dam in Tennessee. That illconceived porkbarrel project has just been revived by Congress and now only President Carter can block it.

description: 1. Holt, Rinehart & Winston: New York City theme.

title: Spanish Premier Welcomes Arafat As P.L.O. Widens European Links
description: MADRID, Sept. 13  Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, met here today with Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez here today. It was the first time that a West European leader acting in his role as head of government had received the guerrilla chief.

title: It Was Givenchy's Hour Again
description: He's as tall as the late Charles de Gaulle and as distinguished looking, now that his hair has whitened, as Cary Grant: Hubert de Givenchy is the prevailing classicist of the French couture, and it was easy to see why, when he presented his fall collection at Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday morning.

title: ABC OUTBIDS MATTEL FOR MACMILLAN INC.
description: The American Broadcasting Companies made a surprise bid for Macmillan Inc. yesterday, upsetting a merger agreement Macmillan had reached just two weeks ago with Mattel Inc., the toy company that built its fortune on Barbie Dolls.

title: Peking Rally Hints at New Surge of Dissident Activity
description: PEKING, Sept. 13  Several thousand people gathered in Tian An Men Square today to hear speeches denouncing special privileges among Communist Party officials and calling for more human rights in China.

title: Inquiry Asked in Freeing Of Four Puerto Rican
description: The possibility that the four Puerto Rican nationalists freed by President Carter last week might engage in violence to further the cause of independence has prompted a nationwide law enforcement officers organization to call for a Congressional investigation into the grant of clemency.

title: For Some Theater People, Home Is LowCost Luxury
description: I am elated, elated no end  I just hope they don't pull it out from under us, said Minnie Gentry, an actress, as she sipped a drink in Manhattan Plaza's lounge  modeled after the Algonquin Hotel's  and looked out the picture window at other tenants frolicking in the project's Olympicsize swimming pool.

title: Education Board Assents to Edict On Sale of Bonds
description: School board officials in New Jersey's Upper Freehold Regional School District said yesterday that they were proceeding to comply with an order by the State Education Commissioner to sell more than $1.6 million in bonds to repair a school roof but that, at the same time, they were not ruling out the possibility of an appeal.

title: Drama: Dance for Me Simeon
description: THERE'S an attractive central image asserting itself in Joseph Maher's Dance for Me Simeon, one of the 16 plays by new writers scheduled to fill  sooner or later  the various small theaters that are beehived into a converted courthouse called the American Theater for Actors, on West 54th Street.

title: Tax Cuts for Inflationary Times
description: New tax cuts are now all but inevitable. They are being proposed by conservatives and soon will be by liberals. The Administration's official waitandsee attitude will not long withstand the chill of this fall's increasing unemployment. Tax cuts could moderate that chill before the 1980 elections. If well designed, they could also lift from taxpayers the extra burden of inflation. So how should such cuts be designed?

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., which last week announced an oil well discovery in the Beaufort Sea in Canada, reported yesterday that although the upper portion of the well gave indications of gas, the producing rates were not commercial.

title: Alcan to Replace Plant
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 13 (Reuters) Alcan Smelters and Chemicals Ltd., a subsidiary of Alcan Aluminium Ltd., said that it plans to replace its carbonpaste plant in Kitimat, British Columbia, starting next spring at a cost estimated at almost $40 million.

title: Film: 'Love and Bullets' Stars Charles Bronson:Bringing Home the Moll
description: "WITH this scum, you gotta take the law into your own hands. You don't just book these guys, you kill 'em." That's a line of dialogue from "Love and Bullets," the new Charles Bronson movie, and it bears the unmistakable paw print of Wendell Mayes, who also wrote "Death Wish." However, this time there's a twist: Mr. Bronson doesn't speak that line, nor does he even endorse its sentiments very strongly.Mr. Bronson plays a police detective who's sent from Arizona to Switzerland to bring back a gangster's moll. And since the moll is played by Jill Ireland, who is Mrs. Bronson, a bit of moderation is called for. So Mr. Bronson does not even begin blowing people up, or puncturing them with a homemade blowgun, until the movie is nearly over. Instead, he spends most of his time escorting Miss Ireland onto trains, into hotels and across the snow.This is all very chivalrous, but it's also dull. The British-born Miss Ireland has no luck in affecting a hillbilly accent, and as a comic presence she's simply not there. However, she and Mr. Bronson approach each other with an appealing ease, which would be more appealing if it were not the movie's only selling point. Mr. Bronson grows ever more coolly dependable with each new film, but "Love and Bullets" is too clumsy to show him off to much advantage.Stuart Rosenberg, who directed "The Amityville Horror" as well as "Love and Bullets," is one of the great wonders of the movie world. Mr. Rosenberg has had a long and successful career, and yet he still pays little heed to the most basic tricks of the trade, like establishing clear time sequences or letting the viewer know on which continent the action is taking place or even keeping his actors' faces out of the shadows. The Swiss scenery for "Love and Bullets" involves a lot of bright, snowy outdoor shots in which Mr. Bronson and Miss Ireland virtually disappear.Another of Mr. Rosenberg's trademarks is his way of keeping his extras just busy enough to distract attention from the principals. You may not be sure where Mr. Bronson and Miss Ireland are going on any particular leg of their journey, but you can't help noticing who else is on the train."Love and Bullets," which opens today at the Rivoli, also features Rod Steiger as a godfather with a very large mansion and a stammer. His performance, which could seem restrained only in comparison with his "Amityville Horror" turn, would have been quite overwrought enough without the speech defect."Love and Bullets" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains some violent episodes and a relatively tasteful shot of a nude corpse.

title: SALVADORAN REGIME PRESSED ON REFORM
description: SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 13  In an atmosphere of mounting violence, moderate business, political and church groups are pressing El Salvador's rightwing military regime to carry out sweeping economic and political reforms.

title: EPISCOPALIANS VIEW HOMOSEXUALS ROLE
description: DENVER, Sept. 13  The Episcopal Church began hearings last night on the issue of ordaining homosexual priests with a lowkey, at times humorous, forum that was in sharp contrast to the bitter debates that have divided the 2.8 million church members in the past.

title: Watson Unavailable For Ryder Cup Golf
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 13  The 23d biennial Ryder Cup matches between the United States and European golf professionals got off today with a rousing prelude of camaraderie and international good will, but without the Americans top player, Special to The New York Times The occasion was a flagraising ceremony that emphasized friendship, which is the point of the Ryder Cup matches that begin tomorrow morning and continue through Sunday afternoon. They are held every oddnumbered year, alternating between British and American courses. The most significant innovation this year was the expansion of the traditionally British and Irish team to include players from continental Europe.

title: Regency Dips Into Vintage British Films
description: If Alex were alive, said Michael Korda, he'd be delighted to have all these pictures replayed. He always said they were like his grandchildren. They'd go on forever. Michael Korda is the editor in chief of the publishing house of Simon & Schuster. Alex is his Uncle Alex  the late Sir Alexander Korda, a cynosure of the 13week, 60film series opening Sunday at the Regency Theater on Broadway between 67th and 68th Streets.

title: Carter to View the Damage
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  President Carter will go to the Gulf Coast tomorrow Special to The New York Times to inspect the hurricane damage, the White House announced today. The President plans to tour Mobile, then board a helicopter for an aerial inspection, ending the tour in Pensacola, Fla.

title: HispanicAmericans Are Named To Top Navy and Protocol Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, D.C., Sept. 13 President Carter appointed HispanicAmericans as Secretary of the Navy and United States Chief of Protocol today and described them as two superb new leaders. It was the first time HispanicAmericans had held the positions.

title: Macmillan Tradition Grew Beyond Books
description: Macmillan Inc, which received takeover offer yesterday from the American Broadcasting Companies, is one of the great names in book publishing on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Ship Survives MastHigh Waves
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 13 (UPI)  A freighter disabled in the Gulf of Mexico with 16 crewmen survived hurricanepropelled waves as high as the mast, according to a radio message from its captain. A Coast Guard spokesman said that meant that the waves could have been as high as 90 feet. The 230foot Mary's Ketch, registered in Britain and with a home port of Grand Cayman Island, was being towed to Tampa today.

title: Events and Openings
description: RUN AFTER ME UNTIL I CATCH YOU, a French comedy directed by Robert Pouret; starring Annie Girardot and JeanPierre MarieIle, at the Eastside Cinema.

title: United Press international
description: OH YEAH? YEAH!: Bobby Cox, manager of the Braves, and Umpire Ed Montague having a difference of opinion on a balk call against Phil Niekro, Braves pitcher, yesterday at San Francisco. Montague's opinion prevailed, but Atlanta won, 41.

title: BeatIhs
description: BACONJohn F. on Sept. 7, 1979, beloved brother of James and the late Edward M. and Mary Bacon. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 3rd Ave. & 85 St. NYC. Religious service Saturday, 10:45 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: San Gennaro Is On All Weekend
description: The 53d annual San Gennaro festival began last night, and the streets of Little Italy are alive and celebrating, with merrymakers and compulsive nibblers joining in to help the devout honor the patron saint of Naples. For the next 10 days, some 300 stalls, offering sausages and peppers, onions, clams, sfogliatelli and other succulent fare, will line Mulberry Street from Park Row to Houston Street, and side streets all along the route in what the Societa San Gennaro calls A festa e tutte e ffeste  Neapolitan for The Festival of All Festivals.

title: Jackson Says U.S. Seeks Deal With Soviet on Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that he believed the Carter Administration was trying to work out with the Soviet Union some rationalization for resolving the problem of a Soviet brigade in Cuba without forcing its removal.

title: Advice to Kennedy, Other Candidates: Avoid Political Macho
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  On Cape Cod last month and in the Berkshires, Senator Edward M. Kennedy romped and relaxed with his family, in what may be the last private moments that he will enjoy for many years.

title: Auctions
description: FOLLOWING the fall of the Shah's government last January, leading Iranian buyers of Oriental rugs withdrew from the market. As a result, the prices for certain types of rugs plummeted, many others found no buyers, and the 10year boom in Orientals from the 16th through the early 20th centuries appeared to have reached a plateau. Since then, auctions of Persian, Turkoman and Caucasian rugs have tested the market and found the response tentative, lacking the fireworks so characteristic of these sales in recent years. Nevertheless all of the major artauction houses intend to continue holding such sales.

title: U.S. Refuses Recognition
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)  The State Department said today that the United States would not recognize Venda.

title: For Children
description: Bird Show Theater WILDLIFE THEATER BIRD SHOW, with seven parrots, including Cookie, a white, sulphurcrested cockatoo and two macaws, who will perform at 11 A.M., 12:30, 2, 3:30 and 4:30 P.M., at the Zoological Park, the Bronx Zoo, Southern Boulevard and 185th Street. Zoo admission: children, 75 cents; adults, $1.50, Friday through Monday. Parking, S2. Call 2205100.

title: IllegalDrug Costs on the Street
description: Federal officials believe that about $8 billion will be spent on illegal purchases of cocaine, heroin, marijuana and hashish in the New York metropolitan area this year.

title: Topics
description: The sale of Howard Johnson's to a British conglomerate has quickly aroused a variety of concerns, including fears of ghastly British food along highways of the New World. Piffle. With any luck at all, the change of hands may raise culinary standards in both countries. New management could certainly improve the food in a famous, if tired, chain of restaurants. And if a British item or two is added to the menu, why expect the worst? For all we know, we may soon be eating superb roast beef, great marmalades and even steakandoyster pudding.

title: Star Attraction Gets New Home
description: The largest meteorite in captivity was put its final resting place yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Norwalk Celebrates An Oyster Festival
description: The Norwalk Seaport Association celebrates it second annual oyster festival this weekend, but although oysters will be in plentiful supply, don't be misled by the title. Everything from kielbasa to tacos is also on the menu, along with musical performances, boat races, fireworks, an art show and a mock revolutionary war battle. The festival is supposed to remind residents of the town's nautical heritage, but the organizers have stretched the maritime theme far enough to include a wide variety of attractions in addition to nautical displays.

title: A Call From Jimmy
description: In Boston somebody said Carl Yastrzemski had made his first hit when John F. Kennedy was President and might not make his 3,000th until Teddy was. However, after a delay that was beginning to make everyone's teeth hurt, Yaz did the deed in time to be congratulated by President Carter. Give me a number, a member of the White House staff had said several days ago to Bill Crowley, the Red Sox vice president for public relations, and we'll call within 20 minutes after the game ends. I can't keep the Boston press waiting 20 minutes, Crawley had said. They're more important to me than you are.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: BUSINESS Digest

title: Satmar Hasidim Appoint Leader
description: Rabbi Moses Teitelbaum has been selected as the leader of the Satmar Hasidim group of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, succeeding his uncle, Rabbi Joel Teitelbaum, who died last month at the aRe of 93.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)  A Federal district judge ruled today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had legally seized thousands of documents from the Church of Scientology's Los Angeles office, records that allegedly described the group's infiltration of Government offices.

title: New Face: Trini Alvarado
description: 12 Years Old, Beguiling And a PartTime Actress

title: New Faces: Susan Orem and Steve Liebman
description: A Soubrette and a Top Banana ELSEWHERE burlesque may be a thing of the past, but not in New York this season. In its latest incarnation, good oldfashioned burlesque has taken up residence at the Orpheum Theater where Susan Orem and Steve Liebman are having a highspirited time of it, starring in Big Bad Burlesque. For both of them, this show represents a turning point in their livesand given the exuberance and comic flair that have won each of them glowing reviews, it seems clear that the direction from here on is likely to be upward.

title: Demic Gives Knicks Badly Needed Power
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 13  Larry Demic leaped high, grabbed the ball off the defensive boards and muscled Ron Behagen, another power forward, out of the play.

title: G.&W. Has Talks With Paint Maker
description: Gulf and Western Industries Inc. said it had held some highly preliminary discussions concerning the exchange of its shares in the SherwinWilliams Company, the paint maker, for certain assets of SherwinWilliams.

title: Senate Unit Approves $29.2 Million Project At Old Custom House
description: A United States Senate panel voted yesterday in Washington to spend $29.2 million to renovate the old Custom House on Manhattan's Bowling Green and use it as a Federal office buildine.

title: 2 Streams of American Art at the Whitney
description: THE Whitney Museum of American Art has never been famous for its masterpieces. From the time of its founding in 1930, the Whitney's policy has been to gather examples of American art in great heaps, leaving the task of sorting and selection to another day. The result is a copious and very varied permanent collection, which, depending on the viewpoint of the curator in charge, can be made to illustrate almost any arthistorical scenario.

title: G.M. Plans Debut Of Chevette in Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 13 (AP)  The General Motors Corporation plans to introduce its subcompact Chevette to Japan near the end of the year, competing directly with Japanese car makers on their own territory, a company official said today.

title: Broadway
description: THE producers of Whose Life Is It Anyway? can't find an actor to replace Tom Conti, who is leaving the show Oct. 27. So, in an 11thhour attempt to keep the play running, they have offered the part to an actress.

title: Jazz: Carmen McRae
description: CARMEN McRAE has developed a personal, idiomatic style as a singer by mixing elements of jazzsinging with elements of cabaretsinging and honing the resultant blend down to a very lean, economical use of her material. It is a style that, largely because of its barebones quality and her rather astringent manner of delivering a line, can sometimes seem chilly and impersonal. But, at the Village Gate, where she is appearing through Sunday, Miss McRae has everything in balance  her material, her approach and her delivery  and she creates an atmosphere that is warm, appealing and communicative.

title: Economic Scene
description: WHAT sort of syntheticfuel program should the United States Government promote and subsidize to reduce dependence on foreign oil?

title: Jazz Trade Haywood For Lakers Dantley
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 13 (AP) The Utah Jazz traded Spencer Haywood, a forward, to the Los Angeles Lakers today for Adrian Dantley.

title: U.S. to Back Coal Projects
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)  The Energy Department said it had decided to continue two demonstration projects for converting highsulfur coal into cleanburning fuels through a solventrefining process. The agency said it had decided to request $85 million from Congress for both projects in its 1980 annual budget, rather than waiting for revenues from the proposed windfall oilprofits tax for the second.

title: Screen: Truffaut's 'The Green Room':High Priest of Death
description: WHEN we first meet Julien Davenne (Franois Truffaut) in Mr. Truffaut's rigorous new film, "The Green Room," Davenne comes as grief's practitioner, not to comfort a friend whose wife has died but to introduce him to the land of the dead.Julien understands his friend's loss and his fury when the priest attempts to console him with clichs about original sin, about death's being the daughter of that sin, and about resurrection. When the friend goes berserk with grief, Julien turns on the priest with contempt. "We don't need platitudes," he says in effect. "We want you to say, 'Stand up and walk.'"Julien knows what he's talking about. His own wife, Julie, died 10 years before, just after they were married at the end of World War I. As he survived the war without a scratch and is obsessed by the memory of fallen comrades, Julien to all outward appearances has survived the loss of Julie but he now devotes himself to her memory. He keeps a room in his house as a shrine to her. He surrounds himself with reminders of the dead and wounded. His housekeeper is ancient, not too far from the great divide. Her adopted son, a little boy named Georges, cannot speak.Julien works for a provincial weekly newspaper, whose subscribers are dying off and which is so far out of things that most people think it has already ceased publishing. Julien's specialty is, obviously, writing obituaries. Julien's love for Julie  so fixed that it denies any possibility of change  is itself a kind of antilove. It's not hatred, certainly, but it's dead.With the scary illogic of the fanatic, Julien says, "The dead belong to us, as soon as we agree to belong to them."Among other things, "The Green Room," which opens today at the Sutton Theater, reminds us of the profound darkness that seems to exist just beyond the lighted area of all Truffaut films  the comedies such as "Stolen Kisses" and "Day for Night" as well as "Jules and Jim" and "The Wild Child."Like "The Story of Adle H.," which is also about an obsession, "The Green Room" is a very romantic movie but less sentimental than a timetable. Quite consciously Mr. Truffaut keeps us one step removed from the grief of Julien Davenne so that, though we appreciate and believe it, we never identify with it and are never moved to conventional pity. We are forever separated from the pain on the screen, much as we are removed from the face of Julien that we see in one especially extraordinary shot  the features distorted by the rippled glass of a door. It's the face of one of those tormented Edvard Munch creatures, just after the scream of terror.Julien's obsession, which begins with the loss of his wife, eventually branches out to include all of the dead who were once important to him. As long as they are remembered they remain alive, he says. To this end he endows and maintains a chapel, filled with candles ("a forest of flame") to the memory not only Julie but of childhood companions, of people like Oscar Wilde, Henry James and all sorts of others, including an unnamed German soldier whose photograph is that of Oscar Werner, the Jules of "Jules and Jim."His companion in this mission is a pretty young woman named Cecilia (Nathalie Baye), who has also suffered a great personal loss. Cecilia, however, refuses to play "the dead against the living," as Julien does, and thus acknowledges her love for Julien. This is, of course, impossible for a priest of death to recognize.Like "The Altar of the Dead," the Henry James short story on which Mr. Truffaut and Jean Gruault have partly based their screenplay, "The Green Room" is sometimes as maddeningly vague and ambiguous in its details as it is resolutely detached from its own feelings.There is an important plot revelation about halfway through the film, which supposedly explains why Davenne has withdrawn from life (it has to do with the unexplained duplicity of a best friend), but if this is true, it seems to betray the enormity of the grief we have been given to understand Davenne felt at the loss of his wife.The movie is extremely beautiful to look at, and the colors reflect the mind of Davenne, much as the slow, lingering dissolves do. But there are shocks, too. In that opening sequence in which Davenne goes to his newly bereaved friend, something most peculiar seems to be afoot when we at last see the body of the wife in the coffin. She has the pouty, dimpled, dyed-blond prettiness of a victim in a 1940's Dracula movie.Mr. Truffaut does not make it easy for us to respond to Davenne, as when Davenne amuses the boy with slides showing the dismembered and decapitated victims of the war. "I claim the right not to forget," Davenne says at one point, and his claim overrides the claims of everyone else.There is also the unsettling (in this case) spectacle of the director being his own star, focusing his camera more tightly and more demandingly on his own face than ever did Chaplin, Keaton and Welles. The Truffaut face is actually most expressive at its most inert, but is he so detatched that he can see in it what we do? I'm not sure.Miss Baye is a lovely, very substantial woman, and her presense gives "The Green Room" an anchor in reality, as does the photography of Nestor Almendros. It's a movie full of rusts and deep greens, the shades of autumn and winter, of a feeling of dampness and cold drafts in rooms that are probably overheated."The Green Room" is not a movie you'll easily forget. It is a most demanding, original work and one must meet it on its own terms, without expectations of casual pleasures."The Green Room," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), is about a subject that is probably beyond the reach of most children but contains nothing in the way of sex, violence or vulgar language that would otherwise merit the PG rating.

title: Withdrawal Symptoms In RobberyProne City
description: Just in time yesterday, the police swarmed into the bank with guns drawn and collared a man they thought was yet another robber in the latest wave of bank holdups in the city.

title: Screen: 'Run After Me':Jokes About Dogs
description: YOU needn't actually have watched "Run After Me  Until I Catch You!" to feel that somehow, somewhere, you've seen this movie before. A lonely, middle-aged woman meets a lonely, middle-aged man, and after some initial fumbling, love blooms: so far, so familiar. Then they fight: familiar too. Finally, they take a country vacation and go bicycling past the wildflowers and jogging across the bosky terrain. If you haven't seen this sort of interlude elsewhere, you simply haven't been to the movies in years. This isn't the picture to bring you back again, either.There's nothing unpleasant about "Run After Me  Until I Catch You!" which opens at the Eastside Cinema today. But there's nothing unexpectedly appealing about it, either. Annie Girardot and Jean-Pierre Marielle are suitably likable as the lovers, and each has been given the obligatory cute quirk. He's a tax inspector, so he has an office full of funny citizens trying to cheat the French Government in funny ways. She grooms pets, so she works in a shop full of funny dogs. The shop is run by Marilu Tolo, whose appearance is brief but eye catching, partly because she's gorgeous and partly because of her surroundings. You'd look good next to a wet poodle, too.Mr. Marielle, who also has a fussy house-husband manner and a loutish son, bumbles sweetly. Miss Girardot is sterner, but eventually she reveals a generous, yielding nature and brings Mr. Marielle breakfast in bed. Both players have an easier time being amorous than being funny, perhaps because many of the film's comic situations have the strenuously wacky feeling of television humor.There is the time when Mr. Marielle is locked into his office and finally climbs out through a ceiling duct, while Miss Girardot thinks he has forgotten they had a date, for instance. Or the time one of his tax dodgers tries to make up a debt with two tons of cabbage. There's even the time Miss Girardot is left with five extra dogs at the end of a day and brings them to Mr. Marielle's house for dinner. Throughout the story, dog jokes abound.

title: Lee Goerner, Editor, Wins Godwin Award
