description: Lee Goerner, a 32yearold assistant editor at Alfred A. Knopf, is this year's winner of the Tony Godwin Memorial Award. It is presented to an outstanding young editor from Britain or the United States and includes a stipend to work in a publishing house on either side of the Atlantic Ocean for six weeks. He plans to work for the British paperback house Pan Books next spring.

title: Cuban Bunion. American Hotfoot
description: The longer the controversy continues over 3,000 Soviet combat troops in Cuba, the clearer it becomes that the chief damage the United States may suffer would be selfinflicted. American security would be substantially diminished, not enhanced, if the SALT treaty is killed in the effort to force withdrawal of the Russian brigade, even if the effort succeeded. It would be like trading a nuclear bomb for a hand grenade.

title: Bridge:
description: A Raconteur Recalls Game He Played Well as Dummy Following an idea tried in Washington, the NassauSuffolk Bridge Association will honor a longtime director this weekend. At Ade1phi University, Garden City, L.I., Harry Goldwater will be a player instead of the director, his customary role for more than 30 years.

title: F.C.C. Acts On UHF Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  The Federal Communications Commission, recognizing the growing economic health of ultrahighfrequency television stations, proposed today to toughen its rules against common ownership of radio and UHF stations.

title: Schoolboy Openers in Peril
description: A lingering strike threat by game officials left uncertainty yesterday as to whether the Public Schools Athletic League's opening games of the football season. scheduled for tomorrow, could actually be played.

title: Rebel Smith Finds Unexpected Welcome in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 13 When Britain was at the height of its imperial power, a man with Ian D. Smith's record of rebellion against the crown could have hoped for little here but incarceration in the Tower of London and trial on charges of high treason, one of two crimes that still carry the death penalty under British law.

title: 3,000 Policemen Attend Rites for Slain City Officer
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., Sept. 13  Nearly 3,000 police officers, some from as far away as Monticello, N.Y., lined the streets of this Rockland County community today to pay their respects to Police Officer Edwin A. Fogel of New York City, who was killed Sunday during an exchange of gunfire with a man on the Harlem River Drive.

title: Professor Says Femininity May Block Career Success
description: A woman whose manner and attire epitomize femininity theorized to a group of prominent career women Wednesday that as long as women strive to hold on to the traditional feminine virtues, they will remain bound to all the other traditions they are trying to leave behind.

title: Giants to Give Taylor the Ball
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 13  The Giants ground game seems to have gone underground. Their longest run of the season has been 9 yards. Their average gain per rush is 2.3 yards. Of the 27 other teams in the National Football League, 27 have gained more yards rushing.

title: Foe of Federal TV Rules Vows New House Fight
description: Representative Lionel Van Deerlin, Democrat of California, declared yesterday his intention to continue to work for a new national communications policy despite the abandonment of his widely publicized bill for a radical revision of the Communications Act of 1934.

title: Brown Says Kennedy Race in '80 Could Help the Democratic Party
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. said today that he considered 1980 a watershed year when the Democratic Party must reconstitute itself and that he believed the party would be better if Senator Edward M. Kennedy declared his candidacy for President.

title: Election Panel Audits Of Campaign Outlays Are Termed Too Slow
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)  The Federal Election Commission came under heavy criticism today from an outside auditing company that said the commission had failed to determine in a timely manner whether candidates were violating campaign laws.

title: United Airlines Fare Move
description: United Airlines said yesterday that had informed the Civil Aeronautics Board of plans to drop, effective Oct. the special oneway fares of $139 and $199 between New York and Los Angeles and San Francisco. Earlier this month, United had raised the fares from $108 and reduced the seats available to discount passengers. The airline said the fares were being abandoned in favor of the Super Saver fares, which are not discounted as deeply and carry more restrictions.

title: Colgate Again Planning Helena Rubinstein Sale
description: The ColgatePalmolive Company, which bought the Helena Rubinstein cosmetics business for $146 million in stock only six years ago, announced yesterday that it was negotiating to sell the company to L'Oreal S.A. of Paris, cosmetics giant, and L'Oreal's licensee in the United States, Cosmair Inc.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Federal Reserve
description: Wednesday, Sept. 12, 1979

title: Texaco Denies U.S. Price Role
description: Texaco Inc. denied yesterday that David Bardin, a high official of the Department of Energy, had pushed the company into announcing a program to hold the line on heating oil prices and to liberalize credit terms for the fuel.

title: Plane With 31 Aboard Goes Down in Sardinia
description: CAGLIARI, Sardinia, Friday, Sept. 19 (Reuters)  An Italian airliner with 31 people on board crashed into mountains last night near this Sardinian city, ANSA, the Italian news agency, reported.

title: WASHINGTON Carter And Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  For the last few weeks, the news here has been dominated not by the major issues of public policy but by political characters who know how to use the instruments of public information for their own personal advantage.

title: Tests Show Drop In Math Ability Of U.S. Students
description: The mathematics achievement of students in the nation's elementary and secondary schools, particularly the ability to apply knowledge to prnblemsolving, has declined in the 1970's, a federally financed study has found.

title: View From Assembly Line in a G.M. Plant
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13  Reginald Peters works in a noisy place that is often hot and has the odor, the feeling, of grease and machines  an automobile plant. Automobile bodies, hauled by a chain device on the floor, pass him once every 1.15 minutes, 52 every hour, 416 every day. Mr. Peters is that mythic Detroit man, the American legend, the assembly line worker.

title: Joel Sayre, Correspondent, Novelist and Screenwriter
description: Joel Sayre, the swashbuckling reporter and war correspondent who was the chief script writer for Gunga Din, died of heart failure Sunday in Taftsville, Vt., where he lived. He was 78 years old.

title: Rio Algom Uranium Suit
description: TORONTO, Sept. 13 (Reuters)  Rio Algom Ltd. said that it had started an action in the Supreme Court of Ontario against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the Tennessee Valley Authority over Rio Algom's contract to supply 17 million pounds of uranium to the T.V.A. It said that the claim sought damages of $1.6 billion.

title: Guidry Posts 11th Straight Victory
description: BOSTON, Sept. 13  While Carl Yastrzemski paused from the hectic political pace in which his 3,000th hit had immersed him, Ron Guidry snatched a bit of attention tonight by gaining his 11th consecutive victory.

title: Ousted Banker Gets Imperial Post
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 (AP) Alvin Rice, ousted in August 1978 as vice chairman of the Bank of America, announced that he was joining Imperial Bank, California's 19th largest, as its new president.

title: Spartans Kelser Is Signed To Record Pact by Pistons
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Sept. 13 (UPI) Greg Keiser, the star forward from Michigan State University, today signed a contract that a spokesman for Detroit of the National Basketball Association described as the richest ever given a Piston rookie.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: David T. Kimball, 52 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the General Signal Corporation of Stamford, Conn., effective Jan. 1, 1980. He will succeed Harold A. Strickland Jr., who will retire shortly before his 65th birthday. Nathan R. Owen, 60, continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Fifth Ave. Is a Midway For Carnival Of Books
description: SHAKESPEARE connoisseurs can meet the Bard of Avon at last. History buffs can hear medieval lute music. Mystery fans can have themselves fingerprinted like the malefactors in a Raymond Chandler novel. All kinds of readers will find their tastes catered to at a virtually encyclopedic outdoor book fair, the country's Fifth Ave. Is a Midway For Carnival Of Books largest in recent memory, which will unfold Sunday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. along Fifth Avenue from 47th to 57th Street.

title: Business and the Law
description: TWICE a day, the Concorde flies between New York and London, and most people on those flights are carrying briefcases. Many of those bags belong to lawyers, whose clients figure the $1,888 roundtrip fare is a bargain, given the fact they are being charged $150, $200, $250 or more an hour for the services of their lawyers. In a profession where time is money, the added expense of the Concorde is more than made up for by the time saved in the crossing.

title: Japan Business Mission to U.S.
description: TOKYO, Sept. 13 (AP)  A 46member Japanese business mission will leave for the United States next month to explore investment opportunities.

title: A Record $3.2 Million Is Pledged by Bantam For New Krantz Novel
description: For a record advance of $3,208,875, Bantam Books Wednesday night purchased the rights to publish in March 1981 the paperback edition of Princess Daisy. The book Is the recently completed second novel by Judith Krantz, author of the bestselline Scruples.

title: News Summary
description: The P.L.O. gained recognition, which it has been seeking along with respectability, in Western Europe. Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, arrived in Madrid and met with Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez. It was the first time that a West European leader, acting as head of government, had received the guerrilla chief. [Page A6, Columns 34.]

title: Appeals Court Hears Disputants On Magazine's HBomb Article
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13  An attorney for the Government said today that the case of The Progressive magazine, which is under court order not to publish an article on the hydrogen bomb, was unlike any previous case involving prior restraint of publication because legislation specifically forbids disclosure of the kind of information in The Progressive article.

title: Jets Are Blacked Out On Local Television
description: A rare opportunity for metropolitanarea fans to watch a pro football game on a Sunday afternoon involving neither the Giants nor the Jets will come this Sunday in doubleheader fashion. Beginning at 1 P.M., Channel 4 will televise Denver at Atlanta and Channel 2 will follow with Chicago at Dallas.

title: U.S. Arrests 13 In JaiAlai Plot To Avoid Taxes
description: STAMFORD, Conn. Sept. 13  Joining a growing investigation of the multimilliondollar jai alai industry, Federal officials today arrested 13 bettors and cashiers at the jai alai fronton in Hartford on charges of incometax violations related to trifecta betting.

title: In a Diplomatic Corner
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  The Carter Administration, in the opinion of informed officials, may have painted itself into a diplomatic corner in the way it disclosed the existence of a Soviet brigade in Cuba and then insisted that it had a combat role.

title: Texas Airline Stake in T.W.A.
description: Texas International Airlines announced yesterday that it had bought stock in the Trans World Corporation, the parent of Trans World Airlines, and that it had discussed with Trans World's chairman the possibility of acquiring the airline.

title: Kennedy Says That Leadership, Not Economic Policy, Is at Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who has linked. his Presidential intentions to the condition of the economy, said today that he did not differ substantially with President Carter's economic policies but suggested that stronger leadership was necessary to make them work.

title: Phils Top Mets
description: When Danny Ozark was replaced by Dallas Green as the Philadelphia Phillies manager almost two weeks ago, Green was characterized as an interim manager who would fill out the 1979 season.

title: Big Landowners Lose Round in Reclamation Battle
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  The Senate today began a longawaited effort to liberalize limitations on ownership of federally irrigated land in the West by defeating two amendments that favored large landowning corporations that now use cheap, taxpayersubsidized water.

title: Swedes Vote Sunday on Fate of NonSocialist Experiment
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 13  Sweden will decide in national elections Sunday whether to continue its threeyearold experiment with nonSocialist government following a campaign unusual for a lack of discussion of two of the country's most sensitive issues.

title: ArcherDaniels Offering
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (Reuters)  The Securities and Exchange Commission said that the ArcherDanielsMidland Company had filed an offering of $100 million of convertible subordinated debentures due July 1, 2009. The company said proceeds of the offering would be used for general corporate purposes.

title: Concert: Kubelik In Opener
description: THE New York Philharmonic opened its season last night in Avery Fisher Hall without the services of its music director. Zubin Mehta is conducting in Europe. When he was appointed music director of the Philharmonic two years ago, was along with some builtin commitments. Star conductors these days are signed up years in advance. Next fall Mr. Mehta, it is promised, will be on hand to inaugurate the season with his orchestra.

title: Lynn to Start for Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 13 Johnny Lynn, a rookie from the University of California, Los Angeles, will replace his roommate, Donald Dykes, as the Jets starter at rieht cornerback.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE RIGHT STUFF. By Torn Wolfe. 436 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95.

title: Miller Ties Prime Jump To Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  Secretary of the Treasury G. William Miller indicated today that he thought the current high level of interest rates was consistent with the present high rate of inflation.

title: Souow Jo AIcidnS III asIu dims
description: The nation's money supply expanded sharply in the latest reporting week, the Federal Reserve said yesterday, leading money, market analysts to conclude that the central bank might soon push shortterm interest rates still higher through a more restrictive credit policy.

title: G.A.O. STUDY ASSERTS THAT OIL COMPANIES WORSENED SHORTAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, asserted today that American oil companies had aggravated last spring's petroleum shortage by cutting production of crude oil within the United States last fall and winter, while imports from Iran were disrupted.

title: U.S.Mexican Gas Talks Gain
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) Carter Administration officials say that there has been substantial progress recently in natural gas negotiations with Mexico, but they are uncertain whether the deal can be completed when President Jos Lpez Portillo of Mexico visits here later this month.

title: Market Place
description: IS the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, a leading paper producer with substantial timber reserves in Maine, being wooed by the Cities Service Company, the large integrated oil company?

title: COMMODITIES Silver Regains Ground; Gold Prices Peak Again
description: Silver futures recovered to resume fiveweek rally yesterday, while gold futures set new highs on renewed speculative buying.

title: New Law in Argentina About Missing Persons Draws Sharp Criticism
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 14 (AP)  A new law that will enable judges to declare missing political detainees dead 90 days after a family or Government petition is filed drew sharp criticism today.

title: Notes on People
description: A notsofunny thing happened to Paul Libin on the way to the theater awards yesterday.

title: PARK AVENUE SYNAGOGUE
description: Harlan J. Wechsler, Assistant Rabbi The Congregation invites your inquiry for membership

title: Sources: American Petroleum Institute for weekly data, Energy Department for projected and minimum accefitable levels for inventories
description: The New York Times/ Sept. 14, 1979

title: Food Inspection Change Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) Assistant Agriculture Secretary Carol Tucker Foreman today proposed a system to modernize inspection of $25 billion worth of processed meat and poultry products purchased by American consumers.

title: Memphis Is Cool to Davis Cup
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 13  On a weekend when Memphis State University and the University of Mississippi are expected to draw a capacity crowd of 51,000 for a college football game here, the United States and Argentina may play in front of about 2,000 spectators in tomorrow's opening singles matches of the Davis Cup American Zone final.

title: Film: 'Shame of Jungle':Me Shame, You June
description: "SHAME OF THE JUNGLE" is an animated-cartoon that unsuccessfully attempts to parody the life and adventures of Edgar Rice Borroughs's Tarzan. The movie, which has been R-rated, is naughty in the old-fashioned way of the National Lampoon, where the cartoons of Picha, the Belgian-born artist who is this film's co-director, have been featured.Among the characters are Shame, the name of this movie's Tarzan, who is as ineffective making love to June, his mate, as he is in swinging from one vine to another; Bazanga, the queen of the jungle, who is bald; a two-headed beautician named Charles of the Pits, and assorted safari types.In the middle of the film there is one very short sequence that seems not to belong to anything that comes before or after it. It is funny. It's about a beer-drinking guru from Champaign-Urbana, Ill., who flies around on a carpet carried by a half-dozen quite angry birds. At the end of the film the secret is revealed. The sequence was "created and performed" by John Belushi. Some other "Saturday Night Live" performers lend their voices to the animated characters, but none for the comic effect achieved by Mr. Belushi.The animation is very nicely done but the wit ("You'd give Bufferin an upset stomach") is bland and exhausting. The film opens today at the Embassy I and other theaters.

title: U.S. Inquiry Reported On 7 Bank Charters To Connally Friends
description: DALLAS, Sept. 13 (UPI)  The Senate Banking Committee is investigating seven national bank charters that were granted to friends of John B. Connally, the former Treasury Secretary, while he served in the Nixon Administration, The Dallas Morning News reported today.

title: United Press International
description: SMOG EMERGENCY CALLED IN LOS ANGELES: Buildings in downtown Los Angeles were obscured yesterday by the worst smog in 25 years. Officials issued hazardous air warnings for six areas there, the first time such a step has been taken. Many outdoor activities were canceled, and car pooling was being urged. Today's pollution was expected to be worse.

title: Senate Panel Approves McHenry for Job in U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today approved the nomination of Donald F. McHenry to replace Andrew Young as delegate to the United Nations.

title: A World of Cultures On Film at Museum
description: If one thing the study of anthropology shows is the kind of choices people make, then the third annual Margaret Mead film festival at the Museum of Natural History, will be an anthropological study in itself. There is no way for people who attend the fourday marathon screening of anthropological films to see everything.

title: Folk Art Festival Focuses on Shakers
description: New York's first American Folk Art Festival is a colorful and impressive addition to the city's art scene. The festival, which is sponsored by the Museum of American Folk Art, has spawned a dozen folkart and Shaker events in the city's museums, libraries, art galleries and an armory, much of it on view this weekend.

title: TV Weekend
description: WHILE the commerical networks go into newseason contortions, public television moves to the other extreme of classical dabblings. Two of the major events on Channel 13 this weekend involve serious music.

title: Radio
description: 87 A.M., WNYCFM. Duo for Glass Harmonica, Naumann; Balletto, Poglietti; Symphony in E flat, Sammartini; Flute Sonata in A, Bach; The Fair Melusine, Mendelssohn.

title: Entertainment On Two Stages
description: The following, subject to change, is a schedule of events on the book fair's two 52d Street stages  Stage 1, west of Fifth Avenue, and Stage 2, east of it:

title: Mother of Carter Calls Kennedy Vote Possible
description: Lillian Carter, the President's mother, said yesterday on a visit to New York City that she would vote for Senator Edward M. Kennedy if he won the Democratic Presidential nomination. But she said Mr. Kennedy would get her vote only if he refrained from personal attacks on the President.

title: Car Sales Up 15%
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13 (AP)  The Chrysler Corporation, benefiting from a rebate program to stimulate customer interest, set a car and truck sales record in early September, helping to push domestic automobile sales 15 percent ahead of the comparable period a year earlier.Continuing the rebound, which began in July, the five United States manufacturers delivered 155,467 cars in the period, against 135,091 in the first 10 days of September 1978, according to company reports issued today.factory rebate check soaring 67 percent above the 1978 period.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: The remains of Hurricane Frederic, visible in the Southeast, arecausing extensive cloudiness. A frontal band of clouds extends from the lake region and the Middle West to the Central Plains States. Scattered to broken cloudiness covers portions of the Rockies.

title: New York Lawyer Had a Key Role in S.C.L.C. Efforts to Further Civil Rights Movement
description: Stanley David Levison, a New York lawyer and businessman, who was a key adviser to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and an important behindthescenes figure in the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, died Wednesday at his home after a long illness. Mr. Levison, who lived at 85 East End Avenue, was 67 years old.

title: TwoThirds Fail Proficiency Test In Mathematics
description: About twothirds of the public school system's ninth and 10th graders failed the mathematics competency test last June. The test is the first of a series of more stringent examinations students will be required to take to qualify for graduation beeinning in 1981.

title: World News Briefs
description: STALAC, Yugoslavia, Sept. 13 (Reuters)  At least 50 people were killed and more than 100 injured early today when a freight train crashed into an express train filled with army recruits near this junction town south of Belgrade.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times on Wednesday on a rally for four Puerto Rican nationalists incorrectly described the ownership of the center where the rally was held. Cuando, the community center at 9 Second Avenue, was lent to Dylcia Pagan for the rally.

title: Some Arab Christians in Jordan, Becoming Restless or Uneasy, Think About Leaving
description: MADABA, Jordan  From the earliest Christian times, pilgrims have been coming to this austere area, the biblical land of Moab. But now the trend is in reverse.

title: Court Backs Vesco Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)  Robert L. Vesco, the financier, is entitled to hearing on his tax dispute with the Internal Revenue Service even though he is fugitive, the United States Tax Court has ruled.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Generally Firmer; Gold Results Are Mixed
description: The dollar rose against most currencies in exchange markets at home and abroad yesterday while gold prices retreated in Europe but rose sharply in New York futures markets.

title: E.E.C. Expects Steel Increase
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 13 (AP)  The European Common Market Commission today predicted an increase in the market nations steel production during this year's fourth quarter, reaching the highest quarterly output since the 1979 oil crisis.

title: McGuire Approves Reorganization Of Detective Squads in Manhattan
description: A reorganization of the Police Department's detective operation in Manhattan, including the elimination of special homicide and robbery squads, has been approved by Commissioner Robert J. McGuire.

title: A Uranium King's Oil Venture
description: TORONTO, Sept. 13  Stephen B. Roman, a onetime tomato picker who parlayed a speculative mining investment into a nationwide reputation as Canada's uranium king, has now decided to move into American oil and gas in a big way.

title: Open House Tomorrow At 207th St. Subway Yard
description: Members of the public will have chance to take over the controls (at least part of the time) tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., at an open house of the Metropolitan Transit Authority's 207th Street yard. The free event, held rain or shine, is part of the celebration of the subway system's 75th birthday.

title: Corporate Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Television
description: 5: 50(5)New Zoo Revue

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: As the gasoline lines recede after Labor Day, it is appropriate that the absence of a U.S. oil policy again be discussed.

title: WEIZMAN IN CAPITAL TO SEEK MORE ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)  Israel's Defense Minister, Ezer Weizman, arrived here today in search of aid, arms and the right to build one of the most advanced United States warplanes.

title: The Region
description: Patrick M. Smith, the general manager of a strike newspaper in Eliza beth, N.J., accused nonstriking employees of The Elizabeth Journal of beating him during an altercation Wednesday morning in a parking lot behind the Journal Building.

title: SLUM LIOLLTIS OunreH ol SIT em xod
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13  Twentieth CenturyFox will distribute all films made in 1979 and 1980 by Melvin Simon Productions, it was announced today by both companies.

title: Churches Tackle Ticket Problems For Pope's Visit
description: A Pope has come to the United States only once before in its history, so a ticket to one of the events at which the Pontiff will officiate during his visit here on Oct. 2 and 3 is a precious commodity.

title: HURRICANE DAMAGES 100 MILES OF COAST, BUT FEW ARE KILLED
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss., Sept. 13  Hurricane Frederid, its fury greatly diminished, moved far inland today after punishing the central Gulf Coast last night with batteringram winds of up to 130 miles an hour.

title: $35 Million Bid Made for Hess's
description: Hess's Inc., the 82yearold departmentstore chain that drew national attention by bringing Paris couture originals to the Lehigh Valley of eastern Pennsylvania, said yesterday that the Crown American Corporation was making a $35 million cash tender offer to take it over.

title: The Pop Life
description: Veteran British rock bands alive and well.

title: Further Spending Cuts And Less Dependence On Aid Urged on City
description: The special deputy state comptroller, Sidney Schwartz, urged New York City yesterday to curtail further its spending and its reliance on state and Federal aid.

title: White of U.S. Wins 800 Meters at Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 13 (AP)  Ilie Floroiu of Rumania completed a distance double, the United States won two gold medals and Pietro Mennea led a winning Italian 400meter relay team today in track and field events on the final day of the 10th World University Games.

title: Athletes Visit Washington Urging Women's Equality
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)  A group of women athletes led by Donna de Varona, the former Olympic swimming gold medalist, urged President Carter and Congress today to be firm in efforts to insure equal treatment for women in school sports. Promises of support, but no firm commitments, were given the group, which also included Janet Guthrie, the racing driver; Carol Mann, the golfer, and Lacey O'Neal, the former Olympic hurdler.

title: After the Storm Some Feel Joy, Others Anguish
description: ALABAMA PORT, Ala., Sept. 13 Pacing a road embankment, Thelma McWhorter gazed across the acres of flooded forest between her and her mobile home and wailed. I've got to have my insulin, she said, wringing her hands. I've just had a knee transplant and I can't wade out there.

title: F.B.I. Is Said to Broaden Inquiry on Jordan and Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  The Federal Bureau of Investigation has expanded its investigation of alleged cocaine use by Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, after receiving new accusations that Mr. Jordan used cocaine at a party in Los Angeles in October 1977, according to Justice Department officials.

title: Advertising
description: VIEWERS of the Today show are well aware of Changing Times magazine, which has advertised on the NBCTV network program since it started in 1952. What they may not know unless they are one of its 1.4 million subscribers, or secondary readers, is that the national monthly magazine has survived for 33 years without taking advertising.

title: Gelberg Firm Adds ExJudge
description: Asa S. Herzog, a 75yearold former bankruptcy judge in Manhattan Federal court, will join Gelberg & Kronovet of New York, a new commercial law firm, effective Oct. 1, Frederick Gelberg, senior partner, said yesterday.

title: Movie: 'City on Fire' Tells a Tale of Terror:Employee's Revenge
description: "CITY ON FIRE," which opens today at Loews Astor Plaza and other theaters, tells the cautionary tale of what can happen when a minor official at a huge oil refinery fires  I mean dismisses  a short-tempered employee who then runs crazily around, opening some valves and closing others, until the surrounding city has been saturated with gasoline and other petroleum by-products.What happens is that the city catches fire, all over, more or less at the same time, which puts a lot of people under great stress. These include the fire chief (Henry Fonda) and the members of his department; the chief surgeon (Barry Newman) of a new hospital and the rich playgirl (Susan Clark), who gave the hospital $3 million; a boozing television personality (Ava Gardner), who has to describe the holocaust to network viewers; the mayor (Leslie Nielsen), who allowed the refinery to be built inside the city limits; a fat, plucky chief nurse (Shelley Winters), and a determinedly cheerful, pregnant woman who is in labor throughout the entire crisis.The movie is supposed to be set in Anywhere, U.S.A., but was actually shot in Montreal. Some of the special effects are good; some are dreadful and some are in between.There are a limited number of variations that can be worked on the spectacle of people and buildings going up in flames. Only one of the film's so-called stars is fatally injured, but there are lots of unpleasant shots of other people  bit players  as they are being roasted alive or shortly after they're done.The Japanese do this sort of disaster movie much, much better.

title: Mixing of Prayer Books Approved
description: DENVER, Sept. 13 (AP)  The convention agreed tonight to allow bishops to mix parts of the 1928 Book of Common Prayer with a controversial revision of the text. In response to widespread support for the older version of the book, beloved by thousands of church members, the House of Bishops voted that specific phrases and words in the 1928 versions of prayers and hymns may be used in worship, under the authority of the Bishop as chief pastor and liturgical officer.

title: At the Movies
description: Richard Gere turns nice guy in Yanks.

title: SIEGMUND FRIEDLER
description: Siegmund Friedler, director of sales development for The New York Post, died Wednesday after suffering a heart attack at his office. Mr. Friedler, who lived in Baldwin, L.I., was 62 years old.

title: Democrats Plan To Nominate Six For Judge Races
description: Nominations for State Supreme Court judgeships, the top elective jobs in the New York State courts, will be awarded by promotion in Brooklyn and Queens, Democratic party leaders said yesterday.

title: About Real Estate Wide Impact on Upgrading Foreseen in Tax Proposals
description: What happens in tax policy closely affects what happens in housing production and investment. New Yorkers in particular have had reason to appreciate that truism in recent years in the operation of the J51 tax incentive program to stimulate new investment in existing buildings.

title: Pendragon Wins Sail Title As Protest Is Disallowed
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 13 (AP) The West Coast yacht Pendragon won the One Ton Cup world sailing championship today despite a protest lodged by the British yacht Indulgence.

title: South Africa Starts a New Nation
description: THOHOYANDOU, South Africa, Sept. 13 (UPI)  The impoverished area of Venda, one of the regions that South Africa has designated as tribal homelands, was proclaimed an independent black nation today as part of the Government's policy of separate racial development.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Consolidating Police Forces
description: One of the principals involved in Mayor Koch's effort to unify law enforcement groups under the command of the Police Department recalled the other day how  when the Transit Authority was recently robbed of $600,000

title: Stocks Off Slightly
description: Takeover developments dominated Wall Street's attention yesterday as the stock market generally marked time. Certain oil issues, meanwhile, gave ground following recent sharp gains.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Prices of Bonds Rise Modestly
description: Interest rates, which had bounced up and down with a fair amount of volatility early in the week, settled down yesterday to await the Federal Reserve's money figures late yesterday afternoon. When they were published, bond prices rose moderately.

title: Robert W. Price, a Former Editor At New York Herald Tribune, 54
description: Robert W. Price, former financial news editor of The New York Herald Tribune, died on Tuesday at his home in River Vale, N.J., after an extended illness. He was 54 years old.

title: Canada Price Rises Slow
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 14 (AP)  Canada's consumer price index rose fourtenths of 1 percent in August and was up 8.4 percent in the last 12 months, Statistics Canada said today. The August rise was the smallest monthly increase since last December, when consumer prices were up threetenths of 1 percent.

title: No North Sea Asset Sale
description: LONDON, Sept. 14  The British Government, under intense political pressure, has reversed course and decided not to sell the state oil corporation's North Sea assets.

title: Dance: Mix Of Miss Fenley At the Kitchen
description: Dancers midperformance grins tend to be selfconscious, but those of Molissa Fenley and Dancers, performing Miss Fenley's new Mix on Thursday at the Kitchen, had the spontaneity of children at play. And, with its rigid rules, splitsecond timing and repetitiveness, Mix was very like a game devised by a precocious child.

title: Carey Looks Favorably On a Race by Kennedy
description: Governor Carey thinks that Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat, will announce his candidacy for. the Presidency sometime this fall, and he is leaning toward sup. porting such a candidacy, aides to the Governor said yesterday.

title: Deaths
description: CASNERHarry, beloved husband of Rose(nee Davis). Devoted father of Leonard and the late Alfred S. Loving grandfather of 4 grandchitdren,7 great grandchildren. Services Wien & Wien 2030 Kennedy Blvd, Jersey City, Sunday 1:30pm. Period of mourning at the residence, 225 St.Pauls Ave, Jersey City.

title: Monroe at Odds With Knicks
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 14  Earl Monroe, in the midst of another contract dispute, missed the opening of the Knick training camp today for the second straight season. As 21 Knicks gathered at Monmouth College, the Knick captain, a free agent, was in New York, unhappy with the terms of a oneyear contract offered him.

title: A Casino Reflects Sun, Scorching Boardwalk
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19  The gold reflective panels that ring the facade of the Boardwalk Regency sometimes focus so much solar light and heat on the Boardwalk that it smolders.

title: Time Magazine Erred in Calling Facility in Cuba a Soviet Station
description: A facility described as a Sovietbuilt intelligence station in Cuba pictured in the Sept. 17 issue of Time magazine apparently is instead an installation built by I.T.T in 1957 to relay telephone calls between Cuba and the United States, Time acknowledged yesterday.

title: Miller Confident That Recession Is Halfway Over
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Treasury Secretary G. William Miller said today that he was personally confident that the country was halfway through an economic recession that began in the spring.

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: Night game. Television game.

title: SALVADORAN POLICE FIRE ON PROTESTERS
description: SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 14  Apparently as part of an effort to discourage demonstrations this weekend, Salvadoran security forces opened fire on an antiGovernment protest march by militant students and teachers today, killing three youths and wounding about 30 persons. witnesses said mat several aemonstrators then drew pistols and shot back at the police, while others set fire to more than a dozen vehicles before retreating to the university, about two miles away.

title: U.S. Output Fell 1.1% In August
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 14 (AP)  The nation's industrial output plunged 1.1 percent in August  the first drop since April  as production of automobiles and household goods slumped sharply, the Government said today.

title: Rhodesian Split on British Proposal Threatens Peace Parley in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 14  A rift that could imperil prospects for a settlement of the crisis in Zimbabwe Rhodesia has developed between black and white members of the Salisbury Government, British and African sources reported today.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Quintet in E flat for Oboe, Three Horns and Bassoon, Beethoven; Trio in G, Fasch; Les Aventures de Mercure, Satie; Violin Sonata No. 15, Handel.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 20.

title: Deaths
description: HENRYLyndon. The Furriers Joint Council joins in mourning the death of a distinguished leader of the fur workers who made many notable contributions to the wellbeing of all the workers in our industry.

title: F.T.C. Facing Challenge; House Unit Backs Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  The Federal Trade Commission, the increasingly besieged regulatory agency that deals with subjects ranging from eyeglasses to oil companies, is facing the strongest attack on its powers since its creation 65 years ago.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For 6erlods as shovm.( P4 ) inchcates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: CORRECTION
description: In Yehuda Z. Blum's article Thurs., day, The U.N.'s Ongoing Decline, a production error altered a sentence. It should have said that all of the Arcib members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries combined contribute 0.84 percent of the (United Nations] budget, with Saudi Arabia contributing 0.23 percent (onethird of Denmark's contribution) and Iraq  a recent complainant over New York's gas shortage  contributing 0.08 percent (onethird of Israel's dues).

title: Economic Leaders Set Paris Talks
description: PARIS, Sept. 14  Top economic officials from the United States and four other industrial nations will meet here this weekend amid rising concern over the high level of inflation and soaring interest rates that are threatening to disrupt the industrial economies.

title: Carter Tours Storm Stricken Gulf Cities in a Copter and Pledges Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  President Carter toured the hurricanestricken Gulf Coast cities by helicopter today, praised the courage and selflessness of the storm's victims and pledged continuing Federal aid for the area.

title: Sally Shaw Oliver Is Bride Of Stephen James McVeigh
description: Sally Shaw Oliver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Cunningham Oliver Jr. of Sewickley, Pa., was married there yesterday to Stephen James McVeigh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Alexander McVeigh of Scituate, Mass. The Rev. John Yates performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Oliver home.

title: Business Records
description: Friday, Sept. 14, 1979

title: Goodyear Sees Loss For Quarter
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 14  The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest tire maker, predicted today a thirdquarter loss because of two plant closings and poor auto tire sales in the United States.

title: Stricter Zoning Rules for City's Sidewalk Cafes Proposed
description: New York City's sidewalk cafes, a felicitous import from European capitals, are causing distress in some neighborhoods and may soon come under tighter municipal rein.

title: Emhart in Accord To Acquire VSI
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., Sept. 14 (Reuters)  The Emhart Corporation said that it had tentatively agreed to acquire the VSI Corporation.

title: Worst Smog in Decades Plagues Coast
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 14  Lucille Hurt, who has lived here for 40 years, thought that Pasadena's polluted air had finally done her in last night.

title: McEnroe, Gerulaitis Give U.S. a 20 Lead In Davis Cup Tennis
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 19  There was no letup in John McEnroe's championship tennis tonight as the United States took a 20 lead over Argentina in the Davis Cup American Zone final.

title: Duke Helps RollsRoyce Open Offices in Jersey
description: LYNDHURST, N.J., Sept. 19  The cheapest RollsRoyce automobile costs $77,600, which is $5,200 more than the average price of a new home in the United States. The most expensive, the Corniche twodoor convertible, is priced at a breathtaking $140,000.

title: United Press International
description: TOO LATE: Gary Maddox of the Phils being forced at second by Mike Kelleher of the Cubs last night at Philadelphia. Larry Bowa was safe at first on play. Cubs won, 20, in 10 innings.

title: Marsha Norman Wins Playwrighting Award
description: Marsha Norman, author of Getting Out, at the Theater De Lys, has won the first George OppenheimerNewsday Playwrighting award, given to new American playwright whose work is produced in New York or on Long Island. Created by Newsday, the $1,000 award is in honor of George Oppenheimer, drama critic at the newspaper till his death in 1977. The award will be given at a luncheon next month.

title: Most Big Banks Set 13% Prime
description: Most of the nation's major banks yesterday followed the lead set earlier in the week by the Chase Manhattan Bank and raised their prime lending rates to a record 13 percent.

title: Arafat, in Spain, Receives Visitors
description: MADRID, Sept. 14  Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, received a steady stream of visitors today, the second day of his visit to Spain at the invitation of the Government.

title: F.B.I. Admits Planting a Rumor To Discredit Jean Seberg in 1970
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  The Federal Bureau of Investigation acknowledged today that its agents plotted in 1970 to besmirch the reputation of Jean Seberg, the actress who committed suicide last week, by planting a rumor with news organizations that she was pregnant by highranking member of the Black Panther Party.

title: Notes on People
description: Senator Barry Goldwater expressed puzzlement yesterday over a lawsuit filed in Federal Court in New York by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. The suit seeks to enjoin the publication of the Senator's memoirs, With No Regrets, by William Morrow & Company.

title: Anthony Limits Shakespeare Bid
description: SOUTH GATE, Calif., Sept. 14 (AP)  Anthony Industries Inc. said today that it would not extend past Sept. 18 its offer to acquire the Shakespeare Company of Columbia, S.C., in a transaction valued at more than $38 million. And it said that Anthony would seek Shakespeare by proxy fight, tender offer or openmarket purchases, if Shakespeare did not accept the acquisition offer.

title: Senate Relaxes Limits On Irrigated Holdings And Exempts Big Area
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  The Senate voted today, 47 to 23, to place a limit of 1,280 acres on the amount of federally irrigated land that a farm operator may own or lease. But it exempted most of the large land corporations in California that would be affected by the limit.

title: Myra Rosenfeld Married To Robert Patrick Little
description: The marriage of Myra Nan Rosenfeld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Rosenfeld of Greenwich, Conn., to Robert Patrick Little, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Milton Little of Montreal, took place yesterday at the Harvard Club of New York. Rabbi Abraham J. Klausner performed the ceremony.

title: Philippine Cardinal Calls for End To MartialLaw Rule by Marcos
description: MANILA, Sept. 14  Jaime L. Cardinal Sin, leader of the Roman Catholic Church in this country of 40 million Catholics, called today for an end to President Ferdinand E. Marcos's seven years of rule by martial law.

title: Organizing Push Gets Under Way At a Major Store
description: A union has begun a major organizing drive among departmentstore employees here, focusing initially on those working at Abraham and Straus in Brooklyn.

title: Around the Nation
description: DALLAS, Sept. 14 (AP) A 16yearold college student who disappeared a month ago and was feared to have been an accidental victim of an intellectual fantasy game was reunited with his tearful parents today, a private investigator said.

title: Money
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1979

title: The Ballet: Dowell Partners Miss Makarova in Swan Lake
description: Natalia Makarova and Anthony Dowell danced the leading roles in Swan Lake at the American Ballet Theater's Thursday night performance at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: New Vitality Sensed in Soviet Writers
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14  A group of American writers who took part in SovietAmerican writers workshop at the Black Sea resort of Batumi are going home reporting they sense a new strain of vitality, diversity and independent thought in the Soviet literary establishment.

title: Christian Brothers Bows On VintageDating Issue
description: The last bastion of resistance to the practice of vintagedating American table wines has crumbled. Christian Brothers, one of the largest wine producers in California's Napa Valley and the only major holdout against vintagedating, will soon offer four varietals carrying vintage years on their labels.

title: PlayboyElsinore Applying for Casino
description: TRENTON, Sept 19 (AP)  PlayboyElsinore Associates formally applied today for a casino license for the $90 million Playboy Hotel now under construction next to Atlantic City's Convention Hall.

title: The City
description: A midtown Manhattan jeweler fell victim to burglars who took an estimated $800,000 in gems from his safe, the police said.

title: Heart Condition Is Blamed In Death of Cardinals Cain
description: ST. CHARLES, Mo., Sept. 14 (AP)A congenital condition that eventually shut off the blood supply to the heart re sulted in the death of J. V. Cain, the St. Louis Cardinals tight end, on the practice field.

title: Cabaret: Karen Akers Singing at Reno Sweeney
description: Karen Akers is a tall, slim singer with a fascinating face  interesting planes, a generous mouth, an adventurous nose and huge, exploring eyes. She also has an attractive, confident voice, and, at Reno Sweeney, where she is appearing Tuesdays and Wednesdays through this month, her program balances contemporary pop and theater songs, songs in English and songs in French.

title: Listening to The Doctor  And to Your Body
description: To my patient: It may be helpful, at the outset of our relationship, to tell you how I propose to get you well and to keep you that way.

title: Lion Theater Opens Nov. With Knuckle Sandwich
description: The world premiere of Knuckle Sandwich, a dramatic farce by Howard Waxman about a Jewish family in Brooklyn, will open the sixth season of the Lion Theater Company, 422 West 42d Street. on Nov. 7.

title: Allied and Armco Set Accord on Suit
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation and Armco Inc. announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement in principle for Allied to pay Armco $20 million to settle their litigation regarding coke and coke oven gas supplies.

title: Striking Paterson TeachersJailed for Desobeying Court
description: Fifteen teachers in Paterson, N.J., were jailed yesterday after being charged with violating a backtowork order issued by the courts in an effort to end an eightday strike there, and 930 teachers in the Morris Regional School District walked out to support demands for higher wages..

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Friday, Sept. 14, 1979

title: Contract for Court Officers
description: Officers of New York State Supreme Court have approved a new threeyear contract that will provide 18.8 percent in wage and benefit increases, a spokesman announced. The ratification vote, conducted by the Honest Ballot Association, was 511 to 68.

title: Olga de Hartmann, 96, Widow Of Russian PianistComposer
description: Olga de Hartmann, widow of Thomas de Hartmann, the Russian pianist and composer, died at her home, Nambe, in Santa Fe, N.M., on Wednesday. She was 96 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 14  Greg Buttle practiced for the first time today since suffering food poisoning after eating clams last Tuesday night. The Jets outside linebacker is expected to start on Sunday against the Detroit Lions.

title: Frederic Drops Rain on New York
description: Storm Frederic, nee Hurricane Frederic, finally reached the New York City area yesterday evening, quickly spattering the streets with only a third of an inch of rain.

title: Aleksei Kapler Dead; Top Soviet Filmwriter Was Exiled by Stalin
description: Aleksei Yakovlevich Kapler, a leading Soviet screenwriter, has died in Moscow, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency. He was 75 years old.

title: Departing Deputy Mayors Upset Tempo of City Hall
description: The appointment diaries are being packed, the Green Books shelved, the resumes updated and assembled. The official stationery will soon be recycled into scrap paper.

title: Thrift Unit Peril Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Anita Miller, the acting chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today that the viability of New York savings banks and savings and loan associations was in jeopardy. She urged Governor Carey to establish a blueribbon panel to deal with the situation. miss miller mace ner comments in an interview here and earlier in a speech at the annual mortgage conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. One of the most urgent problems, she said, is the state's severe restriction on the amounts New Yorkchartered thrift institutions may borrow from nondeposit sources to offset deposit outflows.

title: Jersey Utility Facing Challenge
description: NEWARK  The Jersey Central Power and Light Company has suffered severe economic strain since the accident that closed its Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania on March 28, and now faces the possibility of losing its franchise.

title: Your Money
description: WITH shortterm interest rates continuing to soar to record levels, small investors are actively seeking opportunities that will allow them to make the most of their money.

title: Examination for Principals, First Since 64, Is Scheduled
description: The Board of Examiners announced yesterday that it would give an examination for junior high school principals Nov 12 to fill 90 principals jobs at intermediate and junior high schools in New York City.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1979

title: Westinghouse on Suit
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 (Reuters) The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said that the lawsuit filed in Ontario Supreme Court by Rio Algom Ltd. is without merit. Rio Algom is seeking damages of $1.6 billion in a dispute over a supply contract with the Tennessee Valley Authority.

title: PCB Contamination Is Reported In Food Produced in Four States
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 19 (AP) Health inspectors said today that they expected to find more contamination from PCB, a banned chemical that has already been found in meat meal in Montana, chickens and eggs in Idaho, bakery goods in Utah and chicken parts in Iowa.

title: Irish vs. Big 10: Michigan First Test
description: Dan Devine, Notre Dame's football coach for the last four years, has been known to shed crocodile tears from time to time, bemoaning the overwhelming schedule usually facing the Irish. This year he may be justified, starting today, when the Irish open one of the most difficult football schedules in Notre Dame history by meeting Michigan at Ann Arbor.

title: Billy Carter Is Quoted On Zionist Campaign
description: KUWAIT, Sept. 14 (AP)  Billy Carter was quoted today as having said that he would continue to support the Arab cause despite what he called a Zionist campaign against him.

title: Amoco Unwilling To Freeze Prices
description: The Amoco Oil Company, a unit of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), said yesterday that it was not willing to make a commitment to freeze prices on heating oil, as President Carter had urged on Wednesday.

title: Catholics Protesting Curb on Laymen for Visit of Pope
description: Some Roman Catholics in the United States are protesting the decision by the Vatican to bar unordained men and women from serving holy communion at masses said by Pope John Paul II on his visit to this country Oct. 1 to 7. Several Catholic officials say it is possible there will be organized protests on this issue while the Pope is here.

title: OffDuty Police Officer Is Killed In Shooting on Brooklyn Street
description: An offduty NeW York City policeman was shot to death at Nostrand and Atlantic Avenues in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn early this morning, according to a Police Department spokesman.

title: Mattel's Net Declines 26%
description: Mattel Inc., the nation's largest toy maker, reported yesterday that its net income declined 26 percent in the second fiscal quarter and 30.2 percent in the halfyear ended Aug. 4.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Agriculture U.S.A. (5)Patterns for Living

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Some were amused, others were outraged and The New York Times (Topics Aug. 29) worried that the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance never sleeps  all in response to the sensational story about the upstate boy selling worms and the collection of sales tax.

title: Duchess of Windsor Back Home
description: PARIS, Sept. 14 (AP)  The Duchess of Windsor, who entered the American Hospital in Neuilly nearly four months ago with a bacterial infection, was released today, a hospital spokesman said. The 83yearold Americanborn Duchess, for whom King Edward VIII gave up the throne in 1936, was hospitalized once before this year for surgery. She has lived in Neuilly since the Duke died in 1972.

title: Entertainment Events
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA, Puccini's Madame Butterfly, 2, and Gounod's Faust, New York State Theater, 8.

title: COMMODITIES Silver Passes $13 Mark; Gold Futures at High
description: Silver breached the $13anounce mark yesterday and gold futures also set new highs, while copper, livestock and grains fell.

title: Nuclear Carrier Voted For Military by House In Bill of $41.4 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI)  The House today passed, 282 to 46, a $41.4 billion military spending bill that includes nuclear aircraft carrier that President Carter does not want.

title: The Quarterback From Delaware
description: Every little bit helps a defense that ranks last of the 14 teams in its conference. So John Mazur, whose title on the Jets is defensive coordinator, asked Joe Klecko: The Detroit Lions quarterback, Komlo. He played for Delaware. You know anything about him?

title: News Summary
description: A rift threatens the London parley on Zimbabwe Rhodesia, according to British and African sources. They said that Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa and former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith had disagreed over Britain's proposals for an independence constitution. Prime Minister Muzorewa, the sources said, has decided to accept the proposals, but Mr. Smith reportedly balked at provisions that would weaken safeguards for the country's white minority, for which he is chief spokesman. [Page 1, Columns 12,]

title: Vienna Opera Post Likely for Maazel
description: VIENNA, Sept. 14 (AP)  Lorin Maazel, conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra, emerged today as the prime candidate for director of the Vienna State Opera.

title: It's Debra Jo, Wowin em, In Beaumont
description: SILSBEE, Tex.  Debra Jo Fondren and the discovery of oil at Spindletop are the only two things that ever happened in Beaumont, Tex. It was 1901 when the gusher blew in, and Debra Jo was a Playboy cover girl and Playmate of the Year last year, with photos made in Paris by Francis Giacobetti who lighted her and photooranhed her like a cathedral.

title: All Night Strut Will Use Music of 30's and 40's
description: The music of the 1930's and 40's will come alive in The All Night Strut, which will begin previews Sept. 28 at Theater Four, 424 West 55th Street. Composers represented in the musical, created by Fran Charnas, include Irving Berlin, Johnny Mercer, Fats Waller. Duke Ellington and Charlie Parker.

title: TENTATIVE CONTRACT IS AGREED TO BY G.M. AND AUTO WORKERS
description: DETROIT, Sept. 14 The United Automobile Workers Union and the General Motors Corporation announced tentative agreement tonight on a threeyear contract covering 460,000 G.M. workers in the United States.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Gold and Silver Climb; Dollar Finishes Mixed
description: The price of gold soared more than $12 an ounce to record levels during trading in European and United States markets yesterday, with analysts attributing the jump to strength in silver orices. The dollar was mixed.

title: Sindona Lawyer Receives a Photo
description: ROME, Sept. 14  A lawyer here said today that he had received an envelope containing what purported to be a recent photograph of Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who disappeared last month in New York, and a list of demands for his release by a group that said it was keeping him a prisoner.

title: United Press International
description: HELLO, BIRDIE: Sandra Palmer throwing her cap into the air after sinking birdie putt on the 16th hole in first round of Ladies Professional Golf Association team championship in Portland, Ore. Miss Palmer, who is playing with Pat Bradley, pushed her team into the lead with the birdie.

title: Day Rest No Break For John
description: Even before rain washed out me Yankees game with Detroit last night and created a 1 P.M. doubleheader today, Tommy John was scheduled to pitch today and he could not understand why. His next start, he thought, should have been scheduled for last night. Billy Martin thought otherwise.

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1979

title: Panel Urges Senate to Denounce Talmadge on Financial Misconduct
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  The Senate Select Committee on Ethics, after a 16month inquiry, recommended today that Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, be denounced by the Senate for engaging in financial misconduct.

title: Walter Kidde Bids For Jacuzzi Bros.
description: CLIFTON, N.J., Sept. 14 (AP) Walter Kidde & Company offered today to buy Jacuzzi Bros. of Little Rock, Ark., for almost $70 million in cash. Jacuzzi's president said he was pleased by the offer.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Natlonal owaaank and Ahnosphorle AdrolnistratFon/UPI

title: Container Suit Settled
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP)  A settlement of $200 million has been awarded to some 2,500 purchasers of cardboard containers who had filed suit against 24 manufacturers charging them with price fixing, according to two FederalDistrict Court judges.

title: The Region
description: A fourfoothigh cross, was burned on the lawn of the Port Jefferson, L.I., home of the regional director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday. It was was the fifth such incident on Long Island in the past month.

title: REPLACEMENT VOTED FOR UNDERCARRIAGES ON 754 SUBWAY CARS
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to begin work on replacing defective undercarriages on the entire fleet of 754 subway cars purchased from the Pullman Standard Company in 1972.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON THE president of a New Jersey research company believes he has found the answer to an important industrial problem  how plastics can be coated with metal economically.

title: Fisher Issues Warning To Garelik's Successor
description: Harold L. Fisher, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, told the new chief of the transit police, James B. Meehan, yesterday that he had one lob.

title: Acting Chief Given PATH Title
description: Francis A. Gorman has been named director of rail transportation by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, giving him oversight of the PATH commuter rail system under the Hudson River. Mr. Gorman, 47 years old, was been named acting director of transportation after the previous director, John F. Han, died last spring. Mr. Gorman has been with the Port Authority since 1958.

title: With Neto Gone, Angola Rebel Renews Plea for Talks to End Civil War
description: PARIS, Sept. 14  In the wake of the death this week of President Agostinho Neto of Angola, the spokesman for the opposition guerrilla force led by Dr. Jonas Savimbi has renewed an appeal for negotiations to end the country's long civil war.

title: Bridge:
description: Giving an opponent a chance to make an error is an art that is insufficiently cultivated at the bridge table. Technique is not enough  one must be able to exploit weaknesses in the opponents technique. An elegant example is the diagramed deal, played some years ago in a European Championship in Estoril, Portugal.

title: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 15, 1979
description: Treasury Secretary G. William Miller said he was confident that the country was halfway through the recession that began last spring. He insisted that an antirecession tax cut planned for this winter was unwarranted, but that proposed individual and business tax reductions for 1981 might be appropriate. [Page 1.]

title: German Chemical Sales Up
description: BADENBADEN, West Germany, Sept. 19 (Reuters)  Sales volume in the West German chemical industry rose 15 percent in the first seven months of this year over the yearago period, supported particularly by foreign business, which grew 17 percent, Matthias Seefelder, president of the Chemical Industry Association, reported.

title: SIEGMUND FRIEDLER
description: Siegmund Friedler, director of sales development for The New York Post, died Wednesday after suffering a heart attack at his office. Mr. Friedler, who lived in Baldwin, L. I., was 62 years old.

title: Opera: Serbo Sings Faust In City Debut
description: Frank Corsaro's eccentric production of Gounod's Faust was performed by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater on Thursday night, with Rico Serbo making his City Opera debut in the title role. Mr. Serbo is a Californiaborn tenor who spent six years in West Germany, where he sang with opera companies in Koblenz and Munich.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CARIBBEAN SOUNDS An increasing  but unknown  number of Caribbean peoples are living and working in New York. Several radio stations and a television channel are 100 percent Latin. One radio station is oriented to migrants from the Englishspeaking Caribbean. On Labor Day, a West Indian carnival in Brooklyn attracts millions.

title: Ladylike Pumps Are Back
description: If you follow fashion at all, you know that as far as shoes go, this is the year of the pump, that classic closed shoe that was out of favor in recent seasons. Women were wearing espadrilles or platform shoes or wedgies or bare sandals. But the return of the suit and other more dressed up styles has brought back the ladylike shoe as well.

title: American Express And Warner in Deal
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it planned to acquire 50 percent of Warner Communications Inc.'s cable television business for $175 million.

title: Panel on Estrogen Holds Patient's Decision Is Key
description: BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 14  An expert panel convened by the National Institutes of Health concluded today that the decision to use estrogens to treat menopausal symptoms should be based on an individual judgment by the woman after she has been clearly told of known risks and benefits.

title: Conciliator Koch
description: This morning, Mayor Koch will get together with Representative Charles Rangel and five black members of the City Council at Gracie Mansion, beginning a series of regular meetings to improve relations with black and Hispanic New Yorkers. The effort is as welcome as it is overdue.

title: Irving Bluestone
description: DETROIT, Sept. 14 The United Automobile Workers, in its efforts to negotiata,a new contract with the nation's three major automobile manufacturers, put one of its most seasoned bargainers at the head of its team of negotiators at the General Motors Corporation: Irving Bluestone, who has participated in negotiations with General Motors for 31 years.

title: Pan Am Flights to China Win Approval of C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  The Civil Aeronautics Board approved an application today to permit Pan American World Airways and the national airline of China to operate the first commercial flights between the United States and China since the Communist takeover in 1949.

title: PerformingArts Specials Planned by NBCTV
description: A series of primetime performing arts specials, all telecast live, will be presented on NBCTV starting Jan. with a concert by the New York Philharmonic under the direction of Zubin Mehta.

title: Associated Press
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 14  Team golf, in which player has to think for his partner as well as for himself, is a long way from the individualism of tournament golf, and an American team of professionals did the better job of mastering the art today than their European opponents.

title: George Bader Morris jr.
description: DETROIT, Sept. 14  George Morris was asked recently how it felt to be the chieL labor negotiator for the General Motors Corporation.

title: Belfast, Ulster's Volcanic Capital
description: BELFAST  This capital of Northern Ireland, with its bombed and burnedout buildings, military checkpoints, roadblocks and sloganed walls, is a city at war with itself. Its gigantic cranes, the world's largest, towering like cathedral spires over Belfast's moribund shipyards, stand as mute symbols of its economic and political stagnation.

title: Now, E1 Salvador
description: El Salvador marks its independence today. The occasion will be tense. The nation's cycle of terrorism and repression began long before revolutionaries drove General Somoza from Nicaragua. But that event has led Washington to take an urgent new look at impoverished El Salvador, which seems to be Central America's next candidate for leftist revolution. Hoping to head it off, the Carter Administration is asking Gen. Carlos Humberto Romero to liberalize his regime. The prospects for change from the top do not look bright.

title: Carter Expected to Refuse Senators on Arms Request
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Although President Carter has pledged to increase defense spending in 1981 to take account of inflation, he is likely to refuse a request by several senators that he promise to seek higher military spending in the two Federal budgets after that, informed Senate sources said today.

title: Manis Held After Hurling Debris From Church Roof on West Side
description: A man who said that the police had ignored three attempts on his life within the last year threw bricks, wooden planks and steel rods into the streets from a scaffold on a Manhattan church for four hours last night.

title: United Press International
description: TOO LATE: Gary Maddox of the Phils being forced at second by Mike Kelleher of the Cubs last night at Philadelphia. Larry Bowa was safe at first on play. Cubs won, 20, in 10 innings.

title: Chrysler Will Give U.S. Its Recovery Plan Today
description: Senior management and the board of the ailing Chrysler Corporation will meet today with top Treasury Department officials in Washington to present the company's longawaited plan for financial rehabilitation, company and Government officials confirmed yesterday.

title: RightWing News Magazine Hits British Newsstands With Sellout
description: LONDON, Sept. 14  Now!, a weekly news magazine that hopes to fill a void in British publishing, hit the newsstands today amid a blast of publicity and quickly sold out its 400,000 copies.

title: Publicly Traded Funds
description: Friday, Sept. 14,1979

title: Letter: On Assisting the Poor
description: To the Editor: I noted with concern your Aug. 30 editorial on the energy problems of the poor. I agree with you that we must respond to this need, and that a special fuel grant program is a poor solution. However, an energy stamp program modeled after or in conjunction with the food stamp program is also not the answer.

title: U.S. Tells Israel It Will Consider Request to CoProduce Fighters
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Secretary of Defense Harold Brown today told Ezer Weizman, the Israeli Defense Minister, that the United States would seriously consider a proposal by Israel that it be allowed to begin joint production of advanced American fighter planes.

title: Prices in Israel Up By a Record 8.4%
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 14  Israel's consumer price index rose by a record 8.4 percent last month, it was officially announced in Jerusalem today.

title: Deregulating the Airlines Safely
description: The airline business is booming, thanks in large measure to deregulation. But not everyone is happy with the airlines new flexibility. There are complaints from some cities to which the major carriers have reduced or eliminated service. And questions have been raised about the safety record of the small commuter lines that are moving to fill the gaps.

title: G.M. Seeks China Pact
description: PEKING, Sept. 14  The General Motors Corporation is negotiating in competition with five other American and foreign companies to manufacture trucks in China on a largescale jointventure basis, a General Motors executive disclosed today.

title: I.B.M. and U.S. Ready for Talks
description: Lawyers for the International Business Machines Corporation and the Justice Department said yesterday that they were willing to discuss a settlement of the Government's 10yearold antitrust suit against the computer giant.

title: Output Up In Europe
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 14 (Reuters)The European Economic Communitys industrial production index rose by a seasonally adjusted 1.5 percent in June, putting the increase for the first six months of the year at 6 percent, the E.E.C. Commission said in its monthly economic survey.

title: Quarries Cutting More Granite for Skyline
description: BRANFORD, Conn.  Granite, one of man's oldest building materials, is making a major comeback on the Manhattan skyline, where the architectural trademark in recent decades has been the sleek but energywasteful expanse of glass framed in metal.

title: Rights Group Visiting Argentina Pleased at Coverage by Its Press
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 14  Members of the InterAmerican Human Rights Commission, now in the midst of a twoweek inquiry into conditions in Argentina, say they have been pleasantly surprised by the wide coverage given their work by the Argentine press.

title: Sports Today
description: At Bridgehampton (L.I.) Race Circuit, 10 A.M.

title: A Silent, Emaciated Girl Poses Mystery in Queens
description: When police officers carried the young girl into the emergency room of the Queens Hospital Center in Jamaica at A.M. last Monday, the doctors and nurses were appalled.

title: U.S. COLD TO PROTEST ON 4 PUERTO RICANS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  President Carter's decision to free four Puerto Rican nationalists for terrorist acts they committed in the 1950's was taken after White House and Justice Department officials became convinced that their unconditional release would entail no sub1 stantial risk.

title: Christians of the Mideast Uneasy Among Moslems
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 14  From the Tigris and Euphrates to the Upper Nile, Christian communities in the predominantly Moslem Middle East are increasingly concerned over their future in an era of ma i or upheaval.

title: About New York
description: At the edge of the naked city, far from the rentcrazed hordes and strobelighted poseurs, lies a place that is the heart of whiteness, a fragrant, monomaniacal place called Port Ivory.

title: Nigeria Seeks U.S. Investing
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 13  Alahaji Shehu Shagari, Nigeria's Presidentelect, said here today that his administration would emphasize agriculutural production and economic selfsufficiency, and would like heavier American investment in its rapidly expanding economy.

title: 2 Areas of Queens Cut ZIP Tie to Brooklyn
description: So concerned were residents of Ridgewood and Glendale in Queens about the encroaching blight of the neighboring Bushwick section of Brooklyn that they voted overwhelmingly recently to change their ZIP code from a Brooklyn one to a Queens one.

title: Associated Press
description: A MILLION INDIANS IN ONEDAY STRIKE: In New Delhi, a woman waved a rolling pin and a can of cooking oil in a protest against the cost of living. In six months the price of oil has risen 50 percent. About a million workers staged strikes against 189 Governmentowned factories and organizations, protesting antilabor policies, poor wages and working conditions.

title: A Reprieve for School Games
description: A strike threat by game officials that hung over the opening of the Public Schools Athletic League's football season today was lifted when the P.S.A.L. Football Officials Association agreed yesterday to work without contract until the middle of next week.

title: Ralph Mayer Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for Ralph Mayer, an expert in paint technology as well as an artist, teacher and writer, will be held Sept. 24 at 5 P.M. in the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. Mr. Mayer died of a heart attack last month at the age of 83.

title: Deaths
description: RIDGLEYL. Clark, 39, died Thursday in Houston Texas. Survived by wife, Mrs. Linda Walsh, Houston; Parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ray A. McCreary, Farmington, Missouri, daughters; Miss Amanda J. Ridgley and Miss Melissa J. Ridgley, both of New Canaan, Conn. Sister, Mrs. Marilyn Fuller, Atlanta, Georgia. Memorial service 2:00PM Saturday, Houston Arboretum Amphitheater. Remains will be sent to Farmington, Missouri for services and burial. In lieu of usual rememberances, family favors Nature Convervancy, Petroleum Commerce Building Suite 618, 201 North Saint Mary Street, San Antonio, Texas 78205. Attention: Mr R. Scott Spann, Texas Chapter.

title: Market Registers Sharp Rise
description: Tossing its textbooks out the window, the stock market surged forward yesterday in the face of such normally typical deterrents as record prices for gold bullion and record levels for the prime lending rate of major banks.

title: On the Road With the Presidential Panel on Women
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 14  The women of North Carolina today wound up two days of pouring out their problems to 19 members of the President's Advisory Committee for Women, who were meeting away from Washington for the first time.

title: Moses Extends Streak With a Hurdle Record
description: LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP)  A sellout crowd of 17,000 saw Edwin Moses, the American hurdler, break his British allcomers record in the 400meter hurdles tonight at an international track and field meet at Crystal Palace.

title: Socal Refinery Damaged
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 (Reuters)  The Standard Oil Company of California said today that its Pascagoula, Miss., refinery had suffered moderate damage from Hurricane Frederic. The refinery was shut down Wednesday in expectation of the hurricane and was unlikely to resume full operation for several weeks, Socal added.

title: Stanley Stamaty, An Illustrator For WellKnown Publications, 63
description: Stanley Stamaty, an artist and cartoonist whose illustrations had appeared in many national magazines, including The Saturday Evening Post, Colliers and Look, died Wednesday in Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. Mr. Stamaty, who lived in Elberon, N.J., was 63 years old.

title: I.T.T. Expands Consumer Segment
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced the formation of a consumer services, publishing and home products group.

title: OBSERVER Playboy To Carboy
description: The things big spenders spend big for these days suggest there has been a. decline in the American bigspending imagination. According to a Wall Street Journal report on the present generation of spendthrifts, those in the upperincome brackets think pretty much like pinchpennies in we miacue and lower brackets when they splurge.

title: House to Get Education Dept. Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Stripped of antibusing, antiabortion and proprayer amendments, a compromise proposal to create a Cabinetlevel department of education will reach the floor of the House of Representatives next week for what is expected to be another lively debate.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14  The ChineseSoviet negotiations that had been tentatively scheduled to start here Tuesday have been postponed for a week or so, diplomatic sources said today.

title: HURRICANE'S DAMAGE PUT AT $1.5 BILLION
