description: PASCAGOULA, Miss., Sept. 14  As stormstricken residents of the central Gulf Coast began a frustrating, uncomfortable recovery from the ravages of Hurricane Frederic, it appeared today that the storm would rank among the three most destructive hurricanes ever to hit the United States.

title: Books of The Times Machiavelli of Modern Art
description: Sergei Diaghilev may have done more to publicize modem art than anyone else in this century. Besides revolutionizing ballet, he brought to European and American audiences the music of such composers as Stravinsky, Satie, Poulenc, Auric, de Falla, Honegger, Milhaud and Prokofiev. He commissioned paintings and stage decor from Picasso, Braque, Juan Gris, Derain, Rouault, Mini, di Chirico, Gabo, Utrillo and Delaunay. Diaghilev was the Machiavelli, the message center, the eye of the storm, in the evolution of dance, music and painting in the first three decades of the 20th century.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DORIC (Home). Left Bermuda Sept. 13; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Mikolajczyk to Be Out 4 Weeks
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 14  Ron Mikolajczyk, Joe Pisarcik's favorite protector, was put on the injured reserve list today as Ray Perkins, the Mississippi gambler, shuffled what appears to be an empty deck.

title: Congress Guards Its Fingers In Wielding the Budget Ax
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Russell B. Long left a heated meeting of Senate Democrats last week and marched across the marble corridors of the Capitol. The subject had been how to cut $4 billion from the Federal budget, and the voluable Louisiana Democrat was fresh out of ideas.

title: Audit Critical of Psychiatric Units
description: A state audit charged yesterday that three psychiatric clinics in the city had engaged in questionable practices that cost the state hundreds of thousands of dollars in Medicaid payments.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WOODLANDS, Tex., Sept. 15 (AP)Bob Carmichael and Tim Gullikson had never played together before they were matched and seeded No. 8 in the $150,000 Association of Tennis Professionals world doubles tennis tournament.

title: HOME CLINIC New Light on Dimming Devices
description: DIMMER switches have been popular in homes and apart- ments for some years now because they provide a sim- ple means for controlling the bright- ness of lights in a living room, den, bed- room or similar area where lighting needs may vary  from full brightness for working, reading or playing games, to softer lighting that may be desired while dining, socializing or watching television. In the past couple of years, dimmer switches are also being installed for another reason  as a means of cutting down on the size of the monthly electric bill.

title: Russians in Cuba; A Red Herring?
description: With the strategic arms treaty apparently well on its way to Senate ratification, presumably the last thing the Carter Administration wanted was a showdown with the Russians. Yet when two Democratic Senators raised the issue of Soviet combat troops in Cuba, with SALT at stake, we felt we had to come out swinging, a White House aide explained. Last week, it appeared the Administration's quick haymaker had missed, leaving it open to new attacks on the treaty and President Carter's reelection prospects.

title: If It's Wearable, It's in Southampton
description: SOUTHAMPTON

title: Farmers
description: LEWISTON, Me., Sept. 15 (AP) Once again the Postal Service has run afoul of the Farmers Almanac, this time over a plan to introduce a ninedigit ZIP code.

title: Brighton Conference Demonstrated a New Attitude
description: LONDON  In the old seaside resort at Brighton, south of London, 500 British homosexuals gathered one weekend last month to discuss the progress of their campaign for better treatment under the law, and to plan future strategy.

title: A Second Look at Merano
description: We were approaching Merano, and I had to admit I was apprehensive. The last  and only  time my husband and I had visited this resort in the mountains of Northern Italy had been almost 20 years ago. We had driven in from Switzerland in a Volkswagen that had gasped and faltered on the high, snowbanked roads, and we had yearned more intensely with every passing mile for our first taste of Italian food, Italian sunshine and Italian architecture.

title: R.C. Boothby, Miss Sheppard Are Married
description: The marriage of MaryHelen Corning Sheppard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winston C. Sheppard of Dresher, Pa., to Richard C. Boothby took place yesterday in St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Whitemarsh, Pa. The Rev. Richard Hawkins, assisted by the Rev. Otho Hoofnagle, performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Willard S. Boothby Jr., chairman of Blyth Eastman Dillon & Company, investment banker, and Mrs. Boothby of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia.

title: The Death Knell for the MG
description: Another dark shadow was cast over Britain's ailing auto industry last week when BL Ltd., the stateowned automobile company, announced that it would end production of its MG sports car, once the most popular sports car in America. The move means layoffs for 25,000 workers and the closing of 13 plants.

title: U.S. Aide in Turkey Wounded
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 15 (Reuters)  A United States consular official was wounded here early today when he was caught in an exchange of fire between the police and gunmen here early today, American officials said. Peter Pulton, 29 years old, of Chicago, was hospitalized with a back wound but his condition is not serious, the officials said.

title: Is TV's Image of Blacks Improving?
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Cooking Schools Offer Novel Recipes for Learning
description: AFTER a summer at the backyard barbecue, it's time to learn how to cook again. The Island's cooking schools are happy to comply, with an abundance of courses, especially in Chinese, French or Italian cooking and in bread and pastry making. One of the newer trends is for couples (or singles) to take courses in the evening. Since most classes end with a meal that includes wine, cooking class becomes a delightful, instructive and certainly more economical alternative to dining out.

title: Community Panel Narrowly Backs Upper East Side Historic District
description: The historic district proposed for the Upper East Side of Manhattan, facing opposition from the realestate community, narrowly received the endorsement of committee of the area's community board.

description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Sept. 15 (AP) Paul McDonald, a quarterback who played only the first half, completed eight of nine passes for 108 yards and two touchdowns today as the University of Southern California routed Oregon State University, 425, in Pac10 action.

title: When Giants Meet Redskins, Keep an Eye on the Long Snapper
description: The Giants are on national television tomorrow night. The significance of the game against the Washington Redskins may be only that football fans,in Ypsilanti, Mich., will have a rare look at one of their favorite sons bending over to perform one of the most overlooked and most underrated specialties in an increasingly specialized game.

title: His Conventional Is Different
description: Douglas Dunn has threaded his way through New York's avantgarde dance scene for 10 years, a lowkeyed presence who has managed, nonetheless, to emerge as a choreographer and performer consiaerea one or me most dependably interesting of the postmodern dance breed.

title: ANTIQUES A Market for Buyers With Limited Funds
description: SOUTHBURY AS prices for many antiques con- tinue to spiral upward, it sometimes may seem that there no longer is room in the market for new buyers with only mod- est amounts of money to invest. That is not true, say many dealers, who point out that there still are areas of collect- ing that have not as yet reached their peak. Three dealers who plan to exhibit at the Nutmeg Flea Market Saturday suggest, for example, such diverse categories as ironstone china, decoys and small decorated boxes.

title: Kennedy Tiptoes Much Closer To a Candidacy
description: Reading the papers, Jody Powell cracked at a news briefing last week, 1 got the impression it was 1980 and that we had just passed New Year's Day, not Labor Day. The press secretary had been asking reporters to please pay attention to Jimmy Carter's work on the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty and energy legislation. But all he kept hearing was Kennedy this and Kennedy that until, finally, he announced that the White House would not get bogged down so early in playing games with Presidential politics.

title: Fashions for Faces: Fuchsia Plus
description: AMAKEUP expert once observed that, unlike the constant changes in clothes styles, fashions in faces really changed only every five years or so. This is obviously a fifth year. The monochrome beige and brown look we're getting bored with is giving way to a frankly painted female who is out to play the seductress and be noticed. She's more like the pinup of World War II than anyone we've seen for a long time. Ironically, it seems that the more equality women ask for, the more they want to celebrate la difference with their looks.

title: Food
description: Summer, officially, is almost over but there is still time to put up summer foods through one means or another.Freezing is by far the most expeditious and easiest method of preserving foods, far less time-consuming than packing foods in pepper, salt and other preservatives, ana tar less teaious man preserving Dy long cooking and canning.

title: Some Contemporary Labors of Love
description: If the musicians who perform contemporary music do so as a labor of love, companies that record it often do so as an act of faith. Few people have ever become rich from new music  indeed, nearly all recordings of contemporary works need to be subsidized in one way or another. That has not prevented the release of many disks each year, nor has it discouraged the development of many excellent artists who specialize in this field.

title: Liturgical Dance a Memorial for Teacher
description: THERE is a time to mourn, and a time to dance, according to a passage in Ecclesiastes that Steffi Nossen enjoyed. Mourning and dancing will come together today at 2 P.M. in St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont at a memorial service for the moderndance artist and teacher who died last month at the age of 74.

title: Japan Hails Elders Amid New Concern for Them
description: TOKYO, Sept. 15  The Japanese honored their elders with a national holiday today, called Respect for the Aged Day. as they do every year. But there was something special about the occasion this time, for one of those being honored, Shigechiyo Izumi, is believed to be the oldest living human of verifiable age.

Capalino, who was named commissioner of the department last February.

title: Associated Press
description: FIFTYFIVE AND RUNNING SMOOTHLY: William Handley of Manchester, N.H., driving his 1924 Model T Ford in Concord recently. He says that he drives it 250 miles a week, and gets about 27 miles per gallon of gasoline.

description: OTTAWA, III., Sept. 15 (UPI)  The United Automobile Workers, in an unusual negotiating move, announced today that the union would strike all three of the nation's major farm implement manufacturers if no new contract was reached by Oct. 1.

description: The 58foot Thunderhead, sailed by Paul Hoffman of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was the largest yacht in the sixth annual Governor's Cup race held yesterday in New York Harbor. It also was the fastest.

description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 15 (UPI)William Niehous, who was kidnapped from his home in Caracas, Venezuela, and held captive for 40 months by leftist terrorists, will return to work Monday.

title: For Fall, the Dressy Look Is a WellSuited One
description: YOU'VE heard it before. We'll say it again: you buy just one article of clothing this fall, make it a suit. Dressed up. Pulled together. Ladylike. Those are some of the words that apply to fashion now. And one of the most dressedup, pulledtogether styles ever invented is the suit.

title: Study Finds Fitness Doesn't Insure Health
description: Superior physical fitness and habitual exercise programs do not guarantee protection against sudden death during or after exercise, according to a study by Stanford researchers who urged doctors as well as joggers and runners to pay more attention to minor discomforts that could herald heart attacks or death.

title: Connally Organizing Campaign Workers in Florida
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Sept. 15  John B. Connally, discounted by some Republican professionals because his Presidential campaign has seemed short on organization, showed at a party meeting in Florida today that he is working to make up for lost ground. But later in the day party leaders showed Mr. Connally that their hearts were still with Ronald Reagan.

title: Kate Winslow, Editor, Wed
description: At the Riverdale Presbyterian Church in the Bronx yesterday, Kate Nichols Winslow, an editor at the Institute for the Development of Indian Law in Washington, was married to Robert Spellman Sherman Jr., a reporter with the Jack Anderson column in Washington. The Rev. John Crocker Jr. of Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. Winslow of Riverdale and Mrs. Sherman of Riverside, Calif., and the late Mr. Sherman.

title: Tuning In to Another World
description: IN a naugahideous Washington, D.C., hotel room recently, I became John Cheever's Enormous Radio. In that classic short story, a radio rejects the conventional airwaves and tunes into the lives contained in a New York City aoartment building. The experience for the protagonist, a gentle woman whose most compelling ambition is to move to Westchester, is shattering.

title: Furs Turning Sleeker, Narrower and Smarter
description: THE Wild West look in furs went riding off into the sunset this year. The 1979 fur is sleek and narrow and sophisticated. After almost decade of enormous, longhaired pelts, furriers are thinking small again. (Not about prices, however; we'll go into those later.) There are still longhairs to be had, of course, but even raccoon has slimmed down. The main fashion swing is to flatter furs that are used like fabric.

title: European Plots and People
description: AVIS GALLANT'S new book is billed as a novella and eight short stories, but it's not clear which is the novella. None of the pieces is very long; and if a novella is defined by terms other than length  by its greater depth or scope then any one of these stories could qualify. Each is densely woven, wide-ranging, rich in people and plots ammature more sausrying man many Lull scale novels

title: `Space Adventures For the EarthBound
description: I joined a group of wouldbe space people at the entrance ramp to the space shuttle that was about to blast off into the peace of weightless zero gravity in the outer darkness. Even though it was a makebelieve flight at the Alabama Space and Rocket Center, near Huntsville, tne wrest of towering missiles and rockets standing upright all around made us mere humans seem slight, fragile and quite powerless.

title: THEATER Carousel: Once Great, Now Good
description: DARIEN IN 1945, much younger and more easily moved to tears, I sobbed my way through the original Carousel three times. Well, today I am older, wiser and slightly disillusioned. I choked up a bit for old time's sake at the close of Carousel at the Darien Dinner Theater, but I came out of the theater with several thoughts about the collected works of Rodgers and Hammerstein.

title: From the Golden Age
description: In The Strange Case of Dr. Walter Roebling and the Voice Machine, threerecord set of old Superman radio episodes interspersed with Kellogg's Corn Flakes commercials, Dr. Roebling, the brilliant scientist, apparently has invented a voice machine that can retrieve sounds from any point in time or space on command. The invention itself seems to have fallen into the hands of the record industry, which can now transport you via disk transcriptions of original radio broadcasts right out of the television present and into the golden age of radio.

title: Kreszentia Margaret Duer Wed
description: Kreszentia Margaret Duer, daughter of Grace Cook Duer of Philadelphia and the late Douglas H. Duer and a descendant of Chief Justice John Marshall, was married yesterday to Jef- frey Balkind, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Balkind of Johannesburg. The Quaker ceremony was performed at the Abington Friends Meeting House in Jenkintown, Pa.

title: Emily Williams Wed to William Draper Jr.
description: Emily Royall Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence E. Williams of Short Hills, N.J., and Sagaponack, L.I., was married yesterday to William Franklin Draper Jr., son of Barbara Cagiati Draper of Wainscott, L.I., and Mr. Draper of New York.

title: SPOTLIGHT On the Firing Line at Chrysler
description: DETROIT  President Carter had some unkind words for the Chrysler Corporation last week. Speaking in Steubenville, Ohio, the President chided the beleaguered company for making gasguzzlers. At the same time, Lee A. Iacocca, several hun- dred miles to the north and unaware of the President's remarks, was presiding at the introduction of Chrysler's 1980 models and defending the company against such very charges.

title: A Correction Officer Is Wounded In Shooting at Bar in Manhattan
description: A New York City Correction Department officer was wounded twice just before midnight yesterday when he attempted to stop a holdup of a bar in upper Manhattan, the police said.

title: Ken Howard

title: The End of an Era: Gas Consumption Peaking
description: Gasoline used to be a classic growth product. In its heydey, demand sometimes soared by as much as 6 percent in a single year. But today, the era of runaway growth in the gasoline business seems gone forever. Consumption has tapered off as Americans have switched to the new breed of smaller, more fuelefficient cars, and industry forecasters have for some time been saying that this Federally mandated changeover will probably cause the demand for gasoline to peak by 1981, level off for a year or two, then slip into a long, slow slide.

title: The Frantic, Nonstop Preparations For a New Menotti Opera
description: Aweek before the world premiere of Gian Carlo Menotti's La Loca, the score was still not finished. Mr. Menotti arrived at the end of May in San Diego (the San Diego opera company had commissioned the work as a 50th birthday present for Beverly Sills) with a suitcase crammed with music manuscript. The composer was rushed from the airport to a suite in the Westgate Hotel across from the theater. With a staff of roundtheclock copyists, he remained sequestered in his posh prison until the afternoon of the dress rehearsal, when he penned the final notes of the score.

title: The Launching of a Fledgling Playwright
description: Martin Fox, whose play The Office Murders is scheduled to open Tuesday at the Quaigh Theater in a showcase production for 18 performances, is an intense, softspoken man of 48 who has been writing plays for nearly 20 years. Like so many other playwrights whose work has not been widely performed, he has always dreamed of a commercial production in New York and now may be on the brink of achieving that goal  subject, of course, to the way critics and theatergoers react to the Off Off Broadway production coming up at the Quaigh. The showcase is the culmination of six years of effort  and waiting  on the part of Mr. Fox, who sat down to write this particular play in 1973.

The Montreal Expos will be here for twilightnight doubleheaders Wednesday and Thursday, both at 5:35. The Mets conclude their home season with games against the St. Louis Cardinals Friday night at 8, Saturday night (Fireworks Night) at 7 and Sunday (Fan Appreciation Day) at 2 P.M.

title: How Studs Lonigan
description: IN June 1929, I was a young man who had burned other bridges behind him with the determination to write, whether my efforts brought me success failure. I was then finishing what happened to be my last quarter as a student at the University of Chicago. Three times before I had dropped out classes because I was restless and dissatisfied, resolved to devote my time writing and to educating myself in my own haphazard manner. For a fourth and last time I had matriculated and I managed to finish the quarter. Although I read continuously and rather broadly, after my sophomore year I could not maintain a steady interest in any of my courses except in composition, where could write as much as I pleased. I would cut other classes, day after day, nally dropping out, heedless of the loss of credit and the waste of money I had spent for tuitioo.

title: Nina L. Mayer Married To Byron D. Allen 3d
description: Nina Louise Mayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Mayer of North Salem, N.Y., and Jekyll Island, Ga., was married yesterday in North Salem to Byron Donald Allen 3d, son of Mrs. Roberta Allen of Sterling, Va. The Rev. Doyne E. Mitchie, a Presbyterian minister of Fort Wayne, Ind., performed the ceremony in St. James Episcopal Church.

title: SmithKline's Revival
description: PHILADELPHIA  For nearly a decade, the SmithKline Corporation fit the profile of a company going nowhere: It lagged in developing the new products necessary for success in the researchintensive drug industry. Today, however, the diversified healthcare concern is an example of how one product breakthrough can turn a floundering company into a shining, if somewhat controversial, star.

title: Arafat Ends Visit to Spain, Praising Its Mideast Stand
description: MADRID, Sept. 15  Yasir Arafat today praised the Spanish Government's progressive stand on the Middle East, called the American diplomat Andrew Young a good friend and compared the unjust and barbaric treatment of American blacks with the situation of the Palestinians.

title: The Rise of Fall and the Fall of Summer
description: AS a diehard weather watcher for more than 15 years, Westchester summers lose their attractions for me after midJuly. The dog days that last about three weeks from midJuly through the first week of August make me yearn for the refreshing cool of autumn.

title: Where the Customer Isn't Always Right
description: THE build-a-better-mousetrap theory has proved itself over and over again in New Jersey and all around the metropolitan area. One of the more recent instances involves the enterprising Elizabeth Ewing, who has worked out practical method of individual dressing for the busy woman. She designs the clothing offered in her shop and then her customers select from samples.

title: FOREIGN AID BY U.S. DROPS UNDER CARTER
description: Cuts in the Congress Raise Doubts on Administration's Ability to Promote Foreign Policy

title: White House Delays Revision of WagePrice Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  The Carter Administration announced today that it would delay revision of its voluntary pay and price standards for a maximum of 15 days in a further effort to win the support of organized labor for its antiinflation program. Labor has been seeking larger voice in how the guidelines are to be changed.

title: Morrene Hubbard Wed to J.A. Jacobs
description: Elizabeth Morrene Hubbard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Morrison Hubbard Jr. of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday to Jay Austin Jacobs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Andrew Jacobs of Baltimore. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Dr. Robert Kelsey of the Central Presbyterian Church of Summit, assisted by the Rev. Joseph T. Webb, an Episcopal priest.

title: Where to Brush Up on Culinary Arts
description: FALL  the harvest season  is a season of serious cooking. Cooking classes are about to begin in earnest in late September and early October. A few have already begun.

title: 25 Women to Receive Pilot Training in 1980
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 15 (UPI)  Although views at the Air Force Academy differ as to women's piloting combat planes, 25 female members of the 1980 graduating class at the United States Air Force Academy here are scheduled to enter pilot training next summer.

title: Foreign Scientists Get Rare Trip to Remote Soviet Region
description: MAGADAN, U.S.S.R.  The night plane from Khabarovsk had touched down after a 1,000mile flight of two and a half hours across the Sea of Okhotsk in northeastern Siberia. As the airliner, an IL18, rolled to a stop on the Clark runway, the voice of the flight attendant came over the publicaddress system. Comrade passengers, she said in Russian, we have landed in Magadan. The temperature outside is 11 degrees centigrade. Please have your documents ready for inspection.

title: Nan S. Wells Wed To Mark P. Leone
description: Nan Shelby Wells, director of governmental affairs at Princeton University, was married yesterday to Mark P. Leone, associate professor and acting chairman of the anthropology department at the University of Maryland. The Rev. Bertram Smith, a Disciples of Christ minister of Glasgow, Ky., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Luther L. Wells Jr. of Glasgow.

title: Miss Brownell To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Foote Brownell of Exeter, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Gordon Brownell, to James Bainbridge Lee Jr., son of Mrs. Edward J. Raleigh of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Lee.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Pace University is offering noontime jam sessions on alternate Wednesdays on its Pleasantville and Manhattan campuses through Oct. 31.

title: The Club Pro of the Yankees
description: Sport of The Time

title: ARTISTS AND AGENCY CLASH OVER EXHIBIT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  A local arts group has said that it will dismantle an exhibition of Latin American art in the General Services Administration headquarters if the agency does not rescind its ban on eight large panels of photographs and text.

title: LOTTE JACOBI: BORN WITH A PHOTOGRAPHER'S EYE
description: Autumn has come to the mountains in Deering, N.H. You can tell, says a flatlander who's learned, by the quality of the light and by the fog that persists beyond morning into the day and settles over the reservoir. To get to Lotte Jacobi's photography studio, you have to drive around a big gray cloud of nothingness.

title: Grasping for Immortality In the Boxes of Section Six
description: CATCHING a foul at the ball park is like getting a garter from Gypsy Rose Lee or (these passions are transient) snatching a scarf from Elvis. It is at once participation in an event (Guidry threw this; Rice hit it; I caught it) and the immediate creation of a myth.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: JOSEPH GRAF

title: New York City Has a New Police Czar
description: Not long after Robert J. McGuire became New York City's Police Commissioner in January 1978, Mayor Koch, the man who chose him for the job, began to refer to him as the best Police Commis- sioner the city had had since Theodore Roosevelt. Ac- tually, President Roosevelt, who served the city from 1895 to 1897, had it easier than many of his suc- cessors. In those days and until shortly after the turn of the century, the Police Department was governed by a board of four commissioners.

title: Saban's Army Debut Is a 26-to-10 Success
description: WEST POINT, N. Y. Sept. 15  Although Army's 2610 victory over Connecticut in Michie Stadium today was not artistic, it went into the record as a successful debut for Lou Saban, the 28th coach in the history of the United States Military Academy.

title: African Nationalist Leader Died in Moscow Last Week
description: PARIS  The death of Agostinho Neto has opened new uncertainty in the tangled complex of wars southern Africa. The 57yearold leader of Angola died in Moscow last week, where he was receiving medical treatment, and the importance of his role was reflected in the range of messages sent by government leaders to commemorate him.

title: Design
description: TWO TASTES LIVING AS ONE

title: An Unhurried View of Joggers
description: THE passing parade now comes by at tempo jog and the variety of costumes enshrouding the runners these days displays an enormous vigor of design, a wardrobe as colorful and eyecatching as those that used to go public in a Ziegfeld Follies.

title: Woman on High Court Predicted
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 15 (UPI) Justice Potter Stewart of the United States Supreme Court says it is likely that woman will be appointed to the Court while he is still on the bench. Justice Stewart, 64 years old, made the prediction at a news conference after addressing the Cincinnati Bar Association Thursday night. He also said the Court would eventually permit television cameras to record its proceedings.

title: Barbara Jane Goldsmith Is Betrothed to Robert J. Page
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry P. Goldsmith of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Jane Goldsmith, to Robert J. Page, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Page, of Manahawkin, N.J., formerly of Clark. N.J.

title: MARINE IS AWAITING INQUIRY ON TREASON
description: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C., Sept. 15 (UPI)  Pfc. Robert R. Garwood has been working as a clerk at this sprawling and isolated infantry base for four months while the Marine Corps investigates charges that he collaborated with the North Vietnamese in his 13% years as a prisoner of war.

title: Cyprus Seizes Icons From U.N. Aide
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 15 (Reuters) A United Nations official in Cyprus resigned today after the police raided his home and removed three truckloads of valuable antiquities.

title: Naval Academy Graduate Challenges New G.I. Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)  The Veterans Administration is studying the case of a Philadelphia naval officer who says that he and 4,000 other 1977 service academy graduates are being cheated out of education benefits under the G.I. Bill of Rights.

title: Greek Vases Found Off Sicily
description: MESSINA, Sicily, Sept. 15 (UPI)  Police divers working near the Lipari Islands north of Sicily have found 90 Greek vases and part of a ship in what archeologists termed a major find. Authorities said the vases were in excellent condition and probably dated from 200 B.C., when Greek traders plied the seas around Italy.

title: Rhode Island Considers Planting Trees for Fuel
description: NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Sept. 15 (UPI)  Local energy officials have decided to start a longterm hedge against the ultimate heatingoil shortage.

title: Article 6 -- No Title
description: YANKSVanessa Redgrave and William Devane (left) are one pair of lovers (Richard Gere and Lisa Eichhorn are another) in John Schlesinger's film of World War II romance between American soldiers and British women. Opens at the Cinema I on Wednesday.

title: Federal Judge Grants Trial Delay On Indian Land Claims in Maine
description: PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 15 (AP) Federal District Judge Edward T. Gignoux has again granted a delay in setting a date for a trial on Indian land claims in Maine.

title: Laura Brown Wed To C. P. Cronin Jr.
description: Laura Porter Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Montgomery Brown Jr. of Gates Mills, Ohio, and Hot Springs, Va., was married yesterday to Cornelius Patrick Cronin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cronin of Lexington, Mass.

title: China's Herbal Treatments Impressing U.S. Doctors
description: PEKING, Sept. 19  Smoke curled from a box lying in the small of woman's back at the Institute of Traditional Chinese Medicine here, permeating the area with the pungent smell of burning herbs.

title: Mrs. King, Miss Goolagong Advance to Final in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Sept. 15 (AP)  Billie Jean King of the United States and Evonne Goolagong of Australia reached the final of a $150,000 tennis tournament today.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: HAPPY ALL THE TIME, by Laurie Colwin. (Pocket, $2.25.) Two young men, cousins and close friends, come down from Harvard all set to make it big in Manhattan. They court and win two young women who are just right for them, but it takes them a little while to appreciate just how fortunate they are. A lovely book, written in porcelainclear sentences with a Mozartian elegance, our reviewer, John Romano, described it, adding that he feared Laurie Co!win made happiness seem a less complex matter than it really is.

title: Vietnam to Hong Kong: A MuchDetoured Escape
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 10  When Chen Meihua covertly made her way overland to China last year from her home in Ho CM Minh City, she thought she had found sanctuary. But the Chinese Communists soon ordered her to work on a state VIM in the countryside, the very fate she had Sled in Vietnam.

title: Norwalk Boat Show Opening
description: With a fleet ranging from a $314 dinghy to a sumptuous motor yacht bearing a price tag of more than half a million dollars, the fourth international inwater boat show will get underway at 10 A.M. Thursday for a fourday stand at Cove Marina in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Alison. Teal Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Alison Teal of Washington and New York to Sam W. Brown; director of Action, the Federal agency for volunteer service, which includes the Peace Corps and VISTA, has been announced by Miss Teal's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Clarence William Teal of Omaha.

title: Fashions for Faces: Fuchsia Plus
description: AMAKEUP expert once observed that, unlike the constant changes in clothes styles, fashions in faces really changed only every five years or so. This is obviously a fifth year. The monochrome beige and brown look we're getting bored with is giving way to a frankly painted female who is out to play the seductress and be noticed. She's more like the pinup of World War II than anyone we've seen for a long time. Ironically, it seems that the more equality women ask for, the more they want to celebrate la difference with their looks.

title: WHY HAVE ONE WHEN MANY WILL DO?
description: Like some giant amoeba, the Federal Government has been reproducing by separating into ever more parts, and no one seems to be able to stop it.

title: RentOvercharge Inquiry Widened To Cover Scores of City Landlords
description: In response to complaints from tenants, the State Attorney General says he has broadened an investigation of rent overcharges to include scores of major landlords in New York City. If the complaints are found to be valid, thousands of tenants may be eligible for refunds that could exceed $1 million.

title: The Cost of Obedience
description: AN atmosphere of listlessness, a weight of moral claustrophobia  that is how people experience life in the authoritarian countries of Europe. There is no longer much fear of indiscriminate terror, the knock on the door at four in the morning. To get by now, you just have to mumble sterile formulas at boring meetings and keep your mouth shut the rest of the time. For some people, however, this is hard take. They choke on the denial of their true thoughts and feelings, they get into trouble by not fulfilling their quotas of bad faith.

title: Incumbent Mayor Loses to a Former Police Chief Who Resigned Under Fire
description: Politics in New Haven, Conn., are not quite as eth- nocentric as they used to be, remarked a middle- aged Democrat of Irish extraction after last Tues- day's Democratic primary. He was reminiscing about the way things were when he began working for the party as a boy. In the old days, he said, when the party machine transported voters to the polling places, We'd have a priest in the back of the car saying Now Mrs. Reilly, you know tis a mortal sin to vote fora Republican. m

title: Realty News
description: The mortgage brokerage and sales concern of Pearce, Mayer & Greer Inc., which handles more than $550 million a year in financing and sales, has been sold by W. R. Grace & Company to an investing group headed by Charles J. Urstadt and including Henry Pearce and Jules Mayer.

title: Alaskans 78 Income Highest Among States
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) Alaska enjoyed the highest income per person of any state in the nation last year and Mississippi had the lowest, the Commerce Department said in an analysis made public today.

title: L.I. Youth, 19, Is Held in Murder Of. Brother With Cerebral Palsy.
description: SHIRLEY, L.I., Sept. 15 (AP)  A 19yearold Long Island youth was arrested yesterday and charged with murdering his older brother, whose nude body was found shackled to a tree with a bicycle chain on Sept. 4.

title: SmallTown Snobbery in Canada
description: HE Beggar Maid is a figure in a painting by BurneJones to which Rose, heroine of Alice Munro's 10 interwoven stories, is likened by the man she is to marry. Rose is poor, and Patrick, heir to a chain of department stores in British Ca lumbia, loves her for qualities she hasn't got. This common occurrence is highlighted with uncom- mon clarity when Rose looks up the painting in an art book: She studied the Beggar Maid, meek and voluptuous, with her shy white feet. The milky surrender her, the helplessness and gratitude. Was that how Patrick saw Rose?

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Parting the Curtain

title: The Designing Minds Behind Water Pic
description: Back in 1965 while working for Raymond Loewy, an industrial designer, three inventors had the idea of transforming a dental hygienist item into a consumer product. The result  the Water Pic. Its success prompted the three men  Gary Grossman, Edward Meisner and Edward Levy  to form their own group of inventors and de- signers called Innovations and Development. The Fort Lee, N.J., operation creates, designs and develops consumer products for corporations.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Death watch. The bond that links members of one of literature's friendliest fraternities is, in a word, murder. Right now there's a spate of publications that show the camaraderie that unites writers and readers of mystery stories. To wit: qThe Foul Play Press, of Taftsvilie, Vt., has just brought back into print three of Phoebe Atwood Taylor's highly esteemed 1930 stories of murder on Cape Cod ($4.50 each). For their covers, three wellknown aficionados have obligingly posed for photographs of themselves as the stories bloodstained victims: Dilys Winn, editor of the bestsellhig anthology Murder Ink, appears,on the cover of Figure Away; Carol Brener, who runs Murder Ink, a Manhattan bookstore that's a hangout for mystery buffs, is on the cover of Octagon House; and Edward Gorey, whose version of Dracula is a Broadway hit, can be seen on The Cut Direct.

title: Gettysburg's Historic Fields
description: Standing on these autumngold Pennsylvania fields visitors can read the battle of Gettysburg from the lay of the land beater than they can in any book.

title: Seawall: Who Needs It?
description: THE battle continues to maintain Liberty State Park in Jersey City as a natural green preserve without the inclusion of massive concretions, such as a twomilelong seawall at a cost of some $30 million.

title: Dilemma for Skeets
description: SCOTCH PLAINS

title: Brock Scholarship Dinner
description: ST. LOUIS (AP)  Henry Aaron, Ernie Banks, Mickey Mantle, Willie Mays and Stan Musial will be among celebrities to attend a a $100aplate dinner honoring Lou Brock on Sept. 29. The dinner is being held to raise funds for Southern University scholarship fund in Brock's name. Brock, who added 3,000hit aggregate to his basestealing records last month, is retiring at the end of the season.

title: U.S. Will Share Allied Air Bases In War or Crisis
description: RAMSTEIN, West Germany, Sept. 19  The United States Air Force in Europe has given high priority to a program that in war would enable reinforcements flying from America to use airfields of eight allies in the North Atlantic alliance.

title: Candice J. Larson Is Married To Roger Schnapp, Lawyer
description: Candice Jacqueline Larson, daughter of Mrs. Melvin B. Larson of Niles, Mich., and the late Mr. Larson, was married yesterday in Manhattan to Roger H. Schnapp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Schnapp of Long Beach, L.I. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony at Temple EmanuEl.

title: Accessories: A Shift From Neutral Tones To Strong Colors
description: LOOK for color and shape in acces- sories this fall. Shapes are usu- ally geometrics, colors not bright but strong  plum, burgundy, deep green. These new colors are meant to be worn as the old neutral browns and blacks once were.

title: Paying to Pray On the Holy Days Upsets a Reverie
description: FOR the first time in many years, I find myself eagerly anticipating the Jewish Holy Days of Yom Kippur and Rosh haShana, traditions born in the dawn of time and renewed afresh in the crisp, clean air of September.

title: Associated Press
description: Mariners Floyd Bannister beating Royals Friday.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: DIMMER switches have been popular in homes and apartments for some years now because they provide a simple means for controlling the bright- ness of lights in a living room, den, bedroom or similar area where lighting needs may vary  from full brightness for working, reading or playing games, to softer lighting that may be desired while dining, socializing or watching television. In the past couple of years, dimmer switches are also being installed for another reason  as a means of cutting down on the size of the monthly electric bill.

description: The Week's Concerts

title: Torn Seaver, in 13th Season, Still Working on the Basics

In the end Wadkins, playing on his second Ryder Cup team, and Nelson, playing on his first, won the match, 5 and 4.

description: EVEN men who shrug at fashion will probably find themselves in jackets with padded shoulders this fall. Broad shoulders are back, casual is out and dressy is in. And for whatever ominous reasons, so are dark, moody colors.

title: Pirates Set Back Mets, 54
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15  With the Pirates engaged in a tight race with the Montreal Expos for first place in the National League East, it was rather unusual that the Pittsburgh manager, Chuck Tanner, had considerable mis givings today before his team played the lastplace Mets in the opener of twogame series. After all, most contenders look to fatten up on the alsorans at this stage of the season.

title: Miss Lindenthal, George D. Jones 3d Are Wed in Jersey
description: MaryElizabeth Lindenthal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Liridenthal of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to George Davenport Jones 3d. son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones Jr. of Concord and Wianno, Mass. The ceremony was performed in St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church by Msgr. Harrold A. Murray.

title: DINING OUT Indian Cooking That's Richly Varied
description: JHOOLA, an Indian restaurant that opened about six weeks ago in Smithtown, is on a par with the better Indian restaurants in Manhattan. The name refers to a type of elaborate, freestanding swing, one of which divides the bar area from the small dining room.

description: Indications that the nation is sliding further into the economic downturn surfaced on several fronts last week.

title: Ballet:Bissell in Baryshnikov Quixote
description: As most dance fans probably knew, the American Ballet Theaters Don Quixote has little to do with Cervantes's novel. It can even be argued that it has not much to do with ballet as a serious art. It is silly  monumentally silly. Yet Don Quixote has held the stage for a century.

title: Lawyer Says Woman Reported Jordan Used Cocaine in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15  A lawyer for a 36yearold Texas woman has told the Justice Department that she observed Hamilton Jordan, President Carter's chief of staff, sniff cocaine at a 1977 dinner party in a Beverly Hills restaurant.

title: Aircraft Join in Fighting 2 Fires In the Angeles National Forest
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 (AP)  Firefighters, aided by tanker airplanes and helicopters that dropped water, battled two fires today in the Angeles National Forest near Palmdale, 40 miles northeast of here.

title: How the Race Is Run
description: A weakened America will be led for the next 14 months by an alarmingly weak President. Congress knows it. The Russians know it. The Israelis and Arabs know it. The oil companies and labor unions know it. Does Jimmy Carter understand that fact and know how to deal with it? The signs are not encouraging. Do his political rivals and the rest of us understand the predicament and the risks it carries? We wonder.

title: Afghan Radio Reports Dismissal Of 2 Top Government Ministers
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 15 (Reuters)  Kabul radio reported today that Prime Minister Hafizullah Amin of Afghanistan has dismissed two Cabinet ministers who helped lead the coup that brought the Sovietbacked Government to power in April last year.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Americans tend to be insular in many ways  and to a great extent, this was long the case in numismatics. Until recent years, an overwhelming majority of this country's collectors never gave a second thought to the coins that originate in other lands. Many still do not, but a growing number are finding foreign coins a stimulating field  and also a highly fertile one for investment.

description: AUTO RACING

title: Victims Will Benefit From Sum to Be Paid For Cape Man
description: ALBANY, Sept. 15 (AP)  A New York City movie producer has been ordered by the State Crime Victim's Compensation Board to pay the board $2,500 owed as part of a contract for the rights to a film about the life of the Cape Man murderer.

title: DelBello Sees an Effort To Force Shift of Offices
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 15 (UPI)  Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive, said this week that he thought the City of White Plains was trying to force Westchester to move its county seat from the city.

description: THANKS to pioneering legislation, buyers of newly constructed homes have some financial protection in the event that their roofs literally cave in.

title: Syracuse Defeats West Virginia, 2414
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 15  For Frank Maloney, the Syracuse head coach, the feeling was all very familiar. On the first play of the second half against West Virginia today, Bill Hurley, the Orangemen's quarterback, came up limping and had to be helped from the field. He did not return because of an ankle injury.

title: Clothing (and Coffee and Conversation)
description: CAROLE EGE WEART presides over her women's clothing and gift shop with a mixture of wit, hospitality and fashion wisdom reminiscent of the famed salon women who held court in their homes for the artistic elite of France's 19th century.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: if F you ain't a sprintcar fan, the bumper sticker said, you ain't nuthin'. The sticker had a truck pasted to it, and I was streaking along a couple of lengths behind, cutting straight across Indiana at the wheel of a Big American Car in the middle of Big America.

title: Russian Escapes to West By Using a Rubber Boat
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 15 (AP)  A Russian who escaped across the border in the forests and lakes of the Far North said yesterday that he had traveled for 26 days, paddling by rubber boat along rivers and walking through forests to reach Finland and then Sweden

title: DINING OUT
description: THE other night in his little shop on Crompound Road in Yorktown Heights, Paul Ma held one of his regular classes on the culture of China.

title: MUSIC It's Orchestra Time
description: SEPTEMBER is orchestral wakeup month in Connecticut, as the symphonic ensembles around the state end their vacations and spin off into a rush of rehearsals for the fall. Three weeks ago, I wrote about the adventuresome pro- grams being planned for the New Haven Symphony, starting Sept. 25. Next in line, with opening night set for Sept. 28, also in New Haven, is the Chamber Orchestra of New England, founded and directed by James Sin- clair. It will be magnificently Ma zart that first evening.

title: FACING THE REALITY OF MEXICO
description: The first time Jose Lopez Portillo visited Washington as President of Mexico, he came almost cap in hand. Only 10 weeks earlier he had inherited a shattered economy, a restive peasantry, an angry private sector and dismal relations with the United States. He wanted to make a fresh start with the just-inau- gurated Carter Administration and he wanted Washington to begin under- standing Mexico.

title: Economic Development Administration Bucks a Retrenchment Trend
description: WASHINGTON  While the ailing Chrysler Corporation's plea for Federal aid, and the troubling issue of what is an appropriate relationship between the private and public sectors, was vigorously debated on Capitol Hill again last week, a multibilliondollar program to spur private economic development in the nation's depressed urban and rural areas was quietly working its way through Congress. Adminis- tration officials and legislators agree that the Economic Development Administration is likely to receive the $3.1 billion the White House is seeking.

title: Texas Governor Sees Pact Delay
description: MOSCOW (AP)  Gov. William P. Clements Jr. of Texas predicted today that the strategic arms treaty would not be ratified by the Senate in its present form and would not clear at all until after the 1980 elections. Mr. Clements is in

title: Times Misinterpreted U.S. Agency's Report On Production of Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  An article in The New York Times yesterday misstated a report by the General Accounting Office in suggesting that American oil companies deliberately cut domestic production of crude oil last fall and winter, thus contributing to the oil shortage in the sorin2.

title: Taking a Stand Against Aid to Chrysler
description: The issue rages on. Should the Government bail out the Chrysler Corporation? Some key Congressmen indicated last week that they were against Federal aid and some businessmen feel that such a rescue has no place in the free enterprise system. Now a new group has joined the opposition  the Council for a Competitive Economy.

title: The Region
description: Connecticut, says Gov. Ella T. Grasso, is the land of steady habits. Last week, voters in mayoral primaries in several Connecticut cities demonstrated what she meant.

title: Sunday Observer
description: As a devoted student of the business pages, I was amused by the market panic created when Crosscut Saw was absorbed the other day by Intermac. Anyone who studies the exhilarating world of business closely, as I do, could have seen that Intermac's cash flow had created a temporary bulge in pork bellies, and that Crosscut Saw was ripe for plucking.

title: China Appoints 1,000 to Resolve Complaint Cases
description: PEKING, Sept. 15  The Chinese authorities have appointed 1,000 officials to look into the cases of the thousands of petitioners who have been demonstrating in Peking during the last month against personal injustices, The People's Daily announced today.

title: OLOF PALME CAREER AT STAKE IN SWEDEN
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 15  The outcome of voting in national elections here tomorrow carries the possibility of ending the political career of the country's bestknown politician, Olof Palme, the former Prime Minister and Social Democratic Party chairman.

title: Ford Fund Slashing Aid For PublicInterest Law
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)  The Ford Foundation says it is tapering off financial support for publicinterest law firms but denies it is under corporate pressure to do so.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)  President Carter has signed two proclamations, one designating Sept. 22 as National Hunting and Fishing Day and another proclaiming Oct. 1 as Child Health Day.

title: New Hearing, New Wrinkles In Appeals on HBomb Case

That is what has happened in the First Amendment test of The Progressive magazine's right to publish an article on thermonuclear weapons. Or so it appeared when a threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit heard argument in the case here last week.

As the school year opened this month, thousands of children in the New York metropolitan area were programmed into classes to be taught in Spanish, French and other languages besides English.

description: COOKING schools throughout the state are as varied as they are many. Virtually every adult school of any consequence has several cooking or food-oriented courses on its list, and kitchenware establishments and small catering shops are branching out into teaching. too.

title: Accessories: A Shift From Neutral Tones To Strong Colors
description: LOOK for color and shape in accessories this fall. Shapes are usually geometrics, colors not bright but strong  plum, burgundy, deep green. These new colors are meant to be worn as the old neutral browns and blacks once were.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: DUST COMES TO WALLINGFORD

title: State Help Solves Dispute on Times Square Youth Center
description: Governor Carey has decided to donate the use of the state's former Manhattan Rehabilitation Center on 10th Avenue to Times Square shelter for homeless youths, resolving a dispute with local merchants and theater officials who opposed a planned expansion of the shelter's facilities on Eighth Avenue.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: I'm not a screenwriter. I'm a novel- 1st who writes screenplays, William Goldman told us from his vacation hide- away in Puerto Rico, where he was rest- ing after a promotion tour for his 11th novel, the bestselling Tinsel.

title: Jaycees See Positive
description: TULSA, Okla., Sept. 15 (AP)  The national leader of the United States Jaycees says that court challenges to the organization's allmale membership rule have had a positive result because they have put the group in the national limelight. They have not, however, changed his mind about admitting women.

title: A Festival of Independent Films
description: In New York, feature films of every nation, stripe and persuasion seem to land theatrical engagements except, that is, those made by Americans outside the studio system. To focus attention on such hide- pendents as Richard Pearce, who directed Heartland (above), the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Film Fund are sponsoring the Festival of American Independent Feature Films at the Paramount Theater, 2 Gulf & Western Plaza, as an adjunct to the 17th New York Film Festival. Starting Saturday, a halfdozen featurelength independent films that have not been commercially released, as well as nine that have, will be shown.

title: That's Doing in MEMPHIS,
description: RIVER CITY  Memphis sits high above the Mississippi River, which is its western boundary and separates it from Arkansas. The city, with a metropolitanarea population of more than 800,000, is in the extreme southwest corner of Tennessee.

title: ART VIEW; Henry Fuseli A Leader in Romanticism
description: HILTON KRAMER

title: Patricia B. Conover Married To Douglas Everard Miles
description: The marriage of Patricia Barwick Conover, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cameron Howard Conover of Summit, N.J., to Douglas Everard Miles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles William Miles Jr. of Basking Ridge, N.J., took place yesterday in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Murray Hill, N.J. The Canon Charles A. Shreve performed the ceremony.

title: Emily Fuller, R. G. Watson Are Married
description: Emily Anne Fuller, daughter of Mrs. Brooks Brown Jr. of York, Me., and the late Henry Morrill Fuller, was married yesterday afternoon to Ronald George Watson, president of the Northeast Boat Company in Stonington, Me.

title: Rev. Marcia Smith Wed To Donald L. Klepper
description: The Rev. Marcia Blakeslee Smith of Greenwich, Conn., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merwin B. Smith of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, and Donald Lawrence Klepper, son of Judith Littlewood of Northport, L.I., and Arthur Klepper of Huntington Station, L.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. T. Merton Rymph performed the ceremony at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, where the bride is associate minister. Her husband is a staff assistant with the Southern New England Telephone Company in New Haven.

title: An Unhurried View of Joggers
description: THE passing parade now comes by at tempo jog and the variety of costumes enshrouding the runners these days displays an enormous vigor of design, a wardrobe as colorful and eyecatching as those that used to go public in a Ziegfeld Follies.

title: CRIME
description: Campbell Black, who appears not to have been active in recent years, returns with BRAINFIRE (Morrow, $10.95). Mr. Black is attracted by themes concerning the mind. At least, in his Death's Head, published in 1972, he had a good deal to say about mental torture. Something of that theme is present in Brainfire, though there are also elements of science fiction here.

title: LETTER TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Rodino Is Assailed On Choice for Bench

description: Senate

title: Lafayette 33, U.S.M.M.A. 6
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., Sept. 15  Ed Ruth, returning after having missed the last two seasons with injuries, ran for 71 yards in 11 carries, but it was not enough to prevent a 336 defeat of the United States Merchant Marine Academy by Lafayette.

title: Paper Concern to Pay Damages to Gardeners Because of Herbicides
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 15 (AP)  The St. Regis Paper Company will pay damages to 164 eastern Maine residents whose vegetable gardens may have been contaminated by drifting herbicides this summer. a comnanv official says.

title: Page Rinehart Wed to David Rollin Du Val Regine Rayevsky Wed to Dr. W. A. Fisher
description: Page Rinehart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodger Richmond Rinehart Jr. of Charlottesville, Va., was married yesterday to David Rollin Du Val, son of State Senator Clive Livingston Du Val 2d and Mrs. Du Val of McLean. Va. The Rev. Charles Walter Carnan Jr. performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Ivy, Va.

title: Koch's First Meeting With Blacks To Improve Relations Productive
description: Mayor Koch yesterday held the first of a series of meetings designed to improve his relations with the black community and pronounced it very productive.

title: Opera: Gianna Rolandi in Lucia
description: The New York City Opera staged plausible Lucia di Lammermoor with a familiar cast Friday night, the opera's first performance of the season. Tito Capobianco's production strongly accents the work's undercurrent of Romantic melodrama, sometimes to excess and with a good deal of unmotivated business. At least the action is kept lively and forwardmoving, while the singers on this occasion entered into the spirit of things with a fair amount of raw energy.

title: Furs Turning Sleeker, Narrower and Smarter
description: THE Wild West look in furs went riding off into the sunset this year. The 1979 fur is sleek and narrow and sophisticated. After almost a decade of enormous, longhaired pelts, furriers are thinking small again. (Not about prices, however; we'll go into those later.) There are still longhairs to be had, of course, but even raccoon has slimmed down. The main fashion swing is to flatter furs that are used like fabric.

title: Rocket
description: ROSLYN HARBOR

description: MEL GUSSOW

title: Dr. Barnard Dream: Transplanting The Heart of a Black Into a White
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 15 (UPI) The heart surgeon Christiaan Barnard told doctors here today that before he retired he wanted to transplant a heart from a black Zambian to a white South African.

title: Black Architects Find Recognition An Elusive Goal
description: Black Architects Find Recognition An Elusive Goal

title: Ah, High School!
description: THE fact that a new school year has just begun is the reason, I suppose, that I had a dream the other night that I was back in high school, of all places. I wouldn't mind having my life to live over again, but to be back in high school? No way.

title: Connecticut Considers Another Investigation Of 73 Fatal Accident
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept 15  State officials said this week that they were considering reopening a grand jury investigation into a highly publicized hitandrun death in New London more than five years ago, although it is too late to prosecute the case.

title: Interpretations of Bible Divide Protestant Denominations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)  An increasing number of religious groups are engaging in bitter internal debates over how the Bible should be read and interpreted. The debate is like the one that helped bring about a schism in the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod two years ago.

title: Barbara Lounsbery Wed to C.R. Johnson Jr.
description: Barbara Lounsbery, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Phillips Lounsbery of Bedford, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Charles R. Johnson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Raymond Johnson of Litchfield, Conn. The Rev. Daniel Miner performed the ceremony in St. Matthew's Episcopal. Church.

title: Swedish Sport Finds Its Way Here
description: FROM the people who brought you the rigors of crosscountry skiing, the mental storms of Bergman films and the intense concentration of Bjorn Borg, comes a sport challenging both mind and body: Orienteering. This curpriigh imnort has been termed cunning run- ning, and bumper stickers on the cars of enthusiasts proclaim, Orienteering, the thinking sport.

title: Bomb Injures Policeman in Israel And P.L.O. Claims Responsibility
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 15 (AP) A bomb exploded in the Tel Aviv suburb of Bat Yam, injuring a policeman who was trying to move it, the police said today.

title: Salvagers Hoping to Find Silver Inside Tug That Sank Off Alaska
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 15 (AP)  Salvagers say they are hoping to haul millions of dollars in silver from a tug that sank more than 20 years ago off the Pacific coast of Alaska.

title: R.P. McGraw, Editor, Weds Dawn Watson
description: The marriage of Dawn Ann Watson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Watson of Leonia, N.J., to Robert P. McGraw of New York took place yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church of Englewood, N.J. The Rev. Harry Chase performed the ceremony.

title: L. Clark Ridgeley, 39, Executive With Mutual Fund Organization
description: L. Clark Ridgeley, a vice president and director of the trading department for American General Capital Management, died of a heart attack at his office in Houston Thursday. Mr. Ridgeley, who lived in Houston, was 39 years old.

title: Mississipi Capital Gaining in Recovery From Flood
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 14 (UPI) We've got the worst behind us, said Connie Devos, sitting in the red brick house that was filled to the attic with water five months ago.

Through September. $5.50 to $7.50. Discount available for students, the elderly and groups. Reservations. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, junction of Routes 6 and 118. 6281169.

title: DINING OUT Meals for All at Moderate Prices
description: FAIRFIELD DINING at Dogwoods can be an eclectic experience. One is likely to see teenagers on dates, small children celebrating birthdays and opening gifts with abandon, swinging singles, sedate elders. The reason is obvious at a first glance at the menu: This yearold restaurant is filling a real need in Fairfield and offers some of the best allround value seen lately.

title: Nathaniel Rosen Set For Carnegie Debut
description: Nathaniel Rosen, the first American cellist to win the Tchaikovsky Gold Medal in Moscow, will make his Carnegie Hall debut Oct. 3 at 8 P.M. as soloist with the Moscow State Symphony Orchestra.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING Housing Shortage at Local Colleges
description: WHEN the 27,000 undergraduates who attend Westchester's 13 colleges headed for the campus this month, only one in five carried clothes, stereos and easy chairs to school. The rest turned around at the end of the day and went back to the same dormitory they lived in during high school  their bedroom at the family home.

title: OneMan Bridge?
description: HOW sweet it was to be in Canada in 1968. The afterglow of the previous year's joyous celebration of the centennial of Canadian confederation still suffused a country that seemed at last to have shed its reputation for national grayness. By comparison with the United States and in Canada it is an imperative comparison  Canada was a blessed place.

description: IMET James T. Farrell on the great day, late in 1934, when he finished Judgment Day' the concluding volume of the Studs Lonigan trilogy. I had heard that he was a tremendous ideological scrapper, given to demolishing as You phony! many an

title: Liberal Reforms and Radical Visions
description: SINCE 1960, American society has been transformed by a quiet revolution. In response to the unrelenting pressure of a militant civilrights movement, the courts and the Congress dismantled a racial case system embedded in law and practice for generations. The old order was swept away by legislation including the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965, as well as by the commitment of billions of Federal dollars to socialwelfare programs.

title: A Detour to Nihilism
description: JOHN HAWKES writes as thought perversity were the lively part of civilization. His characters are sexual oddballs who could have surfaced from KrafftEbing, thrilling to fetishes. Typical is Hencher in The Lime Twig (1960), who returns to his home years after the Blitz to loll in the bed of his dead mother; or Skipper in Second Skin (1964). who submits to his daughter's wish that he tattoo her long and ominous name, Cassandra, on his breast in green because green's a bad color ... green's going to hurt; or the couples in The Blood Oranges (1971), whose sexual mission is to drain each other. Riveted in obsession, such characters are virtual antidotes to the detached people of much new fiction and reminders of the mysterious forms of fulfillment.

title: Shoulder It, Men: Padding Is Back
description: EVEN men who shrug at fashion will probably find themselves in jackets with padded shoulders this fall. Broad shoulders are back, casual is out and dressy is in. And for whatever ominous reasons, so are dark, moody colors.

title: Grain Elevator Explosion Kills 1
description: MONTEVIDEO, Minn., Sept. 15 (AP)  The Pillsbury grain elevator here exploded and burned yesterday, killing one man and injuring three. The victim was Harlan Guse, 20 years old. Sparks from an overheated bearing were suspected as the cause of the blast, the authorities said.

title: U.S. Takes Doubles For 30 Cup Victory
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 15  In the end, was the streak that saved them. After trailing, two sets to love and 45, Stan Smith and Bob Lutz could have bowed quietly today and extended the drama of the American Zone Davis Cup tennis final another day.

title: Editors'
description: BURGER'S DAUGHTER, by Nadine Gordimer. (Viking Press, $10.95.) The daughter of a South African political martyr struggles to keep her father's cause alive and to find an identity of her own: a dazzling novel.

title: When Music (Thud! Crash!) Fills the Air
description: NEEDING peace, I left New York City six years ago to settle in a little town in New Jersey. But even there Oradell, in Bergen County  I cannot escape the clamor that attacks the senses.

description: A group of female scientists have begun circulating a petition among their colleagues in colleges and universities throughout the city in support of Dr. Jewel Plummer Cobb, a prominent cell biologist, to become the eighth president of Hunter College.

description: Aline Wallace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip V.G. Wallace of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Leo Gendron, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Gendron of Houston. The Rev. Stuart Sandberg performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: Notre Dame Wins by 1210; Blocks Late Michigan Kick
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 15 Chuck Male, a soccerstyle kicker who grew up within four miles of Notre Dame's Golden Dome, kicked four field goals today to give Notre Dame major upset over Michigan, 1210, in the seasonopening football game for the Irish.

title: South Africa Recruiting More Blacks for Its Army
description: LENZ ARMY BASE, South Africa Last year, Frans Raseroka, like thousands of young South Africans, went to war.

title: Auburn 26, Kansas State 18
description: AUBURN, Ala., Sept. 15 (UPI) Charlie Trotman ran 39 yards for an early touchdown and passed 30 yards for another today to help Auburn post a 2618 victory over Kansas State.

title: Wine
description: This is the beginning of the busiest of all seasons in the wine shops. From now until Jan. 1, the rush is on. It may seem a bit early to select the wines for your Thanksgiv- ing dinner and New Year's Eve party, but it's more relaxing to buy early and there is money to be saved in buying by the case. What's more, inflation has less chance to take its toll. It's a safe bet, for example, that champagne purchased now will be cheaper than the same wine bought at the peak of the holiday period.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: I chuckled when I read the article Abortion Bill: Debate On [Aug. 26].

title: Reagan Urges Senate To Reject Arms Pact, But His Tone Is Softer
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15  Ronald Reagan called for rejection of the second treaty on limitation of strategic arms in moderately worded speech today that appeared to reflect efforts by his advisers to make him appear less vehement on issues that arouse high emotions among conservatives.

title: STAMPS
description: A 10cent postal card depicting a sprinter will be issued tomorrow by the United States as the second item in its continuing postal releases for the 1980 Olympic Games. Then on Sept. 23 a 15cent Bicentennial commemorative for John Paul Jones, naval hero of the American Revolution, will be issued as part of its ongoing observance of the great events of 200 years ago.

title: A Morbid Fascination With the Next Table
description: SHE started the conversation by saying how disappointed she was that they were out of arugula.

title: Clock Collectors
description: Lancaster County in Pennsylvania has been celebrating its 250th anniversary this year, and some of its museums have mounted special exhibits of the work of local artisans to mark the occasion. Among them is the museum of the National Association of Watch and Clock Collectors, which is just off U.S. 90 on the eastern bank of the Susquehanna in Columbia, 10 miles west of the city of Lancaster. Its exhibit, 225 Years of Timepieces: A Lancaster County Legacy, which is in addition to its permanent display of timepieces, is continuing through Oct. 31.

title: Cheerfulness Tempers Terror of Hurricane as Victims Do Without 20th Century Comforts
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss., Sept. 15 Looks like Mardi Gras, said a teenager on a bicycle as he tried unsuccessfully to force his way through a monumental traffic jam at the corner of Pascagoula Street and Highway 90. The crush had developed as an anxious throng with coolers and chests besieged an ice house in a quest for the big 50pound blocks that would keep their food from spoiling.

title: Wake Forest Upsets Georgia
description: ATHENS, Ga., Sept. 15 (AP)  Jay Venuto threw three touchdown passes and James McDougald ran for 189 yards as Wake Forest upset Georgia, 2221. today.

title: United Press International
description: UNSUCCESSFUL BLOCKING: Bill Russell of Dodgers avoiding the sliding Hector Cruz of Reds to throw to first for a double play. Cruz, forced out at second, slid into base in an attempt block the double play in third inning yesterday. Reds won 21.

description: DETROIT, Sept. 15  The tentative agreement reached last night on a new threeyear contract between the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation, averting a strike against the big automobile maker, was hailed today in Government and industry circles.

title: Feeling A Draft
description: WASHINGTON  To most Americans, the familiar Edward M. Kennedy is the Senatorial Kennedy, an oldstyle liberal who has remained true to the credo that ever bigger Government is ever better, even while liberals all around him are abandoning the territory. Last week, a Presidential Kennedy appeared, and during a brief foray into broad economic issues, offered a more au courant philosophy dwelling heavily on free enterprise, the limitations of Government and inflation. The Kennedy who has waged wars for tax reform for working families now stressed that when a tax cut became necessary it should first include breaks for business, to spur investment.

title: Epidemic of Charger Mania Hits San Diego

That seems to fit for San Diego, where the early success and considerable promise of the pro football team, the Chargers, has the attention of the city. Chareer mania is building to the proportions of the Bronco mania that swept through Denver two seasons ago when the hometown team became a big winner for the first time and went on to the Super Bowl.

title: On Initiative And Referendum
description: NEW YORKERS are taking a look at the processes of initiative and referendum. Voters in other states have used these procedures of direct democracy since the Progressive Era a hundred years ago. The initiative gives citizens a way in which to place measures of their choosing on the ballot for a public vote; the referendum offers the opportunity to accept or reject, by public vote, a measure passed by the legislature.

title: Paperback Story
description: IN July 1977, In Place of Love, a second novel by Aviva Hellman, arrived at Bantam Books from the subsidiaryrights people at G. P. Putnam's Sons. Written by a former model and onetime publicrelations director at Cosmopolitan magazine, the book follows the story of a woman who, after her marriage dissolves, forgoes love transform a moribund women's magazine into the biggest deal in publishing, then risks it all by printing a male movie idol centerfold (not Burt Reynolds).

title: Dayan Is Not The Only Rebel In the Begin Government
description: JERUSALEM  Some Israelis call it open government, others call it anarchy. But whatever its label, the characteristic freewheeling, outfront squabbling among Israel's Cabinet ministers has begun to create confusion in the sedate world of international diplomacy which still subscribes to the notion that a foreign minister, for example, ought to speak and act in accordance with his Government's policies.

Roehm of Weston, Conn. The Rev. James Chapman, assisted by .the Rev. James Kennedy, performed the ceremony in the Greens Farms (Conn.) Congregational Church. title: Bluebirds Are Back
description: THERE'S nothing more fun than hearing the lovely little song of the bluebirds, Mrs. William S. Gray was saying the other day. She has reason to be pleased, for six or seven (she's not sure how many) bluebirds were born and fledged on her Fairfield County property this summer.

title: Judith Jean Galloway Bride of David Totaro
description: Judith Jean Galloway, daughter of Jean Price Feidelson of Wantagh, L.I., and Ben F. Galloway of Beaumont, Tex., was married in New York yesterday to David Jonathan Totaro, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Samuel Charles Totaro of West Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. F. Reid Isaac performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Robert E. Cowden 3d To Wed Martha McCahill
description: Mr. and Mrs. Woods McCahill of Albany and Delray Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Martha McCahill, to Robert E. Cowden 3d, son of Mrs. Cowden Jr. of Dayton, Ohio, and the late Mr. Cowden.

title: IDEAS &
description: WASHINGTON  The Miltown generation has given way to one that pops Darvon, Librium and Valium like candy corn. So Congressional investigators are not alone wondering aloud if Americans are overmedicated and whether the laws regulating prescription drugs should change. Last week a Senate panel held hearings into the prescribing of Valium, now taken routinely by more than 15 percent of the adult population, and concluded that if its use continues to climb, more millions of Americans will be relying on Valium to start, face and end the day.

title: Officer Is Slain and U.S. Agent Hurt in 2 Shootings
description: A United States Secret Service agent was shot and seriously wounded early yesterday while trying to stop a holdup in a Manhattan restaurant, little more than an hour after an offduty policeman was killed in a separate incident in Brooklyn.

title: AMERICA'S MOST INFLUENTIAL JONES
description: The absurdly long, black limousine entered the gates and wheeled smoothly along the winding driveway to the entrance to the White House. Usually, a Presidential aide would greet the limousine's occupant. But the tall, soberfaced figure that emerged from the car was stirred to see a slight, sandyhaired man with a wide, toothy grin waiting to shake hands. The car's occupant wasn't the Prime Minister of Britain or Vice Premier of China. It was Reginald H. Jones, the chairman and chief executive of the General Electric Company.

title: E.B. Howard Weds E. Elizabeth Wallau
