title: Scientists Say Major Solar Flare May Indicate New Disturbances
description: BOULDER, Colo., Sept. 15 (UPI) Federal scientists say a major flare on the surface of the sun, which has been relatively quiet in the last two weeks, may be the first in a new series of solar disturbances.

title: DINING OUT A Potential Standout in Bergen
description: THIS is the kind of restaurant that makes you feel at home immediately. It has warmth, the staff is a mixture of smiling and friendly young people and the menu is pleasant, not too ambitious and tends toward lightness in food. It an establishment with promise.

title: The Man Who Bought the France
description: OSLO  It's not being advertised yet, and the booking lists still aren't open. But already more than 20,000 Americans have applied for berths on the world's largest and grandest oceangoing liner, once called the France and now rechristened the Norway, when she starts her new, more democratic life as a Caribbean cruise ship sailing out of Miami next summer.

title: Megan Lloyd Slate Wed To Matthew L. Greene
description: Megan Lloyd Slate and Matthew Lanning Greene were married yesterday at the Manhattan home of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Piker. The Rev. George La Porte performed the Unitarian ceremony.

title: A 1950's Teenager
description: ONCE upon a time, way back in the prehistoric 50's, which was about 20 years B.C.K. (Before Calvin Klein), all that was needed to look right in high school were twotone Oxfords, bobby sox, bulky sweater and a $15 tartan kilt. Clothes didn't even need to fit well. You could borrow from a friend. You frequently did.

title: Father and Son Team Puts Great Adventure to the Test
description: Twelve-year-old Patrick, always eager for Saturday with Daddy, was up early and excited for the visit to Great Adventure in New Jersey. His brother, Michael, who is 20, had told him about the rides: You sit in a hollow log that runs through water and splashes all over. And there's a safari with real animals.

title: Accessories: A Shift From Neutral Tones To Strong Colors
description: LOOK for color and shape in accessories this fall. Shapes are usually geometrics, colors not bright but strong  plum, burgundy, deep green. These new colors are meant to be worn as the old neutral browns and blacks once were.

description: ATLANTA, Sept. 15 (AP)  The Federal Commerce Department has granted $2 million to help build a center for multilingual meetings at. the Martin Luther King Center for Social Change.

description: MOST politicians who were tempted to draw conclusions from last week's pri- maryelection results shied away from sweeping analyses because the candidates personalities, particularly in the key mayoral races, played such strong roles in the cam- paigns.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 (AP)  In 1892, a small group of men gathered in the downtown office of Warren Olney, a San Francisco lawyer, to write the articles of incorporation for their small explorer group.

title: A Changing Role for Party Leaders

He got on the phone to key district leaders to say that he was cutting off patronage to Troy. Within 24 hours, Donald Manes was Queens Democratic chairman.

title: CHESS
description: According to Anatoly Lein, a 43-year-old emigrant from the Soviet Union who now lives in Cleveland, defensive play comes to him more naturally than pressing an attack. The mutt, genial granamaster seems to enjoy an uphill struggle to an adjournment, which he can analyze all night through  or at least as long as the beer and cigarettes hold out.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times on Friday misstated a section of a report by the General Accounting Office on a decline in domestic crude oil production. A corrective article appears on page 23.

description: WHEN Anne Williams and Susan Kelly pulled their aluminum canoe out of the water at Old Saybrook recently, they had completed a river tourney into Connecticut's past.

title: Lynda Jean Holohan Is Married
description: Lynda Jean Holohan and Kenneth Patrick Baron were married yesterday at the United Methodist Church in Smithtown, L.I., by the Rev. John Bardsley. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Holohan of Forest Hills, Queens. Her husband is son of Mr. and Mrs. John Baron of Maspeth, Queens. The bride graduated from the Mary Louis Academy in Jamaica, Queens, and magna cum laude from Queens College. Mr. Baron owns the Northside Riding Club in Port Jefferson, L.I.

title: NORTHSOUTH GROUP REACHES AGREEMENT
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C., Sept. 15  Leaders of the North and South, regions that have been engaged in an intense economic war for two years, have reached agreements that they believe could lead to important breakthroughs on national policy in such areas as transportation, energy and Federal funds.

title: Rock Stars Are Into Politics Again
description: Madison Square Garden will be the site this week of what seem likely to become the biggest series of political benefit concerts in the history of rock-and-roll, or perhaps of any form of popular entertainment. The MUSE Concerts for a Non-Nuclear Future are expected to draw some 100,000 people from Wednesday through next Sunday, and will be both recorded and filmed. And on the fifth and final day of the concerts, there will be a mass rally featuring many of the concert performers. It will be broadcast nationwide, and will take place at the Battery Park City landfill, south of the World Trade Center. Given a bit of luck with the weather, it could also challenge attendance records for rallies of this sort.

title: Lawyer Recalls His Personal Fight to Learn
description: When 16-year-old Hector Nava arrived in New York City from his native Argentina he hadn't the faintest idea, as he puts it now, of how to ask to go to the bathroom. I didn't know what was going on.

title: On Language
description: Have you positioned yourself yet on the issue of verbificaHon? Put another way: Have you taken a position yet on the issue of turning nouns, adjectives and the like into verhq?

title: Conservative Government Faces Test in Today's Election
description: STOCKHOLM  Thewinner in today's Swedish election is the welfare state. Regardless of the outcome, the social services budget will grow, the number of the bureaucrats who administer it will increase, and the range of cash, benefits and security the state offers will expand  in exchange for new taxes, new forms to fill out and only occasional questions about whether it's worth it all.

title: Closing of Murder Trial Brings High Court Plea
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 15 (AP)  The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press is asking the United States Supreme Court to hear an appeal by Richmond Newspapers Inc. of a judge's closing of a murder trial to the public.

title: Pop: The Who's Balance
description: The Who have remained a superb performing band throughout their long and varied recording career, and it was this facet of the group that a packed Madison Square Garden celebrated Thursday night. Despite the addition of John (Rabbit) Bundrick's keyboards and a threeman brass section, and the replacement of the late Keith Moon, the Who's original drummer, by Kenny Jones, this was basically the same, familiar Who. And despite the complaints of diehard fans, who missed Mr. Moon and seemed to resent the group's deployment of additional instrumental resources, the Who gave a splendid rock-and-roll concert that carefully balanced innovation and tradition.

title: Senate Unit Forces Floor Debate on Synthetic Fuel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  President Carter has lost the first round in his struggle to persuade Congress to create multibilliondollar Government corporation to develop synthetic fuels and produce them in volume.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: About 10 years ago this would have been a revolutionary book. The notion that traditional roles assumed by or thrust upon men could be arbitrary, artificial and destructive to men and to women, the idea that men had to be freed from rigid emotional constraints, the idea that men needed the freedom to feel gentleness, vulnerability, doubt these were just beginning to stir about the land in the late 1960's.

title: THE HIGHS OF THE GAME
description: All the years I played basketball looked for that perfect game. I never had that perfect day, and I graded myself after every game to see how far in my own mind I fell short. The best score I ever gave myself was 65 on scale of 100. It was a game in Boston in 1964, which I consider my best year. got between 30 and 35 rebounds, made a high percentage of my shots, blocked a

title: C.W.Post Is Beaten In Opener
description: GREENVALE, L.I., Sept. 15  East Stroudsburg State College spoiled C.W. Post's season opener by turning back the Pioneers. 1710. today.

title: An Appeal to Break Up That 01
description: THE college football season is upon us, but please excuse me for not getting very excited about it. No, I do not dislike college football; I've followed it since Pete Dawkins's days at West Point in the late 1950's and I prefer the college game to the National Football League version. The sport has lost most of its charm, however, and has become something worn and tired, like an old Errol Flynn movie seen too many times.

title: For Jets
description: Rarely have so many people worried about the psyche of a left tackle. Even the men who play against the Jets Chris Ward seem to have compassion for him.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS The Rightists Brigade
description: WASHINGTON  It is getting harder and harder to know what is going on in Cuba with that Soviet brigade, and easier and easier to understand the disarray in Washington. Maybe the Soviet personnel in the brigade have been in Cuba since 1962. Maybe they did perform training and advisory duties and were just recently given a brigadecommand structure. Maybe it is a combat brigade now, and worthy of a serious Administration response. But the point is this: Before the facts could be established, a number of scared and ambitious political leaders, legislators and a few Administration policy makers went off like firecrackers.

title: Auditioning for Woody Allen

description: Opening statements are expected to be presented tomorrow by the prosecution and the defense at the racketeering trial of Anthony M. Scotto of the International Longshoremen's Association.

description: For years, the beauty of late summer and autumn wildflowers was ours only when we went for a walk or a drive along country roads. Although we have been wildflower enthusiasts for years and have an extensive wild garden. we had never populated it with flowers that bloom at this time of year. Of bloodroot, there is an abundance, but nary an aster.

title: Penn State's Warner Routs Rutgers, 4510
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 15  For 15 minutes today, Joe Paterno could hardly believe what he saw. His Penn State football team, acclaimed far and wide as the class of the East, was held to a standstill by Rutgers.

title: Afghans Talk About Torture and Killings by Regime
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 8 (AP) A Kabul businessman locked the door, switched on a radio and turned up its volume. Then he described in a low voice what he said was a 17month reign of terror in which real or imagined opponents of the Afghan regime have been arrested, sometimes with wives and children, tortured and secretly executed.

title: IS THERE SEX AFTER MARRIAGE?
description: Sex therapists are encountering increased numbers of married patients suffering from inhibited sexual desire. The leading reason that marital sex dies: underlying rage toward one's spouse.

title: Miss Mestern Wed To P. J. O'Brien Jr.
description: Gretel Mestern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Mestern of Lakewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul John O'Brien Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Brien of Daytona Beach, Fla. The Rev. Charles J. Mahoney performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Fashions for Faces: Fuchsia Plus
description: AMAKEUP expert once observed that, unlike the constant changes in clothes styles, fashions in faces really changed only every five years or so. This is obviously fifth year. The monochrome beige and brown look we're getting bored with is giving way to a frankly painted female who is out to play the seductress and be noticed. She's more like the pinup of World War II than anyone we've seen for a long time. Ironically, it seems that the more equality women ask for, the more they want to celebrate la difference with their looks.

title: ISRAELI JEWS CLASH ON SABBATH TRAFFIC
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 15  Hundreds of Orthodox and secular Jews confronted each other angrily for several hours this afternoon with taunts and sporadic rock throwing across a stretch of road that the Orthodox have been trying for months to close on the Sabbath.

title: Torture Case Tests Argentina's Ability to Curb Police
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 15  A wellpublicized case of police torture of a political prisoner has become a test of whether Argentina's military regime is prepared to discipline its security forces.

title: HOME CLINIC New Light on Dimming Devices
description: DIMMER switches have been popular in homes and apartments for some years now because they provide a simple means for controlling the brightness of lights in a living room, den, bed- room or similar area where lighting needs may vary  from full brightness for working, reading or playing games, to softer lighting that may be desired while dining, socializing or watching television. In the past couple of years, dimmer switches are also being installed for another reason  as a means of cutting down on the size of the monthly electric bill.

title: Broker Commissions An Issue in Nation
description: About to place her $45,000 twobedroom condominium in Cromwell, Conn., on the market earlier this year, Lorraine Turbidy blanched at the idea of having to pay $2,700 in commission fees to her local real estate agent, the traditional 6 percent rate for the area.

title: Other World Events
description: Citizens from all over China with complaints have been camped in protest outside Communist Party offices in Peking this summer. Last week, some of them braved official disapproval to hold a rally against privileged bureaucrats. We have wiped out capitalists, landlords and rich peasants, but now we have a new rich class, said one speaker. The rally of 1,000 young workers and students, peasants and army veterans in Tien An Men Square followed a protest march to Government offices by several hundred rejected students and a meeting in a park by 300 writers to discuss the state of official and underground literature.

title: The Empty Promise of an Oil Reserve
description: If five years of debate over energy has yielded consensus on any issue, it is the need for a reserve against interruptions in foreign oil supplies. For fear of driving up world oil prices, however, the Carter Administration has suspended purchases for the emergency storage program. The strategic petroleum reserve, now appears, may fall victim to the same public indifference that has sunk virtually every worthy energy initiative.

title: Lessons of Nicaragua's revolt don't quite fit in El Salvador. Page 4.
description: SAN SALVADOR  Immediately after the Sandinist success in Nicaragua this summer, both left and right in nearby El Salvador agreed that this would be the next Central American Republic to be convulsed by insurrection. Demand for change had been repeatedly frustrated by fraudulent elections, while official repression had spawned leftist terrorism and militant political movements.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)  The Federal Government today rejected Chicago's latest school desegregation plan, saying that the city's school board had illegally segregated its schools for decades. The action could lead to the largest Federal desegregation suit in history.

description: AFTER reading The Hidden Woes of Doctor's Wives [Aug. 26], I was suddenly possessed by the rebuttal demon and found myself sitting in front of my typewriter.

title: St. John's 6, Kean 6
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 15  St. John's University and Kean College battled to a 66 tie today at Hofstra University's field. The Redmen (0-1-1) opened the scoring in the second period

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IF James L. Buckley, the former ConservativeRepublican Senator of New York, did decide to run for the United States Senate in Connecticut and if he were to get elected, he would still have a way to go to match the record of one James Shields.

title: A Year After Camp David: Egypt and. Israel Still Seek Peace Despite Setbacks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  On the anniversary of the Camp David accords, the United States, Israel and Egypt find themselves in relative harmony, after several weeks of intense friction caused by American efforts to lure the Palestinians into negotiations at an early stage.

title: Dr. Patricia Glowa, Physician, Married
description: The marriage of Dr. Patricia Todd Glowa, daughter of Sally Todd Nelson of Montreal and Fair Harbor, Fire Island, L.I., and Michael Glowa of North Springfield, Vt., to Dr. Donald 0. Kollisch took place yesterday on the beach at Saltaire, Fire Island. Mayor Norma M. Ervin of Saltaire performed the ceremomy. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Stephen T. Kollisch of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Shifts Loom As Counties Eye Census
description: WHEN the results of the 1970 census came nearly a decade ago, they sketched out the dramatic population shift that had swept across Long Island during the 1960's. Those heeding an injunction to Go East nearly doubled Suffolk's population in 10 years.

title: World News Briefs
description: SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 15 (AP) About 2,500 people marched in a funeral procession today for two leftist high school teachers who were shot to death a week ago.

description: Reporter's Notebook: A Presidential Forerunner

description: MAPLEWOOD, N.J.  It's time to say a few words in defense of inaccessibility.

description: RUMSON

title: Associated Press
description: NEW AT THE ZOO: A young female tapir is nuzzled by her mother at the Los Angeles Zoo. At birth, two weeks ago, she looked like a furry brown-andwhite watermelon, said Dr. Warren Thomas, zoo director. Tapirs are mountain animals native to the Colombian and Ecuadorian Andes.

title: Carter Offers Message For Jewish Holy Days
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) President Carter said this week in note of the Jewish high holy days of Rosh haShanah, Sept. 22, which is the Jewish New Year, and Yom Kippur, Oct. 1, the Day of Atonement, that he hoped the next year would bring the world closer to Just and lasting peace. His statement, released on Tuesday, said:

title: Mary B. Pivirotto Bride in Greenwich Of Robert Murley
description: Mary Burchfield Pivirotto, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Roy Pivirotto of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert Scott Murley, son of Mrs. Vernon L. Frazier of San Marino, Calif., and the late George

title: Tests in English Said to Mislabel Many Hispanic Pupils Retarded
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A few years ago Olivia Martinez, then a guidance counselor for the San Francisco public schools, was asked to have a look at a 10-year-old Hispanic girl in a class for mentally retarded children.

title: A 10Year Writeoff Schedule Proposed
description: Calls upon Congress to liberalize the depreciation allowances for real estate are rising in the wake of continuing inflation, raising again some longstanding issues on the relationship of taxes and investment property.

title: 20,000 March to an Oompah. Beat As City Celebrates Steuben Day
description: Twenty thousand marchers moved up Fifth Avenue in the dazzling sunshine and cool breezes of a nearperfect late-summer day for the 22d annual Steuben Day Parade yesterday.

title: Suffolk Voters Display Their Anger
description: Mea culpa, said a penitent John V. N. Klein, throwing himself on the mercy of the voters. Nothing doing, replied the angry electorate last week, as Suffolk County Republicans turned out the Suffolk County Executive.

title: Scot Unearths Gold of 700 B.C.
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 15 (Reuters)  A farmer in northern Scotland has unearthed a cache of gold jewelry dating from about 700 B.C., archeologists said today. The jewelry, five bracelets

title: For Higher Education, a Later Chance'?
description: THE most politically sensitive issue to come before the General Assembly at its 1980 session will be the reorganization of higher education in Connecticut. The basic proposal of the State Board of Higher Education would effect a rea- lignment of existing branches of higher education in the hope of reducing duplication and fragmentation. The redrawing of bureaucratic lines in Connecticut state agencies is not a new phenomenon and it may mean little more than business as usual. So one begins to look elsewhere for successful models of higher education in order to measure the boldness and resolve of the B.H.E. and the Legislature for providing a progressive, farreaching system of higher education.

title: Passengers Seize Plane As French Pilot Strikes
description: PARIS, Sept. 15 (AP)  Passengers on a French jetliner, enraged at their pilot's decision to go on strike a few minutes before takeoff, seized the aircraft to force the company to find them an alternative flight, said officials of Air Inter, the French domestic airline.

title: INVESTING A Healthy Market for Vintage Photos
description: Photography has come out of the darkroom and into the gallery in recent years, and the works of the early masters such as Mathew Brady, Alfred Stieglitz and Julia Margaret Cameron  limited in number and bearing the unique qualities of primitive techniques  are now recognized as thoroughly desirable investments.

title: Issue and Debate Outlook on Continued Use of Juries in Complex Civil Cases
description: Trial by jury has been a cornerstone of democracy in America, but in the last several years, as courts have become more and more clogged, the jury system has become the target of increasing criticism.

title: Jessica Lynn Blackman Is Bride of Richard Schwabacher
description: Jessica Lynn Blackman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman S. Blackman of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Richard A. Schwabacher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Schwabacher on Montclair, N.J. The ceremony was performed at the Mountain Ridge Country Club in West Caldwell, N.J., by Rabbi Ely Pilchik.

title: HeatingOil Scapegoats
description: Heating oil prices have gone through the roof. Yet the latest figures suggest that by late fall the country may be drowning in the stuff. And the apparent contradiction is almost certain to touch off a round of witchhunting, with the oil companies and the Department Energy forced to carry the brooms.

title: Swedish Leftists Hold Narrow Edge That Could Be Upset by Mail Votes
description: STOCKHOLM, Monday, Sept. 17  The Social Democratic and Communist opposition parties held a oneseat lead in elections for Sweden's Parliament yesterday, but the margin was so thin that it could be overtaken by the governing nonSocialist bloc when mail ballots are counted this week.

title: Chicago School Officials Optimistic on Desegregation
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (UPI)  School officials expressed optimism today that an acceptable desegregation plan could be negotiated with the Federal Government to avoid a Justice Department lawsuit requiring the busing of school students in the nation's second largest city.

title: Wounded Officer Is Satisfactory
description: An offduty correction officer wounded during a robbery in a Manhattan bar Saturday night was in satisfactory condition yesterday. He was the third law enforcement officer shot in the city during the weekend.

title: Chance of CarterKennedy Match Troubles O'Neill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  Despite his girth, Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. has generally demonstrated an ability in the past to tiptoe gently through the thorniest of political thickets.

title: Kuwait Raises Oil Prices On Increases in Contracts
description: LONDON, Monday, Sept. 17 (Reuters)  Sheik Ali Khalifa alSabah, Kuwait's oil minister, said that his country had cut the credit time allowed to buyers of its oil to 30 days from 60 days, and had told buyers that if they wished to purchase oil in addition to the amounts already contracted for, they would have to pay the higher free-market price.

title: Utah Symphony Opens Its New Home
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 16  For a while, at least, it is going to seem strange. For three decades the Utah Symphony Orchestra under its music director, Maurice Abravanel, played concerts and made recordings in the 5,200seat Mormon Tabernacle, which helped give the orchestra an international identity.

title: Layoffs at Ford Plant to Begin
description: MAHWAH, N.J., Sept. 16 (UPI) Tomorrow marks the beginning of a twoweek layoff for 4,900 assemblyline workers at the Ford Motor Company plant here. The laidoff workers, who make up almost the entire force at the plant, will receive about 95 percent of their normal salaries during the idle period through union, company and other benefits. Ford officials blame poor sales for the layoffs, which follow by a few months the permanent discharge of 75 lighttruck line workers at the plant.

title: S.M.U's Ford, Chasing Mark, Hurt
description: Mike Ford, the Southern Methodist University quarterback who was on his way to becoming the first major college player to pass for more than 8,000 yards in his career, underwent knee surgery yesterday morning and will miss the remaining nine games of his iunior season.

title: Israeli Is Shot Dead in Jerusalem After Family Visits Wailing Wall
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 16 (Reuters)  A 47yearold man was shot in the head and killed about midnight while standing next to his car near the Church of Gethsemane in the Arab part of Jerusalem, the police said today.

title: Canadian Mideast Envoy Meets With Turkey's Foreign Minister
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 16 (Reuters)  Canada's special Middle East envoy, Robert Stanfield, discussed the Middle East, Cyprus and other issues here today with Foreign Minister Gunduz Okcun of Turkey, a Ministry spokesman said.

title: Weizman Defends Bid For $1.8 Billion in Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)  Defense Minister Ezer Weizman of Israel today defended his nation's request for $1.8 billion in United States military aid by saying a billion dollars simply isn't what it used to be.

title: Women's Suits Make Big Comeback
description: In the early 1970's, Ted Green was devoting 95 percent of his production to coats  even though his company, Suitime Inc., had been in the women's suit business since 1945. The suit business was flat. But no more.

title: U. S. Blacks, on Visit, Said to Honor Qaddafi
description: LONDON, Sept. 16 (Reuters)  A delegation of black Americans visiting Libya today gave what they called the decoration of Martin Luther King to Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the Libyan leader, the Libyan press agency Jana reported.

title: Steelers Win on Bahr's Field Goal
description: Matt Bahr, a rookie from Penn State, kicked a 20yard field goal with 13 seconds left in the game to rally the Pittsburgh.Steelers to a 2421 victory over the Cardinals in St. Louis. The major share of the Steelers 11th straight victory, including three this National Football League season, however, belonged to the defense.

title: Joan M. Saunders Bride Of Patrick J. Markham
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle in Yonkers yesterday, Joan Marie Saunders, daughter of Frank A. Saunders of New York and Siasconset, Mass., and Margaret Tuohy Saunders of New York, was married to Patrick Joseph Markham. son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Martin Markham of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Peter Gilhawley performed the ceremony.

title: Becton Details Suit's Demands
description: Becton, Dickinson & Company said that it had filed a memorandum with the Southern District Court in New York outlining the remedies it sought in its lawsuit against the Sun Company, Fairleigh S. Dickinson Jr., F. Eberstadt & Company and others. A hearing to determine the appropriate relief is set for late October.

title: Israel Lifts Censorship on Charge Officer Murdered Four Lebanese
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 16 (AP)  Military censors have allowed the disclosure of allegations about the murder last year of four Lebanese civilians by an Israeli officer after a written account of the crime appeared in the foreign Dress.

title: Rochelle Emmer, Executive, Bride of Douglas Rochester
description: Rochelle Emmer, manager of promotion design at Random House, was married yesterday at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing Meadow, Queens, to Douglas Rochester, a senior systems analyst at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. Rabbi Meyer Rosen performed the ceremony.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: U.S., Wary After Rebellion in Nicaragua, Weighs How to Act in El Salvador as Violence There Mounts
description: SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 16  Having intervened in the Nicaraguan crisis too late to avoid an outright Sandinist victory, American officials say, the Carter Administration is now weighing how deeply it should become involved in El Salvador to prevent an upsurge in this country's simmering civil war.

title: Fixing Tickets in the Big Leagues
description: It is no surprise that used car dealers do not like the Federal Trade Commission. It wants to make them disclose any major defects in the cars they want to sell. It is no surprise that funeral directors do not like the F.T.C. The commission wants them to itemize their prices for bereaved customers. It is no surprise that cereal companies do not like the F.T.C. It is considering possible restrictions on the kind of advertising they aim at young children, especially on behalf of heavily sugared cereals.

title: In Brooklyn, a Tour of Illustrious Graves
description: What Virgil did for Dante in The Inferno, William J. Ward, a 56-year-old freelance writer, and his wife, Marjorie, a kindergarten teacher, do for throngs of the curious at GreenWood Cemetery in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn.

title: Fishermen and Oil Drillers Vie for Use of Georges Bank
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass., Sept. 15  Despite the bright sunshine and crisp breeze of a sparkling late summer day, a current of gloom ran across the bustling docks of this old harbor as fishermen repaired their nets and tended their boats.

title: Viola: Rivka GolaniErdesz
description: ASUPERIOR viola recital, expertly played and expertly programmed, was given Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The player was Rivka GolaniErdesz, a violist of passion and taste who was born in Israel and now lives in Canada. The program con- sisted of sonatas by Hindemith (Op. 11, No. 4) and Schubert (the Arpeggione'), Faure's Apres un Reve and two contemporary pieces  Variations for Four Drums and Viola by Michael Colgrass, and Agada by Oedoen Partos.

title: NUCLEAR UNIT URGED TO WEIGH ACCIDENTS IN CONSIDERING SITES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has recommended that the Government begin considering the accidental release of dangerous amounts of radiation when deciding where new reactors should be built.

title: Yanks Bid Hunter Farewell
description: On a day when the Yankees ceremonially said goodbye to 33-year-old Catfish Hunter and eagerly said hello to 20-year-old Dave Righetti, they also said goodbye sadly to their threeyear reign as American League champions.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: American Express Deal Raises Hopes at Warner

title: CORRECTION
description: CORRECTION

title: Susan Goetz Bride Of Benjamin Zwirn
description: Susan L. Goetz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice H. Goetz of Manhasset, L.I., was married there yesterday in Temple Judea to Benjamin L. Zwirn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Zwirn, also of Manhasset. Rabbi Martin Rozenberg performed the ceremony.

title: Nancy Lopez Duo Wins
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 16 (UPI)Nancy Lopez and Jo Ann Washam, capitalizing on birdie putts by Miss Washam on the 17th and 18th holes, won the Ladies Professional Golf Association team championship today with total of 198, 21underpar..

title: L.I.. Gold Coast
description: Caumsett, one of the last remaining great mansions of Long Island's Gold Coast era and once the country estate of Marshall Field 3d, has been obtained by Queens College, which will use it as a Center for Environmental Study and Research.

title: Fought Buick Victor
description: GRAND BLANC, Mich., Sept. 16 (AP)  John Fought, a 25yearold rookie on the PGA Tour, sank a 3foot putt for par on the second playoff hole to defeat Jim Simons in the $150,000 Buick open today.

title: Market Place
description: Robert Metz

title: ArmoredTruck Guards Report $228,000 Theft
description: Two guards who left their armored truck to make a routine pickup at a Bronx supermarket yesterday afternoon returned to find the truck missing, along with almost a quarter of a million dollars in currency and coins, they told the police.

title: Outdoors: Be Prepared for HeavyWeather Sailing
description: THE storm struck at dusk and gained in intensity through the night. Boats sailed off the breaking crests of massive waves and fell 10 to 20 feet into the troughs. Some rolled 360 degrees. Walls of water cascaded onto decks. Rudders broke. Visibility, at times, was zero.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Sword Play

title: China Doubles the Area of Inner Mongolian Region
description: China has virtually doubled the area of its Inner Mongolian Autonomous Region, restoring it to the size it had before being truncated in 1969 during the Cultural Revolution.

title: Associated Press
description: RETRACING HISTORY: Two elephants of an expedition led by Jack Wheel- er, a former teacher from Los Angeles, cross the Alps from France to Italy through Clapier Pass. The route may be the one that Hannibal, commander of the Carthaginians, took with 37 elephants in 218 B.C.

title: An Early Leader in Counsel for the Dying Moves into Spiritualism
description: ESCONDIDO, Calif., Sept. 13  Dr. Elisabeth KublerRoss, who was among the first to encourage candid counseling of dying persons and their families, has turned to spiritualism.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Satellite Photograph

title: Finance Chiefs Say Little of Paris Talks
description: PARIS, Sept. 16  Finance ministers and energy experts from the United States and other major industrial nations engaged in secret discussions here today about the world's worsening economic prospects, but revealed little about their deliberations.

title: 2 Win AmericanMusic Competitions
description: The finals of two competitions designed to spur the cause of American music were held over the weekend at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. On Saturday night, William Parker, a 35yearold baritone from Butler, Pa., Won first prize in the second annual Kennedy CenterRockefeller Foundation International Competition for excellence in the performance of American Music. Yesterday afternoon, the winner of the second annual Kennedy Center Friedheim Awards for composition of the best new American instrumental chamber work was George Rochberg for his String Quartet No. played by the Concord Quartet.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TODA

title: I Am Not a Lady
description: There are one or two counts upon which I am definitely not a lady. First of all, I work. If gentlemen do not work, at any rate for overt pecuniary reward, it follows that ladies most certainly do not do so. My pecuniary reward is only too overt. It arrives by way of a narrow slip of wnite paper giving me the payroll number xyzsdz19553. That is all I can bear to read, because once I catch sight of the

title: Conference Examines Pornography as a Feminist Issue
description: One by one the images flashed onto the screen, each accompanied by gasps and exclamations from the audience: a naked woman gagged and bound, hanging from the ceiling by her wrists, her back flayed with whip lashes; a woman's body being fed into a meatgrinder; the dismembered body of a woman as a chicken on a plate of cacciatore, covered with tomato sauce or blood.

title: Physician Pronounces President Fit After NearCollapse in 6Mile Race
description: President Carter was given a comprehensive medical examination and pronounced fit yesterday by his personal physician after nearly collapsing from heat exhaustion in a foot race Saturday.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Companies

title: MISTAKES BY MUNSON BLAMED IN JET CRASH
description: The chief of the Federal team investigating the jet crash that killed Thurman Munson said his field report would show that startling mistakes by Mr. Munson as the pilot caused the accident. But he strongly suggested that the Federal Aviation Administration was a party to the fatal accident through lax licensing procedures.

title: Arthur Wolfish, Lawyer, Marries Jeanne Feldman
description: The marriage of Jeanne Feldman, a teacher at the Kingsway Academy in Brooklyn, to Arthur Bernard Wolfish, an assistant district attorney in New York County, took place yesterday at the Chateau Garod in Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Shlomo Margolis and Rabbi Jordan Kelemer officiated.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Deaths
description: BARTONMichael J. Reposing at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway, Bronx, until Tuesday 9:30 AM.

title: Paper Challenges Government
description: The Chicago Tribune has informed the Federal Government that it will print appropriate and informative portions of the Hansen letter, in effect challenging the Government to stop publication through legal action.

title: Lynn Povich Is Married To Stephen B. Shepard
description: Lynn Povich and Stephen B. Shepard, senior editors of Newsweek magazine, were married yesterday in the apartment they will occupy in Manhattan. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony.

title: TV: On Eve Of War in Germany
description: ALTHOUGH it lacks strong dramatic elements and is mild in its depiction of concentrationcamp barbarity compared with last week's television showings of The Holocaust and Seven Beauties, Only a Day, which will be seen from 9 to 10:30 tonight on WNET, Channel 13, is worth a look.

title: Jets, Behind Todd, Rout Lions, 3110
description: Suddenly, in less than three hours yesterday, the Shea Stadium fans began to love the Jets and Richard Todd again.

title: Kidnappers Free Boy, 13, in Italy
description: PERUGIA, Italy, Sept. 16 (Reuters) A 13yearold boy, kidnapped from his parents country home 28 days ago, was freed today after payment of an undisclosed ransom, the police said. Guidio Freddi, the son of a Rome engineer, was found a few hours after midnight in parking area on the RomeFlorence highway.

title: U.S. Golfers Take Ryder Cup, 1711
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 16  The United States team of golf professionals won the 23cl Ryder Cup Matches today by beating the Europeans in eight of the 11 singles matches that concluded the threeday competition. The final score, including the fourball and foursome matches that were played yesterday and Friday, was 1711.

title: Last Week's Active Issues
description: For the week ended Sept. 14, 1979.

title: Trudeau Flies to China for Visit
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Sept. 16 (Reuters)  Former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau flew to Peking today for a 10day trip that will include visit tc Tibet.

title: Blackout Affects 2,200 Students
description: NORMAL, Ill., Sept. 16 (UPI)  Officials at Illinois State University advised 2,200 students who were left without power in a huge twin tower dormitory complex that they might have to find other accommodations for up to three weeks. The two transformers in the 28story Watterson Towers blew out yester day. Officials said that it would take up tc three weeks to replace the transformers.

title: ABROAD AT HOME A Fight To The End?
description: WASHINGTON  Reading some of the papers this past week, one might have thought that the 1980 Democratic nomination was all settled. Senator Edward Kennedy had inclined his head, and at the appropriate time he would be anointed.

title: Panel Bids Episcopalians Bar Homosexual Priests
description: DENVER, Sept. 16  In a move that has surprised many participants at the Episcopalian Church's 66th triennial convention here, a committee of the House of Bishops has proposed a resolution that would bar the ordination of practicing homosexuals and others who engage in sex outside of marriage.

title: Leventhal Moves To City Hall Role
description: With a meticulousness that he concedes is compulsive, Nathan Leventhal has been getting ready to take over his new position today as New York City's Deputy Mayor for Operations.

title: An English Woman of a Certain Age
description: Although there are still splendid English Ladies carrying on bravely in our rapidly changing society, there can be no doubt that their ranks are getting thinner.

title: Deaths
description: SCHWARTZPhilip, husband of Zelda, devoted father of Diane and Peter, loving grandfather of Michael, Scott, Danielle and Gabrielle, on September 13, In Florida, formerly of Great Neck. Burial In New York.

title: ISRAEL ENDS ITS BAN ON LAND PURCHASES IN OCCUPIED REGIONS
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 16  The Cabinet ended a 12year regulation prohibiting Israeli citizens and businesses from buying land in the occupied Arab territories today in a move to strengthen the Israeli presence in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: 9 Are Injured in New Hampshire As Truck Hits 7 Cars at Toll Booth
description: BRENTWOOD, N.H., Sept. 16 (AP) A tractor trailer truck plowed into seven cars waiting at a toll booth yesterday, setting two of them afire and injuring nine persons, the police said.

title: Experts' Advice on Chrysler
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  The Treasury Department has asked the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse & Company and at least three major New York investment banking firms to help the Government scrutinize the financial rescue plan submitted yesterday by the Chrysler Corporation, according to Government and industry sources.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ZANDVOORT, the Netherlands, Sept. 16 (UPI)  Rob Slotemaker, a 50yearold Dutch racing driver, died today when his Chevrolet Camaro crashed into a doctor's rescue vehicle during the Trophy of the Dunes touringcar race.

title: U.N. Assembly, Opening Tomorrow, to Focus on Mideast, Africa and Cambodia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 16 For the next 13 weeks, the halls here will resound to angry denunciations of Israel, Egypt and the Camp David accords, to bitter attacks on white rule over blacks in southern Africa and a clash between the rival regimes in Cambodia.

title: Soccer Title to Sacramento
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 16 (AP)  Ian Filby, a Sacramento forward, broke a scoreless tie at 83 minutes 22 seconds to give the Gold a 10 triumph over the Columbus Magic in the American Soccer League championship name today.

title: Dilemma at the Justice Dept.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  The question of whether a special prosecutor must be appointed to investigate allegations that Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, used cocaine has developed into a complex, thorny and at times divisive issue in the Justice Department, according to senior officials there.

title: Valerie Mayer Is Married
description: Valerie Mayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolf Mayer of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Nicholas A. Tiliacos, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony N. Tiliacos of Athens. The nondenominational ceremony was performed at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains by the Rev. Dr. Robert C. Neville. The bride is an officer and director of A. & L. Mayer Inc. in Scarsdale, of which her father is president. Her husband is manager of project finance at G.T.E. (General Telephone and Electronics) in Stamford, Conn.

title: U.S. Seeking to Widen Business Ties to Cairo
description: CAIRO, Sept. 16  In addition to trying to ease the political differences between Egypt and Israel, President Carter's special envoy, Robert S. Strauss, has been trying to drum up American investment for the two countries.

title: I.M.F. Lists Year's Credits
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (Reuters)  The International Monetary Fund said today that it had approved stanby credits for 14 countries during its fiscal year ended last April, compared with 18 arrangements the year before.

title: Expos Regain First
description: AT MONTREAL  Dave Cash slammed a basesloaded homer off George Frazier in the 10th inning to give the Expos their secondgame triumph. Gary Carter opened the twoout rally with a double off Roy Thomas (34). Jerry White was intentionally walked and Warren Cromartie reached base on an error by Ken Oberkfell.

title: Cowboys Top Bears On Late Touchdown
description: IRVING, Tex., Sept. 16.  Torn Landry, coach of the Cowboys, has long maintained that it takes his Dallas teams until late October or November to play football up to his considerable expectations. Until their skills are honed to Super Bowl level, the Cowboys struggle but still win more often than lose.

title: Candidates Running for Visibility in New Hampshire
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Sept. 13  Last Monday halfpage advertisements blossomed in 12 New Hampshire newspapers stating: John who? John Anderson. Oh, yeah, John Anderson. He's. running for President. No pictures, no comments, iust that one simple message.

title: Consumer Group Gauges Windfall
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 16 (AP) A Washingtonbased consumer group said today that decontrol of domestic crude oil prices could increase the revenues of the 23 largest oil companies by almost $4 billion a year.

title: Disney's Sleeping Beauty
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16  Sleeping Beauty  the most romantic of Disney animated films and a boxoffice failure in 1959 and 1970  may have at last found an audience  20 years after it was created.

title: Writer Tells of Long Concern on Nuclear Weapons
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16  The man whose letter to the editor has been called a national security violation said today that his research into nuclear weapons started in 1971 when the Atomic Energy Commission provided him with a list of sources of unclassified information.

title: Oil Executives End Meeting
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 16 (UPI)  Oil executives from 70 nations have ended a fiveday conference here with a reminder that oil is politics and a warning that government interference is jeopardizing the world's future oil supplies.

title: Deaths
description: DOUBLEDAYRichard, of 5 Roosevelt Place, Montclair, NJ on Friday, Sept 14, father of Barbara Perry of Vermont, Deborah Doubleday of Millis, Mass., Richard, Jr., Edgar, William and James of Montclair, NJ. Memorial services will be held at Rosedale Crematory In Orange, NJ at 10AM, this morning.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1979

title: Signs of the Times
description: We fell into conversation the other day with an old New Yorker who had just read that a simulacrum the old Times Tower was about to be painted on the facade of another old building across from it on the south side of 42d Street. I grew up with the Tower, he said, and it'll give me a sharp pang every time I look up this painting of it, but what got me to thinking so much about the project was something else.

title: Miss Antman, Greg Geller Of CBS Records Married
description: Hope Caryl Antman, daughter of Mrs. E. Milton Sachs of New York and Sidney Antman of Arlington, Va., was married yesterday to Greg Geller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew M. Geller of Northport, L.I. The ceremony was performed at the Manhattan home of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Alvord N. Luria, by Rabbi David Seligson, rabbi emeritus of the Central Synagogue.

title: Lauda Triumphs
description: IMOLA, Italy, Sept. 16 (AP)  Niki Lauda of Austria, driving a Brabham, won the Dino Ferrari Formula One race at the Autodrome today. Carlos Reutemann of Argentina, in a MartiniLotus, placed second.

title: Michaels Versus Martin
description: THROUGHOUT the Jets' 3110 victory over the Detroit Lions at Shea Stadium yesterday, Bob Martin stood in the sun in front of the Jets bench, never too close to Coach Walt Michaels but never too far away. Every so often the linebacker with the curly blond hair would smile or laugh. He appeared to be enjoying the Jets first triumph this season, after two losses. And say this for him: He did not sulk and slouch on the bench, even though he had been benched. Now in his fourth season, Bob Martin has been considered one of the Jets cornerstones for the future  6 feet inch, 214 pounds, not quite 26 years old, a scientist rather than a slammer at right linebacker.

title: G.E. Fattens B.B.D.O. Account
description: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, for 59 years a General Electric ad agency, has just been named to handle all of the company's majorappliance advertising, except for the the airconditioners.

title: Sales of Gasohol Gaining Support In 3State Area
description: In the few months that gasohol has been on sale in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut, the blend of gasoline and alcohol has gained a loyal following among motorists and the relatively few service stations that sell it. But with the return of nearnormal fuel supplies, gasohol has faded from the minds of public officials who saw it as a key to dealing with the gasoline shortage.

title: Job Money and Too Few Takers
description: For years, business leaders have argued that the answer to high unemployment among teenagers and the poor is not shortterm public service employment but private sector jobs. The Carter Administration therefore persuaded Congress last fall to offer tax credits and training subsidies to encourage firms hire the disadvantaged. But according to a recent Labor Department survey, few employers even know about the new Jobs programs. It seems time for businessmen who favor this approach to do some vigorous selling within their own ranks.

title: Synthetic Fuel Air Threat Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) major international effort to produce synthetic fuels will contribute to increased levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, possibly leading to dangerous changes in global climate, Senate committee said today.

title: 11 in Texas Take Rabies Shots
description: DENTON, Tex., Sept. 16 (AP)  Eight students at North Texas State University, a campus policeman and two animal control officers have started taking antirabies injections since they were exposed to a rabid kitten. A campus officer, Tom Newell, said the kitten was one of two that ran wild among about 50 people watching the lunar eclipse Sept. 6.

title: Deaths
description: GUSSOWEmanuel. We mourn the passing of our former president, who served our lodge with distinction and concern. Our condolences to his wife, Jean, and the family. Samuel Schaeffler, President, Naomi Lodge, B'nel Brith

title: Falcone and Allen Blank Pirates, 30
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16  Pete Falcone, the Mets' most improved starting pitcher, scattered seven hits in eight innings today and combined with Neil Allen to blank the Pittsburgh Pirates, 30, and end the Mets fivegame losing streak.

title: Weekly Lotto
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 4, 17, 23, 8, 22 and 5. The supplementary number was 33.

title: United Press International
description: BONN, Sept. 16  In one of the most spectacular escapes in years, two East German families landed in West Germany today after flying 28 miles across the heavily guarded border in a homemade hotair balloon.

title: Calder Sidewalk Being Restored
description: The black and white terrazzo sidewalk designed by Alexander Calder that stretched between 78th and 79th Streets on the west side of Madison Avenue was removed last week, the victim of nine New York winters and thousands and thousands of pedestrians. Construction has begun on a new sidewalk based on the original design.

title: The Region
description: ROCHESTER (AP)  A 17yearold youth was charged with four counts of manslaughter after the car he was driving smashed into a tree and split in half, killing four teenaged passengers.

title: Notes on People
description: Shah's Eldest Daughter Is at Prep School Near Hartford

title: Commodities
description: FOR inflation watchers, there may be some good news about oranges, a favorite fruit of many Americans. The price of frozen orange juice concentrate is heading downward, according to some experts, reflecting the price of oranges.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ART CAPITAL Under the heading Art Galleries & DIrs in the Manhattan Yellow Pages there are more than 800 entries. The Art Dealers Association of America says some of those listed sell pictures, and the association has far fewer New York members than the phone book lists. The better dealers, i.e., more reputable and knowledgeable, specialize. The Margot Gallery sells Eskimo art; Merton D. Simpson sells African art. Some specialize in French Impressionists, some in old master's drawings. Dealers are experts in their speciality and their artists. For example, whoever represents Andy Warhol knows his work from the first soup can and Brillo box to the latest celebrity portrait. Galleries with contemporary artists have a stable, of about 20. Dealers influence the public taste in contemporary art by showing artists whose works get talked about, reviewed, shown in museums and purchased.

title: New Harvard Hillel Center Opens
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16  Hillel, the Jewish religious and cultural society, moved to a spacious new home at Harvard University today as daylong dedication ceremonies celebrated the increasingly central role of Judaism in the life of the campus.

title: Rights Inquiry in Argentina Finds Evidence of Violations and of Reform
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 16  The InterAmerican Human Rights Commission has found overwhelming evidence of methodical killing and torture of prisoners in Argentina at the same time that it has seen evidence of recent efforts by the military regime to reduce human rights violations.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE world of Freud, Kafka and Einstein was Austria and Germany before, during and after World War I, until the Nazis decided that Viennese and Weimar culture was a bad idea and burned the culture and gassed many of the people who had made that culture possible.

title: China Takes Ambitious Steps to End a Deadly Fever
description: SHANGHAI, Sept. 18  China has undertaken one of the most ambitious diseasecontrol efforts in history, seeking to wipe out snail fever by 1985. About 2.5 million Chinese suffer from the disease, which is often fatal if untreated.

title: NBC to Give New Shows Time to Grow Into Hits
description: As the network running third in the competition for viewers, NBCTV is aiming in the new season to rise steadily by improving its share of audience in every time period, according to Myron (Mike) Weinblatt, president of NBC Entertainment.

title: BBC's World Service Is Under Budget Ax
description: LONDON, Sept. 16  To the degree that British foreign policy has any influence outside Rhodesia, an Asian ambassador said last week over lunch, it's because of the impact of the BBC. Mrs. Thatcher doesn't seem to know it, but shortwave is this country's most important export.

title: Advertising
description: Rodgers Reshaping N.C.& K.

title: Tenor: Byung Sun Soh in Tully Hall Recital
description: BYUNG SUN SOH, heard Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall, is a young Korean singer who once wanted to be a lawyer, but has pursued a vocal career since moving to the United States 10 years ago. He has studied at Juilliard, among other places, and made his local recital debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last year.

title: Nixon, on Trip to China, Says Carter Could Win
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 16 (AP)  Former President Richard M. Nixon described President Carter today as a tighter he would not sell short in any battle for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Sesame Street Ratings Secure
description: IT is a cold Saturday in autumn when the Notre Dame football team doesn't make one touchdown, and it rarer still when Notre Dame wins without trespassing on the opponent's end zone. It happened Saturday for the edification of a national television audience. Four field goals by a scholar named Chuck Male produced the points for a 1210 victory over Michigan, whose savants made a touchdown and field goal in the first half and nothing in the second.

title: Constitution and Crowds: Problems for Pope's Visit
description: BOSTON, Sept. 16  The scheduled visit of Pope John Paul II to six American cities next month has set off a string of controversies over how far local governments can legally go in welcoming a religious leader.

title: Nigeria Pushes Energy Plan
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 13  When Andrew Young arrived here this week with an American trade delegation, reports were already swirling in this capital city that Nigeria was about to break the $23.50abarrel price ceiling of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Conrail Commuter Lines Found Declining With Bad Equipment
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 15  The Conrail commuter lines serving Westchester County and Connecticut are steadily deteriorating, with inadequate maintenance sidelining more and more cars, according to a draft study prepared for the New York State Department of Transportation.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The tentative agreement worked out last Friday between the United Auto Workers and General Motors most likely means more pressure pushing interest rates still higher, which is tough news for the credit markets.

title: Giants Confronted By New Redskins
description: The party's over and Diron Talbert keeps looking over his shoulder at his souvenir, a photograph that he keeps in his locker. Sothetimes he thinks it will drive him crazy.

title: ESSAY Reading Jimmy's Mind
description: WASHINGTON  For me to have to drop out of a foot race, right after Teddy lets the world know he's in the race for my job  that's typical of the way my luck has been running lately.

title: Wisconsin Newspaper Publishes HBomb Letter Barred on Coast
description: MADISON, Wis., Sept. 16  The text of a letter that, according to the Government, contains secret information about the hydrogen bomb was published here today in a special edition of The Madison Press Connection and is to be published again in tomorrow's editions for the newspaper's 11,000 paid subscribers.

title: Dance: Diane Jacobowitz
description: THE most fascinating thing about the Diane Jacobowitz Dances program, Saturday night at the American Theater Laboratory, was not the dancing, but the music. All scores were performed live. Two were by Tom Wachunas and two were collaborations involving Miss Jacobowitz, Mr. Wachunas, Susan Greenblatt and Gene Schwimmer of The Pseudos, and Linn Walker, one of the dancers. Most of these scores were based upon ostinatos for voice and piano or guitar, and the dancers occasionally had to sing as they moved.

title: Deaths
description: KLEINRegina. Devoted wife of thelate Lazarus, loving mother Sidney. Leonard, and Jerome. Loving grandmother of Helen, Jeffrey, Steven, Lowell, Jan, Jill, Joanne, and Jane, and great grandmother. Services at BoulevardPark West 115 West 79th St., N.Y.C. Monday at 10 A.M.

title: Bridge:
description: The rising price of silver has had an impact on criminal activity, as the Greater New York Bridge Association found recently: during August, a dozen trophies were abstracted from a Manhattan apartment where they were stored.

title: 7 Killed in Air Collision in France
description: HAZEBROUCK, France, Sept. 16 (Reuters)  At least seven people were killed today when two light planes collided in the air and crashed near this northern French town, the police said. The planes were flying in an air show at local festival.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Rhodesian Leaders Disagree on White Privileges
description: LONDON, Sept. 16  Ian D. Smith, the leader of Zimbabwe Rhodesia's white minority, indicated today that he intends to fight for the maintenance of white constitutional privileges even at the risk of splitting the delegation of blacks and whites representing the Salisbury Government at the weekold peace conference here.

title: 2 Columbia Alumni Give $4 Million
description: Columbia University has announced that two of its alumni have given $2 million each toward the renovation of two undergraduate residence halls on its Morningside Heights campus. The donors  Jerome L. Greene, a senior partner in the law firm of Marshall, Bratter, Greene, Allison & Tucker, and Ira D. Wallach, chairman of the board of Gottesman & Company, a pulp and paper concerngraduated from Columbia College in 1926 and 1929, respectively, and from its Law School in 1928 and 1931.

title: For Moscow, A Crucial Test
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 16  The SovietAmerican negotiations on Soviet troops in Cuba appear to be a crucial test for Soviet diplomacy no less than for the Carter Administration. At stake is Senate approval

title: HEINRICH TENHUMBERG
description: MUNSTER, West Germany, Sept. 16 (Reuters)  The Roman Catholic Bishop of Minster, Heinrich Tenhumberg, died of a heart attack today at the age of 64, a church spokesman said. The Bishop's diocese contained over two million Catholics.

title: Old Ways, And New
description: With the evolution of the status of women, might the standing of gentlemens wives be in jeopardy?

title: Radio
description: Music

title: The City
description: Twenty thousand people gathered at Battery Park yesterday for the Great New York State Children's Party, a statesponsored celebration held to mark the International Year of the Child.

title: De Gustibus
description: Some of the most entertaining correspondence to reach this desk in recent weeks has had to do with a curious food called isinglass. When a reader inquired what the product is, I volunteered that it is a form of gelatin, much used many years ago as a thickening agent until the advent of gelatin in granulated form. I added that I had used isinglass years go while attending a hotel school in Switzerland but had never seen reference to it in cookbooks written in English.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 8:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4;30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 9.5300; NASSAU CO. (516) 747.0600; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 669.1600; CONNECTICUT (203) 343.7767.

title: Myra Saul, Lawyer, Bride of Howard Pinn
description: Myra Leslie Saul, a lawyer with the New York regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was married yesterday to Howard Hartley Pinn, a financial analyst with Gibbs & Hill Inc., an engineering concern in New York.

title: Opera: La Loca
description: BEVERLY SILLS was supposed to have retired from the operatic stage last season. But she did have one final commitment, and last night she observed it, singing the title role in La Loca,

title: Cross Burnings On L. .I. Prompt Federal Inquiry
description: Crossburnings and vandalism against homes and property of black and Jewish families on Long Island  the latest occurring early yesterday morning in Baldwin  have prompted the United States Attorney for the Eastern District to investigate possible civilrights violations under the Fair Housing Act.

title: Loss of Hospitals in Central Cities Said to Cause Array of Problems
description: Hospital closings and relocations may be the most searing of the losses in the continuing pattern of innercity disintegration, according to black medical administrators and health consumer advocates.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Tip for Tennis Hackers

title: Output Dip Worsening, I.M.F. Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (Reuters)  The International Monetary Fund said today that the industrialized world now faces a much sharper decline in economic output than was generally expected at the beginning of the year, mainly because of oil price increases.

title: Brazil Exiles, Victims of Police, Return With New Hope
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 16  The last time Jose Luis Saboya was in Rio he was trussed and suspended upside down from the ceiling while officers poured ice water into his nostrils, applied electric prods to his body, doused cigarettes on his feet and threatened to torture his wife in front of him.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON ON almost every level, G. William Miller has settled in briskly as Secretary of the Treasury. Most centrally, he has moved quickly to take control of the Economic Policy Group, the focus of Administration decisionmaking on the economy and related matters. Participants in the group's deliberations say that Mr. Miller, as the new chairman, produces decisions more rapidly and crisply than did his predecessor, W. Michael Blumenthal.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: No Layoffs Expected In Hospital Closings, A City Official Asserts
description: The president of the city corporation that has approved the closing of four municipal hospitals said yesterday that he expected that no layoffs would result from the proposed closings.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Alvin Ailey and the board of the Dance Theater Foundation Inc. have announced the appointment of Donald S. Sutton as executive director of the foundation, the parent organization for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and Repertory Ensemble and the American Dance Center.

title: Coast Brush Fire, Fueled by Wind, Destroys 18 Homes
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16  A fast-moving brush fire, fanned by hot, dry winds, destroyed at least 18 expensive homes in the Hollywood Hills area of Los Angeles this afternoon.

title: Wealthy New Investors Fueling the Gold Market
description: The lunchtime crowds at Deak-Perera's Fifth Avenue coin outlet have been bigger in the last few weeks but not nearly as turbulent as the explosion in gold prices. Perhaps a better thermometer for gold fever consists of the telephones at Deak's. They have been ringing incessantly.

title: L.I. School Dedicates a Do-It-Yourself Pool
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 16  Fortyone plumbers, bricklayers, carpenters and other workers halted their labors this afternoon, changed their clothes and  in their more familiar roles as the Marianist brothers and priests of the Chaminade School in this Nassau County community  presented a cornDieted swimming pool for dedication.

title: U.S. Has No Comment
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  A State Department spokesman said today that would have no comment on the Cabinet decision until it received a full report from the United States Embassy in Tel Aviv.

title: Synagogue Sold, People Hold Sidewalk Services
description: The congregants of a Lower East Side synagogue, locked out of their former house of worship, held religious services on the sidewalk in front of the building over the weekend and vowed to keep Buddhist church from taking over the synagogue.

title: Emmy Lou Lilienthal Wed to Morton Pepper, Lawyer
description: The marriage of Emmy Lou Lilienthal, widow of Howard L. Lilienthal, to Morton Pepper, a widower and a member of the New York law firm of Pepper & Pepper, took place yesterday. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony in his study at Temple EmanuEl. of which Mr. Penner is a trustee.

title: James G. Grant, Associate Editor Of Time Magazine, Is Dead at 53
description: James G. Grant, an associate editor of Time magazine, died Saturday of a heart attack at the Westchester County Medical Center. Mr. Grant, who was 53 years old, lived in Hartsdale, N. Y.

title: LAWRENCE GROSS LANE
description: Lawrence Gross Lane, a professor of English literature at the University of Texas, died of a brain hemmorhage Saturday in Provident Memorial Hospital in El Paso. Professor Lane, who lived in El Paso, was 31 years old.

title: B.A. Weprin Weds Patricia J. Langer
description: Patricia Jean Langer and Barry Alan Weprin were married yesterday at the Tappan Hill Restaurant in Tarrytown, N.Y., by Rabbi Allen S. Kaplan.

title: Merchant Slays Brooklyn Thief And Is Arrested
description: A Brooklyn grocery store owner shot and killed one of three men who tried to rob him yesterday morning, then was arrested because he did not have a license fora gun.

title: Lion End Praises Ward
description: Al (Bubba) Baker, the 6-foot6inch, 260pound defensive end for the Detroit Lions, recorded his first two quarterback sacks of the season yesterday in the game against the Jets.

title: New Model Rooms Are a Designer's Farewell
description: They make a very handsome swan songand it's not one bit sad.

title: J.E. Lobsenz Weds Elizabeth S. Choy
description: Elizabeth Suenghae Choy, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. SunHak Choy of San Francisco, was married yesterday i the Stanford (Calif.) Memorial Church on the Stanford University campus to James Elliot Lobsenz, son of Margery Thorndike of Westport, Conn., and Nor- man M. Lobsenz of Los Angeles. Dean Robert HamertonKelly performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Japan's Trade Deficit Grows
description: TOKYO, Sept. 16 (AP)  Japan posted a trade deficit of $1.64 billion in August, but continued to show a surplus in its trade with the United States, the Finance Ministry said in a preliminary report.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With two outs, a double steal is attempted, but the lead runner is thrown out to end the inning. Does the other runner, who advanced safely, get credit for a stolen base?

title: Miss Kozac and Allen Reiter, New York Prosecutors, Wed
description: Karen Kozac, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Kozac of Jenkintown, Pa., was married yesterday to Allen Gary Reiter, son of Anna Reiter of the Bronx and the late Leo Reiter. Rabbi Howard Herman performed the ceremony at the Kozac home.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 16 (UPI) Key aides to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini charged today that Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan's regime was falling apart and called for his Government to be replaced. It was the sharpest attack against Mr. Bazargan since he took control in February after the ouster of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: Supplementary O-T-C Listings
description: Week Ended Sept. 14, 1979

title: Fans in Capital Are Ever Loyal
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  With arched white neck and prim disdain, the Gibson girl on the plastic lantern advertising Pabst Blue Ribbon peered at the Wednesday night crowd at Jackie Lee's Lounge in northwest Washington. The offduty bus drivers and government employees paid her no mind, with her upswept hair and turnedup nose. They were socializing in the bar's crimson glow, candent with talk about the Skins and how the team would beat the Giants.

title: George G. Cameron, 74, Educator And an Expert on Ancient Persia
description: George G. Cameron, founder of the University of Michigan Department of Near Eastern Studies and an expert on ancient Persia, died Saturday at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 74 years old.

title: The New York Times/Marilynn K. Yee
description: Parade of Print Brings Thousands to Fifth Avenue Fair

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Officials Surprised
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  The appearance of Mr. Hansen's letter in The Press Connection came as a surprise to Federal officials here who had tried to prevent its publication in other papers through legal action and oral persuasion, an Energy Department official said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Cyanamid Company, Wayne, N.J., a manufacturer of chemdals and drugs, has named Gordon M. Garrett president of its Household Products division.

title: The Bear Keeps Rolling With the Tide
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Chess:
description: The Kees Kemet International Tournament in Hungary was won by Grandmaster Ivan Farago of Hungary, who tallied 114 in the 16player roundrobin

title: The Region
description: Conrail introduced new schedules to provide additional seating and, in some cases, faster service on three divisions in Westchester County and Connecticut yesterday, but passengers on all commuter lines encountered delays of about 30 minutes in the morning.

title: House Panel Approves Compromise on F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  A bill that provides funds for the Federal Trade Commision until Nov. 15 but forbids it to issue any consumer protection trade rules was approved today by the House Appropriations Committee.

title: Buildup in Meadowlands Expected to Be Curtailed
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., Sept. 17 Plans for commercial and residential building in the Hackensack Meadowlands, the oncemarshy wasteland now containing perhaps the most ambitious and concentrated growth in the New York metropolitan area, have been scaled down amid a disagreement between Meadowlands planners and the Tristate Regional Planning Commission over whether continued growth might hasten the decline of neighboring cities.

title: Giants Trounced By Redskins, 270
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  Joe Pisarcik played scared and the Giant defense played angry. The result was that the Washington Redskins handed the Giants their third straight embarrassing defeat under Coach Ray Perkins, 270, before a crowd of 54,672 and a national television audience.

title: Associated Press
description: ALL ARMS: Fred Stanley waiting for throw from Jim Beattie after the Yankee pitcher bobbled an infield hit in the first inning at Cleveland. Beattie held onto the ball and Stanley was able to hold Mike Hargrove at third.

title: Buccaneers Are 30, But Coach Is Wary
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers, the 1976 expansion team that lost its first 26 games in the National Football League, are one of six undefeated teams in the league after three weekends of play. But the coach, John McKay, is nervous rather than content.

title: LoftDance Festival Will Begin Sept. 28
description: LoftDance, a monthlong festival devoted to the work of 25 loftbased choreographers and held in SoHo loft studios, will begin Sept. 28 with two concerts by Ritha Devi at 145 West 21st Street. For reservations, call 7887697.

title: Auxiliaries May Patrol In Unused Police Cars
description: The Police Department has decided to allow auxiliary police to patrol in squad cars that are not being used by regular officers, a department spokesman said last night.

title: The Most Rev. Vincent J. Baldwin
description: The Most Rev. Vincent J. Baldwin, auxiliary bishop and vicar general of the Rockville Centre (L.I.) Roman Catholic Diocese, died Sunday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip, LI., after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: Cleveland Policeman Is Slain Outside a Queens Motel
description: A 52yearold Cleveland detective sergeant just four months away from retirement was shot to death in the parking lot of a Queens motel last night when he apparently resisted a holdup attempt by three young men who sped away empty handed after cutting him down with a single blast from a 12gauge shotgun.

title: Chicago Paper Plans to Print Letter Today
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 17  The Chicago Tribune today moved ahead its scheduled publication of a letter that the Government has contended contains secret and restricted information on the hydrogen bomb.

title: U.S. Navy Ships Rescue 65 More Boat People
description: SUBIC BAY, Philippines, Sept. 17 (Reuters)  United States Navy vessels landed 65 Vietnamese refugees at the naval base here today, and a plane spotted 9 others drifting in an open boat in the South China Sea, a naval spokesman said.

title: Going Out GUIDE
description: WHAT IT IS Ansel Adams, now 77 years old, is still a straightahead photographer. He has concentrated on Western landscapes  breathtaking blackandwhite pictures of mountains, trees and lakes. He ranks as one of the nation's foremost photographers because of his eye and his innovations in printing  making photographs from negatives. He once said, If I have any credo it may be this: If I choose to photograph a rock, I must present a rock. The print must augment and enlarge the experience of a rock, stress tone and texture, yet never, under any conditions dramatize the rock, nor suggest emotional or symbolic connotations other than what is obviously associated with the rock.

title: Headstones in a Gas Pump Graveyard
description: Victims of inflation and obsolescence, a cluster of robotfaced gasoline pumps and compressed air dispensers await the junkman on the fringe of an Exxon station on the Garden State Parkway at Forked River, N.J. Unable to register unit purchases of more than 99.9 cents, the gasoline pumps  like those at many stations across the New York metropolitan area  have been replaced by the new tripledigit models which were pumping gasoline for the lines of cars in the background. New tire pumps are still providing compressed air at no charge, according to a station attendant, but that, too, may soon go the way of the gratuitous oil check, the free windshield wash, the old driverightupto the pump service and other relics of an automotive age before the gasoline shortage.

title: Trans World Lists Lower Earnings
description: The Trans World Corporation, the parent company of Trans World Airlines, said that its earnings for the JulyAugust period fell to $34.7 million, or $1.96 a share, from $62 million, or $3.66 a share, in the same period last year.

title: World Airways Posts Loss
description: Grounding of all the McDonnell Douglas DC10 aircraft from June 6 to July 13 adversely affected revenues and income of World Airways Inc. in the quarter ended June 30, its report yesterday showed. The company announced a net loss of $2.2 million, compared with $163,000 lost in the June quarter last year. Revenues, however, increased to $49 million from $39.4 million.

title: 5 Nations Set I.M.F. Dollar Plan
description: PARIS, Sept. 17 Finance ministers of the United States and four other industrial countries agreed in principle here over the weekend to back a new plan to shore up the dollar at next month's annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, European monetary officials disclosed today.

title: Britain's Oxfam Mounts Relief Effort for Cambodia
description: OXFORD, England, Sept. 17  Oxfam, the British relief organization, is mounting a major effort to save the lives of tens of thousands of Cambodians who, it believes, will starve if food and medicine do not reach them soon.

title: U.S. Clears a Merger Of 2 Commodity Boards
description: The Commodities Futures Trading Commission disclosed in Washington yesterday that the United States Justice Department had withdrawn its objection to the proposed merger of the New York Cocoa Exchange with the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
