title: More Promotions at G.E.
description: In a followup to the election last month of three vice chairmen and apparent heir apparents for the top job, the General Electric Company announced yesterday the appointment of five executive vice presidents, effective Oct. 1. These executives, who had been senior vice presidents, will be the only ones holding the title of executive vice president.

title: Independent Contractors Are Target of Tax Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  Asserting that there is an unacceptably high rate of tax evasion by independent contractors, the Treasury Department urged Congress today to impose a flat 10 percent withholding tax on payments to such workers.

title: RapidAmerican Meeting
description: The RapidAmerican Corporation's chairman and president, Meshulam Riklis, said the company's rescheduled annual meeting of stockholders would be held on Oct. 16 in Wilmington, Del., to act on the election of 16 directors and the creation of a new class of preference stock.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Guest KeenUnilever Talks
description: LONDON, Sept. 17 (Reuters) Guest Keen & Nettlefold Ltd. and Unilever Ltd. are discussing the acquisition by Guest Keen of Unilever's majority interest in the Unigep group of companies in France, which distributes auto and industrial components, a joint statement said today.

title: When Crocodiles Roamed the Badlands
description: SENTINEL BUTTE, N.D.

title: Shopping Units Sold By General Growth
description: General Growth Properties, a real estate investment trust based in Des Moines, said that it had agreed to sell 10 of its shopping centers to the Aetna Life Insurance Company for $90 million in cash and about $70 million in mortgage debt. The sale should result in a capital gain distribution of about $15 a share, the company said.

title: Taxes
description: THE arcane and highly technical subject of depreciation is attracting wide attention these days as support builds for a bill that would liberalize writeoffs for corporate property. The dollars at stake are immense. Corporate depreciation totals almost $100 billion, according to Treasury Department figures.

title: Neto's Body Is Placed On Display in Angola
description: LUANDA, Angola, Sept. 17 (AP) The body of President Agostinho Neto was put on public view today in a glassandstone sarcophagus in the People's Palace following a funeral and procession through the streets of the capital.

title: Rainbow Room Books Seven Singers From 1940's
description: Back in 1993, Fran Warren was saying, she came down from the Bronx to audition for Duke Ellington. I was 15, but of course I said I was 17, she said. Duke said he liked the way I sang but there was no way he could hire me.

title: Factory Operating Rate Down
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP)  The operating rate at the nation's factories plunged 1.3 percentage points last month to the lowest level since June 1978, the Government said today.

title: Cannabis Seized in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 17 (Reuters)  Police seized 1.5 tons of cannabis or hemp resin worth nearly $4.4 million early today in Britain's biggest drug haul, customs officials said.

title: Expos Fall, 21 Trail by 1
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 17  In Don Robinson's locker, there hangs an autographed picture with the inscription: Robbie. See you in September. It is signed Tony Perez.

title: 8 Dallas School Aides Dismissed In Inquiry on Business Practices
description: DALLAS, Sept. 17 (AP)  Eight city school employees have been dismissed and lie detector tests are to be given to several other workers as part of an investigation into the school system's business practices, the superintendent of schools, Linus Wright, said Saturday.

title: Allied to Dismiss 400 in New Jersey
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation said that about 400 employees at its headquarters in Morris Township, N.J., would lose their jobs in a major reorganization of the company. The company also said that about 300 additional employees at 35 other locations would be discharaed as well.

title: U.S. DROPS EFFORTS TO BAR PUBLICATION OF HBOMB ARTICLES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  The Justice Department announced today that it was abandoning its efforts to prevent publication of articles on the hydrogen bomb by The Progressive magazine and a newspaper in California.

title: Carter Expected to Name 2 Trade Office Deputies
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  Robert D. Hormats, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, and Michael B. Smith, the Administration's chief textile negotiator, are expected to be nominated by President Carter as deputies to Reubin Askew, who has been nominated to be the special trade representative.

title: Japanese Formally Open Election Campaign
description: TOKYO, Sept. 17  Beginning what promises to be a spirited contest turning mostly on financial issues, nearly 900 aspirants for the 511 seats in the House of Representatives registered as candidates today as national electoral authorities proclaimed the official opening of the campaign for elections Oct. 7.

title: OBSERVER
description: One day a United States senator jumped onto the bed and screamed, There is a mouse under the bed! The other senators present all jumped onto the bed with him, pulled their trouser cuffs up to their knees and cried, A mouse is under the bed!

title: Postal Ballots Expected to Give NonSocialists Slim Edge in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 17  Olof Palme, the Social Democratic Party chairman, said today that he felt postal ballots would probably wipe out a Socialist bloc lead and tip Sweden's election to the nonSocialist parties when the mail votes are counted Wednesday.

title: Canadian Envoy Arrives For Meetings in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 17 (Reuters) Robert L. Stanfield, Canadian special envoy, arrived here today from Turkey for talks with Jordanian officials on whether his country should move its embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

title: Deaths
description: PRESSBERGJack. Pinebrook Hadassah of New Rochelle is saddened by the passing of Jack. Husband of our president Blanche and extend our deepest sympathy to her and the family.

title: Residents of Prospering Industrial Town in Iowa Show Few Signs of General Malaise
description: WATERLOO, Iowa, Sept. 15  Harry Olson, a tall, softspoken man, leaned forward at his desk, frowning as if he were trying to find a flaw in his personal situation. But it was hard.

title: Deaths
description: FRUINJohn Gibson, Esq. of Inwood, L.I. on September 17, 1979. Beloved husband of Alta (nee Pearsall). Dear brother of Mrs. James Clyne and Miss M. Cornelia FruIn. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Reposing at Meserole Funeral Home, 143 Lord Avenue, Inwood. American Legion and Veteran of Foreign War services Tuesday, 8:00 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10:15 AM at Our Lady of Good Counsel R.C. Church, Inwood. Interment Greenfield Cemetery, Hempstead, L.I.

title: Bomb Debate Sure to Go On
description: Has a letter published on Sunday by a Wisconsin newspaper made it suddenly easier for America's enemies  governments or terrorist groups  to build hydrogen bombs?

title: Bo Belinsky?;
description: In a philosophical moment, Yogi Berra once grunted, You're never out of it until you're out of it. But now the Yankees are out of it. After three years in the World Series, they have time this October to watch the leaves turn. They also have time to plot how to obtain a center fielder, a catcher and a startine pitcher or two if they are to challenge the Baltimore Orioles in the American League's Eastern Division next year. Meanwhile, three other division races are coming to a boil. Two nouveau riche National League teams are challenging old money  the Montreal Expos against the Pittsburgh Pirates in the East, the Houston Astros against the Cincinnati Reds in the West. And in the American League West, the California Angels hope to hold off the Kansas City Royals after nearly two decades of frustration. It would be the Angels first division championship since Gene Autry financed the franchise that Bo Belinsky, the legendary lefthanded lover and pool shark, put on the map with a nohit

title: Former Employees Are Questioned
description: Detectives questioned numerous past and present employees of a Westchester County armored car company yesterday, but made no arrests and reported no major leads in the hijacking of an unattended armored truck with $228,651 outside a Bronx supermarket Sunday afternoon.

title: F.J. McNamara, 82, ExU.S. Aide
description: Francis J. McNamara Sr., a lawyer, corporation executive and former official in the Department of Justice, died Thursday at his home in New Canaan, Conn., after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: World News Briefs
description: VERACRUZ, Mexico, Sept. 17 (AP) A hurricane with winds of up to 107 miles per hour moved through the Gulf of Mexico today toward Mexico's southern coast.

title: Sweatshops Thrive Despite Union and Federal Efforts
description: A small dress factory lies behind the folding steel gate of a grimy storefront in the shadow of the elevated IRT tracks along Jerome Avenue in the South Bronx.

title: Gio Ponti, Architect, Innovative Designer Of Articles for Home
description: Gio Ponti, a leading modern architect and designer, died Saturday at his home in Milan, Italy. He was 87 years old.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Indians Top Yanks  Twice by 51 and 65
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 17  Mike Hargrove did more than his share for Cleveland tonight as the Indians won a doubleheader from the Yankees, 51 and 65.

title: Episcopal Bishops Vote to Reject The Ordination of Homosexuals
description: DENVER, Sept. 17  The House of Bishops, one of two legislative bodies of the Episcopal Church, overwhelmingly adopted a resolution today holding that homosexuals have an equal claim with others upon the love, acceptance and pastoral concern of the church but should not be ordained as priests.

title: CETA Workers in Layoff Seeking Jobs
description: Margaret Clarke, a personnel interviewer for New York Telephone, was pleasantly surprised yesterday. Of the first eight abouttobelaidoff municipal employees she screened, she considered seven to be excellent prospects for hiring by her company.

title: FedMinutes Bill Advances
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP)  The House approved today and sent to the Senate legislation that would require Federal monetarypolicy officials to resume taking minutes at their secret meetings and to make them public four years after each meeting.

title: Associated Press
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 17 (AP)  The new leader of Afghanistan's proSoviet Government said today that his takeover of the Presidency yesterday marked the beginning of a better socialist order, and he announced that some enemies of the people had been eliminated.

title: Ceremony at White House Marks Anniversary of Accords on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan told President Carter and Egypt's Vice President today that the differences between Israel and Egypt over the issue of Palestinian autonomy were smaller now than those that divided the two countries at the start of last year's Camp David talks.

title: Yastrzemski Honored
description: Carl Yastrzemski, who last week became only the 15th major league player to reach the 3,000hit plateau, yesterday was named the American League's player of the week. The milestone single was Yastrzemski's only hit of the week.

title: Concert: Classical Music From India
description: L.SUBRAMANIAM, the south Indian violinist, was positively dazzling during his opening set at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening. One is used to coming away from certain performances of Indian classical music impressed by a musician's technique, by his sense of structural development or perhaps moved by his soul and intensity. But Dr. Subramaniam achieved a delicate balance of all these factors, something he was not quite able to do last year when he gave a lovely performance in New York at the Center for International Arts.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Little Vatican to Accompany the Pope on Journey to Ireland and U.S.
description: ROME, Sept. 15  When Pope John Paul II sets out on his journey to Ireland and the United States, he will take a flying little Vatican with him.

title: Victors Move Within 2
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 17  If psychological impact counts for anything in baseball pennant races, then the Kansas City Royals may have made an impression of major significance here tonight.

title: Lane Irregularity Voids Bowler's Double300 Feat
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 17 (AP)  The two consecutive 300 games bowled by Roger Twiss last week have been disallowed.

title: Study Points to True Altruism in Fish
description: A young researcher, diving in coves off the Antarctic Peninsula to observe the behavior of a species of small bottomdwelling fish, believes he has discovered what may be the first recorded case of true altruism in lower animals.

title: Soviet Wheat Purchase
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) The Agriculture Department today announced the sale by private exporters of 200,000 metric tons of wheat to the Soviet Union. The latest sales brought total Russian grain purchases for the fourth year, which begins Oct. 1, of a fiveyear wheat agreement to 6.63 million tons, including 3.96 million tons of wheat and 2.67 million tons of corn.

title: Nixon Arrives in Peking at Start of FourDay Visit
description: PEKING, Sept. 17  Richard M. Nixon arrived tonight in Peking, the scene of what was perhaps his greatest triumph as President, for a fourday visit.

title: Gulf, Sun Bar Heating Oil Vow
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP)  Two major United States oil companies told Congress today that they could not endorse President Carter's request for a freeze on heating oil prices and a third refused to testify entirely.

title: U.S. Banks Status Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  American banks are treated fairly in most foreign financial centers, although few countries would allow United States banks to acquire control of large indigenous banks, according to a Treasury report released today.

title: Carter Faces Uphill Campaign in New York
description: President Carter's problems in the state are pointed up by the strategy of the two chief Carter campaigners here: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Joel McCleary, who has left the White House staff to be the New York coordinator for the Carter campaign.

title: New Shell Wells in Gulf
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 17 (Reuters)  The Shell Oil Company said today that it had begun oil and gas production from two wells on the Cognac Platform, situated in the Gulf of Mexico, about 15 miles southeast of the mouth of the Mississippi River. Shell said it planned to have another 60 wells on the platform and by 1983 expected production of about 50,000 barrels of oil and 100 million cubic feet of gas a day.

title: About New York
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Cradling the telephone chintoshoulder, the junior Senator from New York snatched up a copy of the Constitution and scrambled to find the Second Amendment.

title: Scientists Group Seeks Indian Point Plant Shutdowns
description: The Union of Concerned Scientists, an antinuclear lobbying group, petitioned the Nuclear Regulatory Commission yesterday to shut down immediately the two nuclear reactors now operating at Indian Point. The group asserted that there were major safety shortcomings at the plants, 36 miles north of New York City.

title: Move to Curb MediaSponsored Campaign Debates Hits Senate Snag
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  The Senate is ready to block regulations proposed by the Federal Election Commission that apparently would make it illegal for corporations, including newspapers and broadcasters, to sponsor political campaign debates, according to Senate staff members.

title: Scottish Shipyards Long Slide
description: GLASGOW  James Lindsay, a 52yearold electrician, stood watching a tide of men in blue coveralls dashing from the old Govan shipyard for lunch as he recited the famous names: Harland & Wolff, Fairfield, Inglis and Upper Clyde, the consortium that wound up with John Brown, producer of the three mighty Queens.

title: CHRYSLER CHAIRMAN WILL RETIRE EARLY
description: DETROIT, Sept. 17  John J. Riccardo, the Chrysler Corporation's 55yearold chairman and chief executive officer, said today that he would ask Chrysler's board of directors to grant him early retirement, effective on Thursday.

title: Trial Ordered for Freelance Writer In 'son of Sam PhotoBribe Case
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that a freelance writer must stand trial on charges of bribing a correction officer to get prison photographs of David R. Berkowitz after his 1977 arrest as the Son of Sam killer.

title: F16 Fighter Firing Curbed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)  The Air Force said today that it had temporarily ordered F16 fighters not to use their 20mm. cannon after two aircraft experienced an expected rocking motion during test firings. The problem was first perceived in one F16 in April, and again on Sept. 7 when another F16 testfired its cannon at an altitude of 14,000 feet. The Air Force described the problem as an uncommanded yaw during firing.

title: State Checking 11 Cities Courts For Efficiency
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 17 City Court judges and their procedures in 11 municipalities north of New York City will come under scrutiny in the next three months to determine if they can function more efficiently with uniform procedures.

title: Old Dominion Is Penalized
description: NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 17 (UPI) Old Dominion University's women's basketball program, which fielded the nationchampion team last season, has been censured, reprimanded and placed on two years probation for a recruiting violation, the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women said today.

title: The Continuing Crash of 68
description: Fifty years ago this fall, the stock market crashed, leading the country into the Great Depression. In our mythological memory it was a great crash, in a single day, with people leaping out windows on Wall Street. It fact, it was nothing of the kind. The incidence of suicide, for instance, was probably lower than average. Thp qtnrk market did not crash in a single day.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: XRAYS of the 2yearold boy's wrist showed broken bones from what the mother said was a fall down the stairs. It was a plausible story when the pediatrician first treated the patient in the hospital emereencv room.

title: EDUCATION
description: LAST year 535 firstyear teachers in the Dallas school system took a test of basic academic skills, and officials were shocked to discover that one out of three did worse than the average high school junior in both mathematics and English.

title: Bridge:
description: The Harry Goldwater tournament at Adelphi University, in Garden City, L.I., during the weekend came within hairbreadth of producing a triumph for the veteran tournament director in whose honor it was held. In the Swiss Team event Sunday, his partner was the alltime great B. Jay Becker, who said he was impressed by the performance of a man who for 30 years has supervised the play rather than taken part in it.

title: Cosmos Begin Far East Tour
description: The Cosmos left yesterday for a fiveweek tour of the Far East that will include 12 exhibition matches.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: TALKS ON RHODESIA BOG DOWN IN LONDON
description: LONDON, Sept. 17  With the peace conference on Zimbabwe Rhodesia bogged down over powers for the white minority and other issues, Britain de. cided today to abandon full conference sessions for the time being in favor of separate negotiations with the Salisbury Government and its guerrilla foes.

title: FRANK BURNS
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 17 (AP)  Frank Burns, a retired executive who helped create the marketing for PepsiCola, died yesterday at the age of 91.

title: Macchiarola Promises To Hasten Placement Of Disabled Students
description: School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola pledged yesterday that within 18 months long waiting lists and red tape in the placement of handicapped youths would be eliminated.

title: ABE MURDOCK DEAD; FORMER U.S. SENATOR
description: Funeral services for Abe Murdock, a former United States Democratic Senator from Utah, will be held on Friday in the Beaver Mormon 3d4th Ward Church chapel, Beaver, Utah. Mr. Murdock died Saturday in a Bethesda, Md., hospital. He was 86 years old.

title: New Company Formed
description: Murry M. Salzberg, chairman of Central Jersey Industries Inc., yesterday announced the formation of a new company out of the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey, which has been in reorganization since 1967. He said the company had new directors, officers and shareholders as well as revised debt structure. Mr. Salzberg said the company was no longer in the railroad business and that it intended to look for new economic opportunities.

title: Gas Problem Spurs Fuel Saving by Police Departments
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  The gasolinesupply disruptions of last spring and everincreasing costs have prompted many police departments across the country to turn to more fuelefficient patrol cars, to handle more cases by telephone and to dispatch more foot patrols, a check of departments has shown.

title: Goldschmidt Drops HighwayMass Transit Merger
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  Neil Goldschmidt, the new Secretary of Transportation, says that he will abandon his predecessor's plan to bring coordinated planning to road and public transit policies by combining the Urban Mass Transit Administration and the Federal Highway Administration.

title: McGeorge Bundy Questions View U.S. Strategic might Is Impaired
description: PARIS, Sept. 17  McGeorge Bundy, who was the national security adviser in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, said in a speech made public today that the American nuclear commitment to Western Europe remained unwavering and the deterrent to Soviet attack unimpaired.

title: Simpson Aims at Nets Job
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Sept. 17 Kevin Loughery remembers Ralph Simpson as a freshfaced youngster who dominated the defunct American Basketball Association eight months after his freshman year at Michigan State University ended.

title: Ballet: 3 Puixotes Fill 2 Days With Surprises
description: THE American Ballet Theater's fall Encore Season at the Metropolitan Opera House may have been a little heavy on staples, but its closing performances of Mikhail Baryshnikov's Don Quixote were full of surprises. There was the very fine debut of Cynthia Harvey as Kitri on Sunday afternoon, followed that evening by the kind of showmustgoon incident of which legends are made, when a young corps dancer stepped into the lead male role on a few seconds notice. All in all, it was not day to be missed.

title: Science Watch
description: A group of researchers at Ohio State University has reported that treating laboratory rabbits with tender loving care seems to greatly reduce the risk of heart disease, even for animals fed abnormal amounts of cholesterol.

title: Rates On Mortgages At Records
description: Interest rates on home mortgages continued to rise to records yesterday, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported.

title: Darwin Is Still A Target
description: Charles Darwin remains the bete noire of fundamentalist Christians who, 120 years after publication of The Origin of Species, insist that biology textbooks pay attention to the activity of a supernatural Creator. They Press their cause before school boards, state legislatures and even the staid Smithsonian Institutions where they were demanding that a new Dynamics of Evolution exhibit be closed or offset by an equally prominent display of creationist notions. This long struggle has damaged the teaching of sound biological science. Creationists have won few legal battles, but they have so intimidated many publishers and authors that Darwin would have as much trouble as the Creator being adequately represented in many publicschool biology texts. This continuing suppression of evolution, through voluntary restraint by authors and publishers in the face of the strong feelings of a religious minority, hints that the phenomenon is deepseated. It is not just the lastditch effort of religious bigots. While the declared creationists are relatively few, they find wider sympathy. And publishers sense that they still must tread carefully.

title: TV: 'sheriff Lobo Rides the South
description: RECENTLY, in one of his opening monologues, Johnny Carson explained a spinoff was one series developed out of another successfully established series. Then, referring to his own network, he added mischievously, You have to give NBC some kind of credit, though, for coming up with a new series out of a flop.

title: Poorer Countries Persuade OPEC To Negotiate Oil Prices and Supply
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 17 After six years of suffering in silence over the skyrocketing price of oil, the world's poorer nations have persuaded the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to agree to negotiations on pricing and supply.

title: Congress Focus: Where to Draw Lines on Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  Congress took up the Federal budget for next year today and immediately began debating which groups should bear the burden for fighting inflation. In the process, the lawmakers demonstrated how difficult it is to impose fiscal restraint at a time when every special interest in the capital is fighting to bear as little of the burden as possible.

title: Deaths
description: ADAMSONRonald Dutton. On Sep. 16, 1979. (Associated with Charbert Fabrics Corp., N.Y.C.) Beloved husband of Mary (nee Carney) of Rye, N.Y. Devoted father of Master Sgt David M. (instructor at U.S. Military Academy, West Pt., N.Y.) Jean Ann O'Neill of St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands. Brother of Nancy Adamson Foster of Bridgeport, Vt. Also survived by 6 grandchildren. Family will receive friends from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 P.M. at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, N.Y..

title: Advertising
description: DEVISING hand signals as voice substitutes to be used when ordering products is not an altogether novel advertising approach. Remember Three rings, get it? for Ballantine beer? That was more than 45 years ago.

title: Down the Line, to Jean Seberg
description: The horror of COINTELPRO didn't sink in for a lot of people until this weekend when the F.B.I. disclosed how it had used its counterintelligence program against the late Jean Seberg. The story tells much about the tyrannical old F.B.I., the conscientious new one, and how Congress needs to shore up the latter.

title: Agency Heads Are Blamed As City Capital Projects Lag
description: The chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee, Edward L. Sadowsky, charged yesterday that delays in New York City's capitalconstruction program suggested that agency heads were fiddling while the city crumbles. He said he would propose changes to expedite Projects.

title: ExOnondaga Aide Pleads Guilty
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 17  The former District Attorney of Onondaga County today admitted participation in a kickback scheme to raise funds illegally for the county Republican Party.

title: Arab Communications Job
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Sept. 17 (Reuters)  International corporations have been invited to bid on an Arab satellite project, the official Saudi news agency said today. The project, to provide 12,000 telephone circuits and eight television channels, is expected to be in operation 30 months after the signing of the contract, according to the report.

title: Joseph P. Richardson, Architect For Many Buildings at Harvard
description: BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP)  Joseph P. Richardson, a prominent architect, died Friday at his home in Brookline. He was 66 years old.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, Sept. 17, 1979

title: Koch to Decline $20,000 Raise; Fears Problem Asserts He Didn't Realize Deep Feeling Against It
description: Mayor Koch, saying he had not realized the depth of feeling against recently voted raises for the Mayor, City Councilmen and members of the Board of Estimate, disclosed last night that he would not accept the increase in his salary from $60,000 to $70,000 this year and to $80,000 next year.

title: 66 Supermarkets Ban Eggs for High Levels of PCB
description: HELENA, Mont., Sept. 17 (AP)Three supermarket chains took all eggs produced in Montana off the shelves at 66 stores today as the Food and Drug Administration continued its sixstate investigation into chicken feed contaminated by the banned chemical PCB.

title: Astronomer Suggests Sun Could Function As Telescope Lens
description: Man's quest for other solar systems capable of habitation by intelligent beings is hindered by the relatively puny power of the instruments with which he confronts the immensity of space. But an astronomer at Stanford University has proposed the idea of a telescope 205 billion miles long that could do the job.

title: OPEC to Plan Policy Steps
description: BAHRAIN, Sept. 17 (Reuters)  The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will begin consultations next month on policy coordination, the Saudi Press Agency said today.

title: Gold Soars To $355.50 In London
description: LONDON, Sept. 17  The price of gold soared above $350 an ounce for the first time today, with some dealers saying the end of the spectacular climb was nowhere in sight.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 17 (AP)  A judge in the Bahamas ended liquidation proceedings for one of the world's largest refineries today, in effect handing control of the facility to the Charter Company.

title: EARNINGS
description: Foreigncurrency losses reduced the net income of the Sony Corporation by 40.1 percent in the third fiscal quarter and by 37.6 percent for the nine months ended July 31, according to yesterday's report by the Japanese manufacturer of radios, recorders, television sets and other electronic products.

title: Topics
description: How should the Senate label Herman Talmadge's financial misconduct? In its final recommendation, the Senate Ethics Committee had no trouble over adjectives. It called the Georgia Democrat's behavior, including the way he chiseled $50,000 in official expenses, reprehensible.

title: Strangers Are Causing Rumpus in Texas
description: FORT WORTH, Sept. 17  The Texas Rangers have been absorbing some cruel and unusual punishment this month. The Rangers, nearly out of pennant contention in the American League West since their oncepromising season turned sour, have been bedeviled recently by another team from Texas, the Fort Worth Strangers.

title: FLORIDA TO PROVIDE EARLY TEST FOR 80
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 17  President Carter, despite past successes here, support from almost the entire Democratic establishment and pointed use of White House resources, could encounter a setback next month when Florida holds the Democratic Party's first measurable test of strength between him and Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: ExPresident of Philippines Attacks Carter Over U.S. Support of Marcos
description: MANILA, Sept. 17 Former President Diosdado Macapagal has charged that the Carter Administration has coddled an overstaying and corrupt dictatorship against the people by supporting President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who has ruled by martial law for seven years.

title: Slick
description: Despite strangulated cries Of dunelovers and the bourgeoisie In coastal resorts, thirsty

title: Reds Lose to Giants, 74
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 (AP) Roger Metzger's tworun triple capped a fiverun firstinning that carried the San Francisco Giants over the Cincinnati Reds, 74, tonight.

title: KimberlyClark Sells California Assets
description: The KimberlyClark Corporation said that it had sold 323,000 acres of forest land and two sawmills in northern California to the Roseburg Lumber Company of Roseburg, Ore., for about $252 million in cash.

title: Tommy Leonetti, 50, a Singer On Your Hit Parade in 195758
description: Tommy Leonetti, a singer with the 195758 cast of Your Hit Parade on television and the Tony Pastor and Charlie Spivak bands, died Saturday of cancer in St. Joseph's Hospital in Houston. He was 50 years old and lived in Los Angeles, where he owned a recording studio.

title: Studebaker Shares To McGrawEdison
description: ELGIN, Ill., Sept. 17 (Reuters) The McGrawEdison Company announced today that 93 percent of the outstanding common stock of StudebakerWorthington Inc. had been tendered to it under its 351.50ashare takeover offer. The $721 million offer by McGrawEdison, an electrical products company. had expired last Friday.

title: Attorneys for ExPanther Leader Rest Their Case in Murder Retrial
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 17 (AP)  The defense in the murder retrial of Huey Newton, a former leader of the Black Panther Party, abruptly rested its case today, contending that the prosecution had failed to prove that Mr. Newton killed Kathleen Smith in 1974.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: San Diego Primary Set Today
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 17 (AP)  Mayor Pete Wilson will seek a third term tomorrow in a sixway, nonpartisan mayoral election. Mr. Wilson would have to win more than 50 percent of the vote to avoid a runoff in November.

title: Rocky Summer For Film Industry
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 Summer, which, for movie theaters, traditionally extends from Memorial Day to Labor Day, was something of a disappointment to Hollywood and the country's 18,000 theaters this year.

title: Compromise on Canal Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 House and Senate conferees agreed today on a compromise bill to carry out the Panama Canal Treaty, only 14 days before the treaty noes into effect.

title: Two Principal Dancers of Bolshoi Are Given Political Asylum in U.S.
description: Leonid and Valentina Koslov, a husband and wife who are principal dancers with the Bolshoi Ballet, were granted political asylum in the United States yesterday.

title: $1.91 Million For Paperback
description: Ballantine Books, a division of Random House, last night won the paperback rights to Marilyn French's next novel, The Bleeding Heart, auctioned by Summit Books, a division of Simon and Schuster. The successful bid was $1.91 million. In the final bidding, which began in the morning and extended late into the evening, five other paperback houses  Fawcett, Avon, Pocketbooks, Warner and Berkley competed. All had begun with an opening figure of $1 million and each increment under the bidding rules was by at least 5 percent. Berkley stayed closest to the winning figure. It had been the paperback house that scored a success with Miss French's previous novel, The Women's Room.

title: Starrett City Lone Concern: Rent
description: From a distance, the 46 brown and beige masonary towers that rise out of the surrounding swamps resemble a child's set of plastic building blocks. When the sun shines, the towers take on the artificial gloss of an artist's rendering. But this is not the land of makebelieve21,000 people live in Starrett City.

title: SixMonth Bills At 10.315%
description: The average rate for the sixmonth bills rose to a new high of 10.315 percent from 10.294 percent for the preceding week as yields were mixed on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and the 182day maturities.

title: Around the Nation
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 17 (AP) Nurses at the Rhode Island Medical Center voted 74 to 20 today to continue their fivedayold walkout in defiance of a Superior Court backtowork order.

title: Financing Arranged For Barclay Hotel
description: The Connecticut General Life Insurance Company said that it had agreed to provide $37 million in permanent financing to the Intercontinental Hotels Corporation in connection with the purchase and planned renovation of the Barclay Hotel in New York City. The renovation will be comnleted in 1981.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Edward Kennedy may say and even believe that he hasn't finally decided to be a Presidential candidate next year, but it's hard to see what would make him back down now.

title: Kenny Rogers to Be Host Of CountryMusic Awards
description: Kenny Rogers will be host of the 13th telecast of the Country Music Awards Show, on Oct. 8. The broadcast, from 9:30 to 11 P.M. on CBS, will be simulcast by 50 countrymusic radio stations.

title: Piano: James Dick Gives Recital at the Y
description: FOR a pianist of formidable attainments, James Dick doesn't seem to turn up in New York very frequently. A 39yearold Texan, he has won prizes in a number of international competitions, and now has his own summer festival in Round Top, Tex. His recital Sunday night at the 92d Street Y was his first local solo appearance in three seasons.

title: 700 Tourists Become iII in Japan
description: OSAKA, Japan, Sept. 17 (Reuters) About 700 tourists in the Japanese city of Osaka became ill after eating packed lunches bought from a local catering company, the Osaka city government said today. The government said that 119

title: Agency Opposes Hospital Closing Sought by Koch
description: The city's federally funded Health Systems Agency recommended yesterday that the Metropolitan Hospital Center on the lower fringes of East Harlem remain open. The planning agency's proposal ran directly counter to a plan by Mayor Koch to close the hospital.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Associated Dry Goods Corporation  announced that Joseph H. Johnson, currently vice chairman and chief financial officer and treasurer of its Lord & Taylor division, will join corporate headquarters as executive vice president on Nov. 1.

title: A Colloquy on the Sanger Spirit
description: The Domestic Relations Code in Georgia begins with a law stating that the husband is the head of the family and the wife is subject to him. That means that in Georgia today the family house belongs to the husband, no matter who makes the payments.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 3 P.M. to begin 39th session.; Tickets are available at the public desk in the main lobby, United Nations headquarters. Tours: 9 A.M.4:45 P.M.

title: F.T.C. Case On Du Pont Dismissed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP)  Antitrust charges against E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company were dismissed today by a judge who said a competitive advantage gained by the nation's largest chemical company had resulted from intelligent planning.

title: Q & A
description: Q. If a neutrino has no mass and no electric charge, what does have?

title: Deaths
description: EPSTEIN LasarAt 93 years on September 16, 1979 at Workmens Circle Home and Infirmary Bronx. Beloved father, Grandfather, Great. grandfather of Israel and Elsie Ep. stein and family. Dear Uncle of Beba and Lee Leventhal and family. Services 1 PM Wednesday, September 19, Park West Chapel, 115W 79th St., NYC.

title: Todd Given Praise, But Job Is Still Open
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 17  At opposite ends of the locker room at the Jets practice camp today, two players accepted without question their uncertain status, indicating that Coach Walt Michaels's iron grip on the young team was as strong as ever.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown.(N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Armory in Puerto Rico Is Hit by 3 Explosions
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Sept. 18 (UPI)  Three explosions rocked a National Guard armory west of San Juan late today and a National Guard truck was burned.

title: JET LOSES TAIL CONE BUT RETURNS SAFELY
description: The rear door and tail cone of an Air Canada DC9 twinjet airliner were ripped away high over the Atlantic yesterday and assorted parcels and a food cart were swept out through the gaping hole, but the plane was able to land safely with no serious injuries to the 43 persons on board.

title: Store Sales Up 7.6% in July
description: The nation's largest retail chains had an average sales gain of 7.6 percent in July over the yearearlier month, while sales for the year's first seven months rose 7.3 percent over the 1978 mark, according to a survey by Chain Store Age, a trade publication.

title: Opera: Capital Hears `Cendrillon
description: IF bets were to be placed on the survival potential of all the Massenet operas that have been recently brought forward for reevaluation over the last few years, the most favorable odds would doubtlessly be placed on Cendrillon. Last spring, Columbia released a recording that seemed to enchant just about everyone, even people normally allergic to Massenet's skillfully prepared confections.

title: Foes of Louisville Mayor Seek Impeachment Vote
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Mayor William B. Stansbury's 30year climb through the Democratic ranks in this old river city is threatened at its apex by a sharp intraparty feud in which his opponents are seeking to impeach him and may well succeed.

title: Details of Pope's New York Visit Expected to Be Disclosed Today
description: Roman Catholic Church officials said yesterday that they expected details of the visit of Pope John Paul II to New York to be announced soon  possibly todaybringing to an end continuing differences over how the Pontiff should divide his time in the city between the United Nations and events planned by the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Notes on People;
description: Justice Brennan Recovering After a 'small Stroke

title: Food Fair Delays Bankruptcy Plan
description: Food Fair Inc., the Philadelphiabased supermarket chain, failed to deliver a bankruptcy reorganization plan it had hoped to have ready yesterday. Michael Crames of the law firm of Levin & Weintraub of New York, which is representing Food Fair, told a bankruptcy court hearing in New York that the company's creditors had not yet agreed on restructuring debt.

title: A Swimsuit Extravaganza From Israel
description: It was one of the most extraordinary fashion shows ever staged, in the opinion of many of the 500 viewers at the Hotel Pierre the other day, combining elements of Diaghilev's Ballet Russe and Ziegfeld's Follies. Its 11 scenes were keyed to such varied themes as English gardens, French Impressionists, Oriental potentates and Latin American fiestas.

title: Steel Output Down in Week
description: Steel production fell 1.3 percent to 2.431 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, from the previous week's 2.464 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Federal Reserve appeared to put the credit markets on notice yesterday that it was about to raise shortterm interest rates still further. The central bank's action, coupled with the news of the recent generous wage settlement in the auto industry, drove fixedincome prices down sharply.

title: Reuss Dubious On Bonn Policy
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Sept. 17 (Reuters)  West Germany's current monetary policy risks weakening the United States dollar and forcing the Federal Reserve Board to take countermeasures that have serious conseauences for the world economy, said Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Banking Committee, in an interview published here.

title: Deaths
description: MARGETTGrace U. (nee Quinn) On Sept. 16, 1979, loving wife of Charles (Associate Justice Supreme Court Appellate Division), dear sisterinlaw of Sara Posner,Estelle Margett and Nora Quinn. Funeral from Schwartz Brothers Chapel, 11403 Queens Boulevard (at 76th Road) Forest Hills on Wednesday. Services 10:30 A.M. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery. Donations to L.I.J.Hillside Medical Center preferred. Visiting hours 7:30 to 9:30 P.M.

title: Peoples Gas Unit Buys Share of Tracts
description: The Peoples Gas Company said that Its Teacoma Production Company subsidiary had bought an equity interest in two of the Superior Oil Company's recently acquired oil and gas tracts in the Gulf of Mexico for $44 million.

title: Strauss to Aid Carter Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  Robert S. Strauss, the special American envoy to the Middle East, said today that he would play an active role as a primary strategist and fundraiser in President Carter's reelection camoaign.

title: Free as a Balloon
description: And still they come. Despite the Berlin Wall, despite the mined frontiers, police dogs, barbed wire and automatic weapons, the flow of escapees from East Germany continues. The dangerous 28mile flight to West Germany by two couples and their four children on a tiny metal platform slung below a homemade hotair balloon speaks volumes.

title: An Awakening at Quality Inns
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., Sept. 17  At one point in the mid1960's, Quality Inns International Inc., had a 40to1 priceearnings ratio and was being touted as the next Holiday Inns. Today it is hard to find anyone on Wall Street who still follows the company's fortunes.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Sept. 8 reported incorrectly the salaries of justices of the New York State Supreme Court. The justices now receive $52,928. That will rise to $56,098 on Oct. 1.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Agency's Plan for Hospitals
description: The Health Systems Agency of New York City recommended the following hospital closings, mergers and bed reductions as part of its draft of a comprehensive health plan for the city:

title: DC10 Sets Passenger Record
description: LONG BEACH, Calif. (UPI)  The DC10 jetliner, which was grounded by the Federal Aviation Administration for time this year, has rebounded to carry more passengers in the month of August than in any previous month in its history, according to the plane's manufacturer.

title: Persistent Amateur Expert on Nuclear Weapons
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17  Fame and national publicity have closed in on Charles R. Hansen. Before last Friday, he was an articulate and zealous advocate of the concept that it was possible for anyone with a little training and a Man in the News lot of patience to find out from unclassified sources how to build a nuclear bomb. He was attracted to the subject by the Government attempt to bar The Progressive magazine from printing an article that contained what its author found in unclassified sources.

title: California Takes Lead in Lawyers Amid Continued Shortage of Jobs
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17  This year, for the first time, California has surpassed New York as the state with the most lawyers. But that distinction may be dubious because there are several indications that more lawyers are out of work in California than anywhere else.

title: Reynolds, Alcan Raise Some Prices
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 17 (AP)  The Reynolds Metals Company confirmed today that it had increased prices of aluminumcan body sheet by about 7.7 percent.

title: Feinstein Is Leaving As Executive Director Of Kennedy Center
description: Martin Feinstein, regarded in cultural circles as the impresario who pulled Washington out of musical provincialism, will be leaving his position as executive director of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. One of the reasons may have been the alarm with which the center's board regarded Mr. Feinstein's ambitious and expensive visions for a resident opera company of international caliber.

title: Islanders Sign Bossy To 3Year Contract
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 17  Mike Bossy, whose 122 goals are the most scored by any player in his first two seasons in the National Hockey League, signed a threeyear contract today with the New York Islanders.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: William F. Niehous, the OwensIllinois executive who spent more than three years as a captive of leftist Venezuelan guerrillas, returned to work yesterday at the company's headquarters in Toledo, Ohio, and made it clear that his main desire was to get on with his job. I want to start living a normal life, he said.

title: G.O.P. Senator Urges a Delay in Arms Treaty Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  Senator Henry Bellmon, Republican of Oklahoma, urged today that Senate action on the nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union be postponed until next year pending a reappraisal of foreign and defense policy.

title: About Education For the Writing Crisis, Help is on the Way
description: THE latest target of public criticism is the Second R  riting. Why Johnny Can't Write is the favored new topic for acid comment in popular journals. Quite predictably, educators are beginning to strike back at those who have charged the schools with creating the writing crisis.

title: Outdoors at Summer's End Before the Fall Sweeps In
description: As an attendant cleaned up refuse from the sidewalk, diners at an outdoor cafe on 52d Street and Third Avenue yesterday enjoyed mild summer temperatures and clear and sunny skies. Temperatures in Manhattan reached a high of 82 degrees in the early afternoon. The forecast for today is for sunny skies and temperatures in the mid80's.

title: Curvature of Spine: Feedback Method Shows Promise
description: SCIENTISTS at Rockefeller University are exploring the possibility that some patients can correct curvature of the spine by a process of trial and error posture training alone.

title: Barber Oil Gets 2d Takeover Bid
description: The Barber Oil Corporation, which recently accepted a $147.3 million takeover offer from the Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation, said that it had received a $164.7 million offer from another company that already holds 9 percent of Barber

title: Miami Area Voting Today on Petition to Cut Taxes
description: MIAMI, Sept. 17  Dade County voters will go to the polls tomorrow to vote on a countywide operating tax cut of 99.95 percent for one year.

title: Deaths
description: BOTK INIHymanOf Kew Gardens, NY. Husband of Victoria. Father of Ell and Sheldon. Suddenly on September 12 1979.

title: New VicePresidential Tableware
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  When it comes to future informal diners at the Vice Presidential mansion, there will be no more than 16 guests, the color scheme will be muted beige with mauve overtones and everyone will have to sit up straight  the stemware is tall.

title: CUBA FREES LAST 4 FROM U.S. DETAINED IN POLITICAL CASES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Cuba freed the last four United States citizens it was holding on political charges today in what appeared to be a response to President Carter's release earlier this month of four Puerto Rican nationalists.

title: Early Market Gains Lose Ground
description: The stock market gave up robust early gains yesterday following signs that the Federal Reserve might be pushing interest rates higher for the first time since early September.

title: Quantum Theory Makes Leap To Biology
description: CAN human behavior, cancer and other complex biological mysteries be explained by he cold mathematical equations of physics? A team of chemists at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore believes that there may be qualified yes to this question, despite the many failures of others throughout history to calculate total man from the sum of his parts. The chemists Johns Hopkins University and School of Medicine are unlocking secrets of biological chemicals using a key normally reserved for the physics of fundamental matter quantum mechanics.

title: Ohio's Little Brown Jug Draws Field of 17 Pacers
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 17 (AP) Seventeen colts were entered today in the Little Brown Jug, the middle leg of the triple crown for 3yearold pacers. The event will be held Thursday in two divisions at the Delaware County Fairgrounds for a purse totaling $226,455.

title: Kosygin Ends South Yemen Visit With Signing of Economic Pact
description: KUWAIT, Sept. 17 (UPI)  Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union left Southern Yemen today, ending a 22hour visit during which an agreement for economic and technical cooperation was signed, the Aden radio said.

title: In Front of Moscow's Synagogue, a Place for Gossip
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 17  They met, about 300 of them, outside the synagogue on Arkhipov Street. There was a chill rain, the beginning of autumn, but this was where they met every Saturday at 4 o'clock, and mere rain could not keep them away.

title: Market Place
description: FACET ENTERPRISES, saddled with heavy pension expenses since the company was founded in a spinoff in 1976, appears to be on the verge of a settlement of pension claims. The claims are against Facet's progenitor, the Bendix Corporation, which spun off the auto parts manufacturer to shareholders at the behest of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Economists Warn On Interest Rates
description: The Shadow Open Market Committee, in a policy statement issued yesterday, warned the Federal Reserve against overtightening monetary policy and called for a $15 to $20 billion reduction in taxes and Government spending to stimulate savings and investment.

title: GiantsRedskins Summary
description: Giants Notes

title: The City
description: A 28yearold Brooklyn man was riddled with bullets as he got out of his car a block from his East Flatbush home early this morning, the apparent victim of a submachinegun attack, the police said.

title: Police Disperse Crowd Seeking Food Stamps In Wake of Hurricane
description: MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 17 (AP)  The police dispersed a crowd of 5,000 people that overwhelmed a food stamp distribution center here as residents of communities on the Gulf of Mexico in Alabama, Mississippi and Florida continued to dig out today from under the rubble of Hurricane Frederic. Losses from the hurricane are now estimated at more than $1 billion.

title: Two Teachers Strikes Are Ended in Jersey; Walkout Starts on L.I.
description: Teachers in Woodbridge and Paterson, N.J., voted yesterday to accept new contracts and end their strikes.

title: Friedkin Defends His Cruising
description: CONTRARY to the promises of his notquitefanmail, William Friedkin has indeed finished shooting Cruising and did leave New York alive. And the occasion of his departure, on a vacation trip a week ago, was Mr. Friedldn's idea of the right time to describe his experiences directing a film on the streets of New York while homosexual protest groups actively attempted to stop him. Throughout an eightweek shooting schedule that was complicated by bomb threats, the defections of a few extras, steady picketing and even steadier publicity, Mr. Friedkin had gone about his business, believing that the least inflammatory course of action was to remain more or less mum.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Bright spiraling clouds of Hurricane Henri are centered in the western Gulf of Mexico, with clouds extending northward across the lower Mississippi and Tennessee Valleys. Rain clouds extend across the Texas Panhandle. Clear skies are apparent elsewhere.

title: Anta Selling Option On Nursing Homes
description: The Anta Corporation, an Oklahoma Citybased operator of nursing homes, said that its executive committee had approved a contract to sell its option to buy seven Minnesota nursing centers currently owned by Challenge Homes.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Energy

title: Nigeria Oil Said to Top OPEC Cost
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 17 (AP) Nigeria has informed its crude oil contract customers that a $3 to $5 special premium will be charged above the official prices set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries beginning Oct. 1, the usually authoritative Middle East Economic Survey has reported.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE ULTIMATE BASEBALL BOOK. Edited by Daniel Okrent and Harris Lewine. With historical text by David Nemec. 352 pages. Illustrated. Houghton Mifflin. $29.95 until Dec. 31, $35 thereafter.

title: Rise in Rates and Gold Lowers Stocks
description: Soaring gold prices and rising interest rates sent the stock market sharply. lower yesterday. For the second consecutive session, precious metal issues were the stars of Wall Street.

title: Citicorp Note Rate Up
description: Citicorp sold $150 million of 91day notes yesterday at an average rate of 12.268 percent, up from 12.13 percent last week and the highest rate the bankholding company has paid in the auctions it has now held weekly for a year. A total of $744.2 million of bids was submitted and those accepted ranged in rate from 12.2 to 12.31 percent.

title: A Committee to Help Kennedy Is Organized in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Sept. 18  Formation of a Democratic campaign organization to support a possible Presidential candidacy of Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts was announced today by James P. Dugan, former chairman of the. New Jersey state Democratic committee.

title: General Assembly's Young African President
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 18 Eight years ago, when the General Assembly voted at a tumultuous meeting to expel the Chinese Nationalists and to seat Peking's representatives, a young Tanzanian diplomat leaped from his seat in front of the hall and jumped for joy in the aisle. More sedate now, Salim Ahmed Salim was elected president of the 34th General Assembly today.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Germany Stresses Need of NATO for Nuclear Weapon
description: BONN, Sept. 18 West Germany's Defense Minister today vigorously and repeatedly stressed the need for NATO nuclear weapons to meet the threat posed by the Soviet Union's new intermediate range nuclear missile.

title: Fast Food: A Nutritional Trap?; Personal Health
description: MEALS around the family table, while not quite dead and ready to be buried, are a far less common phenomenon these days than in decades past. Today, as a result of increased travel, smaller families, working wives, and increased discretionary income and leisure time, more than half of all Americans eat more than half their meals away from home.

title: Baden Superseded a Report in PoliceBrutality Inquiry
description: Dr. Michael M. Baden superseded an associate city medical examiner's autopsy report on the death last June of a mentally disturbed Harlem man, placing greater emphasis on the possibility that the police caused the injuries that killed him, it was learned yesterday.

title: E.E.C. in Steel Accord
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 18 (Reuters) Foreign ministers of the European Economic Community who are meeting here agreed in principle to limit aid by member countries to their steel industries, Adam Butler, British Minister for Industry, said today. But the decision will not be confirmed until Italy has insured that the way it finances its steel industry will not be affected, conference sources said. Britain's Parliament must also assent to the measure.

title: Carey Asks CeaseFire
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 18 (UPI)  Governor Carey of New York said today that he believed there should be a political ceasefire on all discussion of who will be the 1980 Democratic candidate for President.

title: The Editorial Notebook Blue Chips, Gold Bugs
description: Stock in General Motors represents fractional ownership in the bluest of blue chips, a brilliantly managed company with a long record of profitability. Gold is a rare, chemically stable, heavy metal with some industrial and medical applications, but its primary use is decorative.

title: 3 Types of Businesses Deregulated
description: Mayor Koch yesterday signed legislation that relieves the city of the obligation to license miniature golf courses, coffeehouses and massage parlors.

title: Coast Utility to Sell Bonds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (Reuters) The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the Southern California Edison Company had filed for an offering of $200 million of first and refunding mortgage bonds, due 2004, to be offered at competitive bidding. Bids will be accepted until 11 A.M., New York time, on Oct. 11, 1979. The company said proceeds or trie Orfering would be used to finance construction.

title: Richest Spaniel In South Africa
description: When Roy Harris of Cut and Shoot, Tex., was an undergraduate at Sam Houston State Teachers College, he got into a fight with another student.

title: Chinese Visitors Try a Factory Cafeteria
description: HAMPSTEAD, MD.

title: Pope to Cancel a Mass In Capital If Suit Wins
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI) Pope John Paul II will cancel his scheduled mass in Washington if Madalyn Murray O'Hair, an American atheist leader, gets a court order barring the celebration, a spokesman for the National Conference of Catholic Bishops said today.

title: To Impresarios, Focus Is Art, Not Politics
description: A star from the Bolshoi Ballet defects in New York. Two weeks later, two stars from the Bolshol defect in Los Angeles.

title: Bolshoi Couple Say They Defected For Personal and Artistic Freedom
description: Leonid and Valentina Kozlov, the Soviet ballet dancers granted asylum in Los Angeles on Monday, defected in order to gain personal and artistic freedom, according to United States immigration officials. They added Mrs. Kozlov also sought religious freedom in this country.

title: Croatian Cleric: To Yugoslays, A Saint or Nazi
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept. 13 Each day from dawn until well past dusk scores of worshipers move slowly through the Cathedral of St. Stephen past the main altar to a small shrine covered with flowers.

title: Senate Approves Military Budget Larger Than Carter Had Wanted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  The Senate, over President Carter's objections, amended the Federal budget today to provide for an increase in military spending of almost $40 billion over the next three years.

title: GasolineRule Shifts Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 18 (AP)  The Energy Department proposed today to make major refiners stop subsidizing the retailing costs of their own gasoline stations at the expense of independent retailers who buy gasoline wholesale from them.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Q&A
description: Q. I was recently served a Middle  Eastern cheese called kaskawan. Can you tell me the country of origin, what kind of milk it is made from and the etymology of the name?

title: For One 19YearOld, a Third Abortion
description: I just can't keep on destroying babies

title: In the Vineyards Among Friends
description: CLINTON CORNERS, N.Y.

title: Recipes for the Foods Proust Loved to Eat and Write About
description: Madeleines

title: Rossman Is Stopped By Ranquello in 6th
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 18  Ramon Ranquello, a littleknown fighter from West New York, N.J., scored a major upset tonight in Giants Stadium when he stopped Mike Rossman, the former World Boxing Association lightheavyweight champion.

title: Deaths
description: ABIANThelma on Sept. 17, Ames, Iowa, devoted wife of Alexander, mother of Rimma, Lisa and Andrew, sister of Mary and Elizabeth Vartanian of New York City. Wake service Tuesday, 7:30PM, Stevens

title: How Japan Rescues Companies
description: The Chrysler crisis illustrates the extravagant price that the United States probably pays for its giant companies relatively loose relationships with their banks.

title: G.O.P. Bloc Lists Billions in Waste
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  A group of Republican Congressmen today released a listing of what they called $10.8 billion In waste, fraud and mismanagement in the Federal Government. They said that this amount could be cut out of next year's budget without affecting services.

title: Eisenhower Diary Said to Assail MacArthur and Adm. King in 42
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 18  In secret parts of a wartime diary that were supposed to have been destroyed, Dwight D. Eisenhower characterized Douglas MacArthur as a baby and an uncertain factor who likes his boot lickers, The Houston Chronicle has reported in two copyrighted articles.

title: South Africa Gold: No Sales Shift Seen
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 18 (Reuters)  There has been no basic change in South Africa's policy on gold sales and the country will continue to sell more or less its full output of gold, informed sources said today.

title: BREWSTER S. BEACH
description: Brewster S. Beach, a former New York publicrelations man and reporter, died Saturday in Bonaire, the Netherland Antilles, where he lived. He was 86 years old.

title: Kingman Hits Give Cubs Sweep of Mets
description: Dave Kingman usually wins games and influences people with his home runs, but last night the Chicago Cubs slugger did it with a pair of singles, knocking in the deciding runs in a 20, 21 twilightnight doubleheader sweep of the New York Mets before a sparse crowd of 4,233 in Shea Stadium.

title: A Government Magazine Tells How to Snack
description: WASHINGTON

title: Police Identify Ill, Abused Girl Found in Queens
description: The mystery of a mute, sick and severely abused young girl who was found on a Jamaica, Queens, street nine days ago has been partly solved. Her grandmother and mother have come forward, but lawenforcement and childwelfare authorities declined to identify the child or her family.

title: Egypt Said to Get First Delivery Of U.S. Armored Cars and F4's
description: CAIRO, Sept. 18 (AP)  Seven United States Phantom jets and 50 armored personnel carriers reportedly arrived in Egypt this week, the first American weapons sold to Egypt in 25 years.

title: Press, Bomb and Pistols
description: No grave danger to national security justified the unprecedented sixmonth suppression of The Progressive magazine's article about Hbomb design. That, at last, will be proved with its publication. If the Government had really lost a valuable secret, it plainly would  or should  have stood mute instead of alerting technicians the world over. As was quickly apparent, the feared damage lay mainly in the demonstration of how much weapons information can be collected and deduced from public sources. And that meant there was  or should have been  no basis for restraining an American publication.

title: TV: Mrs. R's Daughter, Rape Victim
description: DAN CURTIS has put it all together with Mrs. R's Daughter, which will be seen from 9 to 11 o'clock tonight on NBCTV. Even by the kneehigh standards of madefortelevision films, it is unspeakable.

title: Bidders at U.S. Auction Take Gold Out of Mundane Category
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  Christopher Columbus was reported to have once observed that, He who possesses gold has all the needs in this world. At today's auction of 750,000 ounces of the Treasury's stockpile at Fort Knox, the bidders, mainly foreign banks, appeared to be taking the explorer's words to heart.

title: Hrs. Carter Will Greet Pope in Boston Oct. 1
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) Rosalyrm Carter will officially greet Pope John Paul II on behalf of President Carter when the Pope arrives in the United States next month, the White House said Monday.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Markets

title: Manhattan Voters Elect Poverty Board Members
description: Voters in Manhattan elected representatives yesterday to several new area policy boards and the Citywide Cornmunity Action Board. The elections represent the Koch administration's restructuring of the city's antipoverty program.

title: Police Clear Drug Supermarket Off Block
description: Children played ball on West 123d Street in Harlem the other day. Some jumped rope near Lenox Avenue and others, clutching money to buy groceries, ran past two police officers to a store on Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard.

title: U.S. Delegates Named For General Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 18 The following is a list of the United States delegates, and alternates, to the 39th session of the General Assembly:

title: Pope to Visit Harlem and South Bronx While in the City
description: Pope John Paul II will visit both Harlem and the South Bronx during his stay in New York City next month, according to the official schedule for the Pope's visit announced yesterday by the Vatican.

title: Giants Defeat Reds by 31
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 (AP) Darrell Evans collected three singles as the San Francisco Giants defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 31, tonight.

title: Pope's Itinerary for IrelandU.S. Visits
description: ROME, Sept. 18 (UPI)  The Vatican today released the following official itinerary for Pope John Paul ll's trip to Ireland and the United States Sept. 29 through Oct. 7. All times are local.

title: Faulty Auto Repair Loss Is Put at $8 Billion a Year
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  The automobiledriving public wastes from $8 billion to $10 billion a year on unnecessary or faulty auto repairs, a Congressional panel concluded today, and two House members warned that the problem might become even worse.

title: Notes on People
description: I'm nobody! Who are you? Are you nobody, too? If you could have answered yes to Emily Dickinson, you're the sort of person Derek Evans and Dave Fulwiler of San Diego are looking for.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) Three oil companies, including the Mobil Oil Corporation, the nation's second largest after the Exxon Corporation, have settled Energy Department allegations of overcharging for oil and oil products by agreeing to make refunds totaling more than $21 million, the department said today.

title: A Jobless Dispatcher Is Now Man of Leisure
description: TRENTON, Sept. 18 (AP)  An unemployed shipping clerk, who said he might throw the biggest block party his hometown of Lindenwold has ever seen, won the $1 million top prize today in the state's Lottery Derby game.

title: TV Importers Draw 7 Suits
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI) The Government filed seven civil suits today against importers of Japanese television sets, including two New Jersey concerns, in an effort to recover $30 million in unpaid duties levied on TV sets dumped into the United States market up until 1973 at prices below fair market value.

title: Electrical Workers Settle
description: DETROIT, Sept. 18 (UPI)  The International Union of Electrical Workers reached a tentative agreement today with the General Motors Corporation on a new contract for 32,000 G.M. employees.

title: Miami Area Rejects 99% Tax Cut
description: MIAMI, Sept. 18 (AP)  A misworded referendum that would virtually erase countywide property taxes was defeated tonight in Dade County, Fla.

title: Albert E. Kahn, a Writer Critical Of Government in McCarthy Era
description: Albert E. Kahn, a writer and publisher who was an outspoken critic of Government activities during the McCarthy era, died of a heart attack Saturday while driving near his home in Glen Ellen, Calif. He was 67 years old.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: MY WIFE and I, writes Jim McCabe, spent one recent night on the town in SoHo and Greenwich Village. About 2 A.M., we made ready to return home. At Charlton Street and Avenue of the Americas, I spotted a beardless, shoeless derelict crawling into a huge cardboard box on a park bench.

title: Rates Up as Fed Reins Tighten
description: Prices fell moderately and interest rates rose late yesterday afternoon after the Federal Reserve raised its discount rate to a record 11 percent. The action by the monetary authorities quickly dispelled the notion that the Federal Reserve had, at least temporarily, completed its effort to restrict the recent rampant growth of money and credit.

title: Episcopal Group Limits Homosexuals Ordination
description: DENVER, Sept. 18  The House of Deputies of the Episcopal Church voted overwhelmingly today to concur with the House of Bishops on a resolution holding that homosexuals should be accepted into the church but should not be ordained if they are sexually active.

title: Senate Roll Call
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)  Following is the roll call today by which the Senate recommended 5 percent real increases in military spending for fiscal 1981 and 1982 :

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown.(N) indlCates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Transit Agency to Review Decision Extending Police Aide's Pay Status
description: The New York City Transit Authority said last night that it was reviewing a decision it had made to keep Anthony Bouza, former deputy chief of the transit police, on the payroll for almost six months beyond his departure to compensate him for unused vacation and overtime days accrued during his 34 months on the lob.

title: 2 Intruders Kill a Man In Closed Tailor Shop
description: Two men, one armed with a baseball bat and one with a shotgun, barged into a tailor shop in Brooklyn last night, forced five men who had been inside to lie on the floor and then shot and killed one of them and fled without taking anything, the police said.

title: Whose Plays Roger Stevens Books Into Kennedy Center Stirs Sharp Debate
description: A once quiet argument about the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington has turned into a flourishing debate. A number of

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: IT'S all very well and, in fact, it's very nice, to be first in a movie line, first in examinations or first in a race. But first at a dinner party? The gaucheness of it all is apparently beyond words. Why this should be, or how it developed, is a mystery of life not really worth investigating. However, one theory advanced is that, with only the host and/ or hostess on hand, it is impossible to make a worthwhile entrance. Being denied an entrance is as serious to some people as being relegated to the Outer Mongolian, Siberian or ketchup sections of chic restaurants.

title: Texaco and Mobil Seek Belridge
description: A secret bidding battle among oil giants for a littleknown petroleum producer broke into the open yesterday with the disclosure that the Mobil Oil Corporation and Texaco Inc. had made a joint bid to purchase the Belridge Oil Company of California.

title: Remembrance Of the Foods Proust Loved
description: ALMOST without question, the most memorable association of food and literature is that of madeleines and Marcel Proust. The thought that intrigues, however, is that countless people who are aware of that association have never gotten past page 10 of Proust's Remembrance of Things Past. There are others, too, who, aware of the association, could not describe in precise (or even vague) detail what madeleines are.

title: Market Place
description: CAN the small investor make an intelligent investment decision on the basis of information available on file with the Securities and Exchange Commission? Homer Kripke says no. Mr. Kripke, who spent five years as counsel to the S.E.C., teaches securities law and accounting at New York University.

title: Around the Nation
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 18 (AP)  A destructive tornado roared through a heavily populated area of $100,000 homes in western Houston late this afternoon, destroying 10 homes and damaging 40 others. There were no reports of serious injury.

title: P.L.O. Official in France Reports Arafat Awaits Giscard Invitation
description: PARIS, Sept. 18 The Palestine Liberation Organization's representative in France, Ibrahim Souss, said today that Yasir Arafat, head of the guerrilla organization, was awaiting an invitation from President Valery Giscard d'Estaing to visit France.

title: Booklet on Jersey Gaming Rules
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18 (AP)  The New Jersey Casino Control Commission has published a 44page booklet outlining the rules of the casino games in this resort. The booklet costs $2 at the commission's Trenton office, 379 West State Street, or its Atlantic City office, Tennessee Avenue and the Boardwalk. The booklets can be purchased by mail for $2.50 by writing to the commission's Public Information Department, 379 West State Street, Trenton, N.J. 08625.

title: POWELL SAYS CARTER HAS MADE A DECISION TO SEEK NEV TERM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, made clear today that President Carter would definitely seek another term but had not decided when to announce his candidacy.

title: Writer of HBomb Letter Expresses Surprise at Uproar
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18  Charles R. Hansen said at a news conference today that he was astounded by the fuss caused by his letter to Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois about hydrogen bombs and Government secrecy, and somewhat surprised by the company he finds himself in.

title: Nixon Aide at Budd Unit
description: Hugh W. Sloan Jr., who had been the treasurer of the Committee for the Reelection of the President during the Nixon Administration, became president and general manager this month of Budd Canada.

title: Reserve Board, by 43, Raises Rate On Loans to Banks to Record  11%
description: In an unusual 4to3 split, the sevenmember Federal Reserve Board voted yesterday to raise the discount rate by half a percentage point to a record of 11 percent.

title: Private Lives
description: YOU see: They have gone back to school, the mother who teaches and the daughter who learns. After months of noise, there is silence. You rose at 7 in the morning to grind the beans and boil the bile for coffee. Then you roused the mother and the daughter. Summer is over. On being roused, they insisted on banging pots and eating food. The idea of food before breakfast disgusts you. You retired to the columbarium  it is not, of course, really a columbarium, but because it is your office, it does contain, in book form, the ashes of many dead thinkers  to read the box scores of last night's ball games in the newspaper of record.

title: New Hires Face a Loss In Auto Pact
description: DETROIT, Sept. 18  Newly hired workers will face lower pay standards for their 90day probation under the tentative threeyear agreement reached last week between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, new details of the oact show.

title: The Abortion Repeaters
description: ALMOST two of every five women having an abortion in New York City have had one before  or two, or four, or five, or, in one exceptional case, 14.

title: Amex Builds Ties With Survival Trip
description: The idea was simple. Since the various constituencies at securities exchanges  floor members, upstairs members, the board of governors, the listed companies and the staff  do not always work well together, why not bring them together in an informal situation, away from the business environment, where they could get to better understand each other's role?

title: Wine Talk
description: No matter how high prices go for famous wines, there are always plenty of lesser ones around that are affordable. Or so I always thought. Recently, the wine shops have been displaying an appalling amount of junk, reflecting, of course, their own problems in finding good wines to sell.

title: DeepSeated Malaise Exposed, Bolshoi Dancers Arrive Home
