description: MOSCOW, Sept. 18  A Bolshoi Ballet troupe returned today from a defectionridden American tour that has exposed a deep malaise in the company's ranks.

title: Willis Goldbeck, 80, Was Movie Producer, Director and Writer
description: Willis Gcildbeck, a motionpicture screenwriter, director and producer, died Monday in Southampton, L.I., of a heart attack. He was 80 years old and was on a visit from his home in Los Angeles.

title: Events Today
description: YANKS, directed by John Schlesinger; starring Richard Gere and Vanessa Redgrave, Cinema I.

title: Stage: Office Murders,  a Comedy at the Quaigh
description: MARTIN FOX'S The Office Murders takes place in the offices of a trade magazine. Actor Bob McDonald, as a homosexual proofreader, spends all of his time eavesdropping on telephones, listening at doorways, hiding behind desks. threatening suicide. and attempting to paw the immediate object of his attentions, editor Austin Pendleton. Mr. Pendleton spends his  time worrying about his wife and kiddies and wondering if he's the emotional slave of his boss, Joel Crothers.

title: Tumult Mars First Hearing on Ceilings for RentControlled Apartments
description: The first public hearing ever held on setting rent ceilings for 250,000 rentcontrolled apartments in New York City led to shouting matches yesterday between 200 landlords and tenants and one city official. The city official, Daniel W. Joy, deputy housing commissioner, prevailed, in a sense.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, Sept. 18, (Reuters)  The Philippines has turned down a request from the Soviet Union to allow two of its warships to enter Manila this week on a goodwill visit, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Vatican Workers Plan Union
description: ROME, Sept. 18 (UPI)  A group of Italian employees at the Vatican have written to Pope John Paul II asking for more pay and saying they are organizing a union. If successful, the move would mark the first time a union had been formed to represent Vatican workers.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: When Bonwit Teller closed and Herms found itself without a New York home for its wonderful leather things, Bergdorf's pounced and has completed a replica of the classy Hermes shops around the world on the street floor. The shop is full of those handsome handbags, silk scarves and other goodies which mean status to the cognoscenti, who are aware that status and superb workmanship don't come cheap. The newest Hermes handbag, for instance, is made of horsehair fabric (it used to cover Victorian sofas), edged with leather. A mediumsize envelope bag is tagged at $1,000.

title: Gold Price Soars At Record Pace In Wild Trading
description: LONDON, Sept. 18 A wave of speculation swept into the world bullion markets today, carrying prices for gold and silver to new peaks in heavy trading that some dealers called chaotic at times.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Heated AmericanIsraeli Dispute Erupts at Washington Dinner Party
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  Tensions between Israeli and American officials over Israel's recent bombing raids in southern Lebanon erupted into acrimonious debate between Defense Minister Ezer Weizman and the State Department's top Middle East official the other night.

title: CONFEREES RESOLVE GAS RATIONING ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Senate and House conferees broke their impasse tonight on how President Carter and Congress should share responsibility for preparing a plan to ratio gasoline in periods of shortage.

Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: TV: Pop Sociology
description: WITH a full schedule of new madefortelevision programming tonight, CBS is offering two halfhour slices of kidvid and a full twohour loaf of pop sociology. One category is as carefully undemanding as the other.

title: Personal Income Up 0.4%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  The business slowdown that began last spring cut into manufacturing payrolls last month and held down the rise in overall personal income to a scant fourtenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Philosophically Opposed, A.M.C. Asks Chrysler Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  The chairman of the American Motors Corporation said today that, while he was philosophically opposed to Federal financial assistance for the ailing Chrysler Corporation, failure to help the company would be wrong on social grounds.

title: News of the Theater Maggie Smith to Star As Virginia Woolf
description: MAGGIE SMITH is letting her versatility show. The actress, absent from the New York stage for several years, is returning in one new role this fall and has just signed to do another next season. She has a sixmonth

title: Tennessee Factory Ordered Shut In a Search for Missing Uranium
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The Federal Government today ordered shut for at least 45 days a privately owned factory that makes fuel for the Navy's nuclear submarines because the Tennessee facility could not account in a recent inventory for a significant amount of highly enriched uranium, a material that could be fashioned into an atomic bomb.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: AT times there is no accounting for the place names that are tached to various dishes. The name Argenteuil is on asparagus dishes because the town is associated with asparagus culture. For the same reason, dishes made with carrots are called Crecy. Who knows why quicklysauteed liver with onions came to be closely associated with two European cities, Lyons and Venice? And who knows which dish was created first, foie de veau lyonnaise or fegato alla veneziana. as the dishes are known respectively?

title: Chrysler Only U.S. Maker in Top 10 on Gas Rating
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)  The financially troubled Chrysler Corporation is the only American automobile maker to offer 1980 models ranking among the top 10 in fuel economy, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Express Company has named Joanne Black senior vice president of industry marketing and advertising for the conpany's card division.

title: U.S. CRITICIZES ISRAEL FOR LETTING CITIZENS BUY WEST BANK LAND
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The United States said today that Israel's decision to allow its citizens to buy land from Arabs in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan seems contrary to the spirit and the intent of the peace process.

title: Trail Blazers Get 3 Players And No. 1 Pick for Walton
description: The Portland Trail Blazers yesterday received Kermit Washington, forward; Kevin Kunnert, a journeyman center; Randy Smith, a highscoring guard, and a firstround choice in next year's college draft as compensation for the San Diego Clippers signing of Bill Walton.

title: A Hanover Trust Vice Chairman
description: Llewellyn Jenkins has been appointed a vice chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the major subsidiary of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. John F. McGillicuddy continues as chairman and president and there are two other vice chairmen: Harry Taylor and John R. Tore11 3d.

title: S.I.A. Disbands Governing Council
description: The Securities Industry Association has disbanded its 70member governing council in the first major restructuring of the trade association since it was established in 1972. The move to streamline the S.I.A. structure was made at a meeting of the board of directors in Atlanta Monday.

title: Koch Wants Board of Education To Give Up Its Chauffeured Cars
description: Mayor Koch, asserting that he believes there has been abuse of automobiles by members of the Board of Education, has called on them to give up their permanently assigned chauffeured cars and to use cars instead from a central motor pool when they have a specific need.

title: Stargell Home Run Sinks Expos, 53
description: MONTREAL, Wednesday, Sept. 19 After almost 6 hours 10 minutes, what you knew was that Willie Stargell could still hit a ball a long way when it counted. It counted in the top of the 11th inning early this morning with the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Montreal Expos tied at 33 and Mike Easier of the Pirates, who had singled, on first.

title: China Reports Oil Reserve Up
description: TOKYO, Sept. 18 (AP)  Oil reserves at Daqing, China's biggest oilfield, are 25 percent higher than previously believed, Peking's official New China News Agency reported today. The agency gave no figures to show the volume or value of the newly discovered reserves.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company Inc. reported yesterday that it had unaudited consolidated net earnings of $15.5 million, or $1.02 a share, for July and August, up from $2 million, or 13 cents a share, for the similar two months last year. Sales for the period totaled $241.2 million, compared with $161.3 million for the 1978 two months.

title: Capitolism, Or, How To Climb
description: WASHINGTON  I was 21 when I came to work in Washington, first in President Ford's executive offices and later on the staff of Congress's Joint Economic , Committee. Within two years, I saw the range of young people in political Washington and witnessed the effects that service to powerful politicians and bureaucracies had on them. Most of them came to gain influence and after prolonged exposure to the Washington scene became extremely insecure, floppyminded, and cautious secondbananas for whom it was easier to feel compassion than respect.

title: A Druggist Sedates Gunmen, Freeing 5 Hostages
Movie: 'Yanks' and British Girls
description: TOWARD the middle of "Yanks," John Schlesinger's mostly genteel romantic drama about the impact of United States servicemen on English life in World War II, there occurs a brawl between white and black American soldiers during a boozy New Year's Eve party at a Yorkshire dancehall. Though it is agonizing, the confrontation is rather clumsily set up. Long before anything happens, the camera points out the instigator, a brutish white soldier, who, furious at seeing a black soldier jitterbugging with a white English girl, moves through his crowd of friends, pouring hatred into their ears with all the subtlety of the player-uncle as he poisons Hamlet's dad.Near the end of the film we catch another brief glimpse of this same soldier shooting craps with his buddies in a field as their camp is being struck, preparatory to the journey that will lead to the beaches of Normandy. The scene is one of chaos. Trucks are coming and going. Soldiers stand around all packed but with no place to go yet. The local kids crowd around the barbed wire for the treats the departing soldiers toss them.Suddenly the bigot, who was the winner in the crap game, spots one especially appealing face, that of a solemn little boy who'd never dare ask for a second helping. The soldier goes over to the child, says brusquely, "Hold out your hands," and presents the child with his fortune in coins. For the little boy it's Christmas in May.It's a beautifully realized, contradictory moment that evokes all sorts of feelings about war and peace, about the nature of bigotry, about behavior in alien lands, about childhood  the kinds of things that "Yanks" could use a lot more of. This big, expensive, meticulously detailed production otherwise has the look of someone who's fat without being well fed. It's soft, sort of spongy and so bland that you may well remember the scenery better than anything that happens in front of it.This, I suspect, is a risk that Mr. Schlesinger and his screen writers, Colin Welland and Walter Bernstein, took quite consciously when they decided to make a war movie without a war. "Yanks" is not about battles but about the effects of war on people far from the front, making do as best they can under circumstances that are demanding in direct relation to boredom, homesickness, loneliness and inconvenience. No guns are fired. The only violence is psychological.The focus of "Yanks," which opens today at the Cinema One, is divided among three couples  an attractive, intelligent, married, high-born English woman (Vanessa Redgrave) and the American officer (William Devane) with whom she has a gentle affair; a virginal English girl (Lisa Eichhorn), daughter of the local postmaster, and the nice American mess sergeant (Richard Gere) with whom she falls in love, and a pert, funny, wise-cracking bus conductor (Wendy Morgan) and her lover, an Army cook and part-time prizefighter (Chick Vennera). They are all decent people and so relentlessly without idiosyncrasy that they hardly even quality as types.With the exception of Miss Redgrave, who can find humor and common sense in parts that virtually don't exist, the other leading actors are no more interesting than their material. Mr. Vennera and Miss Morgan are fairly lively in roles that I associate with the kind of old-fashioned musical in which the best friends of the hero and heroine have all the funny lines. Miss Eichhorn, an American actress, plays the English girl most persuasively, but she's so sweet that after a time one feels like ditching her. Mr. Gere underplays his role as if the movie were going to take up the slack and give his physical presense some sort of emotional impact. It doesn't.As is often the case with such films, the supporting actors have a better time of it, getting on and off the screen quickly with material that is more vivid for being compressed. Rachel Roberts and Tony Melody are totally honest and at ease as Miss Eichhorn's lower-middle-class parents, and Martin Smith is excellent as Miss Eichhorn's little brother, the fellow who, at the end, finds himself an apparently rich man."Yanks" isn't crass or vulgar, though at times you might wish it were. Such good taste is an invitation to snooze. In small things, though, the movie looks and sounds absolutely authentic, as in the mutual embarrassment felt by everyone when a well-meaning G.I. comes to call on an English family and overdoes the generosity with presents for everyone."Yanks" never succeeds, however, in making these three stories urgent or especially moving. The lovers and their various crises never rise above the perfunctory. As if aware of this, Mr. Schlesinger attempts to speed things up by using the soundtrack as a kind of teaser for things to come. While we're watching one scene, we hear dialogue and sound effects from the next scene, sometimes so far in advance of the cut you may think something has gone very wrong in the projection booth. It hasn't. What's wrong went wrong when the movie was being edited and, even before that, when it was written.

title: F.T.C. Both Assailed and Praised As Hearings on Its Power Begin
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)  The Federal Trade Commission was attacked by a business corporation today and praised by a lawyer for citizen groups as Congressional hearings on the agency's operations opened.

title: Film: Wambaugh's 'The Onion Field'
description: THE story told in Joseph Wambaugh's "The Onion Field" is true: that was the book's biggest asset, and it's the movie's biggest problem. The crime at the heart of the tale is the 1963 kidnapping of two Los Angeles policemen  and the murder of one of the them  by a bizarrely matched pair of hoods, whose subsequent trials and retrials made this the longest court case in California's history. Meanwhile, the events took a terrible toll on the surviving officer, whose guilt about the incident led to nightmares, impotence, weight loss, height loss (he shrank by a full inch), kleptomania and a tendency toward suicide.This is a strong, affecting story but it's also a straggly one, populated by tangential figures and parallel plotlines; the criminals' histories are every bit as convoluted and fascinating as those of the policemen they abducted. Even the courtroom drama is unusually complicated, introducing a new legal team with each new trial. In writing his book about this, Mr. Wambaugh had time and energy to explore each new twist. But the format of a movie demands something more concise.Harold Becker, who directed "The Onion Field," and Mr. Wambaugh, who wrote the script and reportedly supervised the production closely, have worked so hard to preserve the story's complexity that they've left it fragmented. The film is generally crisp and at times exciting, but it's also full of incidents that are only sketchily explained, and minus the all-important narrative thread that might have provided a clear point of view. Not even the surviving policeman, Karl Hettinger (John Savage), emerges as focus for the audience's sympathies. If anything, Hettinger is made to seem uncommonly remote.After Hettinger witnesses his partner's murder and is very nearly killed himself, he virtually disappears from the movie for a while; there's no scene that really gives him a chance to describe or illustrate how he feels. This is accurate enough, insofar as Hettinger appears to have been an unusually taciturn character, with a young wife cut from the same cloth. One of the more astonishing touches in Mr. Wambaugh's book, not used in the movie, is an account of 22-year-old Mrs. Hettinger giving birth to her first child, alone and at home, while her husband was busy testifying against his assailants.So perhaps it would have been inaccurate to show the stoical Hettinger confiding in his wife, or in anyone else. But it's a miscalculation, at least in dramatic terms, to keep him at arm's length from the audience. Mr. Savage is seen waking from bad dreams, looking upset, even holding a gun to his head in one scene. He does it all well, but he never seems to be doing enough, and the fault seems not to be his own. A crucial scene, in which Hettinger confronts his kidnapers for the first time, has the officer running out of the room before his reaction even registers. A moment that must have been important  the moment when Hettinger first gave an account of what had happened, once he was out of harm's way  is omitted altogether.The high point of "The Onion Field," which opens today at the Beekman and other theaters, is the crime itself, which is terrifyingly re-enacted midway through the movie. Before that, much of the story is given over to a long, tawdry account of how the two criminals met and how the charismatic psychopath Greg Powell (James Woods) developed his hold over the weak, gullible Jimmy Smith (Franklyn Scales), who had been out of prison only days before committing this new crime. Once again, the movie offers more information than it needs to, and the results are confusing  especially since Mr. Becker's direction is so very lurid at this stage, as if to make sure the villains don't ingratiate themselves with the audience. Mr. Woods is much too ghoulish for there to be any danger of that.But after their capture, Mr. Seales and especially Mr. Woods become less exaggerated and more frighteningly plausible. Mr. Woods has some superb exchanges with Ronny Cox, who gives a fine performance as the detective in charge of interrogating the pair. This latter part of the movie is by far the most successful, perhaps because the courtroom scenes at last require the characters to explain themselves. For all the movie's crispness and authenticity, the clarity is long overdue.

description: SIC TRANSIT The city's first subway, an Interborough Rapid Transit Company line, opened Oct. 27,

title: Careers
description: INDUSTRIAL disasters often create career opportunities. For example, the Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Corporation's chemical waste spill in the Love Canal near Niagara Falls, and the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania, illustrate how the need for chemical engineers, especially those with expertise in waste disposal and in protecting the environment, has grown.

title: Bridge:
description: Two small problems notwithstanding, the two double knockout team championships organized by the Greater New York Bridge Association are about to begin another season, with entries closing this week. Information

title: PPG in Japan Venture
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 (Reuters) PPG Industries Inc. and the Asahi Glass Company said they planned to build a multimilliondollar plant at Chiba, Japan, scheduled for completion in 1980. Under the agreement, AsahiPenn Chemical, a joint venture, will manufacture cr39 monomer, which is used in optical plastics, while PPG Industries (Japan) will market it.

title: A.T.&T. Denied Request For Higher Profit Margin
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  The Federal Communications Commission today denied a petition by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for an immediate increase in the amount of its allowable rate of return, but the commission agreed to withhold any orders for a customer refund until a study was completed.

title: Europeans Get Egypt Phone Job
description: CAIRO, Sept. 18  A European telecomunications consortium has edged out American and Japanese competitors by signing a $1.8 billion contract to rescue Egypt's faltering telephone system.

title: Deng, Welcoming Nixon, Toasts Fight Against Soviet Dominance
description: PEKING, Sept. 18 (UPI)  The senior Deputy Prime Minister, Deng Xiaoping, told former President Richard M. Nixon today that friendship between China and the United States helped the struggle against the Soviet Union.

title: New Quake Hits Indonesian Isle
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 18 (UPI)  A second powerful earthquake rocked Japen Island, 2,300 miles east of Jakarta, killing two people, reports said today. The quake registered 6.7 on the Richter scale and came a week after one measuring 7.9 caused waves that destroyed 6,000 homes and killed at least 12 people.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Sept. 18,1979

title: Jackson Trade in Winter Seen
description: As sniping between Reggie Jackson and George Steinbrenner escalates, speculation continues to grow that Jackson's tenure with the Yankees will end this winter.

title: Dizzy Spells Keep Howe From Drills With Whalers
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 18 (AP) Minor dizzy spells are keeping 51yearold Gordie Howe from beginning training for his 32d season as professional hockey player.

description: In percent

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, McGeorge Bundy, national security adviser in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, was misquoted in The Times yesterday in comments on Soviet and American nuclear weapons. The quotation should should have said: Because the deterrents on both sides are so ample, there is a large margin of safety.

title: Japan Reports Record Deficit
description: TOKYO, Sept 18 (AP)  Japan's Finance Ministry reported preliminary figures today showing a record $1.53 billion currentaccount deficit for August, topping the previous record of a $1.46 billion deficit in July.

title: Jersey Mental Unit Frees Russian And He Is Seized on Spy Charges
description: NEWARK, Sept. 18 (UPI)  Ivan Rogalsky, an alleged Soviet spy, was released from a state psychiatric hospital and immediately arrested by Federal agents on espionage charges.

title: Chess:
description: The 1979 World Junior Championship in Skien, Norway, was won by Yasser Seirawan, an 18yearold Seattle master. He led a Swiss system field of 56 contenders with a score of 103, with eight victories, one loss and four draws.

title: Caldor Splits Stock
description: Caldor Inc. said its board of directors had voted a 4for3 commonstock split to be distributed Nov. 9 to holders of record Oct. 12. Carl Bennet, chairman of the discount department store, said the stock split had been approved to provide wider distribution and improved marketability by increasing the company's stock float.

title: Space Panel Discloses Factors Causing Delay In Shuttle's Timetable
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI)  A space agency panel today blamed insufficient funds, unrealistic schedules and inadequate longrange planning for the excess costs and lagging timetables plaguing the space shuttle program.

title: State Broadens Asbestos Study; 200 to Get Tests
description: New York State physicians are planning to test about 200 workers from state power plants for lung problems they may have developed after they were exposed to asbestos, the state's Health Department announced yesterday.

title: Best Buys
description: FOOD prices were generally in a holding pattern last week. Following a slight drop for the week ending Sept. 7, the price of the 41item market basket rose 4 cents, to $89.29, according to the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Bonn Fights Industrial Spying
description: BONN, Sept. 18  In West Germany, spies are exchanging their cloaks and daggers for business suits and briefcases.

title: Economic Scene
description: IT is becoming increasingly clear that the United States has entered the recession that most economists had been forecasting since late 1978. But confusion and uncertainty about the depth and duration of the recession persist.

title: Advertising
description: THIS week has been something of a high point in Edgar T. Mertz's twoyear career at the Pillsbury Company, the home of the Doughboy. The Procter & Gamble graduate came aboard as group vice president for the Pillsbury Consumer Products from H.J. Heinz, where he was executive vice president for the domestic company.

title: Starting With Rosh haShanah, a Time of Sweet Feasts
description: May it be Thy will to renew unto us a good and sweet year.

title: 64 Victory Raises Lead to 3 Games
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 18  If the California Angels were suffering any shellshock from last night's 164 battering here, they did not show it tonight.

title: Manhattan Voters Pick Members Of AntipovertyProgram Boards
description: Voters in Manhattan elected representatives yesterday to several of the city's new area policy boards and the Citywide Community Action Board. The elections were the first in the antipoverty program since 1972.

title: Kitchen Equipment Keeping Knives Sharp
description: AT a buffet in a restaurant not long ago, I watched a poor fellow try to slice roast beef while impatient, wouldbe diners pushed around him. This young man had to suffer in public as the victim of three apparent mistakes: the roast beef was too rare to slice, the knife was serrated, thus better for bread than beef, and worst of all, the blade did not appear to be sharp. As result, the meat was torn rather than sliced.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Symphonies for Oboes, Hunting Horns and Strings, Mouret; Sonata in D, Albrechtsberger; Serenata for Clark net, Bassoon, Horn, Cello and Double Bass, Nielsen.

title: Firestone to Pare Dividend by 12####
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 18 (AP) Directors of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company cut the company's quarterly dividend today to 15 cents a share of common stock from 27 cents, payable Oct. 19 to holders of record Oct. 5.

title: U.N. Session Opens With a Call for Palestinian State
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 18 The General Assembly opened its 34th annual session today with a vigorous plea from its new president for an independent Palestinian state negotiated by the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: U.S. Said to Develop Policy Options on Issue of Soviet Force in Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  Officials said today that the United States was developing several policy options in the event of an unsatisfactory resolution of the dispute over Soviet troops in Cuba, including an increase of American naval and air force units in the area.

title: A BrokerLoan Rate Up to 13%
description: In a move viewed as a precursor to increases in the prime rate, the Bankers Trust Company raised to 13 percent yesterday the interest rate it charges securities dealers to finance their customers margin accounts.

title: 2 US. Missionaries, Caught in Crossfire, to Leave Rhodesia
description: NYADIRI, Zimbabwe Rhodesia  Like most of the victims in the sevenyearold war here, Marvin and Carolyn Piburn are innocents caught in a crossfire between guerrillas and the Government's security forces.

title: Damage to DC9 More Dangerous Than Was Believed
description: The damage caused when an Air Canada jet lost the last 20 feet of its fuselage Monday was potentially much more hazardous than originally thought, safety experts agreed yesterday.

title: About Real Estate; Tall Building (by L. Standards) Rises at Roosevelt Field Shopping Mall
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.  The late William Zeckendorf, one of the great developers of the postwar period, may have been ahead of his time with the Roosevelt Field shopping mall. It opened in 1956 with Macy's as the anchor tenant, but the leasing of the satellite stores built about the same time was painfully slow.

title: WASHINGTON In Praise Of Fishing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  The collapse of President Carter the other day during a public sixmile uphill foot race in Maryland raises some fundamental questions that are awkward but won't go away.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: I WANT to know somewhere else, Rosa Burger says. She is in her middle20's, and for a quarter of a century she has known nothing but failures, as she puts it, for she is the daughter of a famous white revolutionary leader in South Africa and failure is their daily bread, it is the accumulated heritage at resistance without which there is no revolution.

title: Tiny Iowa Church Awaiting Pope
description: CUMMING, Iowa, Sept. 18  The white church surrounded by cornfields has been without a pastor for several months, but on Oct. 4, for 20 minutes, it will have the most important Roman Catholic pastor of all.

title: Coping With Chrysler Layoffs
description: DETROIT, Sept. 15  Ronald Plumb's boss came by his office at the Chrysler Corporation the other day and told him he did not have a job any more.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Faces Attack in Own Party on Rhodesia
description: LONDON, Sept. 18  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's policy on Zimbabwe Rhodesia appears likely to come under sharp attack at the Conservative Party conference next month.

title: Cairo Condemns Israeli Decision
description: CAIRO, Sept. 18 (AP)  The Egyptian Government today condemned Israel's new policy allowing Jews to buy land in occupied Arab territories.

title: An American Citizen, Freed From Cuba Jail, Reunited With Family
description: WASHNGTON, Sept. 18  Pale and emaciated after more than 19 years in Cuban prisons, a 55yearold American rancher arrived here today for what he said was an indescribable reunion with his family.

title: Koch Lead on Pay Raise Not Followed by Council
description: New York City's elected offieials refused yesterday to join Mayor Koch and reject the raises they voted themselves this summer.

title: Wisconsin Capital Was Natural Setting for the Furor Over HBomb
description: MADISON, Wis., Sept. 18  There are not many cities where it could happen two small, financially struggling publications challenging the Federal Government on the right to publish information about the manufacture of hydrogen bombs.

title: TALKS SEEK TO KEEP CITY HOSPITAL OPEN
description: Leading state and city health officials said yesterday that they had begun talks aimed at keeping Metropolitan Hospital Center open as a major municipal hospital.

title: Prosecutor Describes Scotto as Corrupt Labor Leader at Trial on Payoffs
description: Anthony M. Scotto, a major dockunion leader charged with labor racketeering, was described by a prosecutor yesterday as a corrupt and greedy official who demanded and received $300,000 in cash in illegal payoffs despite a union salary of more than S100.000 a year.

title: State Is Reviewing GiftforInterest Plan
description: A new banking lure that offers timedeposit customers their immediate choice of gifts up to a RollsRoyce in lieu of interest has come under review by the New York State Banking Department, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: ABC Off to a Top Start
description: Running in what amounted to a onehorse race, with the rival networks still largely in the summer rerun phase, ABCTV won the first heat of the television season last week on the strength of series that were popular last season.

title: Chaim Shlome Kazdan, 96, Dies; Longtime Educator and Author
description: Chaim Shlome Kazdan, a longtime member of the Jewish Labor Bund, and a writer and educator, died Saturday at the Workmen's Circle Home for the Aged in the Bronx after a long illness. He was 96 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Creeks and Concrete in the Meadowlands
description: Today the Hackensack Meadowlands Commission will show, at least indirectly, just how serious Governor Byrne means to be about rebuilding New Jersey's cities. The commission must judge several proposals develop largescale office complexes and shopping centers. and Mr. Bvrne's nositions can still be influential. Many planners argue that the projects would undermine the future development of the state's old cities. We think they're right.

title: A Legislative Session On HomeHeating Oil Is Asked by Anderson
description: ALBANY, Sept. 18  The majority leader of the State Senate, Warren M. Anderson, today urged Governor Carey's Democratic administration and Democrats who control the Assembly to reconvene the Legislature for consideration of bills to help consumers cope with homeheating costs.

title: NewFound Vacancy Enlivens Race for Judgeships
description: The maneuvering for State Supreme Court judgeships sharpened yesterday with the discovery that there was an unexpected extra seat to be filled and a finding by a Bronx panel that 23 candidates were qualified.

title: Indians Rout Yanks, 163, With 8 Runs in 4th Inning
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 After having dealt them their first double defeat of the season in a twin bill played night earlier, the Cleveland Indians continued to pound Yankee pitching tonight with a 163 romp that included five home runs and an eightrun fourth inning.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: DUBLIN  I would shoot Jesus, said a Rhodesian guerrilla recently.

title: W.W. Kirkland, Photographer With Life, 88
description: Wallace W. Kirkland, a former photographer who had been with Life magazine from its early days until he became the first photographer to retire from the magazine, died Friday at Oak Park Convalescent Center in Oak Park, Ill. He was 88 years old and had been paralyzed by a stroke for the last 10 years.

title: Gunmen Kill 6 Teachers and Hurt 2 Others At a College in Turkey
description: ADANA, Turkey, Sept. 19 (UPI)Three masked gunmen burst into a college recreation room in the southeastern Turkish city of Adana tonight and fired at eight teachers watching television, killing six and gravely wounding two others.

title: Giant Coach Is Hopeful Despite Losses
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 18  A copy of a magazine called Emergency Medicine lay on the floor in front of Joe Pisarcik's locker today. It won't help Pisarcik, the Giant quarterback, make it to practice tomorrow. He's much too battered and bruised.

title: The City
description: Joseph L. Galiber filed 18,500 signatures with the Board of Elections seeking to get on the ballot as the New Alliance Party candidate for Borough President of the Bronx. He said he would try to fashion a black and Puerto Rican coalition to beat the incumbent, Stanley Simon.

title: Packaging Whets Appetites at Food Fair
description: COLOGNE, WEST GERMANY

title: Redeeming Argentina's Name
description: Argentina's military rulers are clearly uncomfortable about foreign criticism of their insatiable security system. In the past three years, thousands of political prisoners have vanished, as if swallowed up by the jungle darkness. In the brutal summary of a ranking Argentine general, There are the dead, the wounded, the jailed and those who are absent forever. Don't ask for explanations where there are none.

title: The Region
description: The Nassau County District Attorney, Denis E. Dillon, asked yesterday that Federal authorities work with his office to determine whether residents of Valley Stream, L.I., had formed a civic association with the intention of keeping blacks out of the area.

title: A Hospital on the Edge: Metropolitan and the Business of Survival
description: To poor residents of East Harlem, Metropolitan Hospital is the family doctor. Streaming into waiting rooms with problems that are often the consequence of their poverty, many patients develop a lovehate attitude toward the institution.

title: Northwest Airlines Pact Ratified
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 18 (UPI) Travel agents and clerks with Northwest Airlines today ratified a new contract with the company that includes a minimum salary increase of 33.3 percent over three years. The vote was 1,355 in favor of the new pact and 589 against it, said Arlo Bertsch, general chairman for the Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks.

title: Dublin Problem: Fighting Any Irish, Even Terrorists
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 15  When President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania came here the other day on a state visit, one of the first places he was taken was Dublin's Garden of Remembrance, a tranquil little park not far from the center of town, dedicated to those who gave their lives in the cause of Irish freedom.

title: Ulster Prison Aide Slain, The Second in a Week
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 19 (AP)  An assistant governor of Crumlin Road Prison in Belfast was shot to death in his car near the jail today, the police reported.

title: FRANCIS V. COGGINS
description: Francis V. Coggins, a New York lawyer, died Saturday at a nursing home in Huntington, L.I., after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Arson Up 75 Percent For City in Two Years Despite Drop in Fires
description: The number of fires in New York City has declined, but arson has increased more than 75 percent in the last two years and the number of deaths from arsoncaused fires is continuing to rise, according to a report released yesterday by the city's Arson Strike Force.

title: Exxon and Gulf Reply to Oil Plea
description: Two more oil companies responded yesterday to President Carter's request to hold prices of heating oil at current levels.

title: Q & A
description: Q.We have a persistent leak from a stall shower above me that has caused the ceiling and wall below to buckle, the paint to peel and blisters and mildew to form. We have made numerous repairs to the tile floor of that shower, including filling in the joints, but the condition continues. What can I do to remedy this situation before the ceiling is repainted and patched once more?  R.S., Brooklyn.

title: Winds and Heat Hamper Firefighters in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (AP)  Firefighters battling hot weather and erratic winds struggled today to quell at least 16 fires burning some 90,000 acres of brush and forest from one end of California to the other.

title: About Peconic Bay
description: JAMESPORT, L.I., Sept. 17  Season's blessings on Peewee Gevenski, an old man on a blue bicycle, happy as child on this special day as he pedals down to the state dock to kibitz and watch all the fishermen  nononsense oldtimers and whiskylaced amateurs  launch themselves into the new scallop season.

title: 3 Statues of Saints Stolen
description: VALHALLA, N.Y., Sept. 19 (AP) Three lifesize statues valued at $24,000 and depicting SS. Peter, Paul and John were stolen from the Kensico Cemetery here some time between Monday night and yesterday morning, the police reported.

title: Madrid Looks Abroad
description: MADRID, Sept. 19  The official visit of Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has ended, and Libya's leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, is about to arrive. The Spanish observer delegation to the recent conference of third world countries in Havana has returned home, and Prime Minister Adolfo Surez is due to set off on a visit to Nicaragua and the United States.

title: John Wins 19th for Yankees, 20
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 After having seen the Yankees crushed, 163, last night as the Indians produced 16 hits, including five home runs, Tommy John joked before the start of tonight's contest between the two teams:

title: Final Amtrak Bill Kills 5 Trains and Exempts 2
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)  A HouseSenate conference committee agreed today on the final version of an Amtrak authorization bill that would kill five longdistance trains but preserve two lightly patronized lines across West Virginia.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 (AP)  The Reliance Electric Company filed a Federal court suit today to force the Exxon Corporation to go through with its proposed $1.17 billion takeover of Reliance.

title: Angels Lead Reduced to 2 Games
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 19  Jolted earlier in the day by the loss of Willie Mays Aikens, the California Angels suffered two further setbacks tonight.

title: Gold Find Reported
description: The Gateway Sporting Goods Company said that results of the geological survey of part of its leased Zulu Mine in Gila County, Ariz., disclosed indications of substantial reserves of gold on one of the five claims on the property. The Zulu mine was worked in the 1930's and was shut down at the beginning of World War II.

title: Dow Rebounds as Oils Advance
description: The stock market recovered its equilibrium yesterday as oil issues moved ahead and the precious metals group lost ground after a rousing performance earlier this week.

title: JOHN A. FLYNN
description: John A. Flynn, proprietor of Flynn's Restaurant and Hotel in Ocean Bay Park, Fire Island, died Saturday at his home in Bay Shore, L.I. He was 89 years old.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Group Asks U.S. Judges
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)  The Southern Regional Council said today that a survey taken by the organization had found that three out of every five Federal judges in the South and probably a majority in the nation belonged to segregated, allwhite social clubs.

title: Soviet Loses U.N. Skirmish Over Cambodia's Seat
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 The Soviet Union lost a diplomatic skirmish today when the Credentials Committee voted 6 to 3 against removing Pol Pot's representative from the Cambodian seat in the General Assembly.

title: Pope Will Visit Capital Even if Mass Is Banned
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) Pope John Paul II will go ahead with his plans to visit the capital even if the Federal courts should bar him from celebrating mass on the Mall Oct. 7, church officials said today.

title: Home Improvement
description: THOSE homeowners, as we said in this space last week, who have oil or gasfired heating systems usually find it worthwhile to add such fuelsaving devices as automatic vent dampers or electronic spark ignitions to their heating units, although the payback period  the time it takes for fuel savings to equal the cost of the new equipment may vary.

title: Stage: Streamers Revived at AMDA Stage One
description: BECAUSE of his choice of setting and characters, David Rabe is commonly regarded as a playwright who writes primarily about war. However, as the revival of Streamers at AMDA Studio One reminds us, his principal subject is actually life as a battlefield  black against white, homosexual against heterosexual, son against family, the individual against authority.

title: Pop: Ruby Braff's Tribute to Crosby
description: SWINGING on a Star, Ruby Braff's tribute to Bing Crosby, alternately enlivened and hushed Michael's Pub in its debut performance on Tuesday. Mr. Braff seems to enjoy being unpredictable, and sometimes one suspects him of inserting sudden commanding blasts into his carefully plotted cornet solos simply to make sure his audience is listening. But he also likes to step away from the microphone and play so softly that the aficionados in the house shame the bon vivants into something approaching silence. The result is a show that's full of sudden shifts in dynamics, but the musicality and swing don't flag for an instant.

title: Dallas Skipper Captures U.S. Shields Class Crown
description: MARION, Mass., Sept. 19 (AP) Anthony Merit of Dallas skippered the winning boat to 14 points and the national championship in the Shields OneDesign Class races which ended here today.

title: L.I Village Trying to Forget CrossBurning
description: VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Sept. 18 has been five weeks since a cross was burned on the lawn of a black family that had moved to a white, middleclass section of this village, and neighbors say that their street has returned to normal.

title: A Family Lives Under House Arrest
description: WHEN the police moved in, with their pistols and their submachine guns, Jacobo Timerman's family was almost grateful. House arrest, they reasoned, was preferable to the imprisonment and torture already endured by the former Argentine publisher, and they were right.

title: 2 Children Murdered; Mother, 32, Is Suspect
description: A 32yearold Queens woman fatally shot her two small children early yesterday, then shot herself in the chest, according to the police.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Committee to Review United Nations Public Information Policies and Activities  10 A.M.

title: Deaths
description: FRIEDMANMax L. Mutual Benevolent Society of 1865, Inc. mourns the loss of our beloved life membei and extends its sincere condolences to the bereaved family.

title: JEANNE CORWIN
description: Jeanne Corwin, founder of the League of Women Voters chapter in Baldwin, L.I., in 1935, died Tuesday at the South Nassau Communities Hospital, Oceanside, L.I., after a brief illness. She was 78 years old and lived in Baldwin.

title: Market Place
description: THE small investor can be forgiven if he assumes that the corporate annual report, with its 10year rundown of income and its balance sheet, gives a meaningful picture of what is happening.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: VIENNA, Sept. 19 (AP)  Dmitri Sitkovetsky, a 25yearold Russianborn American, today won the International Fritz Kreisler Violin Contest.

title: Iowa Literati Narrow ChinaTaiwan Gap
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa, Sept. 17 Paul Engle was being corrected by his wife:

title: EARNINGS
description: The American Telephone and Telegrph Company reported yesterday that its profits in the third fiscal quarter ended Aug. 31 were up 5 percent while revenues rose 10.6 percent.

title: Upping the Ante in the Great Gilbert Stuart War
description: BURKE, Va.  For most of us, but particularly Bostonians, Gilbert Stuart's matched George and Martha Washington portraits  the Athenaeum portraits  are more than simply fine examples of early American art. While our $1 bill popularized the artist's paternalistic portrayal of a national hero for all to enjoy, the Bostonians, in whose city the pair have hung for over 100 years, consider them part of their historical heritaee.

title: TOP POP RECORDS
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets, singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk Indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: Design Notebook
description: HYDE PARK, N.Y.

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY,SEPTEMBER 19, 1979

title: Deaths
description: SANDSRenee Ledoux, age 71 at Cornwall on Hudson, N.Y. September 15th 1979 following a prolonged illness. She is survived by her husband, Malor General Thomas J. Sands, USA (Ref); a son, Richard J. Sands, and a granddaughter, Renee Ledoux Sands. Graveside services will be held at The United States Military Academy Cemetery, West Point, N.Y. on Thursday September 20th, 1979 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Cornwall Hospital, Cornwall, N.Y. 12518 will be appreciated.

title: HOUSE VOTES DOWN BUDGET BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  The House defeated a proposed Federal budget for the 1980 fiscal year tonight, sending the measure back to committee by a vote of 213 to 192.

title: Venezuela to Curb Oil
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 19 Venezuela, one of the most important suppliers of foreign oil to the United States East Coast, announced today that it would reduce production of crude oil next year by 6 percent and exports by 7 percent.

title: Israeli Legislator and Financier Sentenced in Absentia by France
description: PARIS, Sept. 19 (UPI)  A Paris court today sentenced an Israeli financier and member of Parliament, Samuel Flatto Sharon, in absentia to a fiveyear jail term and a fine of $7,200 for largescale tax evasion and illicit financial dealings in France.

title: Around the Nation
description: WARWICK, R.I., Sept. 19 (AP)  A sixday strike by nurses at the Rhode Island Medical Center ended tonight, hours after the union and the state reached contract agreement. The nurses began returning to their jobs before midnight, relieving the National Guardsmen who had been called up to care for 1,500 patients.

title: Arafat in Jordan to Visit King
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 19 (UPI) Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, arrived here today for talks with King Hussein, the state radio reported. Palestinians in Beirut said the visit was at the invitation of the King. It followed a tour by Mr. Arafat that began in Spain, included Tunisia, Morocco, Algeria and Libya and ended in Syria.

title: TRW and Fujitsu Study Joint Venture
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 (Reuters) TRW Inc. and Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan said today that they will study the feasibility of establishing by early 1980 a joint venture to market certain of Fujitsu's informationprocessing products in the United States.

title: Sihanouk Rules Out a Front
description: PEKING, Sept. 19 (Reuters)  Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former Cambodian leader, said today that he would not form a front as an alternative to the contending administrations in his homeland.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 19 (AP)  On a 32 vote, the Thoroughbred Board of the Maryland Racing Commission denied yesterday a request for reinstatement by four jockeys suspended for their part in the celebrated Valentine's Day fix at Bowie Race Course in 1975.

title: Bank Patron, 81, Shot in a Holdup
description: An 81yearold man was seriously wounded yesterday during a bank robbery in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, reportedly after begging one of the two robbers not to hurt anyone. The wounded man was identified as Ben Joseph of Riverdale.

title: Slain Officer Honored by 5,000 Policemen
description: On the street outside the funeral home at 1 Troy Avenue in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn where they had come to pay their respects to Police Officer Melvin E. Hopkins, 5,000 policeman stood silently in formation as the funeral procession made its way slowly past them and out to the Calverton National Cemetery on Long Island.

title: Jets Cut Unhappy Bob Martin
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 19  The Jets acted today against Bob Martin, their only player who had acknowledged being unhappy. They dropped him.

title: 3 Women to Be Picked for State Court
description: Women will get three of the four nominations in Queens for State Supreme Court justice, Democratic political leaders said yesterday.

title: Europe Cutting Oil Use
description: BRUSSELS, Sept 19 (Reuters)  The European Economic Community will achieve its goal of cutting daily oil consumption 5 percent by the end of this year, E.E.C. officials said today. But they expect crude oil consumption by the nine Common Market nations for all 1979 to be well above the target set last March.

title: Witness Asserts He Gave Scotto $25,000 a Year
description: A key witness testified yesterday that he had personally given $25,000 a year in cash payoffs to Anthony M. Scotto of the International Longshoremen's Association.

title: British Accuse Senate Aide on Rhodesia
description: LONDON, Sept. 19  Britain has complained to the United States about the activities of an aide to an American Senator, asserting that during a recent trip to London he encouraged former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia to take an unyielding line in negotiations on new Zimbabwe Rhodesian constitution.

title: Disks: Pollini at Piano, On Beethoven, Bartok
description: MAURIZIO POLLINI'S growth as one of the leadcontinues. This Italian artist's early work was often accused of cold, mechanical perfection; critics complained that he lacked the warmth and individuality of great pianists of previous generations.

title: Independence Campaign Is Confusing Quebecers
description: GATINEAU, Quebec, Sept. 13 Across the Ottawa River from Canada's capital, motorists leaving or entering this Quebec bedroom suburb receive a confusing picture of the Frenchspeaking province's political future.

title: Hong Kong Reports a 4Day Lull In Vietnamese Refugee Arrivals
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 19 (Reuters) Hong Kong officials report a fourday lull In the arrival of Vietnamese refugees, saying that no boat people had landed here since a group of 415 came Saturday.

title: New Afghan Head Called Survivor Of a Rebel Ambush Over Weekend
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 19 (Reuters)  Travelers from Afghanistan said on reaching Pakistan today that the new Afghan President, Hafizullah Amin, came to power over the weekend despite an ambush intended to kill him.

title: Notes on People
description: The name of Irvin F. Westheimer may not ring a chord with most Americans, but many have benefited from an idea he had back in 1903, when, he said yesterday, he saw a poor boy salvaging food from garbage cans in Cincinnati.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: THERE are numerous ways to keep such hardtoorganize items as cans or fruit in order in a refrigerator. Bottles can be put into a bottle sling that hooks under a shelf. These slings are wide enough to accommodate a wine bottle or a large soda bottle, and several can be mounted side by side if necessary.

title: GARDENING
description: IT'S time to think about daffodils. They have to grow roots. Many gardeners never realize how important this underground activity is, yet to daffodil bulbs, roots mean everything. They anchor the bulbs so they can support the spring flowers and foliage. They are the bulbs link to life, their means of absorbing nutrients and moisture from the soil.

title: Gene Kelly, Announcer, Was Voice ofPhillies
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP) Gene Kelly, known as the Voice of the PhiHies when he was that National League baseball club's playbyplay announcer during the 1950's, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 60 years old.

title: A Hot Line for Everyday Family Stress
description: HELP line. For most people, the words ring only one bell  trauma. Telephone help lines have been reserved for people enmeshed in personal tragedy: rape victims, drug abusers, people who are suicidal. But in Nassau County the phones of a threemonthold family help line are kept busy with ordinary people calling about ordinary problems.

title: Wien Air Files Petition With C.A.B.
description: Wien Air Alaska Inc. announced it had filed a petition with the Civil Aeronautics Board requesting the board to reconsider an Aug. 24 order that, among other things, granted Alaska Airlines authority to operate in competition with Wien along a certain route.

title: House Rejects $4,025 Pay Increase After Approving It Off the Record
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  A skittish House, after first approving a 7 percent, or $4,025, Congressional pay increase in a nonrecorded vote today, reversed itself when opponents of the raise forced it into voting on the record.

title: Beached Baby Whale Is Rescued in Oregon
description: A newborn female sperm whale was wrapped in wet cloth by volunteers in Rockaway, Ore., late Tuesday, after rescuers failed to get it to swim back into the ocean. The 800pound whale was then loaded onto a truck for an overnight ride 300 miles to the Seattle Waterfront Aquarium. Its chances for survival were called slim  no sperm whale has ever been kept in captivity  but the whale was active in its tank within hours.

title: Sotheby's To Advise Citibank
description: Sotheby Parke Bernet and Citibank have entered an agreement for the Britishbased auction house to act as a consultant to the bank on purchases of art and antiques.

title: Topics
description: It isn't always necessary to shout to get people to listen. Proof of this was Judge Charles Fahy of the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington, who died Monday at the age of 87.

title: Insider Reports for Exchanges
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: YOUNG FRENCH OFFER
description: PARIS, Sept. 19 A group of young intellectuals collectively called The New Right, held a news conference this week to explain their ideology. They denounced egalitarianism, Christian ideology and American imperialism and called for a return to the antique origins of European culture.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: Giants List Mendenhall As Doubtful for Eagles
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 19  John Mendenhall visited a chiropractor today as the Giants injury list continued to grow.

title: LessCostly Gas Forces New Exxon Sales Curb
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Sept. 19 (AP)Motorists lining up for the relatively inexpensive gas at the Exxon service stations on the Garden State Parkway have forced the company to set a $3 limit on purchases, the New Jersey Highway Authority said today.

title: HIGHINTEREST FOES FEAR DEEPER SLUMP
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  Two of the three members of the Federal Reserve Board who opposed the board's latest increase in a key interest rate said today they feared that driving interest rates above their already high levels risked making the business slump deeper and longer.

title: Pope Reported to Plan Conclave of Cardinals
description: ROME, Sept. 19 (AP)  Pope John Paul II will summon cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church to a special conclave shortly after he returns from his visit to the United States and Ireland. Vatican sources said today.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: A Span of Beauty to Some, the Edge of Desperation to Others
description: After talking a desperate man out of jumping off the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday afternoon, police officers led him to safety down the Manhattan side of the bridge. Since the bridge was opened on May 24, 1883, it has been the site of scores of jumpings; some for publicity's sake, once in 1886 by Steven Brodie, a man who reportedly jumped off on a $200 bet, but most by desperate people seeking an avenue of escape from their hardships.

title: Home Beat
description: A Touch of Nature: The Painted Pelt

title: Piano: Delaflor Fantasies
description: AQUARTET of fantasies made up the piano recital by Manuel Delaflor in Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night. This is not a new idea, but it remains an intriguing one, and it provided a fillip to this return appearance by the Mexican artist. Included in the program were Bach's Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue, the Schumann Fantasy, the Chopin Fantasy and Schubert's Wanderer Fantasy.

title: Trans World's Board Opposes Takeover Plan
description: The board of directors of the Trans World Corporation, the parent company of Trans World Airlines, joined the company's management yesterday in opposing plans by Texas International Airlines to gain control of T.W.A.

title: Bomb in Central Jerusalem Kills One and Wounds 58
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 19  One person was killed today and at least 58 injured when a bomb exploded during evening rush hour at a crowded pedestrian mall in the heart of Jerusalem.

title: News Summary
description: To monitor the Mideast peace pact,the United States, Egypt and Israel announced a tentative accord on a new formula that will require increased American ground and air surveillance of the Sinai Peninsula. Officials said that the United States Sinai field mission, which has been operating a warning system for three years, will have its mission extended and functions broadened. [Page Al, Column 3.]

title: Reds Extend Margin
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 19 (AP)  Johnny Bench belted a tworun homer to lead Cincinnati to a 32 victory over the San Diego Padres tonight and increase the Reds lead to 2 games over the Houston Astros in the National League West.

title: Bills Sign MikeMayer
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., Sept. 19 (UPI)  Nick MikeMayer was signed today by the Buffalo Bills of the National Football League, becoming the seventh placekicker to make the club's regularseason roster in the last four years. To make room him, Coach Chuck Knox released Tom Dempsey, who kicked for the Bills last season and in the first three games this year.

title: Detective Is Wounded Resisting Holdup Men
description: An offduty New York City policeman who was fishing at the end of a Brooklyn pier received superficial wounds from a shotgun blast last night when he tried to draw his revolver durine an attempted holdup.

title: Fairs and Exhibits On Furnishings
description: A Family Day celebration opens a major children's architectural exhibition Sunday at the Newark Museum with exhibits ranging from historic objects of the 18th century to imaginative concepts by present day artists. The activities take place from noon to 5 P.M

title: Smiles of an Attorney General
description: Frankly, we admire the electrifying smiles of Robert Abrams, the Attorney General of the State of New York. We admire also the energy he marshals for his busy office. But last week, having observed what struck us as one big smile too many, we began to feel that the responsibilities of an Attorney General include abstinence as well as commitment.

title: Lilco Plans Two Windmills At Montauk in Power Tests
description: The Longs Island Lighting Company yesterday proposed building two windmills that would rival in size and novelty the old Montauk lighthouse, the most prominent landmark on Eastern Long Island. The windmills would rise 350 feet and support 300foot blades that would generate electricity as they spun in nearconstant winds.

title: Europeans Rediscover Gold
description: BONN, Sept. 19  West German investor interest centers on the French, South African or Mexican gold coins on sale at branch banks. In Zurich, the focus is on bullion and gold certificates. And in the Austrian Alps, specks of gold are being sought in allbutpannedout streams.

title: S.E.C. Adds Reporting Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)  Oil and gas companies must include a separate financial summary of their oil and gasproducing activities in their annual reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission under a plan approved by the agency today. The commission originally proposed the requirement a year ago.

title: Wicker's A Time to Die Being Made Into TV Film
description: A Time to Die, Tom Wicker's book about the 1971 uprising at the Attica Correctional Facility in upstate New York, is being turned into a twohour madefortelevision movie entitled Attica. It will be broadcast on ABCTV this season on date to be announced.

title: Blacks Will Ask Vance for Increase in Aid to Africa
description: A delegation of black political and civilrights leaders are scheduled to meet Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance this morning to urge him to Seek massive increases in American aid to Africa in coming years.

title: 10 Are Seized in LoanShark Raids By ShotgunWielding Police Team
description: A special squad of 40 police officers in cars, vans, scooters and a helicopter carried out a citywide roundup yesterday of members of what law enforcement officials called a multimilliondollar loansharking operation that was attempting to take over whitecollar businesses.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  One of the reasons the price of gold has been jumping is the belief held by many wealthy Middle Easterners that a coup or a civil war will soon take place in Iran. The goldbuyers guess that whatever the result  a sovietsupportea regime or a scorchedearth guerrilla war  the amount of Iran's oil available to the West will decline, and the price of oil (usually followed by the price of gold) will rise.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Gold and silver prices, which have shown sharp gains in recent weeks, took time out for a breather yesterday in the American commodities markets as well as in Europe. Most market participants, however, were not yet ready to say that the upward spiral has run its course.

title: C.A.B. Acts On Travel Agent's Fee
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)  The Civil Aeronautics Board moved today to end a practice under which an industry group determines the rates that travel agents receive as commissions for selling airline tickets.

title: Auditors Qualify Report by Advent
description: Arthur Andersen & Company, independent auditors for the Advent Corporation, have qualified Advent's annual report for the fiscal year ended March 31,1979.

title: House Committee Backs Hospital Costs Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)  The House Commerce Committee voted today to move forward with President Carter's plan to impose standby Federal controls on hospital expenses and revenue.

title: Advertising
description: TWO former WarnerLambert Company marketing men and a professional engineer have teamed up to bring us something new in a national franchise operation: a building inspection service called HouseMaster of America. And they have retained a WarnerLambert agency, Ted Bates & Company, America's 10th largest, to supply that critical ingredient, advertising.

title: The Region
description: HACKENSACK, N.J.  Robert Reldan was called a cold, calculating, cunning murderer as his second trial opened yesterday in the slaying four years ago of two Bergen County women.

title: Alden C. Smith, Former Member Of Price Waterhouse Executive
description: Alden C. Smith, a former member of Price Waterhouse & Company's executive committee and once a Mayor of Scarsdale, died Tuesday at the age of 76 in Naples, Fla., where he had been living.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: New York Telephone Gets New Top Executive

title: Canada Cautious On Chrysler Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) The Canadian Government is not likely to help the Chrysler Corporation's Canadian subsidiary until it sees what steps the United States takes to help the ailing auto company, a highranking Canadian official said today.

title: Catching Up With Inflation
description: Leaving aside the semantics of which costs are, or are not, included in President Carter's wage guidelines, it is clear that the contract between the United Auto Workers and General Motors destroys whatever moral force the guidelines still had. Given realistic estimates of inflation, wages will rise by more than 40 percent over three years. Pension increases will average an additional $110 a month. Paid personal holidays are to go from 12 to 26 and there will be larger subsidies for buying G.M. shares and cars.

title: Miller Sees No Change In U.S. GoldSale Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Treasury Secretary G. William Miller said today that there were no plans to change the monthly auctions of 750,000 ounces of gold from the Fort Knox stocks, which have been coming under increasing criticism as doing more harm than good.

title: Dalai Lama, in Texas, Hears Debate Among Learned Men
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 19  As the Dalai Lama listened intently, a widely varied group of 13 panelists today debated the relationship between contemplation and action in the Eastern and Western worlds.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Further Copper Price Cuts
description: A number of copper companies participated in another round of price cutting yesterday. The Phelps Dodge Corporation and the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company cut their base prices for whole plate electrolytic copper cathodes by 3 cents a pound to 89 cents.

title: Fans Are True to Mets In Sickness or in Health
description: If you have seen more than 500 consecutive Met home games, should make a difference that most of the games these days are not very important? If you are 19 years old and in love with a center fielder, does really matter mat nts team is more than 30 games from first place? If you enjoy watching the Mets lose and their fans suffer, is this any time to stay away?

title: Monroe Signs With Knicks for a Year
description: The Knicks said yesterday that they had signed Earl Monroe, the 34yearold backcourt man who will be entering his 13th season in the National Basketball Asssociation, to a oneyear contract estimated to be worth $250,000.

title: U.S. Coal Still Sought By Ontario
description: BANFF, Alberta, Sept. 19  Ontario will continue to buy large volumes of coal from the United States, according to Robert Welch, the province's Energy Minister, indicating an apparent reversal of earlier policy that had envisaged rising volumes of both steam and metallurgical coal supplied from western Canadian mines.

title: Ozark Cancels More Flights
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (UPI)  Ozark Air Lines, shut down by a flight attendants strike, today canceled all regular flights through Monday. A spokesman said the airline would cancel an additional day for each day the strike continues because it will take at least four days for union members to vote when a tentative agreement is reached, and two additional days for the airline to prepare planes for flights. The attendants struck Friday.

title: Bridge:
description: A group of New York players has been mopping up titles in regional championships this month, first in Montreal and then in Puerto Rico. Kathie Wei won four events, David Berkowitz three, and Mamie Lee, Judy Tucker, Alan Sontag, Harold Lilie and Jim Becker two each.

title: Reporter's Notebook: For Ian Smith, a Strange Encounter
description: LONDON, Sept. 19  While black and white delegates to the peace conference on Zimbabwe Rhodesia here haggle over a constitution, the killing at home continues at the rate of at least one more victim shot, axed or burned to death every hour. The death toll for the seven years of war is now over 20,000, almost a third killed this year.

title: No Evidence Found That Connally Helped Friends Get Bank Charters
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19(UPI)  Senator William Proxmire said today that the staff of his Senate Banking Committee had found no evidence that John B. Connally had used improper influence in granting national bank charters when he was Treasury Secretary.

title: Hers
description: MY mother died last month. She was my closest friend. She was also my father's closest friend, and his dreamsharer, his adviser on family policy, his unwilling but able first mate when they sailed, his sense of direction when he drove, his childhood sweetheart, his muse, his best audience, much more.

title: 6 Wait in Wings as Javits Ponders Future
description: Andrew J. Stein says he has become leery about running as part of a CarterforPresident ticket.

title: Land Deals That Israel Can't Afford
description: The Israelis keep nibbling at the political status quo in the West Bank territory and then ask the world to believe that their modest maneuvers and settlements have no great bearing on the issues on which  peace there will finally depend. The United States, Egypt and others are expected to protest, but Jerusalem proceeds as if the erosion of Arab claims is costfree so long as it develops in slow motion.

title: Deaths
description: FRIEDMANMax L. A curtain of sorrow has descended upon Congregation Bnal Jeshurun where Max L. Friedman for more than a half century was among its noblest sons and preeminent leaders. His gentleness and kindness endeared him to all. His philanthropy was rooted in the enduring values of the Jewish People. We who have benefited from his graciousness have lost an unusual friend and benefactor and the Household of Israel one of Its leading lights. His leadership In our congregation as officer and member of its Board of Trustees was rooted in wisdom, love and abiding loyalty. To his unusual wife. Sadie and to the entire family we offer our deepest sympathy. May their burden be lightened by the awareness that this was a life that enriched the lives of many and left a legacy of noble and unforgettable works.

title: E.P.A. Inspector General Named
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)  President Carter announced today that he would nominate Inez Smith Reid, now a deputy general counsel in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, to be inspector general for the Environmental Protection Agency. The President also said he would nominate William G. Sykes, deputy secretary of the Maryland Department of Human Resources, to succeed Thomas Houser, who resigned as deputy director of the Peace Corps.

title: WNET Divides Prime Time
description: Early next month, well after the new television schedules of the commercial networks and stations will have gotten under way, public television station WNETTV will officially open its fall season with an innovation: the nightly division of prime time into two parts, one for news and current affairs, the other for cultural, entertainment and documentary programs.

title: CAROL DUCKMAN ROYKO
description: Carol Duckman Royko, a painter who was married to Mike Royko, a columnist for The Chicago SunTimes, died of a massive intracerebral hemorrhage yesterday at Columbus Hospital in Chicago. She was 43 years old.

title: Residents Suing to Bar Nixon Apartment Deal
description: Residents of a Fifth Avenue luxury building filed suit yesterday seeking to block former President Richard M. Nixon from buying an apartment, saying the presence of the Secret Service would disrupt their peace and quiet.

title: Pirates Split With Phils, Lead Down to One
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19(AP) The Pittsburgh Pirates rallied for five runs in the ninth inning, capped by Manny Sanguillen's gamewinning pinch triple, to beat the Phillies, 96, in the first game of a twilightnight doubleheader today, then saw Philadelphia rally for a 65 triumph in the second game.

title: Mall Developers In Meadowlands Must Trim Plan
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., Sept. 19  The development board of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission approved a slightly scaleddown plan today for a $1 billion commercial shopping center, office building and housing complex known as Berry's Creek Center.

title: MAX FRIEDMAN, 93, HEADED A. S. BECK
description: Max L. Friedman, former president of the A. S. Beck Shoe Corporation and a benefactor and charter member of the board of overseers of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old.

title: Issue and Debate Koch s Plan for City Hospital Closings
description: New York City officials no longer believe that the municipal hospital closings proposed by Mayor Koch will be carried out in the face of the intense opposition they have generated among black and Hispanic constituencies in the city.

title: Kathryn Kuhn, 84, a Dressmaker And Ziegfeld Costume Designer
description: Kathryn Kuhn, a custom dressmaker whose clients included the late Sophie Tucker, died Saturday at her home on West 55th Street. She was 84 years old.

title: Amoskeag in Candy Bid
description: The Amoskeag Company, a diversified Boston concern that owns 90 percent of the Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, said that it planned to buy the rest for $18.50 a share, in cash or Amoskeag stock. The 281,031 shares sought would thus be worth about $5.2 million.

title: Top Postwar Apartment Buildings
description: IT does not take an expert to know that the best New York apartment houses are old ones. Almost every newcomer to such buildings as the Dakota, the Beresford or 998 Fifth Avenue comes away muttering something to the effect that they don't make them like that anymore. Even the casual observer can see that smaller rooms, thinner walls, lower ceilings and surfaces devoid of detail do not make the architectural history books.

title: Shakespeare Agrees To Anthony Merger
description: Anthony Industries Inc. said that the Shakespeare Company's board had agreed to merge its company into a subsidiary of Anthony Industries after Anthony raised its bid to about $40 million from $38 million.

title: Fitting Harvest: SixFoot Weeds
description: AT this time of year, as all gardeners know, we are approaching final harvest, or at least most of us are. In my case, I am approaching weeds  sixfoottall lamb's quarters, among others  which have split my cabbage, overrun the bush beans, and caused Mr. Olson, the septuagenarian who oversees our community garden, to telephone frequently to sorrow over my tomatoes, which I keep forgetting to pick. This kind of waste befuddles Mr. Olson, who has never let a tomato or a Social Security check slip by him. But this morning, my weeds caught up with me.

title: Preston Jones, Playwright, Dead; Author of Texas Trilogy Was 43
description: Preston Jones, author of A Texas Trilogy, died yesterday in Dallas after haying undergone surgery for ulcers. He was 0 years old. Mr. Jones was an actor as well as playwright with Paul Baker's Dallas Theater Center.

title: Coast Court Inquiry Stirring Fear of Politicizing Judiciary
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19  When Rose E. Bird was named Chief Justice of California in early 1977, she recalled in an interview this week, she harbored no illusions that the job would be easy.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch by United Press International in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported plans by the Xerox Corporation for its plant in Blauvelt, N.Y. The company said that equipment refurbishing operations at Blauvelt are being transferred to other parts of the country because less refurbishing capacity is needed. It said virtually all the 210 affected employees would be offered positions at other Xerox operations.

title: Deadly Munitions Dump Stirs West German Furor
description: WEST BERLIN, Sept. 19  When an explosion in a Hamburg suburb killed a small boy and maimed two of his playmates earlier this month, it seemed like one of those tragic accidents in which World War II munitions and explosives still occasionally kill people decades after the end of the war.

title: 11 Animators Quit Disney, Form Studio
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 A severe blow was struck at Walt Disney Productions animation department last weekend when 11 members  over 15 percent of the department  resigned to form a rival company. As a result, the animated feature on which they were working, The Fox and the Hound, may be delayed nearly six months beyond its anticipated Christmas 1980 release.

title: Bill Threatening Tax Official Puts Gov. Brown on Spot
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19  Among the package of bills that the Legislature passed and sent to Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. last Friday night was at least one hot potato.

title: Hope in Midwest Grain Strike
