description: DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 19 Negotiators broke a deadlock today in a grain handlers strike that has closed the important ports of Duluth, Minn., and Superior, Wis., for 11 weeks, cost farmers and grain elevator operators hundreds of millions of dollars and reduced United States export tonnage.

title: Fundamentalist Christian Unity in Politics Sought
description: PASADENA, Calif. Sept. 18  More than 2,000 Christian ministers are scheduled to receive a letter from Pasadena soon giving the voting records of all United States senators and representatives on abortion and legislation dealing directly or indirectly with homosexuality, pornography, anticommunism and a variety of other issues.

title: Kim Stanley Returns, Directing Ensemble Troupe
description: IF Kim Stanley was not the finest young actress of the 50's, then certainly she was one of the finest, and in a remarkable variety of roles she was luminous. She was Millie, the I3yearold hoyden in Picnic; she was Cherie, the tough nightclub singer in Bus Stop. She was full of intensity, and when the curtain fell each night she would be wrung out and undone.

title: H. Thomas Cavanaugh, 77, Dies; Was Retired Investment Banker
description: H. Thomas Cavanaugh, a retired investment banker, died Tuesday at the age of 77 in Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital. He was a resident of Southport, Conn.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Details of the Pope's Visit Keep City Agencies Busy
description: When 13,000 people gather on the grass of Yankee Stadium next month to watch Pope John Paul II celebrate mass, will they ruin the playing field?

title: Pirates Split With Phils
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 96, with 5 runs in the ninth but lost the second game, 65. Page D21.

title: Deaths
description: CLARKECamilla G. on September 17, 1979 Survived by nephew, Philip E. Gaucher and his wile. Services I were held.

title: Inventories Of Fuel Oil Up Sharply
description: Hurricane Frederick knocked out 180,000 barrels of refining capacity in the Gulf Coast region last week but supplies of distillates, or homeheating oil and diesel fuel, climbed sharply despite the devastation, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

title: Sound
description: BACK in the 1920's, Alfred P. Sloan, the guiding spirit of General Motors, invented planned obsolescence as a marketing aid. And to make sure that his products became obsolete quickly enough, he also invented the annual model change. The main idea, of course, was to make the owner of last year's model feel stodgy and out of fashion so he'd rush out and buy a new automobile. But occasionally the new models were indeed better than the old, so the whole thing was proudly hailed by the name of progress.

title: Nuns Sue to Force Accountability on Coal Company
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 19  An order of Roman Catholic nuns that has ministered for more than a century to the people of the Appalachian coal fields filed suit today against the Blue Diamond Coal Company, saying it would seek to force corporate responsibility on the mine operator.

title: Seagram Lifts Net 18.1% Before British Tax Rule
description: A special tax adjustment by Britain swelled net income of the Seagram Company by $75.6 million but distorted its results for the quarter and fiscal year ended July 31, according to the report yesterday by the world's largest distiller. Edgar M. Bronfman, chairman, noted however, that earnings before special items were up 18.1 percent for the quarter and 15.4 percent for the fiscal year, setting new highs for the periods.

title: A Speech by U.S. Envoy Leads to Protest by Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 19  The United States Ambassador here has broken a taboo that had endured since the Korean war by using in public the official name of North Korea, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. The South Korean Government, unhappy with the action, protested to the American Embassy.

title: United Press International
description: LOOSE CHANGE: Interstate 80 near Reno was paved with silver after a driver fell asleep, sideswiping another vehicle and losing cargo of $800,000 in quarters being shipped from Denver Mint to San Francisco.

title: Metropolitan Opera's Pulse Quickens As Monday's Opening Night Nears
description: IT was the first dress rehearsal of Verdi's Otello, which will open the Metropolitan Opera's 93d season Monday night. The cast was on stage in costumes and makeup: Placid() Domingo as Otello in his sumptuous robes of gold and black and Gilda CruzRomo as Desdemona in a gown of pale blue satin trimmed with pearls. From back in Row M, directors and technicians shouted comments to the company, and from the aisle, television cameras monitored the progress of the work.

title: The Smoke Detector
description: HOURS after a fire killed nine people and injured 78 at a Holiday Inn in Cambridge, Ohio, fire officials were blaming the motel's quite legal lack of smoke detectors for the scale of the disaster. I'm quite sure that an earlywarning system, like smoke detectors, would have saved those people, said Donald Ryan, chief of Ohio's Fire Prevention Bureau.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DAY OF ROOTS The Yueh Lung Shadow Theater will take its version of the ancient Chinese drama form into the Stein Senior Center, at 301 East 29th Street, today at 1 P.M. Admission is free.

title: Compensation Knicks Paid for Webster Is Voided
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Larry O'Brien, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, was excessive in his compensation to the Seattle SuperSonics for the New York Knicks' signing last September of Marvin Webster, a free agent who had been with Seattle.

title: The City
description: Fourteen persons and Kinney Systerns Inc. were indicted on charges involving theft and bribery at 12 hospitals in the New York City area, Charles J. Hynes, the special state prosecutor for nursing homes, health and social services, announced yesterday.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Group Seeks to Rid Beers of CancerCausing Agent
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) Beerdrinking Americans are being exposed to significant amounts of a cancercausing agent, and the Government should order brewers to clean up their products, a public interest group said today.

title: Associated Press
description: The Federal Aviation Administration issued an emergency directive yesterday requiring a prompt visual search for rearbulkhead cracks on about 100 United Statesowned DC9 jetliners similar to the Air Canada plane that lost a rear door and tail cone over the Atlantic on Monday.

title: U.S. Agencies Split On CableTV Scope
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  Two Govenunent agencies have taken sharply different positions on the degree to which cable television systems should be permitted to pick up and retransmit television signals from other cities to their communities.

title: Soviet Quintet Will Play 14 Colleges on U.S. Tour
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 19 (AP)  The men's Olympic basketball team from the Soviet Union plans to visit the United States in November for a coasttocoast tour against 19 collegiate teams. The tour schedule, released yesterday by the Amateur Basketball Association of the United States of America. is as follows:

title: M.T.A. to Drop Garelik at Year's End
description: Sanford D. Garelik will remain as director of security for the Metropolitan I Transportation Authority only until the end of the year, John D. Simpson, the M.T.A.'s executive director, said last night. Mr. Simpson had indicated that Mr. Garelik would stay on indefinitely, after he was ousted as chief of the Transit Police last week.

title: Corporate Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: 10 Blacks From U.S. Tour South Lebanon, Meet With Guerrillas
description: BEAUFORT CASTLE, Lebanon, Sept. 19 (AP) A delegation of 10 black Americans representing the Southern Christian Leadership Conference toured wardevastated areas of southern Lebanon today, examined fragments of Israeli weapons and declared that Israel should not use United States equipment against the Palestinians.

title: Goodrich Expansion
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 (Reuters) The B.F. Goodrich Company said today that it planned to double total production of polyvinyl chloride at its Pedricktown, N.J., plants to about 350 million pounds a year as part of a previously announced sixyear expansion plan for polyvinyl chloride in North America.

title: St. Louis Symphony Cancels 6 Weeks of Concerts
description: ST. LOUIS  The next six weeks of performances of the St. Louis Symphony, including a West Coast tour and two recording sessions, have been canceled after efforts failed to resolve a twoweek strike by musicians.

title: Carter Proclaims Day of Prayer
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) President Carter today proclaimed Oct. 3 as National Day of Prayer. In a proclamation pursuant to a 1952 law, the President said, We accept our responsibilities and make our choices with all the will and determination at our command, but always in the full knowledge that we are finally in the hands of God.

title: SINAI ACCORD IS SET; MONITORING BY U.S. IS TO BE BROADENED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The United States, Egypt and Israel announced tentative agreement today on a new formula for monitoring the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty, requiring increased American ground and air surveillance of the Sinai Peninsula.

title: Sicilians Protest Over Pollution
description: AUGUSTA, Sicily, Sept. 19 (Reuters)  Hundreds of people in this port town went on a oneday strike today to protest air and sea pollution by coastal industries. The protest was aimed at a huge Esso refinery and two plants producing chemicals, blamed by city officials for pollution that killed 15 tons of fish this month.

title: Eastmet Begins Offer for U.I.P.
description: The Eastmet Corporation, a metal distributor, said that it had begun its previously proposed tender offer for one million common shares of the U.I.P. Corporation, makers of castings and plastics, in a $20 million transaction.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: IN the early 40's, while bombs were dropping on London and many thought a German invasion imminent, Robert Graves was brooding about bad prose. Convinced that English has for some time been

title: Israeli and U.S. Aides Friendly After Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) Ezer Weizman, the Israeli Defense Minister, and Assistant Secretary of State Harold H. Saunders went out of their way today to project a spirit of good fellowship after publication of reports about an argument between them at a Party last weekend.

title: Technology
description: DURING the 1950's, a fleet of buses roamed the streets of several towns in Switzerland and Belgium without an ordinarily vital bit of equipment  an engine. Instead of an internal combustion or electric motor, the buses were driven by flywheels, heavy metal disks spinning at high speeds.

title: Obituary 9 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Chemical Lifts Prime To 13%
description: The Chemical Bank raised its prime lending rate to 13 percent from 13 percent yesterday, one day after the Federal Reserve System raised its discount rate and signaled still greater monetary restraint.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Air Canada has named as chairman Pierre Taschereau, a director and former chairman of the Canadian Governmentowned airline.

title: Optimism Seen Off Among Executives
description: The Conference Board announced yesterday that its measure of business confidence, based on a survey of more than 1,600 chief executives across the nation, had dropped to its lowest level since it was created in early 1976.

title: Democrats Ask Control Of Fuel Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  House Democrats called on President Carter today to reimpose price and allocation controls on homeheating oil, but few of them thought the White House would respond.

title: Poehl Is Named Bundesbank Head
description: BONN, Sept. 19 (AP) The West German Government nominated Karl Otto Poehl today as the next president of the Bundesbank, the country's Frankfurtbased central bank.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON, Sept. 19  When the Justice Department abandoned its effort to keep The Progressive from publishing an article on the hydrogen bomb, the magazine celebrated. The editor, Erwin Knoll, said: It's a clearcut victory, not only for The Progressive but also for the American oeoole.

title: Jazz: Red Garland Group
description: RED GARLAND, the elusive pianist who has spent most of the years since his mid50's tenure with the Miles Davis Quintet quietly playing in Dallas, is at the Village Vanguard this week. He's been there twice before since he reemerged a little over a year ago with some new recordings for the Galaxy label, but this time he's brought his own auartet along from Texas.

title: Yugoslays Buy 2 727's
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 19 (Reuters)  The Boeing Company says Yugoslav Airlines has ordered two 727 jets costing a total of $32 million. The planes are to be delivered late in 1980.

title: Building Of Homes Down 0.4%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) The number of new homes built in August was fourtenths of 1 percent lower than in July, an indication that the housing industry was performing more strongly than expected in a weak economy, the Government reported today.

title: Goldin Would Include Homosexuals in Promoting City
description: New York City's Comptroller has told group of homosexual business leaders that it might make sense  dollars and cents  to include the gay community in the national promotion of New York City as a tourist attraction.

title: Wood, Field and Stream;Season for Grouse Is Extended Upstate
description: Upland bird hunters in New York State's Northern Zone will have, beginning today, 11 extra days to go after ruffed grouse this season.

title: Suit Against Ford Is Dismissed
description: ALBANY, Sept. 19 (AP)  The highest court of New York State has dismissed a $50 million lawsuit filed by Roy M. Cohn, the lawyer, against Henry Ford 2d and the Ford Motor Company.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets scored substantial gains yesterday, cutting short the downward trend in fixedincome prices that began late Tuesday after the Federal Reserve increased the discount rate.

title: United Press International
description: HAPPY AT HOME PLATE: A jubilant Bill Madlock of the Pirates signaling to teammate, Ed Ott, as Ott crossed the plate for score in ninth inning last night in game against the Phillies. Both Madlock and Ott scored on a triple by Manny Sanguillen.

title: A Listing of Courses on the Practical Arts
description: Amateur carpenters, woodworkers, interior designers, clothes makers and auto mechanics may find subjects to help them with their current projects among the cornucopia of courses offered in the metropolitan area this fall.

title: World News Briefs;Quake Strikes From Naples To Florence, Killing 2
description: ROME, Thursday, Sept. 20 (AP)  An earthquake shook central Italy from Florence in the north to Naples in the south shortly before midnight last night, killing at least two persons and sending people running into the streets. Buildings were damaged in many cities, including Rome.

title: Young, Making Stop In Uganda, Says U.S. Plans Emergency Aid
description: ENTEBBE, Uganda, Sept. 19  Andrew Young made an unscheduled stop today in Entebbe at the invitation of Uganda's President and heard his host appeal for American financial aid for the reconstruction of the wardevastated country.

title: Talking Business
description: Giorgio Mazzanti became chairman of Ente Nationale Idrocarburi, Italy's giant stateowned oil company, on Feb. 1  right in the midst of the Iranian oil shutdown. Italy was in trouble. The multinational oil companies were announcing significant supply cutbacks, and Italy's smaller, private oil companies were especially strapped.

title: Expos Double Vision
description: In the hours before the Montreal Expos doubleheader with the Mets at Shea Stadium last night, Rusty Staub yawned as he sat at his locker in the Expos clubhouse.

title: Deaths
description: ELGARTHElizabeth of Commack on September 12th, 1979. Beloved wife of Jacob J. Loving mother of Eva and George Dedicos. Dear grandmother of Bernhard. Beloved aunt of Benlamin Algart. Funeral services were held Friday, September 14th, 10 A.M. at Commack Abbey, Inc. Commack, N.Y. Interment, Colchester, Conn.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Her Rooms Belong to New York
description: BARBARA D'ARCY of Bloomingdale's never did subscribe to the hallowed maxim that less is more  and she doesn't now. Indeed, even more has often seemed barely sufficient.

title: Carter Campaign Office Spurred By Prospect of a Kennedy Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 At 19th and K Streets, a few blocks from the White House, in several floors of nondescript offices. with neither a title on the door nor a carpet on the floor, the CarterMondale Presidential Committee is plotting strategy, organizing workers and raising money to win a second term for Jimmy Carter.

title: OPEC Seeks Gas Price Pact
description: VIENNA, Sept. 19 (AP)  The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is trying to reach a uniform price for natural gas exports from member countries, an OPEC spokesman said today.

title: San Diego and Tucson Mayors Win Easily at Polls
description: The Mayor of San Diego won reelection and the Mayor of Tucson, Ariz., won renomination on Tuesday. A proposal to reduce property taxes was defeated in Dade County. Fla.

title: Nixon, on Peking Visit, Sees the Prime Minister
description: PEKING, Sept. 19 (AP)  Former President Richard M. Nixon met today with Prime Minister Hua Guofeng, who called the visitor an old friend and said he was looking better than when they first met in 1976.

title: Montreal Now Only a Game Out of First
description: Manager Joe Torre didn't seem too surprised last night when his Mets dropped a doubleheader, 31 and 41, to the Montreal Expos at cold and windy Shea Stadium. After all, the Mets have now lost nine of their last 10 games and are deep in the cellar, while the Expos are battling for the National League Eastern Division title. With the Pirates having split their doubleheader with the PhiIs, the Expos now trail Pittsburgh by only a game.

title: NONSOCIALISTS WIN SWEDISH ELECTIONS
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 19  A count of postal ballots today wiped out a lead held by the Socialist bloc in the Swedish elections and gave victory to the nonSocialist parties three days after the voting had ended.

title: More Aid to Women's Colleges Promised
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  After years of complaining that they were neglected stepchildren in the nation's educational household, women's colleges were assured this week by Federal officials that they are both wanted and needed.

title: DR. LEONARD J. THALHEIMER
description: Dr. Leonard J. Thalheimer, a pediatrician, died yesterday at ColumbiaPresbyterian Hospital after a long illness. He was 52 years old and lived in Plainfield, N.J.

title: We Wished We Had a Knife
description: It was Sunday and there was a chance of sun, so we went to Fire Island, $2.80 round trip on the train. We were glad we did. As usual, when we got there we said to ourselves, This is our place, just for us. We stayed late into the evening and, sunburned and feeling good, took the last ferry to the mainland, the last train back to New York.

title: Wide Overcharging on Gasoline Is Found in City by State Panel
description: A state legislative investigating committee reported yesterday that it had found that nearly twothirds of the gasoline stations it covered in a survey in New York City charged more than the new maximum prices allowed by Federal law.

title: Mortgage Chief Named
description: Bernard L. Charles was named chairman of the State of New York Mortgage Agency by Governor Carey yesterday. Mr. Charles, 52 years old, was appointed as a member of the agency by the Governor in June for a term ending Jan. 1, 1983. He is a program officer for the Carnegie Corporation.

title: Charles J. Donahue, 70, Is Dead; Professor Emeritus at Fordham
description: Charles J. Donahue, professor emeritus of English at Fordham University, died Tuesday at Lawrence Hospital in Brormille, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 70 years old and a resident of Eastchester. N.Y.

title: A.T.&
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  The Federal Communications Commission said today that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company must bear responsibility for improper political solititations by some of its Southern Bell executives.

title: The Region
description: The Westchester County Board of Legislators is preparing to extend its terms of office from two years to four years next month, on the eve of election for all 17 members.

title: From Ocean to Ocean on Two Wheels
description: Glenn Hayden, 21, of Absecon, N.J., back home on the Atlantic shore yesterday after a 5,000mile, 90day ride across the country from Portland, Ore., to Atlantic City. Mr. Hayden made ride to raise money for the Leukemia Fund.

title: Obituary 7  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Colts' Coach Cuts Linhart, Kicker
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 (AP) Coach Ted Marchibroda of the Baltimore Colts today cut his placekicker, Toni Linhart, despite protests from the club's owner, who had given Linhart a $10,000 raise after a poor performance last Sunday.

title: Abrams Threatens to Limit The Cases He Will Appeal>
description: New York State's Attorney General, Robert Abrams, has threatened to change the traditional policy under which the Attorney General represents state agencies in judicial and administrative proceedings even when he is doubtful about the merits of the state's case.

title: Chargers, Patriots Top Weekend Slate
description: The New EnglandSan Diego game at Foxboro, Mass., on Sunday heads the National Football League schedule. It matches two teams selected as division favorites in preseason estimates, and they are at or near the top in important statistical considerations.

title: Afghans New President Said to Oust Governors
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 20 (AP)  Afghanistan's new President has reportedly replaced four provincial governors and renewed the Government's offer of amnesty to Afghans who fled to Pakistan in connection with the Moslem rebellion.

title: Bridge:
description: A confusing area in modern bidding concerns the opening bid of two notrump, which needs to slot into the structure of bidding so that all point counts can be described effectively. For 30 years textbooks have laid down a range of 22 to 24, indoctrinating beginners with something that has never been expert practice.

title: G.M. and Soviet Hold Auto Talks
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20 (AP)  The Soviet press agency Tass reported today that a delegation of the General Motors Corporation was here for talks with Soviet authorities about questions of cooperation in auto making.

title: Events and Openings
description: SAMMY STOPS THE WORLD directed by Mel Shapiro; starring Sammy Davis Jr., at the Victoria and other theaters.

title: Art: A Surreal View From Chicago
description: THE Chicago school, with its blend of homebrewed Surrealism, comicstrip kitsch and a monster for every pot, still lives! And by way of confirmation, there is the Second Citified work of Roger Brown, a strong fantasy painter with a firm grip on his obsessions, now on view at the Phyllis Kind Gallery, 139 Spring Street (through Oct. 27).

title: Job With a View
description: Bob Melleky, a steeplejack, held onto harness yesterday as he painted flagpole on the International Building, part of Rockefeller Center, overlooking Fifth Avenue. St. Patrick's Cathedral and Manhattan skyscrapers are below.

title: DC9's Passing Tests for Faults Asked by F.A.A.
description: Most of the approximately 100 DC9 jetliners affected by Wednesday's Government order for emergency inspections had passed inspection by yesterday. Scheduled service was maintained with scattered delays but no serious disruptions.

title: Philharmonic: Britten and Schumann
description: GOING a bit afield, Rafael Kubelik conducted two rather unusual works last night before ending his New York Philharmonic program with the Schumann Second Symphony. Occuping the first part of the program were the Sinfonia da Requiem by Benjamin Britten and Dvorak 's Serenade in E (Op. 22).

title: Pan Am Supervisor Slain
description: A supply supervisor for Pan American World Airways was shot to death outside his Wantagh, L.I., home yesterday morning. Within hours, Federal agents said they were investigating a possible connection between the slaying and the recently uncovered theft of Pan Am navigational computers valued at $3 million.

title: UnfairLabor Charges Are Filed by Umpires
description: The Major League Umpires Association accused the National League yesterday of unfair labor practices involving salaries and fringe benefits.

title: Strike at Reducing Spa Pits Workers Against Union
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., Sept. 19  This week those who can afford to spend $165 a day in hopes of shedding a few pounds at the LaCosta Health Spa are having to lose weight on their own.

title: Castino's Home Run Paces 31 Victory
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 20 A onerun single and a tworun homer by John Castino, Minnesota's rookie third baseman, provided the Twins with the onetwo punch they needed today for a 31 victory over the New York Yankees that kept the Twins in the running for the American League West crown.

title: Loan Ring's Bid To Spy on Police Proved a Failure
description: At the same time that the police were penetrating a multimilliondollar loanshark operation that preyed on businessmen, members of the ring were trying to infiltrate the Bronx District Attorney's office to obtain information about the investigation.

title: East German Leader Reports a Buildup of Defenses
description: WEST BERLIN, Sept. 20 East Germany's Communist Party leader says that his country and the Soviet Union are strengthening and modernizing their military capabilities in Central Europe in a move to counter Atlantic alliance plans for emplacing new nuclear missiles in West Germany.

title: Transit Authority Rules ExAide Is Not Entitled to a $20,000 Claim
description: The Transit Authority has determined that Anthony V. Bouza  deputy chief of the transit police under Sanford D. Garelik until both were removed at the Mayor's request 10 days ago  is not entitled to the $20,000 he had sought as reimbursement for unused vacation days and overtime.

title: Union Approves Lefrak City Pact After a 4Day Strike
description: A fourday strike at Lefrak City that disrupted services and left some buildings with accumulations of trash and flooded basements was settled yesterday.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: According to His Honor's Need
description: Mayor Koch responded to a familiar political instinct when he decided not to accept the raise that he had fought so hard to win for senior elected officials. Presumably, he saw it as awkward to take a $20,000 increase as he heads toward difficult contract negotiations with the city's employees. Perhaps he also thought it would make his 1981 campaign stormier than necessary. Council President Carol Bellamy said from the beginning that she would turn down her raise. Most other officeholders are taking the increases, to which we believe them entitled, grumbling only slightly that their leader's lastminute defection leaves them unnecessarily exposed.

title: Soviet Art Show to Shut In Dispute Over Defector
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  Soviet officials have decided to close a Russian art exhibition at the Renwick Gallery seven weeks early, an apparent reaction to the gallery's scheduling of a recital by a defector from the Bolshoi Opera.

title: 1903 Cars Roll Into Subway Museum
description: Donald W. Harold, curator of the New York Public Transit Exhibit, the subway museum at Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street in downtown Brooklyn, does not exactly say that riding the city's subways is fun. But he gives the impression that it was very much so in the days when the Brooklyn Union Elevated Company's wooden cars rattled overhead.

title: Court Panel in California Indicates It Won't Reopen Inquiry to Public
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20  A special panel of the California Supreme Court left little doubt today that it would rule against resuming public hearings into whether any of the seven permanent State Supreme Court justices had improperly delayed the release of a key decision.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE Female Executive At Nevv Bell Plateau
description: Virginia A. Dwyer, an assistant treasurer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has been appointed vice president and treasurer, effective Oct. 1, becoming the first woman to reach that level at the world's largest corporate enterprise.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: ONE wants to squeeze James Baldwin 's new novel like a sponge, to wring its neck of excess adjectives, repetitions, digressions, sermonettes and selfregard. Just Above My Head is such a swollen book, so bloated with details and exhortation, that it tends to obscure its own skeleton, the cage of bone around its astonishing heart.

title: Fed Money Policy Criticized
description: The use of a restrictive monetary policy as a means of fighting inflation came under increasing fire yesterday in speeches by two Federal officials. The attacks came during an allday economic seminar in New York sponsored by the Conference Board and attended by about 600 businessmen.

title: 116 Triumph Puts Lead at 3 Games
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 20  Just when they were beginning to look like candidates for the emergency ward, the California Angels bounced back to health tonight with an 116 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, report in the Times yesterday incorrectly described the components of the United States Sinai field mission charged with monitoring the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty. No military personnel will be added to the allcivilian group.

title: Gillette Paper Pact
description: The Gillette Company said it had agreed to acquire the Liquid Paper Corporation for about $47.5 million in cash. Liquid Paper, which is privately held, earned more than $3.5 million on sales of $38 .million in its fiscal year ended April 30.

title: Doubleheader Loss Is Mets 3d Straight
description: The Montreal dressing room resounded with singing and shouting last night after the Expos had completed their second doubleheader sweep from the Mets in two days, 63 and 20. The victories enabled Montreal to move into first place in the Eastern Division of the National League, a halfgame ahead of Pittsburgh, which lost to the Philadelphia Phillies, 21.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, Sept. 20 (Reuters)  About 100 Chinese railway workers and their families scuffled with the police today as they tried to protest their treatment outside the compound housing China's leaders.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: West German General Appointed NATO Central Front Commander
description: BONN, Sept. 20 (Reuters)  Gen. Ferdinand von Senger and Etterlin of West Germany was appointed commander of NATO'S central front today, the Defense Ministry here reported. The 56yearold general will take over Sept. 30.

title: Short Interest on Big Board Off in Month
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 291,536 shares in the month ended Sept. 14 to 50.1 million shares. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 41.3 million shares.

title: Gov. Grasso May Ask State For Aid for FuelOil Dealers
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 20  Gov. Ella T. Grasso said today that she expected to call the General Assemby into a special session before the end of the year to consider legislation to help fueloil dealers survive higher interest rates coupled with tighter credit policies instituted by the major oil companies. The legislature is scheduled in convene in February.

title: President Moves On Rail Strike In the Midwest
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  President Carter moved today to restore service on the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad, which has been shut down by a strike that has halted part of the nation's grain shipments from the Middle West.

title: Pressing for Peace in Rhodesia
description: A prudent London bookmaker would set long odds for the success of Britain's latest Rhodesian peacemaking effort. One British Government after another has insisted that settlement was within reach. Each time, the angry rivals marched home to resume what has become a brutal, and widening, civil war. That is still the result that the prudent gambler would find most likely. But at least this time there are stirrings.

title: State Savings Up in August
description: The 125 savings and loan associations in New York State experienced a net inflow of $18 million in savings during August, the Savings League Association of New York reported yesterday.

title: Reporter's Notebook: New Flag and Old Wars at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20 In a ritual as old as the United Nations, the flag of the small Caribbean island of St. Lucia was hoisted to the top of a 22foot pole yesterday, in an outdoor ceremony honoring the newest member of the world organization.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: If you are a fancier of chrysanthemums, you can indulge yourself at a festival that starts today in Bristol, Conn. More than 80,000 specimens of the perennial, from delicate button pompons the size of a nickel to full chapelbells 4 inches in diameter, are growing in a field of the Bristol Nurseries, and 35,000 more are potted and may be purchased. There are singlepetal mums that look like daisies and others whose long petals open out at the tips like spoons. Some are rust, some white, red, yellow, pink or purple, and they are just starting to come into color; the high point of bloom is the last week of September and the whole month of October. In fact, in October, you'll be able to dig up what pleases you in the field and take it home, for a little more than a dollar a pot. So the opening this weekend is a kind of appetizer. The event will include boat and bicycle races tomorrow and floats and marching bands Sunday. You can drink beer both days. The festival ends Oct. 7. To reach it from New York City, take Interstate 84 to Route 69 to Bristol.

title: Episcopal Church Is Still Divided Over Women Priests
description: DENVER, Sept. 20  When the Rev. Pamela A. Mylet sought to be ordained in the Chicago diocese of the Episcopal Church in 1977, it had been a year since the church had struck down its prohibition against ordaining women into the priesthood, and her prospects looked Rood.

title: Not by Romantic Love Alone
description: Our limits today for the unfettered indulgence of emotion are more rigid than ever before because unless we take heed of those limits we risk the destruction of ourselves and our planet. So far, women have been able to lay most of the blame on men but, with our dawning freedom to participate, it is vital that we bring with us the cold clear light of reason. There is no question of our ability to do this and in doing so, counteract generations of male unreason; the only question lies in whether we see the dangers of irrationality or simply add to them in the name of the eternal feminine.

title: Scotto Jury Hears Tape Recording Of Alleged $5,000 Payoff in 1978
description: William Montella Jr., who operated a waterfront company, testified yesterday that he wore a concealed tape recorder at a 1978 meeting when he gave an envelope containing $5,000 to Anthony M. Scotto, a top leader of the International Longshoremen's Association.

title: Publishing: Maas, Dickey and Gill
description: PETER MAAS, author of The Valachi Papers and Serpico, first met Frank Costello, the socalled Prime Minister of the Underworld, in 1962 while working on a magazine piece. During the next few years, whenever he ran into Costello at such hangouts as Dinty Moore 's or P. J. Clarke 's, Mr. Maas would exchange greetings with him. The pleasantries apparantly paid off: although Costello had gone to jail rather than answer the questions of a Senate committee, Mr. Maas was able to persuade him in 1973 to be interviewed extensively for a biography.

title: The Pop Life
description: BONNIE RAITT hasn't had a new record out since 1977, and when word filtered from Los Angeles that she was working with Peter Asher, who produces Linda Ronstadt and James Taylor, some of her fans started to worry. For althouagh Miss Raitt is a child of Hollywood (her father is the musicalcomedy star John Raitt), she attracted her initial audience by singing tough country blues. Her subsequent albums drew on the work of a coterie of singersongwriters that included Jackson Browne, but she remained a gritty, harddriving singer, and her records preserved a certain raw energy that seemed at odds with the careful, pristine productions Mr. Asher is noted for.

title: Historical Society Displays Some of Its Oddities
description: To most New Yorkers, the NewYork Historical Society means American period rooms, or fine old silver, or Audubon bird prints. But hidden away in the museum's recesses are such rare treasures as Gouverneur Morris's wooden leg, a military camp cot George Washington slept in and an oil portrait of Edward Hyde, Lord Cornbury, a muchdetested Colonial Governor, masquerading as his cousin Queen Anne. And to celebrate its 175th birthday, the society has gathered up all its oddest artifacts and put them together in a small show called Knickerbocker Birthday: An Irreverent View of the NewYork Historical Society.

title: Dean Likely Starter For Battered Giants
description: Still battered and bruised from Monday night's game, Joe Pisarcik, the Giant quarterback, was unable to practice yesterday, and that made it likely that Randy Dean would start Sunday afternoon against the Philadelphia Eagles at Giants Stadium.

title: Vance Offers Ideas to Resolve Soviet Brigade Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  Administration officials said today that talks with the Soviet Union about its reported combat brigade in Cuba had taken a new turn, with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance offering ideas for the first time on how to resolve the problem, which has jeopardized Senate approval of the strategic arms treaty.

title: 500 Fare Linked to Bond Vote
description: Governor Carey believes that subway fares in New York City could go up unless the state's voters approve the transportation referendum that will be on the ballot in November, a spokesman for the Governor said last night.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP)  Joseph Hannon, the superintendent of schools, whose new desegregation plan calling for mandatory busing won school board approval, says he expects some changes may be necessary after it is reviewed by Patricia Roberts Harris, Secretary of Health Education and Welfare.

title: Kahane Begins Israeli Jail Term
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 20 (AP)  Rabbi Meir Kahane, founder of the Jewish Defense League, began a threemonth prison term today for violating an order barring him from the West Bank city of Hebron, the Israeli radio reported.

title: Screen: Sammy Davis:Film Version of Play
description: SAMMY DAVIS Jr. is not my favorite performer, and "Stop the World, I Want to Get Off" is not my favorite show, and "I Gotta Be Me" is a song that makes my skin crawl. So perhaps I am not a fair judge of "Sammy Stops the World," a filmed version of Mr. Davis's appearance in "Stop the World" at the Long Beach Terrace Theater last October, now at the Victoria and other theaters.The thing I liked best about "Sammy Stops the World" was that Mr. Davis does not sing "I Gotta Be Me," one of his trademark songs, because it isn't in the show. The big number here, only slightly less hair-raising and very much in the same vein, is "What Kind of Fool Am I?" Mr. Davis performs this with the stagey humility and mock-soul-searching manner that are also trademarks of his.This version of "Stop the World" features a gaudy set, a few uneasy references to current events, and floppy, ill-fitting costumes on everybody but Mr. Davis, who wears a silky sweater and pants but no jewelry, because he is supposed to start out poor. Marian Mercer is amiable as Mr. Davis's co-star, playing the four different women in his life. Music, mime and merriment are in abundant supply  all the ingredients of a perfectly nice evening at a Dinner Theater in a suburb somewhere. Except for the dinner, that is.

title: Restaurants
description: FORTUNE GARDEN on Third Avenue near 67th Street is a Chinese restaurant with a reputation that far exceeds its performance. For though it offers a moderately pleasant dining experience, only a few of the dishes we had there during four visits were in any way exceptional. Because it is a comfortable restaurant, with large, widely spaced tables, attractive china and a bearable noise level, and because the food is fresh and decent, it's the sort of place one might go to if in the neighborhood and in search of a satisfying meal.

title: Rosh haShanah Starts At Sunset This Evening
description: With synagogue services and private prayers, Jews will begin the observance of Rosh haShanah, the Jewish New Year of 5740, at sundown today.

title: Salisbury Aide, in London, Calls Accord Very Close
description: LONDON, Sept. 20  Agreement on a new independence constitution for Zimbabwe Rhodesia is very close, the country's Foreign Minister, David Mukome, asserted today as the Lancaster House negotiations approached the end of their second week.

title: Market Place
description: AS the Exxon Corporation temporizes in its proposed acquisition of the Reliance Electric Company, some lawyers are wondering why Exxon did not include the usual escape clause in its $72ashare cash offer for Reliance common stock.

title: An Appeal to Carter: Regain Control Over Foreign Policy
description: Effective control over the conduct of foreign affairs is slipping away from Jimmy Carter, and that is sad to see.

title: Armani, Fendi, Missoni and Versace: The Italian Designers Come to Town
description: Even a casual follower of the fashion scene could hardly help noticing that the Italians were everywhere this week, predominantly the north Italians. Recently the Milanese knitters and tailors have overshadowed the couturiers of Rome and environs in fashion circles.

title: WASHINGTON The Chaos In Foreign Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  The misconduct of foreign affairs in the United States has lately become something of an international scandal. You can seldom pick up a newspaper these days without reading about some selfappointed Secretary of State who is embarrassing the country.

title: Laboratory Orbited by U.S. to Study Cosmic Rays
description: A new orbiting astronomy observatory was launched early yesterday by the United States to scan the heavens for cosmic rays and gamma rays in a continuing effort to learn more about the past and, possible future of the universe.

title: Tenants Sue to Bar Nikons From Moving to Apartment
description: A lawsuit seeking to bar former President Richard M. Nixon from moving into a condominium apartment at Fifth Avenue and 63d Street was filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday by the building's board of managers.

title: A TransAtlantic View
description: Rolf Genssler, who was named president of the nickel division of Amax Inc. this summer, has had experience working with both American and European companies. A German, he spent eight years in management posts in the West German steel industry and four years running a central European unit for a British company before joining an Amax subsidiary in West Germany in 1966.

title: Foes of Canal Pact Still Fighting Despite Its Approval by Senate
description: The emotional debate over the Panama Canal treaties  perhaps the most controversial fight in American foreign policy since the Vietnam War  reached a crescendo with the Senate's approval of them last year, but sparring over carrying out the treaties and over what they mean has continued virtually without letup.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Bankers Trust Company announced yesterday that it had arranged for the sale of four more of its metropolitanarea branches with total deposits of about $50 million.

title: Auctions
description: NEXT week, there will be a burst of auction activity in Chinese art and antiques at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, and at PB84, Sotheby's uptown annex at 171 East 84th Street. The largest selection of Chinese paintings ever auctioned in this country will be sold at the main galleries in two sessions next Thursday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. The art works number more than 240 and date from the seventh through the 20th centuries, with presale estimates ranging from about $200 to $10,000. Among the more notable lots are a 14thcentury scroll of the Poems of the Immortals (estimated to sell for up to $10,000), a 17thcentury landscape attributed to Cao Youguang (up to $10,000) and two watercolors of garden settings by the modern artist Fu Baoshi (one may bring as much as $6,000, the other $10,000). The following day there will be a larger, twosession sale of more than 340 lots of Chinese ceramics and works of art, including jades, silk robes and textiles, lacquered panels and smaller wares, stone and wood sculpture and metal figures. Outstanding among these are a 17thcentury, Taoist silk tapestry, expected to sell for up to $15,000. Notable among the ceramics is a vase from the 1730's, enameled in vivid colors and depicting a scene of a young woman, two small boys and two lively kittens. It may sell for up to $6,000.

title: New Face: Lisa Eichhorn Why Heroine of Yanks Is as English as Apple Pie
description: IN Yanks, 27yearold Lisa Eichhorn makes her screen debut as a shy English shopgirl who falls in love with an American soldier during World War II. It is a long and demanding role for a newcomer, and she is very believable as Jean, with her soft Yorkshire accent, her misty blue eyes and her strawberriesandcream complexion framed by dark brown hair.

title: The City
description: Classes were suspended indefinitely at Long Island University's Brooklyn Center, where a strike began a week ago. A university spokesman, who preferred not to be identified, said that negotiations had broken off early yesterday morning and that no date has been set for resumption of negotiations.

title: Chemical Inquiry Widens in West
description: HELENA, Mont., Sept. 20 (AP)  Federal officials said today that they had expanded their investigation of possible contamination by the banned chemical PCB to meatpacking plants and feed lot operations in some Western and Middle Western states.

title: Screen: 'Mondo Video':Spoof's the Word
description: THE most depressing thing about "Mr. Mike's Mondo Video," yet another side venture by some of the people who have given us the National Lampoon and "Saturday Day Night Live," is that there are beginnings of funny sketches all over the place but they've been abandoned before anything was done with them. There's nothing as dead as an unrealized gag, except, perhaps, the single surviving sock of what once was a pair.The movie, which opens today at the Forum and other theaters, is apparently something that was originally put together by Michael O'Donoghue for television and then found to be too gamy for the tube. It may also be that the television people didn't find it all that hilarious. It's about 20 years too late to spoof "Mondo Cane" and its terrible spin-offs, though that's the format of this film. Among the sketches are one about a swimming school for cats in Amsterdam and one about a celebrity with webbed toes. There are some promisingly dopey man-in-the-street interviews ("Do you believe in capital punishment for elephants?") and lots of rude things such as a sequence showing the late Sid Vicious singing "My Way" and a repeated shot of groceries outside an apartment identified as Gig Young's.The best and only really funny thing in the movie is a marvelous sketch about movie-making called "Armageddon," contributed by Ernie Fosselius, who made the short but witty parody of "Star Wars" called "Hardware Wars."In addition to Mr. O'Donoghue, the director-producer as well as the star, the actors (all of whom are seen fleetingly) include Gilda Radner, Jane Curtin, Carrie Fisher, Mrs. Richard Nixon (in a newsreel clip) and other people too obscure to mention.

title: Mother of Abused Girl, 7, Is Charged With Assault
description: A 31yearold Queens woman was charged yesterday with assaulting, endangering and abandoning her 7yearold daughter, who was found last week on a Jamaica street in the middle of the night. Detectives and doctors said the girl had shown signs of severe neglect and abuse.

title: At the Movies
description: WITH. sciencefiction films enjoying what seems like an enduring vogue, the specialeffects men who create the illusion of reality, or unreality, as the case may be, on Space Ship This and Galaxy That are at long last coming into their own.

title: Some U.S. Aides Fear a Directive By Carter Will Slow Arms Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  A White House directive on how to handle future negotiations with Moscow has led Administration arms control experts to question whether the President is reducing his commitment to seek further constraints on Soviet and American military forces.

title: Nets Defeat 76ers, 10298, As Rookie Forwards Excel
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Sept. 20 (AP)  Two Nets rookies, Cliff Robinson and Calvin Natt, sparked a 35point New Jersey fourthquarter rally that overtook the Philadelphia 76ers tonight, 10298, in the first preseason National Basketball Association game for each team. Robinson scored 14 ponts and Natt added 9 in the period.

title: Iacocca Named Chrysler Chief
description: DETROIT, Sept. 20 Lee A. Iacocca and his team from Ford took charge of Chrysler today.

title: Lobby Linked to I.R.A. Asserts It's Gaining Support in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  In a narrow, whitepainted brownstone near the Capitol, a Roman Catholic priest from Northern Ireland, a Belfast housewife and a lawyer with the United States Customs Service have quietly begun an ambitious and controversial drive seeking American support for the withdrawal of British troops from Northern Ireland and the unification of Ireland.

title: Business and the Law
description: LOS ANGELES CALIFORNIA has long been the home of legal innovations. Early in the 1970's, it was the birthplace of storefront legal clinics that merchandise law on an assemblyline basis. The latest bright idea to emerge from the state is the lawyerless law office. And that development could have significant business consequences for banks and retail stores.

title: Music: Y Opens Chamber Series
description: THE present season of Chamber Music at the Y, which began Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y, is the biggest and most adventurous since the series began in 1974. The number of concerts has grown from 3 to 10. The repertory, which used to be heavily stocked with such staples as the Schubert quintets, still sticks to the mainstream 18th and 19thcentury composers, but the works themselves are considerably less familiar than in years past.

title: CoverUp Alleged in Monastic Scandal
description: PHILADELPHIA  Pope John Paul II, whose sixcity tour of the United States is less than two weeks away, and John Cardinal Krol, the Archbishop of Philadelphia, have been accused of helping to cover up a scandal involving the Pauline Fathers.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Blast on Spanish Freight Train
description: SANTURCE, Spain, Sept. 20 (UPI) The police reported today that three bombs had exploded in a stationary freight train carrying a consignment for the French automaker Renault. They said the bombs destroyed part of the load and damaged two of the train's seven carriages.

title: Flair for Marketing Cars
description: After devoting his life to the automobile business since he was 16 years old, Lido Anthony Iacocca has reached a No. 1 spot. But it is not the No. 1 he had sought. Throughout his career, Lido Iacocca,known more familiarly as Lee, has set goals and deadlines on when to achieve them. But getting the top job yesterday as chairman of the Chrysler Corporation is not the high point that the 54yearold son of an Italian immigrant had envisioned.

title: House Panel Seeks Compromise In Effort to End Budget Impasse
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  Following the defeat by the House of Representatives last night of a proposed budget for the fiscal year 1980, the House Budget Committee decided today to try again to present a new budget proposal next week.

title: Neto Aide Is Appointed New President of Angola
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 (Reuters)  Jos Eduardo dos Santos has assumed the post of President of Angola and of the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola after the death of President Agostinho Neto, the Angolan news agency reported from Luanda tonight.

title: ExPresident Svoboda Dies at 83
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 20 (UPI)  Ludvik Svoboda, a former President of Czechoslovakia, died today of a heart attack following a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Books: The Smiling Popes Story
description: THE REV. ANDREW GREELEY says he set out to do the popes as Theodore H. White has done Presidents, presenting a history in which he is himself passionately involved. The White model works pretty well, freeing the author to present an account of last year's doings in Rome, which, for all its unambiguous partisanship, tells us more about the election of two popes (and the future of the church) than less knowing reporters ever could.

title: Carter Plans SixHour Visit to New York on Tuesday
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  President Carter will travel to New York City on Tuesday to speak on energy and transportation matters and hold a town meeting in Queens.

title: For Children
description: CITICORP KIDS DAY, a special prograi, Saturday at 11 A.M., with entertainment by Bob Wolencheck who will present Woodenhead Varieties, (ventriloquism combined with folk tales), at the Market at Citicorp Center, 153 East 53d Street, between Lexington and Third Avenue. Free. Call 5591715.

title: Art: Drawings by a Disciple of Gorky
description: DESPITE the speed of modern communications and the illusion it induces that we very quickly know everything there is to know about significant artists everywhere, it is still possible for certain artistic careers to prosper outside New York and yet remain unknown, or at least littleknown, to the art public here. Take the case of Hans Burkhardt, whose show of Drawings: 19361979 has just opened at the Robert Schoelkopf Gallery, 825 Madison Avenue at 69th Street (through Oct. 6).

title: Special Effects Keep Peter Pan Flying
description: If you believe in lasers, putting your faith in a fairy will be a lot easier this year. The fairy is Tinkerbell, the smallest star of the current Broadway production of Peter Pan, at the LuntFontanne Theater. Tink is a laser beam, filtered, bent, oscillated and endowed with a certain undeniable personality by her creators, Laser Media Inc.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown.(N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Vincent Buist of Reuters
description: Vincent Buist, a correspondent for Reuters in the postWorld War II era and an authority on Communist affairs, died Wednesday in London. He was 60 years old.

title: Pittsburgh Second by a HalfGame
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 (AP)Manny Trillo's runscoring single in the seventh. inning broke a 11 tie and helped carry the Philadelphia Phillies over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight, 21.

title: Hirschfield In Talks With Fox
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20  Alan J. Hirschfield, who was dismissed as president of Columbia Pictures Industries when he opposed the rehiring of David Begelman during Mr. Begelman's embezzlement scandal, has been negotiating to become president of all the leisuretime divisions of Twentieth CenturyFox, movie industry sources confirmed today.

title: Croquet Elite Politely Fight It Out in the Park
description: At midday Wednesday the wind in Central Park was creating dust swirls on the Sheep Meadow, and the walking paths were ajive with the usual sounds of portable taped disco music. But up on the croquet green, a swath of lush emerald lawn trimmed with red begonias and blue ageratum, there was little that disturbed the sharp, resonant click of mallet against ball.

title: House Rejects a Raise Of 7% in Second Vote But Plans New Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  After suffering two decisive knockouts, backers of a Congressional pay increase will climb back into the House ring again, possibly tomorrow, this time asking for a smaller salary increase.

title: Hot Hitter Prevails In Little Brown Jug
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 20 (AP) Hot Hitter, the overwhelming favorite, won the $226,455 Little Brown Jug in straight heats today at the Delaware County Fairgrounds halfmile track.

title: ISRAELIS AVOID TALKS WITH JESSE JACKSON
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 20  The Israeli Government's decision not to receive the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson at high levels during the black leader's visit to Israel next week was formulated by Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan, a source in the Prime Minister's office said today.

title: TV Weekend A Tough Detective Weighs In on NBC
description: A NEW series with the improbable title of Eischied (pronounced Eyeshyed) offers tall, heavyset Joe Don Baker as Earl Eischied, Chief of Detectives in New York City. If Kojack had his lollypops, Eischied puffs on big cigars and fondles a pet cat. He is the former street cop surrounded by guys with degrees. His main adversary is the department's press secretary.

title: Court to Study Use of Constables in Nassau
description: WOODSBURGH, L.I., Sept. 20  Angered by vandalism, burglaries and rowdiness by gangs of teenagers that had disturbed the tranquillity of this small South Shore village on Brosewere Bay, residents took action by hiring two armed constables. But the village ran into objections from the Nassau County Police Department, which contends that the supplemental force is illegal.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Lack of Oil Angers Brazilians
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 20  Why wouldn't God have conceded this present to us, complained Juracy Magalhaes, the first president of Brazil's National Petroleum Company, when confronted with studies suggesting that the fifthlargest country in the world may not have significant oil deposits beneath its vastness.

title: COMMODITIES Closing Selloff Trims Silver and Gold Futures
description: By The Associated Press

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television  Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio  WMCA, 8 P.M.)

title: Reds Get 5 in 8th to Win
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 20 (AP)  Dan Driessen of Cincinnati keyed a fiverun rally tonight in the eighth inning with a twoout double as the Reds defeated the San Dieno Padres. 85.

title: Coin Sale Stopped
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)  The United States Mint has discontinued the sale of uncirculated Bicentennial coin sets because the price has fallen below the market value of the silver they contain, the Treasury Department announced today.

title: Notes on People
description: With his scary running experience of last weekend only a few days behind him, President Carter has resumed jogging. On Tuesday night, he told some White House visitors, My wife and I went out and ran a couple of miles.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: RICHARD A. EISING

title: Old Missiles Called Health Peril
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)  Senator Bob Dole said today that 54 obsolete Titan missiles in Kansas, Arkansas and Arizona were a safety hazard and should be removed. The Kansas Republican said at a news conference that leaks of missile propellant from at least six of the 18 missiles based in Kansas were a serious hazard to public health. The Titans were deployed in 1963.

title: WHITE HOUSE ORDERS THE SECRET SERVICE TO PROTECT KENNEDY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  President Carter ordered Secret Service protection for Senator Edward M. Kennedy today, shortly before the Massachusetts Democrat disclosed plans to form, in early November, an exploratory committee for a Presidential campaign.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bond Prices Move Up After an Early Decline
description: The credit markets, after declining for a time yesterday, recovered and closed higher in price for the second day in a row. It was a day full of price shifts and conflicting market influences.

title: HOUSE VOTE DEFEATS A BILL TO CARRY OUT PANAMA CANAL PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  In a surprise action, the House defeated by 11 votes today a bill that would carry out the terms of the Panama Canal Treaty.

title: Water Bill Approved by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI)  The Senate approved legislation today to authorize $33.7 million for Federal water resources programs in the fiscal year 1980.

title: The Return Of the Blues
description: THE blues  the plain old unadorned blues has suddenly returned to New York with vengeance. During the last few years, only the music's biggest names regularly visited the city, and blues fans had to content themselves with more or less annual appearances by B. B. King, Albert King, Muddy Waters, John Lee Hooker and few other groups. There were occasional college concerts and other special events but for the most part, younger blues musicians and old masters who lacked record company support simply couldn't find paying jobs in New York and they stayed away.

title: Freed American Talks Calmly of Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  He was at last in the country he had longed for, where the listeners were sympathetic and knew his language. But he spoke slowly, trying to translate past into present and apologizing when the words would fail.

title: PUBLISHER'S RELEASE URGED IN ARGENTINA
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 20  For the second time in little more than a year, the Argentine Supreme Court has ruled that Jacobo Timerman, the former newspaper publisher who has been detained without charges since April 1977, should be set free.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1979

title: Foreigners Farm Holdings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) Foreign investors own an interest in about four million acres of United States agricultural land, less than fivetenths of 1 percent of the 1.05 billion acres owned by farmers and other private citizens, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Less Peril in GeneSplicing
description: Federal restrictions are about to be eased again on those oncefeared recombinant DNA experiments, in which genes from different organisms are spliced together. The director of the National Institutes of Health will almost certainly concur with the recommendation of an advisory committee to free from restrictions more than 80 percent of all current genesplicing experiments  namely, those using a standard laboratory bacterium.

title: Bokassa Is Reported Overthrown In Coup in Central African Empire
description: Emperor Bokassa I of the Central African Empire, who had ruled that country autocratically since 1965, was overthrown in a bloodless coup last night, Agence FrancePresse reported from Bangui, the capital, citing French Embassy sources.

title: Obituary 9  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Dines Injunction Lifted
description: A judge in New York dismissed an injunction yesterday against James Dines, the Californiabased publisher of a newsletter that advocates investment in gold and other metals. The decision in Manhattan Supreme Court automatically vacated a temporary injunction obtained by the state Attorney General barring Mr. Dines from doing business in New York on the ground that he had failed to disclose required financial information.

title: Unconventional Tenor Bows in Rossini's Count Ory Attracted Attention
description: The kind of elegant, ethereal singing that tenors are called upon to perform in Don Giovanni, The Barber of Seville and Don Pasquale is often assumed to be a product of rarified, hothouse bEickground and training that one would find only in sophisticated urban centers, and as likely as not, European centers at that. The career of Rockwell Blake, the 28yearold tenor who is to make his New York City Opera debut on Sunday evening in the title role of the company's new production of Rossini's The Count Ory proves how wrong that common assumption can be.

title: World Gold
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1979

title: Chairman of J.P. Stevens Will Step Down Jan. 1
description: James D. Finley, who has been at the helm of J.P. Stevens & Company throughout much of its 16year battle against textile workers seeking to organize the company's plants, will step down from his post, the company said yesterday.

title: Paul Maze, a Painter for 70 Years
description: Paul Maze, a Frenchborn artist who had been a painting companion of the late Sir Winston Churchill, died Monday at his home near Midhurst, Sussex, England. He was 92 years old.

title: Texaco Won't Bar Oil Rise Next Year
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) Officials of Texaco Inc. said today that despite some unsolicited praise from President Carter, they could not promise to freeze heatingoil prices for the entire winter.

title: F.C.C. Says Small A.T. &
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  The Federal Communications Commission charged today that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has been selling privateline telephone services to highvolume users at unjust, unreasonable and unlawful rates that are subsidized by ordinary telephone users.

title: A Guide to the Great Mansions of the Hudson Valley
description: The Mills family, descendants of wealthy financiers and philanthropists, owned five palatial homes  in France, California, Rhode Island, New York City and in Hyde Park, two hours north of the city, overlooking the Hudson River. They always occupied their Hyde Park home for six weeks, mainly to see the fall colors.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Loan Demand Still High
description: The Federal Reserve reported yesterday a continued surge in corporate loan demand, while major banks responded to stong credit demand and tighter monetary policy by joining a move initiated Wednesday by the Chemical Bank to raise the prime rate to 13 percent from 13 percent.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Drops Sharply
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP)  Lack of confidence in United States economic policies sent the dollar plummeting on world money markets today, with analysts predicting that more losses might be on the way. Gold prices hit record levels in Europe but slipped in New York after an early surge.

title: Nicklaus Agrees on Deal To Redo Hastings Club
description: HASTINGSONHUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 20 Directors of the St. Andrew's Golf Club, the oldest in the country, have negotiated an agreement with Jack Nicklaus under which the champion golfer would redesign the course to attract major tournaments and build condominiums on the club property.

title: Turnout of 200 Greets Mondale At Coast Event
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20  To the dismay of some supporters here, Vice President Mondale attracted only 200 northern Californians to a $200aplate luncheon for the CarterMondale Reelection Committee today. The total included holders of 50 tickets that were sold last night for $10 or were given away.

title: Pop Music: Antinuclear Marathon at Garden
description: THE last words spoken from the stage of Madison Square Garden Wednesday night, at the first of five benefit concerts for the antinuclear movement sponsored by Musicians United for Safe Energy, were Graham Nash's: We can do it.

title: Piano Recital: Andrzej Wasowski
description: ANDRZEJ WASOWSKI, a Polish pianist who made a considerable splash in Europe right after World War II and has demonstrated a distinctive style in his few appearances here, gave an absorbing recital in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night. He is not an immaculate technician when the going is fast, but he can always command attention with the high quality of his ideas.

title: Publications Head Quits at McGraw
description: Gordon L. Jones, for three years the president of the McGrawHill Publications Company, submitted his resignation yesterday in order to become an executive of the Hearst Corporation. Just what kind of an executive Hearst was not ready to say yesterday.

title: IN THE NATION Birds Of A Feather
description: Now that the real Ian Smith has stood up in London, the sight may be educational to some Americans (not Jesse Helms) who have favored recognition of the pseudoGovernment to which Mr. Smith gave pseudopower in the pseudoZimbabwe he calls Zimbabwe Rhodesia.

title: Gas Parley In Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 20  Senior United States and Mexican officials held talks today aimed at reaching agreement on Mexican sales of natural gas to the United States before President Jose Lopez Portillo pays an official visit to Washington next week.

title: Lay Vatican Workers Seeking Pay Rise Send Pope a Bitter Letter
description: ROME, Sept. 20  Ten days before his departure for Ireland and the United States, Pope John Paul II is facing labor problems at home.

title: N.B.A. Appeals Ruling in Webster Case
description: The National Basketball Association yesterday filed an appeal of a Federal judge's ruling that voids the compensation that the New York Knicks were required to pay to the Seattle SuperSonics last year for the signing of Marvin Webster.

title: Advertising
description: THE Eagle has landed . . . on all fours.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER, 21, 1979

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Nurses End SevenDay Walkout At Rhode Island Mental Hospital
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 20 (UPI) Striking nurses have ended their sevendayold walkout at the state medical center in Cranston. The decision came only hours after a judge threatened stiff fines if the strike did not end by today.

title: Interco Revises Ethan Allen Pact
description: Interco Inc., a shoe manufacturer, said it had signed a amended agreement to acquire Ethan Allen Inc., a furniture maker, in exchange for a new series of cumulative convertible preferred stock paying an annual dividend of $7.75 apiece.

title: Obituary 8  No Title
description: TREITLERAnna, beloved mother of Marilyn Evans and Sandra Mutchnick, loving sister of Samuel and Harry Fertman, dear grandmother of Evan, Eve, Ilene and Patrice. Services today, 12 noon, Parkside Memorial Chapels, 9860 Queens Blvd, corner 66 Ave, Forest Hills.

title: San Francisco Schools Reopen Though Teacher Strike Goes On
description: San Francisco's 72 elementary schools reopened yesterday with picket lines out front and classrooms halfempty as about 32,000 teachers remained off the job in 11 states.

title: Broadway
description: DICK VAN DYKE will star in The Music Man, and Michael Kidd will be its director and choreographer. The revival of the Meredith Willson musical will open in Las Vegas next month, play other places in the months after that and arrive on Broadway sometime in the spring. This is a season for revivals, and while you may say that Broadway is turning into a living museum, you may also say that great musicals are national treasures and should be preserved. Either way, Mr. Van Dyke is coming into The Music Man with a nice fresh eye: he did not see Robert Preston as Prof. Harold Hill in The Music Man when it opened in 1957; he has even declined to listen to the cast album. The problem is that everyone tries to do an imitation of Robert Preston, he says. Mr. Van Dyke wants to do it his way.

title: Free Dance on Pier 84
description: A free, outdoor performance will be given by the Big Apple Dance Theater tomorrow at 1 P.M. on Pier 84, on the Hudson River, at the foot of 44th Street.

title: Powell Says That Jordan Won't Resign His Post
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI)Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, will not resign or take a leave of absence if a special prosecutor is appointed to investigate allegations that he inhaled cocaine at a Hollywood party, President Carter's chief spokesman said today.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE soaring of the gold price to $375 an ounce its closing price yesterday in New York  has stirred up lust on the part of buyers out to make a killing and anxiety on the part of monetary officials concerned that the flight from currencies, feeding on fears of .world inflation, will generate even more intense inflationary expectations.

title: Storer Broadcasting Loan
description: MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 20 (Reuters)  The Storer Broadcasting Company said it had obtained $120 million in longterm financing to be used primarily for expansion of its cable television division. It said half of that amount was provided by the Prudential Insurance Company and the Teachers Insurance Annuity Association of America.

title: Energy Bill Advances In Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  President Carter's energy legislation showed signs of movement in Congress today, as the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee completed work on a bill creating a mobilization board to speed construction of experimental projects.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK; MANHATTAN 43d60th Streets; Upper East Side Upper West Side Specials BRONX BRONX (Cont'd) BROOKLYN STATEN ISLAND QUEENS LONG ISLAND Suffolk LONG ISLAND (Cont'd) ROCKLAND WESTCHESTER FAIRFIELD
description: Below 42d Street

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1979

title: Regents May Remove Schools' Accreditation IF Over 15% Fail Test
description: ALBANY, Sept. 20 (AP)  In a 12to3 vote, the New York State Board of Regents set new standards for high schools today that would allow the board to withdraw the accreditation of any school in which less than 85 percent of the members of the senior class passed the state's competency tests in reading, writing and mathematics.

title: Brazil's Arid Northeast Skeptical As Help Is Promised Once Again
description: TERESINA, Brazil, Sept. 18  The Brazilian Government has just launched its most ambitious effort to aid the semiarid impoverished Brazilian northeast, but residents here are reacting to it the way New Yorkers greet perennial proposals to clean up Times Square.

title: Balalaikas and Domras to Strum at Tully Hall
description: Most Americans associate balalaika playing with the hurdy gurdy background music they hear in nightclubs, said Walter Kasura, conductor, director, and principal arranger of the Balalaika and Domra Society. Our goal is to bring the balalaika out of the cabaret and into the concert halls to show what the balalaika can really do.

title: Macy Earnings At Peak Level
description: R.H. Macy & Company sales and earnings rose to records in the fourth quarter and fiscal year ended July 28, reflecting strong performance across the board, the company reported yesterday. Profits jumped 80.4 percent for the quarter and 23.8 percent for the year.

title: Help for VISTA's War on Poverty
description: In Sumter County, Alabama, small farmers earn more than they used to. One reason is that VISTA workers from the Federation of Southern Cooperatives are organizing the growers into coops that buy supplies and sell produce. In New York City, also with the help of VISTA, tenants are renovating tenements under an AdoptaBuilding program. These projects exemplify the work of the 4,200 members of the Volunteers Service to America, a Federal program that has helped millions of poor and handicapped Americans.

title: McDonnell Debentures
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept, 20 (Reuters)  The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it intended to purchase its 4 percent subordinated convertible debentures, due 1991, in the open market and in block transactions. It has $61.8 million principal amount of the issue outstanding.

title: About Real Estate
description: Part and parcel of the realestate business is dealmaking, but apartment renters rarely get involved in it. Unless, of course, somebody is trying to convert their building to a cooperative.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Carter Losing Some of Labor's Support to Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  Organized labor's political support of President Carter, always tentative and lukewarm at best, is beginning to wane with the emergence of Senator Edward M. Kennedy as a potential candidate in 1980.

title: Alabamians Urged by Governor To Aid HurricaneStricken Areas
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 20 (AP) Gov. Fob James went on statewide television tonight to urge Alabamians to contribute nonperishable food to areas of south Alabama that were devastated last week by Hurricane Frederic.

title: U.S. Trade In Deficit For Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)  The United States posted a $965 million deficit in the balance of payments for international goods and services for the second quarter, the Commerce Department reoerted today.

title: Dow Scores 17.24Point Advance
description: Stock prices soared yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average scored its biggest advance since last November. A boom in oil issues set the tone for the boisterous market.

title: Off Broadway Is Making A Vigorous Comeback
description: SHERIDAN SQUARE, the corner of Greenwich Village that gave its name to the original Circle in the Square, was for almost two decades the heartbeat of Off Broadway. Geraldine Page, Jason Robards, Robert Duvall, Jon Voight and many others writers and directors as well as actors  first made their reputations on the stages crowding the area. Then, in the early 1970's, as Off Broadway was caught in an economic squeeze, Sheridan Square became only intermittently a home for the performing arts. However, led by the Circle Repertory Company, this section of lower Seventh Avenue is once again a busy crossroads of theater.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, Sept. 20, 1979

title: Radio
