description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Suite from Iphigenie en Aulide, Gluck; Sonata in D (Op. 50) for Flute and Piano, Hummel ; Four Dances from Saudades Do Brasil, Milhaud.

title: Spain's Freemasons, Legalized, Fight Among Themselves
description: MADRID, Sept. 18 Long after a score of leftwing political parties were allowed to function legally, the Spanish authorities this summer gritted their teeth and legalized not one, but two, Masonic factions.

title: President's Wife Says He Has Chosen Date for 80 Bid
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 20  Rosalyn Carter said today that her husband had selected a specific date later in the fall to announce his candidacy for a second term and insisted that his plans would not be affected in any way by a challenge from Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: School Lunch Week Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) President Carter today signed a proclamation designating the week of Oct. 14 as National School Lunch Week in tribute to all those who determine whether the food served is actually eaten.

title: A Noisy Spat in the Baseball Sandbox
description: Baseball has always been a game little boys could play, and that is one of its charms. It has the beautiful purity of childhood, the simplicity and freshness. Trouble is, sometimes little boys of 33 do play it, sometimes little boys of 51 manage teams and sometimes a little boy of 49 becomes owner of a club.

title: KEY SCOTTO WITNESS ADMITS OWN CRIMES
description: William Montella Jr., a key witness for the prosecution in the trial of Anthony M. Scotto, acknowledged under crossexamination yesterday that for years he himself had lied, stolen and made payoffs.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Bridge:
description: Bridge experts, like some mile runners, begin relatively slowly and finish at top speed. Lesser performers tend to start the play of a hand at a great pace and then slow down, winding up as losers.

title: StrikeSupport Tradition Shaken in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21  For almost 40 years the tradition around here has been that the public will support organized labor when it strikes to force a recalcitrant employer to terms. It is a tradition that has its roots in the tur- moil that surrounded Harry Bridges's efforts to organize the waterfront here in 193334.

title: Voice of Dissent in China, Still Small, Is Growing Louder
description: PEKING, Sept. 21  After a few glasses of wine at a dinner party in a foreigner's apartment, a factory worker began to complain about his boss, the factory manager.

title: N.Y. Stock Exchange Bond Trading
description: WORLD BANK

title: Texan Sees Inflation and Bureaucracy, Not Malaise, as Major Problems of U.S.
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 20  Step past the pine and mimosa, past the sycamore and magnolia and live oak, into the living room of Gerald and Carolyn Fuhrman, and you are visiting by proxy hundreds of thousands of third and fourthgeneration Texans raised on the buoyant frontier values of adventurous optimism and fierce independence.

title: Books of The Times
description: Henrietta Szold's history is inseparable from the history of Israel. Some of the parallels are ironical. Because she was so dark and her mother so fair,

title: Washington Aids Royals' 134 Victory
description: GAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 21 (AP)U.L. Washington drove in six runs with his first two major league homers, two threerun shots, to lead the Kansas City Royals to a 139 rout of the Oakland A's tonight.

title: Pirates Fall, Trail by Game
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP)  Scot Thompson drove in two runs with a fifthinning single, and Lynn McGlothen held Pittsburgh to four hits as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Pirates, 20, today.

title: P.L.O. Says Israel Raids Lebanon But Tel Aviv Denies Any Action
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 21 (Reuters)  The Palestine Liberation Organization said that Israeli forces made an armored thrust toward a key bridge in southern Lebanon tonight and were beaten back.

title: Koch, Disputing Carey's View, Denies The 50Cent Fare Is Tied to Bond Issue
description: Mayor Koch yesterday opposed Governor Carey's effort to tie preservation of the 50cent transit fare in New York City to approval of the state's transportation bond issue.

title: Gracing the Skyline Not Disgracing It
description: At a recent meeting of Community Board 5, during a discussion of the impact of continued highrisebuilding development on density factors in midtown, New York City was chided when a comparison with the open, lowrise cityscape of Paris was made. It is clear that New York is not Paris, and shouldn't want to be.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Daredevil's Great Leap Delayed Anew
description: WADDINGTON, N.Y., Sept. 21 First the ramp was too low. Then the money ran out, and next the engine blew up. On Labor Day the parachutes hadn't arrived. And now Ken Carter says someone has stolen the yellow. orange and red, rocketpowered flying car that was to have taken him across the St. Lawrence River and into the stuntman's hall of fame.

title: Central African Republic
description: The Central African Republic is set on a plateau In the heart of Africa, bordered by Zaire, the Sudan, Chad, Cameroon and Congo. It covers 240,471 square miles, of which 80 percent Is grazing land, and the three largest cities are the capital, Bangui, with 350,000 inhabitants, Berberati, with 93,000, and Bambari, with 35,000.

title: Fed, at August Meeting, Authorized Higher Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Authority for all the recent interestrate increases by the Federal Reserve System was voted by the top policymaking body of the Fed in August, according to a record of the central bank's actions released today.

title: Sotheby, Citibank Explain Pact
description: Citibank and Sotheby Parke Bernet officially announced yesterday that they had entered into an agreement for the auction house to advise the bank on art investments for its clients. The venture  the first in this country involving an auction house as a formal adviser to a bank  is designed to serve those of the bank's clients who are prepared to spend $1 million or more on art and antiques. The project was announced yesterday at a news conference held at Sotheby's, Madison Avenue and 76th Street.

title: Message Systems Decontrol
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  The Carter Administration gave strong endorsement today to lagging legislation in Congress that would reduce regulation of the telecommunications industry and encourage market competition.

title: Frank I. Madigan, 70; Director of Law Force In Protests at Berkeley
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 (AP) Former Sheriff Frank I. Madigan of Alameda County, who gained national attention for his hard line against University of California demonstrators in the 1960's, died Wednesday at the university's medical center here. He was 70 years old.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)  A plea by Bill Baird, the abortion rights advocate, to prevent the use of Boston Common for a restrictedaccess mass by Pope John Paul II was taken under advisement today by Federal District Judge Walter Skinner.

title: The Region
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  The Long Island Lighting Company has asked the State Public Service Commission for a 2.5 percent, or $25.6 million, electricityrate increase that would go into effect early next year.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 43.

title: Record Level Of Asbestos In Hair Dryer
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)  Government tests have discovered the highest level of asbestos yet measured in a hair dryer since a massive recall of dryers began earlier this year.

title: Plainfield Reported Calm After 2 Nights of Disorder
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 21  After a week of growing racial tension and two nights of sporadic violence in Plainfield's predominantly black West End, a tense calm prevailed today as black and white officials sought to quell volatile rumors and assure citizens of their safety.

title: Progress Seen in Planning for City's Health Services
description: When Congress passed the National Health Planning and Resources Development Act of 1974, the clear intent was to prod local communities toward comprehensive health planning. In New York, which is surely not a typical community, consumer health advocates have been concerned that the power of the city's voluntary hospitals and a local agency set up by the Federal legislation might be two major obstacles to setting up a comprehensive plan.

title: Black Group Invites Arafat to U.S. And All Sing We Shall Overcome
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 21 (UPI)  Ten American black leaders ended a fiveday tour of Lebanon today with an announcement that they had invited Yasir Arafat to attend conferences they were arranging in the United States.

title: Pop: Soul Act Opens Concert For the Clash
description: There's one good thing to be said for the Clash. They have the good sense to bring in Sam and Dave as an opening act for their twonight run at the Paladium that began Thursday night. And Sam and Dave, the black vocal duo whose original 1960's soul recordings have very profitably been imitated by the Blues Brothers and other white copyists recently, were superb.

title: E.P.A. Is Trying to Cut An Insecticide Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 21 (Reuters)  A worldwide shortage of a flower sometimes called the death daisy is threatening to reduce United States supplies of insecticides commonly used against cockroaches and other insects in the home.

title: Philadelphia Archbishop Named
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)  Pope John Paul II has named the Rev. Myroslav J. Lubachivsky to become archbishjop of the Ukrainian Catholic Archeparchy of Philadelphia, Archbishop Jean Jadot, the Apostolic Delegate to the United States, said today. Father Lubachivsky, spiritual director at the Ukrainian Catholic Seminary in Stamford, Conn., succeeds Archbishop Joseph Schmondiuk, who died last December.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, Sept.22

title: Oil Concerns Curb Credit Cards
description: No Gas was not the only sign to frustrate motorists early this summer. As supplies grew tighter, warnings that read No Credit Cards or No Master Charge or Visa accepted appeared more and more frequently in servicestation windows.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 (AP)  Directors of the Ralston Purina Company have decided to sell 232 Jack in the Box restaurants and related facilities in the central and Eastern portions of the United States, it was announced today.

title: Dance: Deborah Riley and Douglas Dunn Perform in Foot Rules
description: Deborah Riley and Douglas Dunn danced a duet choreographed by Mr. Dunn on Thursday night at the American Theater Laboratory. Foot Rules, to an electronic score by John Driscoll, was certainly a dance for two. Yet to call it a duet may be misleading, for the word duet can suggest a brief, pretty dance, whereas Foot Rules was an epicscaled threeact duet that, with intermissions, lasted almost 90 minutes.

title: A.M.C. Votes Dividend, The First in Five Years
description: Directors of the American Motors Corporation marked the financial recovery of the small automobile manufacturer yesterday by voting a common stock dividend of 7 cents a share  the first payout since August 1974.

title: Gold Jewelry Prices Set to Jump
description: The impact of the skyrocketing price of gold is yet to be felt in the retail jewelry market.

title: Black Caucus Event Bars Speeches by '80 Hopefuls
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)  The Congressional Black Caucus opened two days of politicking and fundraising today by attacking President Carter's record and denying him a chance to make a speech.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times on Wednesday reported incorrectly the estimated amount of money spent on unnecessary automobile repairs. Investigators for the Department of Transportation and the House Subcommittee on Consumer Protection said the money wasted annually totaled $20 billion

title: Letter: On Social Security
description: Your Sept. 4 editorial Social Security Versus Reality ignores some important realities. For example, the editorial opines that providing adequate financial resources for Social Security would require huge additional taxes which no one seems willing to pay. From this you deduce that the major alternatives are to (1) tax benefits, (2) raise retirement age (which would reduce benefits to all below the new higher age) and (3) provide twotier benefits consisting of a basic nearsubsistence benefit for all and an optional supplement paid by voluntary extra contributions.

title: Chrysler To Submit New Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Treasury Secretary G. William Miller and Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said in separate statements today that the company would soon submit a revised financial rescue plan to the Treasury Department.

title: The City
description: An election for members of neighbor hood antipoverty boards conducted in the Bronx on Thursday will probably be invalidated, and similar elections scheduled for next Tuesday and Thursday in Brooklyn and Queens have been postponed, the city's Community Development Agency said yesterday.

title: Medical Center Offers a New Kind Of Specialist: The Family Doctor
description: It looked like almost any doctor's waiting room. Worried people were glancing fitfully at magazines and a whitecoated receptionist was answering phones and writing things down and calling out names.

title: Sheldon R. Coons, 84; Mt. Sinai Benefactor Counseled Businesses
description: Sheldon R. Coons, former chairman of the board of trustees of Mount Sinai Medical Center and a prominent business consultant for many years, died yesterday at the hospital after a long illness. Mr. Coons, who lived in Manhattan, was 84 years old.

title: Coup Leader in African Republic
description: In 14 years of despotic rule, JeanBedel Bokassa, ousted yesterday from his selfproclaimed position as Emperor of the Central African Empire, had one uncharacteristic lapse: Three years ago, he ended the house arrest of the man he had overthrown as President in a 1965 army coup and installed him in the imperial palace as a personal adviser. Just before mid

title: Canadian Atlantic Well To Get More Tests for Oil
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Sept. 21  The first tangible evidence of petroleum reserves off Canada's east coast has been detected at a well drilled by Chevron Standard Ltd. 195 miles from St. John's, Newfoundland, but more tests are planned, the company said today at its headquarters here.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: 1. In a White House ceremony, representatives of Egypt, Israel and the United States marked the first anniversary of the Camp David accords. Two days later, the three nations announced tentative agreement for monitoring of the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty, requiring increased American ground and air surveillance of the Sinai peninsula.

title: Authors Plan Study On Library Royalties
description: The council of the 5,500member Authors Guild has voted unanimously to study what role it should play in the growing fight over the concept of the rights of authors to receive remuneration for books lent by public libraries. This concept is expected to be resisted by a much larger group in the United States  the professional librarians.

title: Philharmonic Players Vote Pact
description: The players of the New York Philharmonic voted approval yesterday of a new threeyear labor contract that will give them a $50 increase in weekly pay each year, raising the minimum weekly salary to $630 in the third year of the contract.

title: Knicks Ask to Be Repaid
description: The New York Knicks asked the Na tional Basketball Association yesterday to give them back all elements of compensation previously awarded to the Seattle SuperSonics in the cornplexMarvin Webster case.

title: Merrill Develops Model Of Electronic Order Unit
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. announced yesterday that it had developed a prototype of an electronic securities order system that could be a step toward the longawaited national market system.

title: Lou Graham Leads by Shot
description: NAPA, Calif., Sept. 21 (UPI)  Lou Graham, with only three victories in 15 years on the PGA Tour, made a move toward his third triumph of the year today by shooting a sixunderpar 66 and taking the secondround lead in the $300,000 Napa Classic.

title: RAIL WORKERS DEFY CARTER OVER STRIKE
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP)  Trains of the strikebound Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad remained stalled today despite a back-to-work order by President Carter.

title: Festival Sheds Light On Skating Problem
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y. Sept. 21 From the outside, it could pass as an architectural remnant from the movie Star Wars, with the jagged black and white colored steel and darkly tinted glass panels.

title: Letters
description: The F.B.I.'s effort to smear actress Jean Seberg is an instance of governmental abuse of power which demands thorough scrutiny by the Carter Administration. Recently released government documents show that F.B.I. counterintelligence officers sought to neutralize Miss Seberg, a supporter of black nationalists in the early 1970's.

title: Yankees and Guidry Bow to Blue Jays, 32
description: TORONTO, Sept. 21  A shaky start by Ron Guidry and a Blue Jay triple play in the seventh inning proved to be the key deterrents tonight in the Yankee lefthander's goal to become a 20game winner for the second straight year.

title: RHODESIA'S REGIME ACCEPTS PRINCIPLES OF BRITISH PROPOSAL
description: LONDON, Sept. 21  The Government of Zimbabwe Rhodesia accepted today the general principles of the constitutional changes that Britain has proposed for it.

title: Market's Turnover Is 5th Biggest
description: The stock market advanced slightly yesterday in the fifth heaviest trading session in the history of the New York Stock Exchange. Wall Street analysts viewed the session as a positive performance that consolidated Thursday's 17point gain.

title: Union Fund Aide Quits; A Second Is Dismissed
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP)  The executive director of the teamsters' union's $1.5 billion Central States Pension Fund has resigned and the comptroller has been dismissed.

title: 2,000 Tickets Offered For President's Forum
description: Tickets for President Carter's town meeting at Queens College Tuesday evening will be available in the lobby of Queens Borough Hall starting at 8 A.M. Monday and continuing until 8 P.M., or until about 2,000 tickets are distributed.

title: Wendy Willow Norban Is Wed to A.S. Carduner
description: Wendy Willow Norban, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Norban, was married yesterday to Andrew Stephen Carduner, a consultant and investor in the electronics industry. The ceremony was performed at the Sherry Netherland Hotel by State Supreme Court Justice Burton Roberts.

title: Senate Panel Snags Plan to Expand Capital University
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Officials of the University of the District of Columbia, Washington's only public university, are trying to overcome Senate objections to their plan to consolidate the university's liberal arts, business and graduate schools now scattered in 14 buildings around the city.

title: World News Briefs
description: Marcos Vows to Step Down If Filipinos Don't Want Him

title: Temple Passer Gets Top Rating
description: Mark Herrmann of Purdue, Mike Ford of Southern Methodist, Phil Bradley of Missouri and Ed Luther of San Jose State are some of the quarterbacks who were expected to set the standard for passing in the 1979 season. But Herrmann is the only one who is close to the top this week.

title: Pericles Callimanopulos, 86, Dies; Founded and Led Hellenic Lines
description: Pericles G. Callimanopulos, founder and president of Hellenic Lines, died Thursday after suffering a heart attack at his office at 39 Broadway. He was 86 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Deaths
description: KORNMorris. Beloved husband of Hattie. Devoted father of Bertha Friedman, Ruth Blumenfeld and Seymour Korn. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Service Monday September 24 11:30 AM at The Riverside, 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Making Plans Without a Planner
description: The only professional architect and planner serving on New York City's Planning Commission left last December and has not been replaced. Now the commission's chairman, Robert Wagner Jr., is expected to leave soon to become a Deputy Mayor. Then the commission will have neither the leadership nor the expertise to deal as it should with the city's growing zoning and development problems.

title: Persistent Cuban Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  President Carter's effort to show political firmness while seeking a diplomatic solution to the problem caused by the reported presence of a brigade of Soviet combat troops in Cuba has produced a new set of tensions in his Administration.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON ASEATTLE inventor has patented a microprocessor to prevent the piracy of computer programs. Robert M. Best says such programs, sold for use in personal computers, may cost the manufacturer hundreds of thousands of dollars but can be easily reproduced and plagiarized by competitors. Copies can be made for $2 each.

title: About New York
description: Anyone who has ever had to witness a summer session of state legislators learns to beware of middleaged men who wear white patentleather slipon shoes with buckles.

title: Cleveland Councilman Is Cleared
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 (UPI)  City Councilman Ceasar Moss, indicted in an alleged carnival kickback scheme involving prominent politicians, was cleared today of all charges. Common Pleas Judge George Tyack cleared Mr. Moss of two bribery charges on the ground that there was insufficient evidence.

title: Deaths
description: EISINGRichard A. The Officers, Board and Staff of The Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged of New York note with extreme sorrow the death of the beloved husband of our esteemed VicePresident, Marie Eising. Heartfelt condolences are extended to members of his family.

title: Bokassa Is Third African Dictator To Be Ousted in the Last 6 Months
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 21  Six months ago there were three undisputed dictators in Africa: Idi Amin of Uganda, Nguema Biyoto Masie of Equatorial Guinea, and Emperor Bokassa I of the Central African Empire.

title: Hauppauge, L.I., Abortion Clinic Sues to Prevent Demonstrations
description: A Long Island abortion clinic has filed a $500,000 suit against several antiabortion groups in an effort to stop demonstrations at the clinic.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Carter Asks for List of Aid City Seeks
description: The White House has asked the Koch administration to prepare a list of pending Federal legislation, grants and other actions that would be helpful to the city, City Hall sources said yesterday.

title: 450 Students in Nyack Stage Rally To Protest Defeat of School Budget
description: NYACK, N.Y. Sept. 21  More than 450 high school students stayed out of classes here today to protest the cancellation of sports, bus service and other extracurricular activities, resulting from the district's defeat on Wednesday of a supplementary school budget.

title: A Death In My Family
description: They tell me that when they found my sister, the washcloth was still wrapped around her throat and that there was still a pungent hint of the black salve she'd smeared on her neck, hoping it would somehow stop the pain that had been nagging her for weeks.

title: U.N. Assembly, Rebuffing Soviet, Seats Cambodia Regime of Pol Pot
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 The General Assembly delivered a rebuff to the Soviet Union tonight by voting to allow the representative of the ousted Pol Pot regime to keep Cambodia's seat here.

title: What to Call Teachers
description: It is a common complaint that teachers now seem to have no better command of the three R's than their pupils. Last year in Dallas, for instance, a third of the city's firstyear teachers scored below the average high school junior in mathematics and English. To avert any such erosion in teacher quality. the New York State Board of Regents is thinking of designating public school teachers as professionals, to be licensed after passing a state exam and to be monitored by a professional practices board. It sounds too facile.

title: Salvadoran Is Slain as 2 Americans Are Kidnapped
description: SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 21 (UPI)  Two Americans were kidnapped and their Salvadoran companion was shot dead today in an ambush near San Salvador airport, the United States Embassy said.

title: Church to Pay for Pope To Use City's Stadiums
description: The Archdiocese of New York will pay the city between $30,000 and $40,000 to use Yankee and Shea Stadiums during Pope John Paul II's visit Oct. 2 and 3, Park Commissioner Gordon Davis said yesterday.

title: Carter, After Defeats in Congress, Vows New Discipline for Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  In response to a string of frustrating defeats on Capitol Hill this week, President Carter has told a group of Democratic Congressmen that he will do more rewarding of allies and punishing of enemies in the future, in an effort to enforce more discipline within party ranks.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Mexico will soon begin exports of natural gas to the United States, the two nations said today, thus easing tensions between them on the eve of next week's talks in Washington between President Lpez Portillo and President Carter. Mexico, holding out for a relatively high price, will start shipments in January. [Page 1.]

title: Powell, Jets' Tackle, Quietly Outstanding
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 21  Unlike most of his Jet teammates, Marvin Powell was not joking before practice today. His head was bowed in prayer. Powell prays a dozen times a day.

title: Bronx Lot Is Cleared For Visit by the Pope
description: A lot on Morris Avenue between 150th and 151st Streets  for years a reminder of the blight in the South Bronx neighborhood  received some attention yesterday. The impending visit of Pope John Paul II to the area brought representatives of the Archdiocese of New York and city officials to the lot, along with sanitationmen.

title: Paul Dubov, CoAuthor With Wife Of With Six You Get Eggroll
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 (UPI)  Paul Dubov, who collaborated with his wife to write the story of their marriage as the novel and later a movie, With Six You Get Eggroll, died yesterday of cancer at Encino Hospital.

title: Deaths
description: ADAMSLouise Drummond, on September 20th. Beloved wife of the late Arthur F. Adams. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81st St. on Saturday and Sunday, with service on Monday, 1 PM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: News Summary
description: A major concession in London was made by the Salisbury Government, which accepted the general principles of the constitutional changes that Britain has proposed for Zimbabwe Rhodesia. But Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa said acceptance was contingent on a number of details and subsequent steps, which he declined to specify. Former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, a member of the predominantly black Salisbury delegation, apparently did not support the decision, which raised doubts about its support among his country's white minority. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Goodrich Ends Offer
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 21 (Reuters) The B.F. Goodrich Company said today that it had completed its tender offer for all Tremco Inc. shares at a price of $40 apiece. Goodrich said that by the expiration yesterday, it had received tenders for more than 70 percent of the construction company's stock and guarantees of delivery for an additional 12 percent.

title: The Screen: 'Heartland,' Unsentimental Pioneers:Puerto Rican Dancers Schedule Oct. 11-14 Season
description: There are two very different ways of recalling the lives of the pioneers who settled America's frontiers and carried civilization westward. One way is to remember the terrible physical hardships that had their equivalents in the settlers' psychological dislocations and disorders. These were the things that Boynton Merrill Jr. recorded in his remarkable book "Jefferson's Nephews," about the decline and fall into poverty and madness of the members of one branch of the Lewis family when, in the early 19th century, they moved from Virginia into the Kentucky wilderness.By far the more popular method is to recall the pluck and perseverance that overcame all obstacles and made America great. There's nothing wrong with this method, though it does tend to be sentimental, prompting us to grieve for an innocence that probably never was. It also gives rise to the sort of myth about "the American character" that Dr. Norman Vincent Peale celebrates five nights a week in a 90-second syndicated radio show (WOR-AM) sponsored by International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. If I understand Dr. Peale correctly, the young men who save strangers from burning automobiles and the housewives who know how to give mouth-to-mouth resuscitation at the supermarket are the direct descendants of Virginia Dare.The nicest thing about "Heartland," a new, low-budget, uncommonly beautiful film written by Beth Ferris and directed by Richard Pearce, is that even though it celebrates the people of the American frontier, with emphasis on the women, it largely avoids sentimentality. The screenplay, based on the real-life story of Elinore Randall Stewart, is about an impoverished Denver widow who, in 1910, moves from the comparative ease of the city to the wilds of Burntfork, Wyo., to become the housekeeper for a taciturn Scottish rancher named Stewart. With her small daughter from her first marriage, and with Stewart, whom she eventually married, Mrs. Stewart survived just about everything the frontier could throw at her, including the death of a newly born baby and the loss of most of the ranch's livestock, as well as the sort of weather in which someone might freeze running from the house to the barn.The movie will be shown today at 9 P.M. at the Paramount Theater as part of the Festival of American Independent Films, being held in conjunction with the forthcoming New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center. It will be shown again at the Paramount tomorrow at 3.Though Mr. Pearce has made documentaries and features for television and was the cameraman for Peter Davis's Oscar-winning "Hearts and Minds," this is his first theatrical feature as a director. It is also Miss Ferris's first theatrical screen credit as a writer. Together they have made an unusually accomplished work."Heartland," which was shot entirely in Montana under what must have been difficult circumstances, also has the benefit of three remarkable performances  by Rip Torn, as the dour rancher, a man whose humor, though buried, is as real as his courage; by Conchata Ferrell, as the no-nonsense housekeeper, a big, hearty woman who is strong without being tough, and by young Megan Folsom, as her small daughter, who looks a bit the way Peggy Ann Garner did in "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn." Barry Primus is also very good as the ranch's hired hand, and Lilia Skala brings a kind of highly theatrical energy to her role as the local midwife. I just wish she hadn't plucked her eyebrows.Because the seasons are as important as anything that happens in them, the photography by Fred Murphy is very much a part of the film's success. The movie seems to have been shot mostly in the drained colors that Alan Pakula wanted for his "Comes A Horseman," though what we saw on the screen was often so dark we couldn't tell what was going on. Mr. Murphy seems to have achieved his effects with high color contrasts that are never too bright and that have the texture of early black-and-white photography."Heartland" doesn't entirely avoid the clichs of the genre. It may be time to declare a moratorium on the slaughter of pigs on camera to indicate the fundamental laws that rule the farm. Also, there must be ways to celebrate the so-called miracle of life without forcing us to endure both human and animal births. After a point, they all look alike.Most of the time, though, "Heartland" is firm and realistic in its appreciation of its people and the quality of their lives. One feels they are so stubbornly independent that they would have little patience with prefabricated pep talks about the American character. In Mr. Torn and Miss Ferrell the film also has two actors who look and behave as if they were quite capable of coping with nature's worst and smiling about it afterward.

title: Notes on People
description: The Senate Ethics Committee has come up with a solution to the problem of whether Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, may keep the money he's earning by fiddlin around.

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: Other Games

title: GOINGIOUT Guide
description: UP AND OUT At 11 A.M., 1 P.M. and 3 o'clock today at the 12,000acre Jamaica Bay National Wildlife Refuge Visitors' Center, there are scheduled talks on the flora and fauna of the sanctuary. After the talks, a ranger leads a guided tour of the West Pond. The event takes an hour and a half.

title: Miriam Blecher, a Choreographer
description: Miriam Blecher, a modern dancer, choreographer and cofounder of the New Dance Group, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles after a brief illness. She was 67 years old.

title: State to Free the Capeman, StreetGang Leader Who Killed 2 in 1959
description: Salvador Agron, the Capeman murderer who was sentenced to die in the electric chair for the knifeslaying of two Iteenagers on a West Side playground during the height of streetgang violence in New York 20 years ago, will be paroled about Nov. 1, state parole officials announced yesterday.

title: MEXICAN GAS SALES TO U.S. AGREED ON; 2YEAR SPLIT ENDED
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 21  After more than two years of sporadic and often heated negotiations, the United States and Mexico announced agreement today on the sale of Mexican natural gas to the United States.

title: Recital: ?? Wernick's Cadenzas' for Cello
description: One legitimate reason for composing a piece of music, though hardly the best, is to test the utmost capabilities of the instrument and the instrumentalist. Richard Wernick's Cadenzas and Variations III for solo cello, which had its New York premiere at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night, had such testing as its goal and seemingly not much else. Still, Bert Phillips, who performed the 12minute work, may not have been the ideal cellist to bring out its deeper qualities, if any. Throughout the remainder of the program, which he shared with the pianist Toby Blumenthal, Mr. Phillips played tentatively at best and often with a shakiness that was puzzling in so experienced a musician (he is a 20year veteran of the Philadelphia Orchestra). ?? off night, perhaps.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Beatrice Foods Company reported yesterday that it had profit increases of 10 percent for the second fiscal quarter and 12 percent for the six months ended Aug. 31. The results for the threemonth period were the highest for any quarter in its 82year history and the sixmonth figures were at a record high, according to James L. Dutt, chairman.

title: Swede's AirFare Cuts Praised
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 20  For the first time that anyone can remember in a country that has never reserved any great warmth for its moneymakers, a young Swedish businessman has become a media star.

title: Business Records
description: DURABLE DENTAL EQUIPMENT AND SUPPLY CORPORATION, also known as Durable Dental SupPlies Inc., as the Durable Dental Supply Company, 3001 Eastchester Road, the Bronx. The petitioners are the J. Palmer., Sales Company, the Union Broach Corps ration, and Coe Laboratories Inc.

title: France Sends Troops After Bokassa Ouster
description: PARIS, Sept. 21  With Bokassa I, the selfproclaimed Central African Emperor, deposed, France today sent about 300 soldiers to help keep order in the country.

title: Four Gas Concerns Plan Pipeline System
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (Reuters)  The Peoples Gas Company said its Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America subsidiary and three other interstate gas transmission concerns signed definitive agreements today to build a $400 million pipeline system.

title: Soviet Said to Offer 7 Pentecostals in U.S. Embassy Chance to Leave
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 21  Soviet authorities have offered to consider granting exit visas to seven Russian Pentecostals who have been in asylum in the American Embassy for the last 15 months  provided they first leave the embassy and go back to their home in Siberia.

title: 12 at Missile Silo in Little Rock Suspended in Marijuana Incident
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 21 (UPI) Twelve persons were temporarily suspended from duty as a result of the discovery of a marijuana cigarette on the floor of a missile silo near Quitman, Ark., according to a spokesman at Little Rock Air Force Base.

title: WOR to Televise Special On Pope's U.S. Trip
description: A onehour special focusing on Pope John Paul II's visit to the United States will be telecast on WORTV on Sept. 30 at 7 P.M.

title: Russian Novelties Highlight Fall Furs
description: They arrived, 1,000 strong, and jockeyed for the best seats in the grand ballroom of the Plaza Hotel the other afternoon. The Ben Kahn fur show is an event customers had marked off on their calendars months ago. Besides the chance to drool over a $100,000 lynx coat, the audience expects a little extra. Ernest Graf, president of the company, doesn't disappoint them.

title: Backers of Canal Pact Campaign to Save Enabling Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Congressional supporters of the Panama Canal Treaty, stung by yesterday's unexpected defeat of legislation crucial to the future operation of the canal, embarked today on a campaign to insure passage of a revised bill early next week.

title: Judge Arraigned on Drug Count
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 21 (AP)  Judge Paul Halvonik of the State Court of Appeal and his wife Deborah, a lawyer, were arraigned today on felony drug charges. The judge, 40 years old, and his wife, 37, were accused of growing 323 marijuana plants at their home. Mrs. Halvonik, who pleaded not guilty, also was arraigned on charges of possessing onethird of a gram of cocaine. Judge Halvonik was granted a delay in entering his plea.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OP DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. (518) 6??91??00; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Mrs. Carter Firmly Defends Jordan in Cocaine Inquiry
description: JACKSONVILLE, FLA. Sept. 21  Rosalynn Carter offered a spirited defense today of Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff who has been accused of illegal use of cocaine, describing him as a very cleancut, very decent youngman.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens. First game, 4 P.M. (Television  Channel 9, 7 P.M. Radio  WMCA, picked up in progress after Notre DamePurdue game.)

title: Kennedy Private Life Questioned; He Is Called Known Womanizer
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 21 (AP)  The leader of a national womens' political group says that Senator Edward M. Kennedy is a known womanizer whose private life raises questions about his possible candidacy for President.

title: Robber Trying to Flee As the Police Close In Dies in 7Story Plunge
description: A young gunman attempting to flee from the police fell seven floors to his death yesterday afternoon after robbing a photographic supply office on the 15th floor of the building at 100 Fifth Avenue, at 15th Street.

title: 50,000 Conrail Commuters Delayed by Fire
description: From 50,000 to 60,000 rushhour travelers from Westchester County and Connecticut were stranded on Conrail trains and at commuter stations for up to an hour and a half yesterday morning after a fire in an electrical transformer six stories under Grand Central Terminal knocked out rail service into the station.

title: At 100, Patron of Music Tunes Up for a New Age
description: LONDON, Sept. 21  Sir Robert Mayer, who is, at the age of 100, the grand patron of the British musical scene, has a vision of a new artistic age in which this country and the United States will lead the field in music.

title: VW Announces Price Increases
description: DETROIT, Sept. 21 (AP) Sticker prices of strippeddown 1980model imported Volkswagen, Audi and Porsche cars will increase by an average of 6 percent over the 1979 models, Volkswagen of America, the importer, announced today. Options will go up 8 percent.

title: Senate Confirms Goldschmidt
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)  Neil E. Goldschmidt, former Mayor of Portland, Ore., was confirmed by the Senate today to be Secretary of Transportation. The vote was 83 to 0. Mr. Goldschmidt has been Acting Secretary since President Carter appointed him to succeed Brock Adams, who resigned July 20.

title: Study Asserts Nonsmokers Live 2 Years More by Heeding Alerts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)  Americans who were persuaded not to smoke by health warnings about cigarettes are gaining an average of two extra years of life, a Federal report said today.

title: Koch Rebuts Badillo, Who Charged Mayor With Polarizing City
description: Mayor Koch responded yesterday to criticism by Herman Badillo, an outgoing Deputy Mayor who had charged in a speech the night before that policies of the Koch administration were stupid and were polarizing the city.

title: Maazel Signs 4Year Contract To Direct Vienna State Opera
description: VIENNA, Sept. 21 (AP)  Lorin Maazel, the conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra who describes himself as a fanatic for opera, signed a contract today to become director of the Vienna State Opera for 198286.

title: U.S. Gold Sales Tied to Dollar's Health
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  A high Treasury official said today that, if the current goldbuying fever had an adverse speculative effect on the dollar, the United States would open the vaults at Fort Knox for even larger amounts of bullion to offer at monthly auctions.

title: J.A.B. van Buitenen; Authority on Sanskrit Taught at Chicago U.
description: Johannes Adrian Bernard van Buitenen, one of the world's leading Sanskrit scholars, died yesterday in Champaign, Ill., after a short illness. He was 51 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: U.S. Will Allow OilLease Sales In Fishery Area
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  The Carter Administration announced today that it would proceed with plans to permit drilling for oil and gas on the Georges Bank off Cape Cod rather than declare the rich fishspawning area a marine sanctuary.

title: Another Hit for Rod Carew
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 21 While the bookbuyers waited for Rod Carew, an electric fan induced metallic chimes from the twirling disks of a nearby mobile. Across the aisle, in an area called Homebase, a few shoppers browsed among wooden cheese trays that were loaded with rubber crackers and

title: OBSERVERS'
description: I had promised my mother that when I grew up I would never cuss, wear doubleknits or run for President. Eventually, of course, I did run

title: The Days of Awe Begin
description: Jews waiting to enter Temple Emanuel, at Fifth Avenue and 65th Street, yesterday just before sunset, when Rosh haShanah, the Jewish New Year of 5740, began. The sacred 10day period, the Days of Awe, will end on Oct. 1 with Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, a time of fasting and soulsearching.

title: Abrams Aide Faulted for Tax Case Refusal
description: In a renewal of a dispute between Attomey General Robert Abrams and some state agencies, the State Tax Commissioner, James H. Tully Jr., said yesterday that it was a bloody outrage that an Abrams aide had refused to defend a state taxprivacy case.

title: Astros Defeat Reds, 32, in 13th
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 21  James Rodney Richard's approach to his work is to stay calm, stay cool, stay relaxed, no matter how important the game. Richard was calm, cool and relaxed tonight in a crucial game for the Astros. Houston's 6foot8inch righthander pitched 11 strong innings against the divisionleading Reds and Houston went on to win, 32, in 13 innings in the opener of a threegame series.

title: Senator Nunn Says That a Lack Of Troops Could Cost U.S. a War
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 81  Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, said at a secret session of the Senate today that severe manpower shortages in the armed services could cause the United States to lose a major war with the Soviet Union in Central Europe.

title: Reject SALT, But Seek Genuine Nuclear Disarmament
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Americans should be concerned about what action the Government will take to offset the Soviet Union's largescale military buildup in both nuclear and conventional forces. As I observe the SALT process, I conclude that the odds of providing for an adequate defense and encouraging international stability would be enhanced by rejection of SALT II and its protocol. At the same time, I suggest that we accelerate efforts toward achieving genuine nuclear disarmament.

title: Helstoski Is Cleared Of 7 Bribery Counts On Request by U.S.
description: NEWARK, Sept. 21  Seven briberyrelated counts of a 12count indictment against former Representative Henry Helstoski were dropped today at the request of the Government.

title: Injuries Deplete Giants' Ranks
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 21  And now there's confusion in the basement: Coach Ray Perkins of the Giants was undecided today about six starting positions, including quarterback and middle linebacker, for Sunday's 4 P.M. game here against the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Bloody Kabul
description: The already grim news from Afghanistan has turned even grimmer with reports of a coup that may have cost the life, among others, of former President Noor Mohammed Taraki. His successor, Prime Minister Hafizullah Amin, is no friend of the United States. Nor is he likely to be an asset to the Soviet Union, his nominal ally.

title: Tax Credit In Energy Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  The Senate Finance Committee approved tentatively today an energy conservation program under which the Government would provide a tax credit of up to $1,000 for every homeowner who replaces an electric space heating system with a heat pump.

title: Radio
description: 58:30 A.M., WBAI: Folk Music. Ira Leibin, host.

title: Services for Ralph Mayer, Artist
description: A memorial service for Ralph Mayer, a writer, artist and authority in the field of paint technology, will be held Monday at 5 P.M. in the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the Library of the Performing Arts, Lincoln Center. Mr. Mayer died Aug. 3.

title: Your Money
description: AS the cooperative apartment market continues to boom, demand for coop loans is also increasing feverishly. And consumers will find that money has become more expensive and the terms of the loans more stringent. Interest rates like the prices of the coops  have gone up sharply in the last few months and now are at least at 11 percent, compared with 10.5 percent last spring.

title: Marshall Recommends Choice for Labor Post
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall has recommended that President Carter name John N. Gentry as Under Secretary of Labor to replace Robert J. Brown, who resigned earlier this summer, Administration sources said yesterday.

title: Crum & Forster Loss
description: Crum & Forster said yesterday that the estimated pretax loss of its insurance companies from Hurricane David was no more than $3.5 million, and $6.1 million from Hurricane Frederic.

title: Halt Proposed In A.T.&T. Suit
description: A Federal magistrate recommended the dismissal of a $1 billion antitrust suit over telephone equipment filed by Litton Industries against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, an A.T & T. spokesman said.

title: Congress Is Moving Slowly on Heating Oil Subsidy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Rising prices for home heating oil will force many poor people to choose between food and heat this winter, Government officials say, but efforts to enact a subsidy program for elderly and lowincome people have gained little momentum in Congress.

title: Stewart Resigns as Arlen Head
description: Robert F. Stewart, who joined the financially troubled Arlen Realty and Development Corporation as president 15 months ago, abruptly resigned yesterday, several months before the end of his twoyear contract.

title: Sara Sage Is Upset Winner Of. L.I. Golf Championship
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 21Sara Sage of Piping Rock, who last won. the event in 1962, captured the Long Island women's golf championship today at the Glen Oaks Club when she upset Judy Cooperstein of North Shore Country Club, 2 and 1, in the 36hole final.

title: A Guide To Family Nurseries
description: PECONIC THESE days, what with chain garden centers and discount houses proliferating, the oldfashioned, familyowned specialty quality nursery is more and more difficult to find. But there are still a number of them on the Island.

title: The Man Who Wants Howard Johnson's
description: LONDON  One late summer day in 1901 James Buchanan Duke, head of the mighty American Tobacco Company, burst into the Nottingham offices of John Player & Sons and bluntly declared: Hello, boys. I'm Duke from New York come to take over your business.

title: AntiCastro Figure Is Shot
description: MIAMI, Sept. 22 (UPI) Antonio Veciana, a former leader of the antiCastro Cuban exile underground organization, Alpha 66, was wounded in the head yesterday by shots fired from a car that pulled alongside his auto in Miami. He was reported in good condition at Jackson Memorial hospital.

title: Realty News
description: The prices of apartments in cooperatives and condominiums in Manhattan leaped to new highs in the year that ended June 30. a new report has found.

title: 30Month Marine Designer Strike At Newport News Is Called Off
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va. (AP)  The United Steelworkers of America called off its 30month marine designer strike today at Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

title: Dealer Gets Year in Jail In Smuggling of Reptiles
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (UPI) One of the nation's largest dealers in rare reptiles was sentenced to a year in Jail yesterday and fined $10,000 for smuggling endangered species.

title: The MX Express, or Dr. Strangelove Rides the Rails
description: TO seasoned commuters on the New Haven division of Conrail it is staggering news indeed to learn that the Defense Department plans to build 200 MX missiles at a cost of $33 billion and deploy them on railroad trains.

description: BANGUI, Central African Republic, Sept. 22  David Dacko, who seized power on Thursday from Emperor Bokassa I of the Central African Empire, said today that he had planned the coup with France and friendly African nations during the last two months.

Razook of Rye and Lake Placid, N.Y., was married in Rye yesterday to Bernd Michael Lehmann, son of Dr. and Mrs. Karl Frederich Lehmann of Braunschweig, West Germany. The Rev. description: WHICH will prevail? The push to wipe out hidden costs by recycling, or the wasteful habit of dumping in landfills?

The 1980 finals, sponsored by the National Pork Council, appeared limited to men by rules calling for a national cookout king contest.

title: Penn State Bows To Texas A & M

title: Help for Stroke Victims and Their Families

description: WASHINGTON IN a rating comparison that might correspond to the saw One man's meat is another man's poison, William Carney, the conservative Republican Representative of the First District in Suffolk County, has just scored 100 on his voting record this year.

title: Peter Elliott Schruth, 62; ExPublisher of Holiday
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., Sept. 22 (AP) Peter Elliott Schruth, a broadcasting executive and former publisher of Holiday magazine, died yesterday after a heart attack. He was 62 years old.

title: Food
description: The most sophisticated, simple frozen food to prepare at home is an ice made with berries or other fresh fruit. All it takes is blending pured fruit with sugar  it isn't even necessary, in spite of what most recipes say, to bring the mixture to a boil.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: This is one of the most extraordinary stories yet to reach us from the bitter ashes of Nazism. The strange title, The Parnas, is the name given by Sephardic Jews to a spiritual leader. In this case, it refers to an Italian, Giuseppe Pardo Rogues, who was a leader of the Jewish community in Pisa before World War II. It is his strange and tragic story that Silvano Arieti tells in this brief, moving book.

title: Fashion View
description: Winnie's troubles are the talk of Seventh Avenue. After shining brightly for 37 years as the symbol of the prestigious Coty American Fashion Critics Awards, the voluptuous bronze statuette  the fashion industry's equivalent of moviedom's Oscar, television's Emmy and Broadway's Tony has recently lost much of its luster. Its reputation has been tarnished this year by charges of overcommercialization by Coty Inc., its cosmeticcompany sponsor, and by the refusal of two famous designers to accept special honors at the annual award ceremonies to be held this Thursday at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City.

title: An Idea for Better Bus Service
description: SOMEONE once suggested that the returnfare booths for the George Washington Bridge and the New JerseyNew York tunnels be removed and a onepayment toll instituted. It would be impossible to calculate how much gasoline ana trustration have been saved since that idea was put into action.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Somerville residents, as well as those in the area, will have an opportunity today to explore the full spectrum of performingarts classes. The occasion will be a Sunday Sampler at the New Jersey Center for the Performing Arts, 17 Division Street.

description: Statistics for commercial agricultural loans, carloadings, steel, oil, electric power and business failures are for the preceding week and latest available

title: MUSIC
description: IN a form of musical lightning striking twice, two of the greatest doublebass virtuosos in the country will be giving recitals in Connecticut this week. This afternoon at 4, Gary Karr will play at the Westport Town Hall Arts Center, and on Friday at 7:30 P.M., James VanDemark will give a concert in the Chapel of Choate Rosemary Hall, on North Elm Street in Wallingford.

title: Crystal Palace Wins, Ties for Lead in Soccer
description: LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP)  Crystal Palace moved into a tie for first place in the English First Division soccer standings by defeating Stoke City, 21, today.

title: Holdup Victim in Bronx Is Killed After Refusing to Give Up Money
description: A man was shot to death early yesterday at a Bronx social club after he refused to turn over his money to two masked gunmen who had ordered all the patrons in the club to lie on the floor and had already robbed the others of $220.

title: What's Doing in TEL AVIV
description: Tel Aviv is celebrating this year the 70th anniversary of its establishment as a suburb of Jaffa, an ancient Arab city it later incorporated. It was described as the first allJewish city in the world and it attracted streams of Jewish immigrants before the establishment of Israel. It was the hub of political and commercial life in the Jewish community before nationhood and was Israel's first seat of government in 1948. Jerusalem reclaimed its position but Tel Aviv remained the leading metropolis, the center of commerical activity and cultural life, with the leading theatres, orchestras, opera and ballet.

title: 300 Years Of Craftsmanship
description: HARTFORD ME than 250 pieces of folk art the largest such collection ??er assembled of objects ??t reveal what the men and women of Connecticut admired and enjoyed having in their homes from the Pilgrims' century to the present  are included in the exhibit Three Centuries of Connecticut Folk Art, scheduled to open Wednesday at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford.

title: Fashion
description: Sparklestrewn fabrics are back. Bugle beads dot camisoles, jewels stud jackets and fine sequins stripe pajamas. With the new, unabashedly affluent mood of fashion, refined razzledazzle once again looks right. It suits the feeling for luxury today, a mood which is the antithesis of the downtrodden look of jeans and workshirts.

description: Engagements

title: Affirmed, With Pincav, Takes Woodward
description: Affirmed won the $191,000 Woodward with consummate ease at Belmont yesterday and tightened his claim on horseoftheyear honors, but much of the credit must go to his jockey, Latin Pincay.

title: A MakeBelieve Sung Village
description: Soong Wusao was a roadside hawker outside the Restaurant of Plentiful Joy on the bustling main street in a capital of the Sung Dynasty. For years the Door widow had been brewing fish soup, but sales were sluggish.

title: A Meeting of Champions and Their Chain Saws
description: CHARLOTTE N.C., Sept. 22  It's easy to tell the difference between real chainsaw man, the lumberjack who makes his living driving highspeed steel through poplars and pines, and the weekender who saws a little firewood against the coming winter's chill.

title: Film: Robert M. Young's 'Alambrista!':The Cast
description: Robert M. Young's "Alambrista!" ("The Illegal") is a small, gentle, beautifully made film about a subject that might, in more conventional hands, have received either harsher or more histrionic treatment. Without sentimentality or rhetoric, it follows a Mexican farmworker on his illegal journey into California, which he soon discovers is hardly the land of opportunity. Roberto (Domingo Ambriz) will inevitably return to Mexico  that much is certain from the film's opening sequence, which shows him in circumstances far more peaceful and accommodating than anything he will find north of the border. Mr. Young accepts at the outset that Roberto's pilgrimage is futile and unavoidable, and then goes quietly about the business of detailing the trip.Mr. Young, who made "Short Eyes" and the current "Rich Kids" after directing "Alambrista!" for public television, shows himself to be a superb cinematographer, not just because "Alambrista!" is handsome, but also because it adapts so readily to the large screen. Instead of seeming broadly detailed or full of empty spaces, as many made-for-television films might in a theatrical setting, "Alambrista!" has an unexpected intimacy in its present form. The encounters are brief but uncommonly vivid. And the details, presented unobtrusively, ring true.Roberto, who speaks no English and is in any case nave, gets quite an education during the course of the story. He meets Joe (Trinidad Silva), who gives him a hilarious lesson in how to march into a cafe, cross his legs like a gringo, order a gringo's breakfast ("what you really want is tortillas and beans  but here you order ham-eggs-coffee") and flirt with the waitress. This last activity is anathema to Roberto at first; he is married in Mexico, with his mother leaving nearby, and hasn't fully made the move from a society of women to a society of men. But the film watches him adjust more comfortably to the company of the other male farmworkers after a time. And besides, the screenplay has a waitress in store.The portion of the film that introduces Roberto to Sharon (played sweetly by Linda Gillin), who can't help but take him home after he falls asleep in the luncheonette at which she works, is its most delicate passage. Mr. Young uses Sharon as a way of underscoring the paradoxical quality of Roberto's new life  there's a tiny, touching scene in which Sharon helps him buy a money order and send it off to his family, realizing only afterward this means he must be married. Sharon also takes him to a feverish revival meeting and to a department store, two places that make Roberto's foreignness seem most acute. His status as an outsider is the thing about Roberto that Mr. Young is most intent on capturing, and in this he clearly and affectingly succeeds."Alambrista!" will be shown today at the Paramount Theater, as part of the American Independents series.

title: A Tree Planted Now Gets a Grip on Its Site
description: IF you are one of those people who lost a tree in recent storms, you may be considering a replacement. Or perhaps you have an old, halfrotted tree that is causing some concern and should be taken down. Whatever your reason for considering a new tree, fall is an excellent time to Want one.

title: Old Southern Themes
description: IKE most novels in the Southern tradition to which it emphatically belongs, Ellen Douglas's fourth novel deals with the region's great questions: the byzantine tangle of blackwhite reiations, memory and history, religion and religiosity, transgression and guilt. But it also deals with a theme that so far has received little attention in Southern fiction: the corro sive effect upon whites and their families of massive, violent reaction to the civilrights movement. It is this theme, and Miss Douglas's admirably sensitive treatment of it, that gives The Rock Cried Out its true distinction.

title: Martha McDowell Bride of Dmitri Ilyinsky
description: The marriage of Martha Murray McDowell, daughter of Mrs. Richard O. Pollard of North Haven and Fenwick, Conn., and Edward I. McDowell Jr. of Hamden, Conn., to Dmitri Romanoff Ilyinsky took place at the Holy Transfiguration Russian Orthodox Church in New Haven yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Ilyinsky of Cincinnati and Palm Beach, Fla., and a grandson of the late Audrey Emery of Cincinnati and the late Grand Duke Dmitri, cousin of Czar Nicholas II of Russia. The Right Rev. Paul Zlatkowski performed the ceremony.

title: The Gentleman and the Romantic
description: AARON BURR The Years From Princeton to Vice President, 17561805. By Milton Lomask. Illustrated. 443 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $17.50.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Rodchenko in point of fact is not as well known as his colleagues. Thanks to the pioneering enthusiasm of Alfred H. Barr Jr., the Museum of Modern Art in New York has a large holding of his work. The antiquarian bookstore called Ex Libris at 160 East 70th Street usually has some of his publications in stock. But he and his work have not the almost universal currency that can now be ascribed to Tatlin's Monument to the Third International and to the no less famous painting by Malevich that is called White on White. Yet Rodchenko, unlike most of his colleagues, was active at strictions that is the bigcity building game, which constantly tests the power of the city's planners against the power of the real estate community, the city is steadily losing ground. And the process is irreversible.

title: Northstage Palatably Serves `Sound of Music
description: GLEN COVE WHEN The Sound of Music opened in 1959, was critically regarded as an act of atavism by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, who had previously provided the musical theater with historic breakthroughs in form and content. In retrospect, the pair's innovations seem more like departures than real influences, and The Sound of Music need no longer suffer the barbs of captious critics or comparisons with its artistically ambitious predecessors  not that audiences ever really minded; the show ran for three years.

title: Doubleheader Loss Mets' 4th Straight
description: The New York Mets lost for the eighth time in the last five days and Lou Brock achieved another milestone, but the spotlight at Shea Stadium yesterday was on Keith Hernandez, who had four more hits in his quest to add 100 points to his average and capture a batting title.

title: The Solution
description: In the confusion over Federal Judge Robert L. Carter's decree in the Marvin Webster case, the solution for Commissioner Larry O'Brien would appear to be as clear as Mike Burke's affidavit. The solution evolves from the Knicks president having originally offered Lonnie Shelton and a firstround 1979 draft choice (who turned out to be Vinnie Johnson, a Baylor guard) to the Seattle SuperSonics as freeagent compen sation for the 7foot1inch center. Instead of letting the case drag on in the Court of Appeals, the commissioner simply has to instruct the National Basketball Association champions to keep Shelton and Johnson but refund $450,000 to the Knicks treasury, another part of the award that has been deemed excessive.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: As I read Linda Howard's article Paying to Pray [Sept. 16] my stomach turned and my skin crawled from the label Seats for Sale that Mrs. Howard attempted to hang on her fellow Jews just as our sacred season of the High Holy Days nears. My initial reaction is that this is a classic case of a lady who wants to have her cake and eat it too!

title: Michele Perry, Student, Wed
description: The marriage of Michele Ann Perry to Phillip William Barnhill took place yesterday in the Congregational Church of New Canaan in Connecticut. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith performed the ceremony.

title: A Fall Chore Rakes Up a Lifetime
description: AS A romantic since birth, I have experienced decades of poignant autumns. The burnished gold and crimson, the haunting fragrance of wood smoke, the hardwood forests ablaze on an October hillside... every seasonal stereotype has been real for me and I often wonder how I can continue to be affected by a time of the year that has long since become one of the temperate zone's most repetitive clichs.

title: Patricia Ann Burd Is Married to Gunther Bogensperger
description: At St. Anne's Episcopal Church in Old Lyme, Conn., yesterday, Patricia Ann Burd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Burd of Old Lyme, became the bride of Gunther W. Bogensperger, son of Mrs. Friedrich Bogensperger of Graz, Austria, and the late Mr. Bogensperger. The Rev. Charles Griswold performed the ceremony.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: The Star in the Forest is set in the Frankish kingdom of Neustria during the late sixth century, a time when pagan slaves might still work their dark spells from within the walls of a Christian lord's manor and the flesh and blood ancestors of the Faery Folk could be counted on to spirit away unbaptized and unwanted infants. In short, this is the sort of territory that a few veteran practitioners like Rosemary Sutcliff can transform into high romance and which less skilled writers are apt to clutter up with highflown verbiage. Martha Bennett Stiles has not entirely avoided the pitfalls of the genre. I cringed when her villain's twitchy cheek threatened to leap out from under his hand while his brain kicked at his skull. More important, the plot is so thick with omens and forebodings that crucial action scenes sometimes get short shirft.

title: CHILD LABOR: THE SHAME
description: The scandalous exploitation of child labor that marked the Industrial Revolution in the 19th century in Europe and America has by no means disappeared. New studies done in connection with the current International Year of the Child show that more than 55 million children under the age of 15 are working today, most of them in the world's developing countries, many jobs that are not only grueling but hazardous. Photographs by JeanPierre Laffont. Text begins on page 36

title: PayPhone Credit Card Proposed for the Blind
description: ALBANY, Sept. 22 (UPI) The New York Telephone Company will provide credit cards to allow certain handicapped persons to make operatorassisted calls at pay telephones without incurring extra charges, the State Public Service Commission said today.

title: Florida Governor Names Aide
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 22 (AP) Jere Moore, 47 years old, a former Associated Press correspondent and Florida TimesUnion bureau chief here, was named yesterday as special assistant for Cabinet affairs to Gov. Bob Graham. He replaces Elton Gissendanner, who was appointed recently as the new director of the Department of Natural Resources.

title: Gains in Mideast Peace Brighten Rosh haShanah
description: There is an adage that it never rains on a Jewish holiday, but that sunny saying proved to be only half true yesterday as thousands of Jews in the New York metropolitan area made their way to Rosh haShanah services in a driving rain.

title: ANTIQUES
description: FLEMINGTON JEAN BACH'S redbrick house at the corner of Church and Main Streets is stuffed with antique dolls and toys. In more than 40 years of collecting, Mrs. Bach not only has parlayed what some people would call a childish obsession into a paying business, but also has made herself an expert whose appraisals have been sought by doll owners in this country and abroad.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Yankees Win, 74, As Gamble Hits 2
description: TORONTO, Sept. 22  There was El Senor Luis Clemente Tiant, the 38yearold Cubanborn righthander, stripped to the waist, lying on his side on the Yankees' clubhouse floor, puffing, naturally, on a cigar.

title: Nancy Reighley Wed to Banker
description: The marriage of Nancy Elizabeth Reighley to John Howell Cavanaugh, son of Mrs. Jere Howell Cavanaugh of Houston and the late Mr. Cavanaugh took place yesterday in New Canaan. Conn. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr., minister of the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ward Reighley, parents of the bride.

title: Weicker Still Jousting With All Comers
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. LOWELL P. WEICKER JR. was aggressive, independent and abrasive in the Watergate summer of 1974, when it was clear where his battle was leading him. He shows those same characteristics now, but some political observers  including some Republicans  are wondering where the attacks on President Carter, the Democrats, and even his own Republican party are leading him.

title: $100,000 Sporting Goods Robbery
description: Burglars broke through the wall of fashionable midtown Manhattan sportinggoods store and took more than $100,000 in gold jewelry, elephanthide attach cases, hunting equipment and other merchandise, store officials told the police.

title: Giants May Try to Exploit Familiar Eagle
description: He played oneonone against Ray Perkins, he has been with the same team as Perkins, and here is Bob Howard again today, going up against a team coached by Perkins.

title: Ford Recalling Mercury Capris
description: DETROIT, Sept. 22 (AP)  The Ford Motor Company says it is recalling about 100,000 Mercury Capris from the 1971 and 1972 model years to fix headlight switches that might fall apart.

title: Cornell Crushes Penn
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22  Pennsylvania opened its 103d football season by taking the worse shellacking in the history of its 86game series with Cornell.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: IF you've been feeling depressed these days, you've got good reason, according to Eugene Aronowitz, Westchester County's Commissioner of Community Mental Health. You're also not alone.

title: Year of Testimony on Texas Prisons Ends With No Decision in Sight
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 22 (AP)  Nearly a year after it began, testimony in a trial involving the Texas prison system has ended, but it may be several months before the judge hands down a decision that both sides say will probably be appealed.

title: Marriage Announcement 24 -- No Title
description: Ann C. Shakeshaft Married To Michael J. Tobey, Broker

title: Coal Operators and Union Agree to Improve Safety
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  The coal industry and the United Mine Workers, with a history of recrimination over curbing the hazards of the most dangerous of industrial jobs, disclosed today that they had signed a pledge to improve health and safety conditions in the mines.

title: ESCAR THOMPSON
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 22 (AP) Escar Thompson, a former correspondent for The Associated Press, died early today at Fort Sanders Hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: Wende L. Stone And James G. Bell Wed in Maryland
description: Wende Laine Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Edwin Stone of Washington and John's Island, Fla., was married yesterday to James Gatewood Bell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Amer Bell 3d of Lexington, Ky.

title: Shots Fired From Car on 77th St. Strike Man and Break Cafe Glass
description: Four shots fired from a car wounded Yonkers man Friday night and broke window of a restaurant at Columbus Avenue and 77th Street.

title: President Minimizes Role of Polls
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  President Carter says that his Administration's superb record and his reputation for being steady in an emergency will be much more important factors for voters in the 1980 election year than his standing in public opinion polls.

title: America's Role In Cambodia
description: Following are excerpts from a letter to The Economist, published in its Sept. 814 issue, from the former Secretary of State commenting on the British magazine's review of William Shawcross' book Sideshow: Kissinger, Nixon and the Destruction of Cambodia.

title: The Baldrige Book of Manners
description: Whether to seal a deal with a handshake or a bearhug, when to offer coffee and when to offer something stiff  they're questions of manners, and in international business, manners matter. So says Letitia Baldrige, the woman who was the social director of the Kennedy White House. Miss Baldrige now is in business for herself, advising businessmen on how to behave.

title: Purdue Rallies in 2d Half To Top Notre Dame, 2822
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., Sept. 22  Mark Herrmann of Purdue and an excited Boilermaker defense sparked secondhalf comeback that provided 2822 victory over Notre Dame today.

title: P.S.A.L. Threatened by Work Stoppage
description: The Public Schools Athletic League is threatened with a job action by officials and coaches that may cause the cancellation of all sports this season except football. Unfortunately, the real losers might be the city's young athletes.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: FIELDS OF FIRE, by James Webb. (Bantam, $2.50.) A platoon of Marines makes its way through Vietnam's rice paddies and jungles, beset by the violent deaths, hideous injuries, miserable living conditions and feelings of aimlessness. Vividly, sometimes awkwardly narrated by a man who was there, this novel is one of the best works to come out of the war.

title: Disposal Woes Beset Connecticut As Federal Sewer Funds Go Dry
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 22 (AP) Nicholas DelRosso lives in a neighborhood built on clay soil and steep slopes.

title: New Hampshire Top Court Backs Parents in Suits Over Damages
description: CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 22 (UPI) New Hampshire's Supreme Court has ruled that parents of injured children can sue for emotional anguish, even if they did not see the accident in which a negligent driver injured their child.

title: Elderly Found Portrayed As Stereotypes on TV
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 (UPI)A University of Pennsylvania study concludes that older actors are given very few roles on television and that the parts they do get perpetuate stereotypes of the elderly.

title: Uncertainties Surround Utility Plan
description: THE battle that has already begun between the Westchester County government and the Consolidated Edison Company over who will control the electric utility in the county may ultimately be decided by a man who is neither a voter nor an official of Westchester  the Comptroller of the State of New Yorkbecause of the legal and political ques tions that surround the county's plan to finance a public utility.

title: 16 Injured as Tractor Explodes
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Sept. 22 (AP) A tractor exploded and injured at least 16 persons, three seriously, during a tractorpulling contest tonight, the police said. According to an ambulance dispatcher, a valve blew on one of the engines, sending shrapnel into the crowd.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP)  The General Motors Corporation has developed a smaller, lighter, more powerful battery that will enable it to market electricpowered cars by 1985, The Chicago Tribune said in its Sunday editions.

title: Human Factor Involved in N.B.A. Rulings
description: Kermit Washington, Randy Smith and Mederia Webster have one thing in common: they have all been affected by the compensation system that exists in the National Basketball Association.

title: Cynthia Hosbach Wed to S.N. Miezeiewski
description: In St. Philip the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Saddle Brook, N.J., yesterday, Cynthia Leigh Hosbach was married to Stephen Nelson Miezeiewski by the Rev. Michael J. Nickelson.

title: Nancy E. Barry Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Barry of Madison, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Elizabeth Barry, to Laurance David Bruce, son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Bruce of New Rochelle, N.Y. A February wedding is planned. Miss Barry, a graduate of Ohio University, is a technical clerk with Exxon International Company, tanker division, in Florham Park, N.J. Her father is assistant controller of the Mobil Corporation in New York. Mr. Bruce, a Syracuse University alumnus, is with Actuarial Services Inc. in Union, N.J. His father is a clinical psychologist in New Rochelle.

title: Men's Club Is All Green Thumbs
description: JAY GOULD, a former owner of the estate, might have been amused to find his stables filled with what an uninitiated viewer would describe as miniature trees in pots. And a lady of the house might have been horrified to discover four different place settings, complete with floral arrangements, on the diningroom table. But to the visitors and competitors it was quite an exhibit.

title: Fall Planting Cue: Get It Done, but Make Haste Slowly
description: IT'S planting time, yet many signs would seem to contradict that: Nature is bedding down. The sweet corn season is over. Dogwoods have red berries. Boston ivy has red edges. Impatiens, true to its other name, touchmenot, has formed seed pods. Touch them and they will open with lightning speed.

title: College Football Era Is Coming to an End
