description: PRINCETON ALTHOUGH their football teams will meet again in New Brunswick next fall, when they close out a series that began there 110 years ago, next Saturday's PrincetonRutgers game at Palmer Stadium here will mark the end of an era.

title: CAMERA
description: There are many cherished notions  old ideas about photographic equipment and technique  that aren't necessarily true, but which are still accepted as holy Writ by many photographers. Some of these misconceptions and fallacies about photo methods can lead to mistakes, or worse yet, may hold a person back from exploring new techniques and methods. Here are a few of these misconceptions and fallacies that photographers should watch out for:

title: Sutherland: No More Goofy Roles
description: LOS ANGELES When I was 16, says Donald Sutherland, I distinctly remember asking my mother if I was goodlooking, and watching her face go absolutely white when she knew she had to confront something she didn't want to. I wished I'd never asked the question, because she turned and said, No... but your face has a lot of character.

title: Fall Planting Cue: Get It Done, but Make Haste Slowly
description: IT'S planting time, yet many signs would seem to contradict that: Nature is bedding down. The sweet corn season is over. Dogwoods have red berries. Boston ivy has red edges. Impatiens, true to its other name, touchmenot, has formed seed pods. Touch them and they will open with lightning speed.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Rhodesians at Home Unfazed by Talks in London
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia While the protagonists wrangle over this nation's future in London, life here wends its anachronistic and illusory way.

title: In Bulb Planting, Plan Ahead Before You Grab Your Trowel
description: THE bulbs for a spring bloom must be planted right now, but before you dash for your spade or trowel, spend some time planning how to get the greatest landscapeeffectiveness out of your selections.

title: Werner Harder 3d Weds Martha McDonald
description: Martha McDonald and Werner Paul Harder 3d were married yesterday afternoon in their home in Washington by the Rev. Nell Carlson of the United Church of Washington.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Mr. Van den Blink has grouped all graduates of colleges having teaching as their primary objective into one group and stated that these people are less than mediocre, etc.

title: Phnom Penh Says Thais Provide Bases for the Forces of Pol Pot
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 22 (UPI)  Cambodia's Hanoibacked Government charged today that Thailand is providing bases for continued guerrilla action by forces loyal to the ousted regime of Pol Pot.

title: Racquetball Set to Take Big Bounce
description: Is racquetball ready to take off the way tennis did 10 years ago?

title: Jazz: Brubeck Quartet Broadens Its Directions
description: Dave Brubeck's new quartet, which gave its first New York performance at Pace University on Friday night, is already the best he's led in several years. The drummer, Butch Miles, retains the fire and flash he brought to his years with the Count Basie band, but he's also paying careful attention to dynamics, something he didn't always do. The tenor saxophonist, Jerry Bergonzi, pays excessive homage to middleperiod Coltrane  sometimes he sounds like he's regurgitating bits and pieces of Mr. Coltrane's more celebrated recorded solos  but he's a capable technician, and he plays fast and hard. Chris Brubeck, who's a flexible and attentive Fender bassist and a pleasantly buttery trombonist, remains from the quartet the elder Brubeck recently led with his three sons.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Susan E. Erny Is Bride Of Joseph L. Tobin 3d
description: The marriage of Susan E. Erny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Erny of South Hempstead, L.I., to Joseph L. Tobin 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Tobin Jr. of Hempstead, L.I., took place yesterday in Baldwin, L.I. The Rev. Robert L. Isaksen performed the ceremony in the Bethlehem Lutheran Church.

title: Crash Kills Three, Injures 13
description: COATESVILLE, Pa., Sept. 22 (AP) Three children were killed and 13 people were injured when a station wagon carrying a group of children to a church meeting collided with two other cars on a rainslick highway last night, the state police said. Six persons were admitted at hospitals in critical or poor condition and seven were admitted in fair condition.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: AT midnight in Eisenhower Park, automatic sprinkler systems go on in the three golf courses and at the outdoor Lakeside Theater, keeping the grass green, despite the use it gets between thousands of treading feet.

title: Foods of the Indians:
description: A COOKBOOK. An ethnobotanical treatise. A cultural history. A forager's handbook. Native Harvests by Barrie Kavasch (Vintage paperback, $5.95, hardcover $10) is all four. The subject is the food of the American Indians and the Indians of the Northeast in particular.

title: Dancing the African Way
description: Some people think African dance is all oogaboogabooga  what you see in the Tarzan movies. Charles Moore shakes his head and laughs. He knows how easy it is for Americans to retain a stereotyped image, drawn from a few halfremembered Hollywood films: halfclothed natives leaping about in some malevolent ceremony in a jungle clearing. Mr. Moore plans to upset some stereotypes this week, though, when he and his wife, Ella Thompson Moore, bring their company of 15 dancers and musicians, Dances and Drums of Africa, to Marymount Manhattan Theater for a program of complex and joyous African dancing. There will be three performances beginning Friday.

title: CALENDAR
description: Wednesday through Nov. 18. Exhibit, Three Centuries of Connecticut Folk Art. Wadsworth Atheneum, Main Street, Hartford. Take Capitol Area Exit from 191.

title: Joan Rivers Sings Paean to Larchmont
description: OUTSIDE the windows of the star suite in the Las Vegas Hilton, a dusty red sun was sinking behind the mountains. Shadows were beeinnine to creep in over the gritty desert, and all the gaudy lights of the Strip were coming on. I was talking to Joan Rivers, who was sitting, tailor fashion, on one end of the sofa, halfspecs on nose as she worked at her needlepoint, and the topic was incongruous, considering the subject: Westchester and the East Coast.

title: Marriage Announcement 21 -- No Title
description: Elizabeth Coxe Is Wed To Edward P. Bullard 3d

title: Miami Beach Outlaws Official Bikini Pictures
description: MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 22 (AP) This resort city's tourism authority has ordered its staff photographer to stop snapping promotional shots of women in bikinis, calling the practice out of style.

title: Marriage Announcement 17 -- No Title
description: Kathleen M. Cinotti Wed To John M. Passidomo

title: New Design Criticized
description: WASHINGTON  The point has been all but lost in the last decade, but in the beginning, the Federal Government sponsored research on a new generation of buses to help preserve competition  not to develop special transportation for the handicapped. That was mandated later.

title: There Are Signs of Change On the Stage in China
description: In recent months, Peking has seen greater cultural diversity than at any time since the start of China's Cultural Revolution in 1966. Activities have ranged from the taping of a Bob Hope television special before selected audience in Peking's Capital Theater, to the televising of Bertolt Brecht's Galileo. In addition, there have been many performances of traditional Chinese music, films and popular drama.

title: G.O.P., WITH $860,000, PLANS CAMPAIGN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The Republican Party has $860,000 in the bank and the beginnings of a campaign plan in its files to help whomever it nominates to try to win the White House.

title: Mailbox: Call 'em As TV Sees 'em
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Painful Art of Rooting for the Giants
description: TALLAHASSEE, FLA. I have been a fan of the football Giants for 18 of my 26 years; I've experienced more than my fair share of depressing defeat. While not a masochistic soul, I nonetheless perservere with unabashed love for this hapless lot from the Meadowlands. This somewhat questionable romance has taken me to many alien stadiums and into contact with fans who probably wished I'd stayed home. My doting on the Giants has cost much money and has worried a lot of my family and friends.

title: Auto Search: Is It Legal?
description: MORE than a decade ago, the New Jersey branch of the American Civil Liberties Union carried to the state's highest court a case designed to stop the police practice of spot checks  having a driver pull over and checking to see if he had his license and registration.

title: Congress Turns Attention To Oil Conservation Plans
description: WASHINGTON  For the last several months, as Congress and the White House discussed synthetic fuels, oil price decontrol and speeding construction of energy facilities, the emphasis has been on new energy supplies. But gradually and with increasing force, conservation is starting to steal the show.

title: 157 at a Hospital Stricken by Salmonella Poisoning
description: As many as 150 staff members, employees and students, as well as seven patients, have been stricken with salmonella poisoning at the city's Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn, a city health aide said last week. He said there had been two outbreaks of the illness in the last month.

title: Marriage Announcement 9 -- No Title
description: Susan Claire Dickhaus Is Wed

title: ART VIEW
description: George Orwell once observed about James Burnham that he was always predicting as the trend of the future something that was already occurring in the present. The exhibition that Barbara Rose has just organized at New York University under the title American Painting: The Eighties is a little like that. It offers itself as a prophecy, but is actually a selective and highly tendentious retrospect on recent events.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Many of the Southington area's largest apple orchards  some of which were founded in 1830 and are among the state's oldest continuously operating businesses, according to the local Chamber of Commerce  will be participating in the 11th annual Southington Apple Harvest Festival Saturday, and Sunday and from Oct. 4 through 7.

title: How Lifeline Plan Will Work
description: TRENTON ABOUT 400,000 families in the state will be eligible for credits toward electricity and naturalgas bills under a law signed by Governor Byrne.

title: Oil or Natural Gas?
description: AS the leaves start to turn and the air becomes applecrisp, homeowners who were glad to see the end of oddeven gasoline rationing can contemplate the next oil crisis in their lives: an expected increase of 50 percent in the cost of heating a home with oil this winter.

title: Despite Talks, The Rivals In Rhodesia Keep Fighting
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia  From a helicopter gunship at 500 feet, they look pitiable, darting through the bush frantically seeking cover from the helicopter's explosive shells. More often than not they are hit, the shattered bodies pitching forward onto the dry scrub like broken dolls. The victims, nameless, will be left to be buried by villagers or to have their bones picked by roaming game. Later, a Government communiqu will record the deaths among the day's terrorist kills to add to 15.000 already slain.

title: Angels Top Ranters, Lead by 3
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 22  Bobby Grich led off the seventh liming with his 29th home run of the season and Chris Knapp pitched a fivehitter today to lead the California Angels to a 31 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: The Midas Twitch
description: President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy weren't yet eyeball to eyeball. But last week, as they moved closer to declared rivalry for the 1980 Democratic Presidential nomination, everyone was taking great care not to blink.

title: In Praise of Louis Auchincloss
description: LOUIS AUCHINCLOSS hasn't often received his critical due, but he seems to be bearing up well, considering. The lawyernovelist who's bar producing at the rate of a book a year for three decades is publishing two new titles this season, and A Writer's Capital, a memoir of his early years, nas just been reissues. persons of Consequence is handsomely illustrated popular history  a set of soundly thoughtout studies of Prince Albert and the prime ministers (Melbourne, Disraeli, Gladstone and Salisbury) who served during Victoria's reign. (There's not much gossip about the Queen's bedchamber.)

title: The Region
description: Mayor Koch, who has often said that his plan to close Metropolitan Hospital was not etched in stone, found last week that his original proposal was apparently written on sand.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  The United States and the Soviet Union are getting into a tight and even dangerous corner over that Soviet combat brigade in Cuba. President Carter has been using very careful words to express his concern, but it is important to know what they mean.

title: A Tree Planted Now Gets a Grip on Its Site
description: IF you are one of those people who lost a tree in recent storms, you may be considering a replacement. Or perhaps you have an old, halfrotted tree that is causing some concern and should be taken down. Whatever your reason for considering a new tree, fall is an excellent time to plant one.

title: TEXAS POLITICS FEEL RESIDUE OF OIL SPILL
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 22  Gov. William P. Clements Jr. of Texas returned to the state today after three weeks abroad, and waiting for him was a nettlesome political situation arising from the Mexican oil spill that fouled the South Texas Coast last month.

title: Paul Funk Weds Jean Beckwith
description: Jean Howell Beckwith, daughter of the late Edmund Ruffin Beckwith Jr. and the late Jean Orr Beckwith of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday in Trinity Episcopal Church to Paul Martin Funk. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Van Keuren Funk of Princeton and a greatgrandson of I. K. Funk, founder of the publishing house of Funk & Wagnalls. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. John Crocker, was followed by a reception at the home of the bride's stepmother in Skillman, N.J.

title: Nets Trim Roster to 16; Drop 3 Guards, Forward
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Sept. 22 (AP)  Three guards and a forward were cut today as the New Jersey Nets trimmed their National Basketball Association roster to 16.

title: POLITICS And as for Nassau's Sewers . . .
description: AT a meeting of Suffolk Republican Party leaders several years ago, one unidentified leader spoke almost reverently of the Southwest Sewer District project.

title: The Burden on Mr. Carter's Rivals
description: Whatever happened to the imperial Presidency? Anyone reading the news may well wonder. It is not simply that Jimmy Carter is losing the big fights; he cannot seem to win even on thirdlevel matters. Consider his setback on what should have been routine Congressional approval of laws to implement the Panama Canal treaty.

title: Western Connecticut: 14 Fall Foliage Tour
description: Every autumn motorists from as far away as Oregon swarm over the backroads of New England to admire the fiery foliage of the hardwood forests. Despite bumpertobumper traffic on the quiet back roads and the haze of exhaust that threatens both leaf and leaflover, their enthusiasm remains as bright as the surrounding colors.

title: Humes and O'DayEchoes of the Big Band Era
description: The echoes of the big band era have been growing fainter and fainter as the years go by. Only two bands from the period  Count Basie's and Woody Herman's  are still playing. The music of the jazz bands and dance bands that flourished between the two World Wars is now almost totally confined to reissues of their records.

title: Inquiries Into Racial Incidents Broadening
description: THE recent rash of crossburnings and swastika painting at homes in Nassau and Suffolk Counties has led Federal and local lawenforcement officials to expand their investigation of civilrights violations to alleged incidents of blockbusting and other conspiracies designed to keep out minorities.

title: Marriage Announcement 12 -- No Title
description: Diana Kubitsky Is Betrothed

title: Three Mile Island Accident: A Cloud Over Atom Power
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  An array of political, financial and technical problems have developed in the six months since the accident at the Three Mile Island reactor, and experts say that together they pose the most serious challenge to the nation's civilian nuclear power program since it began 25 years ago.

title: Fears of Economic Distress Prompt Surge of Gold Fever
description: Gold is a fever indicator of public anxieties over paper money, inflation, recession, unemployment and political instability. Last week, it looked as though the indicator was going through the roof.

title: Veterans Day Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)  Proclaiming Nov. 11 as Veterans Day, President Carter called Tuesday for prayers that America will ever seek the ways of peace and, by her example at home and throughout the world, hasten the return of good will among men.

title: Sewage Spill Wipes Out San Francisco Bay Fish
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 22 (AP)  The southern end of San Francisco Bay has become a virtual septic tank, a dead sea where officials say a sewage spill has wiped out marine life. A sewer plant manager says the problem may take weeks to correct, but state officials say the bay may not recover for years.

title: A Correction
description: The illustration for last week's Gardening column on the repair of damage to trees was incorrect. As the text of the column emphasized, a broken branch should be cut back flush to the trunk or to the major branch from which it grows.

title: Paterson Settlement
description: PATERSON THE nineday strike by 1,700 schoolteachers here ended last Wednesday with both the union and Board of Education elated over the final agreement.

title: Marriage Announcement 16 -- No Title
description: Elizabeth N. Beers Engaged to Marry

title: CONSENSUS PROGRAM PRAISED BY DOCTORS
description: What is the best treatment for breast cancer? How long should a heart attack patient remain in the hospital? Is intestinal bypass surgery a good treatment for severe obesity? Should wisdom teeth be routinely pulled?

title: Holocaust On TV Stirs Poles Anger
description: NEW BRITAIN THE recent rebroadcast of Holocaust, the highly praised television program on Germany's extermination of millions of Jews in World War II, has aroused anger here among members of the large PolishAmerican community, many of whom contend that Poles have been unfairly cast as Nazi collaborators, or at best as passive participants in one of the vilest chapters of man's history.

title: Emergency Room Operation Merges St. Luke's, Roosevelt
description: St. Luke's Hospital Center and Roosevelt Hospital  two of New York City's oldest and most distingushed institutions  have decided that together their best chance of surviving these hard times of shrinking medical resources is to complete the single largest hospital merger ever proposed in New York City and probably in the entire country.

title: Spotlight on County's First Female Rabbi
description: LARCHMONT VICKI HOLLANDER, a petite, 27yearold woman, is nervously moving about in a swivel chair in her small office on the first floor of the Larchmont Temple, her face illuminated by the flash of a photographer's camera. Mrs. Hollander's nervousness is not surprising

title: Drought and Birds Cut Fruit Crop
description: NEW HAVEN CONNECTICUTGROWN apples, pears, plums and peaches are not expected to be as large or as plentiful this fall as in past years, but they may be sweeter, growers say. At least one fruit grower said that next year's crop might also be hurt by the conditions prevailing this year.

title: POLITICS
description: JUST when everything seemed to be going his way, Mayor Thomas F.X. Smith of Jersey City ran into two fires this month.

title: Legion Disease Cases Reported
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 22 (AP) Health officials here are looking for a common denominator in two cases of legionnaires' disease, one of them fatal, among employees of a downtown restaurant. Health officials said yesterday that Beatrice Harris, 49 years old, an employee of King Cole restaurant, died of the illness Tuesday. Ronald Rutland, 46, a cook at the restaurant, contracted the disease Sept. 1 and is recovering.

title: Marriage Announcement 8 -- No Title
description: Debra Ann Lindsay Is Engaged

title: DINING OUT
description: WE first visited Hunan Restaurant in the Smithaven Mall (Lake Grove) about two years ago and were delighted not only with the excellent quality of the food but the variety, especially the many typically Hunanese cold appetizers available. After several recent revisits, we found the variety to be the same (except for price increases, the menu is virtually unchanged) but that the care in preparation and especially in serving has definitely slipped.

title: Jennifer McCartney Is Married
description: In the First Presbyterian Church in Kalamazoo, Mich., yesterday, Jennifer Sanford McCartney and Joseph Wright Rumbough 3d, alumni of Lake Forest College, were married by the Rev. David McShane.

title: THIS WEEK IN SPORTS
description: The Yankees play the Cleveland Indians Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday nights at 8 o'clock at the Stadium and conclude the season with games against the Toronto Blue Jays Friday night at 8 and Saturday (Fan Appreciation Day) and Sunday afternoons at 2.

title: U.S. Judge Sets Quota on Hiring Of Black Policemen in Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 22 (AP)  A Federal district judge has ruled that one of every three new city police recruits for the next five years must be black to correct the results of past discrimination.

title: Brick Halts North Bergen Streak, 147
description: North Bergen had its 14game victory streak snapped yesterday when Brick rallied for a 147 triumph at North Bergen in the opener for both teams.

title: Accord Reached in 2Week Strike Of Faculty at Monmouth College
description: Classes at Monmouth College, in West Long Branch, N.J., are expected to resume tomorrow as a result of a tentative agreement reached yesterday between the faculty association and the administration, the college announced yesterday. The agreement ends a twoweek teachers' strike.

title: Article 6 -- No Title
description: Greetings

title: 18 Dead and 557 Ailing In Iran Cholera Upsurge
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 22 (Reuters) Eighteen people have died of cholera in Iran in the last seven weeks and 557 cases of the disease have been confirmed, Deputy Health Minister Abolqasem Meteqi said today.

title: Marriage Announcement 2 -- No Title
description: Dale Esposito Is Married

title: Memories Urge a Return to Synagogue of His Youth
description: HE was named in memory of his greatgrandfather, Samuel, a pious man. Although he was given the same Hebrew name, his parents decided to call him Sheldon. It was more American, more modern.

title: A Book That Has Everything . . . and More
description: The sun beat down on the outback. That wild, hard, heartseizing land, the interior region of Australia, lay still in the pulsating heat, mysterious, implacable, awesome. Yet pretty young Bridget O'Meara paid it no attention. As she sat by the window of her room in the great house of Killorock, her thoughts were thousands of miles away, with Father Liam O'Malley, her oldest friend, her spiritual adviser her lover.

title: Opponents Delay Curtailment of Offstreet Parking
description: A proposal to curtail offstreet parking in Manhattan has run into opposition from such disparate critics as the operators of parking lots and the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote to adjust levels of revenues, new budget authority and outlays to provide no real growth in Federal spending, rejected, 60 to 28, Sept. 17.

title: Back to Basics Is Not Enough
description: FROM Manhasset to Montauk back to basics is the current rallying cry of every Long Island school superintendent. The three R's are in fashion this year; gone are the overriding concerns of past school seasons: the experimental programs in math and reading and the emphasis on the socialization of the child.

title: Issue Stirs Storm in Paris  ExEmperor Is Held Aboard Jet at Airport
description: PARIS, Sept. 22  Bokassa I, deposed as Emperor of the Central African Empire Thursday, remained isolated in his private plane at a French military airfield today, as officials tried to figure out what to do with him.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Howar
description: The marriage of Cynthia Leila Howar, daughter of Raymond Joseph Howar and Elaine Sirgany Howar, both of Washington, to Richard Stanley Trutanic took place yesterday at St. Albans Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Peter G. Winterble performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Nina Bogdanovic Trutanic of Los Angeles and the late Nicholas Frank Trutanic.

title: Keeping the Pond (and the Fish) Alive
description: FALLING leaves are a good cue to begin dismantling a water garden. Many plants in outdoor ponds can be preserved from one year to the next, and preparations for hibernation should be under way no later than the middle of October.

title: ART
description: WHITEPLAINS AMERICANS are faddists and one of their latest manias in the arts is photography. New galleries are opening as showcases for photography, and some older galleries that used to highlight painting and sculpture have scuttled those arts for picture making. Works of the camera are appearing on the walls of museums, and collectors do not seem to be able to acquire enough photographs. Some artists have abandoned the brush and chisel for the camera.

title: A TOUGH NEW ROLE FOR BEVERLY
description: Beverly Sills has managed more than a few successful leaps in her career, most of them vocal, but now comes a big one. At age 50 and without much administrative experience, the redhaired soprano has begun a new life as general director of the New York City Opera, a company that has been teetering on the edge of financial and artistic collapse for some time. Last week at the State Theater she opened in her final production, Gian Carlo Menotti's La Loca. After the sixth performance, on Oct. 4, she will abandon the opera stage, except for scattered commitments through October 1980, in favor of the managerial desk. Can she leap into this new life and take her troubled company with her?

title: Miss Mayfield Becomes Bride Of a Banker
description: Jacquelyn Gayle Mayfield, publicaffairs adviser with the Mobil Oil Corporation, was married yesterday to Rich. mond Moore 3d, vice president of energy finance at Salomon Brothers, investment bankers.

title: Central Catholic Triumphs by 3514
description: Central Catholic of Norwalk rallied from a 146 halftime deficit to down New Fairfield, 3519, in one of only two games played yesterday in Fairfield County.

title: Underground Grammarian Widens His War
description: GLASSBORO THE Underground Grammarian has widened his war against muddled English. When he first did battle in 1977, firing his broadsides  or broadsheets from a 1906 Chandler and Price press hidden in a basement in nearby Pitman, his targets were fellow Glassboro State College teachers and administrators. Their writing, he felt, demonstrated that they could not think straight.

title: Mexico's Foreign Minister Discusses Relations With U.S.
description: President Jse Lpez Portillo of Mexico arrives in the United States this week for an official visit that will include talks with President Carter in Washington on Friday. Although the two countries last week concluded an agreement on the sale of Mexican natural gas to the United States, relations between the neighbors have been clouded and other important bilateral issues  Mexican oil, agricultural trade and illegal migration remain unresolved. Alan Riding, a New York Times correspondent based in Mexico City, raised these and other issues last week in an interview with Mexican Foreign Minister Jorge Castaneda:

title: V.A. Buys Art for Centers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  The Veterans Administration and the National Endowment for the Arts announced a program last week that will place more than $500,000 in new art works in 15 V.A. facilities and create a pilot program for an artist-in-residence at the V.A. Medical Center in Hines, Ill.. near Chicago.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: GREENWICH Paintings and drawings by Gerald Moore, glass sculpture by Stephanie Ladoff, through Oct. 4, Bell Gallery, 202 Field Point Rd. Tuesday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Free. 8690646.

title: The Singer Shortage Has Sparked Adventurous Programming
description: The Metropolitan Opera has always prided itself on doing things in a big way, ever since the curtain first rose nearly a century ago. Big stars with big voices in lavish productions is a company tradition, and tomorrow's openingnight performance of Otello does not break with the past in this respect. Placido Domingo, Sherrill Milnes and Glide CruzRomo head the cast, James Levine conducts, the familiar Franco Zeffirelli sets and costumes will no doubt look as sumptuous as ever, and the whole glamorous event will be televised around the nation.

title: Seoul's Opposition Party Is Threatened With Split
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 22  South Korea's lingering political crisis moved to a new stage this week with the threat of a split in the opposition group, the New Democratic Party, which has 67 seats in the National Assembly.

title: IrishHeritage Group
description: WE consider ourselves an educational, familyoriented organization scholarly but not stuffy, said Seamus Ryan of Yonkers, a founder of the newly formed American Irish Heritage Association. We are strictly nonpolitical, nonreligious and open to everyone, regardless of ethnic background.

title: Campbell Wins Golf Title
description: WHEATON, Ill., Sept. 22 (AP)  William Campbell of Huntington, W. Va., defeated Lew Oehmig, 2 and 1, today and won his third United States senior amateur golf championship in 25 years. Oehmig, of Lookout Mountain, Term., was two down after the 15th hole, and one down after he birdied the 16th. Campbell won the match on the 17th.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Torn Wolfe used to be a newspaperman himself, so the right place to talk to him about The Right Stuff (reviewed on page 1 today) seemed to be the Artists and Writers restaurantbar on West 40th Street, once The Herald Tribune hangout, equidistant between Times Square and the Garment Center. The fashion plate of American letters  he not Only wears a vest, but it's doublebreasted honed his sentences at the Trib in the early 1960's, but the official identification from his publisher, Farrar, Straus & Giroux, omits any mention of his background as an inkstained wretch.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1979

title: New Rochelle Works to Sharpen Its Image
description: NEW ROCHELLE WE spent a lot of time, money and energy to improve New Rochelle's image  and we are succeeding, said C. Samuel Kissinger, City Manager of Westchester's secondlargest city. As an example of the new look, he pointed out the new $6 million public library and cultural center in the downtown section that opened last Sunday. The 67,600squarefoot complex had been under construction for four years as part of a massive city rehabilitation program.

title: Nurseries: Sniff, Sigh and Select
description: DARIEN PLANT people are as given to trading names of favorite nurseries as food people are sharing names of restaurants. Gardeners can choose their plants at discount stores and roadside stands, in esoteric specialty nurseries or from a dizzying smorgasbord of large garden centers.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Inflation and Recession Make Tax Cut Decisions Difficult
description: WASHINGTON  In economics as in haute couture, there are vogues. In 1984, when Congress passed a tax cut sponsored by President John F. Kennedy, the buzzword was multiplier. It meant that the total stimulus to the economy would be a multiple (by two) of the increased takehome pay produced by reduced individual income tax rates. Now, Congress looks to be preparing to cut taxes again, probably in a 1980 electionyear bill to take effect in 1981.

title: A Union Is Expanding Its Campaign to Enroll Employees of Colleges
description: The Office and Professional Employees Union, now claiming a membership of 110,000 employees at colleges, banks and insurance companies, has stepped up its organizing at colleges in New Jersey and Pennsylvania and is planning to expand its activities still further, according to John Kelly, the new president of the union.

title: SHOP TALK
description: MATTITUCK YOU can buy a lot more than nails in hardware stores these days. RaynorSuter Hardware Inc., on Love Lane in Mattituck is one of the dozens of hardware stores on Long Island that have over the last few years broadened the range of their mechandise to keep up with the consumer demand of a growing number of doityourself homeowners.

title: Just Like Joe Louis
description: After John Tate detached Duane Bobick from his intellect in one round last February, he was asked what he hoped to do with his life. I want to be just like Joe Louis, he said, meaning the young, healthy Joe Louis at the peak of his powers. In one respect, Tate has already realized that wish. although this could be only temporary. Young Joe Louis was undefeated until he was flattened by Max Schmeling in his third year as a pro fessional fist fighter. Now in his third year as a pro, Tate is undefeated and will remain so until Oct. 20, at least. That night in Pretoria, South Africa  it will be Saturday afternoon in New York  he will expose his chin and his record to Gerrie Coetzee, dental technician from Johannesburg.

title: Private Schools Gaining
description: PRINCETON WHILE publicschool enrollment in New Jersey is dropping, nonparochial privateschool enrollment is steadily rising. For whatever their reasons  they feel the discipline is better, the atmosphere is more conducive to learning, the student body is more collegeoriented or there is simply more prestige attached to a private education  parents are willing to spend the thousands of dollars it takes to send their children to private schools.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10:30 A.M. (2) For Our Times: GreekAmerican summer camp.

title: Robbers Get $300,000 by Using Ruse to Enter a Jewelry Concern
description: The police were looking for two men yesterday who robbed a jewelry company in lower Manhattan of about $300,000 in diamonds, gold and cash Friday.

title: Carl Morse: Orchestrator Of Buildings For 54 Years
description: 10 A.M. Carl A. Morse, who is 73 years old, still loves to walk through a skyscraper under construction and hear loose bits of concrete crunch beneath his black wingtip shoes.

title: A Dangerous Affair
description: RUE love in contemporary culture, far from being endless, is all too finite. Judging from divorce statistics, endless love doesn't seem possible. Judging from our culture's dreams, its novels and movies, the prospect doesn't even seem interesting. It is sexual desire, with its apparently limitless variety, that seems to intrigue us now. Love, if it is considered at all, must be reserved for odd couples  eccentrics, homosexuals, old men with young girls, young men with older women  as if fidelity could only flourish at the edge of society. We recognize the promise of true love in adolescents, but we know that soon the time will come when they too will love wisely, but not too well.

title: Complaint Accuses Union Officer And Hotel Executive of Violation
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 22 (UPI) hotel executive and a San Francisco teamsters' union leader have been charged with violating a Federal law that forbids labor representatives to accept favors from management.

title: A Tree Planted Now Gets a Grip on Its Site
description: IF you are one of those people who lost a tree in recent storms, you may be considering a replacement. Or perhaps you have an old, halfrotted tree that is causing some concern and should be taken down. Whatever your reason for considering a new tree, fall is an excellent time to plant one.

title: Oilman Weds Christy Hamilton
description: Christy Hamilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Crawford Hamilton of Denver, was married there yesterday to William Gardner Knight, son of Mrs. Milton Knight of Perrysburg. Ohio, and the late Mr. Knight. The ceremony was performed at the Hamilton home by the Rev. Stuart Plummer, a Presbyterian minister of Denver.

title: Orioles Secure Title
description: With the Brewers losing to Minnesota yesterday in Milwaukee, the Baltimore Orioles clinched the Eastern Division title in the American League. The California Angels took a threegame lead in the Western Division, and Montreal stood a half game in front of Pittsburgh in the National League's Eastern Division race. Page 5.

title: Naples Police Break Theft Ring
description: NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 22 (Reuters)The police arrested 172 suspects in raids against a larceny ring during the night, it was reported today. The police said they had recovered $850,000 in stolen goods, 89 missing cars and had seized 109 unlicenced guns.

title: FOREIGN POLICY ROLE BY BLACKS IS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  Andrew Young, the departing American delegate to the United Nations, asserted in his swan song tonight that black Americans must play a responsible part in making the nation's foreign policy.

title: FILM VIEW
description: With the announcement the last week by William H. Webster, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, that the bureau had, indeed, enaged in a campaign in 1970 to ruin the reputation of Jean Seberg, the story of this innocent abroad becomes even more sad, more particular, more vicious and more particularly American. The original report of her death, a week earlier, had been surprisingly poignant, considering that few of us had ever gone on the record with more than grudging praise for her film performances. The sense of shock we felt had as much to do with the shape her career and the circumstances of her death as it did with a feeling for the loss of the career that had ended.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: PORT WASHINGTON THEY were sitting at the next table, arguing. With only moderate effort, you can eavesdrop on all kinds of arguments in suburban restaurants, but this one was different from anything we had ever heard. The couple at the next table was arguing about chickpeas.

title: Jack the Ripper Meets H.G. WellsOn Film
description: LOS ANGELES I see myself as a storyteller, says Nicholas Meyer, who, having written such bestselling novels as The Seven Percent Solution, is about to make his debut as a film director at age 33 with Time After Time, which opens nationally on Friday. The stories that try to tell, whether in books or on film, at the very least are supposed to distract you from the horror of life, to take you away from yourself and replenish your imagination.

title: Topics Prisoner, Acronym, Emperor
description: Yes, there were excesses of repression, Argentina's military government admits, but now the dirty war is over and things are returning to normal. President Videla and his fellow officers have staged a rhetorical blitz in their efforts to persuade the visiting InterAmerican Human Rights Commission that conditions in Argentina are improving. Perhaps their preoccupation with this operation explains how they could have overlooked an obvious way to demonstrate their point.

title: Pink Cadillac  A Rite of Passage
description: A lot of records sound like they're made by robots nowadays, notes the singersongwriter John Prine, who will be performing at Avery Fischer Hall on Oct. 12. His flat, measured Midwestern drawl doesn't quite mask his enthusiasm for the subject. People keep inventing all these new machines, and producers and recording engineers keep wanting to use them. I decided several years ago that I wanted to make an album with a certain sound to it, a sound like human beings were playing.

title: Matt Robinson of Jets Is Left Wondering
description: Matt Robinson knew it last Monday. Whoever starts Sunday against the Bills will be the Jets' quarterback for the last 13 games, he said.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: For many concertgoers, the solo flute repertory probably extends no further than Bach's A minor Partita, which may have been intended for another instruument, and Debussy's Syrinx, which lasts less than three minutes. Actually, hundreds of works for unaccompanied flute exist, and Sept. 15, Zdenek Bruderhans assembled seven of them for an unaccompanied flute concert at Carnegie Recital Hall. Syrinx and the Bach partita were included, as were compositions by Telemann, Hindemith, Paganini, Luciano Berio and Jindrich Feld.

title: Hopes Rise in Argentina for Timerman's Early Release
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 22  Jacobo Timerman, Argentina's most prominent political prisoner, is spending the Jewish New Year holiday in detention, but with hopes of being expelled soon to freedom abroad.

title: Best Sellers
description: This Week

title: State University Rolls Expected to Show Rise Till 198485 Semester
description: ALBANY, Sept. 22  The 34 stateoperated campuses of the State University of New York will enroll slightly more students in the next few years, but 198485 will see fewer students enrolled, according to university trustees.

title: A Correction
description: The caption on a photograph appearing in this section last week erroneously described the location of a cooking class. The class took place at The Silo in New Milford.

title: Women Pastors Officiating at More Marriages
description: WHEN Debbie Gardner was married to Stanley Fowler in Asheville, N.C., last summer, her college roommate was there  not as maid of honor but as officiating minister. Mrs. Fowler's former roommate, the Rev. Pamela Moffat of Groton, is often called upon to officiate at such outoftown weddings for friends and relatives, male and female, in addition to the ceremonies she performs at Groton's picturesque First Church of Christ, Congregational, United Church of Christ, where she is associate pastor. More and more these days as the number of women in the clergy increases woman ministers are officiating at marriages.

title: Six Foreign Journalists Get Nieman Fellowships
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 22 (AP) Harvard University has announced the names of six foreign journalists who will take part in the Nieman Fellowship program this fall.

title: Notes
description: In three East Coast cities, events in the next few weeks will focus on several aspects of our cultural heritage: restoration, preservation and historic reenactment.

title: Reporter Is Fianc Of Diane M. Batten
description: Mrs. Thomas Clarke Madden of Northfield, Ill., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Diane Marie Batten, to Richard R. Manning, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Manning of Boston. The wedding is planned for November.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: ARSON SUSPECTED IN FATAL NURSING HOME FIRE: Residents of Minneapolis's Bryn Mawr Nursing Home being evacuated after a fire broke out early yesterday in the building. One person died and another was critically burned. Several residents were treated for smoke inhalation. Police believe arson was cause of fire, and a resident of the home was taken into custody.

title: A Fall Chore Rakes Up a Lifetime
description: AS A romantic since birth, I have experienced decades of poignant autumns. The burnished gold and crimson, the haunting fragrance of wood smoke. the hardwood forests ablaze on an October hillside . . . every seasonal stereotype has been real for me and I often wonder how I can continue to be affected by a time of the year that has long since become one of the temperate zone's most repetitive clichs.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE phrase delicatessen sandwich abounds with ethnic ironies. Of course, delicatessen is a German word, but its roots are to be found in both French and Italian. Practically everyone who has bitten into two pieces of bread with meat between them knows that an English nobleman, the Fourth Earl of Sandwich, created the dish. And in the New York area, at least, the word deli is often preceded by kosher.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Stephen King has built a big name and a small fortune writing novels about the occult and other chilling phenomena that make readers flesh creep. I like to scare people. I really do, he says devilishly.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Something for the boys. According to the word in the book trade. 60 percent of the massmarket paperbacks sold these days are bought by women. What about the other 40 percent?

title: Primitive Engine of Ship Stirs Smithsonian
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  On a sunny Sunday afternoon in June 1858, the freighter Indiana sank in lake Superiorthe victim, one could argue, of greed.

title: Queens Man Is Charged In Killing of City Officer
description: The police arrested a man in Brooklyn yesterday and charged him in the shooting death of Police Officer Melvin E. Hopkins on Sept. 15. In a similar incident yesterday, an offduty Housing Authority patrolman was wounded in Brooklyn.

title: U.S. and China Chided By Soviet for U.N. Step
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union accused the United States and China today of having used manipulation and tricks to force the United Nations General Assembly to allow the Pol Pot administration to retain the Cambodian seat there.

title: ExBackers Return, Spurring Mrs. Gandhi's Drive
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 22  The comeback campaign of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is gathering momentum as political leaders who deserted her are flocking back to her banner and one of her most bitter critics has agreed to work with her.

title: Ombudsman Bellamy Asserts Her Main Job Is to Slash Red Tape
description: In a highceilinged room in the crumbling, 19thcentury Tweed Courthouse behind City Hall, four young people sit at castoff desks manning telephones as callers recite a litany of problems with New York City's bureaucracy.

title: To Mount Whitney's Lofty Peak
description: Mount Whitney is the highest mountain in the contiguous 48 states. Backpacking to its 14,495foot summit is not the vacation for everyone. But for people in good physical condition who enjoy scenery that sends their spirits soaring every time they lift their eyes from the trail, and who enjoy clean, crisp mountain air and, above all, enjoy a challenge, this is an experience never to be forgotten.

title: Edward Chase Jr. Weds Miss Wolf
description: Rosemary Wolf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip C. Wolf of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday in Menauhant, Mass., to Edward Fuller Chase Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Chase of Belmont and East Falmouth, Mass. The ceremony was performed in the nondenominational Grace Memorial Chapel by the Rev. W. Ray Worthington, an Episcopal priest and brotherinlaw of the bridegroom.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Render unto the church expense accounts which are religious and unto the city those which are nonsectarian. That became the rule last week as American communities prepared to receive, and pay for, the sevenday visit of Pope John Paul II ; the total cost was estimated at $10 million.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WASHINGTON  Despite accelerating interest rate increases and the vote of no confidence in the Carter Administration's economic management registered by the frenzied buying of gold, the recession the economy apparently entered some time in the second quarter still appears to be pretty mild.

title: MUSIC
description: THE second season of the Philharmonia virtuosi of the State University of New York at Purchase opens this Friday at 8 P.M., with Richard Kapp not only conducting works of Haydn, Rameau and Wagner, but also serving as his own soloist in Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 24 in Cminor. The events switch thereafter to Sunday afternoons, the better to entice you into bringing the whole family, with 3 P.M. starts on Nov. 11, Dec. 16, Feb. 10, March 16, and April 13.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ALL the lights knocked out by Tropical Storm David on Sept. 6 are back on, of course, but the Public Service Electric and Gas Company is a long way from getting its damaged transmission lines completely back to normal.

title: Soccer Growing In College
description: This year, college soccer powers will emerge from more places than usual. In addition to the traditional powers of the Northeast, sections of the Middle West and the Western and Southern areas, a team from deep in the heart of Texas and one from Alabama will be making strong bids for a National Collegiate Athletic Association title.

title: $550,200 Found in Car Still Mystery
description: ROXBURY TOWNSHIP AN AURA of mystery continues to surround the halfmillion dollars found in the trunk of a car stopped by the State Police on Interstate 80 last month.

title: Fun Is Money With Flexitime
description: Flexitime is a way of letting workers choose their own hours, so it's not surprising that employees might welcome it. But what does it do for employers? Apparently it increases productivity, which would spell higher profits.

title: Communications Transportation Energy
description: In former times, the world's radio spectrum was a resource taken for granted, as oil had once been. Its frequencies were allocated by the International Telecommunication Union, an agency of the United Nations, largely on a firstcome, firstserved basis to the countries that were prepared to use them. As a result, by some estimates, about 10 Dercent of the countries have come to occupy almost 90 percent of the available frequencies, leaving little of a limited resource to the less developed nations.

title: Cowboys' Winner: Screen to Y
description: When the Dallas Cowboys take on the Cleveland Browns tomorrow night in a game matching unbeaten teams, one point of interest will be the remarkable cohesiveness of a coach and a quarterback, Tom Landry and Roger Staubach. Should the Browns' defensive players attempt to outguess these two they had better be lucky.

title: TV VIEW
description: The opening moments are familiar yet, somewhat ominously, different. The theme song is still Those Were the Days, but only the melody remains. There is no shot of Archie and Edith putting their heads together to sing the lyrics blissfully off key. Glimpses of the Bunker neighborhood in Queens have been replaced with more detailed shots of business streets somewhere in the area of Astoria. And then, instead of finding the old title of All in the Family, the viewer is confronted with something called Archie Bunker's Place. The new series, salvaged from one of the longestrunning and most influential situation comedies of this decade, begins tonight on CBS at 8 o'clock with a special onehour episode. It is, in just about every respect, a firstclass disaster.

title: Carter and Brown Are Following Similar Strategies
description: WASHINGTON  After a few years of sounding like Republicans, the Democrats are fun again, unless perhaps you work at the White House. They have stopped talking about balancing the budget, or cutting red tape. When they make promises, it's about fighting to the last delegate, not about providing a government as full of love as are the American people. They have the makings of an entertaining brawl, with broad elements of farce.

title: Big 12Meter Effort Launched by Conner
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  The crew begins to arrive at 6:30 A.M. and starts splicing sheets and repairing halyards and anything else that needs fixing. After the sails are loaded on dollies they are taken by truck from the drying shed to the boats.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS
description: FROM Hempstead to East Hampton and from Oyster Bay to West Islip, a look at the upcoming season indicates that musical excitement is stirring on Long Island.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: 3 Arrested in Ohio Officer's Death; One Turns Himself In at TV Studio
description: Three Queens youths were arrested yesterday in connection with the shooting of a visiting Cleveland police detective last week, including one who turned himself in at a TV station yesterday afternoon because he was said to fear for his life at the hands of the police.

title: Differing Views on the Defense Budget Could Affect SALT Agreement
description: WASHINGTON  Last Tuesday, Senator Sam Nunn, the reigning Congressional expert on military affairs, delivered a gloomy message. After giving his colleagues a batch of complicated graphs and statistics, the Georgia Democrat announced that over the past decade, the Soviet Union had outspent the United States for military forces by $104 billion.

title: Headliners
description: The United States Government rarely objects to a Federal employee's religion. But Federal District Judge Marion J. Callister Jr. is a prominent Mormon in Boise, Idaho, where the state is suing the Government for recognition of its right to rescind its approval of the Equal Rights Amendment. Since the Mormon Church opposes E.R.A., the Justice Department has asked the judge to disqualify himself.

title: The Burning Memory of a Cross
description: ACROSS was burned on our lawn when I was less than 5 years old, so when crossburnings suddenly festered on Long Island my antennae quivered with fear. I was once again a defenseless child of the Depression, a parvenu in alien territory, owned by the real Americans of the Rondout Valley, in upstate New York, not the Jews.

title: ART; Wall Hangings and Basketry at The Silo
description: NEW MILFORD CONNECTICUT abounds in converted buildings like The Silo, in New Milford, and can afford to take them for granted To a visitor, though, they can seem a little strange  structures balanced on the cusp between the real and a commercial for what kindly old Pepperidge Farm remembers.

title: Environment
description: Integrated pest management, as Congress will learn this week, is more than a fancy name for swatting flies and spraybombing ants. An innovative, comprehensive approach, it combines crop ecology studies, biological controls, meteorological information and other disciplines and data to protect crops from bug infestation. And with very few pesticides.

title: Peace Hasn't Been Easy for Egypt's Army
description: CAIRO  For three decades, the Egyptian armed forces bore the brunt of Arab wars with Israel, at the cost of 100,000 dead and wounded. Now that Egypt and Israel have made peace, President Anwar elSadat wants to keep his forces powerful to protect his strategic aspirations. With more than 500,000 men under arms, Egypt's military machine remains the largest in the Middle East, and is rated second only to Israel's in effectiveness.

title: Let's Not Enact Any Illegal Laws
description: IN New Jersey, officials elected at the local level take an oath of office stating that they will defend the Constitution. Ironically, hundreds of officials, by their actions, are abusing the very document that they have sworn to uphold.

title: Advice on Getting Ready for a Tough Mountain Trek
description: The key to a successful climb is thorough preparation. Here are some suggestions worth considering before tackling a tough mountain.

title: Patio Paving: Bricks In a Snug Bed of Sand
description: ONE of the easiest ways to create a paved backyard patio or walk is to lay bricks, new or used, in a bed of sand. It's not necessarily the quickest way poured concrete would probably be faster  but it's one of the simplest. Almost anyone can do it without special tools or equipment.

title: Mountbatten Series Set For PBS in November
description: Because of the recent terrorist murder of Lord Mountbatten, the air date for an eighthour publictelevision documentary about the British war hero has been moved up from next year to the middle of November.

title: Federal Narcotics Agents Seize 4 in Brooklyn Quaalude Scheme
description: Agents of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration have arrested four Brooklyn men and charged them with conspiring to sell 250,000 Quaalude pills for $1.5 million.

title: Stage: O'Casey Shadow of a Gunman
description: In anticipation of the centennial of the birth of Sean O'Casey in 1980, the Symphony Space theater is presenting a revival of The Shadow of a Gunman in its home in the converted Symphony movie house on upper Broadway. This, of course, was O'Casey's first produced play  in 1923 at the Abbey Theater in Dublin  and one that quickly established his reputation. The work is brief enough so that it is sometimes preceded by a curtain-raiser, but it is more substantial than it appears to be in Isaiah Sheffer's production.

title: Hotel Plan for Jericho Divides Community
description: JERICHO BUSLOADS of angry Jericho residents plan to turn out ready for battle at Tuesday night's Oyster Bay Town Board meeting on a proposed hotelconference center. They say they are not just against a hotel in their neighborhood, but are fighting to maintain a suburban way of life.

title: An Aluminum Stampede DownUnder
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Comalco, a major Australian aluminum producer, unveiled plans earlier this year for a 200,000ton smelter in Gladstone, on Australia's west coast. Within weeks, five other major aluminum companies had announced similar plans to increase smelting capacity in the country. All in all, the companies earmarked $6 billion for projects that would boost this country's aluminum output sixfold over the next five years.

title: Maria Regina Tops St. Paul's by 200
description: Bob Ford scored two touchdowns to lead Maria Regina of Uniondale, L.I., to a 200 victory over St. Paul's of Garden City yesterday in the season opener for both teams.

title: CHESS
description: Secondbest just cannot succeed forever, even in the hands of Vlastimil Hort, Czechoslovakia's leading grandmaster. He has made a practice of shunning theory's latest word in favor of whatever alternative opening variation has fallen into disuse. The idea is that most opponents won't bother to keep up with the strongest measures against the outmoded.

title: Toby Weintraub To Be Wed Oct. 21
description: The engagement of Toby Weintraub to Robert J. Beckenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Beckenstein of West Hartford, Conn., has been announced by the bridetobe's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Weintraub of Jericho, L.I. The wedding will take place on Oct. 21 in Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Some time ago, having noticed that a man's stature in the world is measured by the difficulty of getting in to see him, I decided to call attention to my importance by going into the business of not seeing people.

title: In Kuwait, Old Trading Family Finds Fortune in New Diversity
description: KUWAIT, Sept. 21  One can hardly turn a street corner in Kuwait without running into AlGhanim. If it is not one of the AlGhanim General Motors showrooms, it is an AlGhanim travel agency, or airconditioning outlet, or rentacar operation. Then, there are AlGhanim ticketing and cargo agents for British Airways, Air India, Qantas and five other airlines. The name also covers television and hifi agents, prefabricated housing, construction equipment, tires and so on.

title: U.S. Is Prosecuting Fewer Cases As It Focuses on Certain Crimes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)  The number of civil cases in the Federal courts set a record again this year, but the number of criminal cases declined by 9 percent because of a policy of focusing on specific crimes, according to an annual study of court activity.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING; Apartments: Endangered Species?
description: WITH the construction of new apartment houses at virtual standstill, affordable rental housing is considered by many to be an endangered species.

title: DINING OUT An Oriental Gem in Waldwick
description: IN JUST a tittle over a year, this relatively small restaurant in Waldwick has established itself as one of the best of the state's Chinese eating places. It has taken a setting that is somewhat of a clich  a corridor, with booths along both walls and tables forming a center island  and made it a restaurant that one wants to return to again and again.

title: In Bulb Planting, Plan Ahead Before You Grab Your Trowel
description: THE bulbs for a spring bloom must be planted right now, but before you dash for your spade or trowel, spend some time planning how to get the greatest landscapeeffectiveness out of your selections.

title: Moving Lady
description: MARTHA GELLHORN is a gentleperson. For 42 pages in this book she writes about an Unwilling Companion on her trip into China's interior in 1941, always referring to him as U. C. and never mentioning that he was in fact her husband, Ernest Hemingway. This  at a time when to have been Hemingway's wife (not exactly an exclusive claim) seems excuse enough to publish every possible remembrance of the great man  entitles Miss Gellhorn to a medal, at least. But her excellence does not stop there. She renders U. C. justice: she makes him a sympathetic as well as amusing figure, although perhaps a wee bit maddening, as in the following case.

title: REINVENTING AMERICA TO SAVE ENERGY
description: Years ago the Sinclair Oil Company had a cuddly, green brontosaurus as its mascot. His purpose seemed to have been to tell the motorists in an age almost as remote as triceratops that Sinclair's fossil fuel came only from the finest U.S.D.A. prime dinosaur meat. Such an arresting pictore: herds of multitonned reptiles, stampeding in uncounted numbers into seasized, Paleozoic pits to lay down their lizard lives so that we might drive to the office every day. Greater love hath no dinosaur. Perhaps if we'd been taught to think of the family Chevy burning up the fossilfuel remains of 6.3 pterosaurs per mile, instead of gallons per mile, we might have realized sooner that there truly is a limited amount of oil.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Starting at 10 A.M., there'll be plenty of activity on the parking field of Eisenhower Park this morning. A treasure hunt, to be specific. You see, the members of the Atlantic Treasure Club have all these metal detectors that they usually use to skim the beach in search of lost coins. But since the beach season is virtually over, to keep in practice, the group has planted tokens that entitle the finders to specific prizes. Hence, the treasure hunt. While bona fide treasure hunters are paying $10 to sharpen their skills and participate in a howto clinic, the general public can just watch the fun at the East Meadow Park. Perhaps without being detected.

title: A Youthful Vision, Turned Perennial: The Perfect Border
description: IPSWICH, MASS. LONG ago, when I was a very young gardener, I set out to design a foolproof perennial border  easy of upkeep, constant in color, capable of expansion, a comfort throughout the season. My inspiration stemmed quite literally from the great herbaceous borders, 10 feet wide and hundreds of feet long, of those enormous English countryhouse gardens.

title: CAPITAL REPORT
description: BEING a friend of Governor Byrne apparently means more than Just knowing a nice guy. Last week, Martin L. Greenberg, the Governor's former law partner, got a plush state job.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: From Binge to Bust: The Legacy of the Crash
description: THE date was Dec. 30, 1929, and the place was the auction gallery of Adrian H. Muller & Son on Vesey Street in lower Manhattan. The Muller firm that day was selling engraved paper, certificates representing investments in dead and dying companies such as the Floridale Townsite Corporation, the Coldstream Golf Club Corporation and the Magazine Repeating Razor Company. Once the certificates were called stocks and bonds, but by the time the Mullers got them, they were known as cats and dogs.

title: Union Council Approved the New General Motors Contract Last Week
description: DETROIT  When the United Automobile Workers began negotiating with the General Motors Corporation two months ago, it looked as if the union wanted to change the world. No issue seemed so esoteric as to escape the attention of the U.A.W. negotiators, who placed demand after demand, a stack of documents an inch and a half thick, before the automobile men.

title: ART
description: AMONG the several photographic exhibitions currently on view in the Island's galleries, two stand out for their combination of historical interest and exceptional imagery.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  American Jumping Derby, Glen Farm, Portsmouth, R.I. Grand Prix for open Jumpers. noon.

title: BRIDGE
description: Although chess is widely regarded as a more difficult game than bridge, computers can now defeat all chessplayers except the very best. while computer bridgeplaying is still in its infancy. One reason for this is that chess is a game of complete information while bridge is not. Another is that the bridgeplayer, unlike the chessplayer, is constantly involved with stylistic, human and psychological factors.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Tropical Storm David has proved to be a literal windfall for seekers of cheap firewood. Westchester parks are issuing special permits to those who want to saw, chop and haul as much as they can carry as a way to help the county clear up downed trees and limbs. The uncut wood has been collected in the parks and is available daily from 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. Permits cost $3 a car, $5 a station wagon or van and $10 a pickup truck. They are available at the sites until the wood out.

title: The Homeowner As Entrepreneur
description: It works this way: Homeowners figure that the purchase of a house has been their best investment. So, they reason, why not buy a second one, fix up and rent or resell it? Then buy another one. And another.

title: A Growing Force In Connecticut Art
description: NEW HAVEN WHEN Three Centuries of Connecticut Folk Art opens Wednesday at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, it will mark the successful completion of the most ambitious project yet of Art Resources of Connecticut, a littleknown New Haven organization that is having a quiet but substantial impact on the cultural life of the state.

title: Princeton Stuns Dartmouth
description: HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 22  The Ivy League football season opened today, and Dartmouth, last year's champion, fell with a mighty thud before Princeton and a shocked hometown crowd of 14.500. The score was 160.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE EDWARD HOAGLAND READER, edited by Geoffrey Wolff. (Random House, cloth, $12.95. Vintage, paper, $4.95.) AFRICAN CALLIOPE, by Edward Hoagland. (Random House, $10.) Two books by a nonfiction writer who, no matter what his subject, manages to be personal, magisterial and persuasive. The first volume is a collection of essays and articles, the second an account of a winter spent in a Sudanese village.

title: Police Arrest 12 and Seize Drugs In Raid at Tavern on Long Island
description: BAYVILLE, L.I., Sept. 22 (UPI)  A dozen people were arrested and a variety of drugs were seized early today in a raid on a Bayville bar, the Nassau County police said.

title: Edith McBean Bride of Duncan MacGuigan
description: Edith Starkey McBean and Duncan Ames MacGuigan, codirectors of Acquavella Contemporary Art Inc., were married yesterday in St. Thomas Episcopal Church by the Rev. John Andrew.

title: East Title Is Clinched By Orioles
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 22 (AP)  The Baltimore Orioles clinched the American League Eastern Division title today when the Minnesota Twins beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 6.3. The victory kept Minnesota within three games of frontrunning California in the West.

title: Philadelphia Luxury Hotel Reopens Today
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (AP) Dust rises around the marble columns in the lobby as construction crews restore the grandness of a bygone era. Other workers are renovating 565 guest rooms in preparation for the reopening of one of Philadelphia's finest luxury hotels.

title: Lisa Hansen, T. N. Burditt Have Bridal
description: Lisa Gardner Hansen, daughter of Mrs. Howard E. Hansen of Wellesley Hills and Wianno, Mass., and the late Mr. Hansen, was married yesterday to Timothy Nye Burditt, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Burditt of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and Manchester, Vt. The Rev. James R. McColl performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Wellesley, Mass.

title: THE MARKETS
description: The stock market last week defied such traditional negatives as record gold prices, a record primelending rate and a faltering dollar to push ahead briskly. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 14.84 points to close at 893.94.

title: Article 10 -- No Title
description: FLORIDA MOVER SEEKS RETURNS LGE/SML LO RATESDIRECT SVC FREE ESTIMATE & INFO FOGARTY VAN LINES NE REGIONAL OFC TOLL FREE 800/5267104 N.J. 2013301771

title: U.S. Court Nominees Said to Quit AllWhite Clubs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)  More than a dozen nominees for Federal judgeships, under pressure from the Senate Judiciary Committee, have agreed in re cent months to resign from allwhite social clubs, committee sources said today.

title: Fall Planting Cue: Get It Done, but Make Haste Slowly
description: IT'S planting time, yet many signs would seem to contradict that: Nature is bedding down. The sweet corn season is over. Dogwoods have red berries. Boston ivy has red edges. Impatiens, true to its other name, touchmenot, has formed seed pods. Touch them and they will open with lightning speed.

title: FOOD
description: HUNTINGTON FOR the last few months, Bobbi and John Tangorra have been into Moroccan food. An exotic combination of minced chicken, raisins and subtle spices layered in pastry and dusted with cinnamon and confectioner's sugar is the latest addition to the everchanging catalogue of savory ethnic pastries available at their immensely appealing takeout and catering shop, Lovin Oven, 8 West Shore Road, Huntington. Lovin Oven is one of the few truly firstrate places to buy prepared foods on the island.

title: A Youthful Vision, Turned Perennial: The Perfect Border
description: IPSWICH, MASS. LONG ago, when I was a very young gardener, I set out to design a foolproof perennial border  easy of upkeep. constant in color, capable of expansion, a comfort throughout the season. My inspiration stemmed quite literally from the great herbaceous borders, 10 feet wide and hundreds of feet long, of those enormous English countryhouse gardens.

title: Landscapist Reaches Beyond the Ordinary
description: PORT WASHINGTON THERE are some artists who have to travel to remote areas of the globe before they can find the subject matter that inspires them. They need something radically different, an unabashed assault on their senses, perhaps, before they can find the artistic expression congenial to their special temperament. But there are others who need not move from their hometowns, nor even step out of their houses, to discover what they are looking for. They live within their own artistic universe.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: It is an old saw that supply and demand, or buyers and sellers, determine stock prices. But that formulation is not very useful. It does not explain how buyers and sellers arrive at opinions as to what prices constitute a reasonable valuation. And now several new academic studies conclude that buyers and sellers have, in fact, been quite wrong in their views of the intrinsic worth of common stocks.

title: Technology as a Detective Story
description: LONDON American television viewers, whose lofty notion of the British Broadcasting Corporation has been formed by such illustrated lecture series as Jacob Bronowski's The Ascent of Man and Lord Kenneth Clark's Civilisation, may be somewhat startled by the latest BBC export. Connections, which will begin next Sunday evening at 8 on public television, is a 10part history of technology in which ideas are simplified, pertinent historical moments are dramatized and each show, in the words of its creator, James Burke, is presented as a sort of detective story.

title: 3 More Alawites Slain in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 22 (Reuters)  Three military members of the minority Moslem Alawite sect have been killed in a spreading campaign that is worrying the Syrian leadership, Arab diplomatic sources here said today. President Hafez alAssad is a member of the sect. The gunmen killed two Alawite officers, Col. Mohammed Jamil Naddah and Lieut. Col. Ibrahim Alia, and a sergeant, according to the Arab sources.

title: Irish Glassware  With a Following
description: The Duchess of Devonshire likes Simon Pearce's glassware so much she uses it for her most formal dinner parties as well as for casual family meals at her summer cottage. While the Irishman's work may not be to everyone's liking, the goblets, bowls, carafes, vases and candlesticks from his workshop in Bennettsbridge, County Kilkenny, are certainly versatile, adapting as readily to romantic 18thcentury furnishings as to 20thcentury chrome.

title: Sweeping Out Chrysler With a Broom by Ford
description: Chrysler Corporation automobiles have a reputation for being long on engineering and short on styling, and after the changing of the guard at Chrysler three days ago, even the company's management imprint has taken on a different look. Now it more closely resembles that of rival Ford.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: Janet L. Igler Bride Of Roger J. Smith
description: Janet Lynne Igler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin R. Igler of New Canaan, Conn., and Roger Jeffrey Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger C. Smith, also of New Canaan, were married there yesterday. The Rev. Charles C. Smith performed the ceremony in the Congregational Church.

title: Fall Planting Cue: Get It Done, but Make Haste Slowly
description: IT'S planting time, yet many signs would seem to contradict that: Nature is bedding down. The sweet corn season is over. Dogwoods have red berries. Boston ivy has red edges. Impatiens, true to its other name, touchmenot, has formed seed pods. Touch them and they will open with lightning speed.

title: Maulana Abdul Ala Maududi, 76, A Pakistani Islamic Party Leader
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 22 (AP)  Maulana Abdul Ala Maududi, a founder of the JamaatiIslami Party in Pakistan and an Islamic scholar and author, died here today at Millard Fillmore Hospital of a heart attack. He was 76 years old and had come to the United States for treatment of liver and kidney problems.

title: Fiery HeadOn Auto Crash Kills 7
description: INDIANA, Pa., Sept. 22 (AP)  Seven persons were killed today when two cars collided headon and burst into flame near here. The state police said that the victims were burned beyond recognition. Billy D. Powell, 21 years old, was alone in one car, and John and Agnes Weston were in the other with two daughters, an infant granddaughter and a niece.

title: Taraki's Downfall Came Immediately After a Visit to Moscow
description: NEW DELHI Some months ago, an American returning from Afghanistan gleefully described the already decaying situation there as the Russian Vietnam. Certainly, there are enough similarities between Moscow's predicament in Afghanistan and the American experience in Vietnam to delight Western cold warriors. But the overriding similiarity that sometimes gets lost in the diplomatic titfortat is that in Afghanistan, as in Vietnam, tens of thousands, even hundreds of thousands of people, are being killed in violence beyond the control of either local authority or great power.

title: Should the Homeowner Convert to Gas?
description: AS the leaves start to turn color, and the air becomes applecrisp, homeowners glad to see the end of oddeven gasoline rationing can contemplate the new oil crisis in their lives: an expected rise of 50 percent in the overall cost of heating a home with oil this winter.

title: Lynch Bids Americans Oppose Ulster Violence
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 22 (UPI)  Prime Minister Jack Lynch of Ireland said today that the most important thing Americans could do to help combat terrorism in neighboring Northern Ireland was to speak out against violence and invest in the province to help its economic and political development.

title: Judge David Rubin to Wed Melinda Wagner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hymen Wagner of Fair Lawn, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melinda Leslie Wagner. to Municinal Court Judge David B. Rubin of New Brunswick, N.J. He is a son of Judge Irving W. Rubin of the Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court of Middlesex County, and Mrs. Rubin of New Brunswick. The wedding is planned for next June.

title: Presenting the Past for Future Generations
description: IEXTRICATED a wrinkled, brown paper bag from stacks of folders that have been waiting for my attention every year since I can remember.

title: CRIME
description: The British actor Charles Paris has solved four mysteries up W now, and detection is in his blood. In A COMEDIAN DIES, by Simon Brett (Scribner's, $8.95), Paris takes it upon himself to look into the death of an entertainer. Nobody has asked him to do so, and he himself is not directly involved. But he becomes suspicious and is determined to solve the case.

title: CAREY DID NOT APPLY FOR TRANSIT FUNDS, U.S. OFFICIALS ASSERT
description: Governor Carey never formally applied for the Federal share of an $805 million masstransit plan that he offered to Mayor Koch to win Mr. Koch's support for the Westway highway project, according to senior officials of the Federal Transportation Department.

title: 5 States Warned of Fund Loss On Highway Speed Enforcement
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)  Five states may be in danger of losing a portion of their Federal highway funds if they do not force greater compliance with the 55mileanhour speed limit, the head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says.

title: 120 Public TV Stations To Offer Education Session
description: Some 120 public television stations will be linked to a closedcircuit television system Monday as part of a national teleconference focusing on adult education and televison.

title: A Correction
description: The illustration for last week's Gardening column on the repair of damage to trees was incorrect. As the text of the column emphasized, a broken branch should he cut back flush to the trunk or to the major branch from which grows.

title: TV Networks to Cover Selected Parts of Papal Visit
description: The networks will be long on specials when Pope John Paul II comes to the United States next week, but short on coverage when his activities clash with football or baseball. And the Pontiff will get a lot more coverage when he is on the East Coast than when he moves west.

title: In Praise of Guilt
