description: DESPITE my nonpatient status in psychiatric circles, I am probably as qualified as the next person to be granted a fouryear scholarship to a leather couch. I daresav that I have as much guilt within my slight frame as the most dedicated of those whose ids are being investigated. It is not only that paying out money to an inkblot specialist would intensify my feelings of guilt by depriving the usual channels of my largesse (sometimes described as smallesse); there is also involved a certain reticence on the ground of principle to dispensing hard cash to a private ear who may have more problems than I.

title: Marriage Announcement 27 -- No Title
description: Anniversaries

title: DINING OUT
description: I'm driving to  today. Is there any place there to have a decent lunch? This sometimes plaintive question is asked frequently. From time to time we will list places where one can lunch comfortably without excessive expense or undue waste of time. The following trio were discovered recently.

title: Fireworks Prompt Calls
description: A fireworks display at Shea Stadium in Queens yesterday afternoon and evening caused many city residents to call authorities to report loud explosions, the police said. The fireworks were part of an attempt to draw more fans to the Mets doubleheader at the stadium, a publicity device that had previously been used in June.

title: CAMBODIA HOBBLING FOREIGN RELIEF AID
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22Although two million Cambodians are facing famine, the Heng Samrin Government in Phnom Perth is obstructing the expansion of desperately needed foreign assistance, apparently for political reasons, according to diplomatic sources here and in Washington.

title: 2 World War II U.S. Fliers' Bodies Found on a French Alpine Glacier
description: CHAMBERY, France, Sept. 21 (UPI)  A mountain climber has found on an Alpine glacier the remains of two fliers. and the remnants of a United States warplane from World War II, the French police report.

title: In Franco's Spain
description: HIS is a city that has sinned greatly, and it must now be sanctified. Altars should be set up in every street to say masses continually. Thus spoke Franco's military commandant of Barcelona a few days after the Nationalist forces had marched into the Catalan capital iu January 1939. The Spanish Civil War had by then raged for two and a half years.

title: Marriage Announcement 14 -- No Title
description: Carol L. Zigarelli Is Married In Jersey to John S. DeBlois

title: A Medieval Irish Town
description: Mention Kilkenny and someone always says cats. No one could ever tell me why. Cats or no, Kilkenny sounded attractive with its medieval feast of abbeys and castles and ancient lanes, its shopper's delight in the Kilkenny Design Workshops, its inn once owned by a reputed witch.

title: STAMPS
description: The first major stamp issue for the 1980 Olympics, a setenant block of four heralding the Summer Games in the Soviet Union, is coming out this Friday as the Postal Service continues its allout effort to leave no American unaware that the Olympic Games are coming.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Of Special Interest

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  I Never Sang for My Father, in an Actor's CafTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Oct. 6). $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50; group rates. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: In Vargas Llosa's Peru
description: POX on translations! We long for a writer's natural line, and we usually get a voice that sounds broken and silly. It may not even be the translator's fault. How do you render the music of one language into another and still manage to hold on to the meaning of a word? And what if the prose has an unconventional music. a rhythm that depends heavily on the exact placement of words? Such Is the predicament The Cubs (Los Cachorros), the title piece Mario Vargas Llosa's first collection of stories in English.

title: PAYMENT OF SCOTTO IS CENTRAL TO TRIAL
description: Cash payments to Anthony M. Scotto have been clearly defined as the central issue in the powerful union leader's trial on Federal racketeering charges in Manhattan.

title: THE REDGLASSES LOOK: ANATOMY OF A FAD
description: Dennis Roberts may have started the fad that saw hundreds of thousands of American women buy rhinestonetrimmed eyeglasses back in 1970, but when glasses with red frames began selling well at his Optique Boutique last December, he did not sense that he was witness to a budding new phenomenon. Few of his celebrity clients wore glasses with red frames. No one he could name had been photographed in red frames. And Elton John  for whom his Sunset Boulevard emporium had made over 400 pairs of glasses  did not particularly favor his red ones. So if Los Angeles women in growing numbers were buying redframed glasses, Roberts concluded, it was because of Christmas.

title: Wendy Dixon, Stephen Fog Marry on L.I.
description: Wendy Merritt Dixon, daughter of Mrs. Lawrence H. Dixon of Lawrence, L.I., and the late Mr. Dixon, was married yesterday in TrinitySt. John's Episcopal Church in Hewlett, L.I., to Stephen Chase Fog, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mario A. Fog of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Earle Pratt performed the ceremony.

title: EngineerFencer Points to Olympics
description: STAN Lekach divides his life between one of the newest of sciences and one of the oldest of martial arts.

title: Marriage Announcement 15 -- No Title
description: Cynthia Seely Cotton Married to Peter Orrick

title: East Germans Open Stork Clinic
description: EAST BERLIN, Sept. 22 (Reuters) Bird lovers have opened a stork hospital in East Germany's southern village of Loburg as part of a nationwide campaign to protect the dwindling stork population, the East German press agency ADN reported today. The agency said that the hospital could accommodate 20 birds and would take in injured or sick storks from all over the country.

title: Backstage at Tanglewood to Be Enlarged
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra will spend over a halfmillion dollars reconstructing and enlarging the backstage area of the music shed at its summer home at Tanglewood, in Lenox, Mass. The project will be started after next season and should be completed in time for the summer of 1981, when the orchestra will observe its 100th anniversary.

title: Recollections Of Some Who Were There
description: TWO elderly women, decked out in flowered print dresses, supglasses  and raincoats, just in case  sat on a bench in Central Park the other day enjoying the sun. Asked for their memories of the Great Crash 50 years ago, one of them, Mrs. Lawrence Stern, recalled: I was living out in the country at the time. Hewlett, Long Island. I had two young children. When the market began to come down, my husband asked me if I thought we should get out, and I said yes.

title: Marriage Announcement 22 -- No Title
description: Karen Joan Terhune Engaged

title: Unit Asks City to Drop Westway And Focus on Community Needs
description: A panel of 17 present and former government officials, academics and business leaders has recommended that the city abandon largescale projects such as the Westway and the South Bronx and instead concentrate on developing small economic projects and on rehabilitating neighborhoods where neonle still live.

title: Melanie Taylor, Robert D. Orr Jr., Architects, Marry
description: Melanie Taylor and Robert D. Orr Jr., alumni of the Yale University School of Architecture, were married yesterday in the Branford Memorial Chapel on the Yale campus in New Haven. The Rev. Donna Schaper, assistant chaplain at Yale, performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 22 (UPI) Syed Ahmad Khomeini, the last surviving son of Iran's Islamic leader, today denounced summary executions of people found guilty of moral crimes.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Liberal Arts College, Living on Borrowed Time, Struggles to Find New Students
description: CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Sept. 21 Each application for admission is cause for celebration at Wilson College, so the arrival yesterday of the first deposit for next year's freshman class sent the admissions director racing to the president's office with the good news. Considering that the school was pronounced dead by its trustees last February, this preoccupation with vital signs is not surprising.

title: Limitations Can Be Overcome by Learning New Skills
description: Although Benny the pony ate a goodly amount of corn and cabbage when he broke into the vegetable garden, he was not even scolded. Why should we yell at him? 7yearold Douglas asked indignantly. We planted lots of vegetables and, besides, the pony gives us rides.

title: Oklahoma Town Tries to Forget Helicopter Plant That Didn't Fly
description: HOMINY, Okla., Sept. 22 (AP) Hidden in a municipal barn in this northeastern Oklahoma community is a dustcovered red, white and blue machine that some people would like to forget.

title: Since Population Means Money, 1980 HeadCounters Will Have to Be Careful
description: There was a time when the Federal Census simply charted every 10 years the growth of the United States from an infant country confined to the Eastern seaboard to a nation that spanned the continent. But no more. Now, as the Federal Government constantly expands its influence in state and local governments, population means money.

title: A London Hit Arrives  With a Controversial Heroine
description: LONDON Evita, the musical hit from London that opens Tuesday night at the Broadway Theater in New York City, where it has already rung up more than $2 million in advance ticket sales, has raised expectations as the first major new musical of the season. But the show, directed by Harold Prince and with lyrics by Tim Rice and music by Andrew Lloyd Webber, the authors of Jesus Christ Superstar, has, like its authors previous work, raised questions about its subject matter, questions which have necessitated some significant reshaping by Mr. Prince.

title: Property Suit Over Unmarried Relationship Barred
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 22 (AP) The Illinois Supreme Court has ruled that couples who share a sexual relationship but do not marry may not sue each other for a property settlement after the relationship ends.

title: Putting a Lid On Hospital Costs Eludes The Congress
description: WASHINGTON  A deadline for Congressional committee action on President Carter's plan to contain hospital costs came and went last week, to no one's great surprise. The proposal has been bounced from committee room to committee room on Capital Hill for nearly three years, and faces more jostling as the Administration pushes toward a showdown that it may have little chance of winning.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The solo may very well be the most daring of dance forms. Dancers who perform solos must stand alone before an audience and in some way persuade, entertain or amaze that audience. They have no one else to help them; only they can do it. Solos are hazardous; they're gambles.

title: Zia Denies Pakistan Builds Nuclear Bomb and Urges U.S. to Resume Aid
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 22 President Zia ulHaq denied today that Pakistan intended to make a nuclear bomb and said that he had appealed to President Carter to review the policy that resulted in a cutoff of American aid.

title: Convention Center Plan Divides Yonkers Leaders
description: YONKERS ADEVELOPER'S plan to build a hotel and convention center on a deteriorating and underutilized 13.5acre site on the Hudson River has met with skepticism from some of the city's business leaders and conservationists, who view the plan as unrealistic in scope and cost.

title: Blind Puerto Rican Named Head Of City's Office for Handicapped
description: Anthony Santiago, a 46yearold native of Puerto Rico who has been blind since the age of 10, is the new director of the city's Office for the Handicapped. Since 1973, Mr. Santiago has been director of community and continuing education programs at Hostos College, a unit of the City University of New York, in the Bronx, and for the last two years he was also acting president of the college.

title: The Prolific Telephone
description: For businessmen who perennially dream of leaving the bustle of modern life and escaping to a South Sea island where there are no telephones, time running out. A recent accounting of the world's telephones shows that silent paradise is increasingly harder to find.

title: Kerry A. Finneran, Researcher, Bride Of George Gardiner
description: Kerry Ann Finneran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Buckley Finneran of Ridgewood, N.J., was married in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday to George Couper Gibbs Gardiner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Asa Bird Gardiner 3d of Jacksonville, Fla. The Rev. Edwin J. Lisson performed the ceremony in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Byrd Says Arms Pact Could Still Be Acted on in '79

title: N.J. Taxpayers Lead Way In Footing Campaign Bills

His Republican opponent, Raymond H. Bateman, spent $1,642,017, including $1.009.720 from state tax funds.

title: QUIET MOVER OF THE
description: Last March, in understated contrast to that imminent spectacular, the first coming of Pope John Paul 11 to the United States on Oct. 1, a whitehaired German Jesuit named Karl Rahner arrived in New York from Munich as inconspicuously as a pensionedoff civil servant en route to visit relatives in Milwaukee. In fact, Karl Rahner made his way to that city to attend a theological symposium at Marquette University honoring him on his 75th birthday. He hitched a ride there from Chicago with a young Jesuit theologian in an aging, mudspattered car, and he stayed at his destination in a sparely furnished room with a bath down the hall.

title: A Very Personal Matter
description: OF all animals, man is apparently the only one who takes his own life, and he has been doing so with increasing frequency. Suicide statistics must be approached with caution, but there is evidence that in the United States and in much of Western Europe, the suicide rate among children and adolescents is rising. Women, who traditionally have attempted and failed to commit suicide more often than men, now are succeeding more frequently. Altogether, about 25,000 Americans kill themselves each year, making suicide the sixth or seventh largest cause of death. This statistic does not take into account fatal automobile accidents, drug overdoses and other accidental deaths, a significant percentage of which, experts believe, may actually be suicides.

title: Man, 81, and Sister, Tied Up by Burglars, Starve in Their Home

But that was the wrong address, and the elderly brother and sister starved to death before they were discovered a week later down the street at 432 West Walnut.

title: Development Activity Astir In the Financial District
description: Lagging a bit behind the recovery of midtown Manhattan, downtown has now gotten its second wind and will catch up in a big way if a number of recent construction plans are fulfilled.

title: CREATING THE ENERGYEFFICIENT
description: Welcome to the efficient society. Almost unnoticed, Americans have begun to save energy by wasting less. In the process, they have almost halted the growth in oil imports, lessened the drain on the dollar, deflected some inflationary forces, avoided a lot of pollution and eased the tension over such issues as nuclear power and strip mining. The nation remains in a difficult energy bind  there is absolutely no question about that  but these un heralded gains suggest that the country is, in fact, stumbling on a way out of that bind, one that is far less tortured and painful than many thoughtful people had feared. It is called energy efficiency.

title: Job Rights: Minorities In Focus
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH laws forbidding discrimination in employment have been on New Jersey's books since World Warn, the state is making a new effort to strengthen them, to widen their applicability and to use affirmative action to increase opportunities for women and members of minority groups.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Iam not going to tell you that actors and directors are crazy, because that would be either libelous or unnecessary. But I'll tell you this. When an actor or director, whether he's worked mostly in films or on the stage, sits down to write a jolly or perhaps profoundly philosophical volume of memoirs, he does it with just one thing in mind. He means to drive you crazy.

title: Screen: 'Rape of Love' by Miss Bellon:The Cast
description: Imagine a nice young Frenchwoman  no, imagine a perfect young Frenchwoman. She is kind, generous, intelligent and absolutely gorgeous. She has a loving fianc, devoted friends and an interesting career. And then, just after "Rape of Love" has invited the audience's unqualified respect and admiration for her, she is brutally attacked by four men, in a rape sequence that is long, vicious and almost unbearably harrowing. The emotional power of this episode is beyond question. At this point, the director, Yannick Bellon, has the audience in the palm of her hand.That Miss Bellon then proceeds to fritter away her film's forcefulness is both unfortunate and objectionable. An audience that has weathered such a grueling ordeal deserves to feel that it has witnessed these horrors for a reason. But the latter part of "Rape of Love" is nothing more urgent than dull, dutiful propaganda  a feminist comic strip, with dialogue that ought to be coming out of balloons. Kind, understanding woman lawyer: "A silent victim is an accomplice." Courageous rape victim: "I'll see it through." Victim's supportive best friend: "You're not alone."The rapists are presented in similar terms. While committing the crime, they demonstrate their hatred of women with clarity that would do a textbook proud, and at least one of the men indicates that he is covertly attracted to the others. Later, the ring-leader is seen at home, dandling his wife on his knee. "I'm scared of breaking my little woman," he jibes. "You don't mind my breaking my back doing laundry," says she.Much of "Rape of Love," which opens today at the Little Carnegie, plods along in this well-meaning but hopelessly didactic tone. Some children are seen playing, and they decide on a game of bank robbery  but a little girl, after anouncing she wants to be a gangster, is told,"Forget it, you're a teller," by a little boy. The rape victim and her friend visit a school and look at perhaps two dozen children's drawings, all of them saying the same thing: Mom does the cooking, and Dad goes to work. There is talk about how flowers are pollinated, and about whether rape exists in the animal kingdom. Every scene has a point, and every point is made in triplicate. Even the wispy, weepy theme song is played several different times.The trouble with such a commonsense approach is that the crime seems as much a violation of logic as of the victim's body. And Miss Bellon is so determined to present the issue in calm, considered terms that she neglects its terrifying irrationality. Indeed, in her film, the victim recovers more quickly and easily than perhaps the viewer will. When it is mentioned, months after the incident, that she has been afraid to make love with her fianc since the rape occurred, the information simply doesn't match what's on the screen. Despite her ordeal, she still seems as perfect as ever.Nathalie Nell, who plays the rape victim, is a lovely, gifted actress who makes "Rape of Love" more involving than it otherwise could be. Miss Nell has a cool beauty and a sharp, commanding gaze, qualities that don't exactly suit her character but certainly hold an audience's attention. It is never especially plausible that a woman of such fierce and evident pride would wait months before going to the police, or be in love with the kind of man who would regard an attack on her as an embarrassment rather than an outrage. But Miss Nell, who has made other films but has not previously been seen by American audiences, makes a spellbinding impression  the kind that guarantees she'll have a chance to work with material better suited to her talents later on.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY

title: Beauty
description: Cosmetics are becoming more like drugs, and dermatologists are going to be looking at them more like drugs, says Dr. Albert M. Kligman, professor of dermatology at the University of Pennsylvania Medical School. When cosmetic companies talk about makeup these days, you keep hearing the word treatment. They say, This is our treatment line, not This is our lipstick line. What they are telling the customer is: Use our products because your skin will not only look better, it will actually be better. If it is oily or dry or has spots, it will be improved.

title: James Baldwin Writing and Talking
description: IT'S true there's a fashion right now for the big novel, the one with historical sweep (in Hollywood they call it high arc), the family saga or the pseudoTolstoyan pseudoepic with both world wars in it. But not all temptations to bigness and historicity in a novel are corrupt. Especially to the lyrical novelist, to the visionary, they hold out the promise of grounding one's vision in acknowledged reality, of putting solid weight on insights that might otherwise seem too subjective, of giving one's ideas a foundation in known things.

title: GALLERY VIEW

Everything that they did is praised to the skies. Everything that happened to them is agreed to have been atrocious. They and their work are beyond criticism, and every penciled scrap that they left behind them is worth a great deal of money.

title: Stage: Equity Library Offers a Classic
description: Applaud the Equity Library Theater. It is doing The Sound of Music, and is performing it gracefully. This is no small matter, because The Sound of Music is abundant with sentimentality. The Equity Library Theater, however, pulls it off  narrowly, but it makes it.

title: The Sky Is Our Domain
description: AS to just what this ineffable quality was ... well, it obviously involved bravery. But it was not bravery in the simple sense of being willing to risk your life ... any fool could do that. ... No. the idea ... seemed to be that a man should have the ability to go up in a hurtling piece of machinery and ptit his hide on the line and then have the moxie, the reflexes, the experience, the coolness, to pull it back in the last yawning moment  and then to go up again the next day, and the next day, and every next day.... There was a seemingly infinite series of tests ...a dizzy progression of steps and ledges ... a pyramid extraordinarily high and steep; and the idea was to prove at every foot of the way up that pyramid that you were one of the elected and anointed ones who had the right stuff and could move higher and higher and even  ultimately, God willing, one day  that you might be able to join that special few at the very top, that elite who had the capacity to bring tears to men's eyes, the very Brother hood of the Right Stuff itself.

title: U.S. TO GAUGE IMPACT OF CHRYSLER FAILURE

title: The Flute Attains Solo Status

A relatively natural instrument that is both easy to make and easy to play in its simplest form, the flute is common to primitive cultures around the world, and archeologists working at sites of ancient civilizations invariably dig up more ornate flutes of bronze and ivory, or at least representations of flautists in wall paintings.

title: Ancient Statue Stolen in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 22 (Reuters)  A tiny gold figure known as the Million Dollar Man but valued at about half that was stolen yesterday from a London jeweler, Scotland Yard said today. The 2,00yearold figure of a Persian man was part of a collection at Spink and Son Jewelers that was to be auctioned in Zurich next month.

title: Villella Begins Sharpening the Eglevsky Repertory
description: THE style is not right there, said a jeanclad Edward Villella to a group of dancers. You've lost the Classical line, and without that you haven't got anything  no style, nothing.

title: Letters TO THE EDITOR
description: It's interesting to note in Desmond Smith's article (Television Enters the 80's, Aug. 19) that NBC's primetime programs were aimed at what the programmers derisively referred to as Billy and Mary SixPack. It's very probable that the quality of NBC's prime time programming reflected that derision, and that even Billy and Mary's sixpack consumption hadn't dulled their sensibilities to the fact that they were being treated scornfully.

title: New York State Has 300 Potential Sites for Generators
description: Back in 1783, Matthew Lyon built the first waterpowered sawmill in the United States,ushering in over a century of waterpowered textile, paper and iron mills.

title: The Federal Pickpocket
description: With the interest rates that banks charge their customers hitting new peaks almost daily, the time has come to remove the regulations that now limit how much banks and savings and loan associations can pay their small depositors. These regulations limit the small saver to a 5 percent rate of return while inflation is running at 12 percent or higher. And while such savers are losing 7 percent on their savings, the unregulated market for large savers  of $100,000 or more is paying 12 percent. The large saver at least breaks even with inflation; the small saver suffers losses because of the Government's Regulation Q.

title: A Tree Planted Now Gets a Grip on Its Site
description: IF you are one of those people who lost a tree in recent storms, you may be considering a replacement. Or perhaps you have an old, halfrotted tree that is causing some concern and should be taken down. Whatever your reason for considering a new tree, fall is an excellent time to plant one.

title: Public Theater Will Show Mizoguchi Film Festival
description: The Saga of Kenji Mizoguchi, a threeweek festival devoted to the work of the Japanese film maker, will be presented by Joseph Papp's Film at the Public program in association with the FDM Foundation for the Arts, starting Tuesday.

title: Unlikely RoundtheWorld Sailor Learned Haw on the Way
description: Naomi James, a 29yearold former hairdresser who grew up on a landlocked New Zealand dairy farm, sailed 30,000 miles around the world last year in a 53foot sloop, beating Sir Francis Chichester's record for speed and becoming the first woman to do it alone.

title: Article 8 -- No Title
description: CENTURY VILLAGEBOCA RATON 1BR 1 bth oelux avail immed. $40,500. Anytime 212 5395459 or 516 23968501

title: Questions/Answers
description: I have had for untold years an areca palm which is now touching the ceiling. Can I cut off the roots and push the stem down into the pot so it will reroot? Mrs. V.B., Jackson Heights, N.Y.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: BROOKVILLE  Faculty art exhibition; through Oct. 5; Hillwood Commons, C. W. Post Center. For hours 2992233.

title: Fall Might As Well Be Spring
description: AUTUMN is as good a time as spring to think about things that grow. While certain plants  annuals and vegetables among themcannot be started in the fall, others do nicely in the season of early dusks and orange leaves.

title: Hockey Federation Backs Canada Cup
description: THE HAGUE, Sept. 23 (AP)  The International Ice Hockey Federation has given Canadian delegates official approval to start a regularly scheduled Canada Cup next fall.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How is the site of the Soccer Bowl chosen? Why is there no allstar game in the North American Soccer League, as there is in the American Soccer League?

title: Six Inquiries Seek the Lessons of Three Mile Island
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  In a warehouse a few miles south of the United States Capitol is a fullscale mockup of the control room of the Three Mile Island nuclear reactor.

title: Recital: Joyce Mathis Heard in Song Program
description: TASTE, intelligence, thoughtful programming and solid musicianship characterized Joyce Mathis's recital yesterday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall. Even with all these good things, one sometimes wondered if the soprano had really chosen the best material for her voice, which did not consistently respond to all the demands she made upon it.

title: China and Wildlife Group Agree On Help for Endangered Species
description: PEKING, Sept. 23  China signed an agreement with the World Wildlife Fund today that is expected to lead soon to international exchanges to help preserve some of China's endangered animal species.

title: Many Widows Find A New Life Running Husband's Business
description: For 38 years, says Evelyn Borgenicht, I was a suburban mommy. She raised fouechildren, she did volunteer work in her Westchester community, she listened with sympathetic interest every night when her husband came home and told her how things had gone at work, in the business he had started in 1930 and run ever since.

title: Balloonists Set for Trip After 22 Cancellations
description: TILLAMOOK, Ore., Sept. 23 (AP) A crosscountry odyssey that the participants hope will be the first nonstop transcontinental flight in a balloon is scheduled to begin tomorrow morning.

title: Politics of the Papal Trip
description: OXFORD, England  Officially, Pope John Paul II's visit to the United States has no political implicationsit is spiritual in tone and pastoral in purpose; but it would be naive to take these views at face value. The Pope, on the international scene, is head of the Vatican City state. It may be a tiny state, but it allows the Pope, in the jargon of international affairs, to be a transnational actor.

title: Opera: City Troupe Offers Count Ory
description: EVEN during the bel canto craze after World War H, one masterpiece of the genre was conspicuously missing: Rossini's Count Ory, one of his last operas (it was composed in 1828 and Rossini stopped composing operas after 1829). In New York there were performances by small groups, but neither the Metropolitan Opera nor New York City Opera ever staged it. Last night the City Opera corrected the omission, and Count Ory entered its repertory.

title: Townies in Boston Still Have High Hopes
description: BOSTON, Sept. 23  Three and a half centuries have passed since John Winthrop and a band of English families landed at Charlestown, across the harbor from what is now downtown Boston, to colonize a continent.

title: U.S. Fuel Standards Questioned
description: The savings expected under a Federal program designed to increase the fuel efficiency of autos are unlikely to be realized over the long term, according to a analysis to be released today by a Bostonbased management consulting and research firm.

title: Making a Vonnegut Novel Sing
description: THE characters in Kurt Vonnegut's sardonic novel God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater are alive and well and singing these days in an old ballroom of the Ukrainian National Home on Second Avenue and East Ninth Street. They have stepped out of the pages of Mr. Vonnegut's 1965 book into a new musical comedy now in rehearsal and being produced by the author's 28yearold daughter, Edith.

title: U. S. Soldiers Morale Is High At NATO Exercises in Europe
description: HOHENFELS, West Germany,  Cpl. Marion Hayes okulted himself lucky. He had had three hours sleep the night before. Now he and the others of his scout platoon were filtering across narrow valleys and heavily wooded hills to find the enemy.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE EXECUTIONER'S SONG. By Norman Mailer. 1,056 pages. Little, Brown. $16.95.

title: Notes on People
description: A footnote or two to recent American history emerged over the weekend with disclosures about taped Interviews with Robert F. Kennedy that are being stored in the John F. Kennedy Library, scheduled to open on Oct. 20.

title: Judicial Panel Studying High Court In Pennsylvania Over Rizzo Ruling
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 23 (UPI) The Pennsylvania Supreme Court is undergoing a rare review by a judicial panel because the Chief Justice has suggested that improper influence played a part in a decision favoring Mayor Frank L. Rizzo of Philadelphia.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Memorial for Stanley Levison

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 24,1979

title: Obituary 9 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Sporting Gear
description: Boatowners who fear the moment when their electrical equipment mysteriously dies out may be aided with a Unity Marine transient voltage suppressor. The boxinclosed unit is a solidstate electronic clamping device for controlling surges of high voltage from the boat's power source. The unit protects electrical gear and increases the operating life by dissipating temporary surges of energy from the various motors, transformers, relays and other equipment on the same circuit. Ranging in price from $98 to $558 in AC and DC models, they can be ordered through Griffith Marine Navigation, 134 North Avenue, New Rochelle, N.Y. 10801, (914) 6364340 or (212) 8285554.

title: Elderly Called Mail Fraud Target
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI)  The Postal Service's fourth annual Postal Consumer Protection Week begins tomorrow with a warning that elderly people are often targets of mail fraud. Postmaster General William Gordon said the elderly were prime targets because they are trying to protect their savings from the effects of inflation. Typical examples of such conspiracies. the Postal Service said, include various investment offers, phony franchises, miraculous cures for illnesses and workathome plans.

title: Chess:
description: Playing to obtain the bishop pair, often a valid strategy, can be overworked. The slight advantage of two bishops over a bishop and a knight or two knights is not worth dislocating a position for.

title: Brock Steals No. 938 In Met Home Finale
description: Lou Brock of St. Louis became the unquestioned career leader in stolen bases yesterday as the New York Mets rang down the curtain on their season at Shea Stadium in the same fashion in which they had begun the 1979 campaign. They lost.

title: Robbery at Brooklyn Synagogue Fails to Halt Religious Services
description: A dozen members of a Brooklyn synagogue were robbed of cash and jewelry worth more than $1,000 by three men Saturday, but they completed their Rosh haShanah service before reporting the robbery, the police said yesterday.

title: Fought Birdies 18th To Win 2d Straight
description: NAPA, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP)  John Fought broke out of a fiveway tie for the lead with a birdie on the final hole today and won his second consecutive PGA Tour event, the $300,000 Napa Classic.

title: On the Road, Going Nowhere, With the Yankees
description: TORONTO GOING nowhere in the American League, but going firstclass, the Yankees last week boarded a chartered jet at La Guardia Airport and flew into the chilly Midwest to play with diminished passion a summer game as autumn approached.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amstar Corporation, a sugar producer, has elected William C. Shanley 3d a corporate vice president and president of the American Sugar division.

title: Autumn Makes a Bow as Summer Lingers On
description: Right on its celestial cue, autumn made a brilliant entrance yesterday morning and then withdrew to the wings after only a modest intrusion on the summer scene in and near New York City.

title: Rhodesia Conference: Future Clouded by Questions
description: LONDON, Sept. 23  Agreement by the Salisbury regime to accept in principle Britain's proposals for a new Zimbabwe Rhodesia Constitution answered one question, but it raised a halfdozen others.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TODAY

title: Pop: Springsteen Makes Biggest Impact at Antinuclear Benefit
description: TO judge from the expectation and applause at Friday night's concert, Bruce Springsteen made by far the biggest impact of any of the performers at the five nights of antinuclearprosolar benefit concerts at Madison Square Garden, which ended last night.

title: Flanagan's 23d Beats Indians
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 23 (UPI) Mike Flanagan pitched a twohitter to earn his 23d victory today, enabling the Baltimore Orioles to score a 31 decision over the Cleveland Indians. It was the Orioles' 100th triumph of the season and gave them a split of their doubleheader with the Indians.

title: Sindona Photo Received;  Kidnap Report Bolstered
description: ROME, Sept. 22  A photograph of a haggard Michele Sindona and a list of 10 questions about his financial dealings have been received by his lawyers here in a letter postmarked in Brooklyn, increasing the belief among lawenforcement authorities that he may indeed be a kidnap victim.

title: Some Democrats Say Carter Offers Census Jobs to Allies
description: President Carter plans to use some 275,000 census jobs  a onceadecade patronage bonanza  to line up support for his renomination campaign, Democratic Representatives from New York and other states contended yesterday.

title: Last Week's Active Issues
description: For the week ended September 21, 1979

title: American Aides Voice Concern Over Arrest of Haitian Politician
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  United States officials here and in Haiti have expressed concern over the Aug. 30 arrest of Sylvio Claude, founder of the Haitian Christian Democratic Party, one of the first independent political parties to operate openly in Haiti in 22 years.

title: Around the Nation
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (AP)  Officials have estimated that the major brush fires in southern California in the past week had cost fire agencies millions of dollars in unbudgeted, emergency funds.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Even though the Federal Reserve Board raised the discount rate last week to a record 11 percent and commercial banks posted unprecedented prime rates of 13 percent, prices in the credit markets advanced on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, pushing rates downward.

title: Suzanna Yeh Wed To a Coast Lawyer
description: Suzanna Yeh, a student at the University of California at Berkeley, was married in Berkeley yesterday to John Plotz, an Oakland, Calif., lawyer. The ceremony was performed at the home of Julie Conger by Judge Marylin Patel of the OaklandPiedmont Municipal Court.

title: Miss Post Wins by 2
description: OVERLAND PARK, Kan., Sept. 23 (AP)  Sandra Post fired three straight birdies on her way to a threeunderpar 70 today to register a twostroke victory in the $100,000 Kansas City Classic.

title: Lebanon Accuses Israel Of Drive Across Frontier
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 23 (Reuters)  The staterun Beirut radio said today that several Israeli armored vehicles had crossed the border and were heading for the southern Lebanese village of Kafr Kila.

title: 8Day Preparation Begun By Cooke for Pope's Visit
description: Marching onto the sunbathed playing field at Yankee Stadium at the end of a procession of 300 redandwhitegarbed priests, Terence Cardinal Cooke yesterday began an eightday period of spiritual preparation by Roman Catholics in the New York metropolitan area for next week's visit by Pope John Paul II to New York City.

title: The Editorial Notebook Till Taxes Do Us Part
description: Like tens of thousands of affluent couples, David and Angela Boyter enjoy a week or two in the Caribbean each winter. But the Boyters add a wrinkle: They use their time in the sun to obtain a quickie divorce. Then, when they return home, they get married again. There is method to this madness. By ending the year as single adults, they can cut their Federal income taxes by a fourth.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: ESSAY Rejected Counsel Returns
description: WASHINGTON  I am pleased to see that Ted Kennedy has on his staff a Rejected Counsel. That used to be my job in the White House: to go into the President's office before a major decision and say, Do the popular thing. Take the easy way. Later, in a ringing speech, the President could truthfully say, Some of my advisers have told me to do the popular thing, to take the easy way. I have rejected such counsel....

title: Penn State's Defeat Buoys Rivals in East
description: Penn State has dominated football in the East so much during the last dozen years that fans of other teams dream of winning the Lambert Trophy as often as Republicans must muse over chances of getting a majority in Congress. The Nittany Lions have taken the award as the top major college team in the East 10 times in the last 12 years.

title: F.C.C. WILL CONSIDER A PLAN FOR PAY TV
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  The Federal Communications Commission will take up Tuesday a new proposal to cultivate the growth of pay television broadcasting, a medium that has achieved little attention in the past.

title: Diana L. Stark Is Married To James Stuart Francis
description: Diana Lynn Stark, a manager in the publicrelations department of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States in New York, was married yesterday to James Stuart Francis, an associate in the corporate finance department of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, also in New York.

title: Reds Defeat Astros For 1Game Lead
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 23  The Cincinnati Reds had started their two best pitchers on Friday and Saturday nights, and had finished with two losses. Their lead over the Houston Astros in the National League's Western Division had shtrunk to halt a game after scoring only three runs in two games. They had come to the Astrodome with a 2game lead, but today they were playing for first place.

title: West Germany Revalues the Mark; European Move Tied to Dollar Ills
description: GENEVA, Monday, Sept. 24  West Germany early this morning bowed to mounting pressure on the foreignexchange markets and agreed to revalue the mark against other leading European currencies.

title: Kennedy Jet Diverted to Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP)  An American Airlines Boeing 707 en route to Las Vegas, Nev., landed without difficulty here today after its landing gear failed to retract following takeoff from Kennedy International Airport in New York, authorities said. The pilot of charter flight 9565, carrying 173 passengers, notified authorities after the problem developed that he was going to Chicago's O'Hare International Airport.

title: Cable Television Plan Will Provide Students View of Government
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Thousands of high school civics students will be able to tune in to the Washington political scene right in their classrooms this winter through a new cable television arrangement.

title: TV: Last Convertible, A 3Part Series on NBC
description: AS a novel and now as a television small series, beginning tonight at 9 on NBC, Anton Myrer's The Last Convertible is less an exploration than reconstruction. Designed as a tribute to the generation that matured in the 40's and 50's, the story offers a 1938 Packard Super 8 convertible as a symbol for a golden dream of youth, of careless freedom, of personal style.

title: Uruguay Eases Its Iron Control But Bars Dissent
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 19Though opposition leaders assert that Uruguay is still a police state, the military regime has reined in the more violent excesses of its security system and won a partial lifting of a ban on military and economic assistance that was imposed by the United States in 1976.

title: TV Workshop Creates Science Series.
description: The Children's Television Workshop, the nonprofit organization that created the revolutionary publictelevision series Sesame Street in 1969 and The Electric Company two years later before venturing into adult progratnming, is returning to the children's sphere with a new $11.7 million science series to begin in January on the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Wambaugh Is Filming. His Books His Way
description: LOS ANGELES JOE WAMBAUGH  police officer turned novelist turned movie producer  crouches in the corner of a Hollywood restaurant watching Paula Prentiss and Robert Foxworth speak words from his script of his bestselling novel The Black Marble. Motionless, his sharp eyes fixed on the actors like a cobra eyeing its dinner, his intensity is overpowering.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an error by The Associated Press, an article in The Times yesterday incorrectly reported the opening date of Philadelphia's Fairmont Hotel, once known as the Bellevue Stratford. The renovated hotel will open Wednesday.

title: Royals Win on A's Error
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP)  A fielding error by Wayne Gross at third base allowed the Kansas City Royals to score three unearned runs in the fourth inning today on their way to a 42 victory over the Oakland A's.

title: Commodities
description: Platinum, even higher priced than gold, advanced sharply last week, with the October delivery contract closing on Friday at a record $493.60 after two consecutive days of $20 limit advances. Other platinum contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange showed similar gains.

title: Uganda and Tanzania: Stuck With the Status Quo
description: ENTEBBE, Uganda, Sept. 19  Whenever President Godfrey L. Binaisa talks about Uganda's languishing economy and its internal security problems, his conversation invariably turns to Tanzania, whose troops set in motion events that led to his becoming President three months ago.

title: Expos Win, Retain Lead
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (AP) Andre Dawson hit two basesempty home runs and Chris Speier drove in three runs, allowing the Montreal Expos to retain a halfgame lead over Pittsburgh in the National League Eastern Division with a 74 victory over Philadelphia today.

title: Patriots Hold Off Chargers, 2721
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. 23  The New England Patriots, a team as well endowed with fine athletes as any in pro football, confound their supporters. The Patriots are capable of playing superbly in spurts but seldom for the duration of a game. Often they commit a blunder, and sometimes they pay for it.

title: Census Bureau Plans 2 Surveys To Update Consumer Price Index
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)  The Census Bureau is planning two surveys of consumer spending this fall to help update the Consumer Price Index.

title: The Visitor From Tibet
description: The scene that has charmed us the most during the Dalai Lama's visit to the United States is, we admit, parochial, even political, although he has been scrupulously neither. One day, the Dalai Lama (whose name means something like ocean of wisdom) was touring New York in his maroon robes. As he headed for his limousine, a big New York cop shouted, Get out of the way of His Majesty!  and someone said, Hey, you know who that guy is? That's the King of Tibet!  and then an onlooker wearing a threepiece suit and eating a bean sprout sandwich said, Far out.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON IT looks as though Congress will finally repeal one of the most complicated taxlaw provisions ever enacted. And it seems it will be done by getting around a threatened Presidential veto.

title: Maine Women Win N.Y. Rugby Classic
description: The Portland (Me.) Women's Rugby Football Club beat the Boston Women's Rugby Football Club yesterday, 40, to win the second annual Big Apple Women's Rugby Classic. The event was held at the fields adjoining Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

title: Sports Briefs
description: Fluorescent Light, ridden by Jeff Fell, held off a late rush from Tiller yesterday to win the 78th running of the Manhattan Handicap at Belmont Park. The margin was threequarters of a length.

title: Kissinger Memoirs: Frank Views but No Surprises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The first excerpts from Henry A. Kissinger's memoirs were published today and although they contain no startling revelations, they do have some candid impressions of former President Nixon and Chinese and Soviet leaders.

title: Islanders and Flyers Tie
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (AP) Rick Macleish scored on a 30foot shot with 1 minute 39 seconds remaining to give the Philadelphia Flyers a 11 tie against the New York Islanders in a National Hockey League preseason game.

title: Susan Kane Wed To B. G. Palitz Jr.
description: The marriage of Susan L. Kane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Kane of Waldwick, N.J., to B. Gregory Palitz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Palitz of Newtown, Conn., took place yesterday at the Harmonie Club. State Supreme Court Justice Burton Roberts performed the ceremony.

title: Chinese Report Surge Of Some Cancer Types Among Local Groups
description: CANTON, Sept. 20  China is suffering from high incidence of four types of cancer, three of them so clearly localized that cancer specialists hope that it will be possible to identify the causes.

title: Theater in Seattle Is Seeking Scripts
description: Seattle's Empty Space Theater, which is beginning its 10th season, is accepting scripts for its third New Playwrights Forum.

title: Dean Ineffective Against Eagles
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 23  The last time Randy Dean started a game at Giants Stadium, fans were outside burning tickets.

title: Gulf Oil, After Dry Spell, Regains Investor Favor
description: Only a few years ago, the Gulf Oil Corporation seemed to be in sad shape. By the end of 1976, the company had suffered six straight quarterly earnings declines, and the pinch was on. In a remarkably candid address to shareholders a year and a half ago, Jerry McAfee, Gulf's chairman, announced a series ot Deittigntening moves, incluciing a layoff of whitecollar workers, something almost unheard of in the oil industry.

title: TV's Katie Kelly: Feisty Critic With Folksy Taste
description: You weigh 96 pounds with your glasses on, you've never quite lost that Nebraska twang and at 41 years of age your hair has turned gray and you're an outofwork journalist. All of a sudden, the phone rings and there's this guy on the other end asking if you might like to stop by NBC's studios the next day to join the evening news as a television critic.

title: Talks Scheduled in Airline Strike
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 (UPI)  Representatives of Ozark Air Lines and striking flight attendants arte scheduled to meet tomorrow for the first time since the walkout began Sept. 14, halting the airline's 195 daily flights in a dispute over wages and insurance benefits.

title: U.S. Skaters Inspire Olympic Optimism
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 23 Charlie Tickner watched Jan Hoffmann of East Germany skate carefully to complete an intricate circle while judges hovered nearby to rate the quality of the school figure on the ice.

title: Bucs Sink Rams and Stay Unbeaten
description: During 1976 and 1977, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers lost the first 26 National Football League games they played. Last season they attained respectability with a 511 season. And now, in their fourth season, the Bucs seem to be a legitimate contender for honors in the National Conference's Central Division.

title: The City
description: The Federal Government has indicated that it will probably not approve New York City's request for a test program in which welfare recipients and their landlords would both be required to endorse welfare checks, the city's Deputy Mayor for Operations said.

title: Eleventh Annual AfricanAmerican Day Parade Marches Through Harlem
description: Blowing his euphonium, this marcher, along with more than 10,000 others from the tristate area, stepped along Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard yesterday from 111th to 142d Streets as more than 100,000 delighted spectators watched. On hand for the event were many of the city's black leaders, including Basil A. Paterson, Secretary of New York State, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Judge Bruce Wright and Assemblyman Estella B. Diggs.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Sports World Specials
description: Healthy for the first time in almost two years, Walt Frazier is working out twice a day with the Cleveland CavaHers, preparing for what may be his final season as a basketball player.

title: Bokassa Successor Says Dictator Killed Children in April Massacre
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic, Sept. 23 (Reuters)  President David Dacko, who overthrew Emperor Bokassa I in a bloodless coup last week, said today that the deposed dictator of the Central African Empire had personally murdered children in a massacre last April.

title: Bridge:
description: It is broadly true, sad to say, that large metropolitan areas, high standards of play and low standards of manners tend to go together. The farther one moves from New York, Chicago or Los Angeles, the more ability and discourtesy decline. There are, of course, many ??otable individaul exceptions on both sides of the equation, but the tendency is clear.

title: Bishop in Iowa Hopes That Pope Will Discuss Use of Land in U.S.
description: DES MOINES, Sept. 18  The solitary dream of one Corn Belt farmer has given Middle Western Roman Catholics a chance to raise some of the most pointed questions about religion's role that Pope John Paul II is likely to encounter on his trip to the United States.

title: Kennedy Candidacy a Big Topic At Michigan Republicans' Parley
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Sept. 23  His name was not on the guest list or even the agenda, but when 1,150 Michigan Republicans met here this weekend, Senator Edward M. Kennedy was at least as prominent a topic of the Republican Presidential hopefuls who turned up to advertise themselves.

title: Black Family That Was Burned Out Moves Into Rebuilt L.I. Horne
description: DEER PARK, L.I., Sept. 23  It was raining Friday night as Thomas and Vernerva Mosley moved into their new house but, as Mr. Mosley sat down for his first breakfast there yesterday morning, he insisted, When it rains, that's good luck.

title: Final Tentative Accord Is Reached In Midwest Grain Handlers' Strike
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 23 (UPI)  The last of eight tentative agreements was reached today in the 12week grain handlers strike that has cost an estimated $1 billion in losses to farm economies in Upper Middle Western states.

title: Gold Traders' Hectic World
description: John Ezzo trades gold every day. Or, more precisely, he buys and sells promises to trade gold some time in the future. Occasionally he trades for himself, but mostly he trades for customers of the firm he works for, MintzMarcus & Company. Either way, he never sees any gold.

title: The Region
description: The Hancock, N.Y., summer home of Charlotte Louise Rivenburgh, an official of the Metropolitan Museum of Art who was slain a halfmile from her Delaware County retreat on Aug. 16, has been destroyed by fire of undetermined origin, according to state police investigators. They said no links between the blaze and the murder had been established.

title: Palestinian Guerrillas March for Libya's Leader
description: Col. Muammar elQaddafi, Libya's head of state, reviewed military parade in Tripoli recently, marking the 10th anniversary of his rise to power. Among those participating in the parade were Palestinian guerrillas, below, who are reportedly being trained in Libya. Colonel Qaddafi assumed power in 1969 after overthrowing King Idris.

title: Sol Goldberg, 73; Was President Of Grayson Fabrics for 27 Years
description: Sol Goldberg, president of Grayson Fabrics Inc., died Saturday at the Peninsula General Hospital in Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 73 years old and was a resident of Rockaway Park, Queens.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, SEPT.25 QUEEN ELIZABETH 2 (Cunard Line). Left Southampton Sept. 21; due 9 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Civil Rights and the Budgeters
description: Whatever troubles President Carter may have with minority groups on other fronts, his Administration has done well on civil rights enforcement. It has revamped the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare has worked doggedly to desegregate Southern colleges. Now the Office of Management and Budget is creating its own civil rights unit to watch over Federal agencies.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: BENJAMIN CONSOR

title: More Outside Directors Listed
description: Outside directors now outnumber members of company management on the boards of hundreds of the nation's major corporations by an average of about two to one.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Outdoors: Angling for Trout in a Truly Remote Setting
description: SUNDERLAND, Vt. SLIPPING out of my pack on the south shore of 48acre Bourn Pond in the Lye Brook Wilderness Area of the Green Mountain National Forest, I was content.

title: Angels Maintain ThreeGame Lead
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP) Carney Lansford's threerun homer highlighted a sixrun, fifthinning rally today, and Dave Frost pitched a sixhitter as the California Angels beat the Texas Rangers. 61.

title: Film: Nunez's 'Gal Young Un':In Florida's Backwoods
description: IT is the Prohibition Era, the late 1920's, and the place is the backwoods country of Florida, which, though no part of it is much more than an hour's drive from the sea, is light-years away from the fancy resorts that stretch alone Florida's Atlantic and Gulf Coasts. Mattie, a middle-aged widow, lives alone on a substantial spread in the pinewoods. She's not a recluse but she has given up society. It's easier that way. She works her place for her immediate needs, pays her bills on time, takes care of her cat and smokes a pipe to relax. Within her community, Mattie is a woman of property.Enter Trax, a no-good, untrustworthy, womanizing scamp with a gift of gab and an air of totally bogus gallantry. Trax, in need of money, courts Mattie, who is old enough to be his mother. Mattie is charmed as much by the transparency of his courtship as by his energy and youth.Finally, when Trax proposes, Mattie feels compelled to ask why he'd want to marry someone as old and tired as she is. Trax hesitates, then says with as much conviction as he's ever mustered, "Why not? There's not a thing wrong with you.""Gal Young Un," an astonishingly good first feature, written, directed, photographed, edited and produced by Victor Nuez, is the story of the peculiar marriage of Mattie and Trax, in which Trax, after fighting a losing battle against his natural inclinations, embraces them wholeheartedly. By threatening to leave her, he blackmails the law-abiding Mattie to finance his moonshine operation and to become his chief distiller. Soon enough Trax is spending most of his time in the big cities, attending to his business and living high on the profits.Trax comes home only to pick up another load of liquor and to leave his laundry for Mattie to wash. She doesn't complain. She bides her time, but if you think Mattie will be bested by Trax, you don't know the kind of woman she is, or the kind of writer Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings was."Gal Young Un," based on Mrs. Rawlings's 1932 story, is a most invigorating and comic film, though I don't think there's one actual laugh in it. However, make no mistake about it, it is funny, partly because it's so far from being a tragedy. Though she's no earth mother, Mattie is healthily robust, a woman of substantial reserves. She keeps her own counsel, and her reaction to Trax's predictable ways is touching, sweet and surprisingly satisfying.The film will be shown at the Paramount Theater today at 9 P.M. as part of the Festival of Independent American Films being held in conjunction with the forthcoming New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center. It will be shown again tomorrow at the Paramount at 3 P.M.I know very little about Mr. Nuez except that he lives and works in Florida, but if he's representative of our new regional film makers, things are looking up."Gal Young Un" is a very good, fully realized movie, shot in the Florida back country that so fascinated Mrs. Rawlings ("South Moon Under," "The Yearling," etc.). Further, it has three extraordinarily effective leading performances.Though Dana Preu, who plays Mattie, is an English professor and has apparently never acted before, she is riveting to watch. Hers is the kind of face the camera loves to read, though it can never see everything. Something is always held in reserve. I'm not sure if this is acting but the result is clearly a performance.That David Peck, who plays Trax, is an actor is evident in the richness of detail in his comic deceit. His Trax is the sort of cad who always seems to be aware of how dreadfully he's behaving, though that never stops him from going right on. The third important cast member is a young actress named J. Smith, who plays the waif Trax takes up with for a while and then, when he tires of her, more or less abandons with Mattie. This girl, Elly, never says very much but she doesn't have to. She possesses the biggest, most expressive eyes you may have seen all year.The film's period details and technical credits are first-rate. Especially good are Mr. Nuez's camera work and the country-music score by Charles Engstrom. I'd also like to mention Pat Gabriel, who in addition to being the film's grip, is credited as the trainer of Mattie's cat. This cat, a large, handsome yellow creature, doesn't do tricks. Like Spencer Tracy, it never appears to be acting. It simply behaves  beautifully  and never once does it stare at the camera. As superior cat performances go, it's a match for the cat that Robert Altman used so hilariously in "The Long Goodbye."

title: President Asserts Jewish Leaders Did Not Pressure Him to Dismiss Young
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  President Carter declared today that no American Jewish leaders or anyone else urged him to seek the resignation of Andrew Young, whose tenure as thief United States delegate to the United Nations ended this afternoon with the swearingin of his successor, Donald F. McHenry, at a White House ceremony.

title: Treasury to Tap Market
description: The Treasury is scheduled to come to the credit markets three days this week to sell $17.55 billion of bills and notes to refinance maturing debt and to raise $480 million more to help bridge its everwidening fiscal gap. The notes may carry record yields, and the bills will be near their recent highs.

title: 10 Injured as Car Crashes Into Nathan's at Coney I.
description: An outofcontrol car crashed into Nathan's Famous restaurant at Coney Island yesterday afternoon, severing the arm of a 30yearold woman, who was immediately flown by helicopter to Bellevue Hospital where surgeons were trying to reattach the arm early this morning.

title: Knicks Lose Preseason Opener
description: LANSING, Mich., Sept. 23 (AP) Gregory Keiser, a rookie forward making his first National Basketball Association appearance, led the Detroit Pistons to a 10495 victory over the New York Knicks in the opening preseason game for both teams.

title: Constance Marshall Married To Mark S. Kolber, a Broker
description: Constance J. Marshall, a psychiatric social worker, was married yesterday to Mark Stephen Kolber, a member of the American Stock Exchange. The ceremony was performed in the Terrace Restaurant at Butler Hall on the campus of Columbia University by Cantor David Benedict.

title: Shanghai Mayor Reports a Rise  In Smashing and Looting Cases
description: PEKING, Sept. 23 (Reuters)  Hooliganism and violence are on the increase in Shanghai, China's largest city, and public order has been seriously disrupted, according to the city's mayor.

title: Banks Close to Assets Milestone
description: The BankAmerica Corporation and Citicorp are likely to reach a milestone in banking by the end of this quarter, commanding total resources of $100 billion each.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising
description: THE magazinepublishing community is being offered an opportunity to step into the future by two young men from Denver who have harnessed the power of the computer in hopes of pleasing consumers, advertisers and publishers.

title: Volcker's Rate Policy: 6 Weeks of Sharp Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  For the six weeks he has been chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker has spoken with a clear voice, maintaining steadfastly that expansion of the money supply must be curbed if inflation is to be brought under control.

title: Bumped Air Travelers May Collect Up to $400
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI)  Passengers who are bumped involuntarily from an overbooked passenger plane can collect up to $400 from the offending airline, according to the Civil Aeronautics Board.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DANSE A MIDI The 10yearold Dance Theater of Harlem spent most of last month in the British Isles. In London, the dancers were acclaimed as the dancing wonder of Harlem. Black dance, one writer said, uses the flexible pelvis, classical ballet a straight back, and the Harlem dancers slip easily from one language to another, extending the whole range of dance options as they do so. They were described as exhilaratingly in unison because they are so innately musical.

title: Four Gas Concerns Plan Pipeline System
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (Reuters)  The Peoples Gas Company said Its Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America subsidiary and three other interstate gas transmission concerns signed definitive agreements last week to build a $400 million pipeline system.

title: De Gustibus
description: In an article on the cooking of Spain, I outlined in considerable detail the recipes of perhaps the best Spanish cook I know, Penelope Casas. I noted that Penny, as she is known to her friends, is Americanborn of Greek parents but married to Luis Casas, a urologist who is Spanish.

title: Calcutta's Ruling Marxists Shun Reformer Label
description: CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 19  At the headquarters of the Communist Party of IndiaMarxist, on Alimuddin Street in a typically rotting neighborhood of this pervasively rotting city, R. K. Nag, showed tolerant bemusement as he explainea to a visitor that just because his party had come to power through democratic means did not suggest that it had forsaken its revolutionary character.

title: Bombs Go Off Near Irish Border
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 23 (Reuters)  Bombs destroyed a pub and part of the post office today in Forkill, a village near the border with Ireland known to be a stronghold for the Irish Republican Army. No one was injured in the explosions.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON  That Henry Kissinger did not welcome a documented account of his role in the Cambodian tragedy was no surprise. But few would have guessed at the depths of anxiety and anger he revealed in a letter to the editor of The Economist, excerpted on this page yesterday.

title: Market Place
description: EVERYONE wants to hedge against inflation, but the question is, can everyone afford to? That is, at the current 11 percent rate of inflation, one needs to earn a return on capital of significantly more than that when taxes are taken into consideration.

title: Exiled Colonel Back in Portugal
description: LISBON, Sept. 23 (Reuters)  Col. Antonio Varela Gomes, who fled the country following an abortive leftwing coup in .November 1975, returned to Portugal last night from exile in Mozambique, military sources said today.

description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 23 (UPI)  Don Money's twoout single scored Charlie Moore's tiebreaking run in the sixth inning and Gorman Thomas blasted his leagueleading 44th home run of the season to power the Milwaukee Brewers to an 87 victory over Minnesota today.

title: PoorNation Growth Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)With India showing considerable strength, the underdeveloped countries outpaced developed nations in economic growth last year, the World Bank reported today. It also said that India was the largest borrower of bank resources, receiving just under $1.2 billion, followed by Indonesia, Brazil and Mexico.

title: Grass On Buckwheat

However, the A.C.L.U. does take a firm stand on the Constitution of the United States and the 26 amendments thereto.

title: Nearly 200,000 Rally to Protest Nuclear Energy
description: Nearly 200,000 people gathered peacefully on the sands of the Battery Park City landfill yesterday in the nation's largest antinuclear rally to date. It was more than three times the number of demonstrators that marched on the Capitol in Washington in May.

title: Peking Has No Room for the Thousands Asking to Return
description: PEKING, Sept. 23  Lin Fengmei says she never had a childhood. When I was 6, in the Cultural Revolution, my father was accused of being a historical counterrevolutionary, since he had once been a member of the Kuomintang, and our family was driven back to his ancestral home in a village.

title: Belgrade Seeks Debt Refinancing
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 23The Yugoslav Government has asked the major American and West European banks that have extended loans to the country to attend a meeting this week at an Adriatic resort to discuss refinancing of some $600 million of debt coming due over the next three years, American and Yugoslav banking sources report.

title: Frenchman Nears Motorcycle Title
description: HOCKENHEIM, West Germany, Sept. 23 (AP)  Patrick Pons of France virtually clinched this year's Formula 750 motorcyling world championship today by sweeping both 20lap races at the Hockenheim Motordome.

title: Franks Won't Return to Cubs
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP)  Herman Franks said today that he would no return as manager of the Chicago Cubs next season and did not know why the team was waiting to announce that decision.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: Is someone reading John Rawls in Brazil? Mr. Rawls, whose modern classic A Theory of Justice has been agitating philosophers and economists since its appearance in 1971, is an unregenerate political and economic egalitarian. For him, equity in the distribution of income and wealth requires that the social order is not to establish and secure the more attractive prospects of those better off unless doing so is to the advantage of those less fortunate.

title: AtlantaLondon Flight
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 23 (Reuters) British Caledonian Airways announced the start of onceaweek cargo service between Atlanta and London. The airline said it would use Boeing 707320's on the run, scheduled to arrive in Atlanta each Saturday afternoon and in London Sunday.

title: The Phenomenon at Giants Stadium
description: ON the roads circling Giants Stadium yesterday, the blueonwhite signs announced, No Tickets Available for This Event. And no tickets are available for any of the Giants' six remaining home games this season, just as none have been available for two decades, and just as none will probably be available for another two decades.

title: Buffalo's Ferguson, Butler Star
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., Sept. 23Jerry Butler has now shown that he can do for Buffalo's offense what Wesley Walker does for the New York Jets', if not more.

title: Chinese Ready To Begin Talks With Russians
description: MOSCOW  Only six months ago, during the Chinese invasion of Vietnam, students from the Moscow State University were hanging Maoist aggressors in effigy from the trees across Friendship Street from the Chinese Embassy. The Soviet leadership gravely warned the Chinese to pull out of Vietnam before it was too late.

title: U.S. Pair Takes Dance Roller Skating
description: ALTENAU, West Germany, Sept. 23 (UN)  Fleurette Arsenault and Dan Little of the United States won the doubles dance event last night at the 24th world artistic rollerskating championships.

title: Ford Plans Visit to Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 23 (Reuters)  Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, will visit Japan late next month to meet with executives of the Toyo Kogyo Company Ltd., Toyo Kogyo said. Industry sources said the two companies were expected to hold indepth discussions of the plan, agreed to in July, for Ford to acquire a 25 percent stake in Toyo Kogyo on Nov. 1.

description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 10, 40, 3, 34, 21 and 26. The supplementary number was 25.

In his fulltime, salaried N.A.M. post, he will succeed R. Heath Larry, formerly a vice chairman of the United States Steel Corporation.

For many, it no longer is A strike begun on April 14 by members of Local 3 of the Newspaper Guild of New York has split the town, and now, according to Mayor Thomas G. Dunn.

title: Westchester Will Shift Control of Clinic
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 21  Westchester County, after struggling for years to gain control of its medical center, has taken the first firm step toward turning that control over to a nongovernmental corporation

description: TORONTO, Sept. 23  Tommy John finally gained his 20th victory today, pitching the New York Yankees to a 75 triumph over the Toronto Blue Jays despite a slightly stiff neck and a sore leg.

title: Joy in Metville  Gone but Not Forgotten
description: The closing image of that surrealistic season is still fresh in my mind a decade later  and still hard to believe: Cleon Jones sinking down to one knee in the outfield (to play it safe or to pray, or both) as he speared the year's last line drive, closing his eyes in brief disbelief as Shea Stadium exploded into tumult from field to rafter.

title: World News Briefs
description: MADRID, Sept. 23 (Reuters)  Basque separatists murdered the military governor of Guipzcoa Province today in what Spanish authorities regarded as a fresh attempt to wreck plans to give Basques a measure of home rule.

title: Colors of Pope to Light Empire State Building
description: When Pope John Paul II visits New York on Oct. 2, the papal colors of white and gold will light up the upper floors and tower of the Empire State Building.

title: CLEANAIR PROGRAM IN NEW YORK STATE SAID TO BE IN DOUBT
description: New York state's plan for complying with the Federal Clean Air Act has been placed in serious doubt by a disclosure that the Federal share of an $805 million masstransit program is not available, the regional office of the Environmental Protection Agency said yesterday.

description: PEDRO SEGUNDO, Brazil, Sept. 19  Each year nature is merciless to the residents of this town In the middle of the northeastern drought belt.
