title: Sports and Pupils Back At Nyack High School
description: Students at Nyack High School returned to classes after staying out Thursday and Friday to protest the cancellation of interscholastic sports, bus service and extracurricular activities. The activities were canceled because voters defeated a supplementary school budget.

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS  The Westchester County Board of Legislators refused yesterday to allow a referendum in November on whether the Villages of Pleasantville and North Tarrytown could secede from the Town of Mount Pleasant.

title: Taxes
description: ATHOUGH the Internal Revenue Service has attempted to estimate the size of the underground economy  transactions strictly for cash on which taxes are not paid  the General Accounting Office thinks the figures are too low. In recent testimony before the subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs of the House Government Operations Committee, Richard L. Fogel, associate director of the accounting office's general government division, disputed the estimate by the revenue service that income not reported on tax returns totaled between $100 billion and $35 billion for 1976.

title: Fox Talking to Hirschfield
description: Dennis C. Stanfill, chairman and president of the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation, confirmed yesterday that his company was engaged in serious discussions with Alan J. Hirschfield, former president and chief executive of Columbia Pictures Industries, to come to Fox in a very senior position. Mr. Hirschfield is currently a consultant to Warner Communications Inc.

title: EARNINGS
description: The General Tire and Rubber Company yesterday reported a 29 percent decline in earnings for its third quarter ended Aug. 31 on sales that declined 5.7 percent.

title: Astros Trail by 2 As Braves Win Two
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 24 (UPI)  Eddie Solomon pitched a fivehitter and Gary Matthews drove in four runs tonight to lead the Atlanta Braves to an 81 victory over Houston and complete a doubleheader sweep that jolted the Astros' division championship chances.

title: Military Regime in Ghana Yields Power to Civilians
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 24  More than seven years of military rule formally ended in Ghana today as an elected President and a 140member civilian Parliament were sworn in amid applause, a 21gun salute and a warning.

title: Copper Makers Increase Prices
description: Several copper producers increased the price of the metal yesterday. Among them, Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting and Magma Copper increased the price of their electrolytic copper fullplate cathode by 3 cents a pound to 93 cents. Phelps Dodge and Noranda Mines raised their price for copper by 4 cents a pound to 93 cents.

title: Mortgage Yield At Peak Again
description: Mortgage rates are continuing to rise to record highs as home sales continue to increase, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported yesterday.

title: Rates on New York City Notes Drop
description: While other shortterm interest rates have soared this year, the rate New York City must pay to borrow has dropped significantly.

title: Film: 'Bush Mama' Tells Story of a Coast Ghetto:Hartford Ballet to Offer Chilean 'Carmina Burana'
description: DOROTHY (Barbara O. Jones) is a woman who hears voices  nothing intelligible, just a headful of kaleidoscopic noise. These sounds both insulate and plague her as she wanders numbly through Haile Gerima's "Bush Mama," a film about ghetto life with a Los Angeles setting and a forcefulness that transcends its specific locale."Bush Mama" is fiery, furious, overflowing with rhetoric and slightly out of breath. The Ethiopian-born Mr. Gerima made the film as his thesis project at the University of California at Los Angeles, with a low budget and a lot of audacity. Its rough edges, occasional incoherence and polemical urgency all mark it as an especially passionate early effort.Mr. Gerima is so single-mindedly committed to his film's political stance that its dramatic aspect often gets blurred. Dorothy evolves from a sleep-walker into a new version of the African militant heroine whose poster adorns her wall, a transition that is signaled by her killing a white policeman and throwing away her wig. Before a Kafkaesque arrest scene triggers this conclusion, Dorothy spends much of her time in a daze. Her friends remark that she drinks to excess; one of them even says she's suffered brain damage. At charges of this sort, Dorothy merely shrugs. Her days are devoted to walking down to the welfare office and fighting half-heartedly with bureaucrats. That seems to have sapped all of her energy."Bush Mama," which will be shown today and tomorrow at the Paramount Theater as part of the American Independents series, has a visual style as jumbled as its soundtrack, though this quality of sensory overload is as dulling to the eye as it is provocative to the ear. The film's principals, all of them very strong players, emerge from a cluster of vividly sketched lesser figures, like a man who claims to be a prince and eats only "prince food" (he then describes an exotic dish that turns out to be a hamburger). Everyone in Dorothy's life is stronger and more vehement than she  from a lover (Johnny Weathers) who becomes radicalized in jail, to a neighbor (Cora Lee Day) who sounds full of bluster but is stubbornly on the side of the white man.The sense of these characters' imprisonment and frustration is the film's most vivid message, far more powerful than the angry declaration at which Dorothy finally arrives. And the dissatisfaction extends to issues both large and small. "We claim that we right on," says Dorothy's lover, "and they come right back at us with 'Right On' deodorant." A neighbor's daughter begins hanging angry posters in Dorothy's apartment because her own mother doesn't approve of such things. "Militant stuff," the young woman explains. "Well, I guess that's anything Mama don't want to know about."One of these posters shows a black man who has been shot 25 times by the police. A bold headline says as much, but Mr. Gerima deliberately keeps his camera away from the photograph until Dorothy herself is willing to stare at it with outrage, and almost with surprise. This is an unusually delicate stroke in a generally broader film with little time or patience for such telling details.

title: Plainfield Officials Seek Tie In Series of Racial Incidents
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 24  Officials said today that they were seeking to determine if there was any conspiracy to provoke racial unrest here by outsiders, including four young men who were arrested late Friday for allegedly firing shotgun blasts at the homes of two blacks.

title: Solomon Sees Gains By Dollar
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 24  Anthony M. Solomon, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today that he expected the dollar to grow stronger as a result of improvements projected in the balance of payments and the inflation rate and the upward revaluation of the West German mark.

title: Police Academy In Albany Adds Minority Groups
description: ALBANY, Sept. 24  The largest number of blacks, Hispanic people and women ever to enter the State Police Academy reported for duty today.

title: Late Trading Rates
description: LONDON, Sept. 24 (AP)  These were the late trading rates for the dollar in Europe today after the mark revaluation, compared with last Friday: Frankfurt, 1.7690 marks, up from 1.7635; Zurich, 1.5780 Swiss francs, up from 1.5730; Paris, 4.1555 French francs, up from 4.1497; Amsterdam, 1.9485 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9525, and Milan, 807.45 Italian lire, up from 807.35

title: Arty Bostonians Invade Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  The folks from the land of the bean and the cod invaded what they consider enemy territory this evening  the national capital, Washington, and the home of the Smithsonian Institution  to raise money to keep the Gilbert Stuart portraits of George and Martha Washington in New England.

title: BROADCASTERS BID FOR 1984 OLYMPICS
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24  Organizers of the 1984 Summer Olympic Games say they expect to sell American television rights to the games this week for at least $200 million, plus an agreement to pay for $100 million in facilities and services for broadcasting the event overseas.

title: Carey Says 50 Fare Is Not Tied To Adoption of Rail Bond Issue
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that approval by the voters of the $500 million transportation bond issue in November was not a condition for keeping the 50cent subway fare until 1982.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Chicago Garage Passes Test
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP)  An underground parking garage near Grant Park, the site of a mass to be said by Pope John Paul II on Oct. 5, can safely withstand the weight of an expected crowd of 1.5 million people, Mayor Jane Byrne said today. She said that the engineering firm of A.O. White Jr. of Atlanta completed preliminary stress tests on the garage roof Saturday and reported no visible damage or deterioration to the garage.

title: Coast Guard Rescues 16 As Boat Sinks Of Fire I.
description: Coast Guard helicopters rescued 16 persons from the Atlantic Ocean off Fire Island last night after their chartered fishing boat hit a submerged object, broke up and sank.

title: Agnes de Mille Recalls Henry George Presence
description: HENRY GEORGE, the political economist whose famous study Progress and Poverty is 100 years old this year, may have been a prophet of a new order to many of his readers, but to his grandchild, the distinguished dancer and choreographer Agnes de Mille, who will preside over a reception opening a display of his memorabilia tomorrow night, he was more than an illustrious ancestor; he was a palpable presence though he died before she was born.

title: Park Avenue: A World Where Change Is Subtle
description: On upper Park Avenue there are no demonstrations or parades, no trucks or buses, no billboards or electric signs. They are all banned by law. The street, in fact, remains a gray expanse of homogeneous respectability.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: MIAMI, Sept. 24 (AP)  National Airlines, in a letter to the Civil Aeronautics Board released today, chided the agency for taking too long in formally approving Pan American World Airways planned takeover of the Miamibased carrier.

title: HusbandWife Team Broke New Ground in Pairs Skating in 1960's
description: As the first pairs team selected for Figure Skating's Hall of Fame, Oleg Protopopov and Lyudmila Belousova brought the same dimension to the sport that Sonja Henie, Dick Button and Peggy Fleming created as solo artists.

title: F15's Were Used
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 24  The Chief of the Israeli Air Force acknowledged tonight that all four Syrian jets destroyed this afternoon were shot down by Americanmade F15's, but he said there was no reason for the United States to object.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times
description: HER grandfather, Joseph Medill, was a newspaperman who suggested to Lincoln that he seek the Presidency and then delivered the Ohio delegation to him at the Republican National Convention in 1860. Her cousin Col. Robert R. McCormick ran The Chicago Tribune. Her brother, Joseph Patterson, ran The Daily News. Her niece, Alicia Patterson, ran Newsday. William Randolph Hearst thought that she could do no wrong, especially after she had lent him a million dollars. She was, briefly, the motherinlaw of Drew Pearson, which must have been a trial.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title

title: Quilted Coats for Winter
description: The sources were diverse: the downfilled parkas that came off the ski slopes, the padded jackets that came out of the Orient when trade relations with China opened up.

title: Regular Bronx Democrats Surprise Manhattan Faction on Court Slate
description: With quiet help from representatives of Mayor Koch, the regular Democrats from the Bronx captured two State Supreme Court nominations last night that the Manhattan organization thought it had sufficient votes to win.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Last year, John Schnapp, a vice president of Harbridge House, the Bostonbased management consulting and research firm, was primarily responsible for a study concluding that Federal regulation of the automobile industry was causing economic hardship to the Chrysler Corporation and the American Motors Corporation. Yesterday, the firm released another controversial study affecting the automobile industry and Mr. Schnapp was again the man in charge.

title: Perkins, Players Differ on Carson Benching
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 24  Ray Perkins benched his best player yesterday to teach us a lesson that if you don't practice, you don't play, several Giant veterans said today. The coach denied that was why Harry Carson, who had a virus last week, was in for only three plays against the Philadelphia Eagles, but that was the message that got across the locker room.

title: Chrysler Rebate Spurs Sales Rise
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP)  The Chrysler Corporation's rebate program has generated a 28.1 percent increase from a year earlier in the number of cars sold between Aug. 21 and Sept. 20, a company spokesman said today.

title: Roy Silver, a Reporter Based on Long Island For Times, Dead at 60
description: Roy R. Silver, a reporter for The New York Times who had been with the newspaper 38 years, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at Northern Dutchess Hospital in Rhinebeck, N.Y. Mr. Silver, who lived in Freeport, L.I., was stricken Sunday while visiting friends. He would have been 61 years old on Thursday.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Q & A
description: Q How is plutonium made?

title: The I.R.A. Connection
description: DUBLIN  It was his 12thcentury predecessor Adrian IV who started it all by making a gift of Ireland to the British crown; but John Paul II will be the first Pope in the eight centuries since then to set foot on this divided island when he arrives here later this week. To many of this devoutly Roman Catholic country's 3 million people, his visit is the event of a lifetime.

title: Song: Nana Mouskouri
description: NANA MOUSKOURI has fashioned a bland but interesting hybrid out of the Western world's popular and folk musics. Its blandness Is perhaps inevitable, since it has been designed to appeal to the broadest international audience; the fact that it does appeal so widely is also its chief attraction. It's all very well to think of Edith Piaf as truly French or Bob Dylan as truly American, but Miss Mouskouri's versions of the former's Les Trois Cloches and the latter's Hard Rain both sound perfectly at home on her program. Not even the sentimentality of the first song and the apocalyptic tone of the second seemed to make much difference. Miss Mouskouri is indicating some cultural and, more specifically, some musical values that a large portion of the world's population holds in common, and this alone makes her worth hearing.

title: A Leaden Foot on the Monetary Brakes
description: The Federal Reserve Board is hitting the monetary brakes too hard. Three of the seven members of the Fed, feeling that the current tightmoney policy should be allowed time to prove itself, voted last week against even higher interest rates. The economy is already responding to tight money policies. The real gross national product is already lower than it was in the fourth quarter of 1978 and is expected to decline further over the next several quarters. Unemployment is rising. The utilization of industrial capacity is falling.

title: Cornfeld Trial Starts In Geneva
description: GENEVA, Sept. 24  Bernard Cornfeld, the American founder of an illfated investment empire, pleaded not guilty today when he went on trial here to face charges of defrauding his employees in a $39.5 million stock deal.

title: Bridge:
description: If asked to vote for the world's most interesting tournament, many knowledgeable votes would go to Deauville in France, staged annually in July. The main event this year was almost a miniworld championship, for it was an invitation team event with two groups from North America and one each from France, Italy and the Netherlands.

title: Iowa Group Sues Over Holiday for Papal Visit
description: DES MOINES, Sept. 24 (AP)  The Iowa Civil Liberties Union went to Federal court today, asking that the county be prevented from giving workers a holiday for the visit of Pope John Paul II on Oct. 4.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, Sept. 24, 1979

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: New DisasterMonitoring Agency Finds Carter Tightfisted on Aid Money
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)  In Washington, where there is a Federal bureaucracy for virtually every contingency, there is an agency whose computers can produce long columns showing what disasters cost and which Presidents are openhanded and which are tightfisted in declaring disasters.

title: New Revelations of Microscope Research
description: THE pictures seem to take the viewer into an alien world: nightmare dragons staring with huge, unnatural eyes above cruel fangs and hairy foreclaws; forests of unearthly, bulbheaded trees sprouting from mossy plains; thickets of twisted tubes and stalks that took like nothing at all familiar to humans; strange caves and canyons inhabited by floating spheres whose surfaces are covered with tendrils.

title: Soviet Nuclear Blast Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (Reuters)Seismic signals, presumably from a Soviet nuclear explosion, were recorded last night by the United States Atomic Energy Detection System, the Department of Energy said today. The department said the signals originated at Novaya Zemlya in the Arctic.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (TelevisionCableevision cable, 8 P.M. RadioWINS, 7:50 P.M.)

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error by The Associated Press, an incorrect table on cash prices was published in Business Day on Saturday. A correct version appears on page D16.

title: Notes on People
description: Since his release by Soviet authorities in a prisoner swap last April, Aleksandr I. Ginzburg, the Russian dissident, has been living on the fencedin country estate of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, at Cavendish, Vt. Now, however, Mr. Ginzburg says he will leave the home of his fellow dissident because he wants to live a more public life.

title: Image Crisis: Israelis Feel Isolated and Baffled by Criticism
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 24  Despite the peace with Egypt, Israel these days feels like a cage.

title: Senate Panel Passes Bill To Lift Savings Interest
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)  The Senate Banking Committee approved a bill today to phase out Federal controls that limit the interest that banks and other institutions pay on savings accounts.

title: Bostonians Vote Today to Select Two for Spots in Mayoral Runoff
description: BOSTON, Sept. 24  Bostonians will vote tomorrow in a nonpartisan preliminary election to narrow the field of candidates running for Mayor and for positions on the City Council and the Boston School Committee.

title: Swiss Alps Get Heavy Snow
description: CHUR, Switzerland, Sept. 24 (Reuters)  The first heavy snow since last winter blanketed the eastern Swiss Alps over the weekend, temporarily blocking six passes. The official start of autumn brought snowfalls of four to 20 inches in Grisons, a province popular with tourists.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1979

title: Around the Nation
description: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Sept. 24 (AP)  Four Army recruiters relieved of duty In a nationwide recruiting scandal have described the workings of what they term a corrupt system.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1979

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, SEPT.25

title: PATRONAGE HIRING IS UPSET IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 29  In a decision that may have farreaching implications in other cities, a Federal district judge ruled today that patronage hiring for city and county jobs here, the base of the Democratic Party's power in Chicago, is unconstitutional.

title: Haydens Start a 52City Nuclear Protest
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., Sept. 24  Jane Fonda, the actress, and her husband, Tom Hayden, stood arm in arm today before the cooling towers of the closed Three Mile Island nuclear power plant, and he called it a special place  the scene of probably the end of the nuclear age as it plays itself out.

title: PCBPoisoned Cattle Buried With Wastes In a Dump in Kansas
description: FURLEY, Kan., Sept. 24 (AP)  The shots that rang out on a tract of ghost land near here last week were an unpleasant reminder for local residents that they live near a burial ground for industry's poisons.

title: About New York
description: Joseph Popper recalls exactly each scrap of dialogue from the meal that was to be his family's last, 33 years ago, the final gathering when he was 10 years old and his father questioned him sternly one last time across the dinner table.

title: Steve Brooks, Jockey; Won Kentucky Derby In '49 Aboard Ponder
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 24 (AP)Steve Brooks, a member of horse racing's Hall of Fame and the rider of Ponder, the winner of the 1949 Kentucky Derby, died here last night. He was 57 years old.

title: Mets Beat Cubs, 31, To End Slump at 9
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 24  The New York Mets, who had lost nine straight games, finally won today, beating the Chicago Cubs by 31 and spoiling the debut of Joe Amalfitano as the interim manager of the Cubs. Amalfitano took over for Herman Franks, who resigned earlier in the day.

title: Pete Rose Gets a Record 10th 200Hit Season
GOING OUT Guide
description: SKYSCRAPERS PLUS New York's physical and spiritual attributes, often commonplace to residents, give the city its unique, attracting qualities. Sometimes, these features must be pointed out, put into some kind of context.

title: Bucs Have the Lead At the QuarterMark
description: With onefourth of the National Football League season complete, the team with the widest lead over its division competition and a record the equal of any is Tampa Bay. The Buccaneers are unbeaten after four games and have a twogame lead over Chicago and Minnesota in the Central Division of the National Conference. They can improve their position on Sunday, when they play the Bears.

title: Dollar Rallies a Bit; Gold Sharply Higher
description: LONDON, Sept. 24  European currency markets settled down today after European finance ministers early this morning announced a 2 percent increase in the value of the West German mark against other leading European currencies.

title: Thousands Try Male Pill In China
description: SHANGHAI IN the 1950's, peasants in China's Hebeh Province began suffering from a variety of alarming and perplexing symptoms, such as infertility and cardiac irregularities. Prolonged investigation uncovered the cause and has led to what many birthcontrol specialists consider the most promising male contraceptive pill yet developed.

title: Maximum Price of Gasoline Listed by U.S. for New York
description: After charges of widespread gasolinegouging by New York City service stations, the Department of Energy released the latest brandbybrand maximum legal prices yesterday.

title: Carter Seeking Support in Visit Today
description: President Carter flies to New York City today for a quick visit to begin shoring up his political defenses.

title: Bank Passerby Flees With $2,000 Dropped When Thief Is Caught
description: A passerby apparently helped himself to more than $2,000 late yesterday afternoon after a bank robbery suspect was tackled by a teller on a busy Manhattan street following the city's eighth bank robbery of the day.

title: Mortgage Unit Deal By Citicorp
description: Citicorp announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell its Advance Mortgage Corporation subsidiary to Oppenheimer & Company, a New York securities firm. Citicorp said it expected a $16 million increase in its fourthquarter profit as a result.

title: CARTER GIVES OATH TO TWO IN CABINET
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)  President Carter formally ended his Cabinet shakeup today with installation of two former mayors, Moon Landrieu of New Orleans and Neil E. Goldschmidt of Portland, Ore.

title: Shreve, Crump Plans Canadian Merger
description: BOSTON, Sept. 24 (AP)  The Shreve, Crump & Low Company, a Boston jeweler since 1800, has signed a definitive agreement to merge with Henry Birks & Sons Ltd., of Montreal, the Massachusetts concern said today.

title: Chicago's Musicians to Vote on Pact
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 24  The Chicago Symphony's musicians have reached a tentative contract agreement with the orchestra's management that would end a sixday strike that forced the cancellation of four preseason concerts.

title: Our Founding Uncle
description: A recent news item, headlined Black Theologians Want to Add A Letter by Dr. King to the Bible, in which clergymen at the third conference of the Black Theology Project meeting in Cleveland made that very interesting suggestion, reminded me of a letter my Uncle Walt once wrote that would just be a perfect addition to the Constitution.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Air Products and Chemicals Inc. has elected Jack B. St. Clair a director.

title: 27 Photographers in State Cited For Awards by Associated Press
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 24 (AP) The winners in the 1979 New York State Associated Press photography contest were announced here today at the association's 50th annual meeting.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: CATHERINE HOLLAND

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: U.S. and Canada Collide on Tax Issues
description: TORONTO, Sept. 24  Quietly, in the halls of Congress and the conference rooms of Washington, Ottawa, Buffalo and here in Toronto, American and Canadian businessmen are fighting a littleknown guerrilla war over an estimated $115 million in international television and tourism business.

title: Advertising
description: DESPITE the seeming dependence of broadcast advertisers on the numbers  audience research data  some topnotch ones have signed up with the new Entertainment and Sports Programming Network, which went on the air Sept. 1 and still does not know who makes up its audience. Maybe they are lust farsighted.

title: Expos Keep Lead; Split With Pirates
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24  The Montreal Expos and the Pittsburgh Pirates appear cursed to follow each other through the final days of the baseball season in a state of perpetual anxiety. Neither team, each good enough to win a division championship, apparently wants to do it.

title: Jets Waiting for Their Defense to Improve
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 24  The Jets have so many reasons for pro football's worst defense that all of them make sense. Not one, however, fully explains the problem.

title: ExBank Official Enters Guilty Plea
description: Porleaf Benestad, a former senior vice president of the defunct American Bank and Trust Company, has pleaded guilty to a charge of misapplying $8.1 million in bank funds, a felony carrying a maximum penalty of four years in jail.

title: UShaped Behavior Challenges Basic Concept of Development
description: NWBBORN infants can walk if properly supported but this capacity disappears during the first months of life, only to reappear at about one year of age.

title: Jackson Asks a Fuel Plan Independent of Profit Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that the proposed multibilliondollar synthetic fuel program should not be made dependent on revenue from the windfall profits tax, as President Carter has proposed.

title: Market Place
description: SHARES of leading fastfood companies have recovered in the last two months from weakness that had lasted more than a year, but the worst may be yet to come.

title: A Benefit Tailored For Actors
description: Barney's is a long way from Broadway, but never mind. Some of the biggest names in show business trooped down to the store, at 17th Street and Seventh Avenue, last night to dine and dance the night away for the benefit of the Actors' Fund of America.

title: Prices Slide on Reports That I.B.M. Plans Offer
description: The Treasury Department yesterday postponed today's sale of twoyear notes and the sale of fouryear notes tomorrow because Congress failed to act to extend the $830 billion debt ceiling on the Federal Government's debt that expires Sunday.

title: COMMODITIES
description: The metals futures markets were scenes of violent price swings again yesterday. After silver, copper and platinum prices soared their daily permissible limits and gold came under some lastminute selling, one broker summed up the markets by noting:

title: L.I. Union Official Is Found Guilty
description: A New York union official was convicted yesterday of having extorted more than $1 million in cash payoffs from construction companies over an 11year period.

title: Events Today
description: EVITA, a musical, with music by Andrew Lloyd Webber; lyrics by Tim Rice; choreography by Larry Fuller; directed by Harold Prince; starring Patti Lu Pone, Mandy Patinkin and Bob Gunton, at the Broadway Theater, Broadway at 53d Street, 6:45.

title: Alexander Asserts Army Will Not Help Close Fort Dix
description: TRENTON, Sept. 24Clifford L. Alexander, the Secretary of the Army, has told W. Graham Claytor Jr., the newly appointed deputy defense secretary, that if the Pentagon wants to close the Army Training Center at Fort Dix, it will have to do so without the cooperation of the Army, Congressional and Administration sources said today.

title: Rapist of Estranged Wife Jailed 3 to 5 Years in Landmark Case
description: SALEM, Mass., Sept. 24 (AP)  A man convicted in a landmark case of raping his estranged wife was sentenced to three to five years today in a maximumsecurity prison.

title: FloridaPoland Student Exchange Thrives
description: WIESLAW KLASKALA, a 31yearold history professor from Adam Mickiewicz University in Poznan, Poland, hopes to spend a second year as an exchange scholar in Latin American affairs at the University of Florida in Gainesville.

title: Hypertension: Is It Too Pleasant to Give Up?
description: HIGH blood pressure, the silent killer, may sometimes be a treacherous killer as well, actually making the victim's world seem more comfortable while the stage is being set for disaster.

title: Fire in Panama Kills 18 in Tenement Building
description: PANAMA, Sept. 29 (AP)  A fire killed 18 persons early today in a tenement apartment building in an old section of the city, the National Guard reported.

title: VISIT BY POPE POSES PROBLEMS FOR IRISH
description: WATERVILLE, Ireland, Sept. 24With the arrival of Pope John Paul II less than a week away, this devoutly Roman Catholic country has worked itself into a frenzy over what an excited priest described as the greatest Irish event since St. Patrick.

title: Obituary 9 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: 50 Years Later, Blind Flight Is Routine
description: BOONTON, N.J., Sept. 24  A bright sun and high cirrus made it hardly the kind of day for flying blind. But today was the 50th anniversary of the first flight guided only by instruments, a milestone in the evolution of allweather flying, and so the little biplane chugged down the grass runway and took off on a ceremonial reenactment of the first blind flight.

title: OBSERVER
description: Have you ever noticed, friend, that when you are sleeping happily and the telephone rings and you reach an arm from under the blanket and say Hello into the mouthpiece, the voice on the telephone always says, Did I wake you up?

title: Astros Fall 2 Back
description: The Houston Astros dropped a twilightnight doubleheader to the Braves last night at Atlanta and fell 2 games behind the firstplace Cincinnati Reds in the National League Western Division. Story on page C14.

title: Bargains by the Book: A Guide to the Guides
description: Once upon a time, when prices made sense and store clerks smiled and sales were rung up on trustylooking cash registers, shoppers knew exactly where to buy whatever it was they needed. Those days, to judge by the number or snopping guides being published, have gone the way of the twopants suit.

title: Priests Urge a Boycott Of Pope's Capital Rite In Dispute on Sex Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)  A national group of Roman Catholic priests supporting admission of women to their ranks asked local clergymen today to boycott participation in Pope John Paul II's mass in Washington because women have been barred from helping.

title: Key Witness Hated Scotto Sometimes
description: A major witness for the prosecution testified under crossexamination yesterday that he had sometimes hated Anthony M. Scotto while making cash payments to him.

title: All XBody Compacts With Automatic Shift Are Recalled by G.M.
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP)  The General Motors Corporation recalled all of its new frontwheel drive compacts with automatic transmissions today to fix either fire hazards or steering gear problems.

title: Webster Hurt; Walton Returns
description: Marvin Webster came up hurt; Bill Walton played his first game in 17 months and gave himself a passing grade, and Earvin Johnson got good reviews. That was the news Sunday night as three of the National Basketball Association's heralded millionaires began preseason play.

title: GUERRILLAS PROMISE WHITES IN RHODESIA SEATS IN PARLIAMENT
description: LONDON, Sept. 24  In a significant concession, Zimbabwe Rhodesia's guerrillas formally agreed today to guarantee the country's white minority 20 percent of the seats in Parliament under a new constitution.

title: Nuclear Test Is Announced
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 24 (AP) The 13th announced underground nuclear test of the year is scheduled for Thursday morning at the Nevada Nuclear Testing Site about 95 miles northwest of Las Vegas. The test, codenamed Sheepshead, will have a yield between 20 and 150 kilotons. The test is the 543d announced detonation at the test site.

title: McDonnell Sells DC10's
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP)  The McDonnell Douglas Corporation today announced $155 million in orders from two airlines for two of its problemplagued models  the DC10 jumbo jet and the DC9. Mexicana Airlines signed an $85 million contract to purchase two DC10's for delivery in 1981, and Midway Airlines signed a $70 million agreement for five DC9 jets and the leasing of five more, McDonnell Douglas said.

title: Met: Something Special About Domingo's Otello
description: THERE seemed to be something special about last night's Metropolitan Opera opening. Perhaps it was the excitement attendant on a great opera, Verdi's Otello. For the opera buffs there was the added attraction of Placido Domingo in the title role. Mr. Domingo had not previously sung the role in New York, and there was much anticipation and even worry. Was Otello too heavy for him? Would he strain? Would there be damage to the wonderful voice?

title: Thompson in Pact For Specialty Shop
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company, one of the world's largest general agencies, plans to move into recruitment advertising in a big way with the acquisition of the World Wide Agency, a Los Angelesbased specialty shop with 28 offices and four production centers. The two companies announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement in principle for the acquisition. Thompson declined to disclose details.

title: The City
description: Two men were held on charges of burning a cross outside a black family's Brooklyn home last week. Bennett Simon, 19, the employee of an airconditioning company, and Padraic Anthony Keating, 20, a laborer, were charged with attempted arson, criminal trespass and criminal mischief in connection with the incident Sept. 19 outside the Borough Park home of Wayne Quamina, a television engineer. Mr. Simon and Mr. Keating, who are white, were seized Sunday through tips to the police.

title: Robert A. Vitello, Health Teacher And Rhode Island Hospital Head
description: EAST GREENWICH, R.I., Sept. 24 (UPI)  Robert A. Vitello, president of St. Joseph Hospital and a nationally known healthcare educator, died Sunday at age 47.

title: Electric Car? G.M. Stock Rolls
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP)With the president of the General Motors Corporation scheduled to make an announcement in Washington tomorrow, conjecture grew today that it might concern a breakthrough toward a practical electric car. G.M. stock, one of today's most active Big Board issues, closed in consolidated trading at 65 up 1

title: Larsen Drops Third Game In Riga Chess Tournament
description: MOSCOW, Sept 24 (Reuters)  Bent Larsen of Denmark lost his third game in succession at the Riga interzonal tournament of the world chess championship and dropped to fifth place, Tass, the official news agency, reported today.

title: Angels Beat Royals And Lead by Four
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 24  With Nolan Ryan pitching a fivehitter and Dan Ford driving home all their runs, the California Angels advanced to the threshold of a divisional championship tonight.

title: Advice, Not Consent, on Bigotry
description: Those who insist that it's all right for Federal judges to belong to whiteonly social clubs had better look around. Their stand is now to the right of Strom Thurmond, the ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. Senator Thurmond, once a champion of official segregation, has joined Senator Kennedy in advising judicial candidates to quit groups that engage in invidious discrimination.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: CORNELIUS M'GRATH

title: Ford Expected to Oppose Arms Treaty Approval
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  Former President Gerald R. Ford is expected to recommend this week that the Senate should substantially amend the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union and insist on stiff increases in military spending as a condition of approving the pact.

title: Critic's Notebook
description: ONE of the legends that has attached itself to the career of the French photographer Henri CartierBresson is that he has never allowed himself to be photographed. Intent upon preserving an anonymity he deemed essential to his work as a photojournalist. Mr. CartierBresson always adamantly refused to become a photographic subject himself. That, at least, is the legend.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Balletto, Tolar; Sonata in E minor for Violin, Viola da Gamba and Continuo No. 7, Buxtehude; Festmarsch from Tannhauser, Wagner; Meditation and Intermezzo from Thais, Massenet; Overture to Peter Schmoll, Weber. The Heidelberg Chamber Orchestra.

title: Jesse Jackson, Advocating Talks With P.L.O., Meets Critics in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 24  The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson arrived in Israel today with a plea for talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization, and he immediately ran into a wall of tough Israeli argument at a meeting in City Hall.

title: Merger Sights Are Refocused On Energy
description: The oil industry, after a period of flirtation with acquisitions in unrelated fields, has refocused its attention on the energy field, lured by the prospect of oilprice decontrol and Government incentives for the development of alternative fuels.

title: Increase Foreseen In Wives at Work
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)  Only one in four married women will be a fulltime housewife and mother by 1990, a new book on employment predicts.

title: I.R.A. Terrorists, More Deadly Than Ever After Reorganization, Prove an Elusive Foe
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland  Two averagelooking men in their early 20's sneak into the center of a little town southwest of here and plant a bomb in a battered old car that an accomplice has stolen and left outside a pub. A fourth man, holding a hand detonator adapted from the control device of a model airplane kit, waits a couple of blocks away, watching.

title: Market Registers a Broad Retreat
description: Glamour stocks and oil issues showed particular weakness yesterday as the market pulled back in a broad retreat that followed a strung showing last week.

title: Conferees Agree on a Compromise Panama Canal Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  House and Senate negotiators reached agreement today on a compromise bill to carry out the Panama Canal treaties, and opponents of earlier legislation said they expected the new measure to be passed by Congress.

title: Carey Reports More Transit Aid;  White House Denies Commitment
description: Governor Carey said he had received a firm commitment yesterday from the Carter Administration that New York State would receive next year at least $60 million more than it would normally get in transit aid. But hours later the White House said no such commitment had been made.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION; Specialists Leery Of Math Reforms
description: MATHEMATICIANS and educators warned last week that reports of students declining performance in mathematics may touch off reforms that will make the problem worse. In interviews, they expressed the view that pressures to increase classroom drill and prepare students for minimum competency tests will further erode students capacity to use mathematics to solve problems.

title: Settlement Offered In Beneficial Suits
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) The Government today announced a proposed settlement of antitrust suits that would permit the Beneficial Corporation to acquire most of two smaller loan companies, Capital Financial Services of Columbus, Ohio, and the Southwestern Investment Company of Amarillo, Tex.

title: Henry Boettcher, ExChairman Of Drama at CarnegieMellon
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24  Henry Boettcher, chairman of the department of drama at CarnegieMellon University for 22 years, died last Friday. He suffered a heart attack in his home in Palm Springs, Calif., where he had moved shortly after retiring in 1972. He was 76 years old.

title: City Is Tackling Problem Of Traffic on Pope's Visit
description: It you drive in Manhattan on Oct. 2 or 3, you're not only not going to get where you're going; you're not going to be able to get back to where you came from, a police spokesman said yesterday.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) over-the-counter.

title: Yields on Bills Off at Treasury
description: Yields declined on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and the 182day maturities.

title: Astros Draw 1.9 Million
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)  Three consecutive seasonending sellouts against the Cincinnati Reds enabled the Houston Astros to reach 1.9 million in home attendance, the club's best total since 1965, when the Astrodome opened.

title: Science Watch
description: In common with all birds, the extinct moa, an ostrichlike runner that sometimes grew 12 feet tall, ate gravel and pebbles. Birds need grinding material in their crops, which serve the same function as the teeth used by other animals for chewing food.

title: Gromyko and Vance Discuss Soviet Cuban Brigade
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union met with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance yesterday to respond to American suggestions for resolving the problem caused by the reported presence of a Soviet combat brigade in Cuba.

title: Baseball's Abraham Lincoln
description: Sports of The Times

title: Exxon Fulfills Offer Despite F.T.C. Challenge
description: The Exxon Corporation, unable to reach mutually satisfactory terms with the Federal Trade Commission over its offer to purchase the Reliance Electric Company, announced yesterday that it had broken off negotiations with the Government agency and had bought Reliance anyway.

title: SENATE, 6922, BACKS EDUCATION AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)  President Carter's proposal for a Federal education department breezed through the Senate today but faces an unexpectedly cool reception in the House of Representatives.

title: Coping With the Worst Nuclear Site
description: The 200,000 demonstrators who jammed into lower Manhattan Sunday heard a rock concert and a parade of speakers urging an end to nuclear power. Their presence added political weight to the plea of the Union Concerned Scientists that two nuclear plants at Indian Point, some 35 miles north of Times Square, be shut down immediately. They assert major safety shortcomings there, which, if they exist, could not be tolerated anywhere. But the scientists' group has an even bigger objection: it believes the site to be inherently unsuitable because it is so close to so many people.

title: Ties to South Africa Sought
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic, Sept. 24  David Dacko, President of one of the 25 poorest countries in the world, said today that he would move to establish diplomatic and trade relations with South Africa if that nation could help improve the economic situation here.

title: Carter Names a Deputy For Delegation at U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) President Carter today announced the nomination of William J. vanden Heuvel to be deputy United States representative at the United Nations.

title: The BodySnatchers on Capitol Hill
description: One appeal of The Invasion of the BodySnatchers, last year's prime horror movie, was that the mysterious pods from space attacked with some subtlety. They did not simply kill their victims; they inhabited them, turning free spirits into willing drones. At times, PAC's  political action committees for special interest groups  give off similar vibrations in Congress.

title: U.N. Aides Decline Comment
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24 United Nations officials declined specific comment on Arkady Shevchenko's allegations, saying that they had not seen the text of the BBC broadcast, but they condemned the former Soviet aide generally as a renegade.

title: August Tool Orders Up
description: Orders for machine tools increased in August, little affected by a broad economic slowdown, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday. Orders for the machines used in making industrial equipment totaled $429.2 million, up 19 percent from July's $362.1 million and up 15 percent from the $374.8 million of orders in August 1978.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Obituary 10 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY SE TELEPHONED TO 354-900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIOHS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 34900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (616) 741500; SUFFOLK CO. (516)5091800; CONNECTICUT (203) 345767.

title: Phone Offering
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (Reuters)  The Securities and Exchange Commission today said that the General Telephone Company of the Southwest has filed for an offering of 250,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock and $75 million of first mortgage bonds, due 2009. The company said proceeds of the offering will be used to reduce shortterm debt.

title: 8 Escape Rikers I.; 3 Are Retaken
description: Eight prisoners escaped from the Men's House of Detention on Rikers Island last night, but three were recaptured within two hours and authorities expressed confidence that the others would soon be rounded up.

title: New Medical Specialty Accepted
description: Emergency medicine, a medical discipline that hitherto had been regarded as hard to define because it involved so many medical approaches, has been recognized as an approved specialty, the American Board of Medical Specialties announced.

title: VANCE SAYS THE U.S. SEEKS FIRMER TRUCE FOR SOUTH LEBANON
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24 The United States is planning a fresh effort to transform the frequently shattered ceasefire in southern Lebanon into a more durable truce, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said here today.

title: Parts of Venice Are Flooded
description: VENICE, Sept. 24 (AP)  A high tide and strong winds brought flooding to some sections of Venice today. The water was reported nearly 3.3 feet above the pavement in the worsthit areas.

title: Browns Trounce Cowboys
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 (AP) Brian Sipe passed for two touchdowns and Thom Darden returned a pass interception for another score in a firstquarter scoring flurry that carried the Cleveland Browns to a 267 National Football League victory over the Dallas Cowboys tonight.

title: Soviet Defector, on BBC, Says Moscow Agents Have Penetrated the U.N.
description: LONDON, Sept. 24  Arkady N. Shevchenko, the Soviet diplomat who defected last year, says that Soviet intelligence has made a very substantial penetration into the United Nations Secretariat.

title: World News Briefs
description: SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 24 (Reuters)The police shot and killed a American student and two Salvadorans yesterday in a halfhour gun battle on the grounds of the presidential palace, El Salvador's Defense Ministry said today.

title: New York Music Week Begins
description: New York Music Week, a fiveday celebration of the diversity of New York's musical life, got under way yesterday with a series of free lunchtime performances around Manhattan. Melanie was at the Citicorp Plaza, Tito Puente performed at the World Trade Center Plaza, there was a contemporary classical song recital at St. Paul's Church, another classical concert at Trinity Church and the Johnny Griffin Quartet with the Jazzmobile at Columbus Circle.

title: Itel Plans to Withdraw From Computer Business
description: The troubled Itel Corporation is effectively withdrawing from the computer business and has agreed to transfer most of its computer sales and service operations to the National Semiconductor Corporation, according to a company announcement late yesterday.

title: Dr. Elizabeth van Laer, 47, Dies; Professor of Psychology at L.I.U.
description: Dr. Elizabeth K. van Laer, professor of psychology at Long Island University, died of cancer Saturday at New York Hospital. She was 47 years old and was a resident of Manhattan.

title: Met Reaps Bonus as Gala Otello Greets Season
description: The Metropolitan Opera's opening always a festive occasion, but last night it was more festive than usual, and truly national in its impact.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: JAMES G. KING

title: 4 Syrian Fighters Downed by Israeli Jets Over Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 24 (Reuters)  Syrian and Israeli fighter planes clashed over Lebanon today for the second time in three months, and both sides said four Syrian jets were shot down.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1979

title: Bokassa Arrives in Ivory Coast, Where He Has Political Asylum
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Sept. 24 (UPI)  The deposed Central African emperor, accused of murder in his homeland and denied political refuge in France, flew to this former French colony today and was granted asylum.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Miami Planning Festival Of Performing Arts in '82
description: Plans for a threeweek performingarts festival in Miami in June 1982 have been announced by the Greater Miami Opera Association. Expected to cost more than $1.5 million, the festival will have as its major aim the presentation of premieres of major works commissioned from outstanding American composers, playwrights, choreographers and lyricists.

title: IN THE NATION
description: In early 1976, Jimmy Carter's showing in the Iowa Democratic caucuses caught the nation's eye. Then, his firstplace finish in the New Hampshire primary gave him the frontrunner status he never lost. Thus. before it had well begun, the campaign was profoundly  perhaps decisively  affected by the actions of a handful of voters in two states with only 12 electoral votes.

title: Rich and Poor Clash, Delaying World Talks On Radio Frequencies
description: GENEVA, Sept. 24  The opening of a 140nation conference called to decide how the world's radio broadcasting frequencies should be allocated for the remainder of the century was delayed today by a dispute that threatened to turn the meeting into a confrontation between rich and poor nations.

title: Hartford Congressman Is Linked To Nursing Home Under Inquiry
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 24  A New Haven nursing home that is partly owned by a Hartford Congressman is the subject of an investigation involving its treat. ment of patients and its physical facilities, a state official says.

title: Plea by Fraiman To Alter Rebuke Denied by Court
description: In a brusque, twoparagraph letter, the State Court of Appeals has unanimously rejected a plea by Justice Arnold G. Fraiman of the State Supreme Court to modify part of an opinion that was especially critical of his conduct.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: THE simplest and lightest gravies and sauces are those that come from the juices yielded by a roast  any roast  of pork or beef or fowl. They add subtlety to the tenderest meat and they can virtually resurrect a roast that has succumbed to human error.

title: Carter Trade Plan Sent to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) President Carter formally submitted his proposed trade reorganization legislation to Congress today, saying it would improve the efficiency of the nation's trade.

title: Carter Declares Disaster Areas
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)  President Carter today signed disaster declarations for six Texas counties and three Louisiana parishes. The areas were struck by severe storms and floods last week. The declarations will make the residents of the areas eligible for Federal relief and recovery assistance, including grants, temporary housing and lowinterest loans from the Small Business Administration and the Farmers Home Administration.

title: Economic Scene
description: ATIMEHALLOWED rule among finance ministers is to declare firmly that nothing is going to happen just before announcing a devaluation or revaluation of a major currency. That rule was observed late last week when the ministers of the European Monetary System wound up their Brussels conference by declaring that they saw no need for technical modifications and waived a fullscale review of the alignment of the member currenciesjust before they revalued the West German mark.

title: McMillen Leads Hawks Over Nets in Exhibition
description: GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 25 (AP)  Tom McMillen scored 18 points and Steve Hawes had 16 to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 125120 victory over the New Jersey Nets tonight in National Basketball Association preaseason play.

title: Paris Murder Arouses Fear of RightWing Violence
description: PARIS, Sept. 25  The street murder of a 35yearold leftist writer last week has led to warnings here that extremist rightwing and antiSemitic groups may be starting a campaign of violence.

title: 4 Held in Attempt to Burn Man
description: Four youngsters were arrested for trying to set fire to a man sleeping on a stairway in a subway station at Houston Street and Second Avenue early yesterday, authorities said. The four, two of them 12 years old and two about 16, were arrestea ny a Transit Authority police officer after they poured kerosene on Aaron Bridler at about 2:30 A.M. and tried to set the fuel afire with matches. The youngsters' names were not disclosed.

title: World Gold
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1979

title: COMMODITIES Silver and Some Golds Off as Other Metals Rise
description: Prices of silver futures tumbled yesterday as nervous traders with large paper profits sought other stores of value, such as copper, which scored limit advances on all deliveries.

title: CARTER, IN QUEENS, CRITICIZES KENNEDY
description: President Carter used his town meeting in Queens last night to criticize his chief potential rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, as an ineffective champion of his own legislative program.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS The Death Of the Center
description: WASHINGTON  The political center that used to provide the ballast for United States foreign policy is just about destroyed and is being replaced by the right wing.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows the past week (Monday, September 17, to Sunday, September 23), listed according to their rank In the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: Javits and Kennedy Clash in Vote On Judge Tied to AllWhite Club
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Senator Jacob K. Javits and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who usually agree on civil rights issues, engaged in an unlikely battle on the Senate floor today over the confirmation of a Federal appeals court judge who agreed under pressure to suspend, but not to resign, membership in an allwhite club.

title: John McQuade, Actor; Was Protg of Cohan
description: John McQuade, who appeared in a number of Broadway plays in the 1940's, before turning to movies and television, died last Friday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 63 years old.

title: House Members Pressing to Curb SpecialInterest Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  Last year, Representative Tom Railsback ran without opposition in his Illinois district. But political action committees sent him campaign contributions anyway, about $9,000 worth, usually without being asked.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ONE of the great omissions of my life is that I have never been in Spain. The closest I ever came was the Basque country France. But over the years I have dined with friends who are excellent cooks in the Spanish tradition. One of the most memorable Spanish dishes I've ever sampled was in San Juan. P.R. Now. it's an established fact that San Juan is, unfortunately, not all that celebrated as a restaurant mecca, but on the evening in question we dined at a small, unpretentious place called La Fragua in the Caprice Hotel. The food, overall, was excellent, but the triumph of the evening was a dish of fish a green sauce. The chef explained to me that the fish was called mero, which, I believe, is grouper and is not available at my local fish markets.

title: Open Primary in Wisconsin Periled in a Reform Conflict
description: MADISON, Wis., Sept., 25  Wisconsin's Presidential primary, often a decisive event in its 67 years of existence, could soon lose its importance in a conflict between the political reform movement of the 1970's and the spirit of the earlier Progressive era.

title: Israel Lowers Flag Over Another Part of Sinai and Egyptians Take Over
description: CAIRO, Sept. 25  Israel returned another wedge of the Sinai Peninsula to Egypt today in the third phase of its withdrawal arranged under the peace treaty signed last spring.

title: Religious Strife in an Otherwise Model City Puzzles India
description: JAMSHEDPUR, India, Sept. 21  This wellplanned city of 500,000 is a model of paternalistic industrial development, providing residents with the highest pay scales in the country, the best free medical care, fine schools, large parks and abundant recreational facilities.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FORTUNE 500, SYNCOPATED During the summer, the Helmsely-Spearowned 1 Penn Plaza presented a series of outdoor concerts. The series ended last week, but the impresarios in charge of these events have added one more concert to the series  the 47th Street Stompers.

title: Gulf Oil to Buy Canadian Concern
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25  The Gulf Oil Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy Amalgamated Bonanza Petroleum Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, in a $120.7 million deal that will add to Gulf's domestic oil and as reserves.

title: 5 of 8 Who Escaped From Rikers Island Still Hunted
description: The police were searching yesterday for five men who escaped from Rikers Island late Monday night by sawing through a cell bar with a tinyjeweler's saw and then using the sawedoff bar to jimmy open a reinforced window.

title: Iacocca Car Show Is Plea to Editors
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich., Sept. 25  Lee A. Iacocca, the Chrysler Corporation's chairman and supersalesman, broadened his appeal for help for his financially distressed company today. He offered a rare glimpse of his company's future cars along with a pugnacious defense of his plans to rescue the company to a gathering of newspaper editors and publishers.

title: Tests Fail to Explain Plant's Uranium Loss
description: ERWIN, Tenn., Sept. 25 (AP)  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that it could find nothing in soil samples to explain the loss of at least 19.8 pounds of weaponsgrade uranium from a defense plant here.

title: Private Lives
description: OF the two birds, only one survived. The first bird was delivered to us in our bedroom on a Saturday morning a couple of weeks ago. The black cat, for whose intelligence and cunning I have never had much respect, was pleased with herself. After an entire career of being outwitted by butterflies, of hiding from the ringing of the telephone, she must have gotten lucky during the night. She brought her prize through the window and up the stairs and dropped it at the foot of the bed for us to admire.

title: 7 Salvadorans Are Reported Killed As Troops Open Fire on Guerrillas
description: SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 25 (AP) Guerrillas hurled bombs at the National Palace tonight and troops opened fire, witnesses reported. Red Cross officials said at least 7 persons were killed and 30 wounded.

title: Stage: Evita, a Musical Pern
description: THERE'S an eerily prophetic line close to the very opening of Evita, the Tim RiceAndrew Lloyd Webber musical that chooses to sing about the brief, bizarre life of Eva Pern and her joint rule of Argentina with her dictatorhusband. Juan. The evening opens with the announcement of her death at 33  we pick it from the inside of a movie theater, as an ongoing western is suddenly replaced on the screen by the huge shadow of a man proclaiming the news  and then proceeds at once to the state funeral of a woman who was both hated and held to be sainted.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Thomas and Simmons Set For 2 City Opera Debuts
description: Michael Tilson Thomas will conduct opera for the first time in New York in 1981, when he makes his New York City Opera debut in the spring as conductor of Janacek's Cunning Little Vixen. The announcement was made yesterday by Beverly Sills, general director of the company.

title: Challenge Grant Given For Library Fund Drive
description: The New York Public Library could receive up to $1.6 million in Federal aid as part of a challenge grant if it raises double that amount from private donors, the National Endowment for the Humanities announced yesterday.

title: ENERGY AND HOUSING PACE 1.1% INCREASE IN CONSUMER PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Propelled once again by energy and housing costs, consumer prices rose by 1.1 percent in August, the seventh consecutive monthly increase of 1 percent or more.

title: August Inflation in New York Area Adds Up to 12Month Rate of 9%,
description: Consumers in the New York area lost an additional 70 cents on every $100 last month as the inflation index rose seventenths of 1 percent, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: CAREY AND U.S. AIDE AGREE TO WORK OUT CITY TRANSIT GRANTS
description: After days of conflict between Washington and New York State officials over Federal masstransit aid, Governor Carey and Secretary of Transportation Neil E. Goldschmidt met yesterday evening and agreed that the combined transit needs of New York City and the state can and will be met.

title: A Staten Islander Is Found Guilty In $2.2 Million Hijacking in 1978
description: A Federal Court jury in Brooklyn found Staten Islander Joseph A. Marino guilty on all counts last night in the $2.2 million hijacking of a Wells Fargo armored truck last December.

title: Coast group Finds a Rise in Workers Sharing Jobs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 (AP) More and more workers and their employers are getting involved in job sharing, according to New Ways to Work, a nonprofit organization with offices in San Francisco and Palo Alto.

title: Best Buys
description: THE monthlong trend of stable food prices here continued last week, with the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs reporting that the cost of a 41item market basket had increased just 4 cents from the previous week, to $89.33.

title: Cairo's Censors Mar the Hopes Of Film Festival
description: CAIRO, Sept. 25  Before the Fourth Cairo International Film Festival opened last week, there was hope that the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty had erased a longstanding ban on movies with Jewish themes or actors identified with Israel.

title: Of Soccer, SALT and Sanity
description: What, we wonder, have those 2,700 Soviet noncombatant combat troops in Cuba been doing lately? They're confined to barracks, no doubt, at least in daylight when the U2's can fly over to determine whether their boots are laced in parallel or diagonal patterns. There are 2,000 or so equally idle American servicemen at Guantanamo at the other end of the island, but they at least can pass the time at golf and baseball. As Henry Kissinger recalls in his new memoir, even a Soviet soccer field in Cuba would inflame American suspicions.

title: F.C.C. Removes Barrier to Growth of Pay Televison
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The Federal Communications Commission today struck down a rule limiting communities to one overtheair pay television station each, clearing the way for more rapid expansion of the industry.

title: Sailor Pleads Guilty to Spy Charge
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 25 (UPI) Yeoman 3d Class Lee Eugene Madsen, a Pentagon security officer, pleaded guilty today to a single count charging that he had sold seven top secret intelligence and military documents to an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Gromyko, at U.N., Calls Concern Over Soviet Unit in Cuba Artificial
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25 Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union today dismissed as artificial the United States concern over the Soviet brigade in Cuba and urged Washington to drop the matter.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Lose 99th, 113, Then Top Cubs in 10
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 25The New York Mets, within one strike of losing their fifth doubleheader in eight days, rallied to tie the Chicago Cubs today, then beat them, 43, in 10 innings and gained a split. The Cubs, with a sevenrun first inning, won the opener, 113, giving the Mets their 99th defeat of the season.

title: A.&P. Reports A Profit in Quarter
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company reported yesterday that it had net earnings for its fiscal second quarter ended Aug. 25 of $3.9 million, or 16 cents a share, on sales of $1.68 billion.

title: SCM Seeking Holder Support
description: The SCM Corporation, facing a proxy fight by a dissident group seeking to dismantle the company, urged stockholders in a letter yesterday to resist the rival group, assembled by N. Norman Muller, board chairman of MacMuller Industries.

title: More Students Hold Jobs During College
description: THE Horatio Alger hero may be making a comeback this year. You'll probably find him on a college campus. And he is just as likely to be a she. Now more than ever before, according to college financial aid officers, young men and increasing numbers of young women are working their way through college.

title: Federal Water Versus Reason
description: The Senate's decision to reduce acreage restrictions on users of Federal irrigation water has been widely interpreted as a setback for small farmers. But if the House goes along, the big losers will be taxpayers, not those hardy pioneer farm families celebrated in fifth grade history texts. Tax dollars bought the water that turned huge swatches of Western desert and semiarid pasture into some of the richest agricultural land on earth. Yet in the debate over acreage restrictions, no one considered the option of recapturing the vast wealth created by Government irrigation for the United States Treasury.

title: Chrysler Aid Is Opposed By N.A.M.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The National Association of Manufacturers today opposed special Federal financial assistance for the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Church Calls for Delay In Nuclear Treaty Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)  Senator Frank Church, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today that the panel should hold up the nuclear arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union until the issue of Soviet troops in Cuba is resolved.

title: Richard D. Werner, 80, Chairman Of AluminumProducts Company
description: Richard D. Werner, chairman of R. D. Werner Company Inc. of Greenville, Pa., manufacturer of aluminum ladders, stages, scaffolding and extrusions, died at his vacation home in St. Lawrence Gap, Barbados. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Norway Faces Enemy Dilemma
description: OSLO  One notice in the bedrooms of a leading hotel here exhorts guests to save energy. Another cautions them not to get scalded by the piping hot bath water.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday incorrectly listed the gasoline with the highest maximum price allowable under Federal ceilings in New York City. The product with the highest price is Sunoco premium, at $1.194 a gallon.

title: F.H.A.'s Mortgage Rate Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)  The Department of Housing and Urban Development raised to a record 10.5 percent today the maximum interest rate that will be allowed on Governmentinsured home mortgages.

title: Errant Hammer Throw Sends Fans to the Exits
description: SPLIT, Yugoslavia, Sept. 25 (AP) Spectators at the eighth Mediterranean Games nearly took a hammering today.

title: Reds Lose As Margin Is Cut to 1
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 25  The celebration plans were set in motion after the Cincinnati Reds won at Houston on Sunday, and after the Astros lost a doubleheader yesterday to put the Reds 2 games ahead in the National League Western Division race. The city of Cincinnati planned for its first World Series in three years, and one of its newspapers considered the plans more important than a visit from Vice President Mondale.

title: Spritzer, Egg Cream And Other Recipes
description: Here are some uses for seltzer:

title: Action on Rock Island Strike Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission delayed for a day today plans to order a swift resumption of freight shipments on the strikebound and financially stranded Rock Island Railroad.

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: I.B.M. Plans $1 Billion Debt Issue
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to raise $1 billion in what would be the company's first venture into the public credit markets. The borrowing is believed to be the largest debt offering ever by an industrial corporation in the United States.

title: Calmer Plainfield Credits Racial Good Will
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 25  One of three shotgun blasts fired into the home of Walter Saxon, a black housepainter, from a passing pickup truck last Friday night blew out a secondfloor bedroom window and left seven pellet holes in the ceiling, about two feet above the heads of three adults and two children who were watching television.

title: Danny Lopez Knocks Out Caba in 3d to Retain Title
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25(AP) Danny (Little Red) Lopez caught up with Jose Caba in the third round tonight and twice knocked him through the ropes onto the ring apron to retain his World Boxing Council featherweight championship for the eighth times

title: 11 Jurors to Decide Davis Case
description: FORT WORTH, Sept. 25 (AP)  State District Judge Gordon Gray announced today that the trial of Cullen Davis, a millionaire oil industrialist, on charges of trying to buy the killing of a judge would resume tomorrow with 11 jurors. The judge said a doctor attending Katheryn Holman, a 53yearold juror, said she would be hospitalized at least three weeks. Mrs. Holman broke her leg while shopping last weekend, and underwent surgery yesterday.

title: For Domingo, Otello Is the Dream of a Lifetime
description: IT was an auspicious day for Placido Domingo. Although was opening night at the Metropolitan Opera House and he was starring in the title role of Verdi's Otello, the celebrated tenor was his usual buoyant, easygoing self.

title: Rutgers, 4 Other Schools Resign from the E.C.A.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) George Washington University, Rutgers, Massachusetts, Duquesne and St. Bonaventure resigned today from the Eastern College Athletic Conference after having been threatened with expulsion because of participation in the Eastern Eight Conference's basketball television package.

title: Trial Starts in Jersey Abduction Of Paterson Bank Official's Wife
description: NEWARK, Sept. 25  A jury of 10 men and six women was selected today for the trial of four resident aliens accused of abducting the wife of a Paterson banker in July and holding her for more than $200,000 in ransom.

title: Queens Audience of 1,700 Applauds Carter At President's First Town Meeting Here
description: President Carter presided over his first town meeting in New York City last night, and transformed a quiet audience at Queens College into a cheering throng that whistled and interrupted his answers with applause.

title: Philip Alger, 85, Dies; Helped G.E. Develop Early Electric Motors
description: Philip L. Alger, an electrical engineer for nearly 40 years with the General Electric Company, where he took part in the early development of electric motors and electricmotor drives, died Monday at Ellis Hospital in Schenectady, N.Y. He was 85 years old, and lived in Schenectady.

title: Bridge:
description: An application of suit preference signaling methods that is often overlooked by average players occurs at the second trick. A player who has given a discouraging signal on the first trick may well have a choice of plays next time, and can seize the opportunity to point to some other suit.

title: Knicks Rebuffed by O'Brien
description: Larry O'Brien, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, yesterday rejected the New York Knicks request that the Seattle SuperSonics be immediately ordered to return Lonnie Shelton, Vinnie Johnson and $450,000.

title: Boston Mayor Wins Runoff Spot
description: BOSTON, Sept. 25  Mayor Kevin H. White easily won a place on the November mayoral ballot today in a nonpartisan preliminary election held to narrow the field of candidates from six to two.

title: Judge Allows a Boston Park Mass
description: A Federal district judge ruled yesterday that a papal mass could be held on Boston Common, but more legal action was threatened in Des Moines.

title: For Republicans, Hard Bleachers
description: PITTSBURGH  Political attention is naturally drawn to the Democrats now that Edward M. Kennedy may go the distance and Jimmy Carter has shown fourmile endurance in a 6.2mile race. How should Republicans view these goingson?

title: President Urges Quantum Rise In Transit Funds
description: President Carter called yesterday for a quantum jump in the nation's investment in public mass transit, including funds to modernize and refurbish the New York subway system.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: MYRON B. BLANCHARD

title: Senate Unit Backs Curb On Oil Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The Senate Finance Committee voted overwhelmingly today to exempt newly discovered oil from the proposed windfall profits tax, on which President Carter is relying to finance his energy program.

title: RetailChain Sales Rise
description: The nation's largest retail chains had a sales increase of 9 percent in August over the yearearlier month and a gain of 7.6 percent in the year's first eight months over the comparable period of 1978, according to a survey by Chain Store Age, a trade publication.

title: Nigeria Denies Oil Price Rise
description: LONDON, Sept. 25 (AP)  Nigeria's stateowned oil company denies reports that it is about to raise prices by $3 a barrel, the Nigerian News Agency said today.

title: U.S. Report Says Soviet Attempted Deception on Its Nuclear Strength
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  A report by the Carter Administration on Moscow's compliance with the 1972 strategic arms accord has concluded that in recent years the Soviet Union has made several apparent attempts to deceive the United States on the size and capabilities of its nuclear arsenal.

title: Books of The Times
description: ALTHOUGH it is true, as Ruth Benedict said, that no man looks at the world with pristine eyes, it is possible, as Paul Ricoeur said, to cultivate a second naivet, and this is what our best travel writers do. They go to a country in an attitude of what Freud called freefloating attention and simply let us see what they saw. If the political correspondent tries to make sense of a culture, the amateur traveler often addresses himself to its nonsense.

title: News of the Theater
description: ALTHOUGH he never made an official announcement of the event, David Merrick let it be known some months ago that this was to be the season of his return to Broadway. The producer, whose name has been associated with Hello, Dolly! and numerous other hits, has peen concentrating on nuns in recent years. His last Broadwaybound show was a musical called The Baker's Wife, which closed in Washington three years ago.

title: House Votes $25 Million in Relief For Battered Caribbean Islands
description: WASHINGTON; Sept. 25 (UPI)  The House voted today to authorize $25 million in disaster relief for Caribbean islands battered by recent hurricanes. The vote was 370 to 27.

title: Hope Stops Baker in 7th And Retains W.B.C. Title
description: WEMBLEY, England, Sept. 25 (AP)  Maurice Hope of Britain stopped Mike Baker of Spartanburg, S.C., at 2 minutes 30 seconds of the seventh round tonight and retained the World Boxing Council's lightmiddleweight title.

title: Vietnam Reported to Open Offensive in Cambodia
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 25  Although the rainy season has not yet ended, a Vietnamese offensive against the forces of the deposed Pol Pot regime has been started in central Cambodia, informed sources reported here today.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Gold Prices Fall Slightly, Dollar Finishes Mixed
description: The price of gold slipped on bullion markets yesterday despite news that consumer prices in the United States shot upward by 1.1 percent in August. The dollar was mixed on currency exchanges.
