title: U.S. Weighs Impact of Attack in Cambodia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25 Administration officials are consulting with allies and Congress on steps to alleviate expected military and refugee pressures on Thailand caused by the apparent new Vietnam offensive in Cambodia, American officials said today.

title: Clergy in Iran Assail Oil Head
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 25 (Reuters)  The ruling Islamic clergy reiterated today its demand for a purge of the oil industry's chief executive.

title: Pope to Meet 150 Polish Children in City
description: New York City's PolishAmerican community, which had sought to play a major role in the visit of Pope John Paul II to the city, will get at least a small part, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn announced yesterday.

title: City Plans to Hire 562 More Men For Sanitation Force Next Month
description: New York City plans to hire 562 more sanitationmen next month at a cost of more than $6.5 million over the next eight months. The move would be the first step in a program to clean the city's streets more efficiently and to induce the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association to make concessions in a drive for increased productivity.

title: Atomic Power Station Shut Down in Virginia As Radiation Escapes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The Virginia Electric and Power Company said today that its North Anna Power Station Unit One was shut down early this morning when a heat exchanger tube failed. The company said that a small amount of radioactivity had escaped into the atmosphere.

title: Personal Health
description: ESTROGEN, the predominant female sex hormone, has long been linked to femininity in the public mind. So it's little wonder that when women were told they could be feminine forever by taking estrogens after menopause, millions asked their doctors to prescribe the hormone to replace what nature had so cruelly taken away.

title: Downtown Everett, Wash., Evacuated After Tank Car Derails
Religious News Officials Express Fear Over Court's Press Rulings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)  An interfaith committee of religious news officiais has expressed its concern about a series of Supreme Court rulings that the committee believes curtail freedom of the press.

title: The City
description: A subway clerk was arrested early yesterday for allegedly selling cocaine from his IRT token booth in Harlem.

title: Q&A
description: Q I have a batch of snail shells that have been used, and I am not happy with the way they were cleaned. I simply washed them in soapy water and drained. Is there a better way?

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: NEW Yorkers like to believe they have shucked off primitive obeisance to the pulse of nature. What can it really matter that the seasons have changed  that at 11:17 A.M., Eastern Standard Time, on the 23d day of September, the calendar says autumn has replaced summer?

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: WE all know that New Yorkers fiercely defend their places on line, writes Karen Markoe, but sometimes the practice can be carried to extreme. Such was the case when I was rushed to the delivery room of Albert Einstein Hospital. Meanwhile, my family went to the maternity waiting room, where another family had been waiting for several hours.

title: Film: 'Northern Lights,' Story of Early Labor Wars:A Look at Long Ago
description: AT the beginning of "Northern Lights," Henry Martinson, who is 94 years old and still does push-ups, ruminates on the soundtrack about his days as a homesteader in North Dakota, about his friends and especially about Ray Sorenson. Like Henry Martinson, Ray was an early organizer for the Nonpartisan League, a populist movement that revolutionized prairie politics in the years before World War I.Henry realizes this story is important and he pushes himself to write it down, which he does on an electric typewriter. With just the smallest hint of humor, Henry says, "I'm not getting any younger."Henry Martinson is a real person, for 28 years the labor commissioner of North Dakota and a former secretary of the Socialist Party. His recollections provide the frame for "Northern Lights," the stunningly photographed, fictionalized story of Ray Sorenson and other farmers like him who were radicalized in the first decades of this century. The film is the first dramatic feature by Rob Nilsson and John Hanson, both of whom have roots in the Middle West and are documentary film makers.When "Northern Lights" stays close to the soil of North Dakota and to the events that shaped its political history, it is splendid. It becomes uncertain and ineffectual when it attempts to make dramatic the private lives of Ray (Robert Behling) and Inga (Susan Lynch), the girl he wants to marry."Northern Lights" will be shown at 9 P.M. today at the Paramount Theater as part of the Festival of American Independent Films being held in conjunction with the forthcoming New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center. It will be shown again at the Paramount tomorrow at 3 P.M.Mr. Nilsson and Mr. Hanson are remarkably successful in integrating their professional actors (at least, they are so good I assume they are professionals) with the non-professionals who also appear in the film. And when the film's focus is on labor history, remembered or recreated, it is extremelly moving. Fortunately this is most of the time.They are not so successful, though , when they shift  like authors moving from a third- to a first-person narrative  to the personal stories of Ray and Inga. Mr. Behling, who looks like a cousin to the Carradine brothers, and Miss Lynch are both good actors, but their material doesn't measure up to the rest of the movie. It seems to have been dictated by a 70's sensibility.What one remembers of "Northern Lights" are the more general things  the look of the winter landscape during a funeral, when the mourners are black silhouettes and the sun is a dim white disk in a gray sky; the faces of the farmers as they listen to Ray's organizing speech, the jokes and songs at family celebrations. These things have the truth of reportage of a very high order.What one remembers best of all is Henry Martinson, whose memory is our periscope on the past. Mr. Martinson is the subject of "Survivor," a documentary that Mr. Nilsson and Mr. Hanson completed after making "Northern Lights." That is a film I don't want to miss.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, Sept. 25  Another important figure in the Red Brigades terrorist organization, Prospero Gallinari, was captured by the police here last night after being shot and critically wounded. A woman accomplice was also captured but a second accomplice fled.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 (AP) The Transamerica Corporation, a diversified company with interests in insurance, entertainment, travel and business enterprises, has offered $246.3 million to acquire the NN Corporation, a Milwaukeebased insurance company, the corporations said today.

title: Dazzling Scaasi Custom Styles
description: There's nothing abstract or abstruse about seeing an Arnold Scaasi fashion. show. The audience doesn't have to worry about what stores will carry the clothes six months or so hence. Or whether an offbeat color that appeals to them will be flattering or blah.

title: Pakistan Sues In DC10 Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) Pakistan's national airline told a Federal court today that the McDonnell Douglas Corporation had defrauded the air carrier of more than $1.6 million in the sale of four DC10 jet planes in 1979 and 1976.

title: Korvettes Loss Up; More Aid Advanced
description: Korvettes Department Stores, the 50store retail chain acquired last March by the AgacheWillot group of France, reported losses yesterday of $12.9 million for the first half of its fiscal year and $5.8 million for its second quarter, both higher than those of a year earlier.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amax Chemical Corporation has named Steven L. Yurman vice president of business development.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1979

title: Chess:
description: In winning the world junior championship in Skien, Norway, Yasser Seirawan of Seattle automatically earned internationalmaster rank. He also has a grandmaster norm, achieved at this year's Louis D. Statham International Tournament in Lone Pine, Calif. He needs two more to obtain that rank.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1979

title: Chrysler Paces Rise In 10Day Auto Sales
description: DETROIT, Sept. 25 (UPI)  The Chrysler Corporation, outperforming the rest of the auto industry with rebates, said today that midSeptember sales of its domestic models were 35.7 percent above the same period last year.

title: Witness Asserts He Tells Truth At Scotto's Trial
description: William Montella Jr., a witness who has said he lied many times in the past, insisted yesterday that he had testified truthfully about Anthony M. Scotto of the International Longshoremen's Associations.

title: Argentina Expels Publisher It Had Held for 29 Months
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25  Argentina's military Government today expelled Jacobo Timerman, a former publisher who had been held without judicial charges for 29 months.

title: The Battling Bonito Of Menemsha Bight
description: MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., Sept. 25  Morning came in on the tailgate of night, arriving too soon. In the gray chill over the Coast Guard station in Menemsha a red flag flew as a small craft warning. We might be in for some weather, Doug Fischer said, but it wouldn't take long to get out of it. The idea was to anchor just outside the mouth of Menemsha Creek where the tide runs swiftly between Vineyard Sound and Menemsha Pond and bonito follow the tide in pursuit of baitfish. Get fast to healthy bonito, Doug said, and you'd think you had a bonefish on, the way those critters could run. We took 21 bonito yesterday, he said, and we don't have to burn a lot of gas.

title: Quake Rocks Greek Area
description: ATHENS, Sept. 25 (UPI)  A tremor shook the Pella area in northern Greece today, causing two houses to collapse, the police said. There were no reports of injuries.

title: Guidelines Board Lifts PayRise Standard to 8%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The Council on Wage and Price Stability liberalized its voluntary pay standard today by authorizing an extra one percentage point pay increase for roughly 90 percent of the work force.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: A Capital Party That Few Skipped
description: WASHINGTON

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Mascagni's Cavalleria Rusticana and Leoncavallo's Pagilacci, 8.

title: Yankees Win; 13th For Davis
description: Bucky Dent, whose fortunes plummeted as quickly this season as they soared after last year's World Series, sat on the bench with his .230 batting average last night and watched Damaso Garcia provide a glimmer of support to the Yankees hopes that he can replace Dent as their shortstop next year.

title: New Orders Of Durables Up by 0.8%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) New orders for durable goods received by the nation's factories rose by eighttenths of 1 percent last month, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Islanders Triumph on Late Goal by Rookie
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 25  Two goals in the last eight minutes made up for a sloppy start and allowed the Islanders to win their first National Hockey League exhibition game, 21, from the Buffalo Sabres at Nassau Coliseum. The Sabres have yet to win in four contests.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Prices Drop Moderately As I.B.M. Confirms Offer
description: The International Business Machines Corporation confirmed its plans for a billiondollar borrowing in midOctober yesterday and the credit markets moved lower in price and higher in yield as a wide variety of new fixedincome issues were offered for sale.

title: Lefley of Blues Injures Shoulder in Comeback Bid
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 (UPI)  Chuck Lefley, trying to return to the St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League after a season in Europe and a season out of hockey, is expected to be sidelined for two months because of a shoulder separation.

title: 2d Mistrial Is Declared for Newton; Prosecutor to Seek Closing of Case
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 25  The jury in Huey P. Newton's murder trial was dismissed this afternoon when its members said they were hopelessly deadlocked, 11 to 1, for acquittal.

title: Real Estate
description: SURELY Northern Boulevard in Long Island City is one of the stronger spines of production and distribution in the city. Among the names that grace the major commercial properties are Gallo Wines, Standard Motor Products, Columbia Pictures and Ronzoni Macaroni. The latter is a longtime fixture that recently built a formidable addition to its main manufacturing plant.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Sidney Harman, the highfidelity pioneer who served for almost two years, until last December, as Under Secretary of Commerce, has agreed in principle to reacquire two of the companies he sold to the Beatrice Foods Company in 1977. And in a telephone interview from Goteborg, Sweden, where he is spending the week as a consultant to Volvo, he explained the reasons why.

title: Getting to the Source
description: Some deliverers of seltzer require minimum orders and most require deposits on the bottles. The reason for these requirements is that part of the charm of seltzer  that it is made the same way it was 40 years ago and comes in siphon bottles of handblown European glass made 40 or more years ago  is also part of the headache of running a seltzer business.

title: Angels Take Western Title
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 25  The magic number reached zero here tonight as the California Yes We Can Angels clinched their first divisional baseball chamnionship.

title: Achieving Mideast Peace
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Most Arabs and their governments believe that. the current bilateral negotiations between Egypt and Israel are based on error and, as in previous peace efforts, are likely to lead to a dead end.

title: State's Chief Judge Contends Backlogs In Courts Demand Sacrifice by Jurists
description: Citing staggering calendars which face the trial courts of our state, New York's Chief Judge, Lawrence H. Cooke, last night urged the state's trial judges to sacrifice by giving much more of their time and of themselves to the solution of this serious problem.

title: Head of Teamster Local And ExOfficial Indicted
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 (AP)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation today arrested the president of a teamsters union local and a former official of the union on charges that they had violated Federal racketeering statutes by committing murder, attempted murder, arson and embezzlement of union funds.

title: Advertising
description: OVER the years, the country's campuses have been both the birthplace and the burial ground of many brave new entrepreneurial concepts in the area of advertising media. Since many advertisers support the philosophy of the bent twig, there are many entrepreneurs thinking of ways of carrying their messages to where the twigs are growing.

title: Notes on People
description: Mamie Eisenhower suffered a stroke yesterday at her farm home in Gettysburg, Pa., and was rushed to Walter Reed Army Medical Center near Washington. The 82yearold widow of Dwight D. Eisenhower was later listed in stable condition and was under medication.

title: Dayan Calls Carter Friend of Israel, Despite Rifts
description: Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan, who a month ago was expressing concern about trends of American policy, said yesterday that President Carter and his Administration had done more for Israel than any previous Administration, even though Israel was often subject to criticism from Washington.

title: Pringle Memorial Set for Today
description: A memorial service for J. Donald Pringle, a former deputy chief of the United Nations Radio Service, will be held at 6:30 P.M. today at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 73d Street and Madison Avenue. Mr. Pringle died last week at the age of 65 at his home in Manhattan. After retiring in 1974 after 28 years on the United Nations staff, he became a United Nations correspondent for Radio Eireann, the Irish radio network.

title: The Story Behind the Signal To Brush Back Cliff Johnson
description: The most disastrous single event of the Yankees' year of frustration was a postgame lockerroom brawl in which the team's star relief pitcher, Rich Gossage, injured his throwing hand fighting with a big, burly secondstring catcher named Cliff Johnson. Gossage subseguently missed most of the season, and thOugh five months have now passed since the incident  during which Johnson was traded to the Cleveland Indians there is latent enmity on the part of some Yankees toward their former teammate. And when Cliff Johnson was batting against the Yankees in Cleveland last week, in a game that the Indians won by 163, a fastball was aimed high at his body and hit him on the left arm, which he had suddenly lifted to protect his face.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Careers
description: ENTREPRENEURSHIP, which might be defined roughly as the ability and desire of an individual to operate a business, is on the rise. The proof is not only in commments from experts that the availability of venture capital has been growing despite the economic slowdown, but also in the spate of courses and seminars offered by various institutions to help people start new businesses. In addition, many colleges are beginning to offer courses in entrepreneurship.

title: Around the Nation
description: THREE FORKS, Mont., Sept. 25 (AP)  The trail of a toxic chemical accidentally mixed into animal meal at a Montana packing plant has led to a fourth Western poultry producer, and the owners have slaughtered nearly 53,000 laying hens.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: TAPIO RAUTAVAARA

title: Bronx Man and Sister Seized in Conspiracy To Kill 5 for Revenge
description: A Bronx man and his sister were arrested yesterday on charges they had paid $10,000 to a hit man  who was in fact an undercover police officer  to murder five men in a revenge conspiracy.

title: Seltzer: A Renaissance in Fizz
description: ONCE a month on Wednesday nights, the man's connection conies  a lean bluejeaned young man with long hair (a hippie, his mother would say), schlepping a weathered case of seltzer to an apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side. The man keeps the case under his kitchen counter, always minus two of the venerable siphon bottles, which he cools in his refrigerator. He drinks his seltzer straight. For his children he mixes his seltzer with Fox's UBet syrups, just the way they did in the candy stores of his childhood; and to much the same delighted reception. He is one of the thousands of New Yorkers joined in a symbiotic relationship with a handful of dealers that has created a renaissance in the seltzer. trade. At a time when the haut monde has turned to Perrier and other sparkling waters in its relentless effort to inject all life with effervescence, a coincidence of nostalgia and the desire for unadulterated products and calorieless treats has focused attention on the city's ineradicable and thriving seltzer underground. While a few oldtimers still practice the seltzer trade among a clientele of oldtimers, the new wave is characterized by dealers in their 20's and 30's and a clientele returning to the ways of their parents and grandparents. There to meet them are companies with names like Gimme Seltzer, Seltzer Unlimited and Marty the Seltzer Man. What they are offering, now as in the past, is a product that contains nothing more and nothing less than thricefilteredtered water and carbon dioxide. No salts; no flavors; no preservatives  a trio that is sweet music the palates of the health conscious. What they bring is a 10case of 26ounce bottles, all definitely recycled, since none is younger than 40 years old, a result of the fact that the manufacture of seltzer bottles hereabouts is a dead art. And what they take away are the empties, and $4 or $4.50. While the competing international and domestic behemoths of the sparkling water trade plow large sums into advertising, the new breed of seltzerman is characterized by simple, straightforward praise for his product. Probably one of the most uncomfortable things to carry home in a shopping bag is bottles of soda, said Ron Roth of Seltzer Unlimited. We deliver it for you. But seltzer is really a good product. I don't have to lie about it to sell it. It's a pure, clean natural beverage, and on top of that, it's fun to play with. Mr. Roth, apparently a Pavlovian theorist, used seltzer to train his cat. Every time I saw him on one of my speakers, I squirted him. It was very effective. Effective, too, was the use of seltzer by generations of comedians from the Silent Era onward, who used a quick squirt to deflate the pompous and drench the starchy. Seltzer was brought to the United States by Jewish immigrants in the early part of this century. David Alan Kirsch, the executive vice president of Kirsch Beverages Inc., recalled not long ago that when his grandfather Hyman, the company's founder, arrived in New York from Russia in 1904, the streets were so full of seltzer wagons that he decided to make fruitflavored sodas rather than compete. The wheel turns, observed Mr. Kirsch, noting that in this, its 75th anni- versary year, Kirsch Beverages Inc., has become the exclusive distributor for Montclair SparWhere To Get It, How To Use It See Page C6

title: Geneen and 17 Buy 9.7% Of Pneumo
description: An 18member investor group including Harold S. Geneen, chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, has purchased a 9.7 percent stake in the Pneumo Corporation, the diversified aerospace company said yesterday.

title: Students Boycott High Schools To Back Coaches Pay Demands
description: Thousands of high school students, waving placards and chanting We want sports, walked out of class yesterday morning in support of a job action by coaches that has halted extracurricular sports activities in most city high schools.

title: Jesse Jackson Visits A Palestinian Camp, Sees Jewish Memorial
description: KALANDIA REFUGEE CAMP, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Sept. 25Mixing a preacher's theatrical style with the instinct of a politician on the stump, the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson swept through a Palestinian refugee camp outside Jerusalem today.

title: Carter Signs Legislation Approving Completion of a Dam in Tennessee
description: President Carter signed legislation last night permitting the completion of the Tellico Dam, the hydroelectric project in Tennessee that had been blocked for five years because of fears that it threatened the existence of a small fish known as the snail darter.

title: Dispute on Transit Fund Compounded by Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  With its charges, countercharges, accusations and denials, the current dispute over the availability of Federal masstransit money for New York State erupted into the most serious battle yet between Gov- ernor Carey and the Carter Administration.

title: Senator Pressler Joins G.O.P. Race For 1980 Presidential Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Larry Pressler, a freshman Senator from South Dakota, announced his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination today, making him the eighth candidate and, at 37, the youngest contender for the office.

title: S.E.C. Extends Trading Tests
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission approved threeyear extensions today for two experimental securities trading systems that may be forerunners of a national market system.

title: South Africa Extends the Rights Of Blacks' Unions to Negotiate
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 25 (AP) South Africa granted union rights to the nation's black majority today, including the two large worker categories that had been excluded under a similar directive in the spring.

title: NBC Leads, in TV Upset
description: In an astonishing upset, sparked by such blockbuster movies as Coming Home and SemiTough, NBCTV vaulted from last place in the audiencepopularity ratings to a decisive No 1 for the first week of the new television season. The primetime averages in the Nielsen ratings for the week that ended Sunday were 20.6 for NBC, 18.0 for ABCTV and 16.9 for CBSTV.

title: House Votes Bill Giving Congress A Raise of 5.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The House of Representatives, by a fivevote margin, today approved a 5.5 percent pay increase for members of Congress and about 20,000 toplevel Federal employees and judges.

title: Justice's Arrest Fans Criticism of Brown Appointments
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25  Last week the Oakland Police Department made a pair of arrests on marijuanacultivation charges that have resulted in further reexamination of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s judicial appointments.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: One of the most fascinating stores in Manhattan is Shackman's on lower Fifth Avenue. It's crammed full of all those small things that have delighted children (and adults) since the 19th century  books, toys, tricks. There are copies of books with colored illustrations by Kate Greenaway and George Cruikshank (his The ToothAche is especially amusing) as well as Victorian cards and games. And, oh joy, those small picture books from our childhood, where the characters move when the pages are flipped. And more: enough doll house furniture, including minuscule real books, to furnish an entire hamlet, and copies of the ByeLo doll of 1923, for which Grace Storey Putnam, the sculptor, used a newborn baby as model. Shackman's is at 85 Fifth Avenue (16th Street).

title: Treadway in Care Suit
description: Treadway Companies Inc. announced yesterday that it had filed a complaint in Federal court in New York against the Care Corporation and two officers. The suit alleges that the defendants conspired to seize control of Treadway, filing false statements as to Care's real intent in purchasing Treadway stock. Treadway also asked that Care be made to divest itself of the 32 percent of Treadway it recently acquired.

title: Union May Widen Dutch/Shell Strike
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 25 (AP)  A strike at Shell's giant Pernis refinery and its nearby Moerdijk chemical complex could spread if demands for shorter working hours are not met, union officials said today.

title: Jane Fonda to Office Workers: Organize
description: Jane Fonda, the actress, urged 800 office workers last night to organize and become a force, as women and as clerical workers.

title: Getting Elected in Japan Is an Expensive Business
description: TOKYO, Sept. 25  Shortly after the Government announced Japan's next parliamentary election for Oct. 7, about MO candidates for the 511 seats in the House of Representatives lined up in front of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira at the Tokyo headquarters of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party for a simple but important ceremony.

title: Market Place
description: BECTON, DICKINSON & COMPANY appears to be in a strong position to influence the court in the divestiture by the Sun Company of its Becton shares.

title: Reliance Gets 64% Of Rothschild Bid
description: LONDON, Sept. 25 (Reuters)The Reliance Group Inc. said today that it had received acceptances covering some 64 percent of Rothschild Investment Trust Ltd.'s ordinary shares, following its $6.50ashare bid to acquire 5.4 million shares, or 23.9 percent.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Morgan Stanley Shuns I.B.M. Issue
description: To the surprise of Wall Street, the $1 billion debt offering that the International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday will not be managed by Morgan Stanley & Company, I.B.M.'s traditional investment bankers. Salomon Brothers and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith will handle the offering instead.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Inquiry Discovers No Cause For Reilly Case Grand Jury
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Sept. 25  A special assistant state's attorney appointed nine months ago to investigate the murder of Barbara Gibbons  for which her son, Peter Reilly, was convicted but later exonerated  reported today that there are not sufficient grounds at this time to call for a grand jury investigation of anybody.

title: Vietnam Veterans Found To Have Major Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The first Governmentsponsored study of Vietnam veterans has tentatively concluded that more than 40 percent of them suffer major emotional difficulties, such as alcoholism and narcotics abuse, and that more than 75 percent of them complain of nightmares, marital discord and job problems.

title: Opera: Something Special About Domingo's Portrayal of Otello
description: THERE seemed to be something special about Monday night's Metropolitan Opera opening. Perhaps it was the excitement attendant on a great opera, Verdi's Otello. For the opera buffs there was the added attraction of Placido Domingo in the title role. Mr. Domingo had not previously sung the role in New York, and there was much anticipation and even worry. Was Otello too heavy for him? Would he strain? Would there be damage to the wonderful voice?

title: WASHINGTON
description: BOSTON, Sept. 25  The first impression one has of political audiences in this Presidential campaign is that they are skeptical of all candidates, even here in Kennedy country, but are ready for serious discussion of the complicated issues that now confuse and divide the nation.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1979

title: The Region
description: MELVILLE, L.I.  A truck carrying an 8,000pound piece of surgical machinery containing radioactive material was halted at Exit 48 of the Long Island Expressway here yesterday because the truck had balding tires and bad brakes, according to Suffolk County safety and health officials.

title: TV: CloseUp at the Met
description: THE Metropolitan Opera is no neophyte in the electronic medium. Several of its opening nights were televised in the past, beginning in 1948 with another Otello that starred Licia Albanese and Ramon Vinay. Those early broadcasts, though, tended to be technical nightmares, producing pictures that too often suggested pools of watery blackbean soup.

title: Texas Air to Pursue T.W.A.
description: Texas International Airlines announced after a meeting of its board in Houston yesterday that it intends to continue seeking means to acquire Trans World Airlines despite the flat refusal by the Trans World Corporation, the parent of T.W.A., to discuss such a combination. Last week the board of Trans World joined the company's management in opposing the Texas International plan.

title: White Sox 9, Twins 3
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 25 (AP)  Claudell Washington had three hits and drove in two runs tonight, powering Ken Kravec and the Chicago White Sox to a 93 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: In Paris, the Old Cuisine Lives
description: FASHIONS in food and restaurants are as fickle as those in clothing and home furnishings and all too often only the latest is in. Anyone who confines eating in Paris to new restaurants and the nouvelle cuisine is certain to miss out on some lusty and spectacular food, for is doubtful that such inclinations would lead one to the drab doorway of L'Ami Louis in the obscure, downandout Fourth Arrondissement.

title: Experiment in Learning: Bilingual College's Way
description: When Harvard recently announced plans for a new undergraduate core curriculum that emphasizes the approach to knowledge rather than its accumulation, a sense of satisfaction and recognition was felt in New York City at a school whose ties are with the inner city rather than with the Ivy League.

title: I.B.M. Rally Steadies Stock Market
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, which helped send the stock market into a tailspin Monday amid unconfirmed reports of plans for a huge debt offering, rallied late yesterday and finished higher. I.B.M.'s recovery played a key role in steadying the overall market, although declining issues still outnumbered advances by ratio of more than 4 to 3.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Sept. 25, 1979

title: Montreal Star Ceases Publication After Loss of Circulation in Strike
description: The Montreal Star, an afternoon newspaper that has been struggling to regain circulation lost to a morning rival during an eightmonth strike, announced yesterday that it was ceasing publication because of heavy financial losses.

title: Compromise Canal Bill Passes Easily in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)  The Senate today passed a bill designed to carry out the Panama Canal Treaty.

title: Putting Pizazz Into a SaltFree Diet: A MotherinLaw's Advice
description: In their enthusiasms, people who cook without salt are like golfers. Or tennis players. Or skiers. But rather than discuss their latest exploits in sinking a putt or the newest racquets, or the snows of yesteryear and tomorrow, the saltfree people talk about the secrets they use to give special force or emphasis in flavor to foods.

title: G.M.'s New Battery for Small Cars
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The General Motors Corporation unveiled a new electric power source for a midget car here today, a zincnickel oxide battery that corporate executives called a technological breakthrough.

title: Johnny Appleseed
description: Johnny Appleseed, a.k.a. John Chapman, born this day in 1774, was a Massachusetts man who for almost 50 years planted seeds and seedlings across a stretch of frontier from northwestern Pennsylvania to Fort Wayne, Indiana. What was equally important to him, he scattered the seeds of Swedenborgianism wherever he went. He was no simpleton, though he went barefoot if he could, even occasionally in the snow, as he conceived that a biblical Christian would have. He wore a pasteboard cap and coffeesack smock and lived on cornmeal mush and roast potatoes, which he traded for apples, but he passed up meat, remonstrating with people who hunted wildlife for the pot. He was also angered by the practice of torturing fruit trees by grafting them. To him, their flowering was a recapitulation of God's own intricate abundance.

title: Excerpts From Carter's Town Meeting Exchanges
description: Consider your 1976 election campaign promises, and consider how those ideas and programs have progressed. Consider that the American dollar has been plummeting. Consider the rise in inflation; the oil crisis; the gas lines; the tremendous cost of homeheating oil. Consider the tumultuous nature of your everchanging Cabinet. Consider how we have added more destruction to our eco system with nuclear energy and oil spills.

title: $1 Bill's Replacement By a Coin Suggested
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)  The dollar bill should be systematically replaced with the new Susan B. Anthony dollar coin, and the halfdollar coin should be eliminated, a highlevel Government study group recommended today.

title: Oppenheimer Prospers In Unusual Investments
description: They're not brokers, they're entrepreneurs, said a close associate of Oppenheimer & Company. He was describing the Wall Street partnership of 25 men that this week agreed to buy Advance Mortgage, the nation's thirdlargest mortgage banker, from Citicorp for an undisclosed sum.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE word from the vineyards is good. Last week, the grapes in the Mdoc were round and fat and full of color and the scratchy gray soil was warm from repeated days of autumnal sun. To the north, in the Loire where there have been two disastrous years, there was mounting excitement as farmers watched what could be a huge crop reaching maturity. Across France, except in the Cotes de Nuits, where floods and hail did great damage in the spring, current signs point to a fine harvest.

title: U.S. Challenges Cross Merger
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it had filed a civil antitrust suit challenging the merger of the Cross Company and the Kearney & Trecker Corporation into a holding company called the Cross & Trecker Corporation. The two companies merged on Feb. 13.

title: Pirates Win and Regain Lead
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25  There is something awesome in Willie Stargell's home runs as the ball dives into a sea of waving arms and clutching hands, each grasping for a piece of the moment.

title: YOUNG MEETS DAYAN AND A RIFT IS ENDED
description: Andrew Young paid a call upon Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel yesterday to heal a personal rift caused by his assertion that Mr. Dayan had disclosedhis unauthorized meeting with a Palestine Liberation Organization envoy.

title: The Theater: Love's Labour's Lost
description: ON opening night of Michael Moriarty's production of Love's Labour's Lost, staged without scenery in a small downstairs space at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, I wrote on my note pad, Berowne is smirking. Berowne, as you remember, is the wittiest and the most sophisucated of snake speare's quartet of gentlemen who have temporarily foresworn the company of women in order to pursue a life of learning. Berowne might smile sardonically, but he would never smirk.

title: Cubic Collects on Fare Systems
description: SAN DIEGO  Walter J. Zable, chairman and president of the Cubic Corporation, sometimes sounds as if he is unhappy about the company's fastestgrowing line of business, the development of mass transit fare collection systems. If we had to go into the business today, we'd never do it, he said. That's why I.B.M. got out. It didn't fit their operations and the public exposure can be awful. All the flak you get.

title: Monterrey:Setting The Pace
description: The list is overwhelming. Millions of tons of steel, miles of pipe, acres of sheet glass, billions of cigarettes, millions of bottles of beer, thousands of miles of copper wire, millions of tons of cement. Cookies, truck bodies, plastic bags, light bulbs, chemicals, dyes, synthetic fibers and animal feed. And more.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Opera: Met Presents Le Prophte
description: BEFORE the Metropolitan Opera revived Meyerbeer's Le Prophte in 1977, it hadn't been heard in the house since 1928. The 1977 production offered Renata Scotto, Marilyn Home, James McCracken, Jerome Hines and Morley Meredith, conducted by Henry Lewis, and there were grumblings then that that lineup failed to live up to past castings.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1979

title: Braves Phil Niekro Sparks 94 Rout
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 26 (AP)  Phil Niekro drove in four runs and earned his 20th victory in outpitching his brother, Joe, as the Atlanta Braves dealt another blow to the Houston Astros division title hopes with a 94 victory tonight.

title: 11,500 Officers To Protect Pope On Visit to City
description: A total of 11,500 of the city's 23,700 police officers, including some overhead in helicopters and others in scuba gear in the waters off La Guardia Airport and Battery Park, will be mobilized next Tuesday and Wednesday to protect Pope John Paul II, control crowds and handle traffic.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: New Suffolk Law Bars All Repricing of Items On a Grocer's Shelves
description: The Suffolk County Legislature has approved legislation that would prohibit supermarkets and other food stores in the county from raising the prices of groceries once they have been marked and placed on a store shelf.

title: The Rat and I: A Behavioral Test
description: ONE meets rats these days mostly in books about poverty, where they are naturally resented, but it was not that way with me and my rat. Our encounter was ambiguous.

title: Now, a Better View Up in Central Park
description: Elizabeth Barlow whispered like a successful conspirator to Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis yesterday during a dedication ceremony in Central Park.

title: Angels and Autry Celebrate First Title
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 26  An hour after the Angels clinched it, their bestknown fan held up a soggy towel in the locker room.

title: Don Zimmer Is Still There
description: The word is that Don Zimmer is staying on as manager of the Boston Red Sox, Haywood Sullivan and Buddy LeRoux having discovered that Zim did not, alone and unaided, lose the 68 games that appeared in the team standings yesterday under L. If this is so, the decision of the team's coowners will be more popular with the players man with we fans, and more popular with Don Zimmer than with anybody else. The player like Zim, but Zim loves the job.

title: Ford Opposes Arms Pact Unless U.S. Builds Strength
description: CARLISLE, Pa., Sept. 26  Describing himself as deeply troubled, former President Gerald R. Ford said today that he would oppose ratification of the United StatesSoviet strategic arms treaty until and unless we can once again be certain of our strength.

title: Amid Urban Decay, Reflections on Pope's Visit
description: Even in neighborhoods where enthusiasm is overlaid with cynicism and belief is an iffy proposition, an impending papal visit generates excitement and anticipation. Such is the atmosphere in two of the city's symbols of urban decay  Harlem and the South Bronx.

title: John Who? Gets Fast Start In New Hampshire Primary
description: CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 26  Representative John B. Anderson, the 10term Illinois Republican who wants to be President, had just finished a short but, as usual, polished dissertation on what he sees as the continued potential for danger in the politically volatile Middle East.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Kazanas of Y.&R. Moves To New York Magazine
description: Constantine J. Kazanas, vice president/print media at Young & Rubicam and a wellknown industry expert, has put the agency world behind him to become advertising sales director of New York magazine. Surmise. Sunrise.

title: Nuclear Device Detonated
description: PAHUTE MESA, Nev., Sept. 26 (UPI)  A nuclear weapon detonated underground at the Nevada Test Site today sent shock waves that were felt slightly in Las Vegas 115 miles away. The nuclear device, codenamed Sheepshead, had an explosive yield of 20 to 150 kilotons, or the maximum equivalent of 150,000 tons of TNT, according to a spokesman for the Department of Energy.

title: Presidential Politics Rides the Subways
description: As Governor Carey and the Secretary of Transportation, Neil Goldschmidt, walk arminarm into the sunset, it becomes clear that the four days of bickering between Washington and Albany have had little to do with major transportation issues and much to do with the 1980 campaign. New Yorkers, bewildered, could at least take solace from the fact that the Federal Government will now try to find extra money for New York City's mass transit system. But it remains necessary to sort out smoke and fire and to know what that money is meant to buy.

title: Goodyear Tire Shipments
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 26 (UPI)  The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company reported today that its winter tire shipments were 8 percent ahead of last year, an early surge that the company's analysts attributed to the experience of the last three harsh winters.

title: Suspenders to Be Staged At Henry Street Theater
description: Suspenders, a play by Umar Bin Hassan that examines the tangible signs of success, will be performed from next Thursday through Oct. 21 at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater, 466 Grand Street. Alan Freeman Jr. will direct.

title: Girl Killed, 22 Hurt in Crash
description: WILLMAR, Minn., Sept. 26 (AP) 13yearold girl was killed and 22 persons were injured when a semitrailer truck carrying 51,000 pounds of durum wheat struck the rear of a school bus, the authorities said. Cindy Dierenfeld of Willmar was killed when she was thrown from the bus in the accident yesterday.

title: U.S. to End Import Aid on Heating Oil
description: PARIS, Sept. 26  Energy Secretary Charles W. Duncan Jr. promised European and Japanese energy ministers today that President Carter would end his $5abarrel subsidy on imported heating oil on Oct. 31.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: REELS provide a neat storage system for such things as wire or hose, which otherwise can easily become tangled.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 26 (UPI) Three newspapers and two television stations received subpoenas today demanding that they turn over to a Federal grand jury all material relating to coverage of a recent bar association assembly.

title: Advertising
description: SINCE the most consistently controversial facet of the advertising business is syndicated magazine audience research, it wasn't surprising that the release of the latest Simmons study yesterday was preceded by a furor. The cause for the howling is the way the research company adjusted some of its findings. But first, what about the findings of 1979 Study of Media and Markets?

title: A Judge Charges Transit Authority Ignores Impending El Disaster
description: A State Supreme Court justice assailed the New York City Transit Authority yesterday, saying it ignored impending disaster by not responding sufficiently to danger from an elevated structure in Brooklyn. Parts of the BMT's B line structure  nuts, bolts and spikes  have been falling into the street over the last year.

title: Proxmire Lauds Volcker On High Interest Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board won praise today from Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, for the board's use of high interest rates to fight inflation, despite widespread criticism.

title: Both Sides Are Acting to Minimize Dispute Over MassTransit Subsidy
description: A dispute over Federal aid for New York's mass transit system wound down yesterday, with both sides attempting to smooth over events of the last several days.

title: Quakes Rattle California Area
description: BISHOP, Calif., Sept. 26 (UPI)Three small earthquakes shook the Long Valley area, west of San Francisco at the Nevada border, yesterday morning. There were no reports of damage from the quakes, the largest of which was measured at 3.8 on the Richter scale.

title: Soviet Warship Enters Japan Sea
description: TOKYO, Sept. 26 (AP)  The Soviet guided missile cruiser Petropavlovsk has entered the Japan Sea after cruising in the Tsushima Strait between Japan and South Korea since Sent. 28. the Jananese Defense Agency said today. A Japanese reconnaissance plane spotted the 8,200ton warship about 185 miles north of Tsushima early today, the agency said.

title: Rightists Blocked in Madrid
description: MADRID, Sept. 26 (Reuter)  The Spanish police, using tear gas, broke up an unauthorized demonstration by 200 extreme rightwingers in the center of Madrid last night. The demonstration, organized by the New Force Party, was the second in two nights in the wake of the weekend killing of Guip(izcoa Province's military governor by Basque separatists.

title: Home Improvement
description: MOST wellstocked paint and hardware stories have at least one color mixing system, which enables the dealer to mix hundreds of different paint colors after the customer selects the desired shade from color samples. The dealer adds premeasured quantities of color according to a formula supplied by the manufacturer.

title: Parole Is Granted to Dr. Coppolino, Jailed in 67 in Killing of His Wife
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 26  Dr. Carl A. Coppolino, the New Jersey physician who was sentenced to life in prison in 1967 for the murder of his wife, Carmela, was granted parole today on condition that he not practice medicine without written permission of the Florida parole authorities. He will be released from the Avon Park Correctional Institution on Oct. 16.

title: Ceiling on C.D.'s Raised
description: The Treasury yesterday raised the rates that banks may pay on certificates of deposit maturing in more than four years that they issue in October. The maximum rate for such commercial bank C.D.'s was raised to 8.25 percent from 7.95 percent in September, and the rate for savings institutions was increased to 8.50 percent from 8.20 percent.

title: Arabs Building a Tanker Fleet
description: KUWAIT  Arab oilproducing countries, having captured substantial control over the price and supply of oil in the last decade, are slowly moving into other segments of the oil business, particularly transportation.

title: Cities on the Pope's Tour Brace For Throngs Hoping to See Him
description: In Boston, a city buried under an avalanche of conventions, the Convention Bureau has written a form letter telling people that there are no hotel rooms on the day that Pope John Paul II is arriving in town.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets drifted downward yesterday, discouraged by the continued large increases in the Consumer Price Index and the rise in durablegoods orders, which indicated that the steam has not gone out of the economy yet. Bond prices declined and interest rates rose.

title: Charges of Illegalities in Simon's Bronx Campaign Bring F.B.I. Inquiries
description: Charges of illegalities in Stanley Simon's successful campaign for the Democratic nomination for Bronx Borough President have prompted inquiries by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Iranians Expel Reporter Of Wall Street Journal
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 26 (Reuters) Iran today ordered the expulsion of Rama Chandra Mohan, the correspondent in Teheran for The Wall Street Journal.

title: Parley Worries White Rhodesian Farmers
description: BEATRICE, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Sept. 26  Collin J. Cook came home here yesterday after three weeks he spent in Britain for a medical checkup and a close look at the talks that may determine his future.

title: Brutality Laid to 4 Border Agents
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 26 (UPI)  Four Border Patrol agents were indicted yesterday on charges that they had banded together as vigilantes to brutalize Mexicans who had illegally crossed into the United States and had then covered up their actions.

title: Carter Acts to Strengthen Federal Consumer Programs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  President Carter signed an executive order today that he said would make Federal consumer programs more responsive to consumer complaints.

title: Bridge:
description: A year ago, the triathlon, a contest devised in Athens, proved a considerable success in New York. Like the decathlon and the pentathlon, which are included in the modern Olympic Games, the triathlon consists of several events in one.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, Sept. 26  While military agents and the police looked on, 400 students of the University of the Philippines sang patriotic songs and chanted Down with the U.S.Marcos dictatorship in a twohour demonstration this afternoon.

title: On the Bill Curbing Interests' Gifts
description: WASHINGTON  A bill that the House may be soon asked to consider is designed to reduce the amount of money that a politicalaction committee, or PAC, can give a House candidate and the amount any candidate can receive from all PAC's. Its highminded sponsors believe it would magically prevent alleged specialinterest manipulations of the Congress. None of the bill's supporters has been able to identify any House member who has been unduly influenced by any interest, nor have they shown that PAC contributions are a greater, or less great, influence than editorials, direct lobbying, demonstrations or independent expenditures.

title: Auto Union Neutral for Kennedy
description: DETROIT, Sept. 26  The United Automobile Workers, one of the more politically effective unions in the country, is now neutral for Kennedy, Douglas A. Fraser, the union's president, said today.

title: TimeLife Books Sets Up Stonehenge Press Imprint
description: TimeLife Books of Alexandria, Va., one of the giants of the mailorder book business, has set up a separate imprint, Stonehenge Press.

title: Arco Polymers Unit
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 (Reuters)  Arco Polymers Inc. said it had formed Arco Durethene Plastics Inc. as a wholly owned subsidiary. Arco, a subsidiary of the Atlantic Richfield Company, said the operation was formed to capitalize on the longterm growth potential for fabricated plastic products.

title: Mass Transit: Carter's Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  President Carter's proposal to spend $50 billion for mass transit over the next 10 years has less to it than meets the eye and is predicated on several conditions, one of which seems questionable at the moment.

title: McCann in Chinese Ad Venture
description: McCannErickson Worldwide, one of the world's largest advertising agencies, announced yesterday that it had established a joint venture in Peking and was prepared to handle advertising in China for Western corporations and advertising in the West for Chinese Governmentowned foreigntrade corporations and other organizations.

title: ABC Publications' Chief Draws Criticism
description: The remarks of Seth H. Baker, president of ABC Publications, quoted in this space recently, really got under the skin of William H. Ryan, articles editor of Next, a new publication from Litton Publishing.

title: Ottawa Envoy on Mideast Issues Meets With Officials in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 26 (Reuters)Canada's special envoy for Middle East questions held talks here today with Iraqi leaders on the ArabIsraeli conflict, the Palestinian problem and other issues.

title: Test Well Off Newfoundland Gains
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Sept. 26  A deepening of the Hibernia 015 discovery well off Newfoundland has yielded additional hydrocarbons, significantly improving the commercial prospects for the East Coast's first crude oil strike, H.J. Haynes, chairman and chief executive officer of the Standard Oil Company of California, said today.

title: Competitive Broadcaster
description: Within the television industry, the legends of Roone Pinckney Arledge Jr. are much like instant replay  a series of events worth repeating.

title: Endangered Houses
description: ONE of the more evocative American adventures is to tread, acre by acre, the 16mile stretch of land on the east bank of the Hudson River that was developed in the earlier part of the 19th century by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Livingston and their 10 children.

title: Market Place
description: IRVING TERRIS did not convert his UV Industries preferred convertible stock before the Feb. 28, 1979, deadline and thus missed out on a chance to get 2.368 common shares for every share of preferred he owned. His case is symptomatic of a widespread problem: It seems that there is always someone who misses out on a conversion.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  An undercover state task force caught bartenders in nine New Jersey taverns serving alcohol to drunken customers during the past weekend, Attorney General John J. Degnan reported.

title: Jazz Horns: James Moody
description: LIVING in Las Vegas is supposed to be good for a jazz musician's health and pocketbook and bad for his artistry. But James Moody, the saxophonist and flutist who Is making one of his very infrequent New York club appearances at Sweet Basil through Saturday, seems to be thriving there.

title: Musicians Strike Minnesota Orchestra
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 26 (AP) The Minnesota Orchestra went on strike today, the first musicians' strike in its 76year history, and delayed the debut of Neville Marriner as successor of conductor Stanislaw Skrowaczewski.

title: Red Sox Replace Jackson With Podres as Coach;
description: BOSTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)  The Boston Red Sox dropped their pitching coach, Al Jackson, today and solidified Don Zimmer's job as manager into the 1980 season.

title: ABCTV Pays Record 225 Million for '84 Olympics
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26  In one of the most expensive transactions in the history of television, the American Broadcasting Companies today won United States television rights to the 1984 Summer Olympic Games in Los Angeles with a bid of $225 million.

title: An Accounting Error Leads to 17% Pay Cut
description: ALBANY, Sept. 26 (AP)  The chairman of the Legislature's Bill Drafting Commission reduced the paychecks of most of his 300 employees by 17 percent today after discovering the commission did not have enough cash to get through the year.

title: 40 Black Artists to Show At Henry Street Center
description: Cross Sections, an exhibition by 40 black artists, will be on display from next Thursday to Dec. 3 at the Henry Street Settlement Arts for Living Center at 466 Grand Street.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Alexandra Tolstoy Is Dead at 95; Author's Daughter Aided Refugees
description: It was early in the century and she was a young woman in Russia when she fell ill and was sent to the Crimea to recuperate. Sasha has gone, her father, Leo Tolstoy, lamented in his diary. I love her, I miss her, not for the work she does but for her soul.

title: Carey Asks Immediate Fuel Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Governor Carey appealed to Congress today for immediate passage of the Carter Administration's proposed program of emergency assistance to lowincome families faced with high fueloil bills tins winter. But Mr. Carey broke with the Administration by urging that the assistance program not be tied to an oil windfallprofits tax to pay for it.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Brothers Sentenced In Plot to Kill Prostitute
description: A former New York City correction officer sobbed uncontrollably yesterday as he and his brother were sentenced to state prison for conspiring to kill a prostitute.

title: Koch Greeted Warmly in South Bronx
description: Mayor Koch drew a large crowd and warm welcome yesterday in a surprise visit to a South Bronx area that one official referred to as Badillo country.

title: The Milan Furniture Fair: Comfortable Classics
description: MILAN, ITALY NO matter what the language or accent, the word on the lips of visitors to the 19th Salone del Mobile Italiano here was tradition. The international furniture fair, which ended Tuesday, has been a showcase for avantgarde Italian design. This year it offered quieter. more sober fare.

title: CarLicense Deadline Extended
description: ALBANY, Sept. 26 (AP)  Drivers whose car registrations and licenses expire at the end of this month have been given until midnight Oct. 2 to renew because Sept. 30 is a Sunday and Oct. 1 is the Jewish holy day of Yom Kippur, the State Motor Vehicle Department announced today.

title: HolmesShavers: A Bout Between Friends
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 26  Roberto Duran and Sugar Ray Leonard are preliminary fighters. Wilfredo Gomez's defense of the World Boxing Council's superbantamweight title is the warmup bout. Jimmy Young meets the undefeated Michael Dokes in a 10round heavyweight contest that could be a main event in most arenas but is the bottom of the card here.

title: BEGIN WARNS WEST OF PALESTINE PERIL
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 26  Prime Minister Menachem Begin warned the West today that creation of a Palestinian state would provide the Soviet Union with a valuable base in the heart of the Middle East, giving Moscow an important strategic advantage and presenting a great danger for the free world.

title: Building Products Show Profit Rise
description: Profits and sales of manufacturers of building products continued to rise in the second quarter. But the gains were smaller than in previous quarters, reflecting the impact of recession, the F.W. Dodge division of McGrawHill Information Systems Company said yesterday.

title: Spectacular Bid's Workout At Pimlico Called Perfect
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 26 (AP)  Spectacular Bid, training at Pimlico Race Course in preparation for the $350,000 Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park on Oct. 6, ran a mile and an eighth at dawn today in what his trainer, Bud Delp, described as a perfect workout.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Tchalkovsky's Eugene Onegln, 8.

title: Brushback Inquiry Is On
description: An American League spokesman said yesterday that Lee MacPhail, the league president, had asked the New York Yankees for a complete report regarding the pitch that hit Cliff Johnson of the Indians in a game at Cleveland on Sept. 18. The spokesman, Bob Fishel, said that this was part of a league investigation already begun, entailing the questioning of officials from both teams and umpires who were at the game.

title: British I.T.T. Unit Closing 2 TV Plants
description: LONDON, Sept. 26 (AP)  A British unit of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, I.T.T. Consumer Products, announced today that it planned to close two of its three color television plants in Britain next year.

title: Concerns Describe Uranium Find
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Sept. 26 (Reuters)  Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd. and the Inco Metals Company, a division of Inco Ltd., said today that their recent 90hole uranium drilling program in northern Saskatchewan had traced a continuous 2,100foot length of mineralization.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Westchester House Tour, Hudson River Museum, Trevor ParkonHudson, 511 Warburton Avenue, Yonkers, N.Y.

title: Foreign Affiliates List Outlay Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (Reuters)  Foreign affiliates of United States companies plan to increase capital spending by 15 percent next year to $43 billion, following a nearrecord 22 percent rise in 1979, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Guidry Notches His 18th; Nettles Signs for 3 Years
description: Characteristically, Ron Guidry pitched explosively and Catfish Hunter left unpretentiously. Uncharacteristically, Bucky Dent ignited a minor controversy. Somewhere in between, Graig Nettles signed a threeyear contract worth about $1.3 million.

title: MEXICO: A New Kind of Partner
description: The second summit of 1979 between the presidents of Mexico and the United States is on a new stage, but will deal with familiar problems. And, possibly, a kind of partnership.

title: Fuel Oil Supplies Up For Week
description: Stocks of heating oil and diesel fuel increased by six million barrels last week, bringing the total to 216.7 million barrels, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At this time last year, refiners had 207.1 million barrels of these middle distillates in inventories.

title: Living With Dash When Short of Cash
description: IF, for the moment, they cannot live in luxury  if they even teeter rather close to their budget's edge  they can at least live with dash. Living well, on a tight budget, means living wisely  and using generous amounts of elbow grease. The city is full of men and women who have put enormous energy into making their homes something to be proud of. In Your Space: How to Put It Together for Practically Nothing, to be published shortly by St. Martin's Press, the photographer Jon Naar and the author Mary Ellen Moore discuss the way some of these people have managed.

title: Insults Added to Injuries As Jets' Defense Hurts
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 26 Today was a day of big hurts and big insults for the Jets, who began rehearsing for their meeting with the undefeated Miami Dolphins Sunday.

title: Carter Declares Disaster Areas
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)  President Carter yesterday signed disaster declarations for six Texas counties and three Louisiana parishes. The areas were struck by severe storms and floods last week. The declarations will make the residents of the areas eligible for Federal relief and recovery assistance, including grants, temporary housing and lowinterest loans from the Small Business Administration and the Farmers Home Administration.

title: Amtrak Revamps Top Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The president of Amtrak, acknowledging that the system's record for running trains on time often has been sad, announcea a sweeping reorganization of personnel and pledged today to improve service with better food, a more courteous staff and ontime trains.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Payments to Scotto Were Nonpolitical, Witness Says
description: A major prosecution witness, William Montella Jr., vehemently denied yesterday that he had given money to Anthony M. Scotto as cash contributions for political candidates.

title: Senate Unit Pares Funds From Carter Fuel Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The Sen. ate Finance Committee continued to reduce today the money potentially available for President Carter's energy program, while one member proposed a new tax on oil in an effort to provide some financing for the program.

title: Saudis to Extend Extra Oil Production
description: Saudi Arabia, the largest member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and the supplier of 20 percent of United States oil imports, an nounced yesterday that it would continue through the end of the year to produce an extra one million barrels of crude oil a day above what its official production ceiling allows.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: The Time to Soak Up Dollars
description: Hundreds of billions of dollars held abroad make up a sort of supercurrency, a convenient way to pay bills in Bahrain, or store liquid wealth in London. But those billions sloshing around the world's currency markets also represent a threat to the stability of international finance, and a potentially unwelcome source of external pressure on American economic policy.

title: The City
description: Citing rising fuel costs, a landlord group said it was seeking rent increases ranging from 7 percent to 11.5 percent for tenants in 350,000 rentstabilized apartments.

title: Auditor Tells of Tricking Agency With Check to Fictitious Concern
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)Financial safeguards at the General Services Administration are so lax that its own auditors were able to trick the scandalridden agency into sending a $95,000 check to a fictitious concern for goods never supplied, the chief auditor said today.

title: CatchPhrase Dictionary Will Become a Paperback
description: A paperback edition of Eric Partridge's A Dictionary of Catch Phrases will be published next month by Stein & Day.

title: Writes Senator a Letter  Statement in Queens Is Defended by Powell
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  President Carter sent a handwritten note to Senator Edward M. Kennedy today assuring him that his statements last night about leadership and not panicking in a crisis had not been intended as a personal attack.

title: South African Might Review Ban On Interracial Sex and Marriage
description: CAPE TOWN, Sept. 26 (Reuters) Prime Minister P. W. Botha has offered to consider changing the South African laws barring sex or marriage across the color line.

title: Copper Up 11.35 Cents, A Record
description: The price of a pound of copper soared 11.35 cents yesterday, the largest oneday rise in the value of the metal ever recorded on New York's Commodity Exchange, the world's largest market for metals futures.

title: Reds Triumph, Lead By 2 as Astros Lose
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 26  Tom Seaver, 10 years after, walked to his locker and took off his Tshirt. It was a red Tshirt. I love you, Cincinnati, it said.

title: Sunny Mexico: The
description: So say the Mexican tourist ads. The sun never shined on a more beautiful goal. Mexico.

title: Technology
description: THE setting: a quiet university town somewhere in the Northeast. An intruder electronically penetrates the operating system of the town's centralized data processing center. After causing a series or bizarre accidents, the interloper threatens to crash the system, throwing municipal services into chaos unless a $5 million ransom is paid and electronically transferred to a numbered bank account somewhere overseas.

title: Long Wharf to Give Watch on the Rhine
description: A revival of Lillian Hellman's antiwar drama Watch on the Rhine will open the season next Thursday at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. The play, which opened on Broadway in 1941 and was later made into a Bette Davis movie, will star Jan Miner, George Hearn, Joyce Ebert, Jill Eikenberry and Harris Yulin, and will be staged by Arvin Brown, artistic director of the Long Wharf.

title: Rangers and Flyers Play To 55 Tie on Garden Ice
description: The Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers played with intensity, muscle and no little skill last night in a National Hockey League preseason game at Madison Square Garden that wound up in a 55 tie before a crowd of 16,970 that was in midseason form with its cheers and moans.

title: O'Neill Birthday Series Will Begin on Oct. 14
description: A group of 300 prominent writers, directors and actors will gather on Oct. 14 at the Public Theater to begin a series of annual Eugene O'Neill birthday celebrations over the next decade. The highlight of the evening will be a staged reading of Barbara Gelb's O'Neill and Carlotta, to be performed by Jason Robards, Colleen Dewhurst, Geraldine Fitzgerald, Jos Quintero, Philip Anglim and Madeline Kahn.

title: Arizona Guardsmen Seize Factory Where Radioactive Gas Is Leaking
description: Acting under a declaration of emergency issued by Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona Tuesday night, National Guard troops took over a Tucson factory yesterday and seized more than 1,000 gallons of a radioactive substance that had been leaking from the plant for several months.

title: Home Beat
description: PETER SHIRE was born and reared in Echo Park, Calif., and went to art school down the road. Seven years ago he opened EXP Pottery in Echo Park, the area of Los Angeles inhabited, he says, by the people who like the hills but can't afford the Hollywood Hills. At his studio, Mr. Shire does two types of work, production pieces and his more personal and detailed signed pieces. My approach to clay is a design approach, Mr. Shire explained. I don't push, pull or throw clay, but treat it more as if it were metal or wood. Mr. Shire's pieces are compositions assembled of slabs, sheets or extruded pieces of clay. He has a definite predilection for spouted objects  although he denies being particularly a teadrinker. I feel challenged by everyday objects, he added. I try and get them as outrageous as I can and still make them function. In New York, Peter Shire and EXP Pottery is sold at Jenny B. Goode, 1194 Lexington Avenue, and Stephen Anson, 1058 First Avenue. The newer pieces, at right, can be ordered through either of the stores.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1979

title: President's Supporters in an AllOut Fight to Get Florida Caucus Votes
description: MIAMI, Sept. 25  The Carter campaign has unexpectedly put the draftKennedy movement on the defensive here with an allout push over the last two weeks that includes a deal with organized labor, a string of highlevel visits, fresh Federal aid for the state and the assignment of half a dozen White House staff aides to its Florida effort.

title: Mel Gussow to Review The Theater on WQXR
description: Mel Gussow, a drama critic and cultural news reporter for The New York Times, will review Broadway and Off Broadway plays five mornings a week on WQXR radio.

title: Bonemeal for Bulbs: Quality Counts
description: IS bonemeal good for bulbs? Yes, provided it is pure steamed bonemeal. A question was raised in last week's Gardening column when the timehonored tradition of using bonemeal for bulbs was broken by quoting a daffodil expert who said, Bonemeal? Don't use it. The best has gone into dogfood.

title: Argentine Release of Timerman Hailed as Victory for Rule of Law
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26  The Argentine Supreme Court has tried to set a legal limit on the military junta's powers of arbitrary arrest, according to constitutional lawyers here, in the decision that freed Jacobo Timerman, former publisher of La Opinin, after 29 months of detention.

title: P.L.O. Adviser Accused Of a Smuggling Attempt
description: A Hempstead, L.I., engineer, who describes himself as an adviser on American matters to the Palestine Liberation Organization, has been charged with attempting to smuggle stolen communications equipment to the Middle East.

title: Stacking the Schedule Put NBCTV in Top Spot
description: IF one week were a television season, Fred Silverman would have demonstrated last week why he holds the reputation as television's master orossammer and why he was hired last year, at an annual salary of around $1 million a year, to be president of the faltering National Broadcasting Company.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article about Canadian oil in Business Day last Saturday incorrectly described the ownership of the Hibernia well. The largest stake is held by Mobil Oil Canada Ltd.

title: Q&A
description: Q. In two of my rooms the previous owner applied paint over wallpaper. It is hard to tell how many layers of paper there are, but there seems to be just one coat of paint. I have been advised to size the paper and then apply another layer of wallpaper, or to remove the wallpaper and then paint or paper the walls. What do you suggest and what is the best way to remove the paper?  E. T., Washington

title: Connecticut Man Is Indicted By U.S. in a CrossBurning
description: STAMFORD, Conn. Sept 26  A Federal grand jury today indicted a 19yearold Ridgefield man in a crossburning incident in that town last year. It was the first such Federal prosecution in the recent wave of crossburnings around the metropolitan area.

title: World Gold
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1979

title: Sound
description: OUR exploratory ramble among the latest sound gear, begun last week, focuses initially on receivers. Two reasons justify this priority. First, receivers, which combine the amplifier and radio tuner in a single unit, are by virtue of compactness and economy favored by most listeners as the central components of their stereo systems. Secondly, nothing is lost by this particular shortcut. Today's better receivers fully match the performance of separate tuners and amplifiers, and at the present level of receiver technology, any argument as to the relative merits of receivers against separates is apt to be academic.

title: BERNARD BERELSON, POPULATION EXPERT
description: Dr. Bernard Berelson, a social scientist who was president emeritus of the Population Council, died Tuesday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 67 years old.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar declined against major European currencies and the British pound rose sharply yesterday as rumors spread that oil producers were thinking of going off the dollar standard.

title: EgyptianIsraeli Session Opens With Sharp Exchange
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Sept. 26  The sixth round of Palestinian autonomy talks opened today with a sharp exchange between the Egyptian and Israeli delegations over Israel's decision to permit its citizens to buy land from Arabs in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Carter Names a Panel On Soviet Cuba Force
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  President Carter has called upon a group of seven former foreignpolicy and nationalsecurity officials to help advise him on how to react to the presence of a Russian combat brigade in Cuba.

title: Koch Criticized On Plan to Hire Sanitationmen
description: The chairman of the City Council Finance Committee, which, along with the Board of Estimate, must approve Mayor Koch's plans to hire 562 additional sanitationmen, said yesterday that he had serious reservations about whether the city could afford the move.

title: Relief Agencies Report Accord With Cambodians
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 The United Nations Children's Fund and the International Committee of the Red Cross announced today that Cambodia's two rival factions had agreed to admit foreign representatives to insure that food and medicine reaches Cambodia's civilians and not soldiers.

title: Labor Sets Role in U.S. Pay Guides
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  After three months of difficult negotiations, the Carter Administration has taken a step toward repairing its frayed relations with organized labor by working out an agreement to give labor a highly visible advisory role in reviewing and applying the Government's voluntary standard for pay restraint.

title: Congressional Pay Rise Denied by Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)  The Senate Appropriations Committee voted unanimously today to deny a pay increase for members of Congress but to allow other toplevel Federal employees to receive a 5.5 percent raise.

title: A Step Forward in South Africa
description: Fending off hardliners with claims that the only choice is between reform and revolution, the South African Government of Prime Minister P. W. Botha this week significantly enhanced the position of black labor. Black unions now will have a right to negotiate and to strike under the same general rules as whites. At the same time, they will be subject to closer governmental supervision and risk losing their new status should they become too militant for the authorities' taste. In short, they have been given a privilege, not a right.

title: Country: Good Cheer
description: ALTHOUGH neither Moe Bandy nor Joe Stampley has crossed over to the general popmusic audience, both men are consiaerable stars on the country circuit, and count as leading lights of the younger, tougher sort of country style that has become fashionable in the wake of Willie Nelson's and Waylon Jenning's success.

title: Wildcat Strike Ends in Detroit
description: DETROIT, Sept. 26 (UPI)  City sanitation workers, who held a wildcat strike yesterday in support of a disciplined coworker, have agreed to return to their Jobs, labor negotiators said early today. The 500 workers, members of Local 26 Of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, set up pickets at Environmental Protection and Maintenance department yards yesterday morning.

title: Pirates Win, 101, Go Ahead by 1
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26  There are times when every baseball team lives up to its nickname. The baseball team in Pittsburgh is named the Pirates. Pirates plunder. Tonight at Three Rivers Stadium, the Pirates plundered the Montreal Expos, 101, and moved oneandahalf games ahead in the National League East. There are four games left for the plunderers and five for the Expos.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Canzona Seconda, Mielczewski; Les Patineurs Suite, Meyerbeer; Sonata for Two Pianos, Stravinsky; Parthia, Krumlovsky.

title: Canada Enters Ranks of Top Film Nations
description: TORONTO CARS screeching around corners. Barroom brawls. Murers. Bodies hurtling off tall towers. And Richard Burton jogging past picnickers eating dinner on a sedate urban beach at 8 A.M.
