Just common ordinary sights here these days as Hollywood tinsel takes over Toronto and other Canadian cities.

title: Nation's Only Cable Cars Halted As Unsafe in Almost All Aspects
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26  No longer do little cable cars climb halfway to the stars over San Francisco's hills. The nation's only cable cars went out of service at 1 A.M. today. Oral L. Moore. who began studying the system when he was appointed chief engineer for the Public Utilities Commission three weeks ago, announced that the system is unsafe in almost every aspect.

title: Music: Fillin Conductor
description: IN Leonard Bernstein's time as music director of the New York Philharmonic, the orchestra usually had two assistant conductom, young men or women who had been winners in the nowdefunct Mitropoulos Competition. But in the last few years, the orchestra seems to have lost interest in the nurturing of young talent and has restricted itself mostly to one experienced man, David Gilbert. This summer, Mr. Gilbert resigned.

title: Tufo, Being Sworn In For 2d Term, Defends Rikers Contact Visits
description: Peter F. Tufo was sworn in for a second term as chairman of the New York City Board of Correction yesterday and used the occasion to assail suggestions that contact visits in prison facilities had contributed to Monday's mass escape from Rikers Island.

title: Archer Cancels Offering
description: DECATUR, Ill., Sept. 26 (Reuters)The Archer Daniels Midland Company said today that it had canceled a proposed public offering of $100 million of convertible subordinated debentures due July 1, 2009, because of currently unfavorable market conditions.

title: Can TV's Mary Tyler Moore Succeed on Broadway?
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Ford Motor In Bank Borrowings
description: The Ford Motor Company has borrowed approximately $500 million from banks around the country in the last few weeks, according to banking sources, marking the first time since the recession of 197475 that the usually cashrich automobile manufacturer has turned to the banks for funds.

title: Arab League, Angry With Cairo, Adapts to Home in Tunis
description: TUNIS, Sept. 24  Despite Egypt's claim that the Arab League never left its imposing home overlooking the Nile in central Cairo, the league is at work in a modest new office building on the outskirts of Tunis.

title: A Holiday at Home, A Widening Gulf
description: FOR single Jewish adults, the isolation of urban living is abruptly challenged by the Jewish holidays, Rosh haShanah (the Jewish New Year) and Yom Kippur (The Day of Atonement). On these days, observing ritual, we join our parents for dinner and maybe worship at the synagogue that once was a very familiar part of our family life.

title: Notes on People
description: On the sick list yesterday were two of America's wellknown women.

title: Cook Plans Payment To Settle Grain Case
description: Cook Industries, once one of the nation's largest grain conglomerates, agreed yesterday to pay $4 million in civil penalties to the United States to settle threeyearold charges that the company had shortweighted grain for export.

title: Carter Assailed on Dam Periling the Snail Darter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Angered and dismayed by President Carter's refusal to veto the construction of the Tellico Dam, a group of environmentalists who had been among his staunchest political allies in 1976 said today that they were withdrawing their active political support.

title: Philadelphia Hotel Is Back in Business
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26  When the Bellevue Stratford Hotel closed three years ago following an outbreak of legionnaires disease, many wondered whether the hotel, long a cultural landmark, would ever open again. The thenmysterious disease, which killed 29 persons and hospitalized more than 100 others associated with a state American Legion convention held at the Bellevue Stratford, crippled the hotel's already faltering business.

title: Letters
description: While reading and enjoying Rachel Billington's delightful piece in The Home Section [The British Offer Some Cold Comfort, Sept. 13) I was suddenly brought short by a bit of a muddle that badly wants clearing up.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1979

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 26 (AP)  The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the Northeast Utilities Service Company of Hartford today settled a suit over uranium supplies that the utility had brought against Westinghouse.

title: Brezhnev to Visit East Berlin
description: EAST BERLIN, Sept. 26 (UPI)  Leonid I. Brezhnev and leaders of other Communist countries will meet in East Berlin next Thursday to celebrate the 30th anniversary of East German statehood, officials here announced today.

title: Moscow Symphony's U.S. Tour In Doubt Over Fear of Defection
description: The United States tour of the Moscow State Symphony, scheduled to open next Wednesday at Carnegie Hall, has been thrown into jeopardy, apparently because of Soviet fears of defections by orchestra personnel.

title: Duke of Luxembourg Is in China
description: PEKING, Sept. 26 (Reuters)  Grand Duke Jean of Luxembourg arrived in Peking today. He and the Grand Duchess will be in China for the celebrations next Monday of the 30th anniversary of the Communist Government along with another former royal leader, Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia.

title: Study Finds Big Vitamin C Doses Not Beneficial to Cancer Patients
description: Large amounts of Vitamin C showed no therapeutic benefit in a group of 150 Mayo Clinic patients with advanced cancer, according to a study published yesterday by a team of researchers from the clinic in Rochester, Minn.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil, wrote Edmund Burke, is for good men to do nothing.

title: Soviet Said to Put Troops On an Island Off Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept 26 (Reuters)  The United States has told Japan that Soviet soldiers have moved onto a disputed island close to northern Japan, Foreign Ministry sources said today.

title: Ben Touster Dead at 86; A Former Hias President
description: Ben Touster, former president of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society and former chairman of the board of CARE, died Tuesday at his Manhattan home. Mr. Touster, who was the president of the Cinderella Hat Company of New York City, was 86 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHAT is property? asked PierreJoseph Proudhon in 1840. And he replied: property is theft. He was 31 years old, of peasant stock, the son of a barrelmaker, an autodidact who taught himself Greek and Latin ana Hebrew, a socialist on his way to becoming an anarchist, a pacifist who specialized in vitriol, an intermittent antiSemite, a fulltime male chauvinist pig  and he was telling the French bourgeoisie, the Roman Catholic clergy, the leftover monarchists and the Napoleonic epigones exactly what they didn't want to hear. As a consequence, he spent several years in jail, several in exile and his whole life in debt, while his books were usually banned and his newspapers always surpressed.

title: Nuclear Industry Truth Squad Joining the FondaHayden Tour
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The nuclear power industry said today that it had formed a truth squad consisting of two young nuclear engineers who would follow Jane Fonda, the actress, and Tom Hayden, her activist husband, on their monthlong, 50city tour to campaign against nuclear power.

title: A Rockaway Girl, 17, Killed by Shots Fired From a Passing Auto
description: Two men in a passing car fired into a crowd of teenagers outside a Queens social club early yesterday, killing one girl and wounding another before speeding away, the police said.

title: McDonnell Given Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)  The Air Force has awarded an $807.1 million contract for 78 F15 fighter planes and support equipment to the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the Pentagon announced today. The contract is for we C and D models, which have increased fuel capacity and improved capabilities, an Air Force spokesman said.

title: Approval to Cut Service Given to Milwaukee Line
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (UPI)  The bankrupt Milwaukee Road's request to suspend rail service over large portions of its track was granted today by United States District Judge Thomas R. McMillen.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: Mobil Oil Report
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that its Mobil Exploration Equatorial Africa Inc. affiliate had logged a potentially significant hydrocarbonbearing zone off Cameroon, in Africa. Mobil said the exact nature of the zone and what part, if any, was oil or gas would require extensive production testing after completion of drilling operations.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SPECTRUM Color is to New York what cinnamon is to homemade apple pie; the colors of its people and their clothes, their work places and their homes all contribute to New York's singular piquancy. The city's chromatic aspects are the subject of a Fifth Avenue exhibition of more than 200 large color photographs in 80 stores, banks and airline offices on both sides of Fifth Avenue, between Rockefeller Center and the Plaza Hotel.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Jesse Jackson, in Nablus, Exhorts the Arabs and Criticizes Terrorism
description: NABLUS, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Sept. 26 (AP)  The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson stirred hundreds of Palestinians today with chants of black pride, then crossed the Jordan with a plea to the Palestine Liberation Organization to cease terrorist actions.

title: All Safe in Fire on Sudanese Jet
description: ROME, Sept. 26 (Reuters)  The crew and 89 passengers aboard a Sudan Airways Boeing 707 escaped unhurt today when one of its jet engines caught fire after a landing at Fiumicino Airport, officials said. The plane came from Athens.

title: White Motor Corp. Moving Near Detroit
description: EASTLAKE, Ohio, Sept. 28 (AP) The White Motor Corporation said today that it would move its headquarters from the Cleveland suburb of Eastlake, Ohio, to the Detroit suburb of Farmington Hills, Mich., in order to be closer to the center of the motor vehicle industry.

title: Cadillac Switches To New Design
description: ORCHARD LAKE, Mich., Sept. 26 (AP)  The 1980 Cadillac Seville has been changed to look something like a RollsRoyce of yesteryear because other auto makers were copying Cadillac's design, says Edward C. Kennard. general manager of the Cadillac division of the General Motors Corporation. The new Seville, with a frontwheel drive and a diesel engine, has a humpbacked trunk.

title: F.D.A. Gets New Power In PrescriptionDrug Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)  The Senate gave quick, easy passage today to a bill aimed at updating the country's prescriptiondrug laws and streamlining procedures for approving new drugs.

title: After Willowbrook
description: Seven years have passed since disclosure of the atrocities at the Willowbrook Developmental Center on Staten Island forced New York State to abandon its policy of confining the mentally retarded to lame institutions. A United States District Court decree mandated return of residents to home counties to be cared for in smallgroup homes, individual apartments and foster and natural families. Although the state has met community resistance in implementing this decree, it has also been impeded by its own confused priorities. A prime example is its circumvention of a recent State Supreme Court decision, in Sundheimer v. Kolb, that provided financial assistance for natural parents caring for their retarded children at home. As a result of the state's action, Willowbrook parents are soon to return to Federal court to urge, once again, compliance with the detree.

title: London Negotiators See New Hope for a Rhodesia Pact
description: LONDON, Sept. 26  As British negotiators met again today with representatives of the warring factions in Zimbabwe Rhodesia to hammer out complex constitutional changes, a new mood of optimism seemed to have overtaken the twoweekold peace conference here.

title: C.A.B. Rejects Air Rate Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)  The Civil Aeronautics Board rejected today the latest round of increases in passenger fares and cargo rates requested by virtually all international air carriers.

title: Stocks Register a Modest Gain
description: The stock market posted a small advance yesterday with the copper and a few of the special situation issues scoring the best gains. The oil issues closed with only moaerate gains aster being sharply higher in early trading.

title: Fidrych Passes One Test
description: DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP)  Mark Fidrych, the Detroit Tiger pitcher who has been sidelined by injuries for most of two seasons, pitched one inning without pain today in the Florida Instructional League. Fidrych was pleased with his performance, in which he allowed no runs and one hit while throwing 19 pitches, said a spokesman, Dan Ewald.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Daylin ExHead Joining Kaufman & Broad Inc.
description: Sanford C. Sigoloff, 49 years old, a former chief executive officer of Daylin Inc. and the Republic Corporation, is to be named vice chairman and chief operating officer of Kaufman & Broad Inc. today, the company announced yesterday. Eli Broad (pronounced to rhyme with slowed), who is 46, is to continue as chairman and chief executive.

title: About Washington Depot
description: WASHINGTON DEPOT, Conn.  A young deer blithely skipped across Route 47 just north of this exurbanite hamlet the other day, narrowly avoiding a transformation into venison under the wheels of a touring car with New York plates.

title: Aide Implies Thailand Will Not Again Expel Cambodian Refugees
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 26  Thailand, which expelled about 45,000 Cambodian refugees at gunpoint in June, gave implicit assurance today that it would not do so again as famine and a renewed Vietnamese offensive made likely another mass exodus of Cambodians.

title: Andrew Gomory, 87; Banker Who Advised Foreign Governments
description: Andrew L. Gomory, former executive vice president and head of the international division of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 87 years old.

title: I.C.C. Acts to Open Rock Island
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The Interstate Commerce Commission directed a group of railroads today to resume operation of the Chicago. Rock Island and Pacific Railroad, a major grain carrier in the Middle West that has been shut down since late August by a strike and financial problems.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Filipino Communists Boast of Rising Guerrilla Insurgency
description: BANAUE, the Philippines, Sept. 21 Two wellspoken men in their early 30's suddenly materialized from a cluster of mountain tribesmen who had gathered around their headman. The villagers moved aside for the men.

title: Costly Vandalism Disrupts Services Of New York Association for Blind
description: Services to the blind have been severely curtailed by two incidents of vandalism and theft during the past three weeks at the midtown offices of the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, association officials said yesterday.

title: Hers
description: NATALIE hasn't had a date for three months. If Natalie looked like Alice Cooper or had a sixword vocabulary or were in he habit of snarling at wellmeaning men, it would be easy to understand why she has become such an authority on afterhours television. But Natalie is none of the above. She is, instead, what every girl wants to grow up to be: the composite best of Lynda Carter, Margaret Mead, Suzy Chaffee, Isadora Duncan and the Rockettes. The ideal date, in other words.

title: Canada Oil Cutback Worries Midwest
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Oil refiners in the upper Middle West say that they are becoming increasingly concerned that sharp cutbacks in supplies of Canadian crude oil will disrupt energy supplies this winter in the border states of Montana, North Dakota, Minnesota and Wisconsin.

title: Mexican Exports Up
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept 26 (AP)  Mexico's exports to the United States jumped by 47 percent in the first six months of this year to more than $3.82 billion from $2.92 billion in the same period last year, the Commerce Ministry said yesterday. Mexico, reversing a deficit trend, also reported a surplus with Spain and socialist countries during the same period, according to the report.

title: ACCUSER OF JORDAN ALTERS HER ACCOUNT
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26  A lawyer for Lana Jean Rawls said today that she had told him in an interview that she did not observe the use of cocaine by Hamilton Jordan, but that she did deliver cocaine to a group of White House aides and Democrats at a dinner party here in 1977.

title: Top Prices at Morgan Auction in England
description: HATFIELD, England, Sept. 26  The contents of a 16thcentury manor house formerly owned by a greatnephew of J. Pierpont Morgan have fetched prices more than double those estimated by Christie's, the auctioneer. during a fourday auction here this week. Indeed, despite grumbling by dealers about the uneven quality of the objects, the total has already exceeded $5 million, with the sale of the mansion's 1,000book library still to come tomorrow.

title: HOUSE ENACTS BILL TO CARRY OUT TERMS OF PANAMA TREATY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The House approved by a comfortable margin today a compromise bill that allows the terms of the Panama Canal Treaty to be put into effect on schedule next Monday.

title: CHICAGO BUSING PLAN REJECTED BY H.E.W.
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 26  The Department of Health, Education and Welfare today officially rejected the latest school desegregation plan submitted by the Chicago authorities on the ground that it failed to accomplish the maximum amount of desegregation practicable and was not clear and detailed enough to demonstrate that it had a realistic chance of achieving its objectives.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO END DEBTLIMIT DEBATES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The House of Representatives today approved the abolition of special votes on the Federal debt ceiling, one of Capitol Hill's most established rituals.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON, Sept. 26  Two million Cambodians  perhaps half the surviving population of that ravaged land  are going to die of starvation and disease in the next few months unless massive help from outside can get to them. That is the estimate of doctors and relief workers who have visited there recently.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bache Halsey Stuart Canada Ltd., a subsidiary of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, named Martin R. Hicks as president and a director.

title: Mack Cuts Holding
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 26 (Reuters)  Mack Trucks Inc., a subsidiary of the Signal Companies, said today that it had reduced its holdings in Mack de Venezuela, a joint venture with Venezuelan principals, to 9 percent from 50 percent. The sale price and purchaser were not disclosed.

title: Legal Confusion Prevails At Cornfeld Fraud Trial
description: GENEVA, Sept. 26  Confusion prevailed today at the fraud trail here of Bernard Cornfield when the judge's bid to disassociate private plaintiffs from the state's prosecution of the American financier was rejected by another court.

title: Mets Beat Cubs, 83
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 26  Tom Hausman did not want to be the pitcher saddled with the New York Mets 100th defeat of the season. With that in mind, he pitched strongly for eight and onethird innings today as the Mets stayed at 99 losses with an 83 triumph over the Chicago Cubs in the final game of the season at Wrigley Field.

title: 2 Killed and 3 Injured By Stolen Bus Driven Along Lenox Avenue
description: Two pedestrians were killed and three other persons were hurt yesterday moring when an empty city bus, stolen from its depot by an allegedly intoxicated man, was driven erratically down 12 blocks of Lenox Avenue in Harlem during the rush hour, the police said.

title: Card Sent to Mrs. Eisenhower
description: NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 27 (UPI)  The officers and crew of the aircraft carrier U.S.S. Eisenhower, the nation's third nuclearpowered carrier, have sent flowers and a getwell card to Mamie Eisenhower, a Navy spokesmau said today. The 82 yearold widow of  former President Dwight D. Eisenhower is being treated for a stroke at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington.

title: U.S. Bill Sale Postponed
description: The Treasury annouced yesterday that it was postponing the $5.9 billion bill sale it had originally scheduled for today. The Treasury said the delay was necessary because Congress had not passed legislation to extend the temporary debt ceiling beyond its expiration Sunday. It added that the auction might be held Monday. Treasury bill sales are normally held on Mondays but this one was scheduled for today because of the Jewish holiday of Yom Kippur.

title: Brzezinski Disputes Ford Over Soviet Arms Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, said tonight that former President Gerald R. Ford's criticism of the strategicarms treaty with Moscow was unfounded, and asserted that the accord was better than one the previous Administration had tried to negotiate.

title: Youth Sparks Islander Victory
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 27  It was the youngsters night out for the Islanders tonight, and two of them scored goals in a 30 triumph over the Atlanta Flames at Nassau Coliseum. But a coupie of oldtimers starred, too, such as Glenn (Chico) Resch, who went all the way in goal to record the shutout, and Mike Bossy, who scored his second goal in as many games.

title: A Last Fling or Two for Danbury Fair
description: For one golden October week almost every year since 1869, the 150acre fairground in Danbury, Conn., has offered an oldfashioned good time. That will be true this year, too, and probably next, but get your fill soon, because after that the old fairground site likely to become a shopping mall with six department stores and 130 shops.

title: Stage: Piiero Evokes Hustlers' World
description: PEOPLE do not amble into Justice's Bar. They charge in, with voices raised and tempers flaring. This is not place for quiet, maudlin drunks. It is home for hustlers or players pimps and their prostitutes. It is where they go between professional engagements, and when the players are not issuing challenges, they are buying round of drinks for the house, or they are singing and dancing. The bar is rowdy and chaotic, but with a raw energy that could stop traffic in the street  and the same description could serve for Miguel Piiero's new play, The Sun Always Shines for the Cool.

title: Teenagers Hope to Tell Pope of Gains by Religion
description: Seven teenagers agreed yesterday at a news conference that the main thing they wanted to convey to Pope John Paul II was that young Americans, after a period of some disaffection, are returning to religion with greater fervor.

title: It's ApplePicking Time Again
description: The orchards of the Hudson Valley and other fruitgrowing areas just beyond metropolitan New York are burgeoning with bright, red McIntosh apples waiting to be picked.

title: Art People
description: You may think of the city's financial district as a turf ruled strictly by bankers and brokers. But it and the neighboring South Street Seaport area have a long artmaking tradition, fed by such creative types as Mark di Suvero, Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper JOrMS, Agnes Martin and the late Barnett Newman, all of whom at one time lived and worked there. And since it's the last outpost in Manhattan of loft space at almostaffordable rents (a situation that won't last much longer), more and more artists are calling the area home.

title: New Central African President Facing Huge Task
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic, Sept. 27  For the second time in the 19 years since the Central African Republic attained independence from France David Dacko is its President, and according to diplomats and sources in the new Government here he faces a task too big for any one man.

title: Where the Best Bites Are on the Orchard Trail
description: Following is a list of nearby pickityourself apple orchards in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, as prepared by agriculture departments in those states:

title: Witness Asserts He Gave Payoffs To a Scotto Aide
description: Nicholas Seregos, the owner of a shiprepair company, testified in Manhattan yesterday that he had given more than $50,000 in cash payoffs to Anthony Anastasio, the executive vice president of Local 1814 of the International Longshoremen's Association.

title: Film: New Bertolucci Opens 17th Festival:Mother and Son
description: EUROPEANS have a tolerance and often even an enthusiasm for a sort of intellectualized romanticism that tends to strike most Americans as bunkum. A French film maker and critic on the order of Francois Truffaut sees the late Luchino Visconti's "Conversation Piece," which opened the annual New York Film Festival some years ago, as the moving statement of a great artist nearing the end of his career. We, here, see a group of artificial characters speaking lines (badly dubbed into English) of breathtaking fatuousness.No matter how civilized we Americans think we are, we find it nearly impossible to walk with both feet off the ground at the same time. We are incurably literal minded. We keep thinking of gravity.This, I suppose, explains my skeptical reactions to Bernardo Bertolucci's new film, "Luna," about a beautiful, successful, willful, American star of grand opera and her brief, unsatisfactory love affair with her 15-year-old son, who is a junkie  which may well be the most obscure movie metaphor of all time. The film, which opens the 17th annual New York Film Festival tonight at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center, is one of the most sublimely foolish movies ever made by a director of Mr. Bertolucci's acknowledged talents.He has taken comparable risks before and brought them off  in "Before the Revolution," "The Conformist" and especially in "Last Tango in Paris." In those films, he seemed scarcely able to control the ideas, the feelings and the sense impressions that poured forth as imagery of both rude and dazzling brilliance. If the brilliance seemed more like applied dcor in "1900," it often looks secondhand in "Luna," which is the work of a good poet on an absolutely terrible day.Mr. Bertolucci has been a poet. In 1962, at the age of 21, he was awarded Italy's Viareggio Prize for his book of poems "In Search of Mystery." He is still a poet, but now when he comes up with a clinker he can't roll up the paper and throw it away. Too much money is involved, and too many livelihoods and reputations."Luna" is an original screenplay by Mr. Bertolucci, his younger brother Giuseppe and Clare Peploe, an Englishwoman who was associated with the director on "1900" and, before that, with Michelangelo Antonioni as an assistant director on "Zabriskie Point." Good luck doesn't follow her around.The difficulty in dealing with Mr. Bertolucci is that he doesn't seem to be an artist totally devoid of humor. Because of that, I kept feeling that "Luna" really intended to be funny  laughably funny  when it was being most outrageous. I don't think it is, however. I suspect he wants us to be both moved and shocked by the awful plight of Caterina (Jill Clayburgh), the opera star, and her deeply troubled son Joe, played by Matthew Barry in the snippy manner of the child actor who played Sidney-the-sissy in the Our Gang comedies of my youth.Caterina, in the person of Miss Clayburgh, comes close to being a great character. She's a mass of contradictions. She's selfish but generous, loving but forgetful, self-absorbed but truly responsive to her art. When Miss Clayburgh says to her son, whose passivity infuriates her, "I come from a world where singing and creating and dreaming mean something," we believe her, for neither the first nor the last time. It's a fine, complex performance in a movie that isn't.When Caterina's husband dies at the start of the film, she quite cruelly uproots Joe from his American roots and takes him to Rome, where she has an extended contract. Joe, who worships her, is once again forced to take second place in her affections as she pursues her career with the happy intensity of a liberated widow. Joe turns to hard drugs, and mom, when she realizes what's happened, turns to Joe. There's nothing silly about the situation, but there is about the way Mr. Bertolucci handles it.One of the movie's grand set-pieces is a scene in which Joe, beginning to feel the terrible need for a fix, is comforted by his ingenuously sexy mother. As she cradles him, he starts sucking at her breast. Her response is to masturbate him to a climax and then, we are led to assume, to a peaceful, drugless snooze. As bizarre scenes go, it is far less shocking than schematic. I also wonder about its medical accuracy, because I've always understood that such giddy sexual activity was impossible for an addict. Has Mr. Bertolucci discovered a substitute for Methadone? But there I go  being literal again.However, for all of Vittorio Storaro's gloriously pretty photography, and for all of the extended excerpts from "Il Trovatore," "La Traviata," "Rigoletto" and "Un Ballo in Maschera" (which we hear with Miss Clayburgh faultlessly lip-synching the words), "Luna" remains earthbound. It keeps demanding that we take it literally.The film might work on a poetic level if Mr. Bertolucci didn't insist on turning Joe into a rather conventional case history of an unloved, neglected child. "I can do all the things dad does for you," the poor kid says ominously early in the picture. Later he must scream like someone in a soap opera that his mother doesn't love him and never has. Still later, Caterina has to moan, "Oh, God, what have I done to you!"No amount of purloined Verdi can transform these banalities into anything else, while the film's ending, if it means what it certainly seems to mean, would embarrass a backstage Broadway musical movie, much less a backstage Rome opera movie.There are a number of isolated moments that are powerful and convulsively harrowing, but such effects are not difficult to achieve when you show such things as a desperate drug addict jabbing his arm with a fork in lieu of a hypodermic needle. Miss Clayburgh is extraordinary under impossible circumstances. There are also good supporting performances by Renato Salvatori, Fred Gwynne, Alida Valli and Tomas Milian, but none of these things can disguise the movie's grandiosity.Mr. Bertolucci's methods are no longer so interesting that we'll make allowances for ultimate muddle. Perhaps the Europeans will.

title: Kennedy Issues a Plan To Spur Foreign Trade And Lift the Economy
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, saying that the aspirations of the American people have failed to be fulfilled, issued a broad set of economic proposals last night to widen foreign trade, lessen individual dependence on the Government and cement the links between government and business.

title: Senate Delays Rail Cutback
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)  The Senate, in a compromise, voted today to delay for 30 days the implementation of a Federal judge's order that would have allowed the shutdown of about twothirds of the Milwaukee Road rail system.

title: $210 Million Marketplace For South Street Planned
description: Agreement was reached yesterday on $210 million plan to build a marketplace of shops and restaurants and a new office and hotel complex in the South Street Seaport area.

title: FreedomofPress Croup Names a New Chairman
description: MIAMI, Sept. 27 (UPI)  Harold W. Andersen, president of the Omaha WorldHerald Company and president of the International Federation of Newspaper Publishers, has been named chairman of the World Press Freedom Committee effective Oct. 19, it was announced today.

title: Police Begin Carrying a New Type of Radio
description: When Police Officers Douglas Drenner and Jack DiCristofalo got into their patrol car yesterday, they did not flip on the police radio as officers usually do, because their car has no radio.

title: Federal Reserve
description: Wednesday, Sept. 26,1979

title: Economic Scene
description: THE latest jump in the Consumer Price Index 1.1 percent in August, or 13.2 percent at an annual rate before compounding, rattled windows around the White House and the Council on Wage and Price Stability. The council promptly raised the wage guideline to 8 percent for those workers who had had only a 7 percent increase in the last year. That includes about 90 percent of all workers.

title: Restaurants
description: IKUO KAMATA is a talented Japanese chef who apparently has strong feelings about the affinity between the cooking of his native country and that of France. About two and a half years ago he was both chef and partner at Ginnoki, a sparkling little restaurant on the Upper East Side where he produced delicate, stylized Japanese dishes while a young Swedish chef handled the French side of the menu. When Ginnoki closed, Mr. Kamata joined Gibbon, opened since June on the Upper East Side. Instead of giving the two cuisines separate but equal status at this new restaurant, he blended features of both into decorative and diverting creations.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday Films

title: Title Is Restored to Galindez
description: MIAMI, Sept. 27 (AP)  Victor Galindez was reinstated today as the World Boxing Association's lightheavyweight champion.

title: Tax Exemption On Tertiary Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (Reuters)  The Senate Finance Committee voted to exempt tertiary oil from President Carter's windfall profits tax. Tertiary oil is oil obtained through special recovery techniques from existing oilfields.

title: Council Stiffens Curb On Noise and Raises Penalties for Littering
description: A measure to reduce noise in the city was passed yesterday by the City Council, 42 to 0, with one abstention. It applies only to stationary sources and not to moving objects. It also provides for three noiselevel zones corresponding to landuse zones and sets day and night standards.

title: Reacting to Fuel Anxiety
description: At the New York introduction of the Ford Motor Company's 1980 models earlier this week, William O. Bourke, executive vice president of North American operations, recalled how the summer gasoline shortage had affected him personally. As a regular weekend commuter between Detroit and his farm in Charlottesville, Va., he knew at first hand the anxiety of trying to find enough gas to get to the airport to catch his return flight to Detroit.

title: WASHINGTON The Phony Political Papers
description: Dear Senator: I don't want to make a habit of this, but during the campaign, I hope we can write in the uttermost privacy to one another. Otherwise we're likely to be misrepresented.

title: Exxon to Abandon Well
description: Exxon U.S.A. announced yesterday that its fourth exploratory well in the Baltimore Canyon 70 miles east of Atlantic City is a dry hole that will be plugged and abandoned. Meanwhile, in Washington, a Federal judge canceled a hearing that was meant to takeup the Exxon Corporation's failure to complete the takeover of the Reliance Electric Company. He cited Exxon's announcement earlier this week that it would complete the purchase.

title: State Tests Arsenic in Mineral Water
description: With the growing popularity of mineral waters, state health officials have become concerned about their concentration of one natural but highly poisonous ingredient: arsenic.

title: Bishop Joseph A. Johnson, 65, Of C.M.E. Church in the South
description: SHREVEPORT, La., Sept. 27 (UPI)Bishop Joseph A. Johnson Jr., presiding bishop of the Christian Methodist Episcopal Church of Mississippi and Louisiana and a noted New Testament scholar, died Tuesday at a hospital. He was 65 years old.

title: Topics
description: A friend hit the jackpot on the fall equinox last Sunday in the Maine woods. From where he stood, he could see a mountaintop in Canada and he thought of the Canadians new gold coin, the Maple Leaf. It seemed dreary by comparison with the yellow gold, pink gold and red gold that the sun scattered through the crackling woods. There was earth gold, too, in the wings of ruffed grouse. And the bellies of brook trout had turned blood orange for the season.

title: Atomic Americans
description: Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona seems to have found an effective, if unorthodox, way of dealing with industrial polluters. Not for him the customarily endless regulating, negotiating and litigating to force despoilers of the environment to clean up their act. Governor Babbitt, exasperated, has called out the National Guard. The offender was a factory in Tucson that for months has been leaking radioactive tritium. A company spokesman called the military incursion absolutely crazy and described the plant as like a Nazi camp in here. But from what we've h'ard of this bizarre affair, our sympathies lie with the Governor.

title: Wind Quintet at St. Luke
description: Seventeen Variations by JeanMichel Damase and Allegro and Arioso by Ingolf Dahl will be among the works played by the Sylvan Wind Quintet tonight at 8 P.M. at St. Luke-in-the-Fields Church, 487 Hudson Street. Members of the quintet are Theodore Baskin, Melissa Coren, Larry Guy, Svjetlana Kabalin and Charles McCracken.

title: NURSES FOR ELDERLY FICHT PATIENT MOVE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP) Nurses cars blockaded the dilapidated and bankrupt Sarah Allen Nursing Home today as a lawyer for the 143 elderly patients promised that we're not going to let them take the people away.

title: Student Holds Class at Gunpoint, Surrenders After Suicide Threat
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 27 (AP) A pistolwielding student burst into a classroom at Knoxville Business College today, threatened to kill himself and kept 30 fellow pupils at bay for an hour, the police said. He surrendered after about three hours, officers said.

title: Issue and Debate Serious Trouble Develops for Arms Treaty With Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  The Carter Administration's drive to win Senate approval of the nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union has run into serious trouble.

title: Yugosla vs Prepare for Bankers
description: BELGRADE Yugoslavia, Sept. 27 Some 6,000 of the world's leading bankers, international monetary officials and interested observers are preparing to descend on this city next week for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

title: Arthur Hunnicutt, Actor in Films
description: Arthur Hunnicutt, the veteran character actor who was nominated for an Academy Award for best supporting actor in The Big Sky in 1952, died of cancer Wednesday at the Motion Picture Country Home and Hospital in Woodlawn Hills, Calif. He was 69 years old.

title: Jersey Coalition Formed to Push for Transit Bonds
description: NEWARK, Sept. 27  The formation of a broadbased coalition to work for voter approval of a $475 million transportation bond issue in November was announced here today. It includes business leaders, labor and autoclub representatives and commuter groups.

title: Trios Sunday on 31st St.
description: Music by Brahms, Roussel, Ibert and others will be performed by three musicians who call themselves A Trio Concert on Sunday at 4 P.M. in the Church of the Good Shepherd, 236 East 31st Street, between Second and Third Avenues. Tickets are $2 ($1 for students and the elderly). Information: 6891595.

title: HolmesShavers: An Early Ending Seen
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 27  The odds here are 52 that the world heavyweight championship fight tomorrow night win end violently, but Larry Holmes and Earnie Shavers weighed in today with such unseemly warmth for each other that for a while it appeared they were in danger of kissing.

title: Kozlovs to Dance in New York
description: Leonid and Valentina Kozlov, in their first New York appearance since their defections from the Bolshoi Ballet this month, will perform with the Maryland Ballet on Oct. 20 and 21 at Whitman Hall, as part of the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College 197980 Dance Series. The Kozlovs will perform excerpts from La Bayadere and will be seen in a new pas de deux choreographed by Vladimir VasiRev, a principal dancer with the Bolshoi. The pas de deux, an adagio from These Fantastic Sounds, is set to a score by Rameau.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Sept. 27 (Reuters)  Zimbabwe Rhodesian troops crossed into Mozambique today to strike at Patriotic Front guerrillas in the first such attack since the start of London talks on Zimbabwe Rhodesia's future.

title: Albany Is Said to Ask City To Help Maintain 50 Fare
description: The administration of Governor Carey is reported to be suggesting that New York City increase its annual contribution to the Transit Authority to maintain the 50cent subway fare. The city is resisting, citing a 1978 promise by the Governor that the city would not have to increase its payments.

title: Excerpts From Speech by Vance in New York on U.S. Policy in Latin America
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a speech on Latin American policy delivered by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance to the Foreign Policy Association yesterday at the New York Hilton:

title: German Cost of Living Up
description: WIESBADEN West Germany, Sept. 27 (Reuters)  The West German costofliving index in September rose onetenth of 1 percent from August and 5.3 percent from September 1978, the Federal Statistics Office said today. The figures are provisional.

title: Tass Criticizes Carter's Tone
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (AP) Tass, the official Soviet press agency, accused President Carter today of using  an ultimatumlike tone in making absolutely unfounded and crude attacks against Cuba on the issue of Soviet troops deployed there.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The cash price of gold crossed the $400anounce mark in late New York dealings yesterday as the dollar's value plummeted on global foreignexchange markets.

title: Bridging the Rio Grande
description: Mexico and the United States are closely bound geographically but grievously divided psychologically. Proximity, in fact, has bred much irritation, even bitterness. And Mexico's discovery of vast oil reserves, which could become the basis of a new relationship, seems so far only to have widened the Rio Grande. What, as they meet again, can the neighbor Presidents do about it?

title: Talks in Egypt on Palestinians End Inconclusively
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Sept. 27  The sixth round of negotiations by Israel, Egypt and the United States on the issue of Palestinian selfrule ended here today with little indication of progress.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, Sept. 27, 1979

title: Folk Dances of Norway At Balkan Arts Center
description: If you've ever had the urge to dance to the music of a Hardanger fiddle, or stomp to the tunes of Gudbrandsdal and Trondelag, tonight is the night to satisfy that urge. If you've never had that urge, tonight is a good time to acquire it because at 8 P.M. the Balkan Arts Center begins this season's series of folkdance sessions with live music using traditional Norwegian dances.

title: JUNE SUSAN MILLNER
description: June Susan Millner, who was to have been ordained a rabbi in June, died Monday at BeekmanDowntown Hospital after a sudden illness. She was 27 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: New Britain Undismayed By Latest Political Scandal
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn.  Every morning for years, Joseph Pac has scratched out his latest political thoughts on a blackboard behind the counter of his dingy, but popular, diner here. One day last week the 62yearold

title: U.T.C. In Accord On Mostek
description: The United Technologies Corporation, blocking a potential takeover battle for the Mostek Corporation, disclosed yesterday that it had bought 21 percent, or more than a million shares, of the hightechnology company and would offer $62 a share for the rest.

title: Jackson Calls for Mideast Justice
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 27 (Reuters)The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson toured a Palestinian refugee camp on the outskirts of Amman today and said there would never be a lasting peace in the Middle East until there was concern for justice and tranquillity on both sides of the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: Transit Police Officer Is Indicted On Charge of Assaulting Student
description: A Transit Authority police officer was indicted yesterday on charges of severely beating a college student, who is the son of a New York City police officer, following an argument on a subway train.

title: Toms Navarro at 95; Noted Spanish Linguist
description: Toms Navarro, who was a founder of modern Spanish linguistic studies and who established one of the world's first scientific phonetic laboratories at the Centro de Estudios Historicos in Madrid, died Sept. 16 in Northampton, Mass. Mr. Navarro, who had lived in Northampton in retirement, was 95 years old.

title: Seagram Pleads Guilty In Criminal Bribery Case
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP) Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc., the liquor company, has pleaded guilty to Federal bribery charges in connection with illegal political contributions and other payments to promote sales and has agreed to pay $1.5 million in criminal fines and civil penalties.

title: I.M. Pei Named to Be Architect For American Embassy in China
description: PEKING, Sept. 27 I. M. Pei has been selected to design a new American embassy in Peking to replace the badly overcrowded United States diplomatic facilities here, a State Department officer disclosed today.

title: JOHN CROMWELL, 91; DIRECTED 42 MOVIES
description: Joan Cromwell who acted, produced and directed on the stage and in motion pictures for more than 70 years and who, helping to create and shape the Hollywood film industry, died of a pulmonary embolism Wednesday in a hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 91 years old.

title: Guardsmen Load Radioactive Agent Seized in Arizona
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Sept. 27 (AP)  National Guardsmen working under emergency orders from the Governor sealed more than $500,000 worth of radioactive tritium into 55gallon drums today, preparing the gas for temporary storage in northern Arizona.

title: Gas Shortage Fears Tied to Grade Shifts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Some senior oil company officials are warning that gasoline shortages could occur again next summer because of a small but steady erosion of crudeoil supplies combined with a reduction in the amount of gasoline that can be extracted from each barrel and demand for higheroctane fuels that in turn require more oil.

title: Advertising
description: WHEN he decided to switch his advertising to a new agency, James M. Stetler, the American Express dropout who is executive vice presidentmarketing of Diners Club, was looking for something special.

title: For Children
description: THEO, THE AMAZING MAGICIAN will tell secrets the Far East In a program of magic, mirth and mys. tery, Saturday at 11 A.M., at the Market at Citicorp Center, 153 East 53d Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues. Free. Call 5591715.

title: Bean's 64 Leads by 2 in Golf
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 27  Golf professionals, among the most pampered prima donnas in sports, can always find something to be unhappy about, and today, in the opening round of the World Series of Golf, the subject was fluffy sand in bunkers. Buried lies were common on the Firestone Country Club's south course, even with balls that merely bounced into the traps.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Art: Another Side Of Edward Hopper
description: LIKE a great many artists of his generation  and of generations before and after his  the American painter Edward Hopper (18821967) produced a considerable quantity of commercial art in the days before he won serious recognition as a professional tine artist. He never really liked working as an illustrator, and he quit this line of work as soon as he was in a financial position to do so. In his later years, when he was firmly established as one of the leading Realist painters of his time, he did almost everything he could to conceal and suppress this aspect of his early career and he remained extremely touchy about all his life. I doubt if he was actually ashamed of his work as an illustrator, but he was clearly concerned to avoid having his mature paintings tagged as examples of the illustrator's art, especially as he was intensely conscious of the differences separating the illustrator's art from the painter's.

title: Airwaves Talks Open In Geneva
description: GENEVA, Sept. 27  A world conference to chart the most effective and fairest use of the airwaves in an age of expanding telecommunications was formally opened today with the settlement of a dispute over the chairmanshin.

title: TV Weekend Jones as a Gentle Bear of Detectives
description: PARIS, a new series beginning on CBS tomorrow at 10 P.M., has two strong assets. The lead role of Woodrow Paris is played by James Earl Jones. And, at least in the first show, this is a cop format with a minimum of violence.

title: CONGRESS APPROVES DEPT. OF EDUCATION; VICTORY FOR CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  The establishment of a Department of Education won final Congressional approval today, giving President Carter one of his first major domestic victories of the year.

title: Democratic Delegates In Westchester Name Carty New Chairman
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 27  Thomas Carty of Yonkers, a heating executive and former City Councilman, was named Westchester County Democratic chairman early today on the second ballot of a convention that attracted more than 1,000 voting delegates, three times the normal number.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Turning much gloomier, the credit markets moved sharply lower in price and higher in yield yesterday in a pronounced response to the larger trade deficit, declining dollar and soaring price of gold.

title: Cairo Gala Draws a Glittering Crowd
description: CAIRO, Sept. 27  A bunch of beautiful people created their own island of conspicuous opulence in a sea of Egyptian poverty this week.

title: Letters
description: Freeport, L.I., After the Influx of Minorities

title: NATO Naval Exercise Off Norway Under Intensive Soviet Surveillance
description: NORTHWOOD, England, Sept. 26 The ships of eight Atlantic alliance navies are moving toward the Norwegian Sea, where a Soviet task force of cruisers and destroyers has begun its own exercise.

title: Museum Urged as Holocaust Memorial
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  The creation in Washington of a national memorial and museum that would help keep alive the memory of the 11 million people slain by the Nazis in World War II was urged today by President Carter's Commission on the Holocaust.

title: Typhoon Strikes Near Okinawa; 23 Saved From a Small Freighter
description: TOKYO, Sept. 27 (UPI)  Typhoon Owen sank a small Panamanian freighter in the East China Sea as it skirted Okinawa today and headed for Japan. The crew of 23 was saved.

title: I.M.F. to Deal With DollarSurplus Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  One of the biggest problems central bankers will have to tackle at the International Monetary Fund's annual meeting in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, next week is how to expunge some of the $500 billion worth of surplus dollars in the world.

title: City Uncovers Fraud In TaxCredit Claims
description: The city's Housing Preservation and Development Department has uncovered $200,000 in false claims by landlords for realestate tax credits, Mayor Koch announced yesterday. Since the fraudulent claims were discovered early in the summer, the city has recovered $108,000.

title: Bird Gets 18 Points and Mixed Reviews
description: Larry Bird, the rookie many feel predestined to help revive the Boston Celtic franchise, rated his play as fair last night in light of his National Basketball Association debut.

title: China Is Scoring Major Successes in MassProducing Fish
description: CANTON, Sept. 21 China has become perhaps the largest producer of freshwater fish in the world, according to reports from Western specialists and interviews with Chinese officials.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 (AP)  The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation won a $111.1 million Federal loan guarantee today to modernize and install pollution controls at two mills in western Pennsylvania. The Economic Development Administration offer of a 90 percent guarantee was the agency's fifth and largest under a special Carter Administration program designed to help the economic health of the steel industry.

title: Money Supply Declines; ShortTerm Rates Lower
description: The basic measure of the money supply declined by $1 billion in the week ended Sept. 19, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Northwest Airlines Averts Strike
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 27 (AP) Northwest Airlines announced today that it had reached a tentative contract agreement with its machinists, averting strike. The International Association of

title: King Applies Massage To Boxing's Big Egos
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 27  In boxing's blaring language, it is being advertised as an epic explosion and the greatest boxing show on earth. Don King trumpets it as my biggest card ever.

title: Brutus Like, Man, He's With It
description: For the first time in almost 30 years, I am not responding, as a teacher, to the suburban highschool bell this month. Though a relatively young 55, I will retire. I will miss many aspects of the academic scene, but I must retire if I am to maintain my selfrespect and sanity.

title: Dance Leaps Onto New Stages For 2 Major Events Downtown
description: AINTERS have garrets. Novelists have their closets. But dancers need space. The search for affordable stage space with smooth, resilient floors goes on and on. Some of the fruits of that search can be seen this weekend, when a new dance series comes into being on East 14th Street and a festival celebrates the kind of experimental dance that has found a home in the loft theaters of SoHo and Lower Manhattan.

title: Screen: H.G. Wells Trails Jack the Ripper into 1979:Down the Years
description: "TIME AFTER TIME" is every bit as magical as the trick around which it revolves. Let us say  or let Nicholas Meyer, who wrote and directed the film, say  that in the year 1893, a very special dinner party is being given by H.G. Wells. He plans to announce that a Time Machine, which looks rather like a rococo jukebox, has been constructed, and to demonstrate how his invention works. He won't actually use the thing  too timid for that, he admits, while showing his friends how to operate the controls. But one of these friends has been moonlighting as Jack the Ripper, and will soon be needing to make a fast getaway from Wells's home  in fact, from Wells's century! What choice will Wells have but to follow? Ah!The rest of the film is set in November 1979  and by then, "Time After Time" will have won plenty of accolades and tickled a lot of fancies. Mr. Meyer isn't a particularly skilled director; this is his first attempt, and on occasion it's very clumsy. But as a whizkid he's gone straight to the head of the class, with a movie that's as sweet as it is clever, and never so clever that it forgets to be entertaining. The satisfactions "Time After Time" offers are perhaps no more sophisticated than the fun one might have with an intricate set of electric trains. Still, fun of this sort isn't always easy to come by, not after one's age has climbed up into two digits. There's a lot to be said for an adult's movie with the shimmer of a child's new toy.Of course, one viewer's favorite bit of whimsy is another viewer's "Harold and Maude"  there's no accounting for taste when it comes to film fantasy. But once it arrives in 1979, with Wells hot on the Ripper's trail, "Time After Time"  which opens today at Loew's New York 2 and other theaters  begins relying on a gimmick of more general appeal. Wells, whose utopian tenets have received a nod or two in the opening sequence, starts off looking suspiciously like Tom Swift with a social conscience. But when he arrives in 1979  which does not live up to his expectations, needless to say  he brings a quick-witted, comic delight to each new mystery.Confronted by a newspaper headline like "Colts Maul Rams," Malcolm McDowell's Wells takes an obvious enjoyment in unraveling every riddle. The screenplay has Amy Robbins (Mary Steenburgen), the modern-day woman with whom Wells falls in love, describing him as having a "little boy lost quality," something that could have been poisonously adorable. But Mr. McDowell remains clear of that, combining the character's quick-witted ingenuity with a fine sense of mischief. There's a good deal of pantomime in the performance, as when he watches someone else hailing a taxi and tries, hilariously, to imitate the process; Mr. McDowell has a particular gift for this sort of clowning. He does even better with the sly wit of Mr. Meyer's screenplay, particularly in a scene that has him lunching with Miss Steenburgen. "I like that suit, is that what they're wearing in England?" she coos. "It was when I left," says he.Wells has landed in San Francisco, because the Time Machine is now part of a traveling museum exhibit. "It was never known to have worked," a little card announces. Mr. Meyer's screenplay, based on a story by Karl Alexander and Steve Hayes, is wise in keeping Wells' behavior logical and his confusion to a minimum. So he is soon canvassing banks  at one he meets Miss Steenburgen  since he needs American currency and supposes the Ripper has met with the same problem. And midway through the story, which takes a lengthy sidetrack to follow the romance, he sneaks back to the museum with Miss Steenburgen to show her that the Time Machine indeed works. At this juncture, Mr. Meyer's sneakiest twist brings the tale emphatically back to its initial, suspenseful mood, as Miss Steenburgen becomes a damsel in distress. Giving the leading lady a strong dose of Valium makes a fine 1979 equivalent to the weary old business of tying her to the railroad tracks.David Warner, who plays the Ripper, is superbly seedy, moving effortlessly from the story's initial Victorian setting to the strip joints of San Francisco's North Beach area. "I belong here completely," he tells a horrified Wells. "I'm home." Indeed, Mr. Warner so effectively makes the film's point about the timelessness of evil that the screenplay's further remarks on the subject seem redundant. ("Violence is contagious, like measles," Mr. McDowell is called upon to say.)Miss Steenburgen, who played Jack Nicholson's bride in "Goin' South," this time takes some getting used to, perhaps because her dizzy, disarming manner at first recalls Diane Keaton's too strongly. But she emerges as a funny and affecting figure, one of the nicest surprises the movie has to offer.Purists may quibble with Mr. Meyer's hedging on a crucial point  it becomes essential, at one stage, to know whether the movie supposes that a time-traveling character can change history, and this information is never supplied. More damaging is Mr. Meyer's inability to create a strong visual contrast between his 19th-century characters and their incongruous new setting. And his pessimism about the present makes this a homely movie, since it's filled to the gills with garish modern knickknacks and gray urban vistas. Well, it can't be easy to make parking meters look pretty."Time After Time" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains several murder scenes, one of them unexpectedly brutal, and some sexual innuendo to go with its central romance.

title: Reds Saved by Rain After Falling Behind
description: Reds Are Rained Out

title: Slavic Enclave in Detroit Blossoms With Photos of Pope
description: HAMTRAMCK, Mich., Sept. 26 The decor hasn't changed at the Yemans Restaurant in as long as anyone can remember, except that now there is a picture of the Pope near the one of Franklin Roosevelt that hangs by the cash register.

title: MOSCOW SYMPHONY CANCELS U.S. TOUR
description: The fiveweek United States tour of the Moscow State Symphony, scheduled to open Wednesday in Carnegie Hall, was formally canceled yesterday, amid a controversy as to whether Soviet authorities were motivated by artistic matters or by fear of further defections.

title: Art: Photography Of 10 Gifted Women
description: FOR reasons that still need exploring, women photographers in this country have gained more recognition than their counterparts in the arts of painting and sculpture. It's hard, for example, to think of more than a few living female painters or sculptors of genuine achievement who were born around the turn of the century and have been accorded the recognition due them.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Bunting Sells Stock in First Penn
description: Bunting Sells Stock in First Penn

title: Pope's Brooklyn Stop Is Canceled
description: The Diocese of Brooklyn announced yesterday that Pope John Paul II would not make a planned stop at St. James Cathedral in Brooklyn to greet 150 PolishAmerican children.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown.(N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Seymour Shifrin, 53, Chamber Composer And Brandeis Teacher
description: Seymour Shifrin, a composer and member of the music faculty of Brandeis University, died Wednesday at BethIsrael Hospital in Boston. He was 53 years old. He had taught at Brandeis since 1966 and lived in Natick. Mass.

title: OPEC Takes Up Monetary Issues
description: VIENNA, Sept. 27 (AP) A meeting of finance ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries exchanged views regarding several issues of the international monetary system today, its secretarygeneral, Rene Ortiz, reported.

title: Israelis Feel Jackson Used Peace Trip for SelfPromotion
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 27  Good preacher, bad listener was the headline of the main editorial in The Jerusalem Post yesterday, and that about summed up Israel's perception of the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson after his threeday swing

title: A Tearful Timerman Gets Israel Citizenship On Arrival in Tel Aviv
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 27Jacobo Timerman, the freed Argentine publisher, became an Israeli citizen at an emotional airport ceremony on his arrival here today.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE final volume of Adlai E. Stevenson's papers winds up one of the extraordinary publishing and editing undertakings of recent times. Seldom before not even with modern Presidents  has a public figure's official documents and personal correspondence been opened to general readers in such detail so soon after his death. Stevenson, the Democratic candidate who ran against General and then President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1952 and 1956, died in 1965. He is remembered as a Presidential loser; but Volume VIII of his papers shows him to be not a defeated man, but the most courageous and loyal American delegate to the United Nations in its history.

title: Dayan Says Israel Might Talk With a Political, Not Military, P.L.O.
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 27  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan, interviewed on Israeli television tonight, said that Israel might be ready to enter talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization if that organization became purely political rather than military in character.

title: Air, a Ragtime Trio, Opens New Jazz Series
description: Henry Threadgill, saxophonist, composer and onethird of the innovative jazz trio called Air, is a dedicated student of turnofthecentury ragtime music. He is also an outspoken critic of the manner in which the music of Scott Joplin, Jelly Roll Morton and other ragtime composers is ordinarily performed. My biggest objection to the interpretation of ragtime, he said during a break in an Air rehearsal session the other day, is that it's too classical. That music was hot. It was breathing. Nowadays you hear people playing ragtime, and they sound like they're playing Chopin. I never heard any black music in my life that didn't have a hot strain in it somewhere.

title: Holdup Man Gets 15 Years
description: Edward Carreras, 22 years old, of 2469 Corona Avenue, the Bronx, was sentenced to 15 years in prison in State Supreme Court yesterday for eight armed holdups of women earlier this year.

title: About Real Estate Breasting Suffolk County's Housing Tide
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I.  The outsider is accustomed to thinking of eastern Suffolk County as a place where new housing, when it is built at all, is intended primarily for young families of moderate income. In the late 1960's and early 1970's thousands of new singlefamily homes were purchased by couples in their 20's and 30's, frequently with at least one child of school age and often with more.

title: IN THE NATION Panic Politics
description: President Carter and his spokesman, Jody Powell, are not convincing when they deny that Mr. Carter's remarks about panic in a crisis referred indirectly to Edward Kennedy's behavior during the Chappaquiddick incident in 1969. And for this subiect to have come up so early in the campaign may make some wonder where the panic really lies.

title: Ford, Warning on U.S. Security, Seems to Encourage G.O.P. Draft
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  Former President Gerald R. Ford, sounding a danger signal on national security, took political potshots today at President Carter, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Ronald Reagan and, smiling broadly, seemed to encourage a Draft Ford movement in New Hampshire.

title: State Senate Panel Foresees Winter FuelOil Shortage
description: Despite repeated Federal assurances that there would be an adequate supply of heating oil this winter, homeowners in New York State and elsewhere in the Northeast are threatened with a dangerous shortage, a State Senate investigating committee warned yesterday.

title: House Passes $548 Billion Budget; Tough Senate Opposition Expected
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  A group of liberal Democrats reversed their votes today and enabled the House of Representatives to pass a budget for the fiscal year 1980 that projects spending of $548 billion and a deficit of $29 billion. An almost identical budget lost by 21 votes last week; but the proposal today carried by 212 to 206.

title: The Pop Life
description: MOST rock critics who regard themselves as serious concentrate these days on newwave rock. Critics who review for daily newspapers are more obligated to pay attention to what's popular; the serious ones ignore or slight what they consider to be a waste of time and devote reams of space to the latest obscure punk act.

title: Top Coty A wards Presented To Perry Ellis and Lee Wright
description: After the biggest controversy of their 37 years, the Coty American Fashion Critics Awards were presented last night, minus histrionics. The ceremony was a quiet, tasteful affair at the Fashion Institute of Technology, where it has been held for the last five years.

title: Market Place
description: IS there time for Chrysler to accomplish its strategy for survival? The company needs a financing bridge that will enable it to introduce its new products while it makes sharp reductions in overhead. If the Government comes through with the $1.2 billion in loan guarantees that Chrysler says it needs over the next 12 months, the company should be able to survive.

title: Martin Seeking Apology by Judge
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 27 (AP)  Manager Billy Martin of the New York Yankees, angered over an East Rutherford judge's remarks about him, has filed a complaint with the state's judicial review board.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Pirates Lead Cut to 1 on Loss To Cards; Expos Rained Out
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27  In the misfortunes of a single afternoon, the Pittsburgh Pirates squandered onethird of the advantage they had struggled for three nights to attain.

title: Screen: 'The Legacy':A Certain Ring
description: "THE LEGACY" is a horror film that is not so much frightening as it is depressing. It is thin and dopey, which is perfectly O.K., but in place of invention it uses contrivance, and in place of imagination it uses shock: an old Nazi is burned to a pile of suet and the suet is fed to the Dobermans; a rock star gets a big hunk cut from his throat; a hotelier has his face blown off. Meanwhile, the stately English home where everything happens is gorgeous. The stars are handsome, too. The movie is at odds with itself.Two Los Angeles architects, played by Katharine Ross and Sam Elliott, are summoned to a job in England. They meet the owner of the stately home, who appears to be, say, 45, but is really an ancient kept evergreen by pills. The pills apparently are supplied by Lucifer; so are the rings worn by the ancient and his colleagues. The rings are the source of wealth, power and success, and someone connected with "The Legacy" has been reading Tolkien.One by one the ring bearers die their filthy deaths, all of them brought about by the ancient, who looks by now like melted wax. He is about to expire, too, although first he passes on Lucifer's power to Miss Ross. "What are you going to do with it?" Mr. Elliott asks. "Anything I want," she answers. This is more depressing than the charred suet.Throughout all this, Miss Ross and Mr. Elliott are laid back, as they say, and very modern, and sometimes Mr. Elliott seems to be dozing off. The director, Richard Marquand, may have something in mind here about the banality of evil, but it comes off as rather attractive instead. As a morality tale, this is not much. The film opens today at the Rivoli and other theaters.

title: How ABC Won Bid for Olympics
description: ABCTV had an ace up its sleeve that enabled it to outbid the other networks for the United States rights to the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles, according to sources close to the negotiations.

title: City Panel to Act in October On Rent Rises Tied to Fuel
description: The New York City Rent Guidelines Board announced yesterday that it would decide next month whether to permit increases sought by landlords for 425,000 rentstabilized apartments to help cover the risina cost of fuel oil.

title: Ford Plans Temporary Shutdown of Seven Plants
description: DETROIT, Sept. 27 (AP)  The Ford Motor Company will close seven assembly plants in the United States and Canada next week for one or two weeks to reduce car and truck inventories, Ford announced today.

title: Happily Embattled Governor
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Sept. 27  I'll tell you just one thing about politics in the West, said an older political reporter to a younger one not long ago, and then, as though revealing the location of gold mine, added, Bruce Babbitt!

title: Deaths
description: AIZENMANAbraham David. Dearest wonderful brother of Helen Selter and Ralphine Kresky. Devoted brother in law of Isidore Setter and Milton Kresky. Adored and favorite uncle of Joel Setter, Eileen and Paul Josephart. A very kind and gentle man. Services at BoulevardPark West, 1901 Flatbush Ave (at Ave L), Bklyn. Friday 1:45pm.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: ART (GR 37014)

title: Tobacco Loans Made
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)  The Agriculture Department said today that it had approved new lines of credit totaling $15 million to help four countries buy more United States tobacco. Officials said the loans, made at commercial bank rates, were: to Australia, $4 million; Ireland, $3 million; New Zealand, $2 million, and Britain, $6 million. At current prices, about 3,165 metric tons of tobacco would be involved.

title: Business and the Law
description: DENVER NOT one of Denver's law firms ranks among the top 100 in the country. Not yet. But Denver has become a boom town, as Atlanta was a dozen years ago. In Denver it is energyrelated companies that are spurring the boom. These new businesses create a demand for secondary businesses  banks, accounting firms and law firms.

title: Broadway
description: FOREVER, it seems, someone has talked about doing a musical called Barnum. Alexander H. Cohen once hoisted a billboard above Eighth Avenue saying it was coming soon, and other producers have considered Barnum, started Barnum, and then given up on Barnum. Now a Barnum with music by Cy

title: C.A.B. Bars Merger Bid By Eastern
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)  The Civil Aeronautics Board turned down today the proposed merger of Eastern Air Lines with National Airlines, apparently clearing the way for the acquisition of National uy Pan American World Airways.

title: Publishing: Surgeon And Incisive Writer
description: I came to writing very late, Dr. Richard Selzer was saying. I had never written before. was 40. But I felt a sudden harnessing of my imagination and the energy to do it. I had gone through one difficult discipline  surgery  and knew if I committed myself to writing, I could do it.

title: French Involvement Is Issue
description: PARIS, Sept. 27  France's involvement in the overthrow of the Bokassa Government in the Central African Republic is increasingly becoming a domestic political issue here.

title: He Who Lives by the Sword
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 27 (AP)  David Bachman walked into a police station here yesterday and said he had been bitten by a rattlesnake  his own, officials said. Mr. Bachman, who is 20 years old, explained that as a hobby he keeps nine poisonous snakes in his apartment and owns about 50 other snakes that friends and relatives keep for him. He was bitten when he reached into a glass case to change the water, he said. Doctors found the bite was superficial and released Mr. Bachman after three and a half hours of observation and a tetanus shot.

title: HISPANIC AMERICANS MEET MEXICO LEADER
description: President Jos Lpez Portillo of Mexico met here yesterday with leaders of major national HispanicAmerican organizations at a meeting that participants hailed as symbolic of a new relationship that could influence American domestic and foreign policy.

title: President of Mexico Is Coming to See Carter Today
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 27  President Jos Lopez Portillo of Mexico begins two days of talks with President Carter in Washington tomorrow aimed at dissipating some of the strains and mistrust that continue to disturb relations.

title: Simms's Status Is Uncertain
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. Sept. 27  Is Phil Simms going to be the Giants starting quarterback for Sunday's game against the Saints at New Orleans?

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1979

title: Schools in Hurricane Area Open
description: MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 27 (UPI)Schools opened for most of Mobile Countys 67,000 students today for the first time since Hurricane Frederic hit two weeks ago. Double sessions were scheduled at some schools to make up for school buildings too badly damaged to open.

title: Yearly Net Off At Dean Witter
description: The Dean Witter Reynolds Organization Inc., the brokerage firm, yesterday said it earned $11.4 million for the fiscal year. ended Aug. 31 on revenues of $521.0 million.

title: Terrorists Blow Up Home of a High Argentine Official
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 27  A leading Argentine economic official narrowly escaped death with his family today when a terrorist bomb destroyed their suburban home.

title: TickerTape Parade Set For Pope in Manhattan
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that Pope John Paul II would be given a tickertape parade in lower Manhattan next Wednesday morning as the Pontiff heads south from City Hall to address what is expected to be a large crowd at Battery Park.

title: 3 Met Operas Planned for European TV
description: Beginning next March, the Metropolitan Opera will televise one live performance each season for three years to Austria, France, Britain, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and West Germany.

title: A Visual Feast of New York Awaits the Pope
description: The New York that Pope John Paul II will see next week will not be the tourist's city, and it will not be the city that most natives know, either.

title: The Concorde's Destination
description: By stopping production of the Concorde, the British and French have signaled the end of their stubborn defense of the technological imperative  the proposition that because something can be done technically, it must be done  even if it makes no economic sense.

title: Reagan Returns To L.I. to Back Cohalan's Race
description: PATCHOGUE, L.I., Sept. 27  Ronald Reagan returned tonight to the scene of political faux pas in his campaign for the 1980 Republican nomination for President and tried to make amends.

title: Senate Supports a Salary Freeze In Congress at $57,000 for a Year
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI)  The Senate voted today to freeze Congressional salaries at $57,500 for another year and said that no future pay increases should go into effect until members of Congress faced the voters in a general election.

title: Around the Nation
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 27 (AP)  Unionized office workers struck 20th CenturyFox and three film processing laboratories today in a move that could touch off an industrywide strike against film processors unless negotiations resume.

title: U.S. Steel Disclosure Criticized
description: In the first ruling of its type, the Securities and Exchange Commission found yesterday that the United States Steel Corporation had failed to adequately disclose the costs and risks of complying with Federal, state and local environmental laws in its filings with the commission from 1973 to 1977.

title: Allegheny Seeks National Base
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  Allegheny Airlines, for years the largest of the nation's regional airlines, is changing its name and broadening its service area in hopes of becoming a truly national air carrier.

title: Yanks Beat Indians On Gamble's Homer
description: Unlike the first time Rich Gossage and Cliff Johnson tangled this season, the Yankees survived their confrontation last night. Not only didn't they lose Gossage, but they also didn't lose the game.

title: Jimmy McCulloch, Was Guitarist In Paul McCartney's Wings Band
description: LONDON, Sept. 27 (AP)  Jimmy McCulloch, who achieved prominence as lead guitarist with the former Beatle Paul McCartney's Wings group from 1979 to 1978, was found dead today in his London home.

title: Bracing Found Useful in Paring Airliner Injuries
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday that data from four recent crashes of small airliners had shown that passengers who assumed braced positions suffered significantly less severe injuries than others on board.
