title: Gracie Fields Is Dead at 81; Was Our Grade to Britons
description: Grade Fields, the rowdy and rollicking singer and comedian who was our Gracie to millions of Britons, died yesterday at her home on Capri. Miss Fields, who was reportedly recovering from an attack of pneumonia, was 81 years old.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE 3 to Head Groups At Allied Chemical
description: At a meeting of its board of directors yesterday, the Allied Chemical Corporation restructured most operations of its eight divisions into three operating companies, parceling out new management responsibilities to three group vice presidents.

title: For 16 Days, Tully Hall to Be Film Capital of the World
description: WITH a 16day program of 24 films ranging from .Bernardo Beriolucci to Bugs Bunny, from Howard Hughes to The Wob blies and from Wise Blood to Nosfera tu, the Vampyre, the 17th New York Film Festival opens tonight.

title: VANCE AND GROMYKO END TALK ON TROOPS; IMPASSE IS INDICATED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union concluded their talks on the issue of Soviet troops in Cuba in New York today with both sides asserting that the discussions had been serious but with no sign of a breakthrough evident.

title: U.S. Trade Gap Wider In August
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) Sharply higher oil prices and increases in other imports widened the United States trade deficit with the rest of the world by $2.36 billion in August, the Government reported today.

title: Venezuela to Raise Some Oil Prices
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 27 (AP)  Venezuela, which supplies about 5 percent of United States oil imports, will raise prices on heavy grades of crude oil by an average of 6.05 percent on Oct. 1.

title: Bridge:
description: Events designed for players with little or no tournament experience are now a feature of nearly all contests held in New York City by the Greater New York Bridge Association. Three such events are scheduled this weekend during the Triathlon tournament at the Skyline Motor Inn, 10th Avenue and 50th Street: Tonight: Newcomers individual 8 P.M. Tomorrow: Newcomers pairs 1:30 P.M.; newcomers Swiss teams 7 P.M.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AnheuserBusch Inc. elected Thomas R. Montgomery vice president of operations.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Klecko Leaves Hospital
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 27  Joe Klecko, the New York Jets starting right defensive tackle, left Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip, L.I., today after a 24hour stay.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: John R. Bunting, chairman of the First Pennsylvania Corporation, who stepped down as its chief executive officer at the end of July, has sold most of the shares he held in the bank holding company.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The listing of executive changes in Business Day yesterday incorrectly identified C. Peter McColough. He is chairman and chief executive officer of the Xerox Corporation and has been elected a director of the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: City's Hospitals Are Said to Face Increased Deficit
description: The New York State Financial Control Board said yesterday that the failure of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation to collect money under the state Medicaid program for the poor was creating a projected deficit far larger than expected.

title: COMMODITIES
description: From the platinum to the potato markets, most basic commodity futures prices posted limit advances yesterday as traders and speculators sought to exchange their paper money for raw materials, particularly metals and foodstuffs.

title: Screen: Affable Bank Job
description: IF A Man, a Woman and a Bank had much of a plot, it wouldn't be saddled with a title so desperately in search of a predicate, or even a simple little verb. Yet the film provides peculiar proof that a movie without purpose needn't be without charm. Donald Sutherland is easily affable, and Paul Mazursky quite droll, as two con men who set out to rob bank by studying its design and security devices before construction is completed. Whoever misnamed the movie either underestimated the importance of Mr. Mazursky's drily funny contribution or doesn't know how to count,.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Dollar Drops Sharply And Gold Tops $400; Trade Deficit Widens
description: BONN, Sept. 27  The dollar plunged today to its lowest level against the West German mark since last October, as tumultuous conditions in world monetary markets also sent gold above $400 an ounce in New York.

title: Two Rikers Fugitives Recaptured As Police Hunt 3 Still at Large
description: Two more of the eight inmates who escaped from the Men's House of Detention on Rikers Island earlier this week were recaptured yesterday, as police and correction officers pressed their search for the remaining fugitives. Three had been captured soon after the prison break Monday night and three are still at large.

title: The Region
description: John V. N. Klein submitted his eighth and final budget as Suffolk County Executive, proposing a spending package of $707.5 million for 1980. In the Sept. 11 primary election, Mr. Klein lost his bid for the Republican nomination to third term as County Executive.

title: City Opera in Labor Rift
description: The New York City Opera announced yesterday that unless it reached a collectivebargaining agreement with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians by Sunday, it would close down operations Monday. Base salary and economic fringes remain to be resolved. The opera company said that although it was proposing an increase of 22.5 percent over three years, the union was proposing a 43 percent increase for the same period.

title: Mexico And Us
description: Mexico's perception of United States resolve to defend its regional national interests will be a key consideration for President Jos Lpez Portillo when he visits the White House today.

title: The Admiral and the Editor
description: In yesterday's announcement of three new directors at the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation, two names stood out. The election of Z.D. Bonner, a former chairman of the Gulf Oil Chemicals Company, might have been expected. But Tesoro also named Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., U.S.N., retired, and Irving Kristol, not quite the typical board candidates.

title: Stock Market Mixed Despite Drop in Dollar
description: The stock market ended mixed yesterday despite a sharp drop in the dollar and soaring gold prices in foreignexchan Pe markets.

title: Notes on People
description: Since leaving the White House, Gerald R. Ford has become quite a man of property. He and his wife, Betty, had a house built in Palm Springs, Calif., and he recently said he was buying two radio stations with Leonard Firestone of the tiremanufacturing family.

title: Drug Assertion About Jordan Is Altered
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27  A lawyer for Lana Jean Rawls told the Justice Department today that his client had told him of obtaining a sizable quantity of cocaine for associates of Hamilton Jordan, but that she had not seen the White House chief of staff or any of the others use the drug during a 1977 dinner party at a Beverly Hills restaurantdiscothque.

title: Critic's Notebook Guide for Perplexed Young Recitalist
description: MUSIC critics read their mail the way most musicians read their reviews, ever hopeful, if not exactly confident, of coming across something sensible. Not long ago, in fact, some sensible words turned up in a letter of puzzlement from a youthful musician who had given an indifferently received recital. I thought I played very well, and so did a number of other knowledgeable people, went the protest. I don't argue with your right to differ, but would be curious to know what you expect. You aren't God, you know, to demand perfection.

title: Auctions
description: SOME of the classiest cars ever produced will be driven into Madison Square Garden today for the auction conducted by Christie, Manson & Woods, Tuesday at 2 P.M. The presale exhibition for this event opens tomorrow at 10 A.M. and remains on view through Tuesday at 11:30 A.M. The 36 sedans, touring cars, roadsters, speedsters, convertibles, coupes and a Willis Jeepster, will be rubbed down so their bodies shine, their whitewalled tires gleam and their chrome bumpers are mirrorbright. The stars of this sale, the second such offering by Christie's of New York, will probably not change the automobile auction record of $400,000 that was established in February in Los Angeles when an anonymous buyer from Monaco purchased a 1936 Mercedes. Nevertheless, next week's sale includes some splendid machines. A 1930 Duesenberg and a 1928 MercedesBenz  carry presale estimates of up to $250,000 each. (The Duesenberg may have once been owned by William Randolph Hearst and Marion Davies.) Other rarities include a 1930 Isotta Fraschini convertible roadster (up to $140,000), a 1908 Mercedes Speedster (up to $150,000), and a supercharged 1926 Bugatti Grand Prix Raceabout that was raced before World War II (up

title: Peking Official, in U.N., Calls Moscow Threat to Peace
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 China condemned the Soviet Union in the General Assembly today, denouncing the Russians as the main threat to world peace.

title: Oilers Threaten Browns Unbeaten Record
description: The games of major interest in the National Football League on Sunday will be played in Houston and Philadelphia, where two of the league's four remaining undefeated teams, the Cleveland Browns and the Pittsburgh Steelers, face strong oppositon from the Oilers and the Eagles, respectively. The two home teams have each won three of their first four games.

title: At the Movies
description: Icelebrated VE Day in May 1945 in Manchester as a private in the Royal Engineers, John Schlesinger, the director of Yanks. was saying the other day.

title: Philharmonic: Mackerras
description: THE New York Philharmonic's agenda called for one debut last night, but that had to be revised when Rafael Kubelik came down with a serious case of gout. Unexpectedly in his place as guest conductor was Sir Charles Mackerras, who is also in the midst of an engagement at the Metropolitan Opera. He led a performance of Le Prophet only Tuesday night and is scheduled to conduct tomorrow's matinee of the same opera. Hardy types, these operatic maestros.

title: Golden Cycle Delisted
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had granted its application to strike the Golden Cycle Corporation of Colorado Springs from listing and registration. The company is engaged in mining, moving and stor age and real estate. Dealings in the issue have been halted since Aug. 10 because the company does not meet standards for continued listing with respect to financial condition, the Amex said.

title: African Oil Price Rise Rumored
description: Oil buyers in New York prepared yesterday for a possibly stiff increase in the price of light African crude oils.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: Will Pay Cash

title: St. Malachy's Presents Recital Series
description: We started praying  we should be pretty good at that, the Rev. George W. Moore said the other day at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, the famous Actors Chapel, at 239 West 49th Street. We had decided to start a series of Encore Recitals here, and a survey showed that the right piano for our purposes would cost about $12,000. Our operating budget is zero.

title: The City
description: The Office for Civil Rights has informed School District 29 in Queens that Federal funds for new projects and increases for current projects have been cut off because the district failed to submit a plan to desegregate an allblack intermediate school.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 27 (AP)  Wendy Turnbull upset Chris Evert Lloyd today, 64, 16, 64, in the $100,000 Atlanta women's tennis tournament.

title: Columbia Pays $2 Million To Jane Fonda for Film
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27  Outbidding three other studios, Columbia is paying $3.65 million for the right to make a prison movie starring Jane Fonda. Miss Fonda will receive $2 million whether or not the movie, tentatively titled Her Brother's Keeper, is ever made.

title: Wesleyan Press Plans Economic Tie to Columbia
description: In an unusual arrangement, Wesleyan University Press, Middletown, Conn., will combine its noneditorial operations with Columbia University Press, which will share in the proceeds from its books. Wesleyan's annual deficit has been about $50,000 recently. After the merger, savings are expected in shipping, billing, marketing and other areas.

title: Opera: Crosby Butterfly
description: John Crosby has been a major figure in American musical life for years, first as founder of the Santa Fe Opera and more recently as president of the Manhattan School of Music. But it has taken until the current round of performances of Madama Butterfly for him to make his conducting debut with the New York City Opera.

title: Sewage Spill Abating on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28  The major sewage spill into the southern end of San Francisco, Bay was almost ended today, more than three weeks after it started, according to officials involved in monitoring the spill.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The gold and currency markets remained nervous yesterday, but trading was light in advance of the meeting of top West German and American economic officials in Hamburg, West Germany. scheduled for today.

title: Nicaragua Says It'Will Repudiate SomozaEra Debt
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 (Reuters)  A leader of Nicaragua's revolutionary Government said today that it could not repay $600 million in foreignkloans granted to the regime of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle and that the debt must be assumed by the international community.

title: Policeman Kills a Brooklyn Man Who Was Carrying Putty Knife
description: A Brooklyn man was fatally shot in his Bedford Stuyvesant neighborhood last night by a police officer from the 77th Precinct after the man threatened the officer with what looked liked a meat cleaver, the police said. The alleged weapon was later identified as a putty scraper  with a fiveinch blade.

title: No More Grease for Chicago's Machine
description: A Federal judge has issued a ruling that may strip the gears of politics in Chicago, that citadel of machine politics. The Chicago Democratic Party has, according to the court, improperly given out municipal jobs to maintain itself in power: patronage is illegal.

title: Wesleyan's Lively Debate: Money, Power and Change
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 27  A proposal by the administration of Wesleyan University to drop almost 10 percent of the faculty, increase the number of students, raise tuition and reorganize several cherished programs has laid the groundwork for a lively debate over the future of the small, wealthy, 148yearold institution.

title: A New California Law To Deregulate Cable TV
description: SACRMENTO, Sept. 28  Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr. today signed into law legislation that authorizes the conditional deregulatioh of cabletelevision systems in California and increases local participation in communityservice channels.

title: Eaton to Sell Unit
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 (AP) The Eaton Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its construction equipment business with headquarters in Batavia, N.Y., to FaunWerke of Nuremberg, West Germany. The price was not disclosed.

title: North American Energy
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  Energy shortages at home, combined with estimated surpluses in Canada and Mexico have prompted five Presidential hopefuls (Howard H. Baker Jr., Edmund G. Brown Jr., John B. Connally, Edward M. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan) to endorse a North American energy common market. We believe that the energy commonmarket concept is unworkable and is diverting attention from the modest and realistic possibilities of cooperation in energy with our neighbors.

title: The Screen: 'Black Jack':The Cast
description: The 18th and 20th centuries collide head-on in Kenneth Loach's "Black Jack," which will be shown tonight at 6 P.M. and tomorrow at 4:30 P.M., as part of the New York Film Festival. Mr. Loach's film, adapted from a novel by Leon Garfield, is set in 1750. But many of its methods are deliberately and jarringly modern. The dialogue overlaps, as it might in a film of Robert Altman's. The pastoral English vistas are suffused with a painterly light, as they were in "Barry Lyndon." The language is relatively contemporary, and the plot, for all its period details, takes a psychiatric turn. Mr. Loach simply sets these elements in motion and lets them go to war.The story has to do with a young girl named Belle Carter (played with a keen intensity by Louise Cooper), whose parents consider her insane. The occasion of an older sister's prestigious marriage induces the parents to pack Belle off to an asylum, because they fear their new in-laws may think the child's problem is hereditary. In fact, she has been violent and uncommunicative since she suffered a severe fever at age 5.But Belle escapes in midjourney, aided by Tolly (Stephen Hirst), a boy her own age, and Black Jack (Jean Franval), a surly, mysterious Frenchman who has miraculously survived his own hanging as the film begins. These three refugees fall in with an itinerant circus of sorts, full of people who speak simultaneously and roam the aformentioned beautifully lit landscapes.Key figures in the circus are three dwarves, a shyster doctor who sells youth serum (Packy Byrne), and a small boy (Andrew Bennett), who is growing into quite a large thief. This boy quickly solves the mystery of Belle's origins and sets to work cheerfully blackmailing both her parents and the asylum proprietors who've lost her.There is a lot more going on in "Black Jack," which shared the International Critics' Prize at Cannes this year. But it isn't always easy to decipher. Mr. Loach's actors, some of whom seem to be nonprofessionals, appear to be doing a lot of improvising. And they do it in thickly Yorkshire-accented monotones, which might be more intelligible if there weren't also a lot of mumbling going on. Mr. Hirst, the young lead, is particularly hard to hear, and his big breakthrough moment with Belle is disappointingly flat. Mr. Bennett, as the thief, speaks just as blankly. But he brings to the character such unmistakable cunning that he's never in danger of being misunderstood.

These you had to be More careful with, since they bruised easily, and once you'd laid them in the bin like a baby, you were entitled to 20 cents a bushel.

title: Screen: 'Wise Blood,' Huston's 33d Feature:The Cast
description: "Wise Blood," based on Flannery O'Connor's 1952 novel about an inside-out religious fanatic of the rural South, is one of John Huston's most original, most stunning movies. It is so eccentric, so funny, so surprising and so haunting that it is difficult to believe it is not the first film of some enfant terrible instead of the 33d feature by a man who is now in his 70's and whose career has had more highs and lows than a decade of weather maps.Mr. Huston's affection for misfits has never been more profoundly expressed than in this uproarious tale about Hazel Motes, a young Army veteran who returns home from the wars  one assumes Vietnam  obsessed with the idea of founding a Church of Christ without Christ. Hazel Motes is no Elmer Gantry and "Wise Blood" is no expos of well-paying religious fakery, although it is about salvation.Hazel's success as a preacher is minimal, even in a region where the crazier the homemade religion, the more likely it is to be popular. Small crowds do listen to Hazel as he stands on the hood of his battered car, and some people are taken by his creed: "I'm a member and preacher to that church where the blind don't see and the lame don't walk and what's dead stays that way." But Hazel is too preoccupied with his own visions to organize his church and reap the financial rewards. He is ruled by fears and furies of the unloving Jesus of his childhood, when his grandfather was a hellfire-and-brimstone preacher."Wise Blood" will be shown at the New York Film Festival at 9 P.M. today and at 7 P.M. tomorrow. Its commercial opening has not been set.Mr. Huston's best films have always been about misfits of one sort or another, from the early ones, "The Maltese Falcon" and "The Treasure of Sierra Madre," through "The Asphalt Jungle" and "The African Queen" to his most recent production, "The Man Who Would Be King," in 1975.The New York Festival's program makes a mistake, I think, in saying that "Wise Blood" marks a return by the director to the "hardheaded" style of his "Fat City." As much as I admired "Fat City," it seems to me that "Wise Blood" is more evocative of "Beat the Devil," the slapdash comedy classic written by Truman Capote. The seriously lunatic characters in "Wise Blood" are much closer kin to the would-be thieves in "Beat the Devil" than they are to the losers in the gritty, realistic "Fat City."Like all fine fiction writers, Miss O'Connor created a self-contained world that was immediately recognizable although very bizarre. No matter how odd the characters and how grotesque the events, one believes in her world because, among other things, it is consistent within itself.This is one of the achievements of "Wise Blood," which is lyrically mad and absolutely compelling even when we don't fully comprehend it. Shot in the South, the film presents us with familiar landscapes in which, however, all the people appear to be just slightly removed from the reality we know. This applies equally to casual passersby and to someone like the county sheriff, who appears in one brief, hilarious scene, and to the principal characters.In addition to Hazel Motes, beautifully played by Brad Dourif (the stuttering kid in "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest"), these include Sabbath Lilly Hawks (Amy Wright), a libidinous teen-ager who looks as if she had grown up drinking Cokes and eating French fries and never coming near a green vegetable; Asa Hawks (Harry Dean Stanton), her evil-tempered father, a conventionally fraudulent side-walk preacher; Enoch Emery (Daniel Shor), a crazy country boy who finds a "new" Jesus at the local museum in the form of the tiny corpse of a shrunken South American Indian; Hoover Shoates (Ned Beatty), a fast-talking promoter who wants to manage Hazel's career as a prophet, and Hazel's landlady (Mary Nell Santacroce), the lonely, middle-age woman who falls in love with Hazel. They're all splendid. Mr. Huston himself appears in several lividly pink fantasy sequences as Hazel's grandfather.The screenplay by Benedict Fitzgerald is not neat by usual movie standards. Characters wander off never to be heard of again. The movie delights in the odd moment that doesn't obviously carry the story forward. Yet it's always alive. Mr. Fitzgerald also seems to have preserved a lot of Miss O'Connor's dialogue. Nowhere else might you hear someone say, "Her hair was so thin it looked like ham gravy trickling down her skull," or another character, Hazel, defend himself and his second-hand wreck of an automobile with the statement, "Nobody with a good car needs to be justified."Hazel's journey toward salvation is terrifying, tortured and bloody; yet the end effect of the film is exhilarating, as it always is when you see something so well and seemingly so effortlessly realized. Mr. Huston is in top form.

title: House Approves Military Budget $2.8 Billion Under Carter Request
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  The House of Representatives today approved $129.5 billion in military appropriations for the fiscal year that begins Monday, a sum $2.8 billion less than the Carter Administration requested but including a nuclearpowered aircraft carrier Mr. Carter does not want built.

title: Rangers and Islanders Play Exhibition Ties
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 28 (AP)  Peter. McNab of Boston and Lucien DeBlois of New York matched powerplay goals late in the second period tonight as the Bruins and the Rangers tied, 33, in a National Hockey League exhibition game.

title: Meany Quitting In Fall as Head Of A.F.LC.I.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  George Meany, the plainspoken plumber from the Bronx who dominated this country's trade union movement for more than a quarter of a century, disclosed today that he would resign in November as president of the A.F.L.C.I.O.

title: CASTRO ASSAILS U.S. OVER TROOP FUROR
description: HAVANA, Sept 28  President Fidel Castro accused President Carter today of being dishonest and of using data from the archives to create an artificial problem over the presence of Soviet troops in Cuba.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Jackson, in Beirut, Urges P.L.O. to Halt Terrorism
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 28  The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson urged the Palestine Liberation Organization today to reassess its policy toward Israel and abandon guerrilla warfare to create a proper mood for peace talks.

title: U.S. Lets City Phase Out 9,100 CETA jobs
description: New York City bas received conditional approval from Washington for its plan to phase out over a 12month period the jobs of 9,100 publicservice employees. However, the city must submit satisfactory grievance procedure for workers who believe their discharges are improper.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DETROIT, Sept. 28 (AP)  The American Motors Corporation today priced its 1980 model cars and Jeeps an average of $111, or 1.5 percent, above final 1979 prices.

title: Saga at Arbor House: Its Sale
description: It all started very humbly. There was no capital, save for a $5,000 loan from a college roommate. There were no books. There was a college senior who worked three afternoons a week. There was a telephone. And there was Donald Fine.

title: Reds Win, Clinch on Astro Loss
description: CINCINNATI. Sept. 28First, there was an important victory, in relief, against the Houston Astros. Next, there was Frank Pastore's first major league complete game, a victory last Sunday against Houston that some of the Cincinnati Reds called the most important of the season. Tonisht. Pastore was even better, pitching his first major league shutout, a fourhit, 30 victory over the Atlanta Braves that helped the Reds secure their sixth National League Western Division champion. ship in this decade.

title: Shell Appears to Win Belridge Bidding Contest
description: The Shell Oil Company appears to have emerged as the victor in the frenzied bidding contest for the littleknown Belridge Oil Company of California, reaching an agreement yesterday to acquire Belridge for an outlay in cash and notes that Shell said would range from $2 billion to $3.65 billion.

title: Bridge:
description: Recent news articles about political and religious violence in Ireland tend to obscure the fact that in less controversial areas, such as bridge, the Irish often cooperate very effectively. For the last 30 years, Ireland has been represented in international competitition by teams including players from both sides of the border between Ulster and Eire.

title: Panel Bars Tax Credits On Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  The Senate Finance Committee withdrew its approval today of $98 billion worth of proposed tax credits intended to spur energy conservation and reduce the nation's reliance on imported oil.

title: Ouster of Iran Oil Chief Spurs Talk of Output Cut
description: The ouster yesterday of Iran's top oil official, Hassan Nazih, stirred speculation among oil industry analysts that Iranian oil production, which has been slipping recently, may decline still further. If so, they said, world oil prices might begin another upward spiral.

title: Joseph Papp Will Sponsor Evening for Boat People
description: Joseph Papp, the producer, and the International ReScue Committee will sponsor An Evening for the Boat People, to aid those Southeast Asia refugees, on Oct. 15, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: About New York
description: Francis Thomas  they call him Doll  is one of those precious New York resources, an 84yearold human time capsule, one of the city's aged whose memories are invaluable data banks of recollection. He is to be found in a fourfloor walkup on West 125th Street, next to the Apollo Theater, as unlikely a setting for an irreplaceable source material as the caves of the Holy Land were for the Dead Sea scrolls.

title: Miss Alexander Quits 60 Minutes
description: Shana Alexander, who for five years battled politics on 60 Minutes with Jack Kilpatrick, has quit in an argument over money with Don Hewitt, executive producer of the CBSTV program, according to United Press International.

title: Inflow Plunges At Thrift Units
description: The nation's 4,700 federally insured savings and loan associations posted their worst August savingsflow rate since August 1974, when the nation was in its last recession, the Government has reported.

title: Poor Nations Agree on Action Plan
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 28 The finance ministers of the Group of 24 developing countries have approved an immediate action program to present to the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank next week.

title: One Big Punch Was Not Enough
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 28  In the years to come, when people mention Earnie Shavers, he will be remembered as the gladiator who was one punch away from the world heavyweight championship  twice. Two years ago he wobbled Muhammad All with that big right hand, but he couldn't finish the nowretired champion. Tonight he threw that big right hand again, in the seventh round, and Larry Holmes crashed onto the canvas as if he had fallen off a porch. Instinctively, the resident World Boxing Council chanipion was up quickly. Too quickly. Larry Holmes didn't really know where he was. Wobbling, he was there to be dethroned. But again Earnie Shavers could not finish what he had started with that big right hand. Lunging wildly, he let Larry Holmes escape during the last 30 seconds of that round.

title: Notes on People
description: Yale's latest Chubb Fellow is Shirley Temple Black, who yesterday wound up three days on the campus at New Haven, holding seminars with students and dropping in on classes.

title: From Bronx Plumber to Voice of American Labor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  He was the honest plumber to his colleague and rival. Walter P. Reuther.

title: In Calcutta's Freewheeling Salons, From Poetry to Politics
description: CALCUTTA, India  One Bengali, they say here, is a poet. Two Bengalis are a political party and three are two political parties.

title: Two Fundamentalists Crusade Against Abortion in 20 Cities
description: The films open with a scene of a young woman in a long white dress wallking slowly through a meadow with two beatific children. Suddenly, she halts to paint on an invislble canvas the question, Whatever happened to the human race? And then an invisible force shatters the words.

title: Canada Will Sell 8 Concerns
description: TORONTO, Sept. 28  Canada's new Conservative Government announced today that it was putting on sale eight major Governmentowned corporations valued at more than $801 million.

title: Cabby Is Killed Resisting Holdup
description: A 46yearold taxicab driver was shot to death early yesterday morning in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, apparently by a man planning to use his cab to escape after a robbery in the neighborhood, the police said. Three persons were later charged in the murder.

description: Deaths

title: Ben Sevren, 63, a Vice President Of New York Division of Gimbels
description: Ben Sevran, former executive vice president of Gimbel Brothers New York division, died yesterday after a brief illness at his home in Huntington, L.1. He was 63 years old.

title: Abortion Fight Blocks Federal Spending Bill; 12.9% Raise Possible
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Unable to break a deadlock over abortion, the Senate and House tonight abandoned efforts to head off an automatic 12.9 percent pay raise due to go into effect Monday for members of Congress and some 21,000 toplevel officials and judges.

title: Elderly With Proud Traditions Find It Hard to Say Help
description: Pounding her cane on the floor for emphasis, Jean Scalabrino declared that, despite seven decades of battling for survival, nothing  not the husband she threw out years ago for fooling around, not the workers at socialservice agencies who are very rude and very abrupt, and not her ongoing bout with Addison's disease  was going to get her down. She is proud, she said, but she has learned to separate her pride and her needs, a line that many of her friends have failed to draw.

title: 2 Poets Pay Tribute Today To Langston Hughes
description: Ted Joans and Lana Turner, two poets, will offer A Poetic Tribute to Langston Hughes today at the Studio Museum in Harlem, 2033 Fifth Avenue, near 125th Street.

description: With their band of southpaw-swinging sluggers scorching Toronto's pitchers, the Yankees clinched their position last night three days earlier than last season. This year, however, the position is three spots lower.

title: CARTER WILL SPEAK MONDAY ON DISPUTE OVER SOVIET TROOPS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  President Carter will speak to the nation Monday night on the impasse with the Soviet Union over the United States contention that there is a Soviet combat brigade in Cuba.

description: BOSTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)  Gov. Edward J. King signed legislation today making Monday a statewide legal holiday, in honor of Pope John Paul II' visit to Boston.

title: Contamination Traced to 17 States
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)  PCB, a toxic chemical suspected of causing cancer, has turned up in animal feed and food in 17 states from Oregon to New Jersey, the Government said today.

description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28  Three potential key witnesses have told the Justice Department that they will not tell what they know about the use of cocaine by Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, unless they themselves are granted immunity from prosecution, department sources said today.

description: Nicholas Seregos, who owns a company that repairs ships for the United States Navy, testified under crossexamination yesterday that he had been under pressure to cooperate in the Government's case against Anthony M. Scotto and Anthony Anastasio, two dockunion officials.

title: School's Out Over Spider
description: Tales of a horde of black widow spiders at an elementary school in Rocky Point, L.I., forced school officials to close the school yesterday for fumigation, even though only one black widow had invaded the building and had been captured by a teacher.

description: ROME, Sept. 28 (UPI)  Luigi Petroselli, a Communist, was sworn in as Mayor of this capital city today, replacing Giulio Carlo Argan, a proCommunist.

description: BOSTON, Sept. 28  Senator Edward M. Kennedy indicated to a Massachusetts labor audience today that he was planning to announce shortly his candidacy for the 1980 Democratic Presidential nomination.

description: DUBLIN, Sept. 28  More than twothirds of Ireland's three million people are expected to see Pope John Paul II during his threeday visit beginning tomorrow.

title: After Rush Hour
description: In the west. Fourth Street subway station; I notice a black teenage boy waiting for the train, sitting on a railing just in front of a moving escalator. It's a muggy evening, there's no air in this station, and I'm sure we're both hoping for one of those nice airconditioned F trains.

title: 25 Die in Vienna Hotel Fire, Including 3 From Maine
description: VIENNA, Sept. 28 (AP)  Fire swept through a hotel packed with tourists before dawn today, killing 25 persons, including three Americans who were members of a Maine tour group that had switched from another hotel at the last minute.

title: LIBERALS IN BRITAIN EXPECT BETTER DAYS
description: MARGATE, England, Sept. 27  The Liberal Party is the permanent invalid of British politics, never really healthy, never quite expiring, with only very occasional surges of energy.

title: Carter and Mexican President Hold A Cordial and Serious Discussion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  President Carter and President Jos Lpez Portillo of Mexico began two days of talks today with an hourlong discussion that United States officials described as cordial and serious.

title: Visions of Profits on Papal Visit Dance in Heads of Businessmen
description: A priest in the office of the Diocese of Des Moines was taken aback one day recently by a call from an entrepreneur who, in honor of the visit of Pope John Paul II, wanted to sell rosary beads made out of kernels of Iowa corn at $3.50 apiece, two for $5.50.

title: Strike Ends at Emery Airfreight
description: A 16day walkout against Emery Airfreight by members of Locals 95 and 851 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters ended with the ratification last night of a new threeyear contract, according to a teamsters spokesman. The action, by 600 drivers and clerical workers, had halted airfreight operations at Kennedy International Airport and at Newark International Airport since Sept. 12. Operations were expected to resume on Monday. The strike was called over a wage dispute after the old contract expired Aug. 31. Details of the new pact were not immediately available.

title: Police Department Promotes 90 Members
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire with Detective Mary Glatzle after her promotion to detective first class. Detective Glatzle, known as Muggable Mary for her work as a disguised decoy, has made more than 500 arrests and has won the Medal of Valor for her arrest of an armed rapist. Chief Daniel J. Courtenay, at right, was promoted to chief of organized crime control and was replaced by Assistant Chief Milton Schwartz, left, as commander of Manhattan South. Mr. Schwartz had been commanding officer of patrol in the southern portion of Brooklyn.

title: CARTER AND UNIONS ANNOUNCE ACCORD ON INFLATION CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  Organized labor and President Carter announced today a national accord on economic policy intended to bring union leadership into a more visible partnership with the Administration.

title: Moscow Banned Books for Preaching
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (AP)  A top Soviet publiShing official said in an interview published today that 44 American books banned from. Moscow's book fair this month preached violence, racism and antiSovietism.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)  A Government index designed to forecast economic trends continued to show weakness in August, remaining unchanged after dropping for two months, the Commerce Department said today.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser,, has challenged former President GeraldR. Ford's assessment of the pending strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union and has warned critics against making it a partisan political issue.

description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 27  As far as the people here are concerned, the world can now stop joking about Anaheim.

The famous piece can be heard tonight in an intimate setting, played as a piano solo by Norman Krieger. The young concert artist will appear with the National Symhony Orchestra in December at Carnegie Hall.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)  The Senate completed Congressional action today on a bill extending the limit on the Federal debt to $879 billion. The measure was passed, 49 to 29, and sent to President Carter.
