title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: SOUTH

title: Kennedy Backs Tightened Rules For Sentencing
description: Calling criminal sentencing in the United States a national scandal, Senator Edward M. Kennedy spoke yesterday in support of a proposal to eliminate indeterminate sentencing and parole in New York State.

title: McGrawHill Merger.
description: McGrawHill Inc. announced yesterday that Data Resources Inc. had become its wholly owned subsidiary through a merger. Previously, the publishing company owned about 95 percent of Data Resources stock as a result of a cash tender offer that was successfully completed on Aug. 28.

title: Gerard Swope Jr., 73, Retired G.E. Counsel And S.E.C. Aide, Dies
description: Gerard Swope Jr., who served as international counsel for the General Electric Company from 1946 until his retirement in 1968, died Thursday at his home in CrotononHudson, N. Y. He was 73 years old.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Music

title: Most Major Banks Post 13% Prime
description: Most of the nation's major banks raised their prime lending rates yesterday by onequarter of a percentage point to a record 13 percent.

title: Pop: Danko in New Band
description: Rick Danko was in the Band for many years; Paul Butterfield was a fixture on the Chicago and national bluesrock scene for years before that. Now the two have Joined in a bandthat also includes Blondie Chaplin; who had one solo.albtun of his own, and the result ended a threenight run Thursday night at the Lone Star Cafe.

title: EastWest Credit Links Grow
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 28 The Communistbloc nations, facing growing needs for financing imports of oil and technology, are forcing a convergence of the international financial systems of the West and the East.

title: Sales of Securities Are Rescheduled
description: The Treasury announced plans yesterday to reschedule four postponed sales of securities totaling $17.5 billion and to sell $1.5 billion of 15year bonds.

title: Film Festival: What's Up, Road Runner?
description: No popcorn or souvenirs, but aside from that, the New York Film Festival has scheduled an old-fashioned Saturday matinee at Alice Tully Hall today. It's "The Bugs Bunny/Road Runner Movie," a selection from the cartoon shorts made by Chuck Jones for Warner Brothers from 1939 to 1963. The single performance of the film, which will be released theatrically, is sold out.Mr. Jones has created 20 minutes of new animation to link the old material, with Bugs looking back on his film career from his cliffhugging mansion in Beverly Hills. Once again Mel Blanc is the voice of the wiseguy rabbit, whose "What's up, Doc?" has, for better or worse, entered the language.Most of the film, which begins with a portentous opening that parodies "Star Wars" and "Superman," is very funny, especially when Bugs tries to talk back to the artist who is creating him and is erased, turned into a four-legged bug and subjected to other indignities.However, having to watch Elmer Fudd, Wile E. Coyote and other villains being smashed flat by falling boulders, blowing themselves up and meeting with other disasters again and again and again and again can be trying, possibly for children as well as adults.As for the Road Runner, created by Mr. Jones in 1948, one can only wish that Frank Perdue had reduced the sum to its parts. Those endless "beep-beeps" are likely to have you saying "bleep-bleep."

title: Television
description: Morning

title: CEREMONIAL COLLAR IS MISSING AT YALE
description: The President's Collar, a necklace of gold, silver and jewels that has been worn by the presidents of Yale University on occasions of high ceremony for three quarters of a century, was reported missing yesterday from the storage vault in the office of the university secretary

title: French Bank Deal
description: The American Express Company announced an agreement in principle with three leading French banks to negotiate the joint issue of a uniform Frenchfranc traveler's check. The three banks are Credit Lyonnais, Banque Nationale de Paris and Crdit Agricole. American Express said that other French banks would be invited to participate in the new venture, as well.

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1979

title: Piano: French Program
description: In a refreshing departure from the predominantly Germanic programs pianists usually play, Michel Block concentrated on French music in his recital at the 92d Street Y on Thursday night.

title: Bars Cited To Chinese I.M.F. Tie
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  Financial experts in the Carter Administration, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank expressed interest but uncertainty today over suggestions by China of willingness to join the institutions.

title: Soviet Symphony Substitutes Sought
description: Columbia Artists Management and the presenting organizations of the 28 concerts scheduled by the Moscow State Symphony struggled yesterday to find substitutes or provide refunds after the cancellation on Thursday of the Soviet orchestra's American tour.

title: Books of The Times Managing Motherhood
description: WOMEN AS MOTHERS. By Sheila Kitzinger. 239 pages. Random House. $8.95.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: Jets Rush, but Oh, That Defense!
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 28 strange combination has turned up on the New York Jets, something that is not supposed to happen to a football team: they are at once the most productive in rushing and the worst on defense in the National Football League.

title: Your Money
description: WITH gold selling near $400 an ounce these days, the gold bugs who advocate sinking one's fortune into the precious metal, instead of into paper investments linked to the declining dollar, might have the right idea after all. A recent plunger (or at least a miniplunger) decided to check out the advice dispensed by different newsletters that specialize in reporting on the gold markets. She ran across an advertisement by the Select Information Exchange, which desctibes itself as America's leading financial publications subscription agency. The ad promised that, in return for $23, the company would send her 30 sample subscriptions to a variety of specialized, savvy services that had regular annual subscription rates of up to $350.

title: IRVING LIEBERMAN
description: Irving Lieberman, who reported the news in Brooklyn for The New York Post for more than four decades, died Sept. 22 at the Helen Hayes Rehabilitation Center in Haverstraw, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: Koch Criticizes Screening Panel Over Judgeships
description: Mayor Koch says the Demotratic panel that screened judicial candidates in Manhattan was dominated by Legal Aid sympathizers who won't approve tough judges.

title: Screen: Story of 'The Stud' Opens:The Cast
description: If only "The Stud" were a documentary about a thoroughbred-breeding farm  yearlings galloping across green fields, mares mooning under the spreading oaks, stallions pawing the paddock and a young girl falling in love with an awkward foal.Alas, "The Stud" is an ugly soft-core pornographic account of the rise and fall of a fancy man, played by Oliver Tobias, who is promoted from waiter to manager of a London discothque because of his ability to gratify the insatiable wife of the owner, played by Joan Collins. It opened yesterday at Loews State 2 and other theaters.Miss Collins's sister, Jackie Collins, adapted her novel of the same title for the screen. It is illiterate and anti-erotic. The performances, Quentin Masters's direction, the cinematography and editing are all amateurish."The Stud" is rated R, probably because of a good deal of pointless obscenity, frontal female nudity and not very convincingly simulated sex.

title: Benefit for Self Help Inc. Tomorrow at High School
description: Max Roach, the composer and percussionist, and Latifah Umranl, the playwright, will be the hosts of a benefit sponsored by Self Help Inc. at the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. High School on Amsterdam Avenue at West 65th Street tomorrow at 3 P.M.

title: Different Wavelengths
description: The World Administrative Radio Conference, which convened this week in Geneva, was once a cozy group of technicians from the industrial powers who focused on such esoterica as apportioning orbits for communications satellites. Today the conference of the 154nation International Telecommunications Union looks more like the U.N. General Assembly.

title: Cairo's Snipped Film Festival
description: It's hard to know exactly why several films depicting Jews were censored at the recent Fourth Cairo International Film Festival. They were, and of course it's bad news. Yet we think it's more interesting that Jewish themes were shown at all. The Nile does not change course readily and Arab politics are well known for relentless boycotts. Yet Egypt is in the middle of a genuine revaluation, and it is happening quickly despite some lurches.

title: Tara Nicholson, Account Representative, Is Wed in Jersey to David Chalmers Olson
description: Tara Ann Nicholson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Gabriel Nicholson of Upper Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday to David Chalmers Olson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Olson of New York and New Milford, Conn. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gabriel the Archangel in Saddle River by the Rev. John F. McDermott, who was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Herbert Anderson of the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: INQUIRY IS REPORTED ON LIBYA PLANE SALE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  The Justice Department has conducted an extensive, covert investigation for eight months, according to department officials, to determine whether there is an elaborate bribery plot under way, designed to win approval from the Carter Administration for the sale of military and commercial aircraft to Libya.

title: A Crowded Agenda For a Pontiff Who Likes Crowds
description: In July, Pope John Paul II accepted an invitation from Kurt Waldheim, Secretary General of the United Nations, to address the General Assembly. The speech has blossomed into an ambitious sevenday tour of the United States that will take the Pontiff to five of the eight American cities where cardinals usually reside, beginning with his arrival in Boston tomorrow from a threeday stay in Ireland.

title: OffCenter Theater Turns To Baking During Dispute
description: Because of a dispute between the Off Off Broadway Alliance and the Actors Equity over working conditions, the 13yearold OffCenter Theater's sixplay fall season has been canceled and the theater is turning its sideline into a full time activity  baking.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: On the banks of the Wabash River, not far from the corn fields of Indiana, stands a dramatically handsome new building representing architecture's most advanced frontier. This gleaming white structure is as radical an addition to the rural American heartland as Le Corbusier's Villa Savoie was to the French countryside at Poissy halfacentury ago.

title: ExI.R.A. Member Tells a Judge He'll Be Killed if He Is Deported
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29  A former member of the Provisional Wing of the Irish Republican Army fought a Government attempt to deport him yesterday, explaining that he would be killed by members of the militant group if he was forced to return to Ireland.

title: Exxon Records in Canadian Trial Point to Artificially High Oil Price
description: An unpublicized civil trial in Canada has produced evidence that the Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, systematically passed along artificially inflated price increases to customers in Canada and elsewhere.

title: WASHINGTON
description: BOSTON, Sept. 29  If God is dead, it's news to Boston. This lovely old city is so excited over the arrival of the Pope that it has almost forgotten the death of the Red Sox.

title: Adventures in Printmaking
description: GREAT NECK TELIER 778, the graphics workshop at 778 Middle Neck Road, is celebrating its first anniversary with an exhibition by participating artists at Gallery Soho 7, through Thursday. The work- shop specializes in encouraging artists who normally work in other media, and the results reflect the experimental approach favored by Elaine Orens and Alyce King Vaccino, who run Atelier 778's weekly sessions, which include technical advice and group critique.

title: Nancy S. Tichner Engaged to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jerome B. Tichner have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Suzanne Tichner, to Mark Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Gordon of Tenafly, N.J.

title: Tilden Wins, 2012, On Run by Beattie
description: Bruce Beattie, a tailback who rushed for 152 yards on 18 carries, ran for a 6yard touchdown in the fourth quarter to give Tilden a 2012 victory over Erasmus.

title: A West Side Sale Leads to Calls For Revision in the Zoning Law
description: All Angels Episcopal Church had been at West End Avenue and 81st Street since 1869, and until April it owned four buildings there. The oldest was the church itself, built in 1890.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: RUMSON THIS is a fantasy house, said Mary Weir of the 35room mansion in which she resides with her husband and their two sons. If so, getting there took a lot more than fantasizing; it took guts, hard work and an impeccable sense of timing.

title: ANNALS OF AN ABIDING LIBERAL
description: THIS book of miscellaneous essays does show John Kenneth Galbraith to be the abiding liberal of its title, though not a particularly impassioned one. The liberalism displayed herein arises not from any loud noise in the outraged heart but from common sense and contemplation of the selfevident. To Mr. Galbraith, illiberal individuals are not wicked so much as they are illinformed or irrational or stupid.

title: President Gets WideRanging Advice on Soviet Troops From 15 Experts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  President Carter received wideranging and often conflicting advice today from 15 former high officials prominent in the national security field on how to respond to the SovietAmerican deadlock over the reported presence of a Soviet combat brigade in Cuba.

title: Dock, Mullein And Primroses
description: Late summer and early fall's landscape have remnants  of wildflowers to take indoors for winter. Dock, common mullein, evening primrose and even the common phragmites can be beautiful.

title: Environment
description: LONDON  The wreck of the Torrey Canyon off Cornwall in 1967 first aroused world concern over the transportation of oil by sea. Efforts to improve the situation gained momentum after the Argo Merchant went aground off Nantucket in 1976, then got a mighty push after 250,000 tons of oil from the Amoco Cadiz spilled near the French coast 18 months ago.

title: New McCarter Season Opens Tuesday Under a New Director
description: PRINCETON

title: Secession: Why a Vote Was Denied
description: WHY, for the first time in its history, did the Westchester County Board of Legislators refuse last week to allow a group of local residents to vote on a question of home rule?

title: In the Cab They Come and Go, Talking of... You Name It
description: IT was 5 o'clock on a Friday afternoon, and it was the driver's 18th haul. He picked up a welldressed man at the New Rochelle train station, then dropped him off a few minutes later at a Dodge dealership on Boston Post Road. The man was renting a car to take on a threeday holiday weekend in Virginia, and the cab driver regarded him enviously. He was only three hours into an 11hour work day, and, although he would travel more than 150 miles by the end of his shift, he would get no farther than the Bronx.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Looking at some new productions in Copenhagen and London makes one realize how insular a sophisticated dance capital like New York can be. For the past decade, we have had a corner on creativity in dance  the best by our standards. that is. Our selfsatisfaction has carried the assumption that the rest of the world would want to follow our lead in dance. Certainly, the new moderndance companies springing up in Europe and Asia are totally derived from the American model. In ballet, however, the rest of the world quite simply has other ideas. Europeans are apt to watch very different ballets from those seen by Americans  ballets that could not conceivably have been produced in America.

title: 3 Boys, 13, Are Arrested In CrossBurning on S.I.
description: Three 13yearold boys were arrested yesterday following an investigation into a crossburning in the back yard of a house on Staten Island occupied by what police described as a racially mixed couple.

title: At Ford, the Gauntlet Passes to a Prince Named Phil
description: DETROIT  There will be no magic day of Oct. 1, said Philip Caldwell, referred to as Phil by Henry Ford 2d and The Prince by his peers who watched his long, quiet climb up the corporate ladder. All this has been evolving and we've all been hard at work at it for quite a long time now.

title: Margaret C. Pollock Is Married
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday, Margaret Cunningham Pollock, an accessories merchandise representative with the Associated Merchandise Corporation, was married to Richard Charles Bondy, an account executive with the Foote, Cone & Belding advertising agency. The Rev. William D. Donovan performed the ceremony.

title: Susan E. Vitale Married To Norman A. Varney Jr.
description: Susan Elizabeth Vitale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. James Vitale of Chester Springs, Pa., was married there yesterday to Norman A. Varney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs: Norman A. Varney of Darien, Conn.

title: Archdioese of Boston Plans Pope Medallion
description: BOSTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)  The Archdiocese of Boston has commissioned a bronze medallion to commemorate the visit of Pope John Paul II.

title: DAILIES IN CANADA IN TROUBLED TIMES
description: TORONTO, Sept. 29  The sudden demise of The Montreal Star on Tuesday shocked the dwindling Englishspeaking community in that city, where the 111yearold daily newspaper had long been a pillar of society.

title: The N.F.L. and Television: Finding the Proper Mixture
description: TO understand why some National Football League games show up on the television screens watched by New York's pro football fans and others do not is an exercise in the recent history of the sport and the television industry. Suppose we go back to the start of this decade.

title: Hambletonian Race: Money vs. Tradition
description: The overstated elegance of the bugler at the Du Quoin, Ill., track remains untarnished, even when he puts down his horn and picks up a rake to smooth the dirt across the finish line of the Hambletonian. His topper unskewed, his morning coat dustless, he lends a touch of grandeur to the menial job of sweeping hoofprints from the dirt.

title: Transportation Bond Issue Is HardSell, Slow Mover
description: What costs $500 million, is supported by leaders of both major New York political parties, offers something for almost every part of the state and is  the professional politicians believe  in deep trouble?

title: Englewood to Offer A Festival of the Arts
description: THE first Bergen County Festival of the Arts may be the last opportunity of the year to attend an openair concert, sit at a sidewalk caf or amble through an outdoor art festival, craft exhibition or flea market.

title: Squirrel and Hawk
description: Driving through bucks county, deep into headquarters road, heading southwest from New Jersey to see hawks fly, my son and I stopped our car by a sudden bend where a rich pear tree dangled its unpicked fruits from tired hands; we stopped our car and backtracked to what we thought was a beehive set on a dead tree's fork. But rammed into that wooden V we saw a squirrel, its head dried flat and insects humming all over its lean body. My son spoke of hawks and that day we did see two hawks, high in the air, wings spread like great palm leaves mighty powers riding the cool October winds, beaks aimed down, claws like knives cuddled into softest feathers.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a homeowner sees that the outside paint on his house is cracked, peeling,. or severely eroded in many places, then he knows for sure that a new paint job will be needed in the near future. However, if the old paint is merely dirty and dingy looking, or perhaps discolored in some places but otherwise seems to be in fairly good physical condition  the chances are that the outside of the house is not yet due for a new coat of paint. It may be that all it needs is a good washing.

title: MAKING IT HAPPEN AT THE GARDEN
description: Sonny Werblln is at the big frultwood desk up on the 18th floor of 2 Pennsylvania Plaza. The head man of Madison Square Garden Corporation is sorting through a pile of mail. The fan from North Bergen, N.J., writes that he has invited his clergyman  a benefactor to his son  to the Ranger game on such and such a date, and he wonders if the Garden can upgrade the seat to the celebrity locations he is sure it must have. Some nerve, Werblln mutters, and moves onto the rambling plea from the highschool soccer coach for a job at the Garden and to the request from a youngster for a Ranger souvenir (Send him a puck, he tells his secretary).

title: Gucci Plunges Into Formality
description: The trend in fashion is to more formality and Gucci certainly has been helping it along.

title: The Region
description: To the untrained ear, it was a rumble over money for mass transit for New York City. But the background noise was a skirmish last week between a President seeking reelection and a Governor he suspects is already in the camp of his challenger.

title: Taking Money Abroad in a New Era
description: A problem when planning a foreign trip is what kind of money to carry.

title: Tennessee Is Seeking Truth About Impostor In Jail Hospitals Post
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 29 (AP)  Tennessee investigators are trying to piece together the past of the man who called himself Dr. Jesse Adams and served as Tennessee's director of prison medical services.

title: Marriage Announcement 5 -- No Title
description: Margaret Mack to Wed Nov.

title: LOTTE DREWBEAR
description: Lotte DrewBear, an expert in the field of Surrealist art who was associated in New York with the Julian Levy Gallery in presenting many phases of the avantgarde development, died Monday in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 68 years old.

title: Lindsay Is Victor In Run
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 29  In college, he ran in the Big Ten Conference shadows of Craig Virgin. Several weeks ago, he won a race but was overshadowed by President Carter. Today, however, Herb Lindsay was the king of the road in the Diet Pepsi national 10,000meter roadracing championship.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: A $420,000 grant that was awarded to the Hudson Valley Emergency Medical Services System last June to provide extended emergency services to sevencounty area has not been turned over to the E.M.S.S. regional council. The reasons are unknown and puzzling to the regional representatives.

title: In Divorce, Little Things Mean a Lot
description: Even in the best of divorces, the ones that seem to be made in heaven, it happens. The couple, a model of civility, agree on child custody, alimony, property, all the major issues. Only a few details remain to be decided before the settlement is signed and the lawyers collect their fees. Then, the teapot begins to boil.

title: Snuffing Out Legal Smoking
description: THE notalways subtle division in American society between smokers and nonsmokers will be a little more noticeable in Connecticut starting tomorrow, when Public Act 79410 goes into effect.

title: Chopping Fuel Expenses With a WoodBurning Stove
description: LAST year, when the cost of homeheating oil went higher than 60 cents a gallon, Bill and Cynthia Jaffee, who own a 12room house in Bedford Hills, decided to heat part of their home with a woodburning stove.

title: Lisa Fry Bride of William B.D. Stroud Jr.
description: Allison Brooks Fry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Morton Fry 2d of Wyomissing, Pa., and Watch Hill, R.I., was married in Wyomissing yesterday to William Boulton Dixon Stroud Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stroud of West Grove, Pa., and North East Harbor, Me. The Rev. Dr. Gene W. Aulenbach, pastor of the Bausman Memorial United Church of Christ in Wyomissing, performed the ceremony at the Fry home.

title: Peter Mancusi Jr. Weds Margery Manning Eagan
description: Margery Manning Eagan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Eagan of Centreville and Fall River, Mass. was married yesterday in Centreville to Peter Joseph Mancusi Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mancusi of Stamford, Conn. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Victory by the Rev. Michael Proterra, a cousin of the bride.

title: The New PrimeTime Lineup
description: This television season might very well be remembered as The Year of Roddy McDowall. Short on both innovation and quality, the commercial networks are preoccupied with standard formats and scheduling tactics. ABC, the ratings leader, is generating less press attention with its new series than with the fact that it broke up a blockbuster combination on Tuesdays and, hoping to strengthen other areas, moved Laverne and Shirley and Mork and Mindy to different nights. Elsewhere, it is generally business as usual. The three networks are offering the public more kidvid ("The Misadventures Sheriff Lobo, 240Robert, The Last Resorts"), more spinoffs ("Sheriff Lobo and Benson") and more ripoffs ("Buck Rogers in the 25th Century"). Some changes have been made on older series. Edith is no longer with Archie every week. Kate Jackson has fled from Charlie's Angels. And, outside prime time, Saturday Night Live will be returning without John Belushi and Dan Ackroyd. Several of the new series  The Associates, Benson and The Lazarus Syndrome, all on ABC  look promising. The news picture is unusually active as a game of executive musical chairs gets underway at the networks and as at least one magazine discovers the ratings pull of popmusic stars. But the overall entertainment lineup seems almost relentlessly familiar.

title: Old Frames Holding Up New Houses
description: This is a very exciting concept  building a new house around an antique shell, said Michael Greenberg, who recently did just that. His new home in Weston, Conn., utilizes the handhewn wood frames and siding from three 150yearold Vermont barns.

title: GARDENING Flowering Plants for Low Temperatures
description: ANTICIPATING cooler home and greenhouse temperatures this winter because of the fuel crisis and the increased cost of heating oil, many home plant growers and greenhouse owners are looking into plants that will thrive in cooler temperatures.

title: Children of Desire
description: Just as everywhere else, there are loving hordes in the Fort Greene slum of Brooklyn who strike back at life with their own fecundity. Individuals fmd each other and reproduce and mark their existence with a new human.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: YOU had better get that horse out of your backyard if you live in Cedarhurst  it's illegal there. But if you're part of the Old Westbury crowd, then it's perfectly acceptable. Indeed, it is almost mandatory.

title: Show Opens Saturday
description: The Japan Camera Show, which has been a fixture in New York for the past 25 years, will open on Saturday for a threeday run in Albert Hall at the Sheraton Center, 7th Avenue and 52d Street. As in past years it will include displays of cameras and accessories, plus demonstrations, photo displays and a lecture program to be held on a stage especially built for the occasion. Admission is $3, or $2 with a discount coupon obtainable from camera stores. Show hours are from 11 A.M. to

title: Joanne Catapano Becomes the Bride Of James G. Combs
description: Joanne Catapano, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Catapano of New York, was married at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church yesterday to James Gerald Cmbs, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Ford Combs of St. Louis. The Rev. Eugene Prior performed the ceremony.

title: When One Becomes Old, Poor and Cold
description: IN the warm sunshine of an autumn afternoon five years ago, an old friend came to visit. It was pleasant reunion, two friends musing over life's fortunes, which had generally treated us kindly. While neither of us was rich, we certainly were not poor.

title: Mortgage Seekers Find Few Doors Open
description: HOW do you feel after 29 banks turn you down for a mortgage loan? Desperate! said Richard Flinn, a schoolteacher and a native Long Islander who recently moved his family back from upstate New York after a twoyear absence.

title: An Appreciation of Wallace Stevens
description: THERE is good reason to celebrate the centennial of Wallace Stevens.

title: Three Bostwicks Perform In Charity Polo Match
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 29 (UPI)  Ricky and Charlie Bostwick, sons of the former eightgoal handicapper, G.H. (Pete) Bostwick, accounted for four goals today, but they were not enough to prevent White Birch Farm from defeating Meadowbrook, 97, in charity polo match.

title: Plan to Ease TrafficCase Jam Is Debated
description: THE courtroom is jammed with motorists involved in traffic cases, and the overflow spills out into the hallways. A businessman complains that he has been sitting around for hours and has missed important appointments. A dentist says patients are waiting back in his office.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: DEANNA SCLAR did a strange thing when she rented a Chevy Caprice from Hertz up in Boston. First, she took the car to a Uniroyal tire dealer for a set of new whitewalls. Then she had him pound five nails into each of the $100 tires before setting off on a crosscountry trio.

title: A U.S COURT UPSETS RULING AGAINST CITY
description: The United States Court of Appeals last week reversed a lowercourt decision that would have required New York City to pay damages to five Pennsylvania landowners who had maintained that cityowned dams on the Delaware River in upstate New York had adversely affected their property.

title: Commuter Parking
description: HUNTINGTON, Hicksville and Babylon have considered themselves fortunate to be the easternmost stops on the Long Island Rail Road's electrified lines, but the improved service has become a mixed blessing.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Same Time Next Year, comedy by Bernard Slade, starring Deborah Neilson and James Gerth. Today 2 P.M. $5.50, discount available for students and the elderly. Reservations. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Junction of Routes 6 and 118.6281169.

title: Barbara Carty Fiance Of Lawrence D. Bodine
description: Barbara Chase Carty and Lawrence Dilworth Bodine, graduates of the University of Vermont, will be married on Oct. 27. Their engagement has been announced by the bridetobe's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Carty of Riverside, Conn. Mr. Bodine is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Bodine Jr. of Villano. va, Pa., and Manchester, Vt.

title: Jape Hopkins Plans Bridal
description: Jane Alden Hopkins, a correspondents processor with the National Geographic Society in Washington, will be married next June to John Patrick Carey 3d, assistant to the president for university relations at Georgetown University.

title: In Moped Country, Gas Sippers Boom
description: WORDS and people change, sometimes dramatically. Once upon a time, one idea of success was to drive big Cadillac or Lincoln, own an allelectric home and swim in an oilheated pool. Such notions of grandeur were thrown into fast reverse by Energy Crunches I and II.

title: CHINA SAYS RUSSIANS TAKE BORDER AREAS
description: URUMQI, China, Sept. 29  A government official accused the Soviet Union today of steadily encroaching on the territory of the vast Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region in Central Asia.

title: World News Briefs
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 (AP)  Argentine Army headquarters announced today that an attempt to oust Gen. Roberto Viola, Commander in Chief, had been put down. Later, it said the general leading the rebellion in Crdoba refused to accept dismissal and remained at the head of a small group of followers.

title: DINING OUT A Bonus for the Montclair Area
description: IT'S a pleasure to watch a restaurant grow and develop, and the pleasure is doubled when the end result turns out to be an establishment good deal better than the usual run. Such place is Jencarelli's, a relatively new restaurant Montclair, and it is particularly welcome because that area, unfortunately, is not blessed with outstanding dining spots.

title: Wine
description: The more time I spend with wine, the more I am convinced that there are fascinating similarities between various wines and the people who make them.

title: Moscow Orchestra Cancelled an American Tour Last Week
description: MOSCOW  He who abandons the land where he was born comes, as a rule, to a sorry end. Trying to get more somewhere else, he finishes up with nothing. Finally, he overcome by despair. He dreams of the Motherland ....I have met them in Soviet consulates in Rome, Vienna and other capitals of the Western world  people with anguish their eyes, pleading to be allowed to go home.

title: Pilgrim's Progress
description: Watching Pope John Paul II wade into cheering throngs, lift babies into the air and indulge in selfdeprecating humor  behavior that can be safely expected during his United States tour that begins tomorrow  has converted even many severe critics of papal authority into admirers of the present Pope. He has in less than a year presented a stunning contrast to the remote, formal facade projected by a most of his predecessors and, in that sense, the Pontiff with the personalist theology has been his own best friend.

title: Penn State Defeated By Nebraska, 4217
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 29  Nebraska exposed all of Penn State's weaknesses on offense and defense today when the Cornhuskers came from 14 points behind to score 28 points in the second quarter and trounce the Nittany Lions, 4217, before a wildly excited crowd of 76,151 at Memorial Field.

title: Wagner and Pace Are Among Victors
description: Wagner College, which won only two of 10 games last season, raised its wonlost record to 31 yesterday afternoon by edging Fordham, 1817, in the first game of a doubleheader at Giants Stadium. A freshman, Phil Marak, kicked an 18yard field goal with I minute 7 seconds remaining in the game to provide the winning margin.

title: New Hope In Child Welfare
description: IT is most appropriate that the Child Welfare Reform Act of 1979 came into being in this the International Year of the Child. The measure, which is intended to have revolutionary impact on New York's childcare system, was enacted by the State Legislature in response to myriad critical studies and reports castigating the state's existing childwelfare program and labeling it a system whose priorities were awry, myopically oriented toward the overuse of foster care.

title: New Disks for The Opera Lover
description: The opera season is well under way, both on stage and on recordings. Nothing may quite match the excitement of a live performance, but records have some special benefits. No opera house can now compete with the richly varied repertory of works presently available on disk, nor, in most cases, can impresarios cast them so lavishly. The record companies initial releases this fall continue to explore fresh territory as well as old favorites with allstar casts.

title: An Appeal to Spare Modern Westport School
description: ELLEN and Allan Holtzberg, who recently moved from Austin, Tex., to Westport, were determined that their three young children should find a school contemporary in design and innovative in environment, as they were used to in Texas. In district after Westport district, they found archaic, multistory schools similar to those they had attended themselves some 30 years ago. Imagine their shock and dismay to learn that the very school they had so painstakingly selected, Westport's celebrated Hillspoint Elementary School, designed by the architect Victor Lundy, was chosen to be closed by the Westport Board of Education.

title: Transfers Are Often Traumatic For Churches and Synagogues
description: By the early 1970's, the Church of the Holy Communion at 20th Street and the Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan knew it was in trouble. Its elderly congregation had dwindled till it could no longer support the complex of dark stone buildings that had once housed trade schools and a health clinic. So in 1975, the Episcopal congregation reluctantly decided to merge with two nearby churches and give up its buildings  a Gothic revival church, rectory, parish and sisters house built in the 1840's.

title: Picaresque Sport
description: HE fiction writer is a confidence man, dealing in sleight of hand and illusion, mixing language, artifice and art In whatever proportions he can muster to swindle us of time. If he is one of the great ones  Cervantes or Melville, for example, both of whom contribute epigraphs to Passion Play  we come away with something in return: an archetype, or something less grand but still worth having, such as an insight into the human condition.

title: A New Geneen Machine?
description: Harold S. Geneen took his time leaving the helm of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, retiring finally at 69 as chief executive. But he still remains as chairman, and his influence lingers. Mr. Geneen was the force behind the ouster of his successor, Lyman Hamilton, and the appointment of the new chief, Rand V. Araskog.

title: Jean M. Gansel Married To Francis Kowalski Jr.
description: Jean Margaret Gansel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gansel of Tenafly, N.J., and Francis Xavier Kowalski Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kowalski of Clearwater, Fla., were married yesterday. The Rev. James Bouffard performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Franciscan Sisters Convent in Tenafly.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Panatta, Borg Gain Final
description: MARBELLA, Spain, Sept. 29 (AP)  Adriano Panatta of Italy and Bjorn Borg of Sweden gained the final of the $200,000 European open tennis tournament today. The winner will earn $100,000 and the loser $40,000. Borg defeated Harold Solomon of the United States, 75, 6.1, in one semifinal and Panatta beat Vitas Gerulaitis of the United States, 46, 61, 64.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Anni and Joseph Albers met and married in 1925 while at the Bauhaus School. In 1933, when the Bauhaus closed and storm clouds were gathering over Germany, they came to the United States and quickly established themselves in the world of art.

title: FOOD/STYLE Island's Apple Scene Branches Out
description: IS your favorite apple the McIntosh or Delicious? If so, you have something in common with the majority of Americans. But at the same time, you may not be giving many other excellent apples a chance.

title: Man Fleeing Police Dies in Fall
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 29 (AP)  A 22yearold man was killed when he fell into the Genesee River gorge here this morning while fleeing from the police. The dead man, who had been stopped by officers at about 3 A.M. for driving erratically, was identified as Frank Lanza of Rochester.

title: Sewanhaka Too Strong For Syosset
description: Sewanhaka, the defending Conference I champion, broke open the game in the second period and went on to defeat Syosset, 506, yesterday in the opener for both teams.

title: Pope May Attract Biggest Press Corps in History
description: When Pope John Paul II tours the United States this week, he will be followed, photographed, televised and written about by what will probably be the largest press corps in history.

title: BIRTHS
description: ERLICHMAN. Honorary Aunt Marilyn Sale of New York City Joyfully announces the birth of Jonathan Emil Nathanson Erlichman onFriday, September 7, 1979In Los Angeles. Jonathan weighed in at 8 pounds B ounces and was 21 inches long. Proud parents are friends Roberta NathansonErlichman and Larry Erlichman of Los Angeles. Grandparents are Helen and Jerome Nathanson of Los Angeles and Pearl Erlichman of Brooklyn, N.Y. Great grandfathers are Barney Jurman and Sam Gershman of Brooklyn. Maze) toy.

title: What's So Great Musicals? The Books!
description: There may be more than mere nostalgia behind the recordbreaking number of musical revivals announced for this season. Broadway has already welcomed back Peter Pan and will soon see new productions of The

title: Laura DeMyer Wed to Steven Williamson
description: Laura Maria Margarita DeMyer, an executive trainee with the Irving Trust Company in New York, was married in Washington yesterday to Steven Lloyd Williamson, an associate with the New York law firm of Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside & Wolff. The Rev. Joseph T. Durkin performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral.

title: A Body From East River May Be Rikers Fugitive
description: A body tentatively identified as that of a man who escaped from the Men's House of Detention on Bikers Island last Monday night washed up on Castle Hill Point in the Bronx yesterday, the police said.

title: Barth
description: Continued from Page 1 work, in which characters (or their descendants) from the earlier novels are represented as living on past the endings of their own stories into the late 1960's, to deal with public and private complexity and to write letters to each other and to The Author, whose controlling hand they more or less discern in their own histories. The epistoj lary novel of Richardson and his successors is the governing form, as the picaresque novel was for The Sotweed Factor, and the absence of a central, authoritative point of view (The Author being only another letterwriter and reader) brilliantly supports Barth's eternal suspicion that life is only a collocation of stories, other people's and our own, that can't be verified by external tests.

title: CONTROVERSY ARISES ON CHINESE SPELLING
description: The introduction of China's official Pinyin system of rendering its language in the Roman alphabet, which the American press has adopted relatively smoothly, has begun to arouse protests from major university libraries in the United States.

title: Margaret Mullins and Robert Tortoriello, Lawyers, Wed
description: The marriage of Margaret Ann Mullins to Robert Laurence Tortoriello took place yesterday in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Deal, N.J. The couple are lawyers. She practices in Upper Montclair, N.J., and her husband is with the New York law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Carton and the Rev. Eugene Geiger.

title: CHESS
description: Attacking at any cost is, at times, going to cost too much. The words, of the famous French master Alexandre Deschapelies (17801847)  I want to check mate. I do not want to capture, to defend, or to attack. I want to check mate, and that's all constitute a boast, not a serious strategy. Even such a great egotist as Deschapelles himself could hardly have believed them.

title: State Comptroller Asks Simpler Municipal Budgets
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 29  State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has been holding a series of meetings around the state in recent weeks aimed at getting local governments to adopt budget methods that people can understand.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a homeowner sees that the outside paint on his house is cracked, peeling, or severely eroded in many places, then he knows for sure that a new paint job will be needed in the near future. However, if the old paint is merely dirty and dingy looking, or perhaps discolored in some places but otherwise seems to be in fairly good physical condition  the chances are that the outside of the house is not yet due for a new coat of paint. It may be that all it needs is a good washing.

title: FullValue Assessments Irk Towns
description: The Town of New Castle, one of the first two municipalities in Westchester to convert to the staterecommended system of fullvalue assessment updated annually, may become the first community in New York to back out of it.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Patients entered his East Side office feeling low, Dr. Max Jacobson once said, and went out the door singing.

title: The Naderites of the Other Side
description: WASHINGTON  It was Washington's first falllike Saturday and Michael W. Uhlmann was at work in his office, decked out in blue jeans and running shoes. A tall handsome 39yearold, he looks like what he is  a publicinterest lawyer, one of the hundreds who have poured into this town since the heyday of Ralph Nader.

title: New Law Impounding Trucks and Fining Drivers Goes Into Effect Tomorrow
description: The trucks roll up to vacant lots in the middle of the night and dump their loads  old mattresses, discarded construction materials and just plain trash. If caught by law enforcement officials, the private carters might receive a summons and have to pay a small fine. But the chances are they won't be caught, and even if they are, they usually consider the fine part of the cost of doing business.

title: A Big Tame Bear. . . An Anchorite of Passion
description: STEVENS had little to do with the usual social activities of Hartford. He remained by calculation an outsider, and people assumed that he was a coldly fastidious and indifferent man. The contrary was the case: though an anchorite, he was an anchorite of passion whose mind blazed continuously with sensual images. He marched like a big tame bear through the streets of our city, but there was nothing tamed about him; he had chose to imprison his fiercer self in a cage of upper-middle-class decorum. Stevens had good reason to keep the rest of us at bay, for at all hours and in all weathers he was intent upon his poems.

title: Pastore Brightest of New Faces Who Have Led Reds to the Top
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 29Frank Pastore had finally made it. There he was in Dodger Stadium, pitching for the Cincinnati Reds an hour away from where he grew up and where throwing a baseball had always been easy. He had survived a minor league career that included a 2230 wonlost record in four years, an arch problem in his feet. a torn arm muscle that almost made him quit, a weight problem, a case of measles, a case of heart sickness and a thick skull.

title: 2,000 Car Radios Put Him in Big Business
description: SOME 15 years ago, a young businessman named John J. Shalam faced a problem. An associate in Japan had sent him a sample of a car radio and asked him to see if he could find customers for it.

title: ANTIQUES The Orient Comes To Hackensack
description: HACKENSACK

title: No Title
description: Kathleen A. Manning Married

title: ANTIQUES
description: The history of watches is a splendid saga covering five centuries of world events that involves the evolution of engineering, design, decoration, metallurgy, social mores and commerce. And when this tale is unraveled by two sophisticated minds who comprehend the technical and esthetic complexities of these portable timekeepers, experts who are also amazingly literate, the results are remarkable.

title: Song: Hernan V. Pelayo
description: Hernan V. Pelayo gave a rather perplexing song recital in Alice Tully Hall last Monday night. A baritone who has appeared sporadically on New York's concert and opera stages over the last 25 years, Mr. Pelayo still commands an impressive basic instrument, but he uses it in a very inconsistent way.

title: Quebec Poll Indicates Majority Are Opposed To Full Independence
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 29  One of the most exhaustive polls yet taken of Quebec opinion indicates a majority rejects independence and separation from Canada, but would be willing to give the present secessionist Government a mandate to negotiate a new association of sovereign states.

title: Strong BackNine Finish Gives Miss Moon Golf Title
description: CANNES, France, Sept. 29 (AP)  Susan Moon of Montecito, Calif., stormed home with six birdies in the last nine holes for a round of 68 and a total of 292 to win the 72hole Women's Professional Golfers Association European championship at the Valbonne course today.

title: Islanders Edge Rangers On FourGoal Rally, 54
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 29  Clark Gillies scored the tying and the winning goals tonight as the Islanders fought back to defeat the Rangers, 54, in preseason contest before 14,387 roaring fans at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Mayor Again to Press In Albany for Reforms In Civil Service System
description: ALBANY, Sept. 29  Mayor Koch will try again in 1980 to push Civil Service reforms through the State Legislature, an aide to the Mayor said here today, but the proposals again drew stout opposition from public employee union representatives.

title: THE MACKINTOSH REVIVAL
description: Virtually forgotten until 10 years ago, this Scottish architect's furniture is now selling at recordbreaking prices.

title: How the Bond Issue Would Aid Colleges
description: TRENTON

title: THE POWER OF COLOR
description: Color has come back with a splash. After years of nocolor modern design, this least expensive of all design tools is enjoying a renaissance. Designers and architects are discovering that color is, indeed, powerful stuff, and they are making the most of it, using it in daring new ways. A room might include every known pastel (it works if the values are equal), an exterior might be painted shades of one hue, or one brilliant color might be used overall in a. joyous.paean to itself.

title: ART Fabric and Wood Paired at the Hudson
description: FABRIC landscapes and fauxarchitecture in raw wood make up the Hudson River Museum's double bill through Oct. 7. The shows, by Susan Zucker and David Durst, respectively, may sound illmatched but they are actually complementary and in some respects similar.

title: 2 Million. Irish Cheer Pope John Paul As He Prays for Peace `for All People
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 29  Two million or more people  twothirds of the population of the Irish Repubic  turned out today to cheer Pope John Paul II, who told them that he was there because I too have heard the voice of the Irish and because he wanted to pray for peace for all the people of Ireland.

title: Charity Lee Sulcer, Christopher Poth Wed in New Jersey
description: Charity Lee Sulcer, daughter of Mrs. Alexander S. Parr of Bay Head, N.J., and the late Henry Thearle Sulcer, was married yesterday to Christopher Anthony Poth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Poth Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

title: HOW THE NORTH WAS WON
description: Three years ago, when Jimmy Carter was elected to the Presidency, the general feeling was that a milestone had been reached in the relations between the South and the rest of the country. The fact that an obscure politician with no national standing and redolent in every way of the culture of the Deep South could now be elected President was widely taken to mean that, a century after the traumas of the Civil War, the South had finally been reabsorbed and was now once again truly a part of America.

title: Stage: A Fanfare
description: ENGLEWOOD TO PUT the matter as modestly as possible, the Center Stage production of The Threepenny Opera is sensational.

title: Mahala Tillinghast Engaged to R.B. Beams
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gardner Tillinghast of Easton, Md., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mahala Willard Tillinghast, to Richard Blanchard Beams, son of Mrs. Thaddeus Williams of Summit, N.J., and the late Robert Hall Beams.

title: Meredith Martin, B.A. Atherley Wed
description: Meredith Louise Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Meredith Martin of Schenectady, N.Y., was married yesterday to Bruce Alexander Atherley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Atherlev of Pittsbureh.

title: THE URANIUM PEOPLE
description: By Leona Marshall Libby. Illustrated. 341 pp. New York: Crane Russak/Scribner's. $15.95.

title: STAMPS New Cards From U.S. and New Trio From the U.N.
description: The United States is issuing two postal cards for the heritage and heroism of its past; Muhammad Ali goes from punches and poems to painting and philately, and the United Nations goes on issuing stamps for independence for Namibia.

title: Northport Is Victor on 4thPeriod Rally
description: Northport High School rallied from a 120 deficit at the end of three quarters to defeat Patchogue, 1512, yesterday in a Suffolk Conference I game.

title: McEnroe Is in Final
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29  More than the San Francisco cable cars went on the fritz this week. At the Cow Palace, away from the center of town, where the $175,000 Transamerica tennis tournament was being staged, seeded players were falling in upsets.

title: Lawyer Is Fianc Of Suzie Pandjiris
description: Mary Suzanne Pandjiris, specialevents coordinator for Saks Fifth Avenue, will be married on Jan. 12 to Millard Warren Browne, secretary and general counsel for the Philip A. Hunt Chemical Corporation in Palisades Park, N.J.

title: A Benefit Concert (And All That Jazz)
description: THE largest jazz event in New Jersey in many years will be staged at Waterloo Village today, when a hundred musicians will keep two bandstands humming from 1 to 8 P.M.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, Sept. 29 (AP)  A 15yearold black student who was shot by a sniper yesterday at an afternoon football scrimmage struggled for life today, the police said.

title: TILE PAZZI CONSPIRACY: THE PLOT AGAINST THE MEDICI
description: The 15th century In Italy  a period of violent, scheming Popes, the renaissance of great art and architecture, murderous dukes and bankers and governors of cities  provides rich fare for an absorbing narrative. Lorenzlno, Arvin Upton's 1977 historical novel about the ruthless and subtle Medici world. came alive as few histories are able to do. Perhaps is my vivid memory of that novel that makes Sir Harold Acton's account of the same family at an earlier period seem so pale, dry and undramatic.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: SIPPING a cup of black tea made from a teabag, Wan Li, Governor of Anhui Province, which produces about 10 percent of all the tea in China, noted that at home, I usually drink green tea.

title: Scalley Passes Spark
description: Greg Scalley completed five of nine passes for 134 yards and two touchdowns as Morristown defeated East Orange, 206, in Morristown yesterday for its second straight victory.

title: CRIME
description: It is with a sinking feeling that one picks up a novel about terrorists in possession of a nuclear device. Usually the situations are predictable, and the downtothewire race between the forces of Good and Evil ends up a bore. But Peter Health Fine, in NIGHT TRAINS (Lippincott, S9.95), has managed to work out something a bit different from the standard routine.

title: LETTERS
description: Regarding synthetic fuels: What so consistently disturbs me, as an energy professional who has spent 18 years researching and designing alternate fuel and energy systems, is the fact that the best and least costly fuel potentials are consistently overlooked.

title: No Title
description: Deaths

title: Robert Andersons: Now There Are 8
description: A fellow called Robert E. Anderson has just been named president of Mattel Inc. Mr. Anderson, who moves into toys from tobacco  he was executive vice president of R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Inc.  undoubtedly got to where he is today through hard work, dedication and demonstrated qualities of leadership. But did his name help, too?

title: Ill Wind Blows For Sculpture In Public Park
description: HOOSICK FALLS, N.Y., Sept; 29 (AP)  George W. Rickey, the artist, says he thinks he will take his metal windmill sculpture and go home.

title: Equatorial Guinea ExDictator Reported Executed
description: MALABO, Equatorial Guinea, Sept. 29 (Reuters)  The ousted dictator of Equatorial Guinea, Nguema Biyoto Masie, and six former aides were sentenced to death today, and informed sources said they were shot within hours.

title: Official in California Shuns High Court Pay Dispute
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29  The justices of the California Supreme Court have been left to their own devices by State Comptroller Kenneth Cory in the dispute over whether their pay should be withheld because they have not complied with a constitutional requirement that cases must be decided within 90 days after they have been heard and the legal work is finished.

title: Bands From the Los Angeles Club Circuit
description: Given its persistent charttopping success in recent months, it might seem a little late in the game to review the Knack's debut album. But as interesting as that disk is in itself, it is also an indication of a trend that should have considerable impact on the charts in months to come. That trend is the sudden appearance on a variety of labels of bands discovered on the newly revitalized Los Angeles club scene.

title: Carter and Mexico Leader Agree to Discuss Compensation to U.S. for Spill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  President Carter and President Jos Lopez Portillo of Mexico agreed today to have their Governments begin negotiations concerning compensation by Mexico for damage caused to the United States by the runaway oil well in the Gulf of Mexico, United States officials said today.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The Susan B. Anthony dollar has not been getting rave reviews  if anything, most coinage critics have panned it. Even so, it figures to be a hit with Uncle Sam because it should still be a money maker.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: If there were such a thing as The Guinness Book of Literary Records, Madeleine L'Engle would have to get a prominent page in it. She's got 11 books coming out in a 12month period.

title: Judge in Dispute on Presley Bars Quick Decision on Autopsy Data
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 29 (UPI)  A Chancery Court judge, asked to decide whether the results of Elvis Presley's secret autopsy should be disclosed, told lawyers yesterday that he would not move swiftly in the case Just because the singer was a national hero.

title: Oceanography
description: In 1979, the final year of the International Decade of Ocean Exploration, immense scientific efforts are concentrated on dispelling the mysteries that still cloak the sea and documenting the ocean's links to the welfare, past and vresent. of mankind.

title: Dacko Denies Attempt on His Life
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic, Sept. 29 (Reuters)  President Dacko today denied reports that an attempt had been made on his life.

title: Suffolk a Key In State Drive For Transit Bonds
description: THERE was a time when politicians promised they would make the Long Island Rail Road the best commuter line in the nation. But in these days of inflation, the energy crisis and rising gasoline costs, the goals seem to have shifted to getting the trains running on time and improving maintenance.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: DANCE UMBRELLA-Opening this week in its new home at Camera Mart/Stage One, the series includes, early on, the Trockadero Ballet, represented by Natch Taylor, left. Sharing the second week will be Kei Takei, front, and Martine van Hamel with umbrella holder Kevin McKenzie.

title: Recital: Joel Spiegeluran in Retrospect
description: A brief retrospective of music by Joel Spiegelman in Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night bore witness to a composer still developing at the same time that he maintains certain stylistic hallmarks. The 46yearold teacher and conductor at Sarah Lawrence College was represented by works written within a decade. Though not performed in chronological order, they included Kousochki (Morsels) (1966), Daddy (1972), Astral Dimensions (1973), Second Fantasy for string quartet (1975) and Midnight Sun (1976).

title: LETTER TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: The attitude of the people interviewed in Betsy Brown's article, Without Fear the Animals Move In, [Sept. 2] was myopic. What about the animals plight and the fact that we moved in on them? Why don't they think about doing something for the animals who are starving and so thirsty that they resort to drinking out of highly chlorinated swimming pools?

title: DINING OUT Rooms With a View
description: SOUTH SALEM E Chteau, attractively situated on the hilltop of a large estate in South Salem, not far from the Connecticut border, is an appropriate setting for an elegant dinner. The former rural mansion overlooks a serene, misty pond and meadows, with forested hills beyond.

title: Senators Clash Over Art Center
description: WASHINGTON NEW JERSEY'S two United States Senators, both Democrats who usually agree, have suddenly found themselves on opposite sides of an issue the production policies at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

title: Unsettled Religious Climate Marks U.S. on Visit of Pope
description: The religious climate that awaits Pope John Paul II's arrival in the United States tomorrow is far less settled than it was when Pope Paul VI made the first papal trip to this country 14 years ago.

title: BokChoy, etc., for the Picking
description: FLEMINGTON

title: FILM VIEW
description: The man with the tape recorder is not the snappiest conversationalist, but that's what makes him a soothing as well as a convenient interviewer when one has several more or less unrelated subjects to get off one's chest.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10:00 (4) Prime Time Sunday: On domestics working for foreign diplomats in Washington; Man finds sister after 37year search; Profile on Earl Weaver, manager of Baltimore Orioles.

title: A Nuclear Plant Guard Held After Nude Swim
description: SHOREHAM, N.Y., Sept. 29 (AP) A security guard at the Shoreham nuclear power plant site was taken into custody early today after he was found swimming nude in the Long Island Sound just offshore from the facility, the police reported.

title: Kristin Mortimer Bride of Physician
description: Kristin Ann Mortimer and Dr. Robert Milton Hartley were married yesterday evening in Harvard University's Appleton Chapel. The Rev. F. Washington Jarvis, an Episcopal priest and headmaster of the West Roxbury (Mass.) Latin School, performed the ceremony.

title: OFFICIAL IN PEKING CONCEDES 60'S MOVES LED TO CATASTROPHE
description: PEKING, Sept. 29  In a speech today marking the 30th anniversary of the People's Republic of China, Yeh Jianying, senior deputy chairman of the Communist Party, offered a candid new version of recent history conceding that the Communists had made a series of errors culminating in the Cultural Revolution.

title: Bonnie Werber Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Bonnie Werber to Mark Goldstein has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Werber of Roslyn, L.I., parents of the bridetobe. Mr. Goldstein is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Goldstein of Westbury, L.I.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: GEORGE Weiner has lost track of the number of times he has been held up or robbed at the pharmacy he has operated for the last 20 years on Fairfield Avenue in the Black Rock section of Bridgeport.

title: October: The Best of Everything for an Outdoorsman
description: Being, alas, a product of a more restrained upbringing, I cannot vouch for October's reputed potential for setting the gypsy's blood astir, but I do know that it induces a strange eagerness in hunters and fishermen.

title: Henry Wiggen at Liberty
description: ENRY WIGGEN is middleaged. Mark Harris has written his fourth novel about the lefthanded pitcher. First was The Southpaw, in 1953, followed by Bang the Drum Slowly and A Ticket for a Seamstitch. Twentytwo years later we have It Looked Like for Ever, which is not so much about baseball as about aging, just as Bang the Drum Slowly was not so much about baseball as it was about dying. It is the strength of all of these novels that Mark Harris uses material that we normally associate with the sports pages and by skill and compassion enlarges what he touches until he reveals us to ourselves  our ordinary, universal lives.

title: Bleak Craft
description: HIRTYNINE stories, coldly and impeccably fashioned, the work of four decades: tales set, for the most part, in Morocco, Mexico and South America, in landscapes of a superlunary authority. (Even Paul Bowles's Manhattan is not our Manhattan.) To state that the intensely evoked settings of Bowies's disturbing stories are usually hostile to his peoplenatives as well as hapless North Americans  is perhaps misleading, for the setting of a typical Bowles story has more life, more iden

title: Miss Meister, M.S. Sweeny Are Married
description: Carolyn Jardine Meister, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Meister of DeWitt, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Martin Skouras Sweeny of Montreal. He is a son of the late Martin J. Sweeny Jr., and the late Athana Skouras, both of New York. Msgr. Daniel O'Brien performed the ceremony in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title: Powell, Campaigning for Carter, Sees Value in Florida Caucuses
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 29 (AP) Jody Powell, the Presidential press secretary, said today while campaigning for President Carter that Democratic Party caucuses in Florida next month would have a strong effect on the Presidential campaign.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The departure of Martin Feinstein from John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts was a shocker. It was announced on Sept. 18 that he would no longer be the executive director, and that he was leaving to become head of the Washington Opera. He would, however, the announcement said, retain a liaison with the Center, becoming director of opera and ballet.

title: Bethlehem Steel: Facing the Downturn With Confidence
description: SPARROWS POINT, Md. - E.L. Auslander, one of the superintendents who run the new giant blast furnace at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's plant here, stood in the immaculate control room and looked over the many gauges that monitor each phase of iron making.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Alternateside parking regulations will be suspended throughout New York City tomorrow because of the Jewish holy day of Yom Kippur, which begins at sundown tonight.

title: Eleanor Miller Bingham Is Bride
description: Eleanor Miller Bingham, an independent producer of television documentaries, was married yesterday in Harrod's Creek, Ky., to Rowland Dumesnil Miller, an architect. The ceremony was performed in St. Francis in the Fields Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Stephen Davenport. He was assisted by the Rev. Frank Cayce and Samuel G. Miller Jr., brother of the bridegroom, who will be ordained an Episcopal priest in December. ceremony was performed in St. Francis in the Fields Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Stephen Davenport. He was assisted by the Rev. Frank Cayce and Samuel G. Miller Jr., brother of the bridegroom, who will be ordained an Episcopal priest in December.

title: Mets Streak Grows
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29  Although some teams may just be playing out the season at this stage, the New York Mets marched to their fifth victory in a row today, holding off the St. Louis Cardinals, 87.

title: Shooting Grouse on Scotland's Heathered Moors
description: A warning whistle shrilled off to our right. Then, over the crest of the hill we were hunkered down behind, a dozen brown streaks etched themselves against the gray sky. POW POW POW POW went the guns on either side of us. Two of the streaks stopped in the air, became recognizable as birds, and fell to earth.

title: Clarkstown North Wins
description: Clarkstown North chalked up its second Rockland County P.S.A.L. victory yesterday by shutting out Spring Valley, 270. Clarkstown was led by Robert

title: $50 for Tankful of Gas In Five Years Foreseen
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)  It may cost United States motorists $50 to fill the tank of a standard American car within five years, Worldwatch Institute said today.

title: Late Rutgers Surge  Conquers Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 29  Rutgers and Princeton played football on equal terms in the first half today, but Rutgers exploded after intermission and defeated Princeton, 3814, at Palmer Stadium before 23,253.

title: The Appeal of Life Insurance Fades, But Most Families Still Buy It
description: Ren A. Wormser is a financial adviser in New York. Like many others, he thinks life insurance is a lousy way to invest. It's probably the costliest method there is, he says. Life insurance has come under the guns of government regulators and consumer protectors for some time, and more recently the ordinary life policies that provide a means to build savings are feeling the heat of a more pernicious force.

title: GARDENING Flowering Plants for Low Temperatures
description: ANTICIPATING cooler home and greenhouse temperatures this winter because of the fuel crisis and the increased cost of heating oil, many home plant growers and greenhouse owners are looking into plants that will thrive in cooler temperatures.

title: POLITICS Suffolk G.O.P. Gets a Leader In a Hurry
description: ANTHONY C. PRUDENTI, the new Suffolk County Republican chairman, has almost as much at stake in the November elections as Peter F. Cohalan, the Republican candidate for County Executive.

title: POLITICS
description: It would have been thought that such activities stopped last month at the latest, for a Federal grand jury indicted Harry Lerner, the former Essex Democratic chairman; John F. Cryan, the county sheriff, and two of Mr. Cryan's aides on charges of extorting campaign donations from county workers in exchange for promotions and choice job assignments.

title: Spain's Socialist Party ReElects Gonzalez, a Moderate, as Leader
description: MADRID, Sunday, Sept. 30 (UPI) Spain's Socialist opposition party reelected Felipe Gonzalez as its secretary general early today and voted overwhelmingly to drop its Marxist label.

title: A Legislator's Call to Aid Farms
description: DURING the last three decades we have witnessed a decline in the number of farms and in agricultural acreage in Connecticut.

description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1,400 bookstores in every region of the United States.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  The White House said today that President Carter would not summon the House of Representatives back from its 10day recess to break its impasse with the Senate on major appropriations bill. The deadlock has threatened to stall expenditures by at least 10 large Federal departments.

title: Atonic Waste Storage Is Target of Protesters At West Valley Rally
description: WEST VALLEY, N.Y., Sept. 29  Opponents of nuclear energy gathered here today to protest storage of radioactive waste in the nowclosed Nuclear Fuel Services reprocessing plant and to call for an immediate cleanup.

description: THE ADVENTURES OF YEMIMA

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: TOKYO  A tendency to look down on fellow Asians is not the only reason Japanese are disliked in Korea and Southeast Asia, where irritation is also expressed over the Japanese preference for animals as opposed to human beings.

title: Filming Henry James-Britain Vs. America
description: A film of Henry James's novel The Europeans, which received high praise when it was shown in London last summer, will have its American premiere Tuesday at the

title: Notes
description: Lost luggage  certainly one of the best ways to ruin a trip  has found someone who is making a business out of returning it.

title: Legionnaire Disease Suspected
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 29 (UPI) Marion County health officials have found several more suspected cases of legionnaires disease among people who work near the Indianapolis Monument Circle. Dr. James Bowes, chief of the county Bureau of Health Services, said yesterday that more blood samples would be taken and other sites checked in an effort to locate the source of the bacteria that causes the disease. Two cases of the disease were confirmed earlier this month in employees at a restaurant near the circle. yesterday that more blood samples would be taken and other sites checked in an effort to locate the source of the bacteria that causes the disease. Two cases of the disease were confirmed earlier this month in employees at a restaurant near the circle.

title: 6 U.S. Cities Spruce Up for Pope's Visit
description: City cathedrals and country churches are being scrubbed, outdoor altars built and banners of welcome strung up. Large security forces are being assembled and experts are grappling with a maze of budgetary, logistic and traffic problems. Potholes are being filled, curbsides mended, graffiti removed and vacant lots cleaned up.

title: Alison Alden Klenk Married To Lawrence Alan Comstock
description: Alison Alden Klenk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Klenk of Tenafly, N.J., and Lawrence Alan Comstock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Foster F. Cornstock of Portsmouth, R.I., were married yesterday in the Tenafly Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Harry E. Chase performed the ceremony.

title: Jazz: Terry Gibbs Opens 3 Weeks on Vibraphone
description: Terry Gibbs, who opened a threeweek run at the Sheraton Center's French Quarter last Monday; was one of the first and best modem jazz vibraphonists. Instead of striving for even, hornlike phrasing like Milt Jackson, his contemporary, he developed a more percussive approach that tended to recall the sound of his instrument's antecedents, the xylophone and marimba. He wasn't wholly opposed to using the vibraphone's sustaining mechanism, but he seemed to distrust its sweetness. Instead of mechanically sustaining a note, he would often simply strike it repeatedly.

title: Yale 24, Conn. 17
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 29  John Rogan, Yale's sophomore quarterback making his first start, completed two touchdown passes to Dan Stratton in the Yale Bowl today as the Elis beat Connecticut for the sixth year in a row. The score, 2417, did not reflect the superiority of Yale, which handled the Huskies throughout most of the contest. The score, 2417, did not reflect the superiority of Yale, which handled the Huskies throughout most of the contest.

title: GARDENING
description: NTICIPATING cooler home and greenhouse temperatures this winter because of the fuel crisis and the increased cost of heating oil, many home plant growers and greenhouse owners are looking into plants that will thrive in cooler temperatures.

title: Ohio State 17. U.C.L.A. 13
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 (AP)  Art Schlichter guided Ohio State 80 yards in the closing moments and capped the drive by hitting a tight end, Paul Campbell, with a 2yard touchdown pass with 46 seconds left today as the Buckeyes rallied for a 1713 victory over University of California, Los Angeles.

title: Wallace Stevens: Poet on Executive Row
description: THE steeples of Farmington, the ponds and pagoda of Hartford's Elizabeth Park, the Connecticut River glinting past Haddam, the metaphysical streets of New Haven are now part of the landscape of modern literature. Wallace Stevens, one of the most important 20th century poets, the 100th anniversary of whose birth will be marked on Tuesday, put them on the literary map in the large body of poetry written during his nearly 90 years as a Hartford insurance executive.

title: Conrail Plans 1,000 Layoffs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 (AP) Conrail will lay off about 1,000 employees throughout its 16state rail system over the next 10 weeks, it was announced yesterday. A spokesman for the federally chartered rail corporation said that the planned layoffs were a result of less freight from shippers.

title: China's Jobless Youth: A Mounting Problem
description: PEKING  Each day for the past several months a group of young men, cameras in hand, has appeared on the corner diagonally across from the Peking Hotel, the Chinese capital's tallest and most modern building. Using the hotel as a background, they take photographs of local and outoftown Chinese for a fee of about 55 cents, slightly less than the staterun photo shop charges; the youths have been doing a brisk business since they opened their photo stand at the start of the summer.

title: Fugitive Justice
description: Clarence Norris was 18 years old when Scottsboro, Ala., police arrested him and eight other black teenagers and charged them with raping two white women. He was 84 years

title: A Novel of Correspondences
description: LETTERS is John Barth's first novel since Giles GoatBoy appeared in 1967. In the meanwhile Barth has published an uneven collection of stories, Lost In the Funhouse (1968), and a volume of three remarkable novellas, Chimera (1972). But it has been a long wait for a major work from a writer who established himself as a contemporary master with three novels in five years The Floating Opera (1956), The End of the Road (1958) and The Sotweed Factor (1960). Some allusions in Chimera to writer's block may be pertinent, but LETTERS could have taken anyone a decade to write, and it is well worth the wait.

title: Massachusetts 20, Harvard 7
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 29 (UPI)  Kevin O'Connor hauled in touchdown passes of 54 and 16 yards from Mike McEvilly and Sandro Vitiello kicked two field goals today to spark Massachusetts to a 207 victory over Harvard.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Nicolai Gedda, the Metropolitan Opera tenor, will appear as guest soloist this afternoon with the Russian Liturgical Folk Singers, whose conductor is George Margitich. The program begins at 4 o'clock at the Plaza for the Performing Arts, 30 North Van Brunt Street, Englewood.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: EAST HILLS  Passageways, paintings by Eleanore Ambrose; 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays; through Oct. 31; Pictureline Gallery, 118 Glen Cove Rd.

title: Spotlight in Scotto Trial Shifts to His Codefendant
description: Attention in the Anthony M. Scotto trial has turned temporarily to his codefendant, Anthony Anastasio, who is charged with obtaining more than $50,000 in illegal payoffs from the owner of a waterfront comoanv.

title: Phil Had a Secret
description: There is an old saying, Phil Bieber writes, that if you have a secret and one other person knows of it, it is no secret. Nowhere is the truth of this proved more often than on the race track.

title: Bronx Pawn Shop Is Robbed of $200,000 in Jewelry
description: A Bronx pawn shop was robbed of an estimated $200,000 in pawned jewelry yesterday morning by three armed men who opened the store's front door with a key and handcuffed and blindfolded the owner and an employee, the police said.The incident came a day after a Manhattan jewel robbery, apparently unrelated, in which two armed gunmen escaped with an estimated $175,000 in bracelets and gold chains.

title: Gliding Over Fall Foliage
description: I first soared during a ski trip to the Grand Tetons. A lovely Schleicher glider looped silently above the skiers enjoying the sun at Targhee Resort, and I was so enchanted that I drove down to the tiny airport in Driggs, Idaho, and signed on for my first flight.
