For nearly an hour we wheeled through the ridge lift on the west slope of the Tetons. As soon as I returned to New York, I began looking for a place to learn to soar.

title: Blue Wave Rolls, 217
description: Darien utilized a ballcontrol offense and swarming defense, which sacked the Staples quarterback, Dave Ross, seven times, to register a 217 victory over the Wreckers yesterday in a Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference contest.

title: Soccer: Still Losing Battle for Glamour
description: Despite the growth of soccer, football retains the glamour in interscholastic athletics in the fall.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Dogwood trees in the Northeast have been in trouble for the last few years. The symptoms start as lack of bloom. Later in spring, leaf edges, then whole leaves wither and turn brown. By the end of the summer, branches are dead, and in fall, sometimes the entire tree succumbs.

title: Yokel Lancelots
description: A Biography of John Steinbeck. By Thomas Kiernan. 331 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $12.95.

title: Guidelines Proposed For Businesses on Ban On Bribery Overseas
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)  Acting on instructions from President Carter, the Justice Department has decided to offer guidance to business executives who are concerned about violating a law prohibiting bribery overseas.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a homeowner sees that the outside paint on his house is cracked, peeling, or severely eroded in many places, then he knows for sure that a new paint job will be needed in the near future. However, if the old paint is merely dirty and dingy looking, or perhaps discolored in some places but otherwise seems to be in fairly good physical condition  the chances are that the outside of the house is not yet due for a new coat of paint. It may be that all it needs is a good washing.

title: Tension and Pressure of a Pennant Race
description: PITTSBURGH IF there were a baseball dictionary, at the beginning of each season its pages would be blank. But after enough April afternoons had rolled into midsummer nights, and after enough double plays had been mishandled and enough men had been left on base. you could begin to write in the dictionary: scrappy, but lacking power; good pitching, but poor defense fourth place. Or perhaps: unmotivated talent; skillful, but unable to perform as a unit  third place. Or even: uniformly strong; well managed with perfect balance  a division winner.

title: Marriage Announcement 8 -- No Title
description: Lisa Pappalardo Is Affianced

title: Peking Police Close Park Exhibit By Young Artists After Two Days
description: PEKING, Sept. 29 (Reuters)  Chinese policemen today stopped an unofficial art exhibition that opened two days ago in park adjacent to an official gallery.

title: Louisiana Man Accused Of Violating Slave Law
description: FARMERVILLE, La., Sept. 29 (UPI)  The slavery peonage law has rarely been used since Civil War days, but the Federal Bureau of Investigation contends that Connie Ray Alford broke it by keeping illegal Mexican aliens on his rural farm in chains, shackles and locks.

title: ART
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THERE is so much breathless celebration and awesome promotion about virtually everything these days that it is difficult to measure the inherent value of anything.

title: Ideas &Trends; In Summary Tangled Legacy of Three Mile Island: Multiple Inquiries
description: Shortly after the accident to the Metropolitan Edison Company's Three Mile Island nuclear reactor at Middletown, Pa. on March 28, the company's executive vice president, Robert Arnold, said he feared the accident was a blow from which the industry would not recover. Last week, as the nation's largest antinuclear rally to date gathered in Manhattan with the fervent hope that was true, Jane Fonda and Tom Hayden kicked off a 52city antinuclear tour, and six Government and industry research groups were trying to find out what the accident really implied.

title: Jazz: Joe Pass, Guitarist
description: Joe Pass, the guitarist, opened a twoweek solo engagement at Fat Tuesday's on Wednesday night, and the basement club was so quiet that the tapping of his heel on the bandstand sounded almost as loud as a drummer's backbeat. It was all the rhythmic support he needed. By sketching in a bass line with occasional roller register runs, spinning out strings of luminous chords, and weaving brisk singlenote lines in and out of the mosaic he was creating, Mr. Pass managed to sound like a full band while swinging with an irresistible momentum.

title: No Title
description: Linda Loeb to Be Wed in June

title: ART VIEW
description: In its confrontations with the classics of Japanese art, the modern Western mind often finds its own most cherished notions of the esthetic to be of little use, at once undermined and outdistanced. Nothing in our assumptions about art or the artistic vocation quite prepares us for what we find in this alien and utterly alluring tradition. It is not only because we are ravished by the sheer visual beauty of Japanese art  though this in itself would be shock enough. (Ours, after all, is a culture that has taught itself to  distrust the very idea of the beautiful in art, and a critic who carried on about it nowadays would quickly find himself in intellectual disgrace.) It is also because of what has gone into the making of this beauty. I mean the sense of spiritual vocation that is often so central to its existence. We have to go back to our own Middle Ages to find anything in the Western tradition even roughly equivalent, and even then the parallels are not exact.

title: Pop: Brand X Reunites Englisfi Rock Musicians
description: The career, disintegration and subsequent reunion of Brand X, an English band with roots in both progressive rock and jazz, never made much of an impression on the American pop audience. But the group has always had an enthusiastic cult here, and to many of its fans Brand X is simply one of the best groups in the world.

title: PLUGGING INTO THE 80'S
description: New decades invite fresh starts: The sleek, minimal style that has dominated 70's interior design may be functional but it is also apt to be stern. Now, the pendulum is swinging back, and a more colorful modern style is emerging that is less fastidious, more comfortable and comforting.

title: Bus Crash Kills One and Hurts 23
description: A Brooklyn woman was killed and 23 other passengers were injured early yesterday when a bus bound from Atlantic City to New York skidded on the rainslicked New Jersey Turnpike, struck curb and overturned at a toll plaza near Secaucus, N.J., the state police reported.Jennie Parker, 75 years old, suffered fatal internal injuries when the bus flipped over at 6:50 A.M. as it approached the toll complex at Interchange 16E, just south of the New Jersey Sports Complex on the Meadowlands at East Rutherford. The woman, whose address was withheld by the police, was pronounced dead at West Hudson Hospital at Kearny.

title: Iowa 30, Iowa State 14
description: IOWA CITY, Sept. 29, (UPI)  Dennis Mosley of Iowa ran for 229 yards on 39 carries and scored three touchdowns today to help the Hawkeyes snap a threegame losing streak with a 3014 victory over rival Iowa State.

title: U.S. and Soviet Said to Increase Arms Shipments to Arab Lands
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  The Soviet Union and the United States are stepping up deliveries of advanced arms to countries on the Arabian Peninsula, Carter Administration officials reported this week.

title: CARTER SEEN GAINING SOME LABOR SUPPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  A series of events this week involving organized labor and the Carter Administration has added several new cards to the political poker game going on between President Carter and his putative rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Mailbox: On the Man in the Houndstooth Hat
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jane E. Macy Becomes Bride Of J.L. Pfeffer
description: The marriage of Jane Elizabeth Macy, an international banking officer in the multinational division of the Wells Fargo Bank, to James Lawrence Pfeffer, an associate in the publicfinance division of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., took place in New York yesterday. The Rev. Anselm Hufstadei, a teacher at the Portsmouth Abbey School, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: LONDON LETTER
description: David Atherton, the ambitious young British conductor, thinks the big London orchestras tend to give concerts that are too safe, too conservative, too lacking in organizing ideas.

title: SURVIVING BLACK OCTOBER
description: On Sept. 3, 1929, the stock market of the United States hit a record high - 381.17 in the Dow Jones industrial average. New highs had been attained nearly every month for the previous two years, so the figure was scarcely news and did not make page 1 of The New York Times (which you could have bought for two cents along with your nickel coffee). Instead, The Times led with a heat wave: YEAR'S HOT-

title: JAMAICAN ECONOMY IS SPEEDING EXODUS
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica  An economic crisis in Jamaica is driving as much as 1 percent of its population a year to emigrate to the United States and Canada, officials here say.

title: Article 7 -- No Title
description: Had his conception not so ideally suited his clients needs, one might suspect Cambridge Architect Graham Gund of indulging hi architecture for the architect's sake. His exquisite Shapleigh house has three parts: a winterized section for the owners, an unheated wing for summer visitors and a part for garages and storage. The total perfectly captures the ethos of its New England coastal site. built in 161635, is a classic precedent, and so, of course, are most of Palladio's villas, whose significant places in the history of architecture hardly come from any functional success they may have enjoyed. But in all of these houses there appears a sense of balance the notions of space and plan that were being explored are in harmony, as in Edith Wharton's house, with the kind of life that was intended to take place within.

title: Music Notes: Casals Festival
description: Since the death of Pablo Casals in 1973, the festival he founded and led in Puerto Rico has been in jeopardy. It has kept going, but without the charismatic presence of the great cellist, it has had problems of identity and direction. Finally, late last spring, with everything planned, the festival had to be canceled. The Puerto Ricans were finding their voice and objecting to a situation where their country was merely a place for the event. In their eyes, the festival should be for them. An impasse developed between the local musicians and the management.

title: It's In the Air Captures Ruffian
description: The contest for supremacy among America's top fillies and mares took on added complications yesterday at Belmont Park as Harbor View's It's In the Air turned in a frontgoing effort to capture the $133,125 Ruffian Handicap before a crowd of 22,014.

title: Settlement of Lawsuit In 2Year Maine Fight Will Topple Billboards
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 29 (AP) Maine's longoutlawed billboards will be torn down beginning next month under a court settlement signed by the State Department of Transportation and three maior billboard companies.

title: Why Aging I.B.M. Wants $1 Billion
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, growth stock with a graying image, has been popping surprises at investors for nearly a year. Just before Christmas, it said it was splitting its stock 4for1, a device lure more investors. Then in January, the world's leading producer or business machines introduced a new generation of computers, the 4300 series, that were so attractively priced some of its competitors may never recover. It followed that up in July by reporting it had arranged lines of bank credit for up to $1.5 billion. And last week, I.B.M. announced plans to borrow $1 billion next month through its first public debt offering ever.

title: Judith Garfield and Gene Farinet of NBC News Marry
description: Judith Garfield and Gene Farinet, who are with NBC News, were married yesterday at the home of the bride in Manhattan. Acting State Supreme Court Justice Jack Rosenberg performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Will Grant City $130 Million to Help Limit Water Pollution
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Administration announced on Friday that New York City would get grants of $130 million for three water pollution control projects now under way that will cost more than $1.5 billion.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following are available from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  I Nevr Sang for My Father, in an Actor's CafTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50; group rates. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: What Makes the Leaves Strike Gold
description: AUTUMN is ready to put on a spectacular display. Trees will be bursting forth in breathtaking colors, dazzling the eye with flaming reds, golden yellows and deep purples. Nature bids farewell to summer foliage in this fiery manner.

title: The Man Behind the Unexpected Tales
description: You're a man of mystery, Mr. Dahl.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Schubert's Die Schne Mllerin not the likeliest vehicle for any singer's New York debut. This song cycle calls for extraordinary vocal finesse, as prerequisite, and its 20 songs must be strung together with dramatic insight, so that a touching narrative of young love gradually unfolds. Frank Kubik, an American baritone who sang the cycle last Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, succeeded in both respects beyond reasonable expectation. A former student at the Hartt College of Music who went on to graduate from the Vienna Conservatory, Mr. Kubik has a penchant for lieder that he has cultivated wisely. The voice, though somewhat limited on top  the climax of Mein! was strained  was smoothly produced and capable of a resonant forte and an unforced pianissimo.

title: A Special Kind of Theater
description: SOME coffeetable book: about six pounds, 13% inches by 10, 353 pages, 395 illustrations (about a third of them in color). It is intended as a reading or browsing book rather than as a reference and as such does not pretend to supersede previous books by David Ewen, Gerald Boardman, Richard Lewine. Richard Burton. Stanley Green or Cecil smith

title: Slippery Rock Invades a Big 10 Stadium
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 29 More than just a funny name, the Slippery Rock brochure says about the country's bestknown unknown college, and this afternoon 61,000 University of Michigan football fans, rooting for the little college that everyone laughs at, got a piece of the xocK while the Kock got a piece of the big time in a stadium that usually rings only with the cheers for players from Big 10 teams.

title: Jane A. Desforges Wed to M.J. White
description: Jane Alice Desforges, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerard Desforges of Melrose, Mass., was married there yesterday to, Michael Joseph White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. White of North Reading, Mass. The ceremony was performed in St. Mary of the Annunciation Roman Catholic Church by Msgr. Alfonso G. Palladino. He was assisted by the Rev. George Morgan, a former teacher of the bridegroom's at the Austin Preparatory School in Reading.

title: Hopeful Nigeria, Anxious Ghana Are Trying Democracy Again
description: ACCRA, Ghana  On the evening of his inauguration last week as Ghana's first civilian President in seven years, Hilla Liman!) sat reviewing the country's economic situation with fellow members of his People's National Party. He paused at one point, wearily wiped his brow, and said, Ah, the enormity of it all.

title: CAMERA
description: All wildlife photographers make a point of knowing the basics of camping, hiking and traditional hunting or stalking techniques because without this knowledge they will seldom have much success in getting the kind of photographs they want.

title: No Title
description: Deaths

title: SURVIVORS DESCRIBE MASSACRE IN BANGUI
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic, Sept. 29 (AP)  Two students who say they survived an April massacre in Bangui's Ngaragba Prison said today that they saw deposed Emperor Bokassa I kill several young boys by striking them on the back of the skull with his ivoryencrusted ebony cane.

title: Headliners
description: The Swiss did not get where they are today by failing to discharge their duties faithfully in financial affairs. Consequently, they take a dim view of the crime of which Bernard Cornfield, the American founder of the oncebrilliant Investors Overseas Service, stands accused in Geneva: fraud, in that he and other insiders sold 3.9 million shares of I.O.S. Ltd., the parent company, to employees and others when he knew the company was in a bad situation and getting worse. At his trial, which began last week, Mr. Cornfeld pleaded not guilty; if convicted, he faces a maximum of 10 years in prison.

title: Passaic Valley Is Winner
description: Steve DePasqual capped a 75yard drive with a 12yard scoring run with 10 minutes remaining to give Passaic Valley a 127 victory over Ridgewood yesterday at Ridgewood. Passaic Valley is now 20.

title: PILOT LICENSE RULES SEEN OPEN TO ABUSES
description: In delegating broad authority to license fliers, the Federal Aviation Administration has opened its licensing system to abuses and potential conflicts of interest, spot checks indicate.

title: First by CrossCountry Mile
description: St. Anthony's and Walt Whitman, the top high school crosscountry teams in New York State, won the team title in their respective races in the Suffolk County Coaches crosscountry meet at Sunken Meadow State Park.

title: Letter
description: TO THE EDITOR

title: Dance: Ritha Devi Links Parts of East and Vest
description: The LoftDance festival is a convenient name for a series of dance concerts being held on weekends through next month, but as it turns out, the definition of loft is highly flexible.

title: For Many From Afar, L.I. Offers a New Life
description: LIKE thousands of other ethnic Chinese, John and Marianne Tang, their three children and his mother and sister fled Vietnam last summer. They spent nearly a year with other boat people in a refugee camp in Malaysia before they were brought to a new home in Sea Cliff.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: DEANNA SCLAR did a strange thing when she rented a Chevy Caprice from Hertz up in Boston. First, she took the car to a Uniroyal tire dealer for a set of new whitewalls. Then she had him pound five nails into each of the $100 tires before setting off on a crosscountry trip.

title: BRIDGE
description: Various attempts have been made to make tournament bridgeplayers feel like track and field stars. There have been marathons, mainly in Europe, in which competitors continue nonstop for about 17 hours. The partnership that can best focus on the cards at the end of that time is usually the winner. And each fall New York has a triathlon, a competition in three events, in which players are in action as pairs, as teams and as individuals, with the results of all three segments being combined to produce a winner.

title: ART Fabric and Wood
description: YONKERS FABRIC landscapes, fauxarchitecture in raw wood: these make up the Hudson River Museum's current double bill (through Oct. 7). The shows, by Susan Zucker and David Durst respectively, may sound illmatched but they are actually complementary and in some respects similar.

title: PONTIFF, IN IRELAND, MAKES STRONG PLEA FOR END TO VIOLENCE
description: DROGHEDA, Ireland, Sept. 29  In a powerful appeal for peace in Northern Ireland, delivered near the strifemarred border between north and south, Pope John Paul II today implored terrorists to desist from hatred and violence and to repent.

title: Knicks Trounce Celtics, 132106; Cartwright Gets 27 and Bird 36
description: Bill Cartwright, the Knicks rookie center, continued to look impressive last night while the Marvin Webster situation became more confused.

title: Music: 7 Post Composers Heard in Alumni Concert
description: The C. W. Post Alumni Composers Alliance presented a concert in Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday night. Featured was music by seven composers associated with the college's music department, either as teachers or students. In all, three generations were represented, ranging from the founder of C. W. Post's music department, the late Stefan Wolpe (Triton Study for Piano, 1936), to its present chairman, Raoul Pleskow (Trio for Flute, Cello and Piano, 1977).

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: tempts on the winning drive. The key play was a 22yard pass from Schlichter to Gary Williams which gave the Buckeyes a first down at the U.C.L.A. 3yard line. The winning score came two plays later.

title: John Kenneth Galbraith in Person and Print
description: TO the Wasteland. That is the heading on the Xeroxed directions to the Vermont summer home of John Kenneth Galbraith. Indeed, the paved road through the woods has become a dirt road, winding and dipping. The visitor and former student is driving slowly, looking for a right turn at the house with the bird cages. Galbraith's? says a local, rising from a porch rocker. A lady in a big white Cadillac came by a while ago, said, where is the Galbraith estate. I said, pretty primitive for an estate. She said, that man must live on an estate. Toward the bottom of the full page of directions, it says, Do not lose courage, keep going.

title: Vienna: Museums for Everything
description: The world's first (and apparently last) reusable coffin reposes in a museum in Vienna. So does one of the largest collections of Esperanto literature. Sigmund Freud's waiting room is there  intact. And the Hapsburg cutlery. Vienna has a clown museum. And a bell museum. And a clock museum. And a tobacco museum. In fact, it seems, if it exists at all, it is probably on display under glass somewhere in Vienna.

title: A Correction
description: The illustration for the Sept. 16 Gardening column on the repair of damage to trees was incorrect. As the text of the column emphasized, a broken branch should be cut back flush to the trunk or to the major branch from which grows.

title: No Title
description: Mary Glennon Married on L.I.

title: Hinkle Dazzles, but Watson's 65133 Leads
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 29  Tom Watson, the leading moneywinner on the Professional Golfers Association tour for the third consecutive year, took a onestroke lead today in the second round of the World Series of Golf. Watson, winner of two British Opens and the 1977 Masters, shot a five-under-par 65 for a 36hole aggregate of 133, while Lon Hinkle carded his second straight 67 for 139.

title: Votes In Congress
description: 1. Vote on establishing a Department of Education, passed, 69 to 22, Sept. 24.

title: No Title
description: Deaths

title: Realty News
description: Increased regulation of apartmentreferral agencies by the New York Secretary of State has been proposed amid charges that many of the agencies have engaged in deceptive practices and, in several cases, have bilked clients.

title: Lieut. Charles Chadwick Weds Nancy Mathiasen
description: Nancy Jean Mathiasen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Mathiasen of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lieut. Charles Robert Chadwick, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Chadwick of Carthage, Miss. Msgr. Robert J. Skelly performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of SS. John and Mary in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: JUDGE AND INMATES DISCUSS GRIEVANCES
description: To the 12 jail inmates, it was the court system itself that was on trial.

title: Film: A Slow Cloud of Gloom for a 'Short Memory':The Cast
description: The light in Eduardo de Gregorio's "Short Memory" emanates from sources at a far remove from the characters  from outside a window if the actors are indoors, or from a lamp that casts their faces in shadow, or perhaps there's barely any light at all. In addition, the sound is muffled, as if the action were taking place under water. This might make for a perfect climate for contemplation if it did not become so evident, midway through "Short Memory," that the effect existed solely for its own sake. The style is arresting at first, but after a time it grows actively unhelpful.Mr. de Gregorio, in attempting to combine a very studied brand of film noir with a meditation on guilt, keeps himself at least two removes from any real insight or urgency. The guilt, which in particular is French guilt about World War II, never emerges from the film's cloud of slow-moving gloom; as for the film noir, it requires more movement than the somnambulant stalking Mr. de Gregorio favors. The problem isn't just the film's muted mood  it's the combination of thoughtful atmosphere and ill-considered decisions that proves most maddening.One such touch is the casting of the same actor as a young man searching for Nazi war criminals and also  in flashbacks  as the criminals themselves. Never mind that the actor, Philippe Lotard, is slightly off-beam for any of these roles, because he must work so hard to eradicate a natural ease that's out of place in this solemn scheme. The real problem is this: Mr. de Gregorio's point in making multiple use of the man  that everyone is an accomplice, something along those lines  is much less important than the likelihood that the viewer will assume that Mr. Lotard, or perhaps his father, or perhaps his great-uncle Fred, actually was a war criminal. The intrigue plot of "Short Memory" isn't remotely strong enough to bear the weight of this confusion.The focus of the story is a glum, lonely UNESCO interpreter, played by Nathalie Baye, who seems the least likely person in the world to get involved in a Nazi-hunting scheme  perhaps that's the very idea. In any case, Miss Baye is seen reading and pacing and brooding for a long while before anything actually happens, although her research is interrupted by flashbacks, some of which feature the director Jacques Rivette. Mr. de Gregorio was a collaborator on several of Mr. Rivette's films, among them "Celine and Julie Go Boating."Bulle Ogier, the star of Mr. de Gregorio's "Serail," appears this time as an Eva Pern figure, wearing spangled dinner clothes and a shrewd, icy smile. Unlike Miss Baye, who is intentionally so bland she can be upstaged by the activity on a televison screen in her gloomy living room, Miss Ogier makes a fine focus of attention. Her character, the very embodiment of evil, is the most broadly drawn figure in the film, and the simplest. Perhaps for that reason, she's the only one who seems to be all there."Short Memory" will be shown today at 2 and 9:30 P.M. as part of the New York Film Festival.

title: A Correction
description: In The New York Times of Sept 23, it was incorrectly stated that the coaches had accepted a 25 percent pay cut and the United Federation of Teachers had accepted it as part of their contract. The U.F.T. was aware of the pay cut, but the issue of the coaches salaries was not part of the contract settled.

title: Other World Events
description: The Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini forced out the chairman of the National Iranian Oil Company last week, raising a threat of new cuts in Iran's ability to produce oil. The ouster of Hassan Nazih, who had resisted attempts to replace experienced oil production managers, had been demanded by oil workers and Islamic groups who demonstrated in Abadan, site of the world's largest oil refinery. The Ayatollah threatened to put Mr. Nazih on trial for treason. Iran supplied 9.6 percent of United States crude oil in the first half of this year, down from 12.6 percent in 1978.

title: Pension Loan to Chrysler Studied
description: DETROIT, Sept. 29 (AP)  The president of the United Automobile Workers says the union may dip into its Chrysler Corporation pension funds to aid the ailing auto maker at the request of the Treasury Department.

title: Pop: 2 Robert Palmers Sind and Play
description: It's nice to see a performer improve. Robert Palmer is a white black singer. In other words, he is a British interpretive singer who works in an idiom made up of rhythmandblues, soul, reggae and New Orleansstyle funkiness.

title: Hydro Plants Spark New Interest
description: EFORE the dawn of the petroleum age, the growth of industry in this old industrial city was based on the ability to harness the power of the Shetucket and Quinebaug Rivers. Now, as OPEC price rises cast a shadow over the future of an oilbased economy, attention is returning to those waters as they rush through the hills to sea level.

title: News Summary
description: Pope John Paul II began his Irish visit with an appeal to terrorists to desist from hatred and violence and to repent. The Pope addressed more than 200,000 people in Drogheda, near the Northern Ireland border, and attempted to allay suspicions among northern Protestants of his church and of himself. He appeared to have avoided the political thickets into which some had feared he would fall when he spoke of the sectarian conflict in the north. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Miss Meriwether, Matthew Heartney, Lawyers, Are Wed
description: Charlotte Graham Meriwether and Matthew Thomas Heartney were married yesterday on the grounds of Rainbow Plantation, the family home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Thompson White Meriwether 3d, near Webb, Miss. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John M. Barr 3d of the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Sumner, Miss.

title: Matawan Wins 2d in Row, 146
description: Matawan scored two touchdowns in the second period and held on to beat Middletown North (11), 146, at Matawan for its second straight victory. Larry Wein plunged 1 yard to cap a 63yard drive, and Tom Scott bolted 9

title: No Title
description: Deaths

title: Columbia Squanders Chances in 147 Loss
description: EASTON, Pa., Sept. 29  Lafayette scored touchdowns on short runs by Ed Rogusky the first two times it had the ball, then held off two Columbia threats in the fourth quarter to defeat the Lions today, 147.

title: THEATER A Strong Showboat On a Compact Stage
description: EAST WINDSOR CONSIDERING that the stage of the Coachlight Dinner Theater measures a mere 16 feet by 16 feet, only a genius or a madman would attempt to stage Showboat there. Showboat is a large cast, largeset show that moves its audience from the dock at Natchez, where the showboat, Cotton Blossom, comes to perform, to the Chicago World's Fair of 1893, with some lesser stops in between. Madman or genius, David Guthrie, who has lately been designing and staging all of the shows at the Coachlight, has somehow succeeded. The clue to how he does it lies in his irreverence toward the original material of old musicals. He keeps the intent and mood of the shows he has selected, but tinkers freely with the materials.

title: What's Doing in SAVANNAH
description: A CITY PRESERVED  Savannah began emerging as a major tourist attraction 25 years ago, when a group of women banded together to save the historic Davenport House from being demolished for a parking lot. Their fer vor was contagious, and Savannah today represents a triumph of the preservation movement. Its National Historic Landmark District of two and a half square miles includes more than 1,100 architecturally orhistorically significant buildings. But Savannah is a living city, not just a museum; of the 900 or so buildings that have been restored, a majority have been recycled, under the auspices of the Historic Savannah Foundation, as banks, restaurants and the like.

title: Racquet Sports the Insider's Game
description: SUMMER activities may be just a memory, but Westchester County's competitive sports enthusiasts have no cause to hang up their racquets or sneakers.

title: The Nation
description: Perseverance paid off for the Carter Administration last week when organized labor agreed to fill onethird of the 15 seats on a new national Pay Advisory Committee, along with public and business members. The national accord to curb inflation was long in coming, and there were questions on all sides how long it could less.

title: Abandoning the Energy Lifeboat
description: A lot of people in Washington are fretting over Soviet troops in Cuba. But no one seems very concerned about the more significant, though less tangible, threat posed by OPEC's oil diplomacy. There were strings attached when Saudi Arabia decided to increase production by one million barrels a day last summer  a decision just renewed for another three months. The Saudis warned the State Department that they would be extremely displeased if the United States resumed putting imported oil into its strategic petroleum reserve.

title: Fashion SPRING STARTS IN MILAN
description: This week Italian designers introduce their collections for spring of 1980. For the most part, these clothes are innovative without being exaggerated. Here is an exclusive preview of what will be shown.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Here Is the monthly electricity bill. It is for $99.61. Should I feel amused or antiquated? At this rate, electricity for the coming year will cost me $1,195.32. The takehome pay for a full year from my first 40hourweek job came to $1,279.20. Today this would be enough to pay my electricity bill in full and leave me $83.88 at the end of the year. I would probably spend the $83.88 before the year ended, a week at a time. This way I would have $1.61 a week for food and rent. Even with that kind of money, it would be frivolous to splurge on clothing. takehome pay for a full year from my first 40hourweek job came to $1,279.20. Today this would be enough to pay my electricity bill in full and leave me $83.88 at the end of the year. I would probably spend the $83.88 before the year ended, a week at a time. This way I would have $1.61 a week for food and rent. Even with that kind of money, it would be frivolous to splurge on clothing.

title: CAPITAL REPORT
description: GOVERNOR BYRNE has managed, perhaps inadvertently, to put himself into position to bring pressure on the Division of Gaming Enforcement.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE EDWARD HOAGLAND READER, edited by Geoffrey Wolff. (Random House, cloth, $12.95. Vintage, paper, $4.95.) AFRICAN CALLIOPE, by Edward Hoagland. (Random House, $10.) Essays by a writer who, no matter what his subject, Is personal, magisterial and persuasive. The first volume Is a collection of short pieces, the second an account of a winter spent In Sudanese village.

title: Hurdles to Presidency: A Seemingly Endless Race
description: A decade of efforts to make the Presidential nominating process more democratic have also created the equivalent of a perpetual Presidential campaign. New party rules, new Federal laws, weaker state and local parties and the impact of television have all played a part.

title: DRAMA MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: Jill Clayburgh Recasts Her Image
description: Roles are funny, says Jill Clayburgh. For more than a year now, people have been saying, You're just like that person in An Unmarried Woman.

title: Motion Pictures 1887
description: FELIX TOURNACHON, the photographer we know as Nadar, spoke of Baizac's superstitious dread when he confronted the daguerreotype camera. According to Nadar, Balzac believed that every body, in its natural state, was made up of a series of superimposed images, which the camera literally peeled away from the body on which it focused. However fanciful the story, it testifies to the supernatural powers once attributed to the camera. we are to understand the pioneer photographer, we need to recover his suspicion that the camera is magic box and that what emerges in the seance of the darkroom is touched with the miraculous. The modern viewer can share in this sensation when he ponders the awesome images sent back from space.

title: First FullScale Negotiations Since 1964 Opened Last Week Playing the Russia Card? Not Yet, Chinese Suggest
description: PEKING  Two decades ago, before China's split with the Soviet Union, two Russian advisers were stationed in the Ministry of Finance. They were very arrogant, recalled Li Xiannian, who was then China's Minister of Finance and is now a Deputy Chairman of the Chinese Communist Party.

title: To Your Health: Bottoms Up
description: Americans are relatively prudent consumers of alcoholic beverages. On average, they drink only two bottles of hard liquor a year. It's a good thing. It has been discovered that some drinkers may not fully appreciate the secondary effects of a drink, and Congress, therefore, is considering legislation to put a label on bottles of hard liquor informing purchasers that the contents may affect them.

title: Brett Angney Weds Miss Whittington
description: The marriage of Carolyn Dale Whittington, a doctoral candidate in psychology at Columbia University, to Brett Ray Angney, who is studying for a doctorate in educational administration at Columbia's Teachers College, took place in Baltimore yesterday. The Rev. Dr. John Wallace performed the ceremony at the Mount Vernon Place United Methodist Church.

title: As the Economy Darkens, a Call for John Dunlop
description: President Carter took new steps last week to toughen his antiinflation battle, announcing a national accord with organized labor that would give an active role in shaping new voluntary wage guidelines. He also brought John T. Dunlop, a figure from the Nixon days of wage and price controls, back to Washington to head a newly created pay board.

title: Route 9: A Window On the State
description: O KAY. You've caught a local bus to Atlantic City with what seems to be a convention of garlic lovers, and they're all pronouncing breathily upon the European Common Market and how to win at blackjack.

title: Apples Corps Goes to the Farm
description: Sunday drive into the country to buy apples has long been a part of the suburban American autumn tradition. But hundreds of Westchester County families are now moving a step closer to nature by picking the apples themselves.

title: Belgrade: The Dollar, Gold and Paper Gold
description: WASHINGTON  Gold at $400 an ounce. It seemed impossible only a month ago. But as gold touched that mark in New York last week, the value of the dollar sagged again to the low point it had reached last October just before President Carter and the the international banking system rallied behind it.

title: Missouri Beaten, 210, by Texas
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 29 (AP)  John Goodson kicked four field goals and a swarming defense helped Texas roll up a 210 victory over previously unbeaten Missouri today.

title: Judi Durso Fiance Of Martin Dolgow
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Durso of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judi Faye Durso, to Martin H. Dolgow, director of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce. The wedding is planned for next August.

title: They All Sing Leads
description: BALDWIN

title: Garfield W. Carter And Julia Murphy Wed in Greenwich
description: The marriage of Julia Huston Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Blair Murphy of Greenwich, Conn., to Garfield Wallace Carter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Carter of Ottawa, took place at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard J. Eckart Jr., uncle of the bride, assisted by the Rev. Bradford Hastings.

title: Other Ideas &
description: The World Administrative Radio Conference, scheduled to begin last Monday in Geneva, was delayed by static for three days. That is how long it took the delegates to agree on who should be chairman of the conference; the eventual choice was Roberto Severini, chief of the Argentinian delegation. The squabble was probably only a token of more to come, as 148 countries, each with one vote, decide how to allocate the radio spectrum for the next 20 years. The technologically advanced countries want, in general, to keep the large share of the airwaves they already have; the less advanced, to stake big claims for future exploitation.

title: Leonard and Duran Are on a Collision Course
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 29  It's as if they were two blips on a radar screen, two small planes swooping toward a midair crash that can't be avoided. Sugar Ray Leonard and Roberto Duran are on a collision course.

title: TateCoetzee Victor Is Holmes's Target
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 29  Scott LeDoux?

title: COUNTRIES AGREE TO BOLSTER DOLLAR
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Sept. 29 The leading economic strategists of the United States and West Germany, meeting here after a week of sharp declines in the dollar's value on international money markets, said today that they would press efforts to strengthen the American currency.

title: Robert J. Ringer
description: Robert J. Ringer enthusiastically recalls his shining moment as the keynote speaker at the Libertarian Party's recent Presidential nominating convention in Los Angeles. As Orson Bean, the emcee, introduced me, he announced that Restoring the American Dream was on the bestseller list. I got a fourminute standing ovation. I felt like I was running for office.

title: National Epidemic Of Pregnancies
description: Every year, more than a million girls from 15 to 19 years of age  plus another 30,000 from 10 to 19become pregnant in this country and threefifths carry through to birth. The result is 600,000 new babies, about half of them ultimately born in wedlock, according to one recent study. One of every three of the pregnant teenagers has an abortion  a category of abortion that has been steadily rising  and the remaining pregnancies end in miscarriages. It is no longer valid to assume that the poor and members of minorities make up the bulk of these statistics; whites and the middle class generally are strongly represented.

title: Television This Week
description: 8 P.M. (4) THE KID FROM LEFT FIELD. A twohour adaptation of the 1953 feature film about a bat boy who helps lead a losing baseball team to the World Series; starring Gary Coleman, Robert Guillaume, Ed McMahon and Tab Hunter.

title: Pirates Lose to Cubs in 13th, 76
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29  Mick Kelleher had a notion. The Chicago Cubs second baseman took his lead off second base in the top of the 13th inning, and when Jerry Martin hit a chopper to the Pirate third baseman, Bill Madlock, Kelleher leaned back toward second.

title: Jill E. Taylor Wed To R. Alan Livsey
description: Jill Ellen Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. Taylor of Verona, N.J., was married yesterday to R. Alan Livsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Livsey of Tucker, Ga. Rabbi Irwin Fishbein performed the ceremony at the Cedar Hill Country Club in Livingston. N.J.

title: 4 on a National Guard Helicopter Killed as It Crashes Into a House
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 29 (AP)  An Army National Guard helicopter lost a rotor about 500 feet off the ground and plunged flaming into a house today, killing all four persons aboard the aircraft and slightly injuring three in the house.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Inflation is now galloping along at an annual rate of 12.7 percent and the worst of it may be that the nation apparently has become so used to it that there's hardly an outcry. With a new recession under way, unemployment is going up too, and the economic establishment actually seems to welcome the increase.

title: GARDENING
description: ANTICIPATING cooler home and greenhouse temperatures this winter because of the fuel crisis and the increased cost of heating oil, many home plant growers and greenhouse owners are looking into plants that will thrive in cooler temperatures.

title: MORMONS MAY LIMIT CHURCH GATHERINGS
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 29 (AP) The Mormon Church, whose members often Joke about the number of meetings they attend, is beginning a program to eliminate some church gatherings and shorten others.

title: THE LIGHTER SIDE OF LASER
description: Laser is the most powerful light on earth. It has been written that, next to the computer, laser is the most versatile invention of the 20th century; its applications cut a broad swath through the fields of manufacturing, medicine, communications, national defense and scientific research of all kinds. But in addition to such serious business as repairing detached retinas and welding steel, laser has a lighter side: it is a beautiful kinetic form of decoration. And it is as decoration that laser is making its debut in the American home.

title: F.C.C. Is Sued for Data On Sect in Guyana Killings
description: Contending that it would be in the public interest to obtain authoritative information about the People's Temple in California and in Jonestown, Guyana, James Reston Jr. has filed a complaint in United States District Court, District of Columbia. The nurnose of the suit is to compel the Federal Communications Commissions to provide him with tape recordings, transcriptions and documents concerning communications between the organization's branches for a book he is writing about the religious sect and massacre at its Jonestown commune last November.

title: Deaths
description: ALTIERRobert Christian, of Middletown, N.J., on Sept. 27, 1979, son of Joseph P. and Cornelia (nee Johnston), brother of Joseph P. Jr., David, Christopher, and Susan, grandson of Mrs. Anne P. Altier. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Robert C. Altier Memorial Scholarship Fund, in care of Christian Brothers Academy, Rte 520, Lincroft, N.J.07738.

title: INVESTING
description: Bankers  including the Morgans, the Mellons and David Rockefeller have always been among the nation's top art collectors. But until recently banks in this country have not viewed art as an investment commodity that they would recommend to their clients.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: It's official. Winter must be on its way. Why else would Nassau County open the Cantiague Park Ice Rink in Hicksville, and the County Arena in Long Beach? And both are open now for daily sessions. Nassau residents can skate for $1.50 a session; children and the elderly, 75 cents. Nonresidents pay $2.50 and $1.50, respectively. The Cantiague rink is on West John Street in Hicksville. 9353501. The arena is on Magnolia Boulevard. 4316501.

title: Events Today
description: Horticultural Society of New York Plant Sala: wide variety of plants for sate, also apples, cider and homemade Items; noon to 6 P.M.; ln West 58th Street.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Shows and Events
description: Tuesday through Thursday  Short Hills Antiques Show, Community Congregational Church, Hartshorn Drive and Parsonage Hill Road, Short Hills. 32 dealers. Hours: Tuesday and Wednesday, noon to 9 P.M.; Thursday, noon to 5 P.M. Admission of $2 includes lectures on antique jewelry (10:30 A.M., Wednesday) and on the care and repair of antiques (10:30 A.M., Thursday). For information, call (201) 3794050.

title: Medical Schools Found Admitting Fewer LowerMiddleIncome Students
description: Students from families with lower-middle incomes  the children of farmers, craftsmen, sales clerks and others in the $10,000 to $20,000ayear range  are gradually disappearing from the nation's medical schools while the percentage of sons and daughters of physicians and other affluent professionals is increasing.

title: No Title
description: Engagements

title: Women With Men
description: WHAT do women want? Freud asked. They want  according to Jill Tweedie, a British journalist and television personality a new kind of love, a love that is equal, free, independent, reasonable, a bornagain love. The world depends on it, and so does Miss Tweedie's book, In the Name of Love, a collection of dizzy essays that sweep into one jumble the thoughts of Sigmund Freud, Charles Darwin, Jacques Lacan, Dory Previn and Marilyn French.

title: At Home:Most of UsAre Job Snobs
description: AMAN came to pump out my septic tank, and I was surprised to see that he was young and handsome, even elegant. Tall and slender, with a casual grace of movement, he might easily have passed for a count or an actor. Hisvoice was melodious and his speech was precise, although slightly tinged with an accent.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE influence of inflation and population growth on the state's economy is reflected in a report by the United States Census Bureau showing that groceries are now New Jersey's largest wholesale business.

title: Carter's Three Wise Men Already Making Changes
description: WASHINGTON  In the small gatehouse at the northwest entrance to the White House, the guards post pictures of the principal assistants to the President on a back wall to remind them who's who. Three new faces have been added to that gallery in the last few weeks  three older, more experienced, nonGeorgian faces on whom Jimmy Carter is relying to bolster the reputation of his staff.

title: Pop: Songs Crooned by Jon Lucien
description: Jon Lucien's rich baritone and athletic good looks are perfect equipment for a romantic crooner, and if Mr. Lucien had come along 15 years ago he might have become just that. But because he's very much an artist of the 70's, Mr. Lucien isn't content to simply wrap his velvety voice around sweet nothings, which he does very well indeed. He also writes most of his own material, including uptempo songs with a Caribbean sway. He spices his romantic lyrics with mysticism. He plays some piano and guitar.

title: Food
description: Swedish roast lamb with coffee cream

title: JACKSON AHD ARAFAT CONFER IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 29  The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, the American civil rights leader, offered himself as mediator between the United States Government and the Palestine Liberation Organization today.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Journalistic distortion of humanistic activity seems to be consistent.

title: Blue Jays Reported Ready To Dismiss Their Manager
description: Roy Hartsfield, the only manager the Toronto Blue Jays have had since they joined the American League three years ago, will be dismissed today, according to United Press International..

title: Marvin B. Eckford, an Executive Of United Mutual Life Insurance
description: Marvin Burk Eckford, secretary and vice president of the United Mutual Life Insurance Company, died Thursday at Greater Harlem Nursing Home. He was 79 years old and a resident of New York City. tar. Eckford, a World War I veteran, was born in San Antonio and earned a B.A. degree at Ohio State University.

title: Book Review
description: NONFICTION

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: THE good news for home buyers is that house prices appear to be leveling off after jumping 20 to 35 percent in the past year. The bad news is that Westchester County's largest mortgage lender now requires a 50 percent down payment and an interest rate of 10 percent.

title: Arizona Moves Radioactive Gas From Shut Plant
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Sept. 29  A convoy with a helicopter escort rolled across Arizona today carrying 42 barrels of radioactive tritium gas to an Army depot 20 miles west of Flagstaff.

title: Carter Has Precedent in Use of Wise Men
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  When President Carter sought the advice of several foreign policy Wise Men today on how to resolve the impasse over the Soviet troops in Cuba, he was following wellestablished practice in American diplomacy.

title: Montclair Trio Excels In 270 Rout of Dunellen
description: Unbeaten Montclair Immaculate received superlative performances from Marcus Hackett, Tim Cummings and Carl Zimmerman yesterday and made Dunellen its third victim, 270, in Dunellen.

title: Gloom Is the Mood as World Bankers Meet
description: GENEVA  The world's finance ministers will gather in an atmosphere of deepening gloom at Belgrade on Tuesday for this year's meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: The Riverside Dance Festival at Theater of the Riverside Church gets under way on Wednesday with a twomonth series that paves the way for the principal 23week 1980 season. The festival presents 13 companies, in a spectrum of modern, ballet and ethnic dance. Leading off is Peter Sparling, who recently resigned as a soloist of the Martha Graham Dance Company to build his own repertory. Mr. Sparling will present three programs of five solos, to be followed by the Puerto Rican Dance Theater, Jessica Fogel and Dancers, the Marcus Schulkind Dance Company and others. (See Dance)

title: POLITICS
description: ASMILING Nancy Reagan sat in her 12thfloor suite at the Marriott Hotel here the other morning and patiently answered the questions from the reporters who were invited in for separate 15minute interviews.

title: To Learn or Teach, They Make a Match
description: THESE days the Nassau Library System is calling itself the newest matchmaker around. The pairing it is doing, however, is not of the romantic sort; rather, the system is putting people who want to learn in touch with those who can teach.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Deerfield Keeps Up A Certain Tradition
description: Lawrenceville, the Eastern prep schools champion last year with a record of 71, lost its second game in two starts yesterday. For the third straight year, Deerfield beat Lawrenceville in their traditional contest. The score was 1913.

title: In Cahoots With Tom Stoppard
description: Ed Berman is a man with a mission. In fact, the burly, bearded American expatriate seems to have missions to spare. His most immediate concern is a new comedy, Dogg's Hamlet, Cahoot's Macbeth, written by his friend and associate Tom Stoppard, which opens Wednesday at the 22 Steps Theater, Broadway at 48th Street. Mr. Berman has directed the play, which will be presented by a new troupe called the British American Repertory Company, or BARC for short. Mr. Berman, the founder of the company, is also an avid punster and it is no accident that an outfit called BARC is staging a play called Dogg's Hamlet. Besides, Mr. Berman, who is given to juggling three or four careers at once, has no time for accidents.

title: White Plains Downs Scarsdale
description: Undefeated White Plains scored two quick touchdowns just before halftime and went on to defeat Scarsdale, 347, yesterday. Coach Brant Wintersteen's Tigers held a 147 lead when Jimmy Lombardi. their quarterback, scored on a 2yard run. Joe Gaito intercepted a Scarsdale pass three minutes later and returned it 47 yards for a touchdown to put White Plains ahead, 277, at halftime.

title: Tar Heels Top Army As Lawrence Stars
description: WEST POINT, N.Y. Sept. 29  Amos Lawrence, the University of North Carolina's 5foot9 inch, 179 pound junior tailback, enhanced his Reisman Trophy and allAmerica credentials today by leading the Tar Heels to a 413 rout of Army before 32,157 fans in Michie Stadium.

title: D.K. Perdue Weds Wendy A. Collins.
description: Wendy Ann Collins, daughter of Capt. John T. Collins, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Collins of Washington, was married yesterday to David King Perdue, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Perdue of Sands Point, L.I. The ceremony was performed in the Chevy Chase (Md.) Christian Church by the Rev. Dr. Christopher Garriott. He was assisted, by Mary Ann Stauffer Collins, a ministerial student at the Princeton Divinity School and sisterinlaw of the bride's brother.

title: DESIGNED TO BE LIVED IN
description: This past summer I had occasion to visit The Mount, Edith Wharton's sumptous 1901 Georgian mansion in Lenox, Mass. It is an Immense house, grand in its appointments and now, unfortunately, in poor condition. It is occupied today by a Shakespeare company which rents it and hopes to find funds to purchase and restore it, but that is another story. What is most striking about The Mount, even in the poor , shape in which we now see it, is how strongly this is a house of ideas - a house built to communicate not only a general image of comfort, stability and style, but also a number of very clear principles of what a house should be.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: DEANNA SCLAR did a strange thing when she rented a Chevy Caprice from Hertz in Boston. First, she took the car to a Uniroyal tire dealer for a set of new whitewalls. Then she had him pound five nails into each of the $100 tires before setting off on a cross-country trip.

title: TermPaper Sales Still a Brisk Business
description: DESPITE 10 years of efforts by lawmakers to prohibit or at least limit the operations of companies selling term papers to students, despite an agreement made last summer as a result of civil suits filed by the United States Attorney's office in Newark and despite attempts by colleges to make the practice difficult for students, the companies are apparently doing as much business as ever.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Larty Clark's photographs of teenage drug addicts, which first appeared in a Lustrum Press book, Tulsa, in 1971, have lost none of their power since then. The book is now out of print, soit is good to see the photographs again in their first New York exhibition, at the Robert Freidus Gallery, 158 Lafayette Street at Grand Street, through Oct. 13. The exhibition includes all the photographs in the book except for a couple of pages of artfully laidout film strips, which are not in fact very much missed, and it arranges them on the wall in the same order as in the book, with the same meager but chilling little text to accompany them.

title: The Successful Failure
description: IN John P. Marquand's novel Wickford Point, literary agent is described as moving in that half world of the imagination governed by editorial fact. Marquand himself was often content inhabit that same world and to do a kind of literary cabinetmaking, with veneers imported from China, Hawaii, Europe or New England, fancy embellishments, shiny varnish, brassplated pulls and filler conceal the joints  all held together by competent craftsmanship and proven design. On these principles he became the most successful novelist in the United States. From sales of stories and serials to The Saturday Evening Post alone he earned more than half million dollars; novel sales swelled with each volume; his movie sales set several records; and receipts were further multiplied by BookoftheMonth Club, Literary Guild and paperback editions. Upon his death he left an estate of $11 million, despite enormous expenditures during his lifetime.

title: School District Sued On TaxCut Repeal
description: MELVILLE THE Long Island newspaper Newsday filed suit last week in State Supreme Court in Riverhead against the Half Hollow Hills School District, and several other large corporations are taking similiar action. They say the school board enticed them to move here with sweet tax abatements  only to take back the offer once construction was under way.

title: Tangled Web of Conflicting Interests Stalls the Carter Proposal
description: WASHINGTON  In the two and a half months since President Carter announced his latest energy program, Congress has not produced a single piece of legislation on the subject to send to the White House. Basic support for the President's goal of energy selfsufficiency is not an issue. The complexity and interlocking nature of the legislation is a problem, but not insuperable. As much as anything, the obstacle is the tangled web of conflicting interests involved, tugging and hauling at energy from so many positions that nothing seems to move far one way or another.

title: THE ELECTRONIC HOME
description: Advanced technology invaded the O'Brien household on Long Island a few months ago, and the home life of the O Briens hasn't been the same since. The reason: a gadget known as a home computer, which O'Brien, in a moment of sheer abandon, bought for $700 and presented to his family.

title: Itinerary of Visits by Pope John Paul II Through Ireland and the United States
description: Following is the itinerary of Pope John Paul II's trip through Ireland and the United States today through Oct. 7. All times are local and approximate, with lastminute changes possible.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Linda Howard's beautiful and moving, if somewhat romantic, depiction of her childhood holiday experience was brutally marred by its last paragraphs [Paying to Pray on the Holy Days Upsets a Reverie, Opinion Page, Sept. 16]. The navet of so sophisticated a writer is hard to believe, for she has fallen into the trap set by those who decry the cost of religion and use it as an excuse to remain aloof from its institutions.

title: Qaddafi's Taste For Adventures Has Lessened
description: TRIPOLI, Libya - Muammar elQaddafi could never be accused of lacking for friends, though the company he keeps has hardly been reassuring to his neighbors and others. The Libyan leader has embraced national liberation movements of nearly every ideological stripe, rival guerrilla factions and radical subversives, not to mention a couple of bloodthirsty African dictators.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Higher education in this country has responded the increased desire for material success by expanding its capacity to instruct people in how make more money. This has been achieved through the growth of graduate business school programs. But the fallout from this proliferation has not been entirely positive.

title: The Detection Club
description: On October 25, the Uncommon Order of Initiation for new members of the Detection Club will be enacted for the 39th time. A room in London's Caf Royal will be darkened. A procession will enter carrying lighted candles. At its head will walk the president, wearing a cloak emblematically scarlet, and a member bearing upon a salver Eric the Skull, whose jaw and eyesockets shine with a light generated from within.

title: Expos Down Phils in 9th by 32 And Remain Alive in Title Race
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 29  Montreal's baseball fans finally had something to cheer about today: a 32 ninthinning victory over the Phillies, a tenuous chance to win their division championship, a fine pitching performance from William Francis Lee 3d.

title: Crane Flock Expected to Grow
description: A flock of endangered whooping cranes that winters in New Mexico's central RIo Grande Valley could be nearly twice as large this year as last year. Hans Stuart of the Fish and Wildlife Service said Friday that eight baby cranes survived at the flock's summer grounds in the Grays Lake National Wildlife Refuge of southeastern Idaho. The cranes should begin their fall migration toward the Bosque del Apache National Wildlife Refuge in New Mexico in early October. If they survive the hazards of the 800mile journey, the size of the flock at the winter grounds would increase to 17 from nine last year.

title: Republicans Take Turns Criticizing Kennedy as Haig Hints He Will Run
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 29  Republican Presidential candidates and other party figures took turns kicking Senator Edward M. Kennedy around today on everything from his political philosophy to his character, and they won applause from the 2,500 members of the National Federation of Republican Women.

title: Topics
description: A couple of Mondays ago, the blind children and adults arriving at The Lighthouse on East 59th Street found that their classes had been postponed for several weeks. The floors were awash. Vandals had turned on taps upstairs and plugged the drains. Ceilings, carpets, tiles were ruined. Elevators didn't work because the water had damaged them. Electronic equipment had been stolen. The New York Association for the Blind, which operates The Lighthouse, estimates the loss at quartermillion dollars. Who would do such things to the 6,800 blind people that The Lighthouse serves? The police are reportedly investigating the incident with unusual care in order to answer that question quickly. We wish them luck.

title: Marriage Announcement 6 -- No Title
description: Mary Beth Selinger Married

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: MARGARET UROFF, a professor of English at the University of Illinois, is interested dispelling the myth of the PlathHughes relationship, both poetic and personal. Her research has proven to her satisfaction that their shared poetic careers paralleled each other's, and that she can detect points at which they encourage each other by example and by criticism. Plath called her poems Echos traveling/ Off from the centre. Professor Uroff believes that this center included Ted Hughes in every sense.

title: MUSIC
description: MOST of the big cultural news  the major orchestras, the celebrity recital series  tend to happen in the lower part of the county. But don't write off northern Westchester too soon. More and more musical items. of note bear datelines such as Yorktown Heights, Chappaqua, Ossining and other towns up into Putnam County.

title: Seton Hall Triumphs As Merklinger Stars
description: John Merklinger, a senior running back, rushed 16 times for 220 yards and three touchdowns yesterday as unbeaten Seton Hall won its third straight game, a 407 victory over Summit at South Orange. Merklinger, an allstate back as a junior, scored on runs of 49,1 and 40 yards. He also kicked four extra points. Joe Marelli sprinted 11 yards for one Seton Hall touchdown and passed 28 yards to Tim Campagna for another.

title: Economic Indicators
description: Statistics for commercial agricultural loans, arloadtnge, steel, oil, electric power and business failures are tor the preceding week and latest available

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: WE BOUGHT a new lamp the other day. Although it cost more than we had planned to spend, it was so beautiful that it was hard to resist.

title: Opera: Juan Lloveras, New Cavalleria Tenor
description: That seemingly inseparable operatic twosome, Cavalleria Rusticana and Pagliacci, lost no time in getting back into the Metropolitan Opera repertory this season. Still looking good in their familiar Franco Zeffirelli productions, the pair of verisino operas returned Wednesday night in musical performances that were generally commendable though not thrilling.

title: Miss Burton Sets Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Mr and Mrs. William Jordan Jr. of New York, Ridgefield, Conn., and Smith's Parish, Bermuda, of the engagement of Mrs. Jordan's daughter,  Christine Florence Olivier Burton, to Jon H. Glickman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Glickman of New York.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: Joyce Anne Pharr Is Married To David S. Steiner in Jersey
description: Joyce Anne Pharr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norris Pharr of Red Bank, N.J., and David Sandy Steiner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Steiner of Middletown, N.J., were married yesterday at the Hominy Hill Country Club in Colts Neck, N.J. Mayor Robert Eckert of Middletown performed the ceremony.

title: Stories With Voiceprints
description: By Jayne Anne Phillips. 265 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. Cloth, $8.95. Delta, paper, $4.95.

title: Oregon's Southern Border
description: As a mountain, Mount Mazama was just one more icy link in the long, spiny chain called the Cascade Range, which runs through the heart of Oregon. But 7,000 years ago, something happened to this unassuming 12,000foot peak that was to win it a place in geological history: It collapsed.

title: Food Store Converted To Offices For M.D.'s
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L.I.  Dr. Mark Fingerhut, an endocrinologist, had an office in Roslyn, L.I., that suffered from growing pains and a parking lot that was afflicted with congestionitis.

title: Splendor In the Grass
description: TUCSON, Ariz.  A high school boy I know recently told me he's been smoking marijuana since the sixth grade. I was astonished by this piece of news because I've known this boy for many years and always thought well of him.

title: On Language
description: When a cannonball serve tips the net before falling into the opposite court, the net umpire shouts, Let! Or, Let ball! Many people think he is mispronouncing net, which is what he says when the serve hits the net without tipping over to the other side.

title: DINING OUT
description: INE BOUCHE is so good that it is hard to resist the temptation to wax lyrical over the culinary skills  especially the baking skills  of Steven Wilkinson, chefowner of this fourmonthold restaurant. The talents of the 31year old chef won threestar kudos for the Old Lyme Inn two years ago, and he left this year to open his own gourmet takeout business, which then blossomed into a fullfledged restaurant. The takeout business continues to flourish.

title: DINING OUT
description: VILLA Parma East in Melville stands out as one of the more elaborate Italian restaurants on the Island. A decorator was obviously hard at work coordinating the abstract burgundy and taupe print of the velvet chairs with matching custom floor tile and even with the vinyl menu covers. One dining room with rust stuccoed walls is warmly handsome; the other, skylit, has an airy look that is especially pleasant at lunch.

title: THE MARKETS
description: A barrage of negative developments finally caught up with the stock market last week to send prices lower. It was, by and large, a week that most optimists on Wall Street would like to forget.

title: Paperbacks:
description: AMERICAN CAESAR, by William Manchester. (Dell, $3.50.) General of the Army Douglas MacArthur (18801964) suffered from a staggering case of egotism, yet he was the most gifted manofarms this nation has produced and a deeply knowledgeable global statesman. Such is the portrait offered in what our reviewer, Eric Goldman, described as the first major biography, a volume based on enormous research and, in general, written with taste, grace and verve.

title: Guignol Theater For Children Visiting Paris
description: Vous allez bien? asks a smiling puppet with a turnedup nose. Are you all right?

title: A Fence Around Oklahoma
description: Last week Oklahoma's attorney general's office announced a crackdown on foreigners who purchase property in the state, ruling that its 1907 constitution forbids ownership of land by distant aliens.

title: Carey Tops Westbury
description: Carey beat Westbury, 90, in a Conference III opener yesterday for both schools. Tom Cullen scored the only touchdown of the game when he culminated a 69yard drive by going over from the 11. Gladitsh made the extra point.

title: New York and Church Officials Finishing Preparations to Greet Pope
description: Flowerarranging at Shea Stadium, cleanup efforts in the South Bronx and settling on a new part of the Pope's itinerary were among the lastminute chores of city and church officials laboring yesterday to prepare the way for the New York visit of Pope John Paul H.

title: Csonka Can Go Home Again, And the Dolphins Are Winning
description: I had memories of Lary Csonka in the Super Bowl years, said Don Shula, the Miami Dolphins coach, and I wanted to have him again.

title: N.L.R.B. Opens Office In New York for Judges
description: A New York office for administrative law judges has been opened by the National Labor Relations Board as a first step in decentralizing the board's division of judges.

title: Value of Tight Ends Is Increasing in N.F.L.
description: Russ Francis, the New England Patriots premier tight end, has the three statistics so sought after by the scouts and coaches who put together pro football teams: height, 6 feet inches; weight, 245 pounds; speed, 4.6 seconds for 40 yards. Those are the triangle stats, as the scouts say.

title: Allesandra A. Hillman Married
description: Allesandra Anna Hillman, daughter of Mrs. William Hillman of New York and the late Mr. Hillman, was married yesterday to Henry Cave Devine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Devine of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Paul Walsh performed the ceremony in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Screenwriter to Talk About Film Making
description: Screenwriter David Newman, whose credits include Bonnie and Clyde and Superman, will speak Thursday in the Astoria Studios master lecture series on films and film making. Mr. Newman will be the second sneaker in the series of 12 lectures by filmindustry professionals. Admission is by subscription or single ticket. The center's telephone number is 3925600.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Landscape  Union Township
description: Cows graze with a quiet regret among industrial nights My home beholds the farm, the railroad tracks, the swiftness of a deer or a pheasant a nightly cotton tail rabbit

title: U.S. Marshals to Get F.B.I.'s Reponsibility For Finding Escapees
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  Beginning Monday, the Federal Bureau of Investigation will no longer be responsible for tracking escaped Federal prisoners and violators of Federal parole, probation and bonds.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: HANNA SCLAR did a strange thing when she rented Chevy Caprice from Hertz up in Boston. First, she took the car to a Uniroyal tire dealer for a set of new whitewalls. Then she had him pound five nails into each of the $100 tires before setting off on a crosscountry trip.

title: Aspen Glories in Its Secret Season
description: Colorado's Aspen is known for highriding skiers in winter and highminded intellectuals in the summer. But what is it like in the fall, after the musicians, the tourists, the culturedispensing scholars have gone home?

title: State Is WhistleStopping on Transit Issue
description: THERE will be no major political races on the November ballot in Westchester, but officials of the Carey administration are nonetheless crisscrossing the county, speaking to every group that will listen. It is not a candidate that the state government is pushing, but an issue a transportationbond issue.

title: Hot Tubs Are a Hot Item
description: PATRICIA Heublein of Farmington had a hot tub installed in her greenhouse, where its benefits are bestowed equally on people and plants.

title: Syracuse Triumphs by 5225
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 29 (AP)  Bill Hurley scored two touchdowns and passed for another and Joe Morris ran for two touchdowns, including a 48yard gamebreaker, as Syracuse whipped Washington State, 5225, today.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BRIDGEPORT  Judith Dolnick, Maureen McCabe, Stephen Zaima, mixedmedia works, through Oct. 9, Carlson Gallery, Univ. of Bridgeport. Weekdays 11 to 5, weekends 1 to 5.576.4016.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: TRAP PLAY: Ken Oberkfell of St. Louis caught Dan Norman of Mets off first after Norman singled in third Inning yesterday. Mets avoided 100th loss with 87 victory.

title: ANTIQUES
description: FOR serious collectors of Americana, the annual Connecticut Antiques Show is one of the premier events of the year. Started in 1967 as a benefit for the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society of Connecticut, this show has gained a reputation for the high quality of the antiques displayed.

title: Fern Chin Betrothed to Thomas Murtagh
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Y. Chin of Lynbrook, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Fern Chin, to Thomas Peter Murtagh, son of Mrs. John M. Murtagh of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late State Supreme Court Justice Murtagh. The wedding is planned for next summer.

title: Jews Start Observance Of Yom Kippur Today
description: Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, the most solemn holy day in Judaism, begins at sundown today when a 24hour period of fasting and prayer will begin for Jews attending synagogues throughout the world.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a homeowner sees that the outside paint on his house is cracked, peeling, or severely eroded in many places, then he knows for sure that a new paint job will be needed in the near future. However, if the old paint is merely dirty and dingy looking, or perhaps discolored in some places but otherwise seems to be in fairly good physical condition  the chances are that the outside of the house is not yet due for a new coat of paint. It may be that all it needs is a good washing.

title: A Correction
description: The caption on the bottom photograph on Page 1 last week incorrectly said that the picture had been taken at the Hun School in Princeton. It was taken at the Princeton Day School.

title: Other National Events
description: It's not a beautiful place, but it's home, said Nurse Cleo Armstrong of the dilapidated and bankrupt Sarah Allen nursing home in Philadelphia last week. Her car, and other nurses', blockaded the old building to prevent Pennsylvania welfare officials from removing 143 elderly patients to a state facility 120 miles away. The nurses won. Gov. Dick Thornburg cancelled the moving plans and began trying to relocate the patients (and the nurses) in the Philadelphia area.

title: Plans Are Laid to Alleviate Heating Oil Shortages
description: BOSTON, Sept. 29  A Federal task force and representatives of the 19 Northeastern and Middle Atlantic states met here today to discuss plans for coping with local emergency shortages of home heating oil and diesel fuel this winter.

title: Beleaguered Indochinese Find Relief on L.I.
description: THE REV. ALAN PLACA is accustomed to hearing tales of human misery. No matter how much one story sounds like the next, he is still emotionally moved.

title: A Novel of Terrorism
description: THERE are some women writers whose face appears in the mind's eye whenever one thinks their books; they are beauties, these women, and we are astonished and heartened at the good fortune and improbability they stand for. George Eliot, we think, had to be a writer, with her ions horse face.

title: Tackling the Fall Season
description: PEOPLE think of football as the main fall sport. For me the playing field is my backyard, and the game is raking leaves.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS Twigs Proves to Be a Real Find
description: FARMINGDALE SOMETIMES great actresses and star directors are just what nice little plays don't need. Such plays can be mangled and misrepresented in the ego trip from page to stage.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: The World
description: The defection by three soloists of the Bolshoi Ballet had been awkward enough to explain, but last week Moscow's managers of cultural exchanges faced a crescendo of embarrassment.

title: Dance: Charles Moore Group and Drums of Africa
description: The Charles Moore Dances and Drums of Africa honored a choreographic pioneer Friday night. The company devoted half of its program at the Maryrnount Manhattan Theater to works by the late Asadata Dafora, the first African choreographer to present African dances on the American stage.

title: Iowa Civil Liberties Unit to Drop One of 2 Lawsuits on Papal Visit
